title: Campaign Reform: The Next Moves
description: The questioning, especially of Gov. Mario Cuomo, might have been more probing. Still, months of public hearings by the New York State Commission on Government Integrity revealed much about how the state's top officeholders raise money - and erased all doubt about the need for state campaign finance reform.

title: Review/Music; Bernstein's Conception Of Mahler's 'Resurrection'
description: Leonard Bernstein's interpretation of Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony is one of the musical touchstones of our time, a reference point even for those who might not agree with its intensely personal view. When the chance comes to experience it in the flesh, as happened when he conducted the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, wise listeners make sure to be on hand.

title: JUDGE WON'T ORDER REAGAN TESTIMONY
description: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North today emphatically rejected an attempt to force Ronald Reagan to appear as a witness, declaring that no written evidence had yet been found to suggest that Mr. Reagan authorized the illegal acts Mr. North is accused of committing.

title: Hole in Bridge Closes 2 Lanes
description: A hole measuring 6 feet by 12 feet was discovered today in the deck of the Rippowam River bridge on northbound Interstate 95, forcing the closing of two of three lanes for more than six hours, transportation officials said. As workers patched the hole, which extended across the center and right-hand lanes near Exit 7, traffic at one point was backed up to the New York State line. William Keish, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation, said a portion of the concrete surface of the bridge had broken away, exposing the steel reinforcing rods and the river. The bridge is undergoing a $6.3 million rehabilitation.

title: Search of Firm Ruled Legal
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a four-day search of Blinder, Robinson & Company's headquarters was legal and that Federal prosecutors may keep the thousands of documents they had seized.

title: Lenses That Cut Glare, by Day or Night
description: Anti-reflective eyeglass lenses, particularly effective for reducing glare from oncoming headlights during night driving, are now being mass-produced for use at all hours of the day.

title: Car Insurance: Two Choices
description: As the national clamor for lower automobile insurance premiums continues, one proposal for a solution is beginning to catch the attention of consumer advocates and the insurance industry. The idea is simple: state legislation that would give the driver a choice between no-fault and fault-based policies.

title: At Michigan, a Wrangle Unfolds As a Locker Videotape Unwinds
description: This strange tale of a tape involves a passionate locker-room speech, finger-pointing by several television broadcasters, many misunderstandings and a motivational tactic that might backfire and motivate the wrong team.

title: Environmental Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year results included a one-time charge of $505,921 related to the writeoff of goodwill.

title: Patents; Creating The Illusion Of 3-D Sound
description: Peter H. Myers, an electrical engineer in San Jose, Calif., won a patent this week for a recording system that creates the illusion of three-dimensional sound through a way of tricking the brain.

title: Treasury Issues Rally on Late Surge
description: An unexpected late surge in prices of all Treasury maturities turned a modest recovery into a strong rally yesterday.

title: Indianian Named Parks Chief
description: James Ridenour, an Indiana political associate of Vice President Dan Quayle, was named Thursday to become director of the National Park Service. Mr. Ridenour, 47 years old, served for eight years as director of the Indiana Department of Natural Resources when Robert D. Orr, a Republican, was Governor.

title: No Secrets Anymore, By George
description: The Charter Revision Commission may compare its work to that of the nation's Founding Fathers, but the statesmen of 1787 faced nothing like the public scrutiny that will dog the drafters of New York City's new constitution over the next few months.

title: T.W.A. Posts Results for '88
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. this week reported a net loss of $59 million for the last two months of 1988 but had a record profit of $249.7 million for the year, with a large part of it coming from income gained from stock investments.

title: No Company Money for Bombs in Animal Case
description: To the Editor:

title: New Kodak Film
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would introduce ''significant new films and unique cameras'' in April. The films, to be introduced April 18, will probably be an expansion of the Ektar color film, which broke new ground in color saturation and speed but was available only in products used by advanced photographers. Analysts speculated that the cameras would be designed for specific users like children or the elderly.

title: Advance Ross reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a loss of $124,000 for the quarter and income of $1,230,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: SmithKline's Stock Surges
description: The stock of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation rose sharply yesterday after the Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain disclosed that it had retained Wasserstein, Perella & Company, the New York merger and acquisitions firm.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on March 11 incorrectly referred to the Philadelphia Dance Theater as the Philadelphia Dance Company. The Dance Theater is a two-member company, founded by Mino Nicholas, that re-creates and preserves work by American modern-dance pioneers. The Dance Company, which is also known as Philadanco, is a contemporary modern-dance troupe under the direction of Joan Myers Brown.

title: Dorothy L. Keur, Anthropologist, 85
description: Dr. Dorothy L. Keur, a retired professor of anthropology at Hunter College, died March 22 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Billings, Mont. She was 85 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: TWO SAVINGS UNITS WITH LARGE LOSSES TAKEN OVER BY U.S.
description: Signaling an increased willingness to crack down on troubled savings and loan companies before their problems get out of control, Federal regulators today seized two money-losing but solvent savings institutions.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry Of First Fidelity
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting an informal investigation into the sudden announcement in December by the First Fidelity Bancorporation that it would post a record loss in the fourth quarter. The investigation was disclosed in First Fidelity's annual report, filed today with the S.E.C.

title: U.S. Won't Press Case in Boston
description: The United States Attorney in Boston announced today that he would not seek charges against the president of the Massachusetts State Senate, who had been under investigation for taking bribes.

title: Bethuel M. Webster, 88, Founder Of Law Firm and Lindsay Adviser
description: Bethuel M. Webster, the founder of Webster & Sheffield, a Manhattan law firm, died of complications from a throat disorder Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: Assistant D.A. Is Dismissed Over Credentials
description: An assistant prosecutor for the Brooklyn District Attorney has been dismissed because he was never admitted to the New York State Bar, the District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Most Throwaway Plastics Face a Ban in Minneapolis
description: In an effort to reduce a growing tide of plastic waste it must either burn or bury, the Minneapolis City Council adopted an ordinance today to ban most throwaway plastic food packaging from grocery store shelves and fast-food outlets.

title: Australian Concern To Buy MGM/UA
description: Kirk Kerkorian agreed to sell most of the MGM/UA Communications Company to the Qintex Group of Australia. MGM/UA's assets include the United Artists studio and a 4,000-film library that includes the James Bond, Rocky and Pink Panther movies. Article, page 33.

title: Gorbachev Hails 'People's Power' in Election
description: As Soviet voters begin preparing for the next round of fledgling democracy, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who stirred up the current excitement, is hailing the results as proof of ''people's power,'' not party weakness.

title: Prospect Group Seeks Brinkmann
description: Prospect Group Inc. offered to buy Brinkmann Instruments Inc. for $16.50 a share in cash. The offer values Brinkmann, a distributor of laboratory equipment, at $60.72 million. Prospect, a New York-based bakery-goods and railroad concern, controls 26 percent of Brinkmann's shares. The stock jumped $1.75 a share today, to $16.50, in over-the-counter trading.

title: A REMINDER
description: Daylight savings time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow. Clocks are set ahead one hour.

title: VSE Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First of Agent Orange Grants Given to Veterans' Agencies
description: The first eight grants to social service agencies that serve Vietnam veterans and their families have been made from a $52 million fund created by the settlement of a lawsuit over use of the Vietnam War defoliant Agent Orange.

title: Communications TransmisFsion Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1 million from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income Results for the latest periods included earnings from the company's 55.6 percent interest in the operations of ALC Communications Corp. on a consolidated basis.

title: Oscar's Endless Night
description: The 61st annual Academy Awards have come and gone. They said the show would be shorter. It wasn't. They said it would be funnier. It wasn't. They didn't say it would be any less tacky. One out of three ain't bad.

title: IDB Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Seijiro Matsuoka, a real estate entrepreneur and art collector, incorrectly named his wife as a survivor. She died some years ago.

title: Sono-Tek Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss After giving effect to a 2-for-1 stock split effective March 31, share earnings for the latest quarter and year were 6 cents and 16 cents, respectively.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SWIMMING Berkoff Breaks Record Again: In the last 100-yard backstroke race of the last meet before he retires, David Berkoff broke the American record last night for the fourth time in seven weeks. The latest record for the Harvard senior came in the national collegiate men's championships at the Indiana University Natatorium in Indianapolis. Using the revolutionary underwater start he perfected, Berkoff won the final in 47.02 seconds, beating Jeff Rouse of Stanford by two yards.

title: Inkster Takes 4-Shot Lead
description: Juli Inkster won the 1984 Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament in a playoff on the day NBC slowed the action and ruined Pat Bradley's charge to victory. This year, Inkster is leading by so much after two rounds and playing so well that it is unlikely anyone will get close enough to force a playoff, let alone beat her.

title: Valdez Townspeople Angered as Oil Slick Continues to Expand Off Alaska
description: The pent-up anger and frustration of townspeople here spilled over today as an expanding oil slick sent its first tentacle out of Prince William Sound into the Gulf of Alaska.

title: New Crises, From Jails to Sludge, Force New York to Rethink Budget
description: The Koch administration, confronting a rising need for jail cells, shelters for the homeless and waste-treatment plants, is planning shifts in spending that could delay dozens of rebuilding projects, from playgrounds to police stations, from streets to swimming pools.

title: COMMISSION BACKS STRONGER COUNCIL
description: Members of the New York City Charter Revision Commission, dismissing attempts to preserve the Board of Estimate as futile, said yesterday that they wanted swift and serious consideration of a larger, stronger City Council that might be elected in a markedly new way.

title: Smith May Be Out
description: Ozzie Smith, who strained a muscle on his left side Thursday while stealing third base, may miss the St. Louis Cardinals' opener against the Mets Monday.(AP)

title: Hopes for Peace Rise for the Basques
description: Hope is rising in the cities and hills of the Basque provinces that two decades of terrorist violence that has claimed more than 600 lives and shaken Spain's young democracy could be drawing to a close.

title: Ferdinand Brickwedde Dies at 86; First to Measure Heavy Hydrogen
description: Ferdinand Brickwedde, a physicist who in 1931 produced the first measurable amounts of deuterium, or heavy hydrogen, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Bellefont, Pa. He was 86 years old. The cause of death had not been determined yesterday.

title: Soviet Player Makes Debut
description: Sergei Priakin became the first Soviet player to compete in the National Hockey League, and an American teammate equaled a league record tonight in leading the Calgary Flames to a 4-1 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Reuters Will Convert Stock
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said today that it had reached agreement with large shareholders to convert all of its closely held class A shares, which have extra voting power, into ordinary stock.

title: Needless Stalling on Namibia
description: The United Nations' independence plan for Namibia takes effect today when a 4,650-member peacekeeping force moves into the field. One of the Reagan Administration's genuine diplomatic achievements, the plan realizes the long-sought American goals of a South African exit from Namibia and the withdrawal of Cuban forces from neighboring Angola.

title: Sis Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Acmat Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extrarodinary charge of $244,751. c-Included a tax credit of $340,100. Year 1987 included a gain of $2,050,000 from a sale of United Coasts Corp. stock.

title: Ralph R. McCoy, 79, Ex-Oil Company Head
description: Ralph R. McCoy, a retired foundation vice president and a former oil company executive, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Conn. He was 79 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Emigres, Moving With Skill, Give U.S. Chess a Soviet Cast
description: Back in the 70's, when Boris Spassky was playing Bobby Fischer, it was easy to tell who was who in international chess. Today, a Boris or an Ivan is as likely to play for the United States as for the Soviet Union.

title: Corrections
description: An article March 17 about the increased sale of assault rifles around the country misidentified a weapon that is a copy of the AK-47. It is the AKS, not the SKS.

title: No Company Money for Bombs in Animal Case; Killing Dogs for Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about William Lucas, who has been named to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, misstated his tenure as sheriff of Wayne County, Mich. He was sheriff in 1976, when a jail beating occurred there, but had left the job by 1985, when a Federal appeals court ruled in the case.

title: Monsanto Sells Silicon Subsidiary
description: The Monsanto Company of St. Louis said it had completed the sale of its electronic materials operations to DNS Electronic Materials Inc., an American subsidiary of Huels A.G. of West Germany. Terms of the sale were not disclosed; the Monsanto Electronic Materials Company had annual revenues of $200 million.

title: A Little Sincerity, Please
description: A fool takes the world at face value. As a result, he and his money are soon parted. Why this is bad is hard to say. People being parted from their money often seems to be what America, as the commercials say, is all about.

title: Sugar Sours the Everglades
description: The Everglades is one of the world's natural wonders. But it's a wonder this vast subtropical wetland even survives. Encroaching development and constantly rising demand for its water have been shrinking the swamp for more than a century. Now there's a new threat, from America's protected sugar industry.

title: U.S. Court Approves Supermarket Merger
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a judge's order that had blocked the consolidation of the Lucky and Alpha Beta supermarket chains, ruling that California had no right to undo the merger.

title: Stable Policy Voted by Fed
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve agreed in early February to leave interest rates unchanged for the immediate future but to push them upward if the risk of inflation rises, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Constantine Stackelberg, 90, Ex-Economist
description: Constantine Stackelberg, a retired economist with the Economic Development Administration in the Department of Commerce, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 90 years old. Born in St. Petersburg, Russia, Mr. Stackelberg was the son of Baron Nikolai Stackelberg, a master of ceremonies at the Czarist court.

title: A Soviet Tonic for European Tensions
description: LEAD: In opening the Vienna talks on conventional forces, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, said Moscow is ready to negotiate the dismemberment of the Soviet military threat that has been the backbone of the cold war in Europe since the late 1940's. Coming on the heels of the unilateral cuts announced by Mikhail Gorbachev at the United Nations, the historic shift in

title: Mcorp Sues U.S. on Seizure And Files for Chapter 11
description: Two days after its banking network was sheared by the Government from 25 units to 5, Mcorp opened a legal counterack on two fronts today.

title: New York Missing Budget Deadline Again
description: For the fifth year in a row, New York State will not have a budget in place by the legal deadline.

title: MINNESOTA DEFEATS MAINE TO GAIN TOURNAMENT FINAL
description: After spotting Maine an early two-goal lead, Minnesota scored seven times tonight to beat the Black Bears in a semifinal game of the National Collegiate Athletic Associaion hockey tournament.

title: Xapuri Journal; Where Back to Nature Is Wave of the Future
description: Valerio da Silva slit an ancient tree trunk with his knife and quickly hooked a cup into the bark to catch the white latex oozing out.

title: Successors Ready, U.S. Oilmen Bow Out of Their Saudi Empire
description: At a quiet little dinner a few days ago, the last American to preside over the world's largest oil company handed over power to its first Saudi boss. The Saudi, a man who started working there more than 40 years ago as an office boy, earned engineering and management degrees as he climbed up the ladder.

title: No Spot for Postema
description: Pam Postema has once again been turned down for an umpiring spot in the National League, as Bill Hohn and Jerry Layne were picked to fill the two vacancies. Postema, who has worked spring training games in each of the last two years while attempting to become the first female umpire in the major leagues, will return to Triple A ball. She was a crew chief last year.(AP)

title: Cherokee Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Review/Music; Peter Sellars Couples Brecht-Weill Despair With Bach's Faith
description: Peter Sellars is widely regarded as the wild man of American opera directors. But his modest double bill of the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill ''Mahagonny Songspiel'' and a carefully assembled dramatic sequence of Bach arias called ''Conversations With Fear and Hope After Death'' has proved one of his most durable, least outrageous creations.

title: Warriors Rout Knicks at Garden
description: The Knicks, who usually win games at home in the fourth quarter, found a way to lose one last night, shooting 23 percent from the field.

title: Flu Prevents Hershiser From Starting Opener
description: Already this season, Orel Hershiser has found something that can knock him out of the box: the flu.

title: Manville to Sell Holophane Unit
description: The Manville Corporation said it would sell its Holophane Lighting systems division for $102 million to the Raebarn Corporation, a merchant banking company in Los Angeles. The division, based in Newark, Ohio, was put up for sale by Manville in November.

title: Fund Transfer Granted To Supply AIDS Drug
description: The Bush Administration today granted the request of two Senators to transfer $5 million of Federal funds for AIDS to a program that provides the drug AZT to patients who cannot afford the medication.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday incorrectly described the content of soy products that resemble breakfast meat. In the example cited, three soy breakfast strips contain 330 milligrams of sodium. They contain no cholesterol.

title: Beard Oil Co. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $966,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. In 1988, the company sold its interest in USPCI to Union Pacific Corp. in connection with the transaction, $58 million and 5,812,149 shares to Beard Oil stock were distributed to the shareholders of Beard Co., the former parent of Beard Oil. The company said it had a 1988 gain of $8,217,000 on the sale of its USPCI stock. It also said, however, lower oil and gas prices, a $2,385,000 provision for economic impairment of producing properties and $3,746,000 in reorganization costs combined to offset the effect of higher production and the USPCI gain.

title: Pittsburgh & W. Va. Railroad reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Jail Crowding Eased By New York State
description: The New York State prison system has begun to speed up its acceptance of inmates from New York City's jails, relieving a backlog of 550 inmates - mostly parole violators -who were awaiting transfer from the city's overcrowded system.

title: On Mountain Highway, Kabul Defends a Lifeline
description: For an hour this afternoon, the last guard post on Kabul's northern perimeter, a cluster of mud-walled buildings squatting beside a dusty highway, was a nerve center of the Afghan war.

title: Sugarman Sells Barris Stake
description: The television producer Burt Sugarman has sold his controlling interest in Barris Industries to the owners of an Australian television network for $34.5 million, it was announced today.

title: Women's Status in Vietnam In Documentary Form
description: In ''Surname Viet Given Name Nam,'' Trinh T. Minh-ha, the young woman who produced, wrote, directed, edited and translated it, examines the present status of women in Vietnam in the context of history.

title: WorldCorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gain of $3.2 million from discontinued operations. c-After gain of $4,357,000 for the quarter and a loss of $13,726,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Women in Local Offices Find High Goals Elusive
description: As Mayor of Clifton, N.J., Gloria J. Kolodziej brimmed with confidence and accomplishment. She consolidated the city's work force, revamped the municipal bonding system and won praise from the state for a model substance-abuse program.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 11.19 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation - down from 11.22 percent last week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm a slick-licker. I'm going to make as much money as I can cleaning up this mess for Exxon. And then I'm going to leave Alaska for good and go someplace where there ain't so much snow and the water's cleaner.'' - Russell Roetman, a Valdez fisherman. [ 1:3. ]

title: Trump Deal For Shuttle Is Revived
description: The Texas Air Corporation and Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate developer, said yesterday that they had reached an agreement under which Mr. Trump would buy the Eastern Airlines shuttle for $365 million, the amount originally agreed to last October. Mr. Trump had sought to reduce the price after Eastern was crippled by a strike.

title: Molitor Out 3 Weeks
description: Paul Molitor, the often-injured star of the Milwaukee Brewers, will be out for three weeks after dislocating the ring finger of his right hand Thursday. Molitor was placed on the 15-day disabled list after undergoing surgery at Osborn Surgical Center in Phoenix.(AP)

title: When Ruby Missed the Final Four
description: This is the 30th anniversary of the year that neither Ron Rubenstein nor I played in the Final Four. I recalled this recently when I saw the booklet ''Final Four Records,'' a history of the Division I men's basketball tournament, published by the N.C.A.A. and put out to coincide with today's semifinal games.

title: About New York; A Zoo Story: 2 Hefty Tenants, Facing Eviction
description: These are melancholy days around Shorty and Betsy's cramped Brooklyn quarters. It seems only a matter of time before their landlord forces them out of the home in which they have lived together for a decade. They have taken to spending hour upon hour staring into space, grunting in monosyllables, listlessly chewing carrots and brooding.

title: Polish Party Approves Draft Of Plan to Alter the System
description: The Communist Party crossed what it called a historic threshold today, approving a draft of plans to transform the political system and end the party's 45-year monopoly of power.

title: Tibet Says 300 Are in Detention
description: Tibetan officials said today that more than 300 people had been detained since martial law was imposed after pro-independence rioting nearly four weeks ago. They offered little hope for a negotiated settlement that might bring stability to the Himalayan region.

title: Maine Official Is Criticized for Comment on Blacks in Sports
description: In three years as president of the University of Maine, Dale W. Lick has heard his share of criticism, but none stronger than that unleashed this week after he said research showed that black athletes perform better than whites because they are better suited genetically for certain sports.

title: Crescott Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $338,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and included a gain of $6,253,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1,300,000.

title: Iran Cites Oil Windfall
description: Higher crude oil prices have brought a $1.5 billion windfall to Iran's oil revenue in the last three months, the country's oil minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, said today. ''We are now selling our oil at 50 cents to a dollar more than official OPEC prices,'' Mr. Aghazadeh told the Teheran radio.

title: Some Pay Phones Are Booby-Trapped With High Rates
description: Starting today, callers across the nation who use a pay telephone for a long-distance call that requires the help of an operator could end up paying a high rate for the call if they do not check the new dialing instructions posted on the phone.

title: Space Scoop for Japanese Annoys Soviet Journalists
description: Cosmic capitalism apparently does not sit well with some Soviet reporters.

title: 2 Planes Collide on Runway
description: Two planes collided in fog while taxiing at Hancock International Airport this morning, spilling flammable fuel and closing the airport's main runway for about 90 minutes. There were no serious injuries.

title: MGM/UA ASSETS SOLD TO QINTEX
description: Kirk Kerkorian, the financier who controls the MGM/UA Communications Company, agreed today to sell the bulk of the company to the Qintex Group of Australia.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, filed an amended plan of reorganization with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in connection with its pending agreement to merge with a subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.

title: Corrugating Wood To Increase Strength
description: Corrugated sheet metals have been a staple in manufacturing and construction for years, because a serpentine shape increases stiffness and strength without requiring extra thickness.

title: Mission Resource Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year included a $4,287,938 gain on the sale of property. Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: Sea Galley Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After losses on the early extinguishment of debt of $31,000 for the quarter and $133,000 for the year, and a charge of $131,000 from the reversal of tax credits for the quarter and a tax credit of $71,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,000 for the quarter and $214,000 for the year.

title: 5 Are Killed as Plane Crashes at Tennis Club
description: A twin-engine plane crashed and exploded today on a tennis court at an exclusive club, killing a Canadian family of five and strewing fiery debris that narrowly missed three other people.

title: The Pollsters Are Coming
description: No sooner had the polls closed in Moscow last Sunday than United States television audiences were informed that Boris Yeltsin had won election to the Congress of People's Deputies. The votes weren't counted until Monday.

title: Guilty Plea In Pentagon Fraud Case
description: The Government today accepted an eighth guilty plea in a scheme to bribe a Navy official for inside information on military contracts. The scheme was uncovered during an inquiry into Pentagon purchasing fraud.

title: Your Money; Tax Problems For Retirees
description: Congress gave middle-income retirees a big job of tax and financial planning in 1983 when it made up to half their Social Security benefits subject to income taxes. Now, by imposing a surtax for Medicare catastrophic coverage, it has created even more complexity.

title: Japan Company in Scandal Aided Takeshita Campaign
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita acknowledged today that the company involved in Japan's widening influence-peddling scandal had purchased $150,000 in tickets for a political fund-raising party of his two years ago.

title: 'Let Mr. Rushdie Be Handed Over for Trial in an Islamic Court'
description: To the Editor:

title: Raytech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year results included unusual charges of $871,000 and $69,090,000, respectively, related to the divestiture of the company's Raymark unit in May 1988. The year-ago periods' results included unusual charges of $1,158,000 for the quarter and $566,000 for the year, related to the writeoff of a Raymark manufacturing facility.

title: Houston Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Muster Injured in Accident Shortly After Gaining Final
description: Thomas Muster of Austria suffered a serious leg injury in an accident tonight less than two hours after he won a semifinal match in the International Players Championships, a tournament official said.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Keeping Cellars Dry
description: If your house is in a low-lying area and the basement tends to flood, spring is the time to buy a sump pump or check the one you have. The pump removes water that seeps through foundation walls before it can flood the cellar. The pump sits in a pit or basin in the cellar, usually 30 inches deep, and as water collects in the pit the pump discharges it away the house through a pipe. Here are three basic ways to avoid problems. Pit Debris: To avoid motor burnout, remove any debris from the pit and scoop out sediment. Mount the pump on bricks, to raise it slightly above the bottom of the pit. Clogged Pipe: Flush the discharge pipe regularly with a garden hose to clear it of any debris. Replacing Pump: Generally, sump pumps should be replaced after six or seven years. A pump should turn on and off automatically and be installed by a licensed plumber. Also, have a battery-operated backup in case of power failure in a storm. Source: The Plumbing-Heating-Cooling Information Bureau, Chicago.

title: F.C.C. Policy Assisting Minorities Is Overturned
description: A Federal appeals court today ruled unconstitutional a Federal Communications Commission policy intended to increase opportunities for members of minority groups to own radio and television stations.

title: Black Judges Needed More Than Coaches
description: To the Editor:

title: Belgium Killings Are Claimed
description: A Muslim group in Lebanon said today that it was responsible for the shooting deaths of Abdullah al-Ahdal, the spiritual leader of Belgium's Muslims, and his deputy earlier this week. The group, Soldiers of Truth, made the claim in a statement sent to a news agency in Beirut. Belgian officials said the killings were linked to Mr. Ahdal's rejection of a death sentence against Salman Rushdie, author of ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: Cuomo Names Prosecutor In Choke Case
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appointed a special prosecutor today to reinvestigate the case of Jimmy Lee Bruce Jr., a 20-year-old black man who died of asphyxiation after a white off-duty police officer restrained him with a choke hold.

title: Tele-Radio Systems Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special gain of $1,212,257, which consisted of a $725,243 gain on the sale of an investment, a tax credit of $526,111, and a $39,097 writeoff of previous years' deferred taxes. The company said that, because of the amalgamation on Jan. 31, 1988 of Orcatech Inc. and Tele-Radio, there are no year-ago comparative figures. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Poloron Products Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $414,000 for the latest year and $1,088,000 for 1987.

title: Reservoirs See a Gain, Just Barely
description: A few days of wet weather and public cooperation since New York City posted a drought watch in January have halted the drain on reservoirs temporarily, but it would take a deluge to end the emergency any time soon, city officials warned yesterday.

title: Xiao Jingguang, Admiral, 86
description: Xiao Jingguang, former commander of the Chinese Navy and Deputy Defense Minister, died on Wednesday, the official New China News Agency said Thursday. He was 86 years old.

title: Back Problem May Force Mattingly Out of Opener
description: A day after Rafael Santana underwent elbow surgery that will force the shortstop to miss the season, Don Mattingly's lower back problems forced him out of this weekend's two-game exhibition series between the Yankees and Mets and put his status for opening night in jeopardy.

title: The Low-Key Style Of Giuliani's Successor
description: Two months ago, when he was named the interim replacement for Rudolph W. Giuliani as the Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, Benito Romano refused to say whether he wanted the job permanently.

title: Vornado Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
P.&G. Acquires Sundor Group
description: The Procter & Gamble Company has bought the nation's sixth-largest fruit drink manufacturer, Sundor Group Inc. of Darien, Conn. Analysts estimated that P.&G. paid $275 million to $300 million in cash. The Cincinnati company did not disclose the purchase price.

title: Waste Cited in Washington-Virgin Islands Project
description: Federal auditors said today that most of the $260,000 the Virgin Islands paid the District of Columbia for a study of the territory's personnel system was squandered on high living and other unauthorized expenditures, some of them traceable to top city officials here.

title: Du Pont Relinquishes Nuclear Plant
description: At midnight, control of one of oldest, largest, most polluted nuclear complexes in the world will shift from E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which designed and built it 38 years ago, to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which the Government hopes will set it straight.

title: INSIDE
description: Trump and Eastern Reach A New Deal for Shuttle

title: At Factory Outlets, a Bright Outlook
description: The hottest trend in retailing is the factory outlet mall, those increasingly smart shopping centers that draw throngs of savvy urban shoppers to out-of-the-way places where designer and brand-name merchandise is offered at bargain prices.

title: Business Leaders Take Ad That Backs Milken
description: A message first seen last year on T-shirts worn by friends and colleagues of Michael Milken appeared yesterday as the headline of a full-page advertisement signed by dozens of prominent business executives: ''Mike Milken, We Believe in You.''

title: Leadership as Seen by a Scourge and a Philosopher
description: Leadership Secrets of Attila the Hun By Wess Roberts, Ph.D. 110 pages. Warner Books. $16.95. Tao Te Ching A New English Version, With Foreword and Notes By Stephen Mitchell 108 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: Taylor Faces Hearing
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker, will face charges of driving while intoxicated at a hearing scheduled for April 19 in Municipal Court in Saddle Brook, N.J., the prosecutor, Joseph Mecca Jr., said.

title: Argentine Minister Resigns After Candidate's Demand
description: Unable to save the collapsing Argentine currency or slow the relentless inflation spiral, Economy Minister Juan V. Sourrouille resigned today, as did other economic officials.

title: LATIN NATIONS ASK FOR U.N. PRESENCE
description: The Foreign Ministers of five Central American countries formally asked the United Nations today to establish an international force of unarmed observers to patrol the region against violation of a peace accord that bans aid to insurgent armies.

title: Dow Up 12.28, to 2,293.62, in Broad Advance
description: Stock prices rose broadly in heavier trading yesterday as the dollar's advance, strength in airline stocks and takeover activity buoyed the market.

title: Liberty Homes reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $872,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY APRIL 1, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Youth Adviser Held On Drug Charges
description: A youth counselor and two other men have been arrested after undercover narcotics agents bought cocaine from them in the Bronx, the police said.

title: New Japan Sales Tax: Gift to Small Retailers
description: Nobody likes to pay new taxes, and Japanese skills at evading them have been the stuff of legends and hit movies. But starting on Saturday, small business owners will have the Government's backing as they pocket a new tax paid by their customers, rather than passing it on to the Government.

title: BELLEVUE AND SOCIAL AGENCY TURN A DISABLED GIRL AWAY
description: A brain-deformed 2-year-old girl suffering from diabetes who was removed from her home by New York City child-protection workers on Thursday was denied admission to Bellevue Hospital Center that night because she did not need emergency care. And, a short time later, the city's overnight service for children turned her away because it could not meet her medical needs.

title: Rangers Are Aiming for Winning Finale
description: It is entirely possible that the game Saturday night between the Rangers and the Pittsburgh Penguins could be a playoff preview. For the Rangers, though, it is absolutely essential that it not be a rerun of their recent performances.

title: NWA Stock Rises on $2.6 Billion Bid
description: Shares of NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, rose $16.625 yesterday, following an offer by Marvin Davis, the billionaire oilman, to pay $2.6 billion in cash for the company.

title: 2 Sides in Milken Case Fail to Agree on Bond
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers in the racketeering and fraud case of Michael R. Milken could not reach an agreement yesterday on how he and other defendants could satisfy the pretrial forfeiture provisions of the Federal racketeering law.

title: Women's N.C.A.A.; Tennessee and Auburn In Tournament Final
description: Tennessee showed tonight why it is the nation's No. 1-ranked team, how it has earned four consecutive Final Four trips and why it is favored to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's Division I basketball title.

title: Composer Replaces Siren's Wail With Melody and Meaning
description: On a deserted street, Max Neuhaus squeezed his eyes shut in rapt concentration and listened to the electronic pings and whoops emanating from a pair of police cars that circled the block in the darkness.

title: Biltmore Theater's Owner Rejects $5.25 Million Offer
description: The Biltmore Theater, a landmark playhouse on Broadway, went on the auction block yesterday for a second time, but the owner refused to accept the high bid of $5.25 million.

title: Rise in 2 Crops Foreseen
description: A Government report today showed that United States farmers, struggling to recover from the 1988 drought, intend to sow more acres of grain and soybeans this year. The Agriculture Department report said farmers planned to plant 73.3 million acres of corn, 8 percent more than last year, and 61.7 million acres of soybeans, 5 percent above 1988. The survey of 65,000 farmers could foreshadow a sizable increase in American feed and food grain production this year, trade experts said.

title: Micropro International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss The latest 6 months included first quarter reorganization severance and outplacement costs of about $500,000 and writedowns of inventory and related capitalized royalty costs of about $300,000.

title: Historical Society Plans Open House Tomorrow
description: The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street, is to hold an open house tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., with behind-the-scenes tours, chamber music and refreshments. The free event celebrates the society's reopening on Sundays after financial difficulties forced it to curtail exhibition hours and close its fourth-floor galleries last summer.

title: How Lord Byron Became Mad, Bad and Dangerous to Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank of America
description: The Bank of America said it would open its branches on Saturdays, from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M., beginning in April. The move by the largest bank in California is the latest salvo in the competition among California banks to offer customers the longest service hours. The Wells Fargo Bank, for instance, is advertising that its branches are open weekdays from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Bridge; A nonstop trans-Atlantic battle of the sexes begins today.
description: Nonstop trans-Atlantic bridge activity begins today at noon and will continue for 14 days. It is the Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes, and one table of two men against two women will be in play at the Cavendish Club at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan. The other table, with men and women in the opposite directions, will be at the Club of the French Bridge Federation in Paris.

title: Two Kits Developed For On-Site Drug Tests
description: Raymond F. Akers Jr., co-founder of Drug Screening Systems Inc. of Blackwood, N.J., has received two patents for on-site drug-testing kits that work like litmus tests and cost about $5 apiece. The first kit detects traces of cocaine, heroin, amphetamines and PCP, and was cleared for marketing by the Food and Drug Administration in February. The second kit detects marijuana, and is still awaiting approval. The company said both tests were more than 95 percent accurate.

title: Sasser Wins the Mets' 24th Spot
description: The Mets broke camp and headed for New York today with a losing record and some unanswered questions, and with Mackey Sasser as the winner of the contest for the 24th and final job on the team that will open the season Monday in Shea Stadium.

title: Interspec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a tax credit of $227,000. c-After a reversal of a tax credit of $14,000. Year-ago first quarter is restated to include the operations of Vingmed Sound As, acquired in July 1988 in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Bush Sees History as 'Basically Kind' to Presidents
description: ''History,'' President Bush said today, ''is basically kind to American Presidents.''

title: Rights Alliance in Cuba Appeals To Gorbachev to Back Its Cause
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives Sunday in this Communist outpost in the Caribbean, he may find that his warmest welcome comes not from his official hosts but from Cuban dissidents who now look to Moscow as an improbable beacon of freedom.

title: Pub Raid Fuels Debate on College Drinking
description: A crackdown on under-age drinking among college students brought state police onto the campus of Montclair State College this month, resulting in the arrests of 11 students and a suspension of the sale of alcoholic beverages at the campus pub.

title: Hawks Avenge Loss To Nets
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 31 points and Moses Malone had 27 tonight as the Atlanta Hawks beat the Nets, 116-99. Both Wilkins and Malone sat out the fourth quarter.

title: A Plastic Bottle to Ship Frozen Fruit Juice
description: Steven Smith, founder of the Fresh Juice Company in Great Neck, L.I., received a patent this week for a plastic bottle that makes it possible to ship frozen, fresh-squeezed fruit juice.

title: Saudis Support Return Of Egypt to Arab Fold
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia wound up a visit to Egypt today by saying he would support Egypt's return to the Arab League. Cairo was expelled 10 years ago for making peace with Israel.

title: America's Forgotten War in the Philippines
description: LEAD: On the night of Feb. 4, 1899, two privates, Willie Grayson and Orville Miller of the Nebraska regiment, were patrolling their camp perimeter in the outskirts of Manila when they discerned the shadowy shapes of four Filipino nationalist soldiers, almost certainly drunk and probably unarmed. Grayson challenged them to halt, then he and Miller fired.

title: Webster Joins Chiefs
description: Mike Webster, a Pro Bowl center nine times during 15 seasons with the Pittsburgh Steelers, has decided to come out of retirement and play for the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: South Africa Says 650 Free
description: South Africa says it has released more than two-thirds of about 900 detainees being held when a fast began in prisons on Jan. 23. Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu said today that Law and Order Minister Adriaan J. Vlok had told him that he had approved 650 releases.

title: U.S. and Moscow Agree to Exchange Diplomacy Experts
description: The United States and the Soviet Union announced an agreement today that will permit the exchange of international-affairs specialists and diplomatic personnel for the first time.

title: Answer to Riddle: East Germany Isn't Prospering
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW FUSION GAIN REPORTED IN U.S.
description: Scientists at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, have fused heavy forms of hydrogen into helium at room temperature, one of the researchers said yesterday. The achievement could eventually lead to new power sources.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Gardening in a Drought
description: The drought that has come with spring threatens May's flowers. In New York City the Mayor has declared a water emergency and ordered strong curbs on water use. Many other parts of the East are also rationing water.

title: Quarterback Stricken
description: Still devastated yesterday by reports that Colorado's starting quarterback, Sal Aunese, has inoperable cancer that has spread from his stomach to his lungs and lymph nodes, several teammates cut short their spring-break vacations to join him in Boulder, Colo. School officials said that Aunese would begin chemotherapy treatment next week..(AP)

title: Exiled Artist Now a Star in Moscow
description: Eighteen years ago, Mihail Chemiakin was an artist forced into exile for ''ideological subversion'' in refusing to paint in what he still sneers at as the ''heroic eunuch'' style of officially approved Soviet realism.

title: Citizens and Southern Maps NCNB Strategy
description: Executives at the Citizens and Southern Corporation, the Atlanta-based banking company, are preparing either to fight the $2.4 billion merger offer from the NCNB Corporation or to squeeze a higher price from the Charlotte, N.C., banking company.

title: Stuarts Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a gain of $902,000 from an accounting change.

title: Alaska's Stain: Delicate Balance Undone
description: Chipping oil-stained ice from the bow of his boat, Russell Roetman seems the ultimate Alaskan jack-of-all-trades: he got rich in the oil boom, went broke in the energy recession, stayed alive as a fisherman and now is planning to ride the lastest growth business right out of Prince William Sound.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 16.

title: Four Tough Teams, but No Big Favorite
description: A few days before the 1985-86 college basketball season began, an 18-year-old Duke University freshman named Danny Ferry tried to discourage the idea that he would be the player to bring Duke its first national championship. ''People might expect me to be a savior of a program and win a national championship,'' Ferry said. ''That's unrealistic.''

title: Uniforce Temporary PersonFnel reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Theater; Frankie Is Still Searching for Togetherness
description: Frankie Addams, the 12-year-old title character in ''The Member of the Wedding,'' shares her dreams and fantasies with her two friends - her 12-year-old cousin, John Henry, and Berenice, the family cook. The three are a family unto themselves and, within the Addams kitchen, Frankie's fancy can take flight. To her, the outside world, the real world, is a fiction.

title: Bears Want Childress
description: Ray Childress has been offered a job with the Chicago Bears and the All-Pro defensive end says he's willing to take it. But first, his team, the Houston Oilers, has a week to match the Bears' offer, reported to be $7.4 million over five years.(AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-5 Mikhail Gorbachev arrives in Cuba tomorrow, and he may find that his warmest welcome comes not from his official hosts, but from dissidents who now look to Moscow as a beacon of freedom. Page 1 Mikhail Gorbachev is hailing results from the Soviet Union's election last Sunday as proof of ''people's power,'' not party weakness. 5 Soviet journalists protest space ride for the Japanese 5 U.S. and Moscow agree to exchange diplomacy experts 5 Five Central American nations asked the United Nations to establish a force of unarmed observers to patrol the region for violations of a peace accord that bans aid to insurgent armies. 4 Japan's new ''consumption tax'' begins today for purchases on everything from subway rides to apartment rents. The tax has shattered any myth that the Japanese organize everything with precision. 1 Prime Minister Takeshita of Japan acknowledged that the company involved in an influence-peddling scandal had purchased $150,000 in tickets for a political fund-raising party of his two years ago. 3 Tibet says 300 are in detention 3 The largest oil company in the world, the Arabian-American Oil Company, has a new chief, and in a quiet but significant shift in power, the new boss is a Saudi, not an American. 4 Saudis support return of Egypt to Arab fold 5 On a mountain highway, Kabul defends a lifeline 3 Violence by Basque separatists may be reaching an end, with the underground Basque separatist organization observing a self-imposed truce since the beginning of the year. 3 National 6-8, 28 Two savings and loan associations that are solvent but losing money were seized by Federal regulators. The move showed a new willingness to crack down on troubled companies before problems get out of control. 1 Three things that Alaskans depend on are oil, fish or beauty. Those needs have coexisted for 12 years, until the recent oil spill has made one threatening to the other two. 1 A town's frustration over the oil spill off Valdez, Alaska, broke out at a news conference called by the Exxon Shipping Company, with townspeople shouting and calling the cleanup effort slow and ineffective. 8 The judge in the trial of Oliver North rejected an attempt to force Ronald Reagan to appear as a witness, declaring that no written evidence suggested that Mr. Reagan authorized acts for which Mr. North was being tried. 1 An eighth guilty plea in a scheme to bribe a Navy official for inside information on military contracts was accepted by the Government. 33 Donald Trump's Eastern-shuttle deal with Texas Air was reaffirmed, with Mr. Trump agreeing to pay the original amount, $365 million. 33 Minneapolis moved to ban plastic used in food packaging from grocery stores and fast-food outlets, trying to reduce the growing tide of plastic waste the city must burn or bury. 6 Control of the nuclear weapon plant at Savannah River, S.C., today shifts from Du Pont, which designed and built it, to Westinghouse, which the Government hopes will set it straight. 7 Forms of hydrogen have been fused into helium at room temperature by scientists at Brigham Young University. The achievement could eventually lead to new power sources. 6 A new sound for emergency sirens has been developed by Max Neuhaus, the designer of environmental sound sculpture. How does it sound? ''Like a big old cuckoo clock,'' a police officer said. 6 George Bush's favorite Presidents include Ronald Reagan and Harry S. Truman, Mr. Bush said. Why Truman? ''I respect a guy that fights back,'' he said. 8 Most of the payment to Washington by the Virgin Islands for a $260,000 study of the territory's personnel system was squandered on high living and other unauthorized expenditures, Federal auditors said. 28 Maine official is criticized for comment on blacks in sports 6 First awards to veteran agencies granted in Agent Orange suit 7 Top business executives back Milken in newspaper ads 45 Regional 29-32 With a rising need for jail cells, homeless shelters and waste-treatment plants in New York City, the Koch administration is planning budget shifts that could delay many rebuilding projects. 1 A stronger New York City Council, instead of a revised Board of Eastimate, should be considered as part of a new city government, several members of the Charter Revision Commission said. 1 Bellevue and social agency turn a disabled girl away 31 The defection of a Soviet chess star, 14-year-old Gata Kamsky, caused chagrin both for Soviet players, who lost a compatriot, and for American players, who gained a competitor. 1 The interim Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, Benito Romano, does not say whether he wants to keep his job, but he has nevertheless begun putting his own stamp on a high-profile prosecutorial outpost. 29 A special prosecutor was named to examine the 1986 death of a black man in Wallkill, N.Y., who died after a white off-duty police officer restrained him with a choke hold. 29 A crackdown on campus drinking in New Jersey colleges, and the first arrests in a campus pub in four years, have posed a problem for colleges: how to regulate drinking by students under the legal drinking age of 21. 29 More women are in local politics than ever before in the region and throughout the nation. But, by and large, their success remains limited to the municipal arena. 29 Four youths on trial in Jersey City for murder were convicted on lesser assault charges in the death of an Indian man that arose from a Hoboken street altercation 18 months ago. 30 Connecticut's governor says he could back a higher sales tax 30

title: Kroger to Proceed With Settlement
description: The Kroger Company said it planned to proceed with a court-approved settlement of a class-action suit by shareholders who challenged the $4.6 billion restructuring the company announced last September. Under the settlement, the Cincinnati-based grocery company will pay $1.275 million in lawyers' fees to about 20 law firms that represented the plaintiffs.

title: Silk Greenhouse Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Youths Convicted of Assault In Death of an Indian Man
description: Four teen-agers were acquitted of murder but convicted on assault charges today in the beating death of an Indian man on a Hoboken street 18 months ago, in an incident that outraged the Indian community.

title: Answer to Riddle: East Germany Isn't Prospering; Poorer Than Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: Empire Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $2.7 million and $3 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included special gains of $100,000 for the quarter and $2.2 million for the 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Tourist Is Rescued After Fall Into River
description: A tourist from Massachusetts fell into the East River yesterday and was rescued by police officers who were pointed to the spot by a traffic reporter in a helicopter.

title: O'Neill Suggests He Could Back 8.5% Sales Tax
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he could accept an increase in the state sales tax to 8.5 percent from 7.5 percent, already the highest in the country, as long as the extra revenue is used to help balance the state's budget.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; Cultures Collide in Papua New Guinea
description: It was 50 years before the time of this extraordinarily intimate documentary that Joe Leahy came into the world, the product of a casual union between an Australian gold prospector and a woman of the lush New Guinea Highlands. Now Joe, brought up as a Highlander but familiar with the ways of the white man, has become a wealthy coffee grower on land sold to him very cheaply by the local Ganiga tribe. ''Joe Leahy's Neighbors'' shows the tribesmen confronting the subversion of their traditions and their sense of security that his presence represents.

title: Irene K. Mitchell to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Mitchell of Larchmont, N.Y., and Sea Island, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter Irene K. Mitchell to Dr. John B. Ryan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles B. Ryan of Auburn, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla. A June 17 wedding is planned. Miss Mitchell, a graduate of Fairfield University, is a corporate bond trader at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York. The future bridegroom is a surgical resident at Robert Packer Hospital in Sayre, Pa. He is a graduate of Hobart College and the Georgetown University School of Medicine.

title: As Incentive, Anything Goes
description: THE NEW YORK STOCKBROKER and his wife approached the mist-shrouded entrance to a giant tent on the grounds of the Boca Raton Hotel and Club in Boca Raton, Fla. Suddenly a pair of six-foot lizards lunged toward them. The broker and his wife fled into the tent -only to be plunged into an alien world. The steamy jungle rang with shrill bird and animal cries. Shadowy forms peered down from treetops.

title: Lina Wertmuller Zeroes In on AIDS
description: What is Lina Wertmuller's next film about? Ask the publicist: ''One of the most potent and controversial topics of our generation.'' Ask the Italian production company: ''A frantic search for truth.'' Ask the leading man, Rutger Hauer: ''A man going through a process of change.'' Ask the director herself: ''The intervention of the media on the delicate human body.'' No one is telling it straight, so read the script: The film is about AIDS.

title: Legal-Aid Project Strives to Help Poor
description: IT was an unusually slow Tuesday morning for Victor Ambrose, a lawyer for the poor. His only case at the Nassau County District Court in Hempstead had just been postponed, and so he trudged several blocks through a chilly rain back to his office at the Nassau-Suffolk Law Services Committee Inc., an organization of three dozen lawyers who represent the poor in civil litigation at no cost.

title: AN ASIAN TALE: YOUNG GIRLS, RED ROSES
description: AMID THE FLASHING STROBE LIGHTS OF BLOOM-ers Nightclub, in Manila's red-light district, a small girl sits perched on a bar stool, her chin on one forearm, gazing up at the young women in string bikinis who dance to the thump of loud rock music. The girl, who is 10 years old and whose name is Winda, swings gently on her bar stool in time to the music, a packet of red roses dangling forgotten from her hand.

title: Catching the Spirit of a Place
description: THE lean, hollow-cheeked pastor looks like one of Jane Austen's somber vicars. Stern and of sallow complexion, he has stubbornly maintained his English pallor although he's lived beneath this tropical sun for 30 years. He stands on his dignity and his difference. Members of his congregation glow in tones of deep mahogany and lighter amber.

title: On Language; Title Search Follow-Up
description: AUTHORS OF BOOKS sneak messages to their readers in titles. So do authors of columns (this one, at least); the double meaning of a pun in a headline can direct readers to an underlying message. In ''Peking Too Soon,'' a pundit was hinting at a domestic political motive in President Bush's recent visit to the Chinese capital, just as in a piece some years ago about the predations of Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, then-Saudi oil minister, a holdup warning was contained in ''Yamani or Ya Life.''

title: Tax-Exempt College Bonds Planned
description: STARTING tomorrow, Connecticut residents will again have an opportunity to order special tax-exempt college savings bonds.

title: An Epicure's Night Out in L.A.
description: LEAD: RESTAURANTS are arguably the most vital public spaces in America today - and, as such, they tend to reflect the sensibilities of the publics they serve. Thus, in a city like Los Angeles, built on glamorous appearances, we expect our restaurants to look good; in a city filled with stars, we want such places to be fitting stages, well lighted, dramatically designed; in a city where the sun is nearly always shining and the sea is never far away, we don't want to have to dress up every time we're in the mood for a Caesar salad or a charred-rare tuna steak.

title: The 'Ring' Bypasses The Brain
description: For the person who hates Wagner, this would be a good time to leave town. From now until the end of the Metropolitan Opera season on May 6, New York will do its best to become Bayreuth-on-the-Hudson. The citizenry will not be required to wear Bavarian costumes, nor will a formal-dress code be enforced in the house itself. Neither will the Metropolitan temporarily replace its cushioned seats with the wooden torture devices, faintly resembling chairs, that Bayreuth visitors are required to endure.

title: KENYAN IS GIVEN AWARD ON RIGHTS
description: As concern grows about the erosion of political and civil liberties in Kenya, a Kenyan lawyer who was imprisoned for his legal work has received a prestigious American human-rights award.

title: South of The Border
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Times: Gun Makers Retrench and Toughen Their Tactics
description: The industry downturn has dramatically altered the dynamics of the gun business. It forced a half-dozen or so producers out of business. And it weakened the positions of many smaller producers. Today, the five largest companies control at least 60 percent of the market, with the remainder divided among more than 50 producers, which may make only 40 guns a year.

title: Leslie Bjerg Lilly Is Wed in Florida To David Wollins
description: The marriage of Leslie Bjerg Lilly, a daughter of Elisabeth B. Lilly of Coconut Grove, Fla., and Westport, Me., and Dr. John C. Lilly of Malibu, Calif., to David Hart Wollins, a son of Constance Graham of Rehoboth Beach, Del., and the late Donald J. Wollins, took place yesterday at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Coconut Grove. The Rev. Woodrow W. Hasty performed the ceremony.

title: The Messy Saga of 'Tilted Arc' Is Far From Over
description: ''Tilted Arc'' is gone. After eight years, Richard Serra's 120-foot-long and 12-foot-high bend of Cor-Ten steel - better known by the press as the rusted steel wall bisecting Federal Plaza - has been disassembled in the dead of night and carted off to a yard in Brooklyn, where its three parts lie stacked and packaged behind barbed wire. ''Good Riddance'' was the headline of the editorial in The Wall Street Journal. The world is finally safe from the evil thing. Whew!

title:
WINE;
Selections At Local Restaurants
description: LEAD: A REVIEW of the current wine offerings at popular area dining spots reveals a trend toward a wider selection of less-known labels and a remarkable restraint in pricing, particularly when tariffs charged for a number of bottles are compared with those at some highly regarded Manhattan eating establishments.

title: ASHBY LIVES AGAIN
description: JULIE By Maurice Valency. 268 pp. New York: New Amsterdam Books. $17.95.

title: Miss Buckley To Be a Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Donald G. Leahan of Newtown Square, Pa., and Walter White Buckley Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Ann Brooke Buckley, to Thomas Anderson Ashforth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Adams Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Peru, Vt. A June wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
Tomatoes That Please the Tastebuds
description: LEAD: BESIDES its traditional red, tomatoes come in pink, orange, yellow and even white. Tomato fruits also come in a variety of forms and sizes.

title: A Patriarch Retires - Cautiously
description: Not even Curt Carlson's daughter knows whether he really means it this time.

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor: Because of the Berwick-Upon-Tweed article that appeared in the Travel section on May 29, 1988, I was determined to end my three-week trip through the Outer Hebrides and Northern Scotland in Berwick-Upon-Tweed. I knew that someday I must be there to walk around Holy Island where one must come and go by the will of the tides. But because the experience of watching the tide come in was not described in the article, I was not prepared for such a rare moment.

title: Journalists Debate the Risks As President Woos the Press
description: Jessica Lee can remember exactly how it felt, the night she attended a dinner party at the Bushes', to drive her rusty blue Datsun sports car through the iron gates and up the driveway to the White House. ''I couldn't get over it, a Washington reporter parking in front of the door,'' said Ms. Lee, the White House reporter for USA Today.

title: Frank Dickstein, Executive, 71
description: Frank Dickstein, a textile executive, died of cancer Friday at White Plains Hospital Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title:
The View From: Stonington;
Sale of Waterfront Parcel Stirs Concern in a Seafaring Village
description: LEAD: To a visitor, the long, tall brick building that is part of the former Monsanto factory complex along Water Street may well seem at odds with the borough of Stonington's otherwise idyllic, seafaring ambiance.

title: No Headline
description: THE scene in Yonkers's ornate City Hall was all too familiar last week - television lights, packed rows of irate spectators and speakers taking turns to berate the members of the City Council, followed by a formal Council session similarly punctuated by angry exchanges and barbed challenges.

title: Learning History Through Paintings
description: EVER since they introduced their students to a program on American art and history at the Montclair Art Museum, Giselle Scarfone-Sanzone and Carol Skopak say, the children have not quite been the same.

title: Jews Divided By a Convent At Auschwitz
description: The presence of a Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp, already seriously straining Catholic-Jewish relations, has now divided Jewish groups as well.

title: SCOTT BYRON: Music Journal Editor
description: Every two weeks, Scott Byron takes the pulse of some 500 college and alternative-radio stations and publishes the results in the CMJ New Music Report, a trade publication with limited circulation but considerable influence.

title: SPEAKING OF THE UPSPEAKABLE
description: I, too, was sexually assaulted after my freshman year in college. Unlike Ms. Sebold, I was not raped. But in an emotional sense, it makes no difference. Seven years later, I still feel the same fear in the pit of my stomach when I put my key in the door late at night. I still hear myself scream in the empty hallway after he let me go.

title: In India, One Ethnic Protest Leads to Another
description: Less than a decade after a violent Assamese-rights campaign brought turmoil to India's northeastern state of Assam, a new guerrilla war has begun in this remote area.

title: Harvard Claims Its First N.C.A.A. Hockey Title
description: Harvard at last gained the pinnacle of the college hockey world by defeating Minnesota, 4-3, in overtime to win the national championship tonight at the St. Paul Civic Center.

title: An Insurance Problem With 'New' House Calls
description: Re: the recent article ''The New Kind of House Call'': Our counselors at Score, the Service Corps of Retired Executives, advise several men and women who desire and have plans to develop a ''house call business.'' Increasingly, however, there arises in our counseling the question of proper advisable insurance coverage.

title: Social Events
description: Guardian of the Needy

title: A British Buyout Cashes In
description: The tale has a familiar ring. A division of a company goes private in a leveraged buyout. Freed from their corporate parent, energized managers breathe new life into a moribund business. And then once they do, the managers decide to sell the business and make a killing - a decision that sparks public cries of greed and betrayal.

title: Inch for Inch, One of the Great Museums
description: Richard, 7th Viscount Fitzwilliam (1745-1816) was a moneyed amateur of art, music and literature who believed that a great university should have a great museum. The one would complement the other to perfection, as he saw it, and when he died he made it possible for Cambridge, England, to have the museum that bears his name.

title: The Island Where The Middle East Conducts Traffic
description: SINCE 1975, throughout Lebanon's turmoil, this island just 150 miles across the water from Beirut has become, in many ways, the city's successor as crossroads of the Middle East, a center of commerce and intrigue.

title: Seton Hall Shocks Duke to Reach Final
description: A Seton Hall basketball season that had already become difficult to believe today arrived at its most unlikely moment.

title: Catching the Endless Wave
description: TO spend a day at the beach in Southern California is to bask in the company of the amiable Pacific. To seek out the beach scene is to make lunch of an apple burrito and bubble-gum flavored shaved ice in the sand; to shop for street clothes made of neoprene (wetsuit material), or to study the latest slang with two girls named Cammie and Tyler, in Hermosa Beach:

title: Alternate School's Future Debated
description: PARENTS and educators at the new Waterfront School in Sag Harbor are more determined than ever to insure the continuation of their school, despite opposition from village leaders that has had them ''jumping through hoops,'' they say.

title: Value Hounds In Hot Pursuit
description: NO ANALYST FOLLOWS THE stock. It pays a measly dividend. You practically have to make an appointment to buy it. You cannot check its price in the newspaper; you have to call a broker. Last month, it was quoted at $14,000 bid, $15,000 asked.

title:
Body and Mind;
Homosexuality: Who and Why?
description: LEAD: IN THE BAD OLD DAYS, WHEN homosexuality was considered a mental illness, a friend of mine was trying to go straight. He was seeing a distinguished psychoanalyst who believed (and still believes) that what some call a life style and still others call a crime is a psychiatrically treatable disorder.

title: INVESTING
description: After two dismal years, biotechnology stocks appear to be on the rebound. At the same time that the shares of these emerging companies are showing strength, the stocks of several large, well-established drug companies also have been outpacing the overall market.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-18

title: Discipline Has Its Limits
description: THERE, IN THE BACK CORNER of the New York Stock Exchange trading floor, an area called ''The Garage,'' stood Italy's automotive king - silver-haired Giovanni Agnelli. At 67 years of age, he ranks as one of the wealthiest industrialists in the world. The market value of his family's stake in Fiat S.p.A. totals some $1.26 billion. His vast empire encompasses automobiles and tractors, railway systems and newspapers. Agnelli had hauled himself all the way to New York to take part in ceremonies attendant to the listing of Fiat on the Big Board, a bid for direct access to the American financial markets.

title: BLACKENED RED DIRT AND OTHER DELICACIES
description: NOW, WHERE WERE WE? By Roy Blount Jr. 252 pp. New York: Villard Books. $17.95.

title: Brennan's Advice on Illness
description: Three students at the George Washington University Law School invited Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court to lunch the other day and were pleasantly surprised when he accepted.

title: Little Rain in Forecast Brings Lots of Worry
description: PREDICTIONS of a three-month dry spell, following the driest winter in 85 years, have Connecticut water officials worried about whether supplies will be adequate this summer.

title: Prospects; As the Economy Cools
description: For more than a year, interest rates have been rising. The prime rate is now 11.5 percent, 2 1/2 percentage points above its January 1988 level. The Federal Reserve Board has raised its rates as well in an effort to combat inflation. The Federal Funds rate - now at 9.83 percent - is more than three points higher than a year ago. Are these higher rates beginning to slow the economy? Four experts give their views. Joseph W. Duncan Chief economist, Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.

title: UNDER THE ROCK
description: NIGHT TIME LOSING TIME By Michael Ventura. 423 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Star Island Developers Seek To Restore Its Glory Days
description: LEAD: WHEN Star Island, now a 60-acre peninsula, was developed in the 1920's, it was said to be the jewel in the crown of Carl Fisher, the man responsible for trying to make Montauk the Miami Beach of the North.

title: A LIFE IN LIMBO
description: LEAD: MY FIRST REACTION WAS A QUIET NUMBNESS - A sort of dreamy, detached feeling that the doctor was talking about somebody else. I managed to respond. In fact, as I recall, I was fairly lucid. Yet, even now - two years later - I am only beginning to realize what it meant when my hematologist said, ''Peter, your test came back positive.

title: Greene's Spirit Won't Let Pirates Die
description: With 8 minutes 54 seconds left in the first half, Seton Hall, the designated Cinderella team of the Final Four this year, watched in horror as Duke began to strip its carriage.

title:
RECORDINGS;
A Label With Its Feet Firmly on Two Sides
description: LEAD: In this age of increasing specialization, it is rare to find a recording firm that deliberately blurs boundaries. Nonesuch and ECM come to mind, but the majority of the major labels seem locked in their market niches, convinced that an audience for one type of music is unlikely to be interested in another.

title: PRAVDA CONCEDES YELTSIN'S APPEAL
description: In some searching questions about what went wrong for the Communist Party in the national elections, Pravda today grudgingly conceded that Boris N. Yeltsin's power reached beyond the party to the people.

title: No Olympic Bid By Lake Placid
description: The Lake Placid Bid Committee has unanimously decided not to make the Adirondack Mountain resort a candidate for the 1998 Winter Olympics, officials said this week.

title: Closely Observed in Burma
description: THE official Tourist Burma guide, embarrassed, looked anxiously around the bus in Taunggyi, 100 miles from Mandalay. ''For your safety,'' she said quietly, ''I ask that you not leave the hotel. If you do try to leave the hotel, I think they won't let you.''

title: Leverett Edwards, Labor Mediator, Is Dead at 87
description: Leverett Edwards, a labor relations expert who for many years helped avert or settle national railway and airline strikes, died yesterday at Harris Hospital in Fort Worth after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived in Fort Worth and Oklahoma City.

title: What Olympics Are Really About
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: England's Realm Of Cider With a Kick
description: I WAS brought up in the west of England, on the Devon and Somerset border in the heart of English cider-making country. Boyhood memories include disappointment with the bitter taste of the cider apples that grow so abundantly there but fascination at the sight of an old screw press squeezing cloudy juice from a mush of apple pulp in a dark farm shed.

title: For Students, Dance Is Part of Life
description: LEAD: BREATHLESS and perspiring after completing a spirited number from ''Pippin,'' the dozen students at Plainedge High School gathered around Ellie Gordon, their taskmaster, for some quiet conversation.

title: FASHION: On the Street; A Rainbow of Raincoats
description: Rainy weather creates its own fashions - not all of them practical, but most of them fun. The drought notwithstanding, April should bring enough water to soak people if not the ground.

title: PATRICK IS A MAN
description: DIFFICULTIES WITH GIRLS By Kingsley Amis. 276 pp. New York: Summit Books.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Signings by Chargers

title: New & Noteworthy
description: UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK: The Life Story of Christopher Nolan, by Christopher Nolan. (Delta, $7.95.) Paralyzed and unable to speak from birth, a young Irish poet tells how he escaped his crippled body by learning to flex the muscles of his very able mind. ''His stylistic hallmark has been a linguistic virtuosity that, at its best, is heady and acrobatic,'' our reviewer, Patricia Hampl, said last year. ''His prose has moxie, though it rushes and stumbles from a pent-up surge.'' FREAKY DEAKY, by Elmore Leonard. (Warner, $5.95.) After serving time for bombing a Federal building, Robin Abbott joins with her fellow veterans of the 1960's to take revenge on the man they believe was the snitch. ''What a master criminal Mr. Leonard would make if he got tired of writing thrillers and changed professions,'' Cyra McFadden said in The Book Review last year. ''The plot of 'Freaky Deaky' races along, constantly changing course and doubling back on itself, like a cunning fox in front of the hounds.'' Mr. Leonard is also getting pretty savvy about marketing. This paperback includes the first chapter of his next novel, ''Killshot.'' PRIME TIMES, BAD TIMES, by Ed Joyce. (Anchor/ Doubleday, $9.95.)
