By the time he was dismissed as president of CBS News in 1986, Ed Joyce had learned to his dismay that television journalism was ''just another business.'' He was also tired of putting up with Dan Rather. ''What he shows us is hypocrisy, paranoia and ego,'' Herbert Dorfman said here last year. ''It is real-life stuff like this that makes movies like 'Broadcast News' seem pale and unimportant.'' DOUBLE WHAMMY, by Carl Hiaasen. (Warner, $4.95.) A hermit who used to be the Governor of Georgia teams up with a detective who doubles as a bass fisherman. ''The writing style is macabre-funny and it delivers the plot's myriad twists and turns with breathtaking speed,'' Walter Walker said here last year. ''All that Mr. Hiaasen requires in exchange for a thoroughly good time is a little suspension of disbelief.'' OTHERWORLD JOURNEYS: Accounts of Near-Death Experience in Medieval and Modern Times, by Carol Zaleski. (Oxford University, $8.95.) Over the centuries, people who claim to have glimpsed the afterlife have surfaced from their experiences with remarkably similar tales. This ''is not a book for occultists and Carol Zaleski is not a parapsychologist,'' Richard A. Shweder said here in 1987. He called it ''a sophisticated post-modern, hence nonphilosophical, book about that timeless philosophical problem'' of ''how to explain mental objects (for example, a vision of heaven or an encounter with a leprechaun).'' SHAKEDOWN, by Gerald Petievich (Pocket Books, $4.50.) After his best informer is killed by a car bomb, an F.B.I. agent named John Novak must find a new way to infiltrate the Las Vegas mafia. The novel is ''exciting, tough and gritty, superbly written with never a false note either in style or in characterization,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. ''It is as good as they come.'' 1999: Victory Without War, by Richard Nixon. (Pocket Books, $8.95.) In a world plagued by ''superdoves'' and ''superhawks,'' the prolific ex-President calls for moderation, warning that Star Wars and the quest for nuclear superiority are as impossible as total disarmament. Written for a mass audience, the book could make ''an important contribution to the maturation of American foreign policy,'' Marshall D. Shulman said here last year. STORIES: Five Acre Virgin and The Travelling Entertainer, by Elizabeth Jolley. (Penguin, $7.95.) In these short stories, Elizabeth Jolley continues her tales of underdogs and eccentrics in Australia. ''A large part of Ms. Jolley's charm is her style, which is conversational, a bit faux naive, but as sharp and clear as a primitive painting,'' Robert Plunket said in The Book Review last year. HOLLYWOOD DOESN'T LIVE HERE ANYMORE, by Robert Parrish. (Little, Brown, $9.95.) In this sequel to ''Growing Up in Hollywood,'' the director Robert Parrish tells about his encounters with Hemingway in Spain. ''With his wry, relaxed style and ingenuously self-deprecating point of view, [ he ] has once again written a much better book than the many Hollywood memoirists whose names are more familiar,'' Ed Sikov said here last year. PRIVILEGED LIVES, by Edward Stewart. (Dell, $4.95.) What does a Manhattan socialite who has just emerged from a seven-year coma have in common with the victim of a kinky ritual murder? In following these converging trails, Edward Stewart has written a mystery that is ''readable and provocative, and can arouse sympathy for the few redeemable characters that are drawn here,'' our reviewer, Bert Atkinson, said last year. MODERNISM AND THE HARLEM RENAISSANCE, by Houston A. Baker Jr. (University of Chicago, $9.95.) Modernism is not the invention of white people alone, the author writes; there is an Afro-American version of the movement with roots in the Harlem Renaissance. This book's tone and style are academic, Tonya Bolden Davis said here in 1987, but that ''does not diminish the saliency of Mr. Baker's ideas.'' THE BRIDE WHO RAN AWAY, by Diana O'Hehir. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $6.95.) Instead of going through with marriage to her irritating older cousin, Grace Dowell flees her small northern California town for the seedy life of Reno. Diana O'Hehir ''writes with tenderness and lucidity about the end of adolescent innocence,'' Marcelle Thiebaux said here last year.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Joseph Grau; 'Productivity and Creativity Will Increase'
description: JOSEPH GRAU, a professor of religious studies at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, says that in the business world, religious ethics should be as important as profits.

title: Reeling From a Wave of Anti-Gun Sentiment
description: The recent ban on imported semiautomatic assault rifles is only the latest blow to American gun manufacturers. Demand for their revolvers, rifles and shotguns failed to rebound after the recession of the early 1980's.

title: Review/Theater; An Acting Equation: 2 Equals 6 (or7)
description: Two actors search out the vanity, rascality, self-delusion and sheer lunacy of six characters in Luis Rafael Sanchez's ''Quintuplets.'' And in the production at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, the actors, Ivonne Coll and Roberto Medina, do create the illusion that they are six people. In fact, a seventh pops up briefly in one scene.

title: U.S. Experts Ponder Approach to Changes in the Eastern Bloc
description: American experts on Eastern Europe are in broad agreement that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's quest for modernization and his calls for change have paradoxically increased the potential for destabilization across the Eastern bloc.

title: World Upside Down
description: Try to imagine the United States if Americans came to question the premise of our political society - the legitimacy of the Constitution and all the history built upon it. By some such analogy we may begin to appreciate the extraordinary character of what is happening now in the Soviet Union.

title: President's Brother Is Promoting a Giuliani-Lauder Alliance
description: Jonathan Bush, a leading New York Republican and the President's brother, is promoting an alliance between Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ronald S. Lauder to head off a potentially damaging Republican mayoral primary.

title: Sheila A. Archer Weds Edward Bugniazet 3d
description: The marriage of Sheila A. Archer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Archer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., to Edward A. Bugniazet 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bugniazet Jr. of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye. Msgr. John J. Barry performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Hungarian Writer Taps Universal Ideas
description: ''THIS is the most important year of my life,'' Miklos Vamos said. To illustrate what makes it so, the 39-year-old Hungarian writer cited the lectures he has been giving on Eastern European culture and the classes he has been auditing on subjects ranging from dramaturgy to fencing, during the current academic year that he is spending at the Yale School of Drama on a Fulbright Fellowship.

title: R. B. Featherman 3d Weds Linda Longley
description: Linda Elizabeth Longley and Raymond Baker Featherman 3d weremarried yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., by the Rev. Frederick T. Bender.

title: Hanoi Chief Assails Obstacles to 'Renovation'
description: The leader of Vietnam's Communist Party has warned that despite encouraging initial economic results in the first two years of the country's ''renovation,'' there remain ''major difficulties'' including inflation and resistance to change from ''a bureaucratic overcentralized system built over many years.''

title: INVISIBLE IN THE FOREGROUND
description: THE IMAGE OF THE BLACK IN WESTERN ART Volume Four: From the American Revolution to World War I. Part One. Slaves and Liberators. 379 pp. Part Two. Black Models and White Myths. 306 pp. By Hugh Honour. Cambridge, Mass.: Menil Foundation/ Harvard University Press. $50 each.

title: Gary Mandelblatt Marries Lisa Wallach, Law Student
description: Lisa Hope Wallach, a third-year law student at Fordham University, and Gary H. Mandelblatt, a consultant with the First Manhattan Consulting Group, were married last evening at the Shackamaxon Country Club in Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein officiated.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Palmer, Mass.;
Mall Welcome, But Not Traffic
description: LEAD: FOR 39 years, Emily Griswold looked from the living room of her modest Cape Cod house here onto an open field. But since October, when a developer bought three and a half acres on Route 20 for $500,000, the view has been changing with the construction of a 27,500-square-foot shopping mall.

title: Recantation II
description: The tangled web that has ensnared the Texas A&M football program has picked up a new tangle.

title: Coach Leads a School Without a Gym to Basketball Glory
description: THE message scrawled on a blackboard in the locker room at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena was simple, yet symbolic. It characterized the St. Anthony High School basketball team and their coach, Bob Hurley. Minutes before the title game against Elizabeth High School in the Tournament of Champions two weeks ago, Mr. Hurley offered his Jersey City team the same statement and same question he posed before every contest.

title: About Men; The Boy in the Photograph
description: THE FATHER WAS SO kempt and so practical. In the cold Michigan winters, for example, he wore spats - those encasements for the ankle considered sportif in warmer climes - not for show but for one overriding purpose: to keep his ankles and feet warm.

title:
TO START WITH...;
'Better Never Than Late'
description: LEAD: SOMEWHERE IN A corporate conference room, a sales manager is pointing at the list of marketing ideas on his blackboard and saying, ''Read my tips.'' In a convention hall, a C.E.O. is proclaiming that ''A new breeze is blowing in our industry.'' These Presidential takeoffs might once have tickled the ribs, but now, according to the man who wrote them, they are as stale as yesterday's news.

title: Mary Craig Wed in Florida
description: Mary Elizabeth Craig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Alexander Craig Jr. of Lake Wales, Fla., was married there yesterday to Andrew Biddle Parkinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dexter Parkinson of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The Rev. Harold Warren performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. R. Stanley Sheffer, in the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: A City's Unwelcome Lesson About Schools and Class
description: PUBLIC education officials in cities across the country ponder the problems of keeping middle-class pupils in school systems whose quality invariably spirals downward as the affluent withdraw. But perhaps nowhere right now are the complex issues presented in crisper microcosm than at the new South Loop Elementary School here.

title: Dede Brooks Makes Her Bid
description: THE CURTAINS PARTED. THERE ON the stage of Sotheby's auction salesroom on Manhattan's Upper East Side, where van Goghs and ancient Greek sculptures are the typical items on display, was a pyramid of cookie jars: pigs and bears, a Humpty Dumpty, a plump panda.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CATHEDRAL MUSIC In a yearlong survey, the music program at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City has traced the history of Anglican cathedral music from pre-Reformation days to the present. Today, the cathedral, the seat of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, begins a four-day program appropriately entitled ''Festival of Anglican Cathedral Music.''

title: Suzanne Millard Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. Millard of Southport, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Marie Millard to Robert Kevin Stanners, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Stanners of Stuart, Fla., and Old Saybrook, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a gallery exhibition of Easter eggs omitted the name of the artist. She is Jane Pollak.

title: John M. Hefton, Skin-Graft Researcher, 50
description: Dr. John M. Hefton, a biomedical researcher whose work in skin grafting led to new techniques for treating burn victims, died of AIDS Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A MEGAMUSEUM IN A MILL TOWN
description: Deborah Weisgall's article presented Tom Krens's discussion of museums in business terms as a novelty. Such a critique of the art world and its institutions has been a subject for artists over the last two decades. ANDREA KIRSH Miami

title: Transfer Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Lost in the Bohemian Fog
description: Jazz music and film have rarely been spun together more evocatively than in ''Let's Get Lost,'' Bruce Weber's documentary biography of the late jazz trumpeter and singer Chet Baker.

title: Companies Discovering Many Values In Artworks LBy ANDREW L. YARROW
description: IF the Medicis were alive today, these great Renaissance patrons of the arts might well inhabit sleek suburban bank buildings and sprawling corporate campuses. Although corporate support for all arts has grown in recent decades, increasing numbers of companies are now aggressively collecting paintings and sculptures to adorn their office buildings and fill corporate galleries.

title: Reissue Bubble Is Still Aloft
description: Recent months have been an especially bad time for record collectors with large LP libraries. The burning issue facing them has been: to duplicate or not to duplicate many favorites on compact disks, or to spend money on new recordings or on reissues of old recordings.

title: REMADE IN AMERICA
description: NEW AMERICANS An Oral History. Immigrants and Refugees in the U.S. Today. By Al Santoli. Illustrated. 392 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Studying Oil Spill's Damage to Wildlife, Scientists Hope to Salvage Lessons
description: The battle against an oily shroud engulfing wildlife along Alaska's southern coast has been lost, and as the casualties rapidly mount, scientists hope at least to salvage some lessons from the disaster.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
'Tax-Exempts' Growing in Existing Space
description: LEAD: THE four major institutions of higher learning in Newark's University Heights section are undertaking ambitious expansion programs that, over the next five years, will add more than 2 million square feet of new academic space - from dormitories to research laboratories - about 4,500 new parking spaces for cars and even rentable space that can bring the schools revenue and add to the city's tax rolls.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Hudson County Jail in New Jersey incorrectly described investigations into conditions at the jail. The county prosecutor's office has ended its inquiry into the beating death of an inmate in March and charged two guards and a deputy warden with murder. The United States Attorney's office in Newark, assisted by the F.B.I., is investigating other allegations of brutality.

title: PERSPECTIVES: After Mount Laurel; Reshaping New Jersey Housing Patterns
description: LITTLE by little, as the towns in growth areas of central New Jersey adopt housing plans that provide for ''affordable'' housing needs, statewide patterns of future residential development are taking shape.

title: The Return of God
description: To the Editor:

title: From Paris, Algerian Pop
description: It has a solid beat, catchy lines for keyboard and guitar, and singers who bend and stretch notes as if their lives depended on it. It also has lyrics in Arabic and melodies halfway between Middle Eastern traditional songs and rock. Rai (Arabic for ''opinion''), the music of the port of Oran in western Algeria, is one more East-meets-West, ancient-meets-modern pop style, and it's now making its way to American ears by way of Paris and its sizable Algerian population.

title: Inkster Leads Dinah Shore by 5 Strokes
description: Winds blew up to 25 miles an hour today and took most scores up with them in the third round of the 18th annual Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament so that Juli Inkster was able to increase her lead from four to five shots despite shooting one-over-par 73 on the Mission Hills Old Course.

title: On Using a Portable Circular Saw
description: PORTABLE circular saws are among the most popular and labor-saving power tools. Many owners, however, find the tools awkward to use and fraught with potential danger. Choosing the right saw for your needs, and learning how to operate it correctly, can minimize hazards and make using the tool easier.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT'S a dry snow falling, mounting inch by feather-puff inch, beneath the feeders at New Jersey Audubon's Scherman Sanctuary. The woods are filling up nicely, and, like the horse and driver in Frost's poem, I'm taking some time to watch.

title: ANATOMY OF A Sitcom
description: OUT OF THOUSANDS OF SITUATION COMEDIES PITCHED in Hollywood each television season, few succeed. This year, there are three new hits: ''Roseanne,'' large, noisy, the tabloid of sitcoms; ''Empty Nest,'' full of lunatic, cheery farce; and an unusual winner, a quiet, downbeat comedy with an impeccable pedigree, ''Dear John.''

title: NONFICTION
description: CHILDREN OF THE SIEGE. By Pauline Cutting. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Most of what we know about the Beirut crisis comes from bewildering, often conflicting news accounts of skirmishes, cease-fires and shifting alliances. It is almost impossible to comprehend the changing motives of those involved, much less what it is like to live within the crumbling buildings and refugee camps of West Beirut. Pauline Cutting, a British surgeon, gives a clearly written report of life amid this chaos in ''Children of the Siege,'' a chronicle of her 18-month sojourn in the Palestinian camp of Burj al Brajneh. As resident surgeon, Dr. Cutting was quickly accepted by the Palestinians. She describes the cohesiveness within the camps in a city where disputes over a street or a building can incite weeks of fighting. When the camp was besieged by Shiite militiamen, Dr. Cutting, trained primarily in plastic surgery, quickly learned to mend shrapnel and bullet wounds. Faced with shortages of medical supplies and workers, she was forced to make agonizing decisions - which patient was to live, which to die. Finally the hospital itself was attacked. Shortages of water and food led to near starvation, and inhabitants were forced to eat weeds, grass, rats. After months of isolation, it became apparent that the Shiites would not cease their blockade of supplies. It was Dr. Cutting who, in early 1987, dared to alert the world to conditions in the camp. ''Children of the Siege'' is a frightening and inspiring account of the hour-by-hour struggle of life in a war zone.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: It came as no surprise to my husband and me that foreign countries trying to aid the stricken Armenians were frustrated by the slowness of the Soviet bureaucracy. On a visit to the Soviet Union last August, we welcomed the friendliness of the people and the freedom to go off on our own, but we also found that Intourist still told us where to sleep, in which restaurant in the giant Cosmos Hotel in Moscow we could eat and what sights to see.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Carnegie-Mellon; A Tradition Ends: Party Falls Victim To a Liquor Law
description: Since 1915, Carnegie-Mellon University students have gotten together every four years for an all-night, all-out costume party called the beaux-arts ball. Until this year. The ball, this 89-year-old college's longest tradition, was canceled a couple of weeks ago by the students who were trying to organize it after selling just 14 tickets. The decision ended a six-month fight between students and administrators, which has included a demonstration, a student government resolution and two other aborted attempts to hold the ball.

title: TALKING: Co-op Leases; Commercial Caveats For Boards
description: WHEN many of New York City's apartment buildings became cooperatives a decade or so ago, those with retail spaces normally inherited leases put in place by the sponsor. Many are now expiring and dozens of boards are grappling for the first time with the complex world of commercial leasing.

title: When Winning Isn't Everything
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: More Waste Dumps Are Placed On List For Federal Cleanup
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has added 101 sites in 33 states to its list of hazardous waste dumps that pose the greatest long-term threat to public health and the environment.

title: Headliners; It's Off to Court We Go
description: At the Academy Awards cermony last week, Snow White, portrayed by Eileen Bowman, followed a chorus line of dancing stars to the stage and in a Betty Boop voice sang popular songs rewritten with Oscar-oriented lyrics. Most critics panned the number. The Walt Disney Company did more. It filed a trademark infringement suit against the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, contending the performance was an unflattering and unauthorized portrayal of the character from the 1937 movie, ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.'' Academy officials declined comment. Said a Disney spokesman, ''The American public saw Snow White portrayed as she never is portrayed in our parks.''

title: Facts and Policy On Police Guns
description: The article on the status of police handguns and the increasing trend to convert to the 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol [ ''Police Turning to 9-mm. Guns to Fight Crime,'' March 12 ] educated the public. Purported decrease in jamming of that 9-millimeter (.354-inch) gun is key.

title: Norwegian Nibbles
description: To the Editor:

title: Splendid Isolation In the Azores
description: THE Azores are a tangle of myths, a tableau vivant of intersecting stories of creation and destruction. Tales of the lost remains of Atlantis, sea monsters attacking fishing towns, rich kingdoms destroyed by volcanic fire - these are some of the stories repeated by young and old alike. These nine Atlantic islands two-thirds of the way from New York to Lisbon were uninhabited by man or animal, lingering in the aftermath of volcanic flux, when the Portuguese colonized them in the 15th century.

title: 9 Held in Protest Near Tompkins Square Park
description: Nine people were arrested yesterday during a demonstration by about 50 people near Tompkins Square Park over the demolition of a nearby apartment building occupied by squatters.

title: Review Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Khomeini Purifies, and Confuses, Iran's Future
description: IN dismissing Iran's first President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, in May 1981, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said that the Prophet Mohammed would have severed the hand of his own son or daughter had either of them been guilty of a crime. Likewise, he warned, ''the day I feel danger to the Islamic Republic, I will cut everybody's hand off.''

title: Question Of the Week; How Will The Yanks And Mets Do in 1989?
description: The Yankees could be in for a long season. The team lacks major league talent at two vital positions: shortstop and centerfield. The catching corps is a defensive liability and the pitching staff boasts no proven winners, save for a 45-year-old superman named T. J. Back in Metland, a modern-day dynasty is in full swing. The pitching is awesome, and the offense, led by Darryl Strawberry, is one of baseball's best. It would take a handful of major injuries and tremendous underachieving for the Mets to finish anywhere but first in the National League East. KOSTYA KENNEDY Great Neck, L.I.

title: Flexibility and Concern
description: Percentage of Israel's Jewish population

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Dumont $215,000 80 East Linden Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old split level; double driveway, w/wall carpeting; close to schools and transportation; taxes $3,702. East Windsor $175,000 8 Wickhame Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old ranch; new kitchen, deck, hardwood floors; taxes $3,105. Franklin Township $112,000 63 Taylor Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old town-house condominium; den, eat-in kitchen, skylights; monthly charges $130, taxes $1,658. Keansburg $175,000 56 Willis Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old colonial; central vacuum, Jacuzzi, landscaping; taxes $3,400. Morris Plains $366,480 159 Sun Valley Way 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, dining room; taxes $5,732. Parsippany $187,500 130 Arthur Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; full basement, eat-in kitchen, c/a; taxes $2,296. OTHER AREAS Harrison, N.Y. $695,000 7 Bates Road 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 62-year-old brick/slate Tudor; fireplace, den, large eat-in kitchen, family room with wet bar and flagstone floor, enclosed porch; taxes $5,773. Torrington, Conn. $155,000 133 Belmont Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, patio; 100- by 161-ft. lot; taxes, $1,339. Bayville, L.I. $209,000 94 Mountain Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 75-year-old colonial; porch, new windows, 1-car garage; taxes $1,650.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Queens College; What Social Life? Commuter School Offers Some Fun
description: Mention Queens College, and you might get these responses: fine faculty, lovely campus, some excellent departments and the Colden Center for the Performing Arts.

title: It Was A Very Good Year (Revisited)
description: TOM POSTILIO is doing it his way. Nineteen years old and dressed in the black tuxedo he owns, not rents, Tom saunters to the microphone in front of the 20-piece Hal Hoffman Orchestra. The dinner-dancers at Embassy East in Franklin Square put down their forks. ''The kid'' is going to sing. ''When somebody loves youuuuu, it's no good unless he loves youuuuu, alllllll the wayyyyy.'' Tom Postilio opens his mouth and out comes Frank Sinatra. Not just Frank Sinatra's song, but Frank Sinatra's voice. Young Tom Postilio sounds incredibly like Frank Sinatra.

title: Windsong Was on His Mind
description: THE BREEZE CARESS-es a wind chime. Near the French doors, a man stands framed by billowing curtains. Cut to a woman, spraying on perfume. Cut to the man and woman together, kissing. Back to the man, alone, dreamily inhaling the scent of his beloved's letter. He looks out, and there she is - in a car below. Smiles all around. Cut to a bottle of Prince Matchabelli's Windsong perfume. In the background, romantic music and a whispered message: ''I can't seem to forget you. Your Windsong stays on my mind.''

title: Darpa's Downside
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrong Architect?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cloud Darkens Opening Day
description: Confronted with the ominous overtones of the Pete Rose investigation and with memories of other off-season, off-field events still fresh in mind, A. Bartlett Giamatti became commissioner of baseball yesterday and prepared to oversee the start of a new season tomorrow. He did not walk into office waving a magic wand to make all of the undesirable events disappear from view and thought.

title: Mommy Track's an Idea Whose Time Has Gone; Highest Quality Results
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LAS VEGAS;
Pace Picks Up At Sun City 4
description: LEAD: THE first residents began moving into one of Nevada's largest housing developments this month and construction is now accelerating at the complex, called Sun City Summerlin. It is the fourth community for retirees to be created by the Del E. Webb Corporation.

title: LARGEST FINE YET FOR TRADE SCHOOL
description: Acting to crack down on deceitful advertising and sham instruction by trade schools, the New York State Education Department has imposed its largest fine yet on such a school and proposed a law that would significantly strengthen a student's right to get a refund on tuition.

title: Transfer of Remaining Oil From Tanker Moves Slowly
description: Hundreds of thousands of barrels of crude oil are still aboard the grounded tanker Exxon Valdez, and efforts to pump it into smaller ships are being hampered by frequent mechanical breakdowns, broken hoses and other mishaps, state officials said today.

title: Ms. de Marneffe Planning to Wed Martin Trimble
description: Mrs. Anthony Ferranti of Arlington, Mass., and Dr. Francis de Marneffe of Cambridge, Mass., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Colette de Marneffe, and Martin Paul Trimble, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. James A. Trimble of Philadelphia.

title: Escaping Mexico City By Railroad
description: LEAD: THE CONSTITUCIONALISTA is almost everything one never expected to find in the way of long straight metal-borne journeying in Mexico - or anywhere else in middle or South America for that matter. On a good day the Constitucionalista, one of several trains in Mexico that offers upgraded service, covers the 200 miles between Mexico City and San Miguel de Allende in little more than four and a half hours.

title: But How Will It Play in Prague?
description: When the Orion Pictures Corporation was founded 11 years ago, its management let it be known that the company intended to produce quality films. Despite some dry financial periods, it has usually done just that, priding itself on the release of such critically praised movies as ''Bull Durham,'' ''Mississippi Burning'' and ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' in the last year alone.

title: Perjury Trial Starts for Figure in Brawley Case
description: Samuel M. McClease, who added a bizarre twist to an already tangled situation last summer with claims that he had secretly recorded Tawana Brawley's advisers, went on trial last week on charges of perjury.

title: Anglers Throw Out the First Hooks
description: Leaden skies, a spit of snow and water temperatures in the high 30's greeted the scores of anglers who journeyed here to celebrate the opening of the state's trout season today on the Catskills' hallowed Beaverkill and Willowemoc rivers.

title: The Story Of Baseball: You Can Go Home Again
description: If baseball is a narrative, it is like others - a work of imagination whose deeper structures and patterns of repetition force a tale, oft-told, to fresh and hither-to-unforeseen meaning. But what is the nature of the tale oft-told that recommences with every pitch, with every game, with every season? That patiently accrues its tension and new meaning with every iteration? It is the story we have hinted at already, the story of going home after having left home; the story of how difficult it is to find the origins one so deeply needs to find. It is the literary mode called Romance.

title: How Court Opens Door for Wide Drug Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Schneider Becomes a Bride
description: Nancy Jill Schneider, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Schneider of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married last evening at the Woodmere (L.I.) Club to Lawrence Allen Marcus, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hershey Marcus of Woodmere. Rabbi Stanley Platek performed the ceremony.

title: Fiscally Battered Blue Cross Fights to Remain Top Insurer
description: Battered by the explosive growth in spending for medical care, the giant Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association is struggling to maintain its role as the nation's largest health insurer.

title: Priest Picked for Library Post Responds to Critics
description: Since February, when the Rev. Timothy S. Healy was chosen to succeed Dr. Vartan Gregorian as president of the New York Public Library, a form of low-intensity intellectual warfare has been waged over the appointment.

title: 'Cinderella' Is a Story, Not Real Life
description: ''ARE all stepmothers mean?'' 8-year-old Jenny asked her mother. ''What makes you think that?'' ''Well, my friend Rosanne's stepmother is a real witch. And last year, there was a girl in my class who complained that all her stepmother ever did was yell at her. She got blamed for everything, just like Cinderella. Her stepmother once accused her of breaking her favorite vase and didn't believe her when she denied it. And then, when she found out that her own daughter Mary did it, she wasn't half as mad.''

title:
FOCUS: LOS ANGELES;
In Watts, Signs of a Long-Awaited Renaissance
description: LEAD: Twenty-four years after the flames of rioting made Watts a national symbol of inner-city frustration and decay, the district is beginning to attract new, and more welcome, attention. Developers, bankers and real estate agents, long put off by the area's reputation for poverty and crime, now see potential for profit.

title: Soviet Presence
description: Sergei Priakin, the first Soviet player to join a National Hockey League team with the blessing of Soviet authorities, was a busy man Friday night.

title: Help Wanted, But Certainly Not Today
description: AT 50, I'm waiting for the phone to ring and someone on the other end to say mine's the greatest resume he ever saw and is he glad someone with my background wrote and am I free for lunch. What I get are letters that thank me anyway and good luck with all those great qualifications, but, alas, they weren't quite right for the position.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will The Yanks And Mets Do in 1989?
description: Aug. 15 - Mired in the cellar of the American League East, the Yankees make the move that has been rumored since their Opening Day loss to Minnesota. Dallas Green is out as manager, replaced by none other than Billy Martin.

title: NEW ENGLAND FANCY
description: We New Englanders have always taken a measure of pride in a reputation for straightforward, no-nonsense attitudes. Here, plain talk, like plain food, is an almost certain route to virtue.

title: Anne E. Bertram And Peter Endler Marry in Florida
description: The marriage of Anne Elizabeth Bertram to Peter Thayer Endler took place yesterday at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Coconut Grove, Fla. The Rev. John Phillips performed the ceremony.

title: Hospitals Warn Legislators
description: REPRESENTATIVES of the region's hospitals came together in White Plains last week to warn a state legislative committee that the crisis in health care was getting worse and that the community-hospital system was ''crumbling.''

title: Eighth Body Is Discovered On Massachusetts Highway
description: Another body has been found along a highway here, the eighth discovered since July. The authorities are urging the person who wrote a letter about the latest victim to come forward.

title: Review/Dance; A Curiosity Shop Of Sound and Motion
description: Festivals, by definition, ought to be special events. But on Wednesday night at the Horace Mann Theater, Festival Showcase II only intermittently looked special. As a result, this program - a presentation of the Morningside Dance Festival of Columbia University Teachers College - was a showcase that had far too many trinkets on display.

title: Three New Hotels to Rise in the County
description: WHEN Yonkers gets its first luxury hotel, it will ''change the business community's image'' of the state's fourth-largest city, said John R. Zakian, executive director of the Yonkers Industrial Development Agency.

title: 'Today,' After That Infamous Memo
description: When Willard Scott planted a kiss on Bryant Gumbel's cheek at the start of NBC's ''Today'' show one morning last month, viewers may have detected a resemblance to the Godfather's tribute to No. 1 on his hit list. This unspontaneous smooch came at the reunion of the two stars of ''Today'' after the disclosure that Mr. Gumbel had written a confidential memo, at the behest of the show's executive producer, criticizing Mr. Scott and several other colleagues.

title: Pianist Is a Guide to the Landmarks of Music Composition
description: ''WE hear all our lives but we don't listen,'' said the pianist and teacher Edith Cornfield. In the sphere of music - particularly classical music - ''passivity'' limits our enjoyment, Mrs. Cornfield said. Music for many serves simply as a background, a pleasant but superficial flow of sound whose distinguishing features are lost in the stream.

title: Galveston
description: To the Editor: Mary Gardner missed the mark on where to eat in Galveston, Tex. (Travel, Feb. 19). In all the years I have lived in Texas, never have I taken an out-of-town visitor to Galveston for bistro food. We can get trendy cuisine at any number of Houston or Dallas eateries. The Galveston Bay area is well known for fresh seafood from the Gulf of Mexico. There are many fine seafood establishments, but none can top Gaido's, 3828 Seawall Boulevard (409-762-9625). Both the food and the service are first rate, and for my money it is the place to eat in Galveston. GRETCHEN LINDQUIST The Woodlands, Tex.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: ABOUT THIS PAGE
description: Home Entertainment/ Recordings will appear biweekly, alternating in this space with Home Entertainment/ Video.

title: Debra L. Lamberg Marries
description: At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., Debra Lynn Lamberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lamberg of Bellmore, L.I., was married last evening to Robert Schmertz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Schmertz of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster officiated. The bride, a credit analyst with the Empire of America savings bank in New York, is a graduate of the University of Maryland. The bridegroom, a sales representative in the shoe division at Esprit de Corp, an apparel company in New York, received a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in business administration from George Washington University.

title: HOPING FOR SOMETHING WORSE
description: LEAD: GEEK LOVE By Katherine Dunn. 348 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: A MEGAMUSEUM IN A MILL TOWN
description: There are some points in Ms. Weisgall's article at which I take umbrage. For example, she describes North Adams as a poverty-stricken mill town featuring tenements on Mount Greylock, diners that do not serve brunch and a mayor in a green polyester blazer.

title: Sand Bars Threaten Shinnecock Bay
description: LEAD: SHINNECOCK Bay, the only viable deep-water port for commercial fishing vessels between Nassau County and Montauk Point, is being threatened with extinction because Shinnecock Inlet, its access to the sea, has become filled with shoaling sand bars.

title: Votive Figures
description: To the Editor: Louis Inturrisi spotlights Rome (''Votive Figures for Collectors,'' Travel, Feb. 19) as a good place to find votive figures. I would like to add that for readers on a more northerly route, Munich - capital of Catholic Bavaria - is also a great source for them. While on vacation last fall, I spent a week in Munich and stumbled upon the silver votive figures at the Auer Dult, a tradtional fair and antique market held three times a year in the Mariahilfplatz. I also spotted them at the enormous Flohmarkt, held every Saturday off the Leonrodplatz.

title: Helping Boston Harbor: A Big Job Begins at Last
description: For as long as people have lived near Boston Harbor, it has been treated like a sewer. Residents say the harbor is so dirty that if you scooped up a cupful of water and poured it back in you would be breaking pollution laws.

title: Why Japan Would Rather Be No. 2
description: The March-April issue of the Harvard Business Review carried an article called ''Power Without Purpose: The Crisis of Japan's Global Financial Dominance'' by R. Taggart Murphy, managing director of Japan private placements, at Chase Manhattan Asia Limited, in Tokyo. In the article - which Mr. Murphy says reflects his views and not necessarily those of Chase - he contends that although Japan is now the world's dominant financial power, it has been reluctant to assume the role of the world's financial leader.

title: New Allies In the Drug War
description: There has been a dramatic shift of perspective on the drug plague among leaders of other nations in the Western Hemisphere. This is vitally important for the U.S., if we know how to use it.

title: Tallis Scholars to Sing
description: The Tallis Scholars, an English early vocal ensemble, is to perform at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, 1 West 53d Street, on Wednesday at 7:30 P.M. The program features several works by Josquin Desprez, including ''Missa L'Homme Arme Sexti Toni'' and ''Ave Maria'' and two works by Heinrich Isaac. Tickets are $15; $10 for students. Information: 757-7013.

title: The Giant With a Black Eye
description: Lawrence G. Rawl must find his current circumstances close to unbearable.

title: Once Again, the Allies Get Touchy About Bonn's Commitment
description: EVERY few weeks, it seems, something happens to raise a new round of nervous whispers about West Germany's enthusiasm for NATO. It may be that Bonn balks at upgrading one missile or another, or a new poll shows that Germans don't think the Russians are all that big a threat anymore, or Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher issues another sermon on the need to give the East greater sympathy and succor, or dovish Greens and xenophobic ultra-rightists unexpectedly make a splash in local elections.

title: Leslie Ann Charleson Marries G. W. Demms
description: Leslie Ann Charleson, a television actress, and G. William Demms, a businessman, were married yesterday at the United Church of Christ in Rowayton, Conn., by the Rev. John S. Livingston, assisted by the Rev. Pamela Demms Anderegg, a Methodist minister and the bridegroom's sister.

title: Wanted: Good Role Models
description: Throughout the city, in church basements and in the projects themselves, people here are fighting back against the violence that has consumed so many of Washington's young.

title: Motown's Magic
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan B. Kemm Wed in Carolina To J. D. Harrison
description: Susan Bischoff Kemm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst Watson Bischoff Kemm of High Point, N.C., was married there yesterday to John Dorward Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Mortimer Harrison Jr. of Durham, N.C. The ceremony at the Wesley Memorial United Methodist Church was performed by the Rev. Barry P. Osborne, assisted by the Rev. Charles T. Midyette 3d, an Episcopal priest. Mrs. Harrison was presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in New York and at the High Point Debutante Ball. She graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where her husband is an undergraduate student, and was until recently a marketing coordinator at the Interbrand Corporation, an originator of brand names in New York.

title: To Close Shortfall, Officials Say, Cuomo Must Find New Revenues
description: The Cuomo administration's announcement last week that New York State is facing an additional $150 million budget gap has made an agreement on a new state budget impossible without a significant source of new revenues, state legislative leaders said today.

title: Q and A
description: Iguassu Falls

title: Lee Haviland Stowell Wed to Anthony Mazza
description: Lee Haviland Stowell and Anthony Michael Mazza, social and youth workers for Clinton Community Services in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Sudbury (Mass.) United Methodist Church. The Rev. Gwendolyn Purushotham, a Methodist minister, and the Rev. Kathleen Mandeville, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Recital; Performance as an Award
description: When Ick Choo Moon completed his doctorate at the Juilliard School last year, he was awarded the William Petschek Piano Debut, which includes a recital at Alice Tully Hall. These days, Mr. Moon is head of the piano department at the University of Californa in Los Angeles. But on Thursday evening, he returned to New York City to collect his prize.

title: Dance School Honnors Nossen Legacy
description: IT has been 10 years since the dance educator Steffi Nossen died, and to mark the occasion the school she founded in 1934 - the Steffi Nossen School of Dance in White Plains - will present two commemorative concerts next Friday and Saturday evenings at New Rochelle High School.

title: Dr. Susan Cohen To Marry in May
description: A May wedding is being planned by Dr. Susan Beth Cohen, a resident in neurology at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, and Joseph Anthony Pannullo, the president of Valor Telecom Ltd., a telecommunications software company in West Orange, N.J.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Donald Ahead by 2 Shots: Despite five bogeys and a two-over-par 74, Mike Donald held a two-stroke lead at 208 yesterday after the third round of the $800,000 Independent Insurance Agent Open in The Woodlands, Tex. Donald started the day at 10 under par with a four-shot lead over Seve Ballesteros of Spain, but his problems started early when he bogeyed two of the first three holes. Ballesteros, after a par 72, was tied for second with John Inman and Lance Ten Broeck. (AP) American Leads in Malaysia: Greg Bruckner of the United States shot a course-record, five-under-par 67 yesterday in the third round of the $175,000 Malaysian Open championship in Kuala Lumpur. He held a one-stroke lead over his countryman Craig McClellan. Bruckner, who last won a title in the 1988 Singapore Open, had a 54-hole total of 211. McClellan, who shot a 71, was at 212. (AP) Boxing Byrd Gains Title: Chris Byrd of Flint, Mich., outpointed Paul Vaden of Puyallup, Wash., 3-2, yesterday for the 156-pound title in the United States boxing championships at the United States Olympic Training Center in Colorado Springs. The bout was delayed one day because of a scheduling problem earlier in the week. All the other final bouts were Friday night, when Jeremy Williams, a 16-year-old high school junior, became the tournament's youngest champion by outpointing Richard Bonds of Ripley, Tenn., 3-2, in the 178-pound final. Tony Gonzales of National City, Calif., won his second national title, and Brian Lonon of Fort Hood won his fourth. Gonzales scored a 4-1 decision over Sean Fletcher of the Navy in the 119-pound final. Lonon won the 112-pound championship on a 5-0 decision over 17-year-old Ricky Jones of Augusta, Ga.(AP) Hockey U.S. and Soviet Teams Win: The United States defeated West Germany, 8-4, and the Soviet Union beat Sweden, 4-2, yesterday in early-round games of an international tournament in Leningrad. The United States and West Germany were tied at 2-2 after the first period and at 3-3 after two periods, before the Americans took command in the final period.(AP) Auto Racing Bodine Triumphs Again: Geoff Bodine won the Country Squire Homes 200 Busch Grand National stock car race for the second straight year, overpowering the rest of the 42-car field yesterday at Darlington Raceway in South Carolina. Bodine, who started from the pole for the third time in a row and fourth in the last five Grand National races on the 1.366-mile oval, took the lead for good on lap 111 of the 147-lap, 200-mile event. He averaged 118.681 miles per hour. Mark Martin, giving a V-6 powered Ford its highest finish ever in the Grand National division, wound up second, finishing 0.37-seconds behind Bodine's Chevrolet.(AP) Horse Show Floridian Takes Freestyle Event: Linda Smith of Venice, Fla., won the Grand Prix Freestyle class yesterday at the Winter Equestrian Festival in Tampa, Fla. Smith, aboard Cyrus, her 17-hand gelding, received the highest score of 41.437 for her musical performance from the three-judge panel. Besty Steiner of Sherrard, Ill., was second, scoring 40.312 with Unanimous, a Dutch-bred gelding. Bowling Title to Aulby: Mike Aulby took advantage of three open frames by Jim Pencak for a 195-178 victory yesterday in the title game of the $500,000 Seagram's Coolers Open in Edmond, Okla., the richest event on the Professional Bowlers Association tour. Aulby earned $100,000 for his 17th career Professional Bowlers Association title and third victory this year. Aulby gained a berth in the final by knocking off Jess Stayrook, 234-222.(AP) Fencing Columbia Rallies for Title: Jon Normile of Columbia won his second consecutive epee title on the last day of competition at the National Collegaite Athletic Association men's fencing championships yesterday at Northwestern University to give Columbia a come-from-behind victory over Penn State for the overall team title. The team championship is Columbia's third straight and 11th since 1951. Columbia finished with 88 points, 3 ahead of Penn State. Going into the epee event, Columbia trailed Penn State by 2 points, and Normile needed to finish at least three places higher than Jim Marsh of Penn State for Columbia to win. Normile lost to Claus Dieter-Block of Wayne State, 10-8, in the winner's bracket, but then defeated Marsh, 10-7, in the loser's bracket to clinch at least a tie for the team title. In his next match, Normile fell behind Matt Andresen, of Duke, 9-4, before rallying for a 10-9 victory and the overall team championship. Normile then defeated Block twice, 10-6 and 10-8, to take individual honors. Dog Show Pointer Nears Mark: Ch. Luftnase Albelarm Bee's Knees, a black and white pointer owned by Isabel Robson and Michael Zollo, who does the handling, moved two victories from a record for the breed, when she was named best in show yesterday at the 67th All-Breed Show of the Bronx County Kennel Club at Melville, L.I. It was the 3-year-old bitch's 21st top award.

title: Poet Takes His Passion for Words on the Road
description: LEAD: ''IT'S O.K. to laugh at poems; you don't have to act like an audience,'' Brendan Galvin once told an audience listening to him read his poems.

title: POSTINGS: Antebellum Buildings; Seaport Living
description: Five pre-Civil War buildings in the South Street Seaport Historic District that have been vacant for more than a quarter of a century will be renovated into 33 condominium apartments in a project aimed at preserving their 19th-century character. Named Seaport Five Ltd., the $4 million project embraces structures on the northwest corner of Peck Slip and Front Street that bear the addresses 29, 31 and 33 Peck Slip, and 240-242 Front Street.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Stuffed Lamb Chops: Simple but Elegant
description: Finding good lamb outside the nation's big cities has been a problem, at least until recently. Not too many people have the luxury of butcher shops in their neighborhoods and have to rely on their supermarkets. But supermarkets tend not to pay much attention to lamb.

title: UConn Hopes to Manage Its Parking Problems
description: THE new sports arena at the University of Connecticut in Storrs is nearly completed, and school officials are now worrying about where people who will attend the games there will park their cars.

title: POSTINGS: Building Up Newark; 33-Story Tower
description: One of the largest developments in the recent history of downtown Newark has been approved by the city's Planning Board, and construction of the $130 million project, named One Penn Center, is to start this summer. The project involves construction of a 33-story tower with 750,000 square feet divided into office space, retail space and a 300-room hotel. The project also will incorporate the Central Graphic Arts Building, a seven-story Renaissance Revival building erected in 1907. The existing building will be topped with four new stories of office space, while interior renovation will create a garage for 1,000 cars.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: The philatelic fabric includes many recycled threads.

title: Long Summer Looms For Troubled Yankees
description: The heat of Florida is behind them and the weekend stopover at home will end this afternoon. Before today is done, the Yankees will pack again and board a flight to Minneapolis, and two nights from now, under a downtown dome, their season will finally, almost mercifully, begin.

title: A Mind's-Eye View of Beckett's World
description: Of all Samuel Beckett's dramatic works, the ones that have been most neglected are his radio plays. The major stage plays are continually revived, the television plays are shown with a certain frequency, at least in West Germany, but his work for radio exists largely as printed texts. On the page, they lose half their dimension. With the help of an aural tapestry - articulate actors, sound effects and music - disembodied voices achieve visceral embodiment. Listeners are transported into a character's subconscious, complete with visual as well as auditory imagery.

title: Hapsburg Grandeur Is Dusted Off for Burial of 'Our Sister the Empress Zita'
description: Old Vienna dusted off its imperial finery today to lay to rest Austria's last Empress, paying a regal tribute to a woman who remained quietly true to her lost crown and to the late Emperor through seven decades of exile.

title: WHARTON IS HIS OWN CHEERLEADER
description: When the national collegiate men's swimming championships ended tonight, David Wharton had two first places and a third and was voted the swimmer of the year. But the 19-year-old Southern Cal sophomore from Warminster, Pa., did not hear the cheers.

title: L.I. Man Burned in Wire Theft
description: A man was critically burned today when he sawed through a 7,620-volt line in an attempt to steal copper wire from atop an electric pole by the Suffolk County police said. The man, Thomas Ramsey, 30 years old, of Brentwood was burned on the head, face, hands and chest as he used a hacksaw on the Long Island Lighting Company electric line on Ruland Road in Melville at 12:40 P.M., the police said. Mr. Ramsey was taken to Nassau County Medical Center, where he was listed in critical condition.

title: Group Homes Gaining Acceptance
description: GROUP residences for people recovering from mental illness, long a sore point in Westchester neighborhoods, are inching their way toward community acceptance, authorities in the field say.

title: Sports of The Times; A Turnaround to Remember
description: You could see they would not give up. It was too soon to go out to a pay phone and confirm the Sunday flight to Newark Airport. Seton Hall was staying for the full 40 minutes.

title: 3 Guards Leave White House After Inquiry Into Drug Use
description: Two White House guards were dismissed and another guard resigned last year after a drug investigation, the Secret Service says.

title: Muster in Car Mishap; Lendl Is Awarded Title
description: A severe knee injury suffered in an auto accident Friday night knocked Thomas Muster of Austria out of the championship match Sunday in the Lipton International Players Championship, and the title was awarded to Ivan Lendl today.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Hastings-on-Hudson Debates Development
description: LEAD: WITH about 8,500 people, this two-square-mile village in southwestern Westchester is small enough to have one telephone exchange, 478, and residents usually give only the last four digits of a phone number, as though it was an extension.

title: A Preoccupation To Be the Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: What's in a Name?
description: ALMOST TWO YEARS AGO, Leonard N. Stern, the 51-year-old owner of the Hartz Group, the pet-supply giant, paid a call on a fellow billionaire. Stern was not selling birdseed. What he had to offer the prospect was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to put his name on New York University's undergraduate and graduate schools of business. The quid pro quo: a $25 million contribution to N.Y.U.

title: MAJORITY IN ISRAEL OPPOSE P.L.O. TALKS NOW, A POLL SHOWS
description: An overwhelming majority of Israeli Jews oppose peace negotiations with the Palestine Liberation Organization at this time, but more than half say they would favor talks later if the P.L.O. were to moderate its behavior, according to a poll conducted here for The New York Times.

title: Cost Comparisons
description: To the Editor: I find myself compelled to take exception to your annual late-winter compilation ''What Your Dollar Will Buy in 16 Cities Around the World'' (Travel, March 5).

title: Cherry Blossoms Ready For Washington Festival
description: Washington's weeklong National Cherry Blossom Festival begins Sunday, as more than 3,200 cherry trees are blooming along the Potomac River Tidal Basin near the Jefferson Memorial and in other park areas.

title: POSTINGS: Bronx Professional Center; New Offices on the 'Medical Mile'
description: A privately financed medical and professional center will rise soon in the booming ''medical mile'' area in the East Bronx, already the site of six hospitals and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. The nine-story, $15 million project, at 1550 Blondell Avenue at Eastchester Road, will be known as the Eastchester Professional Centre.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Did Esposito Make the Right Move?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: A Drive to Woo Women - and Invigorate Sales
description: Just one year ago, Joni Wilkens, a Cincinnati attorney, was a supporter of strict gun-control laws. But after she was threatened by parents of the abused children she represented and her house was broken into twice, the 40-year-old, divorced mother bought a handgun.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have two doors in our house that keep closing by themselves when we leave them open. I have tightened the hinge screws and tried putting shims behind the hinges, but to no avail. Any idea how I can keep these doors from closing by themselves?

title: From Bali: Demons, Heroes and Lovers
description: LEAD: Through a haze of incense, in a Balinese temple courtyard strewn with flowers, half a dozen men were stabbing themselves. The demoness Rangda - an actor wearing a ferocious mask with bulging eyes and a tongue of red-and-gold flame - rampaged through the crowd. It was her magic that had turned the villagers' knives against their own breasts.

title: Gorbachev Said to Reject Soviet Right to Intervene
description: Karoly Grosz, General Secretary of the Hungarian Communist Party, reported to his Central Committee this week that Mikhail S. Gorbachev had indicated to him that safeguards must be provided to prevent a repetition of the Soviet invasions of Hungary and Czechoslovakia.

title: China's Hotels Mean Business
description: RETURNING TO HER room at the Great Wall Sheraton Hotel in Beijing last December, Margaret Z. Lee, a marketing specialist for Honeywell, was astonished to find what appeared to be gold coins twice as big as dollar pieces resting on her pillow. What impressed Lee, a frequent visitor to China from Honeywell's base in Hong Kong, was the size of the foil-wrapped chocolates. ''They used to be only tiny coins,'' says Lee, ''but now they've become enormous.''

title: Kessel's Defense Of Shoreham Deal
description: There is a suffocating smugness in the letter of New York State Consumer Protection chief Richard Kessel (March 19) that hurts, rather than helps his defense of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Governor's latest final settlement of Shoreham.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Cuisine in Chic Surroundings
description: LEAD: MAX'S, which is three blocks west of the Raritan Savings Bank on the main street in Raritan, is a pleasantly chic four-and-a-half-month-old Italian restaurant. From the bright yellow awnings outside, boldly marked in black with the name of the restaurant, to the almost stark yet cozy interior, decorated in neutral colors, and the tiny bar just inside the entrance, the restaurant bespeaks the kind of natural charm most desirable in a local eating establishment.

title: EASY COMFORT
description: Tradition has always been the bread and butter of the Southern Furniture Market, this country's largest wholesale furniture fair, which is held twice a year in High Point, N.C. And this spring's market is no exception. Beginning Thursday and lasting until April 14, showrooms will be filled with designs based on trends that have been popular among leading architects and designers for several years. Biedermeier pieces, for example, those architecturally inspired blond wood objects dating from between 1815 and 1830, are being reinterpreted by Milo Baughman for Thayer Coggin's 20-piece line called Biedermeier 90. ''The time is right,'' says Baughman. ''Only recently has the general public learned what Biedermeier is.''

title: The Cold War Is Over
description: The cold war of poisonous Soviet-American feelings, of domestic political hysteria, of events enlarged and distorted by East-West confrontation, of almost perpetual diplomatic deadlock is over.

title: Mommy Track's an Idea Whose Time Has Gone; Changes of Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bernard King of the Washington Bullets signed a two-year contract Friday that will reportedly pay him $2 million. . . . The Philadelphia Phillies placed the center fielder Juan Samuel and the catcher Tom Nieto on the 15-day disabled list. Samuel has of a pulled hamstring and Nieto has three jammed fingers on his throwing hand. Because the disablements are retroactive to the date of the injuries, both players will have to miss only five games.

title: Oil Exacts A Price From The Earth
description: A DECADE ago, concern about pollution from oil spills reached a crescendo with what remain the two biggest disasters so far: the wreck of the tanker Amoco Cadiz off the coast of France in 1978, spilling 68 million gallons of crude oil along the Brittany shoreline, and the blowout of the Ixtoc I oil well in the Gulf of Mexico a year later, pouring 140 million gallons into the sea.

title: Jimmy Breslin Goes Hollywood, Family and All
description: Jimmy Breslin was calling from California and, as is often the case during holidays and other occasions most people find reason to celebrate, he was depressed.

title: Fashion Iconoclasts Rediscover Subtleties
description: With the world swamped in a wave of fashion conservatism, finding the young and the different in London and Paris can be difficult. Many of fashion's so-called bad boys (and girls), from Thierry Mugler and Jean-Paul Gaultier to Katharine Hamnett, have outlasted their shock value and developed sturdy businesses to merchandise their message.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: If you're looking for the beginning of numismatics just read the Greek historian Herodotus. He states that the first coins were those of King Croesus of Lydia. While Herodotus is only partially correct, an example of Croesus's coins, a stater from the 6th century B.C., will be sold at Stack's public auction in Chicago on Saturday.

title: Democrats Keep Capturing Offices And Coming Apart
description: EVER since last November's election, Democrats have been wondering whether their party will recapture the White House within their lifetimes. What they don't doubt is how strong they are in local and Congressional elections.

title: Who's Ready for Perfection?
description: WE have learned to accept, or at least, live with, the many things in our lives that go wrong.

title: Rationing Care
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Schubert: Piano Sonatas Alfred Brendel. Sonata in D (D. 850) and A minor (D. 784), Philips 422 063-2, CD and cassette only; Sonata in A (D. 959), 16 German Dances and other works, Philips 422 229-2, CD and cassette. Alfred Brendel's return to this literature on records is marked by a new relaxation and breadth of generosity - welcome elements to go with the fierce intelligence and concentration that have always marked his playing. The tempos in D. 959, one of Schubert's most powerful and mysterious works, expand and contract widely and yet retain a single sense of movement. There is a warmth of tone and a lessening of tenseness and aggression in these recent performances that may indicate a new phase in the continuing development of an important musician. -Bernard Holland D'Albert: 'Tiefland' Eva Marton, Rene Kollo, Bernd Weikl, Kurt Moll, others. Munich Radio Orchestra and Chorus, Marek Janowski, conductor. Acanta 43841 2; CD only. ''Tiefland'' (1903) is probably the best example of the effect of verismo on German opera: its post-Wagnerian orchestra sings with a Mediterranean passion. It is a lusty tale of a woman's seduction, oppression and eventual redemption. D'Albert manages his material with great skill, and some of his melodic inspirations are haunting. In this 1983 production Eva Marton interprets the suffering Marta with searing intensity and unwavering strength, Rene Kollo is an intermittently effective Pedro, and Bernd Weikl's grainy baritone lends proper menace to Sebastiano. Led by the superlative Kurt Moll, the supporting cast is fine, and Marek Janowski sustains tension throughout. -George Jellinek Brahms: Piano Concerto No. 2; Variations on a Theme by Haydn Horacio Gutierrez and the Royal Philharmonic, Andre Previn, conductor. Telarc CD-80197; CD only. To pianists, the Brahms concertos are Ultimate Tests, and the Brahms Second especially is one of those make-or-break affairs that separates the mere workman from the real artist. In his first recording of the B flat, Horacio Gutierrez presents a big, vital, warm-hearted performance. It is more than a case of remarkable fingers negotiating the murderous passages. Rather, this is a youthful-sounding Brahms minus the great white beard. Previn, no mean pianist himself, works beautifully with the soloist. The recorded sound is unusually clear. -Harold C. Schonberg Haydn: String Quartets in D major (the 'Lark,' Op. 64, No. 5, and Op. 76, No. 5) and D minor The Lindsay String Quartet. ASV CD DCA 637; all three formats. This excellent young British ensemble has been giving a Genius of Haydn Festival at Wigmore Hall in London, and releasing live recordings of the concerts on disk. In this second installment in the series, the players address three of Haydn's quartets with sensitivity and eloquence, letting the slow movements sing soulfully and whipping the quick finales into brisk dances that crackle with energy. The group's tone is wonderfully textured, and the recorded sound is spacious and appealingly transparent. -Allan Kozinn Barber: Second Symphony, Overture to 'The School for Scandal,' 'Music for a Scene by Shelley,' Essay No. 1 for Orchestra, Adagio for Strings New Zealand Symphony conducted by Andrew Schenck. Stradivari SCD 8012; CD only. The finale of Barber's Second Symphony steadfastly refuses to hang together, despite expert conducting by the Barber specialist Andrew Schenck and proficient playing by the New Zealanders in this first recording ever of the symphony. This is probably the reason why the composer withdrew the work. Stradivari, with the help of the music publisher G. Schirmer, has scored a discographic coup by reviving Barber's moving World War II symphonic tribute to the United States Army Air Force, in which he served. All the selections are extremely well recorded. -Paul Turok POP/JAZZ Jimi Hendrix Experience: 'Radio One' Rykodisc RCD 20078; CD only. Live, without overdubs, and using only the special effects he could play with fingers and feet, Jimi Hendrix tore into his early hits along with old blues and even the Beatles' ''Day Tripper'' in these 1967 sessions for BBC radio broadcasts. The songs, more concise than later live Hendrix recordings, are a reminder that Hendrix was a blues guitarist above all, and a great one; his utterly casual virtuosity - lead, rhythm and noise guitar all in one, while he sings - and buoyant humor mock Hendrix's latter-day imitators. -Jon Pareles Herbie Hancock: 'Inventions & Dimensions' Blue Note 7 84147 2; all three formats. Had the pianist Herbie Hancock gone in the direction of the introduction to ''Succotash,'' the opening piece on the album, he might have started a new school of improvisation, mixing a clean and repetitive Steve Reichian Minimalism with harmonically adventurous improvisations. On this album, recorded in 1963, he's backed by Paul Chambers on bass, Willie Bobo on drums and timbales and Osvaldo Martinez on percussion; they play odd metered tunes that force Mr. Hancock to stretch his rhythmic and harmonic limits, moving further into the austere, percussive style he developed more fully as a sideman with Miles Davis. This is the oddest record that Mr. Hancock made for Blue Note, and if it isn't the most satisfying, it comes close; it's certainly the most adventurous. -Peter Watrous The President: 'Bring Yr Camera' Elektra/Musician 69799; all three formats. The keyboardist Wayne Horvitz's sextet brings together noted Lower East Side composer-improvisers to play his easygoing, thoroughly melodic instrumentals. Mr. Horvitz's pieces dip into blues and slide-guitar rock a la Little Feat, along with mock-minimalist repetition, tinges of gamelan or Latin or Japanese music, and whatever else pops into mind. ''Bring Yr Camera'' is less ambitious than Mr. Horvitz's ''This New Generation'' (actually The President's debut album); at times it turns into unassuming background music. But sooner or later, along comes an overlay of noise or a sneaky transition to re-establish its postmodern credentials.-J. P. De La Soul: '3 Feet High and Rising' Tommy Boy 1019; all three formats. More than anything, this rap trio celebrates wit and comic invention. The record, which sold 100,000 copies in its first two weeks in the stores, is also about eccentricity and insularity. The members have developed a funny language and world view they share with no one, and many of their raps have the evocative abstraction of automatic writing. But for every song (there are more than 20 here) about smelly people needing soap, there's one about stereotypes. Behind the collegiate fooling around, there is a collegiate thoughtfulness. -P.W. Andy Summers: 'The Golden Wire' Private 2048; all three formats. The newest solo album by the former Police guitarist is a consistently pleasant, occasionally eloquent album of mystically inclined music that looks for inspiration to the Middle East and India, among other places. All but one of the 11 tracks are instrumentals, the exception being ''Piya Tose,'' a lush soundtrack that features the young Anglo-Indian singer Najma Akhtar. Though the sonic textures and harmonic modes vary from piece to piece, the overall feel of the album is soft-focus and sensuous. Yet Mr. Summers's guitar is incisive and energized enough to prevent even the album's softer moments from drifting into a mindless fog. -Stephen Holden

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have two doors in our house that keep closing by themselves when we leave them open. I have tightened the hinge screws and tried putting shims behind the hinges, but to no avail. Any idea how I can keep these doors from closing by themselves?

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: If the small green buds are showing, prune rosebushes; apply a scant handful of general fertilizer around the bases of each large-size bush; apply a tablespoonful to miniature roses. Transplant seedlings started indoors to individual pots. Plant spinach, peas, lettuce, radish in the garden. Rose Pruning

title: A Debate Over an FM Innovation
description: For openers, the professor said, ''I have been threatened with legal action, placing me under heavy personal liability, if I proceed with this lecture.'' Then, after a suspenseful moment, he proceeded with his lecture.

title: Amendment on Gun Curbs Causes Dismay in Nebraska
description: An amendment to the Nebraska constitution guaranteeing the right to bear arms ''for all persons'' has raised doubts about whether the state can prevent anyone from owning a gun, including convicted felons and the mentally incompetent.

title:
GARDENING;
Tomatoes That Please the Tastebuds
description: LEAD: BESIDES its traditional red, tomatoes come in pink, orange, yellow and even white. Tomato fruits also come in a variety of forms and sizes.

title: The Star on Cable TV Is the Volunteer
description: Thank you for the article about Cable Television on March 12 [ ''Navigating the Changes in Cable TV'' ] . Readers appreciated the background on the ways franchises are granted and managed in Westchester.

title:
Hoboken Journal;
Kitchen-Table Strategy on Shaping City's Future
description: LEAD: THE old blue-collar days of saloons and longshoremen have given way to gentrification in this waterfront city, but it is still a place of neighborhoods where families sit on stoops, children play in the streets and people greet one another at corner stores.

title: Elizabeth Patience Smith, Executive, Is Married to Kwan-Lan Tom Mao
description: Elizabeth Patience Smith, the daughter of Frances B. Smith of Lake Worth, Fla., and the late Harry M. Smith, was married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York to Kwan-Lan Tom Mao, a son of Bertha Chuang of Hyattsville, Md., and T .S. Mao of Littleton, Colo. The Rev. Dr. O. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony.

title: A Foundation's Helping Hands
description: Pro Bono Inc. may well be one of the ''ducks'' to which Scott McVay, executive director of the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation, referred in the recent article on that organization (''A Low-Key Foundation That Likes to Take Risks in Giving''). As a beneficiary of the foundation's largesse, we know firsthand its willingness to take risks in funding.
