title: Gorbachev-Castro Face-Off: A Clash of Style and Policies
description: The guest is Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the smooth salesman of new Communist pragmatism, who preaches economic experimentation, social liberalization and peaceful coexistence.

title: A MEGAMUSEUM IN A MILL TOWN
description: Why move a prominent collection of contemporary art to a remote village three hours' drive from a major city (''A Megamuseum in a Mill Town,'' by Deborah Weisgall, March 5)? To generate employment for local residents, as suggested by its public founders? It certainly cannot be to fulfill the educational aims of a museum: it will take a year for a museum in North Adams, Mass., to generate as many visitors as it could in a major city in a day.

title: SPEAKING OF THE UNSPEAKABLE
description: There may be more than one reason for denial than that described by Alice Sebold: ''Women disassociate themselves from rape because the vast majority of people still believe that a woman who has been raped is filthy, better off dead, irrational, or got what she was looking for.''

title: POSTINGS: Condos cum Commerce; Tapping a Market
description: In an effort to tap into the demand for upscale housing in White Plains, a 71-unit, $14 million condominium apartment house is to be built in the midst of a commercial area that has one of the lowest vacancy rates in the New York metropolitan area.

title: It Was a Party House, and It Will Always Be a Party House
description: WE moved to Sag Harbor in 1980 and our furniture arrived on Memorial Day. I was standing outside the laundromat at the bottom of Main Street, my dirty clothes safely spinning inside, positioning myself to watch the parade that was about to start, when my husband walked toward me from the motel in which we were staying . . . and waiting.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: Finding a satisfactory way to select a world championship team creates headaches in many sports and recreations. The American Contract Bridge League tried several methods before settling, two decades ago, for the present method, which gives winners of major national events a spot in playoffs.

title: Bearing Burdens
description: To the Editor: Eleanor Schwartz says that she and her English companion felt it immoral to travel on the shoulders of human bearers in India (Travel, March 12). Yet, these poor but proud men were only doing physical labor.

title: Miss Berger to Marry April 30
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Berger of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Ann Berger, to Gary Steven Schonfeld, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schonfeld of Tenafly, N.J. An April 30 wedding is planned. Miss Berger, a systems engineering manager for the International Business Machines Corporation in New York, graduated from Rutgers University and received an M.B.A. degree from Pace University. Her father is chairman and president of PCS Data Processing Inc. in New York.

title: Managers Work on Keeping Players in Good Mental Shape
description: Tony La Russa knows that none of the 10 previous World Series losers won a division championship the following season (only 3 finished above .500). What will he do to avoid that untender trap?

title: Misery Goes On For Met Reliever
description: Ron Darling enjoyed himself.

title: John Singleton Needham to Marry Leslie Brown Slaughter, a Caterer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Slaughter of New Canaan, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Leslie Brown Slaughter, and John Singleton Needham, the son of Richard H. Needham and Mrs. Robert C. Ferris, both of Chicago.

title: Cost Comparisons
description: To the Editor: I am a longtime fan of Portugal and have harangued my friends about its low prices. In your chart, you compare dinner in Lisbon at Gambrinus with the New York Oyster Bar. This is not comparing apples with apples - or even oranges. It's comparing apples with brussels sprouts. Gambrinus is grand luxe. Perhaps a comparison with Lutece would have been fairer. DENNIS WEBSTER New York, N.Y.

title: Review/Dance; States of Doom and Destiny, Crisis and Alienation
description: The Second Avenue Dance Company consists of dance majors in their final year at the Tisch School of the Arts of New York University, and its performances are intended to display their proficiency and versatility.

title: The Business World/Magazine Part 2
description: The Business World/Magazine Part 2

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Fordham; Live Rams Sought For Perilous Job; Any Volunteers?
description: Long, long ago, in the 70's, on the gentle rolling hills of Fordham's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx, the Fordham Ram, the school's mascot, was ambushed, painted green and hung by its hooves from a bridge, the story goes. It died. Eventually, the empty Ram Barn gave way to dormitories.

title: The Name Rings a Familiar Bell
description: MORE than 50 years ago, Jimmy McCluskey opened his first steakhouse on Nassau's South Shore. From that time to this, steaks and McCluskey's have been synonymous. McCluskey's in Bellmore still bears his name, but is no longer owned by the family. Now, a half-century later, Jimmy's grandson and namesake operates McCluskey's Filet Mignon in Island Park.

title: This Spring, Kick Up Your Heels for Less
description: The bottom line for many women is $100, the top price they'll pay for a pair of well-shod feet. Right now around New York City there are dozens of $100-or-less styles that can be worn for work, for play or for more serious socializing. The season is part of the reason.

title: A Festival Without Boundaries
description: Ever since Virgil Thomson's pioneering opera ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' ran on Broadway years before opera companies got around to staging it, the most innovative music theater in America has not had to limit itself to the strict conventions of opera or musical comedy.

title: I.M.F. Official Says U.S. Faces Criticism at Talks
description: American fiscal and monetary policies, especially higher interest rates that have added $10 billion a year to the debt burden of developing countries, will come under attack at a series of international meetings here, the Dutch Finance Minister, H. Onno Ruding, said today.

title: Downtown Plan In Jeopardy
description: THE pullout of the developer and a delay of nearly two years has left in limbo Cincinnati's plans for redevelopment by the mid-1990's of an entire downtown block as a mixed-use complex. City officials are nevertheless optimistic about resurrecting the project.

title: Mommy Track's an Idea Whose Time Has Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Riches of the Capital Luring Poor Youth Down a Bloody Path
description: The teen-ager stood on a street corner in a light drizzle a few minutes' ride from the White House. In his pocket he had a wad of $10 and $20 bills. He was smiling.

title: Robert Lawrence Wed to Jody Bier
description: Jody Ann Bier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Bier of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married in New York last evening to Robert Lloyd Lawrence, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman S. Lawrence of East Hills, L.I. Rabbi Stephen Wise Goodman officiated at the Plaza.

title: Michigan Survives Back-And-Forth Battle
description: On an evening in college basketball where miracles are apt to occur at any second, Sean Higgins of Michigan rebounded an errant shot and tossed the basketball back through the hoop, giving the Wolverines a 2-point lead.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: NED ROREM'S WORK Ned Rorem will discuss his music and his published diaries at a ''Concerts and Comments'' program at 4 P.M. today in the Rye Arts Center. The 65-year-old American composer won a Grammy Award this year for his ''String Symphony,'' and in 1976 his ''Air Music'' won a Pulitzer Prize. A prolific creator, his output covers opera, symphony, chamber works, choral works and pieces for solo voice and instruments.

title: FOR GOD, FOR GOLF AND FOR COUNTRY
description: WILLIE An Autobiography. By Willie Nelson with Bud Shrake. Illustrated. 334 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Guiding Lights
description: MY WIFE, YOLANDE, AND I were traveling in India when we heard the news. Someone had left the door to the chicken coop open at our weekend farm outside Columbus, Ind., and most of Yolande's brood had escaped. A few days later, we linked up with J. Irwin Miller, the renowned chairman of the Cummins Engine Company, where I was a vice president. He knew of her loss, and he proceeded to tell her, with a straight face, that there had been some excitement in Columbus just as he was leaving. A flock of chickens had come running down the main street, feathers flying all over the place. Yolande was panicked, imagining what the neighbors must think - until she realized that he was pulling her leg.

title: Getting Ready For Vacationers
description: OWNERS are refurbishing and rebuilding their commercial properties here for a summer season that is expected to draw more than three million people to the town and to nearby Acadia National Park.

title: Queens Store Owner Is Slain After Intervening in Dispute
description: The owner of a Queens candy store was stabbed to death yesterday afternoon by a man he was escorting from his store, the police said.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Goodbye to All That

title: AGING GRACEFULLY
description: When a California winery can't think of any other way to get publicity, the wine maker is told to grab a clean shirt (or blouse - there are lots of female wine makers these days) and hit the circuit. He or she travels from city to city, fielding questions from amateurs.

title: 'Profscam'
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG MONEY MEETS BIG SCIENCE
description: THE CIRCUIT RIDERS Rockefeller Money and the Rise of Modern Science. By Gerald Jonas. Illustrated. 430 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company.

title: Dr. Patricia Jaros Engaged
description: Christine Jaros Suite of Athens, Ga., and Robert G. Jaros of Cocoa Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Patricia A. Jaros to Dr. Alan R. Ecker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Ecker of Syosset, L.I. A May 6 wedding is planned. Dr. Jaros, an ophthalmology resident at Yale-New Haven Hospital, graduated from Emory University and Emory Medical School in Atlanta. Dr. Ecker graduated from Lehigh University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and Hahnemann Medical College and Hospital. He completed his ophthalmology residency at Yale and is now in private practice in Madison, Conn.

title: Approval Due on Rise In Lilco Rates
description: LEAD: FOR the second time in five months, the State Public Service Commission is expected to approve a settlement between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Long Island Lighting Company that would set electric rates in the post-Shoreham era and forever close the $5.5 billion nuclear plant.

title: SPEAKING OF THE UNSPEAKABLE
description: Alice Sebold's article on rape (Hers: ''Speaking of the Unspeakable,'' Feb. 26) was a painful reminder of a rape incident I faced in college at a fraternity party. I was a bystander, not a victim, but it was nevertheless a harrowing experience for me. It also acted as a catalyst for campus unrest and controversy.

title: BEST SELLERS: April 2, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from Bombay enact the roles of good and evil in contemporary London. 2 2 6 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington and the other in Hollywood. 3 6 2 A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. (Morrow, $19.95.) A schoolboy who accidentally killed the mother of his best friend turns into a prophet with a message for our times. 4 3 6 THE EDGE, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $18.95.) Advice on investing in stocks from a veteran fund manager. 4 4 4 GETTING THE LOVE YOU WANT, by Harville Hendrix. (Holt, $18.95.) Counsel for couples. 5 5 9 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) GOLDWYN: A Biography, by A. Scott Berg. (Knopf, $24.95.) An absorbing treatment, thick with amusing anecdotes and happily short on psychology, of the coarse immigrant genius who gave his name to an ism and his energy to the invention of Hollywood. TARGET: PRIME TIME. Advocacy Groups and the Struggle Over Entertainment Television, by Kathryn C. Montgomery. (Oxford University, $22.50.) Ms. Montgomery chronicles in detail the efforts of special-interest groups to influence entertainment programs and the industry's efforts to deflect or subvert them. THE WHITENESS OF BONES, by Susanna Moore. (Doubleday, $17.95.) This novel of tough action and striking imagery, the author's second, follows two sisters from the innocent sins of tropical Hawaii to far graver violations in steamy Manhattan. WORDSTRUCK: A Memoir, by Robert MacNeil. (Viking, $18.95.) The co-host of the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' tells of his own fascination with words from his Nova Scotia childhood upward. MORE LIKE US: Making America Great Again, by James Fallows. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) A former resident of Japan urges Americans not to go astray through envy of the Japanese but to rediscover their own values and stick to them. A YEAR IN THE SUN: The Games, the Players, the Pleasure of Sports, by George Vecsey. (Times Books, $19.95.) The personal diary, often understated and poignant, of a Times sports columnist who loves both sports and newspapers. FELLOW PASSENGERS: A Novel in Portraits, by Louis Auchincloss. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) A fine entertainment, held together by a narrator who is in the confidence of perfect gentlemen, social climbers and other representative types.

title: Agencies for Children Are Overwhelmed, Too
description: CRITICIZED for their dealings with abused or abandoned children, New York City officials cobbled together some solutions. Now the officials seem to spend much of their time running back to slap another patch on the machinery.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bar Harbor, Me.; Getting Ready For Vacationers
description: OWNERS are refurbishing and rebuilding their commercial properties here for a summer season that is expected to draw more than three million people to the town and to nearby Acadia National Park.

title: Justice O'Connor's Second Indiscretion
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor has again deplorably allowed her name and judicial office to be used for partisan political purposes.

title: Honoring 'Bones' and Buatta
description: Two bright lights were honored at very different parties recently. Marie Brenner, the writer, gave a book party in her East Side town house March 23 in honor of her friend and neighbor, Susanna Moore. Ms. Moore's new novel, ''The Whiteness of Bones,'' describes the adventures of a young woman from Hawaii who comes to New York, entering the web of the city's high society.

title: NONFICTION
description: HORSE-TRADING AND ECSTASY. By Barbara Probst Solomon. (North Point Press, $18.95.) From the trial of Jean Harris to the trial of Klaus Barbie, Barbara Probst Solomon has chosen her subjects over the years with an instinct for the fascinating and the enduring. ''Horse-Trading and Ecstasy,'' a collection of 33 essays, reviews and interviews written between 1959 and 1988, is arranged by theme rather than chronology. The result is a persuasively effective and thoughtful series of contrasting insights that leads a reader to a clear understanding of what Ms. Solomon has been thinking about and why. In a section called ''Fallen Angels,'' for instance, an essay on Sylvia Plath and the woman writer's place in the world, written in 1982, is followed by a compelling discussion of the Ginny Foat murder case, which was published in The Partisan Review in 1986. This segues into a 1981 interview with Norman Mailer from a Madrid periodical. Ms. Solomon, whose previous books include ''The Beat of Life'' and ''Short Flights,'' brings to the page a ferocious intelligence coupled with a luminous prose style. Even when you do not agree with her conclusions about, say, Diana Trilling or Spanish elections, you cannot help but admire how she got there. Essays have spawned much pedestrian writing in the name of ''personal journalism.'' Ms. Solomon, with her dedication to inquiry and intellect, is one very snappy writer who transcends the category.

title:
ART;
Bridging Art and Technology
description: LEAD: ''THE Art of Juan Geuer,'' now at Adelphi University's University Center Gallery, is a small exhibition that touches on large issues.

title: Hollywood's Tunes Are Concerts' Themes
description: MUSIC from the movies looms large on this week's concert scene. At the first of three orchestral programs, the music director of the Stamford Symphony, Roger Nierenberg, will conduct the symphony in a program of film favorites, ''from love songs to adventure themes in outer space.''

title: Chukkers Anyone?
description: THERE ARE ONLY TWO REASONS TO QUIT playing polo: death or poverty. The adage comes from the 1920's and 30's, the game's golden age, which glittered with Social Register names like Winston F. C. Guest and Tommy Hitchcock Jr. Generally thought to be the greatest American player of all time, Hitchcock was also considered remarkable because he actually held down a job, at the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers. ''Poverty'' in this era had a special meaning, as in, ''They lost everything, even the horses.''

title: Asbestos: The Saga Drags On
description: Now that the Manville Corporation, once the leader of the asbestos industry, has emerged from bankruptcy, the tangled drama of asbestos litigation is entering a new stage.

title: The Rise of the 'Atari Communists'
description: In an effort to purge the Stalinist model of development from Socialism, a new generation of politicians, planners and intellectuals is assuming leadership positions in the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and China. Because of their belief in the market, their faith in technology and their suspiciousness of the state, I call this generation of reformers the Atari Communists - after the high-tech, free-market Atari Democrats of California, Colorado and elsewhere.

title: Interior Decorating Can Cause Emotional Damage
description: THE painters are downstairs, chattering happily. I am upstairs, rapidly having a nervous breakdown.

title: Still a Giant
description: Under the new rules, the 619 National Football League players who were declared temporary free agents had from Feb. 1 until midnight yesterday to sign with any other team without that team having to compensate their old team. One of them was Stacy Robinson, a Giant wide receiver for four years. Yesterday, hours before the deadline, Robinson decided to remain with the Giants rather than accept an offer from any of five other teams.

title: Carol Rubin Weds Steven N. Kaplan, Finance Professor
description: The marriage of Carol Jane Rubin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rubin of New York and North Palm Beach, Fla., to Steven Neil Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kaplan of Danbury, Conn., took place last evening at the Loft in New York. Rabbi Robert N. Levine officiated.

title: Dr. A. L. Granger And Gina L. Gray Engaged to Wed
description: Gina Lawson Gray and Dr. Albert Lester Granger are planning to marry on May 6, the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Gray of Baltimore, have announced. Dr. Granger is a son of Drs. Richard and Dorothy Granger of New York, Sag Harbor, L.I., and Isla Verde, P.R.

title: Los Angeles
description: To the Editor: Regarding the answer to a question about finding art exhibitions in Los Angeles (Q & A, Jan. 8): We recently published a guide to contemporary art galleries, museums and restaurants in the Los Angeles area. The guidebook is designed to fit in one's back pocket or purse and divides the greater Los Angeles area into nine areas. There is a detailed map at the beginning of each section, and directions and nearby restaurants are also listed.

title: PASTIMES: Gardening; Nature's Signals Provide Accurate Clues for Planting
description: When forsythia is in bloom, gardeners know it is the proper time to prune the rosebushes. The explosion of yellow flowers signals that the rosebushes will have green buds on their canes, a timing provided by nature.

title: A Big-Top Benefit For Adoption
description: Parents and sipped champagne and children ate tacos and ice cream. ''What a great idea, combining the circus with a party,'' said Emily Becnel, a young woman who had come with friends. ''I think we had even more fun than some of the children. The circus does that to you.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Columbia; An Old Chapel Yields New Space For Art Gallery
description: Three years ago, student artists at Columbia University decided to do something about the lack of exhibition space on campus.

title: Flexibility at Work Helps Parents at Home
description: WHILE most employees at the Olin Corporation in Stamford come in at 7:45 A.M., Debra Stapleton is allowed to arrive up to an hour later, which gives her time to take her son to the baby sitter. She makes up the time at the end of the day, and her husband picks up the child in the afternoon.

title: In Title Game, No. 1 Is Playing No. 2
description: When top-ranked Tennessee battles second-ranked Auburn for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I women's basketball championship Sunday afternoon in the Tacoma Dome, two teams that have been so close for so long at the top will bring the title home to the Southeastern Conference.

title: What's Ahead for Renters With Waiver Fee Gone
description: IF you need a sure-fire topic for a heated discussion among travelers, with shouts of ''You think that's bad!'' auto-rental adventures are a good choice.

title:
DINING OUT;
Contemporary and Italian in Scarsdale
description: LEAD: DINERS looking to spend an evening dining at Dario will not be disappointed to find in its place Marcello. Marcello Giansante, for many years the maitre d'hotel and now the owner, has wisely left what is good-enough here alone: the high drama of the wood-paneled entrance stairway, the lavish display of appetizers at the dining room's threshold, the glassed-in bar and lounge area romantically illuminated with strings of pinlights.

title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold
description: PROPOSALS for drug testing in any segment of American society have been encountering resistance, and, surprisingly, the opposition is especially vigorous on behalf of a population that is most prone to drug abuse: people charged with crimes.

title: Rocket Kills 22 in Afghan Temple
description: After nearly a decade of war that is estimated to have claimed more than a million lives, fresh casualty lists have become commonplace in Afghanistan.

title: An Italian Success Story Continues
description: IT has been seven years since we last looked in at Bella Italia, opposite the North Street Shopping Center in Danbury, and we decided recently to see how things were going for this long-running Danbury success story. Bella Italia began as a minuscule storefront restaurant that surprised everyone because of its creative menu and emphasis on complicated dishes made with fresh ingredients.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have two doors in our house that keep closing by themselves when we leave them open. I have tightened the hinge screws and tried putting shims behind the hinges, but to no avail. Any idea how I can keep these doors from closing by themselves?

title: The Return of God
description: To the Editor:

title: Ludlamania Flourishes in a Gleeful 'Irma Vep'
description: THE notion of a Charles Ludlam play without Charles Ludlam might strike one as something beyond ridiculous.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TAMING THE STAR RUNNER By S. E. Hinton. 181 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Mubarak Rejects Shamir's Request for Talks in Washington
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has rejected a request by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to get together for an informal meeting this week in Washington, where they will both be holding talks with President Bush, Egyptian and Israeli officials said today.

title: Braids, Intricate and Expressive
description: ''Beauty knows no sacrifice,'' Sonya Milliner said, her adage made convincing by the nearly nine hours she had just spent under her hair stylist's comb.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Summer Rentals Increasing in Nassau
description: LEAD: FOR Robyn and Jeffrey Davis, living in the beachfront community of Bayville on Nassau's North Shore is a year-round vacation. The four-bedroom colonial they bought 13 years ago is a block from the beach.

title: Patricia Cunningham Wed
description: Patricia Marie Cunningham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Cunningham of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., and Charles Francis Schmitt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Schmitt of Elmira, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Columba in Hopewell Junction. The Rev. Gerardo Colacicco performed the ceremony.

title: Music and Dance
description: The Concert Royal Chamber Orchestra and the New York Baroque Dance Company are to present a program of music and dance from 18th-century France at 8 P.M. Thursday in Merkin Concert Hall at Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. The concert is in honor of the Bicentennial of the French Revolution and the 10th anniversary of Merkin Concert Hall. Tickets are $15. Information: 362-8719.

title: MESSAGES FROM A HUNGER STRIKE
description: TEN MEN DEAD The Story of the 1981 Irish Hunger Strike. By David Beresford. Introduction by Peter Maas. 334 pp. New York: A Morgan Entrekin Book/The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: Correction
description: An article March 19 about Louis Malle's ''Murmur of the Heart'' misidentified the actor who played the oldest brother, Thomas, in the film. He is Fabien Ferreux. An accompanying caption misidentified the actress shown. She is Gila von Weitershausen.

title: Moving Hunting Rifles Away From the Target of a Ban
description: Although the Bush Administration's ban on imported semiautomatic assault rifles does not directly affect American manufacturers, it has sent them running for cover.

title: Review/Opera; Shifting Faces and Voices In Met's 'Eugene Onegin'
description: Except for Spiro Malas and Andrij Dobriansky in the tiny parts of the Captain and Zaretski, the cast for the Wednesday evening performance of Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin'' at the Metropolitan Opera was entirely different, including the conductor, than when the opera was first presented this season only three weeks ago.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A VISION OF LIGHT. By Judith Merkle Riley. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The 14th century was a wild and crazy time, at least according to Judith Merkle Riley's fast-paced first novel. ''A Vision of Light'' is the story of a woman's search for fulfillment and autonomy in pestilence-scourged England. Young Margaret of Ashbury, although illiterate, is an inventor, philosopher and feminist.

title: LAND GRAB ON THE RIO GRANDE
description: SO FAR FROM GOD The U.S. War With Mexico, 1846-1848. By John S. D. Eisenhower. Illustrated. 436 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: RANGERS' HOPE FOR 2d ENDS
description: The big gamble came just hours before the big game, and it was no doubt all part of the big plan. For a night, though, it produced just another big zero.

title: Islanders Lose; Morrow Bows
description: The Islanders ended their home season on a rueful note in an arena dotted with banners thanking the defenseman Ken Morrow for his decade of service to the club and begging Coach Al Arbour not to desert the youngsters on a team that, after failing in the present, has designated itself as a power for the 1990's.

title:
GARDENING;
Tomatoes That Please the Tastebuds
description: LEAD: BESIDES its traditional red, tomatoes come in pink, orange, yellow and even white. Tomato fruits also come in a variety of forms and sizes.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about the Metropolitan Opera's production of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' referred incorrectly to Rolf Langenfass. He designed the costumes; the sets are by Gunther Schneider-Siemssen.

title: When Wal-Mart Comes To Town
description: IT IS JUST AFTER 6 A.M. IN Independence, Iowa, stars still bright in the dark winter sky, but already the regulars are heading for the Red Rooster diner on Main Street for some breakfast on the way to work. Once inside, they peel off their heavy coats, pulled-down hats and gloves, harrumphing and stomping off the bone-chilling cold.

title: Yanks Beat Mets, But Darling Stars
description: There was no sun and no sign of a pennant race, but there was baseball in New York yesterday. The Yankees and the Mets, crosstown rivals to their fans although nothing more than spring training opponents to each other, met on a cool and mostly cloudy day at Yankee Stadium. Summer finally beckoned.

title:
DANCE;
A Dancescape Full of Premieres
description: LEAD: IN April the state's dancescape reaches full bloom, with companies of every shape and size crowding the performance calendar in a celebration of new works. And for the second year, Gov. Thomas H. Kean has designated April as New Jersey Dance Month.

title: 3 Concerts Offer Diverse Attractions
description: THREE intriguing concerts are on today's schedule, beginning with a free ''Sunday Serenade'' at 3 P.M. in the Harrison Public Library. The members of the Trio d'Anches (anches is French for the reed stops on an organ) have invited two of their wind-playing colleagues to join them for Quintets by Reicha, Vivaldi, Klughart, Zemlinsky and - in transcription one may assume - Scott Joplin. No tickets are required. For further details, call 835-0324.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AVANT-GARDE CONCERT Joseph Celli, an oboist and a former director of Real Art Ways, the avant-garde arts complex in Hartford, returns to his old stamping ground for a multi-media concert at 8 P.M. Saturday.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: JEPHTE'S DAUGHTER. By Naomi Ragen. (Warner, $18.95.) The original, biblical Jephte's daughter was sacrificed to God by her father after a vainglorious vow made during the heat of battle. Before returning to meet her fate, his daughter spent two months wandering in the mountains to mourn the fact that she would die a virgin.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; In Stony Brook, the Past Is Present
description: The museums feature exhibits of famous Long Islanders, miniature period rooms and horse-drawn carriages. The shops sell Laura Ashley clothing, Crabtree & Evelyn potpourri and Godiva chocolates. And at a restaurant in an inn overlooking the water, the waiters wear colonial clothes and pass around baskets of fresh breads.

title: Marcia Bernstein to Wed Keith Waldman on May 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic S. Bernstein of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marcia Bernstein to Keith Waldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Waldman of Margate, N.J. A May 7 wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE DIETER. By Susan Sussman. (Pocket Books, $16.95.) Susan Sussman's first novel falls into the genre in which a vulnerable but feisty woman hits the rocks but rises like a phoenix. Barbara Avers is a wealthy, fortyish Chicago housewife who is passionately devoted both to smoking and to her best friend Sarajane.

title: DOG DAYS, CAT NIGHTS AND POGONIPS
description: IN MY LINE OF WORK, I'M FREQUENTLY TWO years ahead of myself and three weeks behind. I carry little-known facts around in my head - the definition of a blue moon, when dog days begin, what a pogonip is, and the best times to cut your hair or castrate a bull. I can help you find information on how to hypnotize a chicken or a lobster (you supply the motivation), a recipe for dandelion jelly, sure-fire cures for warts or snoring or baldness, or the best times for fishing. My head swims with sage bits of advice and cautionary words, such as ''Stick to your winter flannels until your flannels stick to you,'' or, ''An eel held by the tail is not yet caught.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Quid Pro Quo From Developers; Using Private Funds for Public Improvements
description: In a reversal of practice, when communities offered inducements to attract office and industrial projects, commercial developers today are being pressured to provide public improvements ranging from sewer lines to sculpture. Sometimes the exactions are plainly stated in law books; sometimes they are hammered out informally.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will The Yanks And Mets Do in 1989?
description: The Yankees will finish in sixth place. Injuries to their key players - Dave Winfield, Rafael Santana, Ron Guidry, Wayne Tolleson, Dave Righetti and John Candelaria - will take their toll on the team.

title: Whose Right To Bear Arms Is Protected?
description: Although the nation's courts have been in basic agreement that the Second Amendment to the United States Constitution establishes the right to own guns, scholars have conducted a lively debate over the purpose of the measure, the kinds of weapons it allows and what restrictions can be placed on gun ownership.

title: State Shell? No! Oyster? Double No!
description: IT'S little our state legislators have to do, and it's light they take their commission from we, the people of Connecticut, to represent us in Hartford. For behold, now they've risen to the sublime height of responsibility by considering the naming of a state shell. Happy day! Just what we needed. Not content with naming a state flower, tree, animal, insect, ship and mineral, they are considering giving us a state shell. And what kind of a shell is being considered? Ostrea virginicus is its highfalutin Latin label - better known as the Eastern oyster. They are not concentrating on its succulent contents, but on its outer casing - one of the ugliest shells to wash up on our beaches.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Boston University; A Birthday Party For 1,500 Signals Start of 'New Era'
description: What do you get when you mix 150 years of history with 280 pounds of sugar, 1,500 eggs and 200 pounds of frosting, and then add 4,000 T-shirts, a pep band, hundreds of red and white balloons and more than 1,500 spirited students?

title: Radioactive Sand Is Detected in Abundance
description: LEAD: UNUSUALLY high concentrations of thorium, a naturally occurring radioactive element, can be detected along the Long Island shorelines in the black sands of several beaches and in granitic rock, scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory have discovered.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Mountain Lakes
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES looks remarkably like it did 30 years ago. Most students walk to school, faces are familiar and 300 acres of borough-owned parks - including 162 acres of lakes - provide pockets of peace.

title: A Mother Finds Help With Alcoholism
description: LEAD: THE boy was 6 or 7 years old when his mother's drinking became so heavy she could no longer take care of him. After Child Protective Service workers received three reports of neglect, they obtained a Family Court order to hospitalize the boy for depression and then put him in a foster home. The mother willingly entered an alcohol-rehabilitation program.

title: WHO LOST NICARAGUA?
description: LEAD: SOMOZA FALLING By Anthony Lake 317 pp. Boston: A Richard Todd Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: Julie Brenner to Wed David Newman Julie H. Brenner To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Brenner of Short Hills, N.J., have made known the engagement of Mr. Brenner's daughter, Julie Hart Brenner, to David Martin Newman, the son of Mrs. Harold Levine of North Miami Beach. An October wedding is planned.

title: Roles of 'Uncommon Women'
description: THE drama department in the school where I teach was producing ''Uncommon Women and Others,'' a play about the reunion of a Mount Holyoke College graduating class. Attractive, talented girls from the upper school would be be playing the roles. They are lithe, angular, achingly young and right for the parts.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.;
Low-Rent Units In Empty Homes
description: LEAD: A LOCAL development partnership, aided substantially by government money, is working to create 150 low-rent apartments, mainly in abandoned triple-decker houses, in a blighted neighborhood of Upper South Providence.

title: NONFICTION
description: DON'T BEND OVER THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES. By Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Sex is the subject of Lewis Grizzard's 10th book, which, like its title (that of an ''1800s drinking song''), does not cover - or uncover - much new ground. In his introductory chapter, Mr. Grizzard, a columnist with The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, promises to tiptoe through the tulips and bypass obscenities and tastelessness. His motives are pure: properly portrayed, ''sex sells'' and ''I want this book to sell. This is America, we have a capitalistic society, and I like an occasional bottle of wine with a cork in it.'' As Mr. Grizzard would say of his youthful tussle with his date's brassiere, he almost pulls it off. The book is a discursive, digressive, anything-for-a-laugh assortment of down-home stories, rambling reminiscences and some very old jokes. Mr. Grizzard find AIDS scary, rails against the hypocrisy of television preachers and, in his autobiographical reveries, casts himself as a nebbishly victim who was cruelly abused by fate and unsympathetic, headstrong women. Perhaps for this reason, Mr. Grizzrd's easygoing, aw-shucks comedy frequently flashes a cruel edge: for him, women are either goddesses or harridans, with no one in the middle. Mr. Grizzard is better when he tours bumpkin-land. as he recounts the perpetual passion of Hogg Philpott for his bride, Cordie Mae Poovey, ''who was uglier than a train wreck and twice the size of one,'' he offers Philpott's advice to husbands past their sexual peak: ''I always try to be willing to do whatever it is that is exciting to my woman and won't cause me to lose a lot of time at work.''

title: PAUL LUDICK: Furniture Designer
description: Paul Ludick, a 31-year-old furniture terrorist, designs chairs that cause occupants to sit up and shudder. His Chair-Noble, a play on Chernobyl, is a wooden stool shaped like a nuclear power plant. The back of his Apartheid Chair is fashioned from black-and-white chain link fencing. Pistols point from the Arms Chair, an easy chair calculated to make the sitter uneasy.

title: Mommy Track's an Idea Whose Time Has Gone; The Divorce Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Francis Russell, 84, U.S. Envoy to 3 Lands
description: Francis Henry Russell, a former United States Ambassador, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Cup Group Wants Ruling Appealed
description: The America's Cup Organizing Committee announced yesterday that it would ask the San Diego Yacht Club to appeal a New York State Supreme Court decision ordering the club to forfeit the America's Cup to New Zealand. The announcement serves to underscore a widespread belief in San Diego that much of the blame for the recent court decision belongs on the doorstep of the New York Yacht Club.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Vassar; Tea Is in the Parlor, and the Flavor Is Neo-Victorian
description: It's 3 o'clock on a weekday afternoon. Most students are rushing to the next class, taking a nap or catching up on their favorite soap opera. But there is an alternative here. One can always go to the Rose Parlor for a spot of tea.

title: Linda Rosenberg, Bank Executive, Becomes a Bride
description: Linda E. Rosenberg and George Franciscovich were married last evening at the Stanhope in New York. The Rev. John Cuyler, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: EMMA HOPE: Shoe Designer
description: Emma Hope designs what she calls ''regalia for feet.''

title: Back to Basics With Children
description: IN an age where the tooth fairy leaves at least $1 and children's birthday parties have become costly extravaganzas for many, I'd like a return to simplicity.

title:
ART;
Finding a Role For Decoration
description: LEAD: IN the nomenclature of art, the term ''decoration'' has a certain ambivalent ring to it.

title: SISTERS IN ARMS
description: THE WARRIOR QUEENS By Antonia Fraser. Illustrated. 383 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: The Return of God
description: To the Editor:

title: Suddenly, Mars Seems a Little Farther Away
description: THE dream of people flying to Mars will almost certainly come true in the 21st century.

title: Salesmanship With a Magic Touch
description: LEAD: FINANCIAL wizards are not the only ones capable of performing magic in a corporate board room. Jack Sandorse, a master magician, has pulled sales out of the corporate hats of Cutty Sark and B & L Scotch for more than 20 years.

title: Under Oil's Powerful Spell, Alaska Was Off Guard
description: All through this decade, while earning billions from petroleum, Alaskans have allowed the oil industry to save money by curtailing preparations for an environmental emergency like the one that has now fouled Prince William Sound.

title: Headliners; Breaking the Ice
description: Sergei Priakin played with the Soviet national hockey team for four years but was not an established star. Last week, the 25-year-old right wing made history, becoming the first Soviet athlete permitted to play for a professional team in North America. He signed a contract with the Calgary Flames of the National Hockey League, but he was not the player that was expected to be the pioneer.

title: Concrete Reefs to Face Test
description: ENGINEERS are preparing to install a concrete reef system off the coast of this Cape May County community to demonstrate how to counteract beach erosion. If successful, the project could be duplicated elsewhere and save taxpayers in the state millions of dollars a year in sand replenishment and beach restoration.

title: Dealing With Mortgage-Rate Shock
description: Borrowers who opted for adjustable-rate mortgages knew they were taking a chance. But for years the risks seemed relatively slight as interest rates on their loans remained below those of conventional fixed mortgages. No longer. Some holders of older adjustable-rate mortgages are seeing their rates jump to more than 12 percent, while the rates on new fixed loans are hovering around 11. And many holders of newer adjustable mortgages, while not at the 12 percent level, are nonetheless facing rate increases of two percentage points, the typical maximum increase that a lender can impose on a variable-rate loan each year. Such a jump means that monthly mortgage payments can rise 20 percent or more.

title: The Return of God
description: To the Editor:

title: Joyce Rutter Is a Bride
description: Joyce Anne Rutter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Rutter of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday at the Duquesne Club to Jonathan Scott Kaye, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kaye of Westford, Mass. Judge Francis A. Barry of the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania officiated.

title: Michael Milken Is Indicted
description: Michael R. Milken was indicted last week by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Federal racketeering law. Prosecutors are seeking the unprecedented financial penalty of $1.8 billion in the case against Mr. Milken, the Drexel Burnham Lambert executive who pioneered the use of ''junk bonds'' to finance corporate takeovers. Two others are also charged in the criminal action, the largest ever undertaken against Wall Street figures: Lowell Milken, a senior Drexel executive and brother of Michael Milken, and Bruce L. Newberg, a former trader in Drexel's high-yield, high-risk bonds. All three pleaded not guilty. Arthur L. Liman, who was Senate counsel during the Iran-Contra hearings, will lead the defense team. If there is no out-of-court settlement, the trial may begin as early as the end of the year. *

title: Victory for Lord of the Night
description: Lord of the Night, who has found his best form as a 6-year-old, ran down Dancing Spree in the final yards yesterday to win the $118,400 Westchester Handicap by a head at Aqueduct.

title: Looking Forward to Looking Back
description: THE HUBBLE SPACE TELE-scope, which is expected to provide pictures of galaxies billions of light years distant and to afford scientists their best clues yet about the beginning of the universe, is now scheduled for launch from Cape Canaveral on Dec. 11. The largest optical observation device to be put in use beyond the earth's atmosphere, it is to be set in orbit 320 nautical miles above Earth by the space shuttle Discovery. Already, applications from scientists worldwide would fill the Hubble's first year of observation time sevenfold.

title: Najma: An Old-New Voice In International Pop Music
description: On the British release, ''Qareeb'' (Shanachie 64009; all three formats), the 24-year-old Najma Akhtar harmonizes her Indian Muslim ancestry with the less closed-in musical world around her. In the meditative lengths of their phrases, the vocal lines she has written for herself owe something to the careful unwindings of the ragas of Indian classical music. But as Najma, who records without her surname, sings them in her lucid voice, they catch the Western ear. In her lower and middle ranges, she commands the solid aim and tonality of a pop professional, yet she bounds off up the scale like a rock singer who wants to see how far she might go.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Last week I once again had the dubious honor of being a juror for a nationwide photography competition, this time at the Catskill Center for Photography in Woodstock, N.Y. Together with Catherine Evans, an assistant curator at the Museum of Modern Art, I looked at more than 2,000 slides in something like six hours.

title: Elizabeth Thompson Wed in Capital To Peter S. Hotvedt, Medical Student
description: Elizabeth Ruth Thompson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George M. Thompson of Lenoir, N.C., and Peter Smith Hotvedt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Hotvedt of Bethesda, Md., were married yesterday. The Rev. James T. Maier performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington. Eva Claire Thompson was her sister's maid of honor. Dr. Douglas Nils

title: Atlanta's Gold (Forsythia) Battles Its Purple (Smog)
description: To outsiders Atlanta is a booming, spit-and-polish haven for middle managers and regional salesmen - the heart, if not the soul, of the bustling New South.

title: Rap Will Reclaim Rhyme for the 90's
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; A Touch of Spain in the Hills of Mount Kisco
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings - poor, satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. La Camelia

title: Review/Recital; Romantic Statements On the Piano
description: One of the happier aspects of Gerald Robbins's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night was its ability to accommodate big Romantic statements to the dimensions of a chamber-music auditorium. Mr. Robbins, a Californian now living in Manhattan, plays with a relaxed assurance, the kind that could point out the drama of Schumann's Symphonic Etudes while retaining a certain intimacy.

title: CONNECTICUT OPINION
description: THE recent suggestion by the Rev. Jesse Jackson that black Americans should be called African-Americans got me thinking about whether any of us in the United States - blacks, whites, anyone - are not exhibiting an extreme chauvinism in the first place when we refer to ourselves as ''Americans.''

title: JOHN GOTTI RUNNING THE MOB
description: EVERY WORKDAY ABOUT NOON, WITH RITUAL POMP, A gleaming limousine glides into the driveway of a modest, split-level house in the Howard Beach section of Queens. Emerging from the house is John Joseph Gotti, a spring to his step, his shoulders squared like a West Point plebe. He is dressed impeccably: muted solid-colored double-breasted suit, creamy white shirt and silk tie with matching breast-pocket handkerchief. Behind the wheel of the waiting Mercedes-Benz or Lincoln is one of three driver-bodyguards who rotate in chauffeuring Gotti around New York.

title: Pope Is Content With U.S. Religious Orders
description: Pope John Paul II has given a passing grade to American religious orders in a letter bringing to a close what was once viewed by those orders as a hostile Vatican inquiry into the changes in their activities and organization over the past two decades.

title: How Despair Is Engulfing A Generation in New York
description: JAMES VOORHEES of 114th Street in Harlem, just 16 years old, is holding his family together in a neighborhood that has all but collapsed.

title: Laurie Fishburn Wed in Virginia To Michael Farr
description: Laurie Rodes Fishburn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Fishburn of Roanoke, Va., was married there yesterday to Michael Keogh Farr, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Farr of Chevy Chase, Md. The ceremony, at the Second Presbyterian Church, was performed by the Rev. William R. Klein, assisted by the Rev. Lawrence J. Madden, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Sports of The Times; Memo to Giamatti: Make It One Game, Not Two
description: In the early days of spring training, Bart Giamatti was standing below the raised box seats in Phoenix Stadium while the Oakland Athletics took batting practice. Above him, half a dozen small boys were leaning on the box-seat rail, not even noticing the successor to Peter Ueberroth as baseball's new commissioner. The boys appeared to be from 8 to 12 years old. They were holding baseballs and notebooks and pens as they beseeched the Athletics for an autograph.

title: Struggle to Meet Rush of New Taxes
description: BRUCE GOLDBERG has perhaps 100,000 bottles of beer, wine and rye on the shelves of his West Hartford store, arranged around eight aisles. People buy liquor here with shopping carts, strolling for specials through a store that is bigger than some supermarkets. This weekend, Mr. Goldberg - aided by 20 full- and part-time employees on overtime - has had to count every bottle and change the price on each one.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will The Yanks And Mets Do in 1989?
description: The Mets are headed for first place and the Yankees for the cellar. The Yankee pitching staff and infield is old and injured, while the Mets' only problem is choosing from all their great young players. MARC EDELMAN Merrick, L.I.

title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs
description: Arguing that anti-drug laws have stimulated organized crime without reducing narcotics abuse, a congress of politicians, lawyers, doctors, academics and police officers from a dozen Western countries has proposed the elimination of all prohibitions on drugs.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will The Yanks And Mets Do in 1989?
description: The Mets are a cinch to win even with Darryl Strawberry striking out in the clutch. The Yankees are a different story. With Dave Winfield apparently out for the season, this is the worst Yankee team in 70 years. When Ken Phelps figures to be their best home-run hitter and Andy Hawkins their best pitcher, you know they are in trouble. ROBERT MAYE New York

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Atlanta Center Reopens June 15

title: Too American?
description: To the Editor:

title: Harold Field Horne Jr., Executive, 72
description: Harold Field Horne Jr., former president of the Field Home, a senior-care center in Peekskill, N.Y., died of lung cancer Friday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: Con Beckers Wed To Valerie Asher
description: Valerie Anne Asher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Asher of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Cornelis Johannes Maria Beckers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fons Beckers of Oost Maarland, the Netherlands. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Andrew Kline, an Episcopal priest, at Woodend, an estate in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Japanese School Planned for Purchase
description: LEAD: MANHATTANVILLE COLLEGE in Purchase is looking forward to the next phase in its continuing program of ''intercultural education'' - the establishment of a high school affiliated with a prestigious Japanese university.

title: Other Reflections About Death Row
description: The March 12 article ''Reflections From Death Row'' (New Jersey Q & A) compels these observations.

title: Everybody's Doing It
description: To the Editor:

title: In Paris, a Love Affair Between New and Old
description: The French have always had a fondness for the word ''cohabitation.'' And surely no term more aptly describes the state of public architecture in this city right now, as I. M. Pei's glass pyramid in the center of the Louvre, the very symbol of the late 20th century's intrusion into classical Paris, opens not to the furor that was feared but to a general sense of relief. Almost nobody thinks of the pyramid as being as bad as its critics expected when the design was announced in 1984, and more and more Parisians seem willing to go further and say that the pyramid may even be worth admiring. It is fashionable now to believe that modernism can cohabit with classicism quite comfortably, and that the late 20th century may yet leave a positive mark on Paris.

title: The Technology That the U.S. Doesn't Want Japan to Have
description: SENATOR Jeff Bingaman, a member of a Congressional delegation that spent Easter vacation in Tokyo assessing the growing strain on American-Japanese relations, was blunt when a Japanese reporter asked him last week why the United States was reluctant to turn over fighter plane technology to its biggest Pacific ally.

title: The Ivy League Deserves a Bid
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Black Americans And the Work Ethic
description: Louise Simpson, the Long Island regional director of the N.A.A.C.P., offers a rather novel definition of the American work ethic [ ''Keeping the Dream of Justice Alive,'' Long Island Interview, March 12 ] .

title: A Balance of Bush, The Congress And the Contras
description: ''THE Constitution,'' wrote the great scholar Edward S. Corwin in the mid-1950's, toward the end of his long career, ''is an invitation to struggle for the privilege of directing American foreign policy. The power to determine the substantive content of American foreign policy is a divided power, with the lion's share falling usually, though by no means always, to the President.''

title: Reviews/Music; An Evening of Finnish Works Honors a Composer
description: Finns in New York came to St. Peter's Church to hear their own music on Thursday night. It was a program largely of and for Joonas Kokkonen, the 78-year-old composer, who was present among Thursday's large audience. We know Mr. Kokkonen first-hand through his opera, ''The Last Temptations,'' which the Finnish National Opera performed at the Metropolitan Opera six years ago.

title: Quake in Yellowstone
description: A minor earthquake was felt in Yellowstone National Park Friday but there were no reports of damage or injuries, officials said. The temblor, which measured 3.6 on the open-ended Richter scale of ground motion, came at 11 A.M. on the north shore of Yellowstone Lake.

title: Marta P. Fishman Wed to Executive
description: Marta Pearl Fishman and Gary Mitchel Flaum were married last evening at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan by Rabbi David J. Seligson.

title: Lady in Waiting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha Lowrey and Thomas Luz Wed
description: Martha Caroline Lowrey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Blackston Lowrey of New Orleans, and Thomas John Luz, a son of Mrs. Alan J. McCartney of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and John J. Luz of Amesbury, Mass., were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Dodwell and the Rev. Frank M. McClain, Episcopal priests, and the Rev. Stanley Klores, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Anne E. Murray To Wed in May
description: May wedding plans for Anne Elizabeth Murray and Paul Sergius Gambal have been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Yale Murray of Elmira, N.Y.

title: Matter of Quality Or Abolishment
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Robbins Magic: Characterization on the Move
description: A Broadway musical is not invariably directed by its choreographer. In ballet, however, the choreographer is always the director - responsible for the concept of the entire production, as well as coaching the performers into the desired interpretation from start to finish.

title: Q and A
description: A Leased-Land Co-op

title: The Roar of the Freeways
description: THERE is no point fighting Los Angeles, the vast metropolis where mountains meet ocean, cities meet desert, mirage meets reality and visitor meets confusion. Probably no American city is more intimidating to the traveler. The first reaction is to recoil from the broad roaring freeways, veritable Mississippi Rivers of moving steel and chrome, rushing off to everywhere and nowhere.

title: 30 Improper Strip-Searches Follow AIDS Rally Arrests
description: About 30 women arrested on minor charges in a demonstration over AIDS outside City Hall last Tuesday were subjected to unauthorized strip-searches by civilian matrons employed by the Police Department, police officials acknowledged yesterday.

title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds
description: LEAD: Twelve years have gone by since Paul Zindel's last new play, ''Ladies at the Alamo,'' reached Broadway and then hurriedly departed. In the time since, he expanded a shelf of widely admired novels for teen-agers. He settled in Beverly Hills with his wife and children and wrote movies. He turned out a gory-sexy Hollywood novel for grown-ups in the vain hope of reaping the economic rewards of best-sellerdom.

title: A Do-It-Yourselfer Builds Self-Esteem
description: IT was almost a religious experience. I opened the present, and there it was - a gift so perfect that I had no words to describe my delight. Resting in my own hands was a cordless combination drill/screwdriver complete with the accompanying bit set.

title: Charles S. Peckham, Political Consultant, 56
description: Charles S. Peckham, a retired political consultant, died of a brain tumor Friday at his home in Stonington, Conn. He was 56 years old. In 1975 and 1976, Mr. Peckham was director of field operations for the Republican National Committee. He was a consultant to Mayor John V. Lindsay and President Ronald Reagan. After he left politics, Mr. Peckham founded the American Musical Theater in New London, Conn., in 1984.

title: Reviews/Music; The Minnesota, in a Messiaen Aviary
description: The Minnesota Orchestra has long been one of this country's truly honorable second-rate ensembles. By that I do not mean a cruel dismissal, but a statement of fact: This orchestra has never challenged the American top five. But just below that level, it has proven fully capable of committed, deeply musical performances.

title: How to Extend a Monitor's Life
description: One way to prolong the life of a computer monitor is to dim or blank the screen when it is not in use. If an image is on screen for long periods of time, it can eventually ''burn in,'' resulting in a permanent ghost image on the screen or a loss of brightness in those areas. On some color monitors the problem manifests itself as ''brown-out,'' a muddying of the color.

title: Debra Fine Married To Martin Schneider
description: The wedding of Debra Fine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phil David Fine of Boston, to Martin Ivar Schneider, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schneider of Manhasset, L.I., took place last evening at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Boston. Rabbi Herman J. Blumberg and Cantor Jodi Lee Sufrin performed the ceremony.

title: Star Power Can't Propel All Vehicles
description: In ''A Strange Place to Meet,'' A French film recently shown at the New Directors/New Films series, Gerard Depardieu and Catherine Deneuve play a man and woman stranded for 48 hours at a rest station by the side of a highway, pacing nervously and exploring the essences of their very beings. They do this not because they have to, but because they can. Miss Deneuve and Mr. Depardieu, arguably France's two most bankable film stars, liked this material so much that they chose to co-produce ''A Strange Place to Meet,'' for reasons that will seem incomprehensible to anyone who sees it. Sometimes great success brings actors more discretionary power than they can comfortably use.

title: And What the Audience Did Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Personally Tailored TV
description: If you are missing televised ballgames you wish you'd seen, or William F. Buckley Jr. holding forth on the latest crisis, SmarTV can find them, tape them and play them back at your command. If you want, it will zap commercials, too.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the Prospects column last week mistakenly added a phrase to the comments of Edward S. Hyman, vice chairman of C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc., on the course of inflation. The sentence containing his prediction should have read: ''This means that by late 1990 inflation will be back down to 3 percent.''

title: 'LOOK! WE HAVE COME THORUGH!'
description: LATECOMERS By Anita Brookner. 248 pp. New York: Pantheon Books.

title: James A. Schmidt And Miss Bowden Wed in Greenwich
description: Deborah Worthington Bowden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Bowden Jr. of Oshkosh, Wis., and James Alan Schmidt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Schmidt of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. John W. Bishop officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are certain givens when it comes to memorable days in people's lives. One is a wedding day, which can be a preamble to happiness or misery but is rarely forgotten. Another is the birthday of a child, and still another could be the day of a lottery prize. As they say, it should only happen!

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Neal M. Rosen;
Surprises for a School Board Member
description: LEAD: On Tuesday, voters in about 550 of the state's school districts will vote on school budgets and elect candidates to local boards of education. Among the candidates will be Neal M. Rosen, who is seeking his second term on the East Brunswick board.

title: THE DUKE, THE KING AND THE CITY OF JAZZ
description: THE SWING ERA The Development of Jazz, 1930-1945. By Gunther Schuller. 919 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30.

title: 'SOY-SAUCE CULTURE'
description: SEEDS OF FIRE Chinese Voices of Conscience. Edited by Geremie Barme and John Minford. Illustrated. 491 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $25.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They are cold-blooded. They are completely ruthless about protecting what they have. The only thing they connect to is the money aspect of life. Let's face it: that's the American way.'' - Jeffery M. Johnson, regional chairman of the District of Columbia United Way, speaking of drug dealers. [ 25:1. ]

title: The Dilemma of 'Open Skies'
description: GLOBALONEY,'' SAID THE REPUB-lican Congresswoman from Connecticut. On a February afternoon in 1943, during the darkest hours of World War II, Clare Boothe Luce rose in the House of Representatives to blast the so-called ''open skies'' plan, which called for a free-trade system of international airline service after the war. Primed by Juan Trippe, president of Pan American World Airways, then the nation's only overseas airline, Luce declaimed:

title: A REMINDER
description: Daylight light savings time resumed today at 2 A.M. today. Clocks were set ahead one hour.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on Allendale, N.J., on March 12 misspelled the name of the Thonus Farm Estates condominium project and misstated the status of the community's two elementary schools, which serve Allendale alone.

title: Pseudoscience in Maine
description: Dale W. Lick, the president of the University of Maine, has become the latest public figure to borrow trouble by spouting pseudoscience on athletic differences between blacks and whites when social science would have sufficed.

title: Nicaraguan Opposition Forging Election Demands
description: Working under a deadline established by a regional peace accord, Nicaragua's opposition parties have begun intense negotiations on electoral demands that they say will form their minimum requirements for a fair vote in national elections scheduled for February 1990.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: CHERRY BLOSSOM RUN The Cherry Blossom 10-Kilometer Run, beneath a canopy of cherry trees, will be held next Sunday in Branch Brook Park in Belleville and Newark.

title: Lately, 'Early Music' Is Getting Much Later
description: The English conductor Roger Norrington, who was barely known outside of London just a few years ago, has become about the hottest commodity in classical music. One uses that word advisedly, since aside from awards for his Beethoven symphony performances on original instruments and the reams of journalistic copy he has inspired, his disks sell handily worldwide, challenging the sales of better-known maestros with brand-name orchestras.

title: AT SEA IN VOLUME THREE
description: FIRE DOWN BELOW By William Golding. 313 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: BLUE JAYS MAY BE THE STRONGEST OF A WEAK BUNCH
description: The following American League report was prepared and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in the predicted order of finish, with the Yankees picked fifth in the East. AMERICAN LEAGUE EASTERN DIVISION

title: Books, Beautiful And Rare, in Show In New Rochelle
description: LEAD: SIR THOMAS MORE'S ''Utopia,'' printed in 1518; Godey's Magazine and Lady's Book, a popular 19th-century periodical; ''The American Universal Geographer,'' compiled by Jedidiah Morse, the father of Samuel Morse, and the ''Story of Jack Halyard the Sailor Boy or, The Virtuous Family,'' a story about manners and morals published in 1827 -all are among the diverse books and periodicals assembled for ''The Past in Print: Exceptional Works From the Gill Library.

title: 11 Sites Awarded Restoration Grants
description: A 19th-century fishing schooner, a firehouse that looks like a French chateau, several Episcopal churches and a statue of Neptune are among the recipients in New York City of $2.1 million in historic preservation grants from a state bond act.

title: Mommy Track's an Idea Whose Time Has Gone; 'Parent Track'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba Seeks Better Latin Ties
description: As his affinity for Mikhail Gorbachev wanes, Fidel Castro is seeking to build better ties to Latin America.

title: HUNGARIANS CLAIM SUCCESS IN FUSION
description: Two Hungarian scientists have reproduced an experiment in which British and American scientists said they created nuclear fusion at room temperature, the Hungarian news agency, MTI, said today.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: If you don't like the umpire, just quit. That's what Viktor Korchnoi did at the Linares International Tournament, which began Feb. 18 in Spain.

title: A Taste of Glasnost in Sparta
description: ALTHOUGH 18-year-old Kristen Bennett, a Sparta High School senior, speaks Russian, and a Soviet student, Maria Agafonova, 16, of Moscow, speaks English, their first conversation at a recent reception here to begin an exchange program did not go smoothly.

title: Turning 12-Story Bank Into an Art Gallery
description: ANN VAN BUREN rarely ventures into the Midlantic National Bank building here, where her husband, Robert, presides as chief executive officer, but she has played a leading role in transforming the 12-story office building into one of New Jersey's largest informal corporate art galleries.

title: Correction
description: An obituary last Sunday about Julius Eichel, a conscientious objector in World Wars I and II, misstated the record of his imprisonment in World War I. He received a 20-year sentence in 1917 that was commuted after he spent 26 months in jail.

title: Franklin A. Korn, Telephone Researcher, 83
description: Franklin A. Korn, a Bell Telephone Laboratories researcher who helped create touch-tone telephones and the direct-dial long-distance system, died of kidney failure Friday at the age of 83.

title: Lily Zimmermann to Marry
description: Ambassador and Mrs. Warren Zimmermann of Belgrade, Yugoslavia, have made known the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Zimmermann to Charles Michael Metcalfe, a son of David P. Metcalfe of London and the late Alexa Metcalfe.

title: Admissions Process: Not Impersonal
description: After reading Alice Schultze's article ''The Waiting Game'' [ March 5 ] , I feel it necessary to respond as a person ultimately responsible for assessing over 10,000 applications per year. While I certainly empathize with Mrs. Schultze's frustrations, I would first like to commend her and her family for paying their dues to the college application process.

title: Ms. Quarngesser To Marry in May
description: May wedding plans for Ann Carson Quarngesser and Joseph Henry Gleberman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Harvey Gleberman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Isle of Palms, S.C., have been made known by the future bride's parents, Mary Ann Quarngesser and E. Stuart Quarngesser Jr., both of Baltimore.

title: 'I'm Not Rappaport': Park Bench Pathos
description: HERB GARDNER's Tony Award-winning comedy, ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' at the Arena Players Main Stage Theater in East Farmingdale, is the kind of play that lets us feel good for not doing anything about social problems.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have two doors in our house that keep closing by themselves when we leave them open. I have tightened the hinge screws and tried putting shims behind the hinges, but to no avail. Any idea how I can keep these doors from closing by themselves?

title: Beyond Savile Row
description: IT IS EARLY FRIDAY AFTERNOON ON MOUNT STREET IN the fashionable Mayfair section of London. Behind the window of a shop labeled ''Hayward,'' several impeccably attired men and women mill around talking animatedly. Moving among them as though he were the host at a cocktail party is the shop owner, Douglas Hayward, a London tailor known for his elegant styling, dazzling client list and relaxed, informal manner.

title: A Caribbean Communist Seeks New Friends
description: FIDEL CASTRO will undoubtedly be on hand to offer Mikhail S. Gorbachev an introduction to tropical Communism when the Soviet leader lands in Havana today. The greeting is sure to be warm, but it cannot disguise the ideological gulf that separates the Communist world's two most charismatic leaders -a source of insecurity for Mr. Castro that has led him to seek new ties, particularly in Latin America.

title:
THEATER;
The Trick to Writing a Play About the Homeless
description: LEAD: Seven weeks ago in front of the Plaza Hotel, brunch was being served al fresco. The owner of the Plaza, Donald Trump, was invited but didn't show up that Saturday. Yet some 1,200 homeless people did. They were greeted with a feast of chili, stir-fried vegetables, salads, breads and pies, all of which had been donated by restaurants and individuals.

title: Gorbachev's Hope: U.S. Bails Out Cuba
description: LEAD: It's tempting to think that Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to Cuba this week signals a major shift in Moscow's relationship with Havana. Certainly the Bush Administration, which privately has been urging Moscow to use its influence to curb Cuban and Nicaraguan support of subversive groups in Central America, is hopeful that Mr.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We've had the movie 'Wall Street' but this will be the drama Wall Street. It will have a tremendous impact on public attitudes and perceptions. If we have people telling their stories, it will be like John Dean telling Watergate.'' John C. Coffee Jr., Professor, Securities and Criminal Law, Columbia University, on the Milken case.

title: 43 Artists at Hudson Museum Examine 'Nature of the Beast'
description: PAINTED, sculptured and photographed by 43 artists, the animals now in residence at the Hudson River Museum were assembled by Barbara Bloemink, the museum's chief curator and its acting director.

title: Bethuel M. Webster, 88, Founder of a Law Firm
description: Bethuel M. Webster, the founder of Webster & Sheffield, a Manhattan law firm, died of complications from a throat disorder Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: FICTION
description: SMALL TALES OF A TOWN. By Susan Webster. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) A reporter down on his luck leaves Melbourne for a job in a lonely town on Australia's vast central plain. ''Some people came here on purpose,'' he decides, ''but for most it was by chance.'' He finds a spot on the staff of The Weekly Advertiser, a paper published every Thursday just ''to clean the presses,'' according to its editor. The Weekly Ad won't win any journalism prizes, but it's a great perch for a narrator who wants us to nose around town for interesting people. And we find them. The book's 25 stories - dispatches from a cultural outpost - re-create a year in the life of a collection of characters. The denizens at Molloy's Beer Garden plot against a rival town with a better football team. A socialist newcomer tries to transform the Kookaburra Cafe into the Engels Wholefood Community Co-operative. The narrator's mad-artist roommate walks around wearing a folded paper hat marked, ''Stetson - grey with red feather.'' The least successful chapters here are those that try for a neat moral or for pathos. Best are the comic tales: the case of the poisoned chicken sandwiches, the spirited search for an unknown lottery winner. Susan Webster, an Australian journalist, also gets us to understand something about life on the edge of a hostile landscape: that floods, firestorms and other catastrophes only plant a small town more firmly in the soil.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE STATE OMBUDSMAN'S OFFICE;
Without Question, It's Great to Have Contacts in High Places
description: LEAD: IT was the kind of problem that causes the temples to pulsate, the stomach to tighten, the palms to perspire with frustration. It was the kind of problem that can take a day, a week, a month or more - and countless phone calls - to solve.

title: Makers of 'Handmaid's Tale' Analyze a Grim Fantasy
description: On a serene street lined with stately homes, two futuristic fascists stand guard in navy blue uniforms. While across the road the wintry panorama resembles a Wyeth landscape, on this stretch the view is marred not only by these anachronistic sentries but by a machine gun mounted on sandbags as well. Nearby, a red octagon bears the image of an outstretched white hand: a stop sign for the illiterate.

title: INSIDE
description: Fear of Gorbachev Backlash

title: Penn Has Big Sweep At San Diego Regatta
description: Pennsylvania painted the 16th annual San Diego Crew Classic red and blue today, winning both the varsity and junior-varsity races in convincing style.

title: 40 Years Behind the Camera
description: LEAD: IN more than 40 years behind the camera, Elliott Erwitt has photographed almost everything and everybody everywhere: refrigerators, soaps and cars for advertising layouts, and heads of state, politicians and movie stars for newspapers and magazines.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DADDY. By Loup Durand. Translated by J. Maxwell Brownjohn. say a cliche, of the international thriller for decades. But although Gregor Laemmle, the main Nazi in ''Daddy,'' the French novelist Loup Durand's latest book, is brilliant, cultivated, fastidious, homosexual and a strong chess player - attributes that often connote depravity in fiction of this sort - he's no garden-variety villain.

title: Esposito Replaces Bergeron
description: April Fool's Day was less than 12 hours old, and Phil Esposito, a grim and uncomfortable general manager, was already weary of explaining to reporters that it all was no joke. With two days and two games to go in the regular season and the Rangers staggering into the Stanley Cup playoffs, Esposito today dismissed Coach Michel Bergeron.

title: THE ACCIDENTAL COLONY
description: IN OUR IMAGE America's Empire in the Philippines. By Stanley Karnow. Illustrated. 494 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: Correction
description: The Sound column in the Arts and Leisure section on March 12, about loudspeakers, gave incorrect list prices for Bang & Olufsen wall-hung models. Prices for the Beovox 3000 and 5000 speakers are, respectively, $348 and $548 apiece, not per pair.

title: Innovative Classics: Art Deco Furniture In the Paris Style
description: Robin Symes's collection of Art Deco lacquered or leather-wrapped furniture - the largest private holding of designs by the innovators Pierre Legrain and Eileen Gray - includes many classics of the Paris style. Most were made as prototypes or for major collectors between 1913 and 1930 and were acquired since 1972 by Mr. Symes, a London antiquities dealer.

title: Carolina Wedding For Miss Wellard And an Executive
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Cross in Bluffton, S.C., Caroline Keating Wellard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Wellard of Long Beach, Calif., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., was married yesterday to Thompson Dean 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Dean of Taipei, Taiwan, and Great Falls, Va. The Rev. J. Patrick Gray performed the ceremony.

title: DATA UPDATE: April 2, 1989

IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: REPORTS FROM THE HOLOCAUST: The Making of an AIDS Activist. By Larry Kramer. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) In the early days of his activism on AIDS, Larry Kramer's friends told him, ''You get more with honey than with vinegar.'' Mr. Kramer ignored their advice; during the next 10 years, from 1978 to 1988, he was strictly hemlock.

title: Time-Share Industry at the Crossroads
description: WHEN Mabel Souder of Houston got word not long ago that a new management was running the Gulf Coast resort where she and her husband, Frank, had a one-week share of a vacation condominium, she called to find out if her maintenance fees were going to change.

title: 'Profscam'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Barnard Looks Ahead With a Retrospective
