description: It was just like old times, someone commented at the opening of the Dance Uptown retrospective on Wednesday night at the Minor Lathem Playhouse at Barnard College. And indeed it was, in a number of ways.

title: NONFICTION
description: ELECTION JOURNAL: Political Events of 1987-1988. By Elizabeth Drew. (Morrow, $19.95.) The Presidential election of 1988 offered one of the most unedifying spectacles in the American political panorama. Unfortunately, Elizabeth Drew's ''Election Journal'' reflects much of the tedium of that dismal campaign. The book is a collection of columns written for The New Yorker between Dec. 6, 1987, and Dec. 1, 1988. As such, it has serious limitations. It suffers from its subjects, the seven Democratic candidates and the handful of Republicans who entered the race. With so many people to cover month by month, characterizations are necessarily glib. Michael Dukakis is arrogant, Albert Gore is immature, Paul Simon is naive, George Bush is whiny, Jesse Jackson is an angry anti-Semite. Whatever their usefulness when they were written, these snapshots are of limited utility or interest now. Although the book probably should not be blamed for the inevitable limitations of its format, it is an effort to drag the mind back to many of the events covered here. Every now and then there is a discussion with some meat: Gary Hart's willful self-destruction, Michael Deaver's relationship with the Reagan White House, Mr. Bush's character or lack of it. When she allows herself to be a bit discursive, Ms. Drew can be interesting. And one of her points bears repeating: George Bush won the highest office in the land with a campaign of extraordinary amorality. The lesson of his victory, she writes, ''is that the way to win is to go on the offensive against your opponent early, distort positions to whatever degree you can get away with, play upon people's fears and prejudices - and never let up.''>

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Loyalty to Antiques in Ontario
description: LEAD: WALTON STREET, the main street of Port Hope, Ontario, spills down to the Ganaraska River in an effortless line of Victorian commerical buildings. It's one of Ontario's handsomest streetscapes, and it's also home to more than half a dozen antiques shops that fit very naturally into this house-proud 19th-century town.

title: Trying to Swim in the Newstream
description: OVER THE PAST FIVE years, in talks with executives and lower-echelon employees in dozens of American companies, I have been hearing the sounds of change. The application of entrepreneurial principles to the traditional corporation is producing a far-reaching revolution in business management - in the structure of the corporation (leaner), in its relationships with its suppliers and customers (closer) and in its treatment of employees (rewards tied to performance).

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Thomas Berry;
The Good Earth: Examining the Odds
description: LEAD: AS Thomas Berry sees it, there is some bad news and some good news about the prospects of the survival of the earth.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Philadelphia
description: The Philadelphia of most visitors' imagination is the 18th-century city of Federalist buildings and tidy green gardens around Independence Hall. But there is another historic Philadelphia that has much more to do with the modern city. This is the 19th-century city around Rittenhouse Square, a Victorian enclave about a mile to the west of the Colonial shrines. What the Rittenhouse area lacks as an obvious tourist pathway it more than makes up in stylish residences, the city's toniest shops, several choice museums and galleries and a number of the restaurants that have made Philadelphia one of the nation's more palatable destinations.

title: An Also-Ran in the Cargo Trade
description: THIRTEEN TIMES A WEEK, LUFTHAN-sa's Boeing 747 freighters lift off from New York's Kennedy International Airport and from the bustling international airports of Chicago, Los Angeles and Atlanta. Bound for Frankfurt and Cologne, the world cargo hubs of the West German national carrier, the planes are loaded with American products - electronics, aircraft engines, oil equipment, thoroughbreds. An additional 34 Lufthansa flights a week carry shipments in Boeing 747 Combis, aircraft that can accommodate cargo loads on the main passenger deck as well as in the limited space of the belly.

title:
ART;
The Poetic and the Visual
description: LEAD: THE current main exhibition at the Jersey City Museum, entitled ''The Mirror in Which Two Are Seen as One,'' brings together under one roof eight artists whom one has never thought of together. The upshot of this is a kind of enchanted exhibition.

title: A Flexible Test For Private Schools
description: Certainly, those of us on the other side of the competitive school entrance-admission procedure can empathize with the feelings of Alice Schultz and Linda B. Martin (''The Waiting Game: Student Is a Pawn'' and ''S.A.T. Exams: One Size Doesn't Fit All,'' March 5).

title: NONFICTION
description: XIANG LAKE: Nine Centuries of Chinese Life. By R. Keith Schoppa. (Yale University, $30.) In this carefully researched, scholarly work, a chronicle of the Xiang Lake reservoir in China's Zhejiang province from its creation in 1112 to the present, R. Keith Schoppa promises to show the lake as the stage for ''grand battles between filiality and betrayal, obligation and irresponsibility, loyalty and surrender, chastity and impurity, and civic virtue and private greed.'' In fact, much of the Xiang Lake story necessarily revolves around subjects that will prove rather dull to all but the specialist: reclamations, irrigations and encroachments; pumps, dikes and canals. Mr. Schoppa, who teaches history at Valparaiso University, shows how influential families, who sought to drain the lake for profit, competed with local peasants, who depended on it for irrigation. Today, there remains only a large canal for the use of the town of Xiaoshan, a polluted industrial satellite of the city of Hangzhou. ''Xiang Lake'' is attractively presented, with each chapter representing a ''view'' of the lake and occasional, charming poetry scattered throughout. But the occasional dramatic tales of Japanese pirates, Taiping Rebellion devastations and Red Guard rampages are too occasional to sustain the interest of the general reader. Perhaps a lake cannot be an effective dramatic central character after all.

title: Toronto Choral Festival
description: The 1989 International Choral Festival, to be held in June in Toronto, is to present more than 4,000 artists from around the world during a monthlong series of concerts. The Soviet conductor Gennady Rozhdestvensky will lead the Polyansky Choir of Moscow and the Obretenov Choir of Bulgaria at the gala opening concert on June 1 in Roy Thomson Hall. Other conductors participating in the festival will be Robert Shaw, Charles Dutoit and Elmer Iseler.

title: THE VIEW FROM GLASNOST
description: LEAD: PERESTROIKA 1989 Edited by Abel Aganbegyan. 346 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. Paper, $14.95.

title: Believe It or Not, Joy Lies Ahead
description: IS it the hand of the Almighty meting out retribution for past transgressions? Is it the whim of the Fates, waving capriciously in my humble direction? No matter. The results are still the same. From lofty heights we tumble, from soaring peaks we fall. Just when you think it is safe to go back to hoping and dreaming, they get you again.

title: OVER EL GRECO'S SHOULDER
description: You have to know Spain and love it - or want to - to appreciate Michael Busselle's LANDSCAPE IN SPAIN (New York Graphic Society/Little, Brown, $24.95). His photographs of the Spanish countryside, accompanied by a text by Nicholas Luard, the author of ''The Wildlife Parks of Africa,'' include 120 scenes, but not the kind you will see through the window of a tourist bus. Mr. Busselle's pictures seem more like artistic renderings of landscapes and scenery than objective views of moments captured by a camera's eye. Some are reminiscent of Impressionist works. The clouds in the brooding ''Castle of Santa Catalina'' look painted; it is not hard to imagine that El Greco's angels could feel at home in that sky. Like the country of Spain itself, some of Mr. Busselle's images can puzzle and the subjects can be elusive. These works impart no sense of time or place; not even Mr. Luard's detailed but mostly incidental commentary can clarify them. Is another picture a close-up of moss growing on a rock, or an aerial view of a mountain cliff with the greenery miniaturized by the distant perspective? All this is intriguing. Are we looking at glimpses of a Spain that is, or once was, or never was - that exists only in the minds of artists who try to interpret it in their art? As Spain once comprised many different kingdoms and still takes its regional differences in custom and language seriously, perhaps this enigmatic view is appropriate. After all, this is a land where many perspectives conflict and confound.

title: Mets Look Very Strong But Not Invulnerable
description: Keith HERNANDEZ, one of the question marks, reflected on the question marks confronting the Mets after a so-so spring training and said: ''I like what we have. We'll be fine. Good pitching, it always keeps us in games.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Summer Fireworks Help Finding good summer help is a problem on Long Island, whether your business is parks or pyrotechnics. ''We're looking for the more sophisticated type of person,'' said Felix Grucci Jr. of Fireworks by Grucci. ''We can't have any felons or pyromaniacs.''

title: New York
description: Considering the current status of fashion sales in this country - ranging from fiasco to flat to slightly improved but rarely sensational -who knows what women want? As a result, almost all of New York's top talents are veering away from adventure and sticking to their familiar formulas.

title: Miss Lichter Wed To Haran Rashes
description: Laurie Ann Lichter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul R. Lichter of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married there last evening to Haran Craig Rashes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Rashes of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Lake Bomoseen, Vt. Rabbi Robert Dobrusin performed the ceremony at the Michigan League.

title: SHE MADE A MAN OF HIM
description: LOVING WOMEN A Novel of the Fifties. By Pete Hamill. 414 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WIND. By Leigh Allison Wilson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Leigh Allison Wilson's first collection of short stories, ''From the Bottom Up,'' was firmly rooted in the rural east Tennessee of her childhood. And at the core of its rich ''country melody of salvation'' beat ''the heart of a believer.'' Her second collection, ''Wind,'' which skims with a colder, more calculating prose across a desolate upstate New York, opts instead for unbelief.

title: Ridgefield Dollmaker Creates Brides With a Past
description: SHE stands just 19 inches high and is regally dressed in a high-necked, silk taffeta bridal gown, clasping her bridal bouquet. Nicknamed Rosie, she is a bride doll with a past. Rosie was created by Diane Smoler as a gift for her husband. The doll looks very much like his mother, Rose, did on her wedding day in 1910.

title: Oil Slick Sullies Beach On 2 Hawaiian Islands
description: At least 10,000 gallons of oil from a mystery spill have soiled beaches on two Hawaiian islands.

title: THE THIRD WIFE MAY BE THE CHARM
description: HIS THIRD, HER SECOND By Paul Estaver. 245 pp. New York: Soho Press. $17.95.

title: Automobile Insurance Debate Intensifies
description: THE automobile insurance hearing was intended as an explanation of the Joint Underwriting Association, specifically its $2.9 billion deficit and the $222 annual charge that policyholders pay now to bail it out.

title: LEARNING TO LOVE INFLATION
description: BALANCING ACTS Technology, Finance and the American Future. By James K. Galbraith. 265 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Namibia Rebel Clash Is Reported As Independence Transition Starts
description: The beginning of the transition to independence for Namibia, Africa's last colonial territory, was marred by a serious clash overnight along the border with Angola.

title: STREETSCAPES: St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church; A Touch of the English Countryside in Manhattan
description: IT'S a sight to make a preservationist's blood run cold - heavy scaffolding suddenly going up around a 119-year-old church in an area that has been proposed, but not yet accepted, for landmark designation.

title: Fuzzy Computer Theory: How to Mimic the Mind?
description: For a quarter of a century, Lotfi A. Zadeh has been preaching an obscure computer theory with a funny name: fuzzy logic. Although Dr. Zadeh's ideas have been largely ignored in this country, his theory is finding practical uses in Japan.

title: Headliners; Getting a Forum
description: If Michael R. Milken had been a corporation, his earnings of $550 million in 1987 would have ranked him 65th, just ahead of McDonald's, on the profits list of the nation's 500 largest publicly held companies. Last week, fortunes changed for the 42-year-old executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., who transformed corporate America by pioneering the use of high-yield ''junk bonds'' in corporate takeovers. In the largest criminal action against a Wall Street figure, a Federal grand jury indicted Mr. Milken and two co-defendants on 98 counts of violating securities and mail fraud laws, insider trading, making false statments and racketeering. Vowing to fight the charges, Mr. Milken said, ''After almost two and a half years of leaks and distortions, I am now eager to present all the facts in an open and unbiased forum.''

title: THE WORLD: Montazeri's Evolution; An Heir Is Gone
description: AYATOLLAH Hussein Ali Montazeri, the Iranian cleric who last week was stripped of his designation as successor to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, had undergone a political transformation in the last two years.

title: Reviews/Music; An Overview of Vocal Songs by Elie Siegmeister
description: Elie Siegmeister celebrated his 80th birthday in January, and to mark the occasion, some of the performers who have been among his most devoted interpreters over the years are offering overviews of the composer's work.

title: Math Is Only New When the Teacher Doesn't Get It
description: IN the early 1970's, when I was a graduate student in mathematics, I helped teach elementary college math courses to students who were just out of high school, fresh from that failed experiment in education called the new math. What struck me was their peculiar habit of writing the symbol for the empty set, a circle with a line through it, instead of the number zero.

title: Correction
description: A photograph on March 5 with the New & Noteworthy column was published in error. It showed the poet and scholar Benson Bobrick, not Todd Gitlin, author of ''The Sixties: Years of Hope, Days of Rage.''

title: METS ARE STRONG AGAIN, PADRES ARE STRONG AT LAST
description: The following National League report was prepared and written by Murrary Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish, with the Mets for first place in the East. NATIONAL LEAGUE EASTERN DIVISION

title:
GARDENING;
Tomatoes That Please the Tastebuds
description: LEAD: BESIDES its traditional red, tomatoes come in pink, orange, yellow and even white. Tomato fruits also come in a variety of forms and sizes.

title: Needed: A Price Tag For State Plan
description: WE all need to set priorities and goals. State government, just like a business or a household, sets those priorities based on the limitations of its budget.

title: Insurance Fund Wins Support
description: During the last year, the Westchester Weekly has published numerous stories about local opposition to the proposed HELP II projects and about the Nimby - not in my backyard - factor. Though Mount Vernon and White Plains have agreed to build housing for the homeless in their communities, Westchester is losing the battle against homelessness, and the housing crisis is getting worse.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Pssst! Here's How to Empty the Nest
description: LEAD: IT is evident that the time has come for parents to band together to hire a marriage broker for their children. Too long have 26-year-olds who ''haven't found themselves yet'' filled their parents' empty nests. Too often have 27-, 28- and 29-year-olds stalked the singles scene in search of suitable spouses.

title: Palestinian Killed by Troops And Another Dies of Wounds
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian today in a clash in the village of Bethany in the occupied territories, and another reportedly died of wounds inflicted by Jewish settlers, the army and Arab hospital officials said.

title: Correction
description: An article on March 12 about the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester misstated its financial problems. The orchestra projects a deficit of $6,500 for its current season, not $30,000, and has a carryover deficit of $7,000 from previous years.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will The Yanks And Mets Do in 1989?
description: The Yankees will be lucky to play .500 and finish fourth. Without Dave Winfield, Jack Clark, and Claudell Washington, their offense will be anemic. Opponents will pitch around Don Mattingly, who will lead the league in intentional walks. The team's pitching is a joke.

title:
FOCUS: Los Angeles;
Signs of a Renaissance Emerge in Watts
description: LEAD: TWENTY-FOUR years after the flames of rioting made Watts a national symbol of inner-city frustration and decay, the district is beginning to attract new, and more welcome, attention.

title: Rye Is Handing Out Boxes to Promote Recyclng Paper
description: LEAD: BLUE boxes specifically designated to hold discarded newspapers will be distributed in Rye this week in an effort to encourage recycling.

title: HIGHER FINES URGED IN MEDICARE CASES
description: The General Accounting Office has urged Congress to increase the monetary penalties the Government can impose against doctors for ''gross and flagrant'' mistreatment of Medicare patients.

title: As Computer Bulletin Boards Grow, If It's Out There, It's Posted Here
description: Some 18 months ago, Liz Goldwyn Selisky, a 29-year-old graduate student who lives in Coudersport, Pa., met Julian Ares, a 29-year-old graduate student in Chicago, while she was browsing through a computer bulletin board. Since then, she said, ''he has turned out to be one of my best friends even though I've never met him nor even heard his voice.''

title: THE TYPEWRITER MADE ME DO IT
description: LEAD: In 1967, I decided to become a poet. I was then living in Kolin, a small town in Czechoslovakia, so I was going to become a Czech poet. I was 14 years of age, so I was going to be a major Czech poet. To the time and the place, a poet appeared to be a kind of an instrument, a medium of the Czech language.

title: Satire's Their Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title:
MUSIC;
Another Side Of Mitch Miller
description: LEAD: MENTION Mitch Miller's name, and the 1960's television show ''Sing Along With Mitch'' probably comes to mind. Better known for his ventures in popular music, Mr. Miller has had a long career that includes work as a classical conductor and an oboist and as a record company executive.

title: CRIME
description: It takes one to know one - a cop, that is - and William J. Caunitz, a former detective lieutenant with the New York Police Department and the author of two previous best sellers (''One Police Plaza'' and ''Suspects'') about his trade, does a nice job in BLACK SAND (Crown, $18.95) of showing us that cops are cops the world over.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 2, 1989
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $5.95.) A Congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 9 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 3 23 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 4 9 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.50.) The jealousies and rivalries of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 5 5 THE LAST PRINCESS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Berkley, $4.95.) A socialite sacrifices a family fortune and a wealthy fiance to marry for love. 6 6 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrager's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 7 18 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 8 4 THE HELLION, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $4.50.) Two decades later, love returns to a pair of former high school sweethearts, she an elegant widow, he a fast-track hell raiser. 9 4 A KINGDOM OF DREAMS, by Judith McNaught. (Pocket, $4.50.) A Scottish schoolgirl abducted by a roguish English duke in the 15th century. 10 1 SILVER TOWER, by Dale Brown. (Berkley, $4.95.) The superpowers edge toward high-tech war in the Middle East in 1992. 11 4 PRIVILEGED LIVES, by Edward Stewart. (Dell, $4.95.) A New York cop investigates murder and strange goings-on among the rich and famous. 12 3 ROBOT ADEPT, by Piers Anthony. (Ace, $4.50.) A fantasy about two parallel warring worlds, one of science, the other of magic. 13 9 THE CHARM SCHOOL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $4.95.) An American tourist in the Soviet Union stumbles on a K.G.B. plot. 14 4 KING OF THE MURGOS, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) The second volume in the fantasy saga ''The Malloreon.'' 15 3 THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (Warner, $5.95.) Turmoil and rebellion in 19th- century Ireland. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 4 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society. Q 2 45 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. Q 3 284 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. Q 4 15 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Warner, $5.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. Q 5 15 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $8.95.) A ''new science'' that makes it possible to see order and patterns in what appears to be erratic. Q 6 42 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The ways in which mythology illuminates the stages of life. Q 7 9 ALMOST GOLDEN, by Gwenda Blair. (Avon, $4.50.) The rise and fall of the television anchorwoman Jessica Savitch. Q 8 9 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) Ways in which companies can survive. Q 9 7 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Vintage, $12.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. Q 10 5 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Ballantine, $14.95.) A history of the American Civil War era. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous Q 1 2 YUKON HO! by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. Q 2 36 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people. Q 3 6 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Ivy, $4.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. Q 4 2 GARFIELD CHEWS THE FAT, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $6.95.) More cartoons about a fat cat. Q 5 4 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $4.95.) A physician's preventive medicine program. Q 6 * 12 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1989 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title:
ART;
The Spiritual Side of Art
description: LEAD: THE most discernible change in art over the past decade is not in style or medium; rather it is the willingness to let in a certain kind of content. Previously, the spiritual side of art was not dealt with publicly, or else it was left to an esoteric few. Now, perhaps prompted by a major show a couple of years ago which brought to light the spiritual in all 20th-century art, it is everywhere.

title: Rise in Child Abuse Tied to Drugs
description: LEAD: THE number of reports of child abuse and neglect in the county has more than tripled since 1979, according to figures from the Child Protective Services office of the County Department of Social Services. While some of this increase may be the result of more people reporting suspected cases, the most important factor is increased drug abuse, officials say.

title: From the Garden to the Table
description: CHARD or Swiss chard, is a vegetable with which many people are barely acquainted. There are those who might be able to recognize it in the market but who have rarely cooked or eaten it. For many shoppers, it's just another of those mysterious bunches of green.

title: Devils Can't Match Sundstom's Efforts
description: In a season of discontent, three of the players who survived and may figure prominently in next season's plans for the Devils are natives of Sweden: Patrik Sundstrom, Tom Albelin and Anders Carlsson.

title: U.S. Asks Syria to Curb Group Tied to Terrorism
description: The United States has asked Syria to curb the activities of a Palestinian organization based in Damascus because of the group's involvement in terrorism, State and Defense Department officials say.

title: Mommy Track's an Idea Whose Time Has Gone; Attitudes to Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Calling for a Redesign Of National Security
description: IN the summer of 1949, the Soviet Union exploded its first atomic bomb and Communists came to power in China.

title: Molokai Oil Spill Cleaned Up
description: A cleanup crew has finished scrubbing oil from a 10-mile stretch of Molokai Island's shoreline, but it will take at least three more weeks to clean soiled beaches on nearby Lanai, the authorities said today. The Coast Guard has yet to determine the size or source of the oil spill, but it appeared to be at least 10,000 gallons, said Keith Spangler, a Coast Guard spokesman.

title: Bergner Makes Offer to Buy Carson Pirie for $282 Million
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago-based retailer, said today that it had received a $282 million takeover offer from its Milwaukee-based competitor, P. A. Bergner & Company.

title: Purchasers Say Growth Is Slowing
description: LEAD: The nation's economic growth in March was the slowest in three years, a monthly survey of the nation's purchasing managers concluded.

title: GORBACHEV BEGINS HIS VISIT TO CUBA WITH CASTRO'S HUG
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Cuba tonight to an effusive welcome from one of his prickliest allies, Fidel Castro.

title: SmithKline and Beecham in Talks
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation and the Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that they were discussing a merger that would create one of the largest drug and health-care companies in the world.

title: Renewed Pride for Seton Hall
description: The last time there was a celebration like this at the home of Nick Werkman was 26 years ago, after word arrived that Barry Kramer of New York University had failed to score the 31 points he needed against North Carolina in the final game of the season to overtake the Seton Hall junior for the national scoring title.

title: Alaskan Oil Industry Cancels Its Campaign
description: An advertising campaign for the Alaskan oil industry was canceled last week by companies and industry groups, as a disastrous oil spill in Prince William Sound began blackening beaches and wildlife. ARCO Alaska, B.P. Exploration and the Alaska Oil and Gas Association pulled the broadcast and print ads, which criticized an Alaskan State Government proposal to curtail tax incentives for oil production.

title: 5,000 Protest a Bronx Housing Plan
description: Members from 100 churches thronged into a rubble-strewn lot in the South Bronx yesterday to rally against a city plan to build subsidized condominiums there.

title: Robin Kalish Is Married
description: Robin Joy Kalish, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Kalish of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Frank Kozakawiecz Jr., a son of Mae Kozakawiecz of Albany and the late Mr. Kozakawiecz. Rabbi Richard Sobel officiated at the Canfield Casino. The bride, a graduate of Ithaca College, is an internal auditor for the People's Bank in Bridgeport, Conn. Mr. Kozakawiecz, a graduate of Oswego College, is an assistant trader for Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York.

title: Bridge
description: The Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes began Saturday, with the women's team taking an early lead. After 70 deals of play at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan and the French Bridge Federation's Club in Paris, the women were ahead by 60 imps. But during the night, the men surged into the lead and had a 144-imp advantage after 196 deals.

title: Inkster Wins Dinah Shore
description: Juli Inkster went wire-to-wire as the leader, easily winning the 19th annual Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament today by five shots for her third major championship.

title: Ms. Rosenbaum Has a Wedding
description: Caryn Susan Rosenbaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving W. Rosenbaum of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to Glenn Joel Wolff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin I. Wolff of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Irwin Isaacson officiated at the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center in Queens.

title: New Equipment Enables Alaska to Intensify Cleanup
description: The task of dealing with oil spilled from the grounded tanker Exxon Valdez turned today from defending a handful of fragile bays to more active efforts to clean up Prince William Sound.

title: PRETORIA SUSPENDS THE DEMOBILIZING OF NAMIBIA FORCE
description: South Africa today suspended the scheduled demobilization of its territorial forces in Namibia as new clashes were reported between paramilitary police units and guerrillas said to have infiltrated across the border from Angola.

title: Ageless Players for an Ageless Game
description: Tommy John was supposed to be out to pasture by now. As Dallas Green, his manager on the New York Yankees, put it: ''How many 45-year-old guys are cranking up to play opening day? How many are just plain cranking up? Half of them have trouble getting out of bed.''

title: Washington Talk: Exact Words; 'Watchfires of a Thousand Points of Light'
description: Concluding the final skit at the Gridiron Club dinner Saturday night, a performer and chorus sang this song, ''The Bush Battle Hymn'': Mine eyes have seen the glory of a kinder gentler land, With a cop on ev'ry corner and a gun in ev'ry hand. Tiny tots in public schools will pledge allegiance on command, George Bush is in command. Swift and certain prosecution, merciful electrocution, All within the Constitution, Bob Bork will understand. As soon as he is ready, we'll find steady work for Quayle, We'll send him off to Boston with a shovel and a pail. When he's cleaned up Boston Harbor so the summer folk can sail, We'll send Dan Quayle to Yale. Better, broader education, that's our highest obligation, But we owe it to the nation to start with Danny Quayle. You will see me in the watchfires of a thousand points of light, Peggy Noonan said, ''Just say it and the folks will think you're bright.'' Perhaps she meant the message sent on TV ev'ry night: A thousand sounds of bite. Sis-boom-bah and hallelujah, Eli Yale will boola-boo ya, Read my lips so I can rule ya. You gotta read them right. I've proclaimed a kindly gospel to protect me from defeat. I picked Tower 'cause I always have admired an ath-e-lete. But look at all the wholesome folks the Senate didn't beat: Th' establishment elite. Boola, boola, hallelujah, don't let Congress try to fool ya. Gentle George is gonna rule ya. Being President is neat.

title: Facing Up to a Clean-Air Plan
description: As Southern California grapples with cleaning up air pollution, businesses here face having to make many major changes, from eliminating aerosol sprays to changing the way bakeries make bread.

title: Campaign Matters; Studious Giuliani Crams Eagerly For His Big Test
description: The education of Rudolph W. Giuliani began last August with a book, ''The Ungovernable City.''

title: 7 FALL TO DEATH
description: The section of a concrete highway bridge over the Hatchie River collapsed Saturday night, killing at least seven people.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Wall Street is continuing to feel pinched, after a period of mega-profits. Brokerage houses say their earnings have been tightly squeezed by high interest rates, continuing investor wariness and a decline in the number of big merger deals. [ Page A1. ] Wall Street found Michael R. Milken's income more stunning than the news that the ''junk bond'' pioneer had been indicted. A number of financiers and executives say his huge compensation, $550 million in 1987 alone, highlights enormous and disturbing changes in the financial markets and corporate America. [ D1. ] The Group of Seven committed itself to a stable dollar while expressing concern over recent gains. Economic officials of the U.S. and its leading allies indicated they would act to prevent further rises, and they supported a foreign debt policy proposed by Treasury Secretary Brady. [ D1. ] The Bush Administration has come to a view shared by most allies: taxpayers must assume more of the potential cost of relief to indebted countries. News analysis. [ D5. ] The economy grew in March at its slowest pace in three years, the nation's purchasing managers reported. Advance word of the report set off a rally in Treasury bond prices on Friday. [ D1. ] New York's Assembly will vote on a bill that would allow banks to charge credit-card customers penalties for late payments. [ B2. ] THE MARKETS First-quarter gainers in the stock market reflected a wide array of industries, with airline operators, software makers and energy-related companies posting higher prices. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT The first quarter was full of surprises in foreign markets. Several markets that expected to do well, like those in Japan and West Germany, did not, while others exceeded predictions. [ D6. ] Mexicans cheered the announcement that the state's telephone monopoly plans a $14 billion overhaul. Service is so inefficient, bribery is so widespread and complaints are so numerous that the Government has begun to view Telmex as a barrier to growth. [ D6. ] COMPANIES SmithKline Beckman and Beecham are discussing a merger that would create one of the world's largest drug and health-care companies. SmithKline Beckman is ''in play,'' said one analyst, who valued the company at close to $10 billion. [ D1. ] Carson Pirie Scott received a $282 million takeover offer from P. A. Bergner. The retailer said the bid was unsolicited. [ D7. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Bertelsmann has become the world's largest media company and the kind of formidable global power against which a merged Time Inc. and Warner Communications would compete. [ D8. ] Retail mergers have brought sweeping changes to department store advertising. Long-term image promotions are diminishing in favor of short-term cut-price ads. [ D8. ] Young American, a monthly for 8- to 14-year-olds, has moved into schools across the country. [ D8. ] Fox Broadcasting has made another gamble, betting that viewers will watch prime-time movies on Mondays. Television. [ D8. ] Backer Spielvogel Bates announced a changing of its guard. Robert H. Lenz, an executive with creative credentials, will succeed its chairman. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Bidders for Time Inc. might be more likely to emerge if the tax implications of a merger were less costly. Market Place. [ D4. ] A feud over money paid to settle insider-trading charges is pitting two financiers-turned-felons and the I.R.S., on one side, against the S.E.C. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Suddenly, skies are sunny over the credit markets. The deep pessimism of two weeks ago is almost gone. Credit Markets. [ D5. ]

title: Firearms Market Thrives Despite an Import Ban
description: Although an indefinite ban on importing five popular types of military-style semiautomatic rifles last month aroused intense public interest, gratification and opposition, it hardly dealt a lethal blow to the ownership and use of such guns.

title: West Coast Is Cooking With Solar Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Underestimate Anti-Semitic Soviet Fringe; Not the Czar's Heirs
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Tax Snags Facing Time Inc. Bidders
description: THE dust had hardly settled on news that Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. had agreed to merge before reports surfaced that the Robert M. Bass Group of Texas might enter the fray with a bid for Time. At the height of the rumors, Time stock went as high as $122 a share, but it closed Friday at $115.875.

title: Allegheny Case Ruling
description: Allegheny International Inc. must file a detailed disclosure statement for its latest reorganization plan by April 21 or must move for the appointment of a trustee who will assume the responsibility, Judge Joseph L. Cosetti of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh ruled late Friday.

title: Ultraorthodox Perils
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Publishers Collaborate On a Book About Refugees
description: They number nearly twice the population of New York City, but they roam the world - some 14 million refugees driven from their homes by warfare in places as far flung as Guatemala and the Sudan, Sri Lanka and Iran. And they are increasing, human rights workers report.

title: Gary Lakes, Lost to Sports, Is a Wagnerian Gain
description: The pool of first-rate Wagnerian singers has always been small, and the number of viable Wagner heroic tenors, the kind that can encompass Tristan and Siegfried, is smaller still. Thus whenever a new specimen of that endangered breed turns up, the operatic world takes notice.

title: Yankees Talk With Gossage
description: While Manager Dallas Green pondered an opening-series lineup without Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield yesterday, General Manager Syd Thrift pursued the possibility of bringing Rich (Goose) Gossage back to the Yankees.

title: Dr. Max Fine, Pioneer In Corneal Transplant
description: Dr. Max Fine, an ophthalmologist who performed the first corneal transplant in the West in 1939 and trained many leading corneal surgeons, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Mt. Zion Hospital and Medical Center in San Francisco, where he lived. He was 81 years old.

title: Ms. Raiser Is Wed To Donald Bacon
description: At the Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass., Jennifer Magdalene Raiser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Raiser of San Mateo and Carmel, Calif., was married yesterday to Donald Davis Bacon, a son of Emery F. Bacon of Washington and Key Biscayne, Fla., and the late Helen Hotham Bacon. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Israeli High Court Is Asked To Reopen Demjanjuk Case
description: The lawyer for John Demjanjuk, the retired Cleveland autoworker convicted of Nazi war crimes, has asked the Supreme Court to reopen the case, asserting that new evidence shows that the three-judge panel at the trial was biased, court officials said today.

title: Review/Dance; Movement as a Mystery Without Program Notes
description: ''Between Movement and Light,'' which Russell Dumas presented Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, was curious for a reason that had nothing to do with its choreography. This was one of the few dance events I have ever attended for which there was no printed program whatsoever. That was somehow appropriate, for just as the program did not exist, so the dance scarcely existed.

title: Review/Recital; Caballe in 4 Languages
description: Montserrat Caballe sang the music of 11 composers from 4 centuries in 4 languages at her Avery Fisher Hall recital Friday night. But it really didn't matter. Miss Caballe has her own way of singing just about everything, so that Handel, Pacini, Debussy and Massenet passed through her sensibilities and came out sounding remarkably alike. The Handel arias from ''Semele'' and ''Rinaldo'' had a Bellinian languor, while a little later Miss Caballe's drawling, hesitational delivery in Debussy's ''Beau Soir'' might just as well have been Puccini. Indeed, her rolling elisions, bright sforzato attacks and scooping accents discriminated against no one and were democratically applied.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 3, 1989: MONDAY Carolina Frt Corp Nevada Pwr Co Central Vt Pub Svc Corp Travelers Corp TUESDAY Cummins Engine Inc Pacific Ent Ohio Mattress Co Weiss Mkts Inc WEDNESDAY Houston Ind Inc Neiman-Marcus Grp Inc Hunt Mfg Co Phelps Dodge Corp Mercantile Stores Inc Rite Aid Corp Murphy Oil Corp Southwestern Energy Co THURSDAY Amax Inc General Pub Util Corp Amer Water Wks Inc WR Grace & Co Conagra Inc Puget Sound Pwr & Lt Co Freeport McMoran Sun Inc FRIDAY U S West Inc

title: Political Memo; Big Oil Spill Leaves Its Mark On Politics of Environment
description: The environment, a peripheral political concern for most of the Reagan era, has been pushed to the center of public attention over the last year by a series of highly publicized environmental disasters, culminating in the oil spill in Prince William Sound. The nightly images of oil gobs against stark natural beauty seem sure to herald a newly aggressive phase in environmental politics.

title: Washington State Becomes 36th With National Primary
description: Washington on Friday became the 36th state with a Presidential primary, leading to hopes for a regional set of primaries that would attract candidates to the Pacific Northwest.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President Is Also Chief At Smith International
description: LEAD: Douglas L. Rock has been elected chief executive officer of Smith International Inc., an oilfield service company that specializes in drilling systems. The president and chief operating officer of Smith since it emerged from bankruptcy proceedings last year, Mr. Rock will retain those titles as well.

title: Unofficial Verdict
description: Although the Government's case against Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom is not expected to go to the jury until Wednesday, the Court Buffs of Chicago, a cadre of local court watchers, have already reached an unofficial verdict about what might happen to the two agents. Issue No. 13 of their newsletter, released last week, proclaims:

title: Natalie Dejoux Wed in Florida
description: Natalie Grace Dejoux and William H. Brinckerhoff were married yesterday at the Palm Beach, Fla., home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Grace. The Rev. Robert Pollard, an Episcopal priest, and Judge Gavin Letts, of the Florida Court of Appeals, officiated.

title: Bear, Stearns Newcomer Bullish on Municipals
description: Robert A. Gerard, who has joined Bear, Stearns & Company as a senior managing director in its municipal finance department, says he is ''fairly bullish'' on the prospects for the municipal bond market.

title: Role Finally Fits for Gaze
description: The numbers were sending a message to Andrew Gaze, and the message was not good. For most of his 23 years, he had been raised in the traditions of basketball as it is played in Australia, in a more offensive game, with more opportunities to score and therefore less urgency with each possession.

title: Metro Datelines; 2 Children Are Killed In House Fire on L.I.
description: Two children died and five people were injured after a frame house caught fire, Nassau County fire officials said yesterday.

title: 1,000 Urge Legalizing of Drug
description: A blue cloud of marijuana smoke drifted over the University of Michigan campus today as about 1,000 high school and college students took part in the 19th annual Hash Bash, a rally seeking the legalization of marijuana. No one was arrested, but 15 people received tickets for possession of marijuana, a misdemeanor for which there is a $5 fine, said Capt. Gary Kistka of the Ann Arbor Police.

title: Medical Billing Faces Challenge by Insurers
description: Employers and the Government are beginning to challenge methods some doctors and hospitals use to get around limits on fees.

title: For Want Of Jet Work, Many Hurt
description: When the Pentagon canceled a program in December to upgrade the A-6 attack bomber, made by the Grumman Corporation, the company said it would cut 2,500 jobs on Long Island by the end of this year. But the fallout did not end there.

title: 41 Held in Bronx Cockfight, And 23 Roosters Are Seized
description: The police seized 23 roosters and arrested 41 people yesterday at an illegal Cuban social club in the Bronx where cockfights were being held.

title: Leaders in West Bank Called to Meet Israeli
description: Israeli occupation authorities in the West Bank summoned leading Palestinian figures to a meeting today, and the Palestinians said they had been forced to attend.

title: Sparks Fly in Catskills Over Fantasyland Plan
description: A group of developers would like to turn part of the Roundout Valley here into a 17th-century fantasyland - a European Williamsburg, complete with sound-and-light shows, a costumed Robin Hood and his Merry Men and its own equestrian school.

title: Smith Burke & Azzam Sees More Defections
description: Smith Burke & Azzam in Baltimore, which lost 11 employees to a rival agency last month, is on the verge of losing two more. Tom Amico and Jim Proimos, a creative team at the agency, said Friday that they were planning to leave to establish their own firm in Baltimore. The two are New York-bred copywriters whose work for Maryland Developmental Disabilities, a state agency, won a silver medal at last year's International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes.

title: Some Steps Backward for Health
description: THE experts have long contended that what raises humans above other animals is the ability to reason. But if the experts were ever to see the annual backward mile race at Battery Park they might conclude that man's unique trait is really an ability to deliberately seek out activities that make him look foolish.

title: Steelworkers Vote to End Strike in Alabama
description: Workers voted overwhelmingly today to end their two-day-old strike at a steel plant. Dozens of police officers had guarded against a flareup of picket line violence that led to two arrests and several minor injuries.

title: Steve Fisher and His Resume
description: THE big fear about giving the Michigan job to Steve Fisher is that he's too gentle. This is, after all, a man who listens to his wife when she tells him to chill out.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Construction Spending Feb. Tuesday Car Sales March Wednesday None Thursday Wholesale Trade Feb. Friday Employment March Consumer Credit Feb.

title: Ex-Panther in Prison Says Evidence Was Concealed
description: A former leader of the Black Panther Party is seeking to reverse his conviction 16 years ago on charges of machine-gunning two policemen, contending that prosecutors concealed evidence that could have exonerated him.

title: The Drug Czar's Ideas Are a Bust
description: LEAD: The drug czar, William Bennett, recently told Meet the Press that one of his interesting new policy ideas was to focus a major portion of law enforcement attention on the casual users of drugs. We have been thus far unable to do much about the large-scale drug dealers, he said, so it's time to go after the consumers.

title: End to Beer Breaks at Brewery
description: The Jones Brewing Company has eliminated twice-daily beer breaks for its employees.

title: Portable Water Packs For Athletes on the Go
description: Fitness experts advise athletes to take along water to drink while exercising outdoors. The Nachson Kibbutz in Israel manufactures pouches and packs to carry drinks that come with an optional drinking hose attachment for athletes on the go.

title: A Telephone Overhaul in Mexico
description: A few months ago, officials at the Ministry of Communications and Transportation placed a notice in newspapers here. It said they were unable to continue operations because several of their telephone lines were out of order - some for as long as two months. Telefonos de Mexico, the state telephone monopoly, had ignored requests to repair them, the notice said.

title: Drug Link Reported
description: Representative Peter H. Kostmayer, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee who visited Haiti last week and spoke with the United States Embassy there by telephone this afternoon, said he understood ''it was a drug-related coup, not a political or ideological coup.''

title: Kite Charges Into the Masters
description: NAME the golfer who was born and still lives in Austin, Tex.; tied for the 1972 N.C.A.A. individual championship while playing for the University of Texas team; amassed a fortune as one of the most consistent players on the PGA Tour since he was a pro rookie in 1973, and has entered the Masters as a definite threat to win every year for the past decade.

title: Topics of The Times; More for the National Closet
description: The Smithsonian Institution is a funny red castle on the Mall in Washington, full of whatnots from America's past. More than that, it's a monument - to the average American's inability to throw anything away.

title: A Gala Send-Off Into the Season
description: The Mets and Yankees treated New York to a second straight day of full dress rehearsals yesterday, and the Mets even treated the Yankees to a second straight victory as the teams rang down the curtain on spring training.

title: Dual Celebration for Harvard
description: For Harvard, the weekend was perfect. On Saturday night, the hockey team won the national championship, and today, the team's captain, Lane MacDonald, was awarded the Hobey Baker Memorial Trophy as the sport's outstanding college player this season.

title: For 'Sarafina!' Cast, Life Without Apartheid
description: There was no doubt that the going-back worry would come up. During their 19 months in the United States, the cast members of ''Sarafina!'' have learned that the going-back worry always comes up.

title: Namibia Guerrilla Spokesman Denies Infiltration
description: The South-West Africa People's Organization denied today that clashes over the weekend in northern Namibia involved guerrillas infiltrated over the border from bases in Angola. But it acknowleged that guerrilla sympathizers in Namibia may have been attacked by South African territorial forces and responded in self-defense.

title: Police Officer Dismissed for Notches in Gun
description: A police officer who killed three people in seven months was dismissed Friday after notches were found carved on his pistol.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You can be happy on a lot less money.'' - Donald J. Trump, commenting on Michael R. Milken's 1987 income, $550 million. [ D4:5. ]

title: Officials Debate Asylum for Chinese Fleeing Abortion Policy
description: An immigration judge here has brought to light a conflict inside the Justice Department by granting political asylum to a man who asserted that he fled China after his wife was forced to have an abortion.

title: Bigger Taxpayer Role on World Debt
description: In dealing with the debts of Mexico, Venezuela and other developing countries, the Bush Administration has come to the opinion already shared by most of its allies: taxpayers must assume more of the potential cost of giving the countries some relief.

title: 63% of Freed Prisoners Are Jailed Within 3 Years, U.S. Study Finds
description: Nearly 63 percent of the inmates released from state prisons were arrested for a serious crime within three years, the Justice Department said in a study released today.

title: Leverett Edwards, Labor Mediator, Is Dead at 87
description: Leverett Edwards, a labor relations expert who for many years helped avert or settle national railway and airline strikes, died yesterday at Harris Hospital in Fort Worth after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived in Fort Worth and Oklahoma City.

title: Group of 7 In Warning On Dollar
description: Top economic officials of the seven biggest non-Communist industrial countries said today that a further rise of the dollar could undermine their efforts to keep the world economy sound, and they sent a warning that if the markets persist in pushing the dollar up, they were prepared to try to stop them.

title: Quotas' Cost Estimated
description: The Federal Trade Commission said Friday that a staff study had estimated that the voluntary quotas on imported steel, cars and textiles and apparel cost American consumers $20.9 billion annually. It said this translated into about $120,000 for each job protected by the three voluntary import quotas.

title: Fox Broadcasting's Successful Gambles
description: LAST month the Fox Broadcasting Company agreed to run movies in prime time on Monday evenings between May and September. It was an offbeat bet on building a fourth network by doing precisely what the three television networks refuse to do.

title: Soviets Buy More Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 350,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery in the 1988-89 marketing year that began on Sept. 1, the third purchase last week, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Orders totaling one million tons of corn were reported earlier. Moscow has been buying United States wheat regularly under an export subsidy program, but this week's sales are the first significant corn purchases since Jan. 4.

title: Heading Off Hospital Gridlock
description: In New York as elsewhere, drug abuse and AIDS are creating chaos in urban hospitals -enough to threaten not only the quality of life but life itself. That forces urgent, painful decisions on strapped city and state governments. If the need for action is desperate, so is the need for careful planning and administrative ingenuity.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Take a Tip From the Pros
description: LEAD: GOLF'S touring pros are notorious lesson-takers.

title: Darjeeling Journal; For Gurkhas, Little Time to Stop and Sip the Tea
description: To travelers who once flocked here, before the violence began, these dark hills splashed with crimson rhododendron facing the snow-clad peaks of the eastern Himalayas seemed a flawless setting for a good life high above India's torrid Gangetic plain.

title: Review/Dance; What a Company Does and Doesn't Do
description: The virtues of Nancy Meehan's choreography lie not merely in what she does, but also in what she does not do. Cliches are never in sight - in either her ideas or in her movement images.

title: My Critic's Cloudy Vision
description: I want to set the record straight on Janet Malcolm's recent and wrongheaded two-part New Yorker series. Her ''reflections'' on the reporting technique I used in ''Fatal Vision'' - my book about the convicted murderer Jeffrey MacDonald - and on journalists' ethics in general stray far from reality. Let's look at the facts.

title: Rise in Rates Expected to End
description: The deep pessimism that hung over the credit markets just two weeks ago has almost evaporated. And as the second quarter gets under way, most analysts appear convinced that the steady upward rise in interest rates over the past year is coming to an end.

title: Oil Supplier Warns of Cuts
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company has told its customers for crude oil that it might not be able to meet its delivery schedules for Alaskan crude because of shipping delays at Valdez and might consider cuts in shipments.

title: India Is Reportedly Ready to Test Missile With Range of 1,500 Miles
description: Indian scientists are preparing to test a long-range ballistic missile that would vastly enhance the country's military and political power, Indian and Western military experts say.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an entry in the Executive Changes listing in Business Day on March 22, about World Color Press, misidentified its parent company. It is Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company; the former owner was Pace Industries.

title: In Cincinnati, Rose Casts A Shadow
description: At Riverfront Stadium the groundskeepers, in a light drizzle, were cleaning the red track around the artificial-turf field, buffing, in ascending levels, the 52,392 blue, green, yellow and red seats and sweeping the aisles for Monday's game, the baseball season opener between the hometown Reds and the world champion Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Review/Television; A New Ingredient, Race, Spices a Formula
description: Now in college, Stephanie, Monique and Adam are still as close to one another as they were as children when they were known as the three musketeers. Nothing very startling about that. But there is something new in this particular television mode: Stephanie and Monique are white; Adam is black. And they are part of a daytime soap opera, the television genre that has been noticeably, sometimes notoriously, reluctant to integrate its generally very white and very middle-class suburbs.

title: Party on L.I. Celebrates Latin Adoptions
description: After her only child was killed in a car accident at the age of 5, Mary Ann Morales wanted desperately to have another baby. ''I just never conceived again,'' she said. She and her husband, Ray, began an agonizing search for a child to adopt.

title: The Gridiron; Bush and Quayle Join In an Evening's Ribbing
description: At his first appearance as President at the annual Gridiron Club dinner, George Bush was lampooned in songs and skits Saturday night by journalists who consider themselves Washington's media elite. Mr. Bush answered with some barbs of his own and a bit of self-effacing humor.

title: Daniel N. Jackson Married To Claudia M. Marbach
description: Claudia M. Marbach, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Marbach of New York, and Daniel N. Jackson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Jackson of London, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Marc Angel, Jacob J. Schacter and Abraham Levy at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NATURAL RESOURCES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Maryland Finds It Hard To Define Illegal Guns
description: A board set up to decide what handguns may be sold in Maryland has found it is not all that easy to define just what guns to control.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TV Notes
description: A Final Offer

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Sullivan Wins by 1 Shot: Mike Sullivan had a sudden change of travel plans yesterday after shooting a final-round seven-under-par 65 for a one-shot victory in the $800,000 Independent Insurance Agent Open at The Woodlands, Tex. Sullivan's first PGA Tour victory since 1980 earned him a trip to next week's Masters at Augusta, Ga. Sullivan started the day seven strokes off the pace, but shot five birdies over a six-hole span starting at No. 8. After finishing with a 72-hole total of 280, he sat in the clubhouse watching his challengers fall. Craig Stadler, who led after 12 holes, shot a 70 to finish second at 281. Seve Ballesteros, who moved into contention with a long eagle putt on No. 13, double bogeyed No. 15 and finished with a 72 for 282 and a tie for third. Also at 282 were the third-round leader Mike Donald, who had a final 74, and Mike Reid, who shot a 70.(AP) RUNNING Pihalaja Takes 10-Kilometer Race: Gradon Pihalaja of the Central Park Track Club won a 10-kilometer run yesterday in Central Park. Pihalaja finished in 31 minutes 6 seconds, beating his teammate, Dave Evans, by 125 yards. Evans, who crossed the line in 31:53, was four seconds faster than Paul Friedman of Nike. Stephanie Kessler of the Atalanta Track Club was the women's winner in 38:27. Gillian Horovitz of New York was runner-up in 39:10.(AP) Clark Sets Record in 100-Mile Run: Rae Clark of Santa Clara, Calif., set a meet record yesterday in winning a 100-mile run at Flushing Meadow Park. Clark finished in 12 hours 12 minutes 19 seconds easily beating the mark of 12:56:34 set by Stu Mittleman in 1982. Forty-one men and nine women competed in the Metropolitan Athletics Congress event. Roy Pirrung of Sheboygan, Wis., the 1987 champion, was a distant second in 13:15:50. He was followed by Tom Possert of Brownsville, Ind., in 13:44:28. Christine Gibbons of Elmwood Park, N.J., won the women's run in 16:41:26. Antano Locs of Montreal was second in 18:27:07, followed by Supradha Schecter of Washington in 20:30:40.(AP) AUTO RACING Gant Ends Streak: Harry Gant ended a 90-race, four-year string without a victory as he dominated the TranSouth 500 at Darlington Raceway in South Carolina yesterday. Gant, 49 years old, picked up the 28th victory of his Winston Cup career, driving his Oldsmobile Cutlass across the finish line 1.31 seconds ahead of the Ford Thunderbird of Davey Allison. Gant dominated the last half of the 367-lap event on Darlington's 1.366-mile oval, but had to fend off a challenge from Geoff Bodine and Allison in a three-lap sprint following the final caution period.(AP) DOG SHOW Greyhound Is Best: Dr. Elsie Neustadt's 2 1/2-year-old greyhound bitch, Ch. Rudel's Red Queen of Wonderland, was piloted by Richard Bauer to best in show yesterday at the Riverhead Kennel Club's 38th all-breed show in Southampton, L.I.

title: Youth Paper Expanding Amid Debate
description: With the dispute over television advertising in the classroom still fresh, Young American, a monthly for 8- to 14-year-olds, has moved into schools across the country.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Now that Pete Rose is retired as a player, which player still active is closest to Rose's major league record total of hits for a career?

title: It Need Not Be Too Late to Learn and to Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: The Year for an Unlikely Champion
description: Who, in all honesty, would have thought on Nov. 19, when the college basketball season began, that Seton Hall and Michigan would be playing for the national championship on April 3?

title: Plans Sought for Eastern
description: The unsecured creditors committee of Eastern Airlines has asked that all investors interested in buying the airline present their plans when its 15 members meet tomorrow, a spokesman for the pilots' union at Eastern said yesterday.

title: Wages Even Wall St. Can't Stomach
description: The indictment last week of Michael R. Milken stunned even the most jaded Wall Street professionals - not for its legal implications, but for its revelation of the income paid to the ''junk bond'' pioneer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: international A2-9 Mikhail Gorbachev arrived in Cuba to an effusive welcome and a bear hug and kisses from one of his prickliest allies, Fidel Castro. Mr. Castro clearly hoped to dispel any impression of friction. Page A1

title: Atlanta Finds Economy in Slowdown
description: After reveling in runaway growth for most of the decade, Atlanta is contemplating something quite different: an economic slowdown.

title: Books of The Times; Dazzy Makes His Case, and Other Baseball Tales
description: Baseball Anecdotes By Daniel Okrent and Steve Wulf 356 pages. Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: Assembly Is Expected to Pass Bank Credit-Card Penalty Bill
description: The Assembly is expected to give final approval Monday to a bill that would allow New York banks to charge credit-card customers penalties for making late payments and for exceeding their allowable limits.

title:
photos of P.J. Carlesimo (pg. C1); Glen Rice (NYT/Blake Sell) (pg. C4) SCOUTING REPORTS;
A Tale of 2 Underdogs
description: LEAD: Seton Hall and Michigan, the teams in tonight's final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I basketball tournament, were seeded third in their respective regional tournaments. They have proved that (a) national polls are inaccurate, (b) there is great balance in collegiate basketball, (c) teams playing their best at tournament time make the polls an academic exercise, (d) all of the above.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills, and Thursday's auction of new one-year bills.

title: Off He Goes, Into the Blue Yonder of Legend
description: He has been everywhere and done it all, and perhaps in the process done as much for the morale of the Air Force as anyone. Now Col. Steve Canyon, the comic strip hero, is retiring with full military honors.

title: Don't Underestimate Anti-Semitic Soviet Fringe
description: To the Editor:

title: Franklin A. Korn, Telephone Researcher, 83
description: Franklin A. Korn, a Bell Telephone Laboratories researcher who helped create touch-tone telephones and the direct-dial long-distance system, died of kidney failure Friday. He was 83 years old.

title: Bozell Wins John Silver's
description: After seven rocky months, Long John Silver's has left the Richards Group in Dallas for the Dallas branch of Bozell.

title: Business and the Law; I.R.S. vs. S.E.C. On Insider Funds
description: AFTER admitting in 1986 that they had improperly traded on insider information, two investment bankers paid $15 million - the amount of illegal earnings - to the Government. Now a legal scramble for the money between two Federal agencies and investors and shareholders has made its way to an appeals court.

title: British M.P.'s Form Caucus to Advance Rights of Minorities
description: Nonwhite members of Parliament inaugurated a legislative caucus over the weekend with the aim of advancing the political, economic and social interests of black people in Britain.

title: Tennessee Coasts to the Title
description: No matter where the ball landed or how the game shifted, Tennessee kept driving toward the national championship with a resolve that Auburn found tantalizingly tough to match. Auburn would make one step, Tennessee would make two. Auburn would leap toward the rim, Tennesee would leap toward the roof.

title: Sununu's 'Different Template'
description: A joke is told in politico-economic circles, attributed to Robert Strauss, about the unhurried deliberation - or lack of necessary urgency - that characterizes the Bush Administration.

title: What Now in Afghanistan?
description: For nine years, Washington's aims in Afghanistan were not difficult to grasp or support. The Soviet Union had invaded a nonaligned neighbor to impose an unwanted regime on a fiercely independent people. Arming an indigenous resistance made moral and political sense even at the cost of letting Pakistan's armed forces channel weapons to favored guerrilla leaders.

title: Rangers Reel Into Playoffs
description: The playoffs always wipe the slate clean. The Rangers, who once thought this regular season would be so marvelously memorable, are now only so glad to forget it.

title: Retailers Concerned About Shift in Ad Strategies Brought by Mergers
description: Recent retail mergers have created sweeping changes in department-store advertising, prompting cut-price advertising with short-term effects at the expense of image promotions with long-term impact. The shift is leading to growing fears that Americans will become wandering bargain hunters rather than shoppers loyal to a particular store.

title: Successor Is Named For Anchor Banker
description: The Anchor Savings Bank, one of the largest savings institutions in the New York area, will have a new chief executive, James M. Large Jr., at the end of the month.

title: Senator Shifts On Bush Plan
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee has proposed a major change in how the Bush Administration's savings-bailout plan would borrow the $50 billion needed to shut down 500 insolvent savings and loan associations, a committee official said today.

title: Rape Victim Is Forced Off Roof
description: A 29-year-old Harlem woman was raped Saturday and forced to jump naked from the roof of a housing project, but saved herself by grabbing wires and dangling above the 18th floor until neighbors could grab her.

title: Some Trouble in a River City
description: The groundskeepers at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati were cleaning the field and buffing the seats yesterday in preparation for the baseball season opener today. It was almost business as usual as professional baseball prepared to open another season in the place where it began in 1869. Yet in Cincinnati and elsewhere, it was not quite usual.

title: Washington Talk: Congress
description: When Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was Speaker of the House, he held court in the cloakroom and entertained on the golf course. He was a storyteller and a schmoozer, a walking, talking case study in gregarious Irish charm. Wherever Tip O'Neill was, members clustered. There was the draw of power, to be sure, but there was also simply Tip.

title: Topics of The Times; Let a Smile Be Your Umbrella
description: Umbrellas can do many things. If they're big enough they can keep you dry, and if you're small enough they can act like spinnakers. If they blow out they can leave you drenched, and if they lose the little caps over their spokes they can deliver a nasty gash. Extended closed, they can turn into lances. Extended closed and handle first, they can trip the fleeing pickpocket. But until recently they couldn't give anybody a good laugh.

title: Sihanouk Agrees to Return to Cambodia Talks
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian opposition leader who earlier this year withdrew from talks about his country's future, announced today that he had agreed to return to the negotiating table.

title: INSIDE
description: Battle on Medical Bills Employers and the Government are challenging the ways some doctors and hospitals get around limits on fees. Page A15. An Economic Domino Effect When a bomber program was canceled, the Grumman Corporation said it would cut 2,500 Long Island jobs.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
An Imposing Rival for Would-Be Time Warner
description: LEAD: At the oval wooden table at which Bertelsmann A.G.'s managing board meets here, the place of the chairman, Mark Wossner, is distinguished only by a large pad of plain white drawing paper on which to map corporate strategy.

title: Metro Datelines; 3 Men Shot to Death In Separate Incidents
description: Three men were killed in shootings in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Harlem, including an armed robber who was shot to death by an off-duty police officer as he attempted a street robbery, the police said yesterday.

title: Nedda H. Logan, 89, President Of the Actors' Fund of America
description: Nedda Harrigan Logan, an actress who was the president of the Actors' Fund of America for the last 10 years, died of lung cancer Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89 years old.

title: Stocks That Rose in Quarter Outnumbered Losers 2 to 1
description: Stocks advanced in the first quarter in a wide array of industries, including airline operators, software makers and energy companies.

title: Vandalism at Student Paper That Printed Attacks on Israel Special to The New York Times
description: The office of a student newspaper that printed anti-Israel editorial was aprayed-painted with graffiti Friday by vandals who broke a double glass window, campus security officials said.

title: Las Vegas Journal; Nevada Draws the Line: No Hitler in the Casinos
description: Ever sensitive about their city's reputation, business leaders here are glad the Engelstad affair is finally over. Ralph Engelstad, a casino and hotel operator, agreed recently to pay $1.5 million in fines and damages and promised not to hold any more birthday parties for Adolf Hitler.

title: Global Stock Markets Rose in First Quarter Amid a Few Surprises
description: The first quarter of 1989 has been marked by some surprises in foreign stock markets.

title: A Mountain Waterway Becomes Unable to Support Trout Life
description: To the Editor:

title: How Much Is Too Much to Pay To Meet Standards for Smog?
description: As economists and environmental scientists consider the drastic measures that will be required if the nation is to meet smog reduction goals, many are coming to a conclusion they would once have considered unthinkable: the effort may not be worth it.

title: Arafat Is Elected President Of State He Hopes o Form
description: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was elected president of the self-proclaimed Palestinian state today by the P.L.O. central committee.

title: History and Arcana
description: He has been so closely associated with boxing that it's easy to forget that Bert Sugar, the former editor of Ring magazine and the new owner of the revived Boxing Illustrated, is a man of many sports.

title: Metro Datelines; Muslims Celebrate Drug Patrol Progress
description: More than 1,500 Muslims in New York City met at the Penta Hotel Saturday night to celebrate their progress in ridding their communities of crime and drugs, especially crack, and to call on the city to help them increase their efforts to confront other problems.

title: Haiti, From Duvalier's Exile To Most Recent Coup Report
description: Feb. 7, 1986: In the face of anti-Government rioting, President Jean-Claude Duvalier, ruler of the country since 1971, flees with his family into exile in France. His departure ends 28 years of dictatorship that began with his father, Francois Duvalier. A three-man junta led by Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy takes power. Feb. 10, 1986: A 19-member Provisional Government is formed that includes some prominent Duvalier supporters. The regime dissolves the National Assembly. March 29, 1987: Voters overwhelmingly approve a new Constitution that puts elections for a president and National Assembly in the hands of a civilian election commission. Nov. 2-4, 1987: Headquarters of the election commission are gutted by fire. Violence drives the commission into hiding after it rejects a dozen Duvalier associates as presidential candidates. Nov. 29, 1987: On election day, gunmen kill at least 34 voters and confiscate ballots. The election is called off three hours after it begins. General Namphy dissolves the election commission. In protest, Washington suspends $70 million in aid. Jan. 17, 1988: Leslie F. Manigat, a professor who spent most of the Duvalier years in exile, is chosen President in an election with a small voter turnout. He is inaugurated on Feb. 7. General Namphy becomes commander-in-chief. June 14, 1988: Mr. Manigat places General Namphy under house arrest. June 19, 1988: Troops loyal to General Namphy storm the palace, deposing Mr. Manigat, who escapes to the Dominican Republic. General Namphy declares himself President. Sept. 11, 1988: Nine people are killed and 77 wounded and a Port-au-Prince church run by a dissident priest is burned as soldiers look on but do not intervene. The opposition blames General Namphy. Sept. 17, 1988: General Namphy is ousted in a coup. Sept. 18, 1988: Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, chief of the Presidential Guard and a former Duvalier adviser, declares himself President. March 13, 1989: General Avril partially restores the suspended 1987 Constitution. March 27, 1989: The United States says resumption of aid depends in part on Haiti's efforts to crack down on the narcotics trade. March 29, 1989: Four high-ranking army officers accused of drug trafficking are dismissed. April 2, 1989: Gunfire breaks out at the presidential palace. Reports from Haiti say General Avril foiled an attempted overthrow.

title: Mets Extend Ojeda's Contract
description: The Mets continued to anchor their long-range pitching yesterday when they extended Bob Ojeda's contract for three years for a total of $4.6 million, and then turned to the business at hand: opening the new season this afternoon in Shea Stadium against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Devils Reflecting On a Lost Season
description: Cinderella lost her magic at midnight, it took the Devils a bit longer, but they lost their's, too. A year after they made the playoffs for the first time and came within a game of reaching the Stanley Cup finals, the Devils missed the playoffs entirely.

title: Triple-Double for Jordan
description: Michael Jordan, playing point guard for the 13th straight game, had his fifth consecutive triple-double and ninth of the season as the Chicago Bulls defeated the Nets, 106-95, today.

title: Kansas City to Vote on Return To a Strong Role for Mayor
description: If Kansas City residents do as expected Tuesday, they will put more power in the hands of one man than anyone has exercised here since the days of the legendary Tom Pendergasthalf a century ago.

title: Tokyo Scandal: Public Disgust Soars
description: In the space of a few days, Japanese police have raided several Government offices, jailed a number of civil servants and industrialists and deepened speculation about the involvement of the nation's current and former Prime Ministers in the country's biggest political and financial scandal in years.

title: Surging Prevails In Comely Stakes
description: Surging, who fell back from first to third place at the top of the stretch, regained the lead at the furlong pole and then held off Nite of Fun to win the $87,150 Comely Stakes for 3-year-old fillies yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Cinematheque Honors Spielberg
description: The American Cinematheque honored the director Steven Spielberg on Saturday night at its fourth annual Moving Picture Ball here. The event, which raised $400,000, was held at the Century Plaza Hotel.

title: Why Israel Cannot Talk With the P.L.O.
description: LEAD: In his visit to Washington this week to present his ideas on advancing the peace process, Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, will come under great pressure to recognize the Palestine Liberation Organization and to agree to negotiate with it.

title: B.S.B. Names New Chief For U.S. Unit
description: BACKER SPIELVOGEL BATES announced a long-expected changing of the guard on Friday, promoting an executive with creative credentials to succeed its chairman, G. Robert Holmen.

title: Barrages Wither Both Sectors of Beirut
description: A withering hail of shellfire, rockets and mortar bombs blasted the two sectors of Beirut today in one of the most ferocious barrages of the 14 years of periodic civil strife in Lebanon.
