title: Wall Street, in a Slump, Rethinks Its Business
description: Wall Street, once awash in mega-profits, is now having to cope with a very dry spell. As the first quarter closed last week, executives from an array of brokerage houses voiced the same complaint: their profits have been tightly squeezed by high interest rates, continued investor distrust of the stock market and a paucity of big merger deals.

title: Outdoors: Tips for Surf Fishermen
description: WITH rare exceptions, there is no official opening day for striped-bass angling and none for bluefish, and without a specific starting date, one tends to put off getting salt-water gear refurbished and in order.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in SportsMonday last week about the Montreal Canadiens incorrectly described the team.

title: Esposito Examines Role
description: The dramatic intrigue had been put in motion, and the cameras were rolling. Phil Esposito, having dismissed Michel Bergeron and taken over as coach of the Rangers, stood behind a tangled bouquet of microphones Saturday afternoon at a crowded news conference in Pittsburgh.

title: Tackling Everest on Artificial Foot
description: TO hear Tom Whittaker tell it, scaling Mount Everest will be no fun at all. ''It's like being a slave on a Roman galley,'' said Whittaker, a 40-year-old native of Wales who lives in Pocatello, Idaho. ''The reality is that you're up at 2 in the morning, you load up with 35 to 45 pounds and walk for 6 hours, drop your load and rehydrate and set off back down the mountain as quickly as you can.''

title: L.I. Teen-Ager Charged With Killing His Mother
description: An 18-year-old Long Island youth was charged with stabbing his mother to death this weekend during an argument over a bounced check, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bedford Associates Inc., Norwalk, Conn., an information technology consulting concern that is a subsidiary of British Airways P.L.C., appointed Richard D. Bulman president and chief operating officer.

title: Albany Sees Tentative Pact On New Taxes
description: New Yorkers would pay higher taxes on purchases including cigarettes and co-op apartments under a plan tentatively agreed to by the state's legislative leaders.

title: Court Plan Foe Will Challenge Yonkers Mayor
description: Councilman Henry Spallone, the most outspoken critic of a housing desegregation plan that has preoccupied this city in recent years, declared his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for mayor.

title: He Prowls English, Stalking New Words
description: Inside the vast domain of the English language, David Barnhart is a kind of linguistic astronomer. He peers into the expanse of usage, looking for the glimmer and shine of previously uncatalogued words and expressions.

title: Minority Voices Rise in Reshaping Charter
description: In New York City, where more than half of the residents are black or Hispanic, only 9 of the 35 seats on the City Council are held by members of minority groups. Only 2 of the 11 votes on the Board of Estimate belong to elected officials who are black or Hispanic.

title: Daley Pinning Mayoral Hopes On Party Ranks
description: His pockets stuffed with campaign buttons and a bundle of fliers clutched in his left hand, Pete Andrews was stalking voters in his southwest side neighborhood Saturday, walking door to door and spreading the gospel of Richard M. Daley, Democrat.

title: Wall Street, in a Slump, Rethinks Its Business
description: Wall Street, once awash in mega-profits, is now having to cope with a very dry spell. As the first quarter closed last week, executives from an array of brokerage houses voiced the same complaint: their profits have been tightly squeezed by high interest rates, continued investor distrust of the stock market and a paucity of big merger deals. If these conditions persist, they say, more layoffs and cutbacks will be inevitable.

title: Islanders Defeat Rangers, 6-4
description: Phil Esposito's Rangers continued to crumble last night, backing their way into third place despite the 11th-hour coaching change that was supposed to give the floundering franchise a jump start.

title: Salvador Judge Clears Ex-Officers And Others in Five Kidnappings
description: In a setback for United States policy here, a judge has dismissed all charges against politically well-connected former military officers and civilians accused of running a right-wing kidnapping ring.

title: Making the Grades
description: Colleges kept hiring Mark Brodie to play basketball and Brodie kept flunking out.

title: New Jersey Skeptical on Bid For Casino Gaming License
description: Officials of the Atlantis Casino Hotel made a last-ditch effort today to keep its gambling license by trying to prove it is financially viable, but state regulators were skeptical.

title: Marilyn Wilkes Is Married
description: Marilyn Zurow Wilkes and John Frederick Heimerdinger were married yesterday at Congregation B'nai Yisrael in Armonk, N.Y., by Rabbi Douglas Krantz. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Zurow of St. Joseph, Mo. Her husband is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Heimerdinger of New York and Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Sharon Poritzky Is Married
description: Sharon Poritzky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Sander Poritzky of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Rod Feldman, a son of Frederick Feldman of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Estelle Feldman, were married yesterday evening at the Pierre by Rabbi Chaim Stern. The bride, a graduate of Tulane University, is a sales service executive for the Cable News Network in New York. Mr. Feldman, a graduate of Stanford University, is the president of his own concern, Tri Star Equities, a real-estate finance and development company in New York.

title: U.S. Challenged on Immigration Arrest Tactic
description: Last August two Border Patrol agents without a search warrant entered Rudolph J. Ferguson's place of business in Sacramento and grabbed a worker. When Mr. Ferguson protested, one agent started to draw a gun.

title: Lethal Game of 'Chicken' Emerges for Israeli Boys
description: The Israeli Government is urgently trying to stop the spread of a deadly new game that has taken hold among the nation's youth: a bizarre variant of Russian roulette in which young boys take turns running in front of speeding cars.

title: Vallone Urges Stronger, Bigger Council
description: New York should have a bigger, stronger City Council of 45 members, with 10 seats to be elected by voters throughout the city but spread evenly among the boroughs, the council's majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, said yesterday.

title: Bush Child-Care Plan Offers Too Little
description: To the Editor:

title: Starrett Housing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $10,755,000. The year-ago fourth quarter's share earnings' figure reflects a loss because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: Official Says Beijing Won't Copy Moscow's Political Restructuring
description: In a rebuff to calls for a more democratic political system in China, Prime Minister Li Peng said today that China would not copy the Soviet Union's political restructuring and that China would not take ''hasty'' or ''excessive'' steps toward democracy.

title: P & F Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REBELS INTRUDED, SOUTH AFRICA SAYS
description: About 1,200 guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization have crossed the border from Angola since Friday night in what looks like a coordinated effort to set up armed bases inside Namibia, South African military and police officers said today.

title: Farragut Mortgage reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a writedown of goodwill of $937,000 and non-recurring restructuring charges of about $900,000.

title: Laurence Hewes, 86, Land-Use Economist
description: Laurence I. Hewes, a retired land-use economist who had worked for the Agriculture Department and the Agency for International Development, died of complications resulting from Parkinson's Disease Friday at Williamson Medical Center, Brentwood, Tenn. He was 86 years old and lived in Brentwood.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The United States and Egypt agree that Israel should end its ''occupation'' of Arab lands and that an international conference could help bring about peace, Presidents Bush and Mubarak declared. Page A1

title: Reviews/Music; Berlioz, Schumann and a Tuxedoed Pied Piper
description: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra was on strike for the first 22 weeks of this season, and reconvened only five weeks ago. But hearing the precise, robust sound produced at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, one would not have guessed the players and their conductor, David Zinman, had been apart so long.

title: Westinghouse Credit
description: The Westinghouse Credit Corporation said yesterday that it had formed the Major Industries Finance Group unit to provide financing to the transportation, energy and media industries. Westinghouse Credit, a unit of the Pittsburgh-based Westinghouse Electric Corporation, named George D. Cashman, 35 years old, the senior vice president in charge of the group. He was also appointed to Westinghouse Credit's management committee.

title: Illinois Tool Works
description: Illinois Tool Works Inc. completed its acquisition of the Ransburg Corporation, an Indianapolis-based maker of automation equipment, for nearly $171 million. Illinois Tool paid $21 a share in cash for each Ransburg share; 94 percent of the 8.2 million shares were purchased by today. Illinois Tool's original bid of $20 a share in January was sweetened to $21 a share to match an offer from Eagle Industries, a Chicago-based unit of Great American Management and Investment Inc.

title: Market Place; NCNB Pursues Growth in Texas
description: WITHIN days after the NCNB Corporation had leaped into the upper tier of Texas banking eight months ago, its shares had jumped more than $6, to a high near $30. And hours before its bid for the Citizens and Southern Corporation last Thursday, NCNB shares traded above $36. Yesterday, the stock closed at $35.75, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Namibia Rebels Crossed Border, U.N. Believes
description: International observers sent to investigate clashes in northern Namibia over the weekend reported a ''major incursion'' by guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization, United Nations officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Oil Can Be Replaced
description: The disastrous Alaska oil spill, for which corporate apologies and assurances are poor compensation, is scarcely a cloud with a silver lining. It may provide a new impetus for environmental protection and restoration, but the damage done by the Exxon Valdez and its masters will have been done, and much of it will never be undone.

title: Nissan's U.S. Plant To Build New Car
description: In an announcement that substantiated rumors reported last week, the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation said it would build a new midsize car at its plant in Smyrna, Tenn., beginning in 1992. The company said that the car, a four-door model, would compete in the less expensive part of the market's middle range, complementing or supplanting the Stanza, which is imported from Japan. The Smyrna plant is to continue building the Sentra car and a light pickup truck at current production levels.

title: Brooklyn Fish Market Closed
description: The Fishport project in South Brooklyn, created to promote New York City's fish industry, has been abandoned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as a failure.

title: King-Cayton Dispute
description: Robert Hirth, an attorney for Don King, has asked the New York State Athletic Commission to convene a hearing to consider revoking the license of Bill Cayton, the manager of the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson. In a letter to the commission yesterday, Hirth said Cayton had taken advantage of Tyson financially ''through fraud, the use of unlicensed sham corporations, blatant conflicts of interest.''

title: New York Preview: The Look Is Short (but Not Extreme)
description: Short skirts, which swept the fashion boards at the European ready-to-wear openings last month, will dominate the New York showings next week. Leading designers here, still pinning up the hemlines on their new collections, agree that short skirts look best to them. They are not talking about extremes. ''Not here,'' said Calvin Klein, drawing an imaginary line with his finger at midthigh level. ''But here,'' he said, marking a point just above his knee. Here is what some other designers had to say. Geoffrey Beene: ''Short is the modern way of dressing,'' said this designer, who has bared the knees and then some for almost five years. ''It is not an arbitrary decision. It is based on pure logic. It's based on our constant effort to make clothes lighter and easier to move in.

title: Emerald Mortgage Investents reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There were no year results because the company began operations on July 27, 1988. It reported net income of $5,418,000, or 62 cents a share, for the period between July 27 and Dec. 31, 1988.

title: 8th Victim of Bridge Hunted
description: Workers searched today for the body of a man who they feared was trapped beneath the collapsed Hatchie River bridge. At least seven people were killed Saturday night when a section of the 50-year-old bridge collapsed, plunging a truck and three cars into the water. The authorities were looking today for a fourth car because a local man was reported missing.

title: Bush Takes Mubarak Out to the Ball Game
description: The two Presidents sat in the sky box, watching the baseball game with their Orioles caps, their hot dogs, their pickles, their horseradish, their Cokes in Orioles plastic souvenir cups, their player lineup sheet on White House stationery, their little white binoculars and a black secure phone.

title: Stocks Up Modestly as Dow Gains 11.18
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.18 points to close at 2,304.80.

title: Reviews/Music; On a Wild Joyride With the Replacements
description: The Replacements came to the Beacon Theater on Thursday night with a chip on their shoulders and something to prove. Although their two-night Beacon engagement quickly sold out and their current album, ''Don't Tell a Soul,'' is receiving more radio exposure than any of its predecessors, among longtime fans the reaction to the album has been mixed. It's the Replacements' most toned-down, conventional recording. As if to compensate, the band came out yelling and bashing in a set that included many of its best songs.

title: Why Milk Consumers?
description: Some bad ideas never go away. Just two years after a Federal judge broke up the cozy licensing arrangement that protected New York milk distributors from competition, dairy farmers in 11 Northeastern states are pressing for the right to set up their own cartel.

title: OIL INDUSTRY GETS WARNING ON IMAGE
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. today warned oil industry leaders that public reaction over the Alaskan tanker spill could lead to the blocking of future development of oil and gas on the nation's outer continental shelf and in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Smith, Burke In Merger With Evans
description: SMITH, BURKE & AZZAM, a Baltimore agency that has been rocked by dissension and employee defections in recent weeks, merged yesterday with Evans/McLaughlin to form Gray, Kirk & Evans.

title: Forum Retirement Partners LP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Helene Curtis Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
American Pacific Mint reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $388,000 gain on forgiveness of debt. The company said 1987 figures have been restated.

title: Bobbie Brooks Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the increase in sales and profits in 1988 to the acquisition of the retail and printing businesses of Pubco Corp. In exchange for the issuance by Bobbie Brooks to Pubco of 5.5 million common shares and a new class of preferred stock.

title: Key Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
New World Entertainment Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,681,000 for the quarter and $4,824,000 for the year, and extraordinary gains of $2,558,000 and $95,354,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After income of $208,000 for the quarter and $2,324,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs
description: Dr. Norman E. Zinberg, a psychoanalyst whose research into the effects of drugs on individuals and social groups influenced the direction of drug-abuse treatment, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 67 years old.

title: The Jewish Museum Reaches Out
description: How do you define a Jewish museum in a fast-track city and in a secular age? Joan Rosenbaum, the director of the Jewish Museum, ponders that question a lot. ''We're not a religious institution but a cultural one,'' she said the other day. ''Although almost everything we do is about some aspect of Jewish life, we are a museum for all interests. We make a real effort to serve a general audience.''

title: I.B.M. Caution on Travel Angers U.S. Airlines
description: United States airlines are fuming at the International Business Machines Corporation for advising employees to use foreign airlines for security reasons when traveling in Europe and the Middle East.

title: U.N. RELIEF CONVOY LEAVES FOR SUDAN
description: A long convoy of trucks packed with grain, medicine and solar refrigerators for cooling vaccines left here for the southern Sudan today as a United Nations relief operation got under way.

title: In Jazz and Tributes, A Tradition Continues
description: The 1989 JVC Jazz Festival New York, scheduled from June 23 to July 1, will feature many festival regulars along with tribute concerts and shows co-produced by the Knitting Factory and S.O.B.'s, two Manhattan clubs. The program was announced yesterday by George Wein and Festival Productions, who began producing the Newport Jazz Festival in 1954.

title: Acclaim Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Countrywide Credit Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a $2,314,000 gain from the repurchase of debentures.

title: Perennial Patterns
description: This summer, if you want to be the swing of things, you'll own something patterned with a large, colorful flower print, probably Hawaiian in feeling. By next fall, you'll be dreaming of swathing yourself in a sumptuous fabric glittering with golden threads outlining Oriental or Indian motifs.

title: Alfred Rice, 81, Dies; Lawyer for Top Writers
description: Alfred Rice, a prominent Manhattan lawyer who numbered Ernest Hemingway and E. E. Cummings among his clients, died of kidney failure Wednesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in Queens. He was 81 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: 3 Coaches Change Jobs
description: Wade Houston, an assistant at Louisville, was appointed Tennessee's head coach yesterday, agreeing to a five-year contract worth a guaranteed $850,000. Houston replaced Don DeVoe, who was forced to resign last week. Tennessee (19-11) lost to West Virginia in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Houston will become the first black head basketball coach in the Southeastern Conference.

title: US Shoe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After gains of $16,042,000 from accounting changes. The latest periods' nets reflected one-time charges of 19 cents a share for the quarter and 26 cents a share for the year, both from the restructuring of notes, the closing of a division and other non-recurring items. LIFO gains increased fourth quarter earnings by 2 cents a share in latest year, compared with a reduction of 3 cents a share in prior year. LIFO charges decreased latest year net by 6 cents share, compared with a reduction of 7 cents a share in prior year. The prior year also included a gain of 16 cents a share from the sale of certain operations.

title: Heavy Shelling in Lebanon Takes 12 More Lives
description: Twelve Lebanese were reported killed and 15 wounded today as Muslim and Christian forces continued artillery and rocket battles for a third week.

title: Xerox Vice Chairman To Head Babson College
description: William F. Glavin, a vice chairman of the Xerox Corporation and one of its four top executives, is taking early retirement at age 57 to become president of Babson College, the company announced yesterday.

title: Yankees Will Open Show With Stand-Ins for Stars
description: No, they are not imposters. Even though Willie Randolph is gone and Dave Winfield is lying on his back and Don Mattingly is home in New Jersey, these are still the Yankees. They will dress in their gray road uniforms Tuesday night, and they will send out a 45-year-old pitcher to face the Minnesota Twins.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 3 P.M.

title: Advantage Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $338,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income and included tax credits of $150,000 and $308,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Quest Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $758,329, which included a tax credit of about $855,000 and a loss of about $97,000 from extinguishment of debt. The latest quarter and year results included charges of $369,400 and $381,000, respectively, for legal expenses related to a patent infringement lawsuit and pretax charges of about $80,000 related to the revaluation of certain assets. The year-ago quarter and year results included a pretax charge of about $417,000 related to the sale of a product line. The prior year also included a pretax gain of about $2.5 million from the sale of a product line.

title: Ruth Z. Casselman, 91, Immigration Advocate
description: Ruth Zagat Casselman, an advocate of immigration for more than 50 years, died of cancer Saturday at Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 91 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Rice Claims Scoring Mark
description: With his 31 points tonight, Glen Rice of Michigan became the single-season scoring leader in National Collegiate Athletic Associaton tournament play, breaking a 24-year-old record set by Bill Bradley.

title: MAYORAL ELECTION IN CHICAGO TODAY
description: In a city that is about evenly divided racially, the next Mayor of Chicago will be chosen Tuesday in a contest of turnout between whites and blacks.

title: Ronzoni's Shift
description: Ronzoni is so good, to Cliff Freeman & Partners. The pasta maker awarded the small division of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising its account on Friday. In recent years the account has billed from $2 million to more than $3 million a year. Ronzoni, owned by the Philip Morris Companies, has not advertised for six months, a company spokesman said. The company had used Cato Johnson/Y.& R., a sales-promotion arm of Young & Rubicam, since 1984, but determined ''that the service would be more appropriately rendered by a smaller ad agency.''

title: Guilty Plea Is Expected
description: Ronald Peters, who had been identified in The Dayton Daily News as a central figure in the baseball commissioner's investigation of Pete Rose, announced yesterday his intention to plead guilty to Federal charges of cocaine distribution and lying on an income tax return. Peters, 31, made public his intention at a hearing in Cincinnati in United States District Court.

title: Timeouts Will Be Longer
description: The distance for the 3-point field goal will remain the same in college basketball next season, but timeouts will be lengthened by 15 seconds and two free throws will be awarded for all technical fouls, the rules committee decided today.

title: Integra-A Hotel & Restaurant Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,950,000 and $999,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $19,000 for the quarter and $5,671,000 for the year.

title: Devon Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $3,912,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss

title: High Court Supports States On Taxing of Oil Companies
description: Ruling in a case worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the treasuries of eight states, the Supreme Court said today that states did not have to allow oil companies to deduct their Federal ''windfall profit'' tax payments from their state income calculations.

title: 'We're No. 1' Has a Nice Ring to It
description: Daryll Walker's desperation shot skidded hard off the backboard and into Glen Rice's hands, and moments later Rice was lugging more than just a basketball. Rumeal Robinson, the crafty Michigan point guard, knew how to start the celebration. He leaped into Rice's arms, and with their fists raised, both players chanted, ''We're No. 1! We're the national champions!''

title: American First Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $443,557 for the quarter and $1,003,067 for the year, and the year also included a gain from discontinued operations of $803,303. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $4,111,701 and $6,473,608 for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago revenue included $12,059,905 from the sale of First Affiliated Securities Inc.

title: British Oil Production
description: Britain's North Sea oil production is expected to rise dramatically in the next decade, making Britain self-sufficient in oil until the year 2000, a report said on Sunday. The report, by the North Sea oil brokerage County Natwest Woodmac, the securities arm of National Westminster Bank P.L.C., said that output could reach a high of 2.5 million barrels a day in the 1990's as 42 potential new fields are developed. The report said new field development would increase output by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day, raising total production to near 1985 peaks of 2.6 million barrels a day. Britain's current production is slightly more than a million barrels a day.

title: VMS Mortgage Investors LP III reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're not as bad off as Washington or Miami or Los Angeles. But anybody who goes out into the streets of New York and sees what's going on there will understand that we are facing a major crisis, not just in drugs, but all of the crimes that go with it - murder, child abuse, robbery, all of it. But nobody, at the the national or the state or the city level, seems prepared to make the sort of commitment of resources that is necessary.'' - Robert M. Morgenthau, District Attorney of Manhattan. [ B6:3. ]

title: Col. Louis Nolfo, 85, Ex-Correction Official
description: Col. Louis A. Nolfo, the first Deputy Commissioner of Correction in New York City and former director of the New York State Truck Mileage Tax Bureau, died of a stroke Friday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I. He was 85 years old and lived in West Point, N.Y.

title: Big British Organization Elects Director General
description: The Institute of Directors, Britain's largest business organization committed to the promotion of free enterprise, has appointed Peter Morgan as its next director general, effective July.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Sheila M. Coonan, an actress, misstated the date of her memorial Mass. It is to be celebrated on Thursday, at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church, Sullivan and Houston Streets; it was not celebrated on Friday.

title: Farm Credit Banks Planning Billion-Dollar Note Program
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation announced yesterday that it plans to enter the debt market with a new billion-dollar medium-term note program.

title: Review/Dance; Giving Movement to Fitzgerald's Words
description: Pittsburgh Ballet Theater deserves credit for enterprise. In 1987, when it decided to stage a new multi-act ballet, it refused to do the obvious thing. It did not turn to fairy tales. It also ignored such familiar sources of choreographic inspiration as Shakespeare and Greek tragedy. Instead, it produced ''The Great Gatsby,'' based on F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel of 1925 in which, as he tells a story about love on Long Island, Fitzgerald comments on some of the moral issues posed by an era of jazz, high living and Prohibition.

title: Eastex Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $506,000 pre-tax charge for the settlement of contract litigation for the quarter and the year included a gain of $74,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Anti-Doping Proposal
description: The council of the International Amateur Athletics Federation yesterday proposed using international doping-control squads to test athletes anywhere in the world at any time.

title: Mayfair Gets Bid
description: Mayfair Super Markets Inc. said its chairman and president, Stanley P. Kaufelt, who owns about 46 percent of its class A and class B stock, had offered to acquire its remaining shares for $23.50 each. The company said its board would meet to review the proposal. The stock of Mayfair, which has about 7.8 million class A shares outstanding, soared $6.25 today, to $23.50, in over-the-counter trading, where its gain of 36.2 percent was the largest of the day.

title: In Periodontal Disease, Researchers Focus on Less Painful Therapies
description: RECENT advances in molecular biology may eventually eliminate the need for surgery in treating periodontal disease, the most common dental illness among Americans.

title: Turn Welfare Hotels Into AIDS Hospices
description: To the Editor:

title: Littlefield Adams reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $640,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: Choir to Present 'Elijah'
description: The Riverside Church choir is to perform Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' at 4 P.M. April 16. There is also to be a 3 P.M. carillon recital. The church is at Riverside Drive and 122d Street. Suggested donation is $5. Information: 222-5900, extension 223.

title: New Director For Beverly
description: Beverly Enterprises Inc., the troubled nursing home chain, said yesterday that a representative of the Pritzker family, Will K. Weinstein of San Francisco and Chicago, had joined Beverly's board.

title: NWA Airline In Union Pact
description: Northwest Airlines, a unit of NWA Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement with its machinists, one of its largest unions.

title: REBELLIOUS TROOPS HOLD OUT IN HAITI
description: Rebel soldiers in Haiti continued to hold out against the Government today, a day after an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow the Haitian President, diplomats and businessmen in Port-au-Prince said.

title: Telesphere International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss included an $11.6 million increase in the provision for bad debts, largely due to uncollectibles associated with the introductory 900 service and older receivables; an $11 million writeoff of non-recurring expenses; a $3.5 million reserve for non-income-based taxes, and $2.1 million in restructuring costs.

title: Roger Cortesi, Investment Banker, 87
description: Roger Cortesi, an investment banker, died yesterday at Westerly (R.I.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Stonington, Conn.

title: Hershiser Remains On Minds Of Reds
description: The Cincinnati Reds obviously haven't been distracted by the highly publicized investigation of their manager, but the Orel Hershiser effect is apparently another matter.

title: Kabul Urges U.S. to Shift Policy
description: The Afghan Government urged President Bush today to reconsider United States policy on Afghanistan, beginning with an acknowledgement that the American-armed guerrillas lack the military power to dislodge the Soviet-backed Government from Kabul and other major cities.

title: KEY RATES
Herbalife International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The l988 loss included non-recurring charges totaling $2.4 million. Herbalife said the charges consisted primarily of a reserve of $1.4 million for rental payments on space not used by the company or sublet to tenants at less than the company pays its landord. Also included in the latest year's loss is a $836,000 charge for writeoffs of inventory and a foreign exchange loss as a result of the continued suspension of operations of the Mexican subsidiary.

title: Courter Runs Upbeat New Jersey Race
description: Even as his campaign plane plummeted in one more downdraft, Representative Jim Courter, a Republican candidate for governor with an unflappable faith in the future, seemed unperturbed by the turbulence in the New Jersey sky.

title: Coleco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year losses included charges of $15.4 million and $118.6 million, respectively, both related to restructuring costs and bankruptcy administration costs.

title: Books of The Times; Wrestling With the Beast of the Holocaust
description: See Under: Love By David Grossman Translated by Betsy Rosenberg. 458 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $$22.95.

title: In a Yugoslav Province, Aflame for Six Days, the Resentments Still Smolder
description: While grieving families in this southern region of Yugoslavia were burying their dead from recent rioting, the citizens of the nation's largest republic, Serbia, were celebrating what for them amounted to a national victory.

title: Review/Music; Undermining Romance
description: Voice of the Beehive sabotages pop's romantic stereotypes with neatly mixed messages. At the Palladium on Sunday night, where the London-based band completed its American tour, its two singers wore flouncy dresses and mugged like sitcom teen-agers; while Tracey Bryn played guitar, Melissa Brooke Belland re-created the hand-wringing, finger-pointing gestures of 1960's girl groups. Yet their songs, with lyrics by the California-born Ms. Bryn, are hard-headed, dry-eyed tales of sexual strife, exactly the opposite of the original girl groups' message.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day last Wednesday misstated the number of branches that Chemical Bank plans to close. A company spokesman said the bank had recently sold five branches on Long Island and would close two more; it has not closed 30.

title: Johnston Journal; Drive to Shut Landfill Ends on Artistic Note
description: Not until the state of Rhode Island started sending out lovely color postcards of 328-foot-high Central Landfill and offering public tours of the garbage mound did Mayor Ralph R. aRusso decide to put his foot down.

title: Lamar Hunt Settles Suits
description: The multimillionaire Lamar Hunt and 10 other defendants have independently agreed to settle class-action lawsuits stemming from an attempt by Mr. Hunt and his brothers to corner the silver market in 1979 and 1980, his lawyer has announced.

title: Testimony on Steroid Use by Olympians
description: A prominent American track coach said today that as many as 20 women on the United States track and field team at the Seoul Olympics last fall ''probably'' used anabolic steroids in their preparation for the Games.

title: Burger King to Cut 550 Jobs in Revamping
description: The Burger King Corporation said today that it would lay off about 550 of its 1,500 non-restaurant employees in a restructuring after its acquisition earlier this year by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Is Star Spinning or Vibrating? Is It Even Real?
description: THE pulsating object they saw in January seemed to be everything astrophysicists had hoped for. It appeared in the scattering debris of a recent stellar explosion, and they took this as strong evidence supporting theories of how spinning, superdense stars emerge from explosive supernovas.

title: Israel Laster, Executive, 72
description: Israel Laster, former director of the New York Chapter of the American Jewish Committee, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Addison Gilbert Hospital in Gloucester, Mass. He was 72 years old and had homes in Rockport, Mass., and Manhattan.

title: Officer Kills Bronx Man After Attack, Police Say
description: A 73-year-old Bronx man was shot to death by a police officer early yesterday after lunging twice with a knife at officers who went to his door over neighbors' complaints of an intoxicated man with a knife banging on their doors, the police said.

title: Jury Is Told That Reagan and Casey Picked North
description: An intelligence official said today that President Ronald Reagan and William J. Casey, his Director of Central Intelligence, personally selected Oliver L. North as the Administration's liaison with the Nicaraguan rebels when Congress was preparing to cut off financing in 1984.

title: In an Age When Tiny Is All, Big Computers Are Hurting
description: The mainframe computer is rapidly being turned into a technological dinosaur by the tiny ''computer on a chip,'' which is growing smaller, cheaper and dramatically faster.

title: Reviews/Music; Uncelebrated Composer Finds New Friends
description: Like Charles Ives, Jan Dismas Zelenka wrote music that sounds as if it were little played and even less listened to. The results are both excitement and frustration - qualities that marked the Concerto, the Capriccio and the Sinfonia that Heinz Holliger brought to the New York Chamber Symphony's Baroque Series at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night.

title: Easy Goer Is Back in Town and Ready to Roll
description: The stable area at Belmont Park yesterday morning seemed like a gigantic gray mud pit, and cold rain darkened the skies and almost everyone's mood. But a warm yellow lamp burned in the window of the white office across the road from the Ogden Phipps Stable, where Shug McGaughey was warm, dry and happy to be home.

title: 60's Militant To End Flight After 18 Years
description: Eighteen years after he fled to Guyana to evade a prison sentence for conspiring to murder moderate civil-rights leaders, Herman B. Ferguson is returning to New York City, where, as an educator in the 1960's, he inflamed a raging dispute over the control of public schools by proposing a ''survival curriculum'' of armed combat for black students.

title: A Fair Chance for Young Black Men
description: In 1986 only 40 percent of black college students were male, reflecting a decade of decline in the number of black men pursuing higher education. That portends a gap between black men and women with worrisome implications for black families and an educated work force.

title: Infinite Graphics reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Lawrence Insurance Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said its results for the latest year were affected by several large fire losses and expenses related to product and geographic expansion, office relocation, and the initial phases of a new customer service system.

title: Ann Arbor Goes Into Overtime, Too
description: Mike Ransford, a University of Michigan senior, called it a graduation present from heaven.

title: Famous Potatoes - and Nazis
description: LEAD: There is no urban anonymity in Idaho. Only about one million people live in the entire state, an area as big as five or six of those little patches people call states back East. In Idaho, where it's possible to know every active person in one's community, taking a stand against a determined and violent group makes one extremely vulnerable.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS AIRPORT DETENTION BASED ON 'PROFILE'
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution permits the police to stop and question airline passengers who display behavior patterns that may have an innocent explanation but parallel the actions of drug couriers.

title: SmithKline's Stock Climbs
description: The stock of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation rose sharply in active trading again yesterday after SmithKline and Beecham P.L.C. of Britain announced Sunday that they had been conducting merger talks.

title: Fur Vault Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Murder Victim Identified
description: Investigators today identified the eighth victim of a killer who preys on women who are drug addicts. They also said an informer had come forward who might help solve the crimes. The skeleton, found Friday in brush off Route 88 in Westport, was identified through dental records as that of Mary Rose Santos of Fairhaven, Mass., a 27-year-old wife and mother of two who had been missing since July 15.

title: Guardian Capital Group Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains of $753,000 for the latest year and $6,962,000 for the previous year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Older Pilots Challenge a Rule That Closes Careers After 60
description: The 59-year-old pilot who landed a disabled jetliner in Honolulu a month ago became a hero to his passengers and also a powerful new weapon in a battle against a Government rule that prohibits pilots from flying airliners after they are 60 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS The dollar fell after the Group of Seven nations warned that its value should not be pushed higher. The Bank of Japan backed up the warning by selling dollars for the first time this year. On the Comex, the price of gold rose $1.10, to $386.20. [ Page D1. ] Treasury issues rose in volatile trading amid signs of economic sluggishness and hopes that interest rates may be peaking. [ D18. ] Reflecting the strength in the credit markets, stocks staged a modest rally. The Dow industrials closed at 2,304.80, up 11.18. [ D12. ] Grain and livestock futures prices declined. Precious metals were mostly higher, and energy prices fell. [ D20. ] COMPANIES Citizens and Southern rejected NCNB's merger proposal. The board of the Atlanta banking company also changed the bylaws to complicate any unwanted takeover. [ D1. ] The unsolicited bid puts a new cloud over Bennett A. Brown, who presided over a turnaround at Citizens and Southern. [ D10. ] Hugh L. McColl Jr. has led NCNB through six years of acquisitions, aggressive lending and hard-nosed management. [ D10. ] One reason NCNB has been looking like a glamour stock is its surprising strength in Texas. Market Place. [ D12. ] Carson Pirie Scott's shares soared 52 percent after the retailer received a $282 million takeover offer from P. A. Bergner. [ D1. ] A Dallas investor said he owns 5.3 percent of Lockheed. Harold Simmons's disclosure set off speculation that he or others might bid for the military contractor, or that it might restructure. [ D1. ] The New York Post's publisher resigned. Peter O. Price will become a partner in a venture by Univisa. The Post's owner, Peter S. Kalikow, will assume the publisher's duties. [ D1. ] U.S. airline executives are criticizing I.B.M. for advising employees to use foreign carriers when traveling abroad. [ D2. ] The Bush Administration announced rules to sharpen airline responses to warnings of terrorist threats. [ A1. ] Chrysler changed its buyer incentives, reacting to new programs by its rivals. The No. 3 auto maker's package includes no-interest loans for two-year terms, which few customers choose. [ D5. ] Burger King will lay off 550 of its 1,500 non-restaurant employees as part of a restructuring. [ D5. ] Avery agreed to sell Uniroyal Chemical to a management group for $800 million. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The I.M.F. predicted a higher U.S. trade deficit in 1990, and it said improvements in the budget deficit had stalled. [ D7. ] Several changes to the savings industry rescue plan were proposed by the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. [ D18. ] Construction spending was virtually flat in February. Less work on housing offset an increase in government projects. [ D23. ] States do not have to allow oil companies to deduct Federal ''windfall profit'' tax payments from their state income calculations, the Supreme Court ruled. [ D1. ] Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. warned that concern over the Alaskan oil spill could stymie future oil and gas projects. [ B8. ] Prosecutors vowed to prove that three Teledyne executives conspired to obtain confidential military information. The first Pentagon procurement fraud trial opened in Alexandria, Va. [ D11. ] INTERNATIONAL There was speculation in Havana that the Soviet Union may forgive its unpaid loans to Cuba. [ A12. ] The Eastern Airlines strike is doing grave damage to tourism in several Caribbean resort areas. [ A16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The value of medical procedures is being evaluated in new ways by insurers and hospitals. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Smith, Burke & Azzam merged with Evans/McLaughlin to form a new agency, Gray, Kirk & Evans. Advertising. [ D25. ]

title: Outlet Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The results for the year-ago fourth quarter and full year included a gain of $3,170,000 on the sale of a radio station. The results for both years included Atlin Communications Inc., a former affiliate which was acquired by Outlet on Dec. 30, 1988.

title: First Pentagon Fraud Trial Opens
description: Federal prosecutors today opened the first trial resulting from a three-year investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud by vowing to prove that executives of Teledyne Electronics Inc. had conspired through ''cheating'' and ''lying'' to obtain confidential Defense Department information.

title: We Need Wiser Use of Jails, Not More Cells
description: To the Editor:

title: Comstock Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mesa Plans Sales
description: Mesa Limited Partnership, a leading natural gas and oil producer, said it would sell $200 million to $300 million in properties this year to reduce debt. The partnership's debt rose to $1.57 billion last Dec. 31, from $948 million at the end of 1987, after Mesa spent $715 million to acquire several properties from Tenneco Inc. late last year. The energy company, based in Amarillo, Tex., and controlled by T. Boone Pickens, will sell some of the properties acquired in the Tenneco transaction and some of its existing properties, a Mesa spokesman said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Autoclave Engineers reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included gains of $10,000 and $564,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Witness Rebuts Agents
description: Closing arguments are scheduled to begin here Tuesday in the Federal trial of Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, the sports agents accused of mail fraud and racketeering in connection with their representation of several prominent college athletes.

title: Fusion Claim Is Put to the Test Worldwide
description: THE lowly fax machine is on its way to helping resolve an extraordinary chapter in the annals of science.

title: Bands March, Flags Fly and the Mets Beat the Cards
description: The Mets cast aside the snickers and slumps of their spring yesterday and opened the new season in Shea Stadium with an 8-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, and they did it with all the trappings and reminders of their past success.

title: Student Blamed for Rogue Computer Program
description: A Cornell University commission said yesterday that a graduate student in computer science, working alone, created the rogue program that produced havoc in nationwide computer networks last November.

title: Rocky Mountain High
description: Before his spring ski vacation in Colorado, a fellow in the office romanticized about the contrast with his usual life behind a desk: from artificial light to spring sunshine; from sitting in an overheated room to gliding coatlessly in 14 inches of fresh powder. Now he's back, not sure it's so easy to get away from it all.

title: In Hartford, News by Fax
description: The Hartford Courant has announced a plan that will allow some owners of facsimile machines to obtain advance copies of its news and editorials. The newspaper said Sunday that it would distribute a newsletter, known as Faxpaper, at a price of $2,500 a year. Starting Tuesday, anyone who wants the news, but who does not have time to watch the evening news, will be able to receive Faxpaper, The Courant said.

title: Pirates Aren't Dwelling on Defeat
description: Not long after the sudden end to his college career, Gerald Greene sat before his stall in the Seton Hall dressing room and inspected the box he had received. Inside the box was a small brown wood case. Inside the case was a silver ring with a black stone. On the stone were the letters N.C.A.A.

title: Two Arrested in Grocer's Slaying
description: The Dade County police said today that they had arrested two suspects over the weekend and were looking for up to three more suspects in the March 20 killing of a grocery store owner who had waged a campaign against drug dealers in his neighborhood.

title: George Washington Corp reports earnings for
Chrysler Offers Loan Incentives
description: Reacting to incentives announced by its rivals last week, the Chrysler Corporation today offered a sweetened program of low-interest loans and rebates. The program includes no-interest loans for two-year terms, a financing period chosen by few customers.

title: The Syrian Empire
description: Every day, artillery shells and rockets launched by Syria fall on Beirut. They come from within the city itself or bases just outside it.

title: American Real Estate Parters reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $267,910 and $3,566,882 for the quarter and year, respectively, on property transactions, and losses of $141,939 for the quarter and $641,813 for the year, both on the early extinguishment of debt. c-After a loss of $329,042 for the quarter and a gain of $697,557 for the year, both from property transactions.

title: Careers; New Ways To Present Resumes
description: ''TELL me your company's fax number,'' more and more job seekers are saying to companies where they hope to find work.

title: People
description: * Jonathan Cranin was promoted to senior vice president of Geer, DuBois.

title: Duratek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $73,000 for the quarter and $87,000 for the year. c-Included tax credits of $105,000 and $330,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Duratek is 64 percent owned by National Patent Development Corp.

title: Eastern Strike Leaves Island Resorts in Lurch
description: The strike against Eastern Airlines and the widespread cancellation of its flights have turned an already soft Caribbean tourism season into a disaster for many hotels and restaurants.

title: Science Teacher Is Held in Bronx Heroin Sale
description: A 40-year-old high school science teacher was arrested yesterday when he was seen buying two bags of heroin on a South Bronx street, the police said.

title: Abortion-Rights Backers Set to March
description: Abortion rights advocates from around the country will gather in Washington Sunday for what they hope will be the largest demonstraton they have ever held.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a debate over costs and benefits of reducing ozone misstated the affiliation of Dr. Bernard Gladstone.

title: Changes Offered in Bush Rescue Plan
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee today proposed several changes to the Bush Administration's rescue plan for the savings industry. The changes are likely to please both the industry and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Review/Music; Viennese Chamber Works By an American Ensemble
description: The Ensemble for Viennese Music is part of a cultural exchange wherein this New York-based ensemble offers concerts of 20th-century Austrian music and an analogous group in Vienna (called the American Music Ensemble) performs modern American composers in Austria.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart in Business Day yesterday about stock performances during the first quarter of the year referred incorrectly to Beres Industries. The company is not going out of business. Last week, Monmouth Investments Inc, the brokerage house that specialized in trading Beres stock over the counter, ceased operations.

title: Tranzonic Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago periods' share earnings have been restated to reflect the October 1988 distribution of one class B common share for every two common shares.

title: Business and Health; New Guidelines To Control Costs
description: IN their continuing attempt to improve the quality of health care and reduce costs, large insurers, hospitals and academic researchers are experimenting with several new ways of evaluating the usefulness of medical procedures.

title: Infant I.Q. Tests Found to Predict Scores in School
description: TO the surprise of many psychologists, tests on infants as young as six months of age are predicting their scores on intelligence tests years later, when they start school.

title: Firefighters Lose Challenge To New York Residency Act
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday let stand a law that forces New York City firefighters who live outside the state to move into the city or nearby counties if they want to keep their jobs.

title: CSX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $5 million for the latest quarter and $19 million for the year-earlier period. The company said its first quarter results did not include gains on the sale of Texas Gas Transmission Corp. and the company's 50 percent interest in the Lightnet Fiber-Optic Telecommunications Network, both of which closed Monday.

title: Resorts International Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $6.6 million. The 1988 loss included a loss of $335,690,000 primarily resulting from the sale of the Taj Mahal and the payment of a fee related to the termination of a services agreement.

title: Texas Raider Holds 5.3% Lockheed Stake
description: Harold Simmons, an investor and corporate raider based in Dallas, disclosed today that he owns 5.3 percent of the Lockheed Corporation, setting off speculation about the future of the nation's eighth-largest military contractor.

title: Choice, Not Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Journal of New Jersey reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Prior year loss is after a benefit of $24,278 resulting from a change in accounting method for recording subscription procurement costs.

title: A Matchmaker to Link Companies and Agencies
description: Don Dorward wants to become to the advertising business what matchmakers are to the marriage business - the person who manages the selection process. Mr. Dorward's concern is with the courtship between advertising agencies and their clients. The former chairman of Mojo/USA said yesterday that he would open a consulting firm to advise companies on how to select agencies, solicit speculative creative assignments and negotiate compensation.

title: Hall-Mania Will Last Beyond Loss
description: Save those Seton Hall sweatshirts, the new ones that have not yet gone through their first wash cycle.

title: U.S.-Europe Farm Talks
description: United States and European negotiators have reached ''a sort of understanding'' on wording intended to break a deadlock over long-term government subsidies to farmers, a spokesman for the European Community said today.

title: Carrington Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said the latest quarter included a gain of $252,000 from settlement of litigation.

title: Rise in Condom Use
description: Almost three times as many men from 17 to 19 years old use condoms as did nine years ago, according to a national study.

title: Sri Lanka Investment Up
description: Foreign investors are pumping millions of dollars into Sri Lanka, despite years of ethnic violence, officials say. At least 103 projects totaling about $930 million were worked out last year, said a spokeswoman for the Greater Colombo Economic Commission. Companies based in Japan, South Korea and Hong Kong are the leading investors, lured by raw materials and inexpensive labor.

title: G.E. Capital Notes
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, is offering $500 million of notes due 1990 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. The issue was given a 10 1/4 percent coupon and priced at par to yield investors about 47 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Noncallable for life, the notes are rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporatioon.

title: Zurich Journal; In a Clean Land, Even Dirty Money Gets Washed
description: This city's spotless sidewalks, gleaming shop windows and austere, fortress-like banks have helped give Switzerland its image as a gilded citadel of cleanliness and civility.

title: Club to Appeal Cup Ruling
description: The San Diego Yacht Club announced yesterday that it would appeal the court decision ordering it to forfeit the America's Cup to New Zealand.

title: Millard Sheets Is Dead; Arts Professor Was 81
description: Millard Sheets, a prolific painter, a designer of more than 100 buildings and for 26 years an art professor at Scripps College in Claremont, Calif., died at his home in Gualala, Calif., on Saturday. He was 81 years old.

title: For Leader at Citizens, A Renewed Uncertainty
description: When Bennett A. Brown was named interim president and chief executive of the money-losing Citizens and Southern National Bank in 1978, his 9-year-old daughter rejoiced.

title: Chess
description: It's a cold, cruel world over here in the West. That's what even such a bright prospect as Gata Kamsky, the 14-year-old Soviet who defected at the Penta Hotel last Tuesday at the New York International Open Tournament, is going to find out.

title: Tuscarora Plastics reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Construction Spending Flat; Worst Month Since August
description: Construction spending was nearly flat in February as a small increase in government projects was offset by slower work on housing and other non-government buildings, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: In Once-Pristine Sound, Wildlife Reels Under Oil's Impact
description: As a vast sheet of oil soaks into the shorelines of Prince William Sound, scientists are staggered by the variety of animals placed at risk and fear the destruction may continue for years.

title: Arbor Capital Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Alaska Bans Herring Fishing in Oil-Fouled Sound; New Line of Booms Set
description: Salmon boats aided by Coast Guard helicopters raced today to set a new line of oil spill containment booms across the clear waters of Sawmill Bay at the southern edge of Prince William Sound.

title: Party Ends, but Pride Stays
description: The final shot in a remarkable season had been taken, and the almost 1,000 students and faculty members who packed the student center at Seton Hall tonight stared silently at the giant television screen. The Pirates had come up 1 point short of a national championship, and the heartbreak started to set in. But the pain did not last long.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Brands Inc., Old Greenwich, Conn., said its Franklin Life Insurance Co. subsidiary had completed the sale of Southland Life Insurance Co., Plano, Tex. It was sold to Georgia U.S. Corp., Atlanta, a holding company, for about $433.5 million.

title: O'Brien Signed by Jets To New 3-Year Pact
description: Ken O'Brien, a summer holdout over his last contract, has signed a three-year deal that insures the quarterback will be with the Jets when their spring training begins Monday.

title: Florafax International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Health Unit Bonds Yield Up to 7.70%
description: The Health, Educational and Housing Facility Board of Shelby, Tenn., is tentatively offering $53 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.70 percent for an issue due in 2019. The offering is being made through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Lancer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Mitsubishi to Chiat
description: Chiat/Day won another piece of business yesterday from Mitsubishi Electric Sales America, becoming the electronics manufacturer's sole agency. Chiat/Day will handle advertising for Mitsubishi's 16 subsidiaries, which make products from elevators to facsimile machines. The Los Angeles agency had already handled advertising for the audio and video products of the company, and its corporate advertising. A spokesman for Chiat/ Day said the value of the account had not been determined, but the new business itself was worth significantly more than $1 million.

title: Rebels See Provocation
description: The South-West Africa People's Organization said today that its guerrillas in Namibia had been ruthlessly hunted down and provoked into battle by South African forces. The group said it would be willing to accept an immediate cease-fire if South Africa did the same.

title: Kenya's Leader Attacks Visit By Ethel and Kerry Kennedy
description: President Daniel arap Moi has bitterly attacked the visit of Kerry Kennedy, a daughter of Robert F. Kennedy, who came here last week to present a human rights award to a Kenyan lawyer.

title: Spartan Motors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Canadian Foremost Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary gain of $968,000 from the sale of oil and gas interests. The company noted that 1988 results included those of Drill Systems International Ltd., which was acquired in the 1988 first quarter. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BUSH URGES ISRAEL TO END OCCUPATION OF ARAB TERRITORY
description: President Bush met today with President Hosni Mubarak and later said the United States and Egypt agreed that Israel should end its occupation of Arab lands. They also agreed that an international conference could help bring about peace in the Middle East if properly arranged.

title: Air Supplier Is Indicted As an Illegal Importer
description: A Long Island aircraft equipment corporation and its chairman were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of violating laws prohibiting the importing of materials and goods from South Africa.

title: General Public Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
Ben & Jerry's Homemade reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
An Enhanced Compaq At a Lower Price
description: COMPAQ has long been associated with high-power, high-priced personal computers.

title: Palestinian Killed During Riot
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a 20-year-old Palestinian today during a riot at the Amari refugee area in the West Bank, the army and Palestinians said. Officials at Ramallah Hospital said the Palestinian, Ismail Baba, suffered a gunshot wound in the chest and was dead on arrival at the hospital. The army said it was investigating. Arab hospital officials said at least eight Palestinians were wounded by troops in scattered clashes in the Nuseirat refugee district in the Gaza Strip and in the West Bank towns of Hebron, El Bireh and Ramallah.

title: Japan Waging Economic War Against U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Surge in New York Drug Arrests Sets Off Criminal-Justice Crisis
description: New York City's criminal-justice system is in a state of crisis, just barely able to cope with a growing flood of new drug cases generated by the Police Department's drive against crack, according to judges, prosecutors, correction officials and Legal Aid lawyers.

title: With Iraqi Troops at the Truce Line: Where Legions Died, Deathly Quiet
description: Two United Nations officers stood in silence in the Iraqi observation post, peering through binoculars at Iranian positions across a no man's land and a waterway.

title: Size of Oil Spill May Be No Guide to Its Impact
description: AT first glance, oil spills look diabolically capricious. One might cause an ecological catastrophe, killing whole communities of shoreline animals. Another, equally large or even bigger, might let nature off with little or no damage, leaving everyone relieved but scratching their heads.

title: Pubco reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
In Cuba, Remembering Hemingway
description: For some, a trip to the Hemingway Museum, a house on the outskirts of Havana, where Ernest Hemingway lived for many years, seemed a strange outing for Raisa Gorbachev, the wife of the Soviet leader.

title: Conmed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Q&A
description: Dust Q.What is dust? A.''Dust is any small pieces of matter, little for us but large compared to atoms or molecules,'' said Andrew Fraknoi, an astronomer, the executive officer of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific in San Francisco.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank Leumi Trust Co. of New York, the principal subsidiary of Bank Leumi le-Israel, Tel Aviv, elected David Friedmann chairman.

title: Jean Philippe Fragrances reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
On the Mayoral Trail: If It's Tuesday, This Must Be Queens
description: This time it was Harrison J. Goldin's night.

title: Sierra Health Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary credits of $38,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the year.

title: Rescuers Create a MASH Unit For Hundreds of Stricken Animals
description: Casualties by the hundreds are pouring into a makeshift hospital for oil-soaked animals here, where conditions have begun to resemble those in a battlefield aid station.

title: Bridge
description: It was Black Sunday for the Women's Team in the Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes, which is being played in New York City and Paris. The women were ahead throughout Saturday, when the two-week event began, but the men surged early Sunday morning. The men gained some more in Monday's play, and after 364 deals led by 267 imps. Nonstop play will continue through April 15.

title: Cliffs Drilling reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year included a $23.7 million writedown of the carrying value of drilling rigs.

title: In Rangers' Goal, a Question Mark
description: John Vanbiesbrouck and Bob Froese sat side by side in the Ranger locker room here this afternoon. Both said they did not know who would start in goal Wednesday night in the opener of the Stanley Cup playoffs against the Penguins. Each said he would not mind if it turned out to be the other. Each admitted he would be honored and excited if it happened to be him.

title: Avery to Sell Chemical Unit
description: Avery Inc., a New York-based holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Uniroyal Chemical Company unit to a management group for $800 million.

title: Namibia Rebels Crossed Border, U.N. Believes; A Violation, U.S. Says
description: The United States accused the South-West Africa People's Organization today of violating accords for the independence of Namibia by provoking the worst fighting inside the territory in the guerrillas' struggle for self-government.

title: Off With His Head! And Other Pastimes
description: THE figure on the screen is crude but unmistakable: a French aristocrat, his head under the guillotine's blade. The mob is clamoring for the execution to proceed, and only you can stop it. The words that will save the victim are . . . are . . . ''la fenetre.'' The nobleman smiles and a few bars of ''La Marseillaise'' play.

title: Medar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $100,000 for the quarter and $1,102,574 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,207,900 and $2,131,295 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Alaska Bans Herring Fishing in Oil-Fouled Sound
description: Alaska officials decided today to ban herring fishing this season in Prince William Sound, now covered by an oil slick the size of Rhode Island.

title: VMS Mortgage Investors LP II reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Razing Questions
description: What should be done about a new building on East 96th Street in Manhattan that is 12 stories higher than the zoning law allows? The Board of Standards and Appeals ruled that the city may order the offending 12 stories torn down. Going ahead with demolition might be appropriate if the city were wholly blameless. But city officials initiated the mistake, a fact that argues for a more sophisticated course. The city might well require Queens-based Parkview Associates, the builder, to spend the equivalent of the demolition expense (at least $2.5 million) to subsidize low- and moderate-rent housing in the neighborhood.

title: How to Guarantee a Mediocre Judiciary
description: A recent hearing on an injunction involving Eastern Airlines and the pilots' union presented an interesting juxtaposition. A group of pilots, represented by labor attorneys, contested an action by airline executives, who were also represented by lawyers. Everybody in the courtroom was making well over $100,000 - except the judge. The irony probably did not escape that judge.

title: Citizens Rejects Bid By NCNB
description: The directors of the Citizens and Southern Corporation yesterday rejected a merger proposal from the NCNB Corporation, saying that the offer was too low and that shareholders would benefit more if the banks did not merge.

title: Extent of Wright Friend's Interest In Savings Bill Is Under Scrutiny
description: House Speaker Jim Wright's longtime friend and business associate, George Mallick, had a more direct financial interest in legislation before Congress than has previously been revealed, officials said today.

title: Critic's Notebook; Checking Out the Tuesday-Night Lineup on ABC
description: On any Tuesday evening more than 20 million people tune to ABC. This hot strip of the season, competing with Thursday night on NBC and Sunday night on CBS, begins at 8 with ''Who's the Boss?'' and ends at 11 after ''Thirtysomething.'' In between come ''The Wonder Years,'' ''Roseanne'' (42 million viewers, says ABC) and ''Anything but Love.'' Their appeal, to judge by last week's showing, has to do partly with the reassurance they offer that the direst events, including those that pound away at us on the news programs, can, with humor and affection, be managed.

title: Cincinnati Fans Stand Up for Rose
description: Pete Rose received two standing ovations from the capacity crowd of 55,385 at Riverfront Stadium this afternoon. Rose has been used to cheers, but these, on opening day of the baseball season, were different, if not special.

title: Earle Palmer Brown
description: Earle Palmer Brown's newly opened New York office lured yet another account from Christopher Thomas/Muller Jordan Weiss on Friday, as Town & Country magazine selected the agency for its $1 million consumer and trade advertising account. Last week, the office won the account for Conrad International hotels from Christopher Thomas.

title: Philadelphia Academy Is Closed for Repairs
description: The Academy of Music has been closed for at least a week while engineers inspect two widening cracks in a wooden beam that were discovered Friday in the 132-year-old building and that halted the Philadelphia Orchestra's weekly afternoon concert.

title: Dollar Falls After Allies' Warning
description: The dollar fell sharply today in response to a warning from the United States and its economic allies that the dollar's value should not be pushed higher.

title: No Peace From Mr. Shamir
description: LEAD: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, will arrive in Washington tomorrow equipped not with new ideas but with a tired recipe for maintaining the status quo -which only means the further deterioration of an intolerable situation in the occupied territories. Whether he meets with a firm rebuff or the usual complacent indulgence in Washington will be a test of how serious the Bush Administration is about the search for Middle

title: Super Rite Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about equipment used in cleaning up the Alaskan oil spill included an incorrect report from The Associated Press in some editions about the tanker captain's drinking. Court documents show that the captain, Joseph Hazelwood, admitted having drunk before boarding the Exxon Valdez, not while on board.

title: Varity in 3d Offer For Fruehauf
description: The Varity Corporation, a maker of diesel engines and other machinery, said it was making another bid for the Fruehauf Corporation, its third effort to acquire the Detroit-based maker of automobile parts. Varity, based in Toronto, declined to disclose details of its latest bid.

title: Soviets and Cubans Seem to Be Making Progress on Debt Question
description: The Soviet Union and Cuba appeared today to be moving toward common ground on an issue with powerful political resonance in Latin America, the region's huge debt.

title: Report on Harrods
description: The British Government rejected demands for immediate publication of a secret report into the takeover of Harrods department store by three Egyptian brothers after a bid by Lonrho P.L.C. was blocked by the Government. Lord Young, the Trade and Industry Minister, said premature publication would bar prosecutions for wrongdoing by the Serious Fraud Office. The trade department won a court order last Thursday preventing Lonrho and a newspaper it owns, The Observer, from printing excerpts of the report.

title: Pinchas H. Peli, 59, Dies in Israel; Noted Author and Judaic Scholar
description: Dr. Pinchas H. Peli, an Israeli rabbi and professor whose books, essays and lectures placed him among the world's most popular contemporary Jewish scholars, died of cancer complicated by pneumonia yesterday. He was 59 years old and lived in Jerusalem.

title: H.V. Alessandroni, 81, 30's Olympics Fencer
description: Hugo Vincent Alessandroni, a chemical engineer who won a bronze medal in fencing in the Olympics in 1932, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Little Silver, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: Westchester Passes Anti-Smoking Bill Despite Opposition
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators today approved an anti-smoking bill despite objections by anti-smoking groups that it was too weak to be effective.

title: Orioles Go 1-0 to Start '89 at Top
description: The Baltimore Orioles, losers of their first 21 games last year, won their season opener today, beating the American League East champion Boston Red Sox, 5-4, on an 11th-inning single by the rookie Craig Worthington.

title: Trial Involving Therapy Group Gets Under Way
description: The highly unorthodox styles of life and psychological practices of the Sullivanians, a 200-member therapeutic group that lives communally on the Upper West Side, went on trial yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan as a former member sought custody of his 6-year-old son.

title: The Mets' Unwritten Burden
description: If there's anybody out there who hasn't chosen the Mets to win the National League East, please stand up. And stand corrected. The National League West is a tossup. So is the American League East. And some people think that somehow the Oakland Athletics won't dominate the American League West as they did last year. But to most people, the Mets are a cinch. Too much talent. Too much experience. And especially too much pitching.

title: Oilfields Scar Arctic Wildlife Refuge Even Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Keefe, Bruyette Chief Quits Over Differences
description: Harry V. Keefe Jr., a founder of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a Wall Street investment firm that concentrates on the banking industry, has retired after a dispute with his longtime associates and has formed a new firm, Keefe Consultants Inc.

title: Linguists Solve Riddles of Ancient Mayan Language
description: USING the latest tools of linguistic analysis and with modern languages as guides, scholars are making rapid progress in deciphering the ancient Mayan language.

title: Disease-Carrying Mice Freed
description: A group calling itself the Animal Liberation Front claimed responsibility for freeing more than 1,000 animals, some of them mice carrying a potentially deadly disease, from research laboratories at the University of Arizona this morning and for setting fires that caused an estimated $100,000 damage.

title: Review/Dance; Potpourri Wraps Up Morningside Festival
description: The Morningside Dance Festival's closing showcase program, presented on Saturday night at the Horace Mann Theater of Teachers College at Columbia University, was surprisingly weak, raising questions about the selection process for the series and about the point of the festival itself, which began on March 20.

title: Tobacco May One Day Be Factory for Anti-Cancer Drugs
description: Tobacco might one day be genetically altered to produce anti-cancer drugs, sunscreens and a variety of therapeutic proteins and commercial products, rather than cigarettes, a biologist said today.

title: Carson Pirie Shares Soar 52% on Bid
description: The common stock of Carson Pirie Scott Inc., the Chicago retailer, jumped 52 percent yesterday in the wake of a $282 million takeover offer from P. A. Bergner & Company, a Milwaukee retailer that competes with a number of Carson branches.

title: Notes and Bonds Up in Volatile Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were higher at the end of an active, volatile session yesterday, buoyed by further indications of sluggishness in the economy and hopes that a peak in interest rates may be near.

title: The Budget
description: This is one person's experience playing the Deficit Reduction Game, a computer game developed by a Federal budget official to illustrate the challenge of balancing the budget. The choices the player faces at each step are the same ones confronting White House and Congressional budget negotiators as they try to cut the deficit from more than $150 billion to zero in five years.

title: American Oil & Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said Welltech Inc.'s results were fully consolidated for the entire year of 1988, as compared to 3 months of consolidation for the fourth quarter of 1987. For the first 9 months of 1987, Welltech's results were accounted for using the equity method reflecting the company's 37 percent interest in Welltech.

title: Reviews/Music; Like a Literal Love Machine
