description: Virginia Sandifur, the singer and actress who made her featured Broadway debut in ''Follies,'' bubbles with a buoyant good-humored energy that is better suited to musical comedy material than to soulful self-revelation.

title: Publisher Quits at New York Post
description: A year after taking the job and a month after initiating a Sunday edition, Peter O. Price resigned yesterday as publisher of The New York Post.

title: Patterns
description: Growing Up With Guess Guess Inc., known for jeans that look poured on and for black-and-white advertisements that seem dipped in Vaseline, is about to trade up its image and its merchandise. Losing no time after winning a court battle to regain control of their company from Jordache Enterprises, the Marciano brothers of Guess - Georges, Maurice, Armand and Paul - are starting a new division devoted to better men's wear.

title: Baruch-Foster reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net charge of $873,850 from the writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Enscor Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $250,000 special gain. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Armada Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Halley's as Interloper
description: NEW observations of the chemical composition of Halley's comet suggest that the illustrious traveler through the solar system may be an interloper from deep space, astronomers have reported.

title: Inner Problems Shackle The Washington Police
description: The police force here is struggling with more than just the most lethal drug epidemic in the country.

title: INSIDE
description: Change at New York Post A year after taking the job and a month after initiating a Sunday edition, Peter O. Price resigned as publisher of The New York Post, surprising the paper's owner. Page D1. Criminal-Justice Crisis The thousands of drug cases generated by the police drive against crack are almost certain to paralyze courts in New York City this summer, officials say. Page B1. Monitoring the Gulf Truce Peering across a buffer zone rimmed by fortifications of a tired war, a United Nations team monitors the Persian Gulf cease-fire. Page A10. Pocket of Rebellion in Haiti Holdouts in a failed coup attempt in Haiti fought with Government troops, and diplomats said as many as four were killed. Page A5.

title: Michigan Works Overtime, but It's Worth It
description: The dramatic elements were there for each team. Michigan had lost its regular head coach on the eve of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and had become the first team in history to reach the championship game with an interim coach. Seton Hall, with no majestic tradition to think of, had simply gone from unheralded to great overnight.

title: I.M.F. Sees Trade Deficit Of U.S. Rising Next Year
description: The International Monetary Fund predicted today that the American trade deficit would increase next year, the first time it has issued such a forecast.

title: Colorocs Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it restated its results for the third quarter and 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1988 to reflect a change in accounting for its investment in Savin Corp. The third quarter net income, previously reported as $1,746,000, was adjusted to $5,000. It said the 9 months net income of $593,000 was adjusted to a loss of $1,148,000.

title: Officer Charged in Incident
description: A white Long Beach police officer was charged today with using excessive force when he arrested a black off-duty police officer who was conducting a videotaped ''sting'' operation to illustrate allegations of police racism. The misdemeanor charge against Officer Mark Dickey carries a maximum penalty of a year in prison. In the videotape of the incident, Officer Dickey appeared to shove Don Jackson's head through a store window.

title: Where Chicago Flag and Rushdie Affairs Differ
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; A Variety From Flute And Harp
description: The combination of flute and harp is a delicious orchestral color. Its potential charm in chamber music is apparent enough, but the equally obvious challenge in a program like the one Carol Wincenc and Nancy Allen gave Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall is to forestall objections of the kind one might make to a beautifully cooked meal in which every course involved candied fruit. There was enough variety Friday, but - for the taste of a listener not completely seduced by the combination to start with - just barely.

title: New Lives Start At Group Home: 'Feels Beautiful'
description: Everyone was supposed to be at the new group home for the retarded at 1 P.M. to move in, so of course they were there at 12:30. They each picked a room upstairs; the workers are still finishing the downstairs. The house looked so fresh, so clean, you would never guess that just six weeks ago, as finishing touches were being applied, someone firebombed it.

title: Flames Are Expected Among the Final Cast
description: The Edmonton Oilers traded Wayne Gretzky to the Los Angeles Kings and then dropped to third place in the Smythe Division.

title: Portrait of a Junkie
description: Joletha Simmons, a 34-year-old addict, mixes heroin with water on a soda can, heats the mixture with a flame and draws it into her syringe. Then, peering into a mirror, she puffs her cheek to make a vein stand out in her neck and plunges the needle in. She pauses to wipe tears from her eyes, then bows her head, as if in prayer, while the drug takes effect.

title: Dispute on Access to Beach In New Jersey Goes to Court
description: A campaign by the New Jersey Public Advocate to broaden public access to the beachfront moved into the courtroom today in a suit against one of the state's most affluent shore towns.

title: Servotronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $73,000 for the quarter and $173,000 for the year. c-Included a tax credit of $416,000.

title: NCNB Chairman's Southern Empire
description: In the manner of notches on a gunslinger's gun, the old certificates of incorporation of some two dozen banks acquired by the NCNB Corporation hang in frames on the wall of the Charlotte, N.C., office of the company's chairman, Hugh L. McColl Jr. They bear mute testimony to Mr. McColl's six years as head of what is now the nation's 10th-largest banking company - a time of acquisitions, aggressive lending and an intense management style that has bolstered the company's profile and its profits.

title: Sears Ad Deal With Gannett
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has negotiated an agreement with the Gannett Company that will allow the centralized purchase of advertising in almost 80 of the chain's newspapers.

title: Tofutti Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 loss included a $463,000 tax benefit.

title: Walshire Assurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Westchester Announces Plan To Tighten Water Restrictions
description: Westchester County announced today that it would tighten restrictions on the use of water beginning April 17, moving to the same drought constraints imposed by New York City on March 22.

title: Charge Dropped on Bogus Work
description: A SOCIAL worker who was charged with unethical conduct after submitting a fictitious article to academic journals has been exonerated. But now he may face new ethics charges for having discussed his case with reporters.

title: Airlines Urged To Act Quickly Against Threats
description: The Bush Administration announced rules today aimed at sharpening airline responses to warnings of terrorist threats, but it flatly refused to make such warnings public.

title: A Rich Ecosystem Suddenly at Risk
description: The oil spill in Prince William Sound occurred in one of the richest concentrations of animals in North America and it occurred at the worst possible time, just as salmon, herring and other fish are beginning to spawn.

title: Pioneer Metals reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The 1988 loss included a $25.1 million special charge related to the carrying value of the Puffy Lake gold mine in Manitoba. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: HMG-Courtland Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $760,000 and $3,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively and a $520,613 loss for the quarter and a gain of $10,142,405 for the year, both on the sale of real estate. c-Net loss d-Included a loss of $337,310 for the quarter and a gain of $3,479,799 for the year, both on the sale of real estate.

title: VMS Short Term Income Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Carel Goldschmidt, 84; Led Tobacco Concern
description: Carel Goldschmidt, former president of the American Sumatra Tobacco Corporation, died of a heart attack Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Music; Tomorrow's Singers in Met Concert
description: The Metropolitan Opera has one of the more civilized ways of dealing with the competitive process in music. This year, as usual, the Met's National Council has listened to singers in 8 regions of the country and chosen 10 of the best. There are, of course, losers along the way, but the appearance of all 10 finalists on the Met's stage Sunday afternoon had a way of softening the gladiatorial aspect that music contests have taken on.

title: Great Country Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Accounts
description: * Encyclopaedia Britannica, to Ogilvy & Mather Direct, with a budget of $10 million.

title: Coast Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included tax credits of $700,000 for the quarter and $2,900,000 for the year. The prior year operating net included pretax income of $1.4 million from a litigation settlement.

title: The Many TV Faces of a Presidency
description: Most Americans tune in to their President through television. Here is what they saw Saturday night on CBS News: Oil, miles of it, spread across Prince William Sound. Then ducks drenched in oil. Then President Bush playing horseshoes.

title: Houston Journal; Firm but Helping Hand Is Transforming Slum
description: Just inside the entrance to the Pine Terrace garden apartments here, two men are fixing their car. Greasy parts are scattered over recently mowed grass, and the carburetor is nudging the pansy bed.

title: Kean Offers Plan to Teach 4 'Core Values' in Schools
description: Governor Thomas H. Kean, saying the moral influence of the family, religion and education had declined over the last generation, released a plan today for the teaching of values and character ideals in New Jersey's public schools.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Waterhouse Investors Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
4 Books by Professionals In Academia
description: THE advertising library, never empty, is straining under the weight of four new books by advertising professionals turned academic thinkers.

title: Eastern Sale By Ueberroth Appears Near
description: Peter V. Ueberroth and his group of investors were negotiating again yesterday with representatives of the Texas Air Corporation for the purchase of Eastern Airlines. People involved in the talks said the sale of the carrier to the former baseball commissioner was imminent.

title: Knicks' Defense Fails to Deter the 76ers
description: The Knicks figure to meet the Philadelphia 76ers in the opening round of the playoffs. And if they do, they will have to play a lot better than they did last night.

title: Cintas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Maynard Oil Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $940,000 from sale of property. c-Net income

title: Scripps May Make Bid
description: The E. W. Scripps Company says it may offer to acquire a controlling interest in American City Business Journals Inc. for $22 a share. Scripps, the Cincinnati-based newspaper chain, already controls 21 percent of American City, a chain of weekly business publications. In a letter to Michael K. Russell, American City's chairman, and William H. Worley, a director, Scripps indicated that it was considering a cash offer for their holdings.

title: New Lineup at the Pentagon
description: Donald J. Atwood Jr., Deputy Secretary of Defense (formerly vice chairman of the General Motors Corporation). Paul G. Wolfowitz, Under Secretary for Policy (Ambassador to Indonesia; a Bush choice). Richard L. Armitage, Secretary of the Army (moving up from Assistant Secretary for International Security Affairs). H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, Secretary of the Navy (moving up from Under Secretary of the Navy). Donald B. Rice, Secretary of the Air Force (was chief executive officer and president of the Rand Corporation). George Van Cleve, Legal Counsel (legal counsel to Mr. Cheney when he was House Republican whip). David J. Gribbin, Assistant Secretary for Legislative Affairs (formerly chief of the minority whip's staff). Pete Williams, Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs (was Mr. Cheney's Congressional spokesman). David S. Addington, Special Assistant to the Secretary (member of the whip staff). Kathleen S. Embodie, Confidential Assistant to the Secretary (executive assistant to Mr. Cheney in Congress). Still open - Under Secretary for Acquisition.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: AS we move into the season of fresh vegetables, warmer weather and impending revelation by bathing suit, soups that use available vegetables and add scant calories become even more attractive. The microwave oven makes short work of broth and vegetables while retaining their brilliant color and clean flavors.

title: Citicorp Rates Off
description: At Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday, interest rates declined for the second consecutive week after peaking at the March 21 auction.

title: A Masters Landmark Is Given a New Look
description: The Masters has lost its barefoot image.

title: Medical Groups Ask High Court to Reject Restrictions on Abortion
description: The American Medical Association and seven other medical groups have asked the Supreme Court to overturn a state law restricting abortion, saying the procedure does not cause psychiatric or physical harm.

title: MCM Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $69,000 for the quarter and $110,000 for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $1,227,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $5,822,000 for the year; quarter also included a tax credit of $34,000. The latest fourth quarter and year also included charges for discontinued property and casualty programs of about $4.9 million for the quarter and about $9 million for the year; quarter also included a $3.5 million gain in connection with a pension- plan termination. The 1987 year included charges for discontinued property and casualty programs of about $21 million.

title: Liberal Party, Breaking With Democrats, to Endorse Giuliani
description: Breaking with its traditional Democratic allies, the Liberal Party will endorse a Republican, Rudolph W. Giuliani, for mayor of New York City.

title: Apple-Juice Maker in Layoffs
description: A local apple-juice maker laid off nearly three-quarters of its workforce today because its products have been found to contain Alar. Hudson Valley Apple Products Inc., which said it had lost nearly 90 percent of its customers since last Wednesday, announced the cuts following a report from Consumers Union that said some samples of its juice had unacceptably high levels of daminozide, a chemical that helps apples stay on trees longer to ripen. The company said that since 1968 it has required farmers to certify that they don't use Alar and insisted that its juice is safe.

title: Tribune Co. To Buy Stock
description: The Tribune Company today announced a stock repurchase plan under which it will buy up to eight million shares of its stock in the open market.

title: What Is Irish Cuisine?
description: To The Living Section:

title: Why Nursing Homes Use Antipsychotic Drugs; Paying for Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown, Robert C & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $202,170 from the early retirement of debt. c-Net income and after extraordinary gains of $244,822 and $313,995 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the early retirement of debt.

title: Florio Opens Offensive In Joining Jersey Race
description: Representative James J. Florio formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor this week and quickly attacked the Kean administration on issues ranging from auto insurance to local taxes.

title: Nouvelle Tex-Mex: Mole and Riesling
description: In the last decade, Texas, the land of chili, beef and Tex-Mex food, has gained renown as a center of sophisticated Southwestern cuisine and for its budding wine industry. And for many of the 1,200 food lovers who converged on Austin last weekend for the fourth annual Hill Country Wine and Food Festival, it was considered a victory that smoked shrimp quesadillas could co-exist with cheese enchiladas, and chenin blanc with Lone Star beer.

title: A Mutual Admiration Flourishes
description: FOR 14 years Andre Soltner, the chef and owner of Lutece, has offered Domaine Zind-Humbrecht wines from his native Alsace at his restaurant. Leonard Humbrecht, a leading Alsatian vintner, has returned the favor by naming a parcel of the tiny and prestigious Clos St. Urbain vineyard after Mr. Soltner.

title: Borough-Sclerosis
description: LEAD: The United States Supreme Court has ruled that the governing structure of New York City is unconstitutional. Accordingly, the Charter Revision Commission has set to work to remedy that problem. With deference to the Court, however, the question of the city's formal structure is only mildly important.

title: Lemieux Is Ready To Show Still More
description: The numbers are big and impressive: In 76 games, there were 85 goals and 114 assists for 199 points, a total that accounted for 57 percent of his team's scoring for the season. As adjectives, monstrous and frightening are almost up to the task of describing the numbers.

title: 4,000 Soviet Jews Migrated in March, Highest in a Decade
description: More than 4,000 Jews were allowed to leave the Soviet Union last month, the highest monthly total in 10 years, a group that campaigns for Soviet Jewish emigration rights announced yesterday.

title: Review/Music; An Early-Instruments Man Makes New York Debut
description: Roger Norrington's American debut Sunday evening, leading the Orchestra of St. Luke's in Beethoven's last two symphonies, was not exactly long awaited, because Mr. Norrington has only been famous for a couple of years. But reputations grow fast in the publicity-driven, record-dominated musical world, and expectation was intense.

title: Lessons
description: The next decade will bring some historic changes. In 1992, Western Europe becomes a single economic entity. In 1997, Hong Kong becomes part of China.

title: EATING WELL
description: LEAD: CHICKEN and turkey are almost requirements for people trying to remove fat from their diets while keeping the satisfactions of meat on the table. In fact, given their low fat content, availability and versatility, one could argue that every chicken and turkey ought to have a brace of medals pinned to its breast before being stacked in a refrigerated truck on its way to your neighborhood market.

title: Argentina's Economy Minister Has No Miracle to Offer
description: Argentina's new economy minister, Juan Carlos Pugliese, took office today and warned people not to expect miracles.

title: Anchors Are Drawn Into Gorbachev Orbit
description: The broadcast networks regularly commit resources and manpower to covering United States Presidential visits abroad. But this week, they are lavishing air time and money on the leader of the Soviet Union.

title: Senators Fault Capital Mayor on Crime
description: Angry and frustrated senators today told Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. that he was not doing enough to solve the drug problem in the capital.

title: Matthews & Wright Gr reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Occupying an Apartment Is Not Like Occupying a Hospital Bed; Scapegoats
description: To the Editor:

title: Max & Erma's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 19
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $107,000 for the latest first quarter and $48,000 for the year-ago period. All results have been adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split payable April 21 to stockholders of record March 31.

title: Search for Brooklyn Baby Expands
description: The New York City police broadened their search yesterday for a 6-week-old Brooklyn boy who disappeared with his mother last week, two days before the woman's body was found in the Bronx.

title: Symbol Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Symbol Technologies in November changed its fiscal year-end from June 30 to Dec. 31. The share earnings for all periods are fully diluted. The company said results for the short fiscal year included costs associated with the merger with MSI.

title: Tyco Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The results of Mueller Co. and Atcor Inc. have been included since the dates of their acquisition on Sept. 30, 1988 and Aug. 10, 1987, respectively.

title: World Bank and I.M.F. Approve Plan to Cut Debt of Poorer Lands
description: The countries that manage global finance today approved the first internationally organized effort to reduce the $1.3 trillion of debt that has paralyzed much growth in the developing world, especially Latin America.

title: Oppenheimer Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Oil and Dirty Hands
description: The wreck of the Exxon Valdez: it's already the largest American oil spill. It may yet turn out to be America's most profound environmental disaster. It undermines the oil industry's credibility and threatens future exploration. And its traces will last for years to come, grim reminders of carelessness and official self-deception.

title: Substance in Meat Is Found to Fight Cancer
description: Further confusing the association between diet and cancer, a food researcher said today that a substance in fatty meats and cheeses protects mice against cancer.

title: PRETORIA WARNS U.N. ABOUT NAMIBIA
description: South Africa threatened tonight to suspend Namibia's transition to independence unless the United Nations curtailed the infiltration of guerrillas into the territory.

title: North East Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $163,000 and $578,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $108,000 for the quarter and $540,000 for year. The company said its fourth quarter and year earnings represent its audited results; it reported preliminary results on Feb. 11.

title: Lottie S. Gold, Lawyer, 82
description: Lottie Stillerman Gold, a retired lawyer and former government official, died of a heart attack Monday at Long Beach (L.I.) Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in Long Beach.

title: Occupying an Apartment Is Not Like Occupying a Hospital Bed
description: To the Editor:

title: Fuel Prices Rise in California
description: Gasoline prices in California have risen sharply since the oil spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound, with increases at the pump ranging from as little as 2 cents to more than 20 cents a gallon.

title: Unifirst Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Radar Could Have Tracked Tanker
description: Coast Guard officials acknowledged today that contrary to their earlier statements, their radar station here could have detected the supertanker Exxon Valdez heading for a reef on March 24 if operators had followed the ship on her journey out of Prince William Sound.

title: Futuresat Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. Asked to Release Foreigner With AIDS
description: A Congresswoman is trying today to win the release of a Dutch visitor who was detained at a Minnesota airport because he has AIDS.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A RECENTLY discovered case of leftover Beaujolais nouveau, purchased last fall, prompted me to come up with a dish that could make use of this light and fruity wine. Wine authorities say the short-lived, unaged Beaujolais nouveau should be consumed within six months since it does not have the tannin or barrel aging to impart complexity or shelf life, although I have enjoyed bottles that had been kept in a cool cellar for a year or more.

title: Alexander Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Long Lake Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Holtzman May Appeal Probation For Immigrant in Wife's Slaying
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday that she may appeal a judge's decision last week to give five years' probation to a Chinese immigrant convicted of bludgeoning his wife to death with a hammer.

title: Warming Up: McDowell
description: Manager Davey Johnson said yesterday he still had confidence in Roger McDowell as the right-handed stopper of the Mets' pitching staff. But it seemed clear that McDowell's disastrous performances this spring (10.05 e.r.a.) had changed the emphasis in the bullpen for now and had opened an opportunity for Don Aase, who became an instant hero with a save on opening day.

title: Strober Organization reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Strober said the sales gains were due to its acquisition of General Building Supply Co. in January 1988. It said interest expense for the latest year was $1,516,000 higher than during the prior year, stemming from the financing of the General Building acquisition. In addition, amortization of goodwill and a non-compete covenant related to the acquisition amounted to $834,000 for the latest year.

title: Guillevin International Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: More Soviet Surprises
description: Even Communist Party officials most supportive of Mikhail Gorbachev's reform program admit they were startled by the way the Soviet people took up their first real chance at elections.

title: New York Officials Reject Joint AIDS Group
description: New York State officials have rejected an advisory panel's recommendation for a new city-state commission to oversee AIDS policy and services.

title: I.B.M. Making Version Of Powerful Intel Chip

Somerset is the parent of Somerset Savings, a savings bank with $620 million in assets and four branches.

NCNB-Citizens
description: The NCNB Corporation said there was ''no merit'' to assertions by the Citizens and Southern Corporation that a Government-assisted bank deal in Texas enabled NCNB to make a $2.4 billion bid for Citizens and Southern. NCNB said there was ''no regulatory issue'' over its operations in Texas that would prevent approval of its offer for Citizens and Southern. Citizens and Southern has maintained that NCNB's ability to make the offer rested largely on benefits it received from its Government-assisted acquisition of the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas. NCNB said it had no contractual obligation to receive the approval of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to consummate any new transaction and that it was not using Government assistance on the Citizens and Southern offer.

title: Record Price for a Klee Is Paid at a London Sale

title: A Double Bill That Stars Simplicity Itself
description: A fantasy about a childlike middle-aged Dutch baker and a documentary about a well-known sculptor rearranging stones in the Sahara definitely sounds like a forced double bill. But ''Egg,'' Danniel Danniel's fiction about a 35-year-old naif, and Philip Haas's ''Stones and Flies: Richard Long in the Sahara,'' are both sophisticated films about simplicity itself. These two unconventional works, opening today at Film Forum 1, run scarcely more than an hour and a half combined. They are energetic, engaging, paradoxical little forays into one huge question: how do simple values and forms survive in our complex modern world?

RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf and Navratilova Advance: Top-seeded Steffi Graf and Martina Navratilova, seeded second, both struggled in the early going before winning yesterday in the second round of the $300,000 Family Circle Magazine Cup tournament at Sea Pines Racquet Club at Hilton Head Island, S.C. Graf, the top-ranked women's player in the world, defeated Rosalyn Fairbank of South Africa, 6-4, 6-3. Navratilova was extended to three sets before defeating Laura Gildemeister of Peru, 6-4, 4-6, 6-0. Zina Garrison, seeded third, withdrew from the competition yesterday. She suffered a groin pull against Chris Evert during the the Lipton International Players Championship last week. The only seeded player to lose was No. 12 Raffaella Reggi of Italy, who fell to Jana Pospisilova of Czechoslovakia, 7-5, 6-4. Graf's match with Fairbank lasted 76 minutes under a hot midday sun in the stadium court. The 19-year-old West German fell behind by 4-3 in the first set before taking three straight games. Graf double-faulted to end the sixth game of the second set and allow Fairbank to draw even at 3-3. But Graf then rattled off three straight points to take the set and the match. ''The first match is a little tougher than usual and you're not as patient,'' said Graf, who had a bye in the first round Monday. ''Rosalyn was playing really well. She kept the ball in play and I really didn't have the rhythm.'' Graf, who hasn't lost a match this year, said she was a little anxious. Graf did not play in the tournament last year. Navratilova is the defending champion. In other second round action, Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, seeded fourth, defeated Wendy White of Atlanta, 6-1, 6-2, and Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden, seeded 10th, beat Camille Benjamin of Cleveland, 3-6, 6-4, 6-1. Other winners included Aranixa Sanchez of Spain, Linda Ferrando of Italy, Regina Rajchrtova of Czechoslovakia and Karen Schimper of South Africa. Shaun Stafford of Gainesville, Fla., defeated Donna Faber of Bradenton, Fla., 4-6, 7-5, 6-4, in the continuation of a first-round match suspended Monday because of darkness.(AP)

title: Trial Is Set for a Fourth Man In Murder of Officer Bryne

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL The countries that manage global finance approved the first internationally organized effort to reduce the third world's $1.3 trillion debt. The idea is to persuade commercial banks to lower the debt they hold from developing nations in return for either new bonds or shares of third-world business enterprises. [ Page A1. ] Argentina's new economy minister took office and warned people not to expect miracles. [ D2. ] COMPANIES New York State's highest court issued the nation's broadest guidelines for women to recover damages from makers of the drug DES, which has been linked to cancer, miscarriages and infertility. Among the drug companies affected by the ruling are Lilly, Squibb, Abbott, Boyle, Rorer, Upjohn and Merck. [ A1. ] A financial crisis may be brewing in the insurance industry. Concern is mounting among public officials and analysts as losses in the industry grow. [ A1. ] Lockheed said it would sell some nonmilitary businesses and put 17 percent of its stock in the hands of employees. The announcement reflects growing pressures in military contracting. [ D1. ] Drexel's chief executive is facing a complex challenge: restoring confidence in the firm when questions are being raised about his leadership. [ D1. ] Auto companies had the weakest annualized sales rate in 17 months. A new round of incentives came too late to help. [ D1. ] Peter V. Ueberroth was talking with Texas Air about buying Eastern Airlines. A deal was said to be imminent. [ D1. ] Consolidated Gold Fields gave stockholders a ''pep pill'' in a move to defuse an anticipated new takeover bid by Minorco. [ D4. ] I.B.M. has begun making its own version of an Intel chip used in the computer maker's top-of-the-line personal computer. [ D4. ] American Airlines received approval to fly trans-Pacific routes in a Boeing jet that has just two engines and two pilots. [ D4. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 6.60 points, to 2,298.20, in moderate trading, and traders said investors were increasingly concerned that the economy is slowing. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds continued to rise, and short-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels in nearly a month, after auto sales figures were weaker than expected and positive technical factors set off good buying. [ D18. ] Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were up. [ D18. ] The dollar continued to decline amid signs that large industrial nations want it lower. Gold prices were narrowly mixed. [ D19. ] Futures prices for coffee surged on a lack of bad news from the International Coffee Organization meetings in London. [ D19. ] TECHNOLOGY For locomotive makers, hard times are over. The number of machines delivered jumped from 131 in 1987 to 531 in 1988 and could reach 700 this year. [ D1. ] Three companies are hoping their products - laboratory-grown versions of human skin - will offer a testing alternative to animals and capture part of the billion-dollar testing market. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS ''Managed trade'' is anathema to most mainstream economists, but it appeals to diplomats and politicians as a way to deal with Japan's surplus. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Price competition has grown among Wall Street discounters. A survey of 100 independent discount brokers and 150 bank brokers finds that commission rates vary enormously. Market Place. [ D10. ] Four books were published recently by ad professionals turned academic thinkers. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: Review/Theater; A 3-Day Immersion in New Plays
description: An intensive three days at the Actors Theater of Louisville, seeing plays that often dealt with family and fraternal bonds, brought to mind the company's own past tie with new and developing talent, the founding tradition of the Humana Festival of New American Plays. Under the direction of Jon Jory, the Actors Theater has deservedly won a place as a valuable nurturer of Beth Henley, Marsha Norman, Jane Martin and many other playwrights.

title: 5 More Kidder Departures
description: The head of Kidder, Peabody & Company's mergers and acquisitions department, David C. Wittig, has resigned to join Salomon Brothers Inc. along with four other Kidder investment bankers.

title: Sensormatic Canada Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Wilson Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $951,000 and a reversal of a tax credit of $1,091,000. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $4,321,000 and a tax credit of $2,740,000.

title: American Building Holding Sale Talks
description: The chairman and vice chairman of American Building Maintenance Industries, who control a combined 29.6 percent of the company's shares outstanding, said they had been contacted by a third party interested in acquiring the San Francisco-based building services concern. On Monday, American Building said it was in preliminary discussions with the unidentified third party about a possible sale of the San Francisco-based building services concern.

title: Sale Is Set For Sardi's
description: Broadway Holdings Inc., a real estate developer, announced yesterday that it would acquire Sardi's restaurant in Manhattan in a stock transaction valued at $7.8 million. Broadway Holdings, based in New York, also said it would assume responsibility for retiring $7.2 million in notes for Sardi's.

title: A Jet Crash-Lands in Flames At Peru Airport, Injuring 11
description: A domestic jetliner carrying 137 people crash-landed in flames at a jungle airport, injuring 11 passengers and crew members, officials said today. They said the others escaped unharmed.

title: Boeing Jet Order
description: Piedmont Airlines has ordered three 767-200 extended-range jetliners in a deal valued at about $183 million, the Boeing Commercial Airplanes Company announced. Deliveries of two of the jets are scheduled in March 1990, and the third in September 1990. The planes will be powered by the General Electric Company's CF6-80C2B2 engines, as are six 767's already operated by Piedmont. The 767-200ER is a long-range jet that can operate at distances of up to 5,750 miles.

title: Werner Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Dow in China Deal
description: The Dow Chemical Company entered a joint venture with China's Zhejiang Chemical Factory to build a $50 million chemical plant in Ningbo, China. The new company, the Zhejiang Pacific Chemical Corporation, in Zhejiang Province on the East China Sea, will produce 20,000 metric tons a year of polyether polyol, Dow said. Polyether polyol is used to make foam for furniture, seat cushions, mattresses, automobile parts, laminated fabrics and building insulation.

title: Brother John E. Daly, Educator, 70
description: Brother John E. Daly, a former dean of students and professor of philosophy at Iona College, died of complications from emphysema Sunday at St. Joseph's Residence in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: New Advances In Electronics
description: Researchers in the United States and Japan say they have laid a thin superconducting film on top of silicon, a development that represents another step toward using new superconducting materials in electronics.

title: Security American Financial Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
International Pursuit Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said 1988 revenue does not include $1,022,783 from the sale of an investment. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Europe Unsettled by Gorbachev Drive
description: The Western allies are far apart in their views of how to respond to the profound changes Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies have set in motion in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, as he begins a series of trips to European capitals with a visit to London from Wednesday to Friday.

title: CHINA'S CONGRESS AIRS SOME DISCORD
description: The approval of laws became more complicated in China today, as the National People's Congress adjourned its annual session with a rare flurry of ''no'' votes.

title: 'Your Family' Debut
description: Treading the same territory as Whittle Communications, Family Media Publications has announced the publication of a magazine aimed at women waiting in doctors' offices. ''Your Family,'' which is scheduled to begin in September, will circulate to 29,000 physicians' offices, representing 50,000 pediatricians, family practitioners and obstetrician/gynecologists, none of whom receive Whittle's ''Special Reports,'' a Family Media spokesman said. Like Whittle, Family Media is guaranteeing advertisers category exclusivity for their products; unlike Whittle, which has 30 pages of advertising an issue, ''Your Family'' will limit ad pages to 20.

title: WINE TALK
description: YOU know those old saws: If you liked the book, you'll love the movie. If a thing is worth doing, it's worth doing twice. Well, consider if you will, the case of Beaujolais, the only wine that comes not once, but twice in a year.

title: Now That's A Payday
description: I like to see somebody have a big payday. That's why I was for the big Congressional pay raise when all right thinkers from Ralph Nader to the impoverished philosophers who run radio talk shows were against it.

title: Rozelle Rules That Sanders Can Enter the N.F.L. Draft
description: Barry Sanders, the Oklahoma State running back and Heisman Trophy winner, yesterday became eligible for the National Football League draft April 23-24. Steve Walsh, the Miami quarterback, said he would also forsake his final year of college eligibility and turn pro.

title: CUBANS ARRESTED DURING SOVIET VISIT
description: More than half a dozen Cuban human rights campaigners were jailed today as they prepared to stage a demonstration appealing for support from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: GORBACHEV SIGNS TREATY WITH CUBA
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for an end to all outside military aid to Latin America, and signed a friendship treaty with Cuba condemning the use of force as an instrument of foreign policy.

title: Dynamic Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RTI Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $46,839.

title: Artificial Human Skin For Use in Product Tests
description: The controversy over animal rights has intensified the search by drug, cosmetics and chemical manufacturers for alternatives to using animals in tests to establish the safety and efficacy of many products used by humans.

title: New Season for John Starts Same Old Way
description: The only thing that went wrong on one of the great nights in the life of the Tommy John family was that Sally John took the videocamera to the Metrodome but left the tape at the hotel.

title: American Air Flights Cleared
description: American Airlines said today that it had received approval from the Federal Aviation Administration to fly trans-Pacific routes in the Boeing Company's 767-300ER, which has just two engines and two pilots.

title: Acceptance Insurance Holdngs Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $38,781 for the latest year and realized investment losses of $59,627 for the year-earlier period.

title: Summations Under Way
description: Describing the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom as ''two hustlers from New York . . . who steamrolled over anyone, any institution, that they perceived as standing in their way,'' Howard Pearl, a Federal prosecutor, asked a jury today to find the defendants guilty of mail fraud and racketeering in connection with their representation of several prominent college athletes.

title: Teamster Chief Links 2 Predecessors to Mafia
description: The president of the teamsters' union denied today that he had ever had contacts with organized crime but, in an animated appearance before a Senate subcommittee, testified that two men who preceded him in that post had had such contacts.

title: Haiti Deports 3 Leaders of Failed Coup
description: The Haitian Government said today that it had deported three officers believed to have led a failed coup attempt against Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, the President. Also today, rebellious soldiers who seized the international airport on Monday retreated from their strongholds and returned to their barracks.

title: Two Inspectors For the Schools Are Convicted
description: Two maintenance inspectors with the New York City Board of Education were convicted yesterday of extorting almost $122,000 in payoffs from small contractors who do business with the board.

title: California Yields 6.6%-7.25%
description: In the municipal bond market yesterday, California priced an issue of $280 million worth of serial bonds in competitive bidding.

title: MGM-UA Communications Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Du Pont-Toyo Ink
description: The Du Pont Company and the Toyo Ink Manufacturing Company of Japan announced plans for a joint venture to market inks to commercial printers in North America. Du Pont plans to market inks manufactured at Toyo plants in Japan through Toyo-Du Pont International Ink. Du Pont is one of the world's largest manufacturers of image-making systems. Toyo, founded in 1907, is a leading producer of inks for the Japanese printing industry.

title: Case Dating to McCarthy Era Takes a New Twist
description: The long-running battle between the Federal Government and Frank Wilkinson, dating to the McCarthy era, took another twist Monday when a Federal judge here found him and his lawyers in contempt of court for releasing an internal document of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Doctor at Center of Legal Swirl Is Kept From Trial
description: On the upper level of Dr. Rajko D. Medenica's office on this resort island is a gleaming white laboratory where he crafts innovative drug treatment programs he says are tailored to each patient's cancer.

title: Shandwick Reports Gain in Pretax Profit
description: Shandwick P.L.C., the publicly held British public relations company whose strategy of growth by acquisition has turned it into one of the largest public relations companies in the world, yesterday released its midyear financial report showing sharp increases in pretax profit.

title: Lindsay Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Stewart & Stevenson Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: ''IN Brazil, when you eat a good food you say, 'oh, it's cupim, fine food,' '' said Renato Pereira, 25 years old, explaining the name Cupim Hamburger, a fast-food restaurant his family opened last November in Market Square, one of Atlanta's suburban malls.

title: Rowe Furniture reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 5
Review/Jazz; The Gil Evans Orchestra
description: The Gil Evans orchestra, now led by Mr. Evans's son, Miles, isn't appreciably different from what it was under the elder Mr. Evans's leadership. The essential personnel is the same, including Chris Hunter on alto saxophone, Lew Soloff on trumpet and Mark Egan on bass. The band is playing Monday nights on an open-ended basis at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, keeping to the schedule it had under Mr. Evans's direction. And the band's strength - the ability to change dynamics from a sigh to a loud shout, and turn the horn section into a squalling, harmonically sophisticated force - is still there, along with its ability to cruise through long suite-like pieces without too much turmoil and confusion.

title: Tee-Comm Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The net income for 1987 included $135,170 in tax credits. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Economic Scene; Managed Trade Or Open Trade?
description: IT may be every economist's dream to be taken seriously in a debate over vitally important public policy. But visions of doing well by doing good can turn sour when the research is used to draw conclusions opposite to those intended.

title: Rangers, Penguins Face Inner Demons
description: The Rangers, of course, gained their third-place spot in the playoffs through the proverbial backdoor, heads hung in embarrassment after losing their last five games. The Penguins, though, didn't exactly earn their encounter with the Rangers by storming boldly through the front door; they lost half of their final 10 games.

title: KEY RATES
A Limit on Doctors' Hours Is Debated
description: As New York State prepares to carry out an ambitious plan to overhaul medical education and health-care delivery, a raging debate is focusing on the central feature of that plan: a limit on the hours that residents can work each week.

title: Wiener Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Bear Offer to Childress Is Matched by the Oilers
description: A five-year, $4.7 million offer sheet to Ray Childress from the Chicago Bears that the 6-foot-6-inch, 276-pound Houston defensive end signed last week was matched yesterday by the Oilers. Under league rules, the Oilers had a week to match the offer sheet and keep Childress or lose him in return for top draft choices.

title: Costar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $89,000.

title: Workers Tell Of Patronage By Koch Aides
description: Several current and former New York City employees told a state investigative commission yesterday of sometimes elaborate systems that they said were used by the Koch administration to help place politically connected applicants in city jobs.

title: All the Comforts
description: To The Living Section:

title: Handy & Harman
description: A group of companies controlled by the Omaha investor Warren E. Buffett has lowered its stake in Handy & Harman to 6 percent, from 7.3 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Buffett said he sold 180,000 Handy & Harman shares on the open market on March 27 for prices ranging from $19.50 to $19.82 a share. Mr. Buffet gave no reason for the sale. Handy & Harman, based in New York, is a precious metals concern. Its shares slipped 37.5 cents today, to $19.375, on the Big Board.

title: Jones Intercable Investors LP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The partnership attributed the revenue increase to its acquisition of the Independence, Mo., Cable Television System in May 1987, growth in pay service subscribers, an basic service rate adjustments in the Independence and Alexandria, Va., systems. It attributed the widened loss to an increase in depreciation and amortization.

title: More Viewers for Yanks
description: As major New York City cable television operators and some key suburban systems continued to resist a demand by the Madison Square Garden network that they offer Yankee games as part of their basic, fixed-cost service, the network announced yesterday that it had come to terms on Yankee programming with eight area systems with a total of about 750,000 subscribers, including some 40,000 on Staten Island.

title: Telebyte Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss on the sale of a product line of $112,000.

title: Pathe Communications Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $29,934,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss Pathe had a gain on the sales of assets and subsidiaries of $62,041,000 for 1988, compared with $5.1 million for 1987. Pathe Communications was formerly known as Cannon Group Inc.

title: Moto Photo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago fiscal share earnings was less than one cent a share after the payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: TGX Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Home Capital Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,486,159 on the sale of an investment. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Officer Charged in Scuffle
description: A white Long Beach police officer was charged Monday with using excessive force when he arrested a black off-duty police officer who was conducting a videotaped ''sting'' operation to illustrate allegations of police racism. The misdemeanor charge, against Officer Mark Dickey, carries a maximum penalty of a year in prison. In the videotape of the incident, Officer Dickey appeared to shove the head of the black officer, Don Jackson, through a store window.

title: Smuggling Suspect, in Air Chase, Bails Out
description: A suspected drug smuggler being chased by Federal agents set his plane on automatic pilot and bailed out Monday, letting the aircraft fly on for 180 miles before it crashed into the Gulf of Mexico, officials said today.

title: Colleges Caught in Tuition-Student Aid Squeeze
description: With top private colleges announcing annual price tags edging up to $20,000 for next fall, many of the colleges are now asking themselves how long can they continue to subsidize students, including those from relatively well-off families, at a rate that will keep them enrolling.

title: Runnerup Pirates Return To a Winner's Welcome
description: After spending the last three weeks in places like Tucson, Ariz., Denver and Seattle, the Seton Hall basketball team returned to campus tonight and found out how much its remarkable success has meant to the school's student body.

title: Rise in Hunger Seen As World's Harvests Fall and Costs Soar
description: After two years of poor harvests worldwide, poor countries will experience increased hunger and starvation as their bill for imported food soars by more than $5 billion this year, the top United Nations agriculture official says.

title:
RACE RELATIONS ON CAMPUS;
Stanford University
description: LEAD: Many outside observers fired stinging charges of racism at Stanford University this year and last.

title: Shopping That's All in A Day's Work
description: LEAD: IT'S 7:30 A.M. on a weekday. While many office workers are having their first cup of coffee at home, Chris Chance, a lawyer, is being fitted for shirts at the office.

title: NEW YORK COURT BACKS WIDE CLAIMS ON THE DRUG DES
description: New York State's highest court today issued the broadest guidelines of any state in the nation for women to recover damages from manufacturers of the drug DES, which has been linked to cancer, miscarriages and infertility.

title: Review/Opera; Thomas Allen in 'Billy Budd' Revival at the Met
description: One of the recurring heroes of literature is the innocent who approaches the world with open hand and open heart. Sometimes goodness triumphs and redeems, as with Pushkin's Tatyana and Wagner's Parsifal, pure souls who somehow escape being ground underfoot by a sick or callous society. The hero of Melville's ''Billy Budd'' and of the Britten opera of the same name is not so fortunate. Precisely because he is so clearly good, a holy fool in the Dostoyevsky sense, Billy represents an elemental force that evil must and does destroy.

title: A Peace at Risk in Namibia
description: What appears to be a brazenly illegal infiltration by the South-West Africa People's Organization jeopardizes the U.S.-orchestrated Namibian independence agreement. The State Department, South Africa and apparently U.N. observers all contend that armed Swapo guerrillas began crossing into Namibia from Angola on Saturday, in large numbers and in direct violation of the peace accord.

title: Editorial Board Member Is Named by The Times
description: Michael M. Weinstein, chairman of the economics department at Haverford College, will join the editorial board of The New York Times on May 1. His appointment was announced yesterday by Jack Rosenthal, editorial page editor.

title: The Panel Forging a New Charter
description: Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr. Chairman

title: BRIDGE
description: Women play bridge about as well as men during the day - but not nearly as well at night. That is the preliminary lesson to be drawn from the first three days of play in the Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes, with nonstop play in New York City and Paris lasting two weeks.

title: Brown Eyes Michigan
description: Larry Brown, the coach of the San Antonio Spurs of the National Basketball Association, had expressed interest in the head coaching position at Michigan, The San Antonio Express-News reported yesterday.

title: Country Wide Transport Servces Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest year's results reflect a gain of $678,000 from a change in accounting for income taxes and a loss of $247,084 from a change in accounting for revenue recognition.

title: Chicago Mayor From a New Mold; Richard Michael Daley
description: In the final week of the Chicago mayoral campaign, Richard M. Daley appeared at a downtown luncheon before hundreds of cheering Democratic precinct captains and party regulars.

title: Pickens Group Confirms Stake
description: An investment firm headed by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, today confirmed reports from Japan that it was the largest shareholder in a maker of automotive parts with ties to the Toyota Motor Company.

title: Oxford Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Thomas J. Brogan, 93, New Jersey Car Dealer
description: Thomas J. Brogan, founder of an automobile dealership and a former chairman of the New Jersey Racing Commission, died Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 93 years old and had homes in Bal Harbor, Fla. and in Ridgewood and Spring Lake, N.J.

title: TIE/Telecommunications Canada Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $56,000 for the quarter and $72,000 for the year. c-Included a tax credit of $279,000 for the quarter and after a special charge of $5,560,000 for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,837,000 for the quarter and $4,162,000 for the year.

title: USMX Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Cinram Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $200,000. c-Included a special gain of $300,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: No Extension for Viola
description: Frank Viola, who has the most pitching victories in the major leagues in the last five years, said yesterday in Minneapolis that he was finished trying to negotiate a contract extension with the Twins and would leave Minnesota as a free agent after the season.

title: Southern Union Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,298,000 for the quarter and $4,298,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,234,000 for the quarter and $3,506,000 for the year; the year also included an extraordinary loss of $1,283,000.

title: British Pension Fund Sells $65.6 Million in Artworks
description: A crowd of bidders and onlookers, many in evening dress, looked on and occasionally cheered as 25 Impressionist and modern works of art purchased a decade ago as an investment by the British Rail Pension Fund were sold here tonight for $65.6 million.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
NCR Plans to Sell South Africa Unit
description: The NCR Corporation announced that it planned to sell its South African subsidiary and market its products through a distributor. NCR Products in South Africa will be distributed by Fintech Ltd., which will acquire a controlling interest in the subsidiary. The balance of the shares will be acquired by European investors.

title: Government Unions Put Polish Pact in Doubt
description: On the eve of formal ceremonies to sign accords between the Government and the independent union Solidarity, the Government's own official unions refused tonight to accept a part of the agreement that Solidarity considers essential.

title: Austin, Tex.
description: A YEAR after opening a pastry shop here in Austin, Alain Braux is still unable to fathom the American diet. When Mr. Braux, a 36-year-old native of Nice, France, opened his bakery, he was prepared to make certain accommodations to the American palate. He would gladly bake chocolate chip cookies and muffins, but he drew the line at doughnuts and bagels. And bread.

title: Stop Army-Financed Germ-Warfare Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Perfume That Kills Flies
description: The amber-colored liquid in the odd bottle looks alluring in the roadside ad. Sheila, it is called - the First Australian Perfume. Flashing past in the car, a driver might imagine the ad also says something bizarre, such as ''also kills flies.'' It does. The ad was designed by More-O'Ferrall, a British outdoor advertising company, to test the effectiveness of 4,500 new bus shelter advertising panels it set up two weeks ago.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atari Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., said its Federated Group unit, an electronics chain, would close 15 stores and reduce its headquarters staff by 30 percent as part of a restructuring and consolidation plan.

title:
RACE RELATIONS ON CAMPUS;
University Of Michigan
description: LEAD: During my first two years as an undergraduate at the University of Michigan, I struggled to satisfy its academic requirements amid racial tensions that I thought would ease this year. I thought that the university would strive to create an atmosphere that supported all members of its community.

title: Colortech Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a special gain of $211,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Man Who Got the Pentagon's Attention
description: The Monday morning after he surprised and angered the officer corps by slapping down the Air Force Chief of Staff in public for discussing policy with members of Congress, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney gathered the Pentagon's top civilian officials in his third-floor conference room.

title: Intercontinental Life Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $554,000. c-Included realized investment losses of $63,000. The company said the decrease in income resulted principally from an increase in life and health insurance claims as a percentage of premium income, the amortization of deferred policy acquisition costs and the amortization of the present value of future profits associated with the acquisition of Standard Life Insurance Co. at the end of 1986.

title: Toreador Royalty Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Age Is Certainly No Barrier For Reuss (40) and Fisk (41)
description: Jerry Reuss, who will be 40 years old on June 19, held California to one run, two hits and no walks for seven innings today as the Chicago White Sox opened their season with a 9-2 victory over the Angels.

title: To many in North Salem, Skyglow Has No Romance
description: What John Steele Gordon would like to have overhead during his nighttime walks along the lonely country roads here is a midnight-blue sky flecked with stars. What he has instead is a ring of peach and pearly-white industrial light that coats the sky around the horizon, muting the constellations and robbing him of his rural bliss.

title: Genentech's AIDS Drug
description: Genentech Inc. said today that the United States Food and Drug Administration had granted it orphan drug status for CD-4, a genetically engineered drug for the treatment of AIDS. Genentech's shares rose $1.375 today, to $18.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The decision appears to give

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The Soviet Union has sold to Libya high-peformance bombers and an airborne tanker that would greatly enhance Tripoli's ability to hit targets in Israel and beyond, American officials say. Page A1

title: The Art World Painted in Films
description: Ever since ''An Unmarried Woman,'' in which Jill Clayburgh had a fling with an abstract painter played by Alan Bates, the New York art world has supplied the movies with an assortment of hip locations, expensive-looking wall decorations and, upon occasion, romantic interests.

title: Sri Lankan Refugees In India Return Home
description: About 39,000 Sri Lankan Tamil refugees have returned to their homes from southern India in the last year and a half, Indian Government officials and relief workers in Sri Lanka said today.

title: BASQUES ANNOUNCE TRUCE BREAKDOWN
description: The Basque guerrilla movement E.T.A. today officially ended a three-month truce, ending hopes that the decades of terrorist violence in the north of Spain were drawing to a close.

title: Medical Technology Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Women at Princeton, 20 Years Later
description: Twenty years ago Princeton University began one of the greatest changes, and challenges, since it was founded in 1746: It admitted women as undergraduates.

title: Latin Intellectuals Urge Brazil to Save Amazon Rain Forest
description: A group of Latin American intellectuals has called on President Jose Sarney of Brazil to put an immediate halt to ''massive deforestation'' and other ''acts of barbarism'' in the Amazon rain forest.

title: Pepsi Cancels Madonna Ad
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had canceled plans to broadcast a television commercial in which the rock star Madonna advertises Pepsi-Cola, after finding that consumers confused the commercial with a music video by the singer that included religious imagery.

title: Ousted Tanker Captain Still in Hiding
description: The captain of the ill-fated Exxon Valdez remained in hiding yesterday as some of his shipmates continued to work on the grounded supertanker and the Federal authorities pressed a full-scale criminal investigation of North America's most disastrous oil spill.

title: Morrison a Coach Again
description: Stan Morrison, former head basketball coach at Southern California and Pacific, was hired yesterday as San Jose State's new coach. The 49-year-old Morrison signed a four-year contract that marks his return to coaching after being athletic director at the University of California-Santa Barbara since 1986.

title: Selfix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Thriftier Trickery for the Thrifts
description: Congress is under pressure to cut the cost of President Bush's plan to rescue the savings and loan industry. There's little reason to strain for the industry's sake, but it makes considerable sense to cut the cost to taxpayers.

title: Harris & Harris Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary gain of $52,000. Results for both years are restated to include the operations of Harris & Harris of Kentucky Inc. and Capital Trust Management Corp., which merged with Harris & Harris subsidiaries in November 1987 and April 1988, respectively.

title: Czar Resources Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $1,805,035. c-Included a special gain of $1,895,370. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Chevrolet Lumina
description: The base prices for Chevrolet's new Lumina line will be $11,833 for the basic car and $13,776 for the Euro model, the General Motors Corporation said. The four-door sedans will replace the Chevrolet Celebrity. G.M. will add a two-door model and a minivan to the Lumina line in the fall.

title: Webster Clothes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net income

title: Telemundo Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $43,000 for the quarter and $3,526,000 for the year, both from early repayment of debt.

title: Gulf Applied Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,089,000 and $1,805,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $1,682,000 for the quarter and $25,000 for the year.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday about effects of drug arrests on the New York City criminal justice system included incorrect figures provided by the New York State Office of Court Administration for narcotics cases in Bronx Criminal Court. In the first two months of last year, 2,710 cases were filed, compared with 3,171 this year.

title: India's Envoy to Sri Lanka Gets a Hotter Seat: Pakistan
description: India's Ambassador in Sri Lanka for the last four turbulent years, in which more than 50,000 Indian troops entered the country to put down an ethnic rebellion, has been named envoy to Pakistan.

title: Esposito Puts Himself On the Spot
description: rrWhen he was named the Rangers' general manager in July 1986, Phil Esposito promised to shake the franchise to its core in an effort to bring the elusive Stanley Cup to New York City for the first time since 1940. There were no five-year plans on the horizon, no speeches about the virtues of youth and patience. Esposito is not the patient sort and he said that he would quit or would expect to be fired if he did not reach his goal within a reasonable time.

title: Connecticut Schools Get A Voluntary Racial Plan
description: One year after a state study provoked fears of forced busing with a call for mandated solutions to racial isolation in Connecticut's public schools, the State Education Commissioner issued a new report today with goals that are far less ambitious.

title: Coffey Scores Twice as Rangers Lose Opener
description: For days, Paul Coffey had been hounded by questions about what his playoff experience might mean to the Penguins. What would the veteran of 94 Stanley Cup games say to his young teammates? What tips might he offer his brilliant one, Mario Lemieux?

title: Drive Seeks to Make Sex in Therapy a Crime
description: Accusations against two psychotherapists of engaging in unethical sexual contact with patients have intensified a drive in the Massachusetts Legislature to protect patients from sexual abuse by doctors, therapists and counselors.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Gerber Products Fills New Operating Post
description: LEAD: The Gerber Products Company yesterday named Alfred A. Piergallini as its president and chief operating officer, a newly created post that the company portrayed as a springboard to its top job.

title: 'Wrongdoing' On Harrods
description: A secret report on the disputed takeover of House of Fraser P.L.C., which owns the luxury department store Harrods, by three Egyptian businessmen has ''clearly disclosed wrongdoing,'' the British Trade and Industry Minister, Lord Young, said Tuesday.

title: A Guide to Park Houses
description: A FREE guide to an oft-forgotten resource - the 15 historic houses in New York City parks - has just been published. The handsome booklet includes landmarks like the Gothic Revival Alice Austen House on Staten Island (circa 1620), and the fieldstone Valentine-Varian House (1758), home of the Bronx County Historical Society. To obtain a copy, call 212-360-1350 or write to Historic Houses, in care of the New York City Parks and Recreation Department, the Arsenal, Central Park, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Haitian Leader Challenged by New Army Mutiny
description: In the second military challenge to the Haitian Government in four days, rebellious soldiers demanded the resignation of President Prosper Avril today, threatening to overrun the Presidential Palace if he refused to step down.

title: Ship May Have Been on Autopilot
description: The Anchorage Times reported today that Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood incorrectly set the Exxon Valdez on a course toward a submerged reef and then apparently placed the ship on automatic pilot without informing the crew.

title: Tony Panel to Ponder if Words a Drama Make
description: Play: A dramatic composition or performance. Drama: A literary composition that tells a story, usually of human conflict, by means of dialogue and action, to be performed by actors. - Webster's New World Dictionary of the American Language, Second College Edition

title: Pinnacle Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Walter D. Floersheim, Banker, 89
description: Walter D. Floersheimer, an investment banker and philanthropist, died of cancer Monday at his home in Zurich. He was 89 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: A Debt Swap For Ecuador
description: Environmentalists today bought off $9 million of Ecuador's debt in the largest ''debt for nature swap'' ever signed. Under the agreement, the

title: For the Most Helpless of the Homeless, Brief Refuge
description: Lugging a large suitcase that holds his collection of more than 100 multicolored felt-tip pens, a homeless painter named Arthur James arrives each morning at the renovated basement of a former French restaurant, one block from the New York Stock Exchange.

title: American Greetings reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company recorded a restructuring charge in the third and fourth quarters of fiscal 1989, which reduced net income for the fourth quarter by about $125,000 and for the fiscal year by about $12,026,000.

title: 22 Reported Killed by Artillery Barrages in Beirut
description: Ignoring new calls for a cease-fire, Christian and Muslim factions in Lebanon continued to exchange barrages of artillery shells and rockets today, and the police said at least 22 people were killed and 56 wounded.

title: An Orbital Spaceship To Put Magazines On
description: FOR years, the furniture designer Dan Friedman has been walking the fine line between art and design. The above piece, dubbed the ''Strategic Orbital Simulator'' (it's really a coffee table), is his latest terrestrial exploration of ''the boundaries between furniture and sculpture.''

title: NCNB Seeks Talk On Bid for Citizens
description: The NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., pressing its week-old proposal to merge with the Citizens and Southern Corporation, said every aspect of its offer, including price, was open to negotiation. Citizens and Southern, based in Atlanta, rejected the North Carolina banking company's proposal on Monday. NCNB offered 1.075 of its shares for each share of Citizens and Southern stock.

title: NWA Stock Up Sharply
description: Shares of NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, rose $3.875, to $87.625, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday amid rumors that a $105-a-share takeover bid might come soon, possibly from an investor group headed by Steven G. Rothmeier, chairman and chief executive of NWA.

title: Pirates Sign Meacham
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates signed Bobby Meacham, a free agent infielder who spent six seasons with the Yankees, to a contract yesterday with their Class AAA Buffalo farm club.

title: House Panel Backs Bill For Fairness Doctrine
description: A House subcommittee today approved a bill that would write into law a Fairness Doctrine requiring broadcasters to air opposing sides of controversial issues.

title: Metro Datelines; Ex-Clerk Is Charged In Merchant's Killing
description: A former employee of a Brooklyn merchant was charged yesterday with his murder, the police said.

title: Big East-A.C.C. Series
description: Two of the nation's most powerful college basketball conferences, the Big East and the Atlantic Coast, jointly announced yesterday that in December they will begin an annual series of games involving the teams from both leagues. During the first week of December, eight Big East teams will play eight A.C.C. teams in four doubleheaders, Monday through Thursday. The games, to be televised by ESPN, will be held at two Big East and two A.C.C. sites. Pairings and sites are to be announced in June with teams to be seeded by coaches in their leagues.

title: Drexel Chief Talks About Firm's Future
description: In his first public comments since Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. agreed to settle fraud charges with the Government, Frederick H. Joseph, the firm's chief executive, said today that Drexel had to put aside its recent troubles and ''get on with it.''

title: Baker Meets With Shamir; Calls Ideas 'Encouraging'
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel presented his ideas for settling the Arab-Israeli conflict to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today, and Mr. Baker said he found the Israeli proposals ''very encouraging.''

title: Getty Buys Renoir's 'Walk'
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., was identified yesterday as the buyer of ''The Walk,'' a large oil from 1870 by Pierre Auguste Renoir. The Impressionist depiction of two figures in a summery landscape was part of the British Rail Pension Fund collection auctioned at Sotheby's in London on Tuesday night. Baskett & Day, a London art dealer, acted as agent for the museum, which paid $17.7 million for the painting.

title: Amnesty Looks First at Victims, Not Ideologies
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Defends Practices in Hiring In Testimony Before Ethics Panel
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch, finally facing members of a state commission that has been investigating charges of patronage in New York City's government for more than a year, defended his administration's hiring practices yesterday but said he was not aware of many of the irregularities that panel witnesses have recounted.

title: Calendar: Historic Porcelain
description: 150 Years of Porcelain, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street; 212-879-5500.

title: Stockholm to Charge Palme Suspect
description: The Swedish authorities said today that they would charge a man they have had in custody since December in the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Peoples Bancorp (N.C.) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Greens Are Softer at Augusta for the Masters
description: It took two years or more but eventually those in charge of the Masters got the message: the 18 sidewalks that are called putting greens here at the Augusta National Golf Club had become too hard for fair golf.

title: Palm Beach Journal; Noisy Jetliners Annoy An Enclave of the Rich
description: The jet set has had its fill of jets.

title: International Consumer Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pan Atlantic Re reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $682,513 for the quarter and $1,027,204 for the year. c-After net realized investment losses of $8,968 for the quarter and $849,243 for the year.

title: San Francisco's Cottage Industry: Big Boom in Small Spaces
description: In the San Francisco Bay Area, the cottage has proved itself to be as democratic and durable as blue jeans. From humble beginnings as Gold Rush shanties and shelters for the homeless after the 1906 earthquake, cottages have become the next best thing to a full-fledged house for many people.

title: Grasses, Elegant and Thrifty, In Backyards and on Rooftops
description: IN horticulture, interest in a hitherto unnoticed group of plants swells quietly, like a tide, until the object becomes the subject of every over-the-fence exchange. This year gardeners are abuzz with enthusiasm for ornamental grasses, many of which are especially useful in this age of water conservation.

title: New Head of Cannes Jury
description: The West German film director Wim Wenders is to replace the director Francis Coppola as president of the Cannes Film Festival jury here May 11 to 23. A statement Tuesday by organizers said Mr. Coppola changed his plans because of professional commitments.

title: Times Books Director Leaving For Knopf Post
description: Jonathan B. Segal, the vice president and editorial director of Times Books, said yesterday that he was leaving his administrative post to become an editor at Alfred A. Knopf Inc.

title: Ad Research Shifts From Products to People
description: Time was when an advertising agency had one clear way to sell Bizmarck bubble bath: spend tens of thousands of dollars to send a battery of interviewers to find out who bought bubble bath and how they used it; employ scores of professionals to tabulate the answers, and develop commercials designed to convince bathers that Bizmarck's bubbles are bigger and better.

title: Hawkins Routed in Yankee Debut
description: They are two games into their season, but it is clear the Yankees are still tinkering, still looking for something that will give them stability in a season that already seems shaky.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust New York Corp., a bank holding company, appointed Richard J. Carbone controller.

title: Indian School, Long a Citadel of Hope, Is Troubled
description: The Haskell Indian Junior College, serving about 800 students on a 320-acre campus here, has trained many leaders of Native American tribes, and to some it represents the hopes and dreams of the future.
