title: Amnesty Looks First at Victims, Not Ideologies; Hoover Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Hershiser Loses Game and Streak
description: Orel Hershiser lost his record shutout streak in his first inning and later lost the game tonight when the Cincinnati Reds beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3.

title: William L. Phyfe, 78, Ex-A.T. & T. Official
description: William Lee Phyfe, a former director of shareholder relations for A.T. & T., died Monday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Vero Beach.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M.

title: Olson Has Discussions About Kentucky Job
description: Lute Olson, the basketball coach at the University of Arizona, revealed yesterday that he had a preliminary discussion last week in Seattle with C. M. Newton, the new athletic director at the University of Kentucky, about filling the Wildcats' vacant position of head basketball coach. The opening was created when Eddie Sutton resigned amid controversy over a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation that produced numerous alleged violations, most involving recruiting, on which no sanctions have been announced.

title: PRETORIA SOFTENS STANCE ON NAMIBIA
description: South Africa today promised the guerrillas who have infiltrated Namibia that if they surrendered, they would be given safe passage back to their bases inside Angola under the auspices of the United Nations.

title: Amnesty Looks First at Victims, Not Ideologies; A Single Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Bars Beech-Nut
description: Eighteen months after it was convicted of selling bogus apple juice to consumers, the Beech-Nut Corporation has been barred from doing any business with the Federal Government through 1991.

title: New England Electric Bids for Public Service
description: The New England Electric System of-fered $1.4 billion today for the assets of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, excluding the company's 35.6 percent share of the stalled Seabrook nuclear plant.

title: G.M. Plans Wider Use Of Airbags
description: Following the lead of its two smaller domestic rivals, the General Motors Corporation said today that it expects to install airbag restraining systems in about 500,000 of its 1990 model cars.

title: Lawyer Says Doctor Permitted Steroid Use
description: The lawyer representing Ben Johnson's doctor admitted today that his client administered steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs to Canadian athletes.

title: Whiting Petroleum reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Niagara Mohawk
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation offered $100 million of 10-year first mortgage bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers. The 10 3/8 percent bonds, which mature on April 1, 1999, were priced at par. The issue is rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB-plus by Standard & Poor's.

title: Strategic Planning Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The latest quarter included a $600,000 one-time accrual for future losses in connection with a cost-reduction program to sublet excess space in the Washington office.

title: B&H Ocean Carriers Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time bridge loan financing charge of $2.8 million. The company was formed on June 27, 1988 and operations began on Aug. 17, following an initial public offering; therefore, comparative results are not available.

title: Man Convicted in Killing of 6
description: A man who fired an assault rifle into two crowded shopping centers, killing six people and wounding 10 others, was convicted of murder today. William Bryan Cruse, 61 years old, was convicted on all 32 counts related to the April 23, 1987, shootings in Palm Bay, including charges of first-degree murder, attempted murder and kidnapping. Sentencing was set for April 17, and the state is seeking the death penalty. Mr. Cruse pleaded innocent by reason of temporary insanity.

title: Drug Research Team Sets A Conflict-of-Interest Code
description: A group of medical researchers conducting a clinical drug trial have agreed to guidelines that bar them from having a financial interest in the results of the work.

title: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $183,960,000. The unaudited financial information does not include adjustments to reserve for dispositions, changes in valuation or any other adjustments on the company's financial condition and realizability of its assets, including intangibles, resulting from the recent voluntary bankruptcy filings. Maxicare said during the 3-month period ended Dec. 31, the company recorded a net charge of about $13 million against the valuation reserve which had previously been established. The net charge included about $3 million in net gains on plans sold during the period. In addition, about $16 million of operating losses in the period for the plans sold and the plans to be sold or closed were charged against the reserve.

title: Washington Scientific Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 12
United Stationers reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Furnishing the Homeless
description: New York City has its share of greedy real estate developers, its share of needy homeless people - and its share of decent developers, who are donating furniture to homeless families.

title: Froese Wins a Start on Past Performance
description: Phil Esposito's first major decision in the playoffs was to choose Bob Froese to be the goaltender for the Rangers in their playoff opener against the Penguins, and Froese passed the test with flying volors.

title: Bush Is Said to Weigh 25% Raise for Judges
description: President Bush is weighing the possibility of asking Congress to approve a 25 percent raise for Federal judges, a senior Administration official said today. But this official, discussing Mr. Bush's options on the condition he not be named, said that ''no final decision memo'' has reached the President's desk.

title: Books of The Times; Blood and Brine: The Course of Naval Warfare
description: The Price of Admiralty The Evolution of Naval Warfare By John Keegan Illustrated. 292 pages. Viking. $21.95.

title: P.S.C. Approves Rate Rises And Shutdown of Shoreham
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant moved closer to approval today when the State Public Service Commission endorsed the accord and outlined a series of 5 percent increases in electric rates.

title: Porsche Reduces Some Prices in U.S.
description: Porsche Cars North America Inc., which has suffered the greatest year-to-year sales decline of any importer of European luxury cars, cut the prices of its 944 sports cars. The reductions range from 5.7 percent for the top-of-the-line Turbo, now priced at $44,900, to 8.6 percent for the basic model, now priced at $33,245.

title: Pagurian Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Why, Asks Couple, Did Our Son Die in Police Chokehold?
description: The investigators' report sits on the dining-room table in Maude and Jimmy Lee Bruce Sr.'s frame house on the main highway at the edge of this faded resort village in the Catskills.

title: Stein Proposes a Stronger Oversight Role for His Office
description: The New York City Council President, whose shapeless job could become toothless if the Board of Estimate is abolished, said yesterday that his office should have more authority to watch over the rest of government, including subpoena power to investigate problems.

title: Ojeda's Comeback Provides Mets With a Gain in Defeat
description: The Mets lost a game yesterday, but felt in their hearts that they had really gained a pitcher.

title: Moving a Cabinet Can Give It Achy Joints
description: LEAD: Moving furniture before roads were paved must have been an ordeal. When a cabinetmaker had to travel miles for a delivery, highway robbery or highjacking was the least of the worries; more important was how to pack the piece to withstand jolting over cart tracks.

title: Ocean Bio-Chem Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Fund Yields Up Slightly
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds rose only slightly in the week that ended yesterday, showing signs of going into a holding pattern.

title: Dodgers' Payroll: Record $844,002 Per Player
description: From World Series champions on the last day of the 1988 season to payroll champions on the first day of the 1989 season. That's the route traveled by the Los Angeles Dodgers, who began this season with the first average team salary to exceed $800,000.

title: Award to Elliott
description: Sean Elliott, the star forward from Arizona, was named the winner of the 1989 John Wooden Award yesterday, which annually recognizes college basketball's top player.

title: Reviews/Television; A Look at the Toy Business, on '48 Hours'
description: The program ''48 Hours'' takes a playful look at the toy business tonight, at 8 on Channel 2, and this time out its jumpy style suits the subject. ''Toy Money,'' sharply produced by Steve Glauber, pops from target to target with the zip of a video game.

title: Citizens & Southern Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Kansas City Voters Turn Down a Plan For a Strong Mayor
description: Voters here soundly rejected an amendment to the city charter that would have strengthened the hand of the Mayor at the expense of the City Council.

title: Port Authority Is Offering $100 Million in Serial Bonds
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday offered $100 million of bonds at competitive bid.

title: Phys. Ed.'s Changed Since It Went Coed
description: To the Editor:

title: Dial-a-Tax
description: LEAD: Being penny-wise but pound-foolish is no way to make public policy, yet Mayor Edward Koch and the New York State legislature are about to do just that. They want to impose a new tax on long distance telephone calls made from New York State.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; McGraw-Hill Service Aims at Trade Journals
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. thinks that simplifying the process of placing one advertisement in several trade publications will pay dividends for the magazines in greater ad linage. That is the strategy behind the McGraw-Hill Management Network, a service introduced this week.

title: Campaign Matters; Party at Risk: Can Giuliani Save The Liberals?
description: rrAt first glance, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican, seems like a strange choice for the Liberal Party ticket. And the party leader, Raymond B. Harding, appears to be risking his party's future by endorsing him for mayor.

title: I.B.M. Products For Business Use
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced a series of software products that enable business enterprises to exchange standard-format business documents - like purchase orders, invoices and order acknowledgements - electronically.

title: Peter Miller Apparel Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Music; A Night of Richard Peaslee Theater Songs
description: The Composers's Showcase did right by Richard Peaslee Monday night at Alice Tully Hall. This generous evening of the composer's big-band jazz and theater songs may have slighted his concert scores and his children's music. But theater songs, especially, are what the 58-year-old Mr. Peaslee has concentrated on, and Monday's performances and production proved a fine tribute. Whether it established him as more than a beloved colleague and a deft, adaptable collaborator for stronger creative personalities than his own is another matter.

title: Chronicling the Romance of Tudor City
description: THE historic buildings and parks of Tudor City in Manhattan, complete with gargoyles, are the subject of two photographic exhibits of the work of the Israeli-born photographer Margalit Mannor. The photographs, including the two pictured here, are on view at the Urban Center Gallery (457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street) and the Bertha Urdang Gallery (23 East 74th Street) through April 29.

title: A Warning On Savings Bailout Plan
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that President Bush might veto any proposals that significantly weaken the capital standards required in the President's plan to rescue the savings industry.

title: G.O.P.'s Southern Hopes Set Back in Alabama
description: The vote took place Tuesday amid blinding thunderstorms and several tornadoes, but the worst damage in an election to fill a vacant House seat may have been to Alabama Republicans.

title: Phoenix Agency Revenue Bonds
description: The Phoenix Civic Improvement Corporation is tentatively offering $50 million of airport-terminal excise-tax revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.95 percent for an issue due in 2014 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Gunshots Fired at Abortion Activist's House
description: Shotgun blasts were fired Tuesday morning at the residence of the woman known as Jane Roe in the landmark court case that legalized abortion, and the woman has gone into hiding.

title: DCNY Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net income

title: Two Historians Receive 1989 Bancroft Prizes
description: Columbia University awarded the 1989 Bancroft Prizes in American history last night to Eric Foner, for ''Reconstruction: America's Unfinished Revolution 1863-1877'' (Harper & Row), and Edmund S. Morgan, for ''Inventing the People: The Rise of Popular Sovereignty in England and America'' (W. W. Norton & Co.).

title: Binks Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain of $375,000 from an accounting change.

title: DAY OF ACCORD FOR CABLE TV
description: Yankee fans in Manhattan and parts of Queens and Knick and Ranger fans on Long Island and elsewhere got a last-minute break when three cable systems in New York City and the suburban Cablevision system reached agreements with the Madison Square Garden Network.

title: Like Living Aboard Ship, or on the Concorde
description: WHILE Manhattan apartment residents complain about cramped quarters and claustrophobia, San Francisco cottage dwellers describe their similarly sized living spaces as cozy and comfortable.

title: 250 ARABS FREED BY ISRAEL'S ARMY
description: The army freed about 250 Arab prisoners today who had been jailed for participation in the Palestinian uprising. But the army asserted that the releases were not timed to coincide with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's visit to Washington.

title: Bidermann Head Named As Chief at Russ Togs
description: Russ Togs Inc., a New York manufacturer of women's and men's sportswear, said yesterday that it had named Kenneth Sitomer president and chief executive.

title: The Board of Estimate, 1898 - 1989; Shaping the New New York City Government
description: Don't muck with half-measures. Dissolve the Board of Estimate and reshape New York City's government for real. That's what New York City's Charter Revision Commission says in response to the Supreme Court - and so far, so good. The commission is right. The first thing to get straight about this monumental redesign is that straining to preserve the board makes no sense.

title: 'You Tell Him This'
description: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, sent this invitation to Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak: Stay an extra day in Washington and let us meet in President Bush's office. The Egyptian refused.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have to emphasize that for the first time we have talked to each other using the force of arguments, and not arguments of force. It bids well for the future, I believe, that the round-table discussions can become the beginning of the road for democracy and a free Poland.'' - Lech Walesa. [ A13:1. ]

title: Wickes Selling Unit
description: The Wickes Companies agreed Tuesday to sell its furniture division for $155 million to a senior management group. The group, led by John Klein, president and chief executive of Wickes Furniture, also includes certain affiliates of the Kelso Company. The price includes assumed debt and other obligations.

title: PRESIDENT UNVEILS SCHOOLS PROPOSAL
description: Offering more encouragement than money, President Bush presented a $441 million education package to Congress today intended to promote and reward academic excellence.

title: Daley Reaches Out to Dispirited Blacks
description: Having rolled to a landslide triumph in the election here Tuesday, Richard M. Daley now faces a greater difficulty: putting together the kind of biracial coalition that will enable him to govern as Mayor of all the people, as he promised in his campaign.

title: Chicago Merc Disciplines 8
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange says it is using its computerized trading system to crack down on broker groups that team up to pool business.

title: North Jury Won't Hear Poindexter Videotape
description: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North today denied a defense request to present to the jury a videotape of Congressional testimony by John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser who was Mr. North's superior.

title: U.S. Dismisses Call by Gorbachev To End Latin America Arms Aid
description: The White House today sharply criticized Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for an end to all outside military aid to Central America, saying it contradicted the Soviet Union's own policy of providing arms to Nicaragua.

title: O is for Orientation
description: Anyone who doubts that the Japanese are thorough need only consult the ''New York Dictionary'' now on sale at a Japanese bookstore in Rockefeller Center. Who else would devote a whole dictionary to the special language of a single city?

title: How Much They Make
description: Listed below are the 1989 baseball incomes for players who were on major league rosters or on the disabled list on opening day. Figures, obtained from management and player sources, include base salary, pro-rated share of signing bonus and other guaranteed money. In case where parts of salaries are deferred without interest, the income has been discounted to reflect present-day values.

title: Study Absolves Ex-Smokers: Weight Gain Is Not Their Fault
description: Smoking causes people to use more calories, a new study has found, so when smokers quit, they are likely to gain weight even if they eat the same amount as they did when they smoked.

title: Drawings by Inigo Jones
description: These lectures, walking tours and exhibitions are for the architecture enthusiast.

title: Snowmobile in Quebec Rescue
description: Survivors of a small-plane crash were rescued in an all-night snowmobile operation today after spending 17 hours on a mountain in the Gaspe Peninsula, 240 miles northeast of Quebec City. The survivors were taken to a nearby hospital where they are in stable condition. The pilot of the chartered Piper Apache, Michel Paquet, 34 years old, was reported killed on impact.

title: Kidder Ending Currency Effort
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from the business of buying and selling foreign exchange on a principal basis - that is, for its own account. It will continue to conduct currency transactions for its customers.

title: Mortgage Rates Rose in March
description: Conventional mortgage interest rates rose in March to their highest level since just before the 1987 stock market crash, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported Tuesday.

title: Dr. Jan Rajchman, 80, Electronics Engineer
description: Dr. Jan Aleksander Rajchman, an electronics expert whose work led to the development of high-speed computer memory systems, died Saturday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Many Black College Athletes Express Feelings of Isolation
description: A study commissioned by the National Collegiate Athletic Association says many black athletes feel they are perceived as necessary but not entirely welcome components of campus life whose primary value to their university is generating income and prestige for the football and basketball programs.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Soviets Buy More Corn
description: The Soviet Union bought another 200,000 metric tons of American corn for delivery this year, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. More than 2.1 million tons have been purchased since the Soviets resumed buying United States corn on March 28. The corn is scheduled for delivery by Sept. 30, the end of the sixth year of a long-term grain supply agreement between the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: BUSH NAMES ENVOY TO AFGHAN REBELS
description: President Bush has decided to send a special envoy to the American-backed Afghan rebels, a move that will bolster rebel standing but stops short of formal recognition of the Afghan government-in-exile, White House and State Department officials said today.

title: SAI Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 year included a gain of $183,000 from the sale of the company's headquarters building. The 1987 year included a gain of $786,000 from the sale of certain assets and payment of $175,000 for the reacquisition of reinsurance rights.

title: U.S. Banks Await Debt Plan Details
description: American bankers are waiting for more details about the strategy for reducing third-world debt that was approved on Tuesday by the Internatinal Monetary Fund and the World Bank before discussing whether and to what extent they will participate.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Creamer Dickson Basford said Eleanor Lambert, who handled the high-fashion industry in nine years with the public relations firm, had resigned to open her own company.

title: Dyansen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $60,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income The latest quarter's net from operations included charges of $120,000 to cost of sales for an inventory adjustment, and $150,000 for writeoffs of retail accounts receivable. The company said this year's results were affected by a fire in the company's foundry in late 1987 which affected first quarter sales and the relocation of the foundry which limited third quarter production.

title: Review/Dance; Balinese Troupe, to the Sound of the Gamelan
description: When the Dancers and Musicians of Bali first delighted Americans in 1952, both dancers and audiences seemed a great deal more innocent. The company by the same name that opened Tuesday night at the City Center is by no means the same troupe -nor are the times in which we live.

title: KEY RATES
INSIDE
description: New Mutiny in Haiti

title: Howard Ellis Cox, 76, Manhattan Lawyer
description: Howard Ellis Cox, a socially prominent Manhattan lawyer, died of a stroke Tuesday at the Hospice of Palm Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and maintained homes in Palm Beach, Manhattan and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Soviet Envoy Who Knows How to Please
description: One of the members of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's official delegation is the man who was his disgraced predecessor Leonid I. Brezhnev's principal spokesman, Ambassador Leonid M. Zamyatin.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: SPRING is a time when many parents listen to their children's heartfelt assurances that caring for the crippled bird, the stray kitten or the neighbor's extra puppy really won't be any trouble at all.

title: Personal Health
description: As if there weren't enough dietary pitfalls these days, many people are worrying about the aluminum pots, pans and utensils in which foods are often prepared or stored. The concern arises because aluminum has been linked to Alzheimer's disease, the devastating brain disorder that is becoming increasingly common and costly as the population ages.

title: Galactic Resources Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year loss included the writedown of producing property assets at the Summitville mine of $39,887,000. The year-ago net income figures were restated.

title: Rooms for the Well-Heeled Doll
description: ''I REALLY like this kitchen,'' a towheaded little boy said as he walked through the Lilliputian world of Doll House Antics on upper Madison Avenue. ''Everything is very real, like the Campbell's soup.''

title: U.S. SAID TO CENSOR MEMO ON OIL RISKS
description: Reagan Administration documents show that the Interior Department suppressed warnings last year about the risks of offshore drilling and about the adequacy of technology for cleaning up oil spills, several members of Congress said today.

title: A Tough Principal Turns a School Around
description: It is 8:45 A.M. and dozens of teen-agers are running down Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. Others are moving at a brisk trot from other parts of Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: Philadelphia Mob Leader Is Convicted of Murder
description: The reputed head of organized crime in the Philadelphia-southern New Jersey area and seven associates were convicted of first-degree murder today in the 1985 slaying of another mobster.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Burnett Gets Big Pillsbury Assignment
description: PILLSBURY BRANDS GROUP consolidated its advertising at Leo Burnett yesterday by giving the Chicago agency a $4.8 million account that had been handled by Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: Washington Talk; Images Are Weapons On Abortion Battlefield
description: As the capital prepares for an abortion rights march on Sunday that its organizers hope will draw more than 100,000 people, the battle over the abortion issue is focusing less on fundamental legal principles than on powerful, sometimes disconcerting symbols.

title: Review/Theater; 'H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N,' a Musical
description: When Hyman Kaplan speaks, everybody listens, but few understand. Kaplan's tin ear produces a pidgin English so revisionary that it is foreign even to the immigrants who are his fellow students of English in night school on the Lower East Side.

title: Revolutionary Questions in Cuba
description: Moscow and Havana more than ever resemble a loveless couple sticking together for the sake of appearances. Amid all the hoopla over his visit to Cuba, Mikhail Gorbachev surely observed that the Cuban press barely mentioned last week's contested elections in the Soviet Union. And despite his protestations of comradely solidarity, Fidel Castro had to wonder why the Soviet leader chose Havana as the place to declare that ''We are against doctrines that endorse the export of revolution or counterrevolution.''

title: VIETNAM PROMISES TROOPS WILL LEAVE CAMBODIA BY FALL
description: Ten years and three months after its soldiers invaded Cambodia and installed a new Government in Phnom Penh, Vietnam announced today that it would unconditionally withdraw the rest of its troops by the end of September.

title: Review/Music; Bach's 'Goldberg Variations' by String Trio
description: A transcription for string trio of Bach's ''Goldberg Variations'' is the kind of thing one approaches with the question ''Why?'' in mind. The answer came early at the Metropolitan Museum Monday evening: Dmitry Sitkovetsky, the violinist who made the arrangement and played it with the violist Gerard Causse and the cellist David Geringas, has an intense personal response to this work. He sounded as though he had to play it, which is what one always wants from a performer and is ample justification for an otherwise unnecessary transcription.

title: Rada Electronic Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Comparable figures are not available because the company changed to a calendar year from a March 31 year.

title: Soviets, After 33 Years, Publish Khrushchev's Anti-Stalin Speech
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign to fill in some glaring gaps in the nation's history continued today with the publication, at long last, of Nikita S. Khrushchev's speech denouncing Stalin.

title: Wang Trims Jobs, Plans More Cuts
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. has trimmed 880 people from its worldwide work force in the last three months and is planning further cutbacks, a company spokesman said. The spokesman, Joseph Roy, said that Wang's payroll employees worldwide had dropped from 31,391 on Dec. 31 to 30,700 at the end of February, The Boston Globe, quoting unnamed company sources, reported today that Wang was also considering a write-down of some underperforming corporate assets. Analysts have been encouraging the company to cut costs. Jay P. Stevens, who follows the company for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said Wang's general and administrative costs in comparison with revenue were ''outrageously high, among the highest in the computer industry.''

title: Wright Says Purchase of Books Was His Idea
description: The House Speaker, Jim Wright of Texas, told reporters today that it was his idea to use a speaking fee from a Texas university to buy hundreds of copies of his book for the school.

title: Q&A
description: Painting Shiny Metal Q.Our windows are energy-efficient models with a shiny steel finish. Can they be painted? A.The frames are probably aluminum, not steel. Hold a magnet against the metal; steel, not aluminum, will attract the magnet.

title: U.S. Widens Import Curbs on Military-Like Rifles
description: Extending a ban imposed three weeks ago, the Government today suspended import permits on 24 more models of military-like semiautomatic rifles. Domestically manufactured weapons are not affected.

title: Allied Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: WEDNESDAY is known as Ladies' Day in Times Square. It's matinee day, which means forget about getting a table in one of the area's few decent restaurants, and forget about going to Barnes & Noble to check out the remainders. The bookstore will have browsers to the ceiling.

title: Soviet Chief Ends 3 Hard Days With Castro, Who Spurns Change as Too Steep a Luxury
description: Whatever private diplomacy was accomplished during Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Latin American debut, in public the normally crisp and charismatic Soviet leader seemed to wilt in the tropical presence of Fidel Castro, the towering, theatrical and unreconstructed Cuban commander in chief.

title: TV Coverage: Spill Inquiries
description: C-Span, the cable television service that covers Congress, will broadcast a House hearing today on the oil spill in Prince William Sound.

title: Americana From the Near Past
description: ''OH, boy,'' Bob Monti said when asked to describe the merchandise at his East Village store, Live Shop Die. (Hint to Bob: Mention the Barbie and Midge thermoses, the Brady Bunch activity books and the early-1970's television set known as ''robot head,'' right.) Along with his partners, Trixie Tanabe and a woman named Liz who insists her last name is Forever, Mr. Monti is responsible for this cash-and-carry hideaway, which features offbeat American objects, mostly from the late 60's and early 70's. The store is sometimes referred to by its initials, LSD.

title: Yeats at the End: Still Writing
description: William Butler Yeats sat on a lawn chair by the garden of the Ideal Sejour, his old, cold bones wrapped in a rug that sheltered him from the sea breeze of Cap-Martin.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * The National Committee for the Prevention of Child Abuse has begun a new series of ads that have been designed by Lintas: USA. The ads use this tagline: ''Stop Using Words That Hurt. Start Using Words That Help.'' The broadcast and print ads were introduced at a news conference yesterday.

title: Transamerica's Notes Are Prices
description: The Transamerica Finance Group priced a $100 million offering of three-year senior notes yesterday. The 10 3/8 percent notes, which mature on April 15,1993, are noncallable for two years. The notes ere priced at $99.82 to yield 10.431 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing yield on three-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.

title: New Start for Jones
description: Roy Jones Jr., who won an Olympic silver medal in a disputed decision, will make his professional debut May 6 with a scheduled eight-round junior middleweight bout in his hometown of Pensacola. Jone's opponent will be announced in the next week. A 3-2 decision to a South Korean cost Jones the Olympic gold medal in Seoul last year. The result triggered unsuccessful protests by United States Olympic officials. Jones was later named the outstanding boxer of the Games. ''I feel I'm ready to go back in there and take care of business,'' Jones said (AP)

title: Washington Talk: The Court
description: For reasons known only to the Justices, the Supreme Court has cut back substantially on the number of cases it is accepting for argument and decision.

title: Business Leaders Agree to Seek Money for AIDS
description: Several business leaders met yesterday and agreed to seek more financing - possibly including additional taxes - to fight the AIDS epidemic in New York City and to ease hospital overcrowding.

title: HEALTH: Disease Detection; High Breast Density Is Identified By Federal Scientist as Cancer Risk
description: Women whose breasts are composed primarily of fat are less prone to breast cancer than women with denser, firmer breasts, a cancer researcher said this week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Solidarity leaders signed accords with Poland's Government, restoring the banned union's legal status and providing for the first free and open elections in this country since World War II. Page A1

title: Smithsonian Accents
description: THE boutique-ing of American museum collections continues. The latest entry is furniture from the Smithsonian Institution: 10 reproductions to be manufactured by Century, which will be in stores this fall and will retail for $1,000 to $6,000.

title: Metro Datelines; Bosket Is Charged In Jail-Guard Attack
description: Willie Bosket has been charged with assault after hitting a prison guard with a chain Tuesday, officials said yesterday. Mr. Bosket was being led from his cell in the state prison here to an exercise yard, a spokesman for the Correctional Services Department, James B. Flateau, said.

title: Tanker Captain Surrenders; Judge Sets $1 Million Bail
description: The former captain of the ill-fated oil tanker Exxon Valdez surrendered to the authorities here today, and hours later a Suffolk County judge set his bail bond at $1 million, 40 times what prosecutors requested.

title: Xerox Is Sued By Metaphor
description: Metaphor Computer Systems Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., said today that it had sued the Xerox Corporation in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., seeking a declaration that Metaphor's data-base software products do not infringe on Xerox copyrights. The suit was filed in response to a letter from Xerox accusing Metaphor of violating those rights and requesting royalties.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Thursday about the Government's seizure of 20 banks owned by Mcorp referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of major banks in Texas that had required Federal assistance to remain open. Not every major bank in the state has needed assistance; Texas Commerce Bank has not received Federal aid.

title: Patrick Quits As Chairman Of the F.C.C.
description: Dennis R. Patrick, one of the Reagan Administration's most ardent deregulators, resigned today as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Desert Foliage in An Eastern Garden
description: The desert starts blooming in the rolling Pennsylvania countryside Thursday when the new Silver Garden opens at Longwood Gardens.

title: Dallas Prosecutors In '76 Slaying Case Are Leaving Office
description: Two prosecutors who were assigned to the case of Randall Dale Adams, who was released from prison last month after serving 12 years for a murder he says he did not commit, have submitted letters of resignation to the Dallas District Attorney. And a Dallas television station reported today that the Assistant District Attorney who led the fight to keep Mr. Adams in prison was dismissed.

title: Corrections
description: Articles last June 21 and on Feb. 19 about a Long Island house built by Otto Kahn misstated its role in the film ''Citizen Kane.'' Many Long Islanders believe that the house was used for filming, but their recollection has been discredited. Extensive checks with students of the film in recent weeks have established that although photographs of the house were used in the film, no scenes were filmed there.

title: HEALTH: Epidemiology; Some Black Groups Are Found at High Risk Of Kidney Failure
description: New national health statistics indicate that blacks have a significantly higher incidence of severe kidney failure than previously believed, particularly so for those in certain age groups who suffer from high blood pressure and other diseases.

title: Bush's Missing Link in Nicaragua
description: LEAD: The Bush Administration recently floated the idea that further progress in Soviet-American relations hinges on Moscow's willingness to help in the democratization of Nicaragua. In other words, we want them to do for us what we have failed to do in eight years of sponsoring the contras.

title: Indian Court Asks Data on Bhopal Deal
description: A five-judge panel of the Supreme Court of India yesterday asked the Indian Government and the Union Carbide Corporation to produce documents showing how they reached the $470 million settlement in connection with the industrial disaster at Bhopal.

title: Albany Chiefs Want to Add $300 Million to Budget
description: Four days after the state's budget deadline, legislative leaders told Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today that they wanted to spend $300 million more than the state is expected to raise in tax revenues.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Ease
description: Treasury note and bond prices dipped slightly yesterday, as some dealers took advantage of the recent rally to take some profits. Trading activity was markedly slower from the brisk pace of the previous two sessions this week.

title: Precedent Is Seen in DES Decision
description: New York State's highest court established an important precedent in product liability law this week in the DES drug case, drug industry spokesmen, analysts and lawyers on both sides of the case said yesterday.

title: Accord Is Seen For Ueberroth To Buy Eastern
description: The Texas Air Corporation and Peter V. Ueberroth were said to have reached tentative agreement yesterday on the structure of a deal in which the former baseball commissioner would acquire Eastern Airlines. But people involved in the negotiations said a signed agreement remained elusive as discussions on details of the sale continued through the evening.

title: Taro Vit Industries Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The dollar amounts are translated at the rate of U.S. $1.00 equals 1.807 adjusted new Israeli shekels, the exchange rate as of Dec. 31. The company said the latest quarter sales decrease was because of a sudden devaluation of the Israeli shekel on Dec. 31, which more than offset a slight increase in U.S. and Canadian sales for the period.

title: Thatcher and Gorbachev, Far Apart on Issues, Rekindle Their Cordial Ties
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and Margaret Thatcher, the British Prime Minister, rekindled their unusual political relationship tonight with a midnight talk after Mr. Gorbachev flew in from Cuba.

title: Talking Deals; Armco's Accord With Kawasaki
description: ROBERT E. BONI, the chairman of Armco, the nation's fifth-largest steelmaker, said his company's agreement to sell a 40 percent stake in its steelmaking division to the Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Japan had come a little late. The deal, signed last week, followed similar arrangements by nearly all the major players in the steel industry. ''We're sort of lagging behind many of the others,'' he said.

title: KABUL COURT PUTS PAKISTAN ON TRIAL
description: With two suspected Pakistani infiltrators as its showpiece, the Afghan Government staged a spy trial today that appeared designed to press claims that recent guerrilla attacks on Jalalabad and other Afghan cities have been organized and supported by Pakistan.

title: First Commercial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included pretax provisions for loan losses of $225,000 for latest first quarter and $135,000 for year-ago period.

title: Luria (L.) & Son (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included $357,000, or 6 cents a share, from an accounting change. Fiscal year 1989's net was reduced by about $1.4 million because of a $2.3 million provision for litigation in the land case.

title: Metro Datelines; Company Admits Illegal Importing
description: An airplane equipment company and its chairman pleaded guilty yesterday to violating an anti-apartheid law for importing four jet engines owned by South African Airways.

title: Metro Datelines; Biaggi Plea for Mercy Is Rejected by Judge
description: Former Representative Mario Biaggi made a tearful plea for mercy yesterday, but a Federal judge refused to reduce his sentence for accepting an illegal gratuity.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Graf Easily Gains Quarterfinals: Steffi Graf rode an overpowering serve into the quarterfinals of the $300,000 Family Circle Magazine Cup yesterday, routing Regina Rajchrtova of Czechoslovakia, 6-0, 6-2. The match at the Harbour Town Racquet Club clay courts in Hilton Head Island, S.C., lasted only 40 minutes as Graf, the world's top-ranked player, surrendered only nine points in seven service games. In the fifth game of the first set, Graf, the tournament's top-seeded player, served three consecutive aces. She also finished the match with nine service winners. All the other seeded players in the tournament advanced yesterday, including No. 5 Lori McNeil, No. 6 Helen Kelesi, No. 8 Hana Mandlikova and No. 9 Sandra Cecchini. Tomorrow, Graf plays the winner of today's scheduled match between Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia and Kelesi.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 135, 76ers 93: Reggie Theus scored 20 of his 30 points in the first half last night to lead Atlanta at home. The Hawks outscored Philadelphia, 40-14, in the second quarter and led by 78-37 at the half. The 78 points is the most Atlanta has scored this season in one half. The 42-point margin of victory tied the all-time record for the Hawks, who beat San Diego, 129-87, on Nov. 30, 1967. Atlanta took a 26-6 lead with 4 minutes 31 seconds left in the first quarter. The Hawks' largest lead was 130-80 on Antoine Carr's technical foul shot with 2:53 to play in the game. Moses Malone scored 25 points and had 12 rebounds for the Hawks, and Dominique Wilkins and John Battle added 19 each. Philadelphia was led by Charles Barkley and Ron Anderson, who scored 18 points apiece.(AP)

title: Dow Offsets Loss With a 6.60-Point Gain
description: Stocks moved moderately higher yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.60 points to close at 2,304.80. That offset, exactly, its loss on Tuesday.

title: Mcorp Case Is Moved
description: Mcorp said Tuesday that United States Bankruptcy Judge Cornelius Blackshear in New York had granted the banking company's motion to transfer its Chapter 11 case from New York to Houston. The Dallas-based Mcorp said earlier that it intended to file motions in Houston to consolidate its case with those of its non-banking subsidiaries, Mcorp Financial Inc. and Mcorp Management. Last week, Federal regulators seized control of 20 of Mcorp's 25 banks after the company disclosed plans to seek Federal bankruptcy protection.

title: CFS Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $60,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $32,000 for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New York Primitivism In Boston
description: JUST when you thought Boston was safe from undue New York influence, along comes the Hub Club, a new three-story New York City-style club smack in the middle of what was once commonly referred to as ''the combat zone'' in downtown Boston.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., an auto-parts company, said it plans to sell its Arvinair division, which makes portable heaters and evaporative coolers, and had assigned Merrill Lynch Capital Markets to seek bids.

title: The New York Times/WBBM-TV Poll; The Vote in Chicago
Giant Yellowknife Mines Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a writedown of the carrying value of assets at its Timmins division of $29,620,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lawrence Pope, Bank Robber, 70
description: Lawrence Pope, a bank president who became a bank robber, collapsed and died Monday on a street in Austin. He was 70 years old.

title: State Overrules Censorship Of Student Publication on L.I.
description: In a ruling with broad implications for school districts in New York, the State Education Commissioner has overturned a Long Island school board's censorship of a student-written publication.

title: A Time for Healing
description: The Supreme Court in January struck down a Richmond, Va., ordinance that set aside 30 percent of public construction work for minority subcontractors. The Constitution requires strict scrutiny of any such race-based plan, the Court said, and Richmond had not adequately justified it.

title: Amnesty Looks First at Victims, Not Ideologies; Rudder Bent Left
description: To the Editor:

title: De Laurentiis Bid Is Made
description: The Roth-Stern Group, an investment firm, said today that it had submitted a bid to acquire the De Laurentiis Entertainment Group Inc., the Hollywood studio that is operating under the protection of Federal bankruptcy laws. Roth-Stern did not disclose the value of its bid or any other details.

title: Groups Protest Drug Unit List Of Suspects
description: A Federal law-enforcement agency said yesterday that it maintains a list of suspected members of violent Jamaican drug gangs operating in New York City and other major cities across the country.

title: Salvador Rebels Issue Threats Against Judges
description: El Salvador's leftist rebels today threatened officials connected to a court order that briefly released two army officers and a right-wing businessman thought to be involved in a kidnapping ring.

title: Celina Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,213,357 from the sale of service subsidiary assets for the quarter and year, a $603,000 investment loss for the quarter and an investment gain of $3,322 for the year. c-Net loss d-After an investment gain of $154,801.

title: Increase in Positive Tests
description: More than 1,100 athletes in 1988 tested positive for banned substances, a majority of them anabolic steroids. Those figures, included in a report by the International Olympic Committee medical commission, represent a slight increase over 1987.

title: Review/Blues; A.C. Reed in Raucous Form
description: The rituals of good-time music were at the Village Gate on Friday night in the form of the blues saxophonist and singer A. C. Reed. Mr. Reed, a veteran of the Chicago blues scene, isn't much of a saxophonist or a singer, but somehow that seemed irrelevant. Backed by a good band, he let his raucous, profane and irreverent personality take over. Had there been a floor for it, the audience would have been incited to dance.

title: Raising Farmer Tax Burden Hurts New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing Journal; Second Thoughts: Laissez Faire or Plain Unfair?
description: After 10 years in which ordinary Chinese citizens were the greatest cheerleaders for change and helped tug the country toward the market, there are signs that they could switch sides.

title: TV Notes
description: Paragon Adds TNT

title: Biosearch Medical Products Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $1,425,000 for the latest year and $122,000 for 1987, both from the early retirement of debt.

title: Review/Theater; Overcoming a Loveless Childhood
description: While most of Francois Truffaut's ''Small Change'' has receded in memory, I can't imagine forgetting the scene in which a baby tumbles from a high apartment-house window and survives. Truffaut made an indelible image out of profound questions that had defined his career from ''The 400 Blows'' and that never leave most of us: By what miracle do some children survive? What happens to those victims of cruel, lonely, loveless childhoods who do grow up but don't bounce back?

title: Tridel Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain on the sale of residential property of $39.9 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Proxy Fight Set By Union Capital
description: The Union Capital Corporation and a group of its senior officers, who control a combined 9.9 percent stake in the General Development Corporation, announced a proxy fight for two seats on the 10-member board of the Miami-based real estate concern. Union Capital, a real estate concern based in New York, revealed the plan in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Bush Set to Extend Economic Sanctions Against Panama for a Year
description: President Bush will sign an executive order this week to extend economic sanctions against Panama for one year, Administration officials said today. They said Mr. Bush might expand the sanctions if the presidential election scheduled in Panama for May 7 is fraudulent.

title: How Koch Aide, Facing Dismissal, Saved His $52,000 Pension
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he was ''distressed'' when he learned last February that his personnel chief, Joseph DeVincenzo, had managed to retire from his $104,500 job before he was forced to resign in the wake of an investigation into a New York City jobs program.

title: B&H Bulk Carriers Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 year was for the period from June 1, 1987 (inception) to Dec. 31.

title: Tax Return Extensions
description: More than six million couples and individuals are expected to take an automatic four-month extension in the time to file their 1988 tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: Publisher of TV Guide Joins New York Post
description: After five turbulent months as publisher of TV Guide, Valerie B. Salembier resigned yesterday to become president of The New York Post.

title: Tele-Optics Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $22,000.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agencies' Roles As Teachers
description: Mindful that many of the David Ogilvys and Saatchi brothers of tomorrow are still in school, several of the nation's leading advertising agencies are sending employees into New York City's schools for a program that offers students a glimpse into the business.

title: Never Underestimate Power of Women in Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Simmons Lowers Stake in Lockheed
description: In a swift turnabout, Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor and corporate raider, lowered his stake in the Lockheed Corporation to 4.2 percent from 5.3 percent. Mr. Simmons sold the 200,000 Lockheed shares on the open market on Tuesday for an average price of $48.81. Mr. Simmons's action came only one day after he first announced his Lockheed holdings. On Tuesday, Lockheed announced that it would sell some of its nonmilitary businesses and put 17 percent of its stock in the hands of employees.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HANGING a mirror, especially a large one, is usually more difficult than hanging a picture the same size. Because mirrors are heavy, awkward and fragile, more planning and organization are necessary, and greater attention must be given to installing the wall fasteners. Still, the task is not beyond amateurs.

title: Nicaragua Inflation Cut
description: Nicaragua's inflation rate, one of the highest in the world, declined sharply in March, according to official figures published this week. Consumer price inflation fell to a monthly rate of 20 percent in March from 46 percent in February. Inflation reached a high of 126.6 percent in December, falling to 91.8 percent in January, when the Government put austerity measures into effect.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hollywood Spent More For TV Ads Last Year
description: Movie advertising on television reflected the glowing performance of the film industry last year, jumping 17 percent above the level a year earlier, according to a survey. Hollywood spent $383 million promoting new film releases in 1988, according to the Television Bureau of Advertising, which compiled the survey.

title: Corrections
description: An article about television ratings in the Word and Image pages on March 29 misstated the number of weeks that CBS placed first during the 1962-63 season. CBS was in first place for 46 weeks, a record that remains unmatched.

title: Broadcaster Gets 6-Month Prison Term
description: LEAD: S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman, former broadcast editor of Business Week magazine, was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail for trading on inside information obtained from proofs of the magazine.

title: New York Cable Systems Agree on Yankee Games
description: Bowing to pressure from public officials and subscribers, three major cable television systems in New York City agreed with the Madison Square Garden network last night to carry the network's Yankee games as part of their fixed-cost basic service.

title: Philips Unit Names Chief
description: Einar Kloster, president of the North American Philips Corporation, will be named to the additional positions of chief executive and chairman of the executive management committee, effective June 1, the company said yesterday. Mr. Kloster, 51 years old, will succeed Gerrit Jeelof, 61, who will continue as chairman. Stephen C. Tumminello, 52, executive vice president, will succeed Mr. Kloster as vice chairman of the executive management committee. North American Philips is a subsidiary of Philips N.V. of the Netherlands.

title: Airship International Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Miller (Herman) Inc.(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
description: b-After a gain of $3.3 million from an accounting change. The latest 9 months included 40 weeks, compared with 39 weeks in the year-ago period.

title: Debt Reduction: Ways to Do It
description: The new approach to world debt that industrial countries have endorsed depends on some fancy financial footwork to achieve its goal - a reduction of the $350 billion that third world countries like Mexico and Venezuela owe American and foreign banks.

title:
Market Place;
Growth Funds Show Strength
description: LEAD: Stock mutual funds posted modest gains in the first quarter of 1989, but as a whole they trailed the overall stock market. One area of the industry stood out, however: funds that concentrate on small, growth-oriented companies did better, on average, than the biggest funds and the market in general.

title: Planters Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Peoples Savings Bank (Monoe, Mich.) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Bridge
description: The big lead held by the men's team in the Marathon Battle of the Sexes reached a peak of 290 imps at midday on Tuesday. But it was then eroded: The women cut the lead by 141 in the next 14 hours of play.

title: Complex Textile Miniatures and Spare Sculptures
description: BEFORE Diane Itter's exhibitions even open there are ''sold'' dots on the labels. The one now at the Heller Gallery is no exception. What is it about these flat fiber miniatures that charms and resonates in such a familiar way?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Ezra Helfand has been appointed senior vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a performance by the Orchestra of St. Luke's on Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall with Roger Norrington as conductor described his appearance incorrectly in some copies. It was his New York debut, not his American debut.

title: A Designer's First Solo, First Store and First Restaurant
description: ONE day last week, the interior designer Bob Patino, tanned and chic in a Comme des Garcons jacket and white shirt, breezed into the L.S. Collection, a Madison Avenue home-furnishings boutique. Greeted with the ceremony usually reserved for a foreign dignitary - Mr. Patino created the interior - he shook hands with the staff, and without much ado gave a few polite instructions on improving the look of the displays. Not that there was much to do.

title: DRUGS AND TERROR LINKED IN COLOMBIA
description: An American human rights group says Colombian cocaine dealers financed, trained and directed paramilitary death squads that committed most of Colombia's political killings and massacres in 1987 and 1988.

title: New Chairman At Blue Arrow
description: Blue Arrow P.L.C. said today that its chief executive, Mitchell Fromstein, had been appointed chairman, replacing the company's founder, Antony Berry, and culminating a feud between the two men that rocked the British employment agency for several months.

title: Washington Talk: Districtspeak; Money Talks, but Not Always With Clarity Special to The New York Times
description: Excerpt from yesterday's communique of the Interim Committee, the Government steering group that sets policy for the 151-nation International Monetary Fund:

title: Canucks Defeat Flames in Overtime of Playoff Opener
description: Paul Reinhart, traded by Calgary to Vancouver before the start of the season, scored at 2 minutes 47 seconds of overtime as the Canucks defeated the Flames, 4-3, tonight in the opener of their Smythe Division playoff.

title: Reviews/Television; A City's Reactions to Its First AIDS Cases
description: By 1991, the experts say, 80 percent of AIDS cases will be showing up not in the big cities like New York and San Francisco, where they have been centered, but in middle-sized ones in middle America. The reactions of the folks in Fort Wayne, Ind., to the appearance of the disease in the mid-1980's are scrutinized in ''America in the Age of AIDS.''

title: Acquittal Bid for Walters
description: The attorney for the sports agent Norby Walters told a Federal jury here today that the Government's case against his client was ''completely empty'' and asked that Walters be acquitted. In his closing argument, the attorney, Robert Gold, prefaced an extensive review of the evidence by saying: ''This is not a morality play. This is a Federal criminal case.''

title: Bush Panel Rejects Arab-American Plea to Curb Israeli Trade
description: A Bush Administration trade policy review committee has rejected a petition from an Arab-American group to strip Israel of privileges to sell some goods to the United States duty free, Administration officials say.

title: Knicks Falling Into Their Own Traps
description: Not too long ago, Knicks' fans were looking at a possible 60-victory season. But with nine games left in the season, unless there is a sharp turnaround, the Knicks may have to settle for 50 - even with games against the Nets and the Charlotte Hornets.

title: Release the Captive Judges
description: President Bush appears ready to recommend a 25 percent pay raise for judges. Such a move would decouple increases for judges from increases for Congressmen. It's a sensible approach, and Congress would earn credit by going along.

title: SOLIDARITY REINSTATED
description: The leaders of Solidarity signed accords with the Government today restoring the banned union's legal status and providing for the first free and open elections in this country since World War II.

title: The Porcelain Art Of Mottahedeh Knows No Age
description: AS guests linger over after-dinner coffee at the White House and diplomats sip cocktails across the street at the newly restored Blair House, they are surrounded by what they suppose to be priceless porcelains: glorious Chinese export bowls holding lilies and freesia; olive dishes emblazoned with the American eagle, serving as ashtrays; a classic Tobacco Leaf epergne, filled with fruits and candy.

title: PENTAGON NOMINEE OUTLINES FINANCES
description: Donald J. Atwood Jr., the former executive of the General Motors Corporation who has been nominated to be Deputy Secretary of Defense, said today that he had agreed to buy an insurance policy that would pay his pension even if the automaker were to go bankrupt.

title: U.S. PROPOSES RISE OF UP TO 150,000 IN NEW REFUGEES
description: The Bush Administration asked Congress today to permit as many as 150,000 additional immigrants, many of them from the Soviet Union, to enter the United States over the next five years.

title: Katharine Zadravec, A Poet, Is Dead at 56
description: Katharine E. Zadravec, a poet, columnist and former administrator of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, died of cancer Tuesday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. She was 56 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Santa Monica Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Smerlas May Move On
description: Fred Smerlas of the Buffalo Bills last season was credited with 54 tackles, including four quarterback sacks, and made the fifth Pro Bowl appearance of his 10-year National Football League career. But the 32-year-old nose tackle learned on Tuesday that he may not play for the Bills again. Smerlas told The Buffalo News that he met with Bill Polian, the Bills' general manager, to discuss his future with the team and received no assurance that he would make the final roster next season.

title: FFP Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company had no prior year results because it began operations in May 1987.

title: Warsaw, as Seen in Moscow
description: The official Soviet press provided detailed coverage of the accord by which the Polish opposition is to be given a role in government. Page A6.

title: Bentsen Warns Europeans Not to Set Trade Curbs in '92
description: The Senate Finance Committee chairman, Lloyd Bentsen, today promised ''mirror action'' retaliation if the European Community raised trade barriers against the United States as the bloc moves toward a single market by the end of 1992.

title: Tanker Captain Freed After Judge Cuts Bail
description: Joseph J. Hazelwood, the former captain of the oil tanker Exxon Valdez, was freed from Suffolk County Jail today after a New York State Supreme Court justice reduced his bail to $25,000.

title: It's U.S. vs. France at Davis Cup
description: The procession of strollers entered Sea World in single file: the Ken Flachs followed by the Robert Segusos; John McEnroe; his wife, Tatum O'Neal, and their two sons; and finally Andre Agassi, who at 18, is too old for a stroller but still just a kid in tennis circles.

title: An Apology to Disney
description: Faced with a lawsuit, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences apologized to the Walt Disney Company today for using its character Snow White on last week's Academy Awards television show.

title: International Lease Finance Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Gorbachev, in London, Chides U.S. on Arms Talks
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today that the Bush Administration's foreign policy review was taking too long and endangering the momentum of negotiations to reduce nuclear arms, a Soviet spokesman said.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY FILMS FROM VIETNAM

title: Journalistic Ethics Well Scrutinized
description: To the Editor:

title: What Government Admits Secret Documents Say
description: Following are excerpts from a 42-page document submitted in the trial of Oliver L. North. The document represents a distillation of a number of still-secret documents that the Government would not allow to be introduced at trial.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Allow Increase in Inmates for Jails
description: A Federal judge denied New York City's request yesterday to put more inmates into its crowded jails and gave the Correction Department 10 days to show that it is no longer housing inmates in holding pens and gymnasiums, in violation of a 1981 court order.

title: City National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After non-recurring income of $445,000 for the latest first quarter and $256,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Mayor Koch, Patronage and Sanctimony
description: What did he know and when did he know it? Nothing and never. That summarizes Mayor Edward Koch's answers to questions about the Talent Bank, his part-affirmative action, part-patronage program that seems to have run out of control. He would give his credibility a boost by accepting some responsibility.

title: Bayard Schieffelin, 85, An Ex-Library Official
description: Bayard Schieffelin, executive officer of the New York Public Library from 1950 to 1968 and a member of the family that owned Schieffelin & Company, the drug-importing concern, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: Ally for San Diego
description: Robert Abrams, New York's Attorney General, has agreed to join the San Diego Yacht Club's appeal of a court decision that took the America's Cup away from the club and awarded it to New Zealand.

title: Rose: Indicted Man Is No Longer a Friend
description: Pete Rose distanced himself today from former acquaintances who face prison sentences on drug and tax charges. The Cincinnati Reds manager, who is under investigation by the baseball commissioner, said after a 4-1 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers that he was not as close to the acquaintances as indicated in news reports.

title: Sihanouk Asks Paris for Help on Cambodia
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian resistance leader, called upon France today to organize an international conference on Cambodia.

title: Theodore Batton, Designer, 39
description: Theodore Batton, a children's clothing designer, died March 25 at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 39 years old and lived in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Charter Hopes Are Faulted By Experts
description: The proposals for a revised New York City government offered this week by the five borough presidents are probably unconstitutional, several legal experts said yesterday.

title: 'Super 8' Festival
description: The Downtown Community TV Center will present 8-millimeter films in a festival called Old and New Masters of Super 8 at the Anthology Film Archives, 34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, through Sunday. Six of the 16 film makers represented in the 29 films will speak. The program is at 8 P.M. tonight and Sunday, and tomorrow at 10 P.M. Admission is $5. Information: 505-5181.

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Beeba's Creations Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Reviews/Music; DePreist, With Sharp Contrasts of Loud and Soft
description: A quarter of a century has passed since James DePreist won the Mitropoulos conducting competition and subsequently became an assistant to Leonard Bernstein at the New York Philharmonic. Many musicians win such contests and subsequently sink from view, but Mr. DePreist has gone on to build a solid career both in this country and abroad. On Wednesday evening he appeared at Alice Tully Hall, leading the New Stockholm Chamber Orchestra in a stylistically diverse program of 18th-, 19th- and 20th-century works.

title: Marcos Is Too Ill to Stand Trial, Federal Prosecutors Now Decide
description: Federal prosecutors reversed themselves yesterday and said former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines was now too ill to stand trial on the criminal charges pending against him in New York.

title: Medicore Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $95,090.

title: Taiwan to Send First Official Delegation to China
description: In its boldest move yet to broaden contact with mainland China, Taiwan announced today that it would send its Finance Minister to Beijing next month as head of its first official delegation to visit the mainland since the Communist revolution 40 years ago.

title: Johnson Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gasoline Prices Rise Sharply On West Coast After Oil Spill
description: Even as the supply of crude oil being shipped from Alaska began returning to normal today, the effect of the oil spill in Prince William Sound rippled down the West Coast, where oil companies have limited gasoline supplies to some distributors and prices have risen sharply.

title: Honolulu Offering Totals $50 Million
description: The City of Honolulu yesterday entered the debt market with a $50 million issue of general obligation bonds sold through competitive bidding.

title: Africa's Ties to Israel, Broken and Resumed
description: To the Editor:

title: A Specter of Severe Economic Ills Haunts The Promise of Striking Political Changes
description: Behind the striking political changes agreed to by Poland's Communist authorities is the apparent realization that the country's economic problems are so severe that the help of Solidarity is needed to solve them.

title: HAITIAN STRUGGLES TO RETAIN CONTROL
description: With dissident troops threatening to attack the Presidential Palace, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril struggled today to save his nearly seven-month-old Government.

title: Metro Datelines; Trustees Approved For Power Authority
description: In another step forward for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the State Senate yesterday approved two trustees for the New York Power Authority.

title: Deal for Jefferson Hotel
description: Paine Webber Properties Inc., a unit of Paine Webber Inc., announced Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire the Jefferson Hotel in Washington. The property, one of the leading luxury hotels in the capital, is being acquired from the estate of Edward Bennett Williams, the trial lawyer, who died last August.

title: Sodarcan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 3 Goals by Kontos Help Kings Tie Series
description: Chris Kontos had a goal in each period as the Los Angeles Kings beat the Edmonton Oilers, 5-2, last night to even their Smythe Division semifinal series 1-1.

title: Dean Albertson, 68, A Professor of History
description: Dean Albertson, a historian who helped develop the oral history project at Columbia University and was a teacher at the University of Massachusetts since 1965, died last Friday at his home in Longmeadow, Mass. He was 68 years old.

title: More Ice Keeps Breaking; Even in Asia, Light at the End of the Tunnel
description: Americans well know that Vietnam is a land of false dawns and unlit tunnels. Yet there's reason to cheer Hanoi's promise to withdraw its remaining 50,000 or more troops from Cambodia this fall. That decision can mean deliverance for an endlessly ravaged country and economic revival for all Indochina. As in Poland, crucial impetus comes from changed Soviet policies, in this case the efforts to end intractable regional conflicts.

title: Audiovox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Paine Webber Quits Venture
description: Paine Webber pulled out of a two-year joint venture with Young & Rubicam yesterday, saying the enterprise had grown beyond its original focus as an investment banking unit.

title: Sensormatic Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: A Special Style

title: N.J. Transit Votes Fare Rise But Delays Cuts in Service
description: N.J. Transit voted today to raise bus and rail fares an average of 12.5 percent but delayed until next month a decision on drastic service cuts proposed to close a budget deficit.

title: Navratilova Gains Easily; McNeil Is Upset, 6-1, 6-2
description: Martina Navratilova, serving and slicing more boldly as the brief match unfolded, had little difficulty today as she advanced to the quarterfinals of the Family Circle Cup after a 6-4, 6-2 dismantling of Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden.

title: Bush Plan On Savings Is Set Back
description: A House banking subcommittee handed a victory today to L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Carolina First Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Judge Bars a Death Penalty For Philadelphia Mob Leader
description: A judge ruled today that Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed head of organized crime in the Philadelphia-southern New Jersey area, and seven associates must be sentenced to life in prison instead of death in the electric chair for killing another mobster.

title: Pact on Emhart Challenged by Suit
description: A class action suit filed in Federal court in New York contends that the agreement between the Black & Decker Corporation and Topper L.P., which ended the battle for control of the Emhart Corporation, violated the anti-fraud provisions of Federal securities laws. Topper agreed to drop its $35-a-share bid for Emhart last month, in return for $21 million payment from Black & Decker, which offered $40 a share for the Farmington, Conn., tool manufacturer.

title: Metro Datelines; Judge Says Land Can Be Developed
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the Village of Scarsdale was within its rights to permit development of 16 acres of property although they were donated to the community for recreational use by the late Harry Winston, the jeweler.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the restoration of the former Studio 54 in New York City for a club called the Ritz misstated its capacity. It would hold 3,000 people standing and sitting, not 3,000 sitting.

title: Restaurants
description: Le Refuge

title: A Tale Of Haste And Waste
description: In 1968, the Atlantic Richfield Company uncovered a vast new oilfield on the North Slope of Alaska. That set off a tale of haste and pressure culminating years later in the disaster of the Exxon Valdez, and featuring one important character now almost forgotten - Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Rite Aid Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
description: b-After income of $1,022,000 for the latest 14 weeks and $827,000 for the year-ago 13 weeks, both from equity in net earnings of 50 percent or less owned companies. c-After a one-time adjusted gain of $47,059,000, or $1.14 a share, on disposition of discontinued operations and a gain of $3,712,000, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest year totaled 53 weeks, compared with 52 weeks in 1988.

title: Howe Richardson Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $550,000 on termination of U.S. pension plans and a provision for plant consolidation in the U.S.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Pistons 115, Bulls 108: Joe Dumars scored 8 of his 20 points during a 15-0 run in the third quarter last night as Detroit beat Chicago for the eighth straight time. The Pistons extended their home winning streak to 15 and tied the franchise record for most victories in a season with 54. Michael Jordan had his seventh straight triple-double for Chicago, getting 31 points, 13 rebounds and 10 assists. Isiah Thomas scored 18 points for Detroit, which won for the 18th time in 20 games. Mark Aguirre and Rick Mahorn scored 16 points each, and Bill Laimbeer had 13 points and 22 rebounds, including 16 in the second half. With the Pistons trailing by 68-61 early in the third quarter, Thomas scored on a drive to start the 15-0 run. After Aguirre hit a free throw, Dumars made consecutive baskets and Mahorn put in an offense rebound to give Detroit its first lead since the opening quarter. Two more baskets by Dumars and a jumper by Thomas gave the Pistons a 76-68 lead.(AP) Bullets 101, Heat 93: John Williams scored 23 points and made six straight free throws down the stretch as Washington won its fourth straight. Miami, playing at home, led through most of the first three quarters, but Williams made two free throws with 2 minutes 10 seconds left to put the Bullets ahead to stay, 93-91. He hit two more with 1:01 to go for a 95-91 lead, and two more for a 97-91 lead with 19 seconds left.(AP) Spurs 122, Kings 116: Vernon Maxwell scored 28 points and Alvin Robertson had 27 for San Antonio. Robertson also had nine rebounds, seven assists and six steals as the Spurs won their fifth consecutive home game. Willie Anderson added 26 points for San Antonio. (AP) GOLF Three-Way Tie for Lead: Dale Eggeling, Deedee Lasker and Cindy Rarick all shot three-under par 68 in 100-degree temperatures yesterday to tie for the first-round lead of the Red Robin Kyocera Inamori Classic in Poway, Calif. In a big group one stroke behind were Pat Bradley, Laura Davies, Sherri Turner, Sherri Steinhauer, Missie Berteotti, Nancy Brown, Martha Nause and Kim Williams.(AP)

title: Document in North Trial Suggests Stronger Bush Role in Contra Aid
description: A document released today in the trial of Oliver L. North suggests that President Bush, while Vice President, may have played a more direct role in secretly arranging aid for the Nicaraguan rebels than he has acknowledged.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''CLOWNING AROUND,'' a show of pantomime, and juggling by Joe Killian and Michael Zerphy, with audience involvement, 1 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at the Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street. Admission: children and the elderly, $2.50; others, $5. Reservations: 777-3240. LOIS LAFOND AND CARLTON BACON CONCERT, a program presented by the Boulder Children's Productions, with original songs and music, including blues, ballads and African rhythms, 4 P.M. today, at Pennywhistle, 448 Columbus Avenue, at 81st Street. Free. Information: 873-9090. Similar programs will be given at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the Newark Museum, 53 Washington Street, N.J.; free; information: (201) 596-6550, and 3 P.M. Sunday, at the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street; admission: children, $1; adults, $2.50; information: 598-0400. ''RING AROUND A RAINBOW,'' a musical health-and-safety puppet show, presented by the Shadow Box Theater, 2 P.M. Sunday, at Y.M.C.A., Memorial Hall, 30 Third Avenue, at Atlantic Avenue, downtown Brooklyn. Admission: $4.50. Reservations: 877-7356 or 724-0677. EXHIBITION OF CHILDREN'S BOOK ILLUSTRATION, a new show of original artwork, including the works of Maxfield Parrish, Arthur Rackham, Edmund Dulac, Kate Greenway, Charles Dana Gibson and others, at the Museum of Cartoon Art, Comly Avenue, Rye Brook, Westchester County, N.Y.
