Hours: 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays and 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays. Admission: children, 5 to 12, $1 (under 5, free), students and the elderly, $2; others, $3. Information: (914) 939-0234. ''BEAR-CUB CAPERS,'' a puppet show by the Moscow Puppets, at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. today and tomorrow, at the Puppet Playhouse, Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890.

title: Economic Scene; Debt Reduction: Now, the Details
description: TREASURY Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has won the formal approval of the steering committees of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank for his effort to reduce the debt burdens of third world countries. The United States urged, and the communique declared, that the new and revolutionary debt strategy will move forward ''as a matter of urgency.'' That does not mean a solution is in the bag.

title: John Kilbride Is Dead; Shipping Executive, 66
description: John Kilbride, the retired chief executive of the North American interests of Sweden's Brostrom Shipping Company, died Tuesday at his home in Bellrose, L.I. He was 66 years old.

title: Nelson Holdings Intl Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $22,836,000 from the extinguishment of debt and income from the reversal of a loss on disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a provision of $5,424,000 for a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations. The latest year's loss from continuing operations included several non- cash items such as a $23 million management provision against various film properties and distribution of licensing rights, and a charge of $5.5 million for the consolidation of Nelson Vending Technology Ltd.'s results. The year-end results for both periods included the operations of Nelson Vending Technology Ltd.

title: Balancing Need and Risk in Pursuit of Oil
description: The ruinous tanker spill in Alaska demonstrates the perils created by efforts to wrest the nation's last supplies of undrilled oil from beneath the land and the sea.

title: Vernitron Modifies Its Strategy on Bid
description: The Vernitron Corporation said it would not necessarily drop its tender offer of $23 a share, or $294 million, for the Kollmorgen Corporation if it loses a proxy fight for control of the board of the Stamford, Conn., electrical machinery concern. Vernitron, a medical equipment maker in Deer Park, L.I., had previously said that it would drop its bid if it was not successful.

title: Let Golf's Old Masters Compete
description: rrEven after a 67 in the opening round of the Masters yesterday, Lee Trevino was a 49-year-old realist. He talked about how it's ''too early to even think about'' his winning the green jacket that he has never been fitted for. Through the years, he has never done better than tie for 10th on the Augusta National course that, in his mind, his game has never been fitted for.

title: Metro Datelines; Foes of Smoking Hail Gains After One Year
description: After a year of anti-smoking regulations in New York City, non-smokers have gained tremendous ground, but tougher measures are needed, the city's Health Commissioner said yesterday.

title: President Is Ousted At National Intergroup
description: National Intergroup Inc. said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Lawrence J. Farley, had been ousted from his positions after three months with the company.

title: Golden Nugget Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Golden Nugget said its 1988 net non- operating expenses were $20,235,000 higher than 1987's, primarily because of additional net interest costs incurred in connection with the financing for the development and construction of the Mirage, its Las Vegas Strip resort project. The company also recorded a $10,668,000 litigation expense during the second and third quarters of 1988. Subsequently, it agreed to pay $8.5 million in full settlement of the litigation and, accordingly, it recorded a $2,168,000 reversal of litigation judgment expense in the fourth quarter of 1988. The 1987 results benefited from a $169,748,000 pretax gain on the sale of its Atlantic City casino-hotel.

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, the retailer, named Martin M. Kalkstein executive vice president.

description: United States airlines received fewer complaints from passengers in the first quarter of this year than in the same period of 1988, the Transportation Department announced today.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Peter Victor Ueberroth; Lost Cause? Bring It On
description: To the casual observer, Peter V. Ueberroth's deal to buy Eastern Airlines yesterday came out of left field - a former baseball commissioner quickly turned takeover specialist and airline boss.

title: Nicosia Journal; 2 Lovers Torn Asunder, but Then, That's Cyprus
description: Alexia Chronia was smitten, and that was where the problem started.

title: Baby Sitter Indicted in Slaying
description: A 12-year-old girl who says she was overwhelmed by the responsibility of daily baby-sitting was indicted Wednesday on charges of killing her 2-year-old half brother and beating her 15-month-old half sister. After two hours of deliberations, a grand jury in Broward County indicted the girl, Arva Betts, a fifth grader, on adult charges of second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse.

title: Did Namibia Rebel Misread Accord?
description: Accounts from northern Namibia indicate that the guerrillas who infiltrated from Angola expected United Nations forces to detain them safely in camps for the duration of Namibia's transition to independence.

title: Honeywell Stock Rises on Rumors
description: Rumors about a possible bid for Honeywell Inc., the big electronics and controls company that has lost money in two of the last three years, have pushed the price of the company's stock higher today. Ross Perot, the founder of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, denied that he would announce that he had a stake in the company. But the stock price still gained $1.375 a share today, to $70.875,on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock rose $1.875 on Wednesday. Honeywell declined to comment on the Perot rumor.

title: Pan Atlantic Re Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $682,513 for the quarter and $1,027,204 for the year. c-After net realized investment losses of $8,968 for the quarter and $849,243 for the year. d-Net income Results are corrected from yesterday.

title: Rebels in El Salvador Kill 3 In Raid on an Army Outpost
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked an army outpost early today, killing at least three soldiers and wounding five, army sources said.

title: Paramount Funding Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The 1988 loss included a $14.4 million writedown of investments, compared with a $23.4 million writedown in 1987. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: The year-ago first quarter's share earnings are not available; the company's initial offering was last October.

title: Review/Film; Toxic Avenger Busting Sludge Again
description: Underneath his mutant's scaly mask and monstrous body, the Toxic Avenger is still a nice, clean-cut suburban fellow named Melvin, who fights the forces of evil wherever they may turn up in his hometown of Tromaville, N.J.

title: First Interstate Corp. of Wisonsin reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The latest quarter results included earnings of First Interstate Bank of northern Indiana, which was acquired in January.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misstated the price paid by the BellSouth Corporation for the paging and cellular phone divisions of the Mobile Communications Corporation of America. BellSouth paid $710 million.

title: Natasha Romanov
description: Natasha Galitzine Romanov, whose husband was a nephew of Russia's last czar, Nicholas II, died March 28 in Woodside, Calif. She was 82 years old.

title: Reviews/Music; American and Israeli Jews Performing Together
description: For three days this week in New York, Israeli and American Jews have been examining the power of music as a bond between them. The centerpiece of this conference - entitled ''Counter-Harmonies: Jewish Experience in 20th-Century Music'' and produced through the 92d Street Y, the Hebrew Arts Center and several agencies in Israel - was a concert at the Y on Sunday night. Under three conductors, the New York Chamber Symphony played the music of seven composers, both American and Israeli.

title: Redmen Meet Mayor
description: The St. John's basketball team, winner of the National Invitation Tournament, was welcomed to City Hall yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch and the city's Sports Commission. Koch noted that it was the Redmen's fifth N.I.T. championship and their first under Coach Lou Carnesecca. ''I know this won't be the last championship they bring back to New York City,'' Koch said.(AP)

title: Shad Held Likely to Join Drexel
description: John S. R. Shad, the former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has told Drexel Burnham Lambert executives that he expects to accept the positions of director and chairman of the firm.

title: Lazard Freres Names Partner
description: Steven Rattner, a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company who specialized in investment banking activities in the communications industry, is joining Lazard Freres & Company as a general partner, Lazard said yesterday.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Market Street Opens War on Trash
description: Flying cheesesteak wrappers, swirling scraps of newspapers, mounds of napkins and soda cans and every sort of whatnot - it is not for nothing that this city is derisively labeled ''Filthydelphia.''

description: Alaskan officials said today that the spreading oil slick from the Exxon Valdez threatened thousands of miles of shoreline, and they insisted that only Federal intervention could prevent further environmental damage.

title: For Many, the Accords Seem to Be a Nonevent
description: The reaction of many Poles to the political and economic agreements signed by the Government and Solidarity was subdued today as they viewed the future with considerable uncertainty.

title: Despit Losses, Green Finds Hopeful Signs
description: In the moments that followed the defeat, the manager seemed to be searching for something that he could carry home. Little about the last two days offered him hope, so Dallas Green turned to the eighth inning, when the game was already lost.

title: Ford Executive Shuffle Reported
description: The Ford Motor Company will shuffle its top management next Monday, naming Allan D. Gilmour executive vice president in charge of corporate staffs, a move that bolsters his position as the leading contender to succeed Donald E. Petersen as chief executive.

title: Life of Indiana reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $55,645 for the quarter and $145,537 for the year; the year also included an extraordinary credit of $13,000. c-After realized investment gains of $131,617 for the quarter and $244,527 for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $42,500 for the both periods.

title: 18 Indians Reported Killed By Rebel Mine in Sri Lanka
description: Tamil militants blew up a truck carrying Indian troops in northern Sri Lanka today, killing at least 18 of them, Sri Lankan military officials said.

title: Dr. Otto Brandman, Diabetes Expert, 88
description: Dr. Otto Brandman, an expert on diabetes and a former president of the New Jersey State Diabetic Association, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Bay Shore Community Hospital in Holmdel, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Locust, N.J. Previously, he lived in Maplewood.

title: Treasury Bonds and Notes Sag
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes sagged a bit further in dull trading yesterday, as market participants awaited the release of March employment data this morning.

title: 2 Hatches on B-1's Fail, Spurring Inspection
description: The Strategic Air Command had to conduct a safety inspection of the B-1 bomber fleet for the second time in 10 days after escape hatches on two of the airplanes blew open in training flights, Air Force officials said today.

title: The Exxon Valdez As a Metaphor
description: Oil whipped by the wind to such a froth that it blows into the trees along the beaches. Oil directly in the path of a giant run of salmon. Oil - millions of gallons - blotting the wide blueness of Prince William Sound like an enormous, oozing shadow. The pictures of the Alaskan spill sickened all who saw them.

title: Walking Tours That Play It by Ear
description: In an age when books can be listened to on car stereos and art can be appreciated with audio tape guides, it is hardly surprising that walking tours are also offered on cassettes. Several areas of Manhattan can be explored with a Walkman and walking shoes. These ambulatory narratives combine bite-sized lessons in local history and architecture, anecdotes about past and present New Yorkers and detailed directions about where to walk and what to look at.

title: Slow Growth Held Necessary
description: The Federal Reserve's tighter credit policies should lead to more moderate economic growth and reduced inflation, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank in San Francisco, Robert Parry, said today.

title: ABC Names Head of a New Division
description: ABC named Michael Brockman the president of a new part of its division yesterday. The position includes responsibility for the network's daytime, children's and late-night programming.

title: Test Said to Tie Suspect To Rape in Bellevue Case
description: A preliminary laboratory test shows that the man accused of killing Dr. Kathryn Hinnant at the Bellevue Hospital Center raped her, a police commander said yesterday.

title: More Ice Keeps Breaking; The Iron Curtain Rises - on Triumph in Poland
description: Lech Walesa and Polish Communist officials together, signing an agreement - smiling, even. There could hardly be more dramatic evidence of the end of the cold war. The agreement shows that even in the Communist bloc, behind what was recently called the Iron Curtain, a grass-roots revolution can achieve something approximating its goals. What comes next will be an early test for policy makers groping for the dimensions of a post-cold war world.

title: William Payette, 75, News Agency Official
description: William Payette, former general sales manager of United Press International and a former president of Sigma Delta Chi, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Dallas. He was 75 years old.

title: Circuit City Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
On Stage
description: Songs of the Silver Screen

title: Cocoa Prices Fall Sharply Amid Talk of Global Surplus
description: Cocoa prices tumbled on both sides of the Atlantic today amid talk of a global surplus and forecasts of a record crop in 1989.

title: Soviets Agree to Discuss Terrorism, Drugs and Environmental Issues
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to meet with the United States to discuss cooperation between the two Governments on the issues of terrorism, narcotics trafficking and protection of the environment, Administration officials said today.

title: Sol Mogal, 77, Ex-Bridge Champion, Dies
description: Sol Mogal, an importing executive who won seven national bridge championships in the 1940's and 50's, died of cancer Wednesday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and also had a home in Croton-on Hudson, N.Y.

title: Tri-Line Expressways Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $2,772,758. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Film; Out of the Asylum, Into Manhattan
description: There's nothing dreadfully wrong with ''The Dream Team,'' Howard Zieff's new comedy, except that it's not funny too much of the time. On those occasions when it is funny, the humor less often prompts laughter than mute appreciation of the talents of the principal performers - Michael Keaton, Christopher Lloyd and Peter Boyle.

title: Metro Datelines; Teacher Is Charged In Molesting of Pupils
description: An elementary school teacher has been charged with molesting four fifth graders at Nathan Hale School, the police said.

title: Capital's War on Drugs: An Assault on 3 Fronts
description: Major elements of William J. Bennett's planned drug crackdown in the District of Columbia will include expanding court staffs to handle offenders in narcotics cases, curbing the drug trade in public housing projects and adding prison space, aides to the Federal drug chief said today.

title: Reviews/Film; A Psychological Drama Of Nightmares and Death
description: Phillip Noyce's ''Dead Calm'' is an unsettling hybrid of escapist suspense and the kind of pure trash that depends on dead babies and murdered dogs for effect. In it, John and Rae Ingram (Sam Neill and Nicole Kidman) are a husband and wife alone on their yacht in still waters. They are joined by a classic intruder, the mysterious stranger, who in this case doesn't arrive nearly soon enough.

title: BRIEFS
description: * APL Corp., Miami, a paper company owned by NVF Co., said it had completed the previously announced sale of its Tissue-Paper Products operations to Newco Merger Corp., a newly formed corporation, for $35 million in cash and about $15 million in stock.

title: Browns Drop Passer
description: Gary Danielson, the backup quarterback who helped tutor Bernie Kosar during the University of Miami all-America selection's first four years with the Cleveland Browns, will not be offered another contract with the Browns. Danielson, 37, filled in when Kosar hurt his elbow in the season opener last season. But Danielson broke his ankle the next week and did not return. (AP)

title: Washington Talk; Around Wright, A 'Loyalty Dance'
description: It is a scene rich with political meaning: Day after day, ever growing masses of reporters are ushered into House Speaker Jim Wright's office for ever more pointed questions about the inquiry into his ethics.

title: An Uninspiring Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: Ekiden: Marathon Minus the Loneliness
description: A year after it made its lonely debut as the first ekiden ever held outside Japan, the America's Ekiden, a five-stage, long-distance relay race through the streets of Manhattan, will return to the city Sunday, this time at a more compact distance over a more appealing course at a more forgiving hour.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Paola's

title: North Takes the Stand to Defend Himself
description: Oliver L. North, appearing calm and defiant, testified today in his own defense, repeatedly insisting that his superiors ordered him to act as the Reagan Administration's covert representative to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Urban Adventures: Touring by the Book
description: Most of the time, New Yorkers dart determinedly from point A to point B, or wander about the city oblivious to the cultural, historical and architectural riches in their midst. Occasionally, they may glance up at a particularly notable building or monument, or even join a walking or bus tour in an attempt to become better acquainted with their home town.

title: BGS Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9 A break in the Middle East deadlock proposed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to allow Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to hold elections was given cautious support by President Bush. Page A1

title: Benching Is Painful for Mullen
description: Having Brian Mullen, their lone All-Star, watch a playoff game from a private box is symbolic of what is happening to the Rangers these days.

title: Books of The Times; How Chaplin the Artist Became Chaplin the Star
description: Chaplin and American Culture The Evolution of a Star Image By Charles J. Maland 442 pages. Princeton University Press. $29.95.

title: Rape Charge Splits Stony Brook Campus
description: Two weeks ago a 20-year-old white student at the State University campus here told the police that she had been raped outside her dormitory. She said that her attacker was a black man and that she knew what he looked like.

title: Archibald McG. Foster, 73, Dies; An Advertising Industry Leader
description: Archibald McG. Foster, a leading figure in the advertising industry for almost 40 years, died of a ruptured appendix Tuesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Layford Cay in the Bahamas.

title: Racial Differences in Alimony
description: White women are nearly twice as likely as black women to be awarded alimony, according to a Census Bureau report issued today. White women were also more likely than black women to receive property settlements.

title: The 'Guilt'? of Jews Threatens Israel
description: No one, no people, has so sadly honed guilt to a finer art than we Jews.

title: Brazil Announces Plan to Protect the Amazon
description: Responding to worldwide criticism of Brazil's haphazard development of the Amazon, President Jose Sarney announced a $100 million, five-year program today to zone the 1.9-million-square-mile forest basin for economic and ecological use.

title: Bass Interests Buying A 7.5% Stake in Vons
description: An affiliate of the Robert M. Bass Group and an investment partnership of which Mr. Bass is a member said today that they had agreed to buy a 7.5 percent stake in the Vons Companies and might acquire up to 17.5 percent of the supermarket company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Frank Lorenzo's bitter fight with Eastern's unions appears to have ended. The Texas Air chairman announced he would sell the airline to an investor group and company employees in a $464 million deal that is contingent on employee wage concessions and subject to approval by creditors and a Federal bankruptcy judge. [ Page A1. ] Those familiar with the career of Peter V. Ueberroth were not surprised by the former baseball commissioner's interest in trying to salvage the airline. Man in the News. [ D1. ] John S. R. Shad expects to become chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the former S.E.C. chairman has told executives with the firm. His final decision will be announced after Drexel settles outstanding fraud charges with the agency. [ D1. ] Ford Motor will shuffle its top management, naming Allan D. Gilmour executive vice president in charge of corporate staffs. The move bolsters his position as the leading contender to succeed Donald E. Petersen as chief executive. [ D1. ] Two groups with ties to Robert M. Bass agreed to buy 7.5 percent of Vons, California's largest supermarket chain. [ D4. ] People in the pharmaceutical industry say they think SmithKline and Beecham will ultimately announce a deal to merge. [ D4. ] Rupert Murdoch may sell his business publications that serve the travel and hotel industry. But his company said it would keep its consumer magazines, which include New Woman and Star. [ D16. ] THE ECONOMY Less-polluting fuels for cars, buses and trucks are receiving more attention. To be sure, striking changes will be required for motorists. [ A1. ] A House subcommittee handed a victory to L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., in his squabble with the White House. The panel amended the Bush Administration's savings industry rescue plan to expand the agency's jurisdiction and insulate it from intervention by the White House. [ D1. ] Federal regulators took over 38 more savings associations in eight states, bringing the total under Government control to 215 in 31 states. [ D1. ] Sales were mixed in March at the nation's biggest retailers. Analysts said the sluggish growth at some stores suggested that higher credit costs were making consumers more cautious. [ D4. ] Americans took out $4.22 billion more in consumer debt in February than they paid off, the Federal Reserve reported. [ D4. ] Lloyd Bentsen promised swift retaliation should the European Community raise trade barriers against the United States as it moves toward a single market by the end of 1992. [ D1. ] MARKETS The stock market fell in modest trading, as investors turned cautious before the nation's employment report for March is released today. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.83 points to close at 2,291.97. [ D6. ] The dollar was generally higher in listless trading. Gold prices rose slightly. [ D13. ] Prices of Treasury issues sagged. [ D12. ] Cocoa prices tumbled amid talk of a surplus and record crop forecasts. Coffee futures fell as international talks stalled. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Important details in the new foreign debt strategy remain to be negotiated. The risks include defaults, economic collapse and political and social disasters. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] A new season has begun for commodity traders, with the release of two eagerly anticipated reports. Last summer's devastating drought has injected new uncertainties into the grain and soybean market. Market Place. [ D6. ] A small agency has taken bold steps toward success. Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster even challenged Dom Perignon in taste tests. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D16. ]

title: No Verdict in Fraud Trial
description: The jury deciding the fate of Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom will resume deliberations Friday after failing to reach a verdict after more than five hours today.

title: PCA International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After tax credits of $1,507,000 for the quarter and $2,081,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,439,000 and $1,801,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest quarter and year pretax income included a restructuring reserve of $1,383,000 resulting primarily from the closing of 72 department store studios, which was substantially offset by a gain of $1,357,215 from the sale of the company's former corporate headquarters. The prior year pretax income included a gain of $212,618 related to the sale of undeveloped land during the period.

title: A Warning For Soviets
description: The Soviet Union is facing its toughest year yet and could degenerate into ''economic chaos'' without urgent reforms, a newspaper said today.

title: Review/Art; Split Show of Black Artists Using Nontraditional Media
description: ''Art as a Verb: The Evolving Continuum'' is important for its art and instructive about where exhibitions of this high level of intelligence and provocation should take place. It brings together 13 artists, 11 of them women, who are involved with media other than traditional painting and sculpture. Many use words. The esthetic is one of action, impermanence and change.

title: CVN Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Bush Renews Veto Vow On Minimum Pay Bill
description: President Bush today renewed his vow to veto any attempt to raise the hourly minimum wage higher than $4.25 as the Senate debated setting the base wage at $4.65.

title: 60's Militant Returns to U.S. From Guyana and Is Arrested
description: Herman B. Ferguson, who fled to Guyana 18 years ago to evade a prison sentence for conspiring to murder two moderate civil-rights leaders, voluntarily returned to New York City last night and surrendered to Federal law-enforcement officials.

title: Electro Rent reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
Barry's Jewelers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings have been restated to give effect to the company's December 1988 stock dividend of 25 percent.

title: Leary of Dodgers Stops Reds, 4-1
description: Tim Leary did what Tim Belcher and Orel Hershiser couldn't do - he beat the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Officials Defend Their Posts to Charter Panel
description: A parade of public officials passed yesterday before the commission that is drafting a new constitution for New York City, virtually all of them presenting plans to preserve, protect or defend the powers of the posts they hold.

title: Incomnet Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $41,403. c-Net loss and included an extraordinary gain of $106,266.

title: Undo the Chains of Adolescence
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Film; Idiocies and Idiosyncrasies Of Bungling Ballplayers
description: There is a religious shrine inside the locker of Pedro Cerrano, one of the Cleveland Indians and a practicing voodooist. On the shelf is a little cigar-smoking voodoo doll and a tiny cup of sacrificial rum. Every day, Pedro opens his locker and lights ritual candles to cure his emotionally troubled bat. The bat likes fast balls very much, he explains, but is ''afraid of curve balls.''

title: Bias Claim Rejected in Johnson Estate Case
description: The widow of J. Seward Johnson, asserting that the surrogate hearing her legal battle over a $500 million estate was biased against her, lost an attempt yesterday to have another court hear the complaint.

title: Rangers' Early Lapses Put Them in 2-0 Hole
description: Mental preparation. For Phil Esposito, it was to be his team's single greatest priority in the playoffs. He had spoken to the Rangers about it in team meetings and reminded his players of it in odd moments in the team's hotel here. Mental preparation.

title: Williams-Sonoma Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Washington Talk: Snapshot; As No. 2 for Urban Affairs, a Child of the City
description: Cities may not rank so high on the Federal agenda any more, but in some Federal agencies, people from cities still rank high. Take Alfred A. DelliBovi of Astoria, Queens, who is about to join Jack F. Kemp of Buffalo, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, as Under Secretary.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Respond to Soviet Initiatives
description: As startling actions and proposals by the Soviet Union and some of its allies spread around the world, pressures are mounting on the Bush Administration to abandon its passive posture and respond to Moscow's initiatives.

title: Prosecutor Discharged Over the Adams Case
description: The prosecutor who fought to prevent the release last month of Randall Dale Adams, imprisoned 12 years for a policeman's murder to which another man all but confessed in December, has been dismissed by the Dallas County District Attorney for his handling of the case.

title: Toronto Testimony
description: Molly Killingbeck, a 400-meter runner, said yesterday that national coaches warned her not to run in the Olympics last year ''if I was on the same stuff'' that Ben Johnson was using. Killingbeck was testifying in Toronto at an inquiry into drug use among Canadian athletes.

title: Trevino, at the Age of 49, Shoots 67 to Lead the Masters
description: Twenty years after he swore he would never play in the Masters again, Lee Trevino shot five-under-par 67 today in the first round of the 53d Masters to become, at 49, the oldest man ever to lead the field in any round of this tournament.

title: Washington Talk; White House
description: Why are President Bush's speeches so, well, boring? We must now consider the possibility of revenge.

title: About Real Estate; 2 Rentals in the Bronx Are Turned Into Co-ops
description: With the exception of its fashionable Riverdale section, the Bronx has so far escaped the tidal wave of cooperative conversions that has been rolling over rental buildings almost everywhere else in the city.

title: Edelman Restricted On Storehouse
description: A British regulatory agency pressed the corporate raider Asher B. Edelman to clarify his intentions on a possible bid for the retailer Storehouse P.L.C. A spokesman for the Panel on Takeovers and Mergers said the nonstatutory body had imposed restrictions on Mr. Edelman's dealings in Storehouse after he built a 7.8 percent stake and spoke of a possible bid for the troubled British company.

title: Alternative-Fuel Vehicles Move From Fancy to Fact
description: In British Columbia, drivers of about 8,000 vehicles are using natural gas instead of gasoline. To fill up, the drivers pull into one of 50 service stations equipped with natural-gas pumps.

title: Court Frowns On Civil Deals By Prosecutors
description: New York's highest court today raised serious questions about a common agreement used by district attorneys to protect municipalities from being sued for wrongful arrest or other damages.

title: Philip P. Shannon, 73, A Pastor in Scarsdale
description: Msgr. Philip P. Shannon, pastor of the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., and a Navy chaplain in two wars, died of bone cancer Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Aircoa Hotel Partners L.P. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,085,000 from the early retirement of debt. The year-ago period covers Dec. 5, 1986 through Dec. 31, 1987.

title: 'Sesame Street': Milestone and Beginning
description: The 20th anniversary of public television's ''Sesame Street'' is being celebrated on commercial television -NBC at 8 tonight - in a production made not by the Children's Television Workshop, which created the series, but by Jim Henson Productions. Mr. Henson created the Muppets. In fact, this special is really sort of the first installment of ''The Jim Henson Hour,'' a series beginning its regular run on NBC next Friday.

title: Black Law Firm Forms Unusual Alliance
description: A firm of five black lawyers and a firm with 92 lawyers here have formed a unusual alliance aimed at netting corporate clients who want to hire black lawyers but need the resources of a large firm.

title: Bush Is Accused Of Backing Away From Promise on 1988 Arms Pact
description: The Bush Administration, citing budget constraints, does not plan to modernize the nation's surveillance satellites despite President Reagan's promise to do so, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said today.

title: American Air To Add Flights
description: American Airlines said today that it would expand service to Miami and the Caribbean by 24 flights a day by June 1, filling gaps left by strike-crippled Eastern Airlines.

title: Review/Theater; The Don Juan Character That Inspired the Others
description: The stage has produced a number of playwrights whose place in dramatic literature rests as much on the influence they have exerted on other writers as on any work of their own. Few, however, have provided more enduring inspiration for later artists than Tirso de Molina, an early-17th-century Spanish ecclesiastic who created the character of Don Juan.

title: No Headline
description: A House subcommittee today approved a bill that would remove the remaining price controls on natural gas on Jan. 1, 1993.

title: Prison for Howard Beach Victim
description: Timothy Grimes, a victim of the 1986 Howard Beach racial attack, was sentenced yesterday to 16 years in prison for shooting and seriously wounding his brother in Virginia last year.

title: Soviet Deal for Maxwell
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, signed a joint venture today with Moscow involving nonclassified Soviet scientific and medical reports. Mr. Maxwell said in a statement that the deal between his Maxwell Communication Corporation and the Soviet Academy of Science involved an initial capital investment of $34 million. The joint venture, known as Scitechinform, was among several British-Soviet deals expected during this week's visit to Britain by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Consumer Borrowing Up Just a Bit
description: Americans took out $4.22 billion more in consumer debt in February than they paid off, the Federal Reserve reported today. The increase in consumer debt was the smallest reported in four months and came as another sign that the economy may be slowing.

title: Pipeline Operators to Check Crews for Drugs and Alcohol
description: The three major operators of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline announced yesterday that they would begin random drug and alcohol testing of their vessels' crews and take other steps that they hope will cut the risk of oil spills.

title: Liability for Exxon Oil Spill: Untested Waters
description: The oil that is causing widespread damage in Prince William Sound is raising new legal questions. Already 14 suits have been filed, and the Exxon Corporation, whose tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground on March 24, is likely to resemble a legal voodoo doll before all the claimants are finished taking aim.

title: Knick Defense Forces Bucks to Shoot Poorly
description: At a time when their ability to play halfcourt defense was being questioned and their pressure and trapping defenses had become less effective, the Knicks played what Coach Rick Pitino called great defense tonight in defeating the Milwaukee Bucks, 112-99.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; When a hard-working judge dies, are his survivors entitled to compensation?
description: The jov of judging, once compara-tively sedate and safe, seems to have grown distinctly more dangerous in these violent times. But can a judge actually work himself to death?

title: U.S. Pledges Trade Reform
description: The United States Agriculture Secretary, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that the United States was willing to stop subsidized farming and called on the European Community to do the same.

title: TV's 'Nightingales' - Or Bird Brains?
description: LEAD: A tribute to Florence Nightingale by the International Red Cross in 1907 read: ''To Miss Florence Nightingale, the pioneer of the first Red Cross movement, whose heroic efforts on behalf of suffering humanity will be recognized and admired by all ages as long as the world shall last.''

title: Grafton Group Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a special charge of $52,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $526,000 for the year. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: TEXAS AIR AGREES WITH UEBERROTH ON EASTERN SALE
description: The long, bitter fight between Frank Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, and the striking unions at Eastern Airlines appeared to have ended yesterday. Mr. Lorenzo conceded that he had lost the fight and announced that he would sell Eastern to a group of investors and the company's employees.

title: David I. Gaines, Professor, 92
description: Dr. David I. Gaines, who taught history at City College for 40 years before retiring in 1967, died March 23 at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Otherworldliness

title: Robert Dineen, 85, Insurance Executive And Dewey Official
description: Robert E. Dineen, a former president of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company and New York State Superintendent of Insurance, died of heart failure Wednesday at his home in Houston. He was 85 years old.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an arit-cle in Business Day on Wednesday about a new microprocessor made by the International Business Machines Corporation misidentified the magazine that first reported the development. It is Computer Systems News.

title: CrownAmerica Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
description: The latest 6 months included an after-tax gain of $319,000 from the sale of a U.K. subsidiary and exchange gains of $387,000 from overseas operations. The year-ago 6 months included a $500,000 gain from an income tax accounting change, a $103,000 tax credit, and exchange gains of $135,000.

title: New President of A.&S. Faces Tough Challenge
description: Leonard Marcus, a Brooklyn man through and through, has been named the president and chief operating officer of one of the borough's leading institutions, Abraham & Straus. But his big test will come in Manhattan.

title: Indiana Agency's Revenue Bonds
description: The Indiana Housing Finance Authority is tentatively offering about $85 million in single-family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.20 percent for an issue due in 2020. The issue, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation, is backed by Government National Mortgage Association securities.

title: Stotler Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public Aug. 19, 1988. The latest year period is from Aug. 22 to Dec. 31, 1988.

title: Reviews/Theater; Dramatizing the Plight of Homeless Women, in 'Ladies'
description: In Eve Ensler's collage ''Ladies,'' nine homeless women drift and dream through nomadic lives. The play (at St. Clement's) has an evident authenticity, having been drawn from the author's experience working in New York City shelters. The scene is appropriately stark but the play is schematic, with monologues failing to merge into a moving dramatic portrait. Though the play lasts barely one hour, it seems longer, perhaps because of its lack of momentum.

title: Review/Art; George Grosz, Elicitor of the Weimar Era
description: Thirty years may have passed since George Grosz died, only days after returning for the first time in decades from his adopted home in the United States to his native Germany, but the artist remains very much with us. When we look at a political cartoon that evokes wealth by depicting fat men puffing on big cigars, it is Grosz whose work we are really seeing. When we conjure pictures of Weimar Germany as a place where soldiers, prostitutes, bankers and beggars jostle one another on the streets of Berlin, it is Grosz's world we are imagining.

title: Taking Firepower Out of Semiautomatics Taking Firepower Out of Semiautomatics; Repeal 2d Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Odyssey Players
description: The Odyssey Chamber Players are to perform Haydn's ''London'' Trio in C, Smetana's Piano Trio in G minor and Joan Tower's ''Petroushskates'' at 8 Sunday at the Brooklyn Music School, 126 Felix Street, Fort Greene section. Tickets are $9. Information: 678-0793.

title: Review/Dance; A Bill by Kathryn Posin, Who Does It Her Way
description: Kathryn Posin has been a professional choreographer for just over 20 years, and in that time has been determined to say whatever she wishes and in any way that catches her fancy.

title: Mostly Magic's 10th
description: Eighteen magicians, comedians, jugglers and singers will help Mostly Magic celebrate its 10th anniversary with two shows tonight at 9 and 11 at 55 Carmine Street. The cover is $15; there is a one-drink minimum. Information and reservations: 924-1472.

title: Tortelier as Soloist
description: The cellist Paul Tortelier is to be the soloist with the New York Chamber Symphony in the Tchaikovsky ''Variations on a Rococo Theme'' and the Faure ''Elegie'' at 8 P.M. tomorrow at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The program, which is to be conducted by Gerard Schwarz, also includes the Schubert Fourth Symphony and the premiere of Harold Shapero's ''Three Hebrew Songs.'' The concert will be repeated at 3 P.M. Sunday. There will also be pre-concert discussions, in which Mr. Shapero will discuss his new work with Joseph Horowitz, scheduled to begin an hour before each performance. Tickets are $17 to $22.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Two Fail to Get Tokyo Routes
description: The Department of Transportation has rejected requests from United Airlines and American Airlines to establish nonstop flights from Chicago to Tokyo, officials said.

title: The Japanese Mystery
description: It is a tantalizing, important question. How do the Japanese manage to avoid the problem that bedevils every other large industrialized and democratic country - the drug epidemic?

title: Asset Investors Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSH SEES BENEFIT IN SHAMIR'S PLAN ON OCCUPIED LANDS
description: President Bush gave cautious support today for the proposal by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to break the Middle East deadlock by allowing Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to hold elections.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Our Towns; 2 Foster Brothers Reliving a Story As Old as Adam
description: In the early 1980's, the Coalition for the Homeless sued New York City and the state because so many children had to leave foster homes at age 18 with no place to go; 25 percent of young adults in city homeless shelters had come from foster homes. From this case came a new state program, Project Independence, to give teen-age foster children skills to make it on their own.

title: A 10-Year Battle Over a Parcel in Rye
description: Ten years ago, a developer named Diane G. Millstein bought a parcel of land overlooking Long Island Sound and ignited a dispute that has only grown more bitter with the years.

title: Grist Mill Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Mott's Super Markets reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $477,094 for the quarter and a loss of $525,161 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,706,542 for the quarter and $2,211,355 for the year, and tax credits of $878,395 and $2,429,893 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: Berenter: Little Agency That Could
description: TIMES are tough for many small, independent agencies, but Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster is like the little engine that could, insisting, ''I think I can.'' With little fanfare, it is succeeding.

title: From Latin America
description: The New York Festival of Song is presenting ''From Rio to Buenos Aires,'' a program of Latin American vocal works, at 5 P.M. Sunday at the Renee Weiler Concert Hall of the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street. The performers are Christopher Trakas, a baritone; Bernarda Finck, a mezzo-soprano, and Steven Blier, a pianist. Among the composers whose works are to be performed are Villa-Lobos, Braga, Nazareth and Ginastera. Tickets are $12. Information: 242-4770.

title: Oratorio Finals
description: The Oratorio Society of New York holds its annual solo competition finals tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. at Weill Recital Hall. Nine finalists will be competing for more than $6,000. Tickets: $5. Information: 758-5045.

title: Manning, Selvage & Lee Wins Four Silver Anvils
description: The Public Relations Society of America announced its Silver Anvil Awards on Wednesday for excellence in public relations. Manning, Selvage & Lee, a subsidiary of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, was the biggest winner, with three Anvils.

title: Administration Urges Plans To Deal With Offshore Spills
description: The Bush Administration today called for the creation of Federal contingency plans to deal with offshore spills and indicated support for legislation to expand the Federal cleanup fund by hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: The Going May Not Be as Easy for Houston
description: The two strong favorites for the Kentucky Derby are running in major prep races tomorrow, but they face quite different tasks. While Easy Goer should enjoy a cakewalk against four outclassed opponents in the $250,000 Gotham Mile at Aqueduct, Houston faces a much sterner challenge in the $500,000 Santa Anita Derby.

title: E.F. Wagner, 91: Led Seamen's Bank And Bible Society
description: Edmund F. Wagner, a longtime real-estate executive and former president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, died yesterday at Lohman Village in the Wartburg Home complex in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 91 years old and, until this year, had lived in Scarsdale, N.Y., for 40 years.

title: Nude Film Shot in School Is Rated F
description: Nicholas S. Rotonda's problems began when a company called Upfront Films Inc. was not up front with him about the kind of movie it wanted to shoot in Palisades Park High School, where he is principal.

title: Aircraft Landing System of Future Is Inaugurated
description: The Federal Aviation Administration inaugurated the landing system of the future today, here at a remote airport far from the congested urban airfields that are supposed to benefit greatly from the device.

title: Statewide Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Market Place; Hectic Trading In Commodities
description: FOR farm commodity traders, like baseball fans, this week is the beginning of a new season. The traders no longer have to base decisions on last year's crop statistics, since they can now use the first Government survey of farmers' planting intentions for 1989.

title: Bill Gunn, Playwright and Actor, Dies at 54 on Eve of Play Premiere
description: Bill Gunn, a playwright, screenwriter, novelist and actor, died Wednesday in Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital, one day before his play ''The Forbidden City'' opened at the Public Theater. He was 59 years old and lived in Tappan, N.Y.

title: Outlook for Airbus
description: Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European aircraft consortium, expects its sales to rise about 66 percent this year, to $4.5 billion, an Airbus spokesman said. Aircraft deliveries are also expected to rise to 107, from 61 in 1988, the spokesman added. The consortium, set up in 1970 by France, West Germany, Britain and Spain, announced the sale of its 1,000th aircraft at the end of February.

title: Review/Art; Lean, Muscular Energies In Late Nevelson Sculptures
description: Louise Nevelson in life had both an unforgettably flamboyant appearance and a direct, laconic, waste-free way with words. In talk, she never faked, fudged or prevaricated. After she died last year at the age of 88, we missed her looks. But we also missed her use of words. Who else will ever talk that way?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It will be a new concept in aviation. We look at organized labor as our partners.'' - Peter V. Ueberroth. [ A1:3. ]

title: Williams Art Museum Names New Director
description: The Williams College Museum of Art in Williamstown, Mass., announced yesterday that Linda Shearer, a curator in the department of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, will become its new director on July 1.

title: Report by N.H.L. Aimed at Expansion
description: The National Hockey League president, John Ziegler, said yesterday in Toronto that the N.H.L. intends to expand and that a report recommending possible sites and dates would be presented to the board of governors in December.

title: Isvestia Reports Poland's Changes In Detail and Straightforwardly
description: Soviet newspaper readers were presented today with a long and straightforward account of the Polish Government's sweeping political initiatives, including news of a crucial innovation notably absent here: the establishment of a formal opposition.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about plans to detour traffic in Manhattan during the demolition of the West Side Highway referred incorrectly to the resulting status of 12th Avenue. While the existing two southbound lanes will be closed, a southbound detour lane will be created. In addition, the two northbound lanes will remain open.

title: Harold Hayes, 62, Esquire Editor During Rise of New Journalism
description: Harold T. P. Hayes, a former editor of Esquire magazine who nurtured the novelistic and experimental new journalism of the 1960's, died of a brain tumor Wednesday at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 62 years old and lived in West Los Angeles.

title: Time-Warner Move Gains
description: The Justice Department said today that it would not oppose the proposed $18 billion merger of the giant media companies Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc.

title: Priakin Adjusts To New World
description: The morning skate was over for the five players who had been asked to attend. The team meeting in the dressing room of the Calgary Flames lasted more than 40 minutes, and then the players headed home to prepare for the second game of their Stanley Cup series tonight against Vancouver.

title: More Ice Keeps Breaking; After the Cold War: Subtlety, Not Stereotypes
description: Stunning is not too strong a word for world events in the last few days: The Polish Government and Solidarity union leaders agree to hold free and open elections. Vietnam promises unconditionally to withdraw its forces from Cambodia. Mikhail Gorbachev chooses Havana as the place to dissociate his country from the export of revolution, the traditional cornerstone of Soviet foreign policy. Now the Soviets even suggest that the K.G.B. and the C.I.A. cooperate, to fight terror. This is not the old cold war. To be sure, the Polish agreement on elections reflects pressures within Poland. To be sure, Vietnam felt the weight of its dead economy in deciding to end its 10-year invasion of Cambodia. But it is difficult to imagine either success story during 40 years of cold war.

title: Victim of AIDS Gains Waiver
description: A Dutch traveler suffering from AIDS should be released from prison and allowed to attend a conference on the disease in San Francisco, regional officials of the Federal immigration service recommended today.

title: No. 2 Official Quits Treasury
description: Deputy Treasury Secretary M. Peter McPherson resigned today to join the Bank of America, where he will be responsible for third world debt negotiations, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said.

title: Longterm Cowboy
description: Jerry Jones, the new majority owner of the Dallas Cowboys, said that he had given Jimmy Johnson, the former coach at the University of Miami who replaced Tom Landry as coach of the Cowboys, a 10-year contract. Jones would not reveal what Johnson, his former roommate at the University of Arkansas, would be paid, saying only, ''He's making more than he was making at Miami.''

title: Diverse Law Faculties Are Urged
description: Students at law schools around the country held classroom boycotts today to protest what they said was the schools' failure to hire more faculty members who are members of minority groups.

title: Silicon Valley Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results reflected a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February.

title: Dow Drops 12.83 as Jobs Report Is Awaited
description: LEAD: The stock market fell yesterday in modest trading, as investors turned cautious before the nation's employment report is released today.

title: Auctions
description: Newly Mined Jewels

title: Money Managers Top S.&P.
description: According to figures compiled by CDA Investment Technologies Inc., the nation's money managers outperformed the overall stock market in the first quarter.

title: Review/Film; From 1938, A Comedy by Pagnol With Fernandel
description: Marcel Pagnol, the French film maker, novelist and poet of the Midi, made ''Le Schpountz'' in 1938, shooting it simultaneously with his better-known ''Harvest,'' with many actors, including Fernandel and Orane Demazis (Mrs. Pagnol), doubling in both films. ''Le Schpountz'' is only now having its New York theater premiere, opening today at the Film Forum 2 as part of the theater's Pagnol retrospective.

title: A Homeless Shelter From the 1700's?
description: What are probably the remains of New York City's first homeless shelter and workhouse, built in the reign of King George II and lost to sight for almost 200 years, have been unearthed behind City Hall.

title: Another 38 Savings Units Taken Over
description: Federal regulators took over 38 more savings and loan associations in eight states today, bringing the total under Government control to 215 in 31 states.

title: Reviews/Theater; A Mother Only a Son Could Love
description: It takes almost three hours, but the infantile 16-year-old hero of ''The Forbidden City'' finally talks back to his oppressive mother. ''Ogress!'' he shouts. ''Bete noire!'' and even ''Fee, fo, fum!'' If there were any doubt that the mother was a dragon, it has long since been dispelled by the fire-breathing performance of Gloria Foster. Both she and the play, which opened last night at the Public Theater, go way overboard. The Wicked Witch of the West is in ''The Forbidden City,'' and her name is Molly Hoffenburg, as played by Ms. Foster.

title: Dining Out Guide: Desserts
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Aurora

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 465 money market mutual funds increased by $1.16 billion, to $301.20 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 140 institutional funds rose by $128.20 million, to $73.18 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were up by $573.30 million, to $98.62 billion. The 94 broker-dealer funds incresed by $462.40 million, to $129.39 billion, the institute said.

title: Stephen E. Rothbaum, Investment Banker, 47
description: Stephen E. Rothbaum, a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company, investment bankers, died of heart failure yesterday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Millburn, N.J.

title: Botha Ends Effort to Remain President
description: Bowing to pressure within the ruling National Party, P. W. Botha indicated today that he would resign as President after a general election to be held before the end of the year.

title: Two Full Days When Jazz Is King
description: ''YOU can always get us together for a benefit,'' the pianist Barry Harris said a few days ago. ''Us'' means jazz musicians, and this weekend two marathon benefit concerts will bring them out in force. A third all-day program is to include live performances and rare documentary film.

title: EX-AIDE TO WRIGHT TESTIFIES ON BOOK
description: A former aide to House Speaker Jim Wright has told the House Ethics Committee that Mr. Wright repeatedly urged his Congressional staff to find ways to sell more copies of a book he and his staff compiled, Democrats familiar with the testimony said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: M.I.T. Will Lease Cray-2 Computer
description: Cray Research Inc. and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have announced a five-year supercomputer research program under which the university will lease a Cray-2 supercomputer.

title: Rain Sends Fernandez To Bullpen
description: Yesterday was a rainy day for Sid Fernandez in more ways than one.

title: Shultz Calls For Limits On I.M.F.
description: Former Secretary of State George P. Shultz contends that the United States and its allies are ''going down the wrong road'' by trying to manage the poorer countries' debt problems.

title: A Bus Headed for New York Is Briefly Hijacked in Canada
description: An armed man who said he had dynamite gave up and released his hostages today after he hijacked a New York-bound Greyhound bus and kept the police at bay for five hours on Parliament Hill.

title: Would New York Dictate to Picasso?
description: LEAD: In the case of Wade v. Rock Against Racism, New York City has urged the United States Supreme Court to accept an absurd argument in favor of a noise control ordinance that treads on artistic freedom.

title: Red Tape, of Course, But Not Payoffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Open Attack on Wright Accuser
description: Nervous about the outcome of an investigation into the financial dealings of Speaker Jim Wright, House Democrats went on the attack today against his chief accuser, Representative Newt Gingrich, the Republican whip.

title: Battle Looms Between Legislators and Axelrod Over Hospitals
description: A legislative battle is looming between lawmakers, who are anxious about the stresses on New York State's hospital system, and the powerful Health Commissioner, who is responsible for setting many of the policies now being questioned.

title: Bush Silent on Contra Aid Role
description: President Bush adamantly refused to discuss his role in the Reagan Administration's secret efforts to assist the Nicaraguan rebels today, saying the ''legal process ought to run unfettered'' while Oliver L. North remains on trial.

title: A New Procedure For Breeding Tomatoes
description: The DNA Plant Technology Corporation of Cinnaminson, N.J., received a patent this week for a method of breeding better tomatoes in petri dishes.

title: James Meredith Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: America's Cup Ruling Serves Sportsmanship; Honor and Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Erratic Golfer, A Shoulder Harness
description: A retired professor in River Edge, N.J., frustrated by his inconsistent golf swing, won patent approval this week for a training device that helps people with plenty of time but little patience.

title: For Inspectors, Each Drop Is a Clue
description: Aubin Norris and Daniel Real rode through the streets of Brooklyn yesterday, seeking clues: a rivulet of water down a curb, a hose snaking across a sidewalk, a car suspiciously wet and parked near a fire hydrant.

title: A Shopper's Guide to Room Air-Conditioners
description: Last summer's relentless heat wave, which found air-conditioners scarce or nonexistent by July, is sending shoppers into the stores right now.

title: Its Boom Years Over, a School Regroups
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University, an upstart that rode the baby boom to a peak enrollment of 20,000 students, is now cutting programs, selling land, scrambling to fill classrooms and closing its well-known dental school.

title: U.S. Says Soviets Put Bugs in Its Consulate
description: The State Department today accused the Soviet Union of installing listening devices in the United States Consulate in Leningrad. A State Department spokesman said it was too early to tell if any highly classified information was obtained.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some editions yesterday about Bayard Schieffelin, a former executive officer of the New York Public Library, listed his survivors incompletely. They include his wife, the former Virginia Loomis of Short Hills, N.J.

title: National Lumber & Supply reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after income of $250,000 from an accounting change.

title: Buyout Talks Held on Unit Of Sara Lee
description: The Sara Lee Corporation, best known for its frozen cakes and pies, said today that it hoped to sell part of its food service business to a management group.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Airlines, Dallas, and Embassy Suites Inc. entered into a joint marketing agreement linking the airline with the all-suite hotel chain. Under the accord, American, a unit of AMR Corp., will offer accommodations for its Flyaway vacation packages at 53 Embassy Suites hotels in 16 states.

title: Poland's Changes Officially Adopted
description: With little debate or dissent, the Polish Parliament today approved six laws agreed to at the talks between the Government and Solidarity to restore the banned union's legal status and introduce broad changes in public life.

title: GORBACHEV PLANS TO STOP PRODUCING URANIUM FOR ARMS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, announced today that the Soviet Union had decided to halt production of enriched uranium and reduce production of enriched plutonium, both key elements of nuclear weapons.

title: Georgia Bank Refuses Talks
description: The Citizens and Southern Corporation continued yesterday to refuse to discuss with the NCNB Corporation the merger proposal made by NCNB last week.

title: Atlantis Casino's Bid to Renew Gambling License Is Rejected
description: The Casino Control Commission voted unanimously today not to renew the gambling license of the Atlantis Casino Hotel, the first such action in the 10 years of casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: Michigan Nears Choice
description: The Michigan athletic director, Bo Schembechler, said he might decide early next week whether the interim basketball coach, Steve Fisher, should become coach.

title: BRIDGE
description: It was celebrity day Thursday at the Marathon Battle of the Sexes, in which the men's team continued to lead the women's team by a moderate margin with one-third of the two-week match completed.

title: Even With New Immigration Laws, Aliens Confront Roadblocks to Work
description: When new Federal immigration laws were signed more than two years ago, Sam Makanju Adedapo thought his problems were over.

title: Dow Up in a Statistically Odd Week
description: LEAD: The stock market rebounded yesterday, led by a sudden turnaround in technology stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 12.83 points to close at 2,304.80.

title: Digital Communications Asociates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an unusual net charge of $12,579,000. c-Included an unusual net gain of $1,854,000, or 12 cents a share, from the sale of investments.

title: 13 Inmates Break Out Of Massachusetts Jail
description: Thirteen prisoners broke out of the Norfolk County House of Corrections sometime Friday evening, the state police said.

title: Italy Indicts 35 in Scandal
description: Magistrates investigating Italy's biggest postwar banking scandal indicted 35 people today but cleared the financier Carlo de Benedetti of any wrongdoing in the collapse of Banco Ambrosiano.

title: Commodity Exchange Chief To Resign at the End of June
description: Alan J. Brody, president and chief executive of the Commodity Exchange Inc., said yesterday that he intends to resign at the end of June.

title: Charter Revision: Why So Fast?
description: With the stroke of a pen, the United States Supreme Court has thrown the New York City Charter Revision Commission, as well as the rest of the political establishment, into spirited debate over the future shape of our government. The first days have been marked by enthusiasm and creativity. That's good. But the commission's decision to put proposals before the electorate on Nov. 7, Election Day, is disturbing. Voters need a longer period to learn about the issues.

title: Rodime Plc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Moon Says New Pact Is Richest in N.F.L.
description: Warren Moon, a quarterback, signed a five-year, $10 million contract yesterday with the Houston Oilers that he said would make him the highest-paid player in the National Football League.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Nacco Sets Purchase Of Hyster
description: LEAD: Nacco Industries, a Cleveland-based company whose businesses include coal mining and cookware manufacturing, agreed yesterday to buy the Hyster Company, the nation's largest forklift maker. Nacco is acquiring Hyster from the Esco Corporation for $620 million in cash and the assumption of unspecified debts.

title: Basque Mail Bomb Hurts 3
description: A parcel bomb mailed to a policeman exploded today, blowing off the arms of one person and also wounding two others, local officials and hospital officials said. The attack in the Basque town of Irun was the first in the region since Basque guerrillas last week called off a three-month truce in their 21-year campaign for a separate state.

title: Salvadoran Refugees Proud and Hopeful
description: To the Editor:

title: The Glove Came Up Empty
description: The Yankees began opening day at home at the Stadium against Cleveland yesterday - amid the cheery bunting, the faces of 11 new players in the dugout, and the lofty hopes of 55,655 fans who filled the park - just about the way they ended last season, in the neighborhood of fifth place in the American League East.

title: Review/Music; Danish Mezzo, In U.S. Debut, Sings Chausson
description: The Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra's performance in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening served principally to introduce a Danish mezzo-soprano named Marianne Rorholm, who, to judge from her rendering of songs by Chausson and Canteloube, is a singer of exceptional skill.

title: Family Dollar Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Zeva E. Spiegler, Educator, 54
description: Zeva E. Spiegler, director of college guidance and head of the science program at the Lenox School, a private school on East 70th Street, died of cancer Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 54 years old.

title: Triad Systems Data To Be Given Volt
description: The Triad Systems Corporation has offered to provide confidential financial data to Volt Information Sciences Inc., whose tender offer of $17 a share, or $132.6 million, was rejected by Triad. The computer systems concern, based in Livermore, Calif. turned down the Volt offer Thursday as inadequate and reaffirmed its intention to proceed with a recapitalization plan, under which Triad's shareholders would receive $14.50 in cash and a share in the recapitalized company.

title: U.S. Reaction to Soviet Move Is Divided
description: The Bush Administration today dismissed a Soviet cutback in the production of nuclear materials as an empty gesture. But some arms control advocates, including members of Congress, were encouraged by the announcement and said they intended to press for a negotiated cutoff in the production of bomb material.

title: Bedford Software Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Campaign Trail; Politicians Turn Up Finance-Law Loopholes
description: New York City's new campaign finance board is to spell out on Monday most of the final rules and regulations governing the upcoming municipal campaigns. They will be the first taxpayer-financed elections in the city's history. Already politicians are finding loopholes. For example, friends and allies of Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins, a mayoral candidate, have set up a voter registration drive that looks suspiciously like a Dinkins campaign front.

title: America's Cup Ruling Serves Sportsmanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Orders Troops to Help Clean Up Oil
description: Conceding that cleaning up the oil stain in Alaska will be ''massive, prolonged and frustrating,'' President Bush said today that he would send troops, military equipment and other Federal assistance to help the stricken area.

title: Iraq Reopening Oil Port
description: Iraq said this week that it would soon resume exporting oil from the southern port of Faw, which had been badly damaged in the Iran-Iraq war. The terminals outside Faw were built in the mid-1970's to receive deep-water tankers but were destroyed by Iran in the eight-year war that ended last August.

title: Hopeful Thesis: That Big-Power War Is Obsolete
description: Retreat From Doomsday The Obsolescence of Major War By John Mueller 327 pages. Basic Books. $20.95.

title: Dr. Aleksander W. Rudzinski, 89, A Polish Diplomat Who Defected
description: Aleksander W. Rudzinski, who in 1950 resigned as a high-ranking member of the Polish delegation at the United Nations to protest Soviet domination of his country, died Thursday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 89 years old.

title: Yorke Allen Jr., 73, Ex-Hartford Lawmaker
description: Yorke Allen Jr., a former representative in the Connecticut legislature and a former associate with the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, died Thursday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 and lived in New Canaan.

title: AIDS Award May Be Trimmed
description: The $7.25 million in punitive damages awarded to Rock Hudson's lover is excessive and will probably be cut to $3 million, Judge Bruce R. Geernaert of Superior Court, who presided in the case, said Friday. Judge Geernaert said he might also be inclined to cut the $14.5 million in compensatory damages awarded the plaintiff, Marc Christian, who sued the actor's estate because Mr. Hudson, who died three years ago, continued to have sex with him without revealing he had AIDS. Tests have shown Mr. Christian, 35 years old, to be free of the AIDS virus.

title: Principal in Inquiry Is Removed
description: A longtime principal of an elementary school on the Upper West Side has been removed from the school while he is being investigated on charges of illegally selling a prescription drug to teachers and parents, Board of Education officials said yesterday.

title: Paul Grossinger, 73, A Former Co-owner Of the Catskill Hotel
description: Paul Grossinger, former co-owner of Grossinger's, the sprawling Catskills resort known for its kosher cuisine and borscht-belt humor, died yesterday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. His death resulted from an automobile accident March 28 in Highland Falls, N.Y. Mr. Grossinger was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pembroke Squires, 69, 'a Father Of American Sportswear,' Is Dead
description: Pembroke Squires, one of a group of fashion designers in the 1950's and 1960's who made American sportswear memorable, died of kidney failure Wednesday at Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, L.I. He was 69 years old and had lived in nearby Quoque since his retirement in the mid-1970's.

title: Castle & Cooke Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: The latest quarter results included a pretax provision of $10 million for anticipated costs associated with the temporary ban on the sale of Chilean fruit by the Food and Drug Administration last month.

title: Harvey Jablonsky, 80, A Northrop Executive
description: Maj. Gen. Harvey Jablonsky of the Army, retired, a former vice president of the Northrop Corporation, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at the Nursing Center of the Army Residence in San Antonio. He was 80 years old and lived in San Antonio.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 10.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Orders the Military To Help Clean Up Spill

title: Asian Video Festival
description: Asian Cinevision Inc. will hold the seventh Asian-American International Video Festival today and tomorrow at the Millennium Film Workshop, 66 East Fourth Street. The nine thematic programs are to encompass documentaries, narratives, experimental works, animation and installation works. The program starts at 6 P.M., today and at 5:30 tomorrow. Programs cost from $5 to $10. Screening times and other information: 925-8685.

title: Soviets Recover Two Treasures
description: Raisa Gorbachev, the Soviet leader's wife, took two cultural objects back to Moscow today.

title: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
Easy Goer Ready for Slop
description: Easy Goer, the favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 6, will run in today's $280,500 Gotham Mile at Aqueduct despite the possibility of a sloppy track, his trainer said yesterday.

title: U.S. LEADS FRANCE, 2-0, IN DAVIS CUP
description: This indoor surface, now a worn and faded green, is one of John McEnroe's favorites. It was shipped here from Dallas for the occasion. And the Davis Cup match that McEnroe played on it tonight was vintage, too, inviting comparisons to the days when he was the best tennis player in the world. It pleased McEnroe that comparisons like these are being made more often.

title: On 'Bandstand,' Dick Clark Says Goodbye
description: ''Hey, hello there. Hey, welcome to 'American Bandstand.' '' Dick Clark won't say a lot more than that before disappearing from television's longest running variety program today at noon.

title: Review/Theater; 'Sweeney Todd' Revival On an Intimate Scale
description: In the 10 years since it first opened on Broadway, ''Sweeney Todd,'' Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler's Grand Guignol musical of revenge run amok, has only grown in stature.

title: Sale of 2 Seattle Stations
description: Adams Radio of Seattle Inc. has agreed in principle to sell two Seattle radio stations, one to Fisher Broadcasting Inc. and the other to Viacom Broadcasting Inc., a joint announcement said Thursday. Under the agreement, Adams would transfer its KZOK-FM station to Fisher and its KQUL-AM station to Viacom. No terms were disclosed.

title: The New Look to Bankers' Hours
description: In California, conventional ''bankers' hours'' have suddenly become a thing of the past.

title: Big Victory For E.P.A. In Court
description: A Federal appeals court in New Orleans has upheld broad Federal regulations aimed at eliminating hundreds of millions of pounds of toxic wastes at chemical plants each year. The decision, handed down last week, rejected company arguments that expensive plant modifications were not justified and that the cost could cripple the industry.

title: U.N. Actions in Namibia Under Fire
description: The countries espousing nonalignment have become bitterly critical of the way the United Nations is carrying out a plan for guiding Namibia to independence from South Africa next year.

title: Composer to Conduct
description: David Simons, a composer and percussionist, is to lead an ensemble in a program of his recent works at 9 o'clock tonight at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street. The program includes ''A Tear in the Fabric of Time'' and ''Canterel's Garden.'' Tickets are $6. Information: 293-8242.

title: New Rules On Reactors
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved sweeping changes in its procedure for the licensing of nuclear power plants. The commission's chairman said the changes could cut in half the time currently needed to build a plant.

title: Police Officer Shot at Manhattan Hospital
description: A New York City police officer was shot early this morning inside St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in upper Manhattan, the police said. Initial reports said the shooting occurred during a confrontation with a man who had taken a hostage inside St.Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in upper Manhattan.

title: 4 SIKHS CHARGED IN GANDHI'S DEATH
description: Investigators today charged four Sikhs, including a dismissed senior policeman, in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Mandela Pleads for Black Unity
description: In a rare appeal from his prison home, Nelson R. Mandela, the jailed leader of the African National Congress, has called for black unity in South Africa and an end to three years of fighting between factions of the Zulu tribe.

title: Samuel R. Shaw, 78, Marine Corps General
description: Brig. Gen. Samuel Robert Shaw of the Marines, retired, who was an adviser to President John F. Kennedy in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, died Tuesday at DeWitt Army Hospital in Fort Belvoir, Va., after suffering a heart attack.

title: Salvadoran Refugees Proud and Hopeful; Making a New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was raised to know the difference between right and wrong. I knew it wasn't right not to tell the truth about those things. But I didn't think it was unlawful.'' - Oliver L. North. [ 9:1. ]

title: Mob Chief and 7 Get Life
description: A judge today sentenced Nicodemo Scarfo, reputed head of organized crime in the Philadelphia area, and seven other men to life in prison instead of death for killing a fellow gangster. The judge, Eugene Clarke, took the sentencing decision away from the jury Thursday after ruling that prosecutors had failed to show enough aggravating circumstances for a death sentence.

title: Brooklyn Token-Booth Clerk Is Shot in Robbery Attempt
description: A token-booth clerk was shot twice during a robbery attempt in a Brooklyn subway station last night, the police said.
