The clerk, Robert Schemitsch, 27 years old, was struck in the neck and chest by bullets fired at about 10:30 P.M. by one of four men who ordered him to open the booth at East 105th Street and Farragut Road in the Canarsie section, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell. Mr. Schemitsch was admitted to Brookdale Hospital in serious but stable condition.

title: U.S. Inquiry Opens on Billions in Medicare Losses
description: Federal officials have begun investigating private insurance companies that they believe may have avoided tens of billions of dollars in medical bills by passing them on to Medicare, Government officials said today.

title: Margery A. Ryerson, Painter, Dead at 102
description: Margery A. Ryerson, a painter and lithographer, died March 30 at the King Street Nursing Home in Rye Brook, N.Y. She was 102 years old.

title: No Verdict on Agents
description: The Federal jury deciding the fate of the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom concluded its second day without reaching a verdict in Chicago yesterday and will resume deliberations Monday.

title: Man, 20, Is Charged In Slaying of Father
description: A 20-year-old Westport man has been charged with stabbing his father to death five days after his mother apparently committed suicide.

title: Coffee Talks At Impasse
description: The chances of reaching an international agreement to stabilize coffee prices looked bleak today after five days of talks failed to break a deadlock between the leading producers and consumers.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Credit-Card Interest
description: Interest rates on bank credit cards are rising as the Federal Reserve increases rates on its own loans to banks and they, in turn, raise their prime rate. That rate - one of the most commonly used benchmarks in setting consumer interest rates - has been increased twice since January, to 11.5 percent. Many formulas used in setting bank-card interest rates are affected. Consumers should study the contract to learn the basis on which a bank sets the interest rate for its card. In choosing a bank credit card, be wary of unusually low rates because the bank may make money by charging interest after a shorter grace period than the usual 30 days. $ Average Annual January January Percentage Rates 1989 1988 Fixed Rate (Established by bank) 17.78 17.84 Variable Rate (Tied to prime) 16.92 15.63 Variable Rate (Tied to 6-mo. Treasury bill) 15.73 15.28 Source: Bank Credit Card Observer, Kendall Park, N.J.

title: Industrial Acoustics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jane V. Williams, Health Educator, 64
description: Dr. Jane V. Williams, a former director of education for the New York City Department of Health, died Sunday at Brooklyn Hospital after a long illness. She was 64 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Review/Film; Grunts, Roars and Screams
description: Few words are spoken in the post-apocalyptic world of ''Cyborg,'' a movie that suggests a distant, impoverished cousin of ''The Road Warrior.'' Most communication consists of grunts, roars and screams emitted by gladiatorial combatants practicing martial arts in a grimy cityscape of smoke pots, rusted automobiles and fishnet-draped buildings.

title: Rose Friend Released
description: Thomas P. Gioiosa, a former housemate of the Cincinnati Reds manager, Pete Rose, indicted on charges of tax evasion and conspiracy to distribute cocaine, was released yesterday in Boston on $20,000 bond.

title: Lincoln Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect 20 percent stock dividend declared March 21. Latest quarter results reflect the expanding economy of its Southern California market.

title: At Times Square, a Music Festival Underground
description: To get to the show, you slip past the peep shows, the popeyed crack addicts strutting with their artificial self-assurance, the people hawking gold chains. You head down the stairs, pay the dollar admission, and there in the Times Square IRT-BMT subway station, beyond the stalls selling Islamic, vegetarian and Krishna literature, is an international world of music.

title: Major Realty Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and resulted primarily from $12.7 million in profit realized from condemnation by the city of Tampa of a waterfront parcel the company previously had contributed to a joint venture between Major Realty and Prudential Insurance Co. of America.

title: Arabs Battle Police at Mosque in Jerusalem
description: A melee erupted outside al-Aqsa mosque in the Old City today as hundreds of Palestinians leaving noon prayers at the start of the Muslim holiday of Ramadan pelted police officers and passers-by with rocks after the police fired tear gas at the protesters.

title: Knicks' Woes Highlighted in Loss to Nets
description: After winning in Milwaukee on Thursday, the Knicks thought the slide was over. They were wrong.

title: Opposition Gains as Managua Moves to Amend Voting Laws
description: Acting under the terms of a recent regional peace accord, the Nicaraguan Government today formally proposed a set of 29 amendments to electoral and information laws to prepare the way for national elections next year.

title: Review/Music; Men and Boys Of Salisbury Cathedral Sing
description: Salisbury Cathedral in southern England was consecrated in 1258, and for its first few centuries its musical practices defined not only English liturgical services, but also those of many churches on the Continent. Since the Reformation, the cathedral's music has not been quite so central. But the cathedral has still prospered as a regional center, and proof of the current good health of its musical program is being provided by the Salisbury Cathedral Choir's first tour of the United States, which brought it to St. Bartholomew's Church on Tuesday night.

title: I.O.C. Suspends 7 Labs
description: Seven laboratories that have conducted drug tests for international sports events, including one in Indianapolis used in the 1987 Pan American Games, have been suspended by the International Olympic Committee's Medical Commission because of administrative or analytical mistakes, the commission announced yesterday in London.

title: Rangers Need a Spark To Keep the Heat Off
description: The Rangers' expressionless stares have masked nothing. The circumspect answers haven't been so much calculated as simply all they can muster. The emotionless play has been no mystery. For the Rangers, there has been no there there.

title: A Soviet Nuclear Sub Catches Fire And Reportedly Sinks Off Norway
description: A nuclear-powered Soviet submarine, reportedly armed with cruise missiles, caught fire while submerged today, then surfaced and later disappeared in the Norwegian Sea, American and Norwegian officials said.

title: Whites Pass Test At a Higher Rate
description: New York City officials said yesterday that non-Hispanic whites had passed last summer's Civil Service examinations for promotion to police sergeant at twice the rate of minority candidates, despite city efforts to minimize bias in the test and make it as job-related as possible.

title: ALIEN WITH AIDS IS ORDERED FREED
description: A Federal judge, overriding action taken by immigration officials hours earlier, ordered today that a Dutch visitor suffering from AIDS be released from custody so that he could attend a conference on the disease.

title: Johnstown reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said it added $5,134,000 to its provision for loan losses during the year. It said the increased provisions came after an analysis of its portfolio in conjunction with its regularly scheduled review by the federal regulators.

title: China Ousts Prominent Dissident
description: A prominent young Chinese dissident who had been detained in Shanghai for 36 hours was escorted to the airport today and put on a flight to Hong Kong.

title: California Urged to Take Lead In Genetic Tracking of Crime
description: The State Attorney General today put forth a plan that would make California the first state to establish a computerized genetic data base of everyone convicted of a violent crime. The data base, created through blood and saliva samples, would be used to help solve future crimes.

title: Employment Report Confuses Bond Market
description: The Treasury debt market was buffeted yesterday after the Government reported that the unemployment rate for last month had unexpectedly fallen to a 15-year low and that the number of new nonfarm jobs had risen less than anticipated.

title: Janiyeh Journal; Who Owns the Land, Arab or Settler?
description: Mariam Abdelmihsem walked to the edge of this tiny Arab village one recent morning, a gusting wind whipping her white headscarf, and pointed across a narrow valley to a cluster of trailers sitting on freshly bulldozed earth.

title: Hedda Nussbaum Story To Be CBS Mini-Series
description: Hedda Nussbaum has sold exclusive rights to her life story to CBS for an unspecified amount, a network spokesman said. The network plans to produce a mini-series based on materials provided by Ms. Nussbaum, including extensive diaries.

title: Anti-Iran Film Dropped By Los Angeles Festival
description: ''Veiled Threat,'' a low-budget American film critical of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, has lost its theatrical distribution in three countries and has been withdrawn from the forthcoming Los Angeles International Film Festival sponsored by the American Film Institute, the film's production executives have said.

title: Data Are Sought On Elf-Pennwalt
description: Federal antitrust regulators have requested additional information from both sides in the $1.1 billion merger between Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the French Government-owned oil and chemical giant, and the Pennwalt Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Elf Aquitaine said that the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department requested ''additional information and documentary material'' on Thursday.

title: Fishermen, Officials and Exxon Defend Hatcheries From Oil
description: Two weeks after the largest oil tanker spill in American history, the only clear success in the cleanup effort has come in defending four commercial salmon hatcheries against the oil - and that was an improvised effort carried out primarily by fishermen.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday in the Long Island Weekly gave an incorrect date for ''Dancescapes,'' a joint performance by the Circle of Dance Repertory Company and Plainedge High School students. It is tonight at 8 at the high school in North Massapequa; it was not last night.

title: Let Them Play Guitars
description: The literary world is stunned by recent evidence that Henry James used anabolic steroids. Not since the disclosure of Shoeless Joe Jackson's role in ''fixing'' the 1919 World Series has there been such an emotional blow to American youth.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday reported on a rape case in Stony Brook, L.I., that has set off a bitter debate about race relations at the State University of New York. The victim, who is white, has identified a black student as her attacker; the suspect says he can prove he was nowhere near the campus on that night, March 24, and several people have backed up his account. The article said the suspect, Quincy Brandon Troupe, ''gave no alibi at the time'' he was identified in a lineup and arrested but only later, after hiring a lawyer.

title: Trevino and Faldo Share 2-Stroke Lead in Masters
description: It seemed like spring training for the British Open today at Augusta National Golf Club as an early morning rain was followed by chilly winds of 25 miles an hour with gusts to 30, hampering players' chances in the second round of the 53d Masters.

title: Percussive Dance
description: Ten Toe Percussion will present the second annual N.Y.C. Festival of Percussive Dance tonight at 8 o'clock at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. The program features large ensemble works as well as solos; the American Tap Dance Orchestra will perform a new suite. Tickets are $20 and $15. Information: 864-5400.

title: A Test to Diagnose Certain Cancers
description: Immunomedics Inc., a biotechnology company in Warren, N.J., was awarded a patent this week for a test to diagnose cancer of the lung, breast, and gastrointestinal tract.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Subway Repair, Repaired
description: Five years ago, as Robert Kiley and David Gunn took over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its New York City subsidiary, the Transit Authority, a subway optimist was any rider who assumed his train would reach the next station under its own power. A recent visit to the T.A.'s 207th Street maintenance and major repair shop in Manhattan suggests that things have changed, and in a big way.

title: NWA Rejects Offer by Davis
description: NWA Inc., parent company of Northwest Airlines, today rejected a $2.62 billion takeover offer by the billionaire oilman Marvin Davis, saying it was too low.

title: Stride-Rite reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: b-Included a loss of $762,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1,723,000 from an accounting change.

title: Excerpts From President's News Session on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Eagle Telephonics reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Profit Regained By Chip Maker
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. returned to profitability in its first quarter ended March 26, after a loss in the fourth quarter of 1988, but the chip maker's results dipped relative to the first quarter of last year.

title: The Sale of Eastern Airlines: Baseball Connection Pays Off
description: Last month, when the owners of major league baseball teams met at the Bonaventure Hotel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Carl R. Pohlad, owner of the Minnesota Twins, and Peter V. Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, slipped away for a private chat.

title: Asad Mansur al-Faqih; Saudi Envoy Was 79
description: Sheik Asad Mansur al-Faqih, the first Saudi Arabian Ambassador to the United States, died of prostate cancer April 2 at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 79 years old.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Property Taxes
description: Gloria and Leonard Pogensky of Westbury, L.I., are pleased that the value of the seven-room, Colonial-style home they bought in the 1950's has appreciated over time. But when the couple's calculations showed that their $10,090 property tax assessment meant that Nassau County tax officials put the value of their home at $313,350, the couple rebelled.

title: Premieres on Flute
description: Robert Stallman, a flutist, is to give the world premiere of Karel Husa's ''Evocations de Slovaquie'' and the New York premiere of Takehito Gokita's ''Yuki No Machi'' at 8 o'clock tonight at Alice Tully Hall. The program will also offer works by Haydn, Widor, Schubert and Bartok. Mr. Stallman's accompanists are to be Erika Nickrenz, a pianist, and members of the Muir Quartet. Tickets are $14. Information: 362-1911.

title: Review/Music; Computer-Inspired Works
description: The problem with electronic music used to be the difficulty of acclimating an audience to a ''concert'' that consisted of music emanating impassively from loudspeakers. That problem was sidestepped either by mixing electronics with live performers or, more interestingly, by ''live electronics,'' wherein onstage performer-technician-composers manipulate electronic processes in ''real time.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APIRL 8, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Big Crowd and Mattingly Can't Help Yanks
description: They had a home crowd and they had Don Mattingly back again, but the Yankees still seemed to be searching yesterday. Four games into the season, they are waiting for and wanting a game that will give them momentum.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Betty Pinkston Campbell, Olympic Diver, 86
description: Betty Becker Pinkston Campbell, winner of two gold medals in springboard and platform diving at the Olympic Games in 1924 and 1928, died of congestive heart failure Thursday in a Detroit hospital. She was 86 years old.

title: Review/Music; A Happy Creation, With a Genteel Adam and Eve
description: The world was created, according to Haydn, in a week of sweet, songful days that culminated in the meeting and genteel courtship of Adam and Eve, chaperoned by the Archangel Uriel and a chorus of hundreds. That, at any rate, was the refined view of ''The Creation'' as presented on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall by the New York Philharmonic under Robert Shaw's direction.

title: Federation Rule Change Opens Olympics to N.B.A. Players
description: The governing body for international basketball voted overwhelmingly today to allow professionals to compete in the Olympics. The United States, which will benefit most from the move, voted against the proposal.

title: VALENZUELA LOSES HIS FIRST START SINCE INJURY, 6-1
description: Fernando Valenzuela, trying to come back from a shoulder injury last year, lost his first start of the season tonight as Jody Davis drove in three runs to lead the Alanta Braves to a 6-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Federal Strategy Is Planned in Drive on Capital Drugs
description: The Bush Administration's plans to combat the drug-related crime plaguing this city include Federal construction of a multimillion-dollar prison and the use of National Guard troops for clerical jobs to free up police officers, Administration officials said today.

title: Valley Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
North Tells Court He Lied To Congressmen on Contras
description: Oliver L. North testified today that he lied about his actions in Central America at a White House meeting with members of Congress in 1986. But he professed that he felt ''like a pawn in a chess game being played by giants.''

title: Paragon Petroleum Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 60's Fugitive Returns to Start Conspiracy Sentence
description: Herman B. Ferguson, standing yesterday in the same Queens courthouse in which he was convicted 21 years ago of conspiring to kill two moderate civil-rights leaders, was ordered to begin serving the sentence he had long evaded.

title: Highland Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain of $5,685,000 from an accounting change.

title: U.S. Office in Chile Attacked
description: A powerful bomb caused extensive damage to the offices of the United States-Chilean Cultural Institute Thursday night and a caller said the blast was in retaliation for a United States embargo on Chilean fruit.

title: No Good News for Smokers
description: Not everyone who puts on running shoes plans to enter the New York Marathon; and rare is the calorie-conscious person who doesn't occasionally fall off the wagon and into a bag of french fries. Nonetheless, it's a fact that Americans are taking better care of themselves, and the Federal Centers for Disease Control can prove it. There are new figures, however, proving that one bad habit has very long-term consequences.

title: U.S. Jobless Rate Declines To 4.9%, Lowest Since '73
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point in March, to 4.9 percent, with employers drawing heavily on black, teen-age and Hispanic residents for new workers, the Labor Department announced today.

title: Mortgage Rate Changes
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 11.07 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The rate was down from 11.19 percent a week earlier. But on one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 9.39 percent this week, up from 9.31 percent the week before, Freddie Mac said.

title: Man Offering Brawley Tapes Is Acquitted
description: The man who said that one of Tawana Brawley's three principal advisers had hired him to eavesdrop on the other two was acquitted yesterday of perjury and obstruction-of-justice charges.

title: Experts Call Warning of Radon Test Failures a False Alarm
description: Earlier this year, with Americans bewildered about Government warnings over carcinogenic radon gas in their homes, a consumer advocacy group alarmed many by declaring that widely sold testing kits were inaccurate and, thus, dangerous.

title: Claim Rejected On Indian Relic
description: The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that it would not give an Indian relic that is more than 150 years old to a Cree Indian who said he had been driven by a vision to retrieve the object for his people. A museum spokesman said a letter was sent on Thursday to the Cree, Jim Thunder, in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada, notifying him of the decision. Mr. Thunder, 38 years old, asked in March for the relic, a sacred bundle wrapped in calico and comprising bear claws, sweet grass and a plug of tobacco. (AP)

title: New Image Is Surfacing For Ford's Presidency
description: To some it may have seemed a bit like an actor whispering advice to the drama critics as they batted out reviews of his performance.

title: In Makeup, Custom Blending Is Back
description: Cosmetics companies, competing for the highly prized loyalties of affluent customers, are reviving an approach to makeup not seen in decades: custom blending.

title: Don't Keep Your Will In the Lawyer's Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Agnew Rebuffed on Refund in Bribe Case
description: Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew may not take a California income tax deduction for repaying Maryland for purported bribes dating back a quarter-century, a state tax appeals board ruled Thursday.

title: G.R.I.  Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a loss of $6,556,000 from an accounting change.

title: About New York; Question Raised By a Dead Son Haunts Parents
description: This is a story about Jeffrey Modell, a sparkling child stricken early in life by a mysterious illness. Jeff was like other children in his love of sports, learning and companionship. He was unlike them in wishing he had leukemia. ''At least it has a name,'' he explained, ''and they know how to treat it.''

title:
Your Money;
Betting on Future Of Interest Rates
description: LEAD: The direction of interest rates plays a large role in investment strategies, and as evidence mounts that the economy is slowing, many people may be re-examining their options. For more than a year, the Federal Reserve has been nudging rates up, hoping to dampen demand and restrain inflation. But a growing number of economists and analysts now speculate that rates have peaked and may decline soon.

title: New Payment to Takeshita Is Reported in Japan Press
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's beleaguered Government was dealt another blow today by new reports that Mr. Takeshita received secret payments from the company at the center of a widening influence-peddling scandal.

title: Bruce Lawrence Bushey, Foundation Officer, 43
description: Bruce Lawrence Bushey, a program officer with the Ford Foundation, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 43 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Ms. Unger Wed in Bermuda
description: Katherine Maffitt Unger, the daughter of Edward Pierce Maffitt of Washington and Mrs. Ralph I. Straus of New York, was married yesterday to Richard D. O'Connor, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James O'Connor of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Fred C. Marshall, a Presbyterian minister, at Christ Church in Warwick, Bermuda.

title: Triton Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Loyalist Haitian Troops Attack Mutinous Soldiers
description: Troops loyal to the President, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, launched a ferocious assault with armored vehicles and automatic weapons tonight in an attempt to put down an army rebellion that has paralyzed the Haitian capital for nearly a week.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf and Navratilova Advance: Steffi Graf defeated Radka Zrubakova, a newcomer from Czechoslovakia, by 6-2, 6-1 in just 35 minutes to advance to the semifinals of the Family Circle Cup in Hilton Head, S.C. Second-seeded Martina Navratilova also adjusted and beat her doubles partner, eighth-seeded Hana Mandlikova of Australia, 6-2, 7-5. In the semifinals today, Navratilova will meet Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, who beat her countrywoman Leila Meshki, 6-3, 6-2, and Graf will face Arantxa Sanchez of Spain, who defeated Linda Ferrando of Italy, 7-5, 6-1. INDOOR LACROSSE Wings 11, Saints 10: The Philadelphia Wings held off a late rally by the New York Saints to squeeze out an 11-10 victory in the championship game of the Major Indoor Lacrosse League last night, in front of a crowd of 16,042 at the Spectrum in Philadelphia. New York's John Driscoll had a chance to send the game into overtime, but his breakaway shot with one second remaining was stopped by the Wings' goalie, Kevin Bilger, who had 42 saves. N.B.A. Hawks 120, Rockets 112: Dominique Wilkins hit a 3-point shot to send the game into overtime and then made another one to ignite Atlanta in the extra period as the Hawks won last night at home. Wilkins led the Hawks with 29 points.(AP) 76ers 118, Hornets 108: Charles Barkley scored 31 points, including a backcourt steal and layup with 1 minute 24 seconds left that turned back a Charlotte rally and sealed Philadelphia's road victory.(AP) Bullets 107, Cavaliers 96: Bernard King scored 10 points in the first six minutes of the fourth quarter and Jeff Malone had 17 in the final six, sparking Washington to its 15th consecutive home victory.(AP)

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 9.

title: Judge Pushing to Get Eastern in the Air Again
description: As Eastern Airlines' unions and representatives of Peter V. Ueberroth met yesterday in Washington, a Federal judge in Manhattan ordered the unions and the strike-bound airline to redouble their efforts to get more planes in the air. Mr. Ueberroth, whose investor group agreed on Thursday to buy Eastern, was negotiating with the unions over concessions he says he needs to complete the deal.

title: Oneok Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Investors Fight Regulatory seizures Of Some Sick but solvent Institutions
description: Federal banking and savings regulators are increasingly finding themselves in a bind. To reduce the drain on the Federal insurance funds, they are moving more aggressively to seize ailing banks and savings institutions before all of their units become insolvent.

title: Iacocca Earned Less Last Year
description: Lee A. Iacocca earned $3,663,577 as chairman of the Chrysler Corporation in 1988, taking home a sum that seemed relatively modest compared with the $17.9 million he collected a year earlier.

title: Bush Meets With Salvadoran Victor
description: President Bush said today that President-elect Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador should be given the opportunity ''to prove his dedication to democracy, peace and human rights.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Ravenmaster at the Tower of London misstated the year of Queen Elizabeth's coronation. It was 1953; she succeeded to the throne in 1952.

title: Father Healy As Public Man
description: The Rev. Timothy Healy, president of Georgetown University, is a solid choice to head the New York Public Library, admired in the world of scholarship and in his native New York. A few disapproving voices are heard, however, some arguing that no Roman Catholic priest, even though accomplished, should guard this intellectual empire. And some members of the gay community charge that he was unduly hostile to gay student groups at Georgetown.

title: Judge Orders Nabisco Halt
description: A state judge today issued a temporary restraining order blocking the record $24.88 billion acquisition of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, but RJR Nabisco said the order should not affect the deal.

title: Relief for Foreign Debtors. But When?
description: The industrial world's major lenders adopted a hopeful new approach to the third world's crushing debt this week, agreeing at last that the debtors must have relief. The trick will be to provide enough, and soon. There is a heavy burden on debtors and creditors alike to get moving.

title: Cable TV Should Be Taxed as a Consumer Item
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Physician Is Wed To Laura Jereski
description: Laura Jereski, a daughter of Evelyn Konrad of New York and Southampton, L.I., and Bernard Jereski of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Laurent Schwartz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jean Schwartz of Strasbourg, France. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in New York.

title: Six Who Told Johnson To Get Out of Vietnam
description: LEAD: It is accepted history that President Lyndon Johnson was not advised that escalating the Vietnam war in July 1965 would be disastrous. History also holds the President did not want to hear such advice and was determined to fight in Vietnam, even before sending hundreds of thousands of troops.

title: Review/Dance; Echoes of Joffrey From Princeton Ballet
description: The Princeton Ballet is a company of 14 well-trained dancers with elegantly pulled-up bodies but not, on the evidence of a single viewing, a great deal of individual presence. That lack is a common enough phenomenon these days, however, and the program the company presented tonight at McCarter Theater was imaginatively varied and well chosen.

title: Secretary of Health Ordering a Revision On U.S. Sex Survey
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services, responding to criticism from the White House budget director, ordered public health officials today to revise a survey that would look into the sexual lives of thousands of Americans.

title: Expos Club Mets
description: The season is barely into its first weekend and the Expos are hailing tonight's 7-3 victory over the Mets as a symbol of rebirth.

title: GATT Farm Accord To Freeze Subsidies
description: Ending a stalemate in international trade talks, negotiators at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreed in principle today to curb Government farm subsidies and agricultural import barriers.

title: Friends Back Up Alibi Of Man Accused in Rape
description: Where was Quincy Brandon Troupe on the night of March 24?

title: NOW Leader Sees Big Turnout at Abortion Rights March
description: The president of the National Organization for Women predicted today that the abortion rights march here Sunday would attract over 250,000 participants and mark the start of a lobbying campaign to rejuvenate a women's rights movement that has at times seemed complacent.

title: New York and New Jersey Jobless Rates Drop
description: The unemployment rates in New York and New Jersey dropped significantly last month, in large part because fewer people were looking for jobs, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING LOANS AND CREDITS TO REWARD POLAND
description: New credits from American and international lending organizations are among the economic rewards being considered by Washington in response to Poland's latest moves toward greater democracy, Administration officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6 Moscow will stop making enriched uranium and reduce production of enriched plutonium, both vital components of nuclear weapons, Mikhail Gorbachev announced. Page 1 United States reaction to Soviet move is divided 6 Disturbances in Soviet Georgia brought troops to the streets of Tbilisi, the capital, in the wake of nationalist strikes and demonstrations, the Georgian press agency said. 1 A Soviet submarine caught fire while submerged in the Norwegian Sea, American and Norwegian officials said. The nuclear-powered vessel surfaced and then disappeared, and U.S. officials suspect that it sunk. 1 U.S. economic rewards for Poland, like Export Import Bank credits, are being considered by the White House in response to moves toward greater democracy, officials said. 1 Polish changes formally adopted 4 Japanese news organizations reported additional payments that Prime Minister Takeshita took from the company at the center of a widening influence-peddling scandal. 3 A prominent young Chinese dissident who had been detained in Shanghai for 36 hours was put on a flight to Hong Kong, suggesting the Government's uneasiness over a handful of democracy advocates. 2 Four Sikhs charged in Gandhi assassination 3 Troops loyal to Haiti's President launched an attack with armored vehicles and automatic weapons in an attempt to put down an army rebellion that has paralyzed the Haitian capital for nearly a week. 6 The Salvadoran President-elect should be given the opportunity ''to prove his dedication to democracy, peace and human rights,'' President Bush said. 6 Nicaragua moves to open elections to the opposition 6 Criticism of how the United Nations is carrying out a plan for guiding Namibia to independence from South Africa next year has been building among nations espousing nonalignment. 3 Mandela pleads for black unity 3 National 7-9, 28, 50 The glue in the latest Eastern deal, between Peter Ueberroth and Frank Lorenzo, is Carl Pohlad, the owner of the Minnesota Twins. He convinced Mr. Lorenzo that he had no choice but to sell the airline. 1 Judge tells Eastern and unions to get more planes flying 35 A data base of criminals' genetic patterns would be established in California for the first time under a plan to help solve future crimes by using DNA for genetic ''fingerprinting.'' 1 Charges that insurers have evaded tens of billions of dollars in costs by passing them on to Medicare are being investigated by Federal officials, Government officials said. 1 To aid cleanup efforts in Alaska, President Bush said he will send troops, military equipment and other Federal assistance to the area. He said the work will be ''massive, prolonged and frustrating.'' 8 Little success in the cleanup off Valdez, Alaska, has been achieved in the two weeks since the spill. Officials cite problems with logistics, communications and organization. 8 The March unemployment rate fell to 4.9 percent, despite an economic slowdown, as employers drew heavily on black, teen-age and Hispanic residents for new workers. 50 New York and Jersey jobless rates drop significantly 50 Oliver North testified that he lied about his actions in Central America at a White House meeting with Congressmen in 1986 but professed that he felt ''like a pawn in a chess game being played by giants.'' 9 Bush silent on contra aid role 9 Michael Milken pleaded not guilty to criminal charges that he earned more than $1 billion through fraud and deception. Supporters greeted him on the steps the United States Courthouse in Manhattan. 33 House Democrats began an offensive against their beleaguered Speaker's chief accuser, Representative Newt Gingrich, in connection with Mr. Gingrich's book deal. 28 Anti-drug plans for Washington include the Federal construction of a multimillion-dollar prison and the use of National Guard troops for clerical jobs, Federal officials said. 7 Gerald Ford stood up for himself before a Long Island conference of 250 scholars dissecting his Presidency, which he likened to hearing to ''the eulogies at your own funeral.'' 7 Targets set for abortion rights march 7 Regional 29-32 The New York State hospital crisis is raising the prospect of a battle between lawmakers anxious about stresses on the health system, and the Health Commissioner, responsible for many of the policies. 29 Loopholes in campaign-finance rules for New York City's first taxpayer-financed campaign are being discovered by politicians. 29 A man who said he recorded talks between two Tawana Brawley advisers was acquitted of perjury and obstruction of justice charges. 29 60's fugitive returns to Queens to face conspiracy sentence 31 On the lookout for water-wasters, 32 inspectors patrolled New York City's boroughs, studying meters, examining wells, checking plumbing, and peering at toilets and sinks. 31 Aliens find roadblocks to work, despite new immigration laws 31 West Side principal removed in drug inquiry 31 Friends of Quincy Brandon Troupe, an engineering student at SUNY at Stony Brook accused of raping another student, have said he was in Harlem at the time of the attack. 30 Fairleigh Dickinson University, a 47-year-old New Jersey school that thrived during the baby-boom years, is cutting back programs, selling land and closing its dental school. 29 New Jersey refuses to renew casino's gambling license 30

title: Not Guilty Plea Given By Milken
description: Michael R. Milken, one of the most powerful and wealthy financiers in Wall Street history, pleaded not guilty yesterday to criminal charges that he earned more than $1 billion through fraud and deception and violated Federal racketeering law.

title: Edwards (A.G.) Inc.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Goldome Realty
description: Goldome, one of the nation's largest savings institutions, said its Goldome Realty Credit Corporation's mortgage banking unit would phase out operations at 21 offices in 11 states in the next three months. The company said it would concentrate on its residential mortgage origination activities in its primary markets of New York and Florida. ''Competition across the nation has grown tremendously,.'' Goldome said, adding that will continue to service its existing portfolio of $11.7 billion of mortgages.

title: Michael Stearns Weds Ms. Peters
description: Roschel Holland Peters, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Ralph Holland of Pittsburgh, and Michael Hartt Stearns, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Mather Stearns of New York, were married yesterday by the Rev. Frederick Hill at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Devon Gaffney, Research Director, Engaged to Marry Jay Cross in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Gaffney of Pittsburgh have made known the engagement of their daughter Ann Devon Gaffney to Loren Jeffrey Cross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon F. Cross of Toronto. A June wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PATH OF NO RESISTANCE: The Story of the Revolution in Superconductivity. By Bruce Schechter. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The men and women who push back the frontiers of knowledge in the physical sciences sometimes seem to be viewed by society as quiet, cloistered ''techies'' and ''labbies.'' In ''The Path of No Resistance,'' Bruce Schechter opens up their world, revealing the passions, humor, jealousies and brilliance of the people who have taken a once quiet back lane of science and transformed it into an international raceway of competitive technology. Mr. Schechter, a freelance science writer, traces the development of superconductivity (the virtual absence of electrical resistance) from its birth in the Leiden laboratories of Heike Kamerlingh Onnes in 1911 through to the months of frantic research that resulted in a new class of high-temperature superconducting materials and the award of the 1987 Nobel Prize for physics. Competition for the discoveries to be made in high-temperature superconducting materials was furious and worldwide in 1986 and 1987 in laboratories across the United States, Europe and Japan. All were seeking development of materials that would make possible superconductivity in materials at temperatures far above the neighborhood of absolute zero (nearly 460 degrees below zero Fahrenheit). The prize was more than a Nobel Prize, for high-temperature superconductors may transform technologies as disparate as transportation, energy storage and computers. Mr. Schechter is gifted in providing an account of this research that contrasts the supposedly open world of shared research results with the manipulations of the real world of fast-paced international teams. Today's scientists have also learned that sharing too much knowledge may mean losing credit for discoveries. Mr. Schechter turns theoretical material into enjoyable, understandable prose for lay readers, making it clear that while research into superconductivity requires low temperatures, it is populated with with warm-blooded, fascinating people.

title: 1960's 'Hair' in Bridgeport Revival
description: IN the late 1960's, there was a musical about innocence, peace, love and harmony - and protest. With a bountiful rock score, a minimalist book and free-flowing staging, it signaled a radical new form for the Broadway musical. It also had a profusion of taboo words, scenes depicting drug use and lovemaking, and one scene displaying frontal nudity.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Menu; Counterculture Potato Dish (But Hold the Cholesterol)
description: Years ago in a counterculture restaurant on the Pacific Coast Highway near Santa Barbara, Calif., one of the most popular dishes was a baked potato awash in butter, smothered with vegetables, seasoned with miso and topped with cheese. Counterculture, of course, was synonymous with vegetarian. There was a long wait, but when the potato arrived the perfectly cooked vegetables atop the fluffy, creamy-white interior were worth it.

title: Where a Complete Education Includes How to Serve Others
description: ON top of a grassy hill in the town of Fairfield sits Bellarmine Hall, an old, stone Tudor house that serves as Fairfield University's administration building. Inside the building, letters of acceptance or rejection are being mailed out to high school students this month. Each year the number of applicants has grown, practically doubling from a decade ago.

title: Mapping The Terrain of Jerseysomething
description: On an early Spring day that threatens snow or sunshine or both, the television trucks descend on a vest-pocket basketball court tucked at the corner of Gregory and High Point Avenues in a working-class neighborhood in Weehawken, N. J. It is a typical spot for pick-up games - except for the million-dollar view through some naked tree branches, across the Hudson to the Manhattan skyline stretching from the Cloisters past the Chrysler and Empire State buildings around to the twin towers of the World Trade Center. A Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sky hook, that view from the concrete basketball court: It takes one's breath away.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling in one of our rooms is finished with sand paint. Some months ago, we repainted, and since then the seams have cracked and pieces have fallen off. We tried to fill in the cracks and repaint, but the ceiling has cracked again. How can I make small repairs to a sand-painted ceiling?

title: ORDINARY FOLKS, REPULSIVE AND OTHERWISE
description: WE ARE STILL MARRIED Stories & Letters. By Garrison Keillor. 330 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: AURAL COURTSHIP AND OTHER SENSATIONS
description: THE FIVE SENSES By F. Gonzalez-Crussi. Illustrated. 162 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: Mementos of the Rise and Staying Power of Rock-and-Roll
description: THE current show at the Museum of Art, Science and Industry contains little art and less science. Of industry, however, there are signs all over the place, although it cannot be the kind of industry that the founders of this Bridgeport establishment had in mind.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: THOSE readers who doubt the continued existence of evil in the world should reflect on two important anniversaries in 1989. Adolph Hitler was born 100 years ago on April 20, and World War II began 50 years ago on Sept. 1.

title: MINDS THAT NEVER MET
description: NEST OF SPIES America's Journey to Disaster in Iran. By Amir Taheri. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: Thatcher Gets Bit of Scolding By Old Guard
description: A prophet is not without honor save in his own country, so it isn't surprising that former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and former Prime Minister Edward Heath of Britain both think that Europe could have achieved a single market long before 1992 - if only people had listened to them.

title: 'Playboy' Brogue Becomes Creole
description: A CROSS-CULTURAL festival of sorts is happening at Crossroads, the black theater company that's as worldly minded as it is theatrically varied. ''Playboy of the West Indies,'' which is boisterously holding forth through next Sunday, is the Trinidad playwright Mustapha Matura's contemporary transposition of the turn-of-the-century Irish classic, ''The Playboy of the Western World'' by John Millington Synge.

title: India Loosens Travel Policies to Woo Tourists
description: In a bid for a bigger share of Asia's booming travel industry and the accompanying hard currency, India is making what its top tourism official calls ''revolutionary'' changes in policy.

title: Sacking Out
description: Richard Press is piqued. Fashion professionals have trumpeted Milan's rendition of the Yankee sack suit - broad-shouldered, wide-chested, loose-fitting - as the last word in high style. But Press isn't having any of it. ''I find it amusing that Milanese designers are telling hairdressers that the sack suit is now appropriate wear,'' says the vice president of J. Press, the venerable East Coast merchant, ''when members of our business and political establishment never thought it was anything but.'' Press, whose shops in New York, Cambridge, Mass., New Haven and Washington, helped make the sack suit synonymous with Ivy League style, claims that most of his customers have never abandoned the natural-shouldered, straight-hanging coat that is granddaddy to most current incarnations.

title: John Conlin Weds Carolyn Peoples
description: The marriage of Carolyn Ann Peoples, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Peoples of Middletown, Del., to John Woods Conlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Conlin of Armagh, Northern Ireland, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley officiated.

title: D. M. Boghossian Planning to Wed Ms. Bartle in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Hall Bartle of New York and Lee, Mass., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Dowling Bartle and David Mark Boghossian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Boghossian of Pawtucket and Narragansett, R.I.

title:
DINING OUT;
Imaginative Presentation in Harrison
description: LEAD: SINCE its inception eight years ago, Jillyflower's has become something of a landmark for diners seeking fresh ingredients prepared with consistent care and imagination. The chef currently in residence is Tony Lopa, who two years ago took the wooden spoon from Mark Filippo without missing a beat, it seems.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FALLOUT: An American Nuclear Tragedy. By Philip L. Fradkin. (University of Arizona, $24.95.) From 1951 to 1962, the United States detonated 100 nuclear bombs at the Nevada Test Site, some 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas. ''Fallout'' describes the ultimately unsuccessful course of a lawsuit brought in Federal District Court by residents of the American Southwest who said they had been harmed by radiation from the blasts. Though it is occasionally too emotional, Philip Fradkin's carefully researched book is a welcome addition to the growing body of work describing an atmospheric testing program so aggressive that it amounted to nothing less than an undeclared domestic nuclear war. In ''Fallout,'' Mr. Fradkin, a former newspaper reporter, argues that the principal victims of the testing program were thousands of families in Utah and Arizona who were exposed to dangerous levels of radiation from the blasts. I know of no other work that provides such an exhaustive recounting of the Federal case, which was won in 1984 by the plaintiffs at the District Court level but later reversed by an appellate court on the grounds that the Government could not be held legally responsible for the damage. In January 1988, the Supreme Court refused to take up the issue and the case died. Mr. Fradkin, however, has made it plain in this book that he intends to keep the memory of a reckless 11-year period in Nevada very much alive.

title: Tea Leaves At the Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonic's announcement of the 1989-90 season, now in hand, does not exactly make one's pulse rate jump off the chart. It is possible to receive calmly the news that Zubin Mehta will conduct nearly half of the 36-week schedule's 137 performances, including the world premieres of works by David Del Tredici and Roger Kellaway. That leaves, after all, 77 performances by other conductors in what a hoary orchestral tradition suggests could be an audition season as the Philharmonic searches for Mr. Mehta's successor as music director.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Esposito Make the Right Move?
description: What Esposito did was plain stupid. Whether the team was losing or not, to shake things up by dropping Bergeron with two games left, and so close to the playoffs, was insane. DINA SHERMAN Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: POSTINGS: Waterbury Mall; Lease-Buy Option
description: The developer of a new retail project in Waterbury, Conn., is using a novel hook to lure tenants: He will lease space in the 49,000-square-foot complex for about $18 a square foot, then allow the tenants the option of buying their stores during the first three years of the lease at a price between $185 and $200 a square foot.

title: New Yorkers, Etc.
description: There is, sitting in a bedroom facing the Hudson River, a perhaps not unique but much loved bassinet, the latest chapter in a story that began about a half century ago.

title: TELEPHONES: HIGH-TECH OPTIONS
description: THE TELEPHONE, LONG A simple, single-purpose household fixture, has recently undergone a revolution. In the past 10 years or so, our homes and, in some cases, our cars have become home to answering machines, cordless phones, automatic dialers, speaker phones, call diverters, cellular phones and telefax machines, to name but a few.

title: Mexican Decor, Festive Mood
description: YEARS ago, when I first ate at the original Don Juan Mexican restaurant in Westbury, I thought it a zippy alternative to the ubiquitous chains. At the newest Don Juan in Hicksville, I decided that Long Islanders who have grown up eating Mexican food at those chain restaurants would feel right at home.

title: Ms. Rosen Is Wed To L. M. Solomon
description: Madelon Joyce Rosen, the daughter of Helen Beck Rosen of the Bronx and the late Samuel Rosen, was married last evening to Lawrence Michael Solomon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Solomon of Brooklyn. Rabbi Israel Miller performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: Daimler On a New Road
description: Edzard Reuter, the steel-eyed chairman of Daimler-Benz A.G., often sounds like a professor propounding his latest vision of the future.

title: Pitino Uncovers the Problem
description: After an hourlong team meeting yesterday, Rick Pitino said that the Knicks' recent slump had been caused largely by personality conflicts among his players.

title: Ads and Attitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: THERE WAS A PLACE AND OTHER POEMS By Myra Cohn Livingston. 32 pp. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. MY MOTHER'S HOUSE, MY FATHER'S HOUSE By C. B. Christiansen. Illustrated by Irene Trivas. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 8)

title: Spanish Handcrafts Faithful to Tradition
description: THE dramatically varied land of Spain has been celebrated for centuries - not just by the prodigious Cervantes or Lope de Vega or Goya or Velazquez, but by the more pragmatic artisans of Spain's pueblos and regions. While Cervantes was immortalizing the man of La Mancha, Velazquez the family of Philip IV, Spain's anonymous potters and spinners were seeing a brown earthenware jar in the clay of Castile-La Mancha, a carpet or tapestry in the hemp of Madrid. Theirs is a tradition of utility and earth-bound beauty, as distinctive as the landscapes that inspired and produced it, and, in its own way, as alive as the paintings that hang in the Prado.

title: Miss Schneeberger to Marry
description: The engagement of Dorothy Donovan Schneeberger to Charles Hamilton Davison Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Davison of Greenwich, Conn., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Carl Schneeberger 3d of St. Louis. A June wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Harrisburg, Pa.;
Swapping Land With the State
description: LEAD: A WASHINGTON developer is trying, under Pennsylvania's land-exchange program, to trade three parcels for a 275-acre tract owned by the state.

title: A Sampling of the Season
description: Daffodils, spectacular in number and variety, are in the midst of their annual show at the Cincinnati Nature Center. They bloom on a 175-acre site, the former Carl Krippendorf estate, which is the centerpiece of the 800-acre nature center.

title: Fire Warnings Came Over the Transom
description: To the Editor:

title: Collector Turns Buttons to Jewelry
description: LEAD: ON a shopping trip to Mystic in 1985, Sharol Stewart of Niantic saw two brass buttons in a clothing shop and bought them on a whim. ''I couldn't believe how beautiful they were,'' Ms. Stewart recalled. ''And a few days later I said to myself, 'Gee, I don't collect anything. I'd like to collect buttons.

title: Miss Cohen Has Wedding
description: Cynthia R. Cohen, a partner in the New York accounting firm of Touche Ross & Company, and Harry N. Turk, a partner in the New York law firm of Epstein Becker & Green, were married last evening at the Grand Bay Hotel in Coconut Grove, Fla. Rabbi Brett Goldstein officiated.

title:
THE WORLDS OF SCIENCE;
IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE AFTER DEATH EXPERIENCE: The Physics of the Non-Physical. By Ian Wilson. (Morrow, $16.95.) We have here a strong contender in the afterlife, after death sweepstakes. This skeptical, well-written inquiry is a humane treatment of an intriguing subject that is easy to sensationalize. Ian Wilson's investigation of the shadowy realm beyond life is bolstered by his knowledge of historical and scientific fact.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Manhasset
description: LEAD: ON the first blue evening of spring, the doors of the shops and the windows of the old churches were flung open. Whitecaps bobbed along Manhasset Bay like paper napkins. Men and women sat in their cars at the train station, enjoying the warm breezes and waiting for their spouses on the 7:20 from New

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Cynthia Riker;
How to Run a Bed and Breakfast
description: LEAD: CYNTHIA AND TOM RIKER of Ridgewood operate a bed and breakfast in Cape May during the summer, an unexpected venture they began three years ago. ''With our daughters, Kristen, 20, and Lauren, 18,'' Mrs. Riker said, ''we had vacationed there and had always found it difficult to leave at the end of our stay.

title: Hands Across the Water
description: Students from kindergarten to graduate school are beginning to use computers and communications satellites to break down cultural and geographical barriers while fostering greater awareness of the interdependent world and their own roles in it.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $325,000 17 South Bay Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old waterfront ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room, 150- by 100-foot lot; taxes $7,000. Coram $165,000 3 School Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; fireplace, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800. Lindenhurst $119,900 11 Wyona Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, dining area, basement; taxes $1,200. Terryville $164,000 Grove Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new split level; family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes have not yet been assigned. West Babylon $155,000 824 Frankfort Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old split level; den, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,900. West Islip $139,990 848 Bay Shore Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,100. OTHER AREAS Glastonbury, Conn. $335,000 493 Tall Timbers Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; sauna, deck, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,338. Armonk, N.Y. $365,000 13 Byram Brook Place 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, basement, workshop, den, 1.3 acres; taxes $4,656. Neptune, N.J. $164,900 108 Elm Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old Cape Cod; c/a, fireplace in living room, deck; taxes $2,554.

title: Leslie Blum Marries
description: Leslie F. Blum, a fourth-year medical student at New York University, and Dr. David George Cziner, a senior medical resident at the New York University Medical Center and at the Bellevue Hospital Center, were married last evening at the Harmonie Club. Cantor Richard Botton officiated. Ms. Blum, who will keep her name, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Manfred Blum of New York. Dr. Cziner is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Cziner of Monsey, N.Y.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Brunch; Pre-Theater Dining In a Bustling Bistro
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Cafe Un Deux Trois * (May 15, 1987), 123 West 44th Street (354-4148) - This sprawling bistro within walking distance of Broadway theaters occupies what was the lobby of the former Hotel ''One-Two-Three.'' The dining room is a visual pun of sorts, with its faux marble columns, walls painted to look as if they are peeling and deliberately chipped moldings. Service is efficient under conditions that border on uproarious at peak hours. A prix-fixe brunch is served Saturday and Sunday and includes soup or green salad to start and entree choices of eggs Benedict and omelets, salmon du chef, steak tartare, grilled chicken and salade nicoise. Desserts are a la carte. Brunch prix fixe, $13.95, is served 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. Odeon * (Aug. 29, 1986), 145 West Broadway, at Thomas Street (233-0507) - Odeon, a veteran of the TriBeCa restaurant scene, is set in a former Art Deco cafeteria. This stylish French-American brasserie is an attractive downtown setting for Sunday brunch. The menu features tradtional egg dishes (omelets, eggs Florentine), two kinds of pancakes (buttermilk and potato), chicken-apple salad and corned-beef hash with poached eggs. There are also smoked fish plates and several specials - for example, shad roe with scrambled eggs. Desserts include fresh fruit, chocolate-hazelnut cake and an occasional special of warm berries, sauteed in brandy, then folded into puff pastry and served with creme chantilly. Menu is a la carte and ranges from $3.50 to $7 for appetizers and $7.50 to $16 for entrees. Sunday brunch served noon to 3:30 P.M. Palm Court Diner's Journal (March 24, 1989), in the Plaza Hotel, 59th Street and Fifth Avenue ( 546-5350) - The Plaza Hotel's Palm Court, one of New York's fabled Old World dining rooms, opens to encompass the three- tier Terrace Room for Sunday brunch. The towering mural-covered ceiling and lavish glass chandeliers provide a classic atmosphere. The opulently arranged buffets are impressive in their variety and freshness. The selection includes cheeses, seasonal fruits, terrines, breads and smoked fish (an exceptionally delicate Nova Scotia salmon and pepper-crusted smoked trout are recommended). For breakfast-food fans, there are omelets and poached eggs. Cold shrimp, crab claws, cold roast chicken and hot entrees of lamb curry and braised veal are available for bigger appetites. An appropriately Edwardian dessert is the sherry trifle, which shares a dessert buffet with ''floating island,'' shortcake, pies and tarts. Brunch is prix fixe at $39 and is served from 10 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Rosa Mexicana ** (Aug. 1, 1986), 1063 First Avenue, at 58th Street (753-7407) - Rosa Mexicana, one of the best and most elegant Mexican restaurants in town, serves authentic dishes in two appealing dining rooms. The front room has a long tiled bar where patrons can enjoy the house margarita made with pomegranates; the back dining area, with rose-colored stucco walls, is subdued and anchored by a flower-filled stone fountain. Sunday brunch is buffet style, with the dishes arranged along the serving bar. These might include guacamole, ceviche, chilled crab meat and jalapenos rellenos to start; among the entrees are roast suckling pig, carne fria and a chicken dish. Flan and mango fruitcake are recommended desserts. Prix fixe, $24. A la carte menu also available with lunch items from $8.50 to $18. Noon to 3 P.M. Voulez-Vouz ** (Feb. 12, 1988), 1462 First Avenue, at 76th Street (249-1776) - Earthy French fare is served in a cool, contrasting setting of glass and mirror. Tones of chocolate brown and pastel pink accent the dining room of this East Side bistro. A wide selection of brunch dishes is offered at an $11.95 prix fixe, with supplements charged for some of the entrees. Among the choices are eggs with smoked salmon, French toast made with croissants, cheese souffle, grilled salmon or chicken, choucroute garni and individual pizzas (one is topped with bacon, mozzarella and sunnyside eggs.) Brunch from 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. WHAT THE STARS MEAN (None) Poor to satisfactory * Good ** Excellent *** Extraordinary These ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction primarily to food, with ambiance and service taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.

title: Social Events
description: Presidential Banquet

title: Getting an M.B.A. on the Fly Via Cable TV
description: A television program starting next fall just might make M.B.A.'s out of America's couch potatoes.

title: Defiant Still, Chinese Dissident Ends Prison Term
description: Unrepentant and defiant as ever, a well-known campaigner for democracy walked out of prison today after completing an eight-year sentence for editing a journal that called for greater human rights in China.

title: Headliners; Eventual Loser
description: Is there a message about current mores in the fact that a former Vice President has spent years in court arguing over the tax treatment of his income from kickbacks? In any case, the former Vice President in question, Spiro T. Agnew, last week lost the argument. Mr. Agnew's lawyers contended that he should be allowed to claim a tax deduction on $142,500 that he paid the state of Maryland in restitution for bribes he was accused of collecting as Governor in the 1960's. (Mr. Agnew pleaded no contest in 1973 to charges that he had evaded income taxes on kickbacks.) Had he been allowed the deduction on his California taxes - he had moved there before Maryland courts ordered him in 1981 to make restitution - Mr. Agnew would have been due a $24,197 refund. Last week, a California court upheld a 1986 ruling denying him the refund.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: TALES FROM INDIANA Jean Shepherd, the man who made Indiana funny and more famous, will relate new anecdotes tomorrow night in his fourth annual appearance at Summit High School.

title: Cosmetic Surgery for Pets
description: And now, for the pet owner with everything: cosmetic surgery for dogs.

title: Friends Capture Plight of Homeless in Book
description: VERNON G. BAKER went from teaching anthropology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to becoming a penniless alcoholic living on the street. That experience was vividly brought back to him when a friend showed him some pictures of homeless people in Hartford.

title: Teen-age Volunteers
description: Taking a cue from their elder brothers and sisters in college, more American high-school-age students are putting their hearts where the money isn't: in public-spirited volunteer service during summer vacations.

title: Corrections
description: A map with an article about New Delhi on March 19 misidentified a hotel on Zakir Hussain Marg. It is the Oberoi hotel; the Oberoi Maidens Hotel is in Old Delhi, near the Red Fort.

title: Red Smith Award
description: Edwin Pope, the sports editor of The Miami Herald, has won the 1989 Red Smith Award for career contributions to sports journalism. The award, given by The Associated Press Sports Editors, is named for The New York Times columnist who died in 1982.

title: Esposito Brothers Facing Off Again
description: They competed against each other vigorously in meaningless street games, in more serious confrontations at the youth level and then, finally, in the National Hockey League. Now, the most significant battle between the Esposito brothers, Phil and Tony, is being fought by others while they watch.

title: In East, Harvard Is Crew to Beat
description: The test between Brown, a formidable challenger, and Harvard, the reigning champion of college crew racing, was postponed today. The 2,000-meter race course on the windy Charles River basin was too turbulent for racing shells and so the race for the Stein Cup will be decided late Sunday afternoon.

title: A Crater Moonscape In Maui
description: IN the late afternoon at Leleiwi Overlook on Mount Haleakala on the island of Maui in the Hawaiian Islands, visitors sometimes see their shadows projected against the clouds below and surrounded by a circular rainbow, a phenomenon known as Brocken's Specter. The shadow occurs as the sun sets behind someone standing on the rim of the dormant volcano's crater, looking down into the clouds. Hawaiians call the phenomenon aka-ku-anue-nue, or the seeing of one's own soul.

title: Kathryn Bergere Wed To Anthony F. Bucaro
description: Kathryn C. Bergere and Anthony F. Bucaro were married yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Robert D. Williams, a Presbyterian minister, performed the Protestant ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn C. Fowler of New York. Her husband is the son of Jack Anthony Bucaro and Vivian Bucaro, both of New York. Yvette Masullo and John Tomaselli attended the couple. Mrs. Bucaro, a paralegal in New York, was previously married and divorced. Her father is a reporter for The New York Times. Her mother, Joan Fowler, is a freelance writer.

title: A Veterinarian Who Makes House Calls
description: LEAD: PET owners in Fairfield County who require emergency visits from a veterinarian at odd hours may find that Jeffrey Feinman is the man to call.

title: Passover Cantata Spans Cultures
description: LEAD: IT took a while, a few weeks in fact, but Jacob Hamilton finally taught Fred Maliszewski the Four Questions.

title: Dr. Mack Lipkin, 82, Professor of Medicine
description: Dr. Mack Lipkin, clinical professor of medicine at the University of North Carolina's Chapel Hill School of Medicine, died of a brain stem infarction Tuesday at his home at Chapel Hill. He was 82 years old and also maintained a residence in New York City.

title: DATA BANK: April 9, 1989
FLASHCARD
description: Given its sparse population, Nevada is a sure bet to be the fastest-growing state in terms of high school graduates, while West Virginia is the biggest loser. Nevada's class of 2004 should be 109 percent larger than its class of 1986. West Virginia's class of that same soon-to-be-vintage year is expected to be 32 percent smaller than its class of 1986. - Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education, Boulder, Colo., 1988

title: Efforts Pressed on Animal Abuse
description: LEAD: DOGS chained to trees for days without food or water, kittens left to die in a dumpster, horses starved and covered with saddle sores. These and hundreds of other acts of cruelty to animals have been reported in Westchester in the last year - and, experts say, the number of cases is on the rise.

title: A Garden That Spans the Centuries
description: Visiting Newby is a spring tonic. The English winter in North Yorkshire can be bleak, yet in the south-sloping gardens of Newby Hall, reached through sweeping parkland enclosed by sheltering woodland, spring comes early. The flowering plants of April and May will surprise and delight visitors.
