The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) IN OUR IMAGE: America's Empire in the Philippines, by Stanley Karnow. (Random House, $24.95.) A sensitive, accurate panoramic survey of the political and social history of the islands, and of the relations between the Filipinos and their American masters and tutors - relations that have survived independence and still seem essential, though often burdensome, to both sides. LATECOMERS, by Anita Brookner. (Pantheon, $16.95.) Ms. Brookner's usual ruthless bleakness yields in this powerful novel to a kind of cautious triumph as a German-born Londoner manages to seize and keep a little bit of freedom and courage. THE SWING ERA: The Development of Jazz, 1930-1945, by Gunther Schuller. (Oxford University, $30.) The second in Mr. Schuller's proposed three-volume history of jazz, this mighty (919 pages) tome is full of technical detail, observation and careful thinking. NOW, WHERE WERE WE? By Roy Blount Jr. (Villard, $17.95.) Humorous essays by one of our leading practitioners, delivered from his customary cheerful pose as a professional cracker. GEEK LOVE, by Katherine Dunn. (Knopf, $18.95.) Ms. Dunn's main success in this novel of love, betrayal and power is with the exploration of the peculiar as an end in itself - exemplified by the book's population, a family of deliberately created freaks. SOMOZA FALLING, by Anthony Lake. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) An informed case study of unsuccessful policy making in a tug of war between political and professional State Department officers in the Carter Administration. THE WARRIOR QUEENS, by Antonia Fraser. (Knopf, $22.95.) An informed and lively miscellany, treating its subjects both as creatures of fact and focuses of myth, starting with Boadicea.

title: Managing When It's All in the Family
description: S.C. Johnson & Sons Inc. is one of the largest family-owned companies in the United States, with revenues of more than $2 billion. Since its founding in 1886, it has always had a member of the Johnson family at its helm. Freed from the pressures of Wall Street,Johnson Wax, as it is widely known, was one of the first companies to institute profit sharing and start a philanthropic foundation. The consumer products company, which is based in Racine, Wis., was also one of the first American corporations to go global - it established its first overseas subsidiary in Britain in 1914. Samuel C. Johnson, the great-grandson and namesake of the company's founder, discussed managing a large family company with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman. Question: As a family-controlled company, you are pretty much exempt from the whims of Wall Street. How do you view Wall Street today? Mr. Johnson: My vision for this company goes counter to what is popular on Wall Street - which is against companies with multiple markets. I consider it a genuine asset to be diversified. If my great-grandfather didn't go out of the parquet floor business, we couldn't be selling products around the world. I began the pesticide business, which is now our biggest business.

title: Alaska Orders New Spill Plan
description: Alaskan officials today announced an emergency order requiring the oil consortium that runs the Trans-Alaska Pipeline to immediately marshal the manpower and equipment necessary to battle future oil spills.

title: Vietnam Still Lives Hand to Mouth, but Less Collectively
description: FOR all the talk of renovating the country's economy, party and ideology, Le Doan Kien was saying over a slug of the local vodka of perfumed rice, Vietnam is a country where 80 percent of the people earn their living directly from agriculture, and most basic industries depend on raw materials seduced from the soil.

title: THE MAN WHO DIDN'T BELONG
description: BAUMGARTNER'S BOMBAY By Anita Desai. 230 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: 'Dividing the Estate,' A Texas Family Saga
description: STELLA, a grandmother who despised her husband, won't divide the estate, not on her life. When she's reminded - and she is, relentlessly - that the profits of a once income-producing property are a thing of the past, she suggests economizing by putting in a garden and getting a cow, even though the family manse is in the middle of town, on a highway, surrounded by car lots and fast-food restaurants.

title: Memo To the P.L.O.:
description: You have reacted with intense skepticism to Prime Minister Shamir's proposal for elections in the West Bank and Gaza. So have Palestinian residents of the occupied territories.

title: High Risk of New Shuttle Disaster Leads NASA to Consider Options
description: The space agency is worried that another catastrophic space shuttle accident seems almost inevitable in the next decade, so it is improving the winged spaceships still more and considering a switch to unmanned rockets for some missions.

title: The Splendors of a Northwest Spring
description: Visitors to the Pacific Northwest are often struck by the richness and depth of April's floral display. Native plants, many of which are prized border shrubs in English gardens, line every country roadside. Azaleas and rhododendrons mingle with rosy sheaves of flowering currant, pallid, drooping Indian plum blossom and the bold, glossy leaves of the umbrella plant. Nowhere is the display more concentrated than within the confines of Seattle's Washington Park Arboretum, an enclave of some 200 acres sandwiched between residential neighborhoods just minutes from the city's heart. Here, native plants are given the same respect as the thousands of exotics that are gathered into a woody collection of international status that has been developed over the last half century.

title: The New Rules Of the Game
description: To the Editor:

title: IS COMPETENCE ENOUGH?
description: According to a professor in Mr. Lukas's article, bureaucrats and government school apparatchiks think the best job to have is one running other people's lives (thunderous applause, please). Further, it appears that ''a lot of what goes on in the private sector isn't terribly important.'' This was no doubt proclaimed by the good professor after he put on sunglasses, drove a car and picked up typed class notes, all of which were supplied by private industry.

title: Spring Inspection Time
description: THE first warm weekend in spring is a good time to make an annual inspection of your home's exterior.

title: Time Executive Retires, to Another Job
description: EARLY on as a correspondent for Life magazine, Don Wilson covered the demise of The New York Sun, the Alger Hiss spy trial and, oh yes, the roller-skating horse in Bowling Green, Ky.

title: Schools Preparing For More Students
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER'S public schools will show an increase in the total number of students in September for the first time since 1970, according to a report by the county's Department of Planning.

title: Music From the Time of Confucius
description: There's ''Early music,'' and then there's really early music. At the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Tuesday and Wednesday, a company of 62 musicians, singers and dancers from China will perform the really early music, re-creating the grand spectacles of the Chinese imperial court from over 2,000 years ago.

title: BASEBALL: Naional League; Ramos and Sandberg Power Cubs to 5-3 Victory
description: Domingo Ramos hit a two-run homer and Ryne Sandberg drove in two runs with a single and a double today, leading Mike Bielecki and the Chicago Cubs past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-3.

title:
AS THE WORLD LEARNS;
Dear Diary
description: LEAD: A 20-year-old beneficiary of the glasnost era in American-Soviet relations, Yekaterina Kontor, a native of Moscow, is one of 56 students participating in the first undergraduate exchange program between the two countries. Under the auspices of the American Consortium for East-West Cultural and Academic Exchange, an association of colleges based at Middlebury College in Vermont, she arrived there in early August for 20 days of orientation to be followed by a year of study at Sarah Lawrence College, in Bronxville, N.Y., one of 26 American liberal-arts colleges in the program.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: There is nothing quite as chaotic in chess as the naming of opening variations. Even in those cases where the original name was perhaps justified, someone will come along and rename it after a current practitioner who enjoys success with it. That may last for one chess generation, that is, until a successor appears on the scene and has it named for him.

title: What to Expect and What to Avoid
description: FRIDAY and Saturday nights have long been peak times at most hospital emergency rooms, in large part because people often engage in high-risk activities over the weekend.

title: Afghan War Is Proving the Hardest on the Young
description: ''Please, sir!'' the woman said, her voice breaking as she thrust her hand through the iron bars in the wall surrounding the Mother and Child Health Clinic in the northern suburbs of Kabul. Fearful that her cry had not been understood, she said: ''Please, sir! Food for my child!''

title: Eastern Europe Tests The Limits of Liberalism
description: THE sweeping new measures announced last week in Poland demonstrate once again how rapid the pace of change has become in parts of the East bloc - more rapid than in Moscow and fast enough to generate new debate in the West about how far it should go in encouraging political transformation in Eastern Europe. The Polish measures, which legalize the Solidarity trade union and introduce changes in virtually every area of political, cultural and economic life, are certain to broaden the ideological gap in the Soviet bloc.

title: U.S. Doubles Has Pair of Aces
description: Compared with their more illustrious teammates, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso lead rather uneventful tennis lives.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Esposito Make the Right Move?
description: Esposito will find out that he cannot motivate the players any better than Bergeron. The dismissal of the coach was one of Esposito's biggest blunders to date. RICHARD S. BEATUS Woodmere, L.I.

title: Chicago Race Divisions Begin at Home
description: WHETHER or not Chicago is the most racially segregated big city in the nation, as demographers often maintain, there is no question that black people and white people are usually not neighbors. Indeed, political experts say, the unusually high degree of segregation in housing helps explain the unusually sharp racial division at the voting booth, as was evident last Tuesday when Richard M. Daley was elected Mayor.

title: Two Colleges With No Rooms For the Selfish
description: STUDENTS at Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic who want a room on campus next fall will have to qualify for it by serving others.

title: Where Poodle Skirts and Crinolines Live On
description: Marjorie McCown was wearing diapers in the mid-1950's, a time when the original production of ''The Pajama Game'' was on Broadway and more mature women were sporting crinolines beneath their poodle-decorated skirts. Ms. McCown, who was born 34 years ago in Tuscola, Ill., may have missed some of the fashions of the 50's the first time around, but she had the opportunity to re-create them as costume designer for the New York City Opera's revival of ''The Pajama Game.'' (The production, at the New York State Theater, will run through April 16).

title:
THE WORLDS OF SCIENCE;
IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ASK SIR JAMES: Sir James Reid, Personal Physician to Queen Victoria and Physician-in-Ordinary to Three Monarchs. By Michaela Reid. (Viking, $21.95.) No Scottish youth entering medical school in 1868 could have foreseen that in 13 years he would be named resident medical attendant to the Queen. Fortune smiled on James Reid, and he not only became Queen Victoria's personal physician (and that of her successors, Edward VII and George V) but also her confidant and adviser.

title: AND MAN SAID, LET THERE BE LIGHT
description: DISENCHANTED NIGHT The Industrialization of Light in the Nineteenth Century. By Wolfgang Schivelbusch. Translated by Angela Davies. Illustrated. 227 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $22.50.

title: Polish Agreement Is Seen as Putting the Economic Ball in the West's Court
description: At the conclusion of the successful round-table talks in Warsaw last week, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, the Polish Interior Minister, who was instrumental in shaping the accord, put the challenge in no uncertain terms. It was time, he said, for Western governments to ''fulfill their commitments to Poland.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Texas; A Disco Inferno As Trash Music Rocks the Campus
description: You thought disco was dead?

title: Claire Mullooly Is Bride
description: Claire Maureen Mullooly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Mullooly of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York to Eugene Arch Preston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Preston of Warren, N.J. The Rev. Damian A. O'Connell performed the ceremony.

title: Shoreham Opponents See Victory at Hand
description: LEAD: NOT trumpets and fanfare, but the sound of stifled yawning arose from the public arena last week as a quarter-century of fighting over the Shoreham nuclear-power plant drew near to a close.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Esposito Make the Right Move?
description: The only right move will be when Esposito trades himself back to Boston. STACY MAZZA New York

title: Afghan Missile Strikes Pakistan
description: In an unusual acknowledgment, the Afghan Government said today that a Soviet-supplied Scud-B missile was accidentally fired across the border into Pakistan early Friday.

title: A Character Actor Respects Tradiiton
description: WHEN George Guidall showed up at Broadway's Brooks Atkinson Theater for the Sunday matinee of ''Cafe Crown'' - the play's 42d performance - just two weeks ago, he noticed that one of the producers was poring over the day's box office receipts. Then, at the end of the first act, he observed some of the costumes being carted away.

title: Glug, Glug, Glug: Yanks Sink Further
description: The Yankees' offense is becoming severely offensive to the Yankees. Their pitching isn't treating them very nicely either.

title: Miss Ivers Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Ivers of Corning, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ellen Ivers, to John Richard Munro Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Munro of New Canaan, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: NEW PARTY MEETS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A new political party, whose members say they want to breach the gulf between white liberals and black anti-apartheid groups, met officially today in preparation for a general election to be held around September.

title: Sugar Sweetens County Commerce
description: I was most interested to read the article ''The View From: Refined Sugars Inc.'' [ March 19 ] . Sugar refining is probably the oldest continuing industry in Westchester, and readers who are interested in learning its history might want to read an article titled ''Sugar Time on the Hudson,'' which appears in the Winter 1989 issue of our journal, The Westchester Historian. Most local public libraries subscribe to the journal, or a copy may be obtained by sending a check for $3.50 to the Westchester County Historical Society, 75 Grasslands Road, Valhalla, N.Y. 10595.

title: Reviews/Music; A French Cellist, 35 Years Later
description: Paul Tortelier, the French cellist, is in the midst of his first trip to New York City in 35 years. His biggest exposure has been as soloist with the New York Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y, but Mr. Tortelier also played for his friends and colleagues of the Violoncello Society on Thursday night.

title: Marsha A. Gisser To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Gisser of South Orange and Margate, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Marsha Anne Gisser, and John Daniel Shyer, the son of Hilda Shyer of New York and the late Michael Shyer.

title: Art Lovers Who Don't Have Thousands to Spend
description: Re: ''A Masters Show,'' an article on March 5 covering a forthcoming art exhibition at the J. Richards Gallery in Englewood:

title: Taking the Mystery Out of Swiss Chard
description: CHARD or Swiss chard, is a vegetable with which many people are barely acquainted. There are those who might be able to recognize it in the market but who have rarely cooked or eaten it. For many shoppers, it's just another of those mysterious bunches of green.

title: Agency Takes 53 New Buses Out of Service for Repairs
description: The New York City Transit Authority took 53 recently acquired buses out of service over the weekend after the manufacturer advised it of a potential problem with the rear-axle assembly, officials said.

title: IT LOVE TREASON?
description: THE MEN'S ROOM By Ann Oakley. 309 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Fewer Problems; The Medical Record On DES Emerges After Years of Research and Anxiety
description: AFTER years of anguish, the daughters of women who took DES during their pregnancies have received encouraging news lately. Last week they won an important victory when the New York Court of Appeals made it easier for them to sue companies that made the drug, which was prescribed to avert miscarriages.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Tingles at the I.R.S. IT'S Tingle Table time at the Internal Revenue Service. ''By next week we'll have all the Tingle Tables in use,'' said Joanne Luciani of the I.R.S., as she and a visitor surveyed the Tingle Table room, officially known as the extracting room, at the I.R.S. Brookhaven Service Center. Tingle Tables are named for their inventor, James Tingle, an I.R.S. employee. The desk, which looks like an octopus carrying 10 dinner trays, is used for opening and sorting the more than nine million individual Federal income tax returns that arrive at the Holtsville I.R.S. facility this time of year.

title: MAINTAINING A DELICATE BALANCE AT ARTHUR ANDERSON
description: In the early morning of March 8, 24 partners of Arthur Andersen & Company filed into the boardroom on the 35th floor of Andersen's world headquarters here. The men, who make up the Board of Partners at the accounting and consulting firm, were choosing a new chief executive, and the matter could not have been more pressing.

title: Impatient Rebels Jump the Gun
description: WHY would hundreds of armed Namibian nationalists return from their Angolan refuge only to be slaughtered, on the eve of a negotiated countdown to independence?

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: SIMPLIFYING STEREO
description: SELF - EFFACEMENT is a virtue rarely found in stereo systems.

title: Fit to Print?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rose Garden Ritual: Athletes on Parade
description: Gone are the Washington Senators -unfortunately only the baseball club, that is - but not the President's affection for sports and sportsmen.

title: A Week for the Voice And for the Piano
description: THIS will be a week for singing, with two operas, an oratorio, a requiem and a musical comedy classic among the concert highlights. It will also be a good week for piano music, because Jorge Bolet, Lorin Hollander, Jeremy Menuhin and Vladimir Ashkenazy are among the visitors.

title: Report Accuses Pentagon of Stalling on Changes
description: The Pentagon has not undertaken improvements required by the 1986 Defense Reorganization Act, according to a new General Accounting Office report.

title: Talk Without Hearing
description: The U.S. and the Soviet Union have never talked on so many wavelengths as they do now. But a week here shows they aren't hearing each other on essentials.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title:
BLACKBOARD;
What's Your Excuse?
description: LEAD: As long as teachers have assigned homework, students have found reasons for not doing it. These days with more sophisticated technology available, excuses go way beyond ''The dog ate it.'' Today, ''The computer ate it.''

title: Two Court Cases That Inspired the March
description: The abortion rights march has its roots in two major Supreme Court cases, one decided in 1973, the other to be heard by the Court this month.

title:
INVESTING;
The Highest-Yielding Fund
description: LEAD: For several weeks the Dreyfus Corporation's Worldwide Dollar Money Market Fund has had the highest yield of any money fund tracked by Donoghue's Money Fund Report. It recently had a compounded yield of 10.89 percent.

title: TWO SEMIAUTOMATIC RIFLES TO GO, PLEASE
description: DAY OF RECKONING By John Katzenbach. 368 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: Melanie Dorsey Is Married
description: Melanie Graham Dorsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Henry Dorsey of Chevy Chase, Md., and Daniel James Standish, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Standish of Englewood, Colo., were married yesterday. The ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase was performed by the Rev. Gregory D. M. Maletta.

title: FLASHCARD
description: In 1972, nearly all coaches of women's college sports were women. By 1986 only about half were women. Title IX legislation banned discrimination on the basis of sex in educational institutions receiving Federal funds. Coaching women's sports could no longer be limited to women and increased salaries made the jobs more attractive. - Department of Physical Education, Brooklyn College, R. Vivian Acosta and Linda J. Carpenter

title: CAMPUS LIFE: University of Michigan; Alumni Club Gives Students a Taste Of the Big Apple
description: This is really a football town, but you would not know that now. Not since the University of Michigan's men's basketball team won the national basketball championship last Monday.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Rutgers; Anthropologist Examines Sex Life On the Raritan
description: In his book about student life on this campus, Michael Moffatt wrote twice as many pages on sex as he did on intellectual life.

title: DATA UPDATE: April 9 ,1989
Carey, Beame Defend Ford At Conference
description: Fourteen years after they faced New York City's fiscal crisis as reluctant partners, a former Mayor and a former Governor met here today at a conference on the President both men now say was unfairly accused of telling them to drop dead when they asked for help.

title: Sarah J. Finlayson to Marry Lindley G. DeGarmo
description: Sarah Jean Finlayson and Lindley Grant DeGarmo, a son of Elsie DeGarmo Smith of Pine Plains, N.Y., and the late Lindley S. DeGarmo, plan to marry in May, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Finlayson of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., have announced.

title: Sex, Drugs and the Doors
description: LEAD: WONDERLAND AVENUE Tales of Glamour and Excess. By Danny Sugerman. 407 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: LENINGRAD CAST The Leningrad Experimental Theater Company will perform in four concerts at two locations in Westchester: at 8 P.M. Wednesday and Thursday and at 7 P.M. next Sunday in the Little Theater of Manhattanville College in Purchase, and 8 P.M. April 18 at Iona College's Joyce Theater in New Rochelle.

title: Minimum Size for School Districts: Is Change Due?
description: With 18 schools and 11,500 pupils, Community School District 1 on Manhattan's Lower East Side is the smallest of New York City's 32 decentralized school districts. Even so, it has more pupils than all but seven school districts in the state outside New York City.

title: 'Concerts in Color' at Union Church
description: ON Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Sunday afternoons from April through December, the stained-glass windows of Henri Matisse and Marc Chagall are on view at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills. Visitors today or the next two Sundays will also find ''Concerts in Color,'' a cycle of 5 P.M. programs sponsored by Historic Hudson Valley and featuring members of the Philharmonia Virtuosi Chamber Players. On today's program are works for flute and harp by Handel, Faure, Ibert and others. For more details, call 631-8200.

title: Soviet Travel: Friendship and Flexibility
description: LIKE explorers finding new riches under the sun, county residents are discovering the Soviet Union. A college modern-dance ensemble, a photographer, a songwriter and a group of high-school students are among the latest to feel the warmth of glasnost in their planned or just-completed trips to Russia.

title: When the World Turns
description: YEARS AGO, ONE OF my professors in medical school demonstrated what happens when there's a miscue in important signals that go out to the body from the labyrinths of tiny pathways within the inner ear. After he volunteered me, probably because I arrived quite late for the lecture on the vestibular system, I sat facing my class of fellow freshmen. He slowly squirted a syringe filled with about two tablespoons of cool water into my right ear - the so-called cold calorics test. Within 30 seconds, I felt woozy, the auditorium seemed to bounce or jerk, my vision blurred, and I grew pale and sweaty. The room began to spin to the left. My body leaned right against my will and if I had stood, I knew I would have to grab onto something solid or I would stagger like a drunk and fall. The hallucination of motion seemed even worse when I closed my eyes, but the sensation lessened when I happened to stare at my hand. Nausea rapidly built until I threw up on the professor's trousers.

title: Pont Lookout Fears Loss of Beach Area
description: LEAD: TOWN of Hempstead officials are calling their erosion crisis at the public beach in Point Lookout, an area known as Town Park, a ''mini-Westhampton Beach.''

title: A Brief Encounter With Einstein
description: Tom Mackin's ''The Day Einstein Went Public'' (Opinion page, March 12) reminded me of another day in 1953, or was it 1954? Although I can remember the event as if it were yesterday, I cannot precisely remember the year.

title: Call Me Speedo
description: A PATRIOT, EVEN SORT OF AN American ambassador, Waldo Stakes is a self-educated engineer who is dedicated to the proposition that what this country needs is the land speed record. ''America really wants it back,'' says Stakes of the world mark, currently held by Richard Noble, an Englishman who piloted a jet car at 633 miles per hour across the Nevada desert in 1983.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Pennsylvania; Getting Personal: Call a Professor And 'Do Lunch'
description: Members of a student group at the University of Pennsylvania, realizing that it is hard for some students to approach their professors in a 200-seat lecture hall, are hoping to encourage their shyer classmates to come out of the shadows.

title: Of Sigmund and Minna
description: To the Editor:

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on March 12 on Stamford misidentified the organization with which Joseph Ercolano is associated. It is the Southwestern Area Commerce & Industry Association of Connecticut.

title: Sunday Silence Soars
description: While all eyes were looking for the $2.9 million colt Houston to step forward as the West's best hope for the Kentucky Derby, a streak of black named Sunday Silence surfaced to win the $500,000 Santa Anita Derby today by a dazzling 11 lengths.

title: Diana Stratton-Crooke Has a Wedding
description: The marriage of Diana Stratton-Crooke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Stratton-Crooke of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Edmund Murphy Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. Kelly of Scarsdale took place there yesterday at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Edward M. Connors, who married the bridegroom's parents, performed the ceremony.

title: A Paterson College Collection Is on View for the First Time
description: ''THE Garret and Jennie Hobart Collection of Art'' is the kind of show that even a decade ago would probably not have been mounted, much less reviewed. Fashions have changed as drastically in this short period as they have since the art was acquired, at the end of the 19th century.

title: FLASHCARD
description: The District of Columbia seems to lead the nation not only in the number of politicians per square inch but also in the amount of college-educated brain matter per cubic foot, at least compared with other major metropolitan areas. Among the District's adults age 25 or older, 38 percent had completed four or more years of college in 1987, and 88 percent had completed four years of high school. Among the 15 largest metropolitan areas in the United States, Pittsburgh has the smallest share (15 percent) of adults with four or more years of college. - Bureau of the Census, ''Educational Attainment in the United States, March 1987 and 1986''

title: Sara R. Gardiner Is Wed in Jersey To Assembly Aide
description: Sara Randall Gardiner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Wade Gardiner of Shrewsbury, N.J., and Kevin Gerard Frechette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Richard Frechette of Holmdel, N.J., were married yesterday at Christ Church Episcopal in Shrewsbury. The Rev. James E. LaSage performed the ceremony.

title: Assault Victim Dies After Feeding Tube Withheld by Court
description: Mark Weaver, whose life-support system was disconnected eight days ago over the objections of the man who stabbed him, died Friday, nearly four years after the stabbing left him in a coma.

title: Outdoors; Spilled Oil Is Something to Cry Over
description: Dead or dying oil-soaked waterfowl, sea birds and sea otters are the immediate and visible victims of the millions of gallons of crude oil that poured from the Exxon Valdez tanker when it struck a reef in Prince William Sound in Alaska last month. Whether the region's production of fish, primarily various species of salmon and the Pacific sea herring, will be devastated cannot be predicted.

title: A SORRY WAY TO SAY THANK YOU
description: THE WAGES OF WAR When America's Soldiers Came Home - From Valley Forge to Vietnam. By Richard Severo and Lewis Milford. Illustrated. 495 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: Let's Get the Contras Out of Honduras Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Roe v. Wade: Nothing Has Changed
description: On April 26, the State of Missouri will ask the Supreme Court to overturn Roe v. Wade, the historic 1973 ruling that left most decisions about abortion up to individual women and their doctors. Today, thousands who hope the Court reaffirms that right to decide will gather in Washington. Like the anti-abortionists who demonstrated in January, they seek to make an impression with their numbers, passion and witness.

title: Judith S. Warner, Writer, Is Married to Max Berley
description: Judith Sharon Warner, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Joseph Warner of New York, and Max David Berley, a son of David Boris Berley of New York and Mary Flanagan Freelon of Marblehead, Mass., were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev. Richard Leonard officiated. The bride, a freelance writer, graduated from the Brearley School and magna cum laude from Brown University. Her father is a psychologist and her mother, Zelda Warner, is the director of admissions at the Grace Church School in Manhattan.

title:
THE WORLDS OF SCIENCE;
IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: IDEAS AND INFORMATION: Managing in a High-Tech World. By Arno Penzias. (Norton, $17.95.) Best known for his work in radio astronomy - he shared the Nobel Prize in physics in 1978 for his work supporting the big-bang theory of the universe - Arno Penzias has spent many years working on the front lines of research on the information revolution.

title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned
description: LEAD: THE 1987 law that established stiffer penalties for drug sales and use within 1,000 feet of public and private schools throughout New Jersey resulted in 6,500 arrests last year, according to the Attorney General's office.

title: Joan Bernstein Marries
description: Joan Eve Bernstein, a writer for ABC News Radio Networks, and Thomas Andrew Harris, a writer for the ABC-TV show ''Good Morning America,'' both in New York, were married yesterday. Don Robert Johnson, the Senior Leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Warwick Hotel. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Bernstein of New York; the bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harris of Brimfield, Mass.

title: Last Colony in Africa Nearing Independence With Jitters For All
description: FOR years, the United Nations condemned South Africa for its refusal to give up Namibia, a territory seized from Germany in World War I. Not only did the General Assembly revoke the mandate given South Africa by the defunct League of Nations in 1920, but it embraced the South West People's Organization, or Swapo, a guerrilla movement fighting Pretoria's rule, as the ''sole and authentic representative'' of Namibia's people.

title: 'I Don't Want Another Car!'
description: ''YOU mean it's - it's terminal?''

title: Lost In Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel Sharp Wed To Revelle Allen, An Art Consultant
description: The Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center was the setting yesterday evening for the wedding of Revelle Pergament Allen, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Pergament, to Daniel Asher Sharp, a son of Miriam Asher Sharp of San Francisco and the late Joseph C. Sharp. Rabbi Joseph C. Glaser officiated.

title: INSIDE
description: Sub Sinking Is Confirmed

title: SCIENCE FICTION: IMAGINARY WOLRDS AND REAL-LIFE QUESTIONS
description: Fourteen years ago I began to teach a course in science fiction at Dartmouth College. Spaceships figured in the reading, along with faster-than-light travel, telepathic robots and in one story some bright orange aliens who rather resembled tennis balls on legs.

title: Katy Kinsolving Weds a Lawyer, R. M. Baumann
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in New York, Katharine Cole Kinsolving, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Lee Kinsolving of Bethesda, Md., and Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Mark Baumann, a son of Mrs. Werner B. Baumann of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and the late Mr. Baumann. The Rev. Harold Elliott Barrett performed the ceremony.

title: THE NATION: The Speaker Speaks; Wright's Strategy: A Pre-emptive Strike
description: ALL he ever wanted was to be Speaker of the House, Representative Jim Wright once said. Mr. Wright got what he wanted in 1987, after 32 years in Congress. Now the question is whether he can keep it.

title: Of Sigmund and Minna
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Season, and Baseball Still Seeks Truth in Numbers
description: LAST Monday, in the third inning of the opening-day game between the St. Louis Cardinals and the New York Mets, the Mets' third baseman Howard Johnson singled to left field, scoring Darryl Strawberry and Kevin McReynolds, giving the Mets the lead for good in a game they would eventually win, 8-4. The achievement, however, will not enter the realm of official baseball history. This unstartling development was the first indication of what baseball is without this year - a statistic called the game-winning run batted in.

title: SPRING REPORT: Morality Lessons; Democracy 101
description: Central to the life of a just community is public discussion of issues that affect students. Through such discussion, students are supposed to listen to others and learn to appreciate their perspectives. Ann Higgins, one of the Harvard University researchers supervising the just community program, says these are both prerequisites for moral development. The resolution of a particular issue by voting may not satisfy all parties involved, as seen in the following exchange within the R.C.S. community at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx. But that is often the case in the democratic process - which is part of the lesson the just community teaches.

title:
RECORDINGS;
A New Wave of Interest For a Beguiling Melodist
description: LEAD: Although Antonin Dvorak was rescued from the butcher's trade to pursue a career that led to the highest musical circles of Vienna, London and New York, he remained ''just an ordinary Czech musician,'' as he put it, a simple peasant at heart, whose favorite pastime was visiting railway stations and switching yards for a bit of ''loco spotting.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the funeral of Zita, Austria's last Empress, referred incorrectly in some editions to the heir to the Austrian throne who was killed at Sarajevo in 1914. He was Archduke Franz Ferdinand.

title:
MUSIC;
Volunteers Keep Alive G & S
description: LEAD: Once or twice a week, from September through May, a dentist, an accountant, a homemaker, two lawyers, a computer programmer, several secretaries, a retired shipping company executive and representatives of several other professions get together in various locations to sing, act and dance. This phenomenon, which has been going on for 52 years, is called the Ridgewood Gilbert & Sullivan Opera

title: Catholic-School Merger Talks
description: LEAD: ARCHBISHOP STEPINAC in White Plains and Maria Regina in Hartsdale, the two single-sex high schools in Westchester sponsored by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, are considering a merger, possibly as early as September next year.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Louisville
description: Stand alongside Jean Dubuffet's dancing figures atop the steps of the Kentucky Center for the Arts and look around. There is hardly a better way to grasp what's happening in Louisville. From this vantage the visitor sees the city's belatedly developing skyline, a vista of black-box and mirror-walled towers and spindly cranes, punctuated by Michael Graves's post-classical Humana Building, a granite-and-marble work. A closer look reveals smaller, blocky Victorian office buildings - some carefully restored, others shopworn and dowdy - tucked between the newer towers.

title: SPRING REPORT: Morality Lessons; 6-Stage Gauge
description: In his studies, Lawrence Kohlberg, a psychologist and director of the Center for Moral Education at Harvard University, found evidence for the existence of six stages of moral reasoning. As Mr. Kohlberg sketched them, they begin with the stage at which people must have rules of morality imposed; they end at a stage in which people are society-minded, having internalized a system of morality, and can contemplate the larger philosophical questions confronting their community.

title: Marina Brandt Weds
description: Marina Brandt, a computer consultant in Montvale, N.J., and Robert A. Peirce, a lawyer in White Plains, were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Pleasantville, N.Y., by the Rev. Philip M. Carr-Harris. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Berthold Brandt of Valhalla, N.Y. Mr. Peirce is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Peirce of Valhalla.

title: John Muir Trail
description: To the Editor: I wonder if the article on hiking California's John Muir Trail from Yosemite to Mount Whitney (Travel, Jan. 15) has not left the impression that hiking any section of the trail is only for hardy hikers? I am certainly not one, yet in 1977 four of us did a lesser backpack, which culminated in climbing Mount Whitney, and we did it without resupply logistics. The men with us may have carried more, but I carried 40 pounds including my camera and assorted lenses and my share of the food for the entire trip.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Robin Truesdell to Wed
description: Robin Suzanne Truesdell and Jeffrey Edward Sher are planning an August wedding, Carolyn Truesdell and J. Richard Cheney of Houston, the mother and stepfather of the bride-to-be, have announced. Mr. Sher is the son of Rabbi Arnold Isaac Sher of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Judith Brav Sher. Ms. Truesdell, a daughter also of Leonard C. Truesdell Jr. of Carbondale, Colo., plans to begin studying for an M.B.A. in September at Tulane University, where her fiance is a first-year law student. His father is the rabbi of Congregation B'nai Israel in Bridgeport, Conn.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Beckett, Mass.;
Fluffing Up Jacob's Pillow
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION of new facilities for the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival is under way here, an example of the growth in tax-exempt financing for nonprofit construction in Massachusetts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 19 about the High Desert Museum in Bend, Ore., misstated the city's location. It is 166 miles southeast of Portland. A map with the article omitted the direct route from Portland to Bend and misidentified the mountain west of Bend. The road is U.S. 26; the mountain is Mount Bachelor.

title: Winds of Peace At Eastern Airlines
description: Frank Lorenzo agreed on Thursday to sell Eastern Airlines, ending his bitter fight with the carrier's striking unions. Under the agreement, Mr. Lorenzo, chairman of Texas, said he would sell Eastern for $464 million to a group of investors led by Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, and the company's employees. The proposed purchase could end a three-year labor dispute, which culminated last month in a strike that virtually grounded the airline and forced Eastern to file for bankruptcy protection. The deal is subject to the unions' agreeing to wage and benefit concessions.

title: EXPERTS CAUTION U.N. FOOD AGENCY
description: Two groups of experts have issued reports urging the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization to stop supporting radical third world demands that few nations favor and to take steps to improve efficiency.

title: Artistic License
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowd Counts Differ Greatly
description: Marches for various causes, like the one to be held Sunday for abortion rights, have drawn big crowds here in recent years, but estimates by organizers frequently differ from those provided by the police and the National Park Service.

title:
THE WORLDS OF SCIENCE;
BORN TO GET ALONG TOGETHER
description: LEAD: PEACEMAKING AMONG PRIMATES By Frans de Waal. Illustrated. 294 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: COLLECTING THE 20th CENTURY
description: One of Sanford L. Smith's favorite objects is a turkey - and in some people's opinion, that's the best you can say about it. Made to be filled with cookies rather than stuffing, this ceramic bird has survived more than 40 years; it is also so unusual as to be worth about $500.

title: Anne Cady Is Married
description: The marriage of Anne Payan Cady, a daughter of Ruth Payan Cady of Somers, N.Y., and Everett Ware Cady Jr. of Ferrisburg, Vt., to John William Keegan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Keegan of Thornwood, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. Jack Miller performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Mrs. Keegan is a production coordinator for the Reader's Digest Association in Pleasantville, N.Y. Mr. Keegan is a partner in the Mount Kisco law firm of Singleton, Keegan & Spolzino.

title: Headliners; Instant Winner
description: After the University of Michigan's men's basketball team finished third in the Big Ten Conference and its coach, Bill Frieder, took the head coaching job at Arizona State, Michigan's athletic director, Bo Schembechler, made a substitution. Two days before the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament began, he sent in Bill Fisher, an assistant to Frieder, as the interim coach of a team with a history of great talent and postseason underachievement. Last week, Michigan won the national championship, defeating another Cinderella team, Seton Hall University, 80-79, in overtime. ''If any of you will hire me as your ghostwriter,'' the interim coach told sportswriters, ''I'll retire. Undefeated and untied.''

title: A Thanks to Archie From Mamaroneck
description: I read with great interest the article about Archie Comics [ ''The View From: Archie Comic Publications,'' March 12 ] . The article was done very well.

title: Rebuild Herod's Temple? A Few Israelis Hope
description: Rabbi Yisrael Ariel sees himself as a dreamer, but most Israelis would not be so generous.

title: Dr. Gross to Marry in May
description: Dr. Sherry Lynn Gross and Dr. Jason Neal Pozner, surgical residents at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, are planning to marry in May, the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon Gross of Torrington, Conn., have announced. Dr. Pozner is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Pozner of Fort Lee, N.J. The future bride graduated from the Loomis Chaffee School and magna cum laude from Brown, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She and her fiance both graduated from the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Medicine. Dr. Pozner graduated from the Horace Mann School and Cornell University.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It will be a nes concept in aviation. We look at organized labor as our partners.'' Peter V. Ueberroth, prospective chief of a corporation to be called Eastern Airlines Employess and Service Company.

title: Review/Cabaret; Dixie Carter in Several Modes and Moods
description: Dixie Carter is a singer who seemingly makes good use of all aspects of her career, even those that didn't work out.

title: Of Sigmund and Minna
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Clacking of Tap Shoes In Village Gate Series
description: A new series of tap-dance performances got under way Monday night at the Top of the Village Gate, where every Monday this month Manhattan Tap, a talented young ensemble, is to appear with guest dancers and musicians. The first guests in the series were Charles (Cookie) Cook and James (Buster) Brown, two veteran tap dancers who are among today's most distinguished exemplars of that art form.

title: U.S. Sports Heading Overseas; PRO LEAGUES IN AMERICA EYE THE GLOBE
description: Symbolically and fittingly, a basketball painted like a globe sits in the locker-room-sized office of David Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner.

title: One Way to Beat Inflation: Be A Principal
description: The cost of a lot of things in education these days seems to be outpacing the rise in the inflation rate, including the care and feeding of your local school principal.

title: Emmary Allen Is Wed To Lawrence Carlson
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, Emmary Armstrong Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Allen of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Lawrence Bruce Carlson, a son of Rubydonna J. Carlson of Wilton, Conn., and the late Bruce Carlson. The Rev. Damian A. O'Connell performed the ceremony. Mrs. Carlson, a graduate of Hollins College, is a market representative at the May Merchandising Corporation in New York. The bridegroom, a senior special counsel in the enforcement division of the New York Stock Exchange, graduated from Bucknell University and the Washington & Lee University Law School.

title:
GARDENING;
Planting With Water Shortages in Mind
description: LEAD: AFTER such a dry winter and with a slim outlook for significant rainfall in the near future, this is likely to be a difficult season for gardeners. The time has come for gardeners to consider alternatives that will allow them to have an acceptable garden while conserving water.

title: CAN GORBACHEV FEED RUSSIA?
description: IN MOSCOW LATE LAST SUMMER, I DID as ordinary Muscovites must - joined a creeping line in a sour-smelling, meagerly stocked food store, shuffled for half an hour toward a poky butcher who mostly loitered with his back turned, and finally bought a kilo of fat attached to a sliver of beef.

title: 80 Nations Clear Way to Resume Trade Talks
description: More than 80 trading nations today adopted negotiating guidelines for textiles, agriculture, and two other areas, clearing the way for the resumption of suspended international trade talks.

title: Q and A
description: Interest on Down Payment
