title: To Most Potential Judges, $89,500 Is Plenty
description: To the Editor:

title: Katmandu
description: To the Editor: Perhaps Ms. Fleming didn't see any flower children during her three-month stay in Katmandu, but I certainly did last November. They are disguised as post-pubescent yuppies and ride bicycles around the city like maniacs. They'd put most New York bike messengers to shame.

title: Review/Concert; Euterpean Ensemble
description: The Euterpean Choral Ensemble gave its spring concert on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall, and as choral programs go, one could hardly have hoped for a prettier progression of works than those chosen by Philip A. Olsen, the group's director.

title: Portraitist Seeks Area's Character
description: LEAD: IT is not by chance that Caroline Gassner Kaplowitz used variations of red for the backgrounds of her 15 portraits that go on view today at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor.

title: Cara Marie Navin Is Wed
description: Cara Marie Navin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Navin Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Winston Moxley, the son of Dorthy E. Moxley of New York and Lake Tahoe, Calif., and the late John David Moxley. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rose of Lima.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Out of the Oil Spill, a Boon for Science
description: Nobody is happy about the oil spill, but, by and large, local residents do not share the rage against the oil companies that has been expressed by conservationists outside Alaska. Last week the Mayor of Valdez, Dr. John Devens, rose before a City Council meeting and an audience of townspeople to denounce harassment of pipeline and oil workers by demonstrators from ''the Lower 48.''

title: Photos Recall the Westport of Dirt Roads and Trolleys
description: LEAD: A PHOTOGRAPHY exhibit celebrating the 100th anniversary of the the Westport Historical Society provides striking testimony to the fact that while some familiar landmarks remain untouched by time, still others have changed dramatically.

title: THE SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME
description: The year 2000. Once distant and unfathomable, it now looms on the horizon like a monolith, a gateway to ''The Future.'' It is a year that will usher in not only a century, but a millennium. As arbitrary as these milestones may be, they are also seductive, luring creative thinkers into the speculation game: What will our lives be like in the homes of the 21st century?

title: Review/Dance; Baking Bread as Metaphor In Martha Bowers Work
description: Martha Bowers turns ordinary gestures into dances. One clever example of how she accomplishes this is ''Bread,'' the new work that her company, Dance/Theater/Etcetera, presented Thursday night at the Dia Art Foundation.

title: Two Pound Ridge Authors Picked as Favorites By Readers
description: LEAD: TWO books by Pound Ridge authors have won this year's Washington Irving Book Award. In the contest, sponsored by the Westchester Library Association, a nonprofit organization, readers were asked to vote for their favorites from a list of 13 recent works of fiction and 12 recent nonfiction books, all by writers who live in

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Parsippany Returning to Housing Focus
description: LEAD: OVER the last decade, a strong focus on commercial development has made the Parsippany-Troy Hills area the economic hub of eastern Morris County. Now, however, development in the township's 25 square miles has returned to a concentration on housing.

title: Grandmothers Bear a Burden Sired by Drugs
description: Already exhausted by age, poverty and heartache, the grandmothers of the drug-ravaged inner city are emerging as the quiet victims of the cocaine crisis.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Drake; Restaurant Bans Night Owls Carrying Books
description: Some Drake University students are being shown the door, not a table, at an all-night restaurant just off campus.

title: Touching All the Bases of Sculpture
description: ''What's in a name?'' Plenty - and all the more so if your name happens to be Bourgeois.

title: Canal Symbolizes Long Reach of Past
description: The Morris Canal was a great engineering and economic project of its day, a marvel of 19th-century inventiveness. Now, as New Jersey tries to plan its future in the 21st century,, the canal has come to symbolize the far reach of the past.

title: In California, a Brouhaha Over Pai-Gow
description: In a corner of the Bicycle Club in suburban Bell Gardens, gamblers raise a brass dice container over their heads, shake it, then smash it on the table to determine the first player. Domino-like tiles fly and dealers and players egg each other on in Cantonese. Pai-gow is in full swing. The ancient Chinese game, pronounced pie gow, was once popular only in underground clubs in the Chinatown section here. But it is now at the heart of a battle pitting Los Angeles County law enforcement officials against a curious alliance of municipal officials and casino operators.

title: Face to Face With the New Me
description: MORE THAN 40 years of looking at myself in the mirror have left me, like so many women I know, almost totally ignorant of what I look like. The mirror image I see is not a real reflection at all, but a composite of memories, wishes and half-truths. Photographs always surprise me. Because, of course, I never thought my nose was so long. I hadn't realized my lips were that full.

title: Review/Music; Organist In German Tradition
description: The exquisite sunlight last Sunday afternoon must have taken a heavy toll on the potential audience for Herfried Mencke's organ recital at St. Bartholomew's Church, but the tiny group that ventured indoors heard an hour of fine, unostentatious playing.

title: A CHILDHOOD SOUTH OF NOWHERE
description: BEHIND THE MOUNTAIN Return to Tasmania. By Peter Conrad. Maps. 232 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $18.95.

title: Miss Winchester And M. F. Burke Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Linda Susan Winchester to Michael Francis Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Churchill Burke of Watch Hill, R.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Marion Sullivan of Greenwich, Conn., and Dr. J. David Winchester of Clinton, Conn. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: 3-Year Term for Cross Burner
description: A white supremacist was sentenced Friday to up to three years in prison for burning a cross outside a black family's home. Judge J. Spencer Letts of Federal District Court told Gary Skillman, a 24-year-old former tattoo artist, that he had committed the most ''grievous crime'' short of physically injuring someone. The defendant had been convicted of conspiring to violate the civil rights of the family for burning a four-foot cross on the lawn of their Orange County home in July.

title: Leaving East Rockaway
description: I've finally made up my mind. After eight years of living in East Rockaway, I'm packing my belongings and moving back to Rockville Centre.

title: Images of the Sixties, Drawn from 'Life'
description: To some eyes the exhibition ''Life: Through the Sixties,'' now on view at the International Center of Photography, provides a fascinating and enlightening glimpse into a period of United States history that has acquired an aura of near-mythic proportion. For those of us who came of age during the 60's, however, its meaning is more complicated, mixing equal parts of nostalgia, regret and irony.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'A CONNECTICUT YANKEE' The Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam is observing the 100th anniversary of Mark Twain's ''Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court'' by reviving a 1927 musical comedy based on the book. It will open the new season on Tuesday and run until June 23.

title: Laughter - the Best Medicine for Stress
description: When Zanies Comedy Club opened in Chicago in 1978 and told patrons it featured stand-up comedy, customers would often ask, innocently: ''Does that mean we have to stand?'' recalled Bert Haas, general manager.

title: David H. Collins And Susan Wood To Wed in May
description: Nancy Blum Wood of High Point, N.C., and Dr. George Thomas Wood 3d of Hilton Head, S.C., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Susan Wendell Wood and David Harrison Collins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Harrison Collins of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: A Place for Dreaming
description: THERE always came the day when the sun suddenly warmed for real. Then, heeding voices that only children could hear, my friends and I raced home, shed our Mackinaws and earmuffed caps and retrieved from storage our bats, balls and gloves. The baseball season had officially begun, and for the next six months the game would be the hub of our universe.

title: Paul Taylor: Dances In Varied Vocabularies
description: LEAD: ''A dance,'' Paul Taylor was saying, ''should do its own talking.''

title: Just Another Great Power
description: What we are witnessing today in Russia is the break-up of much, if not all, of the system of power by which that country has been held together and governed since 1917.

title: Review/Rock; Roots-Tinged Sounds And Dance-Floor Style
description: The New Orleans Radiators should be heard from a dance floor. The band, which was formed in 1977, has perfected a sputtering, undulating, relaxed but insinuating mambo-shuffle-funk groove that goes straight to the hips. Long established as New Orleans's best-loved bar band, the Radiators have built a nationwide following with that groove and with arrangements that recall Little Feat, the Grateful Dead, the Band, the Allman Brothers and other roots-tinged rockers.

title: Abortion Marchers Gather in Capital
description: People began to gather in the nation's capital today for a march intended to counter a hostile White House and an unpredictable Supreme Court with a decisive display of public support for the right to choose an abortion.

title: Benefits Law Vexes Experts
description: LEAD: A LITTLE-understood portion of the l986 Tax Reform Act intended to equalize benefits for employees, which went into effect this year, will probably do little more than cost the Government money and create a windfall business for accountants.

title: Correction
description: An article Feb. 19 on Panamanians' attitudes about the United States misstated the origins of most black Panamanians. As a reader has written to point out, nearly all the black workers on the Panama Canal went to Panama from the West Indies, not from Africa and the United States.

title: RIGHTS VIOLATIONS IN ANGOLA CITED
description: Thousands of Angolan civilians have been killed by land mines, by indiscriminate attacks and by starvation as both sides in their nation's civil war have violated international codes of war, the human rights organization Africa Watch charged today.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article in the Westchester Weekly today about emergency rooms includes several duplicate paragraphs from another article. The misplaced passages consist of the first column and the first nine lines of the second column on page 8.

title: FINDING 'THE ZONE'
description: NO ONE KNOWS WHEN IT FIRST CAME TO BE called ''the zone,'' but if you want an example of the lofty, almost mystical state to which sport, at times, can grant one entry, you couldn't do better than this one, recalled by the great Brazilian genius of soccer, Pele, in his book, written with Robert L. Fish, ''My Life and the Beautiful Game.''

title: Jacqueline Parker to Wed
description: Jacqueline Lourie Parker and Stanton John Freeman, the son of Anya Freeman of Southfield, Mich., and Toronto and the late John Freeman, plan to marry in June. The couple's engagement was made known by the future bride's parents, Margaret Williamson Parker of Hoboken, N.J., and Jacques William Parker of New York.

title: Old Galway's New 'Left Bank'
Donald M. McGayhey, Lawyer on L.I., Will Marry Sarah Gambling in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Alfred Gambling of New York and Shelter Island, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Jane Gambling to Donald M. McGayhey, a son of Beatrice M. Dickerson of Shelter Island and the late Martin E. McGayhey. A June wedding is planned.

title: Lloyd F. MacMahon, a Federal Judge, Dies at 76
description: Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon of the Federal District Court in Manhattan died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday morning at White Plains Hospital. He was 76 years old and a resident of White Plains.

title:
GARDENING;
Planting With Water Shortages in Mind
description: LEAD: AFTER such a dry winter and with a slim outlook for significant rainfall in the near future, this is likely to be a difficult season for gardeners. The time has come for gardeners to consider alternatives that will allow them to have an acceptable garden while conserving water.

title: Many Sided Minds
description: When Howard Gardner, a Harvard psychologist, and his colleague David Feldman, a psychologist at Tufts University, began developing a new theory of intelligence several years ago, they thought of it as an academic endeavor only, a research project on how the mind works. And it was - but not for long. Today they are immersed in an ambitious program to apply their findings to children of economically deprived families, devising a curriculum that they hope could change the way these children are taught and encourage them not only to learn but to enjoy learning as well.

title: Reappraisal Urged for N. J. Transit
description: APPROACHING its 10th anniversary, N. J. Transit has become immersed in what officials and critics alike call ''crisis'' as a result of the agency's recent proposal to increase fares and decrease services to avoid a $55 million shortfall in next year's budget.

title: Education Life/Section 4A
description: A geography quiz, on page 24, is among the items on education in America.

title:
THE WORLDS OF SCIENCE;
IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HUMANS IN SPACE: 21st Century Frontiers. By Harry L. Shipman. (Plenum, $22.95.) ''Where are we going in space?'' With this provocative query, Harry L. Shipman begins ''Humans in Space.'' He does not intend to provide an answer, but instead explores three related questions: Does the United States have the courage and the vision to explore and settle outer space?

title: Steinbrenner's Blind Spots
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Homeowner Insurance Becoming Cheaper
description: LEAD: ANYONE looking to protect his home and belongings against disaster, burglary or personal liability is in luck, and those not looking to do so should perhaps consider shopping around in what is shaping up to be the best buyer's market for homeowner insurance years.

title: ROTTEN, VICIOUS AND SURREALIST
description: LEAD: LIPSTICK TRACES A Secret History of the Twentieth Century. By Greil Marcus. Illustrated. 496 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: Amanda Trager to Wed Joseph Fyfe
description: The engagement of Amanda Trager to Joseph D. Fyfe has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, James Trager and Mrs. Jonathan Altschuler, both of New York. A Sept. 16 wedding is planned.

title: Accountability
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Gorillas in the Mist 1988. MCA Home Video. 2 hours, 9 minutes. $89.95. Laser disk, $39.95. PG-13. Sigourney Weaver, ''trim, impatient, utterly confident,'' plays the naturalist Dian Fossey in a self-assured manner befitting a woman among the Rwandan mountain gorillas that Ms. Fossey studied for 18 years before her murder in 1985. Ms. Weaver's ''fine performance comes from the intelligent, muscular resilience she projects so fiercely.'' (Janet Maslin) Mystic Pizza 1988. Virgin Vision. 1:44. $89.95. Closed captioned. LD (Image Entertainment), $39.95. R. Three young women - voluptuous Daisy (Julia Roberts), level-headed Kat (Annabeth Gish) and wise-cracking Jojo (Lili Taylor) -pick their way out of girlhood in picturesque Mystic, Conn. The people - ''attractive and real'' - and the largely predictable situations are ''presented in an entirely winning way.'' (Maslin) Stealing Home 1988. Warner Home Video. 1:38. $89.95. CC. LD, $24.98. PG-13. The light is golden, the beach clean and the script stuck in ''suffocating sentimentality'' in this hazy tale of a boy helped through adolescence by his wise and worldly babysitter and confidante (Jodie Foster). ''The fact that the characters frequently change ages is only one of the film's staging problems.'' (Maslin) Tucker: The Man and His Dream 1988. Paramount Home Video. 1:51. No price suggested. LD (Image), $34.95. CC. PG Jeff Bridges plays the auto maker Preston Tucker in Francis Ford Coppola's jaunty film about Tucker and his revolutionary, ill-fated vehicle that shook up Detroit for a while in the 1940's. Beneath a sunny exterior lies a story of disappointment and failure with a wistful bittersweet edge. Mr. Coppola ''shares much of his subject's exuberance,'' making this ''the best thing [ he ] has done in years.'' (Maslin) Son of Frankenstein 1939. MCA. 1:39. $29.95. Boris Karloff lurches about the castle on his last tour as monster. ''Imagine, if you can,'' wrote one reviewer in 1939, ''a picture so tough that Basil Rathbone plays a sympathetic part [ the baron ] , so ghastly that Bela Lugosi [ Ygor ] is only an assistant bogyman.'' Crossing Delancey 1988. Warner. 1:37. $89.95. LD, $24.98. CC. PG. Izzy Grossman (Amy Irving) from the very-now Upper West Side and her grandmother Bubbie (Reizl Bozyk) of a long-ago Lower East Side are but two of the characters who mix into a film with a ''realistic, well-populated feeling and a nicely wry view of the modern world.'' (Maslin) A Taxing Woman 1987. Fox-Lorber Home Video; available through Tamarelle International Films at 1-800-356-3577. 2:07. $79.95. Japanese with English subtitles. Not rated. Tax cheats and nabbing same is the name of the game in this ''solemnly funny'' satire by Juzo Itami, the director of ''Tampopo,'' that is also a densely detailed essay on contemporary Japanese manners. Ryoko (Nobuko Miyamoto), recently divorced and mother of a 5-year-old son, takes a job with the Japanese equivalent of the IRS and turns into a cool and relentless pursuer of the delinquent. Mr. Itami ''is a man in touch with the passions of his obsessed characters.'' (Vincent Canby)

title: A TALE OF TWO CLOSET
description: Last summer I visited friends who had recently moved into a new house. Their architect had done well by them: The spaces were generous, the rooms lofty, the kitchen appliances had been cleverly tucked into the walls, and any surfaces that might get wet (and some that might not) were covered in granite, slate or marble. It was all very contemporary and upscale.

title: High School Sports March Toward Exploitation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Carol A. Cossum To Marry in May
description: May wedding plans for Carol Anne Cossum and Michael Maurice Maher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Joseph Maher of Malden, Mass., have been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. Richard E. Burns of Chappaqua, N.Y., and William Edward Cossum of Ellenton, Fla.

title: Answers  [ to Geography Quiz ]
description: Fold back to page 24.

title: Shaking Up Executive Compensation
description: Corporate executives who receive stock options and other stock-related incentives may soon find it easier to cash in their awards. Proposed changes that would relax the rules governing directors, officers and other corporate ''insiders'' who deal in their company's stock are now in the final stages of review by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should N.B.A. Stars Play in the Olympics?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Laser 3-D Lessons
description: Besides the subjects you would expect in an elementary-school arts program, like drama, dance and art, the elementary schools of North Bellmore, L.I., offer a bit of the esoteric: holography. According to its officials, it is the nation's only permanent program in grade school.

title: Correction
description: The About Cars column in the Sports Pages March 26 misstated the Range Rover's date of introduction.

title: 'My Work Is No Good'
description: WORKING DAYS The Journals of ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' 1938-1941. By John Steinbeck. Edited by Robert DeMott. Illustrated. 180 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95. THE GRAPES OF WRATH By John Steinbeck. Introduction by Studs Terkel. 619 pp. New York: Viking. $25.

title: Laura Lovelace to Wed Kent Guernsey May 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. Giles Edward Lovelace of Charleston, S.C., have announced plans for a May 6 wedding for their daughter, Laura Sue Addison Lovelace, and Kent Chapman Guernsey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Taylor Guernsey of Litchfield, Conn.

title: Cy Coleman Still Does It for Broadway
description: The interview is about a Broadway musical, but Cy Coleman is talking about money. The two subjects seem to go together a lot these days.

title: Let's Get the Contras Out of Honduras Now Lift Trade Embargo
description: To the Editor:

title: 3d Arrest Made in Miami Grocer's Slaying
description: A convicted cocaine dealer was arrested Friday night and charged with arranging the killing of a 51-year-old grocer who had led a neighborhood campaign against drug trafficking.

title: A Humble Beginning
description: On May 17, 1939, Princeton edged Columbia, 2-1, in 10 innings at Baker Field in Manhattan to sweep an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League doubleheader. At the time, virtually none of the participants had any idea that they had just taken part in an historic day in broadcasting.

title: Child Care Wars
description: The squat white building at a busy Washington, D.C., intersection is anything but impressive, but by most standards it is the very model of quality child care. The building, housing the Senate Employees' Child Care Center just a few blocks from the Capitol, is open from 7:30 A.M. to 6:45 P.M., accommodating the needs of working parents.

title: Making Mashed Peas Pay Off
description: When David Johnson, the chairman and chief executive of the Gerber Products Company, describes his management style, he uses the languages of art, religion, motivational seminars and the circus.

title: The Powerful Push for Self-Service
description: ARCO customers are an independent bunch these days. First, they pump their own gas, at pumps that have been designed to make the process as fast as possible. Then, if they are hungry, they walk over to the adjacent AM/PM convenience store and serve themselves a hamburger kept fresh on a special warmer since it was made several hours before. Maybe they pick up a quart of milk to take home. Only then do they deal with another human being - and only to pay for whatever it is they bought. Gas pumped, dinner eaten, shopping done - all in minutes.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Esposito Make the Right Move?
description: Two wrongs don't make a right. Trading a first-round pick for a volatile coach was the first wrong. Dropping that coach just before the playoffs was the second, and only amplifies the first. GEORGE SIDEBOTHAM Princeton, N.J.

title: Namibia Talks Proceed; Rebel Chief Orders Pullout
description: Negotiators from five countries gathered today to seek a way to stop the fighting in northern Namibia between Namibian rebels and South African forces and salvage a United Nations plan for territorial independence. [ As the talks were under way, Reuters reported from Luanda, Angola, that the leader of the Namibian rebels, Sam Nujoma, had ordered his troops to stop fighting, regroup and withdraw to Angola within 72 hours. [ Mr. Nujoma called on the United Nations to assist his soldiers in leaving the country, saying that they had ''nothing to gain by further loss of lives and the collapse of the U.N. independence plan for our country.'' ] Ranking officials from Angola, Cuba and South Africa, the three combatant nations that signed the political settlement for southwestern Africa in December, convened a special session of their joint monitoring commission today to discuss the rebel presence.

title: Chaplin, Inventing Modern Times; Spinning Reels of Memory On a Master's Centenary
description: What is your favorite bit of business from a Chaplin film? Charlie stealing a hot dog from a baby and, when he has finished it, carefully wiping the tot's lips? Charlie planting a fringed lampshade on his head and then standing rigid enough to pass for furniture? Charlie putting up with a 4-year-old monster until the room clears of adults, then treating the brat to a precise, rather refined, thoroughly deserved kick in the midriff?

title: O'Neill to Marquette
description: Kevin O'Neill, who earned a reputation as one of the nation's top recruiters during three years as an assistant at Arizona, was named Marquette University's head basketball coach yesterday. The 32-year-old O'Neill replaced Bob Dukiet, who was dismissed in March after three tumultuous seasons marked by player-coach conflicts and a 39-46 record. O'Neill spent one season as an assistant at the University of Tulsa before joining Luke Olson's staff at Arizona in 1986. . . . Dave Odom, an assistant at Virginia last season, was named the head coach at Wake Forest, replacing Bob Staak, who resigned last month. Wake Forest was 13-15 last season. (AP)

title: Crimes at Historic Sites Reported to Be Down
description: The vandalism and burglaries that once plagued New York City's historic homes are on the decline, curators and government officials report.

title: House Panel Questions U.N. Relief Effort in Sudan
description: An American Congressional group emerged from the Sudan and Ethiopia this week with sobering impressions of the United Nations effort to avert another season of mass starvation in the southern Sudan.

title: Headliners; Quick Cancellation
description: Pepsico Inc. thought it had hit the spot by paying $5 million to Madonna for a two-minute television commercial. In the commercial, which first appeared March 2, Madonna traveled back to her 8th birthday. A day later Madonna released her latest music video, ''Like a Prayer,'' which traveled in another direction. It was about a young girl struggling with feelings of guilt and sexuality and contained religious imagery. Last week, Pepsico said it had canceled the commercial because some consumers believed that the video was part of the Pepsi ad and not because of calls for a boycott from Christian groups. Said a company spokesman, ''When you've got an ad that confuses people or concerns people, it just makes sense that that ad goes away.''

title: Language Proves To Be No Barrier
description: THE winter sun is shining brightly and warming my back as I sit stamping books at our elementary school. Another mother is reshelving books and chatting with the librarian. Her English is tentative. She is Japanese and has been in Westchester only a few months. I hear the librarian's voice rise suddenly:

title:
SPRING REPORT;
As Easy As 1-3-2
description: LEAD: Amy Shimm, an American Civilization major at Brown University, remembers being ''the dumb kid'' in elementary school. Diagnosed at age 5 as dyslexic, she didn't learn to read until fourth grade, after extensive private tutoring in a multisensory phonetic method tailored to dyslexics. ''All I knew is that I had to go to special classes,'' she recalled.

title: Loyal Haitian Troops Seize Garrison Held by Rebel Unit
description: After more than 20 hours of often-ferocious shooting that turned the heart of the Haitian capital into a combat zone, loyalist troops this afternoon captured the garrison of a rebel army unit that had been trying to overthrow the Government for nearly a week.

title: Danish Pastry at the Source
description: ORDER ''coffee and Danish'' in the United States and you'll most often get a bready roll smothered in sticky frosting. But the crisp, flaky delectables known in Denmark as Wienerbrod (Viennese bread) bear little resemblance to what Americans call Danish pastry.

title: THE WORLD: Meeting Bush; To Shamir, Washington Isn't As Warm as It Used to Be
description: THERE was a moment Thursday as Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and President Bush were speaking to reporters about the results of their White House meeting when it sounded as if the two men were actually on the same wavelength. Allowing Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza to elect a leadership, they agreed, was the best way to break the deadlock and open the way for broader negotiations.

title: Party Animals Shine at Events
description: ''It all began when Louis Cartier went on safari in 1914,'' said Kenneth Watson. ''And then the Duke of Windsor commissioned a panther brooch for his wife in 1948, starting a sensation.''

title: UEBERROTH MAKES APPEAL TO UNIONS
description: Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner who led a group of investors into an agreement to purchase Eastern Airlines, said today that the success of the deal rides on the cooperation and input of the employees whose strike has crippled the carrier.

title:
SPRING REPORT: Morality Lessons;
Hear! Hear!
description: LEAD: Theodore Roosevelt High School on Fordham Road in the Bronx is a medieval-looking building in one of the city's more depressed neighborhoods. There, the unofficial rule of conduct for students, as one youngster put it, is: ''Don't look at somebody wrong or they'll beat you up.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Alaskan Spill May Curtail Summer Trips

title: These Modern Schools Work Day and Night
description: Public schools aren't just for kids anymore. Many of the newest schools have been designed to double as community centers, serving children by day and adults by night, often year-round.

title:
SPRING REPORT;
Silver Buffalo Reunion
description: LEAD: Our class officers called the 25th reunion of our high school classes of '62, '63 and '64 the ''Year of the Silver Buffalo,'' after the school mascot. We had all gone to Charles H. Milby High School near the ship channel in the east end of Houston. Some of our parents had been the first students at

title: Oil Platform Being Towed Off South Carolina Topples
description: An oil drilling platform with a 300-ton crane on top flipped over in heavy seas Friday, but a Coast Guard helicopter crew that spotted the rig today saw no evidence of an oil leak, a salvager said.

title: Child's Play
description: Just about every youngster loves chocolate, so what better way for children to learn about the world than from a chocolate bar? In classrooms nationwide teachers are holding up chocolate bars and asking, ''Where did this come from?''

title: No Depth on 'Wuthering Heights'
description: Of all the spirits fluttering over the moors of Wuthering Heights, the most restless, disturbed soul must be Emily Bronte's. Imagine her returning through the years, a ghostly presence hovering in movie theaters, watching what has become of her novel. She hears the audience sob and sniffle when Merle Oberon dies in Laurence Olivier's arms. She might cry, too, at the way William Wyler's 1939 film turns her furiously passionate Cathy and Heathcliff into star-crossed romantics, an overaged Romeo and Juliet.

title: STREETSCAPES: Sylvan Terrace; Restoration Leaves a Lot of Unhappy Homeowners
description: ARE the residents of Sylvan Terrace looking a gift horse in the mouth? Or have they just been taken for a ride?

title: Reviews/Dance; Serenity and Bellicosity In Jackson-Tanabe Bill
description: The exquisite can be compelling, but generally only in small doses. And the doses were large in ''Daimon,'' a program of new and recent dances by Kristin Jackson and Mariko Tanabe that ends today at the Mulberry Street Theater (70 Mulberry Street).

title: Even Wall Street Is Paved With Rust
description: America's $700 billion financial services industry is fast becoming our nation's next ''rust belt'' as Japanese banks, securities firms and insurance companies invest heavily to overtake yet another complacent American industry.

title: Fear of a Lockout Next Season Is Growing Among Players
description: The word keeps growing. It experienced another growth spurt last week. It's as if it has become a neon sign flashing brighter and brighter in larger and larger letters in front of the players' eyes:

title: Correction
description: A caption today on the Sports Highlights page in the Television section, distributed in the New York region, and a listing for next Friday morning give the day and time incorrectly for the Boston Marathon. It will be run on Monday, April 17, beginning at 11:45 A.M.

title: New Attention Focused on Pediatric Emergencies
description: LEAD: THEY are the calls that emergency medical personnel dread most: a baby choking and turning blue, a child gravely injured in a car accident, a toddler lying limp at the bottom of a staircase.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: JOHN HELD, JR.: Illustrator of the Jazz Age, by Shelley Armitage. (Syracuse University, $24.95.) By creating the image of the Flapper, John Held Jr. helped define the free spirit of the 1920's and made himself a millionaire. But styles changed, his fortunes crashed and he was left to start life over again. ''Those halcyon days of speak-easies, free love and jazz are vividly brought back to life,'' our reviewer, Al Hirschfeld, said when this illustrated biography was published in 1987. THE MYSTERIES OF PITTSBURGH, by Michael Chabon. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) During the summer after college, the son of a Jewish gangster mustJU decide whom he really loves: Arthur, a charming homosexual whose best friend is a biker, or Phlox, a beautiful born-again Christian whose previous passion was punk rock. ''After the recent spate of novels that seem to begin and end arbitrarily, with resolutions no more satisfying than a shrug, it is both refreshing and encouraging to find a writer who so skillfully sets down the elements of his plot, diligently sets them spinning and then carefully attempts to bring about both a climax and a resolution,'' Alice McDermott said here last year. ''The wonderful use [ Michael Chabon ] makes of each description, of Pittsburgh itself, [ is ] often astonishing.'' THE EMPEROR: Downfall of an Autocrat, by Ryszard Kapuscinski. Translated by William R. Brand and Katarzyna Mroczkowska-Brand. (Vintage International, $7.95.) In 1974, when Haile Selassie was being toppled from a half-century of absolute rule over Ethiopia, Ryszard Kapuscinski, a Polish journalist, was there to investigate his fall. ''The mentality of a dictator on the way out is beautifully evoked'' in this allegory, Xan Smiley said here in 1983. ''Mr. Kapuscinski has pulled off a clever coup.'' OSCAR & LUCINDA, by Peter Carey. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $8.95.) On a boat to Australia an Anglican minister and a teen-aged heiress fall in love and decide to build a glass cathedral in the outback. In 1988 our reviewer, Beryl Bainbridge, said Peter Carey shares with Thomas Wolfe ''that magnificent vitality, that ebullient delight in character, detail and language that turns a novel into an important book.'' It won Britain's 1988 Booker Prize. FLIGHTS OF PASSAGE, by Samuel Hynes. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) When Samuel Hynes's memoir of a World War II marine aviator was published last year, our reviewer, Diane Ackerman, called it ''a cross between 'Tales of the South Pacific' and 'Catch-22.' '' ''He paints a moving portrait of a whole generation of teen-agers, fresh from high school but still socially awkward and wet behind the ears, who were given planes and told to drop bombs.'' DOWNRIVER, by Loren D. Estleman. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) An ex-con hires Amos Walker, the Detroit detective, to help him recover the $200,000 his partners got when he went to prison 20 years ago. ''The dialogue is crackling, the writing is unpadded, and one can smell and even taste the city of Detroit,'' our reviewer, Newgate Callendar, said last year. RECONSTRUCTION: America's Unfinished Revolution, 1863-1877, by Eric Foner. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $14.95.) Reinterpreting the aftermath of the Civil War as a time of great awakening, Eric Foner lays to rest the views of apologists like D. W. Griffith, whose 1915 film ''The Birth of a Nation'' showed evil Northerners oppressing the noble sons of the South. With this ''compelling narrative'' the author becomes the ''pre-eminent historian'' of the period, William S. McFeely said here last year. PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Bantam, $4.95.) This novel by Dominick Dunne, who writes about rich people for Vanity Fair, is ''an anthropologically fascinating picture of Manhattan's high society in the 1980's,'' Kit Reed said here last year. ''The dialogue is funny and dead-on target.'' LIBBY: The Alaskan Diaries & Letters of Libby Beaman, 1879-1880, edited by Betty John. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) In the late 1800's, Libby Beaman used her social connections to persuade President Rutherford B. Hayes to give her husband a job as a Government agent in the Pribilof Islands, near the Arctic Circle. Surviving starvation and challenges to her Victorian upbringing, she wrote ''a gritty but romantic feminist chronicle,'' one reviewer said of the book, edited by Libby Beaman's granddaughter and first published in 1987. GOOD HEARTS, by Reynolds Price. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Rosacoke Mustian and Wesley Beavers, the couple Reynolds Price brought together in his 1962 novel ''A Long and Happy Life,'' find that their marriage is falling apart. This is ''superb storytelling by an enduring craftsman,'' Jill McCorkle said here last year. SPIRITUAL POLITICS: Religion and America Since World War II, by Mark Silk. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) Americans have struck a difficult compromise between religious pluralism and the need to believe that their own faith is the one that really counts. ''Many who read 'Spiritual Politics' are likely to agree . . . with the author's hint that we can best live somewhere between the call to exclusion and the lures of adhesion,'' Martin E. Marty said here last year. DEAD RECKONING, by Sam Llewellyn. (Pocket Books, $3.50.) After two disasters at sea kill his brother and destroy his reputation as a yacht builder, Charlie Agutter tries to track down the saboteur. Sam Llewellyn's ''writing is clear and effortless and the mystery carefully plotted,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. ''One can feel the sting of the wind, the spindrift, the little humans trying themselves against the elements.''

title: Land Preservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Rock; A Band With Roots In Genesis
description: Before scoring a No. 1 hit recently with ''The Living Years,'' a searching rock ballad about the death of a parent and its psychological aftershocks, Mike and the Mechanics seemed to be an insignificant offshoot of the English rock band Genesis.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling in one of our rooms is finished with sand paint. Some months ago, we repainted, and since then the seams have cracked and pieces have fallen off. We tried to fill in the cracks and repaint, but the ceiling has cracked again. How can I make small repairs to a sand-painted ceiling?

title: Traditional Thai and Warm Hospitality
description: IT is not a quantum leap from Hunan and Sichuan Chinese regional cooking, a recent rage in Connecticut, to the even more incendiary cuisine of Thailand. A new Thai arrival is King & I in Bridgeport, across from Treeland off the Huntington Turnpike. (Take exit 8 on Route 8.) As new and small as it is - just a narrow storefront with a tiny upper level - King & I was packed with diners on what are normally slow weeknights, and many of the patrons at the close-together tables seemed to be regulars. That hardly mattered, for the warm hospitality of the hostess and waiter made first-time guests welcome.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Cornwall, Conn. $370,000 Whitcomb Hill Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new contemporary; hot tub, solar heat, 7.3 acres; taxes not yet assessed. Glastonbury, Conn. $335,000 493 Tall Timbers Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; sauna, deck, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,338. New Fairfield, Conn. $300,000 105 Route 37 4-bedrooom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; cathedral ceilings and skylights, 2 acres; taxes $3,036. Armonk, N.Y. $365,000 13 Byram Brook Place 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, basement, workshop, den, 1.3 acres; taxes $4,656. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $410,000 181 Long Hill Road East 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; family room, new kitchen, wine cellar, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $6,012. New Rochelle, N.Y. $790,000 65 Overlook Road 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 80-year-old Mediterranean stucco/brick; master suite, 2 fireplaces, library, sun room, terrace, 2 1/2-car garage; taxes $8,575. OTHER AREAS Neptune, N.J. $164,900 108 Elm Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old Cape Cod; c/a, fireplace, deck; taxes $2,554. title: Cable TV Renews Interest in Local Government
description: LEAD: WHEN the White Plains Common Council sought public comment last spring on a proposal to build temporary housing for homeless families in a North Broadway neighborhood, citizens arguing for and against were heard by the more than 200 people who crowded the Council chambers.

title: How Can You Tell the People From the Monkeys in Central Park?
description: With the worst chills of winter finally banished, New Yorkers are again flocking to their parks. And as always, nowhere are the flocks so large or varied as in Central Park.

title: Q and A
description: Fall Honeymoon

title: Preventive Detention May Save Lives
description: THEY are two seemingly unrelated murder cases. One is from Morris County. One is from Cumberland County.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: CHILD ABUSE: THE INTERROGATION
description: Dr. Klass accurately describes the function of the interview in her article. The physical abuse of very young children can be extremely difficult to prove in a court of law. The usual case consists of two witnesses to the actual abuse: the perpetrator, who won't talk, and the infant victim, who can't talk. Therefore, the court must often base its decision on circumstantial evidence such as that referred to in the article.

title: STICKING UP FOR PROGRESS
description: IS SCIENCE NECESSARY? Essays on Science and Scientists. By Max F. Perutz. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: Prospects; Banks as Takeover Targets
description: Last week, the Citizens and Southern Corporation, a bank holding company, rejected a hostile takeover bid from another bank holding company, the NCNB Corporation, which recently acquired the ailing First Republicbank of Texas. While analysts ask whether NCNB can manage Citizens Southern, social activists wonder how advisable takeovers are in the banking industry. Four experts give their views. Walter Wriston Former chairman, Citicorp.

title: Liberal Party Backs Giuliani
description: Saying New York City needs a reformer to root out corruption, the Liberal Party yesterday endorsed Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, for mayor.

title: Ms. Gilmore Is Married
description: At the Chapel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass., Leigh Gilmore, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. George Don Gilmore of Chattaroy, Wash., was married yesterday to Thomas McClure Pounds, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Pounds of West Newton, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, who is the minister of the Plymouth Congregational Church in Spokane, Wash.

title: Capitals Win in Overtime
description: Kelly Miller scored 51 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Washington Capitals a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in Game 3 of the teams' Patrick Division playoff series.

title: Marlene Stewart: Costume Designer
description: In the music video ''Like a Prayer,'' the singer Madonna wears a brown satin slip and dances in front of burning crosses. Objections to the religious imagery caused Pepsico Inc. to cancel a $5 million commercial for Pepsi-Cola that featured the song. More typically, though, it has been Madonna's attire that has caused a stir. That is thanks to Marlene Stewart, a 38-year-old costume designer based in Los Angeles who has designed clothes for the singer's videos, tours - and wedding - since 1984.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Steeplechase 28-1 Shot Wins Grand National: Little Polveir, a 28-1 shot ridden by Jimmy Frost, took the lead halfway through the race and held on to win the Grand National steeplechase yesterday in Liverpool, England. Second was the 1986 winner, West Tip, who led for much of the race, faded and came on strong toward the end. Third was The Thinker, with Lastofthebrownies fourth. Last year, having jumped 25 of Aintree's 30 fences in style, Little Polvier unseated his rider and was unplaced. The owner switched trainers and the move paid off as the 12-year-old coped brilliantly with the heavy ground and a riderless horse late in the race to win by seven lengths in Frost's first Grand National. It was the second Grand National success for the trainer Toby Baldwin, who prepared Highland Wedding, the winner in 1969. The favorite, Dixton House, fell at the fifth fence, the Bechers Brook, on the first of the two 30-fence circuits.(AP) Boxing Fenech Retains Title, Then Retires: Jeff Fenech of Australia pounded out a unanimous 12-round decision over Marcos Villasana of Mexico last night to retain his World Boxing Council featherweight title, then announced his retirement. Fenech said he injured the brittle hands, which have caused him pain throughout his career, during the fight and had abandoned plans to seek a record six titles in different divisions. Fenech (23-0) is one of only 11 fighters in history to win world titles in three different weight divisions.(AP) Soccer Arsenal and Liverpool Keep Pace: Arsenal and Liverpool each won at home yesterday to maintain their battle at the top of the English League First Division soccer standing. Liverpool temporarily went to the top on goal difference after beating Sheffield Wednesday, 5-1, in a morning game behind a pair of goals by Peter Beardsley. Liverpool, 18 points off the pace five weeks ago, won for the ninth consecutive time. But Arsenal came back later in the day to defeat Everton, 2-0, on goals by Lee Dixon and Niall Quinn and regain the lead with 63 points from 32 games. Liverpool has 60 in 31.(AP) Golf Two-Shot Lead for Brown: Nancy Brown shot a one-under-par 70 yesterday to take a two-shot lead over Patti Rizzo after three rounds of the $300,000 L.P.G.A. Inamori Classic in Poway, Calif. Brown, who began the day tied for the lead with Laura Davies, made four birdies and three bogeys on the 6,042-yard StoneRidge Country Club course for a total of seven-under-par 206. Rizzo had a 68 yesterday. Martha Nause, who started the day one shot behind the co-leaders, missed a short par putt on the 18th hole for a 72 and was at 209. Davies had a 76, leaving her at 212.(AP) Booros and Donald Share Lead: Jim Booros and Mike Donald shot four-under-par 66's yesterday to share the lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Deposit Guaranty Classic in Hattiesburg, Miss. Booros and Donald were at 11-under-par 199 on the Hattiesburg Country Club's 6,280-yard course.(AP)

title: STAYING THE COURSE IN THE GO-GO YEARS
description: THE PRESS By Ellis Cose. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: Fire Warnings Came Over the Transom
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Put up a string trellis and plant peas. Finish dormant spraying of trees and shrubs. Scrape egg masses of gypsy moths, which resemble tan suede, into cans filled with a strong dilution of laundry bleach to kill them. Prune fruit trees. Lime lawns; if lawn fertilizer was not spread late last fall, then do so now. Last call to have mowers and other power equipment serviced. To a Robin

title: Rental Roulette On the Island
description: WHEN young couples marry, they vow to love each other for richer or poorer. On Long Island, this ought to include another clause: ''You will love and honor your spouse through good rentals and bad.''

title: A Style With Many Faces
description: SOFTENED MODERNISM? A discovery for interior designers perhaps, but architects have been trying to make modernism's hard edges gentler for more than a generation - although maybe it's more accurate to say that they have really been struggling with the question of just how hard modernism ought to be. To most people, the term suggests glass, metal and concrete, arranged in crisp, geometric shapes. But for much of its history, it has also called to mind something altogether different: soft, flowing forms and sensuous materials. In New York City, for instance, are the decorative embellishments of The Rainbow Room or Radio City Music Hall any less modern than the more severe geometries of The Four Seasons restaurant or Lever House?

title: Jodi A. Grossman Is Married
description: Jodi Ann Grossman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Grossman of New York, was married last evening to Herbert Evan Nass, a son of Edna K. Nass of New York and the late Samuel Nass. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ''MR. KING, YOU'RE HAVING A HEART ATTACK.'' By Larry King with B. D. Colen. (Delacorte, $16.95.) This is a nonbook. Reading it is about as intellectually taxing and about as informative as listening to sound bites on television news. ''Mr. King, You're Having a Heart Attack,'' written by the radio talk show host Larry King with B. D. Colen, a science editor of Newsday, describes in numbing detail Mr. King's heart attack on Feb. 27, 1987, his recovery, his continuing chest pains, his subsequent bypass surgery, his post-bypass depression and his eventual full recovery as a man reborn and reformed. The problem is the style and substance - or non-substance - of the book. If you care about the way a book is written, if you are sensitive to style and grace, this book will make you grit your teeth. If you dislike celebrity name-dropping and puffery, this book will make you snarl. If you have had a heart attack and want some practical advice, there are plenty of other books in your public library. ''Mr. King, You're Having a Heart Attack'' is written in what I can only assume was meant to be a folksy style, as though Mr. King had turned on his tape recorder and sent out an unedited transcript of every mundane thought that passed through his head. It is wordy, padded and patronizing. I was particularly put off by the huge quotations, pulled out in boldface that can take up an entire page, giving such pearls of wisdom as ''Your mind ain't on the thing at hand. Your mind is on 'Am I gonna live?' '' (from Mr. King's discussion of his fear of having another heart attack during sexual intercourse). On the other hand, you can whip through this little book in an hour or so, gleaning whatever advice and information it contains without spending too much time.

title: Unearthing A Roman City In Israel
description: FROM Egyptian times, at least 15 centuries before Jesus, today's dusty and unremarkable little town of Beit Shean has been almost continuously inhabited. Canaanites, Philistines and Israelites, Greeks, Arabs and Crusaders, have all come and gone in turn. An important new archaelogical site (opened last spring) provides a glimpse of this fascinating and complex history. In particular, the largest and best-preserved Roman and Byzantine city in Israel has been unearthed in just two years.

title: Madison Avenue Intersects With College Avenue
description: Recruiting advertisements for Fort Lauderdale College in Florida picture a bikini-clad woman studying on the beach. The Illinois Institute of Technology sends out promotional floppy discs and introductory videotapes. On the other hand, Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, Calif., mails out its ''junk mail premium kit,'' an expressly tacky pamphlet for high school seniors ''fed up to here with dull, repetitive, pedestrian college brochures, pamphlets, posters and broadsides.''

title: Democrats Call for Initiatives On Three Fronts
description: IN a sweeping policy statement, the Democratic members of the Board of Legislators called last week for coordination of government efforts in three areas where they believe the county must be ''challenging and bold'' - the environment, drugs and housing.

title: Katmandu
description: To the Editor: Thanks for Jeanie Fleming's article on Katmandu (Travel, Jan. 15). I appreciated the update on that city where I spent several wondrous days eight years ago - including one unforgettable night.

title: Review/Rock; Rock, Unfettered, by Throwing Muses
description: Throwing Muses have edged toward rock convention with their new album ''Hunkpapa'' and with the kind of set they played Wednesday at the Mike Todd Room of the Palladium. Many songs started with clear, catchy guitar lines and used old-fashioned rock rhythms; a few, especially ''Dizzy,'' have choruses fit for pop hits.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: University of Virginia; Fraternity Pledges Are 'On Line' in Rite of Passage
description: Ten college men stand at attention in uniforms, complete with berets. They speak only when barking responses to their commander's orders and they all have the sternest of looks on their faces.

title: New Sabonis Talks
description: The decision to allow professional basketball players to compete in the Olympics has cleared the way for the Portland Trail Blazers to resume negotiations to sign the 7-foot-3-inch Soviet star, Arvidas Sabonis. That's the word from the Portland president, Harry Glickman, who said that Soviet authorities had previously broken off negotiations until international officials acted to let pros to compete in the Olympics.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BLUEPRINTS Solving the Mystery of Evolution. By Maitland A. Edey and Donald C. Johanson. Illustrated. 418 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: 3 Seminaries Ask 'What Is a Rabbi?'
description: The question 'What is a Rabbi?' would seem to have been settled centuries ago. But at the three main rabbinical seminaries in Manhattan, it is being examined anew.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE AMAWALK OUTLET;
Humans Take the Bait as Trout Season Opens
description: LEAD: IT was opening day of the trout season and the humans were out in force. They lined up along the banks of the Amawalk Outlet here, waded - sometimes chest deep - into its 39-degree water, cruised by in cars to check out the scene.

title: Review/Theater; Introspection and Enigma In Everywoman Drama
description: Before the lights come up on ''Night Breath,'' a curious play by Dennis Clontz that is being staged by the Beacon Project, a medley of recorded folk songs is played as a sort of prelude. One of the songs is ''Wayfaring Stranger,'' and it pretty much sets the tone for what follows.

title: On the Urban Frontier, Clothes Reflect the Spirit of the West
description: Rough wear has become a design category, like evening wear or career wear. Inspired by the styles of the Southwest and by hunting, fishing and riding gear, such clothes tend to be made of simple, durable fabrics, often with brawny, visible stitching and a broken-in, one-of-a-kind look. They are the fashion equivalent of the Jeep Cherokee Chief or Stickley furniture: strong, classic, utilitarian and rooted in American industrial and craft traditions.

title: A Fair Helps Children To Understand Peace
description: FOR Linda J. Cleary of Ocean Township, getting through to an 8-year-old child about the concept of peace is not as difficult as might be expected. Last year, Mrs. Cleary, public relations coordinator for the Red Bank-based Monmouth Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, came up with an idea for a children's peace fair that introduced hundreds of youngsters to the world peace movement.

title: Soviet Writers Look Across A Big Gap
description: THE Soviet Union has never been among the 61 countries that have chapters of PEN, the international association of poets, essayists, novelists, editors and translators - and for obvious reasons. Membership requires adherence to the association's charter. And at the charter's heart is freedom of expression, open protest against censorship and efforts to free imprisoned writers.

title: Reporter's Notebook; 'Jane Roe' Has Part in a Drama of High Emotion
description: On a blustery spring day 16 years after her demand for a legal abortion changed American history, ''Jane Roe'' came to Washington today to march with the humble, the famous and the upwardly mobile, who were gathering to make a dramatic appeal to the Supreme Court.

title: County Volunteers Are Awarded
description: LEAD: VOLUNTEERS across America will be sporting a red ribbon in the shape of a V to celebrate National Volunteer Week, which begins today. In Westchester, activities will focus on honoring people who share their time and talent with others and on organizing possible future volunteers.

title: An Old Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridget Collins Married To Adam Howard Litke
description: The marriage of Bridget Anne Collins, the daughter of Mary F. Collins of New York and Daniel M. Collins of Jersey City, to Adam Howard Litke, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey J. Litke of Bloomfield, Conn., took place last evening at the Yale Club in New York. Justice Ernst H. Rosenberger of the New York State Court of Appeals officiated.

title: KEPPING EMPLOYEES IN STITCHES AND RAISING THEIR PRODUCTIVITY
description: Comedy's hip image, fast pace and young, upwardly mobile audience has made it an effective tool for corporations in advertising and in motivating their employees.

title: Tracing the Echoes Of Mallarme's Enigmatic Faun
description: In this centenary year of Vaslav Nijinsky's birth, one of the most original tributes is bound to be the exhibition at the Musee d'Orsay entitled ''L'Apres-midi d'un Faune, Mallarme, Debussy, Nijinsky.''

title: Visions and Prizes in a World of Quilts
description: MANY quilters today are stitching abstract or realistic art that is intended to hang on walls, but the basic techniques have barely changed since granny went to quilting bees. Most of the quilts in an exhibition from 10 countries at the Morris Museum here could still cover beds and keep out the winter chills.

title: A Correction
description: An Egyptian essay illustrating the March 26 column on the Farouk collection was retouched to show perforations. The essay, like virtually all such proposed designs, does not have perforations.

title: Becoming a Hi-Fi Detective
description: Not all topics warrant the full treatment, and once again it's time for short takes. These are mostly from our mailbag.

title: Capturing The Dreams Of a New Homeowner
description: LEAD: DAN FEW is the founder of The American Dream. The magazine, not the aspiration. As he embarked on the fifth year as publisher of the magazine for new homeowners, the former advertising salesman slipped into his gray suit recently and reflected on the voyage so far.

title: A Night to Celebrate Books
description: Tuesday was Literary Night in New York. On Park Avenue, Sonny Mehta gave a cocktail party for Lady Antonia Fraser, whose latest book, ''The Warrior Queens,'' celebrates, among others, Britain's Queen Boadicea, Catherine the Great, Elizabeth I, Golda Meir, Indira Ghandi and Margaret Thatcher - a formidable collection of overachievers, to say the least.

title: Black-Jewish Talks Produce Angry Clash But Some Hope
description: A conference here on black-Jewish relations broke free of the bounds of amiability at one point when some participants clashed over whether blacks had an obligation to denounce anti-Semitic remarks by other blacks.

title: Dana Stahl Is Married To David Mermelstein
description: Dana Marci Stahl, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin B. Stahl of Edison, N.J., was married there last evening at Temple Emanu-El to David Max Mermelstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon B. Mermelstein of Bear Creek, Pa. Rabbi Alfred Landsberg and Cantor Florence Merel officiated.

title: Correction
description: A table on March 12 listing Government suits involving accounting firms' audits of failed savings institutions incorrectly included Coopers & Lybrand as the auditor of First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Shawnee, Okla. The Shawnee unit brought an action against Coopers & Lybrand as the auditor of CB Financial, a private financial company with which Shawnee conducted business. When the F.S.L.I.C. assumed control of Shawnee, it inherited this suit.

title: Reviews/Dance; Multinational Depictions By Hanna Q
description: One of the maddest enterprises ofthe season took place on Tuesday evening at the 18th Street Playhouse (145 West 18th Street), where the Hanna Q Dance-Theater is performing through April 19.

title: With the Eastern Deal, Did Labor Finally Win a War?
description: THE union hall of District 100 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers in Miami was jammed with Eastern Airlines employees last week when word came that Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, had capitulated and agreed to sell Eastern to a group headed by Peter V. Ueberroth. The workers cheered and burst into the chant that had expressed union sentiment long before the strike that grounded Eastern and led it to bankruptcy court: ''Hey, hey! Ho, ho! Lorenzo's got to go.''

title: COMEDIANS WHO BECOME ACTORS ARE NOW TAKEN SERIOUSLY
description: As the comedy market has gotten hotter, so has the demand for top comedians by television and movie producers. ''There always has been a crossover from stand-up comedy to television and film,'' said Marty Klein, president of the Agency for Performing Artists, which handles Steve Martin and David Letterman. ''But the networks and pay services today are more aggressively locking up talent.''

title: Korea Takes Steps to Loosen Import Curbs
description: The South Korean Government, which has pledged to reduce a huge trade surplus with the United States to avoid the threat of penalties, said today that it planned to liberalize imports of 243 agricultural and fishery products over the next three years.

title: Soviet Georgians Continue Protests for More Autonomy
description: Thousands of Georgians seeking greater political and economic autonomy from Moscow continued to hold demonstrations and strikes in the Georgian capital, Tbilisi, today as the Soviet authorities stationed tanks in crowded streets in an apparent show of force.

title: Bills About Bills
description: The dozen-plus child-care bills that have been introduced in Congress to date fall into one of two camps: direct subsidies to child-care centers and payments to parents of young children, generally in the form of tax credits.

title: Debuts; Pianists and Flutist Play First Recitals
description: Tian Jiang, Pianist

title: Tongue Untied
description: Robert Fraga, an associate professor of mathematics who speaks lovingly of derivatives and integrals, thought his calculus class was getting stale. He recently found a solution - foreign languages. Now his students at Ripon College in Wisconsin are grappling with calculus problems presented in the native languages of Belgium, France, India, Japan and the Soviet Union. And when possible, they are translating, too. ''This gives them a liaison with other countries,'' Mr. Fraga said. ''It shows students that math is truly a universal language, while also providing them with a sense of national flavor. Math reflects culture in surprising ways.''

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Barnegat $124,000 5 Birch Court 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, w/w carpeting, family room; taxes $1,300. Jackson $133,000 37 Beam Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old contemporary; fireplace, dining room, pool; taxes $1,953. Neptune $164,900 108 Elm Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old Cape Cod; c/a, fireplace in living room, deck; taxes $2,554. Oakland $164,000 10 River Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, deck; taxes $2,254. Pompton Lakes $116,000 221 Ringwood Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 7-year-old town-house condominium; w/w carpeting, close to shopping and transportation; monthly charges $70, taxes $1,830. Randolph $185,000 197 Old Center Grove Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood floors, patio, fireplace; taxes $1,672. OTHER AREAS Glastonbury, Conn. $335,000 493 Tall Timbers Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; sauna, deck, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,338.
