title: Sweeping Soviet Law Pushes Property Rights
description: Soviet citizens and businesses may lease land for 50 years or more, sublease it to others and pass it on to their children when they die under a sweeping new law published in today's newspapers.

title: Terms Fixed for Pullout of Guerrillas From Namibia
description: Cuba, Angola and South Africa agreed today on terms for the guerrillas who infiltrated Namibia last weekend to return to bases well inside Angola.

title: Question Box
description: Aiming for 300

title: New President of Brown Inaugurated
description: Vartan Gregorian, inaugurated today as the 16th president of Brown University, took the occasion to assail ''the woeful inadequacies'' of public schools.

title: Bar Arabs From Mosque? Maybe
description: The Government is considering barring Palestinian residents of the occupied territories from Friday worship at Jerusalem's Al Aksa Mosque, one of Islam's holiest sites, to prevent rioting there, the Minister of Police said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our law's in jeopardy.'' - Norma McCorvey, the ''Jane Roe'' of Roe v. Wade. [ B6:4. ]

title: Gooden Salvages Weekend
description: The Mets struggled again today, but this time their lowly output of two runs was enough because Doc Gooden was pitching.

title: TV Notes
description: AIDS Fund-Raiser

title: Reviews/Television; 'Python' Alumnus Consorts With Sitcom
description: What happens to top comedians when they are successful early in their careers? Most go on to repeat themselves endlessly in second-rate movies and television specials. Think of Bob Hope or Dan Aykroyd (''Ghostbusters'') or Chevy Chase (''Fletch Lives''). On the other hand, Woody Allen made the transition from stand-up comic to accomplished writer, director and performer in an acclaimed series of films. But Mr. Allen is clearly the exception. The rule, not a very happy one, is closer to the case of Eric Idle, once of ''Monty Python's Flying Circus.''

title: Soviets Put Death Toll From Submarine at 42
description: Forty-two sailors died in the accident that sank a Soviet nuclear-powered submarine Friday, Government officials announced today.

title:
DIALOGUE: MILITARY POWER AND THE BUDGET REALITIES - THE CHALLENGE TO CHENEY AT THE PENTAGON;
Don't Cut A Winner
description: LEAD: In response to severe budget pressures and to a perceived lowering of the Soviet military threat, there is an emerging consensus that Pentagon spending either must be held level or reduced. The question before Congress and the public is how to meet budget goals while maintaining military effectiveness.

title: Talks on Trade Enter Final Bargaining Stage
description: The leading trading nations have flashed a green light for final bargaining in the postwar period's eighth and most ambitious set of talks to lower trade barriers.

title: 'Heidi Chronicles' Wins Dramatists Guild Award
description: ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' by Wendy Wasserstein, has been named the winner of the 1988 Hull-Warriner Award. The prize, which this year carries a cash award of about $11,000, is given by the council of the Dramatists Guild for a play that deals with controversial subjects involving politics, religion or social mores. Ms. Wasserstein's play received the Pulitzer Prize for drama late last month.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Books of The Times; A Warrior's Tale of Combat and Disillusionment
description: About Face By Col. David H. Hackworth, U.S.A., retired, and Julie Sherman. Illustrated. 875 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: BUSINESS IS DIVIDED ON RACE FOR MAYOR
description: New York City's business community, which twice overwhelmingly supported Mayor Edward I. Koch for re-election, is split on where to put its money and its mouth in this year's mayoral campaign.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Amoco Oil, to Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis, for its motor oil, with a $2 million budget.

title: Sports World Specials: Baseball
description: Driving Collectors Batty

title: >Sad Pasts Live Again on Train to March
description: Aboard the 8:20 A.M. train from New York to Washington, women told stories of going to abortionists in grimy back rooms, of friends who nearly bled to death trying to end a pregnancy, of unwanted babies, unwanted marriages and derailed lives in the days before Roe v. Wade.

title: Mtel Chairman Has Hopes For National Paging System
description: In 1973, John Palmer, an accountant by day, started an answering service in Jackson, Miss., as a moonlighting business. The service grew into a car-telephone business. ''It looked a lot more promising than doing tax returns,'' Mr. Palmer said.

title: Combine Minimum Wage Rise With Tax Credit; Weigh Business Impact
description: To the Editor:

title: Combine Minimum Wage Rise With Tax Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Sun Plans to Introduce Several Work Stations
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. this week will introduce several work stations, including a long-awaited machine that will sell for less than $10,000 and will pose a challenge not only to other work station companies but to some manufacturers of expensive personal computers.

title: RIGHT TO ABORTION DRAWS THOUSANDS TO CAPITAL RALLY
description: Hundreds of thousands of people marched in the capital today in support of abortion rights, carrying coat hangers to evoke the days of illegal abortions and waving banners that urged the United States Supreme Court to keep abortion ''safe and legal.''

title: Washington Talk: Districtspeak; 'The Causes ... Remain Under Investigation'
description: The Defense Department is always a rich source of bureaucratese. But there are times when it outdoes even itself. Take this missive from the Strategic Air Command, which was produced last week to explain what SAC was doing after escape hatches on two B-1 bombers blew off in training flights from Dyess Air Force Base in Texas:

title:
DIALOGUE: MILITARY POWER AND THE BUDGET REALITIES - THE CHALLENGE TO CHENEY AT THE PENTAGON;
Defer Key Weapons
description: LEAD: In response to severe budget pressures and to a perceived lowering of the Soviet military threat, there is an emerging consensus that Pentagon spending either must be held level or reduced. The question before Congress and the public is how to meet budget goals while maintaining military effectiveness.

title: Washington Talk; Limelight Is Elusive If Arms Is the Rub
description: As Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d prepared for his trip last last month to Vienna, where foreign ministers gathered to begin a new round of conventional arms talks, State Department officials were considering ways to turn the tables on the Russians.

title: Faldo Wins Masters In Playoff
description: Nick Faldo of England won the 53d Masters today by rolling in a 25-foot birdie putt on the second hole of sudden death to beat Scott Hoch when gathering darkness made it almost impossible to see 25 feet at Augusta National Golf Club.

title: Rhode Island Is Cited for Sex Discrimination
description: Federal regulators have found that the University of Rhode Island violated rules against discrimination in the cases of eight female faculty members, the university's president has said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMISSION ON THE PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Bullying in the Balkans
description: Only a cynical demagogue would recklessly inflame ancient ethnic hatreds for the sake of his own political ambitions. Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's Communist Party chief and thus the leader of Yugoslavia's largest component republic, has done just that.

title: Carving Up The Budget
description: The battle of New York City's five borough presidents to keep their power in a restructured government is complex, but they made it clear last week that it is, finally, a fight about money - who will get it, control it and be able to claim credit for having spent it.

title: Flying the Flag for the Inventor Not Named Bell
description: John N. LaCorte, president of the Italian Historical Society of America, thinks it is absolutely unfair that Alexander Graham Bell got all the credit for inventing the telephone.

title: Mistake-Prone Yanks Swept by Indians
description: Unlike in some of their previous games in the first week of the season, the Yankees did not ''stink'' yesterday, their manager said. But, Dallas Green quickly added, ''once again we made mistakes,'' and the mistakes led to a 4-3 loss to the Cleveland Indians.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; NBC Walks Into a Cable Minefield
description: NBC, the most successful of the broadcast networks, will take the first step toward its stated goal of becoming a major player in the cable industry a week from today with the premiere of CNBC, a 24-hour, consumer-oriented business channel.

title: Review/Dance; The Proceedings in a Bed Populated by the Restless
description: It is possible to be too clever. That was demonstrated Friday night when the Adaptors Movement Theater presented ''The Bed Experiment One'' at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Miss Silverman, A Student, Wed
description: Emily Leah Silverman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Silverman of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Keith Elliot Mostov, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Mostov of Groton, Conn. Rabbi Stanley Davids and Cantor Richard Botton officiated at Central Synagogue in New York.

title: A Walk on the Wide Side for Tennis
description: LEAD: CAN a fatter figure help your tennis game? It may when you are talking about new tennis racquets.

title: Biaggi Gets Farewell As He Goes to Prison To Serve Sentence
description: Former Congressman Mario Biaggi, maintaining his innocence as he boarded a plane today to prison, said that he served his constituents well and would return ''to pick up where we left off.''

title: Frances Eisenstein, Lawyer, Marries
description: Frances G. Eisenstein, a lawyer in Washington, and Charles M. Lehrhaupt, a lawyer in Princeton, N.J., were married yesterday at Temple Beth-El in Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Jonathan Z. Maltzman officiated.

title: Knicks Respond To Pitino
description: Somewhere in Rick Pitino's book on coaching psychology there are ways to motivate losing teams. And the Knicks' coach looked into that book after the Nets embarrassed his team Friday night.

title: Abbott Has a Rocky Debut
description: He had anticipated this day since childhood and now it was ending prematurely in the top of the fifth inning, four runs having scored, two Seattle Mariners hugging the bases. Even 20-game winners are occasionally forced to retreat the way Jim Abbott was Saturday night, but they are rarely comforted on their solitary walk from the mound to the dugout by a standing ovation. It was a gesture that Abbott acknowledged with a wave.

title: Mexico Dismantles Controls on Interest Rates
description: Seeking to open up the nation's state-controlled financial system, the Mexican Government has revoked the central bank's power to fix uniform interest rates and plans to allow commercial banks to set their own rates.

title: Tunisia Is Pulling a Democratic Rabbit Out of a Dictator's Hat
description: A frail-looking Habib Bourguiba emerged in public last Sunday for the first time since being deposed as President for Life 17 months ago. The 86-year-old Tunisian cast his vote in the first free elections his country has had since he led it to independence from France in 1956.

title: Undoing Dooley's Dictum
description: A burning issue in 1900 was whether the U.S could tax citizens of Puerto Rico, whose island we had won from Spain. Democrats said no, that Puerto Ricans could not be taxed without representation, that ''the Constitution followed the flag.''

title: Lyons Journal; For a Staid City, Neo-Gaullism With Gallic Verve
description: The mayors of France's staid second city are supposed to die in office. Until late March, Lyons was so politically stable that it had only had four mayors in this century, and one of them, Edouard Herriot, reigned for 54 years.

title: Dr. Amy Lynn Siegel Marries Eric J. Miller
description: The marriage of Dr. Amy Lynn Siegel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Siegel of Lansdale, Pa., to Eric Joseph Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Miller of Great Neck, L.I., took place yesterday at the Philadelphia College of Physicians in Philadelphia. Rabbi Dale Polakoff and Rabbi Louis Zivic officiated.

title: Eastern Talks Continue
description: Some union leaders were cautiously optimistic today that negotiations between Eastern Airlines' unions and representatives of Peter V. Ueberroth would produce an agreement that would enable the airline to resume its flights soon. The investor group led by

title: Bridge
description: The Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes broke the record for the longest continuous bridge event at 1 A.M. yesterday. The Guinness Book of World Records reports that four students played for 180 hours in Edinburgh in 1972. It is hard to imagine how they stayed awake.

title: Stock Markets' Role Grows in Chinese Economy
description: Still coping with a trading system that is puzzling to foreigners and Chinese alike, China's stock markets are likely to gain new importance as the Government proceeds with plans to bolster the economy by turning state-owned businesses into shareholder-owned companies.

title: Future of Debt Plan; Expectations May Have Been Raised That Turn Out to Be Beyond Reach
description: There is no quick fix to the developing world's staggering foreign-debt problem, despite the endorsement last week of a new debt-reduction policy by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

title: 31 People Hurt As Explosion Damages Motel in Montana
description: An explosion apparently caused by a natural gas leak demolished a 40-foot section of a motel early this morning, injuring 31 people, the authorities said.

title: Don't Disclose Air Terror Threats
description: Since the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in December, one question dominates discussions of airline security: Should the Government disclose terrorist threats to the public and let passengers make their own decisions about how to react? There are strong arguments pro and con, but on balance, the answer ought to be no.

title: Flyers Tie Their Series at 2-2
description: Tim Kerr and Dave Poulin scored goals off crazy bounces in a four-goal second period that carried the Philadelphia Flyers past the Washington Capitals, 5-2, tonight and evened the four-of-seven-game Patrick Division playoff series at two games apiece.

title: A Tear for the Kurds
description: ''Here they remain,'' wrote Clyde Haberman of The Times from a refugee camp in Turkey, ''yesterday's headline and tomorrow's uncertainty.'' That poignantly renders the unchanging plight of the all-but-forgotten Kurdish people, who probably total 20 million.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American National Red Cross, Washington, said Richard F. Schubert would resign as president, effective May 31.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Akzo Salt to J.W.T.
description: International Salt, a unit of Akzo America, has changed its name to Akzo Salt, and, in the spirit of a new beginning, it awarded its $7 million advertising account last week to J. Walter Thompson. Akzo's products include brands like Diamond Crystal Salt, Red Cross Salt, Sterling Salt and Salt Sense.

title: At Least 16 Killed as Protesters Battle the Police in Soviet Georgia
description: Sixteen people were reported killed and more than 200 hurt just before dawn this morning, when thousands of nationalist demonstrators in Tbilisi, the capital of Soviet Georgia, refused to disperse and troops with riot sticks moved into the crowds.

title: Julia Eagle Weds F. J. Cardo
description: Julia Ann Eagle, a daughter of Marlene M. Green of New Canaan, Conn., and Dr. Irwin J. Eagle of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Frank Joseph Cardo at the Governors Club at Phillips Point in West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Kalman Levitan officiated.

title: Dr. Annette Bond Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Annette Louise Bond, a daughter of Edith Bond of Christiansted, V.I., and the late Dr. Richard Bond, was married yesterday in New York to Dr. David Mark Roth, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Roth of Tappan, N.Y. The ceremony at the Sign of the Dove was performed by Michael Grupp, a leader of the American Ethical Union in New York.

title: Small Field Likely in Kentucky Derby
description: The 115th Kentucky Derby is likely to draw the smallest field since Spectacular Bid whipped nine rivals a decade ago, and for the same reason: Easy Goer is looking like the best American 3-year-old since Spectacular Bid, and no one is eager to challenge him.

title: Miss Bassel, Social Worker, Marries Dr. Alan Konecky
description: Joanne Bassel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bassel of Woodmere, L.I., and Dr. Alan Konecky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Konecky of Brooklyn, were married last evening at the Woodmere Club by Rabbi Joel Zion.

title: Campaign Matters; 50 'Wherefores?' And 'What Ifs?' Worth Asking
description: ''Ask me no questions, and I'll tell you no fibs,'' Oliver Goldsmith wrote long ago. He wasn't quoting candidates.

title: Big Dailies Think Small in Fight for Suburbs
description: In a struggle to retain major advertisers and capture new readers, metropolitan daily newspapers are going to war where the money is, in the suburbs.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Fleeing Group Is Killed by Subway
description: A man being chased by two carloads of pursuers ran into a Bronx subway tunnel to escape them yesterday and was killed by an oncoming train, the police said.

title: Court Upholds Drug Testing On Philadelphia Police Force
description: A Federal district judge has upheld the Philadelphia Police Department's new drug-testing policy, enabling the city to test officers when they are suspected of drug use or as part of routine physicals.

title: Ellen R. Zimmerman Is Wed
description: In the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden yesterday evening, Ellen R. Zimmerman and Howard M. Silverman were married by Rabbi Elezar M. Teitz. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Zimmerman of Elizabeth, N.J. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Silverman of Lake Worth, Fla.

title: Further Rise in Rates Is Expected
description: Despite a growing conviction that the pace of economic growth is slowing, credit market analysts see little reason to expect interest rates to fall soon. Indeed, most say that further increases in the current quarter appear likely.

title: With Water Low, Focus Is on the Catskills
description: The water that New Yorkers drink and bathe in begins its path southward in the smooth surfaces of the rock formations, in the smallest of cracks, and in the bellies of the creeks cutting through the woody hillsides, and even runs over the lawns and swooshes past the tires of cars parked on country streets. This is New York's watershed, that vast part of the Catskill Mountains that spawns the sometimes intricate, sometimes simple process of delivering to New York City its enormous water supply.

title: Reviews/Music; Frederica von Stade With the Chamber Music Society
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center always operates on a high level of proficiency. But sometimes one gets a glimpse of the ragged edges of this hectic week-in and week-out series played by musicians who have other jobs as well.

title: Making Choices: Exquisite Agony for Soviets
description: Soviet citizens today faced another facet of democracy - its uncertainty - and returned to the voting booth to settle runoff races in dozens of districts left unsettled in elections two weeks ago.

title: Ebbing Life: A Library Memorializes Egypt's Jews
description: As its numbers dwindle toward what some see as likely extinction, Egypt's Jewish community has built a library of Talmudic and rabbinical works dating to the 16th century and rated by some as the richest in the Arab world.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Y.&R. Ventures
description: James W. Hood will become the president and chief executive of Young & Rubicam Ventures, a new marketing consulting and investment banking subsidiary. The company was formed by the advertising agency after it and Paine Webber parted ways over their two-year-old joint venture to perform the same services. Mr. Hood, 37 years old, was the chief operating officer at the joint venture and second in command to Edward N. Ney, who has been ap-pointed the United States Ambassa-dor to Canada.

title: Composer Considers His Pulitzer, And Then Gets Back to Work
description: A few days after the announcement that Roger Reynolds had won this year's Pulitzer Prize for music, he recalled the day of the awards as an unexpected ordeal.

title: Treasury Selling 7-Year Note This Week
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills, followed by Wednesday's auction of a new seven-year note.

title: Tax Watch; Waiting to File Can Limit Errors
description: FOR the millions of Americans who are scrambling this week to get their financial records together and prepare tax returns, top professional preparers have one word of advice: Wait.

title: L.I. Woman Is Arrested After Firing at Officers
description: A Suffolk County police officer shot a pistol-grip shotgun out of the hands of a woman who had fired five rounds at the police, the authorities said today.

title: H. L. Foster, 83, Teacher and Horticulturist
description: H. Lincoln Foster, a teacher and horticulturist, died of cancer Friday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Falls Village, Conn.

title: New York Adds to Woes of Children in Juvenile Justice System
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: A brief article on Jan. 2 in the ''On Your Own'' columns of SportsMonday described a waterproof radio headband that could be ordered by mail. Some readers who sent for the product have reported that the manufacterer, in Connecticut, charged their credit cards but did not supply it; others say they received it. In an article today, state regulatory agencies offer advice on obtaining refunds. Page C11.

title: The Great One Is Now the Bad Guy
description: TROY VINCENT of Fort McMurray, Alberta, traveled 500 miles to sit with his cousin Wayland Hall high in the Northlands Coliseum on Saturday night. Vincent had watched the Oilers play in the Coliseum before, but not like this. He wore a white Los Angeles Kings jersey with a silver No. 99 and the name GRETZKY on the back. He once wore a blue 99 jersey, but that one is now hung in a closet at home, a memory of a less complicated time.

title: Washington Talk: Politics; Michael Oreskes
description: For members of the House of Representatives, there are good committee assignments and there are bad committee assignments. And then there is the ethics committee.

title: John T. Dorrance Jr. Dies at 70; Was Chairman of Campbell Soup
description: John T. Dorrance Jr., the chairman of the Campbell Soup Company from 1962 to 1984, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Bryn Mawr Hospital in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 70 years old and lived in Gladwyne, Pa.

title: Duke, 500 Miles Off Broadway, Is an Out-of-Town for Tryouts
description: Duke University has been giving more than its regards to Broadway.

title: Agreement on Budget Appears Near
description: After weeks of private meetings, negotiators for the Bush Administration and Congress appear ready to wrap up an agreement this week on the broad outline, although not the specifics, of a Federal budget for the next fiscal year.

title: Dimples Help A Ball Move
description: Golf equipment manufacturers tend to treat dimples on a golf ball the way the aerospace industry looks at flaps on an airplane. In fact, there is a relation between the two.

title: The World Cup Of Show Jumping
description: The 11th annual Volvo World Cup of the Federation Equestre International is part of a weeklong festival beginning today in Tampa, Fla. The event will include not only the 45 top show-jumping riders in the world, but also competitions for Arabian horses, quarter horses, carriage horses and hunters.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jamaica Tourist Board
description: Young & Rubicam/New York, creator of the popular and enduring ''Come Back to Jamaica'' slogan, has survived a change in Jamaican governments and a review by the Jamaica Tourist Board to keep the $10 million account it first received in 1981. Other finalists included Bozell; Scali, McCabe, Sloves; DDB Needham (a former agency, in the Doyle Dane Bernbach days), and Chiat/ Day, which withdrew before the deci-sion was announced.

title: Correction
description: An obituary and a headline on Friday about the death of Bill Gunn, a playwright, screenwriter, novelist and actor, gave his age incorrectly in some editions, as did a cross reference alongside a review of his play ''The Forbidden City.'' He was 59 years old.

title: Physicians Call for Dismissal Of New York's Health Chief
description: A resolution calling for the dismissal of State Health Commissioner David Axelrod was passed Saturday at a meeting here of delegates from the Medical Society of the State of New York, which represents 27,500 doctors and is considered the voice of the state's physicians.

title: For Both Buyer and Seller, Eastern Costs Are Uncertain
description: It is difficult to gauge whether the Texas Air Corporation's stormy three-year marriage with Eastern Airlines was a financial debacle or a modest success.

title: Fitness; Each Idle Day Requires 2 Days of Exercising
description: STAYING fit is a lot of work, some would even say an unending struggle.

title: Michigan to Name Fisher
description: Steve Fisher, who guided Michigan to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship after taking over as interim coach just before the national tournament, will be named coach of the Wolverines on Monday, sources told The Associated Press today.

title: Burglaries and Car Thefts Lead Increase in Crime
description: Automobile thefts and burglaries jumped at least 9 percent in 1988 as personal and household crime went up 1.8 percent for the second straight year, the Justice Department said today.

title: Officials Offer Sing Sing Prison In an Exchange
description: To help New York City relieve its overcrowded jails, state officials have offered to give the city the state prison in Ossining, Sing Sing, in return for one of the city's upstate jails, people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Georgia a Cruel, Proud and Abundant Land
description: Street fighting, disorder, cries for independence: the events in Tbilisi yesterday had roots deep in the hearts of Soviet Georgians, a people fiercely devoted to their culture and language and to a homeland that has been a prize of Russians and other foreigners for centuries.

title: Reviews/Television; The Ordeal of Couples Fighting Infertility
description: The miracle being sought by the four California couples whom we meet in ''Expecting Miracles'' is having a baby. Unable to conceive or bear a child because of some physical abnormality, they go through years of tests and treatments, for the most part with sadly unmiraculous results. The odds against success with in vitro fertilization, they learn, are 10 to 1.

title: Review/Dance; An Enigmatic Couple Turn From Boredom to Oblivion
description: The Marleen Pennison Company offered theater-dance that was slight but entertaining on Friday at the Triplex Theater of the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Divestiture Is Planned By G.&W.
description: Gulf and Western Inc., once the quintessential conglomerate with interests ranging from sugar to building products to movies, yesterday announced the final step in a lengthy restructuring that will transform it into a pure media and communications company.

title: Safety First in Challenge Series
description: LEAD: THE Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge fitness reception at 5:30 P.M. tomorrow in the bank's headquarters at 270 Park Avenue will look not unlike a typical corporate cocktail party. Perhaps more glasses will be filled with sparkling water than alcohol and maybe the crowd will be leaner but it will not be a place to chitchat.

title: Capistrano Swallows Excel at Pest Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie Gaberman and John Harkavy,Lawyers, Wed in Bridgeport, Conn.
description: Leslie Sue Gaberman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Gaberman of Fairfield, Conn., and John Brooks Harkavy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Harkavy of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday by Rabbi Israel Stein at Congregation Rodeph Sholem in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Texans Believe They Duplicated Utah Nuclear Fusion Experiment
description: A team of 10 scientists at Texas A&M University said yesterday that it had apparently duplicated a University of Utah experiment that appeared to achieve nuclear fusion in a jar of water at room temperature.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 A clash in Soviet Georgia left 16 people dead and more than 200 injured. Soviet troops with riot sticks moved into the crowds as thousands of nationalist demonstrators refused to disperse. Page A1

title: Peculiar Weather Depletes Farmers' Harvest of Maple Sap for Syrup
description: The balmy weather of early spring has resulted in a disaster for many maple syrup farmers in New York and Vermont, which produce three-quarters of the nation's syrup.

title: Sol Fishko Dies at 80; Led a Printers' Union
description: Sol Fishko, president of the International Printing and Graphic Communications Union from 1974 to 1983, died of cancer early yesterday in his Manhattan apartment, his daughter said. He was 80 years old.

title: Justice and the Public
description: Lobbying the Supreme Court is considered very bad form, as the superlawyer Thomas G. Corcoran discovered in 1970 when he visited several justices, all old friends, on behalf of El Paso Natural Gas Company, a client desperate to secure a reversal of an adverse court ruling.

title: Rangers Swept Out Of Cup Playoffs
description: The banner was unfurled with four minutes to go in the second period, in full view of the Madison Square Garden crowd and directly in Phil Esposito's line of sight. It read: ''Time To Go Home To Boston, Espo.''

title: Karen Brandt, Student, And Kenan Onel Wed
description: The marriage of Karen Brandt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert J. Brandt of Lido Beach, L.I., to Kenan Onel, a son of Miriam Onel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Joseph Onel, took place yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Amos W. Miller officiated.

title: Bananas Can't Measure East German Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Combine Minimum Wage Rise With Tax Credit; Tax Credit Preferable
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; A Cry of Anger From an Enemy of the State
description: There is no glasnost for the dissident Czechoslovak playwright Vaclav Havel, who has once again been thrown in prison for championing human rights in Prague, and there is no glasnost in ''Temptation,'' the Havel play now having its American premiere at the Public Theater.

title:
DIALOGUE: MILITARY POWER AND THE BUDGET REALITIES - THE CHALLENGE TO CHENEY AT THE PENTAGON;
Arm for the Real Threats
description: LEAD: In response to severe budget pressures and to a perceived lowering of the Soviet military threat, there is an emerging consensus that Pentagon spending either must be held level or reduced. The question before Congress and the public is how to meet budget goals while maintaining military effectiveness.

title: Agreement Reached On Namibia Rebels
description: Cuba, Angola and South Africa agreed on terms for the withdrawal of 1,600 guerrillas who infiltrated Namibia last week. Under the accord, the rebels will return to bases in Angola under United Nations protection.

title: Developers' Money Threatening Northern Forests
description: The changing economics of the timber business is threatening to reshape the landscape of northern New England and New York State as it becomes more profitable to sell forest land for development than to grow trees.

title: Berryville Journal; Listening for Bulldozers While Seeking Serenity
description: It has been almost 40 years, 40 peaceful years, since subdividers and their bulldozers closed in on 25 Trappist monks in a monastery at Valley Falls, R.I., forcing them to retreat all the way to this distant corner of Virginia's Shenandoah Valley before they found the solitude that sustains their contemplative way of life.

title: Marla Schuster, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Marla Ann Schuster, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Schuster of Dayton, Ohio, and Palm Beach, Fla., to Michael Nissan, the son of James Nissan of New York and the late Grace Nissan, took place yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. Rabbi Lawrence Raphael officiated.

title: Board Members Challenge New School Elections Law
description: A group composed largely of school employees and politicians will seek a Federal court injunction today to postpone the New York City school board elections set for May 2, their lawyer said yesterday.

title: Military Flies Equipment for Oil Cleanup to Alaska
description: Military jets flew skimmers, booms and beach landing craft into Alaska today and commanders issued a call to Pacific bases for more equipment to clean up the oil spilled into Prince William Sound more than two weeks ago.

title: Metro Datelines; Syringe Case Suspect Is Seized in Bronx
description: The police yesterday arrested a 38-year-old Bronx man who disappeared after his March 16 arrest, during which a transit police officer was pricked by a bloody syringe.

title: Desert Sun Sets on the Camel's Glory Days
description: It's a humiliating time to be a camel in Saudi Arabia.

title: Cable Industry Debationg Ways to Sports Profits
description: When the Cable Advertising Bureau meets tomorrow in New York, the discussion panel on sports is likely to be well attended. As the cost of sports rights continues to rise, cable operators and programmers are focusing on how best to profit from athletic events.

title: Owners Bewail Flood of Cabs In New York
description: After seven years of growth in the number of radio cabs on New York City streets, the taxi industry finds itself awash in cabs, and owners and drivers are asking city officials to limit who gains entry to the market.

title: A Patchwork of Responsibilities Marks Kennedy Airport Security
description: Last week, Pan American World Airways began putting all its passengers leaving Kennedy International Airport through a brief interrogation that is seldom experienced at American airports. As a means of preventing a terrorist bombing, trained agents now ask passengers details about the baggage they plan to check.

title: Sports World Specials: Tennis; A Russian Is Thinking Big Red (Mercedes)
description: Natalya Zvereva, the tennis player who just might emerge as the Soviet Union's answer to Steffi Graf, is just 17 years old and already ranked ninth in the world.

title: Davis Cup; McEnroe's Back and So Is U.S. Team
description: Five years ago, the United States Davis Cup fortunes sagged under the weight of ''the letter,'' a reaffirmation of sportsmanship that John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors would not sign. In 1987, when the Americans lost to West Germany in Hartford, they suffered the embarrassment of being dropped from the World Group in cup play to the equivalent of the minor leagues.

title: Rome Prize Fellowships Are Announced
description: The American Academy in Rome, which has served as campus to some of this country's best-known talents since its founding in 1894, has announced the 24 winners of its 1989-90 Rome Prize Fellowships in the fine arts and humanities.

title: South Korea's Open Market Plan
description: In a move to ease mounting pressure from the United States, South Korea has announced a three-year plan to open its market to 243 foreign agricultural and fishery products by 1991.

title: Sarah Sheon Wed To J. C. Gerecke
description: Sarah Lynn Sheon was married yesterday to Jeffrey Charles Gerecke at the National Arts Club in New York. Jean Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union, officiated.

title: Waterford Chief Resigns
description: The chairman of the financially troubled Waterford Glass Group P.L.C. resigned today after an audit showed that accounting errors were made at the crystal and glass manufacturer.

title: Outdoors: An Early Shutout
description: ED VAN PUT did his best to put a trout on my line, even providing me with two peacock herl nymphs ribbed with silver tinsel and wearing bibs of brown hackle, but I foiled his plans.

title: First Novelists With Six-Figure Contracts
description: In a major break with custom, book publishers are paying high five- and six-figure sums for many first novels, often in fiercely competitive auctions. And in what critics call the equivalent of offering superstar contracts to sandlot baseball players, they are dangling lucrative multi-book contracts in front of the previously unpublished novelists.

title: Scratchings of Spring
description: A man who has seen many springs likes to pick out new pleasures each year at this time, such as the arrival of melodious fox sparrow flocks, sportively reddish and speckled with white. They scratch noisily in the dead leaves for seeds and bugs, sometimes with both feet at once (jumping repeatedly to accomplish this), and turn the pine trees into a twittering aviary before heading north toward Quebec.

title: Metro Datelines; One Killed, Two Hurt By Queens Gunman
description: A 34-year-old Queens man was shot and killed last night by a gunman who also wounded two men standing nearby, the police said.

title: Reviews/Music; A Canadian Orchestra as Metaphor for Its City, Ottawa
description: When we think about Canada's orchestras, it is usually the excellent Toronto Symphony or the newly risen Montreal. An ensemble from another major Canadian city returned to Carnegie Hall on Friday night: Ottawa's National Arts Center Orchestra, conducted by Gabriel Chmura.

title: Fires Damage Two Clinics Women in Florida
description: The second fire in 10 days destroyed the remaining shell of this city's only abortion clinic early this morning.

title: Soviet Return to 1917?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Tensions Simmering 3 Months After Violence
description: Three months after rioting broke out in black sections here, Miami is still suffering the aftershocks of the violence and is bracing for the possibility of more disturbances this summer.

title: Scowcroft Sees No Shift In Bush's Soviet Policy
description: Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, said today that the West had the upper hand in dealing with the Soviet Union despite the initiatives of the Gorbachev years and that it would be wrong to advocate ''sharp, dramatic changes'' in United States policy.

title: Advice on Radio-Headband Purchase
description: An article in this space Jan. 2 described a waterproof radio headband for swimmers that could be ordered by mail. Some readers who ordered the product have sinde reported that the manufacturer, in Connecticut, charged their credit cards but did not supply it; others say they received it.

title: Daley's Election Daunts Hopes of Chicago Blacks
description: As Mayor-elect Richard M. Daley begins planning inaugural celebrations and assembling his administration, much of black Chicago is taking a gloomy view of the prospects for the future.

title: Results Plus
description: Running Irishman Wins Half-Marathon: Brian Ronan of Ireland led all the way yesterday in winning the Queens Half-Marathon in 1 hour 8 minutes 39 seconds. John Cantrell of Queens Village finished second in the 13.1-mile race in 1:10:51. Laura Taylor of Bayside, Queens, was the first women's finisher in 1:32:12.(AP) Horse Racing Banker's Lady First: Banker's Lady, making her first start since winning the Ladies Handicap last Nov. 20, remained undefeated on the dirt when she scored a 5 1/4-length victory over Aptostar in the $114,000 Bed o' Roses Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. The winner, a 4-year-old Nijinsky II filly, ran the mile in 1:35 2/5 under Angel Cordero Jr. and paid $3.40 for $2 to win as the favorite. Aptostar ran well to be second, 4 1/2 lengths clear of Avie's Gal. Auto Racing Wallace Edges Waltrip: Rusty Wallace held off a late charge by Darrell Waltrip, beating the 10-time winner at the Bristol International Raceway in Tennessee to the finish line by three-car lengths yesterday and capture the $418,367 Valleydale Meats 500. (AP) Rowing Columbia Triumphs: Columbia's varsity heavyweight crew defeated M.I.T. on the Harlem River yesterday to regain the Alumni Cup for the first time since 1984. The Columbia varsity, guided by Scott MacCormack, a senior in his second race as stroke, settled at a 35-stroke cadence for the body of the 2,000-meter course. M.I.T. had gained an initial seat lead at the start, but then gave away distance to Columbia. The Lions, ahead by a full boat length at 1,250 meters, stretched that lead to one and one-half boat lengths at 1,500 meters, when M.I.T. lifted its cadence to 36 in an attempt to get back in the contest. M.I.T. moved but could not overtake Columbia, losing by 3.2 seconds. Columbia's winning time was 6 minutes 2.4 seconds. Polo Skidmore Takes Title: The Skidmore College women's team won the United States Polo Association national collegiate championship Saturday in Fort Worth by defeating Colorado State, 19-13. Golf Victory for Rizzo: Patti Rizzo overcame three bogeys with five birdies for a 69 and a victory by two strokes in the Ladies Professional Golf Association Inamori Classic yesterday at Poway, Calif. Rizzo, who earned $45,000, had a seven-under-par 277 total on the Stone Ridge course. (AP)

title: Sunrise Paper in New York Suburbs
description: Westchester Rockland Newspapers Inc., owned by the Gannett Company, has introduced its first morning edition to serve areas of the Bronx and Westchester and Putnam Counties.

title: Swiss Bank Turns Aggressive
description: Rainer E. Gut, the chairman of Credit Suisse, Switzerland's third-largest bank, squirmed the other day when a visitor described his bank as aggressive.

title: Judy Licht Weds Richard Tempchin
description: Judy Joan Licht, a freelance writer, and Richard Scott Tempchin, the manager of customer services and marketing at the Edison Electric Institute, both in Washington, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Providence, R.I. Rabbi Daniel H. Liben performed the ceremony.

title: For Valdez, a Tide of Newcomers Seeking Work
description: Old-timers here have begun locking their doors and complaining about traffic. The oil spill, it seems, has given Valdez all the characteristics of a boom town.

title: Graf Easily Beats Zvereva for Title
description: At set and match point, Natalya Zvereva gave a disconsolate shrug and arched into her final serve of the match as if she already knew it was going to be her final serve of the match. The serve was good, but Steffi Graf's return was better, a fact that so little surprised Zvereva that she stood immobile on the baseline and let the ball pass her by.

title: Market Place; Behind the Latest Takeover Surge
description: WITH Wall Street bankers and corporate raiders apparently convinced that lawmakers in Washington will not move to curb takeover activity, the number of attempted takeovers, mergers and other restructurings has jumped sharply in recent days.

title: Sports of The Times; Masters Ignored the Weather Forecast
description: NEITHER wind nor rain nor dark of night stayed Nick Faldo from winning the Masters on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff with Scott Hoch, but the question will endure: With the weather forecast predicting late-afternoon showers yesterday, why didn't Augusta National move up its tee times in order to assure as much good weather and as much daylight as possible?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bloom Brings Back 'Girl' For St. Pauli
description: ''YOU never forget your first Girl.'' Many beer drinkers remember that advertising slogan, which brushed against the boundaries of good taste with hints of sex and sexism. St. Pauli Girl, the German beer that for years used the ''first Girl'' line, suffered when it abandoned its appeal to boisterous young men. In a new campaign that makes its debut this week, St. Pauli is returning to suggestive humor in hopes of recapturing those young drinkers.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales ... March Friday Merchandise Trade ... Feb. Inventory-Sales Ratio ... Feb. Producer Prices ... March Industrial Production ... March Capacity Utilization ... March

title: A Russian's Visit to Besieged City Confirms Plight of Kabul Soldiers
description: A Soviet reporter today gave an account of a tense helicopter trip into the besieged city of Jalalabad that underlined the mounting problems confronting the Soviet-backed Kabul Government in supplying the strategic city with food and military supplies.

title: 2d Ekiden Same as the First
description: The distance was shorter and the weather was wetter. But by the time 300 of the world's top middle-distance runners had splashed their way through 26.2 miles of Manhattan puddles and potholes yesterday morning, the results of the second America's Ekiden were a virtual clone of the results of the first: another come-from-behind triumph for Ireland and another wire-to-wire victory for California.

title: Czechs Study I.M.F. Tie
description: Czechoslovakia's leading banker indicated that his country might seek to rejoin the International Monetary Fund after more than 30 years. Svatopluk Potac, president of the Czechoslovak State Bank, said on Saturday that the world's economy and political atmosphere had changed since 1954, when Czechoslovakia withdrew from the monetary fund and the World Bank after the Communist takeover in 1948. He said new banks would be set up in the country and its banking system would be overhauled to stimulate the economy.

title: Review/Pop; Waiflike Appeal and Caring for Underdogs
description: From its very first hit, ''Holding Back the Years,'' the English pop-soul band Simply Red has made music that is a cut more sophisticated than that of most English groups looking for inspiration to Motown and Philadelphia soul styles of the late 1960's and early 70's. And in electing to play three nights at the Bottom Line, Wednesday through Friday, with a different program each night, the band was clearly staking its claim to be taken as a heavier-weight ensemble than many of its peers for whom American soul is just a trendy fashion.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 10, 1989: >MONDAY Hillenbrand Inds Inc PS Group Inc TUESDAY Divers Energ Inc Minn Procter & Gamble Co Teco Energy Inc WEDNESDAY Caterpillar Inc Chaparral Stl Co Dayton Hudson Corp Hartmarx Corp Texas Inds Inc Tokheim Corp Walgreen Co Woolworth F W Co THURSDAY Ford Mtr Co Del Parker Hannifin Corp Universal Foods Corp Wisconsin Pub SVC Corp FRIDAY First Chicago Corp Flowers Inds Inc Lubys Cafeterias Inc NY St Elec & Gas Corp Shelby Williams Inds Inc UNUM Corp

title: Student Loan Marketing Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
3 EASTERN UNIONS BACK CONCESSIONS IN UEBERROTH DEAL
description: Eastern Airlines' three striking unions agreed today to wage and benefit concessions worth about $200 million a year as part of Peter V. Ueberroth's effort to gain control of the carrier.

title: Home & City Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chile Aide's Visit to Argentina Eases Enmity
description: A visit to Argentina last week by Chile's Foreign Minister is being described here as a turn for the better in the long-troubled relations between the two neighbors.

title: North Hills Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Westinghouse Gets Manila Bid
description: The Philippine Government today suggested a barter deal to settle a multibillion-dollar damage suit against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for a nuclear power plant that Manila contends is faulty.

title: 3 Historic Jazz Shows To Be Staged Again
description: Three historic jazz performances at Carnegie Hall are to be re-created in July in a series called Carnegie Hall Jazz Heritage Concerts.

title: Market Place; A Sudden Change At Campbell Soup
description: PEOPLE who knew John T. Dorrance Jr. say he was a gentlemanly, compassionate man with a lot of moral commitment. Many food-industry analysts were therefore saddened by the unexpected death Sunday of Mr. Dorrance, a former chairman of the Campbell Soup Company and the head of the family that owns 58 percent of Campbell's stock. He was 70 years old.

title: Some in Vietnam Military Indicate Doubts About Cambodia's Future
description: Vietnamese Foreign Ministry officials are determinedly optimistic about the fortunes of their allied Government in Cambodia. But some in the military are less hopeful, predicting losses of territory to the Khmer Rouge guerrillas once Vietnamese troops withdraw this year.

title: Airlines Benefit From Leasing
description: One kind of leasing that has often worked to the advantage of the airlines is the sale and leaseback of aircraft. Large carriers resell their new aircraft to institutional investors, sometimes for more than they paid, which finance them on long-term leases. Other carriers sell used aircraft to operating lessors, also at a premium.

title: Shevardnadze, Native Son, Goes to Restive Georgia
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister canceled a trip to East Germany and flew to the Soviet republic of Georgia today in an effort to restore calm after clashes between nationalist demonstrators and Government troops.

title: Ars Longa, Money Brevis in the Day of the Deficit
description: ''The problem of arts funding today is rather Pirandellian - two endowments in search of a rationale,'' Leonard Garment said with a smile. But he was serious. The arts and humanities, he was saying, can no longer take Government support for granted nor relax in the belief that there is ''assumed virtue for programs like the arts.'' The economic and political climate has changed and ''the people in power are saying that every marginal dollar has to be justified.''

title: Dow Jones & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $164,149,000, or $1.63 a share, from the January sale of the company's 17 percent stake in Continental Cablevision Inc. c-Included an after-tax gain of $64,491,000, or 67 cents a share, from the sale of the company's book-publishing subsidiary, Richard D. Irwin Inc.

title: Houston Biomedical reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Firan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Banponce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company had $101,000 in securities losses for the latest first quarter, compared with securities gains of $1.9 million in the year-ago period.

title: Savings Bank Deal For BankAmerica
description: After years of selling off operations to offset huge losses, the BankAmerica Corporation re-entered the acquisition market as it agreed to buy a savings bank in Tacoma, Wash., for about $68.6 million. BankAmerica will offer $30.05 worth of its own stock for each share of the American Savings Financial Corporation, parent of American Savings Bank, which has 22 offices and assets of $640 million.

title: Reagan Gets Bush's Apology for Remarks by Staff
description: President Bush telephoned Ronald Reagan last week to apologize for reports that White House aides were belittling the former President, White House officials said today.

title: Los Angeles Selects a Mayor Today After a Quiet Contest
description: In a political season spiked with racially charged campaigns, a four-term black Mayor is seeking re-election here Tuesday after a quiet, nonpartisan campaign.

title: San Francisco Drug Protest Follows Fatal Shootings of 2
description: Several hundred residents of a drug-torn neighborhood marched through the streets Sunday in an protest over crack cocaine spurred by weekend shootings that left 2 people dead and 10 injured.

title: Officer Kills Man Swinging Gurkha Knife
description: A police officer shot and killed a disturbed man who had menaced a dozen pedestrians when the man lunged at the officer with a large Gurkha knife on Manhattan's East Side yesterday after four officers were unable to stop him with tear gas and a stun gun.

title: 45 Years for Court Clerk's Killer
description: A man who feigned surrender but then shot at point-blank range and killed a senior court clerk who had intervened in a Harlem robbery was sentenced yesterday to 45 years to life in prison.

title: The Drive To Promote Kosher Food
description: THE biggest season for the kosher market is now, leading up to the first night of Passover, which begins at sundown on April 19 and lasts for 10 days.

title: Pacesetter Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $564,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change for both the quarter and year. The company's 1988 loss included $1,188,000 of increased offsite costs incurred in the final phase of a four-year development which is now complete. Also, the results included $600,000 of non-recurring legal, accounting and stock award costs associated with the company's spin-off from its former parent, American Pacesetter, last June.

title: Article 116789 -- No Title
description: The Grand Union Company, the 11th-largest supermarket chain in the country, is being acquired in a transaction valued at $1.2 billion by an investor group that includes Salomon Brothers Inc. and Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company, a New York-based investment bank that specializes in arbitrage and leveraged buyouts.

title: Hi-Shear Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a pretax operating loss of $2,900,000 incurred by the company' Hi-Shear's space and defense systems operation as well as lower earnings in Hi-Shear's aerospace fastening systems operations.

title: Chess
description: Fifty years ago, organized chess was played pretty much at two speeds, slow and very fast. For major tournaments, 40 moves in two and a half hours held sway, and then there was speed chess, either the European version with all moves in five minutes per player or the American so-called ''rapid transit,'' with a move every 10 seconds. Now, however, there are intermediate time limits.

title: Central Bancshares of the South Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter included $2,100,000 in gains on securities transactions while 1989 net income included an insignificant amount of such gains.

title: New York City Alters 2 Homeless Shelters For More Jail Space
description: With New York City scrambling to find space for its steadily rising jail population, construction was begun over the weekend to turn part of a shelter for homeless men on Wards Island into a prison for 300 female inmates, a Correction Department spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Peoples Savings Bank of Brockton reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the latest quarter loss primarily to a $500,000 increase in the provision for loan losses as a result of anticipated losses on the participation loan for a downtown renewal project.

title: Old Air Bases Ideal As Transfer Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal With French Bank
description: The Export-Import Bank announced an agreement today with a French bank to promote loans for the sale of American products in 18 African countries. The Export-Import Bank said the deal with Banque Internationale pour l'Afrique Occidentale, also known as BIAO-Afribank, would help American exporters penetrate markets dominated by European exporters. BIAO-Afribank, which began more than 130 years ago, has headquarters in Paris and offices in former British colonies, including Nigeria and Zimbabwe. The Export-Import Bank makes loans to encourage purchases of American exports, especially in third-world countries.

title: The Prodigal Son Becomes a Favorite Son in Tennis
description: The signs of change are not as readily apparent on the court where John McEnroe's facial expressions still make it look as if tennis is pure drudgery, and even a mild display of displeasure with a chair umpire or linesman prompts some fans to anticipate a good old-fashioned vitriolic outburst.

title: Ford Names Three Officers
description: Confirming reports of last week, the Ford Motor Company today named Allan D. Gilmour executive vice president in charge of corporate staffs, making him the likely successor of Donald E. Petersen, the company's chairman and chief executive.

title: Clairson International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest first quarter stemmed mainly from the operations of a facility in Garden Grove, Calif., which has been discontinued.

title: Disabled Foster-Care Youths Kept in New York Hospitals
description: More than 100 mentally disabled children in the New York City foster-care system are being kept in hospitals - in some cases more than a year and at costs of up to $900 a day - waiting for the city to find proper homes for them.

title: Merchants Bank of New York reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter's per share earnings were adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split of July 20, 1988.

title: Long Beach Journal; Alaska Oil Pipeline Ends In California Sunshine
description: Had things been otherwise, the crude oil cargo of the Exxon Valdez would by now have been unloaded here at the Port of Long Beach and turned into gasoline, fouling the air of Southern California instead of the waters of Prince William Sound.

title: Archeologists Discover A Lost Rival to Babylon
description: FLAKES of crumbling brick drew the archeologist step by step along the line where the wall of an ancient city of lower Mesopotamia once stood. The trail led to remnants of the south gate, and there on the ground lay a clay fragment bearing cuneiform inscriptions.

title: Bridge
description: After trailing for a full week in the Marathon Battle of the Sexes, the Women's Team regained the lead from their male opponents at 7 A.M. Sunday. This was on Board 1303 of a match that will end Saturday at Board 2352, and by 11 A.M. Monday the women had extended their lead to 31 imps. But this is a very small margin in a match of such length. Play is at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan and the Club du Bridgeur in Paris. Charitable contributions at the American end total about $10,000 so far.

title: L.I. Town's Waste Crisis: Burn or Recycle?
description: Rand A. Burgner is haunted by the specter of the garbage barge Mobro, which turned Long Island's solid-waste crisis into a national embarrassment two years ago when no one would accept its trash.

title: U.S. Checked Private Data For Business
description: Dorcas R. Hardy, Commissioner of the Social Security Administration, told a Congressional committee today that the agency had verified millions of Social Security numbers for private credit companies.

title: Raymond Doop, 91, Store-Chain Executive
description: Raymond C. Doop, a former vice president of the Montaldo Corporation, a chain of fashion specialty shops with its headquarters in Manhattan, died Saturday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla., after a long illness. He was 91 years old.

title: BUSH TO ANNOUNCE ETHICS PROPOSAL
description: In an apparent attempt to seek Congressional favor and avoid a confrontation, President Bush plans to introduce a package of ethics legislation that does not include a ban on lawmakers accepting payments for speeches and public appearances, White House officials said today.

title: More Than Attitude Must Change in Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about John T. Dorrance Jr., former chairman of the Campbell Soup Company, misstated one of his affiliations. He was chairman of the Philadelphia Museum of Art at his death on Sunday, not former chairman.

title: Statewide Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Process to Reduce Cholesterol in Milk
description: SCIENTISTS at Cornell University say they have developed a commercially feasible process to remove up to 90 percent of the cholesterol and reduce the amount of saturated fats in milk, without significantly changing its taste.

title: Electro-Catheter reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: 4 of 5 Men Are Convicted In '83 Wells Fargo Robbery
description: Four Puerto Rican nationalists were convicted today on charges stemming from the robbery of $7.1 million from a Wells Fargo depot in West Hartford in 1983. A fifth defendant was acquitted.

title: Subtle but Intriguing Differences Found In the Brain Anatomy of Men and Women
description: RESEARCHERS who study the brain have discovered that it differs anatomically in men and women in ways that may underlie differences in mental abilities.

title: Sheldahl Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $1,004,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: China Reports Attack On American Student
description: An American student is in critical condition with a broken neckbone after being attacked on a tourist vessel on the Yangtze River, The People's Daily said today.

title: NHD Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Pentagon Fraud Case Goes to Jury
description: A Federal jury began deliberations today in the first trial to result from the Government's ''Ill Wind'' investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud.

title: Topics of The Times; Good Natured in the City
description: A lapsed New Yorker, returning to the city after years in the country, finds himself reaching for signs of nature - tulips in a doorway tub, magnolia buds unfolding beside a brownstone, squirrels digging up acorns in a Peter Cooper Village lawn. But he also found nature reaching for him in unexpected ways.

title: On Horse Racing; Quality (and Spring) Slow to Arrive at Aqueduct
description: The quality of thoroughbred racing in New York is as mecurial as the seasons. In the dead of winter, the rejects of the American breeding industry slog through Aqueduct's frost-proof inner track solely to generate betting revenue for state coffers. In the summer and fall at Belmont Park or Saratoga, the nation's very best horses decide the sport's champions in its most important races.

title: Bush Camp Warns of Veto If Bailout Plan Is Altered
description: The Bush Administration tried to turn up the heat on Congress today, reminding lawmakers that making certain changes in the savings industry bailout legislation could cause the President's advisers to recommend a veto.

title: Gunman Opens Fire in Jerusalem
description: An unidentified gunman opened fire tonight with a submachine gun at an entrance to the Old City, killing one Arab and wounding three, the police said.

title: Grand Met to Retain A Burger King Unit
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., which acquired Burger King as part of its purchase of the Pillsbury Company, said today that it would retain the fast-food chain's distribution company instead of selling it.

title: H. Kermit Green, 86, Former Water Official
description: H. Kermit Green, a lawyer who was a former chairman of the North Jersey District Water Supply Commission, died of complications from surgery Saturday at Mercy Hospital in Miami. He was 86 years old and lived in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: CBS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses on extinguishment of debt of $200,000 for the latest first quarter and $100,000 for the year-ago period. c-Included an after-tax, non-recurring gain of $866.6 million on the sale of CBS/Records.

title: Penny Stock Firm Charged
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed disciplinary charges against the Stuart-James Company, a Denver penny stock firm; its chairman and president, and nine present and former senior officers. The agency said that they engaged in fraudulent sales practices involving penny stocks in 1986 and 1987.

title: White House and Quayle Differ About Impact of Abortion March
description: While the White House acknowledged today that the march in the capital by hundreds of thousands of people in support of abortion rights Sunday was ''very successful,'' Vice President Dan Quayle appeared less than impressed by the turnout.

title: Bradley: 'We Should Be Rational Capitalists'
description: Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, at the St. Paul's Speakers Forum, St. Paul's Lutheran Church, Washington, April 9:

title: Mario Chiari, Costume Designer, 79
description: Mario Chiari, an art director and costume designer, died Sunday in a Rome hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Nepal's Economy Is Gasping as India, a Huge Neighbor, Squeezes It Hard
description: A dispute with India is forcing Nepal, one of the world's poorest and least accessible countries, to fight for its economic survival, a fight that is also testing its political stability.

title: Sodarcan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Interco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $36,225,000 for the quarter and $74,432,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Included gains from discontinued operations of $4,167,000 and $31,569,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said that earnings for the fourth quarter and full year were affected by significant costs and expenses associated with the company's restructuring, and that some of those expenses are not deductible for federal tax purposes.

title: Lundine Surmounts the Little Ignominies of Being No. 2
description: As Stan Lundine has discovered, life as Lieutenant Governor can be filled with little ignominies.

title: Hornbeck Offshore reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DeKalb Genetics reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Jersey Bid to Halt Rise in Commute Tax Fails
description: A Federal judge refused today to issue an injunction prohibiting New York State from raising taxes of nonresidents who work in the state.

title: 'Pushing From The Top'
description: The Pentagon has raised ''practical concerns,'' which some consider a bureaucratic smokescreen, that have slowed down the Bush Administration's proclaimed speedup in the removal of chemical weapons from West Germany. That suggests:

title: Haitians Hijack Plane to U.S., Then Give Up
description: Two Haitians hijacked a twin-engined plane taking nine passengers from Haiti to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., today, and were taken into custody after diverting the plane to Miami International Airport, airport officials said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Assemblyman Changes View On Abortions
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie, the Bronx Democrat who was barred two and a half years ago from speaking in Roman Catholic churches in the Archdiocese of New York because he voted to provide public money for poor people seeking abortions, said yesterday that he had changed his position and would now vote against such use of public funds.

title: Treasury Prices Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in very slow trading yesterday.

title: Minorco Lifts Its Offer for Gold Fields
description: Making its third and ''final'' offer to buy the West's second-largest gold mining company, Minorco S.A., the overseas arm of South Africa's Anglo American and De Beers group, yesterday raised to nearly $6 billion its bid for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Orchestrating a Decline in the Arts
description: LEAD: My world is that of the symphony orchestra. I entered it through the public schools of Washington, D.C., and I now work with one of the very greatest gatherings of musicians on earth: the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

title: Careers; A Program To Recruit More Nurses
description: THE nursing shortage continues, but at least more is being done about it, according to experts like Dr. Joyce J. Fitzpatrick, dean of the school of nursing at Case Western Reserve University, and Dr. Carolyn Davis, an outside consultant for Ernst & Whinney, the accounting and consulting firm.

title: A 1940 Proposal: Register Firearms
description: The following material is excerpted from a Department of Justice documented dated May 29, 1940.

title: Dow Starts Week Down in a Slow Session
description: LEAD: The stock market, increasingly preoccupied with the possibility that the economy is slowing, turned in another listless session yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alcoa, Pittsburgh, said it would expand its operations in Europe and Asia.

title: New World Buyout Set
description: New World Entertainment Inc., a small production company that makes ''The Wonder Years'' for television, agreed today to a buyout offer from Revlon Inc.'s chairman, Ronald O. Perelman, worth at least $120 million.

title: Of Course We Worry About What's in Our Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Aequitron Medical Sale
description: Aequitron Medical Inc., which makes apnea monitors and portable ventilators, said today that it had agreed to a buyout at $4.75 a share from a group that includes a subsidiary of Integrated Resources Inc. and Aequitron's management. The transaction is valued at about $22.3 million. The proposed transaction is subject to approval by Aequitron's shareholders. The company's shares were halted at $4.125, down 12.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Celtics Defeat Nets in a Close One
description: The Boston Celtics took a dramatic victory from the Nets tonight, and in the process moved a step closer to the playoffs.

title: Claim of Achieving Fusion in Jar Gains Support in 2 Experiments
description: A recent claim by scientists in Utah that they had achieved nuclear fusion in a jar of water gained important support today from two independent research groups that repeated part of the experiment.

title: Fountains in Schools Called Health Threat
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that more than a million school water fountains still have lead components or lead-lined tanks that could pose health risks to children.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Eastern Airlines' striking unions agreed to concessions on wages and benefits worth about $200 million a year as part of Peter Ueberroth's effort to gain control of the airline. The concessions are subject to the bankruptcy court's naming a trustee to run the airline as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy. [ Page A1. ] Grand Union is being acquired for about $1.2 billion by an investor group that includes Salomon Brothers. The nation's 11th-largest supermarket chain has been privately held since 1973. [ D1. ] Lilco returned to the public debt market after nearly four years, a clear signal that with an end to the Shoreham controversy in sight, it is back in the land of the living. [ D1. ] Minorco made its ''final'' offer for Consolidated Gold Fields, which quickly rebuffed it. The overseas arm of the mining empire of Harry Oppenheimer of South Africa bid nearly $6 billion for the West's second-biggest gold mining company. [ D1. ] Intel introduced the fastest computer chip yet to run software that is compatible with I.B.M. personal computers. [ D4. ] NEC says it has won the race to create the world's fastest supercomputer, even though the machine has yet to be built. [ D5. ] Silicon Systems agreed to be acquired by TDK, which will pay about $200 million for the chip maker. [ D5. ] Talks between Drexel and the S.E.C. to settle outstanding charges of securities law violations have bogged down. [ D13. ] Citing ''offensive'' skits, Domino's Pizza canceled advertising on NBC's ''Saturday Night Live,'' the third company to do so in recent weeks. [ D25. ] Grand Metropolitan will retain Burger King's distribution company instead of selling it. [ D4. ] Rolls-Royce will acquire Northern Engineering, a maker of electrical generating equipment, for $520 million. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY A Federal jury in the Pentagon fraud case began deliberations. The jury in the first trial to result from the Government's ''Ill Wind'' investigation is weighing the charges against three Teledyne Electronics executives accused of bribing a Navy engineer. [ D19. ] A Treasury official reiterated Secretary Brady's warnings to Congress against changes in the Bush savings plan. [ D20. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S. and Japan are narrowing their differences on the FSX jet fighter project. [ D8. ] Asiana, a fledgling Korean airline, will buy Boeing jets worth up to $1 billion in the next few years. [ D8. ] THE MARKETS The two biggest U.S. commodity exchanges are battling to develop the pre-eminent system for round-the-clock electronic trading. The Chicago Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade see the prize as the global futures market. [ D2. ] The stock market turned in another listless session, with the Dow average off 2.93 points, at 2,301.87. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in slow trading, with dealers expecting light activity until Friday's release of a slew of economic reports. [ D20. ] The dollar strengthened slightly against most major currencies despite reports of dollar-selling by the Federal Reserve. Gold prices rose in the United States after a mixed performance abroad. [ D22. ] Crude oil prices resumed their advance, a reflection of nationwide supply distortions caused by the Alaska oil spill. [ D22. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Stock of Campbell Soup soared after the death of John T. Dorrance Jr., head of the family that owns 58 percent of the company. Market Place. [ D10. ] With Passover approaching, kosher food is entering its biggest selling season. Advertising. [ D25. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the growth of radio cabs in New York City misidentified the president and chief executive of the National Car Rental System Inc. He is Vincent A. Wasik.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Wilson Is Winner: Rick Wilson, who set a record pace throughout the day, outdueled Mark Martin and Rick Mast yesterday to capture the Budweiser 200 Grand National stock car race at Bristol International Raceway in Tennessee. Wilson, who set a race qualifying record last Thursday with a lap of 119.299 miles an hour, led on four separate occasions for a total of 161 of the 106-mile race's 200 laps. Wilson's Oldsmobile Delta 88 averaged a race-record 85.776 m.p.h. as he gave the Grand National circuit its sixth different winner in six 1989 races. Dale Earnhardt, who left the race after an early collision involving Jimmy Spencer's Buick and Tom Peck's Oldsmobile, finished 27th. He had set the old record of 76.162 m.p.h. in last year's Budweiser 200. Rain on Saturday had forced the Grand National race to be rescheduled.(AP)

title: Applied Power Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $200,000 and $650,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Ex-Marines Are Enemies: North Faces His Accuser
description: Oliver L. North, bristling with anger and contempt for his accusers, today defended his handling of hundreds of thousands of dollars entrusted to him in the Iran-contra affair, insisting that ''not one cent'' went for his personal use.

title: Coseka Resources Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a writedown of oil and gas properties of $63.4 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: On the Way: Color for Portables
description: Experimental color screens for portable computers and a memory chip with four times the storage capacity of today's biggest chips are among the significant technological advances on display at the Comdex spring computer trade show starting here today.

title: H. H. Robertson
description: Douglas A. Kass, a New York money manager, said he had bought a 5.1 percent stake in the H. H. Robertson Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Kass said he intended to acquire more than 40 percent of the stock in the Pittsburgh building-products concern. He said he was in talks with third parties to raise money to buy more stock.

title: Sierracin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $400,000, or 12 cents a share. The latest year's net is after a non- recurring credit of $1,150,000, or 34 cents a share, recorded in the fourth quarter related to the final Internal Revenue Service assessment in the tax litigation regarding completed contract accounting.

title: Istec Industries & Technoloies Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results were converted into U.S. dollars at a conversion rate of 1.8065 new Israeli shekels for each U.S. $1.00.

title: Bessie Griffin Is Dead; Gospel Singer Was 67
description: Bessie Griffin, a gospel singer, died of cancer yesterday at Brockton Memorial Center in Culver City, Calif. She was 67 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Man Held in Slaying Of Brother 7 Years Ago
description: A Manhattan man was ordered held without bail today after he was arraigned on charges of killing and dismembering his brother seven years ago.

title: Stake Technology Ltd reports earnings for
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $178,000 and $666,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary items. c-Net income d-Included losses of $128,000 for the quarter and income of $1,313,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary items. Results are in U.S. dollars. The latest quarter and year figures are translated to U.S. dollars at rate of one Canadian dollar for 81.26 U.S. cents; Year-ago and prior year figures are translated to U.S. dollars at rate of one Canadian dollar for 75.64 U.S. cents.

title: Yanks Get One Little Hit in Another Big Flop
description: The Yankees' troubled start got worse last night. They lost their sixth game in six days, and it was undeniably their lowest point in a season without highs. Dave Stieb pitched a one-hitter at the Stadium, sending the Toronto Blue Jays to an 8-0 victory and sending Dallas Green, the Yankees' manager, into a scathing post-game critique.

title: Study to Cheer Ad Industry
description: Those who believe in advertising will be heartened by a new report that says advertising gives a greater return on investment than sales promotions. ''We were rather astonished by the results,'' said Alexander L. Biel, executive director of the Ogilvy Center for Research and Development, which compiled the report.
