title: NEC Says It Will Have Fastest Computer
description: Another Japanese company said today that it had won the race to create the world's fastest supercomputer. The new entry is from the NEC Corporation, but the company conceded that the computer had yet to be built.

title: House Lawyer Finds Wright Broke Rules
description: The outside counsel to the House ethics committee has recommended that Speaker Jim Wright be held in violation of House rules in connection with a publishing arrangement and his financial ties to a Texas developer. These allegations, and a spirited defense from Mr. Wright, are outlined in a document prepared by Wright supporters. The committee is widely expected to criticize the Speaker, but which of the counsel's recommendations will be accepted is a crucial unresolved issue. Article, page A19.

title: Telerate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Topics of The Times; Fun With Fugu
description: In a country where paranoia about pesticides and such is not to be sniffed at, a fish named fugu may soon be smelling like a rose. Funny thing, that, because eating fugu, until recently served only in Japan, is a lot like playing Russian roulette.

title: Mr. North vs. Two Presidents
description: Oliver North's defense is giving Ronald Reagan and George Bush plenty of explaining to do. The former White House aide, apparently determined to pass the blame for the Iran-contra affair back up the line, now deeply implicates the two Presidents in the circumvention of Congress's ban on aid to the Nicaraguan rebel forces. These two Commanders in Chief once celebrated him as a patriot and hero. Now he comes across as an informer trying to escape the felony charges against him.

title: Diversified Human Resources Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $94,800. c-Net loss

title: Silicon Valley Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results reflected a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February.

title: Computers in the Corridors of Power
description: HIS rifle is a dog soldier's best friend, it is said, and a captain, or conceivably a colonel, may occasionally fire a shot in anger. But the Old Man hasn't used a weapon in years.

title: Paramount Funding Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The 1988 loss included a $14.4 million writedown of investments, compared with a $23.4 million writedown in 1987. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Staodynamics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-After a loss of $50,768 from the early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year; the year also included a tax credit of $21,424.

title: PALESTINIANS COOL TO SHAMIR'S OFFER
description: Palestinian community leaders in the West Bank and Gaza Strip have either dismissed Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's offer of elections in the territories, or accepted the idea only under conditions that most Israelis could not accept.

title: New York's Dropouts-to-Be: A Grim Class Portrait
description: A statistical analysis of all students entering New York City high schools last September shows large percentages of them to be at high risk of dropping out because they were older than average for their grade or had a high absentee rate.

title: U.S. Praises Haitian on Drug Efforts
description: The President of Haiti, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, has made serious efforts to combat narcotics, and the United States is encouraging those efforts, American officials said today.

title: China Steps Back From Reform
description: After more than a decade of reform, China has slipped into unmistakable retreat. The telltale signal came when Prime Minister Li Peng told the recent session of the National People's Congress that his Government plans to reimpose a measure of centralized economic control.

title: Topics of The Times; Glorious Gunther
description: Nineteen elephants, one of them a mere toddler, paraded up New York's Eighth Avenue yesterday linked trunk to tail. Preceding them was a pair of police cars; following them, a pair of sanitation trucks, their brushes whirring like all get-out. With them was Gunther Gebel-Williams, the great animal trainer, on his way to the party on the Great Lawn of Central Park celebrating his farewell tour. Among the celebrants were Chinese dancers, a Chinese dragon, the casts of several Broadway musicals and, of course, the 19 elephants.

title: WEATHER HAMPERS OIL SPILL CLEANUP
description: Foul weather hampered efforts today to clean up the oil spilled off Alaska's coast but raised hopes at the same time: rough seas might break up the most threatening slicks.

title: John Paul Riddle, 87, Aviation Education Leader
description: John Paul Riddle, an early aviator and a leader in the fields of air cargo and aviation education, died after a brief illness Thursday at Cedars Medical Center in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 87 years old and lived in Coral Gables.

title: The Politics of Race; Seeing Chicago's Election as a Signal, Blacks Work to Heal New Divisions
description: Do the successive defeats of two black candidates who ran for Mayor of Chicago signal growing racial polarization and a decline in black urban political power? In particular, do they signal danger for David Dinkins's candidacy to become the first black Mayor of New York City?

title: Scintrex Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Home Savings & Loan Assn of Durham, North Carolina Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
London Bookshop Bombings Are Tied to 'Satanic Verses'
description: Two London bookshops were hit by firebombs in separate attacks apparently connected with the furor over Salman Rushdie's book ''The Satanic Verses,'' the police said today.

title: Lessors Thrive on Aircraft Boom
description: In the commercial aircraft boom, some of the largest airplane orders have been placed by companies whose names never graced a fuselage.

title: Pacesetter Business Properies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $1,540,000 from an accounting change for both the quarter and year. The company said fiscal 1988 included nonrecurring pretax costs of $749,000 related to the company's spin-off from its former parent on June 30, 1988, and a stock award to its president. The year also included pretax depreciation of $1,805,000 on rental properties held for investment. Year 1987 included $2,257,000 pretax for such depreciation.

title: High-Speed Chip Introduced by Intel
description: At a time when the computer industry is racing toward greater performance at a dizzying pace, the Intel Corporation today introduced the fastest computer chip yet to run software compatible with I.B.M. personal computers.

title: Boggs Is Still a Hit in Boston
description: After the airplane bomb scare, the underwear sign, the Margo chants and the Margo masks, Wade Boggs returned to Fenway Park today and was welcomed home like the naughty but most-loved son in the family. To the Fenway fans, it did not matter that Boggs had been the center of the Margo Adams controversy for months. He was still the best-hitting member of the Red Sox and that is what counted.

title: CMS Advertising Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Verdict on Agents
description: The Federal jury deciding the fate of the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom will enter its fourth day of deliberation in Chicago today. Walters and Bloom are charged with racketeering and defrauding universities of scholarship money paid to student-athletes who were rendered ineligible because they signed contracts with the agents.

title: Review/Television; Matchmaking as a Sport, on Fox Network
description: Playing sleazy matchmaker for Troilus and Cressida, Shakespeare's Pandarus was a model of decorum compared with the folks on ''Straight to the Heart.'' The new syndicated game show, which can be seen weekday mornings at 11 on Fox television, adds new dimensions to the concept of pandering. Desperation is the name of these games.

title: William H. White, Publisher, 64
description: William Henry White, an author, editor and publisher, died of cancer yesterday at the White Plains (N.Y.) Hospital Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mid-America Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $669,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Henley to Buy PA Holdings Stake
description: Henley Group Inc. said it would buy the 50 percent stake in PA Holdings Inc. that it does not already own for $165 million from Wasserstein, Perella & Company, its partner in the leveraged buyout of the aerospace and military company. Henley teamed with Wasserstein, Perella, a New York investment firm, to buy the company from the Whitman Corporation for $1.2 billion last August. Henley and Wasserstein, Perella invested $100 million in the buyout.

title: When Poles Will Dance
description: Lech Walesa came home from the factory, sat down in his living room and pointed a warning finger at the ceiling.

title: KEY RATES
Migraines and Vision
description: More migraine headache sufferers experience permanent visual impairment than commonly thought, according to a study published in the March issue of the journal Opthamology.

title: Banknote Stake
description: An investment group has raised its stake in the International Banknote Company to 10 percent from 8.4 percent. The group, led by Tsunesaburo Kurosawa, president of the Kurosawa Company, plans to wage a proxy fight for control of the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Kurosawa group said it had bought an additional 223,800 shares.

title: Vietnam's Gift to Cambodia
description: Vietnam's announcement last week of plans to withdraw all of its troops by September is not so much a harbinger as a confirmation of what has transpired in Cambodia in the past year. Simply put, Vietnam now believes that Hun Sen, the head of the regime it installed here in 1979, can keep the Government together while remaining a strong ally of Hanoi. He has opened up the country, revived nationalism and won the confidence of the population.

title: President Bush Signs a Bill To Protect Whistle Blowers
description: President Bush signed a bill into law today strengthening protection for Federal workers who report Government wrongdoing.

title: Reviews/Dance; New Works in 5th Choreographer's Showcase
description: Eight choreographers created short pieces for the fifth Choreographer's Showcase presented Sunday night by Evolving Arts, an enterprising organization founded originally as a school by several noted jazz-dance teachers.

title: Frontier Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Dance; Ailey Junior Ensemble Challenges Main Company
description: The Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble is giving the senior Ailey company a run for its money these days at the Theater of the Riverside Church (Claremont Avenue at 120th Street), where the ensemble performs through Sunday. The company was founded by Mr. Ailey 15 years ago with the idea of giving gifted advanced students at his school a bridge to the stage. But the engaging program presented on Saturday night by the junior company, which is directed by Sylvia Waters, was the work not only of fully professional dancers, but of some distinctive performers as well.

title: Capital's Government Denounced By Bennett, Opening Drug Drive
description: William J. Bennett, the Federal narcotics chief, charged today that this city's government had failed to contain the drug epidemic here.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Aegon Insurance Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars; U.S. dollars were translated at the Dec. 31, 1988 exchange rate of Dfl 2.00 equals U.S. $1.00.

title: Review/Theater; Peeling Ibsen's Existential Onion
description: ''Peer Gynt'' represented, as Ibsen wrote, ''a process of spiritual liberation and catharsis,'' for the title character as well as for the playwright. Though Ibsen himself regarded it as his play least likely to be understood outside of his country, it has become one of his most universal works. Along with ''Brand,'' ''Peer Gynt'' is a masterpiece, fraught with dangers for theatrical mountaineers. For this reason, the play is seldom performed, rarer still in its entirety.

title: Accounts
description: * DCE Inc., a dust control equipment maker, to Bergelt-Litchfield for its advertising and public relations.

title: Dusseldorf Journal; Look at the New Germans, Rich and Living It Up
description: The message along the chic ''Ko'' is etched in marble and polished brass: The Germans are rich, and learning to enjoy it.

title: Knee Surgery for Bell
description: Buddy Bell, who last week became the 62d player in major league history to reach the 2,500-hit plateau, will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati for torn cartilage in his left knee. Bell, 37 years old, who was signed as a free agent by the Rangers on Jan. 9, has undergone seven previous knee operations, including three last season.(AP)

title: Rangers' Downfall Ends a Season Once Filled With Hopes
description: For the Rangers, it had become a ritual of the spring, a melancholy but cathartic party. Players would gather at the team's practice facility, eat and drink while they packed, joke and mourn, then say goodbye until the fall.

title: Should Ballplayers Drive Cabs?
description: Minnesota Twins fans customarily support and inspire their darlings by waving hankies, a seemingly unsanitary though exuberant practice, but on Opening Day they pocketed their linen and booed their best pitcher, Frank (Sweet Music) Viola, even before he had thrown his first pitch.

title: MEXICANS ARREST TOP DRUG FIGURE AND 80 POLICEMEN
description: In its boldest strike against drug trafficking and corruption, the Mexican Government has captured the country's leading cocaine-trafficking figure and taken into custody virtually the entire police force of the city that was his base. Several other senior law enforcement officials were also arrested.

title: U.S. Asks Moscow to Use Restraint in Georgia
description: The United States urged Soviet authorities today to act with restraint in dealing with the protests in Soviet Georgia, which have led to clashes between troops and demonstrators.

title: Experts Assess a Decade of In Vitro Fertilization
description: A decade after the birth of the world's first test-tube baby, specialists in the field gathered here and estimated that 15,000 babies have been born worldwide through in vitro fertilization.

title: In Lilco's Debt Sale, Signs of a New Vigor
description: Returning to the public debt market yesterday after an absence of nearly four years, the Long Island Lighting Company signaled loud and clear that it was back in the land of the living.

title: AIDS Finding Piques Curiosity, but Scientists Are Wary
description: THREE years after he announced that he had discovered a new virus among AIDS patients, a Government scientist has finally published a paper detailing his findings. If he is right, the finding could be of major importance in the battle against the fatal disease.

title: No Election Timing in Koch-O'Connor Book
description: To the Editor:

title: PCA International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After tax credits of $1,507,000 for the quarter and $2,081,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,439,000 and $1,801,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest quarter and year pretax income included a restructuring reserve of $1,383,000 resulting primarily from the closing of 72 department store studios, which was substantially offset by a gain of $1,357,215 from the sale of the company's former corporate headquarters. The prior year pretax income included a gain of $212,618 related to the sale of undeveloped land during the period.

title: NCNB Offer Dealt Setback
description: The NCNB Corporation's offer to merge with the Citizens and Southern Corporation was dealt another setback yesterday when the Georgia Department of Banking and Finance said it could take 12 months to 18 months to rule on the application.

title: Rolls-Royce To Buy N.E.I.
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the jet engine maker, said today that it would acquire Northern Engineering Industries in a deal that values the British maker of electrical generating equipment at $:306 million, or about $520 million.

title: Herbert J. Jacobi, Lawyer, 81
description: Herbert J. Jacobi, a retired lawyer, died of prostate cancer yesterday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 81 years old and also had a home in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: By Design; Flat Feet
description: Whatever shape they take - elegant, amusing or downright odd - the shoes you want for next fall will be flat.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: ENVIRONMENT
description: On the environment, the Bush Administration has a split personality. The Environmental Protection Agency has been given to the white hats while the Interior Department remains the passive force for development that it was in the Reagan era.

title: Drexel Talks With S.E.C. Hit a Snag
description: Talks between Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle charges of securities law violations have bogged down over a single issue involving Michael R. Milken, who has taken a leave of absence as head of the firm's high-yield ''junk bond'' unit.

title: Convictions Appealed In Howard Beach Case
description: Lawyers for three young white men convicted of manslaughter and assault in the Howard Beach racial attack urged an appeals court yesterday to overturn the convictions, contending their clients had been deprived of their constitutional rights by the police and the trial court.

title: Degradable Plastics Show Promise in Fight Against Trash
description: THEY are everywhere: coffee cups and burger boxes, trash and grocery bags, diapers and margarine tubs and containers for everything from milk to antifreeze - billions of pieces of trash, all made of seemingly indestructible plastic.

title: Soil Laboratory Opens Window On Vibrant Life Beneath a Forest
description: RESEARCHERS at the University of Michigan have set up an underground laboratory that offers a window on the little-understood interaction of plants, nutrients and animals below the surface of a forest in northern Michigan.

title: Pentagon Tests Powerful Laser as Antimissile Weapon
description: A powerful laser flashed to life in the first major antimissile weapons test of the Bush Administration, Pentagon officials said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; The Heart of Darkness Beats Again
description: The Whales in Lake Tanganyika By Lennart Hagerfors Translated by Anselm Hollo. 172 pages. Grove Press. $16.95.

title: Willard F. McCormick, 85, Dies; Led Management Consulting Firm
description: Willard Francis McCormick, a founder and former chairman of Cresap, McCormick & Paget, the management consulting business, now part of Towers Perrin, died of a stroke Saturday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: School Suit Seeks to Restore Dancing Ban
description: Barely four months after Purdy high school students made history of sorts with a homecoming dance in their school gymnasium, the town's school board asked a Federal appeals court today to let it reinstate a ban on dancing.

title: Metro Datelines; Use of Genetic Code Leads to Sentencing
description: A man who was convicted of murder after the authorities used genetic coding to prove he had committed the crime was sentenced yesterday to 15 years to life in prison.

title: Decor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Schulman, A Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The share earnings reflected a 3-for- 2 stock split paid last month.

title: Paramount Pictures' Success Key to Revamping at G.&W.
description: In an industry in which consistency means two hit films in a row, the Paramount Pictures Corporation has risen from a weak performer in the 1970's to become one of the two or three Hollywood studios on which Wall Street counts to deliver solid results year after year.

title: Needle-Prick Suspect to Get AIDS Test
description: A Bronx man whose used hypodermic needle pricked the thumb of a transit officer in an arrest last month agreed yesterday to be tested for the AIDS virus and to share the results with the officer. In exchange, the criminal charges against the suspect were reduced.

title: Inflation Rise in Britain
description: The Department of Trade and Industry said today that the cost of raw materials and fuels for British manufacturers in March rose by a strong 1.4 percent. The gain put the annual inflation rate at its highest level since August 1987, raising fears that the Government will push interest rates higher. The market had expected an increase of nine-tenths of a percent, after a fall of a tenth of a percent in February. The inflation rate now stands at 7.5 percent.

title: Fisher Given Basketball Coaching Job at Michigan
description: When Steve Fisher takes his national champion University of Michigan basketball team for a visit to the White House on Wednesday, he will have something in common with the host, President Bush: Both Fisher and the President spent most of the 1980's as second-in-command, then took charge this year.

title: 22 Reported Dead in a French Plane Crash
description: A passenger plane crashed into a foggy mountainside in southeastern France tonight, killing all 22 people aboard, officials said.

title: An Exemplary Office For Conservationists
description: Trying to practice its global conservation philosophy on a piece of New York City real estate, the Natural Resources Defense Council has created an energy-efficient headquarters at 40 West 20th Street that it hopes may serve as a model for others.

title: Study Reports Sex Bias in News Organizations
description: Although women make up 52 percent of the United States population, they hold only 6 percent of the top management jobs in the news media and earn only 92 cents for each dollar earned by their male counterparts in the same top jobs, according to a University of Missouri study.

title: Reviews/Music; Chamber Group Plays the Music Suburbs Hear
description: Music Amici is a flexible chamber ensemble made up largely of freelance and orchestra musicians in New York. It does much of its playing in outlying counties like Rockland and Bergen; and judging by the group's substantial quality and by its inventively chosen program at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday night, Music Amici seems a nice example of what musicians huddling in New York waiting for stardom might be doing with their time. Smaller venues deserve music like this and are apparently supporting it.

title: Fans Are Discovering That Isiah Thomas Isn't the Only Star on Pistons
description: Funny how things work out. Coach Chuck Daly tells the story of how the Detroit Pistons, with the 18th pick, went to the 1985 college draft looking for a big man and came away with a small one instead.

title: Ethics Counsel Recommends Vote Against Wright
description: The outside counsel to the House ethics committee has recommended that Speaker Jim Wright be held in violation of House rules, and Mr. Wright has countered with a spirited defense urging that the findings be rejected.

title: Independent Testers To Check Americans
description: Concerned that the image of track and field has become tarnished by recent admissions and allegations of drug use by athletes and coaches, The Athletics Congress is embarking on a program to drive performance-enhancing substances out of the sport and to restore public confidence.

title: Fall Shows: An Opening Full of Promise
description: THREE models in leopard-spotted jackets - fake, of course - sauntered down the runway of the Hotel Pierre's Cotillion Room at noon yesterday to open the Bill Blass collection, and the fall and winter fashion showings were officially under way.

title: Bernice Segal, 59, a Professor of Chemistry
description: Bernice Segal, a former chairwoman of the chemistry department at Barnard College, died of breast cancer Sunday at her home in Tenafly, N.J. She was 59 years old. Professor Segal, who was born in Brooklyn, was a summa cum laude graduate of Radcliffe College and received her master's and doctoral degrees from Columbia University. She joined Barnard in 1958 and was chairwoman of the chemistry department from 1973 to 1983 and again from 1986 to 1987.

title: At Waterford, Honeymoon Is Over
description: It looked like a perfect match when the Waterford Glass Group of Ireland purchased Wedgwood P.L.C. for more than $360 million in the fall of 1986. The deal brought together two of the most prestigious names in tableware, with a goal of modernizing production and enhancing their global marketing prowess.

title: SAKHAROV OBTAINS PLACE ON BALLOT
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the human rights campaigner, prevailed today in his resistance to the political establishment and was nominated for the new national congress as the Academy of Sciences hierarchy reversed itself in the face of members' spirited complaint.

title: Executone Information Sysems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago results are on a pro forma basis. The company said the year-ago pro forma figures are an approximation of the results that would have been reported if Isoetec Communications Inc. had been merged into Vodavi Technology Corp. The company was formed in July 1988 through the merger of Isoetec with Vodavi Technology. The company's year consists of 6 months from July, when it was formed.

title: No Radiation Leakage From Sub, Soviets Say
description: The Soviet Government said today that the world should have ''no concern whatsoever'' about radiation leaking from the nuclear-powered submarine that sank in the Norwegian Sea on Friday.

title: Q&A
description: Tornadoes Q. Do tornadoes ever strike big cities, or are they really attracted to trailer parks? And what causes dust devils? A. ''Meteorologists also joke about building trailer parks to attract tornadoes,'' said Paul G. Knight, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University, but in this case there is more than a grain of truth in the jest, because trailer parks tend to occupy the kind of terrain that allows tornadoes to develop, he explained.

title: Rise in Rig Count Ends
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas declined by one last week, to a total of 778, halting a two-week increase, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. In the previous two weeks the rig count had risen by 39 following a long downtrend. A year ago, the total was 916. The rig count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity.

title: Healthvest SBI reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSIDE
description: 'Star Wars' Laser Tested A powerful $250 million laser designed to shoot down enemy missiles flashed to life in California in the first major ''Star Wars'' ground test during the Bush Administration, Pentagon officials said. Page A16. Sakharov Gains Candidacy Andrei Sakharov was nominated for a seat in the new Soviet congress after the Academy of Sciences reversed itself. Page A5. Cold Shoulder for Shamir Yitzhak Shamir's election plan for the occupied territories has failed to move the Palestinians, who have rejected the idea or attached conditions that Israelis won't abide. Page A10. Grim School Statistics An analysis of students entering New York City high schools last September shows that many are at high risk of dropping out because they started out older than average. Page B1.

title: Bush Said to Seek More Details on Jet Plan
description: The United States and Japan are narrowing their differences on the FSX jet-fighter project, but Washington has asked Tokyo for new ''clarifications,'' Administration officials said today. The move suggests that further delays are possible before President Bush seeks Congressional approval.

title: Belgian Retailer Bids for Scotty's
description: GB Inno BM S.A., Belgium's largest retailer, offered to buy all the shares of Scotty's Inc. it did not already own for $15 a share. Scotty's shares jumped $2.75 today, to $14.75. The 22.9 percent gain was the second largest on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Skadden, Arps Partner Adds Post at Barclays Bank
description: Robert C. Vincent Jr., a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, is adding the chairmanship of the Barclays Bank of New York to his duties.

title: 2 Big Futures Exchanges in a Race
description: With the global market for the futures business as the prize, the nation's two biggest commodity exchanges are battling to develop the pre-eminent system for round-the-clock electronic trading. Such a system, by allowing traders to buy and sell futures contracts at computer terminals, could eventually replace the physical trading floors.

title: Pan Atlantic Re Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $682,513 for the quarter and $1,027,204 for the year. c-After net realized investment losses of $8,968 for the quarter and $849,243 for the year. d-Net income Results are corrected from Thursday, April 6.

title: Ernest E. Williams, Editor, 72
description: Ernest E. Williams, former editor of The Fort Wayne News-Sentinel, the first person to encourage Vice President Dan Quayle to run for Congress, died Sunday of complications after cardiac bypass surgery. He was 72 years old.

title: Repeal Death Sentence For Film Forum
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Datelines; State Judge Denies Bail to Ex-Fugitive
description: A state judge denied bail yesterday to Herman B. Ferguson, a former school administrator and black militant who surrendered to the authorities last week.

title: Charter Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $9,377,000 and income of $39,393,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary charge of $2,263,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $4,929,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $23,988,000 and $25,177,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $12,272,000 for the quarter and $15,821,000 for the year. The company attributed the final loss in the latest fourth quarter primarily to revised cost estimates and additions made to reserves relating to discontinued operations.

title: S.&P. Rating Group Gets President
description: The Standard & Poor's Rating Group, which assigns a grade to bonds and other debt instruments, has named Leo C. O'Neill president in a revamping that will put more stress on international markets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is our common grief, for which we are all responsible.'' - Dzhumber Patiashvili, head of the Communist Party in Soviet Georgia. [ A1:3. ]

title: First Illinois Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $3,787,000 for the latest first quarter and $2,702,000 for the year-earlier period. The bank said the results from discontinued operations represent results for its Mercury Finance Co. unit. First Illinois is spinning off the unit in a stock distribution to its shareholders.

title: Takeshita, Refusing to Quit, Calls Scandal Fund Overstated
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, moving to quell the uproar from his involvement in an influence-peddling scandal, today outlined details of the controversial campaign funds but vowed again that he would not resign as demanded by his political foes.

title: People
description: * Richard L. Rogers has been named executive vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide.

title: American Health Services reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,054,640 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,376,974 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Included a loss of $2,612,595 from discontinued operations.

title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested
description: A Federal agent and a former police officer whose acquittal in the death by beating of a black man led to race riots in 1980 were arrested on drug charges, the authorities said today.

title: U.N. Force to Monitor Rebel Exit From Namibia
description: The United Nations sent British and Australian troops today to two northern villages where assembly points are to open Tuesday to receive guerrillas for repatriation to Angola.

title: Faldo Silences Critics With Masters Victory
description: Some British golf experts used to refer to Nick Faldo as Nick Foldo, an unkind and inaccurate assessment of the English golfer that indicated he fell short when challenged. These critics were in a class with those in the United States who many years ago accused Tom Watson of the same tendency. So much for experts on either side of the Atlantic.

title: Betty Farrally, Dancer, 73
description: Betty Farrally, a co-founder of Canada's oldest dance company, died of brain cancer Sunday in Kelowna, B.C. She was 73 years old.

title: Metro Datelines; Salerno Admits Guilt In Racketeering Case
description: Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, whom prosecutors called a crime boss, entered his first guilty pleas yesterday as he admitted to Federal charges of extortion and racketeering.

title: 6 Men Shot Outside Grocery in Far Rockaway, and 2 Are Held
description: Six men were shot, one critically, in front of a grocery store in Far Rockaway Queens last night and two men were arrested shortly afterward trying to flee in a car across Broad Channel, the police said.

title: PATTERNS
description: Looking Toward Fall

title: Our Towns; Howdy, Stranger, Have a Big Dose Of Realty Taxes
description: In 1986 Marion Ragsdale, a retired teacher, paid $40,000 for a plain, two-story country house in this quiet Catskills town. Because her income is modest, Ms. Ragsdale, a widow living in a Manhattan apartment, checked the property taxes first; they were $835, quite reasonable.

title: Holly Farms Sets Conagra Terms
description: The Holly Farms Corporation said it and Conagra Inc. had set the common stock exchange ratio for their proposed merger at 1.875 Conagra shares for each Holly Farms share. Conagra's shares closed at $32 today, up 12.5 cents, making its offer for Holly Farms worth $60 a share. Tyson Foods Inc. has offered $63.50 a share for Holly Farms. Shares of Holly Farms closed unchanged at $62.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. Holly Farms and Conagra will both hold special meetings of their shareholders on Friday.

title: First Western Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Last year's per share earnings were restated to give effect to a 5 percent stock dividend declared in July 1988.

title: Mars Graphic Services reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company attributed the decrease in net income to the writeoff of a customer's accounts receivable balance of $467,724.

title: Tabloid on Capitol Hill Finds Keys to Success
description: Perhaps more than any other Federal enclave, Capitol Hill is a self-contained universe. Its working inhabitants form a subculture defined by history, customs, idioms and tribal rites that date from the founding of the Republic, transcending shifts in party control.

title: A 'Distressed' Johnson
description: Ross Earl, a friend of Ben Johnson, told a Canadian Federal inquiry in Toronto yesterday that the sprinter was distressed in the weeks leading up to the Seoul Olympics last year by rumors he was taking steroids.

title: Of Course We Worry About What's in Our Food; The Poison Is Coming
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Course We Worry About What's in Our Food; Cheese Remarkably Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: Tennessee Quits Club
description: The University of Tennessee football coach, Johnny Majors, and the school's athletic director, Doug Dickey, quit an all-white country club in Knoxville, Tenn., yesterday after reports that the incoming Tennessee basketball coach, Wade Houston, who is black, could not become a member of the club.

title: Domino's Pulls 'Saturday Night' Ads
description: Responding to complaints about ''offensive'' skits, Domino's Pizza Inc. has canceled its advertising on NBC's ''Saturday Night Live,'' the third company to do so in recent weeks.

title: Hurst Throws One-Hitter
description: Bruce Hurst pitched the first one-hitter of his career and struck out 13 tonight as the San Diego Padres beat the Atlanta Braves, 5-2.

title: Consolidated Papers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Haitian Says Rebels Are Being Subdued
description: Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril said today that the last of the rebels trying to overthrow his Government for a week were being brought under control.

title: J Higby's Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Both periods have been restated to reflect an accounting change prompted by new S.E.C. guidelines for franchisors.

title: Stotler Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public Aug. 19, 1988. The latest year period is from Aug. 22 to Dec. 31, 1988.

title: Silicon Systems Accepts $200 Million Bid by TDK
description: Silicon Systems Inc., a chip maker based in Tustin, Calif., said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the TDK Corporation for $20 a share, or about $200 million.

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Two Star Quarterbacks Join Supplemental Draft
description: Steve Walsh of Miami and Timm Rosenbach of Washington State, will bypass the National Football League draft on April 23 in favor of the supplemental draft in early summer.

title: For Bhopal Gas Victims, the New Enemy Is Fraud
description: Concern is growing across this city, stricken more than four years ago by toxic gases from a Union Carbide pesticide plant, that the $470 million compensation announced in February by India's Supreme Court may not reach victims of the tragedy.

title: South Korean Airline to Buy 9 Boeing Jets
description: Asiana Airlines, a fledgling South Korean company that began flying in December with a handful of leased aircraft, signed contracts and options today to buy up to $1 billion of jets from the Boeing Company in the next few years.

title: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent earnings per share. Earnings per American Depositary Receipt (ADR) are not shown but each ADR represents one- fifth of an LVMH ordinary share. Results are in U.S. dollars; dollar figures was translated at the Dec. 31, 1988 exchange rate of French francs 6.06 equals U.S. $1.00.

title: Reviews/Music; Underlying Melancholy In Chamber Symphony Bill
description: The works on the New York Chamber Symphony's Saturday evening program at the 92d Street Y seemed connected by a melancholy thread: included were Harold Shapero's ''Three Hebrew Songs,'' prayerlike settings in a sometimes cantorial style; Faure's ''Elegie,'' and Schubert's ''Tragic'' Symphony. Tchaikovsky's ''Rococo'' Variations stood amid these as a generally bright-spirited work, but it has an elegiac variation within it.

title: Experimental AIDS Drug Is Dealt Setback by F.D.A.
description: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration dealt a blow last week to a small New Orleans drug maker, saying the company, Imreg Inc., should start over in testing an experimental AIDS drug.

title: Sensormatic Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
New Look for an Enclave of Art
description: A new look is coming to the Lehman Collection, the museum-within-a-museum established at the Metropolitan by the will of the financier and collector Robert Lehman, who died in 1969. For the first time since the opening in 1975 of this magnificent enclave of Western European art, the shifting, reattribution and rearrangement of paintings, objects and whole rooms is under way.

title: A Japanese Rite of Spring Blooms Amid Unusual Grumbling
description: The other evening, a top official in the Finance Ministry cut short his conversation, explaining that he and his colleagues had another pressing engagement. They all had to adjourn to a nearby park to sit under the cherry blossoms, sing old songs and drink beer or sake.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, an insurance company, named John D. Loewenberg senior vice president.

title: Discus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Gasoline Demand Pushes Crude Oil Prices Upward
description: Crude oil prices resumed their advance yesterday, largely because of the strong demand for gasoline, a reflection of nationwide supply distortions caused by the Alaska oil spill.

title: National Mercantile Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Findings Offer Clues to the Process of Alzheimer's Disease
description: THE main substance that disrupts the brains of Alzheimer's disease patients can help prolong the survival of nerve cells in a test tube, and may promote growth of parts of the nerve cells, scientists have reported. The discovery may offer important clues to the biology of the brain disorder.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Northwest Ads Offer Tips
description: LEAD: Miss Manners might well have written the copy for a new advertising campaign for Northwest Airlines that trumpets the carrier's expertise in serving travelers to Asia and offers tips on social convention in the protocol-conscious Orient.

title: Immucor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included tax credits of $152,761 for the quarter and $401,842 for the 9 months.

title: Metro Datelines; Community Agrees To Cut Beach Fees
description: An agreement by which the community of Sea Girt will charge $2.50 a day for its beach badges was reached during the weekend, Richard Shapiro, director of the State Division of Public Advocacy, said.

title: Gallery Show Unites O'Casey Clan
description: The children of the playwright Sean O'Casey were discussing their father's sole trip to America, in 1934. It was the visit O'Casey never tired of describing when they were growing up in the ramshackle Victorian house in Totnes, England, where the gaunt, fiery playwright lived for decades after spurning his native Dublin.

title: Massachusetts Bond Offering
description: The Commonwealth of Massachusetts yesterday offered $200 million worth of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.

title: How Many Children Will Abortion Foes Take In?; What No Law Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Martin J. Munroe, Executive, 64
description: Martin J. Munroe, a retired vice president of United Parcel Service, died of congestive heart failure Monday at Kennedy Hospital in Saddle Brook, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Barris Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included $6,959,000 of unrealized and realized gains on investments. c-Included net gains of $26,073,000. d-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Feb. 28, about a challenge to the Big Bang theory of the origin of the universe, misstated an interpretation given by Mark R. Morris, professor of astronomy at the University of California at Los Angeles, to phenomena observed near the center of the Milky Way galaxy. He said, in recent correspondence, that the presence of plasma filaments there has not altered his support for the existence in the region of a black hole, a dense concentration of matter whose gravitational force is so strong that light cannot escape. He also said that gravity could be the dominant force in the region.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Amserv Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1988 net income is restated to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend declared in November 1988.

title: Bandag Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
About New York; After 30 Years, A Saint Inspires 2 Friends to Meet
description: ''It's sort of a sentimental journey that started 100 years ago,'' the man said.

title: 'Wear a Barrel'
description: To The Living Section:

title: Elinor G. Black, Teacher, 83
description: Elinor G. Black, a teacher and volunteer in community organizations, died of heart failure yesterday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: J.L. Muscarelle, Builder, 85, Dies
description: Joseph L. Muscarelle, the founder and chairman of one of New Jersey's largest construction concerns, the Joseph Muscarelle Construction Company of Maywood, died Sunday at Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center after surgery for an aneurysm. He was 85 years old and lived in Hackensack.

title: Filmstar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included gains of $6,000 and $28,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from an interest adjustment on convertible debt. c-Net loss The company said during the first 9 months of fiscal 1989 $300,000 in notes were converted from debt to equity.

title: Honor for Battling AIDS Fear
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop on Monday praised Sarasota for backing a family driven from their hometown because three brothers were exposed to the AIDS virus. The city was honored for its hospitality toward the Ray family, who settled here last year after fighting an order banning the boys from Arcadia public schools.

title: Scott Selling Land To Crown Pacific
description: The Scott Paper Company announced it would sell 194,000 acres of timberlands in western Washington to Crown Pacific Ltd. for about $230 million. Scott announced plans to sell its timberlands in the Northwest in 1983, and the agreement with Crown represents all but about 16,000 acres.

title: Sites Weighed for Conversion to Jails
description: Scrambling to find space for inmates, New York City officials last month began an inventory of about 50 public buildings that could be converted to temporary prisons.

title: New Jersey Trooper Kills a Man
description: A New Jersey state trooper shot and killed a man yesterday as the man and a companion tried to flee after the trooper pulled their car over for driving erratically on Route 1 in North Brunswick, the state police reported.

title: De Benedetti In Paper Deal
description: A publishing group controlled by the entrepreneur Carlo de Benedetti said Monday that it would buy a majority stake in the company that owns Italy's leading daily newspaper, La Repubblica.

title: Stake in Ramada Cut by Pritzkers
description: The HCC Corporation, an investment vehicle of the Pritzker family of Chicago, has lowered its stake in Ramada Inc. to 4.8 percent from 7.2 percent. The Pritzkers gave no reason in their filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Persian Gulf Oil Meeting
description: Six Persian Gulf oil ministers are to meet April 26 in Saudi Arabia, an official of their regional organization said today. The official at the Gulf Cooperation Council's headquarters in Riyadh said by telephone that ministers from four OPEC states, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar, would meet in Jidda along with ministers from Oman and Bahrain, which do not belong to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The ministers are expected to coordinate stands on price and production levels in preparation for a June meeting of OPEC.

title: Plasti-Line reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
For Seven Weeks Only, California Moves to 59th and Lex
description: CALIFORNIA has arrived at Bloomingdale's. Marvin Traub sent out for it.

title: Maxwell Gets Israeli Stake
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell has paid $30.4 million for a stake in Israel's largest drug manufacturing company, a spokeswoman for the company said today. It was Mr. Maxwell's third Israeli investment in 10 months.

title: Battle Brews on Justice Dept. Choice
description: He may be known to his friends as ''Cool Hand Luke.'' But William Lucas, the Detroit lawyer who has been selected to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, can inspire a hot-tempered reaction from some of this city's most prominent black citizens.

title: Canandaigua Wine Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $1,031,364.

title: Nassau Orders Drug Testing For All Narcotics Officers
description: All narcotics officers in the Nassau County Police Department will be required to submit to surprise drug testing periodically under a new departmental policy.

title: Insituform Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included unusual pretax charges of $1,573,228 for the quarter and $1,530,054 for the year, including charges related to restructuring of operations in several countries, disposal of peripheral activities and legal costs, among other things. c-Net loss d-Included unusual pretax charges of $1,038,462 and $2,887,227 for the quarter and year, respectively, principally from legal fees, investment losses and certain discontinued operations. Results are in U.S. dollars. The company said figures for 1988 are converted from British pounds at the rate of $1.81 to the pound; figures for 1987 are converted at the rate of $1.88 to the pound.

title: First Bank System
description: First Bank System Inc. yesterday offered an adjustable-rate preferred stock deal through a syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Goldman, Sachs & Company. Under the terms of the deal, the initial rate on 1.5 million shares of $50 adjustable preferred stock was set at 9 3/4 percent. Rates on the issue, which is non-callable for five years, will float and pay quarterly at 50 basis points over the higher of the bond equivalent yield on 3-month Treasury bills, 10-year Treasury notes or 30-year Treasury bonds. Rates on the issue cannot fall below 7 percent or rise above 14 percent. The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB-plus by Standard & Poor's.

title: Israel Assails Killing of Arab in Old City
description: Israeli leaders today condemned the shooting of an Arab by a Jew at the gate to the Old City, while also trying to reassure tourists that Jerusalem remains a safe place to visit.

title: Test Suspension Irks A Star U.S. Hurdler
description: Tonie Campbell, the Olympic bronze medal winner in the 110-meter hurdles last year, has been suspended from competition through June 10, for refusing to be tested for drugs at an indoor meet two months ago in Fairfax, Va.

title: Metro Datelines; Special Prosecutor Is Sought in Shooting
description: A minister and the head of the N.A.A.C.P. in New Rochelle have called upon Gov. Mario Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the death of a black man who was shot by the police when he waved a toy submachine gun at three officers.

title: Oil Slick Stalls Near Kodiak; Crews Will Attack With Nets
description: The oil spill from the Exxon Valdez stalled today near Kodiak, and crews prepared to attack the leading edge of the slick with nets.

title: Huge Plane Order Due From Aircraft Lessor
description: GPA Group Ltd., the world's leading aircraft-leasing company, will announce the largest aircraft order in history next week, a GPA executive said today.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
HDM in Shanghai
description: LEAD: HDM has opened a full-service office in Shanghai. The New York-based agency became the first multinational shop to open an office in China three years ago, when it started a Beijing office. HDM, a joint venture of Young & Rubicam, Dentsu of Japan and Eurocom, has billed more than $3 million in China since 1986.

title: Broadcasting 'Fairness' Bill
description: A House committee today approved a bill that would require broadcasters to use programs that provide opposing views of controversial issues.

title: E-Z-EM Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Ex-Rep. Rousselot Heads Lincoln Savings
description: John H. Rousselot, a former Congressman from California who is seeking to buy the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, was named chairman and chief executive of the institution yesterday.

title: Contra Aid Is Approved by House Committee
description: By a vote of 32 to 6, the House Foreign Affairs Committee today approved a request for further aid to the Nicaraguan guerrillas. The full House of Representatives is expected to approve the proposal this week.

title: A Celebration for the Toast of Two Continents
description: Embassies in the capital entertain at the drop of a hat to promote diplomacy and their countries' cultural and commercial markets. In the case of Monday night's reception at the Royal Thai Embassy in honor of Porntip Narkhirunkanok, crowned Miss Universe last year, it was a celebration of all three.

title: Ibn Batuta and Sitar Challenging Marco Polo and Violin in Schools
description: The push to rid American education of what critics say is a Western and European bias is beginning to change the way history, literature and the arts are being taught from grade school through graduate school.

title: Yankees Lose 7th In a Row
description: In the end, the night looked like all the others. The Yankees played and lost, and in the quiet of their clubhouse, they wondered when they would win again. Their streak is now seven losses in seven games, and there is no end in sight.

title: Late and Lame on The Big Spill
description: Can the Federal Government do more to save Prince William Sound? The near-term answer is no. Despite the dispatch of troops and the brave work of local citizens, the best to be hoped for is that favorable winds blow the oil slick out to sea.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Indigo Girls

title: South Africa Fraud Case
description: South African police have begun an international search for five men who are believed to have defrauded the Trust Bank of Africa and the First National Bank of Southern Africa out of about $19 million. One suspect, Stuart Pegg, a Johannesburg businessman, is believed to have fled to the United States, and the police said they had asked American authorities to help find him. The men are said to have forged the signature of a senior Trust Bank official on interbank documents used to approve cash withdrawals at one bank from an account at another.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
The Artistic Pursuits Of 2 Grey Executives
description: LEAD: Artists and ad people have more in common than the former might wish to acknowledge, but two executives at Grey Advertising confidently describe themselves as both.

title: Social Security: On Whose Account?
description: Americans now regularly provide their nine-digit Social Security numbers for commercial activities from mortgages to credit cards. So what's wrong with the Social Security Administration lubricating the gears of commerce by verifying numbers for credit-reporting agencies?

title: 3 Soviet Astronauts to Leave The Mir Station Unmanned
description: Three Soviet astronauts aboard the Mir space station will return to Earth on April 27, leaving the orbiter unmanned for the first time in more than two years, Tass, the official press agency, said today.

title: WINE TALK
description: ONE can only guess at the number of people who do not or will not drink gewurztraminer because they can't get past the name. Actually, it's not so difficult; so long as you put the accent on the ''wurz,'' it doesn't matter much what you do with the other four syllables.

title: At State, The Acid Of Distrust Corrodes
description: There are political appointees and there are career members of the Government who have seen many Presidents come and go, and in the beginning there can be strains. At Foggy Bottom, the tensions between Foreign Service officers and the inner circle surrounding Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d have been vented in a wicked parody of the State Department employee newsletter.

title: How Many Children Will Abortion Foes Take In?; Misogynist Credo
description: To the Editor:

title: Issue for Editors' Meeting: News vs. Profits
description: A decade or two ago, most editors of major newspapers considered it a principal duty to guard the barricade that separates the news side of a paper from the business side.

title: Collaborative Research reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
Refuseniks and Other Refugees
description: The gateway is packed: many more foreigners want admission to the United States than can be accommodated. Most are immigrants who seek a better life. Some are refugees fleeing persecution. But suddenly, many are not exactly either. What's to be done about them?

title: Marcade Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $673,000 for the quarter and $3,798,000 for the year; the year also included a loss of $1,042,000 on the early retirement of debt. c-After tax loss carryforwards of $638,000 for the quarter and $2,611,000 for the year, and a loss of $2,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,227,000 for the year, both on debt restructuring. The latest quarter's net from operations included a pretax gain on a litigation settlement of $675,000 and a pretax gain on pension termination of $525,000. The net from operations for 1989 included a pretax gain on the sale of property of $1,255,000, a pretax gain on a litigation settlement of $675,000, and a gain on pension termination of $525,000. The year 1988 included a pretax gain on the sale of property of $1,565,000.

title: 12 Bodies Are Found in Texas Near Border
description: Twelve bodies were found in graves in a field outside the town of Matamoros, on the Mexican border, the authorities said today.

Senate, Rejecting Bush Program, Backs Minimum Wage of $4.55
description: Setting the stage for a veto confrontation with President Bush, the Senate accepted a Democratic proposal today that would raise the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour over three years and establish a sub-minimum wage for first-time workers.

title: Georgian Repast: Food and Then Debate
description: Old friends from the city of Tbilisi conferred for their usual quiet lunch today, anxious about what the deadly events back home imply for perestroika as much as traditional Georgian pride.

title: Everglades Fire Covers South Florida With Smoke
description: A thousand acres of brush burned in the Everglades today, covering South Florida with a thick acrid smoke that cut visibility to half a half and forced many Miami residents indoors.

Kafka's Homeland Lifts Its Ban
description: Twenty years after his writings were denounced and suppressed following the brief political and artistic flowering that came to be known as the Prague Spring, Franz Kafka is to be published once again in his native land.

title: MOSCOW TIGHTENS GEORGIA SECURITY
description: The Soviet authorities increased their pressure on nationalists in the republic of Georgia today, with armed soldiers patrolling the streets of the capital, Tbilisi, as an official day of mourning was observed.

title: Girls Catching Up to Boys in Scholarship Programs
description: Boys continued to outnumber girls this year as recipients of state-sponsored college scholarships, but the gap narrowed in the wake of a court order requiring that a fairer method be used in making the awards.

title: Reaction to Alaska Spill Derails Bill to Allow Oil Drilling in Refuge
description: The oil spill in Alaska has derailed efforts to speed legislation opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas development, but the bill's supporters in Congress say they are not giving up.

Six Indicted In California Savings Case
description: In a case that mixed the elements of a novel with the problem of fraud in the savings and loan industry, a Federal grand jury here today indicted six people on charges of defrauding a California savings institution of more than $16 million.

title: Interior Is Renewing Water Lease Despite Concerns on Environment
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. announced today that he was renewing a long-term water lease in California, despite a finding by the Environmental Protection Agency that the effect on the environment should first be assessed.

title: 'Centrist' Is Named Archbishop in Baltimore
description: A Roman Catholic bishop known for his work in building interfaith bonds was named yesterday to head the Archdiocese of Baltimore, the church's oldest diocese in the United States.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds Are Up in Dull Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved marginally higher in another dull session yesterday.

title: Henry Luhrman Dies; Press Agent Was 47
description: Henry Luhrman, a theatrical and nightclub press agent for two decades, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 47 years old. Dr. Kevin Cahill, a spokesman for the hospital, said the cause was heart failure brought on by pneumonia.

title: Everyday Magic: Leftovers as Art
description: ALL the good cooks I know, professionals and home cooks alike, are misers in the kitchen. I am not talking here about the avariciousness of a deceitful cook who skimps on ingredients and shortchanges guests, or the prudishness of a cook whose cuisine lacks imagination. Rather, I am referring to the stinginess that is the result of a profound respect good cooks share for raw ingredients, a sound, common-sense approach they bring to their trade and a thorough knowledge of the cooking process.

title: International Research & Deelopement reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
About Education
description: rrLike any proud grandfather, Dr. Reuven Feuerstein produces pictures of his new grandson. There is a difference: the baby has Down's syndrome, a chromosomal disorder that used to be called mongolism because of the victims' appearance. Dr. Feuerstein shows the picture not to arouse sympathy but to illustrate how his interaction with the infant has already evoked normal responses, like smiles and imitation of sounds.

title: 'Subterfuge' Is Cited
description: Allowing an athlete to dip into a trust fund that is supposed to be closed until he retires is ''pure subterfuge,'' Charles Dubin, the head of a Canadian inquiry into drugs in amateur sport, said yesterday in Toronto.

title: Kollmorgen Invites Bids
description: The Kollmorgen Corporation, a maker of electromechanical components, which has been resisting an unsolicited takeover since December, said yesterday that its board had decided to pursue the sale of the company or one or more of its businesses.

New York City Retail Sales Off
description: Several of New York's largest retailers said yesterday that their sales in March lagged 1.1 percent behind those of a year earlier in their stores in the city. In the metropolitan area, the stores reported an average gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent, a spot-check found.

title: Nets Suffer 15th Loss In a Row on the Road
description: Ricky Pierce's 19 points and Milwaukee's two scoring spurts, one closing the first half and the other opening the second, led the Bucks to a 125-93 victory over the Nets tonight. It was New Jersey's 15th loss in a row on the road.

description: b-Included a $300,000 after-tax gain from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on March 11 about allegations of human rights violations by the Angola guerrilla movement led by Jonas Savimbi inaccurately described statements by Fred Bridgland, a British journalist. Mr. Bridgland said he had evidence that Tito Chingunji, an official of the guerrilla movement, had been accused of witchcraft and of plotting against Mr. Savimbi and that screams had been heard from a hut to which Mr. Chingunji had been confined; he did not say Mr. Chingunji had been tortured.

title: U.S. Urged Not to Back Private Space Station
description: The National Research Council, citing the lack of a ''compelling need'' in the next decade, recommended yesterday that the Government abandon plans to back a privately developed space station that would be put in orbit years ahead of the space agency's own multibillion-dollar station.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Books of The Times; The Post-Chernobyl Blues, From an East German Perspective
description: The narrative of ''Accident: A Day's News'' unfolds during one day, and it centers on two main events: the protagonist, an East German writer, hears the news of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster; at the same time, her brother is undergoing an intricate brain-tumor operation.

title:

Celebrity Portrait Campaigns
description: LEAD: IN a studio portrait of the actor Julian Sands, the high-angle shot emphasizes his sweeping blond hair, high forehead and aquiline nose. Mr. Sands is selling clothes for Barney's, but the details of his dark $215 jacket by Basco disappear in the soft lighting.

title: Review/Organ; Yves Castagnet in Recital
description: In its seeming capacity as a conduit for French music in New York City, the Church of St. Vincent de Paul presented a recital on Monday by Yves Castagnet, who since just last year has held the prestigious post of titulaire of the Choir Organ of Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris.

title: Pact Reached For 36% Rise In Jobless Pay
description: Breaking a longstanding deadlock, legislative leaders and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo agreed today to increase New York State's maximum unemployment insurance benefit by 36 percent, the first raise in five years.

description: Across Western Europe, mainstream politicians are scrambling to embrace the cause of the endangered environment as small ecological parties register startling electoral triumphs.

description: Let's suppose a Mr. Esposito and a Mr. Fisher are seated next to each other on a flight. Esposito: Are you a traveling salesman? Fisher: You might say so. I'm a coach on a recruiting trip.

title: U.S. Soccer Star Ailing
description: Rick Davis, captain of the United States national soccer team, is recovering slowly from his second knee operation in four months and is questionable for Sunday's crucial World Cup qualifying game against Costa Rica.

title: Young in China Being Stirred By an Old-Time Christianity
description: Her hair still glistening with holy water, her spirit soaring with excitement, Lu Yun, newly baptized, brimmed with the kind of reverent ardor that leaves Communist officials queasy.

title: Deadwood Favors Gambling
description: Voters today overwhelmingly approved a return to legalized gambling in this historic Black Hills town, where Wild Bill Hickock was shot to death in a frontier card game. City leaders hope games of chance will revive Deadwood's economy.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $160,000. Year-ago quarter ended March 26, 1988. Year-ago figures were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

description: If you were wondering what the Mets were going to do with all those pitchers, they gave a clue tonight when they platooned three pitchers like outfielders against the Pittsburgh Pirates: Bob Ojeda going the first five innings, Sid Fernandez the next three and Randy Myers the three after that.

title: RUSSIANS PLANNING RECOVERY OF SUB
description: The Soviet Navy indicated today that it intended to try to raise the nuclear submarine lost Friday almost a mile deep in the Norwegian Sea after a shipboard fire.

title: International Paper Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
From One Chicken, Spicy and Earthy Fare
description: NOTHING is as versatile and economical as chicken, especially when bought whole. Compare the prices of a whole chicken and one that has been cut up and note the dramatic difference. Merely splitting a chicken in half increases its cost at least 15 to 20 percent and, should you want to buy only the breasts or drumsticks, you'll find the price per pound is more than double that of a whole chicken. Boned chicken pieces are, of course, costlier still.

title: NAMIBIA TRANSITION AGAIN GOES AWRY
description: An assembly point for Namibian guerrillas being returned to Angola opened here in the dense bush today, but the United Nations troops sent to run it arrived late and the guerrillas did not show up at all.

description: THE abortion-rights march through the streets of Washington on Sunday was really two marches. Maybe there are always two marches, the celebrities in front - whether they be Hollywood stars or politicians or both - and behind them, all the ''just plain folk.''

title: Review/Dance; For Choreographers, a Stage and a Chance to Shine
description: The Vital Signs Dance Collective seeks to provide several choreographers with opportunities to stage works. Its intentions are laudable. But most of the dances it presented Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center were extremely weak.

description: While cyclists, panhandlers and a good spring crowd of strollers enjoyed the sun on the Boardwalk early today, gamblers, diners and employees inside the Atlantis Casino were subdued, wondering whether the financially troubled casino-hotel might be forced to close after eight years of operation. title: Bank Yields Rise Again In Week
description: Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit continued to rise in the week that ended yesterday, despite expectations that interest rates were peaking.

description: CBS-TV reported yesterday that it had confirmed through several sources that former friends of Pete Rose have told baseball investigators they had placed bets for the Cincinnati manager on baseball games, including bets on his own team.

description: All winter, especially on days when pollution readings reached record levels, the 20 million inhabitants of this metropolis longed for spring. April, with its normally refreshing winds, has finally arrived, yet there is no relief in sight.

title: Metro Datelines; Subway Rider Is Shot As Two Youths Fight
description: Shots were fired during a fight yesterday afternoon between two teen-age boys on a subway train, and another teen-ager, believed to be a bystander, received a superficial gunshot wound to the left arm, the police reported.

title: Review/Recital; Murray Perahia, Beyond the Classical
description: If one could chart the development of talented pianists, the line would not be a steady upward curve but a series of plateaus, representing pauses for refining technical, intellectual or temperamental approaches to music. These periods of reassessment may be brief but, in some instances, actually force the artist to retire from the stage for years. The famous midcareer withdrawals of Arthur Rubinstein and Vladimir Horowitz come most easily to mind. Fortunately for career continuity, most important pianists find less radical ways to work through blockages and mount to the next plateau.

title: Reviews/Rock; Neville Brothers' Harmony
description: The circumstances behind a good show are often conjectural. The Neville Brothers' sold-out, ecstatic two-hour concert at the Ritz Friday night, special even by their standards, might be explained by the recent release of one of their best records, solid new material and a New York audience hungry for New Orleans music. It was a masterpiece of a show, the type of performance that brings 3,000 people together in a club, chases the blues and sends them out into the night as better people.
