description: To the Editor:

title: Hei Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
description: b-Included a tax credit of $7,000. c-Included tax credits of $41,500 and $81,500 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Lessons
description: Robert R. Spillane arrived in Fairfax County, Va., four years ago to become superintendent of schools with a bold strategy to bolster the quality of the teaching force.

title: Tele-Metropole Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago 6 months' results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Great American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Share earnings for the latest quarter was less than one cent a share.

title: Hextall Does It All
description: Ron Hextall's second career goal was a carbon copy of the Philadelphia goaltender's first, but the stakes were higher tonight.

title: Chiefs Drop Kenney
description: Bill Kenney, the Kansas City Chiefs' starting quarterback for most of this decade, has been told that he will not play for the club next season.

title: Review/Music; An American, With West German Winds
description: Dennis Russell Davies is one of the best-known American conductors, and one of the best-known champions of American music. But in recent years he has made the bulk of his career in West Germany, first in Stuttgart and now in Bonn. Mostly he conducts operas and orchestras. But Mr. Davies is also an accomplished pianist, and it was in that guise that he appeared Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall for a program of four works for piano and winds with the Stuttgart Wind Quintet.

title: Concern Is a Union Label
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bruins and Blues Clinch Series
description: Randy Burridge of the Bruins broke a scoreless tie with a shorthanded goal in the second period as Boston defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 4-1, and wrapped up their series tonight.

title: John Dolce, Educator And Orthodontist, 78
description: Dr. John Dolce, an orthodontist who headed several organizations in the dental profession, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: Knicks Win a Title On Day Off
description: It was a long time coming, but the Knicks are the Atlantic Division champions for the first time in 18 seasons. And they accomplished the feat last night without playing.

title: Florida Bank Is Ordered To Sell Its Art Collection
description: Florida bank regulators have ruled that the Centrust Savings Bank, a major Miami savings and loan institution that has recently reported millions in losses, must divest itself within the next six months of a $28 million art collection bought over the last year. Included in the demand is a Rubens painting for which the bank paid $13.2 million.

title: Reviews/Music; Bonga in Three Languages
description: About halfway through his short set at S.O.B.'s on Saturday night, Bonga, the Angolan singer and percussionist who is based in Paris, said thank you in English, Portuguese and Spanish. His band, made up of Cape Verdians living in Rhode Island, was playing Cape Verdian music, which is very much influenced by Haitian dance music called compas. Bonga also brought along his musical sidekick from Paris, a Brazilian guitarist; as it is with most post-colonial cultures, different worlds have fused to create a distinct product.

title: Universal Foods reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a non-operating charge of $500,000 for repurchase of common stock for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Perot Is Limited On E.D.S. Hiring
description: A circuit court judge in Fairfax County, Va., has ruled that that H. Ross Perot's agreement with the Electronic Data Systems Corporation does not give him the right to hire E.D.S. employees to work for the Perot Systems Corporation for an unlimited amount of time, as his lawyers had said.

title: In Quick Season, Johns Hopkins Is a Step Ahead
description: Because of academic schedules that have final examinations early in May, the college lacrosse season must be compacted into March and April, two wet, short months for this outdoor sport.

title: Lee Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Greening of Europe
description: Politicians in Western Europe are scrambling to embrace ecological issues as environmentalist parties grow. Page A10.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13 Mexico will borrow $3.6 billion to fight a debt-imposed squeeze on wages and growth, under a tentative agreement with the International Monetary Fund that officials said has been reached. Page A1

title: Slain Knife-Wielder Had Troubled Past
description: The man who was killed by a police officer Monday afternoon after he slashed at pedestrians with a 12-inch blade on a crowded East Side street had been arrested six months ago in Brooklyn for menacing people with a knife, the police said yesterday.

title: State Dept. Applauds Salinas In Arrest of Top Drug Figure
description: Mexico's arrest of a reputed drug baron proves that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is determined to act against the narcotics trade, the United States said today.

title: The Post- Cold War Era
description: It is disappointing to hear that the strategic review being prepared for President Bush recommends scarcely anything but more of the same in foreign policy. There are important dates in the near future when the new American Government seriously needs to offer the rapidly changing world a clear sense of its vision.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: American Museum of Historial Documents reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $131,452 and $136,050 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $6,513 for the quarter and $10,372 for the 6 months.

title: When Planning a Bout Is a Struggle
description: While Don King and Bill Cayton parry one another's legal maneuvers in their struggle to control Mike Tyson's career, rival fight operatives have been trying to dope out how to do business these days with the heavyweight champion. After all, just who's in charge here? In conversations with fight men, King has left the impression that as Tyson's ''adviser,'' he's the only one who can get results.

title: Rio Branco Journal; A Death in the Amazon, From Symbol to Script
description: The movie producer's business card read ''Beverly Hills,'' but her T-shirt proclaimed ''The Union of Acre Natives.''

title: Boston Journal; Blacks and Jews Share A Night Like No Other
description: Why was this Monday night different from all other nights in Boston?

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
People
description: LEAD: * Timothy Corrigan has been promoted to executive vice president of Backer Spielvogel Bates/Europe.

title: Senators Offer Bill to Combat New York Tax on Commuters
description: The Senators from New Jersey and Connecticut today introduced legislation meant to block the revised tax New York has imposed on out-of-state commuters.

title: 'A Sign of Social Decay'
description: To The Living Section:

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday misidentified the founder of the Capitol Hill newspaper Roll Call. He is Sid Yudain.

title: Surgery for Bell
description: Buddy Bell, the Texas Ranger designated hitter, underwent successful arthroscopic surgery on his left knee yesterday at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati, the club announced.

title: Wright Violated Disclosure Rules, Ethics Panel Is Expected to Decide
description: The House ethics committee has decided that Speaker Jim Wright of Texas should have reported as gifts various financial benefits he and his wife received from their relationship with a Fort Worth real estate developer, Democrats on Capitol Hill said today.

title: Middle Schools Grow in Academic Importance
description: LEAD: As New York and other cities continue to grapple with ways to reduce the number of high school dropouts, school boards are increasingly looking to middle schools, a relatively new educational division, to provide guidance and support to keep students on the right path.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ACA Joe Inc., San Francisco, said its reorganization plan had been approved by Federal bankruptcy court.

title: Ueberroth Pessimistic On Eastern
description: Peter V. Ueberroth said last night that he had turned pessimistic about his attempt to buy Eastern Airlines from the Texas Air Corporation.

title: The Drug Czar and His Subjects
description: William Bennett's job is to direct an orchestra of Federal agencies involved in drug control. To judge by his first pronouncement, he must sometimes feel as if he's down in the pit among the woodwinds, overwhelmed by proud, powerful departments. Thus, while his new plan for the District of Columbia may be a good beginning, it's too early to tell whether it can ease the pain and fear of bullet-riddled neighborhoods.

title: Review/Television; People Obsessed With Themselves
description: Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, ''American Playhouse'' is presenting ''Life Under Water'' by Richard Greenberg, whose Broadway play, ''Eastern Standard,'' was widely acclaimed this season.

title: Vivigen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. HEARING ON OIL EMBARGO AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Texas Unit Helps NCNB to Post 8.3% Gain in Earnings
description: The NCNB Corporation yesterday announced first-quarter earnings that were stronger than expected and said it would not abandon its effort to merge with the Citizens and Southern Corporation of Atlanta.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Addenda
description: LEAD: * Diamandis Communications will start another magazine, Elle Decor, in October. The magazine will have an initial projected circulation of 200,000, and will publish 10 issues a year.

title: Bridge
description: The Marathon Battle of the Sexes, with simultaneous play in New York City and Paris, has changed direction again. At midday yesterday, with 10 of 14 days of play completed, the men's team, which lost the lead Sunday, had regained it. They were ahead by 181 imps at one point, but the lead was cut to the tiny margin of 24 imps by 4 P.M.

title: EATING WELL
description: LEAD: BEEF, one of the victims of the food temperance movement, need not be just a pleasant memory for all of us. By incorporating beef as a flavor element in a dish composed mostly of grains, legumes and other vegetables, you can limit intake to around three ounces per occasion.

title: Ford Proxy On Salaries
description: The Ford Motor Company's top two executives earned higher salaries and smaller bonuses in 1988 than in the previous year, but the largest changes in their compensation stemmed from the timing of their exercise of stock options.

title: Charles Walcutt, 80, A Reading Educator
description: Dr. Charles C. Walcutt, a professor of English who campaigned against the ''look-say'' method of teaching reading and urged a return to basic education, died of amyotropic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, yesterday at his home in Great Neck. L.I. He was 80 years old. Dr. Walcutt, who was long associated with the Reading Reform Foundation, became concerned about what he saw as the misteaching of reading in the 1940's. He feared such teaching would lead to growing functional illiteracy.

title: A Kinder and Gentler Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner, a man known for his impatience and for his hastiness in times like these, said yesterday that he would not rush to judgment on his troubled Yankees, even though with a 1-6 record they are off to one of the worst starts in their history.

title: Reitmans Canada Ltd reports earnings for
description: b-After a special gain of $668,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Swiss Move to Curb Laundering of Money
description: Switzerland's Federal Banking Commission said in a report today that it intends to tighten regulations against money laundering.

title: Atari Weighs In With a One-Pound PC
description: The personal computer is continuing to shrink. As designers squeeze more transistors onto a single silicon chip, they are able to put more computing power into smaller packages. The Atari Corporation has now produced a computer compatible with the I.B.M. PC that is about the size of a videocassette and weighs one pound.

title: Premdor Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special gain of $215,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: How Many Children Will Abortion Foes Take In?
description: To the Editor:

title: General Instrument Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
22 Traders Face Charges
description: Twenty-two Chicago traders face possible fines and suspension if they are found to have taken part in a scheme to pre-arrange trades for United States Treasury bond futures contracts.

title: DDI Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Economic Leverage Is Urged In Pressing East Bloc Change
description: The world's industrial democracies should use their economic leverage to encourage economic and political change in Communist Europe while seeking to draw the Soviet Union and Eastern European states into closer association with international economic organizations, a Trilateral Commission study contends.

title: White House Backs Drug Plan but Shuns a Brawl
description: The White House today gave full support to William J. Bennett's plan to combat the drug epidemic in the nation's capital but steered clear of a political brawl with Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. ''We are in this to solve the drug problem, not to pick fights,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, avoiding Mr. Bennett's combative stance a day earlier.

title: Accord Seen as Victory for Mexico
description: Addressing a nation worn out by seven years of austerity and stagnation, Finance Minister Pedro Aspe tonight described a new agreement reached with the International Monetary Fund as ''a full endorsement of Mexico's economic strategy'' that would break the foreign debt logjam that has threatened to plunge Mexico deeper into crisis.

title: Provincial Flavors In an Ageless Ritual
description: WHEN Bertrand Cerf was growing up in Paris in the 1950's it was his job to go to the corner bakery and return home with a baguette for the evening meal. On Fridays he went to the same bakery and picked up a braided baguette for the Jewish sabbath.

title: Qume Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: ACCORD IS REACHED FOR I.M.F. TO LEND MEXICO $3.6 BILLION
description: Mexico has reached a tentative agreement to borrow $3.6 billion from the International Monetary Fund to help it dig out of years of a debt-imposed squeeze on wages and growth. The accord was reported today by officials of the Mexican Government, the Bush Administration and banks.

title: Top School Official In Boston Is Granted Shortened Contract
description: A bitterly divided Boston School Committee voted tonight to grant Laval S. Wilson, the school system's first black supertintendent, a two-year renewal of his contract.

title: Cineplex Officials To Acquire Control
description: The two top executives of the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, a leading United States and Canadian theater operator and movie production house, will have control of the Toronto-based company after acquiring 7.3 million shares from Charles Bronfman, co-chairman of the Seagram Company.

title: Computers Are Due From Sun
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. is nothing if not ambitious.

title: Threats Terrify Small School
description: School buses had state police escorts and absenteeism was up today, a day after threatening grafitti was found on a school wall. About 100 of 850 students were absent from the Brooklyn School, where the words ''You're Dead'' and an assault rifle were spray-painted on a wall Monday, 10 days after an anonymous woman threatened in a telephone call to shoot children at the school.

title: Dana Foundation to Help Blacks Become College Teachers
description: To reverse a nationwide decline in the number of college teachers who are black, a New York City foundation has organized an unusual partnership between predominantly black colleges and a major research university.

title: Of Interest to U.S. Navy
description: The United States Navy would like to get a look at the sunken Soviet submarine and has the technical ability to do so, American naval officers say.

title: Lexington Precision reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After tax credits of $50,000 and $200,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the periods also included securities and investment gains of $728,000 for the quarter and $4,719,000 for the 9 months, and writedowns of marketable securities of $1,650,000 and $2,078,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and included gains of $1,330,000 from the repurchase of notes. d-Net loss and after a gain of $1,674,000 from the repurchase of notes. The company recorded a direct charge to stockholders equity of $802,000 to reduce the carrying value of common stock held for long-term investment purposes to the lower of cost or market value. The latest period results included the business of Elastomeric Products Inc. since Dec. 2, 1988, the date it was acquired.

title: Keystone Consolidated Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $845,000. c-Net loss and included a loss of $128,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Federal Paper Board Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hearth Cooking for Modern Appetites
description: LEAD: ABOUT 20 years ago, Bill and Cindy Clark bought a 1790 cottage in Coventry, Conn., and began spending their weekends scraping, painting and staining. Since Mrs. Clark had little time to cook, she often set a pot of stew in the fireplace to simmer.

title: Hospital Union Hopes to Heal A Bitter Split
description: For much of its existence, Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union was synonymous with the civil rights movement and progressive politics. It fought for voter rights and fair housing alongside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the Harlem Congressman.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WITH the scarcity and soaring prices of bay scallops in the Northeast in recent years, I have been cooking sea scallops almost exclusively. Sea scallops, when properly cooked, are just as tender and delicious, if not quite as sweet, as the best bay scallops from Long Island. Dozens of varieties of scallops are found around the country, and all lend themselves to extremely fast cooking.

title: Metro Datelines; Owner Killed in Fire At Religious Store
description: The owner of a Brooklyn store that sells religious objects was found dead yesterday by firefighters battling a suspicious blaze that ripped through the ground-floor store, the Fire Department said.

title: Provigo Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 28
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $500,000 and an $8.7 million charge. c-After a gain of $1.5 million. The prior year's sales were restated. The company said the $8.7 million charge was mainly from the disposal of the East Coast division of consumers distributing. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New York Vintners To Promote Vinifera
description: IN a move intended to speed up the revolution in New York State's premium-wine industry, a handful of vintners have formed an organization to promote wines made exclusively from vinifera grapes, the species that produces the finest wines of Europe and California.

title: Reviews/Music; The Ordinaires Shed Irony And Join Information Age
description: In the early 1980's, when the Ordinaires came on the New York scene, they seemed like the perfect group for both downtown and the information age. With two violins, two saxophones, two guitars, cello, bass and drums, the group could hurtle through its original, eclectic compositions, evidently drawing on the records of a collector with expendable income: folk music from around the world collided with the sequins of gaudy commercial music, the European classical tradition and all the varieties of rock-and-roll. And since their sensibility - and their often obvious inability to play their instruments - was deeply ironic, they fit their time.

title: House Unit In Bailout Vote Shift
description: In a seesaw battle, a House subcommittee first voted today to greatly weaken the tough capital requirements for savings institutions proposed by the Bush Administration, then undid much of its work.

title: Computer Animation Now Coming of Age By LAWRENCE M. FISHER
description: For more than a dozen years Alvy Ray Smith and Edwin Catmull, two pioneers in computer graphics, made an annual trek to the Walt Disney Studios to urge that Disney's cartoon animators consider using computers to draw and color the animation frames that have been done by hand since the birth of Mickey Mouse. Each year the Disney people would listen and say, ''not yet.''

title: Louis Soriano, 84, Dies; Led Dodger Band
description: Louis Soriano, the originator and leader of the Brooklyn Dodger Sym-Phony, a light-hearted band of nonunion musicians who serenaded the Dodgers and musically harassed their opponents at Ebbets Field from 1938 until 1957, died Saturday at his home in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. He was 84 years old.

title: Biogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pressure on Jalalabad Tightening
description: The Soviet-backed Afghan Government asserted today that its defense of Jalalabad was not faltering in the face of stepped-up guerrilla attacks. But information from the Government and the Muslim insurgents indicated that the battle for the city might be entering a decisive phase.

title: Candid Esposito Itemizes a Long List of Complaints on Bergeron
description: Phil Esposito, in his first extended remarks since dismissing Michel Bergeron as coach of the Rangers 10 days earlier, yesterday leveled an array of charges against Bergeron, ranging from such slight transgressions as not returning phone calls to such serious offenses as secretly trying to instigate trades with opposing coaches.

title: Western Lands Vow $133 Million in Aid For Sudanese Relief
description: Western nations pledged $55 million today in additional aid to fight famine in the southern Sudan, thus raising the $133 million that the United Nations had sought for relief efforts.

title: Muriel Freeman Has a Wedding
description: Muriel Leopold Freeman and Richard L. Blum Jr. were marriedyesterday at the bride's home in New York by Judge Morris E. Lasker of Federal District Court in New York.

title: An Irish Heart Warmed
description: To The Living Section:

title: Quayle Plans Asian Trip
description: Vice President Dan Quayle will visit Australia, Indonesia, Singapore and Thailand on a 12-day trip beginning April 24, his office announced today. Mr. Quayle, accompanied by his wife, Marilyn, will arrive in Australia for a five-day stay on April 26, it said.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: From Charlotte Neuville, Spirited Styles
description: CHARLOTTE NEUVILLE based much of her fall collection, shown Monday at the Plaza hotel, on the men's suit jacket. She calls her softly tailored version, with no buttons and the lapels rolling all the way to the waist, the ''boyfriend'' jacket, like the comfy, oversized coat a woman might borrow from a lover.

title: Economic Scene; Michael Milken's Other Accusers
description: WHY does the mere mention of Michael Milken's name bring a snarl to the lips of some of America's mildest-mannered corporate executives? That may seem a foolish question. After all, the Los Angeles investment banker has been indicted on 98 Federal charges ranging from fraud to racketeering. If the charges stick, Mr. Milken could face decades in prison and billions of dollars in penalties.

title: Reviews/Rock; Playing the Garden at Night: R.E.M. on an Arena Scale
description: For many bands, playing a sold-out show at Madison Square Garden symbolizes success. For R.E.M., whose current arena tour brought the band to Madison Square Garden on Monday night, it seemed to be a threat. R.E.M. rose out of the post-punk ''alternative'' music circuit -word of mouth, clubs, college radio stations - with a tuneful, introverted, fast-changing update of folk-rock, often with lyrics that needed to be pieced together by listeners.

title: Japan Said to Agree to Allot 40% of Work on Jet to U.S.
description: Japan has agreed that 40 percent of the work on a new jet fighter will be performed in the United States and has backed off from its reluctance to share technology from the venture, a Bush Administration official said today.

title: Indictment Says Northrop Falsified Tests on Missile and Bomber Parts
description: A Federal grand jury indicted the Northrop Corporation and five current and former employees today, accusing them of failing to conduct tests and falsifying test results on components of the Air Force's air-launched cruise missile and the Navy's AV-8B Harrier jet.

title: Birtcher Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Real Estate; Former Home Of J.C. Penney Is Renovated
description: SINCE J. C. Penney pulled up stakes in Manhattan last year and headed for its new corporate headquarters in Plano, Tex., its former home, a 45-story tower on the Avenue of the Americas between 52d and 53d Streets, has stood empty.

title: The Fight for Northwest Heats Up
description: The effort by Marvin Davis, the Los Angeles-based industrialist, to win control of Northwest Airlines erupted into battles on several fronts today. Mr. Davis vowed to stage a proxy fight to take control of Northwest's board. Northwest responded by suing Mr. Davis in Federal court, charging that he was illegally interfering with Northwest's labor negotiations by bargaining on his own with the carrier's pilots.

title: Contel Cellular reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: He Knew When To Stop
description: The Thurber House in Columbus, Ohio, is just one of several houses the Thurber family occupied at various times in that city. It was chosen to be The Thurber House because, for one thing, nothing vital to American literature happened in the others, which in any case had long since gone to ruin.

title: Billions Blown on Health
description: Each day this year, Americans will spend $200 million more on health care than they did last year. At the year's end, the total will be $620 billion, up from $550 billion in 1988. And in less than two years, America will break the $2-billion-a-day barrier in health-care spending.

title: Embarrassed U.F.T. Shifts Campaign Policy
description: In a change of strategy, the United Federation of Teachers, long a dominant force in New York City school board elections, is backing fewer candidates in the contests May 2, and more of those it is endorsing have children or grandchildren in the schools.

title: For Klein, Neatness and Luxury Count
description: CALVIN KLEIN presented a lovely, serene collection yesterday in his showroom. It was cleanly focused on pale colors, luxurious materials like cashmere and suede, and simple shapes. Together with the Bill Blass show of fall and winter fashions Monday, it introduced a keenly sophisticated way of dressing, paying homage to tailored clothing with no distraction in the way of glitzy jewelry or hats. Accessories are scarves tucked into necklines of blouses or cashmere polo shirts, belts with a lot of hardware on them and shawls.

title: Market Place; Brady Plan Lifts Big Bank Stocks
description: TREASURY Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's strategy for reducing the debt of less developed countries has lent a new sparkle to bank stocks in the last month.

title: Kentucky Eyes Olson
description: Lute Olson, the Arizona basketball coach, is going to the University of Kentucky for talks about the coaching vacancy created when Eddie Sutton left under fire.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Rolling Stone Purchases Rest of US Magazine
description: LEAD: Rolling Stone magazine became sole owner of US magazine yesterday by acquiring a 75 percent share of the biweekly publication from Warner Communications. Neither company would disclose the terms of the deal. Straight Arrow Publishers, the parent company of Rolling Stone, has held a 25 percent stake in the publication since 1985, but Jann S.

title: Dow Rises 9.71, to 2,311.58, as Dollar Gains
description: Stock prices rebounded yesterday, helped by a marginally stronger dollar and bond market.

title: Petro-Canada reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $22 million of the company's investment in Sedpex Inc. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mississippi to Be Host Of Ballet Competition
description: The Fourth U.S.A. International Ballet Competition is to take place from June 17 to July 1 in Jackson, Miss., it has been announced.

title: 1,773 Ways to Eat Jell-O, And Other Test-Kitchen Tales
description: TUCKED behind the walls of General Foods in White Plains is a carefully guarded place, where staff members all wear laboratory coats and secrets abound.

title: INSIDE
description: Ethics Panel on Wright The House ethics committee has decided that Speaker Jim Wright should have reported various financial benefits he and his wife received from a Texas developer as gifts. Page A18. Contra Package Advances The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a request for up to $66.6 million to supply the Nicaraguan rebels with food, clothing and medicine through February 1990. Page A5. Rights Nominee Opposed William Lucas, the Detroit lawyer selected to head the Justice Department's rights division, has inspired a heated reaction from blacks in his hometown. Page A18. Unemployment Pay Raised After a long deadlock, New York State leaders agreed to increase unemployment benefits by 36 percent to $245 a week, the state's first raise in five years. Page B1.

title: 3 Collections, From Stark To Sumptuous
description: RALPH LAUREN, Oscar de la Renta, Carolyne Roehm. Rat-tat-tat. Three major collections back to back yesterday. Together they embrace the major trends as the fall and winter fashion openings in New York pass the halfway mark. The sweep is vast, from Mr. Lauren's minimalist approach to the sumptuous luxury of Mr. de la Renta and Ms. Roehm.

title: College, in the Realm of the Possible
description: A DOZEN seventh graders, whose ideas of the future usually focus on next week, recently talked about career goals.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES (NFC) - Announced the retirement of Charles White, running back. COLLEGE BALL STATE - Named Deon Chester receivers coach. COLUMBIA - Named Tom Radulski and Sean McDonnell assistant football coaches. LOUISIANA STATE - Dismissed Loren Seagrave, women's track coach. NEW MEXICO - Announced that Vince Cappelli, baseball coach, would retire at the end of the season. NORTHERN INTERCOLLEGIATE CONFERENCE - Announced that Minnesota-Duluth would forfeit its 1987 football victories and league championship and its 1988 baseball victories for using an ineligible player. WASHINGTON - Named Russ Critchfield assistant basketball coach.

title: Ryan Flirts With a 6th No-Hitter
description: Nolan Ryan allowed one hit in eight shutout innings and struck out a team-record 15 batters tonight as the Texas Rangers beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 8-1.

title: Henny Jurriens, 40; Led Winnipeg Ballet
description: Henny Jurriens, the artistic director of the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, died in a car accident Sunday near Letellier, Manitoba. His wife, Judy, a former soloist with the Dutch National Ballet, was also killed. Mr. Jurriens was 40 years old, his wife was 36. Their 3-year-old daughter, Isa, survived the crash.

title: Reviews/Music; A Pianist Plays Beethoven
description: Suzanne Macahilig, a doctoral candidate in music at New York University who is working on a dissertation on Beethoven's piano sonatas, gave a recital of Beethoven, Mozart, Mendelssohn, Chopin, Andrew Imbrie and Hellmuth Dusedau at Weill Recital Hall Monday evening.

title: Review/Music; Conductor on a Marathon 2-Concert Day
description: Gennadi Rozhdestvensky was to conduct the American Composers Orchestra on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, but when the Soviet conductor fell ill and canceled his visit, the orchestra's resident conductor, Paul Lustig Dunkel, stepped in to lead the program.

title: Fund Yields Rise Again
description: Yields for money market mutual funds continued to rise in the week that ended yesterday, despite signs that interest rates may be leveling off as the economy shows signs of slowing. Credit market analysts expect further comfirmations of this trend tomorrow, when several important economic statistics are released.

title: Senators Raise Cap On Retiree Earnings Safe From Penalty
description: In a symbolic move unlikely to lead to any change in current law, the Senate agreed today to permit Social Security recipients under the age of 70 to earn an extra $1,080 a year in outside income without being subject to a reduction in Social Security benefits.

title: A.T.&T. Cited On Illegal Service
description: Capping a two-year investigation, the Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had illegally offered customized telephone networks to large business customers at special prices, terms and conditions.

title: Events: Brooklyn Botanic Garden Tours
description: Flowers, Living and Art, Steinhardt Conservatory, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; 718-622-4433.

title: Father Healy Follows a Catholic Tradition of Service to the State
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 New Division Heads At Arthur Andersen
description: In its latest move to quell outsiders' concerns and to close ranks, Arthur Andersen & Company yesterday picked a pair of veterans to run its two main divisions.

title: Silence and Glee: Eastern Bloc Reacts to Poland
description: From total official silence in Rumania to excited accounts in Hungary, the reactions across Eastern Europe to the milestone agreement in Poland last week reflected the differing degrees of enthusiasm in each country for newly proferred freedoms.

title: How to Prevent Peace
description: Saman Khouri is a Palestinian journalist in Jerusalem. He works for Agence France-Presse, and he has been managing editor of the English edition of the Jerusalem Arabic newspaper Al Fajr.

title: Following the Clay Birdie With Your Gun
description: Griffin & Howe, New York's venerable gunsmithing and sporting-arms retailing firm, will focus on sporting clays when it opens its shooting school at Sandanona in Millbrook, N.Y., April 24.

title: Abbie Hoffman Dies
description: The symbol of radical activism and the founder of the Yippie movement in the 1960's was found dead in his home in New Hope, Pa. He was 52 years old.

title: Elster Stands Tall This Time Around
description: The Mets didn't exactly plan it that way, but their best player these days is Kevin Elster, the shortstop who hit .214 last season and promptly won faint acclaim as a good glove with no bat.

title: Argonaut Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago revenue was restated for an accounting change. Latest quarter results included gains on sales of investments of $600,000, compared to $36.6 million for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary Monday about H. Lincoln Foster, a teacher and horticulturist, listed his survivors incorrectly. His wife, Laura Louise Foster, died in 1988.

title: Mexico Will Seek Debt Relief
description: Seeking ways to lighten its debt burden, Mexico will ask its American creditors and other foreign bankers to cut the value of their loans by $20 billion to $30 billion, international banking officials said today.

title: Early Pollens Make March, April and May The Cruelest Months
description: Every year about this time, many Americans come down with what they think is a cold that seems to hang on and on. In fact, they are allergic to the pollens of spring.

title: Former Chinese Party Chief Reportedly Has Heart Attack
description: Prime Minister Li Peng said today that Hu Yaobang, the former Communist Party leader, had been hospitalized for an undisclosed ailment.

title: Review/Dance; Under the Surface Glamour, A Concern With Conflicts
description: The virtuoso dancers in Jennifer Muller's company, the Works, inhabit a glossy-magazine world; their emotions look as sincere as those of fashion models in new-wave perfume ads.

title: Medical Unit Holds Talks
description: A group including members of the Bass family said that delegates had met with certain directors of American Medical International Inc. to discuss ways to enhance shareholder value.

title: Antiques War: Jousting For Position
description: WITH the new International Antique Dealers Show to open this fall at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 66th Street, long the site of the prestigious Winter Antiques Show, rumblings are heard of a so-called Antiques War. What better place for a war than the century-old armory, a Victorian dream of a medieval French fortress? Its towers are machicolated, or ''fitted with openings through which molten lead could be poured on an enemy trying to scale the walls,'' as Harmon H. Goldstone and Martha Dalrymple note in their guide to New York City landmarks.

title: SETTLERS' LEADER INDICTED IN ISRAEL IN DEATH OF ARAB
description: An Israeli court indicted the leader of Israel's settlers' movement today, accusing him of killing a Palestinian and wounding another after he was stoned outside his settlement last fall.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avon Products Inc., the maker of personal-care products, promoted Everett V. Goings and Phyllis Davis to executive vice president.

title:
Market Place;
An Overemphasis On Bankruptcies
description: LEAD: PERHAPS no investment sector is growing faster than the market for securities of companies that have sought bankruptcy protection.

title: Carson Rejects Offer by Bergner
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company said its board had unanimously rejected the proposal by the P. A. Bergner Company, a Milwaukee holding company, to buy Carson for at least $20 a share in cash, or $282 million.

title: Lazare Kaplan International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included tax credits of $35,000 and $141,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: With On-Off-and-On-Again Events, New Jersey School Will Greet Bush
description: This has been a hectic week for local school officials preparing for President Bush to visit a national education conference here on Thursday.

title: Washington Talk: The Pentagon
description: In the Army they talk about dodging the bullet. In the Air Force it is more like passing the missile.

title: McGwire Is Sidelined
description: Mark McGwire, Oakland's first baseman, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday because of a herniated disk.

title: Mr. Marino Makes Hostages of the Poor
description: Once again New York failed to pass the state budget by the April 1 deadline, disrupting communities, school districts, programs and payrolls. What distinguishes this year's delay - enough to boil the blood of even jaded Albany-watchers - is how the Senate Republican leadership plays politics with the poor.

title: Dropout Rate Unchanged, Despite More Spending
description: Despite extensive programs to prevent students from dropping out of New York City schools, the number of students who left before graduating remained virtually unchanged last year and is not expected to be much better this year, figures released yesterday by the Board of Education indicated.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Peter V. Ueberroth's effort to buy Eastern collapsed. Despite intense talks, the airline's unions refused to compromise on their demand that a trustee be appointed to oversee the company's transition out of bankruptcy. The unions are adamant that Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Eastern's parent, play no role in the transition. Still, the Federal bankruptcy judge, Burton R. Lifland, continued to prod the two sides to come together. [ Page A1. ] SmithKline Beckman and Beecham Group plan to merge. The new company, to be called SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., would be the world's second-largest drug producer, after Merck. [ D1. ] A.T.& T. illegally offered customized telephone networks to large business customers, with special prices, terms and conditions, the F.C.C. ruled after a two-year investigation. [ D1. ] I.B.M. introduced its first big advertising campaign since it shifted its $130 million account last year. Created by Wells, Rich, Greene, the campaign features photos by Richard Avedon. [ D1. ] J. P. Morgan's first-quarter earnings were lower than expected. The banking company said rises in short-term interest rates were largely responsible. [ D12. ] Hewlett-Packard agreed to acquire Apollo Computer in a deal that could be worth up to $600 million. The combined company will be the largest supplier of computer work stations. [ D4. ] Fujitsu will build a plant in Britain to make integrated computer chips. [ D4. ] Whittle Communications hired Joseph M. Barrett to be president of its largest publication, Special Reports. [ D18. ] THE ECONOMY Retail gasoline prices have jumped sharply, reaching their highest levels in more than three years. Experts say higher crude oil prices and anticipation that supplies will be squeezed this summer are largely responsible. [ D1. ] Many people are not complying with the tax code. The I.R.S. said a check of 150,000 returns has found a sizable proportion of the same errors that were noted last year. [ D1. ] The Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved legislation to shut or sell more than 500 insolvent savings and loan associations at a cost of up to $157 billion over 10 years. The money would come from both taxpayers and the savings industry. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL Mexico will ask its foreign creditors to cut the value of their loans by $20 billion to $30 billion, banking officials said. The I.M.F. had announced a new Mexican loan Tuesday in an attempt to persuade banks to reduce that country's debt payments. [ D1. ] GATT adopted measures intended to fend off protectionism and put teeth in its methods for settling disputes. [ D5. ] MARKETS Stocks moved higher. The Dow industrials gained 8.07 points, to 2,319.65. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in light trading. Dealers concentrated on the sale of new notes. [ D15. ] Yields for money market mutual funds continued to rise in the week that ended yesterday. [ D11. ] The dollar was mixed amid speculation about central bank intervention. [ D16. ] Cocoa futures reached a five-month low after rumors of new sales by the Ivory Coast. [ D16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A big increase in takeover activity is expected in Britain in anticipation of a barrier-free Europe after 1992. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The market for the securities of bankrupt companies is booming, a trend that disturbs some experts. Market Place. [ D8. ] Paying to have a product prominently displayed in a movie should be regulated as advertising, some say. Advertising. [ D18. ]

title: Cable Systems End Holdout
description: Two cable systems with 120,000 subscribers in Brooklyn and Queens ended their holdout yesterday and agreed to carry Madison Square Garden's Yankee games as part of their fixed-cost basic service.

title: Air-Fare Inflation Argues for Return to Controls; Yield Management
description: To the Editor:

title: Carlyle Raises Bid for Fairchild
description: Renewing its efforts to acquire Fairchild Industries, the Carlyle Group Inc., raised its offer to acquire the Chantilly, Va., aerospace concern to $17 a share in cash. Fairchild rejected two earlier offers from Carlyle, for $15.50 a share and $16.30 a share. Fairchild has vowed to remain independent.

title: Dfsoutheastern reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company converted from a mutual to a stock thrift institution in September 1988 so a comparable year- ago share net figure is not available.

title: Morgan, J P & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $43 million related to a U.S. federal tax refund. Provision for credit losses in the latest first quarter was $10 million, compared with $50 million in the year-ago period. The net interest income was $299 million in the 1989 quarter, compared with $438 million in the year-ago period.

title: Seized Assets to Go to Areas Hardest Hit by Drugs
description: William J. Bennett said today that he would direct as much as $150 million a year in assets seized from drug dealers to fight the drug problem, especially in areas that have been hardest hit.

title: Mead Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included an 8 cents a share dilution due to the acquisition of Michie & Co. in December. The year-ago quarter included a 17 cents a share gain from the sale of its paperboard products division and a 15 cents a share gain from Brunswick Pulp and Paper Co., which was sold in August 1988.

title: Hong Kong Stock Reform
description: The Hong Kong legislature voted today to establish a watchdog agency to regulate its tarnished securities industry, bringing its financial regulation more in line with that of other countries.

title: Sundstrand Selling A Business to Sony
description: The Sundstrand Corporation is selling its Trans Com Systems to Sony USA Inc. The companies have agreed in principle on the sale, which is subject to approval of the boards of directors of both corporations, Sundstrand said in a statement. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

title: Talking Deals; Takeover Fever Is High in Britain
description: HIGH interest rates have slowed the number of takeovers of British companies this year, but a big increase in deal making is expected as Britain prepares for the elimination of European tariff barriers in 1992.

title: Break Up the Yanks! They Win a Game
description: In the late afternoon, while they were still in the throes of their losing streak, the Yankees closed the doors to their clubhouse and talked. For some 40 minutes, they chastised themselves for their mistakes, kidded each other for their comical blunders and sorted out their differences. Then they played and finally won.

title: First Financial Savings Assn Pennsylvania reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Corrected from yesterday.

title: Why Not a 42d St. Trolley?
description: LEAD: The 42d Street development project, stalled more than once by environmental and clean-air challenges, seems to be moving ahead. But it's too soon to start dancing in the street. Even today, when New Yorkers spend as little time as possible on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues - and visitors are warned to stay away altogether - the traffic and air are heavy.

title: Home Improvement
description: PAINTBRUSHES, like all tools, are designed for specific purposes. Using the correct brush makes painting easier and achieves the best results.

title: Soviets Say Orbiter Will Be Unmanned For Several Months
description: Soviet officials plan a delay of ''several months'' before sending a fresh crew of astronauts to the Mir space station because new research equipment is not ready, the Government announced today.

title: Congressman and Legal Aide Report a Robbery at Capitol
description: A member of the House ethics committee and the panel's special counsel were robbed at gunpoint Tuesday night, the authorities said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The mood is bleak. There is a recognition by virtually all of the people I would consider professional politicians that he will not survive.'' - Representative Robert J. Mrazek, Democrat of Long Island, discussing the Speaker, Jim Wright. [ B10:4. ]

title: Books of The Times; A Couple Share Challenges In an Elmore Leonard Novel
description: Killshot By Elmore Leonard 287 pages. Arbor House/William Morrow. $18.95.

title: Orange Harvest Up 4%
description: The nation's orange crop for the 1988-89 season is estimated at 207.8 million boxes, down by 1 percent from the March forecast, but up by 4 percent over last year's production, the Agriculture Department said this week.

title: Anthem Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Skinner Assails Publicizing of Terrorist Warnings
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, angered by a critical Congressional report disclosing details of official warnings to airlines about terrorist threats, has demanded that lawmakers promise not to divulge such information.

title: Air-Fare Inflation Argues for Return to Controls
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Burton Leeb, 53, A Pathologist in Navy
description: Capt. Burton O. Leeb, a retired United States Navy pathologist, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 53 years old.

title: Some of the Reasons Yanks Are So Bad
description: If the Yankees or their fans think they are having a nightmare and will soon awake to find that what has happened the first week of the season isn't real, a player who watched the team up close for three games can tell them it is.

title: Addendum
description: * Kenmar Communications Inc., a sales promotion and advertising agency, has opened for business at 2 Park Avenue. The agency has been formed by Stanley Pearlman and Don Aaronson.

title: Accounts
description: * Mag Instrument Inc., a flashlight maker, to Grey Advertising, with a budget of $5 million.

title: Europe Ruling on Airlines
description: The European Court of Justice in Luxembourg ruled on Tuesday that almost all pricing contracts between airlines, including routes within the 12 European Community countries and to non-European Community destinations, could violate European competition rules.

title: Savings Bond Sales Up
description: Sales of United States savings bonds increased 3.2 percent in March, to $713 million, the Government reported today. The Treasury Department said sales for the first six months of the 1989 fiscal year, which began in October, totaled $4.02 billion, up 9.5 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. For the period Nov. 1 through April 30, bonds held five years or longer earn an annualized interest rate of 7.35 percent.

title: Float a Pumping Station
description: To the Editor:

title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border
description: Officials from two countries told a gruesome story today of drugs, ritual murder and the occult that has begun to unfold at a remote ranch in the bleak, empty countryside near the United States border.

title: New Housing Up by 2.9%
description: The number of new houses and apartment buildings completed in February rose 2.9 percent, the Commerce Department said today. Completions had risen by a tenth of 1 percent in January.

title: U.S. Identifies Bomb Carrier
description: A Lebanese-American student apparently was the unwitting carrier of the bomb on Pan Am Flight 103, Administration officials said. Page A9.

title: William H. Brett, 95, Former Mint Director
description: William H. Brett, director of the United States Mint under President Eisenhower, died of pancreatic cancer Monday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 95 years old.

title: North Lays Blame on His Boss for Several Misdeeds
description: Oliver L. North, sounding weary and irritable, today blamed Robert C. McFarlane, his former superior at the National Security Council, for several misdeeds Mr. North is accused of committing.

title: Our Town, and Theirs
description: Here today, gone tomorrow - except in cities. What was here in the urban landscape yesterday is very often still here today. Consider the alms house that was built in downtown Manhattan in 1735 for ''Poor Needy Persons and Idle Wandring Vagabonds, Sturdy Beggars and Others'' and torn down in 1797. Its presumed foundations, it now appears, may be just a few feet under the grass and walkways between City Hall and the Tweed Courthouse.

title: Moscow Rations Sugar, a First Since '45
description: Because of a nationwide sugar shortage, the Government will resort to issuing ration coupons in Moscow for the first time since World War II.

title: Unapproved Spending Upsets Trenton
description: A state official who spent millions in unauthorized money to establish new programs for the mentally retarded has created a furor here. And the Kean administration is scrambling to figure out just how he did it and how to pay for the programs.

title: ETHICS UNIT READY TO CHARGE WRIGHT, DEMOCRATS REPORT
description: The House ethics committee, approaching the end of its long investigation, has voted to charge Speaker Jim Wright with violating a series of House rules, officials on Capitol Hill said today.

title: New GATT Procedures On Disputes
description: Hoping to put teeth in its mechanism for settling disputes, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade adopted measures today that its officials said would strengthen its credibility and fend off protectionism by member nations.

title: Dioxin Ruling In New Jersey
description: A New Jersey judge has ruled that insurance companies do not have to pay for a $25 million dioxin cleanup at the site of a former Diamond Shamrock plant but must make payments to a fund for Agent Orange victims.

title: Holmes, D H Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net income and the year included a gain from an accounting change of $5,457,000. The company said the latest fourth quarter included a pretax loss of $3.9 million from the sale of a store in February. It recorded the loss in fiscal 1989 because the agreement to sell the store was entered into prior to the fiscal year-end. The company also said other losses totaling $863,000 before tax resulted primarily from abandoning several capital projects and closing several restaurant operations.

title: I.B.M.'s New Theme: We Care
description: With advertisements photographed and directed by Richard Avedon, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced its first major advertising campaign since shifting its $130 million account last year.

title: 'Run for Your Wife!' Closes
description: ''Run for Your Wife!,'' a comedy written and directed by Ray Cooney, closed after its Sunday matinee at the Virginia Theater, 245 West 52d Street. The play ran for 14 previews and 52 regular performances.

title: Close to Home
description: LAST month a journalist named Janet Malcolm declared in The New Yorker that journalists are ''morally indefensible'' and given to betraying people ''without remorse.'' Some of Miss Malcolm's fellows yelled, ''Who, me?'' Others pleaded guilty. Few mentioned how often people are eager to tell an interviewer things she would not even dream of asking. The nosy stranger, it seems, can elicit more confessions than the closest friend. I say this with some authority, having once been a professional nosy stranger.

title: Stocks Are Higher, With Dow Rising 8.07
description: Stocks moved higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.07 points, to 2,319.65.

title: U.S. Says Many Taxpayers Fail to Follow '86 Revision
description: Taxpayers may be confused or they may be cheating, but the Internal Revenue Service is uncovering evidence that many people are not complying with changes in the tax code that were enacted in 1986.

title: U.S. INQUIRY NAMES CARRIER OF BOMB
description: Federal investigators have tentatively identified a 21-year-old Lebanese-American as the man who unwittingly carried the bomb that blew apart a Pan Am jumbo jet over Scotland in December, an Administration official said tonight.

title: Upset by Hornets Turns the Knicks' Golden Moment to Dust
description: It was a night the Knicks were supposed to get their 50th victory, something only five other teams in the history of the franchise had accomplished. The opposition was the Charlotte Hornets, an expansion team with a nine-game losing streak and a 17-58 record, the second worst in the National Basketball Association.

title: Morgan Says Net Off More Than Expected
description: J. P. Morgan & Company yesterday announced a larger-than-expected drop in earnings for the first quarter. The banking company attributed the decline to higher short-term interest rates in the United States and around the world.

title: 7,000 Scientists Cheer Fusion-in-Jar Experimenter
description: A Utah scientist received sustained applause from 7,000 chemists today as he described an experiment that he said had produced nuclear fusion in a simple electrolytic cell.

title: Currents; 'Portraits' of Buildings That Peek Inside
description: ''I DON'T do chocolate-box illustrations of cottages,'' Sarah Halliday said of her watercolor and pencil renditions of houses and other buildings. Instead, she combines several types of precise architectural drawings.

title: Sex Offender Held in Cousin's '57 Hanging
description: A 52-year-old convicted sex offender was arrested today in the 1957 hanging of his cousin in what the police believe is the longest span of time before an unsolved murder case was cracked in New York.

title: Parent & Child
description: THE satirist Dave Barry suggests that parents select a preschool with a strong prebusiness curriculum that emphasizes blocks, not a liberal arts curriculum that emphasizes gerbils.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Zvereva Is Beaten: Fourth-seeded Natalya Zvereva and six other seeded players lost in the second round yesterday at the Bausch & Lomb championships in Amelia Island, S.C. Regina Rajchrtova, a qualifier, beat Zvereva, 3-6, 6-3, 6-3. Seventh-seeded Larisa Savchenko, lost by 6-4, 4-6, 6-2 to unseeded Angeliki Kanellopolou. Top-seeded Steffi Graf won her 28th straight match of the year, beating Elise Burgin by 6-1, 6-2. Second-seeded Martina Navratilova also won easily, as did No. 8 Hana Mandlikova, No. 6 Arantxa Sanchez and No. 11 Judith Wiesner. Fourteenth-seeded Leila Meskhi, another Soviet player, needed three sets to beat Laura Gildemeister. Eliminated in the wave of upsets were fifth-seeded Lori McNeil, beaten in straight sets by the Amelia Island touring pro, Kathy Rinaldi; ninth-seeded Sandra Cecchini; 10th-seeded Bettina Fulco; No. 12 Terry Phelps, and No. 13 Isabel Cueto. Zvereva played listlessly against Rajchrtova, ranked No. 133 in the world, after winning the first set. ''I didn't feel good motivation to win,'' Zvereva said. ''I didn't want to win. I don't find it very important. I don't know what happened to me. Maybe I need a therapist.'' Rajchrtova had to win two qualifying matches just to get into the 64-player main draw. ''That was the best I ever played,'' she said. ''Maybe she was a little bit upset, but I just concentrated on my game. I didn't care about her.''(AP) McEnroe Outclasses Borg: John McEnroe outclassed a rusty Bjorn Borg, 6-3, 6-3, in an exhibition match yesterday in Singapore. A genial McEnroe dominated the indoor contest played at the air-conditioned World Trade Center. The 30-year-old American is ranked sixth in the world. McEnroe won two singles matches last weekend as the United States swept France, 5-0, in the quarterfinals of Davis Cup World Group play in San Diego. Singapore was the first stop this week for Borg and McEnroe on what is touted as their reunion tour. They will also travel to the Philippines, Taiwan and Japan. Borg, 32 years old, told reporters the Asian tour was his farewell. ''There will be no more tennis for me, tournaments or exhibitions,'' he said. ''My future involvement in tennis will be strictly in coaching the youth and I will be glad to do it in any part of the world.''(AP) BASEBALL Soviet Team Improving: The Soviet Union's national baseball team, which made its United States debut with a 21-1 defeat at Navy on Tuesday, followed that with a 20-1 loss against George Washington University yesterday in Washington. The squad, which made eight errors in the loss to Navy, committed five errors and had five passed balls against George Washington. The Soviet team got only two hits yesterday, but one of them was a home run by Nugzar Popkhadze. Twelve Soviet batters struck out in the seven-inning game.(AP)

title: Fannie Mae Net Up 64%
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the largest investor in home mortgages, today reported a 64 percent rise in first-quarter income. For the January-to-March period, Fannie Mae, a Government-sponsored, privately owned corporation, earned $165.2 million, or $1.98 a share, up from $100.9 million, or $1.27 a share, in the period last year. David O. Maxwell, Fannie Mae's chairman and chief executive, said earnings rose despite higher interest rates and the $8 million cost to phase out the company's Software Systems division.

title: Campaign Matters; Tune In Comedy, Drama or Sports, You'll Get Lauder
description: There is mayoral candidate Ronald S. Lauder, between innings in a Yankees game on television, staring into the camera and talking about cutting cronyism, waste and fraud in city government.

title: Butler Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Currents;
A Fresh And Faded Hint of Italy
description: LEAD: TED TYLER, a fabrics designer, thought the mellowed and faded upholstery, wallpaper and painted and frescoed walls of Italian villas and palazzi could be duplicated in his Tylergraphic workshop in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

title: Baker Calls Latin Plan A Test for the Kremlin
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he viewed Soviet cooperation in Central American peace efforts as a test of whether there really is ''new thinking'' in the Kremlin.

title: Ex-Nabisco Executive To Be Tambrands Chief
description: Tambrands Inc., which for two months searched for a chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday that it would name Martin F. C. Emmett, an investment banker and former Nabisco executive.

title: Kentucky Utilities Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $11,470,000 from an accounting change for both the quarter and year.

title: Cocoa Prices Fall on Talk Of Sales by the Ivory Coast
description: Cocoa futures sank today to their lowest levels in five months amid rumors of new sales on the market by the Ivory Coast, the world's top producer.

title: Israelis Call 4 Arrests Blow to Arab Uprising
description: The Army arrested four suspected leaders of the Palestinian uprising and said today that their capture was a major blow to the 16-month-old revolt.

title: Bush Chooses Former Astronaut to Head NASA, in a First
description: President Bush today named Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly as the new Administrator of the space agency. He is the first astronaut to head it and the first to move directly from the military to the post.

title: Fisk on Disabled List
description: Carlton Fisk of the Chicago White Sox has a new break and an old problem. The 41-year-old catcher was placed on the 15-day disabled list Tuesday after X-rays showed a break in his right hand adjacent to the break that caused him to miss 10 weeks last season.

title: Trial Hints at Wider Role For Bush in Aid to Contras
description: Additional documents released in the trial of Oliver L. North show that George Bush, as Vice President, supported a 1985 plan to increase covert aid to Honduras and thus was more aware than he has publicly acknowledged of Reagan Administration efforts to circumvent a Congressional ban on military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Q&A
description: Cleaning a Fan Q.We have an exhaust fan in the kitchen that has an accumulation of grease and dirt. I fear it might be a hotbed for bacteria. What do you suggest as a procedure for degreasing and sanitizing this unit? A.An exhaust fan loaded with grease is probably more of a fire hazard than a health hazard, but either way it should be cleaned. Shut off power to the fan and pull the plug, which is just inside the housing. If possible, remove the spring-activated door and take it outside for a thorough cleaning with a wire brush and a nonflammable grease solvent; soaking in a strong detergent also works.

title: First Union Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $6 million gain from the sale of mortgage servicing rights. c-Included a $15 million gain from the sale of investment securities.

title: King World Productions Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Latest 6 months included a gain of $2.9 million, or 11 cents a share, from a change in accounting for taxes.

title: Korean Air Plans
description: Korean Air Lines announced plans to spend $250 million on three McDonnell Douglas jetliners. Korean Air signed letters of intent to buy two MD-82 twin-jets and one MD-11 tri-jet. The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said the MD-82's will be delivered to Korean Air in September and November 1993 and the MD-11 in July 1991.

title: Exxon Turns Down U.S. Request For $15 Million to Study Oil Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation today turned down a Government request to provide $15 million to begin a long-term assessment of the environmental damage caused by the tanker accident in Alaska. But the Interior Secretary said he believed the company would eventually provide money for the study.

Gretzky Delivers Fans, but a Cup Is Harder
description: In the noisy Forum, the silver and black Kings colors were on full display Tuesday night as more than 16,000 apprehensive fans came to cheer for a team facing elimination from the playoffs.

title: Olson Stays at Arizona And Receives a Raise
description: Lute Olson, though heavily wooed by Kentucky, decided to remain as the University of Arizona's basketball coach yesterday as the school's regents authorized a new five-year contract that could add more than $75,000 to his annual earnings. Olson's current contract had three more years to run.

title: Epsilon Data Management Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: Principal Reinstated In Furor Over Film
description: A high school principal who was suspended after a movie with nude scenes was filmed at the school can return to his job, a new district board has ruled.

title: Hasidim's Cemetery Wins Approval Despite Neighbor's Ire
description: Over the vehement objections of a neighboring landowner, a Hasidic school and community today received town approval for a cemetery in this rural Westchester County town.

title: OTTAWA IS MOVING TO TIGHTEN BUDGET
description: Canada has tightened its rules for unemployment insurance, a move that may foreshadow a widening erosion of one of the industrial world's most generous social security systems.

title: Russell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dispute on Trustee Blocks Sale of Eastern Airlines
description: The effort by Peter V. Ueberroth to buy Eastern Airlines collapsed yesterday after the carrier's striking unions refused to compromise on their demand that a trustee be appointed to oversee Eastern's transition out of bankruptcy.

title: Mitsubishi Bank Offering of Notes
description: The New York branch of Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. priced a $100 million offering of deposit notes.

title: Apollo Computer Sale To Hewlett-Packard
description: In a move that will create the largest supplier of computer work stations, the Hewlett-Packard Company agreed today to acquire Apollo Computer Inc. for $13.125 a share in cash.

title: INSIDE
description: Cheers and Skepticism For Fusion in a Jar

title: WHERE TO FIND IT
description: THE cars are lined up in a row, their windows just so many black holes. Green glass is strewed across the garage floor. Reggae music blasts through the steel rafters as 20 men perform the same task 300 times a week: replacing car windows smashed by thieves.

title: Gibson, C R reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 6-for-5 stock split paid Jan. 31.

title: Historical Society Names New Leaders
description: The New-York Historical Society named Barbara Knowles Debs as its president and chief executive officer yesterday, and Norman Pearlstine as its new chairman.

title: A Wonder Of Waste Rises on S.I.
description: With a little help from some audacious engineers and dedicated landscape architects, New York City is quietly creating a 399-acre, 505-foot-high pyramid of garbage at the Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island. And yes, they're going to use a deodorant specialist, too.

title: Ethics Issue Hurt Him, Victorious Bradley Says
description: Mayor Tom Bradley acknowledged today that voter concern over his ethics may have contributed to his narrow margin of victory in Tuesday's nonpartisan election.

title: 'Trash TV' Debated at Editors' Convention
description: Phil Donahue blasted his critics as pompous. Jack Nelson of the Los Angeles Times told Mr. Donahue he was not a journalist but a showman. Morton Downey Jr. called Mr. Nelson a snob. Then Don Hewitt of CBS's ''60 Minutes'' denounced Geraldo Rivera for pandering, to which Mr. Rivera thundered, ''This is arrogance! This is hypocrisy!''

title: Tibetan's Tale: Unrest, Explosion, Crackdown
description: The first Tibetans to leave Lhasa for Nepal since the Chinese imposed martial law in the city a month ago say several weeks of growing public protests, culminating in attacks on Chinese residents and shops, led to Beijing's action.

title: Industrial Pollution Called Startling
description: Industry in the United States is putting a ''startling and unacceptably high'' volume of toxic substances into the land, air and water, the Environmental Protection Agency reported today.

title: Transamerica To Buy Criterion
description: The Transamerica Corporation, the San Francisco-based financial services company, has agreed to buy the Criterion Group Inc., an investment management company in Houston, for $13 a share, or $94.3 million, in cash. The transaction, which is subject to approval by Criterion shareholders, is expected to close by the third quarter.

title: Abortion Rights Leader Honored
description: As about 125 anti-abortion demonstrators protested outside the Plaza Hotel last night, about 300 people gathered inside to honor Robin Chandler Duke, the president emeritus of the National Abortion Rights Action League, which sponsored last week's abortion rights march in Washington.

title: Business Outlays in '89
description: The Government reported today that American businesses plan to increase spending this year for plant and equipment by a solid 6.3 percent, and analysts said this could help forestall a recession.

title: White House Seeking a Shift on Rights Panel
description: Seeking to bring a quiet resolution to an embarrassing episode at the United States Commission on Civil Rights, the White House has asked a Republican member to step aside to create a vacancy that President Bush could fill swiftly.

title: LONG PERIL IS SEEN FOR ALASKA COAST
description: Pristine wildlife refuges and fisheries along a vast area of the Alaskan coast will be threatened by oil from the Exxon Valdez spill for weeks if not months, Government scientists said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alberta Energy Co., Calgary, Alberta, said it would sell its non-Canadian oil and gas assets to its Chieftain Development Co. unit for $96.1 million (Canadian).

title: Elexis Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $63,584 for the latest quarter and $379,884 for the year- earlier period.

title: Reviews/Music; Hanne-Berit Hahnemann, Violinist, in a Shortened Bill
description: Hanne-Berit Hahnemann labored under a disadvantage in her debut recital Tuesday evening; a recent hand injury, it was announced, compelled the young Danish-born violinist to reduce her program to three selections from the announced five. But in those three she gave no evident signs of discomfort. The audience at Weill Recital Hall heard a secure, musically sensitive artist able to give convincing statements of two standard Romantic sonatas and curious enough to bring along a new composition somewhat more ambitious than the well-made, interchangeable pieces so often produced to fill the obligatory novelty slot in a program.

title: John Patrick Walsh, Advertising Executive, 58
description: John Patrick Walsh, an advertising executive and former public relations official for the New York City Department of Correction, died of pneumonia Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: Teasing Paint Out of 'Carving' on Chairs
description: LEAD: Though made in a hodgepodge of styles, the pressed-back oak chair kept the furniture-making centers busy from the 1890's to the 1920's.

title: Jury Refuses to Indict Rabbi in Beating
description: A grand jury declined yesterday to indict a Hasidic rabbi and his son who were arrested last month in the beating of a black man who they believed had slashed two people in a robbery attempt in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn.

title: Peter Norton Names Chief
description: Peter Norton Computing Inc., a personal computer software company based in Santa Monica, Calif., said today that Ron Posner had been appointed chief executive. He replaces Peter Norton, the company's founder, who will continue as chairman.

title: Personal Health
description: Smokeless tobacco has been a part of baseball almost since the 19th century. But the tobacco-swollen cheeks of today's players, coaches and managers represent something more than tradition; they signal that the user runs a startingly high risk of mouth cancer.

title:
Currents;
Far From U.S.S.R., 800 Rugs
description: LEAD: AMERICANS will once again be able to warm their feet on the lush, handcrafted rugs from southern regions of the Soviet Union. The rugs have not been exported for 40 years.

title: Washington Talk: Exact Words; A Vision of Justice for All
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. had these words to say about the former Chief Justice Earl Warren in a speech April 8 in San Francisco:

title: Hayes-Dana Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $384,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: No Verdict Yet In Agent Case
description: The Federal jury deciding the fate of the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom failed for a fifth day to reach a verdict after rumors spread that a decision was near.

title: 2 Arrested in Death Of Man Hit by Train
description: Transit police detectives said yesterday that a man who was struck and killed Sunday by a train in a subway tunnel was chased there, and that they had arrested two Bronx teen-agers in the death.

title: SmithKline, Beecham to Merge
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation and the Beecham Group P.L.C. announced today that they plan to merge into a new company, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., that would be the second-largest drug company in the world.

title: Deadwood Favors Gambling
description: Voters overwhelmingly approved a return to legalized gambling Tuesday in this historic Black Hills town, where Wild Bill Hickock was shot to death in a frontier card game. City leaders hope games of chance will revive Deadwood's economy. The measure to legalize poker, blackjack and slot machines received 690 votes, or 75 percent, in favor to 112 votes against. The measure needed 60 percent to past.

title: Rostropovich to Play In His Native Land
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet-born cellist and conductor who was stripped of his Soviet citizenship and who vowed never to return to his homeland until artists were given more freedom, said today that he would perform in the Soviet Union next year with the National Symphony Orchestra.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about developments in Soviet Georgia misidentified Hans-Jochen Vogel in some copies.

title: New York City Faces Big Cuts In Services
description: New York City, threatened with huge reductions in state aid and facing a large budget gap, is suffering an unexpected decline in revenues from several important local taxes amounting to $150 million this fiscal year and perhaps even more next year.

title: Campaign Fund Rules Befuddling Candidates
description: With its first financial disclosure reports due from candidates on May 1, the New York City Campaign Finance Board is issuing regulations so complex that half of the City Council members are not participating in the program they enacted.

title: Witness Reacts Angrily
description: The sprinter Desai Williams reacted angrily yesterday to a suggestion that he has denied taking steroids since 1981 to regain the title of the fastest man in Canada from Ben Johnson.

title: Tepid Backing Is Seen for Boston School Chief
description: Laval S. Wilson, this city's first black school superintendent, received a lackluster endorsement at best, his supporters and opponents agree, when a deeply divided Boston School Committee decided to renew his contract for two years.

title: Peak Norway Oil Output
description: Norway's North Sea oil production reached a record high of 1.53 million barrels a day in March, oil companies said today. Norway, Western Europe's biggest oil producer after Britain, set its previous record of 1.42 million barrels daily in January. Output rose despite a 7.5 percent curb in planned production growth that Norway has imposed to support OPEC efforts to increase oil prices.

title: Kansas City Journal; Museums Make Peace With an Artist's Vision
description: If, as some people suspect, Thomas Hart Benton is somewhere up there looking down on all the to-do here over his 100th birthday, he is sure to be wearing a knowing smile.

title: Latin Nations At High Risk For AIDS, Doctors Say
description: Some Latin American and Caribbean countries may be heading toward an epidemic of AIDS like that sweeping parts of Africa, a Federal health expert said today.

title: The Original Sugar Ray 'Never Lost'
description: Shortly before the first round that night in 1950, the referee called the two boxers together. But rather than listen to the instructions, Sugar Ray Robinson stared at his opponent, a tough puncher named George Costner who had begun to use Sugar as a nickname. Costner had bragged that he would be the only Sugar in boxing. But now, in the center of the ring, Robinson's elegant ego flashed.

title: Puget Sound Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Television; The Urban Working Class, In 'Dream Street' on NBC
description: Having turned suburban yuppie angst into a first-rate series, in ABC's ''Thirtysomething,'' the executive producers Marshall Herskovitz and Ed Zwick are now trying to find a successful formula for urban working-class hopes with NBC's ''Dream Street.'' Created by Mark Rosner, the new show is having a special 90-minute premiere tonight at 9:30. Mr. Rosner is the writer and director.
