A limited tryout run of hourlong episodes will be broadcast Fridays at 10, beginning April 21.

title: Review/Rock; Elvis Costello, Still Taking Risks
description: Elvis Costello insists on making every concert a singular event, every performance a live one. Too often in the age of recordings, musicians try to copy their records or play the same mechanical set night after night. But as he rekindles his own songs and pulls other people's material out of the air, Mr. Costello proves, triumphantly, that every performance can take risks.

title: Jonathan Kandell Weds Joan Witek, a Painter
description: Joan Witek, a painter, and Jonathan Kandell, an assistant foreign editor of The Wall Street Journal, were married yesterday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building in New York. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Crespo of New York. Mr. Kandell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kandell of Mexico City, is the author of ''La Capital: The Biography of Mexico City'' and ''Passage Through El Dorado.'' He formerly served as a New York Times bureau chief in Buenos Aires and Rio de Janeiro.

title: First Eastern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago earnings are restated because of a merger.

title: Fujitsu to Build Plant in Britain
description: Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan announced today that it had chosen Britain as the site for its first integrated chip factory in the European Community.

title: Corrections
description: The Q&A column in Science Times on Tuesday misstated the incidence of tornadoes in major cities. St. Louis and Dallas have both been struck by tornadoes.

title: Sugar Ray Robinson, Boxing's 'Best,' Is Dead
description: Sugar Ray Robinson, the five-time world middleweight champion who was considered by many boxing experts to have been the best fighter in history, died yesterday in Culver City, Calif. He was 67 years old.

title: Barnett Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter earnings restated to reflect mergers.

title: Father Healy Follows a Catholic Tradition of Service to the State; Code Words of Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Cold Fusion' Patents Sought
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology said yesterday that it had applied for patents involving cold nuclear fusion based on the theoretical work of Peter L. Hagelstein, a university researcher who has submitted four papers outlining his theory to scientific journals.

title: New York Awarded A Major Track Meet
description: This summer, for the first time in 23 years, a major international track and field meet will be held in New York City.

title: Swiss Judge Lifts Order on RJR Deal
description: A judge in Switzerland has lifted a temporary restraining order that could have blocked a portion of the acquisition of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. The judge had issued the temporary restraining order March 20 in response to a lawsuit filed by three bondholders in Switzerland who contended that the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco, based in Atlanta, had diminished the value of their holdings.

title: Woolworth Revamping Set
description: The board of the F. W. Woolworth Company approved a plan yesterday to establish a new holding company, the Woolworth Corporation, in which all its operating entities would be subsidiaries.

title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War
description: They include police officers, engineers, doctors, teachers and former soldiers - a select group of men and women between the ages of 23 and 35 from large cities and small villages. At the National Institute of Penal Sciences here, this cross section of Mexican society is being trained as a new elite in the country's stepped-up war against drug trafficking.

title: A Young Long Jumper Taking Aim at the Best
description: Bob Beamon's miraculous 1968 leap of 29 feet 2 1/2 inches is a monument to the long jump's past. Carl Lewis, a two-time Olympic gold-medalist in the event, represents its present. Dion Bentley may be the future. Bentley was not born when Beamon set his world record in the high altitude of Mexico City at the Summer Games. Today, as a 17-year-old high school senior from Penn Hills, Pa., outside of Pittsburgh, he is setting records at nearly every meet in which he jumps.

title: Motorola Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Drowning in a Crime Wave
description: LEAD: Many streets in America's big cities are in a state of anarchy. Too often the police are overwhelmed. In some cities and neighborhoods, people are afraid to go outside. And in and out of their homes, they risk murder, assault, rape, holdups, muggings and theft.

title:
Currents;
To Every Season a Cautious Change
description: LEAD: AT lunch, the Grill Room at the Four Seasons restaurant is packed with people who bring about change in New York City. But when it comes to their favorite lunch spot, most regulars contend they like the Grill Room the way it looks - like the inside of a well-detailed humidor.

title: Washington Talk; Taking Heat When the Boss Is Under Fire
description: Mark R. Johnson is no stranger to adversity. Before he signed on last January as press secretary for Speaker Jim Wright, he was spokesman for Frank Lorenzo, the beleaguered chairman of the Texas Air Corporation.

title: Gasoline Prices Post a Sharp Rise
description: Retail gasoline prices have jumped sharply in the last two weeks, reaching their highest levels in more than three years. Prices at some service stations have gone up by 10 cents a gallon or more, or about 10 percent.

title: Un-American Heritage
description: Greg Norman of Australia, who won the 1988 MCI Heritage Classic and finished tied for third in the Masters last week, and Nick Faldo of England, who won this year's Masters and the Heritage in 1984, head the field of the Heritage, which starts Thursday at Harbour Town Golf Links.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times Tuesday about differences in the brains of men and women misidentified the location and sponsors of a conference on the topic. It was at New York University Medical Center, and was a joint meeting of the New York Neuropsychology Group and the psychology section of the New York Academy of Sciences. The article also imprecisely characterized the position taken by some researchers. They maintain that environmental influences account for differences in men-tal abilities, not for differences in the brains.

title: Gorbachev Appeals for Calm in Georgia
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, sent a message to the people of Soviet Georgia today, saying violent clashes there between nationalists and Government troops ''inflicted damage to perestroika and democratization'' and ''shed the blood of innocent people.''

title: Man Charged in Fire Deaths At Peoria Apartment House
description: A homeless man was charged today with nine counts of murder after telling the police he set a fire in an apartment house that killed seven children and two young mothers, a prosecutor said.

title: Bush Offers Wide-Ranging Legislation on Ethics
description: President Bush today proposed wide-ranging ethics legislation to set uniform standards for Congress, the judiciary and the executive branch.

title: Westinghouse Electric Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Westinghouse said its latest first quarter's net included a restructuring provision of $261.5 million, which essentially offset gains of $266.1 million from the sale of the Westinghouse elevator business and the formation of a transmission and distribution joint venture with Asea Brown Boveri. The year-ago first quarter's net was restated to reflect the adoption of FAS No. 96, which had the effect of increasing net income by $12 million, or 9 cents a share.

title: Algeria Gets Loans
description: The World Bank has lent Algeria $211 million for projects intended to stimulate economic growth, the official press agency reported Tuesday. The money is repayable over 15 years with a five-year grace period at a variable rate of interest, currently at 7.72 percent. A loan of $143 million will help repair 200 miles of railroad track; $14 million will go to an irrigation project involving construction of dams, and $54 million will be used to improve professional training.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Federal Hearing to Focus on Judge's Words to Jurors
description: Officially, Judge Charles L. Brieant called the hearing set for this morning in Federal District Court in Manhattan to decide whether Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno and eight other men are entitled to a new trial after their conviction last May on mob-related racketeering charges.

title: Pistons Stretch Lead by Beating Cavaliers
description: Vinnie Johnson scored 17 of his 31 points in the second quarter as the Detroit Pistons took control tonight and rolled to a 107-95 victory over Cleveland, opening a three-and-a-half-game lead over the Cavaliers in the Central Division.

title: Hungary Ousts 4 Conservatives in a Party Shuffle
description: The Hungarian Communist Party shuffled its senior leadership today, dismissing the party's chief ideologist and three other conservatives on the Politburo and promoting two advocates of change.

title: Senate Panel Approves A Savings Bailout Bill
description: The Senate Banking Committee today unanimously approved legislation to shut or sell more than 500 insolvent savings associations at a cost of up to $157 billion over 10 years. The money would come from both taxpayers and the savings industry.

title: Gunmen Kill Spanish Civil Guard
description: Gunmen shot and killed a civil guard today near the Basque city of Bilbao.

title: People
description: * Mitchell Kozikowski has been promoted to chief executive of the Rowland Co., the United States public relations subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: From Kors, Hoods and Lots of Leg
description: MICHAEL KORS showed a fall collection this week that incorporated lots of leg and plenty of the themes in the fashion ozone At Tuesday night's show, there were luxurious suedes, velvets and woolens in riding styles and rugged men's-wear shapes, like the C.P.O. jacket. Then there were comfortable jackets and jumpsuits, in flannel and terry, derived from the bathrobe.

title: 'Descendant by Purchase'
description: To The Home Section:

title: Currents; How Does Your Plastic Grow?
description: TAKAAKI MATSUMOTO, a partner in the graphics design firm of M Plus M in New York, has come up with a garden for gardeners who hate to muck about in the dirt.

title: Bushes Taxed $62,106 On $278,171 Income
description: President and Mrs. Bush paid $62,106 in Federal taxes last year on an adjusted gross income of $278,171, including his $115,000 salary as Vice President, according to tax returns released today.

title: Southeast Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Two-Year Notes By Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company yesterday offered $150 million of two-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Review/Dance; Spring Is Back, and With It the Paul Taylor Company
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, that sure sign of spring, opened its annual three-week season at City Center on Tuesday evening with all the spirit and sweetness of an April breeze. There were three recent signature works from Mr. Taylor - and a note of special warmth, when the choreographer presented each of his dancers with a bouquet at the closing curtain, thrusting the bouquets with typically gawky grace.

title: Abbie Hoffman, Antiwar Activist And Puckish Protester, Dies at 52
description: Abbie Hoffman, the writer and antiwar protester who founded the Yippie movement in the 1960's and became a symbol of radical activism, was found dead last night at his home in New Hope, Pa. He was 52 years old.

title: Folk Art Museum Gets a Home After Years on the Move
description: The Museum of American Folk Art is a nomad no more. Plagued by financial and real estate problems for a decade and homeless for the last three years, the museum opens a gleaming new showcase today across the street from Lincoln Center. The museum will remain there until 1992, when its permanent quarters are to be completed on West 53d Street and the uptown facility is to become an annex for special exhibitions.

title: Questions Raised on 'Product Placements'
description: IS it advertising when a consumer-products company pays to have its product prominently displayed in a movie?

title: Raytheon Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: The company said its provisions for federal and foreign income taxes in the latest first quarter totaled $53.3 million, up from $49.6 million in the year-ago period.

title: Bulletproof Vests Alter Police-Death Statistics
description: To the Editor:

title: US Trust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Koch Hints At Note Sale
description: The New York State Legislature's failure to pass a budget on time may force New York City to hold a special short-term note sale, Mayor Edward I. Koch and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Hussein and Mubarak Discuss Israel's Plan
description: King Hussein of Jordan met with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt over a Muslim Ramadan supper here tonight to formulate a common response to Israel's newest proposals on the Palestinian issue, including elections in the occupied territories.

title: Hiram Sherman, Actor, Was 81
description: Hiram Sherman, a stage and film actor for more than 40 years, died after a stroke Tuesday in a nursing home in Springfield, Ill. He was 81 years old and lived in Springfield.

title: President Offers Ethics Plan
description: Mr. Bush proposed far-reaching legislation on conflicts of interest, financial disclosure and campaign funds, but he did not mention a proposal to ban honorariums. Page B10.

title: Air-Fare Inflation Argues for Return to Controls; Like Ticket Scalping
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices Lower in Light Trading
description: Treasury note and bond prices dipped lower in light trading yesterday, as dealers concentrated on the sale of $7 billion worth of new seven-year notes.

title: Roadway Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest quarter included operations of Viking Freight Inc., which was acquired in October 1988.

title: Spoof of Phone-Sex Ads From Smith, Greenland
description: A billboard ad campaign in California for Johnnie Walker uses a good deal of skin to sell its Red and Black labels of Scotch whisky, which is nothing unusual. But these liquor ads come with a twist - in a spoof of phone-sex ads, drivers are encourgaed to telephone the attractive male and female models, and a phone number is listed. Almost 45,000 Californians have called it since the ads first appeared in Los Angeles and San Francisco a month ago.

title: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Two TV Spots for I.R.S. By McCann-Erickson
description: To the old saw ''Nothing is inevitable except death and taxes,'' one might add, ''and advertising.'' As if to prove the point, the Internal Revenue Service has enlisted Madison Avenue to guide millions of Americans facing the income-tax deadline.

title: Basic Particle Created in Test Of Accelerator
description: In the first successful test of a new type of atom smasher, American physicists have produced the elusive Z particle, an elementary particle considered to be a key to understanding the fundamental forces of nature. The Americans thus won the first lap in a race with their European counterparts to create the particle in bulk for further research.

title: John Baringer, 67, Ex-Insurance Executive
description: John Lee Baringer, a retired insurance executive and a director of the United Americas Insurance Company, died of bone cancer Sunday at South Miami Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Key Largo, Fla.

title: U.S. AGENCY CHIEF MAY BE REPLACED
description: The Bush Administration is seeking to replace the Social Security Commissioner, Dorcas R. Hardy,who has come under increasing attack from members of Congress, Administration officials said today.

title: Elderly Resident Of Strivers' Row Is Found Slain
description: A longtime resident of Strivers' Row, one of Harlem's most historic sections, was found beaten to death Tuesday night in the basement of a brownstone he owned, the police said.

title: IMC Fertilizer Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings figures are not presented because the company went public in February 1988.

title: White Is Retiring
description: Charles White, who went from a reserve running back with the Los Angeles Rams to the National Football League's rushing leader in 1987, announced his retirement yesterday.

title: Man Found Burned And a Youth Is Held
description: A 16-year-old youth was charged with second-degree murder last night in the death of a homeless man whose charred body was found yesterday in a burned-out lot in Coney Island, transit officials said.

title: Champs Cut Down to Size
description: The New Mexico Activities Association placed the Eldorado High School girls basketball program on probation because a player cut down a net after Eldorado beat Manzano for the Class AAAA state title March 4, the team's coach said.

title: Canadian Rider Wins Cup Event
description: On a night when the course itself almost stole the show from the horses and riders who had to cope with it, Ian Millar of Canada took a big step toward becoming the first rider to win back-to-back titles in the 11-year history of show jumping's World Cup.

title: John Warner, 91, a Top Chemist And University President, Is Dead
description: John Christian Warner, a prominent chemist who was president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology from 1950 to 1965, died in his sleep early yesterday at his suburban Pittsburgh home in Friendship Village. He was 91 years old.

title: Right-to-Die Order Revoked As Patient in Coma Wakes
description: A state judge has withdrawn his permission for removal of a feeding tube from an 86-year-old stroke victim after the condition of the woman - who had been declared to be in an ''irreversible'' vegetative state - improved and she began talking and eating on her own.

title: Concorde Loses Part of Tail In Pacific Leg of World Trip
description: A supersonic Concorde jet carrying 100 Americans dropped a nine-foot section of its tail today over the South Pacific in an attempt to set a speed record, but it landed safely here and there were no injuries.

title: The Lessons Of Jalalabad; Afghan Guerrillas See Weaknesses Exposed
description: The Afghan guerrillas' six-week siege of the city of Jalalabad has shown the difficulties of converting a large but inchoate and often undisciplined force into the kind of army able to fight a conventional battle to seize a strongly defended city.

title: Libeling The Dead
description: There it was, a passing shot at a cinematic hero of mine right in the middle of ''Cary Grant: The Lonely Heart,'' by Charles Higham and Roy Moseley.

title: Kabul Journal; Rome's 'Mullah Sahib,' at Home in Allah's Land
description: Ask around Kabul for the Christian mullah and the chances are that even the street urchins will describe a puckish figure with linen cap and a battered old American-made Ford.

title: Wickes Is Selling Hardware Division
description: The Wickes Companies announced a $134 million deal to sell Orchard Supply Hardware, based in San Jose, to a management group, in the latest of a series of asset sales by Wickes's new owners. The buyer group is headed by Orchard Supply's president, Maynard Jenkins, and was organized by Freeman Spogli & Company, a Los Angeles investment firm.

title: Greek Revival Revival: An 1842 Row House Is Lovingly Restored
description: LEAD: ''I WOULDN'T give a nickel to really go back to the 19th century,'' said Timothy Forbes, the president of American Heritage magazine. ''But we're spending a fortune to get a little bit of it.''

title: One Orchid? Impossible,
description: SOPHIE TUCKER wore them, Nero Wolfe raised them and Rozalia Rau is among those whose life was never the same once she discovered them.

title: United Jersey Banks reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TV Notes
description: A Space Mini-Series

title: 12 Die in Beirut As Artillery War Becomes Intense
description: Twelve people were killed and 34 wounded today in ferocious artillery bombardment between Muslim and Christian forces across virtually all of Beirut.

title: Why Bargain About the Bloc?
description: In asking the right question, Henry Kissinger has come up with a dubious idea for a Western response to the changes shaking the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. How can the NATO democracies encourage the relaxation of one-party dictatorships, notably in Poland and Hungary, without undercutting Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms?

title: First Lady Undergoes Radiation Treatment for Thyroid Illness
description: Barbara Bush was doing fine yesterday after being treated with a radioactive substance to destroy an overactive thyroid gland, a spokeswoman said.

title: Bridge
description: The score continued to oscillate in the Marathon Battle of the Sexes, with the men having the advantage. The women led briefly Sunday, lost ground Monday and trailed by 181 imps early Tuesday. The margin was cut to 24 imps by Tuesday afternoon but at 9 A.M. yesterday the men led by 281 with three days remaining.

title: Revitalization by Theme Is Folly for Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Belgian Chamber Orchestra
description: I Fiamminghi, a Belgian chamber orchestra, is a compact ensemble that deploys itself in an old-fashioned way, with the violinists and violists standing and the first and second fiddles on opposite sides of the stage. On Tuesday evening, it played works by Britten, Mozart and Tchaikovsky at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: NO-SMOKE POLICY ON FLIGHTS STALLS
description: A year after the United States and Canada prohibited smoking on airline flights of two hours or less, both major Canadian airlines have expanded the ban to all North American flights. But in the United States only Northwest Airlines has taken that step.

title: Reviews/Music; Songs of the 20th Century
description: Jessica Marsten, a soprano from Baltimore who studied at the Mannes College of Music and has performed with several of New York's smaller opera companies in recent seasons, chose a program of 20th-century songs for her debut at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon.

title: Amid Death in Ulster, a Man Reflects
description: ''Death means nothing in this country - life has no value here,'' said Martin McCauley, who was nearly killed by the police six and a half years ago as a suspected Irish Republican Army terrorist.

title: KEY RATES
Corrections
description: A picture caption last Saturday, with an article about economic hard times at Fairleigh Dickinson University reversed the identites of the men shown. Dr. Robert H. Donaldson, the university president, was at right and James McCue, vice president for finance, at left.

title: Computer Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ceremony Conceived in Hope Becomes a Memorial Service
description: A ceremony intended to revive hope for Mark Kilroy's safe return became a memorial service today, a day after his body was discovered in a Mexican grave. And a friend of Mr. Kilroy had a special, and personal, recollection of horror.

title: Cognos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Frankfurt Bourse Bombed
description: Masked youths hurled firebombs into the main trading hall of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange today, and a similar attack was made against an electronics company in Muenster, police said.

title: Federal National Mortgage Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mr. Bush's Ethics Plan: Big, and Thin
description: President Bush yesterday finally faced up to the Reagan legacy of easy ethical virtue - the sleaze factor - and he blinked. His challenge to Congress to raise ethical standards for all three branches of government calls for more loophole than law. His new ethics bill should, for instance, have pressed Congress to stop the shameful practice of taking honorariums from interest groups. Instead, the bill leaves a gaping hole.

title: Seattle's Prelate Says Fight With Vatican Is Over
description: Following two recent meetings with Pope John Paul II and a promise to keep his ministry within the bounds of Roman Catholic doctrine, Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen said today that his five-year fight with the Vatican was over.

title: BBDO Executive Gets Post With Whittle Magazines
description: After a 12-month search that looked at 50 candidates, Whittle Communications announced yesterday that it had hired a president for its largest publication.

title: We Can Build Tankers That Won't Spill Oil; Preserve the Refuge
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Errol Garner Impressions
description: Since his death in 1977, the pianist Erroll Garner has been disappearing into a mist of memories. He is rarely mentioned these days and he comes to mind only when some knowledgeable pianist - one of his contemporaries like George Shearing or Ahmad Jamal - colors a performance with some Garnerisms.

title: Adams Express reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The latest period's net asset value per share is after a capital gain distribution of 7 cents paid in March.

title: General Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
National Education Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Pop; Re-creating Staple Sound Of Rock Era
description: Rock-and-roll nostalgia is not the only reason Frankie Lymon and the Teen-Agers are one of the most idolized New York harmony groups of the rock-and-roll era. In 1956 and '57, when the group scored half a dozen hits, including ''Why Do Fools Fall in Love?,'' its lead singer's brash boy soprano introduced a vocal style that singers from Diana Ross to Michael Jackson to Madonna have made into a staple sound of American pop.

title: Review/Art; Images Without Solace, Thrones Without Kings
description: Felix Baldasano is a 32-year-old Spanish artist who is showing in New York for the first time. The dozen or so works on paper and 10 cement sculptures at the Facchetti Gallery in SoHo are dense, ghostly things. They are repositories of bad dreams, scatological pranks, memories of inquisition and ritual.

title: Franklin Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Herbert Mills, 77, a Mills Brother
description: Herbert Mills, who sang hits like ''Tiger Rag,'' ''Paper Doll'' and ''Lazy River'' as a member of the Mills Brothers for more than six decades, died Wednesday at Valley Hospital in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 77 years old.

title: Dolphin Wide Receiver Cleared to Rejoin Team
description: Investigations by the Miami Dolphins and the National Football League into allegations involving Mark Duper uncovered no wrongdoing, and the wide receiver has been reinstated and will report to camp next week, Coach Don Shula said Wednesday.

title: Secret Letters - Japanese Dodge
description: LEAD: It now appears that the dispute over the proposed U.S.-Japanese joint venture to build the FSX fighter plane will be settled by an exchange of secret side letters.

title: Abbie Hoffman, 60's Icon, Dies; Yippie Movement Founder Was 52
description: Abbie Hoffman, the writer and antiwar protester who founded the Yippie movement in the 1960's and became a symbol of radical activism, was found dead Wednesday night at his home in New Hope, Pa. He was 52 years old.

title: The Knicks Are Struggling At Just the Wrong Time
description: Maybe the Knicks are not as good as many thought earlier in the season. Maybe they are tired or in a late-season slump.

title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed
description: Officials today found a 13th body on an isolated ranch west of here and stepped up their hunt for a Cuban believed to be the leader of a drug-smuggling and ritual-murder cult that was apparently responsible for the killings.

title: Number, Please: Adieu Anonymity On the Telephone
description: It happens to many people sooner or later. The telephone rings and there is nothing on the line but heavy breathing. Or a too-ardent salesman. Or a stream of invective and threats, pouring out of the earpiece with smug anonymity. Who is this? Who is this?

title: CPC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chemfix Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; Closed-End Funds Are Easy Targets
description: ON the surface, the bid by NAV Partners for the Cypress Fund, a closed-end investment company that trades on the American Stock Exchange, seems merely an arbitrage play of the kind Robert N. Gordon is known for.

title: Chemical's Profits Drop 6.1%; Bank of New York Up 85.8%
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 6.1 percent, to $117.9 million, from $125.5 million.

title: Burlington Resources Plans Sale
description: Burlington Resources Inc. said today that it planned to sell 88 percent of its large timber company in the Pacific Northwest to a new limited partnership in a transaction valued at $575 million.

title: Dallas Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $675,000.

title: The Charlie Chaplin Centennial: A Genius Is Revisited
description: In the world of silent-film comedians, everything that goes up - be it a brick, a bottle, a pail or a pie - must come down on a foot or a head. Banana peels are discarded to be slipped upon, streets are freshly tarred to be stuck in. God designed rear ends to be kicked (squarely) or to be placed (firmly) atop objects either sharp (tacks are favored) or hot (preferably on fire).

title: Review/Film; Mismatched Teen-Agers Fall in Love, Of Course
description: Can a nice guy named Lloyd, who has no plans for college, win the love of the beautiful ice princess who happens to be class valedictorian? Does anyone over the age of 18 care? ''Say Anything'' has a prepackaged feel, with all the fuzzy-hearted warmth of a John Hughes film. But it was written and directed by Cameron Crowe, who wrote ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High,'' a tough-minded, sardonic film that makes Molly Ringwald's high school girls seem as realistic as Dorothy in Oz.

title: Story in Steinberg Case Is Adoption, Not Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanders N.F.L. Bound
description: Deion Sanders will cut short his minor league baseball season in July to play in the N.F.L., according to a published report.

title: Citytrust Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Senators Assail Deal for Closing Shoreham Plant
description: Amid predictions that New York and other Northeastern states are heading for a new energy crisis, the proposed deal to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island was assailed today by a senior Bush Administration official and members of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee.

title: Fair, Not Fearful, in the Wright Case
description: Who would have thought, six months ago, that the House of Representatives would dare conduct a credible inquiry into the behavior of its potent Speaker, Jim Wright? Yet the bipartisan House Ethics Committee seems to be doing just that. The Speaker's defensive news conference yesterday attested to the committee's independence as it reaches the point of voting on charges.

title: Empire State Life Insurance Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $7,990 and $90,483 for the latest year and year- earlier period.

title: Analysts International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Selections Are in the Mail For N.F.L. Successor to Rozelle
description: Sealed in an envelope with a 25-cent stamp on it could be the name of the next commissioner of the multimillion-dollar National Football League.

title: Exxon Will Help Pay For Study of Oil Spill
description: The Exxon Shipping Company reached agreement today with Federal and Alaskan officials to advance $15 million toward the initial cost of assessing long-term damage from the oil spill in Prince William Sound.

title: Amsouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lebanon's Latest Agony
description: Gen. Michel Aoun, Lebanon's Christian army commander, presses a legitimate cause through fatally compromised means. He demands withdrawal of Syrian occupation troops and restoration of Lebanese sovereignty. But he cannot plausibly speak in the name of all, or even most, Lebanese.

title: Review/Music; In 101 Parts, a Premiere by John Cage
description: The plan was for John Cage to be present in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening when the Boston Symphony opened its concert with the New York premiere of ''1O1,'' a work commissioned by the orchestra and the Fromm Music Foundation. Rearrangement of the program became necessary, however, when it was learned that Mr. Cage's arrival from Boston, presumably on I Ching Airways, had been delayed.

title: Gaze Is Gone But Questions Arise
description: Andrew Gaze left Seton Hall for his native Australia last Friday after spending six months at the school he helped bring to the brink of a national basketball championship.

title: First Bank Offers Preferred Stock
description: First Bank System Inc. offered 3.4 million shares of fixed-rate preferred stock through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets yesterday.

title: Elliott Osserman, 64, Professor of Medicine
description: Dr. Elliott F. Osserman, the American Cancer Society Professor of Medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died of Parkinson's disease yesterday at his home in Closter, N.J. He was 64 years old.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Current Music

title: Review/Art
description: LAST week, the Guerrilla Girls, those intrepid and anonymous demographers of the art world status quo, released new information on the status of women - communicating, as usual, by posters peppering the building walls in SoHo and beyond. The most attention grabbing of the pronouncements compared the percentages of women represented by 33 prominent New York City art galleries with the percentages of women in other jobs nationwide.

title: A Different North
description: Oliver North before the bar of justice seems a different man from the Oliver North who proudly stacked up his telegrams of approval before a wary committee of House and Senate politicians two years ago.

title: Read Congress's Words, Not its Mind, Judges Say
description: When judges wrestle with the meaning of ambiguous laws, they have traditionally looked for guidance in legislative history.

title: Review/Film; Shocked Father Finds Daughter Has Grown Up
description: When Tony Danza realizes his 15-year-old daughter is an attractive young woman, he reacts by telling her she is grounded for the rest of her life - a response that has popped up on television so often it should have been retired ages ago. Anyone who has watched television for even a night will be able to predict every scene in ''She's Out of Control'' with total accuracy. It is an extended version of familiar, bland sitcom situations, with Mr. Danza playing a smoother-edged version of his character on the endlessly running hit ''Who's the Boss?''

title: Peters, J M Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Where British Remain A Power: Advertising
description: Where Americans tend to get mad at advertising, the British are advertising-mad.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''SOUVENIRS OF OLD NEW YORK,'' a new play, directed by Ami Brockway, presented by the Open Eye: New Stagings for Youth, at 2 P.M. Sundays, through April, at the group's theater, 270 West 89th Street. Admission: children, $6; adults, $8. Information: 769-4143. A DISCOVERY HIKE, a woodland hike, with views of ponds and garden displays, led by Mildred Leipzig, a naturalist, 10 A.M. to noon tomorrow, in Clark Garden (an affiliate of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden), 193 I. U. Willets Road, Albertson, L.I. Pre-registration required: fee, $4. Hikers are advised to wear old clothes and comfortable shoes. Rain date: April 22. Information: (516) 621-7568. RIVERSIDE CHURCH TOWER, a 392-foot-high structure at 490 Riverside Drive, at 120th Street, offering views of the Hudson River, New Jersey and Manhattan. Elevator to the 20th floor and one flight of stairs lead to the bell tower, where visitors may view the 74-bell carillon. Daily from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. (not Saturdays) and 12:30 to 4 P.M. Sundays. For children over 6 and adults. Admission: $1. Information: 222-5900. THE INTREPID, the aircraft carrier sea-and-air space museum, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesdays to Sundays, with the last tour at 4 P.M., at Pier 86, at 46th Street. Admission: children, $2.50, the elderly, $4; others, $4.75. Information: 245-2533. ''THE SEAPORT EXPERIENCE,'' a film spectacle about the South Street Seaport, with 104 projectors and special audio effects, 10:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays and 10:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Fridays through Sundays, at the Trans-Lux Seaport Theater, 210 Front Street, at the seaport. Children, $3.25; adults, $4.75. Information: 608-7888. THOMAS McKEAN STORIES, in which Mr. McKean, the author of children's books, will entertain youngsters from noon to 2 P.M. tomorrow, at Books of Wonder, 132 Seventh Avenue, at 18th Street. Free. Information: 989-3270.

title: First Bancorp of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $1,282,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Chanry Communications, based in Farmingdale, L.I., has started its first advertising campaign in support of This Week, a chain of 76 community newspapers to be introduced on May 6.

title: Venezuelan Prices Spurt
description: Venezuela's consumer price index rose 21.3 percent in March after price controls were lifted, the central bank said this week. In the past, Venezuela has had relatively low inflation compared with many South American countries.

title: Randy White Retires
description: Randy White, the Dallas Cowboys' veteran defensive tackle, announced his retirement yesterday because of a lingering neck injury.

title: Automobile Protection reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a tax credit of $50,937.

title: Estimate Board Approves Plan For Jail Barge
description: New York City's plan to build a $130 million jail barge to house 800 inmates was approved last night by the Board of Estimate.

title: A Long-Lost Skeleton In a Synagogue Cellar
description: A dark - or, in any case, bizarre -chapter in the otherwise venerable history of the Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side was reopened yesterday when a long-lost skull rolled out from a coal-ash pile and struck the foot of a workman.

title: Tunis Journal; A Song of Democracy in a Distinctly Islamic Key
description: The leader of the opposition in Tunisia, who answers his own telephone in a scruffy room on the rue d'Algerie, does not have the right to vote and his party is not yet legal. A year and a half ago, he was convinced that he was going to be executed, that only Allah could save him.

title: Kirk Drops Appeal
description: Dana Kirk, the former Memphis State basketball coach who was convicted last November on charges of tax evasion and obstruction of justice, has dropped his appeal of a one-year prison sentence, his attorney said yesterday. Denise McCrary, the lawyer, said Kirk also had dropped libel suits against a Memphis newspaper, The Commercial Appeal, and Sports Illustrated magazine.

title: Dow Chemical's Stock Repurchase
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it would repurchase 12 million of its shares now that it had completed an earlier 10-million-share buyback. Dow Chemical has bought more than 30 million shares of its own stock through 10 repurchase programs since 1983. At the end of 1988 there were 183.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Hard Cash for Hard Choices by Lawyers
description: At a time when most law students are fighting for high-paying jobs in large firms, law schools are involved in a quieter competition to encourage them to choose less lucrative careers.

title: Altera Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NAMIBIA STANDOFF OVER GUERRILLAS
description: A standoff between South Africa and the United Nations developed here today in the rugged bush over the disposition of the first Namibian guerrillas facing return to Angola.

title: Officials Fight Rates In Lilco Pact
description: Even as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant nears final approval, many of the people responsible for the settlement, including the Governor, continue to attack a central element of the accord, the 5 percent annual rate increases granted to the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: First Federal of Michigan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $4,000 gain from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Chip Index Still Strong
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator showed continued strength as American semiconductor orders and shipments reached an all-time high in March, a trade group reported today. The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in Cupertino, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.06 for the three-month period ended in March, down slightly from 1.07 in February, but up from a revised figure of 1.02 in January. The book-to-bill compares orders with shipments.

title: Syria Hits Soviet Ships And Then Apologizes
description: Syrian helicopter gunships attacked Soviet Navy vessels in the Mediterranean on Tuesday, apparently by mistake.

title: On Stage
description: A Musical 'Arthur'

title: Review/Theater; 'Welcome to the Club,' A Musical About Divorce
description: Handed a free night and 90 bucks of mad money, would any couple choose to see a Broadway musical comedy set in a prison for alimony deadbeats? Apparently the creators of ''Welcome to the Club,'' the new attraction at the Music Box, think so, for they have actually put on a show with songs like ''Pay the Lawyer'' and ''Love Behind Bars'' and a production number about a jail break. I didn't laugh, but maybe that's my problem. Until Mel Brooks proved otherwise, who would have believed in the song-and-dance possibilities of Adolf Hitler and Eva Braun?

title: Revisiting Eight Musicals With New Casts
description: IT comes as no surprise to realize that the best musicals are still the best musicals.

title: Plan Is Filed In Hunts' Case
description: Three leading creditors in the bankruptcy cases of Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt have filed a reorganization plan in which the brothers' personal assets would be liquidated to repay more than $2 billion in debts. Lawyers for the Internal

title: Devils Recruit Abroad
description: Lou Lamoriello, the president and general manager of the Devils, will resume his pursuit of Vyacheslav Fetisov and Reijo Ruotsalainen on Monday in Stockholm.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about land disputes between Israeli settlers and Palestinians in occupied territories misstated land area in three instances because of incorrect conversions to acres from an Israeli unit of measure. The correct figures are these: information from the West Bank Data Project and other sources indicates that more than 475,000 acres has been expropriated by the Israeli Government since 1967 because land was deemed unregistered and uncultivated; about 250 acres was set aside for the Jewish settlement of Talmon; a tax receipt held by a Palestinian villager was for about 3 1/4 acres.

title: American Continental Files For Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
description: The American Continental Corporation, the parent of the ailing Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., filed yesterday for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: First of America Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
We Can Build Tankers That Won't Spill Oil; Fossil-Fuel Moratorium
description: To the Editor:

title: Sonoco Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Denys W. Knoll, Retired Admiral, 82
description: Denys W. Knoll, a retired Navy rear admiral who helped organize the first military staff for the United Nations, died Wednesday at St. Vincent Health Center. He was 82 years old and lived in Erie.

title: Baldwin-Enkel
description: The Baldwin Technology Company said it was in talks on a merger of the privately held Enkel Corporation into Baldwin, but there could be no assurance that any agreement would be reached. Enkel makes web handling equipment for the printing and converting industries. Baldwin makes controls, instruments and accessories for the printing industry.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * B. Altman & Co., a department store chain and division of Hooker Corp., appointed Wayne G. Griffin executive vice president.

title: Linear Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Theater; Some Divine Intervention From a Man Named Joe
description: God is just a guy named Joe in Bruce Graham's apocalyptical comedy, ''Early One Evening at the Rainbow Bar and Grille.'' As played by William Wise, He is an amiable fellow, but the concept is at least as old as George Burns - and the playwright does not offer an excess of interesting variations. The play, which was first presented at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays, is at the WPA.

title: Chemical Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank said this year's first quarter figures included Horizon Bancorp of New Jersey, which was acquired on Jan. 3, 1989. Chemical said investment securities transactions resulted in a loss of $600,000 in latest first quarter, compared with a gain of $25.6 million in year-ago period.

title: From Louis Dell'Olio, Clean Cuts and Colors
description: The first models strode down the runway clad in basic scarlet right down to their shoes and stockings. Louis Dell'Olio made the jump suits, cape stoles, narrow trousers, turtleneck sweaters and other essential ingredients of fall and winter sportswear at Anne Klein look fresh by keeping the entire outfit in one color, and that a clear, fiery red.

title: Review/Film; Anthony Perkins Plays a Modern Jekyll and Hyde
description: Dr. Jekyll, the most shortsighted medical innovator in all literature, and Mr. Hyde, his homicidal alter ego, are again ravining through 19th-century London as high as kites.

title: Ravel and Bach
description: The Laurentian String Quartet is to play the Ravel String Quartet, the Mozart Clarinet Quintet and selections from bach's ''Art of the Fugue'' at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 316 East 88th Street, on Sunday at 5 P.M. Gervase de Peyer will be the clarinetist in the Mozart. Tickets are $8. Information: 860-2077.

title: Easy Goer Isn't the Retiring Type
description: In recent years, racing fans have learned to wonder whenever a really good 3-year-old comes along: How long will he be allowed to race?

title: Tough In or Out of Ring
description: Sugar Ray Robinson had a flair for his business, whether he was operating in the prize ring or in the rooms where his purses were negotiated.

title: Longtime Friend of Capital Mayor Indicted on Federal Drug Charges
description: Charles Lewis, the subject of a drug investigation that has also centered on Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on three counts of possessing cocaine and seven counts of lying about drug use and possession.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Education page on Feb. 15 about the use of Braille by students misstated the extent of Michael J. McDermott Jr.'s disability. Mr. McDermott, an 11th-grade student, is blind and not literate in Braille. But in an interview after the article was published he explained that he uses a personal computer with an artificial voice to complete written assignments for his classes.

title: Different brand of bait to lure top law students: appeal to conscience instead of craving.
description: In their annual effort to woo top talent, New York's large firms dangle just about every legal form of self-indulgence in front of law students. But this summer a new program will be doing more than overfeeding appetites. It will cater to consciences, allowing students to work for the indigent, the homeless, the elderly and the unlucky.

title: New Contra Deal, And a Look Back
description: With little of the partisan rancor that has marked the issue in the past, Congress gave President Bush a political victory by approving $49.7 million for the Nicaraguan rebels. Article, page A8.

title: Teleflex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
Tolland Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KEY RATES
Dining Out Guide: Upper West Side
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Alcala ** (March 18, 1988), 349 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street (769-9600) -Tapas, small portions of savory Spanish appetizers, can be a light meal if you select several at Alcala's long marble-topped bar. Among the more intriguing are fresh anchovies in marinade, fried calamari, shellfish salad, and smoked tuna with pimentos. Entrees include grouper with vegetables and broiled lamb chops Orange flan is a winning dessert. Tapas are $4 to $9, entrees $14 to $21. Open 5:30 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday, until 11 P.M. Sunday; tapas bar open 5:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. daily. Baci Diner's Journal (June 5, 1987), 412 Amsterdam Avenue, at 79th Street (496-1550) - Some of the best pasta on the Upper West Side is served at this lively cafe outfitted in the Memphis style. Choices may include penne with eggplant and basil, and ravioli filled with spinach and ricotta. Entrees include chicken and sausage with white wine, balsamic vinegar and rosemary. Appetizers are $6 to $9.50, pastas $10.50 to $12, entrees $14 to $18. Open noon to 3 P.M. Friday to Sunday (brunch menu Saturday and Sunday), 5:30 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday and 5 to 10:30 P.M. Sunday. Coastal ** (June 12, 1987), 300 Amsterdam Avenue, at 74th Street (769-3988) -Cleanly designed, this restaurant has a wood-framed glass facade and a wraparound mural representing the American coastline. Nearly all grilled or sauteed seafood can be recommended. Among other choices are New England clam chowder, redfish fajitas, and steamed lobster. The current dessert menu has a lemon ribbon pie. Appetizers are $4.75 to $7, entrees $12.50 to $19.50. Open 6 to 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday and 11:45 A.M. to 2:45 P.M. and 5:30 to 10 P.M. Sunday. La Boite en Bois * (Jan. 13, 1989), 75 West 68th Street (874-2705) - This is a charming Upper West Side bistro with a little brick-and-barn-board dining room decorated with antique farm tools. Leeks vinaigrette is a good starter. Entrees to try include salmon with mustard sauce cooked in parchment; roast duck with Armagnac, and red snapper sauteed with fresh tarragon, a special. Creme brulee is the star of the dessert menu. Appetizers are $4.75 to $7.50, entrees $16 to $19; pre-theater prix fixe at $24.75. Prix fixe 5:30 to 7 P.M. and a la carte 6:30 to 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 5 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Poiret Diner's Journal (Dec. 16, 1988), 474 Columbus Avenue, at 82d Street (724-6880) - Poiret is a popular, promising bistro with an eye-catching tile mural outside. The reasonably priced French fare includes a good version of carbonade, a beef stew cooked with onions braised in dark beer; navarin of lamb with couscous, and roast chicken. Two presentations of mussels are on the appetizer list - poached in a basil broth and on the half shell. For dessert, there is bittersweet chocolate pave served on a raspberry sauce. Appetizers are $6.95 to $9.95, entrees $12.95 to $19.95. Open 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. Friday and Saturday, until 11:30 P.M. Sunday, with brunch 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. What the stars mean, page C20.

title: Foreign Policy Hurt Drug War, Senators Say
description: In pursuing foreign policy goals, the Reagan Administration often sacrificed efforts to curb drug trafficking, in one case seeking a reduced sentence for a Honduran general linked to the drug trade, a Senate subcommittee said today.

title: Washington Drug Crisis Dominates Local News
description: Just as government officials are struggling for innovative ways to tackle this city's epidemic of drug-related murders, news organizations here are responding with new and hotly debated approaches to chronicling the biggest local story in years.

title: Nuclear Plant Venture in Europe
description: Framatome of France and KWU Group, a subsidiary of the West German electronics giant Siemens A.G., said they were forming a joint company to increase Europe's presence in the global market for nuclear power plants.

title: Bairnco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $3,239,000 from an operation which has subsequently been spun off.

title: Continental Increases Low Fares
description: Continental Airlines is raising its discount fares in most of its markets for the summer travel season, in some cases as much as 18 percent, the company said yesterday.

title: After Loss to Pirates, Mets Are in Last Place
description: The Mets, who failed to generate any offense for most of last summer and all of this spring, got only one hit in eight innings today off John Smiley of the Pittsburgh Pirates, took a 4-2 tumble for their fifth loss in seven games and dropped, to their astonishment, into last place.

title: Integrating School and Home: Rochester Experiment Falters
description: Two years after Rochester began an innovative program to reverse years of educational decline by giving teachers large raises in return for vastly expanded responsibilities, the experiment is struggling with resistance in the teaching ranks.

title: Elcor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jane Scheckter

title: Smith, A O Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Top Judge Tours Courthouse, Highlighting Space Shortage
description: New York State's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, toured courthouses in Queens and Manhattan yesterday to highlight what he called the critical shortage of courtroom space.

title: Bhopal Relief Is Ordered
description: India's Supreme Court ordered the Indian Government today to pay interim cash relief to victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Famous Mouths Eating Klondike Ice Cream
description: The new campaign for Klondike ice cream bars dispenses with catchy jingles and rhetorical questions (''What would you do for a Klondike bar?'') to focus on four mouths. The mouths - which belong to Vanna White, Gene Shalit, Robin Leach and Steve Allen - are shown devouring the ice cream treat, a spectacle that W. B. Doner hopes will inspire television viewers to do likewise.

title: Shamask Tries Out Soft New Shapes
description: Ronaldus Shamask continues to evolve and grow as a designer, experimenting with new shapes and cuts each season. In his fall show Wednesday evening at the Puck Building on the fringe of SoHo, he paraded a variety of easy, comfortable-looking clothes.

title: Steamboat Excursion
description: The Seaport Line and The South Street Seaport Museum have begun another season of narrated excursions in New York Harbor. Aboard the recently refurbished De Witt Clinton and the Andrew Fletcher, re-creations of a 19th-century steamboat and a sidewheeler, passengers will hear 90 minutes of historic commentary on such landmarks as the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, Battery Park and the Brooklyn Bridge. Tours depart from Pier 16. Tickets are $10; $9 for students and the elderly and $6 for children and museum members. Information: 669-9400.

title: Foreign Repairs on Jets Prompt Concern in U.S.
description: Next September an Australian company will begin a major overhaul on some of the Boeing 747's owned by Continental Airlines, stripping down, inspecting and repairing the planes to assure that they are safe for hundreds of hours of additional flying.

title: Capitals Are Eliminated by Flyers
description: Pete Peeters hugged his post, positioned his stick properly, as he had been schooled to and as the Washington goaltender had done countless times. Out of the corner of one eye, he watched Rick Tocchet deep along the boards to his left.

title: Intel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Boase, Massimi Rebuffs Offer
description: Boase, Massimi & Pollitt, the British parent company of Ammirati & Puris, released its formal response today to a French agency's hostile takeover bid, saying, ''Ca ne marche pas'' - ''It doesn't fit.''

title: TWO FOUND GUILTY ON FRAUD CHARGES IN PENTAGON TRIAL
description: A Federal jury today convicted two executives of a California military contractor of conspiracy and wire fraud.

title: Liberty National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Healthcare Compare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
North's Trial: A Glossary
description: This is a guide to some of the names and initials that appear in the documents released at the trial of Oliver L. North: Abu Nidal Nom de guerre of Sabri Khalil al-Banna, reputed head of a terrorist organization called Black September or Fatah.

title: Valley National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Conagra Deal On Holly Farms
description: Conagra Inc. said it had agreed to divest itself of a portion of the Holly Farms Corporation's flour milling operation if it succeeded in a $1 billion buyout of its poultry-industry competitor. The agreement with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission would require Conagra to give up 2.4 million pounds of Holly Farms' daily flour milling capacity if the merger was completed, a Conagra spokesman, Walt Casey, said. The agreement requires divestiture within 15 months after the F.T.C. consent decree process, which should take about 10 weeks.

title: Protest Filed on I.B.M. Bid
description: A leading competitor of the International Business Machines Corporation in the Federal computer market has filed a protest with the General Services Administration over the bidding for a contract to supply a Navy postgraduate school with two mainframe computers.

title: NBD Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TV Weekend; Incest, Murder and Misleading Appearances
description: The subject is incest. But ''A Deadly Silence,'' the docudrama on ABC at 9 P.M. Sunday, concentrates on wider issues. Writing about the project, Robert Greenwald, one of the executive producers (''The Burning Bed''), explains that the film ''cannot just call attention to the fact of incest - for I think every adult knows it goes on - but call attention to the complexities and subtleties in both identifying it and doing something about it.''

title: Old Tune From 1966
description: It was the summer of 1966. The Beatles were singing. The Stones were singing. The Doors were singing, and Ralph Houk had a song of his own:

title: Broker Charges Dismissed
description: A Federal judge has dismissed charges against Meyer Blinder, a penny stock broker; his son and his brokerage. The judge also chastised the Securities and Exchange Commission for misconduct in a 1983 civil case.

title: Gannett Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter results included a $9,000,000 pretax gain on the sale of two newspapers. The company also said the year-ago quarter results included a $45,000,000 gain on the sale of its interest in Cowles Media.

title: Artillery Duels Spread in Lebanon, Killing 15
description: At least 15 people were reported killed and about 40 wounded today as fierce artillery battles raged in much of Lebanon.

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Santa Monica Journal; Aerobics for Homeless: Dancing From the Brink
description: From the sidewalk outside the Main Street Dance and Exercise Studio, a homeless man with a towel around his head peered through the open doorway last Sunday as the members of an aerobics class paused to catch their breath.

title: Gannett Profit Rises Slightly
description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings inched ahead by 1.2 percent, to $74.9 million, or 47 cents a share, from $74 million, or 46 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 7.9 percent, to $817.6 million from $757.9 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Goodwill Games Ads
description: The Goodwill Games - Ted Turner's off-year Olympics - are reaching for prestige in a new advertising campaign. Five athletes with 13 Olympic medals among them are featured in ads promoting the 1990 Goodwill Games in Seattle. Matt Biondi, Greg Louganis, Brian Boitano, Carl Lewis and Jackie Joyner-Kersee will exhort viewers to tune in to the Games. The ads are now appearing on the four networks of the Turner Broadcasting System; print ads will appear in national newspapers and magazines starting in July.

title: British Joblessness Falls
description: The number of British workers without jobs fell to its lowest rate in more than eight years in March and average wages rose, creating inflationary pressures, official figures released today showed. The Government's statistics said that the underlying rise in average earnings - a critical indicator in the Conservative Government's fight against inflation - rose to 9.25 percent in the year through February, up from 9 percent in January. March unemployment, adjusted to account for seasonal variations, fell by 30,600, to 1.92 million - 6.7 percent of the work force.

title: Soviet Georgians Hold March To Mourn Victims of Protests
description: Thousands of people carrying candles walked through the streets of the Georgian capital today as residents held the first of 19 funerals for victims of a brutal confrontation between troops and nationalist demonstrators.

title: New Phase of Iran-Iraq Talks Is Set Next Week in Geneva
description: Direct peace talks between Iran and Iraq, aimed at breaking the deadlock in settling the Persian Gulf war, are to resume in Geneva next week, the United Nations announced today.

title: Review/Film; 'Winter People,' of Love in the Depression
description: One of these days, maybe Kurt Russell and Kelly McGillis will look back at ''Winter People'' and laugh. It has some very funny moments, though it is meant to be an utterly serious drama. It is a historical drama, set in the Depression. It is a family drama, with a Hatfield-McCoy type feud and pained facial expressions. It is a bad drama, in which a gentle clockmaker goes on a bear hunt to prove his love for a skeptical woman with a backwoods accent.

title: Saxophonist at Birdland
description: The saxophonist Clifford Jordna is leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Birdland, 2745 Broadway, at 105th Street (749-2228). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Good Health Walk
description: The second Good Health Walk, a 3.2-mile walk from Times Square to City Hall, will be held on Sunday. Conducted by the New York Road Runners Club, the walk begins at 10 A.M. at The New York Times building, at 229 West 43d Street, and follows Broadway downtown. Henry J. Stern, the Parks Commissioner and grand marshal of the event, will lead the walk to City Hall for refreshments, and there will be a variety of health, fitness and sports activities. Registration is $10. Information and registration: 556-4317.

title: Net Falls 26.4% at Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that net income dropped 26.4 percent, to $33.5 million, or 42 cents a share, for the first quarter of 1989.

title: We Can Build Tankers That Won't Spill Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: North's Defense Ends Its Case After His Testimony
description: Oliver L. North's defense rested its case today after Mr. North, in a final clash with the chief prosecution lawyer, testified that he had been shocked to learn that he might face criminal prosecution because of his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Teledyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After equity in net income of investees of $10.7 million for the latest first quarter and $9.2 million for the year-ago period. The results included pretax gains on sales of investments of $300,000 for the latest quarter and $99.6 million for year-ago period. Most of the $99.6 million in pretax gains came from Teledyne's sale of its stake in Brockway Inc., a glass company acquired last year by Owens-Illinois Inc. The year-ago results were restated for an accounting change.

title: The North Trial Papers: A Window on the Effort to Circumvent Congress
description: The documents released at the trial of Oliver L. North provide an intimate look at the Reagan Administration at work on foreign policy, coolly manipulating negotiations with Nicaragua to keep Congress quiet and discussing the idea of military action in Central America.

title: Marine Midland Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The provision for loan losses in the latest first quarter was $54 million, compared with $41 million for the year-ago period. Marine Midland is a member of the HongKongBank Group.

title: Hawks Gain; Kings, Canucks Still Alive
description: Wayne Presley scored three times, including a record third short-handed goal, and Steve Larmer added two as the Chicago Blackhawks defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 7-1, to eliminate the Norris Division champions.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Truck Talk: When Tough Isn't Enough
description: SOME of the fiercest comparison advertising in recent times has featured Ford and Chevrolet pickup trucks bursting into flames, exploding or plunging through a ''ditch of doom.''

title: Oil Cleanup Project Bogs Down in Confusion
description: At dusk the fishermen on Herring Bay looked at today's catch, mucky pools of oil circled by yellow floating booms, and cursed because the Exxon Corporation had promised to send ships to skim up the oil but the ships had not arrived.

title: NCNB Increasing Texas Bank Stake
description: The NCNB Corporation said it intends to more than double its stake in the First Republicbank Corporation, now the NCNB Texas National Bank, to 49 percent by the end of April. It now holds 20 percent. The additional stake in the Dallas-based bank group, which is co-owned by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, will raise NCNB's investment to $500 million.

title: Flamenco
description: Paco Pena, the flamenco guitarist, is to perform at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $15. Information: 840-2824.

title: Cuomo Settles Suit on a Share In a Law Firm
description: After nine years of bitter charges, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his former law firm agreed yesterday to end a civil suit over whether he had a right to share in more than $4 million in legal fees.

title: Caged for Life, and His Jailers Stand Back
description: To greet a visitor, Willie Bosket must now let himself be chained backwards to his prison cell door, his arms and legs manacled through slots in it. Then the door is swung open, with him splayed out aboard.

title: Smithsonian to Get Concorde
description: A Concorde , will be given to the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum under an agreement to be signed Sunday between the museum and Air France. The Smithsonian said the gift of the supersonic airliner would be made within the next decade as some of the planes, which began commercial service in 1976, are retired. The aircraft will occupy a prominent space in the museum's annex to be built at Dulles International Airport about 20 miles outside Washington.

title: WRIGHT DECLARES HE WILL FIGHT BACK ON ETHICS CHARGES
description: House Speaker Jim Wright vowed today to defend his honor and his wife's against charges that their private finances broke the rules of Congressional conduct.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Sir Speedy, a printing chain, to Keye/Donna/Pearlstein, Los Angeles, with a budget of $3 million.

title: Review/Dance; Taylor Puts Paradox Into Sin and Piety
description: Paul Taylor has choreographed a masterpiece for our time. ''Speaking in Tongues'' takes on the only-too-obvious theme of good and evil and transforms it into dramatic suspense, creating a contemporary morality play.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Faldo Posts a 68: It's a new week with a new tournament for Nick Faldo, who four days ago sank a 25-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole to win the 53d Masters. Yesterday, the 31-year-old Englishman went around the Harbour Town Golf Links at Hilton Head Island, S.C., in three-under-par 68. He was tied for fifth place, three strokes off the pace of 65 set by Payne Stewart and Kenny Perry in the first round of the MCI Heritage Classic.

title: CCB Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Consolidated TVX Mining Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a writedown of mining properties of $26 million for both the quarter and year. The company said revenue figures for the quarter were not immediately available. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cameron Iron Works Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago 9 months included a $20,618,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Talks on Export Curbs Stall
description: The drive by several European nations to loosen restrictions on the sale of high-technology goods to Warsaw Pact nations has stalled at a meeting here of the Coordinating Committee on Export Controls, known as Cocom.

title: Drexel Reaches S.E.C. Accord In Civil Charges
description: In the most far-reaching accord ever in a securities fraud case, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday settled civil charges involving securities law violations, with the influential Wall Street firm agreeing to sweeping changes in how it does business.

title: Marriott Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
description: The latest quarter results included a $5 million pretax development fee received in connection with the sale of three Marriott hotels to a limited partnership.

title: EAB reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Alden P. Yates, 60, President of Bechtel
description: Alden Perry Yates, president of the Bechtel Group Inc., the worldwide engineering and construction company, died of colon cancer Wednesday at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 60 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Georgia Tech Team Reports Flaw In Critical Experiment on Fusion
description: A critical experiment that was the strongest independent support for the claim that cold fusion had been achieved in a jar of water has turned out to be seriously flawed, researchers said yesterday at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta.

title: Grace, W R & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $910,000 from discontinued operations. c-Included income of $10,589,000 from discontinued operations and a $4,854,000 gain from an accounting change. Year-ago quarter discontinued operations included a $10,900,000 after-tax gain for sale of the company's 25 percent interest in Home Quarters Warehouse Inc.

title: Manhattan Doctor Arrested On Cocaine-Scheme Charges
description: A anesthesiologist from Manhattan who law-enforcement officers said was a close friend of a Colombian drug smuggler was arrested Wednesday on charges of conspiracy to distribute cocaine.

title: What Tales Bare Bones Can Tell Scientists
description: To the Editor:

title: Shelton Bancorp Inc reports earnings for
Pop/Jazz; 3 Performers Who Thrive In Cabaret Or on Stage
description: Cabaret and musical theater have always been first cousins. Scores of performers have appeared on Broadway only after first making their names in cabaret. It is also a time-honored tradition for Broadway stars to step out of their stage roles and create a cabaret act.

title: Walgreen Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Congress Votes $49.7 Million in Aid for Contras
description: Congress approved a $49.7 million package of aid to the Nicaraguan rebels today with little trace of the partisan rancor that marked Congressional debate on such issues in the last eight years.

title: Europe Acts To Reassure U.S. Banks
description: Seeking to reassure foreign banks worried about protectionism, European Community officials said today that they had weakened reciprocity proposals that many bankers feared could deny them access to the European market.

title: Glatfelter, P H Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Barry's Jewelers Inc., Duarte, Calif., said it had purchased six Keidan's jewelry stores in Toledo, Ohio, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Affiliated Publications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush Names Navy Secretary
description: President Bush, here for a speech on education, said today that he would nominate Under Secretary of the Navy Lawrence Garrett to be Secretary of the Navy.

title: Review/Film; Fighting Hypocrisy, in Sautet's 'Few Days'
description: ''A Few Days With Me,'' Claude Sautet's new French film opening today at the Paris, is a wan comic fable about Martial (Daniel Auteuil), a rich, handsome, moody young man for whom life has lost all meaning. At the start of the film, he is emerging from a breakdown during which he refused to talk.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Leo Petranker has joined Pancom International Corp. as senior vice president and art group head.

title: A Broad Fall For Stocks; Dow Off 23.65
description: Stocks retreated across a broad front yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.65 points, to 2,296.00.

title: Coca-Cola Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect consolidation of Coca- Cola Financial Corp., a finance subsidiary that previously had been accounted for under the equity method of accounting. The company said the restatement had no effect on previously reported net income or net income per share.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For my good name, which is the legacy I intend to leave my children and my grandchildren, I will fight to the last ounce of conviction and energy that I possess.'' - Speaker Jim Wright. [ A1:6. ]

title: Agreement Is Reached On U.S. Budget Outline
description: After weeks of tortuous negotiations over a relatively small amount of money, Bush Administration officials and Congressional budget writers agreed tonight on the general outline, although not the specifics, of a Federal budget for the next fiscal year.

title: House Banking Panel Backs Measure for Savings Bailout
description: One day after the Senate Banking Committee approved the Bush Administration's rescue plan for the savings industry, a House panel accepted a similar measure, almost insuring that the legislation will become law by the end of June.

title: Grove Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Make Neighborhood Schools More Attractive
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Old Twists: Bank Heist And Inept Detectives
description: ''Disorganized Crime'' combines the old bank-heist genre with the chestnut about bumbling detectives who let a suspect escape from their custody. It is possible, theoretically, to create fresh twists on those creaky rituals, but ''Disorganized Crime'' never gets more clever than its title.

title: United Carolina Bancshares Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chinese Opera
description: Several performers from the Beijing Opera Troupe os Shanghai will give a free demonstration of Chinese opera tomorrow at 2 P.M. at the Flushing Branch Library, 1 Library Plaza, at Main Street and Kissena Boulevard, in Queens. Admission is free. Information: (718) 445-0800.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Jackie Mason's

title: INSIDE
description: Papandreou Friend Jailed A friend of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece was arrested on charges of handling embezzled funds that were said to have been given to the Prime Minister. Page A3. Questions Over Athlete Andrew Gaze's short Seton Hall career and background in Australia raise new issues of recruitment and amateur standing. Page A27. Higher Air Fares Continental Airlines will raise its discount fares on most routes by as much as 18 percent, starting May 26, and there is a good chance its competitors will do the same. Page D1. 13th Body Found on Ranch A suspect led officials to one more body on the Mexican border where a ring of drug smugglers apparently practiced ritual murder. Page A14.

title: Willamette Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Stone's Magical Light
description: ''Brightness'' (''Yeelen'') was shown as part of the 1987 New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 8, 1987. The film, in Bambara with English subtitles, opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Pacific Western Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $1.2 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Too Many Have Access To Medical Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Georges Sebastian, 85, Orchestra Conductor
description: Georges Sebastian, a Hungarian-born conductor who spent two seasons at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City and who conducted orchestras in Germany and the Soviet Union, died Wednesday at his home outside Paris. He was 85 years old.

title: Yes, Street People Can Be Rescued
description: One recent Friday, Isaiah Crumpton, a psychiatric social worker, went to visit one of his clients, recently released from Creedmoor Psychiatric Center. As they chatted, the man burst oddly into laughter. Mr. Crumpton recognized the sign: The man had not been taking the medication prescribed to quiet the demons that once drove him to live on the street. ''Let me see your medicine bottle,'' he asked. It contained too many pills. Mr. Crumpton insisted that the man start taking them again then and there.

title: BIG SHIFT IN POSTS FOR BONN CABINET
description: Fighting the erosion of his Government's popularity, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced a major shake-up of his coalition Government today, dropping the Defense Minister and shifting several major portfolios.

title: Hunt, J B Transport Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bozell Wins Avanti
description: The Dallas office of Bozell extended its hot streak yesterday, winning the account for the Piaggio P180 Avanti, an Italian turboprop aircraft. Bozell will create a campaign for the Avanti, a small plane with an innovative design, in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean.
