Bozell refused to disclose the value of the account, but an agency spokesman said it was a ''multimillion-dollar piece of business.'' Last week, the Dallas office won the advertising for Long John Silver's restaurants, an account valued at $15 million to $26 million.

title: The New York Times Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,975,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,626,000 for the year-ago period. The results also included after-tax equity in earnings of the forest products group of $3,575,000 for the 1989 quarter and $6,834,000 for year-ago period.

title: Northrop Charges Under Review
description: The Defense Department said an Air Force board would review the Northrop Corporation's indictment on charges of falsifying weapons-part test data to decide whether a bar from Government contracts was warranted. ''Any suggestion at this point that Northrop may be suspended or debarred is really speculative and premature because, as you know, there's a process,'' Fred Hoffman, a Pentagon spokesman, told a news briefing.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: The assets of the nation's 464 money market mutual funds increased by $1.33 billion, to $302.51 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 139 institutional funds fell by $111.4 million, to $73.06 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were up by $977.50 million, to $99.60 billion. The 94 broker-dealer funds rose by $464.50 million, to $129.86 billion, the institute said.

title: Dover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Whip Denies Converting Campaign Money for Personal Use
description: Representative Tony Coelho, the third-ranking Democrat in the House, profited handsomely from junk bonds bought in 1986 from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and recorded as a purchase of his campaign committee.

title: Asbestos Peril Pits New York Against Itself
description: The New York City Human Resources Administration, rushing to renovate a closed welfare hotel, improperly tore out asbestos and will be cited for safety violations by the city's Department of Environmental Protection, a spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Elexis Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $63,584 for the latest year and $379,884 for the year-ago period. Corrected from yesterday.

title: Papandreou Friend Jailed in Scandal
description: A prominent businessman and friend of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was jailed today on charges of handling millions of dollars in illegal funds that he is said to have delivered to the Prime Minister.

title: Molex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Art; The Architectural Drawings Of a 17th-Century Master
description: One of the many good things about ''Inigo Jones: Complete Architectural Drawings'' at the Drawing Center is that Inigo Jones (1573-1645) is nowhere described as ''a Renaissance man.'' For that hackneyed phrase - by now the most vapid of compliments - the words ''a universal man'' are rightly substituted in John Harris's introductory essay in the catalogue.

title: Potlatch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dilson Funaro, 55, Brazil Aide
description: Dilson Funaro, a former Finance Minister of Brazil whose hard-line stance included suspending interest payments on most of Brazil's foreign debt, died of lymphatic cancer Wednesday. He was 55 years old.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Loyalists Are Enlisted For Wright's Defense
description: The long investigation into the dealings of House Speaker Jim Wright is no longer about the arcane rules of the House. It has moved beyond the customary backbiting of partisan warfare. It is now very personal.

title: Accugraph Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a special credit of $568,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Artel Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Israelis Kill 5 in West Bank Village In One of Highest Tolls of Uprising
description: Israeli border policemen shot and killed at least five and possibly as many as seven Palestinians today after they were attacked by stone-throwing youths during a predawn raid on this village.

title: Thomas F.X. Gorman, Administrator, 75
description: Thomas F. X. Gorman, an advocate for the mentally ill, died of septicemia April 1 at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 75 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Harry A. Logan Jr., Executive, 64
description: Harry A. Logan Jr., who was chairman and president of the United Refining Company from 1957 until he retired in 1981, died of heart failure on Wednesday at his home in Warren, Pa. He was 64 years old.

title: Marvin S. Corwin, A Retired Executive In Advertising, 75
description: Marvin S. Corwin, a retired New York advertising executive, died Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Vehicle Sales Up, but Slump Is Seen
description: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks rose 28.3 percent in early April, compared with a year earlier, as buyers took advantage of large discounts. But analysts said that the increase was far less than expected, given the size of the sales incentives, and that some auto plants were likely to be shut down later this year because inventories of unsold vehicles remained high.

title: Economic Scene; Pressures for Shift In Trade Policy
description: PRESSURES are building in Congress and among business groups for the Bush Administration to impose on its trading partners quantitative targets for American exports. Those pressures are stemming from discouragement over the persistence of the United States trade deficit. After declining to $126.5 billion in 1988 from $160.3 billion the previous year, the merchandise trade deficit appears to be growing again.

title: Genlyte Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share figure is pro forma; the company was spun off from Bairnco Corp. in August.

title: 'Junk Bond' Prices Fall Sharply
description: There was turmoil in the ''junk bond'' market yesterday as prices dropped sharply in action that several participants described as chaotic. Quoted prices for some bonds fell by as much as two percentage points - $20 for every $1,000 of face value - although professional investors said trades were being executed at lower prices than were quoted.

title: Two Sports Agents Convicted of Fraud And Racketeering
description: A Federal jury today found two sports agents guilty of five counts of racketeering and fraud in connection with payments made to college athletes. The jury acquitted the agents of two counts of mail fraud.

title: Desoto Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1.5 million from an accounting change.

title: Study Sees Better Outlook for Bypass Patients
description: Heart patients who undergo bypass surgery appear to have a better chance of long-term survival than patients who undergo drug treatment alone, a new study has reported.

title: More Betting Links Surface on Rose
description: A check from Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds to a man later convicted of bookmaking was reportedly found during a 1984 gambling raid in Bristol County.

title: Sallie Mae Prices an Offering Of $500 Million in Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday priced a $500 million issue of floating-rate notes.

title: On 42d Street, a Tour Back to the Future
description: Standing on the brittle stage in the near-dark, the visitors held up flashlights to see the ancient, flaking layers of paint, and they could also see the ghosts of John Barrymore, the Marx Brothers and Minsky's dancing girls. A grand old theater, no matter how crusty and dilapidated and otherwise forgotten, can still do this to people.

title: Walbro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $336,000 from an accounting change.

title: Celanese Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

National City Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results restated to reflect pooling of interests with First Kentucky National Corp.

title: International Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Seacoast Banking Corp of Florida reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share earnings has been restated for the 3-for-2 stock split distributed on Oct. 17, 1988.

title: Winning Over the Winner You Didn't Back
description: The unexpected defeat of incumbents can lead to awkward moments for longtime supporters paying respects to the victors. Here is how one labor leader broke the ice with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, who won last November's contest with Lowell P. Weicker Jr.. The account was related by Mr. Lieberman to a group of fellow Yale Law School alumni the other night.

title: Restaurants
description: Does the average diner care if the pecans nestled around his foie gras came from Missouri, or that the baby asparagus with lemon-parsley sauce has a Michigan ZIP code? Probably not. But to Larry Forgione, the chef and owner of An American Place, it is a matter of culinary patriotism that borders on the evangelical.

Marine Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Representative Tony Coelho, the third-ranking Democrat in the House, profited from junk bonds bought in 1986 and recorded as a purchase of his campaign committee. Page A19.

description: Michael Gould, who left department store management for the perfume business three years ago, is moving up within Avon Products Inc.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $57,513,000. Year-ago results have been restated to present Burlington Resources Inc. as discontinued operations.

description: Art by Instinct

title:
About Real Estate;
Converting Brownstones to Co-ops
description: LEAD: The New York City brownstone has made a dramatic comeback since the early 1960's, when row houses were unfashionable and many were used as rooming houses or were torn down to make way for apartment buildings.

title: G.E. Profits Rise by 17.1%
description: The General Electric Company reported today that its first-quarter earnings jumped 17.1 percent from the corresponding period in 1988, in part because of especially strong sales increases in plastic appliances.

description: Debt

title: New York-Financed Apartments For the Elderly to Open in Queens
description: In what experts praise as an innovative approach to housing the elderly, a city-financed apartment building intended to accommodate low- and middle-income people will officially open today in Queens.

title: We Can Build Tankers That Won't Spill Oil; Cockamamie Reasoning
description: To the Editor:

title: FLS Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are not comparable; the company took Florida Steel Corp. private in a leveraged buyout last year. The company's series A preferred stock is publicly traded.

title: Walesa Isn't Among Candidates Solidarity Lists for June Elections
description: Solidarity spokesmen said today that several of the union's most prominent national advisers would lead its slate in open elections for Parliament.

title: A Marathan Concert
description: Composer's Forum and Goethe House are presenting ''Cologne New York/New Music Neue Musik,'' a marathon concert of recent works by composers based in New York and Cologne, tomorrow at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street. The performance is to be offered in two sections, from 2 to 5 P.M., and from 6 to 10 P.M. The program includes electronic music by Karlheinz Stockhausen and Clarence Barlow; improvisatory works by the String Trio of New York and the Cologne Saxophone Mafia; music theater pieces by Robert Ashley, Mauricio Kagel, Carola Bauckholt and Jack Vees, and works by John Cage, Pauline Oliveiros, Bernd Alois Zimmerman and Vinko Globokar. Tickets are $10. Information: 334-0216.

description: Tripmaster Monkey His Fake Book By Maxine Hong Kingston 340 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

WASHINGTON TALK: WHITE HOUSE
description: Perhaps, as King Lear once said, nothing can be made of nothing. Or perhaps, as California's Jerry Brown once said, less is more.

description: The company said revenue for 1988 included $3,050,000 related to gas contract settlements.

description: 'Bonfire' and De Palma

title: Retail Sales, in Reversal, Rose by 0.1% in March
description: Retail sales edged up one-tenth of 1 percent last month after dropping sharply in February. Analysts cited the report as evidence that cautious consumer spending is slowing down economic growth.

title: Moscow Pledges New Arms Aid to Kabul
description: A senior Soviet official said today that the Kremlin had decided to provide the Afghan Government with whatever weapons were needed to defend its cities against guerrilla attack.

title: Accord Reached to Acquire National Enquirer Publisher
description: Macfadden Holdings, a private publishing company, and Boston Ventures, an investment firm, yesterday won an auction to buy GP Group Inc., which publishes the National Enquirer, for $412.5 million.

title: Heritage Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: A chart published yesterday with an article about a pyramid of garbage at the Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island misstated its size. When completed, it will contain 79.6 million cubic yards of garbage.

description: b-After a $920,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: For Abbott, Some Firsts But No Run Or Victory
description: Jim Abbott is still looking for his first major league victory. He's also looking for his first major league run.

title: Brinkmann Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSH ASKS BACKING FOR SCHOOL PLANS
description: George Bush, still running for the title of ''education President,'' brought his campaign here today, staging a rally in a school gymnasium. Mr. Bush is trying to raise support for his proposed $441 million in new school programs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 At least five Palestinians were shot and killed by Israeli policemen in the Israel-occupied territories after the policemen were attacked by stone-throwing youths. Page A1

title: Prices Decline in Light Trading
description: Treasury note and bond prices slipped in light trading yesterday, despite the release of economic reports that were in line with expectations in the credit markets.

title: The Emergency Room
description: This is a man of great power, lying just over there. His wealth, almost beyond counting, has brought him planes and yachts, the friendship of presidents and kings, and mile upon mile of exquisite estate countryside.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Up
description: Japan's trade surplus with the United States shot up again in March, rising to $4.13 billion, from $3.40 billion a year ago, a development that is likely to spur conflict between the nations, economists said today.

title: Subway Plans Challenged in Song and Spoof
description: Saxophone wails, satiric songs and underground one-liners mixed with sober First Amendment arguments yesterday at a public hearing on plans to restrict pamphleteering and performances in New York City's 466 subway stations.

title: I.R.S. Offering Extra Tax Aid
description: The Internal Revenue Service is offering extra help to taxpayers in the final weekend of the tax filing season.

title: Society Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest results do not reflect the previously announced sale of BancSystems Association, which was completed on April 6.

title: The Aged: Sidelined by Taxes
description: LEAD: The reduction in marginal income tax rates was one of Ronald Reagan's most important achievements. Indeed, it is being copied by virtually every other developed nation in the world.

title: Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Investors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bankworcester Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
3 Sooners to Stand Trial
description: A judge ordered three former Oklahoma football players today to stand trial on charges of first-degree rape arising from an incident in January at the athletic dormitory.

title: Russians Acknowledge a Combat Role in Vietnam
description: Soviet soldiers sent to the Vietnam War as anti-aircraft technicians took part in missile-launching combat and shot down United States aircraft, the Soviet Army newspaper reported today.

title: Bank of New York Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first-quarter earnings reflect the acquisition of Irving Bank Corp. The provision for loan losses in the latest first quarter was $41.9 million, compared with $24.4 million in 1988.

title: Review/Music; English Organist in Recital
description: Philip Kenyon is a young English organist, successful and well-traveled in his own country, who is currently on an East Coast tour of the United States. On Sunday afternoon he played a recital at St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: Outlaw Clubs Move to an Elusive Beat
description: Tonight, somewhere in lower Manhattan, hundreds of young club crawlers will find their way to the unmarked entrance of Payday. And if they have the right look or know the right people, they will be granted entree to the exclusive and elusive dance club.

title: Prospective Eastern Bids Face Conflict
description: Peter V. Ueberroth said yesterday that it would be difficult for a potential buyer of Eastern Airlines to reach an agreement that would satisfy both the airline's striking unions and the creditors committee in the carrier's bankruptcy case.

title: New U.S. Trade Chief Is Set to Use a Big Stick Against Any Barriers
description: Carla A. Hills keeps a crowbar in a picture frame in the anteroom of her office two blocks from the White House. It is a handy symbol of the toughness she wants to project as the chief battler against foreign trade barriers.

title: Republic Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
17 Restaurant Workers Are Accused of Bribery
description: An undercover investigation dubbed ''Operation Takeout'' has led to the arrest of 17 owners, managers and other employees of 13 restaurants in New York City on charges of paying bribes to investigators posing as health inspectors, city officials said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HUMANS AND NONHUMANS

title: Steve Jones Pulls Out
description: The 93d Boston Marathon lost one of its name runners yesterday when Steve Jones of Wales, winner of the 1988 New York City Marathon, withdrew because of an injury.

title: Thornburgh Revives an Investigative Power
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has revoked a regulation instituted by his predecessor that required the Government to appoint independent prosecutors to investigate members of Congress who are suspected of wrongdoing.

title: Northwest Air Bidder Blocked
description: A Federal judge today issued a temporary restraining order preventing Marvin Davis from communicating with union officials at Northwest Airlines, which Mr. Davis is trying to buy. United States District Judge

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Criterion's Head Keeps Job After the Firm's Sale
description: LEAD: The sale of Criterion Group Inc., a funds management company, to the Transamerica Corporation puts Charles Miller, Criterion's chairman and chief executive, just where he wants to be: directing the growth of his company, which has $10 billion in assets, from his office in downtown Houston.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Amateur Hour at Seton Hall
description: For Seton Hall University, the Cinderella of this year's national collegiate basketball tournament, midnight may have arrived.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Sex Education Helps Cut Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Rape Charge Bypasses Campus Panel; Criminal Case Proceeds
description: A student who has accused another student of raping her at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., yesterday withdrew a complaint against the suspect in a school judicial proceeding, saying it might have interfered with the criminal case.

title: Sister Mary Assisium, Health-Care Leader, 79
description: Sister Mary Assisium Byrne, a former president of the Staten Island Mental Health Council who was long associated with the St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond, died of colon cancer Wednesday at the Sisters of Charity Home in Yonkers. She was 79 years old.

title: Francis Del Vecchio, Ex-Pastor, Dies at 78
description: Msgr. Francis Del Vecchio, who was pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary and St. Stephen in Brooklyn for 36 years, died of cancer Thursday at the rectory there. He was 78 years old and lived at the rectory.

title: Baseball; Cubs Beat Phillies for Sixth Straight
description: Andre Dawson singled and tripled and drove in three runs tonight as the Chicago Cubs beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-4, for their sixth straight victory. The Cubs had not won six in a row since 1985.

title: VWR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain of $570,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest quarter and year results included a pretax gain of $2,691,000 from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: A Bold Display of Mizrahi Spirit
description: The fashion professionals trudged through SoHo and TriBeCa in the rain and were rewarded with three winning shows. Michael Leva proved he is ready for the big time, Giorgio di Sant'Angelo showed his most wearable collection in years and Isaac Mizrahi was something to rave about.

title: Drug Smuggler Pleads Guilty In Heroin Case
description: Johnny Kon, described by Federal authorities as one of the most important international drug traffickers, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of conspiring to smuggle 1,000 pounds of heroin into the United States from Southeast Asia between January 1984 and March 1988.

title: TESTIMONY ENDED AT NORTH'S TRIAL
description: After eight weeks of testimony, the main part of the Oliver L. North trial came to a close today after the prosecution called the final witnesses, who challenged Mr. North's image of military rectitude.

title: Chambers Development Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,272,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.

title: Bridge
description: Hopes that the women's team would snatch a last-minute victory in the Marathon Battle of the Sexes faded yesterday. The lead enjoyed by the men's team, which had been insignificant Tuesday, had advanced to a commanding 331 imps by 3 A.M. yesterday. With 240 deals remaining to be played, a recovery by the women is unlikely but not impossible.

title: Jacob Goodstein, 84, A Former Accountant
description: Jacob Goodstein, a lawyer and certified public accountant, died of complications following a hernia operation Thursday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 84 years old and lived in Millburn, N.J.

title: International Minerals & Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $32.7 million from the sale of a stake in IMC Fertilizer Group Inc. and a gain of $10 million from the sale of an interest in a Japanese joint venture. Year-ago third quarter sales figures included $93.5 million from IMC Fertilizer. Year-ago 9 months included $573.3 million in sales from IMC Fertilizer.

title: As New Jersey's Budget Tightens, One City Feels the Pain of Layoffs
description: This old industrial city laid off 225 workers, 16 percent of its municipal work force, today, ending a week of protests against the threat of the layoffs with glum farewells in City Hall and police officers' exchanging their badges for unemployment forms.

title: Mathilda Knecht, Professor, 76
description: Mathilda Knecht, a retired professor of linguistics at Montclair State College, died of cancer Monday at her home in Rahway, N.J. She was 76 years old.

title: Heist Nets $200,000 At a Nursing Home
description: Two armed men held up guards making a payroll delivery at a Brooklyn nursing home yesterday, making off with an estimated $200,000, the police said.

title: George Burrows, 89, an A.C.L.U. Founder
description: George F. Burrows, a founder of the American Civil Liberties Union, died of a brain tumor Monday at the Meadow Green Nursing Center in Waltham, Mass. He was 89 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Interest Bill Is Similar In Two Thrifts Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: High Exclusion Quotient
description: Here's a story in New York magazine about a nightclub that won't let you in. That's a big part of its charm. ''I could let everyone in, but then the club wouldn't be fabulous,'' says Rudolf Pieper, the man who runs it.

title: Alternatives to Alaska Oil: Spill Raises the Question Again
description: There are alternatives to shipping oil past the otters and icebergs of Prince William Sound, including fuel-efficient cars and different sources of energy. But so far industry and the Federal Government have avoided them.

title: Gooden Settles Suit
description: A hundred children will benefit from a settlement between Dwight Gooden and Tampa (Fla.) General Hospital, which has acknowledged it erred in releasing results of a blood test showing that the New York Mets pitcher was legally drunk when he fought with the police in 1986.

title: U.S. Seizes Savings Unit in California
description: Federal regulators seized the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., today, capping a long and bitter battle between Lincoln's owner and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board over the institution's strategy of investing depositors' money in real estate and securities.

title: POSTINGS: L.I.C. Housing Survey; Secondary Displacement
description: Fearful that developments proposed for Long Island City will force working-class and poor families from their homes by driving up rents, the Hunters Point Community Development Corporation is surveying potential displacement in the area of Queens along the East River with an eye toward construction of replacement housing.

title: Slaney in L'eggs Race
description: Mary Slaney, the world record-holder in the women's mile and the American record-holder at all track distances from 800 meters to 10,000 meters, has entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon, organizers announced yesterday.

title: Fulbright Has the Last Laugh on Many Critics
description: The Price of Empire J. William Fulbright, with Seth P. Tillman 243 pages. Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: Damon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a $500,000 loss from discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $890,870 and $1,125,707 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and 6 months included costs of $2,234,000 and $4,075,000, respectively, for its defense against Nomad Partners L.P.'s hostile offer. The company also said the latest quarter and 6 months also included $7,460,000 in expenses from the termination of its supplemental executive retirement plan in connection with a merger agreement with Nomad. Year-ago second quarter and 6 months results are restated to reflect Damon Biotech as a discontinued operation.

title: Bonn Says It Can't Verify Reports Of Who Put Bomb on Flight 103
description: West German prosecutors said today that they had no evidence to substantiate reports that a Lebanese-American passenger had inadvertently checked in the bomb that blew apart Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in December.

title: Square D Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
British Inflation Up 0.4%
description: Inflation in Britain rose four-tenths of a percent in March from February, pushing the rate for the latest 12-month period to 7.9 percent, its highest level since 1982, the Government said today. The year-to-year inflation rate in February stood at 7.8 percent. But the March increase was lower than economists had forecast and below the 8 percent psychological barrier that might have renewed pressure on the Government to raise interest rates to cool the economy.

title: Nets' 3-Point Shooting Downs Bulls
description: The sellout crowd tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, which expected to be dazzled by the play of Michael Jordan, was delighted instead by the home team.

title: Nellcor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
RESULTS PLUS
description: BASKETBALL Jazz Clinch Title Karl Malone scored 8 of his 35 points in the first two minutes to start the 112-96 runaway at home last night against Houston that gave Utah the Midwest Division title. John Stockton added 18 points, 11 assists and five steals for the Jazz, who set set a franchise record with 48 victories.(AP) Celtics 113, Cavaliers 104: Kevin Gamble, a rookie guard, had 20 points, 10 assists and 7 rebounds as Boston won its 14th consecutive home game with a victory over Cleveland. Boston (40-37) took a two-game lead over Washington in the battle for the eighth and final Eastern Conference playoff berth. (AP) Hornets 119, 76ers 115: Kelly Tripucka scored 34 points as Charlotte beat Philadelphia for a third time. The Sixers saw a home winning streak snapped at five games by the Hornets, who split six games with Philadelphia. (AP) GOLF Co-Leaders Remain Ahead: Payne Stewart and Kenny Perry each shot 67 and remained tied for the lead yesterday, at 10-under par 132, after the second round of the $800,000 Heritage Classic in Hilton Head Island, S.C. Nick Faldo, the Masters champion, shot a 77 and just made the cut at 145. Greg Norman, the defending champion, missed the cut with a 72-149. (AP) HORSE SHOW Canadian Triumphs: Ian Millar of Canada rode Big Ben to victory in the second competition of the three-part Volvo World Cup final at Tampa, Fla., last night, putting himself in excellent position to become the first rider to successfully defend the title in the 11-year history of this world championship of show jumping. Big Ben, who stands nearly 6 feet tall at the shoulder, used his rangy stride to advantage under Millar's expert guidance around a difficult course, which featured four water hazards and two especially difficult combination jumps. Only 5 of 47 horses made it around the 15-obstacle course without knockdowns in the first round. Joe Fargis of Southampton, L.I., riding Mill Pearl, stands second to Millar over all. The event concludes tomorrow. BOXING Pazienza Wins: Vinny Pazienza of Providence, R.I., the former International Boxing Federation lightweight champion, stopped Jake Carrollo of Chicago last night on a knockout at 1:58 of the second round of a scheduled 10-round junior welterweight bout in Atlantic City.

title: Enterprise Zones Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Evergood Products reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $202,600 for the latest year and $323,500 for the year- earlier period, and the prior year also included an extraordinary gain of $246,585 from the settlement of unshipped bills.

title: International Business Mahines Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $315,000,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Sinhalese Flee After Bombing
description: Many of the 12,000 Sinhalese in Trincomalee took refuge in a navy dockyard today, one day after a car bomb in the port city killed 39 Sinhalese shoppers marking the Buddhist New Year, military officials said. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said security lapses by Indian peacekeeping troops and Sri Lankan forces allowed the booby-trapped car to enter the city, which is 150 miles from Colombo.

title: Larry Earl Bone, Librarian, 56
description: Larry Earl Bone, retired director of libraries at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., died of cancer Monday at Baptist East Hospital in Memphis, Tenn. He was 56 years old and lived in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Chiang Hsiao-wen, Ex-Business Executive, 54
description: Chiang Hsiao-wen, eldest son of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, died of throat cancer today, according to the hospital where he was admitted in September. He was 54 years old.

title: PRODUCER PRICES SHOW MODEST RISE AFTER TWO JUMPS
description: Increases in producer prices for finished goods slowed in March, rising four-tenths of 1 percent after two months of 1 percent increases that had raised fears of severe inflation.

title: Wang to Cut Jobs
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said it planned to reduce its work force by 2,200 people over 15 months. The company, based in Lowell, said its worldwide work force, which totaled 30,700 at the end of February, would be reduced to less than 30,000 by June 30, and to less than 28,500 by the June 30, 1990. It said the levels would be achieved by ''normal attrition, off-setting increases in several areas that are important to our strategy.'' Last week, Wang said it had laid off 180 field-service engineers.

title: Laclede Steel Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in October 1988.

title: Stoneridge Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Both year-ago periods included a pretax loss of $2,255,000 from subsidiary equity offering.

title: AIDS Still Increasing in U.S., but Rate Slows
description: The number of AIDS cases is still growing but at a slower rate, and the focus of the disease in the United States is shifting away from the Northeast, Federal officials say.

title: Corrections
description: The Diner's Journal column in Weekend yesterday misstated the address of Restaurant Raphael. It is 33 West 54th Street.

title: Sugar Ray Danced in a Deadly Game
description: A number of years ago, a friend remarked to Frank Graham, the late New York sportswriter, that he thought Sugar Ray Robinson was the best fighter he'd ever seen.

title: Business Inventories Increase as Sales Fall
description: Business inventories rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February while sales fell nine-tenths, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said such combinations could lead to production cutbacks if they continued.

title: U.S. SETS DEADLINE FOR CLEANUP PLAN
description: The Commandant of the Coast Guard, acting on orders from President Bush, has given the Exxon Corporation until Saturday to produce a plan to clean up the oil spilled south of this port three weeks ago by the tanker Exxon Valdez.

title: Tyler Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss of $1,181,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday tracking the retail price of gasoline misstated the price of a gallon on April 7, the last day reported. The average price was $1.11.

title: Ranks of the Homeless Grow Despite the Millions Spent
description: Even as New York City is spending more than $300 million in services for the homeless this fiscal year, the numbers of homeless single people on the streets and in public spaces continue to rise, city officials and advocates for the homeless say.

title: Liberal Backs Nominee For Civil Rights Post
description: Representative John Conyers Jr., a liberal black Democrat from Michigan, today endorsed the Justice Department's choice of William Lucas to head its Civil Rights Division. Mr. Lucas, who is also black, has been under attack by civil rights groups.

title: Haitians Grow Weary on Long Road to Relief
description: The woman with the red bandanna around her head shifted on an overturned crate and scooped the last of the black beans out of her plastic mug. ''Life is not good for us,'' she said, ''but this is where God put us to live.''

title: Kurds Seek a Safe Home in a Free Country
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Wide-Screen Television
description: It used to be that you bought a television set, took it home, then decided where to put it. But as television screens grow larger, it is impossible to choose a set without knowing a good deal about the room where it will sit.

title: Chattem Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Miss Lilly Marries Timothy Belknap
description: At Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in New York, Catherine Cecelia Lilly, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Lilly of Taylor, Mich., was married yesterday to Timothy Hyde Belknap, a son of Mrs. Charles D. Pearson of Hudson, N.Y., and the late Robert J. Belknap. The Rev. Joseph Zorawick officiated.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about a visit to Britain by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, misstated the length of time since the execution of Czar Nicholas II and the Czarina Alexandra. They were executed 70 years ago.

title: Lilco Board Endorses Sale Of Shoreham
description: After spending more than 20 years and $5.5 billion on the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the Long Island Lighting Company's board of directors today endorsed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to close the reactor.

title: Project to Train Russians Aided
description: J. B. Fuqua, the Atlanta industrialist, said yesterday that he plans to donate $4 million to develop programs for training managers from the Soviet Union in the business practices of market economies. The program will be based at

title: Why Pick on Milken for Having Made Money?

title: Diaz Is Unhappy
description: The catcher Bo Diaz is unhappy about being sent to the Cincinnati Reds' minor league camp in Plant City, Fla., to work back into shape.

Jurors Called to Testify In Inquiry on a Judge
description: Two of the jurors who convicted Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno and eight other men of racketeering charges last May testified yesterday that the trial judge influenced their verdict by telling them outside the courtroom that she did not want a hung jury.

title: Old Family Feuds Over Its Ancestral Island
description: In 1639, King Charles I of England bestowed upon a loyal soldier and engineer named Lion Gardiner a royal patent to this 3,300-acre island of white oak and osprey out between the prongs of eastern Long Island.

title: Francis Griswold, 84, An Air Force General
description: Francis H. Griswold, a retired Air Force lieutenant general who had been a commandant of the National War College and a vice commander of the Strategic Air Command, died of heart failure Tuesday at Saddleback Community Hospital in Laguna Hills, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: Time's Earnings Fell 25.8% in First Quarter
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter net income dropped 25.8 percent, in part because of $15 million in expenses related to the company's pending merger with Warner Communications Inc.

title: Review/Dance; A Taylor Dancer Choreographs Her Farewell
description: This season, the Paul Taylor Dance Company is presenting premieres by three of its members, all of whom happen to be women, as well as new works and revivals by Mr. Taylor.

title: Capacity Use Down to 84%; Output Flat
description: The operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities declined in March for the second consecutive month, the Government said today.

title: Poverty Doesn't Make Blacks Better Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Miller Building Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $215,000.

title: The Tax Returns Of Politicians Are Released
description: In what has become a spring ritual in New York City, many politicians released their tax returns yesterday. As expected, Ronald S. Lauder is the wealthiest of all, and probably the wealthiest person ever to run for mayor.

title: 'Junk Bond' Market Quiet
description: Trading in the ''junk bond'' market was quiet but nervous yesterday as institutional investors and Wall Street dealers continued to react to the fallout from the Government's investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Michael R. Milken, the former head of the firm's junk bond department.

title: Israel, as Well as Palestinians, Must Make Peace; Hussein's Peace Efforts
description: To the Editor:

description: Questions appear on page 33.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * J. P. Industries, Ann Arbor, Mich., completed the sale of its J.P.I. Plumbing Products Inc. unit to Briggs Industries Holding Corp. for $76 million.

title: Sheffield Knife Maker Beats the Odds
description: The squat brick headquarters building of Richardson Sheffield Ltd. looks like a warehouse. But its humble appearance is deceptive, for it houses one of Britain's most surprising stories of industrial success and international competitiveness.

title: Father of Crash Victim Calls Inquiry Anti-Arab
description: The father of a young man who was killed when a Pan Am jumbo jet blew up over Scotland - and who is the subject of speculation that he may have unwittingly carried a bomb aboard - says his family is a victim of anti-Arab discrimination.

title: POSTINGS: New Store Space; Upgrading Delancey
description: Manhattan's Lower East Side retail market area, which still carries a turn-of-the-century pushcart mindset, is heading upscale. Several designer-fashion women's shops have opened on Orchard Street in the last two years and in the heart of the area, Delancey and Essex Streets, a retailing company is building a three-story department store and a nearby two-story structure that will be rented to retailers. The two buildings, which will cost a total of $10 million, will be completed late this year by Sutton Department Stores, which operates 15 clothing stores in New York City.

title: Hu Yaobang, 73, Dies in China; Led Communist Party in 1980's
description: Hu Yaobang, who helped navigate China away from orthodox Marxism and led the world's largest Communist Party for six years until he was forced to resign in disgrace in January 1987, died today, the Government announced. He was 73 years old.

title: Pennsylvania Real Estate Inestment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain of $78,035 on the sale of real estate interests.

title: Review/Art; Idyllic View of a Darkening Era
description: Seven days a week, for several weeks during the winter of 1909, visitors to the recently founded Hispanic Society of America shivered in long lines waiting to see an exhibition of paintings by Joaquin Sorolla y Bastida. The 46-year-old Sorolla had by then enjoyed successes in France, Germany and England, yet with this show in Manhattan he was to achieve his greatest triumph.

title: 2 Basses Weighing Bid For American Medical
description: Unhappy with the pace of merger deliberations by the board of American Medical International Inc., two members of the Bass family of Fort Worth said today that they were thinking of seeking control of the hospital chain.

title: Israel, as Well as Palestinians, Must Make Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany's Costly Game of Brinkmanship
description: In the State Capitol, politics is a macho business and accommodation generally regarded as failure.

title: New Zoning Strictures Proposed for Nightclubs
description: In response to neighborhood complaints of noise, litter and vandalism, the New York City Planning Department is about to formally propose changes in zoning regulations that would restrict the location and hours of large nightclubs.

title: For the First Time, Israel Restricts Palestinians' Freedom of Worship
description: The Israeli police today prohibited nearly all Palestinian residents of the occupied territories from attending prayers at one of Islam's holiest sites.

title: Clayton Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tougher Fuel Economy Rules Planned, in Shift From Reagan
description: Taking an opportunity to embrace oil conservation and clean air, the Bush Administration will soon announce a tightening of fuel efficiency rules for 1990 model automobiles, Government and auto industry officials say.

title: Jury Fixes Blame for Crash That Killed 82
description: A Federal jury found today that an air traffic controller and the pilot of a private plane were equally responsible for a midair collision with an Aeromexico jetliner that killed 82 people here three years ago.

title: Simard-Beaudry Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Agreement Reached On Agents' Forfeiture
description: Attorneys for Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom agreed with prosecutors today on profits that would be forfeited to the Government by the New York-based agents, who were convicted on racketeering charges Thursday.

title: Alaska Radio Is Reimbursed By Exxon for Covering Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation has sent the Alaska Public Radio Network more than $32,000 for expenses that the 24-station network has incurred in covering news of the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

title: Mets and Cone Revive In Soul-Searching Outing
description: Davey Johnson, who said he would do some soul-searching after the Mets left Pittsburgh in last place with a .216 batting average, searched his soul tonight and produced a radically new lineup. And his new lineup responded by exploding for seven runs in the fifth inning and demolished the St. Louis Cardinals, 9-4.

title: Melcor Developments Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $413,000. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Subway Riders Face Weekend Changes
description: About 50,000 riders of the N and R subway lines who travel between Brooklyn and Manhattan will face route changes this weekend and next as new track switches are installed.

title: Cascade Corp. reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
U.S. Trade Deficit Widens Sharply
description: The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in February, the Commerce Department said today, as demand for foreign cars, industrial supplies and consumer goods overwhelmed a slight rise in exports.

title: Adoption Lost on Care Issue
description: The Florida Supreme Court has ruled that a man who fails to support his child's mother emotionally and financially before the child is born loses his standing in an adoption case.

title: Milken Will Put Up $700 Million Guarantee
description: Michael R. Milken agreed yesterday to put up about $700 million as a guarantee against the amount he may have to forfeit if he is convicted of racketeering. The staggering figure was by far the largest obtained in the history of the 19-year-old Federal racketeering statute, according to the Justice Department.

title: Illinois Mayor Jailed Briefly
description: An angry judge jailed the Mayor and City Attorney of East St. Louis for contempt of court today for failing to appear at a court hearing on their city's leaking sewer system. Mayor Carl Officer and City Attorney Eric Vickers were released on $3,500 bond each after spending 90 minutes in the St. Clair County Jail in Belleville, the county seat.

title: Cooper Tire & Rubber Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1988.

title: Marital Law, in a Nutshell
description: What is the legal definition of marriage? It is a civil contract, and also an economic partnership. When does a couple actually become married?

title: Brooklyn Boy Dies After Car Pins Him
description: A 5-year-old boy was fatally injured yesterday when a car veered out of control and hit him and his mother as they left a Brooklyn laundromat.

title: Sherwin-Williams Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its year-ago first quarter earnings were restated for consolidation of Sherwin-Williams Development Corp. and its wholly owned affiliates which were previously accounted for on an equity basis.

title: Allwaste Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Genetics Institute reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter included a non- recurring gain of $5,732,000 from the sale of an equity investment in an agricultural seed business.

title: Review/Rock; The Joys of Maladjustment
description: You wouldn't want to be in a locked room with the characters in Gordon Gano's songs for the Violent Femmes. Lonely, sick, sexually frustrated, vengeful, desperate, at times violently psychotic, they're probably the most maladjusted bunch of misfits a rock songwriter has ever dreamed up. To make them even more disturbing, Mr. Gano usually delivers their sentiments in the first person, with the whiny, nasal voice and contorted face of a nerd in torment. And every so often, between sociopathic tidings, he sings gospel songs.

title: Japanese Scandal: Stark Parable of the Country's Postwar Transformation
description: Scandals come and go in Japan as they do elsewhere. But the bribery and influence-peddling scandal gripping Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's Government has riveted the public like nothing else in years because it reminds people in stark terms of what kind of country Japan has become.

title: Abraham Katz, Executive, 88
description: Abraham Katz, a former vice president of David Crystal Inc., manufacturers of women's clothing, died of kidney and liver failure Wednesday at the Williamsburg Landing Health Center in Washington, Va. He was 88 years old and had lived in Freeport, L.I., for many years before moving to the Williamsburg Landing Retirement Center.

title: Flowers Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 11
description: b-Included a gain of $1,757,000 from an accounting change.

title: Westway's Nihilists
description: All those opponents who defeated Westway, the proposed highway on Manhattan's Hudson shore, now seem agreed on an alternative: nothing. One interest group after another says it prefers the present dilapidated piers to the dirt and noise involved in creating new vistas and uses. It's a timid, even irresponsible consensus.

title: INSIDE
description: Shoreham Closing Advances

title: Mississippi's Other Black Representative
description: To the Editor:

title: Disclosure by TW On Possible Suitors
description: TW Services Inc. said it had received ''preliminary indications of interest'' from several parties interested in buying all or a part of the New York-based owner of the Denny's restaurant chain. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, TW said the discussions with the unidentified parties were continuing.

title: Local Governments Across China Are Said to Face a Cash Shortage
description: A desperate shortage of cash has left some local governments unable to pay farmers for their crops and may force many state-owned factories to close, official press reports and Chinese and foreign economists say.

title: 'Joy Luck Club' Rights Acquired by Vintage
description: Reprint rights to ''The Joy Luck Club,'' a first novel by Amy Tan about Chinese-American women and their immigrant mothers, were acquired Thursday by Vintage Books for more than $1.2 million. Nine publishing houses participated in the auction.

title: Orange-Co Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest 6 months included a pretax gain on the disposition of real property of $1,801,000, compared with $375,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Three Authors to Read
description: Three writers will be featured this month in free readings at Judith's Room, 681 Washington Street. Dorothy Allison, the author of ''The Women Who Hate Me,'' will read at 7 P.M. next Saturday. Jan Freeman, the poet, and Carol Ascher, the novelist, will read from their work on April 30 at 7 P.M. Information: 727-7330.

title: Beene the Inventor Maintains the Mystery
description: The New York fall and winter fashion shows came to a dazzling conclusion yesterday with two supercharged collections that left audiences glowing. With what many considered his best collection ever, Geoffrey Beene continued to narrow the gap between art and fashion. Donna Karan continued her search for simpler ways to dress, using what she calls a unitard or one-piece garment that covers the legs as a foundation for many different designs.

title: Target Date for Withdrawal Of Namibia Rebels Extended
description: South Africa and the United Nations said today that they were extending by a week the target date by which black insurgents should withdraw from northern Namibia.

title: Aluminum Co. of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Your Money;
Where I.R.A.'s Still Have Appeal
description: LEAD: While Individual Retirement Accounts lost much of their allure for taxpayers in the Tax Reform Act of 1986, they are still very appealing to financial institutions.

title: Holly's Move On Meeting
description: The Holly Farms Corporation, the Memphis-based chicken producer, today adjourned until Monday its special shareholders meeting after closing the voting on a takeover bid from Conagra Inc.

title: Movie on Belushi Finds a Distributor
description: ''Wired,'' a film about the actor and comedian John Belushi, who died of a drug overdose in 1982, has finally found a distributor, the Atlantic Entertainment Group. Atlantic plans to release ''Wired'' this summer in up to 800 theaters.

title: Freeport Buyback At $600 Million
description: Freeport McMoran Inc. is offering up to $600 million for 15 million shares of its common stock, or about 21.8 percent of the shares outstanding. The natural resources company said it would buy the shares in what is known as a Dutch auction, setting a price between $35 and $40 a share, based on the number and prices of shares offered by stockholders.

title: Gambling Link Denied
description: A $27,000 check written by Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds' manager, to a convicted bookmaker was apparently not linked to a 1984 gambling operation, a spokesman for a District Attorney in Massachusetts said.

title: Butler National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $59,951 for the quarter and $294,803 for the 9 months. c-Net income and included a loss of $5 for the quarter and income of $57,943 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and tax credits of $66,555 and $238,640 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Louisiana-Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the spinoff of Fibreboard Corp. in June 1988. Year-ago figures do not include a non-recurring gain on final settlement of Redwood National Park condemnation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6 Israel barred nearly all Palestinians in the occupied territories from attending prayers at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem to prevent a recurrence of last week's riots. Page 1 A counterproposal to Israel's idea for elections in the occupied territories has been offered by leading Palestinians from the West Bank. It calls for partial Israeli withdrawal. 6 News analysis: Japan's scandal involving the Government has riveted the unsurprised public like nothing else in years because it reminds people about the kind of rich but not affluent country Japan has become. 6 The violence in Soviet Georgia was described by Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, a native of the republic, as ''a grievous hell.'' He said there ''is no justification for the death of innocent people.'' 3 A shortage of cash in China has left some local governments unable to pay farmers for their crops and may force many state-owned factories to close, official press reports and Chinese and foreign economists say. 3 Vietnamese-Chinese trade has risen markedly in recent weeks, reflecting both the easing of a decade-long chill between the two nations and an increasing tolerance of private enterprise by the Hanoi Government. 5 The father of a man who was killed in Pan Am Flight 103 - and who is the subject of speculation that he may have unwittingly been involved in the explosion - says his family is a victim of anti-Arab discrimination. 5 Bonn says it can't verify reports on Flight 103 bomber 5 Many Haitians have grown weary since the exhilaration that swept the poor country as Jean-Claude Duvalier fled into exile. The terror of the Duvalier dictatorship has been replaced by constant uncertainty. 3 Managua condemned a meeting between opposition leaders and anti-Sandinista rebels on election strategy, citing it as evidence that the opposition lacks identity without military power. 2 National 7-9, 28 Prices for finished goods rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, easing inflation fears. The moderate rise followed two straight 1 percent increases. 1 Dow rises 41.06 as interest rates plummet 35 The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in February, as demand for foreign cars, industrial supplies and consumer goods overwhelmed a slight rise in exports. 37 The framework for a Federal budget for the next fiscal year was announced by President Bush and Congressional leaders. The plan would meet deficit targets without major new taxes or changes in policy. 1 New fuel efficiency rules for cars will be announced soon by the Bush Administration for 1990 models, officials said, reversing the Reagan Administration's practice of relaxing the requirements. 1 The risks of extracting oil in Alaska, highlighted by the Exxon Valdez oil spill, have rallied conservationists and alternative fuel advocates. 8 Government sets deadline for cleanup plan 8 Verifying Social Security numbers for companies that check credit ratings will no longer be a service of the Federal Government, which ended the policy under pressure from Congress. 1 Michael Milken agreed to put up $700 million as a guarantee against the amount he may have to forfeit if convicted of racketeering. It was by far the largest guarantee in the history of the racketeering statute. 35 The trial of Oliver North ended after eight weeks of testimony with the prosecution calling its final witnesses, who challenged Mr. North's image of military rectitude. 7 A nasty fight in the House is brewing as Speaker Wright fights to save his job from charges that he broke the rules of Congress. The Democratic Party's chairman, Ronald Brown, has backed Mr. Wright. 9 Bush counsel amends financial statements 9 A new political battle for the South has started between Republicans, who want to carry successes there to local offices, and Democrats, who are defending themselves. 8 An inquiry into Boston's ex-Mayor, Kevin White, has ended with Federal investigators filing no charges relating to Mr. White's personal finances or political conduct. 7 Prebirth support decisive in adoption case 7 AIDS cases on rise in U.S., but growth rate slows 28 Regional 29-32 A family feud over Gardiners Island off Eastern Long Island has divided the descendants of Lion Gardiner as they prepare to celebrate 350 years of family ownership at their ancestor's Gothic-style mausoleum. 1 Rape charge bypasses campus panel; criminal case proceeds 32 Elizabeth, N.J., laid off 16 percent of its work force after a plea for state aid went unanswered. The city's financial plight is shared by other localities in the state. 1 Lilco's directors endorsed the plan put forward by Governor Cuomo to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant. The company's shareholders are expected to approve the decision in June. 29 Politicians released tax returns in New York City and Ronald Lauder reported an estimated $30 million income. All the mayoral candidates had substantial earnings. 29 The ranks of the homeless have risen on New York City's public spaces, even as the city spends more than $300 million in services for the homeless this year, officials say. 30 News analysis: Albany's budget war continues, with leaders intent on sticking to their positions in the latest battle, a small disagreement over a proposed welfare increase. 29 A man labeled a top drug trafficker by Federal officials pleaded guilty to charges of conspiring to smuggle 1,000 pounds of heroin into the United States from Asia. 31 Korean couples: so long apart, so precious their visit 29 New zoning strictures proposed for nightclubs 31 Killer of five gets maximum setence 31

title: Higher Rebates Due From G.M.
description: Two weeks after participating in the automobile industry's last round of incentives, the General Motors Corporation raised the cash rebates it offers on some of its cars and light trucks. The Chevrolet division raised the rebates for the Corsica and Beretta cars by $400, to $1,000, and that for the Cavalier by $300, to $600. The Buick unit added $200 to the rebate on the Skylark, now at $500; $100 to the Century, now $500, and $500 to $1,000 on different models of the LeSabre and Electra wagons. Buick also lowered rebates on its Regal model by $250 to $500, for a total of $500 to $1,500.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Lyme Disease Alert
description: As warm weather approaches, health officials are urging that precautions be taken against Lyme disease, a bacterial infection transmitted by the pinhead-size deer tick, which feeds on people and animals. Although pets cannot transmit the disease to humans, they can carry ticks into the home. Lyme disease afflicts hundreds of people a year across the nation, but is most prevalent in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. A product called Damminix can be used to rid ticks from a large area. It consists of cardboard tubes filled with cotton balls treated with permethrin. The tubes are put out in a grid, 50 to an acre. White-footed mice carry the cotton to their nests, where ticks make their home. Many insect repellents, like Off and Musk Oil for humans, and Hartz and Scratchex for dogs and cats, contain the chemical agents listed here and are the commonly recommended for use against ticks by physicians and veterinarians. $ Chemical Agent Application DEET Spray on clothing or skin. Permethrin Spray on clothing only. Pyrethrin For pets only: apply to fur.

title: O'Sullivan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fluke (John) Manufacturing Co.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
About New York; Learning to Kick One Disease; Fighting Another
description: Nothing would have been more natural for David S. than having a drink.

title: 3 Airlines Increase Fares, Matching Continental Move
description: Three airlines said today that they would raise some fares, matching the increases that Continental Airlines announced on Thursday.

title: Israel, as Well as Palestinians, Must Make Peace; Be Tough-Minded
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook; Of Hiring of Minorities And Newsroom Ethics
description: The nation's newspaper editors have made only slight progress in the past year at making their newsrooms more racially diverse, according to a new survey made public at the annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

title: Bond Prices Soar on Economic Data
description: Interest rates plunged and prices of fixed-income securities soared yesterday after the Government released data showing a decided slowing of the economy.

title: Microcom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $462,000.

title: Income Realty
description: Two pension funds have formed a corporation to make an offer for the shares of the Income Opportunity Realty Trust that they do not own. The offer, which a spokesman said was believed to be the first by a pension fund, is at $7.50 a share. Income Opportunity, based in Emeryville, Calif., has about 3.7 million shares outstanding, giving the company a total value of about $27.7 million. The funds making the offer are the Policemen and Firemen Retirement System of Detroit and the General Retirement System of Detroit. Income Opportunity's shares rose $1 yesterday, to $7.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Rumania Says It Has Repaid Its $11 Billion External Debt
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania has announced that as of March 31 the country had repaid all its foreign debt, the Rumanian press agency reported.

title: American Television & Comunications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter included revenue of $11.6 million and operating income of $1.6 million from Memphis Catv Inc., previously unconsolidated.

title: I.B.M. Gain Eases Fear Of a Slump
description: Allaying some investors' fears that a computer industry downturn was imminent, the International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that its first-quarter revenues rose 5.6 percent, to $12.7 billion, a result that was slightly better than analysts had expected.

title: Andover Togs reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fine Homes International L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Carnegie Hall's '89 Season
description: The 1989-90 Carnegie Hall season, which begins Oct. 7, is to include more than 100 orchestral, chamber and recital events.

title: Killer of 5 in East Harlem Gets Maximum Term
description: An 18-year-old who killed five people and wounded six others last year in what the police called a cocaine-induced robbery rampage in East Harlem was sentenced yesterday to a minimum of 60 years and 10 months to life in state prison. The judge predicted that the killer would kill again if he was ever released.

title: Kuhlman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $2,200,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

LEAD: The Citizenship and National Service Act, introduced by Senator Sam Nunn of the Democratic Leadership Council, is bold legislation. This bill would establish a voluntary national service program, primarily for young people. The program would meet social needs, such as day care and care for the elderly, that the private sector or government cannot provide.

title: Westwood One reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Pulitzer Publishing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
House Set for Bitter Battle on Wright Ethics Issue
description: The House of Representatives began digging in today for one of the fiercest battles over power and ethics this city has seen as the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, fights to save his honor and his job from charges that he broke the rules of Congress.

title: Dean of Columbia Plans To Step Down
description: Robert E. Pollack, dean of Columbia College since 1982, will step down to take a year's leave of absence and then return to full-time teaching and research as professor of biological sciences. A search committee will be appointed shortly to find a new dean, university officials said.

title: Corrections
description: The Company Briefs listing in Business Day yesterday misidentified the owner of Montgomery Ward & Company in some editions. It is owned by an investment group led by the company's senior managers. It is no longer a part of the Mobil Corporation.

title: Republican Rudolph, Liberal Giuliani
description: Here's a quick political quiz for sophisticated New Yorkers:

title: Hoffman Autopsy Inconclusive
description: An autopsy performed Thursday night on Abbie Hoffman was inconclusive, and results of toxicology tests to determine the cause of his death will not be known until next week at the earliest, a spokeswoman for the Bucks County District Attorney said today. The 52-year-old Mr. Hoffman, a symbol of radical activism who founded the Yippie movement in the 1960's, was found dead Wednesday night at his home in the nearby town of New Hope.

title: G.O.P. Tide Rises in the South, but Democrats Say It Will Ebb
description: Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, thinks he has seen the future in Polk County, Pascagoula and Sumter.

title: Federal Investigation of Ex-Mayor Of Boston Ends Without Charges
description: A Federal investigation into the personal finances and political conduct of Kevin H. White has ended, with no charges being filed against the city's former Mayor.

title: Beating N.B.A.'s Best, Knicks Win Their 50th
description: The Pistons may own the best record in the National Basketball Association, but that means nothing to the Knicks. They own the Pistons this season.

title: Social Security Agency Ends Verification on Credit Checks
description: Under pressure from Congress, the Social Security Administration has ended a policy of verifying Social Security numbers for commercial companies that check credit ratings.

title: Merrill's Net Income Falls 45.5%
description: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 45.5 percent from a year earlier, to $37.2 million, or 31 cents a share. Merrill had earned $68.3 million, or 62 cents a share, in the first period of 1988.

title: Robin Brewster And Serge Okun Exchange Vows
description: Robin Anne Brewster, the daughter of Robert Hamilton Brewster of San Diego and Garden City, L.I., and Mrs. Norman Glenn of New York and North Haven, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to Serge Okun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Gustave Okun of Paris. Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated at the Metropolitan Club.

title: Stanley Butcher Kirk, Executive, 97
description: Stanley Butcher Kirk, a retired vice president of Union Carbide, died Thursday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Medical Center. He was 97 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: On the Contrary, Blacks and Jews Remain Friends
description: LEAD: Participants in a conference in New Orleans on black-Jewish relations reportedly came away with a better understanding of each other as well as tools for improving the dialogue between the two groups. I hope so, because we live in a new day of those relations, which Jewish organizations have been slow to understand.

title: West Bank Leaders Reply to Shamir With Own Election Plan
description: Leading Palestinians from the West Bank have offered a counterproposal to an Israeli idea for elections in the occupied territories, Palestinian officials here say.

title: Brooklyn Company Charged With Dumping Blood Vials
description: A state grand jury has charged a Brooklyn medical laboratory with illegally dumping two blood vials that washed up on the New Jersey shore last summer, the Attorney General's office said today.

title: When an Insurer Fails, All Coverage Isn't Lost
description: One of the insurance industry's best-kept secrets is the guarantee fund, a safety net intended to protect the public if an insurance company goes bankrupt.

title: Gun Vote in Rhode Island
description: The Rhode Island House has approved a bill to ban several types of assault weapons and to increase the waiting period for buying guns to a week from three days. The bill, passed Thursday, goes to the Senate, where approval is in doubt.

title: COUNSEL TO BUSH ALTERS ASSET DATA
description: C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, has amended his financial disclosure statements to show $98,900 more in income that he earned in 1985 and 1986 from a family business but did not report on his disclosure forms those years.

title: Werner Hollmann, 81, Professor at Princeton
description: Werner G. Hollmann, professor emeritus of German at Princeton University, died Thursday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa., after a short illness. He was 81 years old. Professor Hollmann began his teaching career at the New Jersey College for Women, now Douglass College of Rutgers University. He joined the department of Germanic languages and literature at Princeton in 1946 as an assistant professor and retired as a full professor in 1976.

title: Patents; Chambers Separated in Heart Design
description: An unusual artificial heart with chambers that can be separated from each other and placed in different parts of the body has been developed by a heart surgeon and a mechanical engineer.

title: Admiral to Visit Soviet Union
description: Adm. William J. Crowe, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today he will travel to the Soviet Union in June. Admiral Crowe made the announcement during testimony to the Senate Armed Services Committee.The exact date has not been determined, he said.

title: Five People Killed in California Shootings
description: At least five people were killed today in a series of shootings in the wine country northeast of San Francisco.

title: Pritzker Meets On Eastern
description: Advisers to Jay A. Pritzker, the Chicago financier, met in Manhattan yesterday with the creditors committee of Eastern Airlines and asked for financial information, according to people involved in Eastern's bankruptcy proceedings.

title: POSTINGS: Condos off Lower Fifth; The British Touch
description: The developers of the Grosvenor House, an apartment condominium nearing completion in the lower Fifth Avenue area of Manhattan, are using a British motif in an attempt to attract buyers. The building, at 22 West 15th Street, is featuring British carpets and wallpaper, as well as an English-style roof garden with a trestled gazebo and pebble gardens.

title: Corrections
description: An article about basketball in the Sports section Tuesday incorrectly described an achievement by Alex English of the Denver Nuggets. He set a National Basketball Association record by scoring 2,000 points in eight consecutive seasons.

title: Patents; 4 at Genentech Honored For T.P.A. Development
description: Four scientists at Genentech Inc., who used genetic engineering to produce the drug T.P.A., which is used to treat heart attack victims by dissolving clots in the blood vessels, have been named Inventors of the Year by Intellectual Property Owners Inc., a Washington-based association representing inventors.

title: Rome Journal; Vatican 'Saint Factory': Is It Working Too Hard?
description: Despite a Roman Catholic calendar already so crowded that some days are shared by several saints, Pope John Paul II has sharply increased the number of saints honored by the church, apparently in the hope that devout role models can help reinforce the Christian faith.

title: Donald F. Hine, 90, Ex-Investment Adviser
description: Donald F. Hine, an investment counselor who was formerly a partner in the stockbrokerage concern of Neuberger & Berman, died of Alzheimer's disease on Monday at the Sierra Health Care Center in Davis, Calif. He was 90 years old and had lived in Garden City, L.I., and on Shelter Island, L.I., before moving to Davis three years ago.

title: Growing Up French-American in Vermont
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Peripherals column in Science Times on Tuesday incorrectly described the operating systems of Commodore 64/ 128, Apple II, Atari 8-bit, Macintosh, Amiga and Atari ST computers. Each uses its own operating system, not the Microsoft Corporation's MS-DOS operating system.

title: Sandinistas Denounce a Meeting Of Opposition and Contra Figures
description: After months of negotiations over national reconciliation and free elections, the Nicaraguan Government has reacted angrily to a meeting between opposition leaders and anti-Sandinista rebels on a joint strategy for elections next year.

title: Giants Sign Gossage To One-Year Contract
description: Rich Gossage agreed to a one-year contract with San Francisco yesterday and will become the set-up man in the Giants' bullpen.

title: Composer Named Dean Of Yale Music School
description: The composer Ezra Laderman has been named the new dean of the Yale School of Music. He will succeed Frank P. Tirro on July 1. Mr. Tirro, who has been dean since 1980, had announced that he will step down.

title: Royal Business Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Royal Business said it is a Shell company with no revenue and that it is seeking acquisition opportunities.

title: Time Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter's net included $15 million in expenses incurred primarily for legal and banking fees associated with the company's pending merger with Warner Communications Inc. announced in March.

title: Hilton Hotels Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its hotel income in the latest quarter was $21.2 million, down slightly due to the negative impact this year of an earlier Easter and the anticipated start-up losses from two newly opened, wholly owned hotels.

title: Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Drew Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income and after a $234,000 tax credit. The company said operations acquired from Novo Corp. on Nov. 10, 1988 are included from the date of acquisition. Earnings do not give effect for 1-for- 10 reverse split to be paid on or about May 1.

title: No Excuse for Killings, Shevardnadze Asserts
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze today described the violence in the capital of Soviet Georgia as ''a grievous hell'' and said there ''is no justification for the death of innocent people.''

title: 'Welcome' Closes Tonight
description: ''Welcome to the Club,'' a musical comedy with book by A. E. Hotchner, music by Cy Coleman and lyrics by Mr. Coleman and Mr. Hotchner, will close after this evening's performance at the Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street. The production, directed by Peter Mark Schifter and co-starring Avery Schreiber and Marilyn Sokol, will have run for 20 previews and four regular performances.

title: China and Vietnam Try Some Trade Diplomacy
description: In just a few weeks, the volume of individual trade across an open Vietnamese-Chinese border has surged, flooding Hanoi with Chinese bicycles, rice cookers, hot plates, dinnerware and fruit for sale in a plethora of new private shops.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co.  reports earnings for 13wk to March 31
description: Revenue represents total revenue. Commission revenue totaled $416,813,000 for the latest first quarter, compared with $439,599,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Next Flight of Space Shuttle Is Set by NASA for April 28
description: The space agency today set April 28 as the date for the next launching of the shuttle.

title: Mortgage Rates Are Up
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 11.11 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That rate was up from a rate of 11.07 percent last week. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 9.41 percent this week, up from 9.39 percent the week before, Freddie Mac said.

title: Phantom of the Rose Garden
description: What better backdrop for fragrant scenarios than the White House Rose Garden: that's where President Bush and the leaders of Congress yesterday proclaimed their agreement on next year's budget. Their pact leaves a gaping disagreement on taxes. Their numbers are laced with optimism and gimmickry. But give them credit for reaching any agreement at all, and so quickly.

title: Group Considers An Offer for Craig
description: Yucaipa Capital Partners L.P., an investment partnership that owns 9.3 percent of the Craig Corporation, said it might seek control of the Los Angeles-based company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Yucaipa, based in Claremont, Calif., said its decision would depend upon several factors, including ''a continuing evaluation of Craig's business.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 15, 1989
