description: The Economy

title: POSTINGS: Luxury Homes in New Jersey; Watershed Project
description: The first of 24 luxury houses to be built in Bergen County, N.J., on land sold by the Hackensack Water Company, are nearing completion at Woodcliff Lake, about 12 miles north of the George Washington Bridge near Rockland County in New York State. Over the last five years the utility has declared 1,000 watershed acres unnecessary for its water-supply needs and has been divesting itself of small parcels, including 24 acres sold two years ago to a partnership of Michael Sher, Barry Schneck and Dennis Rinzler, who formed Emerald Hills Realty of Westwood, N.J.

title: Israel, as Well as Palestinians, Must Make Peace; Diaspora Is Jewish
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Milken's Guarantee Put at $700 Million
description: Michael R. Milken, the Wall Street executive accused of securities fraud and other crimes, has agreed to put up $700 million that he might forfeit if convicted of racketeering.

title: Nordiques Bring Back Bergeron to Replace Perron as Coach
description: Michel Bergeron, who was abruptly dismissed as coach of the Rangers on April 1, was hired yesterday to replace Jean Perron as coach of the Quebec Nordiques, the team he guided for seven seasons before coming to New York in 1987.

title: Patents; Method to Aid Fertility In Aging Animals
description: Yechezkel Barenholz, a professor of biochemistry at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, has won patent approval for a method of enhancing fertility in aging animals.

title: STREAKING ANTLEY BANNED
description: Chris Antley rode a winner yesterday for the 51st consecutive day of racing at Aqueduct, but was also given a 10-day suspension by the track stewards for causing interference a day earlier.

title: Soviet Tennis Star Reaches Break Point
description: Natalya Zvereva, the teen-ager from the Soviet Union who is ranked eighth in the world, yesterday became the first player to break away from her country's tennis federation and request direct payment of her tournament earnings.

title: Philip J. Furlong, 96, a Retired Auxiliary Bishop
description: Bishop Philip J. Furlong, a retired auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of New York and the oldest Roman Catholic bishop in the United States, died Thursday at the rectory of St. Thomas More Church in Manhattan. He was 96 years old and lived at the rectory.

title: Thomas Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter's net included a non-recurring gain of $1,941,000, or 19 cents a share, from the sale of a lighting distribution facility, and a 2 cents share gain from interest earned on the discontinuance of a note from the purchase of a facility. The year-ago quarter included a gain of $800,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting change, and a gain of $1,576,000 from the sale of the company's minority interests in two wallpaper companies. The company said the latest first quarter's share earnings has been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: With Soviet Blessing, Pianist Resumes U.S. Career
description: As Vladimir Viardo sees it, his mission in the United States is to make up for lost time. In 1973, the Soviet pianist won the gold medal at the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Fort Worth, and toured in the West for two years before the Soviet authorities withdrew his travel visa.

title: Thomas Fogarty Jr., Painter, 73
description: Thomas Fogarty Jr., a painter and art teacher, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73 years old.

title: Dow Surges 41.06 Points; Bonds a Spur
description: LEAD: Riding a wave of economic news that Wall Street viewed as favorable, the stock market staged its best rally yesterday in almost six months, with the Dow Jones industrial average surging 41.06 points, or 1.79 percent, to close at 2,337.06.
LEAD: Over the past year, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, has been promoting a plan for national service.

title: Baseball; A Wild Night For Leiter
description: Al Leiter, the Yankee pitcher whose future should be in the present, was wild and unpredictable last night at the Stadium. Only the patience of Dallas Green saved him.

title: Horizon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Cameras in Courts Approved, but They Must Play by the Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH AND LEADERS REACH AGREEMENT ON BUDGET OUTLINE
description: President Bush and Congressional leaders today announced the framework of a Federal budget for the next fiscal year, but the chairmen of the Congressional tax committees steered clear of the agreement.

title: So Long Apart, So Precious Their Visit
description: Gwang-Mee Pae put his arm around his wife, whom he hadn't seen for eight years, and said quietly in Korean, ''Darling, how much you have suffered!''

title: Patents; Design Said to Extend Contact Lens Wear
description: Richard Y. S. Chen, founder of Ocular Technologies Inc. in Raleigh, N.C., has developed a contact lens that he believes can be worn safely for several months at a time, far longer than the 30 days permitted by current extended-wear lenses.

title: Tax Freedom Day: May 4
description: Although the deadline for filing income tax returns is only two days away, the average taxpayer will not be finished working for the Government until May 4, according to the Tax Foundation, a nonprofit, nonpartisan research organization in Washington. The foundation calls that Tax

title: Review of Nagy Trial of 50's Is Sought by Hungary Panel
description: A Government panel is seeking a review of the trial of former Prime Minister Imre Nagy, who was executed in 1958, the state press agency has reported.

title: Octel Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $584,000 for the quarter and $1,424,000 for the 9 months.

title: MCI Says A.T.&T. Pricing On U.S. Contract Is Unfair
description: Opening a new front in its dispute with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company over the pricing of long-distance services, the MCI Communications Corporation yesterday accused its larger rival of setting prices below cost to win a multibillion-dollar Government contract.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's not a contingency plan, whether it's San Francisco Bay, whether it's New York Harbor, whether it's Puget Sound, there's not a contingency plan that exists that would have addressed a spill of 10 million gallons.'' - Adm. Paul A. Yost, Commandant of the Coast Guard. [ 8:1. ]

title: Let Them Eat Cake
description: When Robyn Stone was a child, she knew nothing of chocolate bars, cookies or cake. Her parents reasoned that if the only sweets in the house were fresh fruit, she would grow up indifferent to sugary, creamy desserts. But at age 5 she went to her first birthday party and tasted her first slice of cake. ''I was so angry with my parents,'' recalls Stone, a Philadelphia graphic designer. ''I came home and I said, 'Why can't we have cake, too?' '' From that day on they did, at least from time to time.

title: URUGUAY TO VOTE ON MILITARY CASES
description: Uruguayans will vote Sunday on whether to prosecute military men for political killings and torture committed during a counterinsurgency drive nearly 20 years ago.

title: There's a Demand for Instruction in Democracy
description: CAN Hungary in the 1990's pull off what Spain did in the 1970's: peacefully transform a one-party dictatorship into a parliamentary democracy? During a visit to Madrid last November, the Hungarian Communist leader, Karoly Grosz, intensely quizzed Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez about the secrets of the Spanish democratic success story. Since then, curious Hungarian officials have been shuttling to the Spanish capital to learn more, and last week a Spanish delegation was in Budapest, discreetly proffering advice.

title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep
description: The most notorious drug-trafficking figure in Mexico, Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, is finally behind bars. But the culture from which he emerged, a virulent combination of violence and vast illegal wealth, remains deeply rooted here in his home city and state.

title: The Smell of the Popcorn, The Roar of the Mall
description: MALLS are all over Connecticut. They breed like rabbits and must emit a high-pitched whistle that only teen-agers and adolescents can hear. Remember that old Victorian on the corner? It's gone. They couldn't fit a mall in the one-and-a-half-acre lot so instead they built a mini-mall.

title: Replacing Rotten Door Sills
description: THE wide board called the sill, which is visible beneath the narrower threshold in an exterior doorway, receives much wear and frequently develops rot. Mildly decayed sills can be repaired by using two-part wood hardener and filler. Worn and badly decayed sills must be replaced.

title: 2 Girls Found Slain, Bringing to 7 the Toll Laid to Winery Worker
description: Law-enforcement officers searching for a winery worker accused of killing his wife and four other people found the bodies of two of his daughters today.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Politics of Potency

title: IMAGINING PURE HORROR
description: SEE UNDER: LOVE By David Grossman. Translated by Betsy Rosenberg. 458 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title: Students Protest Possible Closing Of Legal Clinic
description: Students at Columbia University Law School are protesting what they fear may be the closing of a popular clinic that offers legal help to victims of AIDS discrimination and practical experience for credit to the students who represent them.

title: Whetting the Appetite
description: Restaurant menus are not exactly paragons of truth in advertising. More than once, I have been served high-priced ''bay scallops'' that were in fact lower-quality calicos, ''garden-fresh'' vegetables that were harvested from a freezer and saffron sauces that had merely been tinted with turmeric. For years, I have been suspicious of dishes described as having a Champagne sauce. Having worked in restaurant kitchens and seen how price-conscious restaurateurs must be, I found it difficult to believe that they crack open bottles of expensive French Champagne for cooking when far less costly sparkling wines were available from outside that hallowed region.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title:
DINING OUT;
French Cuisine That's Worth the Price
description: LEAD: LE PAPILLON opened almost six months ago on the same block but east of the old Community Theater in Morristown, directly opposite Novo Chrysler. The building was formerly occupied by a restaurant called the Polo Club and, before that, the Cafe Beethoven. The new owners are seasoned professionals: Josef Koefer was maitre d'hotel at Le Delice in Whippany from 1980 to 1986, and Terry Nahavandi held the same position at Le Petit Chateau in Bernardsville.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Newport, R.I.;
Old Mansions In a Comeback
description: LEAD: TWO sales of seaside mansions in Newport have demonstrated that despite the conversion of some mansions into condominiums in recent years, the use of the stately homes as private residences lives on.

title: Bells Are Ringing as Soviets Return Churches to Faithful
description: In a turnabout that finds Soviet believers praising God, not to mention Mikhail S. Gorbachev, hundreds of tattered old churches have suddenly been returned to surprised congregations in the last year, a boon of the Government's flagging faith in militant atheism.

title: On NBC, A Second Helping of 'Tattinger's'
description: Restaurant closings aren't normally reported in the entertainment section of newspapers. However, last December, ''Tattinger's'' - a West Side eatery at the intersection of Wednesdays and 10 P.M. - was shut down when NBC inspectors found it had ratings in the basement.

title: TOO YOUNG TO DIE?
description: I in no way condone Heath Wilkins's act of murder; however, to put this boy to death would be morally wrong. How can a child who never had a chance, who would have had to overcome tremendous obstacles under normal conditions to make something of his life, how can this child be put to death? He is obviously intelligent, penitent and so devoid of hope that he prefers death to life. How can our society sit smugly in our comfort while there are thousands of abused children, of homeless, of neglected and forgotten human beings?

title: Knicks Have Knack Against Pistons
description: If the Knicks and the Detroit Pistons should win their first two playoff series and meet for the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference title, give the psychological edge to New York.

title: Making Humor Out of Hardship in Managua
description: William Huper, the Finance Minister, is blamed for ''Huper-inflation,'' the explosion in prices that has left Nicaragua's economy in shambles.

title: Review/Recital; Christa Ludwig Sings Works by Schubert
description: Imposing music is often forgotten because we do not know how to make it fit into modern concerts. Christa Ludwig and James Levine solved just such a tailoring problem at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. They took the solo recital format and let it out a little at the waist. Thus room was made for something new and fulfilling to come in.

title: If Fashion Is Changing, It Must Be Almost 1990
description: WORKING on the collections introduced in Europe last month and in New York last week, fashion designers had more to think about than just making pretty clothes that sell. For those who see themselves as pacesetters and who try to anticipate how women would like to look before women think of it themselves, there was another consideration: These were the first collections that would be sold and worn in the 1990's.

title: Rent a Work And Then Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Dental School's Closing Puts Students in Quandary
description: FOR Moshen Taheri, everything had fallen into place. He worked for six years to save money for postgraduate work and to help his younger brother attend school overseas. He got married and bought a house. Now, he finally had the opportunity to realize his career ambition. He would become a dentist by graduating from one of the most respected dental schools in the country.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday in the ''Week in Connecticut'' column about an art show in Westport misidentified the artist and the setting. He is Richard Heim, not Richard Helm, and the show is at the Town Hall, not at the Arts Center.

title: Miss Graves Becomes Bride
description: Leslie Ann Graves and John Thomas Fucigna were married yesterday in the First United Methodist Church in Wilson, N.C., by the Rev. George Johnson, a Methodist minister, assisted by Msgr. John Thomas Fagan and Msgr. Robert Emmet Fagan, uncles of the bridegroom. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Graves of Wilson and Topsail Beach, N.C. Mr. Fucigna is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Fucigna of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Big-Time Chic at Real-World Prices
description: New York designers breathed deep in the fashion air, exhaling caped crusaders, glittering bathrobed socialites and suede-clad equestrians. At many shows the thoroughbred models looked like something out of an expensive remake of ''The Philadelphia Story.''

title: The Andrettis Try Teaming Up
description: With the exception of the Penske organization, the recent history of two-car teams on the Indy-car circuit has not been good.

title: Kathryn Brett to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. James William Brett of Tucson, Ariz., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Kathryn Van Cortlandt Brett, and Timothy Chapman Milstead of Los Angeles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Milstead of Simi Valley, Calif.

title: A Yugoslav City of Minarets
description: ABOUT three hours northwest of Dubrovnik on the Adriatic coast, the road inland follows the clear, green Neretva River through a fertile valley of tidy rows of cabbages and tobacco, orchards of apricots, figs, peaches and grapes. The vineyards produce a delicious white wine, Zilavka, and a strong red called Blatina - Yugoslavia is the fifth largest wine producer in the world. The valley is renowned for its high-quality early ripening fruit and vegetables, the result of its warm Mediterranean climate. Uninhabited, craggy limestone hillsides accented with occasional stone ruins alternate with the lushness. Along the road, makeshift kiosks sell produce and fruit drinks, kept cold by a hose spray that showers the tall bottles.

title: 'HE HAS BECOME A FETISH'
description: CEZANNE AND AMERICA Dealers, Collectors, Artists and Critics, 1891-1921. By John Rewald. Illustrated. 352 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $49.50.

title: A U.N. OFFICE LOOKS TO PREVENT WARS
description: Officials here have decided that it is not enough for the United Nations to send peacekeepers to troubled areas; it must recognize conflicts before they erupt and try to defuse them.

title: Julia Forbes Wed To M. S. Burnett
description: Julia Barrington Forbes, the daughter of Mrs. Eric K. Lindquist of Sarasota, Fla., and John B. Forbes of New York, was married yesterday in Siesta Key, Sarasota, to Matthew Scott Burnett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Burnett of Sarasota. The Rev. William D. McLean 3d performed the ceremony at St. Boniface Episcopal Church.

title: Stewart Leads as Dark Halts Heritage
description: Just before it got too dark to see where a shot sent the golf ball, Payne Stewart broke a close struggle with Ken Perry for the lead during the third round of the MCI Heritage Classic today to go three strokes up.

title: W. Attwood, Ex-Publisher, Is Dead at 69
description: William Attwood, an author, former publisher of Newsday and former ambassador, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 69 years old.

title: The Built-In Bias Against HDTV
description: For those alarmed about America's supposed loss of competitiveness, digital audio tape - a technology that makes nearly distortion-free home recording possible - is the latest example of how the United States has lost its lead. But history shows that new technology often displaces existing technology slowly and with difficulty. This is just as true for digital audio tape as it was for the telegraph, radio and televison.

title: Prospects; The Trade Gap Widens
description: The balance-of-trade figures for February, released Friday, showed a widening of the deficit to $10.5 billion, up from January's $8.6 billion deficit. Imports increased 5.6 percent in February, while exports grew by a negligible amount. Three experts give their views on the widening trade gap. Jerry J. Jasinowski Executive vice president and chief economist, National Association of Manufacturers.

title: ROWING HER BOAT ('HELP!') INTO HISTORY
description: GRACE HAD AN ENGLISH HEART By Jessica Mitford. Illustrated. 159 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E.P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: Hollywood Takes to the Global Stage
description: United Artists, the movie studio founded by Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford, is being acquired by Australia's Qintex Group. International receipts from ''The Accused,'' the Paramount Pictures film for which Jodie Foster recently received an Academy Award, just surpassed domestic box-office revenues. Columbia Pictures Television is co-producing a pilot for a CBS science-fiction series with HTV, a British commercial broadcaster.

title: An Aalto Pilgrimage, on Foot
description: ALVAR AALTO is considered one of the foremost architects of our century, along with Mies van der Rohe, Le Corbusier and Frank Lloyd Wright. Architects from all over the world regularly make pilgrimages to see his work. But his buildings, and most of his designs except for his widely distributed chairs and stools, are far less familiar than the work of other modern masters since most of the best examples are in Finland. We have almost all sat at one time or another on one of Aalto's bentwood stacking stools, but few of us have had first-hand experience of his buildings, or what could better be called his environments. Yet, in a couple of days of well-planned travel in Finland, visitors can see a splendid sampling of Aalto's work.

title: Marathon Is Taking New Route
description: WITH a touch of an Olympics-like finish, a new course and a host of elite runners, the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon is attracting the largest and most talented field in its five-year history.

title: Nuclear Protester May Lose Home Over Tax Stand
description: Three years before he founded the Nuclear Weapons Freeze Campaign in St. Louis in 1980, Randy Kehler started protesting the Goverment's military budget by not paying his Federal income taxes.

title: Charlie Parker Tribute Thursday at Birdland
description: Musicians and jazz critics are to pay tribute to the innovative saxophonist Charlie (Bird) Parker at Birdland, a namesake of the original club named for the musician, at 2745 Broadway, at 105th Street, on Thursday at 8:30 P.M.

title: Who's That Man With Marilyn Horne?
description: SAMUEL RAMEY TILTS FOR-ward in his chair, singing the triumphant tones of ''Vittoria, mio core'' by the Baroque composer Carissimi, as the pianist Warren Jones plays the accompaniment.

title: TOO YOUNG TO DIE?
description: I can think of many reasons to have one's picture on the cover of The New York Times Magazine. But for the cold-blooded, merciless murder of a young woman who was working to help support her family? God, that's bizarre. MICKEY BLOOMFIELD Philadelphia

title: Miriam Kouzel, Actress, Weds Stephen Billington
description: Miriam Kouzel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Kouzel of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married in Chicago yesterday to Stephen Newkirk Billington, a son of Prof. and Mrs. David Billington of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Robert Lee Howell performed the ceremony at St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church.

title: Synagogue Expansion Opposed By SHARON MONAHAN
description: THE desire of a Conservative synagogue to expand its catering facilities in a residential section of Woodmere is being opposed by neighbors, who say it is a commercial venture rather than a religious one. The dispute points up the changing demographics of the largely Jewish Five Towns.

title: Business and Educators Join to Focus on Jobs
description: LEAD: THE county's businesses, schools and colleges have begun a long-contemplated collaborative effort to improve the quality of education in the county and better prepare its students for jobs.

title: Hammond House Seeks Buyer
description: IT has stood on the same Westchester site for 270 years, surviving the whims of landlords like Adolph Philipse, lord of Philipsburg Manor, and Edward I. Koch, Mayor of New York City. But now Hammond House, one of the oldest houses in the county, has been offered for sale by the Westchester County Historical Society, which despairs of ever owning the land on which the house stands.

title: Scrutiny of Fusion Experiment Produces Few Believers Among Physicists
description: The announcement three weeks ago that chemists had initiated nuclear fusion in a jar of water prompted a wave of speculation that a revolutionary new energy source had been discovered. But as growing numbers of skeptical physicists examine the claim, many predict that the bubble is about to burst.

title: A Loving Salute To the Noblest Of Tall Buildings
description: ''Samuel Bronfman turned whisky into gold, and then gold into bronze with this beautiful building,'' said Brendan Gill, the writer, who was co-chairman of the dinner given by the New York Landmarks Conservancy to salute Phyllis Lambert and the impending landmark designation of the Seagram Building. In the 50's, Mrs. Lambert persuaded her father, Samuel Bronfman, founder of the Seagram Company, to retain Mies van der Rohe and Philip Johnson to design the building. There was a cocktail reception in the building's lobby, and dinner was upstairs in the Four Seasons, which was celebrating its 30th anniversary. The restaurant, also designed by Mr. Johnson, sparkled, as did the tributes. Mr. Johnson and more than 250 guests raised their glasses to ''the noblest of all tall buildings in America.''

title: A&E: A Cable Success Story
description: Five years ago, in the formative days of Arts & Entertainment, employees used to pester Nickolas Davatzes, the cable network's president, about his refusal to keep a picture of his family in the office. He would shoot back that he'd tack one up the day - if it ever came - that he felt A&E was going to last. Back then, Mr. Davatzes was not everlastingly serene. There was nothing easy about succeeding with a network that presented Mozart symphonies and felt that ''Jane Eyre'' was promising mini-series material.

title: Stricter Bans On Water Use To Take Effect
description: A WEEK of soaking rains did little to fill the New York City reservoirs on which 90 percent of Westchester depends, so beginning tomorrow most county residents will face dramatic new restrictions on their water use. Empty private swimming pools must remain empty, lawns and flower gardens must not be watered and commercial water use must be reduced by 20 percent or municipal penalties will be imposed.

title: LOVE LETTERS FROM THE MAD
description: DEAR DIGBY By Carol Muske-Dukes. 208 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: TRAITORS OF THEIR CLASS
description: LEAD: A DIVIDED LIFE A Personal Portrait of the Spy Donald Maclean. By Robert Cecil. Illustrated. 212 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95. THE MASTER SPY The Story of Kim Philby. By Phillip Knightley. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. MOLEHUNT Searching for Soviet Spies in MI5.

title: Judith C. Riker And Hugh Wiley To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Riker 3d of Tucker's Town, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of Mr. Riker's daughter, Judith Clifford Riker, to Hugh Clifford Wiley, the son of Rosamond Richards Clifford of Rye, N.Y., and the late Peter Pirrung Wiley. Miss Riker is also the daughter of Mrs. Sara Dwight Smith of Point Richmond, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: From Leipzig, 246 Years of Orchestral Tradition
description: THE 246-year-old Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, one of the oldest orchestras in the world, will be at Bushnell Hall in Hartford tomorrow. Named for the ancient marketplace of the Saxon linen merchants, the orchestra began when Bach was cantor at St. Thomas in Leipzig.

title: On-Site Day Care Puts Companies to Test
description: GROWING numbers of Long Island businesses have recognized that providing child care is an important factor in recruiting and retaining employees.

title: MARKETING OLIVE OIL THAT'S LIGHT ON THE OLIVES
description: Importers of olive oil have been handed a tricky marketing challenge. They've got a hot product in the no-cholesterol derby - a key ingredient in one of the most vaunted European cuisines, a product venerated since at least the Golden Age of Greece - yet Americans complain that olive oil tastes too much like, well, olives.

title: Dead and Diseased Seals on L.I. Beaches Trouble Experts
description: LEAD: EVERY year, migrating harbor and gray seals can be seen in the coastal waters of Long Island. Arriving as early as November from the cold waters of Greenland and sighted until late March and early April, the seals return to the northern waters in the spring, when their pups are born.

title: Air Travel
description: To the Editor: I wish to take exception to the information you were given by the Air Transport Association to answer a question about carrying a portable oxygen unit aboard a plane (Q & A, Jan. 29). You said that in some cases passengers can carry their own oxygen on board, provided arrangements are made at least 48 hours in advance and the airline has confirmation from the passenger's physician that oxygen is needed. You also said that most of the member airlines of the A.T.A. preferred to supply the equipment rather than allow passengers to carry their own.

title: K. W. Willman, A Lawyer, Wed To Miss Crowley
description: The marriage of Rosemary Crowley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Crowley of Rosedale, Queens, to Kenneth Wayne Willman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell J. Willman of Seattle, took place yesterday at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Denis M. Dore performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Edward C. Horne, a United Methodist minister.

title: China's Great Leap Into the World Of Rock Music
description: Wang Meng, the novelist and short-story writer, who is now Minister of Culture of the People's Republic of China, underlined his familiarity with American popular music by singing ''The Way We Were'' when we met last September. When I couldn't reciprocate with a Chinese popular song, he gave me three cassettes of recent Chinese rock music, and I promised to sing for him should we ever meet again.

title: Lisa Lawer Marries
description: Lisa Lawer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lawer of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday to David Post, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Post of Yonkers, at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Steven Geckler performed the ceremony. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is the general manager of the Joyce Theater in Manhattan. She graduated from Kirkland College. The bridegroom, a carpenter in New York at Hudson Scenic Studios, designer of theatrical sets, attended the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: A Shelter From the Woes of Family
description: LEAD: SIX teen-age girls are learning to cope with family crises caused by divorce, abuse, depression, addiction or other problems at a renovated farmhouse in Westport. They are participants in Project Return, an alternative home for girls ages 14 to 18 who need time away from their families.

title: Move for Parental Choice in Schools Gains
description: FOR the last six years, Joyce Caesar has been battling Irvington public school officials over her daughter's education. Continually in trouble at school, suspended several times for defiance of school rules and ostracized by her classmates, the girl, now in the 11th grade, is currently receiving home instruction until a better alternative is found.

title: Casinos And the Age Of Takeovers
description: DONALD TRUMP'S foray into Caesars World International a while ago has clearly intensified regulatory interest in casino takeovers and somewhat changed the terms of the debate. Whereas once there was concern simply over quick raids for short-term profits, more notoriously known as greenmail, we are now having to rethink whether longer-term investments by casino companies for control of a competitor are any better.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE AMERICAN CIVIL WAR AND THE ORIGINS OF MODERN WARFARE: Ideas, Organization, and Field Command. By Edward Hagerman. (Indiana University, $37.50.) Building on the well-known fact that Civil War strategists benefited from the rapid technological breakthroughs of the mid-19th century, Edward Hagerman, who teaches history at York University in Toronto, explores how these advances were employed and how the resulting evolution of military theory contributed to the modernization, even the democratization, of warfare. ''The American Civil War and the Origins of Modern Warfare'' is useful, often challenging. The accurate, long-range, rifled musket transformed the battlefield, de-emphasized frontal assaults of the Napoleonic tradition and shifted tactical dominance from offense to defense. The resultant reliance on trench warfare, Mr. Hagerman shows, anticipated the tactics employed in World War I and beyond. Mr. Hagerman analyzes the contributions of three West Pointers - the Union major generals George B. McClellan and William T. Sherman and the Confederate general Robert E. Lee - in spurring the evolution of military strategy. Interestingly, Mr. Hagerman's portrait of McClellan shows the dawdling, amateurish commander (whom President Abraham Lincoln finally fired in 1862) in a much more favorable light than usual. McClellan's advocacy of field fortification and maneuvering over expensive direct assaults, the author asserts, was uneven in results and unpopular in Washington, but it did have its influence long after the general returned to private life.

title: Minority Firms Feel the Pinch
description: It's crunch time for municipal bond underwriting firms owned by women and members of minority groups.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $450,000 4 Elm Place 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old contemporary; den, playroom, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, screened porch, workshop, 2-car garage, 1.5 acres; taxes $5,197. Ossining, N.Y. $293,500 14 Cherry Hill Circle 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, c/a, patio, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $4,593. Pleasantville, N.Y. $342,500 1199 Bedford Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $2,894. Bethel, Conn. $170,000 48 Old Hawleyville Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 46-year-old Cape Cod; family room with fireplace, 1 acre; taxes $1,751. Norwalk, Conn. $305,000 425 Rowayton Avenue 4-bedrooms, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old raised ranch; c/a, new roof, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,365. Canton, Conn. $160,000 199 Wright Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood floors, double-pane windows, 2 acres; estimated taxes $1,200. OTHER AREAS Bellmawr, N.J. $116,000 1002 14th Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 3-year-old ranch; fenced yard, formal dining room, 2-car garage; taxes $1,395. Brick, N.J. $117,500 60 Burnt Tavern Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; w/w carpeting, pool, deck; taxes $1,500. Commack, L.I. $164,000 2 Barley Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old split level; den, dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000.

title: Miss Mooney Wed to Jonathan Leavitt
description: The marriage of Andrea Park Mooney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stanton Mooney of Bernardsville, N.J., to Jonathan Leavitt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Gibson Leavitt of San Francisco, took place yesterday in Charlottesville, Va., in the chapel of the University of Virginia. The Rev. Richard F. Gottier, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: BORDEN R. PUTNAM;
Guiding State's Economic Growth
description: LEAD: AS the first Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Commerce, Energy and Economic Development, Borden R. Putnam has been a pivotal force in the surge of economic growth after the l982 recession.

title: Jody Ann Hocart, Executive, Weds
description: Jody Ann Hocart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hocart of Essex Fells and Bay Head, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory Michael James, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. James of Glen Rock, N.J., and Fairfield, Conn. The wedding took place at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bay Head, where the Rev. George M. Reilly officiated.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: ABOUT THIS PAGE
description: Home Entertainment/Recordings appears biweekly, alternating in this space with Home Entertainment/Video.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: BARBARA NOTARIUS;
County Tourism, Bed and Breakfast-Style
description: LEAD: THE county wants to attract more tourists to Westchester. To help accomplish this, the county government recently solicited proposals from outside agencies interested in promoting tourism on a contractual basis. The county now promotes tourism - to a lesser degree than it would like - as part of the state's ''I Love New York'' campaign and through the county's Office of Economic Development.

title: Tug-of-War for Black Youths' Hearts
description: Every Saturday morning, Bill Stephenson drives 40 miles from his home in a suburb of Maryland to an inner-city neighborhood where middle-class residents rarely venture.

title: Congress Takes Up Benefits Issues
description: THE American labor force has gone through huge changes in the last 15 years - and in the process, working people have been forced to seek new ways to negotiate job rights and benefits. Into this shifting landscape Congress is stepping for the first time in a decade. Gingerly, even reluctantly, it is becoming a major forum for labor issues. More than 20 bills now before the House and Senate would mandate job leaves for working parents, finance child care, require companies to provide health insurance for employees and improve pension rights.

title: 'Damn Yankees' in Darien
description: ''THE Pajama Game'' and ''Damn Yankees'' are musical-comedy standards, if not classics, but who can tell you why? Only the audiences that were there in 1954 and 1955, respectively.

title: America's 'Obsession' With Skin Color
description: America - a ''color-blind'' society? The recent article on the Bergen Hill neighborhood of Jersey City, where residents are divided over its historic designation, once again focused on America's obsession with the color of a person's skin: ''a tug-of-war between blacks and whites,'' a ''predominantly black'' area, ''other white newcomers,'' ''an all-white suburb,'' ''mixed feelings blacks have about watching whites move in and out.'' Is this America we're talking about? Or Soweto? I was born and bred in Africa and I have seen, firsthand, how destructive the labeling of people by skin color can be.

title: A Show Stopper or Two From Thailand
description: OFF Broadway means theater, perhaps innovative theater, to New Yorkers. But in Sayville, it's another story. It means the Off Broadway Inn on Old Montauk Highway, off Broadway.

title: State House 2d Oldest In Continuous Use
description: The article about the State House restoration (''Grand Buildings Undergoing Restoration,'' March 12) was nice, but I have one tiny correction.

title:
Roxbury Journal;
Man's Refusal to neuter Pets Brings Lawsuit
description: LEAD: A COURT dispute between a 23-year-old institution here and a resident in neighboring Hopatcong is unfolding along the lines of a classic child-custody battle.

title: Tax Revolt Builds On L.I.
description: LEAD: SHOWING signs of staying power, a protest among Long Island taxpayers that began when 1989 property-tax bills arrived last winter has broadened into a genuine revolt this spring.

title: Passing On the Legacy of Nature
description: ONE of my father's most nourishing gifts was an appreciation and deep love of nature. There are few things that fill me with joy more than the discovery of a fawn pausing to drink from an icy brook, or the sight of a porpoise swimming off the shore of a deserted beach. The vibrant cacophony of color that explodes on a hillside as autumn takes possession brings with it an ecstasy that enriches my life and leaves me searching for ever more fulfillment.

title: A Quaint Old Clock Tower, and the People Who Hate It
description: A century-old clock in this New England town has pitted old-timers fond of its hourly chiming against a pair of newcomers who say the clamor interrupts their sleep.

title: DOES YOUR ANALYST READ HENRY JAMES?
description: While psychotherapy has changed since Freud published ''The Interpretation of Dreams'' in 1900, its terminology has not improved. If anything, it has grown worse in going from ''castration complex'' and ''penis envy'' to ''object relations.'' All of these strike me as indecent ways to describe our struggle for happiness. Certainly they don't do justice to our unhappiness.

title: RECIPE FOR MIDEAST CONFLICT: ADD WATER
description: There's a high, bright wind here that sears across a silver sky, and the farmers these days are looking for an event called rain, the last before summer's parching.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Subdividing Union Carbide's Big Center
description: LEAD: THE company that four years ago bought the Landmark at Eastview - the Union Carbide Corporation's 275-acre, five-building research and development center - has subdivided, custom-built and successfully leased most of it to industrial tenants.

title:
FILM;
Miou-Miou Tells A Tale Worthy Of 'La Lectrice'
description: LEAD: It is a spectacular spring morning in Paris. The sun is pouring down through the chestnut trees, and when the door of her apartment opens, there stands Miou-Miou, looking about as happy as a butterfly trapped in a jar. ''Bonjour.'' ''Bonjour,'' says her visitor. ''Any second thoughts?'' ''No,'' she says.

title: The Red-Eye Disease
description: In Moscow recently, a veteran American expert made a comparison. Americans want ''to keep up with the Joneses,'' even if it means a frenetic rat race. Russians worry about ''keeping the Joneskis at our level; why should they get ahead?'' Concern about ''unjustifiable inequality and excessive privilege,'' as a Trilateral Commission report noted, is a major source of resistance to Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms from the general population.

title: Ammonia Tank Drained At Defunct Plant on L.I.
description: Fearing a leak of potentially fatal fumes, chemical experts drained a 10,000-gallon tank of liquid ammonia yesterday at the site of a defunct Long Island industrial plant where radioactive materials were discovered this month.

title: Take That Decision
description: TO ARMS, TO ARMS, the Britishisms are coming!

title: Four Shot in Bronx Project; A Drug Link Is Investigated
description: Four people were injured last night in a shooting in a Bronx public housing project, the police said.

title: CRIME
description: ''The history of guns is the history of Detroit.'' Loren D. Estleman jolts us with this one in SILENT THUNDER (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95), his timely new Amos Walker mystery on the subject of assault weapons in the hands of private citizens. The square-jawed and utterly unflappable Walker - after roughing it up in nine adventures with Detroit's meanest, still one of the most reliable for-hire gumshoes on the job - checks into this case when the murdered heir to an industrial fortune is discovered to have been hoarding enough illegal munitions in his whoopee room to wipe out Zambia. Walker's professional interest is in the victim's wife, who has been charged with the murder; but his nose for smellier business soon has him sniffing around for the source of those C-4 plastic rocket launchers and Claymore mines in the basement.

title: Question Of the Week; Should N.B.A. Stars Play in the Olympics?
description: Why not? What ever happened to the original concept of the Olympic Games: bringing top athletes together to determine who is the best, regardless of politics, race, color, creed or salaries. ERIC HOFFMASTER New York

title: McDowell: Comic Or Reliever?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Susan Wheeler To Wed Architect
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Wheeler of Bronxville, N.Y., and Concord, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Knight Wheeler and Constantine Cacos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cacos of Somerville, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Texas A&M; Crowd of 10,000 Attends Funeral For School Mascot
description: Texas A&M University takes the death of its mascots seriously. Actually very seriously.

title: Fashion; Like a Gent
description: OVER THE YEARS, WOMEN HAVE OFTEN BORROWED STYLISH IDEAS FROM A MAN'S CLOSET. EVER SINCE THE 1920'S, WHEN THE INCOMPARABLE COCO CHANEL LIFTED A MALE FRIEND'S CASUAL CLOTHES AND TURNED THEM INTO DESIRABLE FEMALE ATTIRE, THE FAD HAS COME AND GONE. IN THE 1970'S, THE PRACTICALITY AND COMFORT OF MEN'S DRESS WAS THOROUGHLY ESTABLISHED FOR WOMEN. NOW, AT THE END OF THE 1980'S, IT IS THE HEIGHT OF HIGH STYLE TO WEAR ALMOST EVERYTHING A MAN DOES, IN VERSIONS SCALED TO A WOMAN'S PHYSIQUE BY DESIGNERS ALL OVER THE WORLD. HERE ARE SOME FOR SUMMER.

title: French Evacuate 14 Lebanese Christians
description: In secrecy and in darkness, 14 Christian casualties of shelling in Beirut were evacuated early today to a French Navy hospital ship anchored in the Mediterranean.

title: The Season Was Over, Mate
description: Everything seemed fine until Andrew Gaze got on the plane and waved g'day to his new-found mates. Up to then, we were quite willing to go along with the central story line:

title: For the Pixies, Irony Begins At Home
description: ''I'm in a state, I'm in a state,'' Charles (Black) Francis of the Pixies sighs in one of the 15 songs on ''Doolittle'' (Elektra 60856, LP, cassette and CD); then he howls it. He never gets around to explaining just what that state is, but he doesn't have to. The band's music defines it for him better than anything he says.

title: Born in the U.S.A.
description: Though most people rebel against the style of furniture and objects they grew up with, Riki Gail Zuriff has continued her family's tradition.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LINCOLN, N.H.;
Rethinking Condo Prices
description: LEAD: SALES of resort condominiums in this White Mountain town two and a half hours north of Boston have slowed, but the relative success of lower-priced developments is leading builders to consider emphasizing them.

title:
GARDENING;
When Water Conservation Is Important
description: LEAD: WITH the possibility of water restrictions facing gardeners this season, many are asking whether they should give up all thought of planting this spring.

title: WHAT TO RULE THE WAVES WITH
description: THE PRICE OF ADMIRALTY The Evolution of Naval Warfare. By John Keegan. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Scarfs Add A Bit of Splash To the Season
description: These moments when the thermometer creeps up close to 60 degrees and the wind can almost be described as balmy are not the only signs of early spring. Daffodils, azaleas and cherry blossoms are now visible to the naked eye, as are an abundance of small but very noticeable fashion touches in midtown Manhattan.

title: Fishermen's Foe, the Sea Urchin, Is a Winter Friend
description: In winters past, Ernest Hillman, a lobsterman for most of his 45 years, barely got by dragging for scallops and shrimp when the lobsters were heading for warmer, deeper waters.

title: Co-op Waves Washing Over Flatbush
description: AS Aaron Ziegelman wheeled his Jaguar up to the Flatbush Avenue curb in Brooklyn not long ago, a grizzled man drew near and demanded: ''What building are you seizing today?''

title: Jean Carroll Wed To Todd E. Kemp
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., Jean Marie Carroll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edward Carroll of Miami Beach and McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Todd Ellis Kemp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ellis Kemp of Pretty Prairie, Kan. The Rev. Dr. Mark S. Anschutz performed the ceremony.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Nancy Ruskin, Lawyer, Weds D. J. Castleman
description: The marriage of Nancy Ruskin, the daughter of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Alvin R. Ruskin of New Rochelle, N.Y., to Daniel Jeffrey Castleman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Castleman of Lynbrook, L.I., took place last evening at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Amiel Wohl officiated.

title:
GARDENING;
When Water Conservation Is Important
description: LEAD: WITH the possibility of water restrictions facing gardeners this season, many are asking whether they should give up all thought of planting this spring.

title: Three French Farces, One Sensibility
description: ''HUSBANDS, Wives and Lovers'' is the umbrella title of three French farces currently at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale.

title: Artistic Director to Quit The Royal Shakespeare
description: Terry Hands, the artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, has announced he will resign from the post in 1991.

title: A Feminist's Daughter
description: WHEN my daughter announced what she wanted to be, I wanted to fling myself from the car. I did not mishear her. No such luck for this alert mother. ''I want to be a princess,'' she said during a very un-fairy tale-like ride into New York City.

title: Bird Says He'd Play
description: Even though he is not in shape to play without tiring easily, Larry Bird, sidelined since Nov. 19 after surgery on both heels, says he would play if the Boston Celtics wanted him to.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Middlebury College; How to Confront A Student Crowd On a Tuition Rise
description: When it comes to the unpleasant task of explaining the latest rise in tuition, most college presidents are content to send out letters to students and parents full of stock phrases justifying the increase in the name of better education.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BEACHMASTER A Story of Daniel au Fond. By Tom Shachtman. Illustrated by Jamichael Henterly. 166 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Fight Is Expected Over Defense Budget Plan
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has made tentative decisions about how to cut $6.5 billion in military spending, setting the stage for a fight in the Pentagon next week as 1990 spending plans are made final, Pentagon officials said today.

title: At 70, Grandpa Doesn't Sound So Bad
description: COMFORTING: I no longer have enough years left to go bald.

title: Jewish Rediscovery In 'Shayna Maidel'
description: IT is 1946. Rose Weiss, whose father, Mordechai, brought her to this country from Poland when she was a little girl, some 20 years earlier, has become so Americanized, she's unmindful of the meaning and the rituals of her own Jewish culture. Although Rose is still called Rayzel by her father, she has taken White as a surname because, she rationalizes, it is easier to spell.

title: Nutrition And the Young Chef
description: ''MOST OF OUR PRODUCE is organically grown,'' reads the text at the bottom of the menu at Chez Panisse, the highly acclaimed restaurant in Berkeley, Calif. ''Most of our meat is from animals raised in a wholesome way, without chemical additives.'' This note reflects the philosophy of the restaurant's owner, Alice Waters, that good food and good-for-you food are identical.

title: A City's Romance With a Bowl of Chili
description: ''TWO cheese, no onions on two!'' a waitress cries as she slides into a stainless steel island where chili is being dished out by a cadre of aproned employees. ''Four-way light, two inverted three-ways, and a dry five-way,'' a waiter barks, filling glasses with soft drinks and racing back to his customers.

title: Mayoral Candidates Assail Cuts in Health Aid
description: Four Democratic contenders for mayor of New York, speaking at an annual gathering of more than 300 private-hospital executives last week, criticized cutbacks in Federal and state aid as a major cause of the city's hospital crisis.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Erik Satie: Collected Items From a Silent Dream. Alan Marks, piano. London 425 208-2; CD and cassette. I wonder if we do not undervalue the tiny and often familiar items included here. Listening to Alan Marks's admirable simplicity - simplicity being perhaps art's most difficult chore - one begins to hear not just Satie's gentle admonishment of Romantic excess and charming iconoclasm, but also a disembodied purity of considerable power. This music has some of the same renunciatory qualities we find in Liszt's late music. Mr. Marks, bless him, avoids hesitations, rubato and every other cute interpretive trick. -Bernard Holland Elliott Carter: String Quartets (4), Elegy Arditti String Quartet. Etcetera KTC 1065, 1066; two separate CD's. England's Arditti Quartet is the thinking listener's Kronos: Its energies are focused on substance, not form, and its players have the technique to support their ambitions. The Carter quartets, composed between 1951 and 1987 (the Fourth is a first recording) are dense, harmonically gnarled works that demand concentration and stamina from both players and listeners. The Arditti holds up its end of that bargain here. The music's edges remain jagged and emphatic, but there is warmth in these readings, too, and the group's solidity, drive and textural clarity make for compelling, persuasive listening. The ''Elegy'' (1943-46), in Mr. Carter's early style, is an easygoing footnote. -Allan Kozinn Johann Strauss: ''Der Zigeunerbaron'' (The Gypsy Baron) Nicolai Gedda, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Erich Kunz, Erika Koeth, Hermann Prey, others. Philharmonia Orchestra and Chorus, Otto Ackermann, conductor. EMI CHSB 69526; two CD's.

title: Toiling Teen-agers
description: To the Editor:

title: Kafka Gives His Regards to Broadway
description: Franz Kafka did not automatically expect the worst when he learned that his early masterpiece, ''Metamorphosis,'' was to be turned into a Broadway play. His delicate fantasy had been darkened by so many portentous interpretations by critics - Freudians, Marxists, structuralists and post-structuralists - that a mere transformation from one artistic medium to another might even restore something of its original witty clarity.

title: 'You Can See Your Accomplishments'
description: WHEN Vincent Amato was 14 years old, he said he wanted to be a pilot. Since he was too young to actually fly a plane, he did the next best thing. He started building models. That same year, he started selling model planes from his father's appliance and plumbing store in Middletown. That was beginning of his nearly 50-year career in the hobby business.

title: Annette Arons, Executive, 77
description: Annette Arons, a retired public-relations executive, died of cancer Friday at her home in East Stroudsburg, Pa. She was 77 years old. Mrs. Arons was born in London. She worked for Lem Jones Associates, a Manhattan public-relations firm, from 1958 to 1977, when she retired as vice president. She was a director of the Monroe County Head Start program.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FAILURE TO ZIGZAG. By Jane Vandenburgh. (North Point, $16.95.) Failure to zigzag, in the eyes of Charlotte, the teen-age heroine of Jane Vandenburgh's first novel, is failure to dupe the enemy; it's the mistake that resulted in the sinking of the U.S.S. Indianapolis in 1945, which, she's been told, caused her father's death before she was born.

title: At 40, on the Inside Looking Out
description: ''OVER the Hill!'' The greeting cards with matching balloons and wrapping paper screamed their message in chilling black and white. How cute. I giggled and I laughed until I, too, was Over the Hill and sliding down from the apex of my youth. Frantic at what was beyond my control, I took stock. I had an 18-year-old mind trapped in a 40-year-old body. My teeth and gums, which had barely occupied more than a passing thought, were now a focal point of my existence. I had to learn a new method of brushing to reduce that dreaded demon, Plaque Buildup. I actually had to concentrate on what I was doing. The new man in my life, the periodontist, warned that without proper care I was in jeopardy of losing my teeth. I felt like I was losing my mind.

title: A NATURAL FURHRER
description: LEAD: HITLER The Path to Power. By Charles Bracelen Flood. Illustrated. 686 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: 86 Proof
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: MILWAUKEE;
A Stadium Or Housing?
description: LEAD: AN abandoned railroad yard has become the battleground for one of the hottest land-use controversies Milwaukee has seen in years.

title: A Second Look Renews Old Masters
description: No two human beings read the same book, watch the same play, sit through the same movie, hear the same music or look at the same paintings and sculptures. Different eyes and different ears are at work, and different expectations. Our eyes, ears and expectations change from year to year, moreover. Flux is the law of life, in such matters, and there is no way we can avoid it. The smart thing is to watch out for it, embrace it and risk drowning within it.

title: Paula Sue Lynne To Wed in 1990
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Lynne of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Paula Sue Lynne to Joel Steven Porten, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Porten of New York. A summer 1990 wedding is planned.

title: PROFESSOR JAMES ON THE PODIUM
description: MANUSCRIPT LECTURES By William James. 686 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $70.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THEY begin their exodus to the Shore during the dog days of summer, tree swallows, many thousands of them. By August, New Jersey's coastal marshes are alive with these emerald-backed aerialists.

title: Commuting Is the Only Way to Travel
description: A QUESTION I am asked at least once a month is how I can tolerate my three-hour, round-trip commute each weekday. All that wasted time, they say, when I could be sleeping or spending time with my family or simply relaxing. I just smile and honestly reply that I thoroughly enjoy commuting. I take the Metro-North train from Greens Farms, a medium-sized station in Westport, to Grand Central Terminal. The train ride itself is about an hour each way, and on most days the time flies.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE VOCATION OF A TEACHER: Rhetorical Occasions 1967-1988. By Wayne C. Booth. (University of Chicago, $24.95.) This collection of articles, speeches and journal entries from the last 20 years offers insights on the subjects of language, teaching and the fate of our schools and universities. The author of ''The Rhetoric of Fiction'' and various other works and an aggressive thinker in the world of education, Wayne C.

title: Cleveland Looks to Housing to Revive Its Downtown
description: As the skies darken, the sidewalks surrounding this city's central Public Square grow empty and the outbound cars that clogged the downtown streets during rush-hour gradually disappear. A scattering of lighted office windows is but a dim reminder of the work day.

title: 'Occupation Is the Cause'
description: One day last week a spokesman for the Israeli army said it had struck a major blow against the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. It had brought charges in a military court against four Palestinians who he said were leaders of the uprising ''at the executive level.''

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: Pearl's Progress By James Kaplan Alfred A. Knopf. 304 pages. $18.95.

title: Jane Dreher Wed in Carolina
description: Jane George Dreher, a daughter of Jennie Clarkson Dreher Evins of Columbia and Spartanburg, S.C., and the late James F. Dreher, was married yesterday evening to John Finley Emerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Emerson Jr. of Atlanta. The Episcopal ceremony was performed at the Columbia home of the bride's mother by the Rev. Jennie C. Olbrych, a cousin of the bride. Louisa Taber Brailsford was maid of honor for her aunt. William Austin Emerson 3d served as best man for his brother. The bride, who will retain her name, is the senior associate for the Democratic political consulting concern of Bass & Howes in Washington. She graduated from Ashley Hall and the University of South Carolina, where she also received a master's degree in social work. Her father was a professor at the University of South Carolina Law School. Her mother is a former chairman of the board of advisers of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, and was a member of the President's advisory committee for the John F. Kennedy Center.

title: WHOSE BABY IS IT?
description: LEAD: RECREATING MOTHERHOOD Ideology and Technology in a Patriarchal Society. By Barbara Katz Rothman. 282 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: The Rushdie Affair Lives
description: Salman Rushdie is still alive somewhere in Britain, nine weeks after Iran put a price on his head for the alleged blasphemies in his book ''The Satanic Verses.'' The affair has slipped from Page One, and famous writers have gone back to their famous writing.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Chopper Plans ''The future of America is in helicopters,'' Douglas Garcia said. So might be the future of Fire Island. Mr. Garcia works for Waterfront Airways of Ridgefield, N.J., which has announced plans to build a helicopter barge in the Great South Bay so that Fire Islanders can take helicopters between Manhattan and their barrier beach homes.

title: Music, Maestra, Please
description: When Catherine Comet's daughter Caroline was 5, her mother took her to hear a regular subscription orchestra concert for the first time. Miss Comet was then assistant conductor at the St. Louis Symphony, as well as music director of its youth orchestra, so her daughter had often seen her on the podium. But when Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the St. Louis Symphony, arrived on stage to conduct, the silence between the applause and the downbeat was shattered by Caroline's shocked exclamation: ''Mommy, it's a man!''

title: Reviews/Music; Music From Germany In a Six-Day Festival
description: With considerable support from West German and American funding sources, the Kitchen and the Knitting Factory hosted a six-day festival of avant-garde and vernacularly flavored contemporary music from Cologne under the rather cumbersome title ''Cologne New York New Music Neue Musik.''

title: Review/Music; A Merger Of Classics And Jazz
description: The Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio played only three works at its Wednesday-evening concert at the 92d Street Y, but covered a lot of stylistic ground.

title: A Lot to Crow About
description: Easy Goer may well be able to conquer anything on four legs, but next Saturday afternoon he must handle a larger foe that stands between him and victory in the Kentucky Derby May 6. This opponent is no mere racehorse: it is nearly a quarter of a mile long and 100 feet wide.

title: Question Of the Week; Should N.B.A. Stars Play in the Olympics?
description: Yes. Olympic competition is supposed to represent the highest level of competition. This ideal is not realized when certain people are prohibited from competing because they are professionals. Many believe the N.B.A. stars, not the Olympic stars, are the best players in the world. They should be given the opportunity to prove it. DALE KEIDEL New York

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Iowa; Medical Research Helping Students To Pay Their Bills
description: Jeff Ralston was not being entirely altruistic when he offered his services as a human guinea pig.

title: OPPOSITES ATTRACT: TWO TOP BRANDS LINK AND CUT THEIR COSTS
description: Two industry leaders have realized economic harmony through marriage. Last May, Crystal Brands Inc., which owns the largest costume jewelry maker, Monet, bought No. 2, Trifari, from Hallmark Cards Inc.

title: The Rugged Soul of Frontier Finland
description: FINLAND is a land of contradictions, curiosities and sly surprises. As the eastern limit of the Western world, it is a frontier country. It may live in the shadow of the Soviet Union geographically, sharing a 788-mile border with its giant eastern neighbor, but culturally, economically and politically Finland is entirely Western. It is a Nordic nation, but one with a different feel - a legacy of its distinctive geography, language and an unusually turbulent past.

title: Miss Armstrong Weds
description: At the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y., Gwendolyn Badgley Armstrong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Armstrong of White Plains, was married last evening to Roger Bruce Zeitel, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Bertram Zeitel of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Robert MacLennan, a Presbyterian minister, and Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: Black Virginia Politician Takes a Run at History
description: More than most Americans, Virginians are aware of the burden of history, for so much of American history has been made in Virginia.

title: Miss Gross Wed To S. E. Shanck
description: Stefanie Faye Gross and Stephen Emmet Shanckwere married last evening at Stouffers Westchester Hotel in White Plains by Judge Arthur C. Kellman of White Plains City Court.

title: Western Playboy Wins Blue Grass
description: Western Playboy won the $286,000 Blue Grass Stakes after bumping and battling with previously unbeaten Dispersal today at Keeneland.

title: Wedding Planned By Ms. Demmers
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anton Demmers of East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Demmers, to Richard Luke Rothschild, a son of Richard D. Rothschild of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Jacqueline Kaslow Rothschild. A September wedding is planned.

title: Iran-Contra: The Fog Is Lifting
description: LEAD: In Watergate, the burglars kept silent until they saw the jail house doors open. In the Iran-contra affair, the first man put on trial has turned in his superiors before the jury has even retired to deliberate.

title: Pitigliano
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed William B. Whitman's article on Pitigliano (Travel, March 12). However, the author is unjust to Pope Sixtus V. The pope responsible for the influx of Jewish refugees in 1569 was Pius V (1565-72), who in 1569 expelled the Jews from the papal states. Sixtus V (1585-90) allowed the return of the Jews, including Jewish bankers and moneylenders. He also issued ordinances protecting them from insults and physical attacks.

title: PATIENTS' RIGHTS
description: Morton Hunt writes that his ''wife described her symptoms to one specialist in medically precise terms, to which he smarmily replied: 'Let's not use fancy words.' ''

title: Speaking of the Eucharist
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Theater; Deaths in One Family, An Analysis of Rage
description: ''Walkers,'' an enraged but exasperatingly sketchy new drama by Marion Isaac McClinton, a Minnesota-based playwright, tackles so many serious themes that only a four-hour epic tragedy could begin to develop them into a cohesive dramatic tapestry. Racism, black self-hatred and inherited patterns of family violence are only the three most obvious issues among those raised by the play, at the Hudson Guild Theater, 441 West 26th Street.

title: Health Is the Main Ingredient in New Cooking Classes
description: LEAD: COOKING schools, responding to the wishes of students who have become conscious that they are what they eat, are increasingly giving classes in how to cook more healthful meals.

title: RIVERS PROVIDESLATE SPARK
description: Glenn Rivers did not get a chance to spark Atlanta's fastbreak until the second half tonight. But when he did, it put the Hawks in control of what turned into their sixth straight victory, a 125-100 rout of the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Barrie B. Biddison to Wed
description: The engagement of Barrie Bates Biddison to Roger Gallup Bowers, the son of Ruth G. Bowers of Old Mystic, Conn., and Richard M. Bowers of Delhi, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Gail B. Biddison of Reston, Va., and Alan McCauley Biddison of Richmond. Miss Biddison, a graduate of Herndon (Va.) High School, expects to graduate in May from Barnard College. Mr. Bowers, who is a draftsman at Survey Engineers in Boston, is a graduate of the Williams School in New London, Conn., and Columbia University. A September wedding is planned.

title: Practical Traveler; Who Can Sit by Plane Exit? F.A.A. Proposes a Rule
description: THE Government has taken a step toward regulating which passsengers may be seated in a plane beside an exit, regular or emergency. If the Federal Aviation Administration, after listening to public responses, adopts its rule in the form that it published it on March 13, the exit rows could not be used by the blind, people traveling with small children, children traveling alone, the obese or frail, wheelchair-users, the aged, or by emotionally disturbed or retarded people, and probably others. Whether or not the rule goes through as proposed it is certain to cause an uproar. The president of the National Federation of the Blind, for example, says the proposal represents ''a classic discriminatory position.''

title: BEST SELLERS: April 16, 1989

AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) WORKING DAYS: The Journals of ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' 1938-1941, by John Steinbeck. Edited by Robert DeMott. (Viking, $18.95.) Steinbeck's diary, with commentary and voluminous notes by Mr. DeMott, is a feast for Steinbeck fans and full of encouragement for other writers who think they have problems. BAUMGARTNER'S BOMBAY, by Anita Desai. (Knopf, $18.95.) A daring, colorful novel that depicts how one man's presence can alter a city - in this case, the presence of a Berlin Jew, hemmed in by a foreignness that paradoxically makes him feel secure. OBSERVING THE NIXON YEARS: ''Notes and Comment'' From The New Yorker on the Vietnam War and the Watergate Crisis, 1969-1975, by Jonathan Schell. (Pantheon, $19.95.) More than 100 elegant essays about big events and the enigmatic man in charge. LIPSTICK TRACES: A Secret History of the Twentieth Century, by Greil Marcus. (Harvard University, $29.95.) A bold social, cultural and personal account of the more outrageous forms of political dissent, from the Middle Ages to Rimbaud to Johnny Rotten. BEHIND THE MOUNTAIN: Return to Tasmania, by Peter Conrad. (Poseidon, $18.95.) Meditations on the harsh landscape and dismal history of one of Western civilization's remotest places. PEACEMAKING AMONG PRIMATES, by Frans de Waal. (Harvard University, $29.95.) A research primatologist explores the social mechanisms that maintain tolerance and promote reconciliation among five primate species, including ourselves. DISENCHANTED NIGHT: The Industrialization of Light in the Nineteenth Century, by Wolfgang Schivelbusch. (University of California, $22.50.) How a new, centralized technology changed homelife and the individual's relation to society.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE ELECTRIC LIFE: Essays on Modern Poetry. By Sven Birkerts. (Morrow, $22.95.) Sven Birkerts - who won considerable acclaim for his first book of literary criticism, ''An Artificial Wilderness,'' and who won the 1986 National Book Critics Circle award for criticism - writes in a voice that veers between passionate harangue and smart-aleck banter.

title: Picking Up Banner for Women's Rights
description: UNTIL last Sunday, Joan Douches of Fords had never picked up a banner, marched to the corridors of power and raised her voice in protest.

title: ODE ON AN OED
description: THE OXFORD ENGLISH DICTIONARY Second Edition. Prepared by J. A. Simpson and E. S. C. Weiner. 20 volumes. 21,728 pp. New York: Clarendon Press/Oxford University Press. $2,500.

title: Progress Meets Its Match
description: IT has to go, my old friend, companion of my solitude, queen of my cluttered study, my dear 40-year-old manual Royal typewriter. It got me through graduate school, bravely typing themes of unimaginable dullness. It fed me when I had to write for my living.

title: Blind Engineers At Home in Studio
description: LEAD: IT was Angie Isidro's first day as an engineer at WSTC-AM, a news, talk and contemporary-music station in Stamford. Granted she was a bit nervous, but when she met the engineers assigned to train her, she panicked.

title: Review/Dance; The Free Spirits vs. the Workaday World
description: In ''Enigma,'' presented by Jennifer Muller's company, the Works, on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater, Miss Muller tackles the age-old theme of civilization versus nature or the spirit, and comes out squarely on the side of nature.

title: Sherryl Post Engaged To Dr. Larry D. Dillon
description: Sherryl Ann Post and Dr. Larry Dwayne Dillon are planning to marry in May, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Post of Oceanside, L.I., have announced. Dr. Dillon is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dillon of Omaha.

title: In the Trenches
description: Detective lore has it that there are two kinds of sleuths - the witting slob and the unwitting slob.

title: Voila! In Paris, the Romance of the Century
description: Unlike virtually all other architectural icons, which turn out to be smaller than you think they will be, the Eiffel Tower is bigger. That is the first thing that differentiates it from almost every other well-known structure in the world: no matter how many times you have stood before the Eiffel Tower, it is always at least a little bit bigger than you expect it to be. And it is brown, a sort of medium cocoa brown, and that, too, comes as a surprise, for even if you have been seeing the Eiffel Tower on and off for decades, you still picture it in your mind as gray or silver, the color of metal.

title: Albert Bonnier, 81, A Swedish Publisher With Vast Holdings
description: Albert Bonnier Jr., the former chairman of a family-run publishing empire that included Sweden's two largest newspapers, died yesterday at his home in Stockholm after a short illness, the Swedish News Agency reported. He was 81 years old.

title: Amy B. Slaff, Store Buyer, Wed to William Creelman
description: Aboard the M.V. Providence berthed in Annapolis, Md., Amy Beth Slaff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Paul Slaff of Annapolis, was married last evening to William Kitchell Creelman, the son of John Richard Creelman of Rocklin, Calif., and Renee Crane of Sacramento, Calif. Rabbi Mordecai Schreiber officiated.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 16, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $5.95.) A Congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 11 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 3 2 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.)
