title: Blue Skies for Environmental-Engineering Jobs
description: LEAD: JAMES SCHAEFER, an environmental engineer in New Jersey, spends much of his time these days protecting and purifying municipal water supplies. His current project is to remove organic chemicals from groundwater for Fair Lawn, in Bergen County, which has been plagued with industrial contamination of the water.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The Nehemiah Plan; A High-Volume Builder Yearns for Land
description: BILL LEVITT would have approved of the Nehemiah Plan. The founder of Levittown built his reputation on his ability to mass produce a simple low-cost house at great speed over flat acres of low-cost land on Long Island after World War II.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Disney World Eliminating Three-Day Pass

title: Startled by Pollution Data, Groups Plan New Strategy
description: AFTER recovering from the shock last week of learning that industry had put 58 million pounds of toxic substances into the air, land and water in Connecticut in a year, environmental and citizen groups began to plan how to use the information against polluters.

title: From Toronto, A Fresh Voice In Modern Dance
description: As part of its 20th-anniversary celebrations, Toronto Dance Theater recently presented an entire evening devoted to the works of one of its four house choreographers whose name, incidentally, is Christopher House.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Moderation Becomes Mainstream; The Nation Is Getting Ready To Cut Its Dose of Pesticides
description: THE nation's crops are soaked, sprayed and powdered each year with about one billion pounds of herbicides, insecticides, fungicides and other toxic chemicals, a tenfold increase since the end of World War II. Farmers, pesticide manufacturers, food sellers and Government agencies have long maintained that these chemicals have helped the United States become the world's premier agricultural producer, supplying healthy, nutritious and attractive crops to feed Americans and a large part of the rest of the world.

title: Going Home
description: When he left the Soviet Union in 1974, Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist and conductor, vowed never to return until artists were given more freedom. Four years later the Soviet authorities stripped him of his citizenship.

title: Sugar Ray Robinson: The Man and the Mystique
description: ''The greatest fighter, pound for pound'' was the way many obituaries described Sugar Ray Robinson when he died at the age of 67 last week.

title: 800 Years of Oriental Bronzes on Show
description: Medieval to modern Chinese and Japanese bronzes, popular in the West a century ago, are once again being collected here and abroad. An exhibition presented by Michael Goedhuis, a London dealer, at the gallery of Colnaghi U.S.A., 21 East 67th Street, is the first in decades to focus on Sung through Meiji bronzes. The show of 127 metal works - monumental sculpture, incense burners, vases, scholars' studio objects and decorative sculpture - was organized by the dealer over five years. He shopped worldwide, but found most of the bronzes in England and Scotland, where they were collected in the late 19th century and fell out of favor before World War I. ''My only competition was the British Museum,'' Mr. Goedhuis said last weekend, as he put the finishing touches on ''Chinese and Japanese Bronzes A.D. 1100 to 1900,'' which opened Tuesday and remains through April 29. He said the London museum had, over the last four years, regularly placed its new acquisitions of Chinese and Japanese bronzes on view as they were added to the collection. But, he said, so far there has been no formal exhibition of this material at the museum. The variety of stylistic treatments represented ranges from austerely simple vessels and animal figures, which are found among both the earliest and most recently crafted items, to elaborately modeled works of the 16th through 18th centuries. The bronze handles of vases and censers - wide metal streamers, elephant heads or flying fish - are often what distinguish the finest vessels.

title: Paul J. Clancey Jr. Weds Ms. Smyth
description: The wedding of Sarah A. Smyth to Paul J. Clancey Jr. took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Msgr. John B. Hagerty officiated.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Menu; For Brunches Served Later, Fresh Salmon and Linguine
description: In the days when brunches began at 11 A.M., salmon with linguine and green salad with goat cheese dressing might not have been a menu of choice. but now, brunch is seldom served before noon or 1 on Sundays, and that means most people have had something to eat earlier in the day.

title: AND HE WAS GOOD AT ARMS CONTROL, TOO
description: MONKEYS, MEN, AND MISSILES An Autobiography 1946-88. By Solly Zuckerman. Illustrated. 498 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

title: TV Plea From Yankee Fan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FICTION
description: CHINESE STORY AND OTHER TALES. By Boris Pilnyak. Translated by Vera T. Reck and Michael Green. (University of Oklahoma, $24.95.) In his heyday in the 1920's, Boris Pilnyak was one of the Soviet Union's most popular writers, an enthusiast of the Revolution who nevertheless dared to declare himself ''not a Communist.'' By 1937, he was dead, a victim of the purges. One of the reasons for his liquidation may have been ''The Tale of the Unextinguished Moon,'' a thinly veiled account of the suspicious death on the operating table of one of Stalin's rivals for power. The original version of this bold, devastating short story is being published for the first time in English in ''Chinese Story and Other Tales,'' and it is the most powerful and political piece in the collection. Yet on the whole, Pilnyak is most readable when he stays away from politics. His strongest suit is his love and understanding of Russia - historical, elemental Russia, the land of the peasants, the forests and steppes. This is the Russia he evokes in ''Mother Earth,'' a violent tale about a Bolshevik forester in the Volga region, and the Russia that permeates ''Mahogany,'' an odd novella about the confluence of the new and the old in the revolutionary state. The translations by Vera T. Reck and Michael Green are excellent, although they can't erase the flaws of Pilnyak's style - a tendency to sprawl even in brevity, an occasional self-consciousness with words. But such sins are forgivable, as perhaps are worse ones, too. In the last decade or so, Pilnyak's work has begun to be republished in the Soviet Union; in the era of glasnost, may it find restitution in full.

title: Alex Lindsay: Shopping Bag Designer
description: Consider the designer shopping bag. Consider Alex Lindsay. To all intents they're synonymous.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Outing; Pastries and Other Pleasures in Cold Spring
description: Richard Colangelo doesn't just make Danish. He also makes cheese-filled raspberry croissants, sticky buns topped with nuts, molasses and honey, and chocolate ''kamikaze'' squares, made of white and dark chocolate chunks, butterscotch and ground walnuts. But you have to come to this village of 2,000 people in the Hudson Valley to taste them.

title: Women Surge Into the World of Biking
description: Beverly Walton gets on her new 12-speed road bicycle and proudly takes it for a spin. She has left behind, in the garage of her home in Howell, N.J., the clunker she's had since high school and a two-year-old mountain bike; they are likely to remain right where they are -unused. The clunker tires her out quickly because it's heavy and cumbersome; the mountain bike is uncomfortable to ride because it's too big. ''I was biking in pain,'' she says. ''Seat pain, leg pain, thigh pain. I'd ride to the beach, 30 miles round trip, and feel burnt out on the way back.''

title: Monique Vos to Marry A. C. Merrill Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arend Willem Daniel Vos of Pittsburgh and Paris have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Monique Jeannette Vos and Arthur Cushman Merrill Jr., a son of Mrs. David J. Mahoney of New York, Bridgehampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and Mr. Merrill of Boston and Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Right Places At the Wrong Time
description: THE guard at the gate didn't want to let me in. ''We open again at 2 o'clock,'' he said.

title: Bold New Skin Treatments
description: IN LESS THAN TWO DECADES, DERMATOLOGY has undergone a striking metamorphosis from what was once regarded as the lowly field of cosmetic medicine into one of the frontiers of medical science. Seemingly intractable mysteries of skin physiology are unraveling; once-untreatable conditions are succumbing to potent new medications, and preventive medicine is assuming great prominence in battling skin diseases. In perhaps the most exciting development, scientists are beginning to explore the role the skin plays in shielding people from such disorders as allergies, cancer and possibly even AIDS. Experimental treatments are emerging that seem to cause even the deadliest form of skin cancer to regress.

title: The Soviets and the Enmities Within
description: THE unrest that killed at least 19 people in the Soviet republic of Georgia last week is the latest crisis in what is usually called Moscow's ''nationalities problem.'' But as events there showed, the problem is not so much nationalities - a term that suggests loose ethnic groupings -as old and rooted nations, with identities that predate both Russian and Soviet power. The issue that initially brought thousands of Georgians out onto the streets of Tbilisi, their capital, was a dispute over land, not economic or political rights, Communist control or even Russification. Those larger issues soon overtook the original protest, culminating in a brutal overreaction by Soviet troops, but it is telling that the first spark was territorial.

title: Penn Crews Display Strength
description: Penn proved that its varsity crews were of the all-weather kind yesterday on the Harlem River. The first and second Red and Blue varsity boats rowed away from Princeton and Columbia in the Childs Cup regatta on a cold, murky and wet race course.

title: The Conductor Gets a Tip
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Starts on Road to World Cup Berth
description: Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala and Trinidad/Tobago are the last obstacles for the United States in its attempt to qualify for the 1990 World Cup in Italy next summer.

title: Reviews/Music; Chinese Song and Dance to the Sound of Ancient Bells
description: ''The Imperial Bells of China,'' a colorful pageant of music and ceremonial dances, arrived in New York City on Tuesday for two nights at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. New York was only the third stop on a 20-city North American tour that will include an engagement April 24 and 25 and from April 30 through May 6 at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla. That booking is appropriate, since the show, with its taped narration by a solemn-sounding Gregory Peck, has the tone and look of a staged Hollywood spectacle intended for family audiences.

title: Charles F. Bischoff, Consultant, 61
description: Charles F. Bischoff, a management consultant and retired vice president of Allied-Signal, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in West Caldwell, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: STORMING MONTANA'S WILDERNESS
description: WHEN WE FIRST HIT this country, we thought we had died and gone to heaven,'' says Keith Shaw, a retired biology teacher who describes himself as ''a worn-out cowboy.'' Shaw and his wife, Leslie, live with their seven horses on a windy, flat-country plot of range land - an enthusiastic real-estate agent might call it a ''ranchette'' - 20 miles out of the isolated village of Choteau, Mont., on the western edge of the Great Plains. Both were born and raised and taught high school to the north, in the spectacular shadow of Glacier National Park and its adjoining Canadian counterpart, Waterton Park - Leslie mainly on the vast Blackfeet Reservation in far northern Montana and Keith in Cardston, Alberta.

title: Melanie Ress: Artful Caterer
description: Recently Melanie Ress, art director-turned-caterer, was asked to put together a ''white'' party in an all-white apartment. ''The hostess didn't want any spills,'' she said. That party didn't get beyond the planning stage.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SARATOGA BESTIARY. By Stephen Dobyns. (Viking, $16.95.) You get the feeling from the novelist and poet Stephen Dobyns's detective fiction that despite all the ponies, Saratoga, N.Y., is just another one-horse town on the way from Manhattan to a ski slope - a quiet spa where mineral water, if nothing else, springs eternal.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Bryn Mawr; Talentless Night: The Jokes Are Bad But Who Cares?
description: In a collegiate variation of amateur night, Bryn Mawr has introduced the talentless show - a stunning display of inability called ''Bad Cabaret Nite.'' The name says it all. Singing? Dancing? Acting? All were notable in their absence as more than 100 students squeezed into Good Hart Hall's music room on a recent Saturday night to sample iced tea and stale pretzels and to listen to bad jokes.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Long Island Weekly last Sunday about an increase in sexually transmitted diseases incorrectly described New York State's law on when sex partners of people who have tested positive for the AIDS antibody may be informed of the results. Local health departments may notify sex partners only with consent of the person who was tested.

title: Creative Forces at a New Deal Site
description: ONE of the few good things about the good old days was the New Deal, and one of the many good things about that was the construction, from 1935 to 1938, of the Jersey Homesteads. A Work Projects Administration community, it housed 200 families of mainly Jewish immigrant garment workers relocated from New York City.

title: About Long Island; A Beacon of Classical Music in Port Washington
description: IT was a bitingly cold night, but John T. King was standing outside the front entrance to United Methodist Church in shirt sleeves and jeans, watching the parking lot fill up. One by one, and then in small groups, his talented charges alighted from cars and came toward him.

title: Striving to Become a Global No. 2
description: Last week, after months of rumors, the SmithKline Beckman Corporation, based in Philadelphia, and the Beecham Group P.L.C., based in London, announced their intention to merge. If approved by their shareholders, the new company - to be called SmithKline Beecham - will be the world's second-largest pharmaceutical company after Merck & Company, and would have a research budget expected to exceed $500 million a year. Henry Wendt, the chairman of SmithKline Beckman and the designated chairman of SmithKline Beecham, spoke with the Business Forum editor Joel Kurtzman about how the merged companies will be managed. Question: It not always easy to blend two different corporate cultures after a merger. In your case, you must also blend two different nationalities. How will you go about this? Mr. Wendt: I don't think the binational factor will be difficult. We have many British executives and they have a number of Americans. The language is almost common.

title: Assembly Speaker in Jersey Assails Mayor of Elizabeth for Layoffs
description: Charging that the Mayor of Elizabeth, N.J., had laid off workers prematurely and unnecessarily endangered public safety, the Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, Charles L. Hardwick, announced yesterday the formation of a task force to investigate the city's spending practices.

title: Vital Opinions
description: THE DIAGNOSIS: cancer.

title: Pressing for Abortion, in the Name of Family
description: FOR the organized women's movement, last Sunday's march in Washington was an occasion for renewal. It provided a small jolt to those who thought that something called feminism was dead and reminded this city that mass protest was not just something out of the 1960's.

title: Cards Edge Mets In 10th
description: The revival worked for one day, and then the St. Louis Cardinals teased out a 3-2 victory over the Mets in 10 innings today. But the Mets promised that they would not abandon their new lineup or their new spirit, and said they would rise again.

title: If It's Spring, It Must Be Risotto
description: RISOTTO is a wonderful dish for spring, when young vegetables are in season. It is especially good made with asparagus or fava beans or with seafood, served after a first course of asparagus.

title: Taking the Fear Out of Public Speaking
description: THE two most terrifying words in the English language are public speaking. Or so say speech professionals who earn their living teaching people how to communicate effectively.

title: Pamela Kinder Weds Robert Pik
description: Pamela Kinder and Robert Roger Pik were married yesterday in the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., where the Rev. Edward R. Danks officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Kinder of Pacific Palisades, Calif. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Pik of New York.

title: SOLID CASTING HELPS KEEP THIS PHILEAS FOGG ALOFT
description: Produced by Mike Todd, one of the more irrepressible hucksters in show-business annals, the 1956 film version of ''Around the World in 80 Days'' won a number of Academy Awards, including one for best picture, one for Victor Young's score and another for best script. S. J. Perelman was among the writers. I admit right here that I found the all-star extravaganza, running for nearly three hours, a monumental bore, its elbow-in-the-ribs spoofing generally tedious. The spectacle of sniffy David Niven being seduced by Shirley MacLaine's ridiculous Indian princess had its obvious limitations. So, the prospect of still another ''Around the World in 80 Days'' being produced for television was something less than invigorating. But . . . . NBC's ''Around the World in 80 Days'' lasts six hours - all right, five hours without the commercials. It is being broadcast in two-hour installments over three consecutive nights, beginning this evening at 9. Adapted by John Gay (''Fatal Vision'') and directed by Buzz Kulik, this version of the Jules Verne novel - filmed handsomely on locations in England, Macao, Hong Kong, Thailand and Yugoslavia - has decided to opt for integrity and stick close to the original source. Considered by many to be the father of modern science fiction, the French writer Verne (1828-1905) managed to transmute his keen interest in science and geography into a series of very successful adventure stories: ''Five Weeks in a Balloon,'' ''A Journey to the Center of the Earth,'' ''Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.'' Published in 1873, his now best-known work originally appeared in English as ''The Tour of the World in Eighty Days.''

title: New Fights Over Spoiling Your Baby
description: LEAD: TRY AS WE MIGHT WE CAN'T AVOID them. Spoiled brats! On the bus, at the store, in restaurants, sometimes in our own homes they force themselves on our reluctant consciousness. With horrible fascination we listen to them whining and wheedling, complaining, demanding and reproaching their hapless parents (sometimes us) in tones of voice that set our teeth on edge.

title: Giamatti Is Baseball's Poet
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: E PLURIBUS BRAZIL
description: AN INVINCIBLE MEMORY By Joao Ubaldo Ribeiro. Translated by the author. 504 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $25.

title: A Triumph, Maybe, For Small Science
description: ONE of the laments of modern physics is that the day of the lone experimenter is almost gone. Operating an observatory or a particle accelerator is so labor intensive that making a discovery can be like making a movie, with the list of authors on some scientific papers piling up like credits at the end of a show.

title: Car Thefts Rise, Police Offer Tips
description: MORE cars are being stolen each year in Connecticut, and the figures for this year indicate that 1989 may produce a record for car thefts. Hoping to reduce such thefts, the state police and local police departments have begun programs to teach people how to keep their cars more secure.

title: Judge Lets Eastern Suit Stand
description: A Federal district judge has refused to dismiss a $1.5 billion racketeering suit in which Eastern Airlines accuses the pilots' and machinists' unions of trying to win control of the airline by wrecking it.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE GOOD LIFE: The Meaning of Success for the American Middle Class. By Loren Baritz. (Knopf, $19.95.) The success of the middle class in the United States has as much to do with culture as with economics. Loren Baritz writes in ''The Good Life'' that while this country has allowed the masses to become better off financially, it has even more strongly encouraged people to shed the old and become part of the new. In fact, that desire is so strong that even people who, economically speaking, are not middle-class tend to see themselves as such. Schooling has replaced breeding as a desirable class symbol. Mr. Baritz, who teaches history at the University of Massachusetts, follows the rise of the middle class from the Puritans to the present. This technique obviously requires statistics and generalizations at every turn, but he tries to keep the text moving by aiming at, and often deflating, the hallowed beliefs of each age. For example, he writes that following World War II the role of women was to help civilize returning soldiers, for ''without her guiding hand, he might murder the in-laws and eat the furniture.'' Martin Luther King Jr. was successful, Mr. Baritz argues, because his faith, his oratory and his optimism ''revealed how much he was a part of the American middle class.'' Conversely, King's successors could never unify American blacks because of ''their too obvious scorn for middle-class values.'' More recently, conflict has divided those ''who wanted more and those who would not tolerate less.'' Both groups belong to the middle class, though tensions between the needs and desires of the upper and lower middle classes are increasing.

title: New Historic Hudson Grounds Pass
description: LEAD: VISITORS to Historic Hudson Valley properties who wish to stroll the grounds of a historic site - but not take a house or building tour - may now do so with a new grounds pass.

title: Agents' Trial: Why Bother?
description: Having spent as much time to decide the fate of the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom as the Bible says it took to create the heavens and earth, the jurors who found the two guilty of racketeering and mail fraud were entitled to a day of rest. But instead, on Friday afternoon, they met reporters.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: INTIMATE MATTERS: A History of Sexuality in America, by John D'Emilio and Estelle B. Freedman. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $9.95.) By nurturing a society of consumers driven to satisfy their every whim, capitalism has been a driving force behind the sexual revolution, the authors argue. ''John D'Emilio and Estelle Freedman are not the first to say this, but they say it so convincingly and with such a wealth of suggestive evidence that they might as well take the credit,'' Barbara Ehrenreich said here last year. WHATEVER HAPPENED TO GLOOMY GUS OF THE CHICAGO BEARS? by Robert Coover. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) In his second novel about a character named Richard Nixon, Robert Coover wonders what would have happened if the ambitious young Quaker from Whittier, Calif., had channeled his energies into becoming a football star. ''When the time comes to welcome the what-if genre into the game preserve of literature, Robert Coover's new book ought to be one of the choicest exhibits,'' Robert Kelly said here in 1987. ''Scattered through the book are quotations from Gus that seem the very words of Richard Nixon - they sound so like the man that a mere historian would not dare unfather or debunk them. Gloomy Gus is Richard Nixon, in all his awkward triumphs, in all the plodding determination every act takes, in the harsh light of the will that makes every act equal to every other.'' DREAMS AND DELUSIONS: The Drama of German History, by Fritz Stern. (Vintage, $10.95.) How was a country that gave rise to Nazism and the Holocaust also capable of producing the likes of Albert Einstein, a German-born historian asks in a series of essays. ''Taken together, they represent an original and remarkable interpretation of German history from about 1880 to the present,'' Wolfgang J. Mommsen said in these pages in 1987. THREE NIGHTS IN THE HEART OF THE EARTH, by Brett Laidlaw. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) During a bleak Minnesota winter, a failed poet named Ulysses Turner Fraser meets a tragic end. Last year our reviewer, Robert Cohen, said that this first novel is somewhat overwritten but it ''achieves considerable intensity and grace.'' DEEP ENOUGH FOR IVORYBILLS, by James Kilgo. (Anchor/Doubleday, $7.95.) In autobiographical essays about hunting in the South, James Kilgo reflects on the rituals that form the bonds between people and their land. The result is ''a thoughtful and frequently eloquent chronicle,'' Paul Schullery said here last year. BLOOD AND WATER: And Other Tales, by Patrick McGrath. (Ballantine, $3.95.) In a book of horror stories, some set in lower Manhattan, some in prewar England, Patrick McGrath parodies and celebrates Gothic literature. He ''may be a true post-modernist in the sense that Philip Johnson and David Salle are post-modernists,'' Stephen Schiff said here last year. ''He appropriates like mad, regurgitating outmoded styles and formulas with a heavily ironic wink.'' ALVAREZ: Adventures of a Physicist, by Luis W. Alvarez. (Basic Books, $9.95.) Though Luis W. Alvarez won his Nobel Prize for contributions to particle physics, he spent his later years developing a theory that the dinosaurs were killed when a large extraterrestrial body collided with the earth. In 1987 our reviewer, James Trefil, said this autobiography serves to ''remind us of what can be accomplished by one irreverent individual. It should be read by everyone who is interested in science and adventure, or who just wants to meet one of our most fascinating contemporaries.'' The same publisher has reissued RABI: Scientist and Citizen ($9.95), John S. Rigden's 1987 biography of another of the century's great physicists, I. I. Rabi. DUSK: And Other Stories, by James Salter. (North Point, $7.95.) When these laconic stories about exiles and drifters were published last year, our reviewer, A. R. Gurney, said they are ''obsessed with twilight, constantly aware of the precariously thin net of trust which supports what we call civilization and of the darkness which lies underneath. . . . James Salter is an author worth more attention than he has received so far. '' A CHILLING EFFECT: The Mounting Threat of Libel and Invasion of Privacy Actions to the First Amendment, by Lois G. Forer. (Norton, $9.95.) A Philadelphia trial judge argues that a Federal law defining what is libelous and what is newsworthy would help remove the footnotes to the First Amendment appended by our litigious society. ''Judge Forer's subject is a very important one, and I hope that her thesis will find a large, diverse and argumentative audience,'' Howard Simons said here in 1987. IN THE SHADOW OF THE PEACOCK, by Grace Edwards-Yearwood. (Ivy, $3.95.) The Peacock is a blues bar where a young Harlem woman embarks on an adventure that teaches her what it means to be black. Set during the civil rights protests and riots of the 1960's, this first novel feels a bit contrived in places, Robert Ward said here last year, but the writing is ''evocative and deeply felt.'' BETWEEN PICTURES, by Jayne Loader. (St. Martin's, $3.95.) Jayne Loader's novel about the escapades of a rich, drugged-out Hollywood screenwriter is ''satire muted by complicity, a depiction of Hollywood written with a witty, self-deprecating brio,'' William J. Harding said here in 1987. Reading it is ''like attending a wild, drunken, glamorous party - hilarious, frantic, exhilarating and a little exhausting.''

title: Retracing 1789 Inaugural Journey
description: LEAD: THE re-enactment of George Washington's epochal eight-day journey from Mount Vernon to New York City for his inauguration begins this morning, as it did 200 years ago today, at his estate in the Virginia countryside.

title: Collaboration Is Her Dance Partner
description: What would happen if a random mix of characters from modern fiction were to become the springboard for a new dance? Two years ago, the San Francisco choreographer Margaret Jenkins put this question to herself as she began work on ''Shelf Life,'' her largest collaborative work to date. Eager to take up the challenge, the six dancers who made up her troupe at the time brought their favorite paperbacks to the rehearsal studio; among them were Tom Robbins's ''Even Cowgirls Get the Blues,'' Janet Kauffman's ''Places in the World a Woman Could Walk'' and Ken Kesey's ''Sometimes a Great Notion.''

title: Nancy Robinson And L. A. Breuer, Lawyers, Marry
description: Nancy Scott Robinson, the daughter of Carol B. Robinson and Irwin H. Robinson, both of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Lanny Arthur Breuer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Breuer of Forest Hills, Queens, were married last evening at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Robert Summers.

title: Leslie H. Bailey, A Designer, Wed To M. B. Lanahan
description: Leslie Herrlinger Bailey and Michael Bruce Lanahan were married yesterday in New York at the Church Center for the United Nations. The Rev. Louis Gioia performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Reviews/Music; Mozart's 9th Concerto By Alicia de Larrocha
description: This week's subscription program at the New York Philharmonic combines the tried and true with more of the same: a brightly played early Haydn symphony (the one called No. 5, though it is not really quite that early); Alicia de Larrocha in Mozart's Ninth Concerto, and Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' symphony, under the experienced stewardship of Gunther Herbig.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical DVORAK: SYMPHONY NO. 1. - Neeme Jarvi and the Scottish National Orchestra. A stirring, vibrant performance in a work that bespeaks the composer's extraordinary natural sophistication. (Scherer) Chandos 8597.

title: Valerie Lico to Wed
description: Mrs. Serrie Lico of Pelham, N.Y., and East Quogue, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Valerie Adriana Lico, to Steven Daniel Quarfordt, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Steven Quarfordt of Durham, N.C. Miss Lico is also the daughter of the late Dr. Lico.

title: Coach Retires, Plunges Ahead
description: In 1945, Hobie Billingsley won the national collegiate one-meter and three-meter diving titles for Ohio State. In 1953, after getting a master's degree, he became a high school coach. He earned $500 a year for coaching and $3,900 for teaching physical education classes. He made ends meet by doing comedy diving and trampoline routines with Bruce Harlan, a college teammate.

title: Jordan Does Everything But Bulls Are Slumping
description: There are times when Michael Jordan seems to be everywhere. Go to the supermarket, and you will see Jordan's picture on a Wheaties box. Turn on your television, and Jordan may be on the next commercial.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Determining Family Computer Needs
description: LEAD: NOT so long ago, a public-relations brochure arrived in the mail boasting of our school district's computer-education program. The flier was impressive and the innovation commendable, but the program alone won't make ''mathletes.''

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who Is the Greatest Fighter Of All Time?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Waddesdon
description: To the Editor: The article on Waddesdon, England (Travel, March 5) brought fond memories. I am one of the German Jewish boys who were taken in by James and Dorothy de Rothschild in 1939. Although I arrived from Germany by myself, I joined my brother Bernd, who had arrived a few months earlier. After about a year in Waddesdon, my brother and I came to the United States to be reunited with our parents.

title: Copper Bowl Next
description: An N.C.A.A. subcommittee has given approval for a Tucson group to stage the first Copper Bowl, one of 18 Division I postseason football games. The game is tentatively scheduled for Dec. 30 at Arizona Stadium.The game still needs the approval of the the N.C.A.A. Council, which will vote on it at its meeting Aug. 2 through 4.

title: Ms. Simowitz Engaged to Law Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Simowitz of Wayne, N.J., and North Miami Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randi Lyn Simowitz, to Andrew Feinberg. He is the son of Dean Lilienstern Feinberg of Orange, Conn., and Barry Feinberg of Maui, Hawaii, and West Haven, Conn., and the stepson of Minerva Feinberg. A wedding is planned for next year.

title: WHEN WE FOUND OUR SELVES
description: A HISTORY OF PRIVATE LIFE Volume Three: Passions of the Renaissance. Edited by Roger Chartier. Introduction by Philippe Aries. Translated by Arthur Goldhammer. Illustrated. 645 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $39.50.

title: Can Sand, Even A Mountain of It, Stop the Tides?
description: IT is an enterprise of epic proportions, yet little evidence exists that it has even taken place.

title: Nevada
description: To the Editor: ''Seeing Ground Zero in Nevada'' (Travel, March 12) brought back vivid memories. I was one of ''the national press invited in and allowed to cover'' the first open-to-the-media atmospheric test at Nevada's Yucca Flat on April 22, 1952. Among the reporters who gathered 10 miles from Ground Zero to see (and feel the hot blast of) the explosion were The New York Times's veteran atomic expert, Bill Lawrence, the broadcaster Lowell Thomas and the Hearst columnist Bob Considine.

title: Hispanic Residents Striving for Political and Economic Gains
description: LEAD: LIKE many immigrants, Gustavo Roca came from Cuba with a dream of one day having his own business. A former journalist who settled in Tarrytown four years ago, he thought about starting a newspaper, but put the idea on the back burner as he struggled to make a new life.

title: Budget Agreement Finesses Tough Questions
description: As he announced his budget agreement with Congress in a Rose Garden ceremony Friday, President Bush said it constituted ''a first manageable step'' in resolving the deficit problem that has plagued the United States.

title: English Fades With Empire In Hong Kong
description: In Hong Kong, which has been a British colony for almost 150 years, English is the official language of the courts and Government, English classes are compulsory for all Hong Kong students, and English-language television and radio stations, newspapers and movies abound.

title: Anti-Violence Push
description: A bill in the Minnesota Legislature that sought to fine National Hockey League owners for fighting by players has been withdrawn by the author and replaced with a resolution condemning violence in the N.H.L. The resolution was approved by the State House Judiciary Committee in St. Paul and sent to the House floor.

title: Ulster Town Mourns Victim of I.R.A.
description: They had planned an Old Tyme Horse, Sheep and Goat Fair today to try to revitalize their tourist trade. Instead, the townspeople had to hold a funeral for 20-year-old Joanne Reilly.

title: Park Rules to Limit Homeless Anger Many
description: New rules proposed for New York City parks, many of them aimed at homeless people, have come under sharp criticism from some civic and religious leaders on moral and constitutional grounds.

title:
DANCE;
Themes From Real Life
description: LEAD: PREGNANCY, the approach of middle age, changes in life style and the seductive power of money provide the themes of works in the 1989 State Council on the Arts Choreography Showcase, a limited-engagement dance exhibition. These dances, which take their inspiration from personal and societal issues confronting their choreographers, were created by Janet Rowthorn, Candice Christakos, Megan Brazil and Carolyn

title: For Fido, Broccoli And Yogurt
description: Take away the gravy-laden goodies and treat your dog instead to a dollop of yogurt or some steamed broccoli. And if your cat is bothered by fleas, try using a collar soaked in eucalyptus oil or sprinkling garlic on its supper.

title: S.A.T.'s: Don't Shoot The Test Makers
description: THE college admissions process has become such an ordeal for applicants and parents it is not surprising that scapegoats must be found. The Scholastic Aptitude Tests (S.A.T.'s) are an understandable target for resentment because they seem so impersonal, so important and so unfair to those who do poorly.

title: Justin Chappell Day, a Bank Director, Weds Julian Sebastian Bell in London
description: Justin Chappell Day, a daughter of Mrs. Leigh Barnes Ponvert of Clinton Corners, N.Y., and Arthur C. Mullen of Monmouth Beach, N.J., was married yesterday to Julian Sebastian Bell at St. Bartholomew-the-Great Church in London. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roger Royle, an Anglican priest.

title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In
description: AFTER years of chafing at American complaints of its inability to catch any of the ''big fish'' of the drug trade, Mexico last week blunted such criticism by netting the biggest fish of them all. But even as law enforcement officials here were proudly exhibiting Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo and the policeman he is accused of suborning with monthly five-figure bribes, they were also cautioning privately against premature declarations of victory in the growing war against cocaine, heroin and marijuana profiteers.

title: Father's Odd Behavior On Passover Explained
description: IN recalling Passovers past, neither the white damask tablecloth nor the pastel-flowered pattern of my great-grandmother's Passover china; neither the gleams reflected off glassware and silverplate nor the wine-stained haggadot come remotely close to the recollection of my late father's Passover secret.

title: Question Of the Week; Should N.B.A. Stars Play in the Olympics?
description: The question isn't should they play? Of course they should. One question though remains: Will they play? TIMOTHY M. MORRIS Armonk, N.Y.

title: North Salem Conducts Business in Trailers
description: LEAD: WITH ITS somewhat bulging Georgian facade, North Salem's Town Hall stands its ground on old wood beams that are in turn topped by an array of wood shims. The thick and thin pieces of wood are piled atop vertical beams underground to brace joists supporting a plank floor. Until last month, when clerical workers were evacuated from the 200-year-old building, the beams and their tiers of shims upheld two stories full of people and the paraphernalia of local government.

title:
ART;
Heckscher Salutes Dove and Torr
description: LEAD: ON May 11, 1932, the painter Helen Torr recorded in her diary: ''I worked from 9:30 to 2:30 on 'Hecksher's Park' and am quite crazy about it.''

title: Demonstration Renews Question of Confict for Newspapers
description: Journalists from The New York Times and The Washington Post who participated in last Sunday's march in Washington in support of abortion rights violated their papers' conflict-of-interest policies, according to editors at both news organizations.

title: Leslie F. Moffat And Gary Little To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Keith M. Moffat of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Leslie Frances Moffat to Gary Robert Little, the son of Mrs. Frank Little of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Little. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Hungarian China, Formal to Folk
description: HEREND, or Herendi as it is called in Hungary, has long been among the world's most prestigious porcelains and is still being produced at a little village north of Lake Balaton, about 65 miles from Budapest. Hungarian porcelain - not only Herendi but also the less-known Zsolnay - is also among the things a visitor to Hungary will be tempted to buy.

title: Richard Shuster, Miss Treiger Wed
description: Betsy Treiger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Treiger of New York, was married last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria to Richard Shuster, a son of Matthew Shuster and Nancy Shuster, both of Providence, R.I. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated, assisted by Cantor David Lefkowitz.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lincoln, N.H.;
Rethinking Condo Prices
description: LEAD: SALES of resort condominiums in this White Mountain town two and a half hours north of Boston have slowed, but the relative success of lower-priced developments is leading builders to consider emphasizing them.

title: Naomi Voigt Wed To R. S. Lindahl
description: At the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church in Washington, Naomi Allison Voigt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Holmes Voigt of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Richard Scott Lindahl, a son of Lynne W. Lindahl of Little Ferry, N.J., and John A. Lindahl of Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. Paul A. Kress officiated.

title: Grand Cayman
description: To the Editor: We have just returned from a trip to Grand Cayman and think that our experience may be of interest to those planning a trip to the Caymans.

title: Miss Brainard Weds Richard Armellini
description: Cynthia Lynn Brainard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Brainard 2d of Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Richard Aldrich Armellini, the son of Dr. Ciro V. B. Armellini of Palma de Mallorca, Spain, and Anne H. Aldrich of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
How Freehold Preserved a Farmland Plot
description: LEAD: OVER the last decade, the 38-square-mile Township of Freehold has been a magnet for growth in housing, and it seemed inevitable that the 375 acres of farmland in its south-central sector would be lost.

title: With Love and Hope, Letting Go Of a Son
description: The apartment feels so empty when I come in. What was once my son's bedroom is now a depository for everything that I now don't know what to do with. The hooks are still on the walls but all the pictures of the Mets are gone. The cupboards are practically bare of his clothes and the drawers which used to contain socks and underwear are empty. It is as if the room doesn't belong to anyone anymore.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: ''Forbidden Broadway.'' The very title is clearly meant to suggest something clandestine and a bit wicked. And in its early years, in 1983 or 1984, Gerard Alessandrini's revue did indeed leave you feeling that you'd been sharing the evening murk with a cabal of performing witches and warlocks, assembled to stick verbal pins into effigies of their theatrical enemies - and inflict pain, if not on their bodies, at least on their egos. Nothing more entertainingly malignant was to be found on any New York stage. The art of satire, dead elsewhere, had been surreptitiously resurrected at Palsson's supper club on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: How the History Of New York City, In Little Pieces, Is Being Unearthed
description: AS New York City reaches higher into the sky to build its houses and offices, it is reaching deeper into the earth to reacquaint itself with patterns of life in earlier centuries.

title: A Return To the Girls On the Train
description: WE did everything I hate about commuting. And I loved it. Elaine, Susie and I. It started about five years ago when I was a novice at taking the Harlem Line train from North White Plains to Grand Central Terminal and when I was full of enthusiasm - a good job, at a big company, in the big city.

title: Sarah Jackson Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gregg Jackson of Merion, Pa., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Sarah Grayland Jackson and Jeffrey S. Leonard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Leonard of Huntington, L.I. Miss Jackson, a manager in the finance division of Chemical Bank in New York, graduated from the Friends' Central School in Philadelphia and magna cum laude from Brown University. Mr. Leonard, an associate in the New York law firm of Hendler, Murray & Mait, graduated from Brandeis University and received a J.D. degree from Boston University.

title: A Tradition Based in Words To Come to Life in Pictoral History
description: FOR 20 years the Oral History Center at the University of Connecticut in Storrs has compiled taped interviews with people who lived history, but now it is moving into a different medium. Under contract to the Donning Company Publishers in Virginia, the center is compiling a pictorial history of northeastern Connecticut.

title: Democrats Weigh the Cost Of Defending Their Speaker
description: SPEAKERS of the House give their names to public buildings, leave their mark on legislation and play a central role in the games of power in the nation's capital. But they rarely burst into the consciousness of the public at large.

title: Ivy League Does Something Right
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Good Health/Magazine Part 2
description: Special reports in this issue include an examination of the bold new science of skin treatments.

title: From Rafters to Courtside, Enthusiasm Fills Garden
description: It's a $12 ticket - and it gets David Hayes a seat in the last row of Madison Square Garden - way up where it takes binoculars and a pair of tortoise-shell eyeglasses to improve the view on this April night of the Knicks and the Charlotte Hornets far, far below.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LAST BILLABLE HOUR. By Susan Wolfe. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Tweedmore & Slyde is not your average law firm. Treading on its plush salmon carpeting are lawyers wielding two phones at once and billing 40 hours a day - each. It's the hottest, richest law firm in Silicon Valley, and more than a little intimidating to Howard Rickover.

title: Prime Time for Communists?
description: To the Editor:

title: IT GRIPES ME TO SAY THIS
description: AMERICA WAS NOT BUILT ON SELF-reassurances. Do you know what fully two-thirds of the Declaration of Independence amounts to? Pure griping, against ''a long train of abuses and usurpations.'' The English king ''has refused his assent. . . . He has forbidden. . . . He has utterly neglected. . . . He has dissolved. . . . He has obstructed. . . .'' And on and on, rousingly.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FIRST AID FOR HOUSES Architects, contractors and historians manning a first-aid booth for houses will answer questions during the Old House Fair on Saturday and next Sunday in West Hartford. More than 60 exhibitors from New England and New York will be on hand as well, with restoration services and products.

title: FOCUS: Cleveland; Hopes for Downtown Pinned to Housing
description: AS the skies darken, the sidewalks surrounding Cleveland's central Public Square grow empty and the outbound cars that clogged the downtown streets during rush-hour gradually disappear. A scattering of lighted office windows is but a dim reminder of the work day.

title: Question Of the Week; Should N.B.A. Stars Play in the Olympics?
description: There should take place - between the N.B.A. championships and the Summer Olympics of each Olympic quadrennial -a double-elimination round-robin national tournament to determine what sole N.B.A. team should represent the United States.

title: Mail Calls
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
When Water Conservation Is Important
description: LEAD: WITH the possibility of water restrictions facing gardeners this season, many are asking whether they should give up all thought of planting this spring.

title: 93 Are Dead After a Crush At Soccer Game in England
description: At least 93 people were killed and more than 180 others were injured today when soccer fans surged forward in severely overcrowded stands at a match in the northern English city of Sheffield, according to police and hospital officials.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions of The Week in Review last Sunday on health concerns of women whose mothers took DES in pregnancy misattributed a quotation. It was Dr. Emmanuel Friedman of Beth Israel Hospital in Boston who said of DES and cancer: ''Clearly a relationship exists. But we had felt there would be a horrendous problem, and that didn't pan out.''

title: How the Oil Spilled and Spread: Delay and Confusion Off Alaska
description: Within an hour of the wreck of the Exxon Valdez at 12:04 A.M. on March 24, workers were preparing emergency equipment at the big marine terminal at Valdez, Alaska. It was not dispatched.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark-brown Formica on the tops of my kitchen counters. These tops have become dull and there seems to be a residue of cleaning powder that I am unable to remove. Is there anything I can use that will not harm the plastic surface, and what can I use to restore the original shine?

title: Land Preservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward J. Hogan, Priest, 83
description: The Rev. Edward J. Hogan, who was associated with St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church for 48 years, died of cardiac arrest on Friday at the Murray-Weigel Health Care Center of Fordham University in the Bronx. He was 83 years old.

title: Enzo Gaspari, 74, a Former State Senator
description: Enzo Gaspari, a former New York State senator and assemblyman and the managing legislative lawyer for Shea & Gould, a Manhattan law firm, died of a stroke Thursday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 74 years old and lived in Albany.

title:
Long Island Interview: Mark Mathabane;
African Dreams, American Reality
description: LEAD: THE South African author Mark Mathabane came of age in the black ghetto of Alexandria, near Johannesburg, by reading what books he could acquire, sometimes at peril to his life, and dreaming of escape to America, where black men, he had heard, walked free.

title: Zola Budd Weds
description: With her controversial running career on hold, Zola Budd married a liquor store owner yesterday in her hometown of Bloemfontein, South Africa. Budd, 22 years old, wed Mike Pieterse, 26, in a ceremony attended by about 150 people. The two were engaged last August after Budd suspended her track career in Britain and returned to Bloemfontein, about 240 miles southwest of Johannesburg. Budd has been one of the world's top women distance runners in recent years, but her career has been dogged by controversy since she was granted a British passport and allowed to compete at the 1984 Olympic Games. South Africa is barred from international competition because of its official policies of racial segregation.(AP)

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: JUFFIE KANE. By Beverly S. Martin. (Bantam, $18.95.) The saga of the gorgeous, award-winning actress Juffie (Jennifer) Kane opens with her husband and her girlhood chum in bed together hearing the news that Juffie has been swept to her death in a Swiss avalanche. But no habitual reader of soap-opera novels will be gulled into thinking that Juffie's made her final exit.

title: INSIDE
description: Fusion: Don't Count on It

title: CONSUMER RATES

FILM;
Psychiatry Looks At the Appeal Of 'Rain Man'
description: LEAD: ''Rain Man'' has struck a chord by connecting deeply with the emotional life of its audience. To a psychiatrist, the reasons for the appeal of Barry Levinson's Academy Award-winning film go beyond the obvious. Something about the film works beyond its surface. ''Rain Man'' could easily be viewed as a mundane story of two unappealing but well-portrayed characters and taken as a downbeat recycling of a road picture.

title: Question Of the Week; Should N.B.A. Stars Play in the Olympics?
description: Absolutely not! It would deprive our student-athletes the opportunity of the dream of a lifetime. Although we've fallen short of the gold, the American public should not panic. Attention should be given to the team-selection process, emphasizing players who can score from the perimeter and play good team defense. MIKE WINFIELD Brooklyn

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on March 19 about Versailles described the courtyard incorrectly. It has no steps.

title: Charles Vanel, Stage And Screen Actor, 96
description: Charles Vanel, a craggy-faced actor with a piercing gaze who appeared in more than 200 movies, died today in a Cannes hospital. He was 96 years old.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Two Towers, With Anchor
description: LEAD: THE city is witnessing the construction of the largest office complex in four years - two towers with 1.8 million square feet that will be the headquarters of New England Telephone. The company has leased 500,000 square feet in the building and is a limited partner in the ownership group.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING A TACTICAL SHIFT ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: Bush Administration officials are discussing several new proposals for modifying the United States' position in the strategic arms talks.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Harvard; Rebellious Minds Meet To Recall '69 Protest
description: Student protesters and former student protesters, nearly a generation apart, came together on the campus here last weekend. Those who occupied the Harvard administration building in 1969 to denounce the Vietnam War met their present-day counterparts, who seem to have a somewhat longer list of causes, if a less confrontational style.

title: 23% in a Study Feel They Retired Too Early
description: A new study of more than 6,000 union members has found that nearly one out of every four believed that they had retired too early.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark-brown Formica on the tops of my kitchen counters. These tops have become dull and there seems to be a residue of cleaning powder that I am unable to remove. Is there anything I can use that will not harm the plastic surface, and what can I use to restore the original shine?

title: Giamatti Is Baseball's Pedant
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Delay in Commuter Service On New Rail Line Protested
description: A RECOMMENDATION by N. J. Transit's staff to delay the start of rail commuter service between here and Camden County is causing a furor in southern New Jersey.

title: Andrea V. Fry and Richard Blake Jr. Are Planning to Marry in September
description: A September wedding is planned by Andrea Victoria Fry and Richard Randolph Blake Jr., the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Fry of Reading, Pa., have announced. Mr. Blake is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Blake of Philadelphia.

title: Nicaragua to Deport American Suspected Of Drug Trafficking
description: Nicaraguan officials said today that they will deport to the United States an American pilot who crash-landed his private plane in Nicaragua last month in what authorities described as a drug-related flight.

title: Q and A
description: Park Passes

title: For the Prom, Some Hollywood, Please!
description: The hunt for the ultimate prom dress is under way and, as ever, young women are taking their cues from Hollywood and high fashion.

title: Guetterman's Success Hasn't Changed Him
description: The first time the bullpen gate opened in the ninth inning the other night, Lee Guetterman walked across the outfield grass and heard the thumping of his heart. He had been pitching professionally since 1981, had been working in the big leagues since 1984, and yet this was something brand new.

title: The Area's Economy Feels the Austerity at the Pentagon
description: AFTER the years of rapid growth, military contractors in the New York region are having to cut jobs and costs, and devise new strategies to stay competitive. The pressure in Washington to shrink military spending has squeezed contractors around the country. But the New York region, corporate executives say, faces added competition from companies in the South that have cheaper labor and production costs.

title: Marc J. Cohen: Book Designer
description: Marc J. Cohen has been designing book covers for a dozen years, but only now is the spotlight on the 35-year-old Brooklyn native who heads his owns design firm in Manhattan. This is because he designed the covers for the acclaimed Vintage International series, the first 15 titles of which were published three weeks ago.

title: Pyramid Mountain Should Be Saved
description: We were pleased to see the recent article on the plight of Pyramid Mountain (''Groups Are Trying to Save Their Beloved Mountain'').

title: Waterbury Show Reveas a Confounding Sculptor
description: CHRISTOPHER HEWAT'S view of the art world may be summed up as ''if you can't lick it, join it.'' And to judge from statements made by him for a 1983 show in Manhattan, he has done just that by establishing a museum in his cellar, naming it the Musee Ruse and - something that distinguishes it from most other institutions of this kind - showing only forgeries.

title: Rebuilding Bodies
description: TAKE A LOOK,'' SAYS DR. MARK P. Figgie. ''It's pretty impressive.'' On the operating table is a 72-year-old woman named Maria. Dr. Figgie, an orthopedic surgeon at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York, points to an eight-inch-long incision he has made in her left leg - four inches above the knee to four inches below it. He's opened the flap of skin and lifted off her kneecap. ''See,'' he says, as he points a rubber-gloved finger. ''Arthritis has eaten up the joint.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Rutherford
description: LEAD: A VISITOR stepping from Rutherford's 19th-century train station at the far end of Park Avenue and Station Square quickly sees that this is a community that has not surrendered its downtown to the competition of suburban malls.

title:
LIFESTYLE;
Boston Bartenders Try to Do Something About Those Tales of Woe
description: LEAD: For more than 10 years, two Boston bartenders have not been content just to listen to people's problems, they have often raised the money to solve them.

title: STREETSCAPES: Public School 157; A Conversion to Serve Another Generation's Needy
description: PUBLIC SCHOOL 157, at the northwest corner of 126th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, went up between 1896 and 1899, a time when a new generation of school buildings was created to bring not simply instruction but also an uplifting, cultural influence to New York City's poor and working-class sections.

title: PEDDLING TRINKETS ABROAD TO TIE THE SCORE IN TRADE
description: Exports of costume jewelry jumped 26 percent last year, but the news was of little comfort to American producers. After all, the $111 million in exports was only one-sixth of the value of imports.

title: Catching the Anti-Cholesterol Fever Catching the Anti-Cholesterol Fever
description: In the late afternoon at the cavernous Sunshine Biscuits bakery in Sayreville, N.J., endless sheets of unbaked Hydrox Creme Filled Chocolate Sandwich cookies trundled into a 580-foot-long oven and emerged at a blistering rate of 5,040 a minute, a glutton's fantasy.

title: It's Time for Sharing: Parties Match Singles
description: The share party, a spring ritual enacted by those in search of the perfect summer housemates, is under way in New York apartments, bars and restaurants. This blend of social gathering and screening process brings together single people who have found a summer place and those who are looking for one.

title: Scott, Gumbel And That Memo
description: To the Editor; Willard Scott [ '' 'Today,' After That Infamous Memo,'' April 2 ] is not funny, not faintly amusing, not endearing, not quaint, not cute. To avoid him I don't watch NBC any more in the morning. He is really awful and, believe me, no threat to Bryant Gumbel. MARILYN VALDEN Greenwich, Conn.

title: A May Wedding For Leslie Dickey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Fitz Randolph Jr. of New York and Ridgefield, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for Mrs. Randolph's daughter, Leslie Stuart Dickey, and Sanjay Hiralal Patel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hiru N. Patel of Bombay, India.

title: New Effort Teaches Child Care Skills
description: LEAD: A NEW program in child care at the State University of New York here has enrolled 40 people, more than expected, said Linda Lattimer, director of the Children's Center at the Purchase campus.

title: Warhol Before The Soup
description: The survey of Andy Warhol's pre-Pop work at the Grey Art Gallery at New York University is an excellent and essential exhibition, even though it contains very little that is or even pretends to be fine art. '' 'Success Is a Job in New York': The Early Art and Business of Andy Warhol'' takes its title from an article that Warhol illustrated for Glamour magazine - his first commercial art job after arriving in New York in 1949 at the age of 21.

title: U.S. Toppled by Soviets, 4-2
description: Sergei Fedorov, a rookie, scored two goals today as the Soviet Union defeated a surprisingly strong Team USA, 4-2, in the first round of the world hockey championships.

title: Toiling Teen-agers
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Stifel to Wed J. C. Quinn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Stifel of Short Hills, N.J., and Stratton, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Louise Stifel to James Carroll Quinn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Quinn Jr. of San Marino, Calif. A September wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
Unabashed Glitzy Style in White Plains
description: LEAD: CELEBRATING its fourth year, Livanos retains its new-minted look that makes dining here a little special. The decor is unabashedly, intentionally glitzy, more a style than an affront. We know of quite a few people who find Livanos the place to entertain the folks when they come up from Florida. This dining spot serves nicely for other diners and other occasions as well, because by choosing carefully one can have a first-rate meal and at prices that will not necessarily flatten the wallet.

title: Hu Yaobang, Ex-Party Chief in China, Dies at 73
description: Hu Yaobang, who helped navigate China away from orthodox Marxism and led the world's largest Communist Party for six years until he was forced to resign in disgrace in January 1987, died today, the Government announced. He was 73 years old.

title: Town Acts To Keep Its 'Hams' On the Air
description: AN attempt by local municipalities to regulate the size and location of television satellite dishes and radio antennas has aroused concern among ham radio operators throughout Long Island, who fear that such ordinances will hinder their activities.

title: Keep Ivy League Automatic Bid
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Kathleen Scully Becomes a Bride
description: Kathleen Ann Scully, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brian J. Scully of Villanova, Pa., was married yesterday at St. John Baptist Vianney Roman Catholic Church in Gladwyne, Pa., to James L. Weinstock, the son of Mrs. John R. Shattuck of Cumberland Foreside, Me., and Harold B. Weinstock of New York and Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Charles Robert O'Hara performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
When Water Conservation Is Important
description: LEAD: WITH the possibility of water restrictions facing gardeners this season, many are asking whether they should give up all thought of planting this spring.

title: Baltimore's Working Waterfront
description: ON a foggy night in Fell's Point the dim light from the iron streetlamps casts a pale glow on the paving stones, and Baltimore's old waterfront neighborhood seems little changed from the 18th century. The city's much-touted gleaming Inner Harbor is only a mile - or two centuries - away.

title: Colorado Braking Its Reckless Skiers
description: The two accidents were among the worst on the Colorado ski slopes this season: an 11-year-old girl was killed and an 8-year-old boy's leg was shattered. Both children were struck by adult skiers out of control.

title: Prosecutors Grapple With Questions of AIDS
description: Can defendants who know they are infected with the AIDS virus be prosecuted for attempted murder or reckless endangerment if they rape or bite someone?

title: Outdoors; An Everglades Fishing Treasure
description: On a recent trip to the family's ancestral condo in Delray Beach, I renewed my long-standing acquaintance with Jack Allen, one of the premier light-tackle fishing guides in South Florida.

title: Reviews/Music; Composers From Russia, New and Old
description: The New York University Chamber Music Society has been offering a series called ''The Year of Russian Music'' this season at Merkin Concert Hall. The latest installment, offered on Thursday evening, was almost two concerts in one, with the first half devoted to duo-piano music of Stravinsky and the second to colorfully scored chamber works by contemporary Soviet composers.

title: Removal of Tribute to 27 Dead Stirs Anger
description: A memorial erected anonymously at the site of a crash that killed 27 people has been removed by the state as a safety hazard.

title: Reviews/Music; New Voices In the Met's 'Rigoletto'
description: A number of new voices have been edging their way into the Metropolitan Opera's current cast of ''Rigoletto'' during the past few weeks. These substitutions include just about all the principal parts: the Duke of Mantua (Jerry Hadley), Gilda (Sumi Jo), the title role (Frederick Burchinal), Sparafucile (Kurt Moll) and Maddalena (Sandra Walker).

title: Alison Wylegala Weds S. J. Lewis
description: The marriage of Alison Ramona Wylegala, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Victor Wylegala of Lake View, N.Y., to Stephen Joseph Lewis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lewis of Honesdale, Pa., took place yesterday evening at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Lake View. The Rev. Raymond Donahue, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Lawrence Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: HALF-MAD BILLIONARIES AND ELECTRONIC WHATSITS
description: THE NEGOTIATOR By Frederick Forsyth. 391 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: RYE DERBY Top prize in the First Annual Rye Derby to be run next Sunday will be $1,000 in cash, awarded to the winning male and female finishers. The five-mile race begins at 2 P.M. in front of the Y.M.C.A. on Locust Avenue in Rye and finishes in the parking lot of City Hall. The event is co-sponsored by Nynex and the Y. Eamonn Coghlan, whose 1983 indoor track record for the mile still stands at 3:49, will make his debut as an outdoor runner. His presence, and the flat, fast course through Purchase Street, Grace Church Street, Manursing Way and Milton Road, are expected to attract some of the area's top runners.

title: Film - Shostakovich's Workshop
description: Dmitri Shostakovich, our chief symphonist of the mid-20th century, seems doomed to wear the somber laurels of his Leningrad symphony. Few today remember his reworking of ''Tea for Two,'' and his lifelong work in film has disappeared with the flickering images on screen.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Relocation; New York's Manufacturing Jobs Decline Sharply
description: EXCEPT for a brief stint in Yonkers, the Charles P. Rogers Brass Bed Company manufactured beds in Manhattan from 1855 until late last year, when rising rents and congestion prompted it to move across the Hudson River to Newark.

title: Toiling Teen-agers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Town of Minutemen And Literary Lions
description: THE fight at Concord's North Bridge between British troops and American colonists on April 19, 1775, began as a misunderstanding, as fights often do. Concord minutemen, who with militia from neighboring towns had spent the better part of the morning avoiding the advancing British soldiers, saw smoke rising from Concord's center. Mistakenly believing their homes to be on fire (the smoke came from cannon carriages and munitions the British were burning), the minutemen led a march toward the bridge, the quickest way to town, eager to put out the flames and anxious about the Redcoats in their way. Shots were exchanged. Two colonists and three British soldiers were killed.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Commack $164,000 2 Barley Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old split level; den, dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Glen Cove $330,000 16 Central Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; den with fireplace, skylights, basement, 1-car garage; taxes not established. Miller Place $202,000 7 Landing Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, porch, basement, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $2,900. Rocky Point $265,900 Brookhaven Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; fireplace, whirlpool bath, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $5,000. Shoreham $127,300 24 Hudson Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 0.5-acre, 1-car garage; taxes $1,200. Southold $110,000 Founders Path 2-bedroom, 1-bath 40- year-old cottage; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,300. OTHER AREAS Bellmawr, N.J. $116,000 1002 14th Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 3-year-old ranch; fenced yard, 2-car garage; taxes $1,395. Pleasantville, N.Y. $342,500 1199 Bedford Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $2,894. Bethel, Conn. $170,000 48 Old Hawleyville Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 46-year-old Cape Cod; large family room with fireplace, close to major highways, 1 acre; taxes, $1751.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LACEMAKER. By Janine Montupet. Translated by Lowell Bair. (Atheneum, $21.95.) The French novelist Janine Montupet's new book portrays Alencon, France, in the late 17th century, a time when the streets were filled with blind women - lace makers who had lost their sight, and with it their livelihoods, by working 18 hours a day, six days a week, from the time they were children.

title: DATA BANK: April 16, 1989
Review/Theater; The Nostalgia of Murder When the Lights Go Out
description: Years ago, when movies were in their infancy and television was not even a gleam in an inventor's eye, theater had a stranglehold on what is now called light entertainment. But as the new Equity Library Theater production of a 1916 mystery, ''The Thirteenth Chair,'' indicates, stylish drama like other fashion goes out of style.

title: I Musici Cancels but Rondo Chamber Fills the Bill
description: UPSET, suspense and delight followed each other in quick succession recently for members of the Sleepy Hollow Concert Association. The problem arose when I Musici, the renowned Italian ensemble, suddenly canceled its entire American tour, including what was to have been tonight's 8:30 appearance in Tarrytown's Washington Irving School.

title: Industry-Hoppers Move Ahead
description: LEAD: FIVE months ago, Betty Kennedy, a human resources specialist, made a drastic move: She left the International Business Machines Corporation, where she had worked for more than 27 years, to join a small consulting firm that assists Fortune 500 companies in dealing with culturally diverse work forces and building effective employee teams.

title: THE NATION: A Peaceful Re-Election; Los Angeles Has Problems, But Politics Isn't a Big One
description: THE tameness of local politics in California must astonish Chicagoans, who just witnessed the brawl there known as the Mayor's race, and New Yorkers, who are bracing for their own municipal free-for-all in November.

title: Court Rules Cigarette Warnings Do Not Block Suits
description: The Minnesota Supreme Court has ruled that warning labels on cigarette packs do not give tobacco companies blanket immunity from lawsuits by victims of lung cancer and other illnesses related to smoking.

title: DATA UPDATE: April 16, 1989
A Seemingly Routine Missouri Case Takes Abortion Issue to High Court
description: Beneath the public furor over whether the Supreme Court is on the verge of withdrawing the constitutional right to obtain an abortion is a case that, in another context, might almost be called routine.

title: South of the Loire, a Different France
description: ONE afternoon in the west of France, two women stand at the edge of the road, dressed in skirts and clogs. They lean away from the road making curious, large throwing motions with their arms. They are catching frogs in a dike, by throwing a string with a lure just above the water. The frog leaps to the bait, then - hop! - they jerk back the string just when he has snapped his jaws shut, and with a single motion they throw him into a basket and shut the lid. He will provide lovely fat frogs' legs for someone's dinner.

title: Easing the Next Slump
description: With the economic expansion running out of steam, a number of economists are predicting a recession next year. But many of them lean toward the view that the setback will be short and shallow. One reason is that they believe corporate profits and corporate spending may continue at higher levels than in recent economic slumps.

title: Can Society Tell You What Tastes Good?
description: We are, so it seems, what we are told to eat. We have become a nation of people fixed on, if not obsessed with, the nutritional value of the foods we eat. We are hit left and right with information about which foods are healthy and which are not, which help prevent heart attacks, say, and which help bring them on. We are listening - and we are changing our patterns of behavior, as well as our preferences in foods, in dramatic ways. Americans are now buying less red meat and much more chicken. Consumption of high-energy complex carbohydrates in the form of pasta and grains has increased significantly as well. What Americans once thought tasted wonderful doesn't seem to taste as wonderful anymore. That big, juicy, sizzling steak doesn't taste quite so good to quite so many people. Clearly, society - or the complicated pressures at work within it - is telling us what to like and what not to like.

title: Maria Susan Buteux and Ned Reade, Both Teachers, Plan to Marry in June
description: Maria Susan Buteux and Edwin Godwin Reade 3d, both teachers at Trinity-Pawling School in Pawling, N.Y., plan to marry in June. Their engagement was made known by the prospective bride's mother, Mary Anne Buteux of New Hartford, N.Y.

title:
ART;
'Artistic Encounters' Examines Rural Places, in Katonah Show
description: LEAD: WITH the possible exception of Marsden Hartley, all of the major artists in ''New England-New Mexico: Artistic Encounters'' at the Katonah Gallery also captured in their various modernist styles both the growth and life of New York City. But the rural places of the exhibition were twin attractions in which the artists did some of their finest, meditative work.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Education Fights Apartheid
description: LEAD: We recently traveled to South Africa for a visit that caused some to question why Lee would return there after saying in 1986 that he would not go back until apartheid was dismantled. We found our visit to be educational and enlightening. We went there in 1989 for the same reasons we did in 1971: to see firsthand the living, working and educational conditions of black South Africans and to give them something of lasting value.

title: Rose About the Rings
description: The World Series rings he won with Cincinnati in 1975 and 1976 and Philadelphia in 1980 are stored in a case in his home, Pete Rose said Friday.

title: Chilly Response At the Public
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Yankees' Settles Into Darien Run
description: ''DAMN YANKEES'' and ''The Pajama Game'' are unarguably musical comedy standards, if not classics, but who can tell you why? Only the audiences that were there in 1954 and 1955, respectively.

title: Pushing the Sincerity Button
description: At the end of the first side of Madonna's new album, ''Like a Prayer,'' is a song called ''Promise to Try,'' which seems to be about a woman's need to carry on in the face of emotional adversity. It's not the words that interest me here, however, but the balance between musical cliche and originality in any song.

title: Israeli Curfews Seek to Prevent Protests in Territories Today
description: The Israeli Army clamped curfews on most areas of the occupied territories today to curb protests over the killing of five Arabs last week and thwart demonstrations on Sunday, the first anniversary of the assassination of a Palestine Liberation Organization military chief.

title: Agreeableness vs. Anger
description: HOSTILITY CAN BE SUICIDAL. A host of recent studies come to the same conclusion: People who are chronically hostile, who see the world through a lens of suspicion and cynicism, are particularly vulnerable to heart disease. The data also suggest that hostility increases the risk of contracting a range of other ailments as well. By the same token, amiability - plain old good-naturedness - seems to have a protective effect on health. ''A cynical, mistrusting attitude is a driving force that makes people most susceptible to heart disease,'' says Dr. Redford Williams, an internist and behavioral medicine researcher at Duke University Medical Center. ''Hostility predicts the risk not just of heart disease, but mortality due to all causes.''

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: A declarer at the bridge table is like a commuter with a train to catch: In an emergency he will run assuming that he will not trip but he would prefer to tread a careful path and avoid any perils.

title: Washington Talk: Congress
description: Democrats are obsessed with leadership. Maybe it's because they keep losing the White House. Maybe it's because, in an era of slash-and-burn politics, leaders don't last long.

title: New York's Drug Lesson for America
description: T.N.T.: When New York City announced it a year ago, the abbreviation (for Tactical Narcotics Teams) sounded like a welcome charge of law enforcement dynamite against drug dealing. Now T.N.T. may be blowing up in the city's face, and therein lies an important lesson for those concerned with fighting the drug wars nationwide.

title: New Allies For Studios In Challenge Of Networks
description: The Motion Picture Association of America will announce tomorrow a coalition in its battle with the three major television networks over potential changes that would allow the networks to benefit from syndication of programs.

The loan, which will total $198.7 million, is expected to be arranged by the Fuji Bank and the Bank of Tokyo. The tunnel will link the new town of Sha Tin with the colony's second cross-harbor tunnel on the eastern side of the Kowloon peninsula.

After an emotional victory over the Chicago Bulls on Saturday night in front of a sellout crowd at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Nets had a chance to show some consistency for the first time this season with a victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.
