title: Question Box
description: N.B.A. Scoring Q. The Detroit Pistons and the Cleveland Cavaliers have been jockeying to finish as the team with the best regular-season record in the National Basketball Association, yet neither one will carry into the playoffs a player averaging 20 or more points a game. When was the last time the team with the best record during the season failed to have a 20-point scorer on its playoff roster? A. It last happened in the 1977-78 season, when the Portland Trail Blazers, coached by Jack Ramsay, were attempting to repeat as N.B.A. champions. The Trail Blazers not only had the best regular-season record at 58-24, they also had no player average better than Bill Walton's 18.9 points a game. Six others averaged in double figures: Maurice Lucas (16.4), Lionel Hollins (15.9), Bob Gross (12.7), Lloyd Neal (11.0), Johnny Davis (10.7) and Tom Owens (10.1). Even with all that balanced firepower, Portland's hopes to repeat were extinguished by Seattle, which won the Western Conference semifinals in six games.

description: Cautiously but with rising self-confidence, Japan has begun to assert its economic leadership and speak with a louder voice on the debt crisis crushing the world's poor nations.

The idea of playing music by dead composers for the benefit of the living, in other words, had as little part in this venture as it would have had for Mozart and his contemporaries.

But until recently her personal problems, compounded by confusion as to stylistic direction, helped stall a career that at first had seemed unstoppable.

She has described the eveninglong dance as having been inspired by the writings of Julian of Norwich and Georges Bataille and by her own Irish Catholic childhood. But it was difficult to see anything of these sources, or of the richness and passion of the score, in her piece.

title: Was a Crime Really Committed?
description: The verdict had been rendered. Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, the sports agents, were found guilty of racketeering and mail fraud by a Chicago Federal jury last week. Walters said he would appeal. Bloom broke down in tears. The jury forewoman, Majorie Benson, an administrator at the University of Chicago, said after answering reporters' questions: ''We've told you what we think. What do you think?''

title: Salaries of Chairmen Reflect Hard Times on Wall Street
description: Last year was a tough one for many Wall Street firms, as slack stock and bond markets and intense competition put pressure on industry profits. And in many cases, the pay of the chairmen of several Wall Street firms reflected the performance of their firms, as a survey of the latest proxy statements of the large publicly held Wall Street investment houses makes clear.

title: Reviews/Music; A Soviet Rock Singer Far From His Roots
description: Boris Grebenshikov, a rock songwriter from Leningrad, is about to take his chances in the Western market. In the Soviet Union, he was the leader of Aquarium, an underground band that played without official approval and made recordings privately to be distributed like the samizdat press. Aquarium set Mr. Grebenshikov's imagistic lyrics to music that laced basic three-chord rock with dissonance and eccentricity; a few Aquarium songs reached the United States on ''Red Wave,'' a compilation album of underground bands.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 17, 1989: MONDAY Genuine Parts Co. Eli Lilly & Co. Goodrich B F Co. Springs Inds Inc. TUESDAY AAR Corp. Lehman Corp. Archer Daniels Midland Mellon Bk Corp. Ashland Coal Inc. Morgan Stanley Group Inc. Banc One Corp. Reliance Group Hldgs Inc. Black Hills Corp. Scott Paper Co. First Un Corp. title: D. B. Sayles Wed To Miss Abrams
description: Rebecca Ann Abrams and David Benjamin Sayles were married yesterday at Congregation Mikveh Israel in Philadelphia by Rabbi Reuben J. Magil, assisted by Cantor Albert Gabbai.

title: Rift Runs Deep in Savings Bill Debate
description: The Bush Administration's savings-and-loan bailout plan has led to a battle of the weak versus the strong in the once monolithic savings industry, long feared for its ability to derail legislation or change it in its favor.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Number of Mothers in Jail Surges With Drug Arrests
description: Like most of the inmates in the women's house on Rikers Island, Farah L. is there because of drugs - in her case, a kilo of crack that a police narcotics team found when they raided her friend's apartment in Jamaica, Queens, one hot day last August.

title: Jocko Conlan, 89, Hall of Fame Umpire
description: John (Jocko) Conlan, a National League umpire for 24 years and a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, died today. He was 89 years old. The cause of death was not announced.

title: Entronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Hearst Forms A New Unit
description: In a reorganization intended to coordinate and expand its video activities, the Hearst Corporation has formed a new unit: the Hearst Entertainment and Syndication Group.

title: Sabatini Puts End To Graf's Streak
description: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina ended top-ranked Steffi Graf's 31-match winning streak today with a 3-6, 6-3, 7-5 victory in the final of the $300,000 Bausch & Lomb championships.

title: In Newark's High-Rises, a Desperate Wait
description: Grim and menacing even from afar, the Columbus Homes project is the only world that 21-year-old Felicia Ingram has ever known. But now she wants out.

title: Damon Biotech reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Revenue in year-ago second quarter and 6 months included $1 million and $3,104,000, respectively, realized under two agreements for the commercialization of a biological product. As reported, those agreements have since been terminated, and the company received a cash termination payment of $2 million, which is included in the latest second quarter and 6-month revenue figures.

title: Imperial Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $48,000. c-Net loss and after a gain of $94,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $1,355,000. The company said the 1988 results reflect a gain of $1,400,000 resulting from the sale of the company's investment in Growers Packing Company. The 1987 results included an extraordinary gain of $1,355,000 recognized as a result of the company's settlement of allowable claims with its unsecured liabilities shown on the company's accounting records. Share earnings of common stock gives effect to $330,000 of cumulative preferred dividends not declared for each of the years 1988 and 1987, respectively.

title: U.S. Loses Opener
description: The United States, considered a favorite to qualify for its first World Cup in 40 years, lost to Costa Rica, 1-0, today in its opening match of final-round qualifying.

title: Barbara Horowitz Wed
description: Barbara Horowitz, the daughter of Rose Horowitz of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Murray Horowitz, was married yesterday to Charles Dunn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Dunn of West New Brighton, S.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ian Jacknis at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn. The bride is a vice president of Citibank; Mr. Dunn is the vice president-manager of client services for Reich & Tang, Inc., a New York-based investment management firm.

title: Tobacco Ads And Congress
description: The Congressional war on tobacco advertising heated up late last week as three United States Senators introduced legislation to clamp down on cigarette manufacturers.

title: Shaping Up: What to Do Now That You've Started
description: THREE months ago, a slow but sure way to get in shape that involved walking and beginning calisthenics was presented in this space. Its goal over a period of several weeks was to get the truly sedentary person up off the couch and moving about, expending 1,000 calories a week in aerobic exercise and toning up the muscles of the abdomen, arms, chest and legs.

title: Steam Spray Tested For Cleaning Up Oil Along Alaska Shore
description: An environmentally risky steam-cleaning method was tested today on rocks blackened by America's worst oil spill.

title: World Would Mind a Return to Old Soviet Ways; Gorbachev Looks West
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaders in Georgia Failed, Shevardnadze Tells Pravda
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in remarks published today, described the deaths of 19 people at a rally last Sunday in Soviet Georgia as the fault of local leaders who chose ''to talk to the people from behind tanks.''

title: Rapid Training in the Wildwaters
description: ON a recent April morning the sleet had turned to rain and the trout fishermen, hardly gluttons for punishment, were nowhere to be seen on this part of the Housatonic River.

title: Elexis Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $63,584 for the latest year and $379,884 for the year-earlier period. Corrected from Thursday, April 13.

title: Miss Sheps Is Wed To S. G. Freedman
description: The marriage of Cynthia Sheps, a daughter of Elaine Rudnick Sheps of New York and the late Dr. Jack Sheps, to Samuel Gary Freedman, a son of David Freedman of Highland Park, N.J., and the late Eleanor Freedman, took place yesterday at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y. Acting Justice Jerome Hornblass of State Supreme Court in New York officiated.

title: Hunts' Plan Due in June
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, the two former billionaires who filed for personal bankruptcy last September, have until June 14 to negotiate with their creditors and to submit viable repayment plans, a Federal bankruptcy judge ruled on Friday. Confirmation hearings were tentatively scheduled for September.

title: Excel Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $386,000. c-After a special gain of $6.5 million, including $5.8 million from a restructuring. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Morgan to Sell Bonds By Computer Auctions
description: J. P. Morgan & Company has joined forces with a group of young entrepreneurs to sell new corporate bond issues through computerized auctions, seeking to change radically the distribution of new bonds and to bypass the handful of Wall Street firms that dominate that market.

title: A 70's Youth Movement
description: There may have been something magical about the moon in 1970, at least as far as skiers go.

title: A Man Dies in a Hospital Fire
description: One patient died and two hospital employees suffered smoke inhalation in a fire early today at the Jersey City Medical Center, hospital and fire officials said. The dead man was identified as George Velez, 31 years old, of Jersey City, a hospital spokeswoman said. The fire apparently broke out in the patient's 11th-floor room, said Capt. James Pron of the Jersey City Fire Department.

title: Franklin Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PANEL DEMOCRATS IN SOLID MAJORITY ACCUSING WRIGHT
description: A majority of Democrats on the House ethics committee have joined with Republicans on two important charges against Speaker Jim Wright, according to officials on Capitol Hill.

title: Focus on the Victims, Not the Murderers
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Aryan Archetype and His Date With a Grenade
description: The Killing of SS Obergruppenfuhrer Reinhard Heydrich By Callum MacDonald Illustrated. 239 pages. Free Press/ Macmillan. $19.95.

title: Space Rockets vs. Butter Is the Talk of Russia
description: Bitter conflicts over the expense and management of the Soviet space program, long waged behind the heavy doors of a closed society, are erupting in public in another manifestation of the new policy of increased openness and the deep concern for the country's economy.

title: Bull Run Gold Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said prior year revenue were same as those for the year- earlier fourth quarter because the company began Gold Mining production and sales in October 1987. Prior to that the company was in its development stage.

title: Jazz Offers Jigsaw Help
description: ''Are you puzzled about who to vote for for the N.B.A. post-season awards?'' reads the cover of a small square box sent out by the Utah Jazz.

title: Cable Seeks Sponsors in Spot Market
description: FLUSH with its success at luring advertising dollars away from the networks, the cable television industry now has its eyes on encouraging national sponsors to buy spot advertising in local markets. But the cable companies face an uphill fight.

title: Mets Lose And Get Earful
description: Davey Johnson ripped into the Mets today after they had lost for the sixth time in eight games on their worst trip in nearly a year. He warned them to cut out playing golf and cards and ''lackluster'' baseball and to start living up to their ''billings.''

title: How to Speed Freedom in Poland
description: President Bush can make history today when he speaks in the largely Polish-American Detroit suburb of Hamtramck. The Administration is reported to be fashioning a $1 billion aid and debt-relief package for Poland in response to the breathtaking accord between Warsaw and the Solidarity union. By structuring America's assistance wisely Mr. Bush can begin to define a new relationship with Eastern Europe.

title: General Employment Enterrises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Trend in Pregnancies Challenges Employers
description: Shira Goodman, a 28-year-old management consultant in Boston, is never more aware of her body's new agenda as when her unborn child picks the middle of a meeting with a client to kick. To colleagues, she is still Ms. Goodman, coolly dispensing advice, but momentarily she is Mrs. Shira Gardenswartz, mother-to-be.

title: CFCF Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of radio properties of $5,797,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Agromex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 10
description: The company recently changed its reporting period. For the second quarter ended Feb. 29, 1988, net income was $145,846, or 4 cents a share, on sales of $2,631,905. For the year-ago 6 months, net income was $497,459, or 13 cents a share, on sales of $4,900,742. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Editors' Note
description: A brief article in the ''On Your Own'' columns of SportsMonday last Own'' columns of SportsMonday week provided advice for those seeking refunds for a waterproof radio headband that was described in those columns Jan. 2. The manufacturer, which had temporarily stopped operation and had not responded to phone calls or letters, re-opened its office last week. In an article the manufacturer explains how to receive the product or obtain a refund.

title: Fusion - or Confusion?
description: The occasion was so momentous that the news conference was held in the Presidential mansion. The physicist and President stood before a throng of reporters and announced that nuclear fusion had been tamed.

title: Turning Away From New York, Fairfield Finds Itself
description: Everyone here in Fairfield County used to think Nelson Rockefeller was their Governor. At least that's the kind of tale often told to describe the identity crisis once suffered by those who live in this quilt of affluent suburbs on the New York border.

title: Reviews/Dance; Creatures Who Reveal The Taylor Humanism
description: Deep in his heart, Paul Taylor is the most Whitmanesque of dance poets, the specifically American teller of truths who proclaimed loudly, ''I sound my barbaric yaup over the roofs of the world.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT Japan has begun to assert its economic leadership in the world debt crisis, reflecting its emergence as a pre-eminent power. Indeed, the Brady plan for debt reduction includes ideas advanced by the Japanese and initially rebuffed by the U.S. [ Page A1. ] The formation of a European central bank will require European Community members to harmonize their economic and monetary policies, a report by a community committee says. The report did not set a deadline for establishing a central bank. [ D1. ] Bankers and U.S. officials welcomed a European move toward less protectionism in banking. [ D10. ] The U.S. is pressing India to strengthen its patent laws or face retaliatory trade measures, U.S. and Indian officials say. [ D10. ] West Germany's new Finance Minister is likely to abolish or revise an unpopular agenda. His other goals are unclear. [ D10. ] MARKETS Drexel Burnham Lambert is facing operational changes and challenges from state regulators but, having settled S.E.C. charges of securities law violations, it is optimistic about the future. [ D1. ] A venture to sell new issues of corporate bonds through computerized auctions, bypassing firms that dominate the market, has been formed by J. P. Morgan and some young entrepreneurs. [ D8. ] Salaries of top Wall Street executives did not always mirror the performance of their firms in 1988. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The midnight deadline for tax filing brings a financial bonanza for the Treasury, giving the deficit-plagued Federal budget the glow of a surplus - but only temporarily. [ D1. ] The savings bailout plan has created a battle of the weak versus the strong in the industry, long feared for its ability to derail legislation and influence changes in its favor. News analysis. [ D1. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Magazine writers have found a Good Fairy in Tina Brown. The Vanity Fair editor has doubled the going rate for articles, and some new magazines have followed suit. [ D1. ] The Motion Picture Association will announce a coalition in its battle with the networks over potential changes that would allow the networks to benefit from program syndication. [ D11. ] Animals make advertisers seem more human, some experts say. Four of 10 highly rated TV commercials last year featured dogs, and Bud Light leaped from eighth to third in U.S. beer sales after Spuds MacKenzie became its mascot. [ D11. ] Publishers are giving authors advances so large that they are unlikely to be recouped from book sales. Publishing. [ D11. ] Some radio talk-show hosts are calling for a boycott of Exxon because of its handling of the Alaskan oil spill. [ D11. ] The spot advertising pie is attracting the cable TV industry, which has been successful in luring advertising dollars away from the networks. Advertising. [ D12. ] COMPANIES Prodigy plans to make its home electronic information service available in the New York area. The Sears-I.B.M. venture also plans to announce a strategy for nationwide availability. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Insurance companies won another battle on the issue of who should pay the multibillion-dollar costs of cleaning up pollution and paying victims. But several companies hope to buck the trend in cases against insurers. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Interest rates are expected to remain in a narrow range, as the credit markets face signs of economic moderation and inflation readings that remain uncomfortably high. Credit Markets. [ D9. ] The battle for Consolidated Gold Fields will test the use of the ''pep pill'' as a takeover defense. Market Place [ D8. ]

title: Proper Care Is Given to Every Carriage Horse in New York City; Swans in Prospect
description: To the Editor:

title: Schedule Set in Apple Case
description: The copyright infringement case filed by Apple Computer Inc. against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company will continue into next year and possibly beyond, according to a schedule established by the judge presiding over the case.

title: Narrow Range Expected for Rates
description: For the next few months most credit market analysts expect interest rates to remain mired in a relatively narrow range, trapped between continued signs of moderation in the economy and inflation readings that remain uncomfortably high.

title: New German Official May Move on Taxes
description: For his first significant move as West Germany's new Finance Minister, Theodor Waigel is widely expected to modify or abolish an immensely unpopular withholding tax on interest income that took effect at the start of the year.

title: Health-Chem reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $101,000 and $111,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $669,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and included a loss of $61,000 for the quarter and income of $97,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $144,000 for the quarter and $462,000 for the year. Year-ago quarter and year results are restated.

title: A Dethroning, Gretzky-Style
description: There was no goaltender in the net, no defenseman in front of him, and no question that Wayne Gretzky was going to score and the Los Angeles Kings were going to win.

title: Empire State Life Insurance Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $7,990 and $90,483 for the latest year and year- earlier period.

title: Kaydon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills. Late Friday, the three-month bill rate stood at 8.61 percent, while the six-month rate was 8.59 percent.

title: FLS Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are not comparable; the company took Florida Steel Corp. private in a leveraged buyout last year. The company's series A preferred stock is publicly traded.

title: Guard Arraigned in Shooting
description: An Onondaga County prison guard who the police said tried to kill himself after shooting his wife has pleaded not guilty to charges of first-degree assault and second-degree criminal possession of a weapon. The guard, Eric Hines, 29 years old, was arraigned from his intensive care bed Saturday night. He is accused of shooting his wife, Tonya Hines, 24, before firing the gun into his right temple around 9:45 A.M. Saturday at their home. Mrs. Hines was in serious condition Sunday at University Hospital.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Sweden 4, Team USA 4: Sweden scored all four goals in the final period yesterday as the defending champions rallied to defeat Team USA in the world championships at Stockholm. It was Sweden's second victory without a defeat while the Americans, who absorbed a 4-2 loss to the Soviet Union in Saturday's opener, dropped to 0-2 in the round-robin portion of the eight-team tournament. Team Canada routed Poland, 11-0, to join Sweden and the Soviet Union with 2-0 records. The Soviet Union defeated West Germany, 5-1, at Sodertalje, south of Stockholm. Czechoslovakia beat Finland, 3-1, yesterday at Sodertalje. The Czechoslovaks are 1-0-1; Finland dropped to 0-2.(AP) HORSE RACING Antley Triumphs Again: Chris Antley, who earlier in the day had extended his riding streak to 53 winning days, rode Zee Best to a 1 3/4-length victory yesterday in the featured $88,350 DeWitt Clinton Handicap at Aqueduct. Salarian Way finished second, two lengths in front of Spicy Monarch, with Appealing Guy fourth in the field of eight New York-bred 3-year-olds. Zee Best, owned by the Fran-Jay Stable and trained by James Pascuma Jr., paid $14.60 for $2 to win and ran the seven furlongs on a muddy track in 1:25 3/5. ROAD RACING Ethiopian Misses Mark, but Wins: Belaneh Densimo of Ethiopia failed yesterday in an announced attempt to smash his 1988 world-best time in the marathon, set in the Rotterdam Marathon, but won the 1989 Dutch event in 2 hours 8 minutes 39 seconds. The 22-year-old Addis Ababa policeman said that weather conditions and lack of a stronger challenge from his main rival, Alejandro Cruz of Mexico, kept him from clocking a better time in the event, which he won for the third successive time. Cruz finished second in 2:09:24, followed by Marten Kate of the Netherlands in 2:10:03. (AP) Dickenson Wins in Yonkers: Despite running with spurs on both heels, Dan Dickenson of New York took the lead after 20 miles and won the Yonkers Marathon in 2 hours 31 minutes 29 seconds yesterday, his third victory in the event in the last four years. Christine Gibbons of the Millrose Athletic Association was the women's gold medalist in 2:55:12 as a field of 261 competed in rain and strong winds in the 53d running of the 26-mile-385-yard event.(AP) AUTO RACING Al Unser Jr. Wins: Al Unser Jr. overcame a collision with Mario Andretti 12 laps from the end yesterday and went on to win his second straight Long Beach Grand Prix Indy-car race in California with a record-setting run. The 27-year-old Unser, the son of a four-time Indianapolis 500 winner, earned the ninth victory of his Indy-car career, all of them coming on road circuits. He won $117,660. Michael Andretti was unable to challenge and finished second.(AP) Earnhardt Ends Drought: Dale Earnhardt won for the first time in 16 Nascar Winston Cup races, pulling away from Alan Kulwicki in the final four laps yesterday to capture the First Union 400 at North Wilkesboro Speedway in North Carolina. (AP) GOLF Bradley Wins by a Shot: Pat Bradley, winning for the first time in two years, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to capture the $450,000 Ai Star-Centinela Hospital Classic in Los Angeles by one stroke. Bradley finished the 54-hole tournament at the Rancho Park course with a total of eight-under-par 208, one shot better than Nancy Lopez and Hollis Stacy. Lopez, the defending champion, shot a 69 yesterday, and Stacy had a 68. (AP) Bies Takes Seniors Event: Don Bies shot a bogey-free final round of six-under-par 66 yesterday to beat Gary Player by one shot and win The Tradition, a new $600,000 Senior PGA Tour tournament in Scottsdale, Ariz. Bies finished with a 13-under 275 total.(AP) ROWING Sweep by Yale: Yale's heavyweight crews swept their races against Syracuse yesterday in close decisions on Onondaga Lake. The varsity won by 2.7 seconds, about half a boat length, over 2,000 meters, in 6 minutes 10.8 seconds. The second varsity won by 5.1 seconds and the freshmen by 1.6.

title: C. H. Wolff Weds Nancy L. Wachtel
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue, Nancy Lynn Wachtel, the daughter of Lorraine Wachtel and Alfred Wachtel, both of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Charles Henry Wolff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Georges Wolff of New York and Shelter Island, L.I. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated.

title: Consul Restaurant reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I continue to believe that I have not violated any House rules, and I am absolutely certain that I have never knowingly or intentionally done so.'' - House Speaker Jim Wright. [ A17:1. ]

title: Menlo Park Journal; Stanford Cast as Villain For Farm Worker Woes
description: On land owned by Stanford University, 50 migrant workers have voted to unionize in the hope of winning improved conditions in the fields where they pick blackberries and sow corn and in the barracks where they live.

title: Big Spender at Vanity Fair Raises the Ante for Writers
description: Once in every generation of magazines, a length of time that grows ever shorter, there comes an editor sprinkling gold dust among the nation's writers. In the magazine world of the 1980's, an era of high-style, high-gloss consumer publications, the Good Fairy bears the name Tina Brown, and she makes her home at Vanity Fair.

title: The Touring Pros of the Piano Who Ride the Contest Circuit
description: Like professional tennis players, aspiring pianists follow the competitive tour and chase the rewards. And like their athletic counterparts, the 40 young men and women chosen to battle at the eighth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition will compete against familiar rivals. The two-week event that begins in Fort Worth next month is a particularly inviting stop along the worldwide circuit of musical tournaments, but it is only one of many regularly visited by this small, tight army of competitors.

title: Ms. Waksbaum Becomes a Bride
description: Sherry Waksbaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chanan Waksbaum of Far Rockaway, Queens, and Andrew Baraff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Baraff of Berkeley Heights, N.J., were married yesterday at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi William Horn.

title: A Big Day For the East
description: Harvard and Radcliffe took the championship trophies for men's and women's varsity heavyweight eight-oared crews today at the fourth annual Redwood Shores-Stanford Rowing Classic.

title: Iomega Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lisa A. Kaufman, A Student, Weds
description: Lisa Anne Kaufman and Dr. Walter Delmar Johnson were married yesterday at the Terrace Restaurant in New York by Rabbi Charles Lippman. The bride is the daughter of Dr. Magda S. Kaufman of New York and the late Dr. Lawrence W. Kaufman. Her husband is the son of Dr. and Mrs. C. Delmar Johnson of Singapore.

title: MADRID ENVOY DIES IN BEIRUT SHELLING
description: The Spanish Ambassador to Lebanon and 16 other people were killed today as the capital went through yet another day of heavy shelling by warring Christian and Muslim factions.

title: The American Way: Guns and Death
description: Someone in the United States dies from a gunshot every 16 minutes.

title: Bridge
description: The women gained ground at the finish, but it was the men who won the Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes. When two weeks of continuous play ended midday Saturday at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan, and simultaneously at the Club du Bridgeur in Paris, the men proved to have won by 196 imps. The men had gained steadily since Tuesday, when the score had been virtually tied, but the women salvaged some pride by winning the final day's play by 115 imps. The final margin was a tiny one in view of the length of the effort, by far the longest bridge event ever. It was equivalent to a win by 3 imps in a normal 32-deal match.

title: Greece's Premier Files Libel Suit Against Time
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece is suing Time Inc. for libel in an action to be filed today in London, said his American lawyer, Leonard B. Boudin.

title: Robin A. Katz Marries
description: The marriage of Robin A. Katz and Harry N. Kofler took place yesterday at Congregation Beth Sholom in Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Amos Miller and Cantor Solomon Mendelson officiated. The bride, a ceramic artist who will keep her name, is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Milton Katz of Plainview, L.I. Mr. Kofler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Kofler of Long Beach and Islamorada, Fla., is a commercial estimator and a project manager for Moishe's Moving and Storage Company in New York.

title: Provena Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sales Hall of Fame
description: Malcolm Forbes will be part of another roster of luminaries when he is inducted into the National Sales Hall of Fame. The ceremony tomorrow night is sponsored by the Sales and Marketing Executives of Greater New York. The Forbes magazine publisher will be recognized for achievements in sales and marketing, as will Mary Kay Ash, founder of Mary Kay Cosmetics; J. W. Marriott Jr., chairman of the Marriott Corporation; John H. Johnson, publisher and chairman of the Johnson Publishing Company, and David A. Werblin, former president of the New York Jets. Walter Cronkite will be the host of the ceremony at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Asians in New York Region: Poverty Amid High Ambition
description: Asians living in the New York metropolitan area are better educated, work longer hours and apply less for public assistance than non-Asians, but many continue to live in poverty, according to a detailed study of the community.

title: Outdoors: Promising Outlook for Turkey Season
description: NEW YORK STATE'S spring season for wild turkeys is May 1-31, and a mild winter with little snow has led wildlife biologists to predict that the birds will be more numerous and in better condition than usual.

title: Charles K. McClatchy, 62, Dies; Led Newspaper Company in West
description: Charles K. McClatchy, editor and chairman of the board of McClatchy Newspapers Inc., died yesterday, apparently after suffering a heart attack while jogging. He lived in Sacramento, Calif., and was 62 years old.

title: MOSCOW IMPORTING CONSUMER GOODS TO APPEASE PUBLIC
description: The Soviet Government has quietly begun a major push to buy Western consumer goods, from razor blades and soap powder to women's boots and pantyhose, to pacify consumers anguished by perpetual shortages.

title: Dollar Eases Against Yen
description: The dollar eased against the yen early today, while stock prices rose. The dollar opened at 131.75 yen, down by 0.70 yen, from 132.45 yen on Friday, and stood at 131.67 yen at mid-morning. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 115.72 points, or 0.35 percent, to move to 33,266.16 at the close of the morning session.

title: Diehard Red Sox Fans
description: Even though the Boston Red Sox Class AA farm club is in New Britain, baseball loyalities in Connecticut have long been divided between Yankee, Met and Red Sox fans.

title: Apollo's Chief Cites Benefits of Hewlett Tie
description: When Thomas A. Vanderslice went to Apollo Computer Inc. five years ago, his goal was to take the company to great heights. But last week, Apollo threw in the towel, agreeing to be acquired by the Hewlett-Packard Company for $476.4 million.

title: Thanh Hoa Journal; Then the Bad Party Functionary Lost His Throne
description: He was called the Little King, and for well over two years Ha Trong Hoa used his power and perquisites as provincial party secretary to fire, intimidate and silence those who tried to dethrone him.

title: Avantek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,605,000.

title: Computer Research reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A Landlord Tries to Evict Jesuit Group
description: The residents of the West Side Jesuit Community include a lawyer, a masseur, a poet, a custodian and several teachers. They meet each night for dinner, but most skip the religious service that precedes meals.

title: Shelby Williams Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Inspiration Was a Move
description: A sect of suspected drug smugglers was influenced by a movie called ''The Believers'' at about the time they began performing human sacrifices, the police said Saturday.

title: Met-Coil Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a non-operating gain of $279,000, or 13 cents a share, from the early retirement of debt.

title: Not One of the Elect, But One of the Happy
description: The 40 pianists chosen to compete in the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition have succeeded where 153 of their fellow applicants did not. But not all the losers are really losers. Take the case of Diane Hidy.

title: Review/Television; 'Molly Dodd,' With New Episodes, on Cable
description: Evidently, there is life after network television. Cable is continuing to prove that not only with reruns of old and supposedly ''classic'' series from past decades but also with the continuation of first-rate contemporary series that were unable to survive on network prime time. ''The Paper Chase'' was one example. Now on basic cable's Lifetime television, there is ''The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd.'' It's back - and better than ever.

title: Soviets Debate Space Program
description: Conflicts over the Soviet space program, long debated behind closed doors, are erupting in public because of economic concerns. Page A13.

title: Cubs' Streak Is at 7 As Sutcliffe Wins
description: Rick Sutcliffe won his third straight game and drove in two runs with a bases-loaded single as the Chicago Cubs beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-3, today for their seventh straight victory.

title: Spousal Espousal
description: Voice shaking with outrage, manly tears stinging his eyes, the Speaker of the House rose to defend the honor, good name and integrity of his wife.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Wang Bets Future on New System
description: It was an unusual cameo appearance by one of the patriarchs of the computer industry. Dr. An Wang, the normally reserved 69-year-old chairman of Wang Laboratories, stood amid the glitz of Comdex, a large computer trade show here, excitedly touting his company's new products.

title: New York City Council in Line for New Power, but Is It Ready?
description: The New York City Council, long the stepchild of municipal government, is almost certain to receive vastly expanded power when the City Charter is revised this year. Based on its performance, though, many of the Council's critics and even some of its ardent supporters wonder if it is up to the task.

title: Westin Loses Its New Chief
description: Chieko Nishimura Aoki, named just last month as chief executive and deputy chairman of Westin Hotels and Resorts, has resigned, citing health reasons.

title: G.M. Discloses Top Salaries
description: The General Motors Corporation said Roger B. Smith, its chairman, had earned a total of $3.69 million in 1988, up from $2.38 million the year before.

title: Namibians Accuse Pretoria's Troops
description: Some South African military units, released from their bases with the reluctant assent of the United Nations to fight guerrillas infiltrating into northern Namibia, have been accused of running roughshod over the local population.

title: Crane Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $972,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: Chemist Asserts Backing on Fusion
description: B. Stanley Pons, an electrochemist at the University of Utah who last month threw scientists into turmoil by asserting that he had achieved nuclear fusion in a jar of water at room temperature, said today that 60 laboratories around the world had told him that they had duplicated parts of his work.

title: Business and Health; Controlling Costs: One Good Sign
description: THE early numbers on Allied-Signal Inc.'s daring attempt to control health care costs look so good that the company is wary. They may be too good to be true. The many employers beginning similar arrangements hope not.

title: Reviews/Dance; 2 Young Choreographers Look Back and Reach Out
description: The Mulberry Street Theater is a small, dark corner of what was Public School 23 in Chinatown. It is also a place where theatrical magic seems about to happen. And it did, on Saturday evening, in a program of strong new and recent dances by Marie Alonzo and Mui Cheuk Yin, sensitively lighted by Kim Hanson.

title: Review/Theater; The Fiend and Family Life: Infernal Ingredients
description: Demonism is the subject, hypocrisy the subtext in Dennis Potter's ''Brimstone and Treacle.'' This is Mr. Potter's own stage adaptation of his television play, which later became a movie starring Sting, Denholm Elliott and Joan Plowright. As directed by Rosemary Hay at the Interart Theater, ''Brimstone and Treacle'' is a distinctive Potter's brew, concocted from a recipe of insidious ingredients. The play, staged in sharp, mock-Gothic fashion, is grotesquely amusing.

title: MNC Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dataflex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ameriana Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $102,000.

title: Pentair Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales figures represent net sales.

title: Dauphin Deposit Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Farmers Bank & Trust Co. of Hummelstown in the second quarter and a 5 percent stock dividend paid in February 1989.

BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Prisoner of Rock Wants It Turned Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's N.T.T.: Giant Under Fire
description: For many months now, Haruo Yamaguchi has been struggling to keep the biggest political scandal in Japan's postwar history from splintering Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the biggest company in the world. But more and more people here think that Mr. Yamaguchi, who heads the telecommunications empire, is fighting a lost cause.

title: Quality Food Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
Shiraho Journal; Is Paradise Still a Paradise After It's Paved Over?
description: An article on April 18 about a plan - since altered - to build an airport runway over a blue coral reef in Japan misstated the proposed length.

title: Citizens Savings Bank FSB reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
British Voice Opposition To Monetary Union Plan
description: The British Government gave an immediate and frosty rejection this afternoon to an ambitious plan for monetary union in the European Community.

title: Trapped by Weather in the Middle of Nowhere
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Name For Toothpaste
description: Full-page newspaper advertisements today formally announced that one of the most popular brands of toothpaste in Southeast Asia is changing its name from Darkie to Darlie.

title: Colavita Plans to Step Down As New York's G.O.P. Chief
description: Anthony J. Colavita is stepping down as New York's Republican state chairman as the troubled party attempts to lay the groundwork for next year's campaign against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Comdial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Effect of Oil Spill on Prices
description: Officials of the Department of Energy and the Exxon Corporation told a Senate panel today that the grounding of the Exxon Valdez contributed only negligibly to what has become one of the sharpest retail gasoline price jumps on record.

title: St Paul Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: St. Paul said the latest quarter included gains on the sale of assets totaling $175,000, compared with $2.5 million for the year-ago period. The year-ago quarter included a net charge of $712,000 from the early redemption of notes.

title: Reviews/Dance; Generational Contrasts, As Seen by Works Troupe
description: Jennifer Muller's dances are stylish but not always shapely. They look good; Ms. Muller has an eye for attractive scenery and costumes. Her dancers are talented and her choreography is fluent. But sometimes her works just ramble along. Beneath their trappings, these dances have a bit of choreographic flab.

title: In Wheelchair Division, World Marks Fall
description: Fourteen years after the first wheelchair competitor accepted the challenge of the Boston Marathon and just five years after the wheelchair division was officially accepted as part of the race, five competitors today surpassed the world-best performances.

title: LVI Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $169,000 for the quarter and $307,000 for the year, both from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and after tax credits of $325,000 for the quarter and $1,488,000 for the year, and losses from the early extinguishment of debt of $1,000 for the quarter and $188,000 for the year.

title: Mother Sentenced in Killing
description: A woman who pleaded guilty last June to killing her infant child has been sentenced to a Salvation Army rehabilitation center in Rochester. A judge in the Bronx agreed on Friday to let the woman, Tracey Maye, who faced up to 15 years in prison, spend the next two years at the Salvation Army Adult Rehabilitation Center. Ms. Maye pleaded guilty to beating her 18-month-old daughter, Tess, to death in March 1987, five months after the child had been returned to her from foster care.

title: Telescope's Collapse Tied to Plate
description: THE mysterious collapse of one of the world's most powerful radiotelescopes into a heap of twisted steel and tangled wire last November at the National Radio Astronomy Observatory in Green Bank, W.Va., was caused by the fracture of a critical metal plate, an investigative panel found.

title: Reynolds Metals Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hartz Owner Offers to Build Meadowlands Baseball Stadium
description: Less than 18 months after New Jersey voters overwhelmingly defeated a proposal for the state to build a 45,000-seat baseball stadium in the Hackensack Meadowlands, a developer said today that he would build the stadium and a monorail to serve it.

title: PANEL ACCUSES WRIGHT OF A 'SCHEME TO EVADE' HOUSE RULES ON INCOME
description: The House ethics committee today accused the most powerful man under its jurisdiction, Speaker Jim Wright of Texas, of scheming to evade limits on outside income and taking $145,000 in improper gifts over the last decade.

title: Edward M. Brecher, 77, Is Dead; A Writer on Scientific Subjects
description: Edward M. Brecher, an author of books and magazine articles on medical, scientific and social subjects, was found dead Saturday evening in what was apparently a suicide at his home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: How to Help the Rain
description: After a weekend of rain in New York City the levels of the city's reservoirs rose from 59 percent of capacity. But that's no reason for relief: it rained more in the city than it did over the upstate reservoirs, and they are still barely more than two-thirds full when they should be brimming. Much of the improvement results from the self-discipline of New Yorkers who are learning how to maximize the value of any rain that comes their way.

title: First Chicago Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: First Chicago said the provision for credit losses in the latest quarter was $50 million, compared with $100 million for the year-ago period.

title: Boise Cascade Net Up 14%
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation today reported all-time quarterly records for profits, sales and earnings per share.

title: Reviews/Music; Beethoven Trios by an All-Star Ensemble
description: Beethoven's string trios are not the weightiest or most portentous of his works. They were all composed before he was 30, and they were meant as recreational music, to be played among friends - albeit highly skilled ones.

title: By Design; The Short Cut
description: Right now, if you want to be the first with the latest fashion, make an appointment with a barber.

title: Commodore Environmental reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $4,477,000 on the disposal of a subsidiary. c-Included a write-off of $2,509,000 for expenses related to a canceled public offering and an acquisition recision.

title: Germantown Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $654,000 and $688,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: British Spending Up 3.1%
description: Consumer spending in Britain rose 3.1 percent in March, in line with economists' forecasts and matching February's gain, official figures showed today. The report cheered officials, as any significant gain from February's levels would have raised the possibility of further interest rate increases to choke off inflation, analysts said. But figures on earnings, also released today, showed that wages are rising faster than productivity. The pace of wages per unit increased to 2.9 percent from 2.7 percent, raising concern that wage pressures might push up prices.

title: Exxon's Timetable for Cleanup
description: The Coast Guard Commandant today approved a plan by Exxon to scrub at least 305 miles of shoreline fouled by America's worst oil spill from a tanker, but he demanded that the company also concentrate on oil-tainted beaches outside Prince William Sound.

title: Pesticides Studied in Fight Against Lyme Disease
description: As warm weather approaches and the risk of exposure to Lyme disease increases, health experts say they are studying ways to control the tick species that spreads it, but many questions remain.

title: Eastern Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Applied Magnetics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago quarter and 6 months results included gains of $514,000 and $959,000, respectively, from the retroactive adoption of FASB No. 96. Share earnings for all periods are restated to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend to shareholders of record March 10.

title: Coin Society Benefactor Held in Theft of Its Coins
description: A California surgeon who came to New York to receive an American Numismatic Society award but was instead arrested for stealing its rare coins was released on bail yesterday after promising to return $500,000 in coins he had taken from the society's collections in recent years.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
American Named Head Of Quest International
description: LEAD: Quest International, which has about 12 percent of the world's $6 billion market in flavors, fragrances and specialty food ingredients, has appointed Thomas F. Walsh as its chairman, effective next month.

title: Bushes Attend Brady Fund-Raising Benefit
description: President Bush made a surprise entrance tonight at a fund-raising benefit for the James S. Brady Presidential Foundation, a group founded to assist people, like Mr. Brady, wounded in assassination attempts.

title: Child Dead After Arson Fire
description: A girl believed to be between 4 and 8 years old was found burned to death yesterday in an abandoned building in Brooklyn, the police said. She was wrapped in a blanket and stuffed in a blue travel bag. The girl was found on the first floor after 5 P.M. after the authorities had put out an arson fire at the building at 2045 Union Street in the Brownsville area. The cause of death has not been determined, the police said.

title: Soviet Boxers Agree to Fight as Pros in U.S.
description: Soviet boxers will be turning professional for the first time under an arrangement that will have them coming to the United States for training and bouts.

title: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chess
description: It is no everyday occurrence for the youngest, least tried player in one of the major competitions of the year to take first prize. Yet that is what Vassily Ivanchuk accomplished in the elite, all-grandmaster Linares International Tournament in Spain, which took place from Feb. 19 to March 3.

title: Parker & Parsley reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Public Service of New Mexico reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $200.6 million charge from a regulatory decision and writeoff of assets. c-Net income

title: Town Braces While a Killer Is Loose
description: Cars slowed to a crawl as they passed the ramshackle bungalow on Baines Avenue, and drivers stared with sadness and horror at the three children's cycles beside a blood-stained stoop.

title: LAWMAKERS PLAN $1 BILLION TAX RISE FOR NEW YORKERS
description: New Yorkers will pay almost $1 billion in increased taxes and fees on a wide array of goods and services, including alcohol and tobacco, under an agreement among legislative leaders released today.

title: Kentucky Concedes
description: The University of Kentucky will agree with the National Collegiate Athletic Association that $1,000 was placed inside a package to a recruit sent from the school's basketball office, but it will not concede that the source of the cash was an assistant coach, according to a report Sunday in The Lexington Herald-Leader.

title: William Howard, 61, Film Laboratory Head
description: William Peter Howard, a film reproduction executive, died of a heart attack Friday at Sand Lake Hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 61 years old and lived in New Vernon, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: Sam Wheeler, 64, Harlem Globetrotter

title: Critic's Notebook; Dance and the Influence of Others
description: A few years ago at a college dance festival in Oklahoma, a student company started spinning to a Vivaldi concerto. The work's young choreographer had obviously been influenced by the whirling dances of Laura Dean. Some members of the audience were startled by that acknowledgement of influence. But this critic thought it was just fine for a choreographic novice to be influenced by Ms. Dean - and to show it.

title: U.S. Tobacco Output
description: The nation's tobacco farmers are hoping to increase production this year, and a key reason is the thriving overseas demand for United States cigarettes and unrolled leaf. According to the Agriculture Department, almost one of every six cigarettes made in the United States in 1988 was sold overseas. In response, tobacco farmers have indicated that they intend to plant 713,000 acres this year, up 13 percent from 1988. The department's Economic Research Service says in its latest analysis that cigarette exports rose more than 18 percent last year.

title: 2 Families Among Illinois Lottery Winners
description: Members of two farflung families came forward from four states today to claim half the record $69.9 million Illinois Lotto jackpot, leaving the holders of the two other winning tickets unknown.

description: Sales represent manufacturing sales.

description: * Shelley Diamond has been named senior vice president of Backer Spielvogel Bates.

description: b-Included tax credits of $500,458 and $1,004,952 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Critics Tie Drug to Infants' Deaths
description: A drug commonly prescribed for sedation and colds is linked to sudden infant death syndrome and should not be sold without a prescription, the Public Citizen Health Research Group asserted today. The group urged the Food and Drug Administration to reverse its decision allowing over-the-counter sales of the drug, known by the trade name Phenergan.

Vyquest Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

title: In Darien, a Pre-emptive Strike on Affordable Housing
description: Last year, state politicians declared a housing emergency and established an elaborate system to help suburbs like Darien build subsidized housing for middle-income families. But here in the land of the million-dollar colonial, where $300,000 and luck might get a view of the turnpike, politicians are having none of it.

Morton Thiokol Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $14.1 million from an accounting change. Both latest periods included reorganization and unusual charges of $56 million.

title: In China, Dam's Delay Spares a Valley for Now
description: CHINA'S efforts to build the world's largest hydroelectric project - a structure that would block the Yangtze River, obliterate some of the nation's most famous scenery and force the removal of a million people - have suffered another setback after six decades of debate.

Dallas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Here are the five counts of the report of the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct charging Speaker Jim Wright with violations of House rules, and excerpts of the particulars for each count. Along with the charges are excerpts from the defense prepared by Mr. Wright's lawyers, given when the Speaker responded on March 7 to the committee's inquiry. Representative Julian C. description: The Gannett Company, the nation's biggest newspaper chain and a vigorous opponent of unions, is facing a strong organizing effort at its daily newspaper here.

description: Year-ago quarter figures included results of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Mid-Amercia, which was sold by the company in December.

title: Honoring a Car Thats Still as Frisky as a Colt at Age 25
description: Wearing a bright red Mustang baseball jacket, which matched her fake red Mustang snakeskin cigarette case, which matched her red Mustang cigarette lighter, which matched her 1970 Mustang car, Trudy Kent-Montalbano, president of the Long Island region's Classic Mustang Club, explained the Ford Mustang's enduring appeal.

description: The latest quarter net included an after-tax gain of $3,093,000 from the sale of the company's National City Bank of Ridgedale subsidiary and related land and building.

Bush Unveils Aid Plan for Poland Linked to Recent Liberalization
description: Declaring that ''the winds of change are shaping a new European destiny,'' President Bush today announced an economic aid program for Poland that acknowledges Warsaw's recent agreement to allow free elections.

title: Arab League Is Summoned As Toll in Lebanon Mounts
description: As heavy artillery exchanges continued between Muslim and Christian forces, the 21-nation Arab League was called to a special session today to discuss the violence in Lebanon.

title: Fiber-Optic Calling to Japan Starts Today
description: A fiber-optic communications cable that can carry 40,000 simultaneous telephone conversations goes into service today between the United States and Japan. The new cable will vastly increase the number of calls and the amount of information that can be transmitted between the countries.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Reviews/Music; Singly, a Group's Members Offer 20th-Century Works
description: The printed description of Sunday afternoon's concert at Town Hall did not have it quite right. This was not, as stated, the Emerson Quartet appearing with the Hartt Wind Symphony, but only the ingredients of the Emerson Quartet. There were four string-solo concertos on this fascinating 20th-century program, and each member took his turn.

title: Nature's Sunshine Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $43,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: First Michigan Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NCR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Giants Leave 3 Players Open to Free Agency
description: The Giants have left Jeff Rutledge, Ottis Anderson and Karl Nelson unprotected, making them free to sign with any other National Football League team without compensation to the Giants. However, the Giants also indicated they hoped all would stay with the team.

title: Stocks Mixed, Awaiting Economic Data
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday as many investors stayed on the sidelines awaiting more news on the economy.

title: Not-Guilty Plea
description: Thomas Gioiosa, who once lived with the Cincinnati Reds' manager, Pete Rose, and his family, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Cincinnati to a Federal indictment charging him with tax evasion and conspiracy to distribute cocaine. United States Magistrate Robert Steinberg allowed Gioiosa to remain free on bond.

title: Charlotte C. Handy, Decorator, 97
description: Charlotte C. Handy, retired head of Thedlow Decorators, a New York decorating concern, died of pneumonia yesterday at her home in Old Lyme, Conn. She was 97 years old. In 1919, she opened the business, which has since closed, at 146 East 55th Street in Manhattan. After serving clients on the East Side for many years, she retired in 1974.

title: Our Towns; A Road Atlas To Lyme Disease And Other Ills
description: The pilgrims who arrived in New England 300 years ago weren't too creative when they christened a territory. For colonies, they often just translated from an Indian dialect: Quinnehtukqut became Connecticut. For towns, they usually took a name from home: Lyme, England, became Lyme, Conn.

title: Peoples Westchester Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $340,000.

title: Vernon J. Harward, Professor, 66
description: Vernon J. Harward, who taught early English literature at Smith College for 26 years, died Sunday at his home in Arlington, Mass., after a long illness. He was 66 years old. Professor Harward, who received his doctorate at Columbia University in 1953, was on the faculty at Smith College, in Northampton, Mass., from 1962 to 1988 and was a former chairman of the English department there. He previously taught at City College, New York City.

title: Patterns
description: Roar of the Retailers

title: Control Data Plans Shifts To End Slide
description: In a new attempt to halt a six-year financial slide, the Control Data Corporation yesterday announced a far-reaching reorganization under which it will leave the supercomputer business, cut back on its mainstream computer systems and eliminate 3,100 jobs, or about 10 percent of its work force.

title: Texas Air Says Eastern Will Be Shrunk, Not Sold
description: In a move widely viewed as a negotiating ploy in its strike and bankruptcy case, the Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that it would not sell Eastern Airlines but would reduce the airline's size and raise cash through large sales of assets.

title: Mapco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Connecticut Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge
description: The oldest champion and the youngest champion were partners in the final stage of the Marathon Battle of the Sexes last week. One was 96-year-old Jay Feigus of Middletown, N.J., who appears to own the longest participation streak in any event in any competitive field: He has played in every Goldman Pairs in New York City since that event was instituted in 1929, and plans to play again, for the 62d time, next month. He is a past Vanderbilt Knockout Champion who clearly recalls the wild slam bid he made to win that event in 1948, and he recently won an event in Pennsylvania for the second straight year.

title: General Signal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WASHINGTON TALK: DIPLOMACY
description: Ever since the bipartisan accord with Congress on Central America was hammered out, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has been hammering on Moscow to use its economic leverage with the Sandinistas to compel them to comply with the peace plan. Virtually every public statement by Mr. Baker on Central America contains a challenge to the Soviets to demonstrate some real ''new thinking'' by unilaterally withdrawing aid to Managua.

title: U.S. Staff Backs Full Shoreham License
description: In an action likely to prove largely symbolic, the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today recommended granting a full-power operating license for the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.L. Laboratories Inc., Fort Lee, N.J., a pharmaceutical manufacturer, named Jack Van Hulst executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: John Poole, 76, Dies; A Broadcasting Chief
description: John B. Poole, a lawyer and broadcasting executive, died Friday at his winter home in Miami Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 76 years old. Mr. Poole was a graduate of the University of Chicago and of the Detroit College of Law. He lived in suburban Detroit for more than 50 years.

title: Viola at Standstill
description: Frank Viola's reversal in seeking to accept the Minnesota Twins' $7.9 million contract offer hit a wall when the Twins retracted the offer, and both sides said yesterday that negotiations were over for the time being.

title: Schramm to Leave Cowboys for New Post
description: Tex Schramm, an innovative force in the National Football League and the Dallas Cowboys' only general manager since the team was founded in 1960, will resign in New York today as the Cowboys' president and general manager and will accept a leadership role in the N.F.L.'s intercontinental development league, which is scheduled to start next spring.

title: Standard Motor Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Expos Win and Halt Cubs' Winning Streak at 7
description: The Chicago Cubs' seven-game winning streak ended tonight as Andres Galarraga hit a two-run homer in the sixth inning to give the Montreal Expos a 2-1 victory.

title: Valero Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Roy Sparkles as Canadiens Edge Bruins
description: The Montreal Canadiens, led by the spectacular goaltending of Patrick Roy and an opportunistic offense, beat the Boston Bruins, 3-2, tonight in the first game of the Adams Division final.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After $40 million in tax benefits and income from the sale of a subsidiary. The provision for possible credit losses was $99 million in the latest first quarter, compared with $142 million for the year-ago period.

title: Former School To Be Converted To AIDS Home
description: A former public school building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan will be converted into a nursing home for people suffering from AIDS, the Mayor announced yesterday.

title: Review/Television; A New Extended Family Calls a Rectory Home
description: Television's extended families know no boundaries, reaching from the newsroom gang on ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' to the barroom regulars on ''Cheers.'' Now Nat Mauldin, once a staff writer for ''Barney Miller'' and its close-knit brood of New York detectives, has developed with Jerome Lew and Alicia Ulrich a series called ''Have Faith.'' The family in this instance consists of four Roman Catholic priests living in a Chicago rectory. They are being given a trial run on ABC beginning tonight at 9:30, right after ''Roseanne.''

title: First Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Committee Books Are Still Open on a Well Venture in Texas
description: Although the House ethics committee issued a comprehensive report today on many allegations against Jim Wright, it is still investigating a transaction by which Mr. Wright, George Mallick and their wives acquired part of an unsuccessful oil and gas well and then sold it at a sizable profit.

Inflation Rises in Europe
description: Consumer prices in the European Community rose by five-tenths of a percent in February, pushing the 12-month inflation rate to a three-year high of 5 percent, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today. The rate, only 3 percent a year ago, is the highest since January 1986, when it reached 5.3 percent. Among those registering the highest monthly increases in February were Portugal, with a rate of 1.4 percent; Italy, with eight-tenths of a percent, and Britain, seven-tenths of a percent.

title: Q&A
description: 'Weight' of Earth Q.How much does the Earth weigh? A.''What we think of as weight is the gravitational pull of the Earth itself on a person or object,'' said Andrew Franknoi, an astronomer, who is the executive officer of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific. Therefore, he said, asking the Earth's weight is essentially meaningless, because it has weight only in relation to another object.

Allders operates the duty-free shops at the Heathrow and Gatwick Airports in London, and the unit has interests in Europe, North and South America and Australia. Hanson, one of Britain's 10 largest companies, whose interests range from bricks and tobacco to bathroom fixtures and food, said it would retain a 5 percent stake in Allders.

title: Reviews/Music; A Mahler Third With Its Feet On the Ground
description: Catherine Comet conducted the American Symphony Orchestra in Mahler's sprawling Third Symphony at Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon, and the first testimony to her powers of leadership must be the observation that the orchestra has rarely - never, in the experience of this listener -played so well. The orchestra's composition hovers somewhere between regular freelance and pickup, a situation that cannot be expected to produce the cohesion of a major standing ensemble. Nevertheless, Miss Comet achieved an impressive blend and unity of gesture.

title: Ethics Committee: Speaker's Peers In the House
description: The Republicans 1. Charles Pashayan Jr., California Age 48 . . . elected to Congress 1978, member of the ethics committee since 1987 . . . subject of letter-writing campaign by conservative groups lobbying for strong action against Wright . . . moderate Republican. 3. James V. Hansen, Utah Age 56 . . . elected to Congress 1980, member of the committee since 1981 . . . conservative Republican who voted against the committee's recommendation censuring Rep. George Hansen of Idaho in 1984. 4. Larry E. Craig, Idaho Age 43 . . . elected to Congress 1980; committee member since 1987 . . . conservative Republican who voted against reprimand of Rep. George Hansen in 1984. 8. Thomas E. Petri, Wisconsin Age 48 . . . elected to Congress 1979, member of the committee since 1987 . . . moderate and independent Republican, one of the few committee members who volunteered for this assignment. 9. Hank Brown, Colorado Age 48 . . . elected to Congress 1980, member of the committee since 1988 (also served 1981-1984) . . . conservative Republican with an independent streak who has said he hoped the ethics committee would be more aggressive. 10. John T. Myers, Indiana Age 62 . . . elected to Congress 1966, committee member since 1981 . . . old-line, moderate Republican committed to bipartisanship . . . long congressional career makes his approach to the new ethics questionable. The Democrats 2. Vic Fazio, California Age 46 . . . elected to Congress 1978, member of the committee since 1983 . . . named by Wright to bipartisan task force reviewing House ethics standards . . . suspected by some Republicans, who asked him to disqualify himself from the investigation, of being too close to Wright. 5. Alan B. Mollohan, West Virginia Age 45 . . . elected to Congress 1982, member of the committee since 1985 . . . voted against an early 1988 contra aid proposal, ignoring wishes of Wright. . . . Voted against bringing charges against Wright. 6. Bernard J. Dwyer, New Jersey Age 68 . . elected to the House in 1980, member of the committee since 1985 . . . low-key insider, regarded as reliable vote for the leadership. 7. Chester G. Atkins, Massachusetts Age 41 . . . elected to Congress 1984, member of the committee since 1987 . . . one of two Democrats who have joined the committee since Wright became Speaker; has said he never discussed the assignment with Wright. 11. Julian C. Dixon, California Age 54 . . . Chairman of the committee . . . elected 1978, member of the committee since 1983 . . . responsible for building bipartisan consensus within the committee . . . has taken heat for committee record of finding members guilty of violating House rules but failing to punish them. Joseph M. Gaydos, Pennsylvania Age 62 . . . elected to the House in 1968, member of the committee since 1987 . . . . . . Often broke rank with the committee to vote against bringing charges against Wright. The Lawyers 12. Richard J. Phelan Special legal counsel investigating Wright Age 52 . . . founding partner in Chicago law firm of Phelan, Pope & John Ltd. . . . delegate to the 1988 Democratic National Convention, pledged to Senator Paul Simon. William C. Oldaker Wright's attorney Age 47. . . partner in Washington branch of the Los Angeles law firm Manatt Phelps Rothenberg & Evans . . . Joined the Federal Election Commission in 1975 as Assistant General Counsel and became General Counsel to the F.E.C. in 1977. Left in 1979 to become counsel-treasurer for Senator Edward M. Kennedy's 1980 presidential election committee.

title: Weak Bones Linked To Anorexia
description: Teen-age women whose menstrual periods are disrupted as a result of anorexia nervosa, a dieting disorder, go on to have significantly weaker bones than women who become anorexic later in life, a new study has found. This suggests that normal sexual development in adolescence is crucial to healthy bones, the researchers said.

title: Books About MS-DOS

If you use a computer primarily for designing graphics, making music or playing games, or perhaps for desktop publishing, you are undoubtedly better off with boxes that have Macintosh, Amiga or Atari ST printed on them; if you use a computer for business or businesslike purposes, you are probably running PC-DOS or MS-DOS.

I would have been nothing, nothing but a sassy little brat if it hadn't been for books,'' she said in ''Particular Passions,'' a collection of interviews with notable American women.

title: Survival Of the Fetus: A Barrier Is Reached
description: ALTHOUGH doctors have made great progress in helping severely premature infants survive, they have been unable to overcome a seemingly impenetrable barrier: if a baby is born before 23 or 24 weeks of pregnancy, experts say, it simply cannot survive. And nothing that medical science can do will budge that boundary in the foreseeable future.

description: The top-ranked ''junk bond'' mutual fund manager in the country has taken a six-month leave of absence, officials at Kemper Financial Services Inc. say.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6.2 million and a $2.7 million gain from an accounting change.

title: Killing of 49 Patients By 4 Nurse's Aides Stuns the Austrians
description: Pavilion V of the Lainz Hospital lies hard against a long, gentle slope of the Vienna Woods. But the pastoral setting is a thin veneer over the scene of what Chancellor Franz Vranitzky called ''the most brutal and gruesome crime in Austria's history.''

Amnesty Urges New Inquiry Into Gibraltar I.R.A. Deaths
description: Amnesty International called today for a judicial inquiry into the killing of three Irish Republican Army guerrillas by British troops in Gibraltar a year ago.

title: First American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1988 have been restated to account for acquisitions during the year.

title: Honoring a Car That's Still as Frisky as a Colt at Age 25
description: Wearing a bright red Mustang baseball jacket, which matched her fake red Mustang snakeskin cigarette case, which matched her red Mustang cigarette lighter, which matched her 1970 Mustang car, Trudy Kent-Montalbano, president of the Long Island region's Classic Mustang Club, explained the Ford Mustang's enduring appeal.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 An economic aid plan for Poland that includes eight basic points was announced by President Bush, who said Eastern Europe was slowly changing systems. Page A1

title: Thieves Return One Of 3 Stolen van Goghs
description: Thieves have returned one of three Vincent van Gogh paintings stolen from the Kroller-Muller National Museum in December in hope of getting a $2.5 million ransom, the police here said today.

title: Reducing AIDS Risk
description: A study of gay and bisexual men in New York has found that reducing the number of sexual partners or becoming monogamous does not significantly decrease the risk of contracting the AIDS virus. Only a halting of anal intercourse substantially reduced the likelihood of contracting the virus, the study determined.

title: Market Place; Blue-Chips, Profits And Performance
description: BETTING against Wall Street is said by some to be the way to wealth. Certainly, it is the foundation of contrarian investing. But so far this year, one way of measuring market performance indicates analysts are getting it right.

A Mixed Profit Report From Banks
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported lower first-quarter earnings yesterday than a year ago, when they had unusual profits earned from the sale of assets.

ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included gains from the repurchase of debt of $2,158,000 for the latest quarter and $2,035,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: 5 Palestinians Reported Killed by Israel in Second Highest Daily Toll of the Uprising
description: Five Palestinians died today after being shot or beaten by Israeli troops, and a sixth was killed when soldiers ordered him to climb an electricity pole to remove a Palestinian flag, Arabs said.

title: Modern Concerns Enrich Passover Rituals
description: Jeffrey Bomser, who is 37 years old and has AIDS, looked at the symbols on the Passover table yesterday - the parsley, the egg and the matzoh - and saw ''spring and rebirth.''
