Destiny Beckons, but Is the City Council Ready for Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Archer-Daniels-Midland Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 9 months results are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid September.

title: Late Flourish by Jordan Defeats Knicks
description: Michael Jordan has a knack of taking over a game and tonight he gave the Knicks a taste of it in the final quarter.

title: Here's a 'Tax' Bush Could Love
description: The budget agreement between President Bush and Congressional leaders calls for $5.3 billion in new taxes. With the President up to his lips in a no-tax pledge, lawmakers are understandably wondering where the money will come from. I have a suggestion: re-enact the withholding for taxes due on dividend and interest payments.

title: KEY RATES
Escaped Convict Surrenders After 28 Years as a Fugitive
description: An inmate who escaped from prison 28 years ago and lived under his father's name has turned himself in to finish his sentence.

title: United Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $1 million from discontinued operations. The company said it enjoyed strong across the board performance by all of its units, with U.S. Sprint now steeping solidly into the profit column with operating income of $27.5 million. U.S. Spring is a joint venture between United Telecommunications and GTE Corp. and in the year-ago period reported a loss of $124 million.

title: Shaklee Offer Done
description: The Shaklee Corporation said a unit of the Yamanouchi Pharmaceutical Company of Japan had completed a tender offer for all outstanding shares of Shaklee common stock at $28 each. The offer expired at midnight on Friday. The Yamanouchi unit will own about 92 percent of the common shares of Shaklee, which specializes in the direct sale of food, health products and other products.

title: Synalloy Gets Bid
description: Chariot Holdings Ltd., an investment company in New York, has offered to buy the shares of the Synalloy Corporation that it does not control for $10 each in cash. Synalloy, based in Spartansburg, S.C., is a specialty chemical manufacturer. Its stock closed today at $8.75 a share, up 12.5 cents, on the American Stock Exchange. Chariot, which owns 20 percent of Synalloy, would pay $30.7 million for the remaining shares. A Synalloy spokesman was unavailable to comment.

title: Richard Horn Is Dead; Design Critic Was 34
description: Richard Horn, a writer and design critic, died yesterday at New York University Hospital. He was 34 years and lived in Manhattan.

title: Eli Lilly's Profit Rises 22.1%; Upjohn Posts 7.9% Increase
description: Two major drug companies yesterday reported higher first-quarter earnings, with Eli Lilly & Company posting a 22.1 percent increase and the Upjohn Company posting a 7.9 percent rise.

title: Stadium Changes Hinted in Britain After Disaster
description: The Government announced a wide-ranging inquiry today into the disaster at an English soccer stadium in which 94 people died, and it indicated that major stadiums might have to replace standing-room areas with seats.

title: Cairo Aide's Ouster Tied to Effort to Get Missile Parts in U.S.
description: President Hosni Mubarak's removal of his Defense Minister may be related specifically to clandestine Egyptian efforts to acquire American missile materials, diplomats and Egyptian journalists say.

title: Judge Calls For Sentencing On Rikers I.
description: Saying that ''no greater crisis'' faces New York City's criminal-justice system than the growing tide of crack-related arrests, New York State's highest-ranking judge announced emergency measures yesterday to help the courts keep up with the thousands of new cases, including makeshift courtrooms on Rikers Island to sentence prisoners.

title: U.S. Stops Acquisition By Japanese
description: The Bush Administration has temporarily blocked the proposed Japanese purchase of a New Jersey company, General Ceramics Inc., that is involved in a nuclear weapons contract using critical technology.

title: Madison Journal; City Embraces Symbol Of Its More Radical Past
description: When Paul Soglin was elected Mayor here 16 years ago, he was branded a radical, a troublemaker and a threat to the social order. In Madison, that was not such a bad image.

title: The N.F.L. Needs 11 Rozelles
description: rrWhen the National Football League owners meet today to discuss candidates to succeed Pete Rozelle as commissioner, they will debate whether the job is too much for one man now. One theory is that it should be shared by two people. One would symbolize the N.F.L.'s red-white-and-blue shield while the other tried to solve its legal and labor problems.

title: Review/Concert; The Gewandhaus Orchestra
description: Kurt Masur and the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig spent the last two weekends performing in New York, with the pianist Andre Watts as their soloist in Beethoven concertos. On Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Masur, Mr. Watts and company brought their series to a close with the Beethoven ''Emperor'' Concerto, the bright spot in a program that also included works by Mendelssohn and Schumann.

title: General Building Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
First City Bancorp of Texas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Comparative results for the year- ago period are unavailable because the company recapitalized in April 1988.

title: Corn and Soybean Prices Up On Dry-Weather Troubles
description: Corn and soybean prices climbed yesterday as continued dry weather over most of the Middle West presented farmers with two vexing problems as they prepared to sow spring crops. But wheat prices eased on profit taking after surging late last week.

description: b-Included tax credits of $69,000 and $128,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $142,000 and $1 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Henry H. Bolz, 75, Accounting Professor
description: Prof. Henry H. Bolz, who worked at Fordham University for 30 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Brookville, L.I. He was 75 years old.

title: Crestar Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: First quarter loan loss provision was $10 million, compared with a $15 million provision in the year-ago first quarter.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Leningrad Ads In Time Issue
description: A special advertising supplement in the current issue of Time magazine demonstrates that glasnost has finally trickled into the world of advertising. Time and the city of Leningrad have collaborated to produce a 12-page special advertising supplement that celebrates the city's cultural charms and commercial importance. In an introductory letter, the

title: Frederic Lawrence, 89, Episcopal Bishop
description: The Rev. Frederic C. Lawrence, the retired Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts, died Sunday at his home in Brookline, Mass., after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Mestek Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Board Member to Run Joy Technologies
description: Joy Technologies Inc., a big Pittsburgh-based maker of underground mining equipment that was taken over in a leveraged buyout in 1986, yesterday named an International Paper executive who is a member of its board, Marc F. Wray, as its new chairman and chief executive.

title: Seagate Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Sales represent net sales.

title: Upjohn Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Independent Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Expert Behind Budget Tells a Tale of Change
description: When Congressional leaders and the White House settle on a budget agreement, to a considerable degree the work is not of politicians but of professionals.

title: Motorola Presents Chips for Controls
description: Motorola Inc. introduced a new family of chips for computer control of automobiles and electronic appliances. The company said the General Motors Corporation had agreed to use the chip to control functions in future automobiles. The chips, called microcontrollers, are more specialized versions of the microprocessors used in personal computers. Microcontrollers contain memory and other parts of a computer on the same chip, whereas microprocessors contain only the central processing unit.

title: British Press Scandal: The British Press
description: The British press is under increasing criticism for one of its most pungent distinguishing features - recklessness.

title: Bennett Tries to Smooth Rift Over Barry
description: At first glance, it seemed that William J. Bennett, a man who is not afraid of confrontation, had picked an easy target: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. The Mayor of Washington, crippled by rumors unfolding that he has used drugs, accusations which he denies, is not the popular politician he once was.

title: Fair or Foul?
description: Ponder now with me some recent questions of guilt and/or innocence: 1. Men of Principle. In the House of Representatives, two Democrats on the Ethics Committee joined six Republicans in important votes against Speaker Jim Wright, a Texas Democrat - whereupon another Texas Democrat, Jack Brooks, promptly advised the two errant Democrats to ''pray.'' Still another Texas Democrat, Charles Wilson, observed that when the issue comes to the floor, ''about 24 yellow-belly, turncoat'' Democrats would vote against the Speaker but ''about that many men of principle'' from the Republican side would vote for him.

title: Review/Television; The Shakespeare Mystery: Who Was He?
description: ''Frontline,'' the admirable public-affairs series that has brought us sharp reports this season on Ronald Reagan and Jesse Jackson, the troubles of Eastern Air Lines and the rain forest of Brazil, and illegal drugs and prescription drugs, takes an unaccustomed turn tonight to the 16th century. The issue explored in ''The Shakespeare Mystery'' is whether Shakespeare was in fact somebody named something like Shakespeare, of Stratford-on-Avon, or whether he was somebody else, in particular Edward de Vere, the 17th Earl of Oxford and an important figure in Queen Elizabeth's court. Any doubt that the matter retains urgency for some Shakespeare lovers is laid to rest at 10 tonight on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channel 49.

title: Norwest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Central Jersey Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pair Finds Substance To Curb Blood Vessels
description: AN unusual collaboration between a Harvard doctor and a professor with a background in petrochemical research has produced a substance that seems to stop the abnormal growth of blood vessels. The discovery might eventually lead to drugs that combat blindness, cancer and other diseases.

title: Books of The Times; Ah, Comes the Spring and Love Liberates Logic
description: The Late-Summer Passion of a Woman of Mind By Rebecca Goldstein 261 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Williams Next For Tyson?
description: A heavyweight title bout between Mike Tyson and Carl (the Truth) Williams appeared closer to becoming a reality yesterday. Bill Cayton, manager of the heavyweight champion, told Williams's promoter, Stan Hoffman, he had no objection to Hoffman's negotiating with Tyson's adviser and would-be promoter, Don King.

title: Equimark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Parker Hannifin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KEY RATES
Grey Sets Up Europe Board
description: Grey Advertising today announced the establishment of a European Management Board to help the agency prepare for an onslaught of Pan-European advertising expected when trade barriers are eliminated in Western Europe in 1992.

title: Backer Spielvogel
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates yesterday landed the business of the Kobacker Company, a shoe-store chain. The account, which will be handled by the B.M.B. offices in New York and Columbus, Ohio, is worth $4.5 million, a spokesman for the agency said. Kobacker runs 312 shoe stores across the country, under the names Gussini, Patrini and Shoe Works. The account had been handled by Shelly Berman Communicators of Columbus.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Charles Schwab Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the gain of 27 percent in revenue is due primarily to continued growth in interest revenue resulting from increases in customer credit balances. At the end of this year's first quarter, customer credit balances were up more than 40 percent from a year ago. Interest revenue net of interest expense was $15.2 million in this year's first quarter, up 90 percent from $8 million in last year's first quarter.

title: First Indiana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
60-Minute Gourmet
description: A CLASSIC and simple dish that is the staple of many home cooks in France, and to a lesser degree in this country, is chicken livers with onions. Chicken livers are among the least expensive meats you can find in the supermarket, and they are ideally suited to fast cooking.

title: NICARAGUA INDIANS PLANNING A RETURN
description: Two leaders of Miskito Indian rebels say that they plan to return to Nicaragua within 60 days and that if they obtain financial aid from the United States and Western Europe they will urge 35,000 Indian refugees in Honduras to go home as quickly as possible.

title: Consolidated Freightways Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TCF Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
West Bank Woman Called a Collaborator Is Slain
description: A Palestinian woman was stabbed to death by masked youths in the occupied West Bank on Monday night, and Arabs said today that she was killed because she collaborated with Israel's security agency.

title: Senate Acts On Bush Plan
description: The Senate began voting today on amendments to the Bush Administration's rescue plan for the savings industry, with the leadership of the Banking Committee and the full Senate hoping to limit, if not block altogether, the number accepted.

title: Banc One Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the 1988 mergers with Marine Corp. of Milwaukee and Universal Corp. of Ypsilanti, Mich.

title: Ann Taylor Stores
description: Ann Taylor Inc., the fashion retailer, will open 17 stores by November in 13 cities in 7 states, Joseph E. Brooks, the company's chairman and chief executive, said. Ann Taylor operates 120 stores in 25 states and Washington. Of the 17 new stores, two have been opened near Pittsburgh and the others are expected to be open by the end of November. Stores in Miami, San Francisco and Stamford, Conn., will also be expanded.

title: American Republic Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Survey Shows More People Take Cholesterol Seriously
description: Nearly twice as many adults say they know their cholesterol level compared with last year, and 44 percent say they have adopted diets lower in cholesterol in the last two years, a new Gallup Poll shows.

title: South Carolina University To Halt Visitation in Dorms
description: Reversing more than a decade in which men and women were allowed to visit each other overnight in college dormitories, the University of South Carolina board of trustees has voted to halt such visitation by the 1992-93 school year.

title: Abbie Hoffman Committed Suicide Using Barbiturates, Autopsy Shows
description: Abbie Hoffman, the clown prince of radical protest whose life and death seemed a synonym for the 1960's, committed suicide with a huge dose of barbiturates, a Pennsylvania coroner ruled yesterday.

title: A Storm Swirls Over Eligibility at Iowa
description: When Hunter Rawlings 3d, the president of the University of Iowa, announced his intention to bar freshman athletes from participating in or practicing any sports if the National Collegiate Athletic Association did not enact a similar ban nationally within three years, he caused a storm of controversy that swept the state.

title: Topics of The Times; Justice Takes a Nap
description: ''A disinterested judge,'' our vocabulary teacher used to say, ''is one who keeps an open mind, while an uninterested judge is one who sleeps on the bench.'' New Yorkers can find plenty of the first kind of judge in local courtrooms any day of the week, but on Monday they got a rare glimpse of the second.

title: United Bankers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter results included a gain of about $9.7 million from the removal of the company's deficit investment in the First Bank and Trust of Bryan, which was taken over by federal regulators in February.

title: Aristech Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $23,700,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago figures have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid April 17.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashton-Tate Corp., Torrance, Calif., a computer software designer, said Richard F. DiGiovanni had resigned as president of its Tate Publishing division.

title: Pfizer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company reported first quarter sales gains in three of its segments: health care up 14 percent; consumer products up 45 percent, aided by the acquisition of Plax, a newly acquired dental rinse product; and materials science up 4 percent.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Up Sharply
description: Treasury bond prices rose to their highest levels in more than two months and short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday after Government reports showed inflation was no worse than expected and housing starts had weakened sharply.

title: Kristiansen Setting Her Sights on New York and Waitz
description: Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway had already demonstrated why she holds a pre-eminent position among female distance runners in the world. Today, she continued her effort to become all-Oslo.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Consumer prices climbed 0.5 percent in March, maintaining a 6.1 percent annual inflation rate for the first quarter. The latest increases were greeted with relief by investors, and stock and bond prices rose sharply. [ Page A1. ] Consumer prices in the New York area jumped 1 percent, the sharpest increase since August. [ D5. ] Construction of new homes and apartments dropped 5.4 percent in March. That followed a 12 percent drop in February. [ D5. ] The Supreme Court ruled that state laws may permit consumers to bring antitrust suits barred under Federal law. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Drexel Burnham Lambert will shed its retail brokerage and cut back other operations, reducing its work force by a third. [ D1. ] NWA stock jumped $7.125, to $97.375, after the parent of Northwest Airlines said it was considering options to fend off a takeover by Marvin Davis. Mr. Davis said he had arranged for more than $3 billion in financing. [ D1. ] Eli Lilly and Dow Chemical will combine worldwide agricultural chemical divisions in a joint venture. [ D1. ] Earnings rose sharply at Citicorp and Bankers Trust for the first quarter. Wells Fargo announced a smaller increase. [ D1. ] MCI, GTE, United Telecommunications and Southwestern Bell announced moderate to substantial increases in earnings. [ D1. ] Morgan Stanley and Bear Stearns reported sharp drops in earnings for the quarter. [ D5. ] Four major drug companies reported strong earnings in the first quarter. [ D4. ] Boeing received the largest order in its history, for 182 aircraft worth $9.4 billion, from the GPA Group of Ireland. [ D4. ] Ramada will sell its hotel chain to New World Development for $540 million, in order to concentrate on its casinos. [ D4. ] MARKETS The stock market staged a strong rally, as the Dow Jones industrial average surged to a post-crash high, up 41.61 points, to 2,379.40. The Dow Jones transportation average reached a historic peak. [ D1. ] Prices on long-term Government bonds rose sharply, pushing interest rates below 9 percent. [ D15. ] Prices of crude oil advanced to their highest level since July 1987, largely on the continued demand for unleaded gasoline. [ D16. ] The dollar fell against most major currencies. [ D16. ] Yields were slightly higher for C.D.'s and bank money-market accounts in the week ended yesterday. [ D15. ] The Chicago Merc is expected to limit ''dual trading,'' especially on near-term contracts. [ D7. ] INTERNATIONAL Mexico and its commercial-bank lenders open talks today on reducing the country's debt and interest payments. [ D2. ] Argentina clamped strict controls on all prices and said it would authorize increases only once a month. [ D2. ] TECHNOLOGY The search for oil is changing because of rapid advances in color three-dimensional computer graphics. [ D6. ] Apple and Lotus reported decreased earnings for the quarter ended March 31. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Why not peddle Eastern to a European airline willing to pay for an American foothold? Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Two of the hottest closed-end mutual funds have been those investing in stocks in Brazil and Mexico. Market Place. [ D8. ] The merger of D'Arcy MacManus Masius and Benton & Bowles has not proved the disaster that London's advertising community foresaw. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D17. ]

title: Stanford Reports Success
description: A team of scientists at Stanford University said yesterday that they had duplicated the experiment in which nuclear fusion was reportedly achieved in a jar of water at room temperature. The Stanford researchers said they measured heat but not radiation or subatomic particles that are often produced by nuclear fusion.

title: People
description: * Malachy Walsh has been appointed senior vice president of J. Walter Thompson, Chicago.

title: Computer Sale to Soviets
description: A United States marketing company said Monday that it would sell 1,500 laptop computers made in Hong Kong to the Soviet Union for use by reporters for Tass, the Soviet Government's official press agency. Holographic Systems Inc. said the Defense Department had tried to block the $2.1 million sale of computers with Cyrillic keyboards but that it had received Commerce Department approval.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization
