description: b-After charges from the early extinguishment of debt of $270,000 and $916,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Lessons
description: The world of Mario Salvadori has ranged from Rome, where he was born, to the halls of Columbia University, where he taught engineering and architecture for half a century, to the great cities of the world for which he designed his skyscrapers.

title: How Medicare Surtax Is Dividing Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Flames Win in Overtime; Blackhawks Defeat Blues
description: Doug Gilmour scored 7 minutes 47 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Calgary Flames a 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings in the first game of the Smythe Division finals.

title: Government Outlines Its Plan To Get Families Off Welfare
description: The Government today outlined its plan for states to help poor families get off welfare and become self-sufficient by requiring aid recipients to participate in education, job training and work programs.

title: E W Scripps reports earnings for
description: The company said operating income for cable operations in the latest quarter climbed to $4,528,000 from $1,125,000 in the year-ago first quarter. The increase in earnings was due primarily to higher operating income from its Sacrmaneto, Calif., cable television system.

title: Italian Researchers Report Achieving Nuclear Fusion
description: Italian Government scientists said today that they had achieved nuclear fusion in a simple experiment related to one carried out by scientists in Utah, but that they had used different materials and techniques.

title: KHASHOGGI SEIZED BY SWISS OFFICIALS
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi financier who was a central figure in billions of dollars of arms sales over the last two decades, was arrested by the police in Switzerland today.

title: Book Notes
description: A Star Writer, Too

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a program to educate students about the problem of weapons in New York City schools misidentified the woman shown at the left. She was Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, not Nancy Wenig, the class's teacher.

title: Rayonier Timberlands, LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reduced by $1 million in commission expense from a sales agency agreement with an ITT Rayonier Inc.- affiliated foreign sales corporation. The commissions did not affect unit income, however, as the entire commission is being allocated to the interests owned and controlled by ITT Rayonier. Net income represents partnership income, and share earnings are in units.

title: Automatic Data Processing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Capitol Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Yzerman Leads Canada: The high-scoring captain of the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League, Steve Yzerman, playing his first game of the tournament, scored three goals yesterday as Canada defeated the United States, 8-2, for its third straight victory in the world hockey championships in Stockholm. It was Team USA's third consecutive loss in the preliminary round of the eight-team event. The Soviet Union defeated Finland, 4-1, as Vyacheslav Bykov and Vladimir Konstantinov each scored two goals. The victory gave the Soviets a 3-0 record. Czechoslovakia moved to 5 points, 1 point behind the leaders, by beating Poland, 15-0. West Germany tied the defending champion, Sweden, 3-3. (AP) TENNIS Upsets in Japan: Three top-seeded players - No. 4 Yannick Noah of France, No. 6 Kevin Curren of the United States and No. 7 Andres Gomez of Ecuador - were upset yesterday in the $752,500 Japan Open Championships in Tokyo. No. 2 Stefan Edberg of Sweden breezed past Zeeshan Ali of India, 6-2, 6-2. Noah fell, 6-4, 7-5, to Glenn Layendecker of the United States. Curren was defeated by his countryman Richard Matuszewski, 7-6, 1-6, 7-6, while Gomez lost to Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela, 6-4, 6-1. (AP) HARNESS RACING Mack Lobell Wins in Sweden: Mack Lobell, driven by John Campbell, had an easy victory yesterday at the Jagersro track in Malmo, Sweden. Mack Lobell was timed in 1:15 2/5 over a kilometer (0.62 miles), finishing well ahead of the field. His appearance in Malmo was a test before the major Swedish trotting event, the Elitloppet, in Stockholm on May 28.(AP)

title: Moscow and Madison Sign Schools Exchange
description: The University of Wisconsin and Moscow State University have signed an agreement to provide for an exchange of students and faculty members with no limitations on research.

title: Clippers Ban Williams For Refusal to Play
description: Reggie Williams, a guard, was suspended for the Los Angeles Clippers' final three games Monday night after the club's 108-102 loss to the Utah Jazz.

title: Chairman Defends Exxon's Effort to Clean Up Oil
description: The chief executive of the Exxon Corporation charged again yesterday that the indecision of government officials, rather than a lack of response by the company, allowed the huge oil spill caused by the grounding of the tanker Exxon Valdez to spread out of control.

title: First Florida Banks reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Apple Computer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Knicks Are Stumbling on Offense to the Finish Line
description: The Knicks keep saying the right things and doing the wrong things.

title: Mexico Makes Itself a Model Debtor
description: Mexico, the first big debtor nation to crack under the load of its debts to foreign banks, is now the first to start negotiating with them on debt reduction. The outcome of their negotiations, which start today in New York City, will set a pattern for all the debtors and their creditors. In Mexico's case, relief is well deserved.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Monday with a front-page introduction to an article about 10 shooting deaths in San Jose, Calif., was published in error. The killing described in the front-page passage was carried out with the gun shown inside the paper as No. 1, alongside the article.

title: US Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wine Talk
description: THERE is no particular reason why a new vintage chart should arrive with the forsythia, except that spring is a time of renewal and what more appropriate occasion to update this traditional guide to good wines?

title: Topics of The Times; Tight Little Island
description: A few years ago the courts prevented Palm Beach, Fla., from requiring blue-collar workers to carry identification cards for entry. Now the opulent fantasy island is considering a new safety measure. The city would place video recorders on the three bridges that connect Palm Beach to the rest of America. When crime occurs, the police could view the tapes and possibly identify suspects.

title: Demand for Unleaded Gas Pushes Oil to High Levels
description: Prices of crude oil yesterday advanced to their highest level since July 1987, largely on the continued, and somewhat puzzling, demand for unleaded gasoline.

title: Fairchild Plans To Discuss Sale
description: Fairchild Industries has decided to start discussions with Carlyle Group L.P. about the possible sale of the Chantilly, Va., aerospace concern.

title: E.D.S. Buys Funds Transfer Business
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the data-processing subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, agreed to buy the electronic funds transfer business of iAutomatic Data Processing Inc., for an undisclosed sum. The sale is expected to be completed by June 30.

title: Panel Finds U.S. Lags on Schools and Health Care
description: In a bipartisan report on economic and social issues, Congress's top economic committee found that the nation's school and health care systems lag far behind those in other prosperous countries, even though the United States spends more on them.

title: Hometown Bancorporation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Drexel Will Sell Broker Unit
description: In a large-scale corporate shake-up, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. announced yesterday that it would sell its retail brokerage operation and cut back other divisions, reducing the firm's work force by about one-third.

title: Cayuga Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $68,000 loss from the sale of securities. c-Included a $75,000 gain from the sale of securities.

title: A Butter Cake That Sticks to the Gums
description: SAY St. Louis, and you're talking Gooey Butter Cake. Any self-respecting denizen has sweetened a tooth on this intensely rich piece of gastronomic lunacy that is a hallmark of the city.

title: New Twist On Crack In Florida
description: On the seventh floor of the Broward County Courthouse in Fort Lauderdale, the sheriff's office has been manufacturing crack.

title: F & M National reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cuomo Plan to Shift Local Costs Fails
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan for wholesale shifts of state government costs to local governments failed as the Legislature agreed to maintain several programs the administration had sought to cut, officials said today.

title: Southwall Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $14,000. c-Net loss

title: John H Harland Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Thousands Chant for Democracy Within Earshot of China's Leaders
description: More than 10,000 people took over Beijing's central square on Tuesday night in a rally for democracy. Several thousand students then marched to the Communist Party headquarters, where those in the front of the crowd tried to force their way in to see the nation's leaders.

title: Computers Now Help In the Search for Oil
description: Rapid advances in color three-dimensional computer graphics are changing the way geologists and geophysicists search for oil and decide where to drill wells.

title: Legislators Agree on Budget Without Some of Cuomo Cuts
description: After an all-night negotiating session, legislative leaders reached agreement today on a $47 billion budget that retains many of the programs Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had proposed eliminating. The budget does not put into effect the most sweeping changes proposed by the Governor in his budget plan in January, including an overhaul of the state's Medicaid system and a shift of many costs to local governments.

title: Costs Up a Sharp 1% in New York Region
description: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area jumped 1 percent last month, the sharpest increase since last August, the United States Labor Department's regional bureau reported yesterday.

title: Soviet Convoy of Arms Gets Through to Kabul
description: A convoy of 1,000 armored vehicles and 500 trucks carrying Soviet arms and food broke through a rebel blockade and rumbled into Kabul today in the biggest such operation since Moscow's troops left Afghanistan.

title: First Community Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hibernia Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank said its loan loss reserve totaled $420,102 at March 31, up from $352,728 at Dec. 31. The bank also said it added $66,000 to its loan loss provision in the latest quarter, compared with an $18,000 addition in the year- ago first quarter.

title: Citicorp Paper Posts 2d Drop
description: For the second time this month, interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday dropped sharply.

title: Merck & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest quarter sales growth of 9 percent was reduced 1 percentage point by the effect of a stronger dollar and reduced 4 percentage points from the sale of the company's interest in TorII & Co. Ltd., a former affiliate in Japan.

title: Ringing Denial
description: Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds' manager, has taken the offensive against what he says are erroneous reports that he gave his 1975 World Series championship ring to a convicted bookmaker.

title: But Who'll Empty the Grass Cuttings?
description: A homeowner who must mow the lawn has probably had this high-tech fantasy: a robot lawn mower that cuts the grass while its master lounges nearby in the shade sipping something cool.

title: President Tells Labor Of Hope for Solid Ties
description: President Bush told organized labor today that despite ''honest differences'' he wanted to maintain firm relations with the trade union movement.

title: Morgan Stanley Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share results have been retroactively adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 common stock split, which became effective Feb. 27.

title: NWA Stock Jumps; Davis Gets Backing
description: The stock price of NWA Inc. jumped $7.125, or 8 percent, to $97.375 today, after the parent of Northwest Airlines said on Monday that it was considering options to fend off a $90-a-share, $2.62 billion takeover offer by the billionaire oilman Marvin Davis.

title: Standard Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Scott Paper Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the tissue segment of its U.S. personal care and cleaning business had unit sales volume growth of 14 percent while sales dollars increased 19 percent and profits rose 24 percent.

title: Philharmonic to Tour Eight Asian Cities
description: The New York Philharmonic is to make a 15-concert tour of eight Asian cities this summer. Under the direction of its music director, Zubin Mehta, the orchestra will perform in Singapore; Hong Kong; Taipei, Taiwan; Seoul, South Korea; Tokyo, Osaka and Nagoya, Japan, and Bangkok, Thailand.

title: I.R.S. to Permit Shoreham Write-Off
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that the Internal Revenue Service had ruled that the utility could deduct an estimated $2.8 billion of the cost for the construction of the Shoreham nuclear-power plant in calculating its Federal taxes.

title: Independent Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $89,000.

title: Review/Film; Israeli Depicts Two Egyptians Lost in Sinai
description: An Egyptian soldier stands in the Sinai desert and shouts at an Israeli, ''I am a Jew!'' Then he goes on, ''Hath not a Jew eyes?,'' reciting Shylock's famous speech in accented English, but with all the drama of a player at the Old Vic. He is an actor who has been drafted away from his profession, and who is now lost in the desert in the days just after Israel's victory in the war of 1967. Stumbling across a small group of Israeli soldiers, he tries with his outrageous performance to convince them to give him water.

title: Crown Cork & Seal Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings and shares outstanding results for the 1988 period have been restated to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split distributed Dec. 12.

title: National Savings Bank of Alany reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
10 Offers for Jerusalem Post
description: A Canadian investor group that includes Conrad Black, who owns The Daily Telegraph in Britain, made a surprise $20 million offer to buy The Jerusalem Post, newspaper officials said today.

title: Ravitch Running as the 'Fresh Face' Few Voters Recognize
description: Punctuating his remarks with uncharacteristic karate chops to the air, Richard Ravitch began his pitch to a Brooklyn community meeting the other night by distinguishing himself from his mayoral race rivals.

title: US Surgical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Alaska Public Radio Rejects Exxon Money to Cover Spill
description: The Alaska Public Radio Network has decided not to accept $32,283 that the Exxon Corporation had donated to help the network cover the oil spill from the tanker Exxon Valdez.

title: Dow Soars by 41.61; Bonds Also Advance
description: Buoyed by investors' growing conviction that a slowing economy will contain inflation - and that interest rates may have peaked - the stock market staged another strong rally yesterday.

title: A Bush Nominee Runs Afoul of the Contra Issue
description: A Senate committee postponed action today on President Bush's nominee to be Ambassador to Mexico because of continuing questions about his involvement in the Iran-contra affair during the Reagan Administration.

title: Court Allows States Wide Antitrust Law To Shield Consumers
description: In an important affirmation of the power of states to protect consumer interests, the Supreme Court ruled today that states may pass laws permitting consumers to bring antitrust suits that would be barred under Federal law.

title: How Medicare Surtax Is Dividing Americans; Go After a Real Subsidy
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. COMMITTEEON INFORMATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Security Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council CHILDREN'S FUND - 10 A.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Long live freedom! Long live democracy! Down with the bureaucracy!'' - Demonstrators in Beijing's central square. [ A1:5. ]

title: Apple and Lotus Post Decline in Earnings
description: Apple Computer Inc. and the Lotus Development Corporation both reported decreased earnings for the quarter ended March 31. But the results for both companies were within Wall Street analysts' estimates, based on previous announcements.

title: Chills! Thrills! Spills! Cliffhangers!
description: And now, a quiz for the film fans of yesteryear: From the 1930's to the early 1950's, where could moviegoers be certain of hearing the following bits of dialogue?

title: Kansas Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Journal; Shoeshine Businessman Standing Tall in Victory
description: A District of Columbia police officer saw Ego J. Brown shining shoes at his little stand on Connecticut Avenue recently and did not do anything about it. He only called, ''How's business, Ego?'' and waved a greeting.

title: Broker Guilty of Killing Boss
description: A former stockbroker at Merrill Lynch & Company was found guilty Monday of murdering his supervisor, who had discharged him a day before the killing. The 42-year-old defendant, Lonnie Gilbert, was sentenced to life imprisonment. Mr. Gilbert is black, and defense psychiatrists had testified that he was temporarily insane when he shot his supervisor, George Cook, because he was suffering from a paranoid belief that his lackluster career was a result of racial discrimination.

title: Deep in the Heart Of Atlanta: Texans
description: It was not a scene that will make its way into ''Lonesome Dove II.''

title: Honeywell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: Year-ago first quarter included a gain of $5,000,000, or 12 cents a share, related to asset sales.

title: Economic Scene; One Way Out For Eastern Air
description: IS there life for Eastern Airlines after Peter Ueberroth? With the collapse of the deal to sell Eastern, the odds against finding another buyer satisfactory to both its owner, the Texas Air Corporation, and the unions seem long.

title: American Electric Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Amity Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
D.M.B.&B.: A 'Titanic' Back on Top
description: WHEN D'Arcy MacManus Masius and Benton & Bowles joined forces in 1985, London's advertising community predicted disaster.

title: Housing Construction Down for Second Month
description: New residential construction suffered its second straight decline in March, the Commerce Department said today in a report that analysts cited as evidence that the housing industry will bear the brunt of a campaign to restrain economic growth.

title: MCI Posts Record Net; 3 Others Up
description: Four major telephone companies - the MCI Communications Corporation, the GTE Corporation, United Telecommunications Inc. and the Southwestern Bell Corporation -yesterday announced moderate to substantial increases in earnings for the first three months of 1989.

title: Attention Must Turn to the Black Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Snatching defeat from the jaws of victory is one of the most embarrassing experiences a player can have. Suppose that at the end of a match you judge that your team is slightly behind, and make a desperate effort to regain the lost ground. It fails, and when you compare scores you find that steady play would have sufficed and your effort has lost the match instead of winning it.

title: Westchester Rallies To Defend Parkways
description: Over the last two decades, whenever the state proposed modernizing some of the elegant old parkways of Westchester County, officials thought that they would simply be making them faster and safer.

title: Fairness Doctrine Bill
description: A bill that would require broadcasters to include opposing views on controversial issues was approved by the Senate Commerce Committee today. The bill, virtually identical to a measure passed by Congress in 1987 and vetoed by President Reagan, was sent to the full Senate on a voice vote. It would write into law the so-called Fairness Doctrine, which was repealed by the Federal Communications Commission in 1987. A similar measure is awaiting action by the full House.

title: Ethyl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk; The Capital
description: Like many families, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization always seems beset by an argument or a crisis, but it is better than many at patching things up and staying together.

title: Citizens' Stance On NCNB Bid
description: The Citizens and Southern Corporation will not seek a leveraged buyout or a ''white knight'' to fend off a hostile takeover offer, its chairman, Bennett A. Brown, said today.

title: Restaurant Deliveries: Beyond Pizza
description: UNTIL recently, a delivered dinner meant pizza or Chinese. But now, across the nation, the delivery menu has grown to include a world of choices, from Italian to Ethiopian, Mexican to Indian, and in every price range. In cities like New York, Chicago and San Francisco, and increasingly in suburban areas, restaurant kitchens are sending their meals to the home dinner table, creating a service that responds to consumer demand and at the same time fills a gap left by slower business in the restaurants themselves.

title: Holyfield Makes Plans That Detour Tyson
description: Evander Holyfield isn't waiting for Mike Tyson.

title: De Tomaso Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are translated from Italian Lire at the exchange rate prevailing at Dec. 31, 1988.

title: Bank of South Carolina reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Statement and Affidavits Submitted by Wright on His Wife's Employment
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the House Speaker, Jim Wright, in defense of his wife. He also presented two related notarized affidavits. WRIGHT STATEMENT Committee Assertion

title: Di Giorgio Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
International Multifoods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said the decline in earnings for the latest quarter was due to lower Venezuelan and U.S. operating results before major unusual items and significantly higher interest costs related in part to the repurchase of 1,750,000 shares in November.

title: Food-Relief Effort Impeded in Sudan
description: Midway through an operation intended to deliver large amounts of food to relieve famine in the southern Sudan, the United Nations has run into serious logistical and political problems.

title: Lebanon's Calvary
description: The Lebanese never run short of their own reasons to keep up the intricate killing and dealing that is their 14-year-old civil war. But once again outside events have brought on hellish bombardments of civilians.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: THOUGHTS of the heartland, particularly Peoria, don't exactly spawn visions of fresh lobster ready to boil, bright blue-shelled Puerto Rican prawns or mussels with their beards still dangling.

title: Babylon Journal; Ancient King's Instructions to Iraq: Fix My Palace
description: When King Nebuchadnezzar ran things around here some 2,500 years ago, he left clear instructions for the future Kings of Babylon that are finally being carried out.

title: ITT Unit Offering Of $150 Million
description: The ITT Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of the ITT Corporation, is offering $150 million worth of 9 7/8 percent subordinated notes due in 1997 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Forced Abortion and a Chinese Refugee
description: An act of official inhumanity in his native China drove Lee Yuan Pan to test the humanity of America's refugee law. When Chinese officials forced his wife to have an abortion, Mr. Lee fled to San Francisco, only to be arrested for trying to enter the U.S. on a forged passport.

title: A Courtroom Squeeze: 'Quick Fix' Has Been Neither
description: It was to be a quick fix. The Queens courts, like others throughout the city, faced soaring caseloads. More courtrooms were urgently needed. State court officials and the Koch administration proposed using prefabricated construction to rapidly erect a small annex with a half-dozen new courtrooms behind the Criminal Court Building in Kew Gardens. It would take about a year.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., introduced three models in its 5990 series of mainframes at prices from $3.8 million to $9.8 million.

title: Two Sales Approved
description: The President's son and a former Vice Presidential candidate officially became part-owners of major league baseball teams yesterday when club owners unanimously approved the sales of the Texas Rangers and Baltimore Orioles.

title: Oregon Metallurgical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,157,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest quarter results included pretax interest earnings on an income tax refund of $17,970,000.

title: Righetti Cashes In With a Little Change
description: There was always something special about his fastball. It was more than simply fast, and when Dave Righetti reached back and threw it, he could overpower a hitter. He could make it move, and he could make batters swing wildly at it and miss. He built a career in the big leagues with it.

title: Johnson Trial Put Off
description: Ben Johnson's trial on weapons charges has been adjourned until August because testimony at a Canadian Federal inquiry into drug use in amateur sports could be prejudicial to his case, the sprinter's lawyer, Martin Kerbel, said yesterday in Toronto.

title: New Proposal In Gold Battle
description: Two of South Africa's biggest companies offered yesterday in Manhattan Federal court to post bonds of at least $100 million apiece in an attempt to persuade a judge to reconsider an injunction.

title: Corrections
description: A short article on Monday about plans by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece to sue Time Inc. referred incorrectly to the libel cases affected by a difference between American and English law. It is in actions by public figures (not actions against them) that ''actual malice'' does not have to be shown under English law.

title: A Top Officer Resigns At Sun Microsystems
description: Bernard J. Lacroute, executive vice president at the fast-growing Sun Microsystems Inc., has resigned effective July 1, the company announced today.

title: Discrimination Suit Is Settled
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. has agreed to pay $670,000 and the United Auto Workers $48,000 to settle claims that they discriminated against black employees, a spokesman for the automaker said today.

title: Pistons Defeat Cavaliers to Clinch Division Title
description: The Detroit Pistons clinched their second straight Central Division title and the league's best record tonight, racing to a 20-3 lead and then holding on behind Joe Dumars's 24 third-quarter points to beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 118-102.

title: Lin Broadcasting Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Price Controls in Argentina
description: Argentina began strict controls on prices today and said it would authorize increases only once a month to stop spiraling inflation.

title: INSIDE
description: Base Closings Approved

title: New Munchie Quencher: Indian Snacks With Snap
description: LEAD: THE American love for snack foods seems unceasing. With each new wave of culinary influence has come a new delight - shrimp wafers, rice puffs, nachos, Cajun chips and sesame sticks, to name a few - bringing a multitude of flavors and textures to the palate. The newest arrivals on the crunchy-munchie scene are Indian spicy snacks, gaining a loyal following throughout America.

title: Polish Thaw Sealed With a Handshake
description: In an encounter intended to symbolize the end of long hostility, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who declared martial law in 1981 to crush Solidarity, met today with Lech Walesa, whose union formally regained its legal status on Monday.

title: Credit-Card Fee Law Signed
description: Banks and stores in New York State may impose late fees on credit-card payments under a bill signed into law by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today. The bill, which consumer advocates have criticized, is aimed at keeping banks' credit-card operations in the state.

title: Reviews/Music; Soviet Pianist at Carnegie After 16 Years
description: Vladimir Viardo's career has been a strange one, blown every which way by the political winds. The Soviet pianist won first prize in the 1973 Van Cliburn competition and performed in the United States for the next two years. He was not permitted to return for 13 years, however, an injunction that was lifted last year in accord with the Soviet Union's new spirit of openness. He has permission to pursue his career in America through 1990.

title: Ball Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $17.8 million gain from an accounting change. Year-ago first quarter net from operations included an after-tax gain of $3.6 million, or 16 cents a share, from the sale of an investment in Constar International.

title: Small American Foundations Focusing on Global Concerns
description: With modest amounts of money and a spirit of creativity, small United States foundations are adding a new dimension to international philanthropy.

title: Review/Music; Reinventing the Traditions Of Ancient Nubian Music
description: Music doesn't get much starker than the songs of Hamza el-Din, the Nubian musician who performed Saturday night at the Triplex Theater. He shared a double bill of meditative African string music with Toumani Diabate of Mali.

title: Harold L. Ellis, Neurologist, 94
description: Dr. Harold L. Ellis, a neurologist and psychiatrist, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in the Bronx. He was 94 years old.

title: Hong Kong Developer Buying Ramada Hotels
description: Ramada Inc. said today that it would sell its hotel chain to the New World Development Company of Hong Kong for $540 million, freeing Ramada to concentrate on its casinos.

title: Market Place; The Sharp Climb Of 2 Latin Funds
description: SINCE the beginning of the year two of the hottest closed-end mutual funds have been those investing in stocks in Brazil and Mexico. Shares in the Brazil Fund have soared 54 percent, while that country's stock market has climbed more than 100 percent despite record inflation. In Mexico the stock market is up 13 percent and with the economy's prospects thought to be improving the Mexico Fund's shares have jumped 47 percent.

title: Wainwright Bank & Trust Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Southwestern Bell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk: Exact Words; Agriculture Dept. Lays It on Line for Lemons
description: A ruling issued by the Department of Agriculture, April 12, 1989:

title: Cards-Lions Deal Off
description: The Phoenix Cardinals have turned down the Detroit Lions' offer of the third choice over all in the National Football League draft Sunday in exchange for the Cardinals' first two draft choices.

title: How Medicare Surtax Is Dividing Americans; Base It on Total Income
description: To the Editor:

title: First Colonial Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
In New Jersey, a Cry to Guard Well Water
description: Frank J. Markewicz, a retired state geologist, spends his days exploring the Black River Valley and dreaming of a water bonanza buried deep in its ancient limestone veins.

title: Suit Charges Cover-Up In Death of an Officer
description: The widow of a New York City police sergeant who was found shot to death a year ago in his partner's apartment has filed suit against several city agencies, contending that they covered up her husband's death by failing to investigate it properly and by ruling it a suicide.

title: Chelyabinsk Federals Are Next
description: The authorities were on guard as the Aeroflot jet landed in Moscow. On the manifest were the names of two men recently convicted of racketeering in Chicago.

title: SPACE UNIT WORKS, SOVIETS TELL WEST
description: Soviet space officials have decided to bring three astronauts home from their space station next week and leave it temporarily vacant to save money, the deputy flight director said today.

title: 160 Writers Expected At Weekend Meeting
description: More than 160 writers, including Norman Mailer, Rona Jaffe, Jay McInerney and Susan Brownmiller, are scheduled to appear at the New York Writer's Conference, Friday through Sunday, at the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street, at Houston.

title: Raymond Dier, Professor, 71
description: Raymond Dier, a retired professor of finance at Rutgers University and a retired Methodist minister, died of a heart attack Sunday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Citicorp Net Rises 48% In Quarter
description: Although they followed different business strategies, Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the ninth largest, yesterday announced sharply higher earnings for the first quarter.

title: Secrecy Pledge Ruling Vacated by High Court
description: The Supreme Court today vacated a lower Federal court's ruling that Congress acted without constitutional authority two years ago when it tried to block a Reagan Administration program concerned with disclosure of Government information.

title: Eating Well
description: LEAD: CONSIDER the importance, desirability and sometimes slightly sinful quality with which fruit has become endowed. The language bears witness: forbidden fruit; the fruits of one's labor; ideas or efforts that bear fruit, and those that are fruitless.

title: W W Grainger Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter included a gain of $13.8 million related to the sale of assets of the company's fan and blower manufacturing business. The company said the gain was offset by the adoption of an accounting change for post-retirement health care benefits of $11.8 million.

title: Teachers to Seek Principal's Dismissal
description: The head of the New York City teachers union said yesterday that she will press Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green to dismiss a Bronx high school principal who has been found to have singled out union leaders for harassment.

title: Airport Bonds Due From Albuquerque
description: Albuquerque, N.M., is offering $46.6 million in tax-exempt governmental purpose airport refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.677 percent for a discount issue due in 2019.

title: How Medicare Surtax Is Dividing Americans; Physician Fees Fixed
description: To the Editor:

title: Addendum
description: * Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, a public relations firm, has changed its name to Lewis Gilman Golin/Harris and moved its office to the Bellevue building, at Broad and Walnut Streets in Philadelphia.

title: MCI Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $10,000,000 charge for early retirement of debt. Results for the latest quarter included a pretax gain of $18,000,000 from previously negotiated antitrust settlements. In the year-ago quarter, results included a pretax gain of $28,000,000. Operating margins improved for the seventh consecutive quarter, rising to 15.1 percent from 8.8 percent in the year-ago period. The improvement reflected continued efficiency gains. The company said the strong improvement in net income was accomplished despite an increase in its effective tax rate to 25 percent in the latest quarter from 16 percent last year.

title: Witness Implicates Suspect at Mob Trial
description: A surprise witness in the trial of six men accused of belonging to the Genovese crime family placed a defendant at the Manhattan restaurant where Irwin Schiff, a mob-connected businessman, was killed while eating dessert in 1987.

title: NBC Tightens Grip on Lead, But Networks Lose Viewers
description: Network television lost viewers in prime time again last season, and NBC's dominance among those viewers who remained threatens to turn a once fierce competition into a one-network universe.

title: Senator Says Bush Agrees To Improve Missile Watch
description: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Senator David L. Boren, says he has been assured by the Bush Administration that money will be made available to improve surveillance satellites used to monitor compliance with arms control agreements.

title: U.N. GUARDS REBELS AT NAMIBIA BORDER
description: The first guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization were finally escorted by United Nations monitors today across the border to Angola.

title: How Medicare Surtax Is Dividing Americans; Eat Less to Pay Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Bear Stearns Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Fiscal 1988 results are restated to conform prior year results to current fiscal year presentation.

title: For Well-Traveled Food, Haute or Hash
description: WHAT happens to grilled swordfish that is delivered not five feet from restaurant kitchen to dining table, but five blocks or even five miles?

title: I.R.S. Chief Reported Named
description: Fred T. Goldberg Jr., , a former chief counsel at the Internal Revenue Service, will be nominated to be the agency's Commissioner, Congressional sources said today. Lawrence B. Gibbs Jr. resigned from the post in March to return to private law practice.

title: A Forest Near Times Sq. Faces Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas Brown, 82; Had Arthritis Theory
description: Thomas McPherson Brown, author of a disputed theory on the treatment and cause of rheumatoid arthritis, died Monday at the National Hospital in Arlington, Va., after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Rangers Go to 11-2 By Beating Brewers
description: Cecil Espy had four hits, stole three bases and scored three times on runs batted in by Rafael Palmeiro as the Texas Rangers beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 6-2, tonight behind Bobby Witt's four-hit pitching.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Passover, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Review/Dance; Tapping for a Month of Mondays
description: Need a lift? Manhattan Tap, a highly talented quartet of tap dancers, will do the trick. The popular group has been appearing on Monday nights this month at the Top of the Gate with an unpredictable mix of guest artists. The final session will be on Monday when the veteran tap master, Charles (Cookie) Cook, is to join the squad of regulars - Heather Cornell, Jamie Cunneen, Shelley Oliver and Tony Scopino.

title: First Bank System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increased net income resulted primarily from an improvement in net interest income and the recognition of tax benefits attributable to the sale of investment securities in December 1988. Excluding the effect of the tax benefits, earnings in the first quarter were $43,400,000, or 66 cents a share. Results for the latest quarter included the operations of Central Bancorp Inc. Central Banks, a Denver- based holing company, which was acquired in December.

title: Fab Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
Mercantile Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Critic's Notebook; On Stage, the Feminist Message Takes on a Sly and Subtle Tone
description: On Friday night I joined a capacity audience at the Plymouth Theater to hear the lectures of the art historian Dr. Heidi Holland, as performed by the actress Joan Allen in Wendy Wasserstein's play ''The Heidi Chronicles.'' Although I'd seen ''The Heidi Chronicles'' before, I hadn't quite noticed how comprehensively Dr. Holland - and the author who created her - folded a feminist art history lesson, with slides, into the creases of a play that is otherwise an unpedagogical account of a woman's life in the far-from-academic world of 1965 to 1989.

title: GPA Group Gives Boeing A Record $9.4 Billion Order
description: The Boeing Company received the largest portion of an order for 308 airliners announced yesterday by GPA Group Ltd. of Shannon, Ireland, the world's biggest aircraft-leasing company. The $9.4 billion Boeing order, which is the largest in the company's history and will stretch over the next decade, calls for 92 737's, 50 757's and 40 767's.

title: Accounts
description: * BTS, a Salt Lake City-based broadcast and video equipment manufacturer, to Dahlin Smith White Inc., with a budget of $1 million.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IN Northern California, even the most ardent vegetable lovers will admit that there is one thing better than going to a farmers' market: having a farmers' market come to them. And for the third consecutive year, a small association of farmers is getting ready to pack bushel baskets with organically grown spring crops for weekly delivery direct to customers' doors, mostly in the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: Warhol Estate Explores a Sale
description: The Andy Warhol estate has hired an investment banking firm in its effort to sell its trendy downtown monthly magazine, Interview. The publication was created by Andy Warhol in 1969 and has a circulation of 154,000 now.

title: Primerica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter results reflected the combined operations of Old Primerica and the former Commercial Credit Group Inc., and the 1988 period included results only from Commercial Credit operations. Results for the first quarter reflected interest expense of about $8 million after tax associated with the cash payments related to the acquisition of Old Primerica, as well as amortization of acquisition of goodwill of about $7 million for the quarter. Revenue for the 1989 first quarter included $794.1 million from Old Primerica.

title: GTE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said first quarter results benefited from the absence of US Sprint losses, which adversely affected earnings last year. The company also said improved telephone operations reflect increased usuage of domestic local-exchange networks for long-distance calling and growth in the number of access lines in service.

title: K Mart Expects Earnings to Fall
description: Joseph E. Antonini, chairman of the K Mart Corporation, said the company's earnings for the current quarter would be less than a year earliier. K Mart, based in Troy, Mich., is the nation's second-largest retailer after Sears, Roebuck.

title: Circle Express Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year loss was primarily attributable to significant charges and write-offs related to the closure of non-profitable operating subsidiaries, the sale of certain subsidiaries in March 1988, increases in the company's allowances for bad debts, and reserves for insurance claims and write-offs or writedowns of certain assets of ongoing operations.

title: A L Williams Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included earnings from discontinued operations of $4,158,000, or 10 cents a share. The company said it acquired Massachusetts Indemnity & Life Insurance Co. in November 1988. For accounting purposes, this transaction was treated as a reverse acquisition, with Massachusetts Indemnity assumed to have acquired A. L. Williams. As a result, first quarter 1988 results are those of Massachusetts Indemnity alone, and are not directly comparable with the 1989 figures which include the results of the combined company, including the mutual fund and home mortgage businesses.

title: In Far-Flung Places, Passover Foods
description: ALAN and Elisheva Kaufman of Montpelier, Vt., ordered kosher chicken from Albany for their seder tonight, the beginning of Passover. Pearl Krasnjansky, a rabbi's wife in Honolulu who is hosting two large community seders, had 300 frozen dinners shipped from a caterer in Miami. Raquel Hakim of Monroe, La., drove 350 miles to Houston to buy ketchup, mayonnaise and other specialty items for Passover.

title: From Florida, Worldly Youngsters
description: ''L'Oeuf et Les Schtroumpfs'' seemed to hold more allure for the fourth graders than the teacher's explanation of the proper conjugation of irregular verbs in French.

title: About New York; Spring Harvest: The Brief Glory Of Cherry Trees
description: Life is short, like the three-day glory of the cherry blossom. - Japanese haiku Under the big birds approaching LaGuardia Airport and blocks from the worn streets of Crown Heights, a quiet miracle is waiting to happen. The 76 double-flowering Kwanzan cherry trees of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Cherry Esplanade are just about to bloom.

title: Flightsafety International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter share nets have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock spilt paid in August 1988.

title: Duquense Picks Coach
description: John Carroll, the top assistant at Seton Hall for the last seven years, was named yesterday as Duquesne University's head coach. The 33-year-old Carroll replaces Jim Satalin, who was dismissed six weeks ago.(AP)

title: Panel Finds Dismissal of 2 Lawyers Was Justified
description: An investigation ordered by New York State's top judge has concluded that the dismissal of the two chief lawyers for the committee that disciplines lawyers in Manhattan and the Bronx was justified, court officials said yesterday.

title: Cape Cod Bank & Trust Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sport Network For Southeast
description: The Turner Broadcasting System said today it would join with American Television and Communications of Stamford, Conn., which is a unit of Time Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver to create the Southeastern Sports Network.

title: Wells Fargo & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Massachusetts Unit's Notes
description: The Massachusetts Water Resources Authority yesterday priced $300 million worth of guaranteed bond anticipation notes due on April 16, 1990, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Engraph Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings figures reflect a 10 percent stock dividend declared in February. Latest quarter sales included results for recently acquired Patton & Rixie paper products.

title: Pipe Bomb in Store Maims Child
description: A pipe bomb in a toothpaste container at a discount store exploded in a young girl's hand Monday night, blowing off four of her fingers.

title: Luxembourg, a Ripe 150, Kicks Up Its Heels
description: From the din of church bells in the misty morning to the squib of fireworks after dark, this tiny European nation had a thoroughly enjoyable time today celebrating its 150th anniversary.

title: Lockheed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1 million. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $6 million.

title: Century Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
17 Officers Named in Tompkins Sq. Riot
description: After an eight-month investigation, only 17 New York City police officers were positively identified as suspects in abusing civilians at Tompkins Square Park last summer, despite 121 complaints of police misconduct, the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board said yesterday.

title: Rookie Helps Power The Penguins' Surge
description: Mark Howe, who had really only seen Kevin Stevens on videotape, suddenly had him live and right in front of him late in the third period here Monday night. In his face one instant, Stevens, the young Pittsburgh forward, was behind the veteran Philadelphia defenseman's back the very next.

title: First Financial Management Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included results for Appalachian Computer Services, acquired in December 1988.

title: Hercules Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain on sale of business and other nonrecurring items of $6.1 million, or 12 cents a share.

title: How Medicare Surtax Is Dividing Americans; Over 65, Still Working
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk; The Environment and Man at Yale
description: It should have been no surprise when George Bush proclaimed himself an environmentalist last year. He is, after all, a Yalie, and graduates of Yale University, particularly its law school, have played a strikingly prominent role in the environmental affairs of the country for the last 20 years or more. Indeed, ''Boola Boola'' could well be the fight song of the American environmental establishment.

title: South Carolina National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rohm & Haas Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
At the Nation's Table
description: IT is hard to believe that the pina colada is only 26 years old, or is it 35 years old? And who would suspect that controversy surrounds this cocktail, usually made in a blender with ice, rum, cream of coconut and pineapple juice?

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Robert Ketter, 60, Quake Expert And Ex-College President, Is Dead
description: Robert L. Ketter, an authority on earthquake engineering research and a former president of the State University of New York at Buffalo, died of a heart attack yesterday at Millard Fillmore Hospital in Buffalo. He was 60 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: United Technologies Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its 1988 first quarter results included a pretax gain of $156 million from the sale of its Essex unit and the leasing business of UT Credit Corp. It said the year-ago first quarter included a total of $21 million in pretax profit from the operations of Essex and the impact of unusual gains from the sale of Essex and certain leasing subsidiaries, less restructuring charges. The year-ago first quarter results also included a pretax restructuring charge of $148.8 million. Backlog was a record $18.2 million at March 31, compared with $15.9 billion at March 31, 1988.

title: Mair J. Benardete, 93, Spanish Professor, Dies
description: Mair J. Benardete, professor emeritus of Spanish at Brooklyn College, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Somerville, Mass. He was 93 years old.

title: First Home Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter reflected a one-time $417,000 gain on pretax profit from the sale of Freddie Mac preferred stock and a one-time $165,000 loss for loan-loss provisions.

title: Aides Say Bush Nears a Decision On Course of 'Star Wars' Program
description: President Bush was reported to be nearing a decision on how to proceed with the Administration's missile-defense program and on what new land-based missiles to deploy after convening a meeting today of his National Security Council.

title: Conservatives Choose Lauder In Mayor Race
description: Conservative Party leaders yesterday endorsed Ronald S. Lauder for mayor of New York City, insuring him a place on the November ballot regardless of the outcome of his Republican primary contest.

title: Integra Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included about $1 million in after- tax costs from the retirement of $23.9 million subordinated debentures. Since the consolidation to form Integra was accounted for as a pooling-of- interests, year-ago figures reflect the combined results of Pennbancorp and Union National.

title: Innovators Are Honored As Heroes of Education
description: In spring 1968, when Danny Greene was a freshman at Fordham University, the most popular spring break retreat was the Florida coast. But not for Mr. Greene and about a dozen friends. They spent the week in the coal fields of southeastern Kentucky, helping a minister build a church.

title: Rich, Richer; Poor, Poorer
description: LEAD: Several years ago, a handful of economists looking at income statistics found evidence that the middle class had stopped growing and the United States was on its way toward becoming a two-class society.

title: Borden Chemicals & Plastics LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Profits Up At 4 Drug Companies
description: Benefiting from new products, price increases and tax reductions, four major drug companies reported strong earnings for the first quarter yesterday.

title: Jordan's Founder Adds American Safety Razor
description: While the big buyout deals get all the attention, hundreds of smaller transactions are taking place all the time by the likes of such entrepreneurs as John W. Jordan 2d.

title: Topics of The Times; Deeper Roots for City Gardens
description: Since 1978, Operation GreenThumb has created oases in some of New York City's meanest neighborhoods. Sponsored by the Department of General Services, it leases city-owned vacant lots to community groups for $1 a year and provides them with training, tools, soil and plants. Today there are more than 1,000 such gardens, growing everything from peach trees to sweet corn.

title: Arizona Commerce Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Of the latest quarter's net, $137,000 came from the sale of securities and one branch office. The remaining $94,000 were profit from operations.

title: Lebanon: Not Crisis-as-Usual
description: LEAD: The Bush Administration's show of interest in the growing Lebanese crisis is a welcome if belated and inadequate response to a conflict that the world cannot afford to ignore any longer.

title: Mail on Abortion Deluges Court
description: Americans in record numbers are writing and calling the Supreme Court to express their views on abortion, but a spokeswoman for the Court said today that it was all to no avail.

title: Copying Capitalism
description: Glasnost opened the Soviet Union to the public exchange of information and long-suppressed opinion. Look for the printed word to spread even wider now: Moscow has its first American-style quick-copy shops.

title: Real Estate; Standardized Reports on Office Space
description: A UNIFORM way of reporting office vacancies and construction is being proposed by the Building Owners and Managers Association, a Washington-based trade group that represents most of the country's office developers and owners and most property-management companies.

title: American Home Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Average number of common shares outstanding during each period assuming full conversion of preferred stock. The company said net income for the latest quarter benefited from a lower effective tax rate, reflecting a reduction of foreign tax rates, primarily in Canada and Europe.

title: Reviews/Music; Colombian Group Steps Into Salsa Circuit
description: Grupo Niche, from Colombia, stepped into the New York salsa circuit on Monday night at the Salsa Meets Jazz series at the Village Gate. While many salsa bands carry on a style established in the 1950's by Cuban, Puerto Rican and New York bands, the 12-member Grupo Niche, one of South America's most popular groups, shows how salsa has evolved in the 1980's.

title: Olin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
C. A. O'Malley, 71, Ex-Insurance Executive
description: Charles A. O'Malley, former chairman of Fred S. James & Company, an insurance brokerage firm, died of leukemia on Saturday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 71 years old and lived in Stuart, Fla.

title: Yields Rise Only Slightly For Savers
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money-market accounts were only slightly higher in the week ended yesterday. The upward cycle for interest rates appears to be nearing an end.

title: Wright, Stepping Up His Defense, Releases Data on Work by Wife
description: Speaker Jim Wright intensified his defense both privately and publicly today, trying to shore up support among his fellow House Democrats and releasing documents to buttress his contention that his wife earned the salary paid her by an investment company.

title: Lilly and Dow to Combine Farm Chemical Divisions
description: In the latest in a wave of joint ventures, mergers and acquisitions in the drug and chemical industries, Eli Lilly & Company and the Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that they were combining their worldwide agricultural chemical divisions in a joint venture.

title: Remaking of a Politician: Betty Wright's Influence
description: For better or worse, Betty Wright has remade her husband.

title: Comerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reduced by 21 cents a share by a non-recurring $5 million pretax charge for settlements with bank card merchants who were affected by the bankruptcy proceedings of their processing bureau, Check Reporting Services Inc.

title: Playboy Publisher
description: Playboy magazine yesterday named a 36-year-old magazine executive to succeed Hugh Hefner as publisher. Michael Perlis, president of International Data Group/Peterborough, a computer-magazine publishing company, will head the flagship magazine of Playboy Enterprises Inc. Mr. Hefner remains as editor in chief of Playboy and was publisher until November, when he went into semiretirement. James Spanfeller, the New York advertising sales director of Newsweek magazine, was named associate publisher and senior vice president in the management realignment.

title: Midlantic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the earnings improvement to a 16.7 percent increase in net interest income resulting from growth in all sectors of the loan portfolio and a higher net interest margin.

title: Chips & Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Darling (0-3) Is Rocked Again as Phillies Roll
description: On the night after they hit three home runs on four pitches and shook down the memories, the Mets not only stopped hitting but also stopped pitching last night and subsided one more time into the state of absolute tameness that has silenced their season.

title: Review/Theater; In Short, It's Chekhov, Strindberg and O'Neill
description: Each of the one-act plays grouped under the title ''Serious Company'' is a monologue, or near-monologue, and a natural for an actor's audition. Play the proper notes and they would seem to be three easy pieces.

title: Mexico Starts Debt Talk Today With New Hope
description: The Mexican Government begins debt negotiations in New York on Wednesday with the committee representing its commercial bank creditors, convinced that last week's agreement with the International Monetary Fund provided new leverage that will eventually allow Mexico to reduce the annual outflow stemming from its debt by as much as two-thirds.

title: INFLATION HIGHER
description: Consumer prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in March, maintaining a 6.1 percent annual inflation rate for the first quarter of the year, the Government said today. This compared with a 4.4 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for all of 1988.

title: 'Staying After School' Opens Doors to Learning
description: The face of 10-year-old Aisha Holliday radiated enthusiam as her body moved in time to the music in a recent after-school dance class at Public School 208 in Harlem. Ever since she could remember, she wanted to be a dancer, Aisha said at a break in the class, but she had never had an opportunity to do anything about it until the current class began last year.

title: Teach College Teachers to, Yes, Teach, Panel Says
description: The art of teaching college students is not valued enough on the nation's campuses, a panel of educators said in a report being released today. The report said that too many college teachers are poorly trained to teach and that those who do become good teachers are not well rewarded.

title: Mazda to Purchase Engines From Ford
description: The Mazda Motor Manufacturing Corporation said it would buy engines for its United States-built cars from the Ford Motor Company, bucking the trend of several Japanese car makers, which plan to begin making their own engines in the United States.

title: Patent Is Won By Quarterdeck
description: Quarterdeck Office Systems, a software company based in Santa Monica, Calif., said today that it had been awarded a patent by the United States Patent Office for a program which permits multiple personal computer programs using the MS-DOS operating system to run simultaneously in ''windows,'' which divide a computer screen to allow a user to see more than one operation at a time. Titled ''An Improved Display

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL AMERICAN LEAGUE - Approved the sale of the Texas Rangers to a group headed by George W. Bush Jr. and the Baltimore Orioles to a group headed by Eli S. Jacobs. TEXAS (AL) - Placed Craig McMurtry, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Purchased the contract of Drew Hall, pitcher, from Oklahoma City of the American Association. Assigned Bill Scherrer, pitcher, to Oklahoma City. MONTREAL (NL) - Agreed to terms with Dennis Martinez, pitcher, on a one-year contract extension through the 1990 season. FOOTBALL DALLAS (NFC) - Approved the sale of the Cowboys to Jerry Jones. Announced the resignation of Tex Schramm, president, to head the International Football League. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Signed Ken Sims, defensive end, to a one-year contract. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Announced it will not offer a contract to Babe Laufenberg, quarterback. HOCKEY TEAM USA - Added Dave Christian, forward, and Cleon Daskalakis, goalie, to the team competing in the World Championships. COLLEGE CALIFORNIA BOWL - Announced the retirement of Glenn Driscoll, executive director. C. W. POST - Named Gloria O'Connor women's field hockey coach. DUQUESNE - Named John Carroll men's head basketball coach. INDIANA STATE - Named Andrea Myers associate athletic director. WESTERN CAROLINA - Named Dale Strahm head football coach.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about the settlement between Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the Securities and Exchange Commission misstated the scope of one provision in some editions. Drexel waived its attorney-client privilege of confidentiality on only certain files, involving two employees. The firm did not open all its files to the Government.

title: EATING OUT with Malcolm Forbes; Uncommon Tastes Of a Passionate Man
description: MALCOLM FORBES is one of those bouyant individuals who seem viscerally incapable of indifference on any topic. During a recent lunch at La Reserve on West 49th Street in Manhattan, the conversation touched upon just a few of his passions, among them restaurants, wine, journalism, motorcycles, balloons, yachts, art, necrology, France, corned beef hash and cappuccino ''with granulated sugar sprinkled all over the foam so that every time you take a sip you get some of the sugar - delicious!''

title: Bill Brown, Football Coach, 52
description: Bill Brown, assistant football coach at Hofstra University who played briefly in the American Football League, died of cancer tonight. He was 52 years old.

title: Piety in the Gas Field
description: My lecture fee is $25,000. That's for 20 minutes. If you want more than 20 minutes, you pay overtime. For eating a meal before the speech, I charge a $5,000 bonus. Will pose for photos with up to five members of the program committee without additional charge, provided you pay the $5,000 eat-the-meal bonus.

title: First Ohio Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2.4 million from an accounting change.

title: Neworld Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Vermont Financial Services Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Henry C. Howells, 88, Popularizer of Wines
description: Henry C. Howells, who was active in the popularization of French wines in the United States, died on Monday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old and also lived in Stonington, Conn.

title: Curbs Seen at Chicago Merc
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the world's second-largest commodity market, is expected to announce on Wednesday that it will sharply limit ''dual trading,'' the practice in which floor brokers execute orders for themselves and their customers on the same day, creating a potential conflict of interest.

title:
Books of The Times;
Unextinguished Hope and America's Story
description: LEAD: The Crosswinds of Freedom The American Experiment, Vol. III By James MacGregor Burns Illustrated. 864 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: War in Beirut: 'Bombardment of the Innocent'
description: After another night of heavy artillery battles, Beirut residents emerged today to find devastation even beyond what has become the norm in 14 years of civil strife.

title: California Winery Does Only Whites
description: ''WE'RE a renegade winery,'' said Vivien Gay, director of sales and marketing of the Callaway Vineyard and Winery, as she unpacked bottles and talked about bucking industry trends.

title: First Regional Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Pop Life
description: A Hit for Living Colour

title: Mischer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,692,000 for the quarter and $2,370,000 for the year, and a loss of $1,141,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations for the both periods. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $810,000 for the quarter and $2,062,000 for the year.

title: NATO Looks to Newer, Fewer Arms
description: A classified study by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military commander states that the alliance can significantly cut the size of its nuclear arsenal if it deploys a successor to old Lance short-range missiles and modernizes other atomic weapons, according to Administration officials.

title: Continental Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
House Clears Way to Close 86 Military Bases Beginning in January
description: The House voted overwhelmingly today to support a plan to close 86 military bases by 1995 and scale back five others despite complaints that the move would not save as much money as had been promised.

title: Price Riot in Jordan
description: Riots over price increases erupted in Maan in southern Jordan today and at least 17 people were injured as some 4,000 people attacked shops and set cars on fire, a hospital source said. Security forces opened fire to disperse the demonstrators, the source said. Reached by telephone from Amman, the source said 17 people were being treated at a hospital in Maan.

title: Coniston Reduces Its Stake in UAL
description: Coniston Partners, the New York investment partnership, has lowered its stake in UAL Inc. to 4 percent from 6.5 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Coniston gave no reason for the sale of the UAL shares. UAL is the Chicago-based holding company for United Airlines.

title: Mixed Reviews for Lloyd Webber Musical
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Aspects of Love,'' which opened in London Monday, has received widely disparate reviews, with one British critic proclaiming the romantic musical the composer's ''best so far'' and another calling it ''really nothing special.''

title: BITTERNESS MARKS NORTH TRIAL CLOSE
description: In closing arguments today in the trial of Oliver L. North, the chief prosecutor invoked the Bible and Hitler in painting Mr. North as a habitual liar, while the chief defense attorney castigated the Government as ''off track and running wild'' in its zeal to win a conviction.

title: Mellon Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $24 million gain related to Mellon's capital financing program. The gain resulted from the early retirement of Mellon's 7 l/4 percent convertible subordinated capital notes due 1999. The higher net in the latest quarter reflected increased net interest revenue and service fee revenue and decreases in operating expense and the provision for credit losses. The company said its provision for credit losses was $35 million in the latest quarter, down from $45 million a year ago. The reserve for credit losses totaled $887 million, or 4.82 percent of total loans, at March 31, compard with $909 million, or 4.79 percent at year-end 1988. Mellon has total assets of $31.3 billion.

title: Citicorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included an aftertax gain of $77 million from the sale of Citicorp's Tokyo real estate.

title: On the Hill, Approved Conduct Is Defined Broadly
description: He buttonholed the president of Egypt on behalf of a Texas oil man who cut him in on drilling ventures. He held up crucial banking legislation and tried to get a Federal savings and loan regulator dismissed to help a Texas entrepreneur in a fight to save his real estate holdings.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: WHEN Taemo and Yisoon Kim bought an Italian restaurant here from its Lebanese owner, they began adding Korean dishes to the menu in an effort to increase business.

title: FNW Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
One Era Ends and Another One Begins for the Dallas Cowboys
description: Tex Schramm resigned yesterday in New York as the Dallas Cowboys' president and general manager to become president of the new International Football League, and the purchase of the Dallas franchise by the Arkansas businessman Jerry Jones for $140 million was approved, closing one chapter in Cowboys history and opening a new one.

title: Bill Johnson Surgery
description: The downhill racer Bill Johnson has undergone surgery for removal of a ruptured disk in his lower back and faces extensive rehabilitation.

title: Lukens Inc reports earnings for 13wks to April 1
Bankers Trust Corp of New York reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank said the first quarter earnings improvement resulted primarily from increased non-interest revenue, partially offset by increases in non-interest expenses and the provision for credit losses. The bank also said non-interest revenue totaled $485.4 million in the latest quarter, an increase of 47 percent from the year-ago period. The increase was attributable to higher revenue from trading activities, as well as increases in other non-interest revenue and trust and custodian revenue.

title: 58% Say Koch Should Not Run
description: Fewer than one in three New York City voters approve of the job Mayor Edward I. Koch is doing, and more than half say they do not want him to seek re-election this year, according to a poll released yesterday by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion.

title: Blount Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included gains on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,148,000 for the quarter and $118,167,000 for the year, and the year also included income from discontinued operations of $12,582,000 and a loss of $10,834,000 from an accounting change. c-After income from discontinued operations $4,682,000 and $17,332,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago results are restated.

title: SUNY Tuition Would Rise Under Plan
description: Tuition at the State University of New York would rise by $200 this fall, the first increase in six years, under the state budget that legislative leaders agreed to today.

title: Nuremberg Defense Out of Place in a U.S. Court
description: To the Editor:

title: United National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mid-Hudson Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Food Notes
description: Fighting Hunger

title: Lucille Ball Undergoes 7-Hour Heart Operation
description: Lucille Ball suffered a heart attack and underwent seven hours of open-heart surgery today. After the operation, her surgeon said her condition was guarded and that the next 24 hours would determine how well her recovery would go.

title: Canadian Pacific Forest Prodcts Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures are presented on a pro-forma basis, as if the merger of Great Lakes Forest Products Ltd. and Cip Inc. to form CP Forest had taken place Jan. 1, 1988. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Containers That Count
description: DELIVERED food can be as good, or as bad, as the container it's packed in. Fortunately, the growth of restaurant delivery is leading to new developments in packaging.

title: Campbell Sale Is Denied
description: The family of the late former chairman of the Campbell Soup Company, said today that speculation that the family would sell its stake in the company was without merit. The family of John T. Dorrance Jr., who died on April 9 at the age of 70, owns 58 percent of Campbell's stock. The shares soared after Mr. Dorrance's death on speculation that his heirs would consider selling the company.

title: Soviets Report Use of Toxic Gas In Putting Down Strife in Georgia
description: An official medical commission investigating the clash between Georgian protesters and Soviet riot troops has determined that some victims were poisoned by ''chemical agents,'' the Government newspaper Izvestia reported tonight.

title: Shad All Ready at Site Of Contest on Delaware
description: As of a week ago, shad had already reached the portion of the Delaware River where, as in previous years, the headquarters of the ''Gone Shad Fishing'' contest will be situated.

title: Allied-Signal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oil Changes: Fast and Competitive
description: Changing a car's motor oil may seem a small and mundane event, hardly the premise for an entire industry. Nevertheless, the nation's biggest car makers have cast an envious gaze on the ''10-minute oil change,'' a growing business born of two-worker households and a decline in the number of garages and gasoline stations with trained mechanics.

title: Age Bias Is Personal War for Vermont Justice
description: The Vermont Constitution says Louis Peck is too old to serve as a justice of the Supreme Court. Justice Peck disagrees, and continues to hear and decide cases on the state's highest court.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Basketball; Knick Assistant Joins Dayton as Head Coach
description: Jim O'Brien, an assistant coach for the Knicks, was named head basketball coach at the University of Dayton yesterday, replacing Don Donoher. Before joining the Knicks last season, the 36-year-old O'Brien coached Wheeling Jesuit College in West Virginia, where he posted a 74-69 record.

title: 23 Arabs Shot and Wounded In Gaza, Hospital Aides Say
description: Soldiers shot and wounded 23 Palestinians in the occupied Gaza Strip today, and 11 victims were children, hospital officials said.

title: Possible Action On Executives
description: David S. Ruder, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told a Congressional subcommittee today that his agency might still take disciplinary action against top officials of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance, asked Mr. Ruder why no action had been taken against Drexel officials, specifically the chief executive, Frederick H. Joseph.

title: N.B.A. Must Get Tougher On Its Toughs
description: rrAs the National Basketball Association awaits its playoffs, the Detroit Pistons have the best record and the worst rap sheet. Including two preseason skirmishes, five different Pistons have been fined a total of $27,500 for seven violence-related incidents, mostly fighting. Rick Mahorn has been fined a total of $11,000 for three incidents, Bill Laimbeer $6,000 for two. Isiah Thomas was not only fined $5,000 recently but also docked an estimated $60,000 in salary during a two-game suspension. And if glaring confrontations were included in box scores, the Pistons surely would lead the league in that category.

title: Baltimore Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $323,000 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: Bergner Raises Offer For Carson Pirie Scott
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago-based department store chain, said yesterday that P. A. Bergner & Company of Milwaukee had raised its unsolicited takeover proposal to $24 a share from the original $20 offer of April 3.

title: The 'Cottage' Life
description: To The Home Section:
