title: Amnesty for Drug Users
description: For a limited time only, drug users in Maryland's Worcester County can avoid prosecution by deciding to kick their habit and turning in their suppliers. An advertisement in several weekly newspapers offers amnesty from prosecution until May 15 and includes a phone number to the county's special narcotics team. State's Attorney B. Randall Coates said, ''On Friday, we got so many phone calls we had to advise the people who were calling to call back this week because we couldn't process them all.''

title: Q&A
description: Dripping Noise Q.We have an 8-year-old house. After the toilet is flushed and the tank has filled there is a noise that sounds like water dripping. It lasts about five minutes, yet there is no evidence of water leaking anywhere. What is causing this, and what we can do? A.After the tank fills, water probably keeps dripping into the tank or into the bowl, from the tank. The water probably comes from the small fill tube that goes into the top of the vertical overflow tube in the center of the tank. The drip is possibly due to the fact that the ballcock (the inlet valve) does not shut off completely when the tank is full. Another possibility is that the flapper valve (or rubber ball) at the bottom of the tank needs replacing. This is supposed to drop down and seal off the opening in the bottom as the tank fills. If it does not does this properly it could be allowing water to drip down into the bowl, causing the noise. Attic Humidity Q.Due to an addition that was built onto our house, the attic is in two sections. An opening of about 50 square feet connects the two areas. We are having a severe humidity problem in the new section; the underside of the roof is turning black with mildew and the wood is damp. The new section has five roof vents and three eave vents. One repairman said the problem was due to not enough air circulation and suggested that a roof fan, activated by a humidistat, be installed there. Another said the problem was due to too much cold air coming into the attic and suggested closing off several of the roof vents. What do you think? A.I think the first repairman is right; more ventilation is needed, especially in cold weather. Either there are not enough vents in the eaves and in the ridge or peak, or the vents are just not large enough. An attic fan might help, but only if there are enough vents to bring in the amount of air needed to vent the attic space properly. Weeds Under a Deck Q.I plan to build a wood deck in my backyard. What should I do to prevent weeds coming up through the spaced floorboards of the deck? A.If the deck is to be right on the ground, the usual method is to dig out about three inches of the soil and fill the space with gravel before setting up the deck. It helps if you first treat the soil under the gravel with a week killer. If the deck will be raised, a common method is to cover the soil underneath with a layer of heavy-gauge sheet plastic, weighing it down with bricks or large stones.

title: Jailed 'Monster' Gets More Prison Time for Stabbing a Guard
description: Willie Bosket, proclaiming that ''I'll haunt this damn system,'' was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison today in the stabbing of a prison guard last year.

title: INSIDE
description: High Ratings for Bush

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Basketball; Reinstated at Missouri
description: The Missouri assistant basketball coach, Bob Sundvold, who was suspended after reportedly buying airline tickets for a recruit, will be reinstated May 1, Dick Tamburo, the athletic director, said Tuesday.

title: Michigan National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $8,325,000 from an accounting change.

title: Republic New York Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter results included earnings from Republic New York's 48.6 percent investment in Safra Republic holdings on an equity accounting basis. The year-ago quarter's earnings included results of these subsidiaries on a fully consolidated basis.

title: Personal Health
description: Last month, three men I know were examined by magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., one of the latest and perhaps the most exciting innovation in diagnostic radiology since the development of X-rays.

title: Preston Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Japonica Seeks To Buy CNW
description: Japonica Partners, an investor group that is seeking to replace the board of the CNW Corporation, said today that it intends to acquire CNW for ''a substantial premium'' over an unsuccessful $31-a-share offer made last year by a management group and Gibbons Green, van Amerongen, an investment firm in New York.

title: Statue Atop Capitol to Be Removed for Work
description: The bronze statue of Freedom atop the Capitol's dome is so badly deteriorated after 125 years that it will be removed, probably by helicopter, and restored, the building's restoration architect says.

title: Ashland Coal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $2,029,000, or 15 cents a share, from the favorable effect of an accounting change. The latest first quarter results included Coal-Inc. which was acquired in January 1989.

title: Stamp Is Sought to Send a Message on AIDS
description: Jean Anne Hlavacek simply will not take no for an answer.

title: Anchor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $2.3 million for the quarter and $6.9 million for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After tax credits of $2.5 million for the quarter and $5 million for the 9 months. The latest 9 months final net equals less than 1 cent per share because of preferred stock dividend requirements. Prior year periods have been restated to reflect the retroactive implementation of an accounting change regarding loan fees and origination costs.

title: Protestant Killed in Ulster
description: The nephew of a Protestant militant was found shot to death today, and gunmen seriously wounded a Roman Catholic man in another part of city, the police said. Authorities declined to say whether the attacks were linked, and no group immediately claimed responsibility for them. The police said that the Protestant victim, Francis Galbraith, 29 years old, was a nephew of a former high-ranking officer in the outlawed Ulster Volunteer Force.

title: Ralston Purina Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $71.3 million from discontinued operations. c-Included a gain of $4.6 million from the discontinuance of the company's Van Camp seafood operations for the quarter and income of $14.8 million from discontinued operations for the 6 months.

title: Nonunion Plan Is Set At Eastern by Lorenzo
description: Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, reaffirmed yesterday that Eastern Airlines was no longer for sale and that he planned to rebuild the airline with nonunion employees over the coming months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In one way, you hesitate to say that name, or even to think of it. It causes nausea. On the other hand I grew up already with the sense that Hitler and his Third Reich are part of the distant past, somewhere with emperors, dictators and other people suffering from delusions.'' - Ute Lemper, a West German cabaret star, on the centennial of Hitler's birth. A10:3. ]

ATTORNEY GENERAL OF SALVADOR SLAIN BY BOMB ON A CAR
description: The Salvadoran Attorney General was killed here today by a bomb put on the roof of his heavily armored car by suspected leftist guerrillas.

title: Ethiopia Asking U.S. for Full Diplomatic Ties
description: In the boldest move so far in a recent campaign to win friendly relations with the United States, the Ethiopian Government has asked the State Department to upgrade diplomatic ties.

title: CLOSE AT HOME
description: AT the southern end of Manhattan the grid collapses into pick-up-sticks, and the streets drop numbers for names. Because the island is narrow at this point, you can sometimes get a whiff of salt air, and very often a whiff of something cooking. Something Chinese maybe, or Italian, or Middle Eastern. There's a spot near the Chambers Street subway exit that smells exactly like Istanbul.

title: PNC Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest and year-ago first quarters reflected its merger with Bank of Delaware Corp., compeleted on March 31. The transaction was accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Bard, C R Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lucille Ball's Condition Is Serious After Surgery
description: Lucille Ball was reported in serious condition today after seven hours of open-heart surgery in which she received heart tissue from a 27-year-old man.

title: Wisconsin Blue Cross Succeeds as a Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Profits Increase in Quarter At 3 Large Drug Companies
description: In a generally strong first quarter for the pharmaceuticals industry, three companies reported yesterday that they had double-digit percentage gains in earnings.

title: General Dynamics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago earnings were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Ashton-Tate Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company changed its financial reporting year-end to Dec. 31 from Jan. 31 so the year-ago first quarter earnings figures are not directly comparable. In the first quarter ended April 30, 1988, the company had income of $11,064,000, or 43 cents a share, on revenue of $72,363,000.

title: Austin Joins a Pro Team
description: Tracy Austin, the winner of the women's singles title at the United States Open in 1979 and 1981, will play for the New Jersey Stars through their 14-match season in the Domino's Pizza Team Tennis League. Austin, 26 years old, will be joined by her brother John, a doubles specialist with whom she won the Wimbledon mixed doubles title in 1980.

title: Tribute for a Dauntless Bette Davis. Yes.
description: Ruth Elizabeth Davis wasn't a bit reluctant to say she celebrated her 81st birthday this month. ''I've certainly had a very long life,'' she said forthrightly, then continued in her staccato way: ''I don't have any real regrets. I can't say I have mellowed very much. I always spoke my mind. I did it the hard way. Though when I look back on it, perhaps I should have done it with less vinegar. And more sugar.''

title: Sabre System Cuts Its Price
description: After three months of trying to sell shares in Sabre, their joint reservations system, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines said on Tuesday that they were cutting the price by 25 percent on the first segment of the partnership to help speed Government approval.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Boxing; Tyson Sued for Assault
description: A Brooklyn woman sued Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, for $4.5 million yesterday accusing him of assault and battery in an incident at a Manhattan disco in December.

title: Help for Rain Forests, in the Shower
description: ''RAIN forests are being cut down at the rate of 100 acres every minute and an area the equivalent of Central Park every eight minutes,'' said Daniel Katz, president of the Rainforest Alliance. ''We've only got basically 10 years left to save them.'' To help the cause, Maytex Mills, a home textile company, has produced a rain-forest shower curtain, the profits of which will go to saving the Monteverde Nature Reserve in Costa Rica. The shower curtain is made of brightly colored clear vinyl and depicts a realistic tropical rain-forest scene.

title: LSI Lighting Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest third quarter included operations of Abolite Lighting which was acquired Jan. 1. LSI said the latest third quarter results did not include the operations of Screen Graphics which was acquired on April 17.

title: U.S. Prodded Again to Lift Fetal Tissue Ban
description: A second group of advisers to the National Institutes of Health has recommended that the Government lift a ban on medical research that uses tissue from aborted human fetuses.

title: Merc Panel Issues Proposals To Combat Trading Abuses
description: A special committee of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange issued a long list of recommendations today designed to eliminate trading abuse and quell growing public concern that cheating on the floor of the world's second-largest futures market has become all too common.

title: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter results reflected a $35.2 million pre-tax writedown of MCorp Securities held by the firm, a decline in investment banking revenue and lower net interest income. Partially offsetting these declines were higher commission and investment advisory revenue, along with a $16 million pre-tax reversal of reserves established in 1986 to cover potential losses stemming from the suspension of trading in tin by the London Metals Exchange. The reversal reflects a favorable judgment in the London high court upholding the company's claim against a counterparty in a tin contract. First quarter revenue and expenses include full effect of consolidating E.F. Hutton group, which was acquired in 1988. Year-ago results incorporated E.F. Hutton Financials as of Jan. 13, 1988. Also included in 1988 results was a $33 million pre-tax gain from the sale of the company's interest in McLeod Young Weir. Year-ago expenses include $50 million of non-recurring, pre-tax expenses related to the acquisition of E.F. Hutton.

title: Nacco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mine Safety Appliances Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Stock Surge Moderates as Dow Gains 7.51
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher yesterday, building on a rally that since Friday has pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest level since the October 1987 crash. But the surge moderated, even as trading volume remained strong.

title: Quantum Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $3,900,000 from discontinued operations. c-Included a gain of $5,300,000. The company said the latest first quarter results were reduced by $20.3 million to reflect non-recurring expenses in connection with financing the recapitalization and relocation of facilities. The company also said the estimated $119 million after-tax gain on its $480 million Emery sale, concluded on April 17, will be reported in the second quarter.

title: The New Chicago Style
description: THINGS are moving in Chicago. Older neighborhoods like Printer's Row, Lincoln Park, River North, Uptown and Bucktown are changing rapidly, thanks to an influx of developers and architects, as well as some who are a bit further afield - people in the design world who are are energetically challenging convention in the way they live.

title: Wells Fargo to Sell Its Asian Offices
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it would sell all of its Asian offices as part of a cooperative agreement with the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation that will expand the California bank's international services. Wells Fargo, the nation's 11th-largest bank, said it was selling its Tokyo, Seoul and Singapore offices and would turn over its Hong Kong office to the Asian bank.

title: Consolidated Rail Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Multibank Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Salomon Trims Equities Business
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. began cutting back its equities business, a move that is likely to result in between 20 and 50 people being laid off. A spokesman said that the firm remained committed to the global equities business, but was making the cuts in response to weak market conditions in the United States.

description: b-Included a $68,400,000 one-time gain for an accounting change.

title: Devjo Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Allied-Signal Net Up
description: Allied-Signal Inc. today announced a 12.5 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, attributing the rise in part to improved performance by its aerospace unit. The advanced technology company reported net income for the quarter of $126 million, or 85 cents a share, up from $112 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier. First-quarter revenue was flat at $2.94 billion. In addition to its aerospace business, Allied-Signal manufactures automotive products like anti-lock brake systems and airbags.

title: TV Notes
description: Garner as Producer On April 30 at 9 P.M., ABC will present ''My Name Is Bill W.,'' the 161st Hallmark Hall of Fame special. The program, which dramatizes the founding of Alcoholics Anonymous, was co-produced by James Garner and is his professional reunion with James Woods. In 1986, Mr. Garner played a middle-aged man and Mr. Woods his schizophrenic brother in the Emmy award-winning Hallmark feature ''Promise.'' In an interview this week, Mr. Garner said that he and his partner, Peter K. Duchow, had been trying to film ''My Name Is Bill W.'' for more than five years.

title: Big Offers for Drexel's Retail Unit Called Unlikely
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is unlikely to find a a buyer willing to pay much for its retail division, senior executives of Wall Street firms said yesterday.

title: Georgia Gulf Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Celebrating Masterly Wood Turning
description: WITH today's booming interest in contemporary American crafts, many art galleries are devoting exhibitions to highly specialized media. The Franklin Parrasch Galleries in Washington, for example, has just launched a show called ''The Grand Masters of Wood Turning'' examining the work of five wood-turning masters: David Ellsworth, Mark and Mel Linquist, Edward Moulthrop and Bob Stocksdale.

title: 5 Are Killed in South Jordan as Rioting Over Food Prices Spreads
description: Riots over price increases spread through towns in southern Jordan today and residents reported 5 people killed and 14 wounded in one of the most serious challenges to King Hussein's Government in years.

title: Morgan Products Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Loss for Shearson in Period
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. reported yesterday that it had a $15 million loss in the first quarter, compared with earnings of $74.7 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Alaska Oil Spill Offers A Public Relations Test
description: LEAD: Lecturers at the Global Public Affairs Institute, which opened in January, did not have long to wait for current subject matter. The catastrophic Alaskan oil spill - and the thorny public relations problem it has posed for Exxon - can provide plentiful lessons in corporate public relations.

title: Jostens Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $42,183,000.

title: Bill to Ban Fax Ads Gains
description: The House of Representatives approved today a bill prohibiting unsolicited advertising messages on telephone facsimile, or fax, machines. Violators could be sued for $200 or actual damages, including lawyers' fees. The bill, approved 140 to 1, was sent to the Senate.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Basketball; Cavaliers' Price Ailing
description: Mark Price, a Cleveland Cavaliers guard, will miss the next two games after he suffered a muscle strain in his groin, Bob Price, a Cavaliers spokesman, said yesterday. Price injured the muscle in the fourth quarter of Cleveland's 118-102 loss to the Detroit Pistons Tuesday.(AP)

title: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
Ms. Capellini Wed To R. E. Bendelac
description: Suzanne Marie Capellini, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Capellini of Brooklyn, was married yesterday in Rome in a civil ceremony to Roger Emile Bendelac, a son of David Bendelac of Paris and the late Marie Bendelac.

title: Campaign Aide of Senator Said to Admit Taking Money
description: Senator Dennis DeConcini's longtime campaign treasurer has admitted taking some $500,000 from re-election bank accounts, the Senator's spokesman said Wednesday.

title: Arvin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Net loss and included a loss of $1,348,000 from discontinued operations. The company said last year's first quarter has been restated to exclude the electronics division which is now reported as a discontinued operation.

title: Chairs for Children, In the Realm of Fantasy
description: CARTOONLIKE angels and cowboys, princesses and kings, rabbits and elephants take the form of children's chairs in Bill Bragdon's New Hope, Pa., studio.

title: Selective Service Considering Plan To Draft Medical Workers Swiftly
description: The Selective Service System is preparing a plan to revive the conscription of doctors and expand that draft to include other medical personnel in a military emergency, officials at the agency said today.

title: Homeowners Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEALTH: Psychology; Researchers Find That Optimism Helps the Body's Defense System
description: Working together for the first time, psychologists and immunologists are producing surprising new evidence that altering a patient's mental state can boost the immune system.

title: Senate Panel Approves Compromise on Budget
description: The Senate Budget Committee gave bipartisan approval to a $1.16 trillion budget for the 1990 fiscal year today, a document that reflects the deficit-cutting arrangement between President Bush and Congress.

title: Pentagon Chief Urges Canceling Midgetman Plan
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has recommended to President Bush that the United States cancel the program to develop a truck-borne Midgetman missile and proceed with a plan to put MX missiles on rail cars.

title: Mark IV Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results for fiscal 1989 included after-tax gains of $9,930,000, or 92 cents a share, from the sale of securities and assets. In addition, 1989 results were negatively affected by a $5.5 million after- tax negative interest rate spread, a higher level of interest expense than interest income, in connection with an acquisition. The net income for fiscal 1988 included an after-tax gain of $1,256,000, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of Baird Corp. common stock. Mark IV's 1989 results included 5 months of the operations of Dayco and Blackstone, two Armtek Corp. units acquired in October 1988. Figures also included the results of Cetec Corp. from July 1, 1988; Conrac from May 1, 1987, and Eagle Signal from June 1, 1987.

title: EXPLOSION AND FIRE KILL AT LEAST 47 ON NAVY WARSHIP
description: At least 47 sailors were killed today when an explosion and fire tore through a huge gun turret aboard the battleship Iowa about 300 miles northeast of Puerto Rico.

title: Big Asteroid Passes Near Earth Unseen In a Rare Close Call
description: In cosmic terms, it was a close call.

description: b-Included a credit of $273 million, or $1.17 a share. The company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96, Accounting for Income Taxes, in 1988. In conformity with SFAS 96, the cumulative effect of the change up to Jan. 1, 1988 ($273 million increase to net earnings and $1.17 to earnings a share) was restated in the first quarter of 1988, even though the decision to adopt was made at year-end 1988. Also as required, 1988 quarterly earnings have been restated for the effects of this change, which resulted in a reduction in first quarter 1988 net earnings and earnings per share of $12 million and 6 cents, respectively.Kraft, Inc. became a wholly-owned subsidiary on Dec. 7, 1988. THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
An Inquiry Into Ethics Of Some Ads
description: LEAD: IMAGINE that a governor buys a pearl-decorated handgun for his wife, and that she uses it to wing an assailant. The maker of the gun renames the model the First Lady and hires the woman to appear in print advertisements. Should newspapers run the ad? ''We wouldn't take it,'' said Cathleen Black, publisher of USA Today, at a Manhattan conference Tuesday on ethics in advertising.

description: A WET spot on the ceiling of the top floor of a house is usually the first sign of a leaking roof. Early spring is the season for roof leaks. Most often, the cause is wind-driven rain penetrating roofing that has been weakened or damaged by winter weather.

title: Girl Hurt by Bomb Improves
description: A 5-year-old girl who lost most of her left hand when a bomb inside a toothpaste container exploded Monday night was reported in improved condition at a hospital today. A spokesman for Methodist Hospital, David Richards, said Erin Bower was in fair condition, upgraded from serious. The explosion, at a discount store, also resulted in a severe injury to her left eye, and she may recover only partial sight, doctors said.

title: United Investors Management Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Crude Oil And Gasoline Prices Jump
description: Crude oil prices, sparked by the shutdown of part of a North Sea oil field, rose sharply yesterday, reaching their highest level in more than three years.

title: A 2-House Legislature for New York City?
description: Does New York City need a Senate? Or a House of Boroughs, a Borough Council, a Board of Borough Representatives or a new body by any other name to be the second house in a bicameral legislature?

title: Talking Deals; Betting on the Sale Of Newmont
description: TWO months ago the Newmont Mining Corporation looked like a pretty good takeover target, and stockholders thought they might make a lot of money. Today they are not so sure.

title: Randolph Mauldin, 37, Conductor and Coach
description: Randolph Mauldin, conductor and music administrator for the Washington (D.C.) Opera and a conductor of Broadway musicals, died Sunday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 37 years old.

title: The Life and Hard Times of Metaphor
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: HOCKEY Team USA Is Eliminated Team USA lost its fourth straight game, a 5-4 decision to Czechoslovakia, and was eliminated from medal play at the world hockey championships yesterday. Team Canada beat West Germany, 8-2, and the Soviet Union routed Poland, 12-1, at the Globe Arena in Stockholm to improve their records to 4-0. Sweden, the defending champion, beat Finland, 6-3, to tie Czechoslovakia at 3-0-1.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Pro Bono
description: LEAD: * The New York City Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution has named Lowe Marshalk Inc. to create advertising for this spring's celebration of the 200th anniversary of George Washington's inauguration.

title: Gtech Corp reports earnings for Year to Feb 25
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,405,000 and $5,720,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively, and a gain of $974,000 from an accounting change for the latest year and a tax credit of $692,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest year included a gain of $2,688,000 from the sale of an investment.

title: Philip Morris Earnings Off
description: The Philip Morris Companies reported yesterday that its earnings fell 22.7 percent in the first quarter, to $590 million, from $763 million in the corresponding period last year. Meanwhile, American Brands Inc. reported a 14.4 percent increase in quarterly profits.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Magazine Takes Aim At Hispanic Market
description: LEAD: Manuel A. Casiano believes that middle- and upper-income Hispanic Americans are an untapped market for magazines. Mr. Casiano, who heads Casiano Communications, a publishing company in San Juan, P.R., is betting that a glossy magazine can carve out a prosperous niche in the nation's estimated one million Hispanic households.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Experts Urge Dental Exam Before Treatment for Cancer
description: Cancer therapy can cause dental and oral complications so severe that they can compromise cancer treatment and recovery, dental experts said today in recommending that cancer patients get thorough oral examinations before treatment.

title: Washington Mutual Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jersey Unit Offers Tax-Exempt Issue
description: The New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency is offering $80 million of tax-exempt home buyer revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.90 percent for an issue due 2022 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Signet Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Keystone Financial Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Brazil Needs Help, Not Scorn
description: The reckless destruction of the Amazon rain forest is surely among the worst of the world's ecological disasters. Encouraged by Brazil's Government, cattle ranchers and landless settlers have set fire to huge sections of Rondonia, in western Brazil, fouling the air and laying waste to a rich and precious natural wonder.

title: Ipsco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section on April 12 about seders in Alsace, omitted the title and date of a book that referred to the dish maguen farci a l'alsacienne. It is ''Cuisine Juive Ghettos Modernes,'' published in 1929 by Albin Michel. The author's name was also given incompletely; he was Edouard de Pomiane. The article also misidentified a history professor at the University of California at Los Angeles. He is Eugen Weber.

title: Offer for Pennwalt Extended 3 Weeks
description: The French oil and chemical company that last month agreed to acquire the Pennwalt Corporation has extended its tender offer three weeks. Officials for Elf Aquitaine's subsidiary AC Development Inc. said the offer of $132 a share, or a total of about $1.1 billion, for the pharmaceutical company's stock would expire May 19 instead of April 21.

title: Zions Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included a tax credit of $16,000, or 1 cent per share.

title: Watkins-Johnson Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Accounts
description: LEAD: * Midway Airlines, to Porter/Novelli, Chicago, for its public relations account.

title: Air Products & Chemicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included after-tax gains of $2.5 million from an one-time power cost adjustment and $2.5 million from the sale of businesses, or a total of 9 cents a share. c-Included an after-tax gain of $4.7 million, or 9 cents a share, from the resale of a 50 percent interest in a cogeneration project.

title: Earnings Off At Genentech
description: Genentech Inc. today reported lower earnings for the first quarter, which it attributed to increased expenses for marketing and for research and development. But the company also registered significantly higher sales of its drug for dissolving blood clots, tissue plasminogen activator, or Activase, which had been selling below expectations.

title: Sphinx Mining reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Budget Accord Fails to Dispel Fiscal Worries
description: With the passage of New York State's $47 billion budget early yesterday morning, state officials congratulated one another on averting a potential fiscal disaster for the coming year. But experts who follow the state's finances warned yesterday that despite the budget accord in Albany, the state's financial condition was likely to remain shaky for several years.

title: 400 Ex-Babies Listen Raptly to Dr. Spock
description: DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK spoke to three generations Monday night at the New York Public Library. The older people had often thumbed frantically through his classic ''Baby and Child Care,'' a screaming infant in one arm. Those in the middle years had probably been raised by its precepts. And many of the young had doubtless burrowed in it for the same reassurance their parents and grandparents had once found.

title: CHRISTIANS' SPLIT GROWS IN LEBANON
description: Sporadic shelling kept tension high here today as a split deepened between the nation's Christians over the latest fighting.

title: Charles Holle, 90, a Retired Army General
description: Charles G. Holle, a retired Army major general who was former deputy chief of the Army Corps of Engineers, died of pneumonia and complications of a stroke Monday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 90 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Canadiens Lead by 2-0
description: Bobby Smith scored on a backhander at 12 minutes 24 seconds of overtime tonight, giving the Montreal Canadiens a 3-2 victory over the Boston Bruins and a two-game lead in the Adams Division final.

title: Viola Wins Raise, Loses Game
description: Matt Nokes's two-run ninth-inning homer spoiled Frank Viola's $7.9 million birthday party today and lifted the Detroit Tigers to a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Aging Photographers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ginowan Journal; An Island of Resentment: Okinawa Feels Betrayed
description: When some American paratroopers landed in a privately owned field during exercises near this town the other day, a bit outside their designated landing range, they braced themselves for trouble. Quickly, some angry local villagers surrounded them, there was a scuffle, and the paratroopers had to be rescued by the military police.

title: Birmingham Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dissatisfied Soviet Writers Clamor For New Spokesmen
description: Hundreds of writers disenchanted with the dictates of the powerful Soviet writers' union gathered today to proclaim an alternative force and vow better days for their Government-plagued muse.

title: Japanese Takeover Bid
description: General Ceramics Inc. of Haskell, N.J., will divest itself of units involved in nuclear weapons production to meet objections raised by the Bush Administration to a takeover by the Tokuyama Soda Company of Tokyo, Administration officials said today. According to the officials, the Energy Department is working with the company on a divestment plan, but details were unavailable.

title: Review/Television; Of the Threats in the Workplace, on ABC
description: Tonight's issue of the ''Burning Questions'' series on ABC, filled with case histories of workers who have been killed or injured on the job, is itself a case history of the strengths and disabilities of television documentaries. ''Working in America: Hazardous Duty,'' being shown at 10 P.M., is emotionally moving as it recounts the sufferings of the workers and their families. But it resolutely fails to confront the social costs of reducing risk.

title: Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed
description: Treasury bond and note prices were narrowly mixed in a slow, generally featureless session yesterday.

title: Wright: Cool the Politics . . .
description: The ethical problems of a member of Congress should not be fuel for political arson. But the Democrats' handling of the ethics investigation of the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, has transformed a nonpartisan issue into a partisan firestorm.

title: Reviews/Music; Manilow Recounts a Tale Of Brooklyn to Broadway
description: ''In my heart I will always be a hopeless - no, make that a hopeful -romantic,'' Barry Manilow said at Tuesday's opening night show of his monthlong engagement at the Gershwin Theater on Broadway. The 42-year-old singer's confessions, like the rest of his remarks, were greeted with squeals by the loyal female fans who have been swarming to his concerts since he scored his first major hit 14 years ago.

title: In Fabrics, Orchids Upstage the Rose
description: LEAD: IN the spring fabric collections now appearing in the decorators' showrooms, color is intense, scale is enormous and rich textures and pattern-on-pattern prints dominate.

title: FMC Gold Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bankers First Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tusks Taken Off the Block
description: Four pairs of African elephant tusks, two from adult elephants and two from juveniles, were removed yesterday by Sotheby's from an auction to be held tomorrow. The Friends of Animals and the African Wildlife Foundation had protested the sale.

title: At El Teddy's, 60 Years of Design History in Bits and Pieces
description: A PASTICHE of its former lives, El Teddy's is the fourth and newest incarnation of a restaurant that has been at 219 West Broadway, near White Street, in TriBeCa since the 1920's.

title: Gentex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
S.A.S. to Buy Stake In Hotels Group
description: Scandinavian Airlines System has agreed to pay Japan's giant Saison Group $500 million for a 40 percent stake in its Inter-Continental Hotels group. Saison, a retail and leisure conglomerate with annual sales of nearly $30 billion, bought the Inter-Continental group, which has 106 hotels, from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. four months ago for $2.15 billion.

title: Morrison Knudsen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $535,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Rise in Fund Yields Eases
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds were up for the week that ended yesterday, but for the second straight week the increase was less than in the week before.

title: Plessey Plan Gets Support
description: The European Commission today gave tentative approval to a hostile joint bid by the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain and Siemens A.G. of West Germany for the Plessey Company, the British electronics concern.

title: First American Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
China Called Top Copyright Pirate
description: Companies producing books, records, films, computer software and other so-called intellectual property contended today that 12 countries, headed by China, are depriving the United States of more than $1.3 billion a year of foreign earnings through piracy of copyrighted material.

title: Warner Net Jumps 46.6%
description: Warner Communications, the big communications and entertainment company, said yesterday that its net income jumped 46.6 percent to a record level in the first quarter.

title: Review/Television; NBC Series Is Changed From Soap Into Sitcom
description: Collectors of show-business disasters were understandably thrilled this season with Broadway's ''Legs Diamond.'' Now, as the frosting on the cupcake, they have television's ''Nick and Hillary.'' It can be seen tonight at 9:30 on NBC. Next week it will be shown on Wednesday night at 9:30. Future episodes, NBC swears, ''will be announced soon.'' Collectors be warned: time's a-wasting.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of IMS International on May 26, 1988, accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Delay Seems Likely in Drexel Case
description: A decision yesterday by a Federal appeals panel in Manhattan could delay for months, or longer, the court approval necessary to complete proposed settlements of criminal and civil charges against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Soo Line Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it recorded $6,000,000 in non-operating income in the first quarter, including a $4.1 million pretax gain from the sale of half of its stake in Trailer Train Corp. and $1 million in government funding.

title: American Medical Exploring Options
description: The special committee of the board of American Medical Inc. said today that it would explore ''other alternatives'' to the two previously an nounced acquisition and restructuring proposals it is considering. In a press release issued late today, the special committee said that ''it is appropriate at this stage to consider all serious acquisition interest presented by credible parties, as well as recapitalization alternatives in addition to the restrusturing proposal currently being evaluated.''

title: Events: Honored Quilts From 10 Nations
description: A Traditional Theme, Pier 92, Hudson River at 52d Street; 212-977-7170.

title: Coors, Adolph Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 19
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $2,700,000. c-Net income

title: Finning Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: American Telephone & Teleraph Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said this year's first quarter results reflect the acquisitions of Paradyne Corp. and Eaton Financial Corp. The company also said the latest first quarter net was reduced by $88 million for a change in depreciation method and concurrent changes in estimates of depreciable lives and net salvage for certain telecommunications plant. Year-ago first quarter results were restated to reflect the consolidation of AT&T Credit Corp.

title: Officers Cleared By Queens Jury Of Racial Abuse
description: A grand jury has found that no criminal charges are warranted against white police officers who were accused of beating and racially abusing a black family before arresting them at their apartment in South Jamaica, Queens.

title: A British Play Lampoons in Behalf of Rushdie
description: ''England, where we boast of 'free speech,' seems to have decided to let Salman Rushdie rot, and to forget him,'' the British playwright Howard Brenton laments in the foreword to a new play he and Tariq Ali have written in support of Mr. Rushdie, the beleaguered author of ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: Excel Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included results of Lincoln Trust Co., acquired in July 1988.

title: Wright Unable to Speed Ethics Unit
description: House Speaker Jim Wright and his supporters pressed hard today for a swift resolution of the ethics charges against him, but the most the ethics committee would do was agree to talk about expediting its proceedings.

title: Jefferson Smurfit Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Oil Industry Rebuked as Senate Hearings Begin in Alaska Oil Spill
description: Senate hearings into the huge tanker spill in Alaska opened today with lawmakers and officials of the executive branch charging that the oil industry had responded poorly because of complacency, inadequate planning and lack of equipment.

title: Bill Brown, Football Coach, 52
description: Bill Brown, an assistant football coach at Hofstra University who played briefly in the American Football League, died of cancer Tuesday night. He was 52 years old. Mr. Brown was a 1958 graduate of Syracuse University and captain of the 1957 team, which played in the Cotton Bowl. He was the coach of the offensive line for Hofstra since 1986. He played linebacker with the Boston Patriots in 1960.

title: Bancorp of Mississippi reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Music; A Distinction at Carnegie: Concert World Premieres
description: The Carnegie Hall concert on Tuesday evening by the recently organized New Music Orchestral Project claimed at least one distinction: never before, apparently, had an entire program of world premieres been presented in that hallowed place. Rehearsing and performing such an ambitious night of music would strain the resources of any orchestra, but Jorge Mester, artistic director of the ensemble, brought off the four complicated new works without a major hitch.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Subaru Turns To Epic Images
description: LEAD: Time was when Subaru ads were whimsical tributes to the pluck of this Japanese car. In one award-winning television ad, the Subaru helped whisk a lovelorn teen-ager through a stormy night to his waiting girlfriend. No more.

title: Hussein, in U.S., Backs Bush's Plan, Not Shamir's
description: King Hussein of Jordan met with President Bush today, and endorsed the Administration's efforts to revive the Middle East peace process. But he withheld support for Israel's plan to hold elections in the occupied territories.

title: Public Rates Bush Highly But Sees Mostly Style
description: Americans tend to see more style than substance in the Bush Administration's actions so far, according to a new New York Times/CBS News Poll, but they are not much bothered by that, and they give President Bush high marks for performance.

title: Wang Sees Loss
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., whose growth has waned as its key minicomputers are being challenged by powerful personal computers, said it expects to report a pretax loss of about $55 million for the third quarter ended March 31. The company also said it was apparent that its results for the second half of the year will not exceed those of the period a year earlier. In last year's third quarter, Wang earned $22.7 million, or 14 cents a share, on revenues of $767.9 million. Wang said it expects its fourth quarter to be helped by the strengthening of its product line, especially in image processing, where it has achieved a leadership position.

title: The Energy Vandals
description: Unswervingly, New York is about to commit a blunder so monumental that, like the pyramids, it may prompt future generations to marvel at the ruinous excesses of human folly.

title: Ameritech reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 1.

title: First Empire State Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Multimedia Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Musical Free Spirit Warms Up for Carnegie
description: From a careerist standpoint - an implication from which Sergiu Celibidache would recoil with disdain -the appearances of this 76-year-old cult conductor tomorrow and Saturday nights at Carnegie Hall have been brilliantly orchestrated.

title: Market Place; Surge Confirmed By Dow Theory
description: THE Dow Theory, possibly the oldest technical theory on the American stock market, has provided a confirmation of the buoyancy of the stock market. And the latest explosion in stock prices has thrown a little cold water on what had been rising concern over an early recession.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Boxing; Santiago Bout Canceled
description: Felix Santiago has suffered a slight tear of the retina in his right eye and will not fight Saoul Mamby tomorrow night at the Felt Forum. Bob Goodman, the matchmaker, said yesterday that Santiago would be able to resume sparring in about 10 days and that the bout would probably be rescheduled for late May.

title: Kroger Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter included a LIFO charge of $14.6 million, compared with a $4,585,000 charge in the year-ago period. The latest quarter excluded $12.9 million in operating losses from units to be divested. Pretax losses of $5.6 million from the units to be divested are included in the year-ago first quarter results.

title: On Wright, Cool the Politics . . . And Cut Out The Honorariums
description: There is an old vaudeville joke about the clothing merchant whose wife asks him to explain the meaning of ethics. ''Suppose I sell a suit to a young man for $50,'' he replies. ''He tells me his family is footing the bill and that if I give him a receipt for $100 to give to his parents, he will pay me $25 on the side. The questions of ethics is: Do I keep the extra $25 myself, or do I tell my partner and split it with him?'' The furor about the ethics of Jim Wright's book sales reminds me of that joke.

title: Sovran Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The allowance for loan losses totaled $188.3 million for the latest first quarter, compared with $166 million for the year-ago period.

title: Brand Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Investor Group Buys USAir Stake
description: A group led by the New York money manager Michael H. Steinhardt has acquired a 5.2 percent stake in USAir Group Inc. for more than $88 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Steinhardt said that he had acquired the 2.27 million USAir shares for investment purposes only.

title: Judgment on North
description: The evidence has been presented in the trial of Oliver North. All that remains is for the judge to instruct the jury on the law and for the jurors to reach a decision about whether to believe Colonel North on the facts.

title: Squibb Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales represent net sales.

title: Researchers in India Say They Repeated Fusion Experiment
description: Indian scientists said they had achieved nuclear fusion in an electrolytic cell at room temperature, the Press Trust of India news agency reported today.

title: American Express Down
description: The American Express Company yesterday reported a small decline in earnings although all of its divisions, except Shearson Lehman Hutton, showed gains in the first quarter.

title: General Motors Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter earnings included net income of $40.6 million, or 82 cents a share, from its Electronic Data Systems Corp. subsidiary. The company also said the latest first quarter included net of $60.3 million, or 51 cents a share, from GM Hughes Electronics Corp. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 31. Earnings for the year-ago first quarter were favorably affected by an accounting change that added $224.2 million, or 35 cents a share, to its net income. Revenue figures excluded the revenue of GMAC and other financing operations as well as other income.

title: 100 Reported Seized in Raids On Leftist Salvador Groups
description: Soldiers and policemen arrested more than 100 people in raids Wednesday and today on a leftist union federation, a refugee organization and a women's association, leaders of the groups said.

title: Modest Folk Art Travels To the Big-Museum Fast Lane
description: FROM mousy beginnings 27 years ago in a walk-up on West 53d Street, the Museum of American Folk Art has finally achieved a place in the glitzy world of big-league museums. Not only is it planning a $40 million headquarters, to be opened on West 53d Street in 1992, but also, as a kind of preview of coming attractions, it has just opened an elegant ''branch'' on boutique-y Columbus Avenue, at 65th Street, a storefront space where a respectable slice of its collection is handsomely displayed. The museum and its inevitable shop next door, right across from Lincoln Center, offer visitors on the one hand an enriching view of genuine American folk art and, on the other, a chance to buy folk-artsy knockoffs made by contemporary artists.

title: Sensible Ways to Save Young Lives
description: America may be the richest country in the world but its infant mortality rate still lags shamefully. The National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality, headed by former Senator Lawton Chiles, offers a sensible program for improvement.

title: MCA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: MCA's latest first quarter's results included its share of Cineplex Odeon's fourth quarter 1988 earnings.

title: Review/Film; Miou-Miou as a Paid Reader In 'La Lectrice,' by Deville
description: Michel Deville's new movie, ''La Lectrice'' (''The Reader''), is about the joys and the occasional perils of reading the works of, among others, Marguerite Duras, the Marquis de Sade and Guy de Maupassant, as well as of Raymond Jean, who wrote the novel and the stories on which the screenplay is based.

title: Holiday Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $18,814,000. The latest quarter included property transaction gains of $57.6 million, compared with $8,596,000 for the year- ago period.

title: Books of The Times; A Curse Over a British Family's Ancestral Manse
description: The Grotesque By Patrick McGrath 186 pages. Poseidon Press. $17.95.

title: Lyondell Petrochemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $4.7 million from LIFO inventory reductions. The company went public in January 1989.

title: Bundesbank Move on Rates Causes Sharp Drop in Dollar
description: The dollar dropped sharply yesterday on a surprise move by the Bundesbank of West Germany to raise its two primary interest rates by half a percentage point.

title: Foreign Aid Deals Said to Cost $1 Billion Yearly in Exports
description: American industry is losing exports approaching $1 billion a year because foreign governments are increasingly using foreign aid as a means of expanding their own exports, the Bush Administration told Congress in an interagency study delivered today.

title: Filing by MCA On Cineplex
description: MCA Inc. called today for the establishment of a special committee of the Cineplex Odeon Corporation's board to review plans by the company's two top executives to acquire 34.1 percent of the Toronto-based motion picture theater chain. Under the transaction, Garth

title: Antley Swings Hot Whip
description: rrChris Antley admits he would not recognize Joe DiMaggio if the Yankee Clipper were to smack a double down the home stretch.

title: Tandem Computers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 6-month results included a $9,375,000 pretax charge from the settlement of litigation.

title: Union Wins In Vermont
description: Employees at The Burlington Free Press, Vermont's largest daily newspaper, have voted, 77 to 47, to designate the Graphic Communications International Union as their bargaining agent.

title: Review/Theater; Young Rube Goldberg at a Turning Point
description: Near the end of the first act of ''Young Rube,'' a new musical that focuses on the adolescence of the legendary cartoonist Rube Goldberg, a bunch of the wacky characters who have been percolating in his mind surround him onstage and urge him to pursue his artistic aspirations. ''We can't draw ourselves; you've got to try,'' they plead in the song ''We're Counting On You.'' For a moment, one hopes that what until then has been a lifeless paint-by-number show will demonstrate a spark of life and that the inner world of the cartoonist's imagination will at last be revealed. But the leap is never made.

title: Texans' Hopes for Jet Deal Fade in Wright Inquiry
description: For the Jaffe Aircraft Corporation, the Pentagon's interest in buying small planes to teach basic flying skills looked like a golden opportunity to enter a market potentially worth billions of dollars.

title: NWA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: George E. Bartol 3d, Executive, Dies at 68
description: George E. Bartol 3d, former chairman and chief executive of the Hunt Manufacturing Company, Philadelphia, manufacturers of art and office supplies, died of a brain tumor yesterday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and also had a home in Sonoita, Ariz.

title: Knicks Pound Celtics As Ewing Gets a Rest
description: The Knicks played so well last night they didn't need Patrick Ewing. And the Boston Celtics played so poorly they could have used help from almost anyone.

title: Review/Cabaret; Lisa Kirk Sings and Jokes
description: Lisa Kirk joked about her age (she made her Broadway debut in ''Allegro'' in 1947) and her figure (slim)at her opening at Rainbow and Stars on the 65th floor of the RCA Building (30 Rockefeller Plaza) on Tuesday evening. But she could afford to treat both subjects lightly.

title: Review/Dance; Margaret Jenkins Returns With the Premiere of a Solo
description: It looked like homecoming time at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night when the Margaret Jenkins Dance Company returned to New York after a four-year absence. Several leading modern dance choreographers and other dance notables were in the audience to see the San Francisco-based company and Miss Jenkins, who performed and taught in New York in the 1970's. Her dancers are accomplished, but it was Miss Jenkins's performance in a new solo that stole the show.

title: Phillips Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results included a gain of $17 million from the settlement of gas contract disputes and a $10 million charge from an employee separation program.

title: KEY RATES
Review/Film; Dolph Lundgren In 'Red Scorpion'
description: Dolph Lundgren's pectorals are the real stars of ''Red Scorpion,'' an action-adventure movie set in the fictional African country of Mombaka. Filmed from below so that one has the sense of peering up at a massive kinetic sculpture, his glistening torso, which over the course of the film is subjected to assorted tortures, is the movie's primary visual focus whenever the action slows down. And since Mr. Lundgren remains stone-faced, rarely speaking except to issue commands in a surprisingly hesitant monotone, his heaving chest actually communicates more emotion than his mumbling lips.

title: The Evil Day
description: Hitler - aren't you going to write about Hitler and his 100th birthday and what he meant? somebody said to me. You ought to write about that.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results restated for an accounting change.

title: The Japanese Are Absolutely at Our Mercy; World's Newest VAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Sundstrand Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $26,535,000 loss from an accounting change.

title: Auctions
description: Offbeat Images

title: Arco Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mets Win Two Straight For First Time This Season
description: ''Can the Mets be beaten?'' asked Don Zimmer, the manager of the Chicago Cubs, who arived in town in first place and found the Mets in last. He reached for the honest answer, and said, ''Truthfully, no.''

title: Accounts
description: * Fondo Mixto de Promocion Touristica de Acapulco, the tourist board of Acapulco, to HDM, Los Angeles, with a budget of $10 million.

title: Review/Film; Hoping to Stay Alive To Hear Life's Punch Line
description: Very near the end of ''Checking Out,'' there is a vision of heaven that looks like hell. After passing through a long check-in line, dead souls go to garish pink-and-green cabanas whose interiors look like dingy relics of 1950's motel rooms. For entertainment, men in Hawaiian shirts and women in muumuus stand around a swimming pool, while women who look as if they have entered the evening-gown competition of the Miss America pageant sing ''Dixie.'' Can heaven really be a tacky nightmare version of Atlantic City?

title: Man Is Told to Submit Blood In Killing of Long Island Girl
description: A 19-year-old Suffolk County man was ordered today to submit blood samples to the police in the killing of Jessica Manners, a 14-year-old Stony Brook girl whose nude body was found on a rocky embankment a few miles from her home on March 26.

title: Test Eases Detection of Hepatitis That Is a Threat to Blood Supply
description: A new test is highly effective in detecting a type of viral hepatitis that is the last major threat to blood supplies, medical researchers report.

title: U.S. Researchers Show Gains In the Television of the Future
description: Raising hopes that the United States can become a major player in the next generation of television technology, researchers at the David Sarnoff Research Center here today demonstrated the world's first broadcast system for high-definition television that is compatible with existing sets.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Uncovered Short Sales Reach Record Level on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 6.4 percent, to a record high, in the four-week period ended April 14. The new level surpasses a mark set in August 1987, the same month that the stock market attained its all-time high.

title: A Top Justice Fights Charges Of Misconduct
description: One of New York's most powerful judges appeared before the State Commission on Judicial Conduct yesterday to defend himself against charges that he had improperly interfered in disciplinary proceedings against prominent lawyers.

title: American Express Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $18.8 million from discontinued operations that represented the company's share of the earnings of Fireman's Fund Corporation and a gain on the sale of FFC common stock. The company said the latest quarter included a $21 million after-tax gain resulting from the expiration of certain American Express Company warrants to purchase FFC stock. Prior years' results relating to Fireman's Fund Corporation (FFC) have been accounted for as discontinued operations and, accordingly, have been excluded from consolidated revenues, the consolidated income tax provision, consolidated income from continuing operations and income per common share-continuing operations. The first quarter earnings reflect an accounting change relating to certain long-duration life insurance and annuity products.

title: Review/Music; Partita Group Plays Works Of 2 Centuries
description: The Partita Chamber Ensemble, a band of nine talented string and wind players, offered an enjoyable evening of 19th- and 20th-century music on Monday evening at the Hunter College Playhouse.

title: Penn Central Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $68.5 million, or 96 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Spanish wire and cable manufacturing operations and the wind-up of other foreign wire and cable investments. c-After net from discontinued operations of $2 million. Year-ago sales are restated.

title: Egghead Sets Write-Downs
description: Egghead Discount Software, the leading personal-computer software dealer, said today that it would take write-downs of $8 million to $10 million in the fourth quarter and will probably post a loss for the year ended April.

title: People
description: * Gwyn Kaufman and Ronald Von Urff have been named senior vice presidents of J. Walter Thompson USA.

title: Maytag Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $1.2 million from discontinued operations.

title: Beirut Faces Shortages Amid Lull in Fighting
description: A lull in fighting continued for a third day today as Beirut residents grappled with severe shortages of water, electricity, fuel and food.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Oh, well, they are making me a Nancy Reagan. I felt sorry for her when they did it to her. I don't know why they ever started on me.'' - Betty Wright. [ A15:4. ]

title: Renewed Promise for Bullet Forward
description: When the season ends, Bernard King of the Washington Bullets will fulfill a promise he made four years ago. He will travel to New York, embrace Dr. Norman Scott, and give the Knicks' team physician the basketball from the Bullets-Nets game of April 4.

title: Celebrating Variety of Ellington
description: Like several other organizations around town, the American Jazz Orchestra is celebrating Duke Ellington's 90th birthday by dipping into his immense legacy. But the orchestra, which is to interpret a whole score of unusual and monumental Ellington pieces tonight and on Sunday at Cooper Union, won't be the only group to show off Ellington's brilliance. After the concerts are over, there's just enough time to slip over to Carlos 1 to hear an ensemble featuring the great Ellingtonian clarinetist Jimmy Hamilton, who is finishing a two-week stint there tonight through Sunday.

title: Hurst R. Anderson, 84; Leader of American U.
description: Hurst R. Anderson, president of American University from 1952 to 1968, died of bone cancer Wednesday at the Edward White Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in St. Petersburg.

title: Under Pressure, State Department Moves to End Its Sex Discrimination
description: Acting under court decisions banning sex discrimination, the State Department said today that it is revamping its entrance examination and is informing about 600 female Foreign Service officers they may be entitled to new jobs.

title: Kennametal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. May Tell Soviets: Let's Share Some Secrets
description: The Bush Administration is considering proposing to the Soviet Union that the two countries share intelligence data, the better to combat terrorism and the spread of missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: Delay at Iran Refinery
description: Iran has delayed its first fuel oil exports from its rebuilt Abadan refinery because of a pipeline fault, people in the oil industry said today. The sources in the Persian Gulf said a delay of at least two weeks was likely because of problems on a pipeline linking the plant to the port of Bandar Maschar, which is 60 miles east of Abadan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Credit Markets column in Business Day yesterday misstated the date of the Treasury Department's next auction of two-year notes. It will be held on Wednesday; it was not yesterday.

title: Corey Millen Tests Positive
description: Corey Millen, the center for Team USA, tested positive for a banned drug after a world hockey championship game this week, an American hockey official said today, but international federation officials did not confirm it.

title: Bush to Gather Economists
description: President Bush has invited a half-dozen private economists to meet with him and his top economic advisers at Camp David Saturday, Administration officials said today.

title: Floor Space for the Weekend
description: Ballroom Week begins today in New York City. More than 40 events over the next 8 days will commemorate ballroom dancing. Here is a schedule of this weekend's events. For information on later events, the number is 246-6495. TODAY FRANKIE MANNING AND NORMA MILLER, Bruno Walter Auditorium, Lincoln Center (870-1614). Lecture and demonstration by original members of the Savoy Ballroom's Whitey's Lindy Hoppers. 1 to 2 P.M. Free. DANCE ACROSS THE GENERATIONS, Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Place, Crown Heights (718-735-4400). Dancing with members of Stepping Out Studio. 2 to 3 P.M. $2 suggested admission. COPACABANA, 10 East 60th Street (755-6010). Latin bands. 6 P.M. to 5 A.M. Free, 6 to 7 P.M.; $5, 7 to 9:30 P.M. After 9:30, women, $10; men, $15. BALLROOM OPEN HOUSE, Sandra Cameron Dance Center, 439 Lafayette Street (674-0505). Screenings, swing classes, dancing and performances. 9:30 P.M. to midnight. Free. Tomorrow SPRING DANCE/SWING DANCE IN CENTRAL PARK, 72d Street Band Shell (397-3156). Ballroom dancing with the Alex Donner Orchestra. Weather permitting. 1 to 4 P.M. Free. DANCE ACROSS THE GENERATIONS, Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Place, Crown Heights (718-735-4400). Dancing with Paul Douglas and the Alexander Arts Group. 2 to 3 P.M. $2 suggested admission. DANCE ACROSS THE GENERATIONS, Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103d Street (534-1672). ''American Swing'' lessons, with members of the Sandra Cameron Dance Center. 2 to 3:30 P.M. Suggested admission: $3; $1.50 for the elderly and $1 for children. TANGO NIGHT AT GAETANO'S, Monte Carlo Room, 97-12 63d Road, Rego Park, Queens (718-275-9560). 8 P.M. to midnight. $12; reservations suggested. BALLROOM OLYMPICS, Stepping Out Studio, 1845 Broadway, near 61st Street (245-5200). 8:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. $8 in advance; $12 at the door. ROSELAND RENDEZVOUS, Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52d Street (247-0200). Swing-era music by the Don Glasser Orchestra and Latin rhythms by the Emilio Reyes Orchestra. 2:30 to 11 P.M. $9 before 10 P.M., then $13. Sunday DANCE D'ELEGANCE, La Guardia Community College, 3110 Thompson Avenue, at Van Dam Street, Long Island City, Queens (718-326-2121). Dance Club International sponsors a performance featuring Sarwat and Julia Kaluby. 1 to 3 P.M. $10. BALLROOM SOCIAL, New Heights of Dance, 81 Atlantic Avenue, near Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights (718-643-6186). Dancing, 5 to 8 P.M. Free. SAVOY SHOWCASE AT THE CAT CLUB, 76 East 13th Street (713-5148). Presented by the New York Swing Dance Society, a tribute to Whitey's Lindy Hoppers with the Big Apple Lindy Hoppers, Sandra Cameron Ballroom Dancers and the Harvest Moon Swing Champs. 7 P.M. to midnight. Free from 7 to 8 P.M.; $8 after 8 P.M.

title: Henderson Plans a Scoring Drive
description: Rickey Henderson rested today, which should come as no real surprise. The rest of the Yankees rested, too, given a break by a schedule that rewarded their three-game sweep in Toronto with a one-day respite in quiet Cleveland.

title: Shawmut National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Shawmut said its provision for possible loan losses in the latest first quarter was $16.5 million, compared with $16.1 million for the year-ago period.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Security Council Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Not All Plastic Blights the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Rate Worries Deal Setback to Stock Rally
description: Stocks fell broadly yesterday, weighed down by weakness in blue-chip issues and in the credit market, where bond prices declined after West Germany raised some important interest rates.

title: Pacific Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Pacific Gas attributed the sharply higher net in the latest first quarter to revenue from its Diablo Canyon nuclear facility which nearly doubled to $359 million in latest quarter, from $181 million for year-ago period.

title: Hrkac Boosts Blues In Second Overtime
description: Tony Hrkac, playing in his first playoff game this season, scored at 13 minutes 49 seconds of the second overtime tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks, evening the Norris Division finals at one victory apeice.

title: Brokers in Wright Deal Run a Father-Son Empire
description: The father and son who arranged an oil well deal that was beneficial to House Speaker Jim Wright are successful entrepreneurs with little formal education and longstanding ties to prominent politicians.

title: A Ceremony, a Casket and the Dead Are Taken Home
description: All morning the big Sea King helicopters came and went, disappearing out to sea, over the horizon, only to return half an hour later, skimming in across the azure Caribbean and then the lush greenness of Puerto Rico.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: Review/Rock; From California, a Band Living on Fits and Starts
description: Firehose was founded in 1986, the year after a van wreck killed D. Boon of the Minutemen. The two surviving members of the band from San Pedro, Calif., Mike Watt, its bassist, and George Hurley, drummer, started Firehose with Ed (Fromohio) Crawford, who plays guitar. Mr. Crawford's smoother vocals have added melody to the Minutemen's precision and muscle.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Exact Words; 'Creating a Controversy Where None Existed . . .'
description: Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, discussing the home mortgage interest deduction before the National Association of Realtors, April 19.

title: Inland Steel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $13,240,000.

title: Texas Instruments Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Paris Opera Ballet Cancels at Radio City
description: The Paris Opera Ballet has canceled its season at Radio City Music Hall, scheduled for May 17 through 21. The company said a strike by the dancers was the reason for the cancellation. The dancers have been striking intermittently since mid-March.

title: Soviet Academy Elects Sakharov to Legislature
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist who spent six years in internal exile, won election to the Soviet Union's new parliament, winning the votes of more than 800 members of the prestigious Academy of Sciences, Tass, the official press agency, said today.

title: At a Catholic Health Center, a Haven for AIDS Patients
description: To people like Cookie, who describes herself as a housewife who shot heroin, the new AIDS nursing unit at the Terence Cardinal Cooke Health Care Center - the first hospital in New York City to open a comprehensive-care ward for AIDS patients - is a place where the dying can try to make a better life day by day ''For what we go through, we truly earn our lives,'' said Cookie, who is 37 years old, the mother of a 7-year-old son and the widow of a man who had a penchant for prostitutes. He died of AIDS. ''I'm very fortunate to be here. This is the only place where they love you. You need to feel loved and wanted when you're in this situation.''

title: Georgia-Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Amerada Hess Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included non-recurring income of $8 million from the settlement of an insurance claim.

title: U.S. Weighs Arming Non-Communist Cambodians
description: The United States is considering sending weapons to the non-Communist guerrilla forces in Cambodia, but President Bush said today that he had not decided whether to do so.

title: History's Sliding Scale Of Ethics in the Capital
description: To Speaker Jim Wright's defenders, he is like John G. Tower and Gary Hart a victim of changing standards, yet another example of the perils to the powerful of the new Victorianism in American politics.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jackson Improvisations

title: Kraft Narrows Choice For Maxwell House
description: Kraft General Foods has narrowed its choice for an agency for Maxwell House coffee to Ogilvy & Mather and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: Elizabeth Cornelia Hall, 91, Dies; Headed Botanical Garden Library
description: Elizabeth Cornelia Hall, the retired head librarian of the New York Botanical Garden, died of heart failure Wednesday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. She was 91 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Dale Berra Arrested
description: The former major league baseball player Dale Berra, son of the Hall of Fame catcher Yogi Berra, was arrested yesterday and charged with conspiring to buy cocaine, authorities said. Berra, 32 years old, was among 23 people named in warrants issued after a six-month investigation, Lee Trumbull, the Morris County Prosecutor, and Jay White, the police chief of Morristown, N.J., said in a joint statement. Berra was arraigned yesterday afternoon and bond was set at $5,000, authorities said.

title: Walesa Meets Pope for an Emotional Talk
description: With emotion, and also with a sense of symbolism, Pope John Paul II embraced the Polish labor leader Lech Walesa today and reaffirmed his hope that a new spirit of understanding in Poland would lead to a sweeping transformation of that society.

title: Charles W. Hine, Executive, 79
description: Charles W. Hine, retired president of the now defunct International Latex Corporation, of which Sarong Inc. and Playtex were then divisions, died Tuesday at his home in Madison, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 79 years old and also had homes in Miami and Barbados.

title: U.S. Says Panama Acts to Rig Election
description: The United States said today that the Government of Panama had taken numerous steps to rig the election scheduled for May 7 to insure victory for supporters of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military leader.

title: Region's Power Supply Described as Sufficient
description: Although electricity customers on Long Island face at least two more years of possible shortages until new power sources come on line, experts on regional energy needs said yesterday that the Northeast has sufficient supplies to meet demands until the end of the century.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Passover, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Counterfeit Budget-Cutting
description: The country has just been treated to an unexpected scene: The President and members of Congress gathered together to announce what was billed as a ''bipartisan agreement on the budget.'' No one can doubt the symbolism. But no one should accept symbolism as a substitute for substance. We are afraid that is what we are going to be asked to do.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Northrop's Chairman Will Retire as Chief
description: LEAD: Thomas V. Jones, the embattled chairman and chief executive of the Northrop Corporation and a leader in the military industry for three decades, announced yesterday that he was retiring as chief executive at the end of the year. Mr. Jones, who is 68 years old, said he would continue to serve as chairman.

title: China's Date With Destiny
description: Perhaps the most surprising thing about this week's illegal student demonstrations is that the Government permitted them at all: that the nation's authoritarian leaders have allowed their sleep to be interrupted for the last two nights by thousands of students trying to force their way into the Communist Party headquarters and bellowing such slogans as ''Overthrow the dictatorship!''

title: RJR Profit Down 62% In Quarter
description: Bruised by major expenses from its recent takeover by the investment firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and the costly failure of its ''smokeless'' cigarette, RJR Nabisco Inc. yesterday reported a 62 percent drop in first-quarter earnings.

title: Review/Music; Jazz in Amber by Ravel
description: Listening to jazz and then to Ravel's transmutations of it is the difference between a butterfly in flight and one pinned by a lepidopterist to a board. Like Stravinsky - who learned jazz originally from sheet music brought back from America -Ravel took an alien idiom perceived from a distance, froze it into his Violin and Piano Sonata and created a tart European elegance Louis Armstrong would have scarcely understood.

title: Restaurants
description: Since opening in late 1985, Maxim's, a clone of Paris's legendary nightspot, has had a rough time. This extravagant French dowager fluttered into town amid much fanfare only to find few courters along the boulevard Madison. High prices, a haughty image and heavy, outmoded French food conspired to make Maxim's one of the prettiest empty dining rooms in New York.

title: The Japanese Are Absolutely at Our Mercy
description: To the Editor:

title: SCE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Southern California Edison Co., SCE's regulated utility unit, accounted for 49 cents per share of the company's earnings in the latest quarter, compared with 50 cents a year earlier.

title: Judge's Plea to Jurors on Pistols Stirs Debate
description: A judge's plea to the jurors in a murder case to back handgun controls has prompted an outpouring of condemnation as well as praise as lawyers debate the ethics of his action.

title: Vista Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
