description: b-Included a gain of $368,000 from changes in a stock option plan. c-Included a loss on the payment of debt of $294,000 for both periods, and the 6 months also included a gain of $1,172,000 from changes in a stock option plan. There were no extraordinary items in the latest second quarter.

title: Cuomo's Budget Strategy: Sticking To Some Issues, Giving In on Others
description: In the negotiations that led up to the passage of a $47 billion state budget for New York this week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo followed a strategy that has served him well during his tenure: he refused to be budged on a few issues -and he insisted these issues were key - but he gave in on many others.

title: Bosket's Law: Trouble Sets You Free
description: LEAD: I was almost Willie Bosket's first murder victim. In 1977, the convicted killer known as New York's most incorrigible inmate took a pool cue by the thin end and swung it like a club, aiming it at my skull. I moved and the tip of the stick brushed by my nose. Today, the 26-year-old Willie Bosket has committed so many additional crimes, he won't be eligible for parole until he is 79.

title: Poll Finds Few Have Views On Rose and Baseball Bets
description: Most baseball fans are unable or unwilling to express an opinion on Pete Rose, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. But those who are willing to voice their views are evenly divided about the Cincinnati Reds' manager who has been a subject of reports that he bet heavily and may have bet on baseball games.

title: Review/Film; Of Chet Baker, by Friends
description: Lined and ravaged as it is, the face is ageless: as sunken as a dead man's, as softly bewildered as a child's. Chet Baker's face, and the extraordinary ways in which Bruce Weber has photographed it, encapsulate the story of Baker's life in a succession of ghostly, indelible images that are at once hauntingly beautiful and desperately sad. Applied to a different subject, Mr. Weber's methods might seem disturbingly superficial, but they suit this portrait perfectly.

title: Fred Cramer, Chess Official, 76
description: Fred Cramer, a former United States and international chess official who was Bobby Fischer's manager in a 1972 match with Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, died of cancer Tuesday. He was 76 years old and lived in Mequon.

title: Park Safety: Advice From Runners
description: The attack on a woman running alone Wednesday night in northern Central Park illustrates a danger that exists for joggers in the park despite patrols by the police and others, as well as the presence of hundreds of runners after sundown, officials said.

title: March & McLennan Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Investor Group Acquires Fitch Bond Rating Agency
description: A group of investors announced yesterday they had acquired the Fitch Investors Service rating agency, a venerable bond rating concern whose fortunes have waned in the last two decades.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL West Germany stunned the world's financial markets by announcing it would raise its key interest rates. Intended to reduce inflationary pressures, the surprise step upset stock and bond markets and fueled fears that other industrial nations may follow suit. The tightening means that the global trend toward higher interest rates is continuing. [ Page A1. ] West Germany's interest-rate increases might ''lead to a small reduction in the dollar,'' a senior Administration official said, adding, ''It's unlikely that the Fed will respond.'' [ D6. ] The dollar dropped sharply on the surprise move by the Bundesbank. [ D14. ] American industry is losing exports worth nearly $1 billion a year because foreign governments are increasingly using foreign aid as a means of increasing their own exports, the Administration told Congress. [ D2. ] THE ECONOMY Researchers demonstrated the world's first broadcast system for high-definition television that is compatible with existing sets. The demonstration was important in that it shows the U.S. could develop standards for the next generation of television without waiting for Japan or Europe to create the technology. [ A1. ] COMPANIES G.M. posted robust earnings, up 42 percent to $1.55 billion. Revenue rose 12 percent, to $29.6 billion. [ D1. ] Pactel will buy an interest in Chicago cable TV properties now owned by Group W, if regulators' approve. It would be the first time a regional Bell operating company entered the American cable television industry. [ D1. ] Group W agreed to buy 10 radio stations, including WNEW-FM in New York. The price is believed to be about $385 million, which would make it the largest radio deal ever. [ D15. ] BankAmerica reported sharply higher net income for the first quarter, another signal that its recovery is genuine. [ D1. ] Nynex's profits declined, while Bell Atlantic and U S West reported moderate improvements. [ D5. ] Digital Equipment's profits fell 16 percent, depressed by continued slow sales in the U.S. Texas Instruments said profits dipped 1.1 percent. [ D9. ] RJR Nabisco's profits dropped 62 percent in the first quarter. The company blamed its recent takeover by Kohlberg, Kravis and the failure of its ''smokeless'' cigarette. [ D4. ] An investor group acquired 6.6 percent of Dunkin' Donuts and said it might seek control of the chain. The company responded quickly with a series of defensive actions. [ D5. ] MCA called for a special committee of Cineplex Odeon's board to review two top executives' plans to increase their stake. [ D5. ] MARKETS The spot price for crude oil reached $24.65 a barrel, after posting a record one-day rise of $2.04. [ D1. ] Stocks fell broadly, weighed down by weakness in blue-chip issues and in the credit market, where bond prices declined after West Germany raised some important interest rates. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds tumbled and short-term interest rates shot higher in hectic trading. [ D13. ] Shares sold short and not yet covered reached a high on the Big Board, after climbing 6.4 percent in the period ended April 14. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS British advertising's go-go years appear to have gone, in the wake of Saatchi & Saatchi's announcement that it expects its earnings to decline. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D1. ] The 'failed expectations' theory for the market surge fails to hold up. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Small investors remain wary of stocks, and are opting for a variety of safer choices. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Review/Film; The Jumbling of Households in 'See You'
description: ''I wish you could be more forgiving to yourself,'' someone says to pretty Beth Goodwin (Alice Krige), a talented photographer. Beth's worst fault is that, though innocent, she still feels guilty for her husband's suicide.

title: Nuclear Physicist at Yale Is Named as Science Adviser to President
description: D. Allan Bromley, a leading nuclear physicist, has been appointed science adviser to President Bush, the White House announced yesterday.

title: Soldiers' Remains Identified
description: The remains of six Air Force servicemen killed in the Vietnam War have been identified from among 38 sets of remains repatriated by Vietnam on Dec. 15, the Army's Central Identification Laboratory announced Wednesday. The six, all lost over North Vietnam, were identified as Col. Kenneth D. Robinson of Indianapolis; Maj. Sammie D. Hoff of Kenedy, Tex.; Maj. Robert R. Lynn of Jacksonville, Ill.; Capt. Richard J. Mallon of Portland, Ore.; Capt. Donovan K. Walters of Lebanon, Neb.; and Master Sgt. Charles J. Bebus of Osseo, Minn.

title: Marion Guilfoyle, 68, Lawyer in New York
description: Marion Irene Guilfoyle, a lawyer who was a leader in Irish-American and Roman Catholic affairs in New York City, died of complications from a lung disease Wednesday at Union Hospital in the Bronx. She was 68 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Gillette Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect reclassification of state taxes from operating expenses to income taxes.

title: Money Misused By a Jersey Aide Raised Salaries
description: The $21 million spent without authorization by a New Jersey Department of Human Services official placed few needy retarded people in programs but boosted salaries of the care providers, said a department report released today.

title: Oil Futures Prices Reach 3-Year High
description: The spot May crude oil futures contract expired yesterday at a three-year high of $24.65 a barrel, after posting a record one-day rise of $2.04.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Jane's Bar and Grill

title:
Market Place;
Low-Risk Tactics For Individuals
description: LEAD: THE stock market's recent rally, analysts say, has been propelled by institutional investing and program trading, set off by the belief that interest rates may have peaked. The nation's small investors, by all accounts, are still wary of stocks, and are opting for safety, either in the money markets or in certificates of deposit.

title: Western Digital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included tax credits of $106,000 and $369,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter earnings reflected approximately $1.6 million of costs associated with the reduction in work force announced earlier in the year.

title: Union Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $7 million.

title: Hitler's Centennial Passes Without Incident
description: Across West Germany and here in his hometown, the centennial of Adolf Hitler's birth passed today without serious incident.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush's Science Adviser

title: Father Healy Besieged By Friends and Foes
description: To the Editor:

title: Honorariums Directed To Those With Votes
description: Special interests give out fees for speeches, appearances and articles the same way they hand out campaign contributions, directing their money toward members of Congress uniquely positioned to help them, a new study said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on April 5 about 20 years of coeducation at Princeton University carried incorrect numbers supplied by the university for women in the college's full-time faculty. There are 85 women among the university's 615 faculty members at the rank of assistant professor or above. Forty of the women have tenure. There are 56 women among Princeton's 316 instructors, lecturers and visiting professors. The article also referred incorrectly to the university's private eating clubs for undergraduates. Most of the 13 clubs began admitting women as members before a lawsuit was filed in 1979, not afterward. After the suit, one of the three remaining all-male clubs voted to admit women. The suit is still pending.

title: CHENEY IS HOPEFUL ON MISSILE FUNDS
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that he was ''reasonably confident'' that Congress would authorize $150 million in the next two years to develop a new short-range nuclear missile for Western Europe despite the lack of a commitment from West Germany to deploy the weapon.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jarreau in Two Modes

title: Cold-Shooting Nets End Drab Home Season
description: There were no cheers for the Nets tonight in their last game of the season at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Westinghouse Sets Deal To Buy 10 Radio Stations
description: The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 10 radio stations in major markets, including WNEW-FM in New York, from the Metropolitan Broadcasting Corporation and Legacy Broadcasting Inc.

title: Accused Killer of 7 Deported To California at His Request
description: A California winery worker who is accused of accused of killing seven people, including his wife and two young daughters, was deported from Mexico at his own request today.

title: Rowing Is Surging Forward
description: If the oarsmen had not chosen the wrong boat, the United States heavyweight eight might have won the gold medal in rowing at the Olympics last fall, or probably would have won the silver, instead of taking the bronze behind West Germany and the Soviet Union.

title: NWA Back In the Black
description: NWA Inc., the parent company of Northwest Airlines, said yesterday that it had earned $12.6 million, or 43 cents a share, on revenue of $1.48 billion in the first quarter, compared with a loss of $43.5 million on revenue of $1.24 billion in the comparable period in 1988.

title: Our Towns; Kiss My Grits: 'Closed' Sign At 24-Hour Diner
description: Late at night, mostly on weekends, high-school students still stop by the Windmill Diner on Route 6 for french fries with brown gravy -yes, just as they did a generation ago. And yes, just like Mickey Rourke and the guys in the movie ''Diner.'' They also pull the same kind of doo-wop-era pranks and feats: chugging bottles of ketchup, clogging the salt and pepper shakers with pieces of paper napkin, loosening the twist top on the sugar cannister so it spills when Dottie picks it up. (Dottie Sherrod works here at the Windmill. Has for a dozen years. Her hero is Flo, the waitress from the old TV show ''Alice.'' You know, ''Kiss my grits.'') For the last year, though, the teen-agers -as well as everyone else - have been booted out of the Windmill Diner at 2 A.M., 11 P.M. on weeknights. That's because the Windmill, once a 24-hour diner, is now a 20-hour diner, 17-hour on weekdays. Has been for about a year. In typical dowdy diner-fashion, the homey red brick restaurant's ''Open 24 Hours'' marquee has been blotted out in the middle so it now reads like a smile with its two front teeth knocked out: OpenHours.

title: Waste Management Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
India Postpones Launching Its First Long-Range Missile
description: Indian scientists postponed a scheduled test launching of the country's first long-range ballistic missile today and said the test would take place sometime in the next three days.

title: Saatchi's Slide Causes a Reappraisal
description: British advertising's go-go years appear gone, in the wake of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company's announcement last month that it expects its earnings to decline this year, for the first time in its expansive history.

title: Profit Off 22.3% At Inland Steel
description: Inland Steel Industries, operator of one of the nation's largest steel companies, yesterday reported a 22.3 percent drop in first-quarter net income. The company attributed the decline to higher costs and lower income from its steel service center operations.

title: Bank's Withdrawal Deals Major Blow To Times Sq. Plan
description: Chemical Bank, expected to be a prime tenant in the Times Square redevelopment project, has decided to withdraw, dealing a blow to the $2.5 billion plan.

title: Kissing Leads to Suspensions
description: About 40 students from the Pavilion Central School were suspended today after they walked out to protest a rule prohibiting hugging and kissing on school property, administrators said. The principal said the ban, which will be enforced with detention, was a response to increasing numbers of students kissing in the hallways.

title: Bari Journal; Jewel of the South, but With the Southern Flaw
description: This city on Italy's Achilles tendon is sometimes called the Milan of the south.

title: Schlumberger Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
As Takeshita Marks Time, the Crisis Deepens
description: Despite a flurry of intensive negotiations and maneuvering, Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita has failed to resolve a serious political deadlock in his own governing party over the influence-peddling scandal that has paralyzed the Parliament for six weeks.

title: Lafarge Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Soviet Embassy Hit in Kabul
description: The Soviet Embassy compound in Kabul was struck by a guerrilla rocket today, but embassy officials said none of the 250 staff members who live and work in the compound were wounded.

title: Review/Art; 2 Soviet Emigres Celebrate Their New Home, Bayonne
description: The art of Komar and Melamid, the well-known Soviet emigre team, has been experiencing difficulties for a few years. Their current exhibition at Ronald Feldman Fine Arts indicates that their troubles continue, despite the best of intentions.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Caesar's Spouse
description: Jim Wright, the embattled Speaker of the House, and his wife, Betty, profess outrage: How dare people charge that a job Mrs. Wright held was merely a front for gifts from a business friend from Texas! They seek the sympathy of working couples everywhere, notably members of Congress likely to resent the idea that their spouses' hard-earned earnings should be open to suspicion.

title: The Kabul Capitalist, if Not Capitalism, Thrives
description: For Kabul's poor, a decade of civil war has brought shortages of food and medical care. But for those with money, it is a world of choice.

title: Storage Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $11,300,000. The company said its 1988 results have been restated as a result of an accounting change, prompted by the reinterpretation of FAS 96 by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: Review/Music; Joe Henderson's Big-Band Experiments
description: While Joe Henderson was making small-group albums in the late 1960's, he was experimenting with a big band that met three afternoons a week from 1966 to 1968. His arrangements for that group were never recorded, but they were unearthed for an exhilarating concert by Mr. Henderson with the 17-piece Columbia University Jazz Band on Tuesday night at Horace Mann Auditorium.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY YOUNG FILM MAKERS

title: Mitterrand Ends a Visit to Bonn Tainted by Kohl's Domestic Woes
description: President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl today ended a two-day meeting that was colored by the West German leader's sharpening domestic difficulties, which are causing deep concern in Paris.

title: Molinari Sues to Block Jail Planned for S.I.
description: New York City's plan to build a jail in Rossville, Staten Island was challenged yesterday in a lawsuit that United States Representative Guy V. Molinari announced in front of City Hall.

title: Southern Notes S.E.C. Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a formal investigation to determine if the Southern Company filed false and misleading financial reports with the agency, the company says in its annual report. Southern says it believes the

title: US West Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter included proceeds from the sale of an office tower in Honolulu by the company's Betawest properties unit, but the company did not specify the amount of the proceeds.

title: Bell Atlantic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect the consolidation of its lease financing and real estate subsidiaries.

title: Review/Dance; Joyfulness, Sardonicism and Ritual in Trio by Paul Taylor
description: It's unlikely that anyone but Paul Taylor could have created ''Diggity,'' a signature work that was performed by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on Wednesday evening at City Center. There is the choreography itself, which is unmistakably Mr. Taylor with its grounded lightness and fluidity. But most of all, ''Diggity'' is Mr. Taylor at his sweetest, with his broadest, sliest grin.

title: New York Files Suit On Pan Am Campaign
description: The Attorney General of New York State, Robert Abrams, filed a lawsuit against Pan American World Airways yesterday, accusing it of making false claims in advertising that promotes its low-cost fares to Europe.

title: Sumter Pulls Out Of Clemente Battle
description: Sumter Partners L.P., a group controlled by Thomas B. Pickens 3d, son of the corporate raider, pulled out of a $7.97-a-share takeover battle for Clemente Global Growth Fund Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Grace-Pickens Global Acquisitions Partners, now renamed Grace Global Acquisitions Partners, said that Sumter had pulled out because of an S.E.C. brief filed as part of a court battle between the parties. The S.E.C. brief said that the Grace-Pickens takeover for Clemente violated Federal securities laws.

title: Utah, Thinking of Fusion, Dreams of Gold
description: It may not have anything to do with nuclear physics, but scientists claiming a historic breakthrough in fusion research here have produced one measurable reaction: they have jolted the state's political and business leadership into overdrive.

title: Caterpillar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cooper Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 common stock split of March 20, 1989.

title: Jordan's Revolt Is Against Austerity
description: The young men hauled tires and debris across a street and set the barricade alight so that black smoke curled up under a bright sun. A jeep full of soldiers pulled to a halt, and the men poured from it with their automatic rifles, scanning the roofs of the square, bleached-stone homes for rock throwers.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The American Savings and Loan Association of Florida yesterday brought to market $150 million of mortgage-backed bonds due 1991 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Digital Equipment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Yellow Freight System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Robert Amory Jr., 74, Ex-Official Of C.I.A. and U.S. Budget Bureau
description: Robert Amory Jr., Deputy Director of Central Intelligence from 1952 to 1962 and later head of the international division of the Bureau of the Budget, died of colon cancer Wednesday at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 74 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds increased by $805 million, to $303.45 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 140 institutional funds increased by $240.5 million, to $73.38 billion. The assets of the 233 general-purpose funds were up by $192.3 million, to $99.82 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $372.2 million, to $130.25 billion, the institute said.

title: U.S. Displays Muted Concern on German Move
description: West Germany's interest-rate increases might ''lead to a small reduction in the dollar,'' a senior Administration official said today. And ''it's unlikely that the Fed will respond,'' he added.

title: Dow Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: * Arianespace, the European satellite-launching concern, signed a contract with the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization covering three launchings and four launching options for Intelsat's new family of satellites, Intelsat 7.

title: Breland Gets Substitute
description: The World Boxing Association welterweight champion, Mark Breland, will defend his title against Rafael Pineda (20-0-0,19 knockouts) tomoroow in Atlantic City. Breland (23-1-1) was to have faced Marlon Starling, the World Boxing Council Welterweight champion. But Starling, withdrew from the bout a few weeks ago, saying he had a shoulder injury. (AP)

title: Tennessee Is Honored
description: President Bush honored the National Collegiate Athletic Association champion University of Tennessee women's basketball team in a Rose Garden ceremony yesterday. The team presented the President and his wife, Barbara, with warmup jackets and gave Vice President Dan Quayle a T-shirt.(AP)

title: A Newspaper In Bengali Due
description: A weekly airmail newspaper in the Bengali language for readers in the United States and Britain was introduced this week by a leading Calcutta newspaper and magazine publisher.

title: Even for Private Prison Entrepreneurs, Crime Shouldn't Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Looking for Love

title: G.M. Profit Up by 42% In Quarter
description: The General Motors Corporation posted robust first-quarter earnings of $1.55 billion today, a 42 percent increase from a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter rose 12 percent, to $29.6 billion.

title: BENTSEN SUPPORTS MEDICARE TAX CUT
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen today opened the door to a substantial reduction in the surtax that many older Americans pay for insurance for a major prolonged illness.

title: Pactel Seeks an Interest in Cable Properties
description: The Pacific Telesis Group said yesterday that it would acquire an option to buy an interest in Chicago cable television properties now owned by the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company. If approved by the Federal judge who oversaw the breakup of the Bell system, the deal would be the first time one of the seven regional Bell operating companies entered the American cable television industry.

title: On Stage
description: Youngsters With Potential

title: Partial List of Dead in Battleship Explosion
description: Following is a partial list, released by the Pentagon yesterday, of those killed Wednesday aboard the battleship Iowa. The list was provided by The Associated Press. ADAMS, Tung Thanh, 25 years old, fire controlman 3d class, Alexandria, Va. BACKHERMS, Robert Wallace, 30, gunner's mate 3d class, Ravenna, Ohio. BATTLE, Dwayne Collier, 21, electrician's mate, fireman apprentice, Rocky Mount, N.C. BLAKEY, Walter Scot, 20, gunner's mate 3d class, Eaton Rapids, Mich. BOPP, Pete Edward, 21, gunner's mate 3d class, Levittown, L.I. BRADSHAW, Ramon Jerel, 19, seaman recruit, Tampa, Fla. BUCH, Phillip Edward, 24, lieutenant (j.g.), Las Cruces, N.M. CRAMER, John Peter, 28, gunner's mate 2d class, Uniontown, Pa. DEVAUL, Milton Francis Jr., 21, gunner's mate 3d class, Solvay, N.Y. EVERHART, Leslie Allen Jr., 31, seaman apprentice, Cary, N.C. FISK Gary John, 24, boatswain's mate, Oneida, N.Y. FOLEY, Tyrone Dwayne, 27, seaman, Bullard, Tex. GEDEON, Robert James 3d, 22, seaman apprentice, Lakewood, Ohio. GENDRON, Brian Wayne, 20, seaman apprentice, Madera, Calif. GOINS, John Leonard, 20, seaman recruit, Columbus, Ohio. HANSON, David L., 23, electrician's mate 3d class, Bison, S.D. HANYECZ, Ernest Edward, 27, gunner's mate 1st class, Bordentown, N.J. HARTWIG, Clayton Michael, 25, gunner's mate 2d class, Cleveland. HELTON, Michael William, 31, legalman 1st class, Louisville, Ky. HOLT, Scott Alan, 20, seaman apprentice, Fort Myers, Fla. JOHNSON, Reginald Jr., 20, seaman recruit, Warrensville Heights, Ohio. JONES, Brian Robert, 19, seaman, Kennesaw, Ga. JUSTICE, Michael Shannon, 21, seaman, Matewan, W.Va. KIMBLE, Edward J., 23, seaman, Fort Stockton, Tex. LAWRENCE, Richard E., 29, gunner's mate 3d class, Springfield, Ohio. LEWIS, Richard John, 23, firecontrolman seaman apprentice, Northville, Mich. MARTINEZ, Jose Luis Jr., 21, seaman apprentice, Hidalgo, Tex. McMULLEN, Todd Christopher, 20, boatswain's mate 3d class, Manheim, Pa. MILLER, Todd Edward, 25, seaman recruit, Ligonier, Pa. MORRISON, Robert Kenneth, 36, legalman 1st class, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. MOSES, Otis Levance, 23, seaman, Bridgeport, Conn. OGDEN, Darin Andrew, 24, gunner's mate 3d class, Shelbyville, Ind. PETERSON, Ricky Ronald, 22, seaman, Houston, Minn. PRICE, Matthew Ray, 20, gunner's mate 3d class, Burnside, Pa. ROMINE, Harold Earl Jr., 19, gunner's mate 3d class, Bradenton, Fla. SCHELIN, Geoffrey Scott, 20, seaman, Costa Mesa, Calif. STILLWAGON, Heath Eugene, 21, gunner's mate 3d class, Connellsville, Pa. TATHAM, Todd Thomas, 19, seaman recruit, Wolcott, N.Y. THOMPSON, Jack Ernest, 22, gunner's mate 3d class, Greeneville, Tenn. WELDEN, Stephen J., 24, gunner's mate 2d class, Bethany, Okla. WHITE, James Darrell, 22, gunner's mate 3d class, Norwalk, Calif. WHITE, Rodney Maurice, 19, seaman recruit, Louisville, Ky. YOUNG, John Rodney, 21, gunner's mate, Columbia, S.C. ZIEGLER, Reginald Owen, 39, gunner's mate, Port Gibson, N.Y.

title: RJR Nabisco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter results included $247 million in pretax costs attributable to change in control payments to its employees.

title: Nynex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $10 million for the termination of an investment in a transatlantic fiber loop.

title: Amoco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $57 million from the previously announced work force reduction and consolidation of exploration and production activities. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in February.

title: Net Soars at BankAmerica, Reaffirming Its Recovery
description: The BankAmerica Corporation today reported sharply higher net income for the first quarter, another signal that its recovery is genuine.

title: Bush Choice For Commerce
description: President Bush will name Thomas J. Murrin, the retired vice chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, as Deputy Secretary of Commerce, an Administration official said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.M.E. Inc., Burbank, Calif., a videotape production company, said Walter Lefler had resigned as president and vice chairman of its subsidiary JSL Video Service to pursue other business opportunities.

title: Debate on Feasibility Grant Divides Nonprofit Publisher
description: A dispute has erupted in the Library of America over whether the nonprofit publishing house should have applied for a Federal grant to study the feasibility of publishing a series of biographies of important Americans, publishing house executives say.

title: Not All Plastic Blights the Environment; Sorting the Foam
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate; Sponsors Cutting Prices on Co-ops in Westchester
description: Dozens of cooperative apartments throughout Westchester County are being reduced in price as the inventory of unsold units mounts in a sluggish home market.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Five Share Lead: Don Shirey Jr. shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to tie Tom Sieckmann, David Ogrin, Bill Glasson and Jim Booros for the first-round lead in the Greater Greensboro Open in North Carolina. Three of the five co-leaders - Shirey, Glasson and Sieckmann - had a chance to take sole possession of the lead before late bogeys created the five-way tie.(AP) Garbacz Ties Course Mark: Lori Garbacz tied the course record with an eight-under-par 64 yesterday and took a one-stroke lead after the first round of the USX Golf Classic in Gulfport, Fla. Garbacz had nine birdies and a bogey as she shot 32-32 on the 6,013-yard Pasadena Yacht & Country Club Course. Her score equaled the record set by Judy Dickinson in 1985. Lori West was second with a 65. (AP) TENNIS Top-Seeded Players Gain: The three top-seeded players - Ivan Lendl, Stefan Edberg and John McEnroe - survived gusty winds yesterday and advanced to the quarterfinals of the Japan Open in Tokyo. Top-seeded Anne Minter of Australia and No. 2 Belinda Cordwell of New Zealand moved into the women's semifinals along with Elizabeth Smylie of Australia and Kumiko Okamoto of Japan. Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, beat Bill Scanlon of the United States, 6-2, 6-4, on the hard courts at the Ariake Colosseum. Edberg defeated Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-4. The defending champion, McEnroe, seeded third, rolled over Wally Masur of Australia, 6-2, 6-0, in 65 minutes.(AP) Yugoslav Teen-Ager Upsets Leconte: Goran Ivanisevic, a teen-ager from Yugoslavia, upset the two-time champion Henri Leconte of France, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3 yesterday in the second round of the Swatch Open in Nice, France. (AP) Zvereva Is Beaten Again: Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union suffered her second loss to a qualifier from Czechoslovakia in two weeks when Petra Langrova upset her 6-4, 6-1, yesterday in the second round of the Eckerd Open in Largo, Fla. In other matches, Arantxa Sanchez of Spain won in straight sets while Rosalyn Fairbank and Halle Cioffi survived three-set matches. Sanchez topped Ronni Reis of Miami, 6-3, 6-1. Fairbank, of San Diego, beat Shaun Stafford of Gainesville, Fla., 6-1, 6-7, 6-2. Cioffi, of Knoxville, Tenn., beat Donna Faber of Bradenton, Fla., 1-6, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Graf Beats Navratilova: After Steffi Graf posted a straight-set victory yesterday, Martina Navratilova said she had fun losing - a sure sign that the match was an exhibition. The top-ranked West German defeated Navratilova, 6-3, 6-4, in the final of the Monte Carlo Women's Cup, a four-player invitation tournament.(AP)

title: Shoreham, Despite Plan to Scrap It, Gains Full License
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today granted a full-power operating license to the Shoreham nuclear-power plant, the $5.5-billion reactor that New York State is ready to scrap.

title: Judge in Abortion Case Is Calm in the Limelight
description: Scott O. Wright, the Chief Judge of the Federal District Court here, is not one to agonize over past decisions and that attribute seems unlikely to change now that one of his own is part of the nation's biggest legal controversy.

title: Youths Rape and Beat Central Park Jogger
description: Ayoung woman, jogging on her usual nighttime path in Central Park, was raped, severely beaten and left unconscious in an attack by as many as 12 youths, who roamed the park in a vicious rampage Wednesday night, the police said.

title: Justice
description: The biggest show in town next week, beyond any doubt, will be the Supreme Court argument in the Missouri abortion case. Those lucky enough to get there in time to claim one of the 175 unreserved seats will be able to watch the hourlong argument in person.

title: Textron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $29.7 million. First quarter results do not include Avdel Plc., acquired by Textron in early 1989, but does include interest expense of $3.9 million on borrowing related to the purchase.

title: Comeback Is Possible For Mark Gastineau
description: Mark Gastineau, the former Jet defensive end, may be about to make a comeback. Gastineau, who retired in midseason last year when his fiancee, who was thought to have cancer at the time, has been discussing a return with the Phoenix Cardinals of the National Football League. He met with General Manager Larry Wilson of the Cardinals on Wednesday.

title: Chester L. Marcus, 72, Ex-Church Official
description: The Rev. Chester L. Marcus, a retired regional secretary of the United Church Board for World Ministries, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 72 years old.

title: Jordan King Gives Partial Support To Shamir Proposal for Elections
description: King Hussein of Jordan gave a qualified endorsement today to the proposal by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to allow Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to elect representatives to negotiate with Israel.

title: David B. Findlay, 84, An Art Dealer, Is Dead
description: David B. Findlay, an art dealer for more than 50 years, died Tuesday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut after suffering from cancer, diabetes and kidney failure. He was 84 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Exhibition on Film Makers Who Fled Nazi Germany
description: One of the greatest intellectual exoduses in history began when the Nazis seized power in Germany in 1933, as tens of thousands of scientists, writers, artists and scholars fled that country for the United States and Western Europe. Although much of this story has been exhaustively chronicled, the emigration of countless movie directors, actors and other members of the German film industry - and their impact on Hollywood - has received less attention.

title: New Data on Radon Prompt Call to Test All School Buildings
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, citing new evidence that cancer-causing radon is present in high levels in classrooms, today urged all school systems to test their buildings for the radioactive gas and take remedial action if necessary.

title: Twins Beat Tigers, 7-2, And Regain Mastery
description: Carmen Castillo's run-scoring double snapped a 2-2 tie and ignited a five-run eighth inning today as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Detroit Tigers, 7-2.

title: Youths Rape and Beat Central Park Jogger
description: A young woman, jogging on her usual nighttime path in Central Park, was raped, severely beaten and left unconscious in an attack by as many as 12 youths, who roamed the park in a vicious rampage Wednesday night, the police said.

title: Missiles and Mobility
description: Dick Cheney, the new Secretary of Defense, has struck a blow for good sense in his recommendation to President Bush that no more 10-warhead MX missiles be built, and that the existing 50 MX's be shifted from fixed silos to mobile deployment on railroad flatcars.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $13,802,000.

title: IOWA HEADS HOME, MOURNING 47 DEAD
description: The bodies of 47 crewmen of the battleship Iowa were flown ashore here today and then on to a military mortuary in Delaware for identification. Then the ship, her teak foredeck blackened and the guns of one turret askew, steamed north.

title: Bulgarian Music
description: Balkana, a group of two singers and eight instrumentalists from Bulgaria, are to perform traditional music for dancing in a benefit party for and at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street (691-9510), on Sunday. The dance party begins at 7:30 P.M.; tickets are $25 and $45. A reception with an informal performance by the group, a buffet of Bulgarian food and rare films of Bulgarian village performers will take place at 5:30 P.M.; admission to the reception and dance party is $100.

title: Cleveland Journal; New Hope on the Street: A Home Before Dying
description: Too often, said the Rev. Paul Hritz, pastor of St. Malachi Roman Catholic Church, he has buried people who died alone in their rooms or froze to death on the city's sidewalks.

title: L.I. Sniper Suspect Is Found Unfit to Be Tried for Murder
description: Two court-appointed psychiatrists have determined that a man who said he was a ''Rambo'' commando is not competent to stand trial for sniper shootings that killed one man, injured three others and terrorized two eastern Long Island towns late last year.

title: Review/Art; Gustav Klimt as Decorator, Landscapist and Philosopher
description: Among the major European painters of the period between 1880 and 1918, Gustav Klimt is both the best known and the least known. In one sense, there is no escaping him. Every day, in just about every big city in the developed world, Klimt's portraits of beautiful and unmistakably Viennese young women reign serenely and within reach. Reproductions, posters, albums, postcards, notecards - all are ubiquitous. Dressed, groomed and made up with an otherworldly perfection, Klimt's women are seduction personified. Even when abstracted from their original environment and travestied by reproduction, they work their magic.

title: A Worried Liquor Industry Readies for Birth-Defect Suit
description: Already faced with declining sales and increasingly hostile public attitudes, the alcoholic beverage industry is bracing for the first in a series of trials in which they are blamed for causing birth defects.

title: Dining Out Guide: Mexican and South American
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Cabana Carioca II

title: Ballroom Week: Let's Face the Music and Dance
description: KICK off your bedroom slippers. Scuttle those Reeboks and get on your dancing shoes. Today marks the start of Ballroom Week in New York City, by official proclamation of Mayor Edward I. Koch. And throughout the city this weekend there will be events for experts and beginners of all ages. There will be lectures and demonstrations, and programs designed to teach everyone in the family how to jitterbug and samba. Dancers will strut their stuff everywhere from a park band shell to an elegant 19th-century ballroom. And dance parties are scheduled at nightclubs and studios throughout the city.

title: U.S. Officer Is Killed in Manila
description: Gunmen killed an American Army officer today as he was driving to work at the Joint United States Military Advisory Group headquarters, American and Filipino officials said.

title: Combustion Engineering Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $4,241,000.

title: Economic Scene; Post-Crash High Is Hard to Explain
description: THE rise in consumer prices by five-tenths of 1 percent, bringing the first quarter in at an inflation rate of 6.1 percent, did not fluster the stock market. Quite the contrary: the market soared to a post-crash high.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Data General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Net income The second quarter figures reflect pre-tax gains on the sale of real estate of $8,500,000 in the latest second quarter and $5,900,000 in the year-ago period. The 6 months figures reflect the second quarter pre-tax gains on sale of real estate. The company said the year-ago figures are restated for an accounting change.

title: A Doctor Who Tried to Help Children With AIDS
description: Still wary of portraying homosexuals or drug addicts in any way that might be construed as sympathetic, prime-time television entertainment continues to tell the AIDS story through its most innocent carriers. At the very least, it beats complete silence. The latest and very affecting example is ''The Littlest Victims,'' a CBS movie being broadcast at 9 P.M. Sunday. The teleplay by Kenneth Cavander and J. J. Towne is based on the true story of Dr. James Oleske, director of the division of allergy and immunology at Children's Hospital of New Jersey, a unit of the United Hospitals Medical Center in Newark. In 1982, Dr. Oleske was among the first physicians in the country to notice that infants and children were dying from what appeared to be impaired immune systems.

title: KEY LENDING RATES INCREASED BY BONN TO CURB INFLATION
description: West Germany stunned the world's financial markets today by announcing that it would raise its key interest rates. The surprise action, intended to reduce inflationary pressures, upset world stock and bond markets and fueled fears that other nations might follow suit.

title: Bush Doubts Reagan White House Meant to Conceal Iran-Contra Papers
description: President Bush said today that he did not believe the Reagan Administration had intentionally withheld evidence about the Iran-contra affair from Congress and he declared, ''My conscience is clear.''

title: Capone House in Chicago Won't Get Historic Status
description: A bid to list the former home of the gangster Al Capone on the National Register of Historic Places was withdrawn here Wednesday, in the face of angry opposition from Italian-American organizations and a neighborhood group.

title: Pairs of Actors Play Spin the Bottle In 'Love Letters'
description: A.R. GURNEY'S new play, a work in progress called ''Love Letters,'' has two characters and is performed two nights a week, on Sundays and Mondays. Its stars include Kathleen Turner, John Rubinstein, Swoosie Kurtz, Joanna Gleason, George Hearn, Stockard Channing, Victor Garber, Dana Ivey, John Heard, Marsha Mason, Blythe Danner, Christopher Walken, Richard Thomas, Maria Tucci, Stephen Collins, James Naughton, Nancy Marchand and Paul Sparer.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Stake Disclosed and Resisted
description: A group led by the Toronto business executive George S. Mann said yesterday that it had acquired a 6.6 percent stake in Dunkin' Donuts Inc. and that it might seek control of the Randolph, Mass., doughnut-store chain.

title: Valmont Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Muslim Cleric Urges Defiance Of Israeli Curbs on Worship
description: A Muslim cleric urged Palestinians today to defy Israeli restrictions on worship at the holiest Islamic site in Jerusalem, and United Nations relief officials demanded that Israel stop using gunfire to quell Palestinian protests.

title: Review/Film; A Baseball Diamond Becomes the Stuff of Dreams
description: Kevin Costner, as an Iowa farmer named Ray Kinsella, looks across his cornfield and sees a vision that glimmers like a desert mirage. On a blazing-bright baseball field are men in old-time white uniforms, translucent as ghosts. One is Shoeless Joe Jackson, the greatest member of the Chicago White Sox team that threw the 1919 World Series, and Ray understands that if he builds that baseball diamond, Shoeless Joe will come back to play.

title: Koito Delays Pickens Offer
description: The United States takeover specialist T. Boone Pickens, the largest shareholder in a leading Japanese auto parts maker, failed today in his bid for an immediate seat on its board, the company president said.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; Street-smart defender of reputed mobster, 'simpatico' with client, disdains stigma.
description: When it comes to representing nasty people, criminal defense lawyers have an all-purpose alibi, a Teflon-coated cure. Everyone is constitutionally entitled to a lawyer of his choice, they say; by representing the bad guys, they are actually guarding the liberties of us all.

title: Some Pain. Some Budget.
description: The saga of this year's state budget began in January when Gov. Mario Cuomo called on New Yorkers, especially local governments, to ''share the pain.'' It ends with local governments off the hook and the pain reduced to a few twinges.

title: Salvador Army Fills Ranks by Force
description: Sixteen-year-old Jorge went to the beach and ended up in the army.

title: Restlessness in Soviet Ranks: Order of the Day Is Disorder
description: When First Lieut. Viktor M. Gursky and a fellow officer chained themselves to a lamppost outside the Defense Ministry earlier this month, the idea was to draw attention to the miseries of life in the Soviet Army.

title: Shareholder Rights At Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. adopted a shareholder rights plan intended to give its board more time to respond to any unsolicited tender offer. Apple said the plan had not been made in response to any specific attempt to acquire Apple shares, and the company is not aware of any current efforts to do so. Under the terms of the plan, shareholders other than the would-be acquirer would be able to acquire shares of Apple common stock at a substantially discounted price.

title: Outboard Marine Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $5,841,000 from an accounting change.

title: Treasury Issues Decline Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds tumbled and short-term interest rates shot higher in hectic trading yesterday, as credit market participants rushed to sell securities after West Germany's Bundesbank unexpectedly announced it was lifting key short-term interest rates by half a percentage point.

title: P.B.A. Leader Assails Report On Tompkins Square Melee
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in New York City yesterday denounced the Civilian Complaint Review Board's report on police misconduct at Tompkins Square Park last summer, asserting that the panel had forced its police-dominated investigative staff to reverse several findings that cleared officers of abusing civilians during the melee.

title: Treasury Candidate Seen Getting Job Soon
description: Returning to the job he first assumed under President Ford in 1975, Sidney L. Jones is scheduled to become Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Award Is Upheld On Computerland
description: The California Supreme Court let stand a jury verdict awarding an investor group 20 percent of the stock of the Computerland Corporation, the computer franchise giant. The court unanimously denied a hearing on an appeal by Computerland and its founder, William Millard, from a lower-court ruling upholding the stock award. During the lawsuit, Mr. Millard was driven from control of the Oakland-based company.

title: Nynex Has 8.8% Decline; 2 Others Post Modest Gains
description: Three regional telephone companies announced mixed first-quarter earnings yesterday, as the Nynex Corporation posted a decline and the Bell Atlantic Corporation and U S West Inc. reported moderately improved profits.

title: Paine Webber Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue for both periods included net interest.

title: Deming Lewis, 74, Ex-Head of Lehigh U.
description: W. Deming Lewis, an inventor and researcher who served as president of Lehigh University from 1964 to 1982, died Wednesday at the Blough nursing home in Bethlehem after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Bethlehem.

title: Black & Decker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
description: b-Included tax credits of $5.2 million and $11.5 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $4.6 million for the quarter and $10.6 million for the 6 months.

title: Flyers Are Powered By Immovable Kerr
description: Tim Kerr can often look like nothing so much as a parade float, stuffed full of padding and cruising along the ice with a sort of bulky inexorability. His route is about as predictable, too, for he invariably lumbers his way to the busy hockey intersection known as the slot.

title: Exxon's Public-Relations Problem
description: The Exxon Corporation's reputation was bound to suffer after the Exxon Valdez ran aground off Alaska and dumped 250,000 barrels of oil into Prince William Sound. But experts in public relations say that Exxon seriously worsened the damage to its public standing by failing to seize control of developments after the spill and establish itself as a company concerned about the problems it had caused.

title: Vote on Assault Rifles Is Stalled in California
description: On the eve of passage of a bill to ban the sale and possession of military-style assault weapons, opponents have persuaded Gov. George Deukmejian to delay a final vote in the State Senate.

title: A College President's Sports Gamble
description: College freshmen were made eligible for varsity sports 17 years ago. Ever since, freshman eligibility has been the college equivalent of a nuclear weapon: nobody will give it up unless everybody else does.

title: Easy Goer Isn't Likely to Romp in the Wood
description: The $568,000 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct tomorrow is a race that cries out for a point spread. Those betting Easy Goer to win the race will have to settle for a nickel or a dime on the dollar, since the colt will be 1-to-10 or 1-20 by post time.

title: Boase, Massimi Gets a 2d Offer
description: TBWA, the Paris- and New York-based agency known for its work for Absolut vodka, has entered the battle for control of Boase, Massimi & Pollitt.

title: Pitney Bowes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $6,315,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Former Seahawk Sues
description: Ken Easley, a former Seattle Seahawk safety, has sued the National Football League team, claiming he was allowed to play through the 1987 season without being told he had an irreversible kidney ailment that eventually ended his career. Easley's seven-year career ended last year after the kidney ailment was diagnosed. The suit alleges Easley's kidney problems were caused or substantially worsened by large doses of the pain-reliever ibuprofen, which Easley received while recovering from ankle surgery in 1986. The 30-year-old former All-Pro now undergoes dialysis three times a week at his home, his lawyers said. (AP)

title: Giants' Player Charged
description: A Giants safety, Adrian White, has been charged with smashing a glass into a woman's face during an argument at a bar in Orange Park, Fla., the police said. White was arrested Wednesday on a charge of aggravated battery and later released on his own recognizance from the Clay County Jail, the police said.

title: Betty Wright Says She 'Earned Every Penny'
description: Betty Wright is embarrassed that she was given a salary of $18,000 a year by the Mallightco Inc. investment company. Indeed, she says, she should have been paid more.

title: Judge Tells North Jury That No One Had a Right to Break the Law
description: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North sent the case to the jury today after instructing its members that ''neither the President nor any of the defendant's superiors had the legal authority to order anyone to violate the law.''

title: Review/Music; Irina Arkhipova and Friends
description: Irina Arkhipova holds an honorable place in the great tradition of Russian mezzo-sopranos, and at Symphony Space Tuesday evening she showed that she can still uphold it in the autumn of her career. She brought fine dynamic contrasts, strong old-fashioned dramatic presence and a voice still steady and flexible to excerpts from Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina'' and ''Boris Godunov.''

title: GV Medical Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
United Missouri Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said per share earnings are restated to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 3.

title: Gandhi, His Luster Dimmed After 4 Years, Faces Uncertain Political Future
description: When Rajiv Gandhi came to power in 1984, the young Prime Minister was hailed as a leader who could bring this huge, diverse democracy into a new era. He promised clean politics, good government and a leap into high technology and modern management.

title: Facing the Jail Crisis
description: By the time it reached a Federal courtroom this week, New York City's latest jail crisis had virtually passed -saved not so much by new ideas or projects as by New York State's decision to siphon 800 inmates from the city's bloated system.

title: 2 Bombs Found in Moscow
description: The Government said today that the K.G.B. had defused two homemade bombs planted in the Moscow subway.

title: Cominco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: What's 'Glasnost' in Chinese?
description: Economic revolution and political repression. That's the present policy of the Chinese Communist Party. Perhaps Beijing's leaders can make it work. But any effort that so fundamentally pits entrenched rulers against the next generation of leaders, that allows freedoms in one area but denies them in others, seems fatally flawed.

title: Fox Studio Chief To Leave Post
description: Leonard Goldberg today announced his resignation as president and chief operating officer of 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation. Mr. Goldberg joined Fox in December 1986 after a long career as a television network executive and co-producer of such series as ''Charlie's Angels'' and ''Hart to Hart.''

title: Is Cleaner Air Worth the Cost?  Ask the Asthmatics
description: The need for a stronger Clean Air Act is as evident this year as the dirt in the air we breathe. Thanks to the long stalemate on new clean air legislation, smog levels in 1988 were the worst of the decade.

title: Something's Afoot at Hoffmann
description: The Swiss drug and chemical concern F. Hoffmann-LaRoche & Company said today that trading of its shares would be suspended Monday on the Zurich Stock Exchange because it ''is planning a series of measures which are of considerable significance for the structure and future development of the Roche group.''

title: Ashland Oil Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $9 million charge from an arbitration award in a dispute between Ashland's Riley Stoker subsidiary and a customer. c-Net income d-Included a $40,193,000 gain from a change in accounting for taxes.

title: West One Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SPX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,800,000 and $4,000,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. Latest quarter and year-ago results reflected the anticipated separation of the operations of Sealed Power Technologies L.P., to be created as of May 30.

title: Unbreakfast, Unlunch
description: ''Let's go out for brunch,'' said the son visiting his parents in Westchester County last Sunday, trying to brighten an exceedingly rainy 10 A.M. What a cheery idea: they called around for a reservation. What a gloomy idea: no restaurant they could find started serving brunch before 1 o'clock. Some brunch, he thought, when you have to make breakfast to tide you over till it starts. If that's brunch, what's lunch?

title: A Male Bastion Bows, In Gracious Greeting
description: As the Players Club prepares to admit 30 distinguished women to the all-male bastion at its 100th anniversary benefit tomorrow night, some members of the celebrated theatrical institution are recalling, rather uneasily, an earlier encounter with a distinguished woman: Sarah Bernhardt.

title: HomeFed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue represents total investment revenues. The company said the earnings for the latest first quarter included the operations of Columbus Savings Bank, a unit of Home Federal Savings and Loan, acquired at year-end 1988.

title: Soviets Faulted in Use of Troops at Protests
description: Recently elected members of the new Soviet Congress of Deputies accused the authorities today of wrongly absolving themselves of blame after troops killed at least 20 people last week in Soviet Georgia. They said only the highest Government authorities could have approved the use of the military.

title: Commerce Clearing House Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Neoax Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $813,000 for the quarter and $21,243,000 for the year. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,656,000 for the quarter and $1,355,000 for the year. Neoax said the 1988 results included certain operations of IU International Corp., which the company acquired in March 1988, and reflected the application of ''purchase accounting'' for that transaction, as well as the impact of financing for the $725 million acquisition cost of IU. The 1988 results reflected $38.4 million of non-recurring net charges, including $21.2 million after-tax loss related to the decision to dispose of the company's custom vehicle segment and an $8.4 million after-tax charge for fees related to bridge and other short-lived financing arrangements for the IU acquisition. Results for both years included the operations of Fairfield Manufacturing Co. from its March 1987 acquisition date. The 1987 results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of the company's custom vehicle segment. There were no share earnings in the year-ago quarter because the net did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: Neorx Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring charge of $336,000 for severance and other costs in connection with a 15 percent work-force reduction.

title: Ameribanc Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $170,000.

title: Alvin E. Gershen, 62, Engineer and Planner
description: Alvin E. Gershen, an engineer and urban planner, died of lung cancer Wednesday at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 62 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Figgie International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
3M's Profit Up by 14.8%
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said Thursday that its first-quarter income rose 14.8 percent, to $318 million, or $1.43 a share, from $277 million, or $1.22 a share, a year ago.

title: Macon Patton, 53, Broadcasting Executive
description: Macon G. Patton, chairman of the Cosmos Broadcasting Corporation, which owns eight television stations in the Middle West and the South, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound Thursday at his home in Greenville, S.C., a local coroner said. Mr. Patton was 53 years old.

title: Review/Music; Musings on a Programmer's Motivations
description: The program for Gunther Herbig's second week of New York Philharmonic subscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall was an odd one. Some sequences of scores cohere into a larger statement (Erich Leinsdorf is particularly good at such ingenuity). Others just present a seemingly random assortment of music, with sometimes jarring juxtapositions.

title: Union Planters Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results included a $1.4 million tax credit. The company said the latest quarter's results were adversely affected by a net loss of $1.3 million, or 8 cents a share, in its broker-dealer operations. It said this compared with net earnings of $3.7 million, or 21 cents a share, for the 1988 first quarter. Year-ago first quarter results included a net $1.2 million investment gain and special provisions for losses on loans, other real estate and income taxes of $2 million. Year-ago results are restated for the acquisition of CBC Bancorp Inc. and United Southern Corp., accounted for as poolings of interests. Per share figures reflected a 2-for-1 stock split paid last month.

title: Your Money; Why People Turn to Planners
description: Judging from the holdings of new clients who come to certified financial planners, the majority of Americans need greater diversification in their investment portfolios.

title: Corby Distilleries Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain of $8,005,000. c-After a charge of $3,041,000. The company said the special gain in the latest period represented the net gain, after related taxes and writeoff of goodwill, from the disposal of McGuiness Distillers Ltd. facilities. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Carpenter Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special charge of $13,800,000 for the shutdown of a plant for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Perkin-Elmer Plans to Shed Unit
description: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation, which pioneered development of a significant machine for making advanced semiconductor chips during the early 1970's, said yesterday that it would withdraw from the business, blaming Japanese competition.

title: Bowater Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Tellabs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
National Sanitary Supply Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $830,000 from an accounting change. The company said the increase in sales in its latest first quarter is due to the acquisition of Century Papers Inc. in July.
LEAD: The potential benefits of the clean air bills now before Congress will not be worth the cost imposed on consumers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lendl, Edberg and McEnroe Gain: The top three seeded players - Ivan Lendl, Stefan Edberg and John McEnroe - advanced to the semifinals of the Japan Open yesterday in Tokyo. Lendl, seeded first, overwhelmed 18-year-old Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela, 6-2, 6-2, on the hard court at Ariake Colosseum. He will face an unseeded American, Richard Matuszewski, in a semifinal match today. Matuszewski beat Jason Stoltenberg of Australia, 4-6, 6-4, 7-6.

title: Patents; Applications For Animals Up Sharply
description: A year ago this month, Harvard University made history by obtaining a patent for a mouse genetically engineered to develop cancer. As the first patent ever granted for an animal, the event prompted both cheers and fears.

title: Norfolk Mourns the 47 as Lost Neighbors
description: Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia and 750 other mourners turned out today to pay tribute to the 47 crewmen who ''died too soon'' in the explosion in a gun turret on the battleship Iowa.

title: KEY RATES
Princeton Diagnostic LaboraFtories of America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lance Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
Princess Dok Hye, 76, Of Yi Dynasty in Korea
description: Princess Dok Hye, the last princess of the Yi Dynasty, which ruled Korea for 500 years, until the Japanese annexation in 1910, died today, the state radio reported. She was 76 years old, and the cause of death was not announced.

title: Hearing for Cup Appeal
description: A New York Court has agreed to a hearing on June 8 on an appeal from the San Diego Yacht Club of a ruling ordering it to forfeit the America's Cup to New Zealand. The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court will hear oral arguments at the June session. Written briefs are due in court May 3 from the San Diego Yacht Club. Michael Fay of New Zealand, represented by the Mercury Bay Boating Club, must file his opposing papers by May 24. (AP)

title: Trimedyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $469,000 and $770,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title:
COMSUMER'S WORLD: COPING;
WITH SUMMER CAMPS
description: LEAD: Summer vacation. The words have a magical sound. But everyone has a different vision of the perfect holiday. For some, two weeks of lolling on a sandy beach or gazing at a mountain view from a veranda is just plain dull.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The ability to create entities which are neither children nor furniture puts us in this situation.'' - Alexander M. Capron, expert in biomedical ethics, on the legal status of frozen human embryos. [ 1:6. ]

title: Iona Appliances Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and equals less than 1 cent a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Embryos in a Divorce Case: Joint Property or Offspring?
description: Mary Sue Davis and Junior Lewis Davis are getting a divorce.

title: Pioneer Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $315,000 for the quarter and $636,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $1,027,000 for the quarter and $2,033,000 for the 6 months, and a loss of $325,000 from discontinued operations for the both periods.

title: USG Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $472,000 and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,075,000. Latest quarter results also included a gain of $10.1 million from a settlement of a lawsuit. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,919,000. Sales represent net sales. The company said its most recent quarter is not directly comparable to the year-earlier quarter due to additional interest and other effects of its recapitalization and restructuring implemented in 1988. For example, interest expense in the most recent quarter was $74,734,000, compared with $16,836,000 a year ago.

title: C-Cor Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $543,000 for the quarter and $849,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March.

title: Busy Days for Advisers To Charter Commission
description: One is a law professor and former counsel to the Democrats in the New York State Senate. Another is a soft-spoken government analyst who once ran a blue-sky research group in Albany and later played a central role in hammering out the state's annual budgets.

title: Acme-Cleveland Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $730,000 and $1,040,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss Latest quarter and 6 months' nets from continuing operations included a $700,000 gain from the sale of an investment in an affiliate company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6, 28 In China's biggest protest in years, a crowd defying a ban on public demonstrations swelled to more than 100,000 Friday night in Beijing's central square to press for more democracy. Page 1 Iranians were arrested for spying for the United States, including senior navy commanders who helped the U.S. attack Iranian naval targets, the acting chief of Iran's armed forces said. 5 Price riots in Jordan intensified as they spread to a town 20 miles from the capital. The police and protestors fought for four hours and the conflict assumed an overtly Islamic and political profile. 1 Rajiv Gandhi's popularity is sliding and many politicians, columnists and voters - especially in cities and towns far away from the capital -believe he may lose the next national election. 3 In the upcoming Soviet campaign for seats in the new national legislature, seven Soviet independents were excluded from the ballot by the local party apparatus. 5 After killings in Soviet Georgia, the Soviet authorities wrongly absolved themselves of blame, recently elected members of the new Soviet Congress of Deputies said. 5 To halt the shelling in Lebanon, France has been involved in a solitary diplomatic campaign that has generated only tepid international support and antagonized Syria. 4 Restriction of South African forces in Namibia to their bases for 60 hours will start Wednesday to give guerrillas hiding in the territory the chance to return safely to Angola. 28 Soccer in Liverpool, England has been a cause for celebration amid glaring troubles. It is a working-class sport for a working-class city, and its teams usually excel. 4 National 7-10 A combined mobile missile force will continue to be developed by the United States, President Bush has decided. The decision is among the most important national security decisions. 1 How were the first 100 days? President Bush and senior White House officials are using a flurry of Presidential activities, briefings and interviews to try to generate a flattering assessment. 1 The top U.S. health researcher, Dr. James B. Wyngaarden, will resign on July 1 after seven years of shepherding much of the nation's biomedical research at the National Institutes of Health. 7 Computerized information by phone may be the wave of the future if a Federal court grants American Telephone and Telegraph permission to enter the market of electronic publishing. 1 A fight over seven frozen embryos, eggs from Mary Sue Davis's body that were fertilized with Junior Lewis Davis's sperm, has raised profound and troubling issues like determining when life begins. 1 Nature is removing the spilled oil in Prince William Sound off Valdez, Alaska. Exxon said that so much of the remaining oil has evaporated, dispersed or washed onto the beaches that little additional cleanup of the water is possible. 9 New boosters for the space shuttle will be built by units of the Lockheed Corporation and Gencorp's Aerojet General. The NASA contract that will be negotiated is worth about $1.2 billion. 35 Jim Wright's oil well deal, under scrutiny by the Congressional panel investigating the House Speaker, was arranged when Mr. Wright was under intense financial strain, his financial trustee said. 10 The jury in the Oliver North case is deliberating in a room crowded with hundreds of evidence exhibits. Having reached no verdict, they departed for the hotel where they are being sequestered. 7 To honor the 47 crewmen who died in the explosion of the battleship Iowa, Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia and 750 other mourners turned out in Norfolk, Va. 8 Opposition to Iowa port plan is rekindled 8 The Government is fighting claims that it owes $3.3 billion in royalties and back interest for infringing the patented technology that opened the way for worldwide satellite communications. 35 The stock market resumed its surge yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average broke through the 2,400 level for the first time in 18 months. Traders credited heavy program trading. 35 Award drastically reduced in Hudson AIDS suit 7 Regional 29-32 The youths who raped and beat a young investment banker Wednesday as she jogged in Central Park were part of a loosely organized gang of schoolboys whose assaults terrorized at least nine people in two hours. 1 Two men who were attacked in the park, apparently by the same youths who later raped and beat a young woman, depicted them as calculating and menacing. 30 The war over Shoreham is not over. For officials in Albany and in Washington, the conflict could get worse as the Bush Administration struggles to keep the plant alive. 29 Fund-raising for mayoral campaigns is in high gear at New York City homes and restaurants. In politics, friends of the fund-raisers are fair game for a pitch. 29 Long Island's newest village, Pine Valley, has had a rough first year. With a new mayor, a new attorney and a new Village Board, the village is struggling to move forward. 29 The first ''drug free dormitory'' has been opened at the Atlantic Avenue Armory men's shelter in Brooklyn. A year after the experiment began, it continues to work. 29 New York must pay nursing homes millions of dollars in retroactive Medicaid reimbursements by the end of the year, a State Supreme Court justice in Albany has ruled. 30 News analysis: The jail crisis has pushed New York City further toward remedies that several years ago had been resisted by the Koch administration. 31 The Charter Revision Commission staff is working overtime, responding to the commission's inquiries, researching ideas for reshaping the government and, sometimes, restricting the options. 31 A new way to elect the City Council proposed by a group of Republican leaders might allow more members of their party to win seats. 31

title: Jennifer Convertibles reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Income Opportunity Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter included a loss of $3,207,000 due to writedown of real estate owned and a loss of $947,000 due to the writedowns of Ginnie Maes.

title: South Africa Plans Truce for Namibia Rebels
description: South Africa announced today that it would confine its security forces in Namibia to their bases for 60 hours starting on Wednesday evening to give guerrillas still in the territory the chance to return to their bases in Angola.

title: Wright Needed to Repay Large Loan At Time of Well Deal,Trustee Says
description: The 1988 oil well deal under scrutiny by the Congressional panel investigating House Speaker Jim Wright was arranged when he was under a financial strain and seeking to liquidate his share of an investment company to pay a debt, his financial trustee said today.

title: Indians Halt Yankees' Winning Streak at 3
description: Dallas Green muttered a few expletives and then threw his shoes at the wall, one at a time. In a way, he blamed himself for the events that transpired in the eighth inning tonight and left the Yankees with a 6-5 loss to the Cleveland Indians.

title: Glenmore Distilleries Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest third quarter and 9 months results included the operations of Nedley Distilling Co., acquired in March 1988. Also included are the operations of Fleischmann Distilling Co. from Sept. 8, 1988. Year-ago results included the operations of Corbett Canyon Vineyards, sold in January 1988.

title: Marion Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
California Water Service reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are restated to reflect the May 1988 acquisition of Water West Corp. through an exchange of stock in a pooling of interests merger.

title: TJ International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Merrimac Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the 1988 share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid in April.

title: Winning Clerk Is Charged
description: A county clerk honored last year as Tennessee's Clerk of the Year has been arrested on charges he embezzled nearly $34,000 in public funds. Clerk Milburn Waters, 61 years old, of Blount County and his chief deputy, Margaret Blair, 40, were arrested after their indictment by a county grand jury Monday. They were released from jail after posting bonds of $3,000 each. Mr. Waters has been clerk for 18 years in this eastern Tennessee city. He will be allowed to keep his award, the County Officials Association of Tennessee said.

title: Field for Derby Riding Today On Easy Goer
description: More than a dozen 3-year-olds who are still being considered for the Kentucky Derby in two weeks will have their final prep races today, but what one colt does in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct will decide the future of most of the others.

title: Nichols Institute reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $210,000 from an accounting change. The year-ago share earnings have been restated to give effect to a 5 percent stock dividend declared in March.

title: Suns' Gilliam Banned
description: Armon Gilliam of the Phoenix Suns was suspended for his last two games of the regular season and fined $7,500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday after a fight with Dwayne (Pearl) Washington of the Miami Heat that spilled over from the floor to the locker room. Washington was fined $2,000 for his part in the incident, which took place Wednesday night in Miami.

title: Security Federal Savings (Montana) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Tommy Thompson, 72; Led Eagles to 2 Titles
description: Tommy Thompson, the Philadelphia Eagles quarterback who led the team to National Football League championships in 1948 and 1949, died today. He was 72 years old and had been suffering from brain cancer.

title: Secretary of Health Backs a Plan to End Tuberculosis in U.S.
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today endorsed a plan calling for the elimination of tuberculosis in the United States by the year 2010.

title: First Interstate of Iowa reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included the establishment of a $6,804,000 special reserve due to an unfavorable judgment in a lawsuit.

title: Park-Ohio Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $29,378,000 from the sale of Park-Ohio Energy Inc.

title: Cineplex Share Purchase Blocked
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said that the Supreme Court of Ontario had issued an injunction temporarily blocking Cineplex's two top executives from purchasing a large block of the company's stock from a group led by Charles R. Bronfman, the co-chairman of the Seagram Company.

title: Avemco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pioneer Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter reflected an additional provision of $311,267 for loan losses.

title: Boulevard Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Crossland Savings F.S.B. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $9,420,000 charge in lieu of income tax expense.
