Gains on sales of loans and securities were $539,000 in the latest first quarter, compared with $9,325,000 for the year-ago period. Income tax expense in the latest quarter was $13,764,000, including the charge in lieu of tax, compared with $6,429,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Hasbro Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: The latest first quarter consisted of 14 weeks, compared with 13 weeks for year-ago period.

title: Col. James Rowe, 51, War Hero, Is Killed in an Ambush in Manila
description: Col. James N. Rowe, a United States Army officer who spent five years as a prisoner in Vietnam before escaping in 1968, was shot to death yesterday by gunmen near Manila, where he was a military adviser to the Philippine armed forces. He was 51 years old. Colonel Rowe was being driven to work at the Joint United States Military Advisory Group headquarters in Quezon City, a suburb of Manila, shortly after 7 A.M. when at least two hooded gunmen in a stolen car fired more than 20 bullets into his vehicle.

Cutting County Aid, Cuomo Vetoes a Bill On a Petroleum Tax

title: Hungary Troop Withdrawal
description: The Soviet Union will begin the withdrawal of 10,000 of the 62,000 troops it is estimated to have in Hungary on Tuesday, the commander of the Kremlin's forces here said today. The commander, Gen. Matvei Burlakov, said the pullout would involve 22 units and include 10,000 men, 450 tanks, 200 pieces of artillery and 3,000 vehicles. The pullouts are part of the withdrawal of 50,000 troops and 5,000 tanks from Eastern Europe announced by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in December.

description: Corey Millen, the Team USA center, was disqualified from the world hockey championships in Sweden yesterday and faces an 18-month suspension from international competition after tests indicated he had used steroids. An appeal will be made, but even if the suspension holds, Millen, who is the property of the Rangers, could still play in the National Hockey League next season because steroid use is not grounds for keeping a player from the league.

Wardair had agreed to be acquired by the PWA Corporation for $248 million (Canadian) before AMR announced its interest.

title: Morris Falls to 0-4 as Tigers Lose
description: Chris Bosio won his third game as the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Detroit Tigers, 2-1, tonight and handed Jack Morris his fourth successive loss. Morris (0-4) fell four games under .500 for only the second time in his 13-year career. He was 7-11 last July.

title: Review/Dance; Portraits Of Symbiotic Relationships
description: The Margaret Jenkins Dance Company presented three dances for two people on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. It was impossible to guess what might happen next in any of them, for Ms. Jenkins's stormy choreography was as unpredictable as life itself. The program suggested that Ms. Jenkins, whose dances are all too infrequently seen in New York City, is a steadily developing choreographer and that her San Francisco-based company is dramatically strong as well as technically accomplished.

title: G.O.P. Proposes Council Districts Where Its Candidates Could Win
description: Outside New York's City Hall yesterday, a group of Republicans proposed a way to elect the City Council that might allow more members of their party to win seats inside.

title: Jogger's Attackers Terrorized at Least 9 in 2 Hours
description: The youths who raped and savagely beat a young investment banker as she jogged in Central Park Wednesday night were part of a loosely organized gang of 32 schoolboys whose random, motiveless assaults terrorized at least eight other people over nearly two hours, senior police investigators said yesterday.

title: 7 Soviet Progressives Ousted in Caucus

description: The first thing New York needs in redesigning its government is a strong mayor, but it needs something else just as much - a strong, independent City Council. That's hard to imagine, considering the weak, parochial Council that now exists. But if the city is to work after the powerful Board of Estimate is dismantled, as required by the Supreme Court, it will sorely need a capable legislature to assume the board's role as a counterweight to the mayor.

title: Optical Industry Braces for Change Under Deregulation
description: The Federal Government plans to sweep away hundreds of laws that regulate the sale of eyeglasses in most states. Officials for optical industries say that if the change takes effect as planned on Sept. 1, consumers will see a gradual increase in competition: more advertising, more stores and more superopticals - large stores that offer thousands of eyeglass frames, one-stop shopping and one-hour service.

title: Raymond Andrew Sears, Runner, 82
description: Raymond Andrew Sears, a former track star, died Tuesday after being hit by an automobile in College Park, Md. He was 82 years old. Mr. Sears went from a teen-age track star in Greencastle, Ind., to the best in the world in 1934 for the indoor two-mile (9:07).

title: About New York; After the Beep: Express Yourself To the Unseen
description: Once again instincts of self-expression and compulsions for self-promotion have seized upon available technology to enhance the wit and hype of the city. In the 70's it was the aerosol spray can that permitted graffiti daubers to leave their mark on New York. A decade later, the boom box radios paved the way for a contagion of break dancing. Now the telephone answering machine is ushering in the age of the personal sound bite, making it possible for each of us to declare ourselves, proclaim ourselves and advertise ourselves to an at least theoretically vast audience of relatives, friends, soliciting salesmen, perverts and wrong numbers.

description: Dr. James B. Wyngaarden, director of the National Institutes of Health, said today that he would resign on July 1 after seven years of shepherding much of the nation's biomedical research.

title: Reporter's Notebook; North's Jury Starts With the Basics
description: The note from the jurors to the judge came in shortly before 11 A.M., a reminder that the mundane has its own place even in the weightiest deliberations. ''Can we please have some paper clips?'' said the handwritten message from the 12 men and women who today began considering the fate of Oliver L. North. To that query was added another: ''P.S. Is lunch at 12:00?''

title: Liverpool Journal; There's Comfort in Loving the Team
description: When times are hard, it seems that soccer has a way of straightening the stooped shoulders of this battered old port and transforming its limping gait into a proud strut.

title: A New Duvalier In Haiti?
description: LEAD: In the aftermath of the recent coup attempt in Haiti, the State Department public-relations machine has been working nonstop to persuade Congress to renew economic and perhaps even military aid. In the fantasy the State Department is concocting for Congress, Haiti's leader, Gen. Prosper Avril, is taking a valiant stand against corruption and drug running while making great strides toward democracy.

title: Patent Case May Cost U.S. Billions
description: The Federal Government is fighting claims that it owes $3.3 billion in royalties and back interest for infringing the patented technology that opened the way for satellite communications.

title: Homeless Find Shelter From Drugs
description: Each night, after another day spent in a neighborhood drug treatment program, Michael Patrick, who was homeless, returned to the Atlantic Avenue Armory men's shelter in Brooklyn. There he had one of 700 beds lined up on a drill floor the size of a football field. Back in a world pervaded by drugs and alcohol, he despaired of ever breaking his addiction.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Patching Screens
description: Spring is the time to repair and replace window screens. Conventional insect screens are made of aluminum or vinyl-coated fiberglass and are available at hardware stores and home centers. Solar screens, which also keep insects out, are made of specially woven vinyl-coated fiberglass that blocks heat and glare, and are available at greenhouse retailers and some home centers and from manufacturers. Small holes and tears in all screening can be repaired at home, either with kits from hardware stores, pre-cut patches or patches cut from a sheet of screening. Two screening manufacturers are Screen Manufacturers Association, Park Place, Suite 201, 655 Irving Park at Lake Shore Drive, Chicago 60613, 312-525-2644; and Phifer Wire Products Inc., P.O. Box 1700, Tuscaloosa, Ala. 35403, 800-633-5955. $ Type of Screen Features Repairs Vinyl-fiberglass Blocks 30-35% of Cement pre-cut sunlight; black patches over tears Aluminum Blocks 30-35% of sun- Use kit with snap-on light; silver-gray patches Solar screen Blocks 70-75% of sun- Cut patches to ce- light; black, silver-gray ment over tears ronze

description: Liv Ullmann is to be interviewed, and clips from several of her films shown, in the Tishman Auditorium of Vanderbilt Hall at New York University on May 3 at 8 P.M. The critic Andrew Sarris is to be the interviewer. The program, entitled ''The Creative Process: Behind the Scenes With Liv Ullmann,'' includes scenes from ''Persona,'' ''Cries and Whispers,'' ''The Wild Duck,'' ''Scenes From a Marriage'' and ''The Emigrants.'' The hall is at 40 Washington Square South. Admission is free, but seating is limited. Information: 998-7370.

description: West Germany intends to press the United States to agree to early talks with Moscow on reducing short-range nuclear missiles and nuclear artillery weapons, Western diplomats said today.

title: Bridge
description: One who delights in playing bridge every day of his life, and will overcome great obstacles to do so, is a true enthusiast. A man died Sunday who fitted that definition perfectly: Roy Titus, heir to the cosmetics empire built up by his mother, Helena Rubinstein. For the last two years of his life, ill-health prevented him from leaving his New York apartment, so his friends came every day to play with him and his wife, Nuita.

Advice on investing in stocks from a veteran fund manager. 4 11 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 5 4 7 GETTING THE LOVE YOU WANT, by Harville Hendrix. (Holt, $18.95.) Counsel for couples. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) A DIVIDED LIFE: A Personal Portrait of the Spy Donald Maclean, by Robert Cecil. (Morrow, $18.95.) A sympathetic but hardheaded biography of the industrious, hard-drinking spy who fled Britain for Moscow with Guy Burgess in 1951, by a contemporary who thoroughly understands Maclean's environment and background. THE MASTER SPY: The Story of Kim Philby, by Phillip Knightley. (Knopf, $19.95.) Mr. Knightley, who met Philby shortly before his death, gives a rich sense of the unrepentant K.G.B. agent who penetrated the highest levels of British and American intelligence. MOLEHUNT: Searching for Soviet Spies in MI5, by Nigel West. (Morrow, $19.95.) Was there a Fifth Man, a Soviet spy beyond even Philby and Anthony Blunt in British intelligence? Mr. West expertly recounts the search and the evidence for such a figure. SEE UNDER: LOVE, by David Grossman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) A thoroughly disturbing novel, an investigation of both the horrors of the Holocaust and the art of storytelling, through memory and the techniques of multiple narrative. BYZANTIUM: The Early Centuries, by John Julius Norwich. (Knopf, $29.95.) A congenial and eloquent guide to the first few centuries of the other Roman Empire, the Oriental state that eventually survived Rome itself by nearly a millennium. HITLER: The Path to Power, by Charles Bracelen Flood. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) A scholar's thoughtful inquiry into the mystery of how such a wretch could rise to such power in so great a country. BAUMGARTNER'S BOMBAY, by Anita Desai. (Knopf, $18.95.) A daring, colorful novel that depicts how one man's presence can alter a city - in this case, the presence of a Berlin Jew, hemmed in by a foreignness that paradoxically makes him feel secure.

title: Whirlpool Is Gathering a Global Momentum
description: The Whirlpool Corporation's shareholders have had ample cause for misgivings of late. Whirlpool's 1988 annual report told them that the huge appliance company's profits and return on equity had taken a nosedive. And 1989 seemed to be filling up with bad news.

title: States Exhorted to Toughen Drunken Driving Laws
description: Advocates of tougher moves against drunken driving are pushing state legislatures to lower the allowable blood alcohol level for driving and to take drunken drivers' licenses away.

title: HOW NOT TO MAKE YOUR FIRST MILLION
description: WINTER LOSSES By Mark Probst. 312 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Columbia; In Mid-Career, Finding Time For Student Life
description: On the fast track at the Columbia University Graduate Business School, it is difficult enough to pencil in a social life between job interviews and strategic-management classes. It is even tougher while holding down a full-time executive career.

title: THE WORLD: Incentives for Warsaw; Washington Offers Help for a Price
description: PRESIDENT BUSH signaled last week that Washington is willing to take a chance on Poland, but only if Poland is willing to accept economic changes that give a much freer rein to private enterprise.

title: City Tech
description: To the Editor:

title:
New Jersey Q & A: John G. Avildsen;
Directing the Movie on Joe Clark
description: LEAD: ''LEAN ON ME,'' the movie directed by John G. Avildsen on the efforts of Joe Clark, the principal of Eastside High School in Paterson, to bring order and educational reform to the school, is based on a true story, but it has its elements of fantasy.

title: For Troubled Nassau Museum, a New Start
description: LEAD: THE first action that Serge Sabarsky plans to take as new director of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor is to cover the windows of the museum, the former Frick mansion.

title: Two 18-Year-Olds Are Killed In Housing Project Shooting
description: Two 18-year-old men were shot and killed in the lobby of a housing-project building in Far Rockaway, Queens, around midnight Friday, the police said.

title: Casual Choices in Bustling SoNo
description: OPERATING on the ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it'' principle, the owners of the small, successful Breakaway in Fairfield have opened Sweptaway, another restaurant with the same breezy spirit, in the revitalized SoNo neighborhood of South Norwalk.

title: THEY'VE SEEN THE PRESENT; IT SEEMS TO WORK
description: LEAD: MOSCOW SPRING By William Taubman and Jane Taubman. 301 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: Being a Burden
description: To the Editor: One need not be steeped in Eastern philosophy to see the ethnocentrism in Eleanor N. Schwartz's reluctance to ascend to an Indian hill temple by means of a chair borne on the shoulders of men she describes as ''beasts of burden'' (''A Reluctant Burden,'' Travel, March 12).

title: Podie Lynch, Maker of Dance-Wear, Marries James Torrey, an Executive
description: Rose Peabody Lynch, a daughter of Rose Parsons Lynch of New Canaan, Conn., and R. Vincent Lynch of Dallas, was married yesterday to James Alexander Torrey at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. John Hartnett performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Robert C. Gregg, the Episcopal chaplain of Stanford University.

title: Man Accuses Counsel of Distorting His Testimony
description: A Fort Worth businessman said today that his testimony had been distorted by the special counsel who conducted the investigation of House Speaker Jim Wright.

title: Getting a Grip on Jug Handles
description: ''TURN right at the jug handle and continue another three blocks,'' was the direction given to me on my first day of apartment hunting in New Jersey. The direction was odd for someone from the Midwest, where streets intersect at right angles and jug handles are on vinegar containers.

title: Man Ordered to Take Anti-Psychotic Drugs
description: A man accused of killing his mother while under the influence of cocaine has been ordered by a judge to take powerful drugs that the state hopes will make him competent to stand trial.

title: 'PERSONAL FOR MR. BARHOLOMEW SCOTT BLAIR, URGENT'
description: It is Moscow in the third summer of perestroika. The first-ever British audio fair is drawing to its dreary end. Niki Landau, a Polish-born publisher's representative, is closing down his stand when a beautiful Russian woman, Katya, approaches him and begs him to take a friend's manuscript back to London, and there hand it to a publisher named Barley (Bartholomew) Scott Blair. ''It is a novel. A great novel. Its message is important to all mankind,'' she says. Landau stashes the package in his briefcase, returns to his hotel and reaches his bedroom door.

title: IN THE VALLEY OF THE KILLER DOLLS
description: THere are skeletons in Barbie's family closet. The killer doll, a creepy and ludicrous idea, has inspired plenty of bad films and a very few enduring ones. The best are witty about the silly genre they take advantage of.

title: Bonn's Rate Move Rattles Confidence
description: A surprise from West Germany took some of the conviction out of the widespread belief that inflation in the world economy might be stabilizing and interest rates might ease. Saying it wanted to curb inflationary pressures, the Bundesbank raised the discount rate last week by a half a percentage point, to 4.5 percent. The American discount rate is 7 percent. At 2.7 percent, the German inflation rate seems tame to many nations. But Bonn is known to have little tolerance for rising prices and recent jumps in oil prices apparently have caused distress. Officials in Washington said the move was a surprise but was not worrisome, provided other nations did not follow.

title: Orangemen Show Colors
description: When it comes to dividing up their teams for those color-against-color intrasquad games that traditionally mark the end of spring football practices, college coaches have used a variety of formulas.

title: Historic Adobe, Myths of the Old West
description: ON the plaza in Mesilla, a village of 2,000 in southern New Mexico's wide, rich Rio Grande valley, a sharp-eyed visitor can delight in the details of its carefully restored Territorial architecture. Along the way, shops, art galleries and restaurants add to the mix of history and tourism.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Yale; Samba Seminar Yields Whoops, Yelps and Credit
description: Samba, the national dance of Brazil, known for its fast, polyrhythmic beat, is just one of the Afro-Brazilian dances becoming fashionable among Yale students. And for some of them, it is providing academic credit as well.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Many Shop Around, but Few Stay to Buy
description: SPRING is when house-hunters emerge with the daffodils. The daffodils have blossomed, but, say many Fairfield County realtors, while an encouraging number of house-hunters have appeared, they are more likely to wait and see than to buy.

title: Ethel Bass Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bass of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ethel Bass, to Barry Weintraub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Weintraub of Douglaston, Queens. The couple plan to marry in June. Miss Bass, a producer for the ABC-TV program ''20/20,'' graduated from Brooklyn College. Mr. Weintraub is the president of William Weintraub and Sons, a mechanical contracting firm founded by his grandfather in the Bronx.

title: BASEBALL
description: MY 9 INNINGS: An Autobiography of 50 Years in Baseball. By Lee MacPhail. (Meckler Books, $21.95.) In his distinguished 50-year career as a leading baseball executive, Lee MacPhail seems to have witnessed, participated in or presided over most of the major controversies in the game's recent history, including the end of the reserve system, the player strike of 1981 and the continuing debate over a drug-testing program for players. He also earned a role in baseball lore as the man who overruled the umpires and let stand the infamous 1983 game-winning home run by the Kansas City third baseman George Brett against the Yankees, although Mr. Brett had been accused of illegal use of pine tar on his bat. Although he was never a manager or a player, Mr. MacPhail amassed the front-office equivalent of an all-star record in his positions as general manager of the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles. He also served as the assistant to the commissioner of baseball and, from 1974 to 1983, as president of the American League. In chronicling his career, Mr. MacPhail provides some revealing glimpses of the egos and off-the-field dynamics of baseball's owners and managers. For instance, to keep order at meetings with such colorful and voluble characters as the owners Bill Veeck, Charlie Finley, Gene Autry and George Steinbrenner, Mr. MacPhail would produce a three-minute sand clock, then interrupt the speaker when the sand ran out. Mr. MacPhail also had his run-ins with managers, but when 55,000 fans at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium booed him after he had ruled against the Orioles' manager, Earl Weaver, for improperly forfeiting a game, it was Mr. Weaver who ran to the microphone to calm the crowd. Throughout, Mr. MacPhail comes across as a man of measured words who was not afraid to stand his ground in a dispute and who strove to resolve labor and player relations issues fairly for players and owners alike. One only wishes that in his memoirs he had let down his guard a bit more.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: MUSIC SEASON FINALE A mime, a guitarist playing Appalachian folk songs and a guest cellist will enhance the New Jersey Chamber Music Society concerts in Pomona and Montclair this week.

title: Marianne Norato Marries a Lawyer
description: At St. Rocco's Roman Catholic Church in Johnston, R.I., Marianne Norato, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Norato of Cranston, R.I., was married yesterday to Steven A. Candito, the son of Frank Candito of East Islip, L.I., and the late Rita Candito and the stepson of Sandra Candito. The Rev. Joseph Moffo officiated.

title: Reviews/Music; The Mystical Celibidache Conducts
description: One of the exciting aspects of New York's musical life is the event at which everybody who presumes to be anybody converges to check out the latest sensation. If the sensation happens to be controversial, all the better: then the everybody-anybodies stand around during the intermission and afterwards, when the mere audience is bravoing away, and discuss the concert with gushing enthusiasm, heated animation, bored indifference or cynical disdain.

title: A Longing for Another Month of Winter
description: I KNOW spring is here. Safe from behind a storm window, I have observed its early warning signs, but I'm just not ready for it yet. It's not that I dislike the season. I can marvel at a blanket of crocuses with the best of them. I'm just not ready to turn my fancy from the comforts of winter.

title: Land Rush Re-enacted With Yells
description: Oklahomans on horseback and in wagons today re-enacted the mad rush that occurred on this date a century ago when two million acres of Indian territory were opened to settlement by whites.

title: Sticking to Guns
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi may well rue the day he set foot outside the nice, straightforward international arms trade and tried to help his old friend, former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, make some real estate investments. At the request of United States officials who are seeking his extradition, the Saudi financier was arrested in Switzerland last week on charges that he engaged in ''illegal property dealings'' involving at least $103 million that Mr. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, are accused of stealing from the Philippines. Mr. Khashoggi, who amassed a fortune arranging weapons purchases for his country and, in effect, keeping the change, has also been accused of involvement in the Iran-contra affair and his property in the United States has been seized by the Government. As a result, said a friend, the former billionaire is now worth less than $40 million.

title: Lorenzo's Unlikely Plan for Eastern
description: Frank Lorenzo has been thinking of late about all the people who used to fly back in the days of People Express, when air fares were dirt cheap.

title: Association Addresses the Care of Aging Parents
description: LEAD: IN an effort to foster awareness of the work done by members of a national geriatric organization, two Westchester residents are planning to give a seminar next month on the care-giving, legal and financial issues facing older people.

title:
STYLEMAKERS;
Marie Mercie - Milliner
description: LEAD: Hats, the wilder the better, have made a comeback in Paris, and the revival is being led by a milliner who may be the maddest hatter of them all, Marie Mercie.

title: The Best Things In Life . . .
description: It is spring, and the five boroughs of New York City are bursting with things to do and to see that cost nothing, or next to nothing ($3 or less). Here is a highly selective list. If there is an admission fee, it is indicated; otherwise these attractions, like the best things in life, are free. ALL BOROUGHS

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Norwood E. Jackson;
More Prisoners Means Finding the Space
description: LEAD: IT has been almost eight years since prisoners at the Westchester County Jail in Valhalla rioted for four days, causing millions of dollars in damage. Prison crowding was a major cause.

title: Upper East Side
description: THERE SEEMS ALWAYS TO HAVE been a perception of the Upper East Side of Manhattan as the private preserve of the rich and privileged, its residents of a certain wealthy, conservative and snobbish persuasion. After all, here between the East River and Central Park are the street names synonymous with money and power: the fashionable Avenues, Park and Fifth, the chic Places, Beekman and Sutton. And, in fact, there was a time at the turn of the century when the rich of the Upper East Side lived in mansions that later became museums and kept their private yachts anchored in the East River. Although there were among them enclaves of various ethnic groups, and low- and middle-income earners, it was the affluent who gave the Upper East Side its original cachet.

title: Colonel Steiner Wed To Susan Mary Dunn
description: Susan Mary Dunn, a government-affairs associate for the Champion International Corporation, and Lieut. Col. Charles R. Steiner, an Army officer who is a legislative and public-affairs officer for the European and Canadian Bureau of the State Department, both in Washington, were married yesterday. Msgr. Francis Gartland officiated at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford Village, N.Y.

title: Dede Desrochers, A Banker, Weds Bradford McLane
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., Dorothy Marie Desrochers was married yesterday to Bradford Lawrence McLane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. McLane of New Canaan. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Desrochers of Baltimore. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roland M. Jones and the Rev. Mary von Weise, an aunt of the bridegroom. Mrs. McLane, known as Dede, is a vice president in the capital markets group of the Texas Commerce Bank in Houston. She graduated from the University of Maryland and received a master's degree from the American Graduate School of International Management in Glendale, Ariz. Her father was an analyst for the National Security Agency at Fort George G. Meade, Md.

title: Cincinnati Law Dean to Lead Trinity College
description: Tom Gerety, dean of the University of Cincinnati College of Law, was elected today as the 17th president of Trinity College by the school's board of trustees.

title: Invest In Children Now, Or Pay Later
description: >S state and Federal policymakers debate over how to meet the costs of government responsibility to our children and their families, it is imperative that we consider the dramatic public policy implications of demographic, social and economic trends that will affect our future.

title: Not Leaving East Rockaway
description: At the risk of making East Rockaway too appealing, I must respond to the article by Claire M. Lynch entitled ''Leaving East Rockaway'' (Opinion, April 9).

title: Which Generation Should Foot the Bill?
description: The cost of rehabilitating the savings and loan industry is turning out to be a staggering $100 billion. It is, therefore, important to ask who will pay the bill.

title: UGANDA: AFTER THE TERROR
description: It is unfortunate that Mr. Kapuscinski chooses to describe religion in Uganda solely in terms of its explosive nature. He writes: ''At this time of day, all the prophets are busy in the neighboring villages spreading the vision of a fiery apocalypse.''

title: Editors' Note
description: An article headed ''The Life Style of the East Side 5-Year-Old'' appears today in New York, New York, part 2 of The Times Magazine. As its introduction specifies, the article is based on the lives of several children, but the narrative combines them into two, called Nick and Kim.

title: Shoreham Ordeal: Hard-Won Lessons
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING the crippling accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear-power facility near Harrisburg, Pa., 10 years ago, the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission issued a report detailing lessons learned from the event.

title: The Niche That I.B.M. Can't Ignore
description: In a company celebrated for its managerial conservatism and organizational discipline, R. Andrew Heller was regarded as a renegade.

title: Group Seeks Ban on Use of Hudson River Water
description: An environmental group has asked a Federal judge to block New York City's plan to use Hudson River water starting May 1 as a supplement to the city's water supply, because of the damage the treated water may do to a reservoir.

title: Cooler Cashmere, for Warmer Weather
description: Summer cashmere may sound like a contradiction, but there are four new cashmere boutiques around Manhattan that are hoping to turn it into a fashion trend.

title: Footloose on the Byways of Wales
description: RATIOS in Wales tend to favor the pastoral: there are more sheep than people and more footpaths than motorways. The countryside, like that of England, is honeycombed with these ancient rights of way, probably the only reliable route to a genuine familiarity with Wales.

title: DATA UPDATE: April 23, 1989
WATCHING HER SPIN AND SPARKLE
description: METAPHOR & MEMORY Essays. By Cynthia Ozick. 283 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: For Brian Dennehy, Character Tells All
description: Like a stranded whale, Brian Dennehy lies helplessly behind two trash cans, blood pouring down his arm. The bad guys with their big guns are only one muddy field away, but - since this is make-believe -they must wait while half a dozen people squat on quilts in front of the wounded actor, spraying new blood and shoving measuring tapes in his face.

title: The Problems of DES Exposure Remain Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Words for Rushdie
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sprightly Portable, but Flawed
description: Is any advance in portability worth jeopardizing the integrity of your data? Many people would say no, but one intriguing machine introduced at the Comdex trade show in Chicago earlier this month poses that question bluntly.

title: Miss Waskiewicz Becomes a Bride
description: Anne-Louise Waskiewicz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon E. Waskiewicz of Suffield, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory W. Benning, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Benning of Malvern, Pa. The Rev. Jerald G. Miner performed the ceremony at the Christ Episcopal Church in New Haven.

title:
DINING OUT;
Unpretentious Eclectic Fare in Chatham
description: LEAD: WHEN Chatham's venerable William Pitt Restaurant burned down a couple of years ago, the Morris County town lost an architectural, if not a gastronomic, landmark. Then, starting last fall, a cluster of new buildings in an updated Colonial style sprang up to contain shops and condominiums on the old site.

title: Michelangelo Didn't Lie Down on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES

GARDENING;
Planting Meadows in Place of Lawns
description: LEAD: IN recent years, meadow plantings have become popular. This has resulted partly because they require little maintenance and partly as a way of making an ecological statement. Undoubtedly some have planted them because they like the informal, natural effect.

title: AIDS in a Deficit Year: More Plans Than Money
description: NEW YORK CITY has reached a critical juncture in dealing with the AIDS epidemic. City and state decisions in the next few months may well determine whether the overstressed health care system can cope with a threefold increase in AIDS cases while continuing to serve the rest of the public.

title:
IN SHORT;
BASEBALL
description: LEAD: HOLY COW! By Harry Caray with Bob Verdi. (Villard, $17.95.) For Chicagoans who had long listened to Bob Elson's calm and cool radio broadcasts of White Sox baseball, Harry Caray's arrival in 1971 came as a shock. Bombastic, opinionated and unabashedly enthusiastic, Mr. Caray was a sharp contrast to Mr.

title: Michael J. O'Neill, 69, Magazine Executive
description: Michael Joyce O'Neill, a former magazine publisher, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Architectural Board Accepts L'Ambiance Plaza Agreement
description: The state's Architectural Licensing Board has settled charges against two companies involved in the construction of an apartment building that collapsed here two years ago, killing 28 construction workers.

title: When RICO Bites
description: To the Editor:

title: Princess Dok Hye, 76, Of Yi Dynasty in Korea
description: Princess Dok Hye, the last princess of the Yi dynasty which ruled Korea for 500 years until the Japanese annexation in 1910, died today, the state radio reported. She was 76 years old, and the cause of death was not announced.

title: Deborah Burke, a Caterer, Becomes a Bride in Virginia
description: Deborah Louise Burke, a daughter of Robert David Burke of Annapolis, Md., and Louise White Yoast of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Alan Blount, a son of Donald Wilson Blount and Mrs. Donald Matter Burton, both of Alexandria, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Alexandria. The Rev. Geoffrey M. St. John Hoare officiated, assisted by the Rev. Rodney Brown, also an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride.

title: A Library Where Rare Is Common
description: Rosy Brook he bought a book Though he didn't know how to spell it. Such is the lure of literature To the lad who can buy and sell it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The growing recognition that his campaign to revitalize the economy was simply not working has led Gorbachev to alter his basic approach to solving the country's economic problems.'' - Report by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency. [ 14:3. ]

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the crush at a British soccer stadium in which more than 90 people were killed misstated sanctions imposed on some British teams. English club teams and their supporters have been banned from the three major soccer competitions in Europe, but the English national team and club teams from elsewhere in Britain remain eligible.

title: Reviews/Music; A Freelance Cellist in Recital
description: Andre Emelianoff, a busy freelancer who is principal cellist of the New York Chamber Symphony and a member of several chamber enembles, played a recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening.

title:
THEATER;
A Trilogy Takes Its Playwright Home Again
description: LEAD: In America all writers leave their hometowns - even if only, as in Flannery O'Connor's case, to attend a creative-writing school. Fifty-two years ago, one day out of high school, I left Tampa, Fla., for New York City, too late by a few months for Nazimova in ''Hedda Gabler,'' but in time for Helen Hayes in ''Victoria Regina,'' whose posters I could see as my bus maneuvered into the station across from what I consider to this day to be the real Madison Square Garden.

title: Social Events
description: For New Leaders

title:
INVESTING;
Capital Holding Finds Favor
description: LEAD: Life insurance stocks also offer a defensive play because customers continue paying policy premiums even when the economy turns down. And one insurance stock that has done especially well recently is the Capital Holding Corporation. The company, based in Louisville, Ky., is a premier life-insurance marketer with one of the strongest earnings records in the industry.

title: What a Liberal Must Be
description: To the Editor:

title: Response Plan Readied For Oil Spills in State
description: TANKERS and barges deliver more than three billion gallons of oil and gasoline into Connecticut ports each year, and the shipping has come under intense scrutiny because of the recent oil spill off Valdez, Alaska.

title: Bourque Gets In Last Shot
description: Craig Berube, who regularly hits the ice with the sole purpose of finding somebody to punch, was provoking Pittsburgh's Phil Bourque even before the start of the game between the Flyers and Penguins Friday night at the Spectrum. Berube taunted him, stuck his leg between Bourque's, poked his stick into his midsection.

title: Landry Is Honored
description: Thousands of fans lined a mile-and-a-half parade route in downtown Dallas yesterday to pay tribute to Tom Landry, the coach of the Cowboys for 29 years before he was dismissed when the team was sold.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The longest bridge event ever played, and in many ways the most remarkable, ended eight days ago. It was the Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes, played at the Cavendish Club in New York City and the Club du Bridgeur in Paris. It lasted two weeks.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: John Fedorowicz is going to come as a surprise to those who believe that to be a top chessplayer one must be an egomaniac.

title: Crews From Penn Rule the Schuylkill
description: Penn's heavyweight crews swept the river today in the Blackwell Cup regatta against Yale and Columbia. The Red and Blue varsity, second varsity and freshman eights made short work of the competition on the Schuylkill River 2,000-meter course by establishing early leads and then coasting home.

title: Victorian and Thriving
description: QUEEN VICTORIA DIED IN 1901, and some historians claim she outlived the era that bears her name.

title: Footnote
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Texas; Student's Killing Brings Rethinking Of Trips to Mexico
description: University of Texas students often journey south of the border in search of cheap liquor and a decadent night life. This year, however, many are questioning the safety of such treks after a drug-smuggling cult killed Mark Kilroy, a 21-year-old pre-medicine senior from Santa Fe, Tex.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;
3-Bedrooms For $50,500
description: LEAD: AT first glance, the rows of factory-built town houses, with their brick fronts and high concrete steps, look remarkably like the aging, rundown homes that dominate the crowded, trash-strewn streets of West Baltimore.

title: One Man's Fountain of Youth
description: GOD rested on the seventh day, and so, says the law, must Edmond Koehler. He's not happy about it.

title: BUGGING OUT
description: LEAD: THE COCKROACHES OF STAY MORE By Donald Harington. 337 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Blind Passion

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ARBOR DAY Celebrating Arbor Day these days (yes, it's Friday) goes beyond merely making like Johnny Appleseed, although that's still done.

title:
HERS;
What, Me Angry?
description: LEAD: I WAS IN MANHATTAN, spending the night with friends. It was the early 1970's, and we were talking about the Yale community, from which they had recently moved. ''The provost is making an active effort to recruit female graduate students,'' I told them. ''Isn't that wonderful news?'' The remark proved to be fatal.

title: How I Got off Self-Help Junk Food
description: FROM one Long Islander to another, let me share a secret with you: I am addicted to pop psychology books the way an addict finds temporary solace in his drug of choice. Whether reading ''Your Erroneous Zones'' or ''Looking Out for No. 1,'' the relief I receive is always the same. Quick and painless, momentarily soothing, instantly gratifying, and, best of all, no dangerous side effects!

title: WAITING FOR THE OTHER GUY TO BLINK
description: ON THE BRINK Americans and Soviets Reexamine the Cuban Missile Crisis. by James G. Blight and David A. Welch. Foreword by McGeorge Bundy. 400 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $24.95. WINDOWS OF OPPORTUNITY From Cold War to Peaceful Competition in U.S.-Soviet Relations. Edited by Graham T. Allison and William L. Ury with Bruce J. Allyn. 345 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Ballinger Publishing Company. Cloth, $39.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: Alaskans Are Urged to Mark Spill With Period of Silence
description: Gov. Steve Cowper today asked Alaskans to observe five minutes of silence on Sunday in remembrance of the way things were before the Exxon Valdez oil spill fouled hundreds of miles of pristine coastline.

title: Comics as Inspiration: Are We Having Fun Yet?
description: I the book ''Krazy Kat: A Novel in Five Panels,'' Jay Cantor's update of George Herriman's celebrated comic strip, the angry, brick-throwing Ignatz Mouse writes an indignant letter to Offisa Bull Pup that expresses his frustration with his two-dimensional status:

title: There's No Place Like Restaurant
description: MY PARENTS WERE IN THE restaurant business. When you opened the fridge, food fell on your feet. Mother entertained lavishly, summoning Mattie Watts from the kitchen by pressing her toe against a bell set into the dining room floor. I vowed I'd never summon someone. So I became the summonee.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FREEDOM SUMMER. By Doug McAdam. (Oxford University, $24.95.) In ''Freedom Summer,'' Doug McAdam tells the dramatic story of how the interracial civil rights effort in segregated Mississippi dissolved in 1964 and how the effects of the experience shaped the political and cultural landscape of America into the 1980's.

title: Village Hopes Its Coziness Will Survive Prosperity
description: LIFE moves at an easy, old-fashioned pace in Noank's commercial district. Residents are wondering if that atmosphere will survive a proposed redevelopment.

title: An Artist Whose Portfolio Is the Rooms of His Home
description: WHEN prospective customers ask to see an example of Victor DeMasi's decorative painting, he takes them into his bathroom.

title: Ms. Park Married In a Jersey Event
description: Heijung Park and Michael Colameco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Michael Colameco of Haverford, Pa., were married yesterday by the Rev. Chaiyoung Park, a brother of the bride, at the First Korean Church of New Jersey, a Presbyterian congregation in Jersey City. The bride is a daughter of the late Rev. Sonhyuk Park, a Presbyterian minister, and his wife, the late Bok Yun Kim, of Pusan, South Korea.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: IT is an irony of research that the exciting discoveries one seeks in far-off places may turn up almost within arm's reach, or so it would seem from the career of William B. Styple, a 28-year-old writer and editor who lives in the Hudson County town of Kearny.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FIREBIRD. By James Carroll. (Dutton, $18.95.) In his seventh novel, James Carroll presents a unique hero in the spy thriller genre. His F.B.I. agent, Christopher Malone, is a refreshing departure from Ian Fleming's carousing, amoral James Bond - and he's more than simply a blue-collar version of William F.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Three sides of my house are covered with asbestos shingles. They are in good condition, but we want to put up cedar wood shingles. A contractor recommended putting up furring strips over the asbestos shingles, then nailing the cedar shingles to these. Should the asbestos shingles be removed first?

title: New Shine on a Tarnished Penney
description: The Prestonwood Town Center is a sprawling mall encircled for miles by the well-kept neighborhoods, gleaming office buildings, popular restaurants and busy highways of north Dallas. With 175 stores, including the glittering emporia of Lord & Taylor and Neiman-Marcus and specialty retailers like the Limited and the Gap, it is the chosen battlefield of the J.C. Penney Company.

title: The Greenroom Effect
description: BEFORE THE BRINKLEY program began,'' I wrote at the start of a political harangue, ''in the 'green room' (so named for the guest-relaxing color on its walls). . . .''

title: Sharon Gleeson Is a Bride
description: Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church in North Augusta, S.C., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sharon Gleeson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Gleeson of Smoke Rise, N.J., and David Nicholas Cowart, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Cowart Jr. of Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Samuel Miglarese officiated. Mrs. Cowart, a graduate of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, and her husband, a graduate of the Georgia Institute of Technology, are both mechanical engineers at the Westinghouse Savannah River Company in Aiken, S.C.

title: Nationalities, a Permanent Soviet Crisis
description: In a few days, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union will convene to deal with one, and only one, issue - the national question. This issue was beleived to have disappeared a long time ago. Marx, to be sure, had never shown much interest in these problems nor had Lenin. They believed, like most of their contemporaries, that national differences were bound to wither away in the not too distant future as the result of economic and technological progress. Unfortunately, they were wrong.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Inwood
description: IF a few great downtown restaurants could be hauled on flatbed trucks to Manhattan's northernmost point, the community of Inwood would be complete, say Assemblyman John B. Murtaugh and other neighborhood residents.

title: Why They Smile at Red Lobster
description: The scene, at a Red Lobster restaurant that opened recently here, is a cross between a pep rally and a pop quiz. A large room is filled with raucous students learning the basics of their trade - waiting on tables. Their enthusiastic teacher raises his clenched fists over his head, fires off questions and exhorts his students to answer as loudly as they can:

title: Conservatives Oppose Candidate for Welfare Job
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, has clashed with some Congressional conservatives and those opposed to abortion over his choice to oversee the agency's welfare system.

title:
ART;
Photography Birthday Show Stands Out
description: LEAD: BY now it is engrained in everyone that photography is celebrating its 150th birthday. Exhibitions in honor of the occasion are everywhere, aided by the medium's easy transportability and reproductability. But it is equally clear that some of these birthday shows are better than others, and one of the best is at the Pelham Art Center through

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY;
Manipulating Images
description: LEAD: THE two photography exhibitions now on view at the gallery of the East End Arts and Humanities Council in Riverhead represent very different sensibilities, although both involve manipulated photographic images and subjective interpretations of what is observed.

title: Helping People With AIDS Stay on Job
description: THE longer people with AIDS can stay on the job, the longer they live, say those who monitor people with the disease.

title: TO LIVE AND DIE IN DETROIT
description: LEAD: KILLSHOT By Elmore Leonard% 287 pp. New York: Arbor House/ William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: An Old Baseball Friend Expires Weekly
description: We gather around the television set this season as one might gather around a deathbed.

title: Claiming A Culture
description: IT'S AN EARLY SPRING EVENING IN Brooklyn, and Nur Ali is moving amid the cheerful clutter of what she calls her ''mission shop,'' the Admiral Family Circle, named after the Islamic collective of which she is a part. While Mrs. Ali, 50, calls out advice to Ahmad, a tailor and member of the collective, she rearranges racks of African-influenced dashikis and bubahs, answers the intermittent ringing of a phone and searches through merchandise at the front of the store in order to locate a tajj - a pillbox-shaped leather-and-cloth hat - for her son A. Kareem Ali Stevenson, who takes orders for her work from his high school classmates.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. PAUL;
Housing Project Revival
description: LEAD: TORRE DE SAN MIGUEL, a 20-year-old, 142-unit federally subsidized rental housing complex on St. Paul's West Side, which has a large Hispanic population, is taking a new step in a long comeback with a $3 million renovation.

title: As Seasons Wrap Up, Choices Must Be Made
description: THE end of April brings so many seasonal finales that next weekend more than a dozen worthy events will be competing for attendance. Both the Philharmonic Symphony and the New Orchestra of Westchester have Saturday-night programs listing an important symphony, a romantic piano concerto and a short 20th-century piece.

title: The Art Student's Life: It Takes More Than Talent
description: AS FOUR YEARS OF INTENSIVE dramatic training wind to a close, the drama students from the Juilliard School demonstrate the art of stage combat in scenes of their own design commonly known as ''the fights.'' The fights are the culmination of a course that provides students with ''techniques for creating the illusion of lethal combat.''

title: Paying Homage To West Africa's Golden Age
description: The spectacular gold jewelry and gilded artifacts made in West Africa over the last 200 years are usually outnumbered in art exhibitions by bronze, wood, stone and ivory objects from this sub-Saharan region. The fragility of carvings with gold-foil surfaces and the scarcity of solid gold objects - most were either buried with their owners or recycled - help to explain why such works are modestly represented in most shows.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Hempstead $114,000 111 Henry Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; family room, basement; taxes $1,800. Glen Cove $340,000 894 Glen Cove Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new high ranch; family room, fireplace, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,000. Lindenhurst $152,500 571 South Fifth Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old ranch; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Lakeland $135,000 281 Easton Street West 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 16-year-old ranch; finished basement, pool, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Mineola $273,000 325 Harding Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old, stucco/brick high ranch; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,500. Roslyn $220,000 22 Evans Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old ranch; family room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. OTHER AREAS Stafford, Conn. $128,000 8 Burbank Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, wooded yard, 0.66 acre; taxes $1,039. Rye, N.Y. $347,500 83 Elmwood Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 77-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, den, family room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,777. Bradley Beach, N.J. $175,000 501 LaReine Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old colonial; fireplace, porch, full basement; taxes $2,340.

title: Crusader on the Charles
description: THE CITY OF CHELSEA, just northeast of Boston, might have been created as a case study for American educators. Its residents are poor, more than half are Hispanic or Asian immigrants, and they have one of the highest rates of tuberculosis, alcoholism, drug abuse and teen-age pregnancy in the commonwealth. About half of Chelsea's school children speak English as a second language or not at all; its high school dropout rate is 52 percent. Three years ago, a group of Chelsea's citizens turned to John R. Silber. They knew the Boston University president had offered to manage the troubled schools of Boston, and had been turned down. They asked him to consider Chelsea, and Silber grabbed at the chance.

title: My Brother's Unknowable World
description: IT'S Leonard's birthday.

title:
INVESTING;
Utility Stocks, a Recession Hedge
description: LEAD: With some economists predicting a recession later this year, analysts recommend utility stocks for conservative investors. Regulated utilities produce steady earnings, even during economic downturns, and the sector's hefty dividends provide solid income and help maintain stock prices in declining markets.

title: 66 Cooped-Up Cats And All That Implies
description: One litter box was obviously not enough for 66 cats.

title: Does an Assault on Nature Make Exxon a Criminal?
description: WHILE executives and environmentalists at the Exxon Corporation spent last week in Valdez, Alaska, drawing the latest plans to clean up what they could of the nation's worst oil spill, a Federal grand jury in nearby Anchorage began the task of determining what crimes may have been committed.

title: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: Otto Lowe Is Married to Mary Crisp
description: Mary Louise Nowell Crisp, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sellers Luther Crisp of Greenville, N.C., was married there yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church to Otto Wescott Lowe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Lowe Jr. of Jersey City. The Rev. Dan C. Wilkers and the Rev. Richard R. Gammon performed the ceremony. Florence Amanda Crisp was the maid of honor for her sister, and James Schaefer was best man.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY;
Flowering Medium In Diverse Views
description: LEAD: SOME of the hottest talk in the gallery world centers on photography. There is discussion about the medium having flowered in new ways in the 80's and about widening public appreciation for its creative potential.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE ESSAYS OF VIRGINIA WOOLF. Volume Three: 1919-1924. Edited by Andrew McNeillie. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) Thomas Carlyle once said he would ''as soon wash his face in a dirty puddle as write journalism,'' according to Virginia Woolf; she herself expressed similar reservations, complaining that ''after a dose of criticism I feel that I'm writing sideways.'' Yet not only was Woolf's journalism an economic necessity, writes Andrew McNeillie in the introduction to this third volume of her collected essays; her essays also had an important relationship to her fiction. The present collection, which spans 1919 to 1924, comprises 136 articles of varying lengths and covers an eclectic range of subjects. There are critical reviews of Woolf's contemporaries and near-contemporaries, art and drama notices, occasional travel pieces and extended essays on such subjects as character in fiction, the intellectual status of women and the problems of judging contemporary literature. While all are written in Woolf's expansive pictorial style, the later thematic pieces are far more voluble and relaxed than the earlier reviews. Woolf repeatedly argues the case of modernism - archly mocking the older generation for its conventional methods of character development and extolling her own for its interest in the ''dark region of psychology.'' Mr. McNeillie, who has previously edited other volumes by Woolf, is a scrupulous, if somewhat stiff, annotator. In the exacting notes that follow each essay, he has provided sources, publication dates and bibliographical references, as well as brief excerpts from Woolf's diaries and letters. These often prove as illuminating as the essays. Here we not only get Virginia Woolf complaining about an editor's changes or confessing her guilt about disliking a friend's latest novel, but private thoughts on her own work.

title: RUMORS COME TOO OFTEN TRUE
description: LEAD: THE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF THE DEAD By Danilo Kis. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 199 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Knicks and Nets Go Separate Ways
description: It was Alumni Night at Madison Square Garden last night and the Knicks relived the feats some of the stars of their past had recorded.

title: THE NATION: What Is Right and Wrong With Roe v. Wade?; The View From Friends of the Court
description: IN the abortion case it will hear on Wednesday, the Supreme Court could simply consider whether the restrictions in Missouri's law violate the guidelines of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that legalized abortion. But it could also consider, as both the state and the Bush Administration have asked it to do, whether Roe v. Wade should survive at all.

title: Second Test Clears Carlyle
description: Randy Carlyle, a defenseman for Team Canada in the world hockey championships, was found to be free of any banned substances today in a second testing of his urine and was cleared of wrongdoing.

title: Dukakis Workers, in Quest for Jobs, Learn Again the Meaning of Defeat
description: Four months ago Jim Jones - a 1983 graduate of Georgetown University, a former Fulbright scholar in Munich, West Germany, a holder of a master's degree in international relations from Oxford University and an ex-campaign worker for Michael S. Dukakis - began his search for a position as a legislative aide on Capitol Hill.

title: Correction
description: A map last Sunday showing Soviet ethnic tensions misstated the population of a Turkic-speaking people known as Gagauz. They number about 200,000, not 2,000.

title: How the First Round Might Go
description: The first round as projected by Thomas George of The Times. 1 DALLAS COWBOYS Troy Aikman, QB, U.C.L.A. He becomes the Cowboys' quarterback of the present and future. An elusive drop-back passer with excellent field vision who throws with force. 2 GREEN BAY PACKERS Tony Mandarich, OT, Michigan State He is labeled the No. 1 player in the draft, pound for pound. An overpowering lineman with no flaws. 3 DETROIT LIONS Barry Sanders, RB, Oklahoma State He set 18 collegiate records last season and topped 300 rushing yards in a game three times. Finally, after missing Billy Sims for so long, Detroit will have an outstanding tailback and another Heisman Trophy winner. 4 KANSAS CITY CHIEFS Derrick Thomas, LB, Alabama The Chiefs have never used their No. 1 pick to select a linebacker. The Chiefs were last in defending against the run last season. Thomas fits the need and the situation. 5 ATLANTA FALCONS Deion Sanders, CB, Florida State Possibly the fastest man in the draft and a player every team yearns for. He wants to play in Atlanta. 6 TAMPA BAY BUCCANEERS Broderick Thomas, LB, Nebraska Mike Singletary's nephew is solid with upper-body strength and a reckless style as a pass rusher. Tampa Bay, 27th in the league in sacks last season, sorely needs that. 7 PITTSBURGH STEELERS Tim Worley, RB, Georgia Worley is a versatile back. He runs inside with power and can slide outside as a breakaway threat. The Steelers were last in the league in sacks (19) but can't pass Worley. 8 SAN DIEGO CHARGERS Eric Hill, LB, L.S.U. Already a dominant player outside who might become as good inside. Stocky and sure against the run. 9 MIAMI DOLPHINS Louis Oliver, S, Florida Scouts call Oliver ''a bigger, faster David Fulcher,'' referring to the Cincinnati Bengals' splendid strong safety. Simply ''a David Fulcher'' would be nice, thus, the Dolphins are understandably excited about this speedy, aggressive hitter. 10 PHOENIX CARDINALS Sammie Smith, RB, Florida State Some believe his raw athletic ability equals that of Deion Sanders. Smith combines speed and power. There are questions about his intensity; he is worth the risk. 11 CHICAGO BEARS (from the Los Angeles Raiders) Donnell Woolford, CB, Clemson The first of three Chicago first-round picks and a dandy one here. Woolford is a wondrous athlete who excels in man-to-man coverage and returns punts. 12 CHICAGO BEARS (From the Washington Redskins) Burt Grossman, DE, Pittsburgh Grossman is frequently identified this way: He is Margo Adams's brother, he once had a pit bull and alligator for pets and he once boarded a Pittsburgh team plane at 11 A.M. with a six-pack of beer as his luggage. Grossman already sounds like a Bear. Chicago will appreciate his combative style. 13 DENVER BRONCOS Tracy Rocker, DT, Auburn Denver needs defense and gets it from last season's Outland Trophy and Lombardi Award winner. 14 JETS Andre Rison, WR, Michigan State Could wind up playing near a former Michigan State teammate, Mark Ingram of the Giants. Scouts say Rison is better - he has exceptionally quick feet after the catch - and say he is the draft's No. 1 receiver. 15 SEATTLE SEAHAWKS (From the Indianapolis Colts) Brian Williams, C, Minnesota A bulky lineman but quick. He bolsters a soft spot for the Seahawks. 16 NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS Hart Lee Dykes, WR, Oklahoma State Dykes is an imposing target who has good hands and leaping ability. 17 PHOENIX CARDINALS Eric Metcalf, RB, Texas Some believe he is only the eighth-best back in the draft, but Metcalf - son of the former pro Terry Metcalf - is unquestionably the draft's shiftiest and most slashing back. 18 GIANTS Cleveland Gary, FB, Miami Agile for a big back and an excellent receiver. Gary should give the Giants more consistency in their running game. 19 NEW ORLEANS SAINTS Joe Wolf, G, Boston College The Saints need more punch up front and Wolf can play guard or tackle. 20 CLEVELAND BROWNS Derek Hill, WR, Arizona A problem area for the Browns, and Hill is the answer. He has quick feet, great lateral movement and adjusts to the ball. 21 LOS ANGELES RAMS Bill Hawkins, DE, Miami Hawkins has size, speed and quickness and uses all of those attributes. Rams lost Gary Jeter but can draft a gem. 22 INDIANAPOLIS COLTS (From the Philadelphia Eagles) Lawyer Tillman, WR, Auburn Another big-target swift reciever who can be acrobatic in the clutch. 23 HOUSTON OILERS Steve Atwater, S, Arkansas A sleeper pick, but a player with size and instincts and grit, all the credentials needed to play in Oilers' House of Pain. 24 PITTSBURGH STEELERS (From the Minnesota Vikings) Trace Armstrong, DT, Florida A solid pass rusher, and the Steelers want more pressure. Trim yet powerful. 25 CHICAGO BEARS Andy Heck, OT, Notre Dame A pass blocker with an upscale future. Great quickness off the ball. 26 LOS ANGELES RAMS (From the Buffalo Bills) Tom Ricketts, OT, Pittsburgh Ranked behind only Mandarich among linemen, Ricketts blocks for the run and the pass equally well. The Rams' offensive scheme still relies first on linemen like Ricketts. 27 CINCINNATI BENGALS John Roper, LB, Texas A&M A big-play linebacker the Bengals love, Roper is a natural pass rusher. 28 SAN FRANCISCO 49ERS John Ford, WR, Virginia A bona-fide deep threat who goes up for catches with zest. A prime talent.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WOMEN ANALYZE WOMEN: In France, England, and the United States. By Elaine Hoffman Baruch and Lucienne J. Serrano. (New York University, $29.95.) How women are revising the historically male-dominated field of psychoanalysis, and how they are asserting the right to be co-creators of a discipline being radically altered by recent social and technological changes, are the subjects of ''Women Analyze Women.

title: Easy Goer Up to Par In Wood
description: Easy Goer won the $568,000 Wood Memorial Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday with a performance that may not have looked as impressive as his other triumphs but was actually at least as strong.

title: Jonathan Lindsey And Miss Trower Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. W. Peter Trower of Blacksburg, Va., and Mrs. Jean Christophe Schwarzenbach of Pasadena, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Christine Trower to Jonathan Austin Lindsey, a son of Margay L. Lindsey of New York and the late Theodore B. Lindsey. A September wedding is planned. Miss Trower, a graduate of Hollins College, is a marketing officer with Chancellor Capital Management, an institutional investment management concern in New York. Her father, a nuclear physicist on the faculty of Virginia Polytechnic Institute, is a visiting scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley (Calif.) Laboratory. Her mother, Katharine Bache Schwarzenbach, a former headmistress of the Westridge School in Pasadena, expects to receive a master's degree in social work next month from the University of Southern California. She has a Ph.D in medieval literature.

title: EDNA O'BRIEN'S RITUALS
description: If Edna O'Brien practiced any of the major religions, you would be too scared of repercussions to make fun of her observances (''Reveling in Heartbreak,'' by Richard B. Woodward, March 12). But because she has carved out an original, personal faith, you label her ''kooky'' and write of her ''zaniness.'' There is no reason to put quotation marks around the word ''altar'' just because it has been sanctified by an individual rather than an institution. And a belief in astrology is by no means incompatible with being a serious writer or an intelligent person.

title: Bittersweet Return
description: To the Editor:

title: Closing Shoreham Is Half the Job
description: It must be remembered that closing Shoreham is only half the job. Our next task must focus on providing energy for our growing economy.

title: New York, New York - The Game
description: THE RULES OF THE GAME EQUIPMENT. The game is designed for two, three or four players. Each will need a token to move around the board (a coin, bean, old Monopoly man), a pencil and a score pad. Play requires two dice.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The Greatest Fighter Of All Time?
description: It is nearly impossible to compare fighters across weight divisions and generations. But the quality of their opponents is a reasonable criterion to use in evaluating who was the greatest fighter of all time. Using this measurement, Sugar Ray Robinson seems the greatest of the great fighters. Early in his career, he fought such notable opponents as Fritzie Zivic and Jake LaMotta; midcareer he faced Randy Turpin and Bobo Olson. Toward the end of his reign, he defeated Gene Fullmer and Carmen Basilio. Fighters with half of Robinson's skills and toughness have become ring legends, and some with a fraction of his ability are champions in our own time. MICHAEL STEPHENS New York

title: Montefalco, Perched Over Umbria
description: ITS name roughly translates as ''a falcon on its nest,'' and for centuries Montefalco has afforded travelers to Italy the most panoramic view of the Umbria region. Indeed, perched atop a mountain lining Italy's Clitumnus Valley, Montefalco has also been called the Balcony of Umbria. From inside the ramparts of this tiny 14th-century village, one can see for miles - to Perugia and Assisi in the north, Trevi in the east and Spoleto in the south.

title: Point Pleasant Beach Journal; Resort to Compete With Malls by Building Its Own
description: HAVING had its fill of losing shoppers to the malls in nearby communities, this seaside borough will soon open its own downtown mall less than a mile west of the boardwalk.

title: Couples Who are Partners In More Than Just Marriage
description: THEIR friends said it shouldn't be done, but Stacey and Robert Mileti followed their own inclinations. They married, which was not the cause of the warnings, and they started a business together, which was.

title: Lindsay Anne Berry to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold James Berry of New York, Christmas Cove, Me., and Jackson, Wyo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lindsay Anne Berry to Fabian Chen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Chen of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Cold War Isn't Over While the U.S. Can Help It; A Soviet Ruse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanning 200 Years to the Inaugural
description: Two hundred years ago today, George Washington arrived in New York City for his inauguration as the first President of the United States.

title: Praise That Isn't Fulsome
description: Congratulations! At last, I read the word ''fulsome'' used properly (Topics, ''Weird Hair,'' April 9).

title: James Knott, 79, Dies; Led Hotel Corporation
description: James Knott, former chairman of Knott Hotels Corporation, died of bone cancer Friday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: BASEBALL
description: THE CUBS OF '69: Recollections of the Team That Should Have Been. By Rick Talley. (Contemporary Books, $17.95.) The only time I ever played hooky, I skipped school in 1969 to watch the Chicago Cubs play the Cincinnati Reds. It was June, and I sat with the official Bleacher Bums, tormenting Pete Rose. For any self-respecting Chicagoan, Cubs baseball that year was serious business, and the Cubs' collapse in August was devastating. I thought I was over it, though, until I read ''The Cubs of '69'' by Rick Talley. Mr. Talley, a former sports columnist for The Chicago Tribune, has reconstructed that fateful season in all its poignancy - from the team's 7-6 win (in extra innings) against Philadelphia on opening day through the first rumblings of trouble in the clubhouse between the manager, Leo Durocher, and virtually everybody on the team (including ''Mr. Cub,'' Ernie Banks), all the way through to the big choke of August and September. By the time it was over, the Cubs were No. 2, unceremoniously dumped by the Miracle Mets, and a city was in shock. ''It was as if someone in my family was dying a slow death,'' says one traumatized Cub watcher. ''I'd wake up each morning and say, 'They'll win today.' . . . But they didn't.'' Even non-Cub fans will enjoy this lively, heartbreaking tale of a team that embraced defeat; the story includes interviews with members of the ill-fated squad (it is hard to believe that the pitcher Kenny Holtzman now sells insurance) as well as memories from the folks in the front office, and the requisite statistics. But for those of us who grew up hearing Jack Brickhouse broadcast the Cubs' opening lineup on WGN, Rick Talley's affectionate remembrance of the year we almost made it is enough to make a grown woman cry.

title: House Ethics Panel's Low-Key Chief
description: In a decade in Congress, Representative Julian C. Dixon was rarely in the limelight until last week when the House ethics committee he heads announced a series of accusations against House Speaker Jim Wright.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The Greatest Fighter Of All Time?
description: Mickey Walker, the Toy Bulldog, was welterweight and middleweight champion of the world during the 20's.

title: POSTINGS: Buyers v. Developer; Branch at Root of Condo Suit
description: The Corinthian Condominiums at 330 East 38th Street at First Avenue touts itself as one of Manhattan's most stylish apartment houses, its ads stressing its ''beautiful three-quarter-acre entrance plaza'' and ''sumptuous lobby.'' But 350 buyers of the building's 829 units have obtained a temporary restraining order to stop what they view as the developer's tampering with the entrance plaza and lobby. Members of this group, some of whom paid more than $600,000 for their apartments, have complained in a State Supreme Court suit that alterations being made for a branch bank are against their wishes.

title: Reviews/Music; Violin and Balinese Rattles In Counterculture Program
description: Malcolm Goldstein, a violinist and composer who has been active in what might be called counterculture new music for nearly three decades, performed for an audience of 10 (swelled to about twice that number by a group arriving at intermission) at the Penine Hart Gallery in SoHo Friday night.

title: Free Spirits
description: To the Editor:

title: Iowa Blast Inquiry: Long Search Ahead
description: A Navy spokesman said today that a team investigating the explosion that killed 47 sailors aboard the battleship Iowa was focusing on the possibility of either human error or equipment failure as a 16-inch gun was being loaded with 550 pounds of propellant.

title: Miss Steller Wed In Connecticut
description: Eileen Claire Steller, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Steller of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to R. Andrew Holtvedt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Holtvedt of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Gilbert D'Souza performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: There's Been Time To Have It All
description: Sunday morning isn't Sunday morning without The New York Times. The coffee is hot and plentiful, the bagels are warm from the toaster -only light margarine used these days - and the paper is all over the dining-room table. Sections are passed, I tear out articles to savor thoroughly at a later time, and, of course, there is the crossword puzzle. One of the hardest adjustments for my husband to make was sharing the puzzle with me. But, happily, for the last 24 years, the paper has been our Sunday ritual.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; A Cook's Tour for Every Taste That Never Leaves Manhattan
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Adrienne ** (April 1, 1988), 700 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street (212-247-2200) - This elegant and roomy setting in the Peninsula Hotel offers the sunny and aromatic cuisines of the Mediterranean. The expansive prix-fixe buffet ($32.50) changes weekly. It includes cold dishes like lobster with shallots and a salad of artichoke hearts with shrimp. Hot dishes include veal scallops in a garlic cream sauce, chicken breasts with three-peppercorn sauce and roast loin of lamb in a Pommery mustard sauce. An array of French pastries, cakes and tarts provide the finale. Sunday brunch is served from noon to 3 P.M. (dinner from 6 P.M. to 10:30 P.M.). Ambassador Grill * (Oct. 3, 1986), 1 United Nations Plaza, First Avenue at 44th Street (212-355-3400) - The subterranean Ambassador Grill is a serene, urbane restaurant, with its interplay of dark walls, smoky-glass panels and starry lighting. Just to whet the appetite, diners are served a half lobster. Then they move on to the buffet, with its seafood table, salads, turkey, roast beef and ham carved to order, plus chicken, lamb, fish and pasta dishes. There are, as well, hearty choices like eggs Benedict and omelets. The prix-fixe $35 Sunday brunch includes unlimited sparkling wine. Two seatings at 11:30 A.M. and 1:45 P.M. (dinner from 6 P.M. to 10:30 P.M.) Darbar ** (Sept. 5, 1986), 44 West 56th Street (212-432-7227) - With self-assurance and elan, Darbar features the refined Mogul cuisine of northern India. At $11.95, the Sunday brunch buffet is one of the best buys in town. Included are a refreshing salad of cucumber and tomatoes; a restorative potato-yogurt mixture called raita; reshmi kebab, buttery pieces of chicken rubbed with a mix of Indian spices, and chicken and lamb curries. Sunday brunch is served from noon to 3 P.M. (dinner from 5 P.M. to 10 P.M.) Manhattan Island * (Sept. 11, 1987), 482 West 43d Street (212-967-0533) - This hideaway restaurant provides the nearest thing to a tropical island setting, with its glass panels overlooking the swimming pool of the adjoining health club and, in warm weather, umbrella-topped tables outdoors. The new brunch menu includes a choice of scrambled eggs with scallions, Bourbon baked ham and pan fries; rib steak with bearnaise sauce, fried eggs and pan fries; French toast with fresh fruit and sausage or ham, and grits with Cheddar cheese, served with maple-grilled ham and fried eggs. A good buy: the $12 prix-fixe Sunday brunch includes a choice of Bloody Mary or mimosa. Hours: noon to 4 P.M. (dinner from 4 P.M. to 7 P.M.) Petrossian * (Dec. 21, 1984), 182 West 58th Street (212-245-2214) - This pleasure palace in the Alwyn Court strives to feed the soul as well as the body. The Art Deco dining room is a splendiferous work of art or an ostentatious conceit, depending on your viewpoint. Three separate prix-fixe brunches are offered. The $25 brunch includes a glass of Champagne, a Kir royale or a mimosa, followed by a choice of a smoked-trout quiche, French toast or a candied apple crepe with country sausage, bacon or ham. For $30, the choices are chilled vodka, a Bloody Mary or a screwdriver, followed by a plate of 50 grams (about 2 ounces) of Russian salmon roe and 50 grams of Russian pressed caviar, served with three blini and creme fraiche, or a plate of zakouski, assorted smoked fish. For $35, a mimosa or Kir royale is followed by a choice of assorted smoked fish and foie gras, a caviar omelet or scrambled eggs with smoked salmon. Each Sunday brunch includes dessert and coffee or tea. Hours: noon to 3:30 P.M. (dinner from 5:30 P.M. to 11 P.M.) The Polo ** (Sept. 2, 1988), Westbury Hotel, Madison Avenue and 69th Street (212-535-9141 and 212-535-9142) - The Polo is a plush and patrician refuge, with brass sconces, cozy banquettes, leather chairs and waiters in black tie. The restaurant has a serious commitment to fine dining with an American bent. Among the appetizers are ravioli filled with goat cheese and paired with a salad of walnuts and baby lettuces or air-dried loin of lamb with couscous, young sweet peas and grilled Vidalia onions. Popular entrees are grilled marinated breast of chicken with an endive, orange and walnut salad, and a salad of Maine sea scallops with artichokes in a truffle-accented walnut oil. A basket of homemade muffins and biscuits is a bonus. The three-course prix-fixe Sunday brunch is $29.50. Hours: noon to 3 (dinner 5 P.M. to 10 P.M.) WHAT THE STARS MEAN (None) Poor to satisfactory * Good ** Excellent *** Extraordinary These ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction primarily to food, with ambiance and service taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.

title: This Time, Jets Can't Afford to Gamble
description: This is the deadly serious draft for the Jets today, unlikely to produce some of the ''reaches'' that have marked their drafts in recent years.

title: SoHo-ites
