description: THERE ARE TWO SoHos - the one that's been around since the late 1960's, when artists began to move into the empty manufacturing spaces of the 19th-century cast-iron buildings south of Houston Street, and a newer one, dating from the early 80's, filled with chic boutiques and restaurants and people drawn to the art world not from love of art but in order to share vicariously in the presumed glamour of its way of life.

title: Rejuvenating Screens for Spring
description: WITH warm weather comes the rush to reinstall window and door screens. Many homeowners store screens without repairing them, and so cleaning and rejuvenating them is a common springtime ritual.

title: The Singles Business - Fun and Profit
description: THE SECOND-FLOOR offices of People Resources, decorated with Art Deco prints and furnishings in soft earth tones, are a study in comfort; here even the shyest stranger would feel at home. As Mozart symphonies waft soothingly through the corridors, past softly lighted rooms filled with overstuffed sofas and chairs, three fashionably dressed women offer juice and coffee to visitors. The lush trappings are those of an exclusive club, but only the files of this organization are restricted. Tucked away in private rooms, folders and videotapes describing men and women in search of companionship await perusal. Welcome to the singles scene of the 1980's.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The Greatest Fighter Of All Time?
description: When you come to think of it, isn't a little guy beating bigger guys and knocking them out the mark of a great fighter? That is why I cast all my votes for Hammering Henry Armstrong (the first triple champion) as the greatest fighter of all time. MICHAEL A. CORREA Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Despite Law, Police Fail to Report Bias Crimes
description: A STATE law that requires the police to record and classify all crimes motivated by bigotry and bias and to pass the information on to the state police is not being complied with, say two legislators who sponsored the law.

title: Surviving the Pitfalls of House Hunting
description: ANYONE who has tried to house hunt recently knows that it is no longer a simple task. Notwithstanding the prices, which are, by and large, exhorbitant, you need a bevy of people to help you accomplish the task.

title: George Washington Wept Here
description: On a Thursday afternoon 200 years ago today, George Washington came to New York to be sworn in, a week later, as first President of the United States. A Dr. Cogswell wrote that evening that ''from the Battery to the Coffee House, where the General landed, the ships, docks and houses were crowded with people as thick as they could stand.''

title: Westhab Steps In at Mt. Vernon Hotel
description: LEAD: THE county, under increasing criticism for ''warehousing'' its growing homeless population in transient hotels, is experimenting with a new approach with the help of a private, nonprofit corporation that since 1981 has been quietly tackling the housing problem.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Berkeley; It's Newtonian, But With Eggs This Time Around
description: Engineering students at this university, struggling hard against their image as ''grinds'' who spend all their time studying, took time out recently to show the rest of the campus that they know how to have fun.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: ALPHA HOUSE;
Ex-Offenders Find Temporary Sanctuary Before Facing World
description: LEAD: THE image from old movies is familiar: a former prisoner, just released, strides through the big gates, suitcase in hand, boards a bus and debarks in his hometown, ready to begin anew.

title: 'A Homespun Love of All People'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cynthia Levine to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Levine of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Cynthia Levine and Joseph David Kropp, a son of Mrs. Thelma Kropp Taylor of Peabody, Mass., and the late Nathan Kropp. Ms. Levine is the international sales manager for ABC International, a travel and information service company in Boston.Mr. Kropp, who graduated from the University of Rochester and the Suffolk University School of Law, is an associate with the Boston law firm of Bonin & Zalcman.

title: New York, New York/Magazine, Part 2*
description: Special reports on life styles.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: Good gamblers are a cautious bunch. They figure the odds to two or three-decimal places and know the payback to the exact penny. Nothing irks them more than to be paid in spurious or devalued currency - it throws off their calculations. In the mid-1800's gamblers were faced with a slight problem.

title: Jody Dole - Photographer
description: A year ago, Jody Dole was knocking on doors on Madison Avenue, trying to pitch his decidedly noncommercial photographs to advertising executives. Today he is telling many of those executives he is just too busy to work for them.

title: Understanding Marshall McLuhan
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: 3-Day Meeting on L.I.; Preservation Strategies
description: About 300 people dedicated to retaining examples of the architecture of the suburbs will hear tips about new legal and technical strategies when the Preservation League of New York State holds its 16th annual conference for three days starting Friday at Danfords Inn in Port Jefferson, L.I. Those attending - representatives of local governments and foundations, and amateur preservationists - will tour Long Island properties prominent in preservation and landmarking, and attend lectures. A technical preservation tour will visit restored landmarks such as the Thompson House, built in Setauket in 1700.

title: FAST MONEY AND FRAUD
description: ON THE STRETCH OF INTERSTATE 30 THAT LINKS Dallas to Lake Ray Hubbard, about 19 miles away, Dallas County is a work of urbanization still in progress.

title: Q and A
description: Forgiven Late Fee

title: FICTION
description: APES AND ANGELS. By Philip Appleman. (Putnam, $18.95.) American novelists have routinely peeled back the neighborly veneer of small-town life to reveal a raw and nasty underside. In his third novel, ''Apes and Angels,'' Philip Appleman tries with some success to invigorate this familiar taste of rotten apples within mom's pie. Set in fictional Kenton, Ind., just months before Pearl Harbor, it provides a representative sample of citizens. There's upstanding Dr. Roberts; Paul, a teen-ager stumbling toward sexual awareness; and Paul's iconoclastic biology teacher, Elaine, who's passionate about both evolution and the good doctor. The approaching war is the catalyst that drives and connects their lives, registering first, it seems, in the libido. After hearing President Franklin D. Roosevelt's sonorous radio voice warning of ''insane violence'' in ''the most brutal and terrible of all wars,'' Roberts becomes so lustful that he gropes Elaine in the library. She responds by signing on as his mistress. Similarly inflamed, young Paul steals his brother's best girl. But while desire takes hold of some of the inhabitants of Kenton, others are seized by intolerance. Elaine is forced out of school by fundamentalists, at least in part because she is Jewish. Her father, Saul, publishes scandalously radical articles in his newspaper, attacking Kenton's complacency in the face of Nazi atrocities. When the local Klan burns a cross on his lawn, he turns their symbol of hate into a powerful memorial by tacking photos of missing European relatives to the charred remains. Saul's house is firebombed, and the ensuing conflagration ends up consuming most of Main Street. The fire burns away Kenton's innocent facade; from now on, the ''insane violence'' won't be confined to the battlefield. Although this apocalyptic image is apt, its high drama comes as a surprise in a novel that has focused so observantly on the nuances and niceties of small-town social life. From these peculiarly American details, Mr. Appleman draws a disturbing portrait of frustration and bigotry in the heartland.

title: POACHERS IN KENYA KILLING ELEPHANTS
description: During a two-day shooting spree last month, a gang of ivory poachers with semi-automatic weapons butchered nearly 50 elephants on a private ranch and in neighboring Tsavo National Park.

title: Clearing the Air in the Schools
description: THE signs ringing New Jersey's schools that indicate that one is entering a ''drug-free school zone'' proclaim a worthy goal. A bill recently passed the Assembly by a 59-10 vote that would move our schools significantly closer to becoming genuinely drug-free. Of equal importance, the bill controls tobacco smoke pollution in the public schools and abates the health hazard this material causes.

title: PAKISTAN OFFICIALS TELL OF ORDERING AFGHAN REBEL PUSH
description: The assault by Afghan guerrillas on the eastern city of Jalalabad was ordered by Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government at a meeting of civilian and military leaders in Pakistan, and in the presence of the American Ambassador, according to a Pakistani participant and other Pakistani officials.

title: The Caribbean
description: To the Editor: How ironic that Ms. Wade did not mention the country that offers the best medical care in the Caribbean.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Three sides of my house are covered with asbestos shingles. They are in good condition, but we want to put up cedar wood shingles. A contractor recommended putting up furring strips over the asbestos shingles, then nailing the cedar shingles to these. Should the asbestos shingles be removed first?

title: Eurocentrism? We Aren't The World
description: ''Eurocentric'' has become a fighting word in academe - and it's about time. According to a recent front-page story in this newspaper, attempts are being made to teach history and culture in ways that recognize the contributions of non-Europeans. Those attempts are being resisted in some quarters as voguish and ill informed, as make-work projects for minorities, and as a threat to the cultural achievements of the Western European sphere.

title: T. H. Pough Weds Miss Glendinning
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Victoria Jean Glendinning was married yesterday to Tristram Hooper Pough. The Rev. Allan Arthur Hinman and the Rev. Judith Baumer officiated. Barbara Lundy was her sister's matron of honor, and William Schmidt was the best man.

title: Elizabeth Sporer Is Married
description: The marriage of Elizabeth A. Sporer to Douglas D. Moffitt took place yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: A Yankee Fan Is Brushed Back
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Scrabble is almost like an annuity, and Parcheesi is similar.'' John O'Neill, spokesman for Hasbro Inc., on why his company is bidding for the Coleco toy company.

title: With Papandreou in Trouble, Coming Greek Election Could Be a Milestone
description: Like distant thunderheads, electoral passions are building here, feeding on charges of personal scandal and corruption that have overtaken Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and his most prominent aides.

title: Many Students Feel Isolated
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rangers Give New Owners Fast Return on Their Investment
description: When the Texas Rangers shuffled a dozen and a half players onto and off their roster during the winter, they were trying to improve their chances for winning a division championship. Certainly those changes have produced the best start in the Rangers' history, but a change in the nonplaying ranks may be working for them as well.

title: Exxon's Tight Ship
description: To the Editor:

title: When Spiritual Themes Inspire Movement
description: Though dance may be a physical art, choreographers often use bodily movements to express spiritual themes. Paul Taylor has done so in his new ''Speaking in Tongues,'' which his Paul Taylor Dance Company is presenting at the City Center. In Douglas Dunn's ''Sky Eye,'' staged last month by Douglas Dunn and Dancers at St. Marks Church, in the Bowery, people actually spoke in tongues, conveying ecstatic messages with rationally incomprehensible words. Other recently created dances have also concerned spiritual experiences; although all have been choreographically effective, their religious messages are sometimes ambiguous.

title: Night Shift
description: THE SECOND VERSE OF GENESIS informs us that before there was anything else, ''darkness was upon the face of the deep.'' Then God decreed light. By 7,000 B.C., our ancestors had become handy with fire, and night was more than just something to sleep through. By the 17th century, John Milton could ask, ''What hath night to do with sleep?'' (Admittedly, Milton's own answer might have been skewed by the fact he was blind.) But by the early 1880's, when the buildings of one square block in Manhattan had been illuminated with Edison's recent miracle, the answer was clear to everyone: less and less all the time.

title: Brazilian Pop, Uneasy in the Spotlight
description: Suddenly, the music of Brazil is the height of fashion among those in the United States and Europe who pride themselves on setting trends and defining tastes. The album ''Beleza Tropical,'' compiled by David Byrne of Talking Heads, is selling rapidly and getting extensive play in nightclubs and on college radio stations. Joao Gilberto, Gal Costa, Hermeto Pascoal and other Brazilian singers and musicians are touring the United States to an enthusiastic popular and critical response.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Some years ago, a childless career couple with a five-room apartment that on average consumed about $60 worth of gas and electricity a month received a monthly bill for something over $600. The woman went into a state of shock but, as is usual with such missives, the bill was in Friday's mail, so she had the weekend to become increasingly indignant.

title: Rookie's First Hits Put Unlikely Orioles in First
description: Steve Finley came off the disabled list and got his first two major-league hits tonight as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Minnesota Twins, 4-1, and took over sole possession of first place in the American League East.

title: From Liverpool's decay, A New Tate Gallery Rises
description: Like so much else in this once grand, now impoverished port city, the jumble of brick buildings that has stood on the docks of Liverpool since 1846 had virtually collapsed after years of neglect. Condemned to be torn down some 20 years ago, the Albert Dock complex was saved through financial assistance from the British Government after a combination of historic preservationists and private developers argued that the buildings could be restored and made profitable.

title: THE NEW GARY COOPER? YUP
description: LEAD: KEVIN COSTNER IS CONDUCTING an informal tour of the Raleigh Studios, a small, bustling production complex in Hollywood, where he worked as a stagehand for three years in the early 1980's and where he's recently set up shop for his new production company.

title: What's Happened to Middle Class
description: IT SEEMED SIMPLE ENOUGH, ON THE face of it: find, identify and characterize the middle class in the New York metropolitan area. Sort of like stalking gazelles in the Serengeti just before the rains. Just zero in on the middle-class multitudes and pinpoint the epicenter of their middle-class consciousness.

title: LIVING WITH HELLISH DANGERS
description: ACCIDENT/A DAY'S NEWS By Christa Wolf. Translated by Heike Schwarzbauer and Rick Takvorian. 113 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: Correction
description: The board game of ''New York, New York'' today on pages 16 and 17 in part 2 of The Times Magazine appears with an explanatory line omitted. The New York statistics used in the game were up to date on Feb. 3.

title: About Cars; 1989 Avanti Catches Your Eye
description: New York is a tough town, and it is said the denizens are unfriendly.

title: SPENSER ON THE REBOUND
description: PLAYMATES By Robert B. Parker. 222 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95. By R. W. B. Lewis

title: Reviews/Dance; Steve Gross Examines Human Frailties and Foibles
description: How curious life can be. Steve Gross surely realized this when he devised ''Circa Sense,'' the program he presented Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. His dances examined the perplexities of existence, sometimes with humor, at other times with tears or stoicism.

title: Scotch Tape On the Walls?
description: To the Editor:

title: Weekend Fare for North Jury: Favorite TV Tapes
description: The jury deliberating the fate of Oliver L. North worked half a day today before recessing without reaching a verdict.

title: Reviews/Dance; Pooh Kaye Lightens Her Wild-Child Image
description: Pooh Kaye developed the personality of a ''wild child'' early in her career as a postmodernist choreographer and performer. It has been a potent image, and one that informed the dance Ms. Kaye and her Eccentric Motions company presented on Thursday night at the La Mama Annex (66 East Fourth Street), where the program will be performed through tonight as part of La Mama's Spring Dance Festival.

title: Failures Can Be Productive
description: Organizational learning is the ability of a company to gain insight and understanding from experience. It involves experimentation, observation, analysis and willingness to examine both successes and failures - including those of its competitors.

title: Carolyn R. Cantlay Is Bride Of Alden Sherburne Hart Jr.
description: Carolyn Reid Cantlay, the daughter of Lt. Gen. George Gordon Cantlay, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Cantlay of Williamsburg, Va., was married yesterday to Alden Sherburne Hart Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hart of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. The Rev. David Tetrault performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Bruton Parish Church in Colonial Williamsburg.

title: Sports of The Times; Wilson's Attorney Says 'Other' Bengals Involved
description: Until now, Stanley Wilson was presumed to have acted alone. When the Cincinnati Bengals' running back was declared ineligible for Super Bowl XXIII for having violated the National Football League's substance-abuse policy, his cocaine history was dredged up. Since joining the Bengals in 1983 as a rookie out of Oklahoma, he had been in drug rehabilitation five times. And on the night before his biggest game he had been found alone in a haze in his hotel room with evidence of cocaine use.

title:
GARDENING;
Planting Meadows in Place of Lawns
description: LEAD: IN recent years, meadow plantings have become popular. This has resulted partly because they require little maintenance and partly as a way of making an ecological statement. Undoubtedly some have planted them because they like the informal, natural effect.

title: City Tech
description: To the Editor:

title: Lower East Side
description: IN THE BEGINNING, THE BEGINNING OF the East Village, there was, almost, no such place. The East Village consists of Alphabet City (Avenues A through D) and three avenues running west of Alphabet City from 14th Street down to Houston. Alphabet City used to lie under water. Even today, when it rains, all the basements in the landfill section become flooded. Or used to. I don't know how the rich handle their basements.

title: Hundreds of Lebanese Flee to Cyprus by Ferry
description: A ferry carrying hundreds of Lebanese fleeing the nation's strife sailed today for Cyprus as shells rained down on the port of Junieh.

title: The Zest of the Uninteresting
description: John Cage creates lectures the way he composes, and that has created a hubbub that has kept the artistic community in the Boston area astir for months. During the first of his series of Charles Eliot Norton Lectures at Harvard University, in October, over a third of the audience walked out in the middle, and one local professor emeritus who preferred anonymity remarked that ''it was a testimony to the disastrous state of American education that anybody stayed and listened.'' But a respected young composer, Rodney Lister, called the lecture ''the most direct and moving political piece of music I have ever heard.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE SAVINGS AND LOAN RESCUE;
How the Industry Got into Trouble
description: LEAD: At last count, the cost of paying off depositors with funds at insolvent savings and loans now is over $100 billion. For $100 billion, the public should know how it happened, who's responsible, and that it won't happen again.

title: TALKING: Retirement; Trading Down to Live It Up
description: WHEN planning for a retirement income, most people concentrate on such well-known sources as Social Security, an IRA or Keogh plan or a corporate pension program. Rarely do they consider their home.

title: Q and A
description: Jazz at Sea

title: Retiring Harlem Pastor Busy as Usual
description: Before the sparkling chandeliers in the Grand Ballroom were switched on, before the singing and the speeches had begun, before this season's candidates had arrived to pay tribute, some members of the Abyssinian Baptist Church dabbed tears from their eyes.

title: Circus Maximus, British-Style
description: LEAD: At Sheffield, Britain's steel town, a director of the Liverpool team, Tony Ensor, looked at a boy of 9 or 10 lying dead on the field of Hillsborough Stadium and asked himself the question: ''Is football worth the grief it can cause?'' His answer was that he was not sure any more. I am quite sure that, so far as

title: Deborah J. Savin Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Savin of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Deer Valley, Utah, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Joyce Savin, to Steven L. Scoggan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Scoggan of Boulder, Colo. A September wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: PARIS WITHOUT END: On French Art Since World War I. By Jed Perl. (North Point, $19.95.) ''Paris was a place, but also an idea'' is the central theme of the first book by the art critic Jed Perl. Locating the roots of modern art in the merger of the Gallic and Roman temperaments, Mr. Perl writes in ''Paris Without End'' that because Paris is anchored so securely in the past, its artists could provide the styles, images and ideas whose rejection would result in abstract art.

title: Towns Respond to Growing Noise Complaints
description: AS summer approaches, Westchester residents expecting to hear birds singing when they open their windows may be in for an unpleasant surprise. Increasingly, they may hear instead loud radios, lawn-maintenance equipment, barking dogs and noise from motor vehicles or perhaps from construction equipment.

title: Connecticut Suburbanites
description: THE MANHATTAN PREPPIES who invaded Fairfield County, Conn., in the 60's and 70's, who once roamed the grounds of country clubs clad in green slacks emblazoned with orange sea horses and were notorious for a life style characterized by martinis, marital infidelity and Mercedes Benzes, those uninhibited swingers of yesteryear have settled into a staid, rather stultifying middle age. Raucous cocktail parties have virtually disappeared here, replaced by polite gatherings at which white wine and Perrier are the preferred drinks, and the talk is mainly about hemlock blight, cholesterol and the best place to get your BMW serviced.

title: A GOOD OLD BOY IN A BAD OLD WORLD
description: TIME'S WITNESS By Michael Malone. 537 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Chamber of Commerce Building; New Owner for a 1902 Landmark
description: THE old Chamber of Commerce Building at 65 Liberty Street is a little Beaux-Arts treasure dwarfed by later skyscrapers. But the chamber moved out in 1980 and the building has been in use only intermittently. Now a new owner, the International Commercial Bank of China, is ready to buy the building. Although the exterior is landmarked, the sumptuous Great Hall inside is not, and exactly how the magnificent room - 90 by 60 feet and 30 feet high - will emerge, if at all, is not clear.

title: THE NEAREST TO PERFECTION MAN HAS YET ACHIEVED
description: THE PROGRESS OF THE SEASONS Forty Years of Baseball in Our Town. By George V. Higgins. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. SPRING TRAINING By William Zinsser. Illustrated. 197 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: Tape Recorders Bound Ahead
description: A lock-and-key relationship exists between recording tape and the tape recorders for which they are intended. For best results, the magnetic properties of the tape must dovetail with the characteristics of the recorder. That is why, over the years, the development of recorders has gone hand in hand with corresponding changes in the tape itself; and following last week's discussion of advanced tape formulations, we now turn to recent cassette decks capable of using those tapes to full advantage.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Video-Conference Rooms; Building Electronic Bridges for the Working World
description: WHEN the New York partners of Loeb and Loeb, a bi-coastal law firm, sat down for a meeting several weeks ago, a wide-screen television connected them to the other half of their table in Los Angeles.

title: Building a Museum From Scratch
description: LEAD: THE story behind the Museum of American Political Life, set to open next week at the University of Hartford, could be titled ''The Little Museum That Could,'' for it was through perseverance that a comprehensive private collection of Presidential election memorabilia was saved from oblivion.

title: A Subtle Form Of Racism
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FASHION: On the Street; Protective Coloration For City Critters
description: It's true that the sun's been out a lot more lately, but that's not why you're seeing spots before your eyes. No, the reason is the preponderance of leopard- , cheetah- and jaguar-patterned prints. Thus far they've been most often seen on short coats, although trousers - tight-fitting, of course - low-cut evening dresses with matching gloves, blazers, ties, scarfs, hats, shoes, stockings and bags have got in on the action too. As the weather gets warmer, we'll undoubtedly see them on shorts, tank tops and bathing suits.

title: Cold War Isn't Over While the U.S. Can Help It
description: To the Editor:

title: A LIFE IN LIMBO
description: I am the wife of a hemophiliac who died of AIDS. I want to tell Peter Brandon Bayer not to become too discouraged about his romantic situation (''A Life in Limbo,'' April 2) . I married my husband, Victor, after he was diagnosed with AIDS. It is true that we had a pre-existing relationship. However, it is also true that we had a romantic and sexual life after he was diagnosed. We shared many, many kisses, and deeper intimacies (''safe sex''). I admit that the latter made me and my husband anxious, and that the anxiety could not be overcome completely.

title: An Antic, Insubordinate Performer Babel?
description: One of the exhibitions that this critic was most impatient to see in the United States, these last 10 or more years, was a full-scale retrospective of the work of Marcel Broodthaers (1924-76). That any of the major museums in the Northeast would undertake it was always a faint hope. Remington, Wyeth and O'Keeffe were more to their taste. It is to the honor of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, and of Martin Friedman, its director of more than 25 years' standing, that in collaboration with the Palais des Beaux-Arts in Brussels and the Belgian cultural authorities it has produced a Broodthaers retrospective that in many ways is not far from the ideal.

title: Ideologies Explored in ''Our Own Red Blood''
description: AMID the bloodbath in present-day Belfast, one Dr. Grant is attending to a revolutionary leader named Delaney, who has recently had a hernia operation and may be suffering from irregularities of the heart.

title: Ruse Aids in Tracking Suspect in 7 Killings
description: Ramon Salcido, a suspect in seven killings, was tracked by the police through a ruse in which the Wells Fargo Bank was persuaded to extend unlimited credit to him, officials say.

title: A Lesson In Genetics
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cynthia G. Rolen Weds D. L. Furth In Williamsburg
description: Cynthia Gwen Rolen, a daughter of Comdr. L. F. Rolen, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Rolen, of Richmond, was married yesterday to Douglas Layton Furth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Furth of White Plains. The Rev. Charles A. Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated in the Wren Chapel at the College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Va.

title: New Trials Are Set In Pius Slaying
description: LEAD: TEN years ago last Friday, the body of 13-year-old John Pius, the son of a young Western Electric executive and his wife, was found under a log and some leaves behind the Dogwood Elementary School, near the Pius home in an upper-middle-class section of Smithtown.

title: In Buying the Ring, Togetherness
description: On a recent rainy Saturday, one of the many couples drifting in and out of Cartier on Fifth Avenue was John Le Boutillier, who works at an advertising agency, and his fiancee, Suzy Shore, an employee of the New York City government. At Tiffany's the same day, the counters were crowded with couples peering into the cases, many clutching Tiffany's ''How to Buy a Diamond Guide.''

title: Coping Solo in the Cozy Land of Couplespeak
description: I'M single. There. I've said it. The ''S'' word.

title: C.I.A. Funnels Aid to Noriega's Election Foes
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is funneling millions of dollars in aid and assistance to opposition groups that are trying to defeat Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, in elections scheduled for May 7, Government officials said today.

title: SPARE THAT TREE!
description: The thought of Edmund Morris protectively hugging that 60-foot, white pine tree moved me.

title: L.I. Man Held in Strangling Of Co-Worker's Grandmother
description: A Long Island man, arrested in Florida on charges of strangling a co-worker's grandmother, was ordered held without bail here today after his extradition on Friday.

title: A Tough Course on Horseback
description: I WANTED to get back on horseback where I hadn't been much since age 14 - to learn to ride again, this time properly - and I'd go almost anyplace to do so. Anyplace, that is, that would take a middle-aged novice seriously, and anyplace I could afford. A catalogue of equestrian facilities worldwide listed many possibilities at seemingly impossible prices until my eye lit on one small entry: bed, board and riding instruction plus ''visits to places of equestrian interest'' in England for a week or more, at a very modest sum. Who better than the English to sympathize with my irrepressible if unseasonable wish to ride, I asked myself, and what horses would be more civil?

title: Latvian Front Sees Ballot Victory
description: Leaders of the Latvian Popular Front, in a tour of the United States, predict that their new organization will win a large majority in next fall's elections in Latvia.

title: Pageants and Exhibitions Highlight the Celebration
description: These are some of the events scheduled to celebrate the bicentennial of George Washington's inauguration as the first President of the United States. Today

title: Testing the Wind on Wright, Democrats See No Storm Yet
description: Representative Bob Wise was crossing the street back home in Charleston, W. Va., a few days ago when a man stopped his car, rolled down his window and imparted some simple advice about a tangled controversy. ''Get Wright out of there,'' he said.

title: Jailed for Killing His Child, Father Says He Is a Victim
description: Nearly 22 years have passed since seven of James Joseph Richardson's children and stepchildren died painful deaths after eating a lunch of rice and beans laced with pesticide.

title: Patricia K. Weber Becomes a Bride
description: Patricia Kim Weber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Roger Weber of Palisades, N.Y., was married yesterday to Roger Victor Meier, a son of Frederic Meier and Deborah Willen Meier, both of New York. The Rev. Thomas F. Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: U.S. and Soviet Dancers To Perform Together
description: Students from the School of American Ballet in New York City and the Kirov School in Leningrad are to perform together on June 30 at the Amsterdam Musictheater as part of the Holland Festival, an arts celebration that takes place in four Dutch cities.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bradley Beach $175,000 501 LaReine Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old colonial; fireplace, porch, full basement; taxes $2,340. Fair Haven $167,000 443 River Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old Tudor; fireplace, hardwood floors, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,378. Jackson $162,900 26 Vermont Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; central air-conditioning, dining room, pool; taxes $2,696. Wall Township $187,000 1805 Pomerton Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 13-year-old colonial; family room, front porch, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,206. Wayne $182,000 19 Lake Drive West 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 51-year-old colonial; dining room, fireplace in living room, full basement; taxes $2,381. Westfield $300,000 154 Harrison Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 83-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, fireplace, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,928. OTHER AREAS Stafford, Conn. $128,000 8 Burbank Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, wooded yard, 0.66 acre; taxes $1,039. Rye, N.Y. $347,500 83 Elmwood Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 77-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, den, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,777. Lindenhurst, L.I. $152,500 571 South Fifth Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old ranch; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The Greatest Fighter Of All Time?
description: The beautiful synthesis of speed, power and intuition Muhammad Ali displayed in his prime has never been matched. Anyone doubting his toughness and courage need only replay the Thrilla in Manila. Ali transcended sports worldwide as no other athlete, let alone boxer, has done. MIKE GEORGE West Point, N.Y.

title: THE WORLD: Approaching the Limits of Lebanon's Endurance; The Ebb and Flow of Beirut's Agony
description: THE latest fighting in Beirut has been described as the worst yet in the Lebanese civil war. But if that is true, it is only the latest in a succession of ''worst yet'' moments since 1975, when the war began. Here is a look at several of those periods: Autumn 1975: Five months after the war begins, Lebanon is shocked when 50 people are killed in the collapse of an old hotel in downtown Beirut after artillery duels between Muslims and Christians. Daily exchanges destroy the city's commercial center and the first-class seaside hotels. Business shifts away from the Green Line to shops deep within the Muslim and Christian halves of Beirut. Militiamen on each side of the line come to control the streets, and an exodus of civilians begins. But the airport remains open, and schools open and close depending on the fighting. Autumn 1978: Muslim militiamen, who had returned to hideouts when Syrian troops arrived in 1976, take to the streets again as Christians come under Syrian bombardment. As Christians in East Beirut huddle in building basements and stairwells, life is relatively normal in the Muslim sector. Christian gunmen in speeding cars attack Syrian checkpoints. Christian newspapers say 300 people are killed in one day. Summer 1982: After 80,000 Israeli soldiers invade Lebanon to evict Palestine Liberation Organization forces, a daily bombardment by Israelis of Muslim areas from air and sea causes havoc. The Israelis, now in East Beirut, cut off power and water to the Muslim sector to force the P.L.O. to evacuate West Beirut. Eventually, P.L.O. and Syrian forces leave. But in September, hundreds of people are massacred at Sabra and Shatila, Palestinian camps in southern Beirut, by Lebanese Christian militiamen allowed into the camps by Israeli troops. A multinational peacekeeping force of American, Italian and French troops arrives in West Beirut, where Christian units of the Lebanese Army are in charge. The Green Line comes down. Winter 1984: Four months after 241 United States servicemen and 58 French troops are killed in bombing attacks, West Beirut falls to Muslim forces and the multinational contingents leave. The Green Line is re-established, and militias again rule the streets of West Beirut and the southern suburbs. A wave of terror and hostage-taking against Westerners by Shiite fundamentalists follows. Amal, the main Shiite militia, seeks to head off the return of Palestinian guerrillas by attacking Palestinians entrenched in the outskirts of Beirut. But in much of the rest of the city, life goes on uninterrupted. The airport, which is near the worst Palestinian-Shiite fighting, closes for a few days but soon reopens. Winter 1987: After a week of savage street battles between rival Shiite and Druse gunmen leaves 250 people dead, Syrian troops return to West Beirut at the request of local Muslim leaders. The Syrians end the reign of militias on the streets. Life not only returns to normal, but business resumes and a boom unseen in 10 years begins. But the Syrians stay out of the southern suburbs, which by now have become the base for Shiite fundamentalists backed by Iran.

title: Breland Keeps His Title As Foe Quits
description: Mark Breland retained his World Boxing Association welterweight title today when Rafael Pineda of Colombia turned his back to Breland and quit at 1 minute 14 seconds of the fifth round of a scheduled 12-round bout.

title: TENSION REPORTED IN UNITED COCKPITS
description: Nearly four years after a strike led United Airlines to hire hundreds of nonunion pilots, tensions still exist in the cockpit between the new pilots and the union veterans, industry sources and United employees say.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ALHAMBRA DECREE. By David Raphael. (Carmi House, P.O. Box 4796, North Hollywood, Calif. 91607, $18.) Imagine thinking about the Holocaust without the benefit of books, museums, traveling exhibitions, movies, homages to martyrs and intellectual debate. The Spanish expulsion of the Jews nearly 500 years ago, which was comparable in design if not scope to the Nazi exterminations, is not paid similar tribute at annual commemorations, and so ''The Alhambra Decree'' is a welcome contribution to popular Jewish studies.

title: Caramoor Festival Announces Season
description: A concert version of Beethoven's opera ''Leonore,'' Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's Octet for Strings and a staging of the 14th-century French pageant ''Roman de Fauvel'' are among the highlights of the 44th annual Caramoor Music Festival, which will run from June 24 to Aug. 20.

title: The Hughes Story (Shepard Version)
description: WHEN he died, the story of Howard Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, became grist for the tabloid mills.

title:
DINING OUT;
Bistro Food at a Bargain in Piermont
description: LEAD: OPEN only one month, this informal counterpart adjoining and sharing the kitchen of the soigne Xaviar's in Rockland County has already attracted an enthusiastic neighborhood clientele. It comes for refined bistro food at prices that are a bargain, considering the quality of the ingredients and the skills of the chef and owner, Peter Xaviar Kelly.

title: Where Classic French Desserts Abound
description: I HAD to order the gateau St.-Honore at L'Endroit restaurant in East Hills. It was here a decade ago that I first encountered this sweet extravaganza of layered cake, creamy rich chocolate mousse, dense chocolate cake and whipped cream encircled with miniature cream puffs glazed with chocolate and filled with more mousse.

title: NONFICTION
description: LIVES ON THE BOUNDARY: The Struggles and Achievements of America's Underprepared. By Mike Rose. (Free Press, $22.95.) Mike Rose's book tears apart all of society's prejudices about the academic abilities of the underprivileged. The associate director of writing programs at the University of California, Los Angeles, he has a rare ability to see and nurture the academic talents of his students and to correct their errors by understanding why they make them. Unlike some educators who preach about the challenge of reaching the disadvantaged, Mr. Rose has been there. The son of poor Italian immigrants, he was rescued by astute teachers, but not before he had spent time in vocational education courses, where he learned what it is like to be labeled dumb. He struggled when he went to college because he did not have the training or the context to make sense of the books he was required to read. ''I was the human incarnation of language-recognition computer programs: able to record the dictionary meanings of individual words but unable to generate any meaning out of them,'' Mr. Rose writes. Eventually, Mr. Rose decided to devote his life to helping other disadvantaged students learn the language and the codes of academic achievement. He rails against stereotypes that cast these students as unable to learn. In a series of vividly written vignettes, he describes how he has taught inner-city public school pupils, Vietnam veterans, adult literacy students and poorly prepared college students who were admitted under special circumstances to boost minority enrollment. His message, he says, is that because the least noticed students often are much more capable than educators ever know, ''what we see and hear is, simultaneously, cause for anger and cause for great hope.''

title: Dr. Van de Berghe Engaged to Wed Dr. M. J. Brennan
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Van de Berghe of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Mary Elizabeth Van de Berghe, to Dr. Michael Joseph Brennan, a son of Dr. Joseph R. Brennan Jr. of Breezy Point, Queens, and the late Frances Murphy Brennan. A July wedding is planned.

title: THE NATION: Challenging Atlanta; The South Has Its Second Cities, And They Thrive
description: A DECADE ago, an attempt by a bank in Charlotte, N.C., to take over a big Atlanta institution would have had the appearance of a mouse attacking a lion.

title: Reviews/Music; Electronic Homage To John Cage
description: Thirty years ago, when David Tudor was a young pianist making his reputation as a performer of avant-garde music, John Cage was one of the composers he championed. Later, when he abandoned the piano to compose for electronic instruments, he collaborated frequently with Mr. Cage.

title: Walter H. Sonnenfeldt Plans to Marry Deborah R. Rapin, a Teacher, in June
description: Mrs. Alden A. Rapin of Ogdensburg, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Deborah Rose Rapin to Walter Herman Sonnenfeldt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Helmut Sonnenfeldt of Chevy Chase, Md. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Speed of Sound: A Matter of Fact
description: In Robert P. Levine's essay ''When the Ballpark Cost Just a Nickel'' [ Westchester Opinion, March 26 ] , he states, in an otherwise well-written piece, that he thinks sound at sea level travels 550 feet a second. Of course, he does parenthesize his very inaccurate thought. If he has forgotten what he should have learned in his high school ''physics'' class and doesn't have sufficient reference volumes in his personal book collection, he at least could have made a trip to his local library.

title:
GARDENING;
Planting Meadows in Place of Lawns
description: LEAD: IN recent years, meadow plantings have become popular. This has resulted partly because they require little maintenance and partly as a way of making an ecological statement. Undoubtedly some have planted them because they like the informal, natural effect.

title: John Hurt Zeroes In on Another Outsider
description: John Hurt is an actor who specializes in playing outsiders. He achieved national fame in Britain playing a blue-rinsed sexual outsider, Quentin Crisp, in ''The Naked Civil Servant'' on television. One of his first starring roles in the cinema was as the inarticulate Timothy Evans, hanged for a murder he did not commit, in ''10 Rillington Place.'' Since then he has played the grotesquely deformed hero of David Lynch's ''Elephant Man'' and the stubbornly nonconformist Winston Smith in Michael Radford's version of ''1984.''

title: Incorporation Blues In Pine Valley
description: In response to an article March 19 (''Pine Valley Sings Incorporation Blues''), what is the message that we should really be hearing?

title: The Life Style of the East Side 5-Year Old
description: This is the story of a boy and a girl who live and work and play on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. It is based on the lives of several 5-year-olds who took time out of their busy schedules to talk about their days and their dreams.

title: AT VIDEO SUPERMARKETS WIDER CHOICE, BETTER SERVICE
description: In an industry dominated by mom-and-pop entrepreneurs, the executive team at the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation stands out. Wayne Huizenga, its chairman, is among the founders of Waste Management Inc., a $3.6 billion waste disposal company. Since purchasing the Fort Lauderdale, Fla.-based video retailing chain in 1987, he has hired several seasoned franchising executives. Luigi Salvaneschi, the company's president, is a 25-year veteran and former vice president of the McDonald's Corporation, and Thomas Gruber was the international marketing vice president of the burger chain before joining Blockbuster as marketing chief.

title: Words for Rushdie
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GRINGA. By Sandra Scofield. (Permanent Press, $19.95.) Abilene Painter, the 25-year-old American mistress of the renowned bullfighter Antonio Velez, has lived in Mexico for five years, yet whenever she is asked what she is doing there she responds that she is a tourist. Indeed, Abilene is more of a spectator than a participant in her life.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Store Wars: Showdown in the Discount Aisles
description: LEAD: IN the spring, a man's fancy may turn to thoughts of love. A woman's turns to Loehmann's. Or Saks. Or hundreds of other clothing stores.

title: 'Us' and 'Them' in Poland
description: In principle, Poland has made an enormous breakthrough, away from the failed system of Communist monopoly and toward ''civil society,'' which is how people here name functioning democracy because the authorities abused the usual word so much for so long.

title: Miss Barrett, Nurse, Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary's in Manhasset, L.I., Deirdre Ann Barrett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Barrett of Manhasset and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Donald G. Denihan, a son of Irene Denihan of Manhasset and the late Benjamin J. Denihan. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Lawrence Costello. Susan Veronica Barrett, a sister of the bride, was the maid of honor. Laurence Denihan was his brother's best man.

title: Shelagh Taber and Colin Walsh Marry
description: Shelagh Kathleen Taber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. Taber of New York, and Colin James Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Walsh of Dundonald, Northern Ireland, were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony.

title: In the Bout for Shelf Space, It's a K.O. for the Big Stuidos
description: It is no mystery why the 16 largest video suppliers released 52 percent more titles last year than in 1987. For the movie industry, video distribution has become more lucrative than the theater box office. While theaters yielded $1.9 billion for movie producers last year, videos generated $3.5 billion for distributors, according to Cambridge Associates.

title: Seeking a Job In Midlife
description: Stephen Cuce's lament on his unsuccessful job search (''Help Wanted, but Certainly Not Today,'' Opinion page, April 2) has a familiar sound - especially to this career planner.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Earth's Near Miss; Scientists Try to Handicap The Odds of a Great Celestial Smashup
description: MARCH 23 was a comparatively quiet day on planet Earth. Important events occurred, but nothing cataclysmic. The Afghan Government suffered a small setback in its war with the Muslim guerrillas; Congress and the White House reached a tentative agreement to aid the Nicaraguan contras, while Fawn Hall testified in Federal District Court on behalf of her former boss, Oliver L. North.

title: Opponents Fault Koch on City Maintenance
description: Three candidates who are challenging Mayor Edward I. Koch's bid for a fourth term yesterday assailed his administration's record on maintaining bridges and roads and in building housing, schools and other public works projects.

title: Miss Behrens Wed in Mexico
description: Erica Carolyn Behrens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Meredith Behrens of Westfield, N.J., and West Chatham, Mass., was married at Christ Church in Mexico City yesterday to William Gerard Van Horn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lewis Van Horn of Brick, N.J.

title: Hands-On Lesson for Little Green Thumbs
description: JARBARI SHARIF peeked over the shoulder of another kindergarten pupil, David Marquette, and scolded, ''Hey, you're digging too deep!'' Across the courtyard, Karrie Hucson waved a trowel in the air and shouted, ''Look what I found - an earthworm!''

title: Elizabeth Mason Plans Wedding
description: A September wedding is planned by Mary Elizabeth Mason and Robert John Hay Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Hay of Portsmouth, R.I. The engagement was announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Stayton Mason Jr. of Roslyn Estates, L.I.

title: Capturing the Fire of Flamenco
description: LEAD: WHEN Loretta Maria Annonio was an art history student at the State University at Stony Brook, a date took the young woman from Smithtown to the Chateau Madrid, a Manhattan nightclub. That was in 1971, and things haven't been the same since. Appearing at the club that night was Jose Greco, the Spanish dancer.

title: BASEBALL
description: YOGI: It Ain't Over . . . By Yogi Berra with Tom Horton. (McGraw-Hill, $18.95.) Lawrence Peter Berra has graced major league baseball since the 1940's. He played on 10 world championship teams and managed two other teams to pennants. He is in the Hall of Fame. At 63 Yogi Berra is currently a coach for the Houston Astros. No small accomplishments. He also survived the Normandy invasion and George Steinbrenner. Once again, no small accomplishments. These achievements are recollected by Mr. Berra and his collaborator, Tom Horton, a publisher and friend of long standing, in ''Yogi.'' Other voices are heard in this work, belonging to friends, teammates and opponents who tell tales about the legendary Berra. The book is a trove of Yogi-isms old and new. On a visit to Gracie Mansion, the wife of former Mayor John Lindsay greeted him by saying, ''You look nice and cool, Yogi.'' Mr. Berra responded, ''You don't look so hot yourself.'' After praising a performance of ''Tosca'' at La Scala, Mr. Berra added, ''Even the music was nice.'' His own favorite aphorism is, ''If the world were perfect, it wouldn't be.'' Mr. Berra has been bashed by teammates and the press throughout his career for his unintentional butchering of English. In ''Yogi'' he answers his accusers: ''I know that I do say funny things sometimes, and now that other people get paid to tell stories about me I should keep it up.'' The strengths of this book are Mr. Berra's insights, which, if not deep, can be illuminating. ''I think some of the uniforms are so tight that the base runners can see the pitcher's buttocks tighten when he is going to try to pick them off. You could not tell when Whitey Ford was going to go to first by watching his butt.'' On his former boss George Steinbrenner's treatment of people: ''It was not the way to make your mother proud.'' Mr. Berra's observations go beyond the baseball diamond and its personalities. On the Nobel Prize-winning economist Milton Friedman: ''The books Friedman reads and writes are full of math, and I am not talking ERAs.'' On higher education: ''I think I might have liked some college work. I am not talking about music appreciation because I could always appreciate music.'' ''Yogi'' is a warm, funny and honest memoir. The Yankees' broadcaster Phil Rizzuto has said, ''If you don't love Yogi, you have to like him.'' The same can be said about this book.

title: A Building With the Razzle but Not the Dazzle
description: Like any artist who produces a work of utter brilliance, an architect who designs a truly great building is forever after constrained by it. Not only in the obvious way - does what comes along later measure up to the triumph? - but in a more subtle way, too, in the expectation that all future work will somehow continue to explore the same themes as the great achievement.

title: Kristin West Wed To Michael Sant
description: Kristin D. West, an associate at the Eli Broad Family Foundation in Santa Monica, Calif., and Michael J. Sant, an architect at Barton Myers Associates in Los Angeles, were married yesterday. The nondenominational ceremony was performed in the Radio City Suite of the RCA Building by the Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, the chaplain of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Closing Loopholes to Save Neighborhoods
description: THE view from the back door of Pamela Keating's one-family home on 157th Street in Flushing, Queens, is of a big hole where two other single-family houses once stood. They were torn down last winter, and what will soon rise from the hole is a brick block of a building containing eight apartments.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: NOT THAT YOU ASKED . . . By Andrew A. Rooney. (Random House, $15.95.) Andy Rooney, the syndicated columnist and commentator on the television program ''60 Minutes,'' claims that he hasn't changed his mind about anything since he was 23. Given the mundane realm he focuses on, that's probably true.

title: Giants Want Runners and Blockers
description: The Giants have the makings of a winning team, yet they are not good enough to become a Super Bowl team again simply by filling one or two gaps. They have many holdover offensive linemen and running backs, yet those positions appear to be their two priorities in the National Football League draft today and tomorrow.

title: Tomorrow's Orators Compete in Scarsdale
description: JED SILVERSTEIN has observed a lot about relatives. The way you have to kiss them hello on their stubbly cheeks. The way they make you sit down to talk when you are about to do something important.

title: Day-Care Center Comforts Children With AIDS
description: LEAD: THE 3-year-old sat giggling in her highchair, pretty and feminine in yellow taffeta, matching ribbons in her black hair. Then the vision changed. A visitor spotted the stick-thin legs dangling motionless beneath her - legs, adorned by white tights and Mary Janes, that have never walked or crawled.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 19 about United States companies in South Korea misstated the circumstances surrounding a strike by employees of I.B.M. Korea. Weeks of checking have established that the strike occurred several months after I.B.M. Korea recognized a union. The strike ended when both parties signed a basic agreement, which included a reiteration of I.B.M.'s recognition of the union.

title: Giamatti's Request
description: The commissioner of baseball, A. Bartlett Giamatti, has asked a federal judge to consider Ronald Peters's cooperation in the Pete Rose investigation when Peters is sentenced on cocaine trafficking and tax evasion charges, according to The Dayton (Ohio) Daily News.

title: Principal Bars Student's Exhibit of Fetuses
description: A principal has prevented a seventh-grader from displaying her anti-abortion science project, which consists of 10 jars of human fetuses.

title: Bedtime Stories for Library 'Read-In'
description: LEAD: SLEEP overnight in the school library! The very idea was ''neat'' and ''kind of strange,'' according to 13-year-old Francis Cocozza, who did just that at an overnight ''read-in'' held recently at the Blue Mountain Middle School in Cortlandt.

title: THE REGION: New York Experiment; For Taxpayers, A Collective Role As Fat Cat
description: IF public financing of election campaigns can make it in New York, New York, it can make it anywhere. That is what its advocates are saying about this year's mayoral and other New York City races, one of the nation's big tests of taxpayer-supported municipal campaigns.

title: SPARE THAT TREE!
description: I'm hoping that Edmund Morris (About Men: ''Mr. Woodcutter, Spare That Tree!'' March 5) will take a look at a 1946 movie, ''Three Wise Fools,'' starring Margaret O'Brien, Lewis Stone, Lionel Barrymore and Thomas Mitchell.

title: Lisa Frank and Maureen Fullam - Trompe L'oeil Artists
description: Does Donald Trump like trompe l'oeil? The question arose when Lisa Frank and Maureen Fullam were bidding on a decorative painting job for an interior court of the Plaza hotel. Part of their proposal was to paint a shimmering blue-green rectangle on the roof of the grand ballroom so that guests at the hotel, looking down from their rooms, would think of a swimming pool.

title: Canal Commission Tightens Rules On Development
description: FOR more than 150 years after the creation of the Delaware and Raritan Canal in 1830, the scenery along the 60-mile route changed little. Small settlements like Griggstown, Raven Rock and Kingston cropped up along the route, but they were little more than crossroads separated by miles of farmland and uninhabited natural areas.

title: Solo in the City
description: A FRIEND OF MINE, A MARRIED man with a child, looked into my refrigerator and emerged envious.

title: On Campus, Gospel and New Compositions
description: THERE will be many worthy events vying for attention and attendance in the next week.

title: Bogus Research Shows Experts to Be Embarrassingly Human
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy, 12, Charged in Shotgun Death of Guest
description: State police said yesterday that they were investigating the death of a 12-year-old Orange County boy who was killed by a shotgun fired by another 12-year-old boy.

title: For Her, 'Dance in America' Is More Than a Waltz
description: The poised serenity of Frederick Ashton's 1965 ballet ''Monotones II,'' set to one of Erik Satie's ''Gymnopedies,'' is the first of three works that comprise the latest ''Dance in America'' program, entitled ''A Night at the Joffrey.''

title: STIFFED BY HOLLYWOOD
description: CITIZEN WELLES A Biography of Orson Welles. By Frank Brady. Illustrated. 655 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.

title: Yonkers Office Woos Developers To Build Mixed-Income Housing
description: LEAD: FOR nine months, efforts have been under way in Yonkers to attract private developers to build 800 units of low- and moderate-income housing as part of a court-ordered integration plan.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Andrew Gaze, a starter for National Collegiate Athletic Association runner-up Seton Hall this year, scored 36 points and handed out 10 assists Friday night in his return to his Australian club team. The Melbourne Tigers, coached by Gaze's father, beat the Hobart Devils, 115-98, in the opening game of the Australian National Basketball League. . . . Sean Elliott, the college basketball player of the year, and his Arizona teammate, Anthony Cook, escaped with minor injuries when the car Cook was test-driving flipped over and landed on its roof, a Pima County sheriff's spokesman said Friday in Tucson, Ariz. (AP)

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TRUCK DANCE. By Olive Hershey. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) The road novel has an honorable place in the American literary tradition, and with her first novel, ''Truck Dance,'' the poet Olive Hershey adds another to the canon - but with a new twist. Her traveler is a woman, a big girl with red hair from Little Egypt, Tex., who in her heyday could down a pintail duck with a Browning 12 at 50 feet.

title: Self-Help for Older Women
description: LEAD: TWELVE women in Bergen County are the first volunteers to graduate from the Older Women's Health Project. The program, instead of simply giving advice on how to cope with physical, emotional and social problems, uses the strengths and resources of participants in a self-help approach that gives older women more personal confidence and control of their lives.

title: Practical Traveler; Travel Agents' Choices for Women on Their Own
description: IF you are a single woman at least in your 40's, with some vacation time and some money to spend, what is out there in the way of fun, active and intellectually stimulating travel? Another requirement - it can't involve being locked in with a tour group or eating by yourself in a hotel dining room night after night.

title: Seeking a Job In Midlife
description: In response to Stephen Cuce's article, I offer the following.

title: The Scramble for Eligible Entries
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC TO THE EYES
description: To live in Salzburg, Austria, and go to work each morning in the Mozarteum International Foundation would seem the closest thing to heaven for lovers of Mozart. Rudolph Angermuller lives such a life as librarian and chief of the research department of the foundation. He shares details of the composer's operas from the wealth of archives at his fingertips in MOZART'S OPERAS (Rizzoli, $65), an oversized, beautifully illustrated book. Mr. Angermuller is firmly rooted in earthly academics and dry writing, but his hosannas to Mozart's genius are evident in his persistent dedication to the facts of the 22 operas documented. In chronological order, Mr. Angermuller explains why and how Mozart became involved in each opera, beginning at age 11 with a ''sacred Singspiel'' (a sort of chamber oratorio) and continuing through ''La Clemenza di Tito,'' completed shortly before his death at 35. For each opera, Mr. Angermuller not only discusses Mozart's music but provides the names of the librettist, a synopsis of the plot, names of principal performers, production problems and audience reaction to the first performance. He augments the text with sketches of the first productions' stage sets and costumes and with color pictures of the sets for 20th-century revivals. Mozart scholars, who will certainly be familiar with most of Mr. Angermuller's text (ably translated by Stewart Spencer), may take issue with his calling Ignatz Anton von Weiser, not Jakob Anton Wimmer, the librettist of Mozart's Singspiel of 1767 and listing ''Bastien and Bastienne'' before ''La Finta Semplice'' when the usual chronology is the other way around. Music students should have this pricey book for its analysis of Mozart's composing. General readers should benefit most from the detailed history of Mozart's magnificent work for the musical theater. If nothing else, the words should propel readers to hear the music on record or to see and hear the operas in performance, and that is precisely what a well-written music book should do.

title: BASEBALL
description: CRASH: The Life and Times of Dick Allen. By Dick Allen and Tim Whitaker. (Ticknor & Fields, $17.95.) For 15 years Dick (''Don't call me Richie'') Allen was baseball's bad boy. His ''attitude'' earned him the enmity of Philadelphia fans who eventually took to peppering him with dangerous projectiles. In defense, Mr. Allen wore a batting helmet in the field, which led to the nickname Crash. But as controversial as Mr. Allen was, he was also one terrific baseball player. In a career that took him to the Phillies, the St. Louis Cardinals, the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Chicago White Sox and ended with a cup of coffee with the Oakland A's, Mr. Allen was named rookie of the year in 1964 and the American League most valuable player in 1972. He played on six all-star teams, hit 351 home runs and had a career batting average of .292. Lesser accomplishments have earned players a spot in the Hall of Fame. Now, with the help of Tim Whitaker, an editor at PhillySport magazine, Mr. Allen relates a lively, riveting account of a baseball rebel who happened to be able to hit a ball out of the park with startling regularity. Mr. Allen was a lot of things, but boring was not one of them. He drank - sometimes to excess; he had extramarital affairs; and he occasionally got into fights with his teammates. That's the Dick Allen most people knew. But here, discussing his life with remarkable candor and insight, he comes across as thoughtful, articulate, sensitive, headstrong and misunderstood (''I'd been hearing I was a bum for so long that I began to think maybe that's just what I was''). Also, being enormously talented and black in a game run by white owners, executives and managers didn't make life any easier for him. But when all was said and done, Dick Allen loved the game of baseball, a game, he maintains, that he did not quit on but that quit on him.

title: Mary Finn Weds Daniel Chambers
description: Mary Catherine Finn, the daughter of Mrs. Peter Joseph Piccirillo of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Paul Joseph Finn of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel James Chambers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund James Chambers of Florham Park, N.J. The Rev. Benet Caffrey performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Mary's Abbey Church at the Delbarton School in Morristown, N.J.

title: Saving Lighthouses From Erosion
description: LEAD: SINCE 1797, when Long Island's first lighthouse was built at Montauk Point, the 12 tall beacons encircling the island pointed the way to safety for countless vessels.

title: 2 More Youths Held in Attacks In Central Park
description: Two more teen-agers were arrested yesterday in the series of attacks in Central Park last week. One was accused in the gang rape of a female jogger, who remained in a coma, and the other in an assault on a homeless man, the police said.

title: The Caribbean
description: To the Editor: My recent experience confirms the information in ''Getting Medical Aid in the Caribbean'' by Betsy Wade (Practical Traveler, Feb. 19). She reported that Margaret Zellers, author of ''Fielding's Caribbean,'' awards a star for good medical facilities to only four places in the area: Barbados, the Cayman Islands, Jamaica and Puerto Rico.

title: Managing the Race for County Executive
description: LEAD: BOTH campaign managers in the coming race for County Executive entered politics when they were 14 years old. Both predict victory for their candidates. After that, the similarities trail off.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Three sides of my house are covered with asbestos shingles. They are in good condition, but we want to put up cedar wood shingles. A contractor recommended putting up furring strips over the asbestos shingles, then nailing the cedar shingles to these. Should the asbestos shingles be removed first?

title: WE WERE DISINFORMED
description: DESTRUCTIVE GENERATION Second Thoughts About the Sixties. By Peter Collier and David Horowitz. 352 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: Amanda Werth Is Married
description: Amanda Joanne Werth and Joel Philip Streich, an assistant vice president and vice president respectively of J. P. Morgan & Company in Frankfurt, were married yesterday at the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Russell W. Annich officiated. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Werth of Princeton, graduated from Columbia University. She and her husband, a graduate of the General Motors Institute, both received M.B.A. degrees from Harvard University. Mr. Streich is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Robert Streich of Flint, Mich.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Portland, Ore.
description: Sprouting from the banks of the Willamette River, between the beaches of the Pacific Ocean and the year-round ski slopes of Mount Hood, the traditionally outdoorsy city of Portland, Ore., has evolved into one of the Pacific Northwest's most progressive urban centers.

title: ERIC PACKS IT IN
description: LEAD: THE DREAMERS By Brian Hall. 289 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Suburban Theme in Westport Series
description: THE Theater Artists Workshop of Westport was in a slump. ''We needed to stimulate work, to get people up there,'' said Dorothy Bryce, an actress and charter member of the six-year-old organization whose 150 participants make up a veritable who's who of the Fairfield County theater world.

title: President Bush's Hundred Days; Seen Against Ronald Reagan's 2,922 Days
description: George Bush reaches his hundredth day in office Saturday and already the pundits ask: George, what happened to what you call ''the vision thing''? There's no agenda, complains one political scientist. No clear goals and convictions, writes another; the President drifts while Mikhail Gorbachev catches the wind. By their lights, it has been a bumbling baptism.

title: Global Co-ops?
description: To the Editor:

title: Marrying Overseas: 'I Do' in Greece
description: WHEN my significant other and I decided to get married, we wanted what all engaged couples want - a wedding to remember. But our dreams had nothing to do with posh country clubs, phalanxes of attendants and a satin and lace cathedral train. We longed for an incomparable setting, which for us meant the Greek island of Santorini.

title: ANATOMY OF A SITCOM
description: In ''Anatomy of a Sitcom,'' April 2), Linda Blandford has overlooked a crucial factor in the success of NBC's ''Dear John.'' Yes, the show ''hovers between 10th and 14th place and a 20 percent to 25 percent share of the audience'' every week. Sure, it's one of the three hits of the new television season. But is all that true because the show is of such high quality?

title: For Farmers in Spring, Corn's Promise Is Eternal
description: After a summer of drought, a winter of rising costs and a spring of meager rain, farmers here have plenty of reasons to grumble. But as they climb aboard their tractors and roll out to their fields these days, the mood is generally upbeat.

title: Peter C. Thomes Wed at Andover To Katy Cranton
description: At the Cochran Chapel at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., Kathleen Ann Cranton was married yesterday to Peter Carlisle Thomes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell F. Thomes Jr. of New York and Southold, L.I. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman W. Cranton of Groveland, Mass. The Rev. Philip Zaeder, the Protestant chaplain at the academy, officiated.

title: THATCHER PUTS THE LID ON
description: It seems queer that James Atlas's otherwise fine discussion of censorship in Great Britain under Mrs. Thatcher's Government omits any mention of the notorious Clause 28 (''Thatcher Puts the Lid On,'' March 5).

title: SHE WAS A DESERT CAVALIER
description: ISABELLE The Life of Isabelle Eberhardt. By Annette Kobak. Illustrated. 258 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: DON'T BE CRUEL OR REASONABLE
description: CONTINGENCY, IRONY, AND SOLIDARITY By Richard Rorty. 201 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $34.50. Paper, $10.95.

title: The Hidden Suburbia: Despite Problems, the Spirit Survives
description: THE picture of suburbia is a familiar one. There's the comfortable house on the tree-lined street inhabited by an attractive couple and their lovely children. We know without being told that there are two cars in the garage, toys for both adults and children, little luxuries to make the easy life even easier. Typical of life in the burbs, right? Wrong.

title: Martyrs?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORLD: Hardship Ahead; Poland Can Exercise Political Will, But There's No Way Out of Austerity
description: NOW that Poland's economic crisis has led the Government to seek accommodation with the Solidarity trade union, attention has again turned to how to bolster the economy over the long haul. But a political settlement has proved easier to reach than an agreement on how to pull the country out of its economic straits, and neither side has been able to commit itself to the painful steps that will be necessary to turn things around.

title: Frederick Ost Marries Carol B. Brown
description: Carol Beth Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur Brown of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to Frederick Preuss Ost, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Ost Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N.J. by the Rev. Riley Jensen.

title: A Leader in AIDS Care
description: LEAD: IN 1982, Dr. James Oleske of Children's Hospital, a unit of the United Hospitals Medical Center, was puzzled by the death of several children from unexplained infections. A breakthrough came when he established a link between a bisexual man diagnosed with AIDS and a girl who had died of an unusual pneumonia six months earlier.

title: New Allegations Arise Against Ex-Syracuse Mayor
description: A fellow inmate has raised new allegations against the former Mayor of Syracuse, Lee Alexander, in a continuing corruption investigation that has resulted in a prison term for the ex-Mayor and convictions of nine co-conspirators.

title: THE BEST TYPE OF MAN
description: HERMANN ZAPF AND HIS DESIGN PHILOSOPHY Selected Articles and Lectures on Calligraphy and Contemporary Developments in Type Design, With Illustrations and Bibliographical Notes, and a Complete List of His Typefaces. By Hermann Zapf. 254 pp. New Haven: Society of Typographic Arts/ Yale University Press. $60.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The Greatest Fighter Of All Time?
description: The greatest fighter of all time? Dave Schultz. I'd like to see Muhammad Ali box while on skates. MICHAEL SMOLENS Great Neck, L.I.

title: Blues Beaten, 5-2
description: Denis Savard scored twice as the Chicago Blackhawks continued their playoff revival with a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues in Game 3 of the Norris Division final tonight.

title: It Was a Mistake To Let King Go
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THATCHER PUTS THE LID ON
description: James Atlas's article about censorship in Britain illustrates the essential difference between enlightened Western democracies and some of the more backward countries of the Middle East. While the Ayatollah Khomeini wants authors he doesn't like killed, Prime Minister Thatcher merely wants to put authors that she doesn't like in jail. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D. Lexington, Ky.

title: Soccer Resumes, Sadly
description: Exactly a week after Europe's worst sports disaster, British League soccer resumed today with a nationwide expression of grief for the 95 fans crushed to death at Hillsborough Stadium in Sheffield. More than 500,000 fans from Brechin in Scotland to Plymouth in the English southwest, a distance of 700 miles, observed a minute of silence before the first full soccer program since the Football Association Cup semifinal between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest last Saturday.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Stratford, Conn. $208,000 260 Ferndale Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old contemporary; passive solar heat in family room, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,825. Stafford, Conn. $128,000 8 Burbank Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, wooded yard, 0.67 acre; taxes $1,039. Windsor Locks, Conn. $138,000 17 Fairview 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old brick ranch; fenced-in yard, 100- by 270-foot lot; taxes $848. Harrison, N.Y. $890,000 1 Muchmore Road 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, late 19th-century colonial farmhouse; 5,000 square feet, 2 fireplaces, sun room, terrace, pool w/terrace, 1.3 acres; taxes $10,502. Ossining, N.Y. $297,500 51 Larch Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, new kitchen w/skylight, garage; taxes $3,630. Rye, N.Y. $347,500 83 Elmwood Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 77-year-old colonial; den, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,777. OTHER AREAS Hempstead, L.I. $114,000 111 Henry Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; family room, basement; taxes $1,800. Glen Cove, L.I. $340,000 894 Glen Cove Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new high ranch; family room, fireplace, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,000. Jackson, N.J. $162,900 26 Vermont Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; pool, c/a, dining room; taxes $2,696.

title: Frederick Olivari Marries Kathleen M. Flahive
description: Kathleen Marie Flahive, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Flahive of Yardley, Pa., was married yesterday to Frederick Corrado Olivari, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Olivari of Philadelphia, at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Yardley. The Rev. John C. Marine performed the ceremony.

title: The Rage Unleashed in Soccer Stadiums
description: BRITAIN is still the sick man of Europe in soccer violence, for which it has, as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher says, ''the worst record in the developed world.'' It set another one last weekend when 95 people, most of them youths from Liverpool, died pushing and squeezing their way into a soccer stadium in the northern city of Sheffield.

title: VIOLENT PROTESTS REPORTED IN CHINA
description: A week of growing anti-Government protests turned violent for the first time on Saturday, spreading to the central Chinese city of Xian, where protesters attacked the provincial Government headquarters, injuring 130 officers and burning 20 houses, the official New China News Agency reported this morning.

title: DATA BANK: April 23, 1989
UGANDA: AFTER THE TERROR
description: Ryszard Kapuscinski notes in his article (''Uganda: After the Terror,'' March 12) that he is unable to follow Teso, one of Uganda's many languages, and it is equally clear that he is not conversant in Swahili.

title: Life and Death on Sulawesi
description: AFTER a walk along a path between rice paddies skimmed by large black butterflies with turquoise tails, we stood at the bottom of a limestone cliff. Above us, on two long balconies dug into the rock, tau-tau, effigies of the dead, leaned against a rail. The effigies' wooden hands were extended, their clothes tattered, their bags for traveling into the next world slung over their shoulders, and their wide eyes looked down at us. This is one of the burial places of the Toraja, a group of tribes living in southern Sulawesi, the Indonesian island once called the Celebes.

title: Soviet Economy Not Responding to Change, U.S. Says
description: The Soviet Union has experienced another year of slow economic growth, forcing Mikhail S. Gorbachev to scale back some of his plans for economic change, according to a new report by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Cut to the ground old stalks of perennials left over from last season. Scratch a line of general garden fertilizer around the bases of plants and lightly work it in. Spray peonies with a fungicide to protect them from botrytis. Cut to near ground level the ornamental grasses, but be careful not to destroy new growth coming up for this season. Rose Booklet

title: Edward Gray, 86, Executive, Dies
