description: Edward C. Gray, a longtime executive of the New York Stock Exchange, died of heart failure Thursday at the Carolton Hospital in Fairfield, Conn. He was 86 years old and lived in Westfield, N.J.

title: R.P.I. Coach Quits
description: The Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute hockey coach, Mike Addesa, has resigned after compiling a 188-124-9 record over 10 seasons.

title: A Merry Mess For Yachting
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: POSTINGS: For First-Time Buyers; More State Mortgage Money
description: Cheap mortgages will again be available for families trying to buy their first homes when the State of New York Mortgage Agency opens a new round of lending on May 1. The agency has $144.8 million of new funds available, enough to provide loans to 2,000 first-time buyers of houses, condominiums and cooperative apartments. The loans carry a fixed interest rate of 8.57 percent for a 30-year term, about 3 percentage points less than most new mortgages.

title: Emily Kornfeld, 73; Wrote a Best Seller, 'Profile of America'
description: Emily Davie Kornfeld, an author and actress, died of emphysema Friday at her home in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. She was 73 years old.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Three sides of my house are covered with asbestos shingles. They are in good condition, but we want to put up cedar wood shingles. A contractor recommended putting up furring strips over the asbestos shingles, then nailing the cedar shingles to these. Should the asbestos shingles be removed first?

title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW
description: HEN ANTHONY TROLLOPE published ''The Way We Live Now'' in 1875, no one expected his book to be anything other than a work of fiction. But to tackle the same topic today, we must confront a world grown conditioned to fact.

title:
COLLEGE SPORTS;
Prosecutor's View of Agents
description: LEAD: Did the news media and observers in the courtroom and around the country miss something important in their extensive coverage and analysis of the recent trial of the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom?

title: Earth Shaking
description: THE TUNNEL SHOWN ABOVE, LOCATED beneath Rainier Mesa about 110 miles northwest of Las Vegas, will likely be blown to smithereens pretty soon in a planned nuclear explosion. A recent creation of the Department of Energy on the vast Nevada Test Site that was established by President Harry S. Truman in 1950, it is a sidespoke of what is known as P tunnel, which is itself part of a network of horizontal tunnels used primarily for ''weapons effects tests.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Illinois; Students' Ad Agency: Low-Budget Success
description: Last summer, James Maguire worked at a Chicago advertising agency small enough for him to escape the photocopying machine and jump right into bookkeeping, copywriting and research.

title: Words for Rushdie
description: To the Editor:

title:
7 WRITERS RECONSIDER: NEW YORK TYPES . . . MYTHS AND REALITY;
Carroll Gardeners
description: LEAD: PEOPLE HERE HAVE LIVED ON the same block for 50 years, shopped in the same stores, sent their kids to the same grade school their parents went to. Any day now I expect to get on the B71 bus at Union Street and find Ralph Kramden behind the wheel, grumbling about the Dodgers. The real estate people now call it Carroll Gardens, but a lot of it is still the close-knit Italian enclave once called South Brooklyn.

title: IS COMPETENCE ENOUGH
description: In 1936, Lucius N. Littauer foresaw many of the issues described in your article on Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. In the letter that accompanied his large gift to found the school, he wrote, ''Our public administration needs men trained with a broad outlook into the history, politics and economics of the past . . . the new school shall be organized and conducted not merely to train technical specialists but to educate men in a broad way for public service.''

title: BASEBALL
description: HEROES, PLAIN FOLKS, AND SKUNKS: The Life and Times of Happy Chandler. By Happy Chandler with Vance H. Trimble. (Bonus Books, $18.95.) ''Those people who have done me wrong - well, I try to outlive them,'' Albert B. (Happy) Chandler writes in his autobiography. ''In that, partner, I have succeeded remarkably well.'' As his funny, revealing book shows, Happy Chandler - a one-time semiprofessional baseball player, a former commissioner of major league baseball and a one-term senator from Kentucky - looks over his 90 years with a candor suggesting somebody holding forth on the front porch with a mint julep, regaling visitors with one tall tale after another on a lazy spring day. Much of the book is devoted to his exploits as baseball commissioner, from 1945 to 1951 - that pivotal time in sports history when Jackie Robinson broke the color line (a breakthrough that Mr. Chandler takes no small credit for, the visionary general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, Branch Rickey, notwithstanding). Sometimes Mr. Chandler's prose is a touch strained, and there are occasions in which the presence of his collaborator, the journalist Vance Trimble, is painfully obvious. Still, this autobiography is a brisk read, full of anecdotes and recollections. Evident throughout is a down-home ebullience, a good-old-boy joie de vivre from this man who sees himself ''wearing the world like a loose jacket.'' It is nice to read that at the age of 90 Mr. Chandler is still in there pitching.

title: Watching for Red Flags
description: AS WAS PICKING UP MY son at the day-care center, one of the teachers said to me that she thought his forehead had felt slightly warm late in the afternoon, but he hadn't looked sick at all. I nodded; we all had colds. Oh, added the teacher, and he did just mention that he had a headache. I began to feel slightly nervous; my overactive pediatrician reflexes started to twitch. Did he say anything about his neck, I asked, casually. He didn't mention anything about having a stiff neck, did he?

title: Jurors Mark 2 Years on California Abuse Case
description: Jurors marked the occasion with a cake as the McMartin preschool molestation trial ended its second year Thursday. But no one was rejoicing at the length of the case, which is about to become Los Angeles's longest trial.

title: A Fruitful Collection of Nature Writing
description: ''This Incomperable Lande - A Book of American Nature Writing'' (Houghton Mifflin, $29.95), edited by Thomas J. Lyon, is a superb anthology.

title: FICTION
description: PEARL'S PROGRESS. By James Kaplan. (Knopf, $18.95.) In James Kaplan's first novel, a poet named Philip Pearl accepts a university teaching job in the tiny hamlet of Pickett, Miss. For this bred-in-the-bone Manhattanite, ''progress'' consists largely of a bumpy and somewhat bemused adjustment to life in the Magnolia State. At first, Pearl's point-by-point comparison of the two regions provides the novel with its comic mainspring. But as Pearl's attachment to Pickett grows, this regional comedy softens. Indeed, by the time ''Pearl's Progress'' concludes, Mr. Kaplan's portrait of small-town Mississippi has acquired a fine patina of lyricism, one that allows him to note the afternoon light turning ''close and light gray, opalescent, all the infinitude of Pickett's blue dome gone.'' In the meantime, the transplanted Pearl threads his way through a cultural obstacle course: country music, the Little Big Mall, a Faulkner-obsessed colleague reminiscing about ''ol' Mr. Bill'' and a plateful of inedible fried catfish. Mr. Kaplan is hardly the first writer to attempt such an anthropology of the New South, but his perceptions seem remarkably fresh. In fact, his gift for sidestepping cliches fails him only once, when Pearl encounters an ancient black man on the porch of a shotgun shack, busying himself with gnomic utterances and a battered guitar. Otherwise, ''Pearl's Progress'' succeeds as a deft and witty endorsement for the shock of the new. As Pearl progresses through one new territory after another - romantic as well as cultural - he persuades the reader to share both his excitement and his discomfort: no mean feat, for a series of experiences he's earlier compared to ''losing your virginity over and over.''

title: Words for Rushdie
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; An 1890's Farm, With Jersey Cows
description: Just an hour from New York City there is a nine-acre farm that lives in the past. The Longstreet Farm, part of Holmdel Park in Holmdel, N.J., has tried to re-create life as it was in the 1890's, when farms raised livestock and grew grains and potatoes.

title: Cup Ruling Is Criticized
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil
description: Church experts see the recent dismembering of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese here, the world's largest, as part of an ongoing effort by the Vatican to dilute leftist influences in Brazil's church.

title:
GARDENING;
Planting Meadows in Place of Lawns
description: LEAD: IN recent years, meadow plantings have become popular. This has resulted partly because they require little maintenance and partly as a way of making an ecological statement. Undoubtedly some have planted them because they like the informal, natural effect.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Virginia; It's Addictive, It's Expensive, It's Nintendo!
description: Parents know college studentshave parties. They know that they do more in school than just study English, history and physics.

title: It's Buyer Beware on Long-Term Care
description: Frightened by the prospect of enormous bills that could destroy a lifetime of savings, many elderly Americans are purchasing expensive insurance policies to pay for long-term care not covered by Medicare. But insurance for nursing home, home care or skilled care is a complex product that needs to be evaluated carefully. Besides the usual concerns about price, the buyer needs to make sure that the policy is not riddled with so many exclusions that it turns out to be virtually worthless.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
What Happens When the Cheering Stops
description: LEAD: On this page a couple of months ago, Jim Kaat, the long-time baseball pitcher, examined the reasons why aging ballplayers find the prospect of retirement so unappealing. In a humorous tone, Kaat touched upon a number of reasons: money, pride, competitiveness, fear. There was one area, however, that was relatively undiscussed, a darker side that cuts right to the heart of every professional athlete's sense of identity:

title: At Your Service
description: ANYONE WHO HAS BRAVED THE COSMETICS area of a department store knows the hazards: the frenzied activity, the spritzes of fragrance, the shouts, the hawking. All of this hullabaloo can't disguise the fact that service at the counter is spotty, at best.

title: A Nontraditional Singing For 'Don Giovanni'
description: WHEN the curtain rises Saturday on Christopher Alden's production of ''Don Giovanni,'' opera-goers will see the aristocratic playboy garbed in an up-to-date tuxedo, rather than the traditional 16th-century doublet and hose.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LOS ANGELES;
Ambassador Up for Auction
description: LEAD: THE Ambassador Hotel, long a symbol of Hollywood elegance, eccentricity and tragedy, has closed and probably will be demolished after being auctioned.

title: Review/Theater; Journalists' Ethics, in 'Rebel Armies'
description: In ''Rebel Armies Deep Into Chad,'' Mark Lee raises provocative questions about the ethics and responsibilities of journalists, especially those covering wars and revolutions. But the play itself becomes something of a charade, inventing an unrewarding plot and eventually undercutting its own rationale. In journalistic terms, ''Rebel Armies'' is a digressionary sidebar story rather than front-page news.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 31 of the Arts and Leisure section today about a television production of Mark Twain's ''Diaries of Adam and Eve'' misstates the number of years since Twain's death. He died 79 years ago.

title: For Two of America's Arab Allies, The Worst Wounds Are Economic
description: OVER the last month, the leaders of Egypt and Jordan, the linchpins of Washington's diplomacy among the Arabs, have visited the United States as part of the search for a Middle East peace. At home, their people are locked in a less exalted quest called getting by.

title: Philippine Rebels Say They Killed U.S. Colonel
description: Communist rebels said today that they killed an American army officer on Friday because the officer was a ''direct participant'' in the Government's counterinsurgency program.

title: Head of Howard U. Announces Retirement
description: Howard University announced today that James E. Cheek, president of the historically black institution for 20 years, will retire at the end of June.

title: Rock and Roll Is a Fundamental
description: SOMETHING unexpected happened to me on my way to an empty nest. I knew I'd miss a lot of things when my sons left for college. But I never thought I'd miss their music.

title: DANGEROUS DAYS IN THE MACARENA
description: IT'S AN INCALCULABLY valuable national treasure,'' Dr. Carlos Castano, the director of Colombia's national parks, had told me. Yet when I had said that I intended to visit the country's oldest and, among scientists, most internationally celebrated, nature reserve, Castano became alarmed. ''But it's very dangerous.''

title: American Prints at Newark Library
description: THE Newark Public Library, with its stately marble halls, makes an excellent argument in favor of prints - not the billboard-sized items that flow from chic workshops, but the small treasures meant to be scrutinized in private.

title: Farm Biotech
description: To the Editor:

title: Local Laws Take Aim At Indestructible Trash
description: IN the early 1980's, the cities of St. Paul and Minneapolis joined a growing number of cities and counties with curbside recycling programs, picking up glass bottles, aluminum cans and newspapers that might otherwise go into landfills or incinerators.

title: More Signals On Freedom For Mandela
description: On a prison farm in the verdant wine-growing region of the western Cape, a graying 70-year-old convict serves his 27th year of confinement, while the speculation about his freedom drags on.

title: Correction
description: An article headed ''Matchmaking'' on April 9 in Education Life, about students with learning disabilities, gave an incorrect toll-free telephone number for the Heath Resource Center. Its number is (800) 544-3284.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: In STORMING INTREPID by Payne Harrison (Crown, $19.95) we have a standard Big Book, with one difference. Unlike most of its kind, it is not pretentious. Indeed, it is expertly written and well researched. Otherwise, it follows the down-to-the-wire formula in which catastrophe is prevented at the last second.

title: BASEBALL
description: DIAMONDS ARE FOREVER: Artists and Writers on Baseball. Edited by Peter H. Gordon with Sydney Waller and Paul Weinman. (Chronicle Books, Cloth, $35; Paper, $18.95.) A young lawyer I know, asked what it was like arguing before the Supreme Court for the first time, answered: ''Like playing in the World Series.'' Baseball is America's language, even its glue. Or as the poet Donald Hall puts it in an introduction to this book: ''It is by baseball, and not by other American sports, that our memories bronze themselves. . . . By baseball we join hands with the long line of forefathers and with the dead.'' ''Diamonds Are Forever,'' an elegant collection of text and artwork edited by Peter H. Gordon, a curator at the New York State Museum, with the assistance of Sydney Waller and Paul Weinman, is the color catalogue of a traveling exhibit. It sets out to be about ''one very basic question: 'What is it about baseball that fascinates and touches us so deeply?' '' Andrew Radcliffe's oil painting ''The Baseball Game'' represents all of a game's space and balletic motionlessness, if not the perfect greenness of a northern park. Or as Robert Parker's detective, Spenser, puts it: ''We turned into Yawkey Way. And there we were. In front of Fenway. . . . Inside was eternity.'' There is something to every taste in ''Diamonds Are Forever,'' with its excerpts from 55 writers ranging from Woody Allen to Ernest Hemingway to Carl Sandburg and works by 90 artists, including Andy Warhol, Jacob Lawrence and Elaine de Kooning. Here is the last sentence of Catfish Hunter's brief speech on Catfish Hunter Day at Yankee Stadium: ''Thank you, God, for giving me strength, and making me a ballplayer.'' It is quoted in the British journalist Lesley Hazleton's description of her second day in this country, which she spent at her first baseball game: ''I felt that I had had my first glimpse of a mythical place called America.''

title: Correction
description: An obituary last Sunday about the executive vice president of a retail store in Middletown, Conn., misidentified him and the store. He was Bernard S. Wrubel of Wrubel's Inc. In some copies, because of a mechanical error, the obituary omitted a survivor. She was his wife, Ada, of Hallandale, Fla.

title: Reds Manage to Score And Go on to Win, 5-4
description: A single by Paul O'Neill scored the winning run in the 10th inning and the Cincinnati Reds, shut out in their previous three games, beat the Houston Astros, 5-4, today.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Moving Up Without Having to Move Away
description: LEAD: FOR many residents of Nassau's more densely populated communities, staying in the old neighborhood usually means staying in the old homestead, or one of similar vintage. With little land left for development, the best a would-be buyer eager to move up to a new house can usually hope for is a house replacing one that has been knocked down.

title: Traditions Easily Lose Their Luster
description: Rules worth living by are not numerous. Yes, the Ten Commandments must be considered. And Nelson Algren's ''never eat at a place called 'Mom's.' '' To those immutable laws I would add another: never, even if trapped between flights at an airport, buy a book with an embossed cover. But beyond such rudimentary dicta, human behavior is difficult to keep codified. In music, to pick a subject not quite at random, the honored traditions of one generation are regularly stripped of their epaulets by the next and drummed out of respectability. In a matter of moments, as history views change, holy art becomes satanic practice or the other way around.

title: Pitching Rescues The Mets
description: They may be hitting .226 as a team. Darryl Strawberry has a hurt right shoulder and isn't playing. Howard Johnson has a hurt right shoulder and is playing. And Ron Darling and Bob Ojeda have started seven games, won none, lost six and allowed 49 hits and 28 runs in 30 innings. But don't bury the Mets yet. Pitching depth, which is supposed to rescue the Mets from all those other troubles, did rescue them yesterday when Sid Fernandez and Roger McDowell combined on a five-hitter that stopped the Chicago Cubs, 3-1. And suddenly, after losing 7 of their first 10 games, the Mets have won 4 of their last 6, are 2 games below .500 and 2 games below first place.

title: Championships Are Second Nature to Drum and Bugle Corps
description: ON any Friday night in this peaceful Passaic County community, one need only walk to the center of town to hear the music of what some regard as the world's greatest drum and bugle corps.

title: The Lure of Product Testing
description: LEAD: A TEEN-AGER from Hackensack says he does it because his father told him to. Lisa Bormann of Bergenfield does it partly to help pay her monthly bills. And Doreen Kraeuter of Lodi says she does not know why she does it.

title: West Meets East
description: The nearest thing to a Texas oil millionaire that most Japanese had seen was on ''Dallas.'' Last week, they got a closeup of the real thing, T. Boone Pickens, who was visiting Tokyo after buying a 20 percent stake in Japan's largest automotive lighting equipment company, Koito Manufacturing. In Tokyo's clubby financial world, where takeovers and raiders are rare, Mr. Pickens's visit and his motives caused a stir, despite his assurances that he had no interest in taking over Koito and was just a long-term investor. He also shrugged off suggestions that he was being manipulated by the Japanese financier, Kitaro Watanabe, who sold him the stock and whose motives are also unclear. ''Could happen,'' said Mr. Pickens. ''I'm just a little guy from West Texas.''

title: Approaching The Limits Of Lebanon's Endurance
description: SINCE Lebanon's civil war broke out in April 1975, life here has been governed by a convulsive rhythm: A fragile status quo is established, continues for a period of months or years and is eventually shattered by new events. A spasm of tension, carnage and uncertainty follows. This is eventually calmed by yet another status quo, under which the living conditions are usually worse than they were before.

title: Travlish
description: To the Editor: Elaine Kendall's ''A Short Course in Travlish'' (Travel, March 5) includes Fodor's Travel Guides with most other guidebooks that use ''only words that elicit positive responses, favoring those that conjure up visions of comfort, prosperity and beauty.''

title: Jessica Dowdy Engaged
description: The engagement of Jessica Lynn Dowdy, a bank examiner for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in New York, and Stephen Christopher Everett Fogg, a consultant for T.B.S. Inc., a computer-consulting concern in Bogota, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. T. William Dowdy of Fairfax Station, Va., the parents of the future bride. Mr. Fogg is a son of the Rev. Ralph Everett Fogg of New Paltz, N.Y., and Judith K. Parisi of Charlotte, N.C.

title: Shuttle Modifications Delay Space Missions
description: The space agency has announced that two military space shuttle flights planned for the summer will be delayed, one of them for at least three months, because modifications to the Columbia shuttle are taking longer than expected.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending April 8 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $1.5 million 55 Charles Street 3-family, 4-story town house; 3 bedrooms, 2 baths, dining room, 4 fireplaces, terrace in owner's duplex; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath in others; 20- by 95-ft. lot; taxes $7,000 (Broker: Fields-Eichner Inc.) Greenwich Village $340,000 708 Greenwich Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,250-sq.-ft. prewar, loft co-op; fireplace, high-ceilings, two exposures; maintenance $610, 49% tax-deductible (Broker: Debra Kameros Co.) Park Slope $375,000 549 1st Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 3,200-sq.-ft. garden duplex in a brownstone; dining room, large kitchen, small garden; maintenance $360, 32% tax-deductible (Broker: Madge Rothstein) QUEENS Forest Hills Gardens $600,000 110 Continental Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, detached, brick center-hall colonial; dining room, fireplace, solarium, 60-by 100-ft. lot; taxes $3,200 (Broker: Sarah Jones Realty) Woodside $240,000 43-31 68th Street 2-family, detached, frame house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each; finished basement, 24- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $940 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Bulls Head $202,500 116 Renee Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-famly, semiattached, frame house with aluminum and asbestos siding; dining room, large kitchen, family room, 1-car garage, 30- by 100-ft. corner lot; taxes $1,800 (Broker: Kingsley Real Estate) Westerleigh $160,000 127 Llewellyn Place 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, fireplace, slate floors in kitchen, dead end street; 50- by 98-ft. lot; taxes $765 (Broker: Re-Max Preferred)

title: Failed Plan Leaves Llamas Dying in Tropics
description: Thousands of miles from their home in the cool mountains of South America, a herd of woolly llamas and alpacas have been stranded on a Caribbean island and are slowly dying from heat and stress in the broiling sun.

title: Solid and Reliable Talent For a New Ball Game
description: A mediocre draft? Not everyone thinks so about the National Football League's 54th annual draft, which begins at noon today at the Marriott Marquis in Manhattan. Twelve rounds of selections of college players will take place today and tomorrow as each N.F.L. team hopes to solidify its chances of reaching Super Bowl XXIV Jan. 28 in the Louisiana Superdome.

title: Biking in England's Farm Country
description: THE old adage, it's as easy as riding a bicycle, was about to be tested - literally. I had joined up with a group of bicycling enthusiasts for a weeklong cycling tour called a Bicycle Beano and offered by a company of the same name.

title: A Town Acts on Lyme Disease
description: LEAD: SOMETIME this month, the Town of East Hampton is expected to enlist the help of the white-footed mouse and a pesticide called Damminix in its battle against deer ticks and the Lyme disease that it carries.

title: Versailles
description: To the Editor: I read Charles Lockwood's article on the restoration of Versailles (Travel, March 19). We visited Versailles this past December. We arrived on a tour bus from Paris, as did many others.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Barnstable; Sellers Face New Tax
description: ONE of the flattest real estate markets in Cape Cod history picked up an additional burden this month in the form of a new county transfer tax.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The Greatest Fighter Of All Time?
description: No one can deny Ali's superiority in hand speed and ring mobility. What's underrated is his defense, punching power and sheer athleticism. Without addressing the evident irony, Ali's ability to absorb blows, conceal his injuries and even rise from the canvas when necessary is unequaled. SCOTT LITTLEJOHN Jersey City

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Economy Lagging

title: POSTINGS: Trump Palace Going Up; 55 Stories On Third
description: Construction has begun on what will be the tallest building on the upper East Side, to the delight of its developer, Donald Trump, and the dismay of community groups that tried but failed to cut the planned height of the 55-story structure. At 623 feet, Trump Palace, which is going up on a full blockfront of Third Avenue between 68th and 69th Streets, will be 72 feet taller than the area's present tallest building, the 54-story Galleria condominium at 117 East 57th Street.

title: Year Two in the Decade of the Child
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York deserves praise for calling attention to the plight of poor children. He recently urged all America to join New York in the commitment to a Decade of the Child that he proclaimed in 1987. How is New York doing? The state budget deficit threatened elements of the program. But thanks to Mr. Cuomo's tenacity in some areas and the State Legislature's tenacity in others, the program keeps expanding.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about corporate day care listed one company incorrectly among a consortium studying child-care alternatives. I.B.M. is not in the consortium. The article included three companies incorrectly among those that have used the referral services of Nassau or Suffolk County Child Care Councils. Cablevision, Lilco and Grumman have not done so.

title: 'Mickey Mouse Club' Returns, Minus Much M-I-C-K-E-Y
description: Taking the job of head Mouseketeer on the new ''Mickey Mouse Club Show'' seemed at first a questionable career move to Fred Newman.

title: Glamour Rules At Celebrations Of Fashion
description: Fashion took over the party scene at two big annual events. Elegance was the keynote at both. Evening dresses by top designers - some slit to the thigh for easy dancing - were worn at the Fashion Council's 13th annual event on April 13 at the Museum of Natural History for buyers who had come to see the fall collections.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Where in the world does that stamp come from? Sometimes the design shows the answer very clearly - with a map of the country. Such stamps make up the collecting area of cartophilatelists, and what a rich field it is.

title: The 'Little Guys' Still Belong
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Reaping the Awards
description: ''Greedy, greedy,'' said Bette Davis, who knows something about awards and emphatic statements. ''Can't have too many awards. I've gotten just about every award there is to get. Yes.'' For her more than 80 movies spanning five decades, Miss Davis, at 81, is to receive another award tomorrow for her contribution to movies at the annual Tribute of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: NEW JERSEY FOLLOW-UP
description: Boardwalk Music FOR 34-year-old Celestine Tate, music has been a way of life and a means of earning a living on the Boardwalk in Atlantic City since 1982. The quadriplegic mother of three has reached a settlement with city administrators that will allow her to continue her endeavor, free of what she calls ''police harassment.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Wake Forest; Will the Deltas Ever Overtake The Fideles?
description: Strings, SOPHs, Fideles, Thymes, Lynks, Phoenix, Delphi. These are the societies of women at Wake Forest University whose control over social life is being challenged by the recent introduction of national sororities.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 9 about cable television referred incorrectly to new regulations for organizations that operate community-access channels. The State Commission on Cable Television has proposed the new requirements. It has not enacted them.

title: THE COLD HANDS OF GENIUS
description: LEAD: GLENN GOULD A Life and Variations. By Otto Friedrich. Illustrated. 441 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: JORDANIAN PRINCE REBUKES LEADERS
description: After five days of price riots that spread from southern Jordan to a town outside the capital, Crown Prince Hassan issued a sharp attack today on Government economic policy amid signs of spreading public discontent with the authorities in Amman.

title: 'KILL THE FOREIGNER!'
description: CHINA JOURNAL, 1889-1900 An American Missionary Family During the Boxer Rebellion. With the Letters and Diaries of Eva Jane Price and Her Family. Foreword by Harrison E. Salisbury. Introductory notes and annotations by Robert H. Felsing. Illustrated. 289 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $22.50.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: When Solidarity was organized in Poland in 1980, we wondered whether the Soviet Union could tolerate a challenge to total Communist power next door. The answer was no. Martial law crushed the experiment in December 1981.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Some Basics on Pot Sizes For Good Gardeners
description: LEAD: All flower pots are not created equal. To begin with, they can be made of different materials. The two most common are clay and plastic. These materials have good points and drawbacks.

title: Correction
description: An obituary last Sunday about William Attwood, author and former newspaper publisher and ambassador, misidentified his first book. It was ''The Man Who Could Grow Hair,'' published in 1949 by Alfred A. Knopf. ''Still the Most Exciting Country,'' published in 1955 by Knopf, was his second.

title: Punchless Yanks Now 0-5 Against Indians
description: By the time Tommy John walked off the mound and headed toward the dugout late this afternoon, the game had essentially been played and lost. One run was in, a tie was broken, and all John could do was slump onto the bench and watch the final moments of the seventh inning.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GEORGE AND MARTHA WASHINGTON AT HOME IN NEW YORK By Beatrice Siegel. Illustrated by Frank Aloise. 74 pp. New York: Four Winds Press. A PICTURE BOOK OF GEORGE WASHINGTON By David A. Adler. Illustrated by John Wallner and Alexandra Wallner. Unpaged. New York: Holiday House I DID IT WITH MY HATCHET A Story of George Washington. Written and illustrated by Robert Quackenbush. 36 pp. New York: Pippin Press.

title: Wright Adds Heavyweights To Legal Team, Officials Say
description: House Speaker Jim Wright is beefing up his team of defense lawyers as his fight against charges of ethics code violations heads for a public hearing before the House ethics committee, officials on Capitol Hill said today.

title: Theater's Renewal Tied to Condos
description: LEAD: AFTER eight years of financial obstacles and conflict with the Jersey City government, Albert Stinchcromb remains undaunted. He believes he can restore his deteriorated Majestic Theater to its former grandeur and create a major cultural center that would rival any professional theater in the Northeast.

title: Sellers Face Transfer Tax
description: ONE of the flattest real estate markets in Cape Cod history picked up an additional burden this month in the form of a new county transfer tax.

title: CROSS-SELLING: PEPSI PLUGS 'TOP GUN' FOR A SPOT ON THE TAPE
description: The commercial for Schweppes in a top video rental, ''A Fish Called Wanda,'' illustrates just how self-conscious studios like CBS-Fox Video are about putting advertisements on cassette. In it, John Cleese, a star of the movie, spoofs subliminal advertising in movies - a blinking billboard for Schweppes as a backdrop.

title:
FOCUS: South Florida;
MacArthur Trust Shedding Its Holdings
description: LEAD: THE John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, one of the country's richest trusts, is steadily divesting itself of its vast land holdings in South Florida.

title: West Villagers
description: I HEAR THAT AT ONE TIME THE west Village was an actual neighborhood populated by free-living bohemians and artists. Well, I don't know about bohemian. Today, the word to describe the West Village is cute.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Hoisting a Mug of Wine in Austria
description: LEAD: THE Holy Roman Emperor Joseph II, son and heir of the formidable Empress Maria Theresa, sought renown as the great reformer. Most of his plans misfired, but he is still kindly remembered, after 200 years, as the monarch who granted permission to winegrowers to sell their own wine directly to the public for consumption on the spot, along with any food they might have around so long as it was not hot and the pork came from their own home-grown pigs.

title: Washington's New Wave of Ethics Anxiety
description: PLACES that deal in power, like official Washington, are as uncomfortable with prolonged discussions of ethics as places that deal in money, like Wall Street. Ethical debates are for clergymen and maybe philosophers, many here believe, but last week ethics was the unsettling Topic A. The reason, of course, was the plight of Oliver L. North and Jim Wright, both accused by their critics of breaking the rules and both defended by their friends as upright men acting in keeping with the local mores. In some quarters, their alleged transgressions stirred a sense of moral outrage. But the much more common reaction, especially to Jim Wright's problems, and especially among officeholders, was a sense of shared vulnerability: ''There but for the grace of God . . .''

title: Port Chester Singers to Sing Twice for a U.S. Bicentennial
description: LEAD: THE voices of some citizens of Port Chester will be raised twice in celebration of the bicentennial of the inauguration of President George Washington.

title: Editing Devices Grow in Popularity
description: The six million video fans in the United States who make their own video movies with a camcorder seem to be expanding their creative options. In terms of rising sales, editing devices are now second only to camcorders themselves.

title: Scientist Accused of Faking Findings
description: In what is being called the most serious case of its kind since the Piltdown hoax more than half a century ago, a paleontologist from India is being accused by colleagues of falsifying numerous fossil discoveries in the Himalayas.

title: Referendum Sought on Auto Insurance
description: LEAD: INSPIRED by a grass-roots revolt in California, a coalition of two state citizens' groups last week announced a campaign to allow New Jersey voters to vent their frustration at the polls over soaring automobile insurance premiums.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Reviews/Music; Contemporary Ensemble From Manhattan School
description: Wednesday evening's concert at the Manhattan School of Music was perhaps more useful to its performers than to its audience. That this institution, through the Manhattan Contemporary Ensemble, involves students in full-scale attempts at new and recent music speaks well for its program, especially in a larger music-education system overly concerned with the past. Here there was a nice balance between 20th-century classics and music that is truly new.

title: BLACK ARTISTSInvisible Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine McMahon To Wed Next Month
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. McMahon of West Orange, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Catherine Mary McMahon and Thomas Michael Toomey, 1982 graduates of Stonehill College. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Toomey of Manchester, Conn.

title:
FOCUS: PALM BEACH GARDENS, FLA;
MacArthur Trust Shedding Its Florida Holdings
description: LEAD: The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, one of the country's richest trusts, is steadily divesting itself of its vast land holdings in South Florida.

title: FILM VIEW
description: ''I want you to help me hijack a Polaris submarine.''

title: Discovering the Sweet Inland Waters
description: WHEN winter presses in too hard, I close my eyes and picture the lakes of summer. They exist in eternal August splendor, sparkling, island-studded lakes, lakes upon whose shores I have camped, or upon whose waters I have canoed, or whose fish I have caught. Lake Louisa, Follensby Clear Pond, Suzanette Lake, Long Pond, Smoke Lake, Argo Lake: an endless chain of sweet water.

title: Upper West Siders
description: WHEN I GRADUATED IN 1959, administrators at the Trinity School (on 91st between Columbus and Amsterdam) were considering a move eastward across Central Park. Back then, that part of the Upper West Side was sullen and hazardous. Children in uniform who walked there might just as well have worn signs that read: Rob Me, I'm Middle-Class. Of course, as a wit once put it, you were more likely to be mugged on the Upper West Side than on the Upper East - but you were also more likely to enjoy it. After all, a lot of thoughtful academic and artistic types inhabited the stretch from 59th Street to 96th. Your attacker might very well be liberal, intellectual, politically active, compassionate and living in a cheap one-bedroom under rent control.

title: Cold War Isn't Over While the U.S. Can Help It; End Nuclear Arms Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-op Clues
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTEST IN THE SOVIET REPUBLICS
description: Democracy is the big threat to the Muscovite empire, not nationalism, as Zbigniew Brzezinski argues in his article ''Will the Soviet Empire Self-Destruct?'' (Feb. 26). The protest movements in the Soviet republics have drawn their force more from democracy than from nationalism (the Armenian-Azerbaijani conflict appears to be an exception, and that particular conflict, if unaccompanied by democracy, is isolated and no threat to the empire).

title: BASEBALL
description: BASEBALL ANECDOTES. By Daniel Okrent and Steve Wulf. (Oxford University, $18.95.) Even the most erudite baseball fan may not know that Babe Ruth was the game's first underwear model, that the brainy catcher Moe Berg counted Sanskrit among the languages he knew, that Rogers Hornsby avoided movies to protect his batting eye or that the former Yankee manager Billy Martin had cosmetic surgery on his nose when he was 22 years old. Of such beguiling minutiae is ''Baseball Anecdotes'' made. Daniel Okrent, co-author of ''The Ultimate Baseball Book,'' and Steve Wulf, a senior editor at Sports Illustrated, essentially have written a history of the game in stories - comic, tragic, controversial - starting with baseball's disputed origins and ending with the 1986 World Series. The monochromatic prose rarely does justice to these lusty tales. Some are attributed, some are not and some have the ring of apocrypha about them. The younger fan is enthralled to discover that Hank Greenberg's mother promised to make him 61 baseball-shaped portions of gefilte fish back in 1938 if he broke Babe Ruth's record of 60 home runs in a season. Readers curious about players' afterlives will learn that the Yankee outfielder Mickey Rivers became a professional bingo player, that Honus Wagner toured Pittsburgh saloons in search of recognition and free beers and that a drink-dissipated Grover Cleveland Alexander did a stint as a circus freak. (The authors do not say what kind.) Idolators of macho men will find their demigod in the Cleveland Indians' outfielder Joe Charbonneau, who tried to fix his own broken nose with a pair of pliers, pulled one of his own teeth and stitched up a stab wound with a fishing line. Some stories, however, touch on a provocative point and fail to follow through: the authors never explain why Mr. Martin got that nose job or why the legendary double-play partners Joe Tinker and Johnny Evers did not speak to each other for two years. Gargantuan Boog Powell and paunchy Mickey Lolich are cited for their heft, with no mention of what they weighed. And it is maddening to be told that the career minor leaguer Steve Dalkowski was the hardest-throwing pitcher to walk the earth without reporting the speed of his fastball.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DINOmight ''It's better than Disneyland,'' said Daniel H. Kaplan, one of the curators at the Sands Point Preserve. ''We had 40,000 people in the first two weeks,'' added Herb Mills, curator of geology at the preserve, which is part of the Nassau County Museum system.

title: 'Moscow Station'
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE Z
description: CANADA DAY Ian Millar, the Canadian equestrian who won the Volvo World Cup of stadium jumping in Tampa, Fla., last Sunday, will be among the Canadian sports, arts, business and political figures taking part Tuesday in the Canada Day celebration on the Pleasantville campus of Pace University. The Canadian Consulate General, the Governments of Alberta, Ontario, Quebec and Saskatchewan, the Canadian Society and the Bank of Montreal are participating.

title: Life and Death Are the Actors On Her Stage
description: On stage, a grieving old man paces, mutters, groans, finally exploding into words. It is a speech from ''Titus Andronicus,'' Shakespeare's early, rarely performed drama of revenge, pitting Romans against Goths, with unhappy endings for all.

title: TV Sponsors Heed Viewers Who Find Shows Too Racy
description: A wave of advertiser defections from prime-time network programs has swept through the television industry in the last two months, and industry executives attribute it primarily to widespread, grass-roots objections to sexual themes and explicit language on the public airwaves.

title: Skipwith Redmon And A. C. Banker Exchange Vows
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Skipwith Carter Winslow Redmon, the daughter of Coates D. Redmon of Washington and the late Hayes Redmon, was married yesterday to Alexander Campbell Banker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas H. Banker of Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Anne Alexander Wed in Virginia To D. R. Marshall
description: At Ware Episcopal Church in Gloucester, Va., Anne Stokes Alexander, the daughter of Mrs. Chester Alexander of Gloucester and the late Mr. Alexander, was married yesterday to Davis Ratcliffe Marshall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Randolph Wellford Marshall of Gloucester. The Rev. Daniel O. Worthington Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Dried Cherries: Rich in Flavor, Good in the Kitchen
description: RECENTLY, dried cherries from California, Oregon, Washington and Michigan have become available in fancy food shops and health-food stores. Chukar, American Spoon Foods, Select Origins, Sonoma and L'Esprit are some of the brand names to look for.

title: Colorado Spurns Olympics No More
description: Nearly two decades after Colorado voters spurned the 1976 Winter Olympics as a menace to their taxes and environment, Denver civic leaders are bidding for the games once again, this time arguing that the Olympics are just the tonic for the state's sagging economy.

title: It's Avant-Garde, All Right, But Which One?
description: The compositional career of Karlheinz Stockhausen, who was born near Cologne, Germany, in 1928, has been one of the most curious of our times - so curious that in some sober quarters he is considered by now to have flipped completely into the mystical empyrean.

title: Being a Burden
description: To the Editor: ''A Reluctant Burden'' took me on the dooly ride I didn't make during my trip to India.

title: Miss Geier Is Married
description: St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York was the setting last evening for the marriage of Hope Philippa Geier to Theodore Briell Smith 3d. The Rev. Peter M. Colapietro performed the ceremony.

title: During a Slowdown, the Fittest Survive
description: Andre Blay had little idea how hot a sensation he had stumbled on in 1977 when he put the first feature films onto videocassette. Needless to say, Mr. Blay is now a millionaire and the father of what is now a $9.2 billion retail phenomenon.

title: Jean Dexheimer, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Jean K. Dexheimer, an associate at the patent law firm of Davis Hoxie Faithfull & Hapgood, and Paul M. Dudek, an associate at the law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, both in New York, were married yesterday in York, Pa. The Rev. Burton J. Parry performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SPECTACLES AND ART In certain Italian Renaissance paintings, Jesus and the Apostles are depicted wearing eyeglasses. How the development of lenses in the mid-15th century affected art and other elements of society is the subject of a free talk titled ''Renaissance Vision: Eyeglasses and Diplomacy, Literature and Art,'' to be given Thursday in New Haven by Vincent Ilardi, professor of history at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst.

title: For New Yorkers, Spring Fever Erupts On Softball Diamonds
description: On April 15, a cold, rainy day when most New Yorkers probably were preoccupied with more taxing matters, Marty Mann was on a softball diamond in Central Park, trying to jump-start summer.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Stronger Dollar For Visitors To Brazil

title: Schooling in Japan Offers Some Insights
description: IN cinderblock buildings, 45 students, all dressed alike, sit in barren classrooms and learn from paperback texts with no pictures. This hardly sounds like an educational Utopia. Nevertheless, the typical Japanese high-school graduate has the skills and knowledge of many of our college graduates; and, on standardized tests, Japan's students outperform the world's.

title: The Lasting Scar of Sexual Abuse
description: LEAD: ''I ran away when I was 16,'' the woman said. ''I hung around the streets for a while and then called a hot-line number because I felt so hopeless.

title: Haunting the System
description: Since age 9, Willie Bosket has been in reformatories or prisons almost continuously. He said he committed more than 2,000 crimes by the age of 15, including 25 stabbings and two subway murders. Last week Mr. Bosket, now 26 and described by law-enforcement officials as New York's most incorrigible inmate, was sentenced to 25 years to life for assaulting a prison guard. He was already serving 28 years for attempted robbery, arson and assault on other prison guards. What did the new sentence accomplish? The judge said he was concerned that the added sentence would give Mr. Bosket ''a license to kill'' in prison. The prosecutor said the case might persuade the Legislature to restore the death penalty, although Mr. Bosket would not fall under it unless he killed a guard. Said Mr. Bosket, ''I'll haunt this damn system.''

title: IS COMPETENCE ENOUGH
description: My only complaint about Anthony Lukas's article on Harvard's Kennedy School was its gratuitous swipe at Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's failed bid for the Presidency. Mr. Dukakis has both gut-level values and a mastery of management technocracy. If anyone ''regressed'' in ''the grubby business of getting elected,'' it was George Bush for having unleashed the Ailes-Teeter-Atwater smear team. GERALD W. GRUMET, M.D. Rochester, N.Y.

title: The I.R.A.'s Political Allies Run Against Its Violent Side
description: SINN FEIN, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, is finding itself handicapped as it prepares for elections in Northern Ireland next month. Its efforts to cultivate new allies are being met with skepticism because they are being undercut by the I.R.A.'s repeated violence against civilians.

title: Correction
description: A caption with the Fashion column in The Times Magazine last Sunday misstated prices of two items by Jean-Paul Gaultier on page 73. The rayon, wool and Lycra blazer was $885 and the slim pants were $450.

title: Anglers Return To Reel In Spring
description: IN our family, the most common harbinger of spring is not the return of the swallows to their nests or the sprouting of the crocus. It is the emergence of the fishing poles from their hidden lairs. As soon as the deep freeze of winter begins to thaw, some hidden alarm goes off to signal it is fishing season.

title: Reviews/Dance; Games for the Eyes, by Beals and Solomons
description: Two choreographers shared the program offered by the Danspace Project last Sunday night at St. Mark's Church. Margaret Beals celebrated forces of nature. Gus Solomons Jr. played peekaboo.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl and Edberg in Final: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and No. 2-seeded Stefan Edberg overcame strong wind yesterday to reach the final of the $752,500 Japan Open in Tokyo. Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, beat Richard Matuszewski of the United States, 6-2, 6-2, and Edberg of Sweden defeated third-seeded John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-3. In the women's final, Kumiko Okamoto beat Elizabeth Smylie of Australia, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Sabatini Defeats Sanchez: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini beat fourth-seeded Arantxa Sanchez, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in the semifinals of the Eckerd Open in Largo, Fla. Today, Sabatini will meet No. 8 Conchita Martinez, who beat No. 6 Sandra Cecchini, 6-0, 6-0.(AP) Golf Green Takes 2-Stroke Lead: Ken Green had eight birdies for a six-under-par 66 yesterday for a two-shot lead over John Huston in the $1 million Greater Greensboro Open in North Carolina. Last year, Green lost in a playoff to Sandy Lyle after missing a 3-foot putt that would have given him the victory in regulation. His front nine yesterday led him out of a four-way tie at the end of the second round. Green was at 11-under-par 205. Dave Eichelberger and Jim Booros had even-par 72's and were tied for third at 211.(AP) U.S. Increases Lead: Arnold Palmer holed a chip shot on the 12th hole for an eagle yesterday to help the United States increase its lead over the international team in the Seniors Chrysler Cup in Sarasota, Fla. The Americans won two matches, lost one and halved the fourth in team better-ball stroke play to lead the international squad by 38 1/2-21 1/2. The final 40 points will be decided in eight individual stroke-play matches today. Palmer and Dave Hill beat Roberto De Vicenzo and Doug Dalziel, 65-68. Al Geiberger and Orville Moody edged Bob Charles and Bruce Crampton, 69-70.(AP) Adams 2 Ahead of Jones: Lynn Adams shot a four-under-par 68 yesterday for a two-stroke lead over the defending champion, Rosie Jones, in the USX Golf Classic in Gulfport, Fla. Adams had a 54-hole total of 11-under-par 205. Jones shot a 71 to be in second place at 207. The first-round leader, Lori Garbacz, also shot a 71 and was third at 208.(AP) Hockey Soviet Union Tops Canada: Andrei Khomutov had a goal and an assist yesterday as the unbeaten Soviet Union edged Canada, 4-3, in Stockholm for its sixth consecutive victory at the world championships. The Soviet team needs only a tie against the defending champion, Sweden, tomorrow to finish on top of the preliminary-round standing. Earlier, Vladimir Ruzicka knocked in a rebound with 1 minute 4 seconds left to give Czechoslovakia a 3-3 tie against the Swedes.(AP) Track and Field No Record for Relay Team: A mix-up by the officials and a misunderstanding of the rules by the runners might have cost the Santa Monica Track Club a world record yesterday in an 800-meter relay race at the Mount San Antonio College Relays in Walnut, Calif. The team of Joe DeLoach, Floyd Heard, Danny Everett and Carl Lewis, expecting to break the 11-year-old record of 1 minute 20.26 seconds set by the University of Southern California, won the race, but in 1:20.54. The Santa Monica team, in lane four, assumed that each runner had to remain in his lane for the record to be accepted. Only the first three must for the record, but as Everett, the third-leg runner, waited to take the baton from Heard, an official told the third-leg runners they could break to the inside, and Everett finished his leg in the first lane. Lewis, believing he was properly stationed in the fourth lane for the final pass, had to shift to the first lane just as Everett arrived. ''I thought, 'What the heck is going on?' '' Lewis said. He quickly moved in to accept the baton, but the pass was not smooth and Lewis had little better than a standing start for the final leg. In the men's 100-meter dash, Raymond Stewart of Texas Christian won in 9.91 seconds, but with a tailwind of more than 12 miles an hour. DeLoach was second in 9.97. St. John's Women Take Title: St. John's, with 183 points, won the team title yesterday in the women's Metropolitan Intercollegiate Outdoor Championships at Columbia's Baker Field. Virginia Young, a junior, led the winners with a meet-record effort of 161 feet 5 inches in the hammer throw and a winning throw of 130 feet 5 inches in the discus. She was upset in the shot-put by the freshman Sonja Fitts, one of her teammates, who won at 45 feet, a meet record. Rutgers was runner-up with 168 points, and Manhattan College was third at 117. Dog Show Best of 4,121: A black-and-white pointer, Ch. Luftnase Albelarm Bee's Knees, owned by Isabel Robson and Michael Zollo, was named best of 4,121 dogs yesterday at the 92d fixture of the Old Dominion Kennel Club of Northern Virginia, at historic Bull Run Regional Park in Centreville. It was the 22d top award for the pointer bitch, who was handled by Zollo. Diving Williams and Pichler Lead Qualifiers: Wendy Lian Williams, the Olympic bronze medalist last year, and the unheralded Dave Pichler led the qualifiers yesterday for the 10-meter platform finals at the United States championships in Boca Raton, Fla. Williams, a junior at the University of Miami, is defending her women's platform title. Pichler, a sophomore at Ohio State, heads the men's field of 12 qualifiers seeking to succeed the retired Greg Louganis as champion.(AP)

title: In New England, Work Can Be Mixed Blessing
description: Despite starting pay as high as $6 an hour, McDonald's and the Holiday Inn find it so hard to find workers here that they routinely import workers from sister businesses in Plattsburgh, N.Y., a 60-minute ferry ride across Lake Champlain.

title: Prospects; The Downturn in Housing
description: New residential construction suffered its second straight monthly decline in March, dropping 5.4 percent to an annual rate of 1.4 million units, the Commerce Department announced last week. Applications for building permits fell 13.7 percent to an annual rate of 1.22 million, the lowest in more than six years. Four experts give their views on what the figures mean. John Savacool Economist, WEFA Group Inc., a market research firm.

title: For U.S., a Determining Afghan Role
description: The Pakistani military dependence on American arms and money for the Afghan rebels gives the United States a determining role, even if the tactical decisions and coordination are Pakistan's province.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Eight Men Out 1988. Orion Home Video. 1 hour, 59 minutes. $89.98. Laser disk (Image Entertainment), $39.95. Closed captioned. PG. It's 1919 and the Series is fixed in John Sayles's film about the Black Sox scandal. Moving well beyond baseball, Mr. Sayles projects ''an amazingly full and heartbreaking vision of the dreams, aspirations and disillusionments of a nation, as filtered through its national pastime.'' (Janet Maslin) Cocktail 1988. Touchstone Home Video. 1:43. $89.95. LD, $29.95. CC. R. Tom Cruise is Brian Flanagan, a fast-talking, ice cube-juggling bartender in an ''inane'' romantic drama that only another bartender could love. Mr. Cruise ''doesn't act the role of Brian. . . He visits it with a certain amount of good humor.'' (Vincent Canby) The Last Angry Man 1959. RCA-Columbia Pictures Home Video. 1:40. $69.95. Black and white. Not rated. Paul Muni plays a septuagenarian doctor from Brooklyn who takes on television and Madison Avenue in this sentimental treatment of Gerald Green's novel. Muni, wrote one reviewer, ''knows all the bold and subtle ways of bringing an interesting, robust character to glowing theatrical life.'' Things Change 1988. RCA-Columbia. 1:45. $89.95. LD, $34.95. CC. PG. Wise guys populate David Mamet's film about a Chicago shoeshine man named Gino (Don Ameche) who, for certain pecuniary considerations, agrees to confess to a mob murder he didn't commit. In need of tutoring before turning himself in, Gino takes instruction from Jerry (Joe Mantegna) at a Lake Tahoe resort, where Gino is mistaken for a don of dons, the ''guy behind the guy behind the guy.'' Mr. Mantegna is ''brilliantly funny;'' Mr. Ameche has ''great comic aplomb.'' (Canby) Running on Empty 1988. Warner Home Video. 1:56. $89.95. LD, $24.98 CC. PG-13. Having blown up a laboratory during their days as campus radicals, Arthur (Judd Hirsch) and Annie (Christine Lahti) Pope are still on the run, their two children in tow, in Sidney Lumet's film about fugitives whose lives are constantly uprooted, often at a moment's notice. Stagy and threadbare at times, the story still has a ''lot more momentum than the title suggests.'' (Maslin) In a Lonely Place 1950. RCA/Columbia. 1:33. Warner. 1:37. $89.95. LD, $24.98. CC. PG. As Dixon Steele, a quick-tempered and violent Hollywood writer suspected of murder, Humphrey Bogart, in the words of a critic at the time, ''moves flawlessly through a script that is almost as flinty as the actor himself.'' Callous and vicious when in a bad mood, Steele turns ''tender and considerate under the influence of love,'' which isn't often, even with the ''satiny blonde'' Gloria Grahame. Clara's Heart 1988. Warner. 1:48. $89.95. LD, $24.98. CC. PG-13. Clara (Whoopi Goldberg) does such a good job as a cheerful maid for a rich white couple on vacation in Jamaica that they install her as cook and bottle washer back home in Baltimore. Laundress and sage, Clara is stellar with the housework and as adviser to the couple's son, David (well played by Neil Patrick Harris). Ms. Goldberg is ''virtually the only actress who could turn Clara from an affront into a likable heroine.'' (Canby)

title: Seeking a Job In Midlife
description: Mr. Cuce's article was a most amusing piece - timely, topical and thorough. Now, he must start working on a ''great American satire'' as he has the imagination for it. And he's right! Cats do furrow brows at things - they're absolutely human too. BARBARA SCOTT JORDAN Harrington Park

title: IS COMPETENCE ENOUGH?
description: Your article on the Kennedy School of Government sheds much light on what's gone wrong, not just there, but also at the Harvard Business School (''Is Competence Enough?'' by J. Anthony Lukas, March 12). In both places, a perceived need for ''academic rigor'' that will ''compel respect'' has led to the formulation of ever more sharply reductionist theories of human affairs. Those who aspire to become educated leaders, in either the public sector or the private, might better spend their time reading Gibbon and Thucydides. JOHN F. HELLEGERS Jenkintown, Pa.

title: Linda S. Veith Is Engaged To Bruce William Glover
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Charles J. Veith and Karen MacDonald Veith, both of Wilmington, Del., of the engagement of their daughter Linda Susan Veith to Bruce William Glover, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Thomas Glover of Rowayton, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who Is The M.V.P. In the N.B.A.?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE DAY OF CREATION, by J. G. Ballard. (Collier/ Macmillan, $7.95.) In parched Central Africa, an obsessed British doctor achieves his dream of creating a third Nile. ''Mr. Ballard constructs a moody and well-modeled landscape with as fine a writerly intelligence as we might hope for,'' Samuel R. Delany said here last year. CAPOTE: A Biography, by Gerald Clarke. (Ballantine, $12.95.) Truman Capote was born in a New Orleans hotel to a Southern beauty whose husband, a con artist, wouldn't let her get an abortion. His career peaked while he was still in his 40's with his tour de force of New Journalism, ''In Cold Blood.'' Then his life fell into a sad, drug-sodden decline. In this biography ''nothing, nothing at all, was left out,'' Molly Haskell said here last year. Gerald Clarke ''makes us take a longer look at Capote than I, for one, ever thought I wanted to take, and the result is mesmerizing.'' THE BEGINNER'S BOOK OF DREAMS, by Elizabeth Benedict. (Bantam, $8.95.) Esme, the main character in Elizabeth Benedict's second novel, begins her life of love and squalor with parents a lot like Capote's, but she manages to overcome the handicap. This is ''a bold, expressive view of growing up absurd in New York City in the 1960's and early 70's,'' Cathy A. Colman said here last year. IRON DESTINIES, LOST OPPORTUNITIES: The Post-War Arms Race, by Charles R. Morris. (Carroll & Graf, $13.95.) In his history of the arms race, Charles R. Morris reminds readers that both sides of the equation of mutual assured destruction had reason to be paranoid. Last year our reviewer, Solly Zuckerman, said the ''narrative flows easily, providing a well-balanced picture of the political ups and downs that have been the background of the arms competition of the past few decades.'' FORTY STORIES, by Donald Barthelme. (Penguin, $7.95.) When this collection of stark, surreal stories was published in 1987, our reviewer, Caryn James, said they ''follow the emotional logic of a dream. . . . Donald Barthelme is the author who discovers small, bizarre conjunctions that make enormous sense and offers them in a voice that remains uniquely rewarding and often sounds ageless.'' THE PARIS EDITION: 1927-1934, by Waverley Root. Edited by Samuel Abt. (North Point, $9.95.) Though its contributors and employees included the likes of Henry Miller, James Thurber, William L. Shirer, Ford Madox Ford and Kay Boyle, the Paris edition of The Chicago Tribune was not a particularly good newspaper. What was important, in the recollection of Waverley Root, the paper's book editor, was living among the Left Bank literati of the 1920's. In 1987, The Times's John Gross called the book ''consistently civilized and amusing.'' THE KNOCKOUT ARTIST, by Harry Crews. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) An ex-boxer becomes a freak show star when he discovers that he has the uncanny ability to knock himself unconscious. Last year our reviewer, Christopher Lehmann-Haupt, said that the book was a bit too cute but that he was taken in by ''its offbeat characters, its knowing dialogue and its exhilarating changes of pace.'' IN SEARCH OF NEW YORK, edited by Jim Sleeper. (Transaction/Rutgers University, $19.95.) Thirty-seven essays by writers who include Irving Howe, Marshall Berman and Ada Louise Huxtable describe what has gone wrong with New York City. In 1987, The Times's Sam Roberts said this collection, originally published as a special issue of the quarterly Dissent, contains essays of ''depth and thoughtfulness.'' HARD RAIN, by Peter Abrahams. (Onyx/New American Library, $4.50.) When Jessie's daughter, Kate, disappears with her ex-husband, a studio musician, she tracks them to the ends of the earth - the original site of the Woodstock festival. This thriller about the death of the 60's has ''style, atmosphere and a surprising plot,'' William J. Harding said here last year. THE MAN WITH NO ENDORPHINS: And Other Reflections on Science, by James Gorman. (Penguin, $6.95.) If it is true that the brain makes endorphins, or natural opiates, then why do they desert us when we are most in need, asks James Gorman in his collection of ruminations about science. ''Whether you are the sort of person who studies mosquitoes or the sort who swats them, this is funny stuff,'' Roger B. Swain said here in 1988. THE BRIDE OF THE WILDERNESS, by Charles McCarry. (Signet/New American Library, $4.95.) Leaving behind 18th-century London and a dastardly pursuer, young Fanny Harding flees for the American hinterlands, where she takes up with a dashing French soldier. Last year The Times's John Gross said that ''it is almost as though Mr. McCarry had deliberately set out to prove that it is still possible to write for intelligent adults in the spirit of Scott or Dumas or James Fenimore Cooper.'' MOTHERS OF INVENTION. From the Bra to the Bomb: Forgotten Women & Their Unforgettable Ideas, by Ethlie Ann Vare and Greg Ptacek. (Quill/Morrow, $8.95.) The unsung heroines of this gallery of women inventors include Catherine Littlefield Greene, who helped Eli Whitney invent the cotton gin, and Bette Nesmith Graham, the inventor of Liquid Paper. ''It's a fascinating and gratifying book,'' Nicole Hollander said here last year. ''It's a book not to be read all at once, but to be dipped into, to be shown to your friends and your kids and to be applied lightly to the knuckles of those who ignore the contribution of innovative women.''

title: PERSPECTIVES: South Street Seaport; The Search for an 'Appropriate' Design
description: FOR six years a succession of architects has been trying to design a building for a large vacant site in the South Street Seaport Historic District that the Landmarks Preservation Commission would find appropriate for its setting.

title: Drilling Plan Points Up Questions On Oil and Wilderness in Alaska
description: Here at the north coast of the North American continent, where the dividing line between frozen tundra and frozen sea is covered by an unbroken blanket of snow, a vast industrial development squats incongruously in the nearly featureless landscape. It is America's largest oilfield, with a strategic importance that is tremendous but an environmental effect that has not been gauged.

title: Ruth Ann Fowler Marries G. K. Brazill Jr., a Dentist
description: Ruth Ann Fowler, a manager in the marketing group of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and Dr. George Kingsley Brazill Jr., a dentist, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Frank Goodwin officiated.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Any Catch to Couscous? Just Set the Table Fast
description: Americans are just catching on to couscous. At a supermarket in Pittsburgh recently, samples of a couscous dish were given away, and within half an hour customers had cleared the shelves of couscous. The market had been offering it for years, but most cooks hadn't known out what to do with it until the demonstration.

title: Albany Budget a Relief To Advocates of the Poor
description: Advocates for children and the poor, who were aghast at Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed state budget, are now expressing a sense of relief as they examine details of the $47 billion budget adopted by the Legislature last week.

title: THE BIG, BIG SHOW OF WITTMAN AH SING
description: TRIPMASTER MONKEY His Fake Book. By Maxine Hong Kingston. 340 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: And So to Bed
description: THE IDEA SEEMS SIMPLE: PUT THE VEGETA-bles under the meat instead of beside it. Cooks from all over are playing with this notion by building dishes on beds of vegetables. The piled-up presentation is handsome and sculptural, and a departure from the flat sauce paintings of nouvelle cuisine. But this is more than a mere presentation device. The resulting dishes have a big, intense flavor but no trace of heaviness.

title: British Astronomers Look to U.S., Not Stars
description: Britain, which produced such stellar astronomers as Edmund Halley, Arthur Eddington and James Jeans, is in danger of losing the next generation of stargazers to Government penny-pinching, according to the Astronomer Royal.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: FAST FORWARD;
ROCK REPLAYS A FEW OF ITS GREAT GIGS
description: LEAD: New rock releases are plentiful this month. ''John Lennon and the Plastic Ono Band: Live Piece in Toronto, 1969'' is Lennon's first appearance with the band that included Eric Clapton, Klaus Voorman and Alan White. The well-known rock documentarian D. A. Pennebaker directed.

title:
MUSIC;
Trumpet Concerto To Have Premiere
description: LEAD: A TRUMPET concerto composed by Joseph Turrin of Clifton was the only work commissioned by the New York Philharmonic for the 1988-89 season. Unlike some contemporary works that are completed with no particular performer in mind, Mr. Turrin's concerto came about as the result of a long friendship and working partnership with the trumpet soloist Philip Smith of Montclair.

title: Warriors Talking To Soviet Star
description: Sharunas Marchulionis, a Soviet basketball star, is discussing a contract with the Golden State Warriors and could be playing for the National Basketball Association club next season, a Soviet newspaper reported.

title: A Father's Census Reveals A 97 Teddy-Bear Population
description: I TOOK a census the other morning. Six months after moving, I noticed the corners of our new house beginning to narrow. Someone or something, it seemed, was maneuvering to supplant me. Having just gone into hock to the tune of half the gross national product of Burundi to escape that feeling, I called the family together and took an informal head count.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The Greatest Fighter Of All Time?
description: Ali's detractors are fond of saying that the only thing he lacked was the big punch. This did not prevent him from knocking out the biggest punchers of his day: Sonny Liston, twice, George Foreman, Joe Frazier. Ali was the fastest, smartest, most innovative fighter who fought brilliant defensively and had a jaw for the ages. FRED YANNANTUONO Jr. Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Atheneum Show Draws From Insurance Company's Collection
description: FOUNDED in 1866, the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company was a pioneer in enlightened underwriting that emphasized industrial safety. But as a collector of 19th-century art, the company has been less adventurous, having started late, in 1978, and having confined itself to the work of Connecticut artists.

title: MALE BONDING HAS A FUTURE
description: DREAMS OF DISTANT LIVES By Lee K. Abbott. 206 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: ''People Are Really In a Fishing Mood''
description: THE fishing season, which opened last weekend, is the busiest time of year for George J. Babey. He is the director of the Aquatic Resources Education program of the State Department of Environmental Protection in Hartford, where he trains volunteers who teach classes in more than a dozen cities and towns around the state on where and how to fish. He also inspects the fishing conditions at streams and lakes in the state.

title: Alison Good Wed To Douglas Ross
description: Alison Hovey Good, the daughter of Allen Hovey Good of Summit, N.J., and the late Catherine Campbell Fay, was married yesterday to Douglas Miller Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lamb Ross Jr. of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Dr. John Bell, a Congregationalist minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Summit.

title: Things Happened When Jazz Got on Screen
description: Film and jazz are no strangers, dating back - if one takes liberties with the word jazz - to Al Jolson in the 1927 movie ''The Jazz Singer.'' Lately a spate of films have focused squarely on jazz (''Let's Get Lost,'' '' 'Round Midnight'' and ''Bird''), but between Jolson and ''Bird,'' jazz has made the odd appearance, sometimes in a starring role, sometimes as atmospheric seasoning.

title: THE $700 MILLION UNDERSTANDING
description: IRRECONCILABLE DIFFERENCES Ross Perot Versus General Motors. By Doron P. Levin. Illustrated. 357 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $18.95.

title: 'Soda' Upstages 'Pop,' But Enough is Enough
description: HAVING never before set foot in New England, I experienced a bit of culture shock when I was uprooted from my native Ohio and transplanted on short notice to Connecticut a dozen years ago.

title: Verbatim; Dreaming of Riches
description: 'If this thing is what they think it is, it's better than the gold rush.' - Norman H. Bangerter, Governor of Utah, speculating on what could happen to his state's economy if the breakthrough in fusion research reported by researchers at the University of Utah turns out to be real.

title: In the Movies
description: THE NEW YORK WE SEE IN MOVIES - ground zero for so many different forms of striving - is a place of ever-changing images. One decade's all-white Park Avenue penthouse may connote the same thing as another era's sleek black corporate command center; yesterday's star-struck hoofer on 42d Street may be today's tough young hopeful in a talent-packed urban high school. Though power and glory are at the heart of so many New York-based film fantasies and fierce, flamboyant individuality is central to so many others, these things manifest themselves with new energy and exuberance for each new age.

title: For That Slouchy New Look, Try Cross-Shopping
description: It probably started when Eve borrowed Adam's fig leaf, this idea of women wearing men's clothes. But this century has probably seen more of what in the 1970's was dubbed androgynous dressing than any in history. Think of Marlene Dietrich and Coco Chanel wearing pants, of Rosie the Riveter in men's overalls, of Diane Keaton in the movie ''Annie Hall.'' Now that trend has come around again.

title: Right to Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble for Canseco
description: The way Dave Parker sees it, ''when it happens to Joe Blow or Charlie Tuna, it's no big deal.'' But it was neither Joe Blow nor Charlie Tuna who, as the police tell it, left a loaded pistol on the floor by the driver's seat of a locked car parked on a San Francisco college campus. The auto was in full view of any passer-by curious enough to wonder what a millionaire athlete's $75,000 customized candy-apple-red Jaguar looks like up close.

title: The Bravos Confirm What a Difference a Shell Makes
description: FOR three years, one prominent group of people at concerts in Theater A at the State University of New York's campus here could not hear the music - the musicians themselves.

title: Review/Opera; Pavarotti and Battle in Met 'Elisir'
description: Except for three passages, Nemorino in ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' is nearly a perfect role for Luciano Pavarotti, who sang it at the Metropolitan Opera Friday night in the season's first performance of the work. It doesn't overtax the stamina or volume of his voice (both were more than ample Friday); it isn't too high; it benefits from his lively, pointed diction, and it gives generous opportunities for both of his strongest traits as an actor - clowning and simple pathos. He mugged with relish but was almost never excessive, and he was believable and touching at the moment when poor Nemorino's hopes topple in the first finale.

title: Suzanne Davis Bride Of Jerome J. Cincotta

Cincotta of Burlington, Vt. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Davis of Purchase, N.Y., and Quogue, L.I. The Very Rev. Thomas E. Davis, an uncle of the bride, officiated.
