title: Space Missile Shield Plan, Year to Year
description: The following is a history of the proposed antimissile weapon system: March 23, 1983 - President Ronald Reagan calls for long-term development of military technology that would render nuclear missiles ''impotent and obsolete.'' He envisions weapons to intercept and destroy enemy missiles before they can reach the United States. Jan. 6, 1984 - Mr. Reagan authorizes research on an antimissile system. The Administration contends the directive does not violate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty with the Soviet Union because it involves only research. Jan. 21, 1984 - The Air Force conducts its first test of a missile to destroy satellites. Feb. 1, 1984 - Mr. Reagan's annual budget seeks $2 billion for a long-term program to develop the antimissile system. Dec. 20, 1984 - Robert C. McFarlane, Mr. Reagan's national security adviser, says plans for the system will be ''on the table'' when negotiators meet for arms talks in early 1985. Feb. 4, 1985 - Mr. Reagan's budget seeks $3.7 billion for research on the system. April 24, 1985 - American officials say Soviet hostility to the system is responsible for a lack of progress at arms control talks. Sept. 17, 1985 - Mr. Reagan says the United States will not negotiate a limit on the system in exchange for Soviet concessions on nuclear weapons. Sept. 24, 1985 - The Congressional Office of Technology Assessment says the system does ''not appear feasible'' and could increase the risk of a nuclear war. Oct. 6, 1985 - Mr. McFarlane says research, testing and development of the system are permitted under the ABM Treaty and ''only deployment is foreclosed.'' Feb. 5, 1986 - Mr. Reagan's budget seeks $4.8 billion for the system, up from the $2.7 billion Congress provided in 1986. July 25, 1986 - Mr. Reagan says he will never let the system become ''a bargaining chip'' in arms negotiations. But Administration officials say he offered to delay deployment in exchange for Soviet agreement to reduce nuclear weapons. Oct. 12, 1986 - A meeting between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev breaks down over the system. Jan. 5, 1987 - Mr. Reagan seeks $5.8 billion for the system, more than 60 percent above the amount Congress allotted for 1987. Nov. 12, 1987 - Frank C. Carlucci 3d, Mr. Reagan's nominee for Secretary of Defense, says the Administration has not decided on early deployment of the system. Nov. 24, 1987 - Defense Department officials confirm a plan to conduct the first test of a laser weapon in space in the early 1990's. Feb. 18, 1988 - Mr. Reagan's budget seeks $4.6 billion for the system, up from the $3.5 billion Congress granted for 1988. Oct. 6, 1988 - The Defense Department announces a plan to halve the number of space-based weapons in the system's first phase, reducing that stage's cost to $69 billion from the $115 billion first projected. Feb. 9, 1989 - In a speech to Congress, President Bush says he ''will vigorously pursue'' the antimissile program. April 23, 1989 - Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says fiscal pressures have forced the Administration to cut the system envisioned by Mr. Reagan substantially.

title: Winds Fan Colorado Wildfires
description: Firefighters mopped up a series of forest and brush fires today while a third straight day of record high temperatures and gusty winds helped increase the danger of fires across Colorado. Since Friday, five fires had broken out in the region from Pikes Peak, west of Colorado Springs, to Boulder County, northwest of Denver. They were reported contained or near containment today, and had caused no injuries or structural damage.

Videotapes Have Tips for New Sailors and Old
description: MAKING a mistake on a boat can get you into trouble - far more than with most other sports. If you hit a golf ball the wrong way, the ball may land in a sand trap. But if you steer a boat the wrong direction, you and the boat may end up on the rocks. Videotapes can reduce that risk by showing you what to expect before you leave the dock. Right and wrong is shown graphically through the eye of a camera.

title: Critic's Notebook; Commerical TV Gets Commerical Threats
description: The reappearance of threats to boycott television advertisers has brought little response from defenders of the First Amendment. To take a celebrated recent example, if Terry Rakolta, the 41-year-old mother from Bloomfield Hills, Mich., who made page 1 last month by causing several sponsors to stop buying time on a popular sitcom, had mounted a boycott against a book or a movie that displeased her, she would have been met by counterprotests, with the usual consequence of increased book sales or lines at the box office.

title: Flyers Even Series With the Penguins

With a deadly combination of opportunism and physical punishment, Philadelphia pounded out a 4-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight to even the teams' Patrick Division final series at two games apiece.

title: Two Trials for Speaker Wright; Don't Cut Corners in the Ethical Court
description: Speaker Jim Wright now pleads for swift justice from the House Ethics Committee that has accused him of financial abuses. He's unlikely to get it. One explanation is that the committee wishes to conduct its ethical trial punctiliously, without cutting procedural corners. The second is that the committee sits in judgment only in the ethical trial. The country, meanwhile, sits in judgment as a political trial also unfolds. Can he get a fair ethical trial in so heated a political climate?

title: Abbey Theater Chief Quits
description: Vincent Dowling has resigned as artistic director of the Abbey Theater. Mr. Dowling is the fourth artistic director of Ireland's most famous theater to resign in the last four years. Question Box
description: Baseball on Grass Q. Are there more baseball stadiums with natural grass in the American League than in the National League? A. Naturally, and one reason is because the American League has 14 teams, 2 more than the National. The advantage is more lopsided than that, though, because 10 American League teams play on grass and only 6 National teams do so. That leaves only four American League teams on artificial grass and six National League teams on the unnatural stuff. Looked at another way, even though there are two more stadiums in the American League, there are two more artificial surfaces in the National.

title: Reviews/Music; The Sunny Personality of Al Jarreau

As a ballad singer, he carries forward the tradition of Johnny Mathis by way of George Benson. As an improviser, he is an arsenal of sound effects who especially enjoys imitating funk bass lines and the clicks and snaps of Brazilian percussion instruments.

title: Two Trials for Speaker Wright; There's Much to Judge in the Political Court
description: Speaker Wright's transgressions on behalf of bankrupt savings and loan associations in Texas surely compounded the eventual cost of bailing out the industry. Even so, the House Ethics Committee says, he broke no rules. Indeed, no rules control the insidious mix of politics and money that brought on the industry's crisis. Jim Wright was not the only player in this rotten game, but when the Speaker of the House relentlessly bullies regulators on behalf of undeserving constituents, he bears a special responsibility.

description: The House of Representatives is beginning to resemble the court of a wounded king. The lords and chamberlains gather ever closer 'round their bleeding leader, to best keep an eye on him and each other.

description: b-Included a gain of $1,484,000 from an accounting change.

title: Another Book by Koch: This Time, It's Letters
description: Less than two months after the appearance of his third book, Mayor Edward I. Koch has largely completed and already sold his fourth, a collection of his letters that Simon & Schuster plans to publish next year.

title: BLACKS DISCUSSING ROUTES TO POWER
description: Winning elective office has not brought blacks sufficient power, representatives from around the nation said over the weekend as they grappled with solutions to the social problems facing blacks.

title: Alfred J. Cawse, 80, Criminal Court Judge
description: Alfred J. Cawse, a New York City Criminal Court judge from 1953 to 1972, died of a heart attack on Friday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 80 years old and had lived in Staten Island until he moved to Pittsfield last year.

title: No. 1 Whistle Blower Derides Deficit Figures
description: The Bush Administration and members of Congress may have been impressed by their recent plan to to keep next year's budget deficit under $100 billion, but to the Government's independent auditor, the accord is almost a sham.

description: b-After a tax credit of $3,155,000.

title: Mentor Graphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Music; Peri's 'Euridice' Is Performed by the Bel Canto Opera
description: Jacopo Peri's ''Euridice'' of 1600 is one of the earliest musical entertainments that can properly be called an opera, and the very first for which a complete score survives. ''Complete'' must be understood in the context of the period, though: Peri's score covers the libretto from start to end, but it consists only of voice parts, with one line indicating the instrumental bass, throughout.

title: Test Case for a Crackdown on Animal Drugs
description: The Federal Government has conducted a five-year investigation aimed at breaking up a nationwide black market in toxic drugs that it says contaminated beef, pork and milk.

title: Quayle in the Spotlight: A New Model for No. 2
description: After last November's election, Dan Quayle started shopping at Arthur Adler's, George Bush's favorite men's store, for a tuxedo and some conservative suits. He began describing himself in interviews as a spontaneous sort of person who liked to add off-the-cuff events to his schedule.

title: Webb, Del reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Review/Concert; Living Colour Breaks Racial and Rock Stereotypes
description: By the time Living Colour's sold-out set wound down to a graceful conclusion on Saturday night at the Ritz, it had stormed through music by Led Zeppelin, Tracy Chapman and James Brown, as well as through its own oversized, muscular version of arena rock: all music was the group's territory, it seemed to be saying. And the band played it all to a wildly appreciative, protean audience that spent the evening swarming around the stage.

title: American League; Ryan Comes Close To No-Hitter No. 6
description: Nolan Ryan came within two outs of his sixth career no-hitter, losing it when Nelson Liriano tripled in the ninth inning today as the Texas Rangers beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-1.

title: First Round Holds Some Surprises
description: Troy Aikman, the U.C.L.A. quarterback, gripped a Dallas jersey with No. 8 stitched on it and talked about the pressures of leading the Cowboys, who were 3-13 last season, ''to the promised land.''

title: Newspaper Deal in Italy Stirs Debate Over Press Freedom
description: The compact, chatty, self-absorbed world of Italian journalism was jolted when the industrialist and financier Carlo de Benedetti struck a deal this month that gives him control over two of the country's most influential publications, the daily newspaper La Repubblica and its sister weekly magazine, L'Espresso.

title: Official Says Youths Admit Role in Attack
description: Seven of the eight youths charged in the beating and gang rape of a jogger in Central Park have made incriminating statements about their involvement in the attack, a prosecutor said at their arraignment yesterday.

title: Place Resources Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included writedowns of investments and property of $848,163. c-Net income. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Hawkins, Yanks Shut Down Indians
description: The man with the $3.6 million contract knew that New York was a tough town to please. He had pitched in the Bronx once this season, but neither the reviews nor the results evoked cheers. The patrons, instead, were growing restless.

title: Czechoslovak Band That Suffered for Its Art
description: The Plastic People of the Universe did not plan to risk their lives for their music. Like countless other bands formed in 1968, they just wanted to play rock-and-roll and dress as they pleased. But the Czechoslovak Government saw the Plastic People's independence as dissent and by treating the band with increasing harshness turned it into an underground legend.

title: Noranda Forest reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures have been restated for an accounting change. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: John M. Joyce, 80, Ex-Beverage Executive
description: John M. Joyce, retired chairman of Joyce Beverages Inc. and a prominent Roman Catholic layman and philanthropist, died yesterday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: Agency on Foreign Takeovers Wielding Power
description: For most of its 14 years, the interagency committee that assesses the effect of foreign investments on national security was widely viewed as a paper tiger. But last week, the tiger bared its teeth.

description: At least 47 people were arrested near Pushkin Square in Moscow today as Soviet riot troops broke up a meeting commemorating the deaths of 20 people at a demonstration in Soviet Georgia two weeks ago.

title: The Knicks vs. the Sixers; Ewing Finally at Ease In a Celebrity Setting
description: THE first thing you notice is the smile, something that Patrick Ewing once took out to the public about as often as his college basketball team won a major championship.

description: The Boston Celtics, who had won nine Atlantic Division championships and three National Basketball Association titles since the arrival of Larry Bird for the 1979-80 season, had to go to their regular-season finale yesterday to clinch a playoff spot.

description: MAKE space in your basement for your magazines, because in the not-too-distant future each will be a one-of-a-kind collector's item.

description: Jacques Delors, president of the European Community's executive branch, shares one ambition with his close friend, President Francois Mitterrand of France: to build grandiose monuments by which to be remembered.

description: AS raiders go, the least likely ones are perhaps those now trying to buy a California-based real estate investment trust. The bidders, who have begun a tender offer and will move this week to throw out the management of the trust, are two public pension funds from Detroit.

description: Drug abuse grants totaling $118.8 million will be distributed to the 50 states, five territorial governments and the District of Columbia, the Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh, announced today.

title: Giamatti Notes Cooperation
description: Baseball's investigation of Pete Rose continues in secret, but in one highly unusual development that has become public, the baseball commissioner has interceded for a Cincinnati man awaiting sentencing on cocaine trafficking and tax evasion charges.

description: Patricia Neary, a former soloist of the New York City Ballet, has been named artistic director of Ballet British Columbia. The appointment will be effective July 1.

For its inaugural season, the 16-voice chamber choir is singing three programs at Merkin Concert Hall. The second was offered on Saturday evening.

title: Newspapers Ponder Electronic Rivals
description: When the nation's newspaper pub-lishers gather today in Chicago for their annual convention, talk in the corridors is as apt to be about electronic publishing and competition with the phone companies as about the perennial worries over advertising and circulation.

title: American Ballet Theater Names Executive Director
description: American Ballet Theater will announce today that Jane Hermann has been named executive director. Mrs. Hermann, currently director of presentations for the Metropolitan Opera Association, will assume her new position in September.

title: Kathryn O'Neill And N. C. Katz Wed in Scarsdale
description: Kathryn Mary O'Neill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. O'Neill of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Nicholas Cambas Katz, the son of Dr. Carol Cambas and Sanford M. Katz, both of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Eugene O'Brien performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale.

title: A Double Celebration For Papp and the Bard
description: The works of William Shakespeare and Joseph Papp are to be celebrated on Monday at the City University Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street, from 2:30 to 6 P.M. The university will mark the Bard's 425th birthday by inaugurating its new Shakespeare Institute. Mr. Papp, the founder and producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, is to receive the university's Booth Award.

title: New Delhi Journal; Her Name Is Gandhi, and Animals Are Her Cause
description: When the phone rings at Maneka Gandhi's house, it could be someone looking for a political favor.

title: For City Schools, Election Day Is May 2
description: New Yorkers have an important election to think about long before September's mayoral primaries. It's the May 2 election of community school board members. Voters will choose 288 of them, on 32 local boards. Their choices will test recent school reforms.

He drifted along the sidewalks, without family. He had no friends. Acquaintances saw him go into strange fits and thought him a clown.

description: rrSensory stimulation keeps an exerciser motivated and alleviates boredom, according to John Duke, the inventor of the WaterRower. The only sound the cherrywood rowing machine makes, Duke said, is ''the soothing rush of water keeping time with the natural rhythm of your stroke.''

Rodriguez, has held post since 1973 . . . Current board has two vacancies and, because no member could get the necessary 5 votes, was unable recently to fill posts of president and vice president.

description: Witness to the infancy of the American republic and the prayers that accompanied its creation, St. Paul's Chapel on lower Broadway is about to depart from its tranquil ways and regain momentarily a place at the nation's center.

title: Sports World Specials: Colleges; The Vigilant Eli
description: When it comes to violations of N.C.A.A. rules, some are more overt than others. As a member of the Ivy League, Yale University doesn't have to worry about blatant abuses as much as the well-known football factories, but that doesn't mean Coach Carmen Cozza can let down his guard.

title: Holiday Inn Expansion
description: Two hotels in China are among six new and eight converted hotels added to the Holiday Inn chain in the first quarter of 1989, the chain's parent company announced. The two hotels in Xian and Chongqing give the company a total of five hotels in China, with two more scheduled to open this year. The Holiday Corporation's remaining four new hotels opened in Columbus, Ohio; Lima, Ohio; Decatur, Ga., and Cancun, Mexico. Of the eight hotels converted to Holiday Inns, six are in the United States; one in Ratigen, Germany, and one in Liege, Belgium.

title: Whittle Book Plan Rouses Publishers
description: Without having even a completed manuscript, much less a finished book, Whittle Communications is forcing conventional publishers to rethink some of their ways of doing business.

title: Giants Shore Up The Offensive Line
description: When the Giants got their turn in the first round of the National Football League draft yesterday, it was as if they had found themselves in a candy store.

title: Reviews/Music; Russian Way With Pianism
description: Yin Cheng Zong is Chinese born and bred, but in training, repertory and temperament, he is very much a Russian pianist. Chopin's omnipresent B-flat-minor Sonata had just the kind of familiar firmness, weight and power we expect, for example, of Soviet competition winners. Mr. Yin's performance, in other words, was generic rather than original, and as competent as it was unexceptional. Haydn's Sonata in C (Hob. XVI: 48), on the other hand, suffered from extremes - the opening Andante dragged down to an Adagio and the Presto finale was pushed and hectic.

title: U.S. Feeling Pressure To Cite Japan on Trade
description: The Bush Administration must list Japan as a country engaging in unfair trade practices or it will render new trade legislation ''virtually useless'' and damage relations with Congress, Max Baucus, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's trade subcommittee, said last week.

title: Campaign Matters; Yes, It's Good To Be the Mayor, Sometimes
description: In his movie ''History of the World - Part I,'' Mel Brooks played two roles in the French Revolution episode: King Louis XVI and a lowly servant constantly on the receiving end of royal bile. Given the alternative, and before he lost his head, the Louis character gleefully declared, ''It's good to be the king.''

title: Outdoors: Debate Over No-Kill Fishing Goes On

title: Review/Music; Choral Mozart and Brahms
description: There may be no poetic significance but only coincidence in the fact that Mozart's two great choral works were left unfinished. In the case of the Requiem, nature was Mozart's editor, cutting his life short before the work was ended. The C-minor Mass, on the other hand, was partially done and then seemingly abandoned for more pressing projects.

The police fired dozens of tear gas canisters at the protesters, who numbered about 600. The demonstrators hurled firebombs and rocks at the police, burned an effigy of President Roh Tae Woo and called for the overthrow of the Roh Government.

Review/Music; 3-Concert Ellington Tribute Shows an Endless Range
description: The American Jazz Orchestra's exceptional three-concert tribute to Duke Ellington at Cooper Union underscored several things. First, that the orchestra, in its third year, has become, with its technical excellence and its intelligent programming, an essential part of the city's cultural life, an orchestra that deserves a better home than the uncomfortable and column-ridden hall at Cooper Union. Second, with the immense amount of music covered, it showed Mr. Ellington as a composer with seemingly endless ideas and an optimistic, compassionate world view. And it showed that its conductors - John Lewis, Maurice Peress and Gunther Schuller - can each bring a radically different sensibility to the orchestra.

The NBC News special at 10 tonight treads so carefully that you can't always be sure whether it is inviting controversy or evading it. That is not surprising on so sensitive a subject, but the defensive tone weakens what might have been a daring hour.

Turner said Wilson has not yet met with National Football League security officials to discuss the incident because of offers he has received to sell his story to magazines and book publishers.

Comsat is a publicly traded corporation that provides international, domestic and maritime communications and information services.

title: Three Cheers for Columbus Center Three
description: Good sense has finally emerged on all sides of the controversy over New York City's plan to sell the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle. Opposition reached an emotional peak with demonstrations against the shadows that a huge planned tower would supposedly send deep into Central Park. Such fears now seem allayed by the developer's willingness to re-design, and re-re-design. The building has been reduced from 925 to 752 feet and floor area has been cut almost one-fourth.

title: Hoffmann-La Roche Plans Reorganization
description: F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Company, the $5 billion Swiss drug and chemical concern, said yesterday that it would streamline its structure in what was widely viewed as a step toward attempting a takeover.

title: Market Place; Behind Interest In Michael Foods
description: MICHAEL FOODS' shares are up sharply this year, largely because of hopes that its egg product will sweep the restaurant market by being less cumbersome and more bacteria-resistant than eggs and other egg products.

title: Talking Business with Smith of International Telecharge; Industry Defends Pay-Phone Rates
description: On April 1 the Government began allowing long-distance phone companies to compete for operator-assisted calls made from the nation's 1.6 million pay telephones. More than 200 companies are now competing to be chosen by businesses in an effort to gain access to the $2 billion pay-phone market, in which the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had had a monopoly. Consumers have complained that some competing companies -known as alternative-operator service companies - charge as much as five times what A.T.&T. does. Jim Smith, executive vice president of International Telecharge Inc., one of the largest alternative-operator service companies, recently discussed business practices. Q. Are alternative-operator service companies getting a bad rap or have there been cases of overcharging? A. I am aware of more than one company that has charged excessive rates, but these are the exception rather than the rule. Most of the articles and headlines that accuse this industry of price gouging rely on information that is at least two years old. There have been some incidents but these represent a very small percentage of the calls that the industry carries. The situation is drastically improved compared with a few years ago. Many of the companies that were known for overcharging have gone out of business. Q. But you do charge rates that are higher than A.T.&T.'s. How do you justify this? A. We do not consider A.T.&T.'s prices to be the base-line rate. But the majority of our rates are comparable to A.T.&T.'s prices if not less. In the cases where we do charge more, we are justified because we provide more services and features on our network. We offer operator service in 24 languages, a message-forwarding service, toll-free weather information, discounts on collect calls, teleconferencing, talking Yellow Pages and an electronic concierge that gives local events in the area - all from a pay telephone. We also accept commercial credit cards and give a 5 percent discount on calls billed to a commercial card. Many of these items are free, and to recover our costs we have to charge more. Q. Do consumers want these extra services? A. Yes. Many of the services like message forwarding have been immensely popular. The services allow a caller who receives a busy signal to record a one-minute message that is later forwarded when the line is clear. Services such as these are innovative and result from increased competition. This is why A.T.&T. has been installing new technology in its network. Q. Your company allows businesses to place a surcharge as high as 75 cents on each call made from a pay telephone on the premises.

title: Bette Davis Is Saluted, Spirit and Acid Wit Intact

But for movie fanatics, the real drama was in the anticipation: just what would the volatile Bette Davis say during the awards ceremony?

title: Trail to Charter Revision: Hearings, Meetings, Ballot

title: Q&A
description: Arthritis and Weather Q. Do people with arthritis suffer more joint pain in damp weather? A. ''The answer, of course, is yes and no,'' said Dr. Michael Belmont, a rheumatologist, who is clinical instructor of medicine at New York University School of Medicine.

And outside the gates of the Tamarack Golf Course, 15 cars and vans, red taillights ablaze in the darkness, idle impatiently as their passengers await entry. ''People have parked out there as early as 1:30,'' said Charley King, the golf course's assistant manager.

Indeed, Mr. Williams's Sunday afternoon recital at Avery Fisher Hall might have produced a more pointed effect in a space one-tenth the size. The compensatory electronic amplification was discreet but had the unfortunate tendency to spread the perceived sound source all across the stage. This is no way to appreciate Mr. Williams's undisputed virtues.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Soviet Union in First Place: Valery Shiriayev scored at 7 minutes 4 seconds of the third period as the Soviet Union edged Sweden, 3-2, last night to clinch first place in the preliminary round of the world championships in Stockholm. The Soviets finished the round-robin portion with a 7-0 record. Dale Hawerchuk of the Winnipeg Jets had one goal and one assist as Canada beat Czechoslovakia, 4-2, to finish third with a 5-0-2 won-tied-lost record. The Czechoslovaks were fourth. The final four starts Thursday with the Soviet Union playing Czechoslovakia and Canada facing Sweden.(AP) TENNIS Yugoslav Falls: Goran Ivanisevic, a young star from Yugoslavia, received a rude introduction to the $607,500 Monte Carlo Open as he was beaten by Carl Limberger of Australia, 7-5, 6-4, in the first round yesterday. Ivanisevic, who advanced to the quarterfinals of the Australian Open last January, had made the main draw as a qualifier. A 1988 finalist, Martin Jaite of Argentina, beat a 1987 finalist, Jim Arias of the United States, 7-6, 3-6, 7-5. (AP) HORSE RACING Antley Extends Streak: Chris Antley stretched his Aqueduct riding streak to 60 days when he won the third race yesterday aboard Tis Royal. Antley has won at least one race on every Aqueduct card he has ridden since Feb. 8. Antley will fly to Keeneland in Lexington, Ky., today to ride Dispersal in the Lexington Stakes, one of the last preps for the Kentucky Derby May 6. N.B.A. Trail Blazers In, Barely: The last of 1,025 games provided the last of 16 teams for the playoffs. The Portland Trail Blazers, needing a victory for the Western Conference's eighth post-season berth, got 40 points from Clyde Drexler and defeated the Sacramento Kings, 126-120, in overtime Sunday. Drexler scored 4 points in overtime for the Trail Blazers, who needed to beat Sacramento after Dallas's victory over Denver pulled the Mavericks within a half-game of Portland. Dallas had the edge in a tie breaker because of a better conference record. The Blazers, at 39-43 the only team in the playoffs with a losing reocrd, will face the Lakers on Thursday night. (AP)

title: What's Next for 'Star Wars'? 'Brilliant Pebbles'
description: RAPID advances in the miniaturization of parts for high-technology weapons have allowed the Pentagon to give its ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program a major new emphasis. Instead of focusing exclusively on big, bulky, costly weapons, it would now create swarms of small, cheap, brainy rockets to hurl at enemy missiles with deadly accuracy.

description: William D. MacDowell, a former chief executive of the Burpee seed company, has been named the president of a new venture called Freshworld that hopes to market better-tasting varieties of fresh produce.

title: Pumping of Hudson To Begin Next Week
description: New York City will pump the Hudson River to supplement the city's water supply, a spokesman said yesterday, despite warnings that it could disrupt fish spawning, damage a city reservoir and is not necessary.

title: Party Chief in Soviet Georgia Admits Some Died From Gas
description: The Communist Party leader in the Georgian Republic confirmed today that some of the 20 deaths in nationalist demonstrations here this month were caused by poison gas.

Detroit Journal; The City That Came To Dinner
description: This city so loves to make the eight-cylinder luxury cars that send the message that bigger is better, and so it seems fitting that the biggest civil rights dinner in the country brought together nearly 10,000 Detroiters Sunday in sequined finery, to schmooze and politick and herald the importance of their cause.

title: Campus Battle Pits Freedom of Speech Against Racial Slurs
description: Seeking to curb racial incidents and discriminatory harassment on campus, a growing number of universities are taking steps to restrict forms of expression considered offensive, steps that some opponents believe will infringe on the freedom of intellectual discourse that is at the heart of the university mission.

title: Filenet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
For Next Winter, Coats Will Be Anything but Sober, Dull or Black
description: Everbody needs a winter coat. North of the Mason-Dixon line, a utilitarian outer garment is a necessity three to six months of the year. Utilitarian is the key, for most women do not get too much joy out of this practical article of apparel. If it does not weigh too heavily on the shoulders, if it fits comfortably over other clothes without pinning the arms to the sides - well, that's all one can expect.

title: Fusion May Keep the Continents in Motion
description: THE energy that keeps the continents in motion may come in part from fusion reactions inside the earth, scientists in Utah have proposed.

title: A Doctorate for Tyson
description: Mike Tyson will receive an honorary doctorate in humane letters today from Central State University in Wilberforce, Ohio. ''Mike demonstrates that hard work, determination and perseverance can enable one to overcome any obstacles,'' said Arthur Thomas, the school's president, who cited the heavyweight champion's influence on young people. (AP)

Genuine Parts Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
By Design; The Dark Legs of Summer
description: Come fall, any woman who doesn't sport a pair of opaque, probably ribbed, pantyhose will be left behind. Designers on both continents are suggesting these dense black or deep-toned tights as the major fashion underpinning for every kind of day look and any but the most elaborate evening clothes.

title: Karre Nygaard, 85, Physician and Sculptor
description: Dr. Karre K. Nygaard, a retired surgeon and a sculptor, died of prostate cancer at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 85 years old. Dr. Nygaard, who was a sculptor before he studied medicine at the Royal Frederiks University in Oslo, did his surgical residency at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. In 1940, he opened a private practice in White Plains and began a 40-year affiliation with the White Plains Hospital Center. In 1948, he was made a member of the Special Order of St. Olaf by King Haakon VII of Norway for his humanitarian efforts on behalf of Norwegian merchant seamen.

title: NORTH JURY GETS LARGER QUARTERS
description: The jurors weighing the fate of Oliver L. North today switched to larger quarters for their deliberations after complaining that they needed more room to examine the hundreds of exhibits introduced in the case.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Saturday about the oil spilled from the Exxon Valdez misattributed an assertion that two-thirds of the oil was gone. It was said by Exxon, not by public officials.

description: The District of Columbia's Police Chief, Maurice T. Turner, has submitted his retirement papers and will step down July 31, The Washington Post reported.

title: Lottery's Jackpot $70 Million
description: People have been standing in line to buy a 1-in-9.6-million chance at winning some or all of at least $70 million in the world's biggest lottery jackpot. Pennsylvania Super 7 Lottery tickets sold at a rate of 750,000 an hour over the weekend. The drawing will be Wednesday night. The jackpot would break a record set when four Illinois ticket holders won $69.9 million on April 15.

description: Latest quarter results included 28 cents a share negative impact from regulatory disallowance of $25,000,000 transmission expense.

description: An astronaut scheduled to command a space shuttle flight next year and two high space agency officials announced their resignations today, with two of them citing pending regulations that would have restricted their ability to go to work for aerospace companies.

title: Probation for Cris Carter
description: A Federal judge here today sentenced Cris Carter, a wide receiver for the Philadelphia Eagles, to three years of probation, fined him $15,000 and ordered him to perform 600 hours of community service over the next three years for lying to the grand jury that in 1987 investigated Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, the agents recently convicted of racketeering and mail fraud.

title: Lubrizol Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $8,751,000 from an accounting change.

title: Hedwig Koenig, Pediatrician, 93
description: Dr. Hedwig Koenig, associate professor emeritus of clinical pediatrics at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died April 14 at her home in Pennswood Village, Newtown, Pa. She was 93 years old.

title: Gan Attack: Unusual for Its Viciousness
description: The random, apparently motiveless rampage in Central Park last week that the suspects in the case called wilding was an especially ferocious version of group delinquency that is common but usually not so vicious, law-enforcement officials and psychologists said this week.

title: Oriole Homes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Eastern Airlines' management outlined a plan to turn the carrier into a one-third smaller airline with an Atlanta hub, without waiting for an end to a seven-week strike. [ Page D1. ] As expected, NWA's directors rejected Marvin Davis's $90-a-share offer. [ D9. ] NCNB ended its efforts to merge with Citizens and Southern, after being rebuffed by the Atlanta banking company. [ D1. ] I.B.M. raised its quarterly dividend by 10 percent, to $1.21 a share, the first increase in five years. [ D1. ] Sears, Roebuck had an 80.7 percent jump in net income of its merchandising group in the first quarter, helped by its new low-price policy. [ D1. ] First Boston said it would lay off about 200 employees this week in the final step of a downsizing. [ D4. ] Boeing reported increased earnings and revenues and said it was increasing its dividend to 45 cents a share, from 40 cents, and splitting its stock, 3 for 2. [ D9. ] Northrop seemed to take in stride the Defense Department's decision to delay purchases of B-2 bombers. [ D9. ] Three-quarters of property owners with pay telephones have chosen to keep A.T.& T. as their long-distance company. [ D2. ] Exxon's first-quarter earnings declined 12.7 percent, to $1.27 billion, or 99 cents a share. [ D6. ] Union Carbide and Monsanto reported higher income. Union Carbide's net was up 99 percent; Monsanto's rose 5.7 percent. [ D7. ] G.M. and Ford are trimming production for the next six months in an effort to reduce bloated inventories. [ D5. ] Hoffmann-La Roche will streamline its structure in what was widely viewed as a step toward attempting a takeover. [ D5. ] Gateway, the target of a hostile $2.9 billion bid, has been approached by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts. [ D4. ] Ranks Hovis McDougall stunned the Australian stock market with a bid valued at $2.4 billion for Goodman Fielder Wattie. [ D4. ] Three employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert filed a class action, accusing the firm's top managers of breach of contract and violations of their fiduciary duties. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY The Supreme Court will decide whether customer deposits held by public utilities can be taxed as income. [ D19. ] The budget agreement with Congress was among the achievements cited by President Bush in an address to publishers. [ D22. ] MARKETS Stocks slipped lower after recovering from steep early losses brought on by futures-related selling. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 6.78 points, to 2,402.68. [ D10. ] Stocks rose in Tokyo on news that Prime Minister Takeshita would resign. [ D5. ] Prices of Treasury issues were little changed after what many market participants said was the slowest session of the year. [ D16. ] Weekend showers led to a steep selloff of corn and soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade. [ D18. ] The dollar drifted higher against most major currencies. [ D18. ] INTERNATIONAL A U.N. agency challenged the World Bank's view that Africa had begun a fragile but sustainable economic recovery. [ D16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The alternative-operator pay-telephone industry has cleaned house and ended some abuses, says Jim Smith of International Telecharge. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Michael Foods' shares are up sharply, but doubts are growing about its egg product. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D10. ] Waring & LaRosa stands as a testament to the optimism of advertising people. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D22. ]

title: Review/Television; Defining What's Civilized and What's Not
description: There's a battle being waged in television these days and, broadly speaking, it's taking place along ''us versus them'' cultural lines. Depending on your vantage point, the results so far could be interpreted as either democracy taking the offensive or the barbarians pounding on the barricades.

description: Results for the latest quarter included a gain of about $11,000,000, or 6 cents a share, resulting from an agreement between Armstrong and one of its main insurance carriers to settle California litigation involving insurance coverage for asbestos-related claims. The company said earnings declined primarily because of higher interest expense as a result of its acquisition in October of American Olean Tile Co. for about $330,000,000.

title: GIVE CITY COUNCIL INCREASED POWER, NEW YORK IS URGED
description: To replace the Board of Estimate, the chairman of a panel that is rewriting New York City's Charter yesterday proposed a more powerful City Council and a new commission to oversee city-owned land, rule on private owners' requests for zoning changes and award city franchises.

title: Embarrassment in Panama
description: United States policy toward Panama and its strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, has ranged from stupidity to savagery. The Reagan Administration first embraced him as an asset. Then it tried to destroy him with economic sanctions, which the general promptly turned to his advantage. In frustration, Washington hatched the harebrained idea of a military coup - even though civilian democracy was and is the declared centerpiece of U.S. policy in Latin America.

title: International Agencies Split On the Economies of Africa
description: In an unusual public rebuke, a United Nations agency today challenged the World Bank's view that Africa had begun a fragile but sustainable economic recovery because of market-oriented reforms.

description: During the almost seven months it took Al Bianchi to pry Kiki Vandeweghe loose from the Portland Trail Blazers, the Knicks' general manager was continually asked why Vandeweghe was needed since the Knicks were doing so well.

description: It is getting awfully difficult to make a rational case that Easy Goer will not win the 115th Kentucky Derby 11 days hence.

Park Suspects: Children of Discipline
description: The eight adolescents being held in the rape and beating of a jogger in Central Park were bound to each other by ties of neighborhood, rituals of the playground and common rites of passage that began long before the rampage last Wednesday night.

description: The company attributed the decline in earnings to an accounting adjustment.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 A Soviet political purge of 110 holdovers in the top Communist Party leadership was approved by the party, which also promoted two dozen junior leaders. Page A1

description: Edward A. McDonald, who heads the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force in Brooklyn, announced yesterday that he is resigning to join a Manhattan law firm.

title: Zhou Enlai Welcomed Vietnam Escalation
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Overturns F.B.I. Agent's Spying Conviction
description: A Federal appeals court here today overturned the espionage conviction of Richard W. Miller, the only agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ever convicted of spying. The court ruled that the trial judge had erred in admitting extensive testimony on lie-detector examinations that Mr. Miller failed.

title: Citicorp Rates Up
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper rose for the first time in three weeks. The company sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 9.7245 percent, up from 9.65 percent last week, and $50 million in 182-day paper at an average rate of 9.635 percent, up from 9.51 percent.

title: Bob Allen, Bandleader And Singer, Dies at 75
description: Bob Allen, a bandleader and singer, died of throat cancer on Monday at his home in Stockton, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: Rioting in 2 African Nations
description: Troops patrolled the capitals of Senegal and Mauritania today after riots set off by a border incident. Reports from both West African countries said hundreds of shops were looted and many people beaten up by angry crowds armed with iron bars and clubs. No official death toll was available. About 300,000 Mauritanians live in Senegal, one-third in Dakar, the capital, where they dominate the retail trades.

title: Clock Starts for Shuttle and Long-Delayed Mission
description: With a sigh of relief from project managers and a surge of excitement among scientists, the countdown began today for a space shuttle mission that is to dispatch the nation's first planetary expedition in 11 years.

title: Shell Oil reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included about $70 million from a property insurance settlement. c-Included a $35 million gain from accounting changes. Shell Oil is a unit of Royal Dutch- Shell Group.

title: How a Humble Cut Got a Fancy Price
description: ZARELA MARTINEZ, the owner of Zarela's, a Mexican restaurant on Second Avenue, was upset. No, outraged was more like it. She was fuming about the price of skirt steaks for fajitas.

title: School Aides May Sit on Local Boards, Judge Says
description: Less than a week before New York City's school board elections, a Federal judge yesterday struck down a state law prohibiting city school employees, political officeholders and some party officials from serving on the city's school boards.

title: La Petite Academy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Charter Panel Ponders Broad Power For Mayor Over Awarding Contracts
description: The commission rewriting New York City's Charter discussed yesterday giving broad new authority to the mayor over the awarding of $5 billion a year in municipal contracts, while it simultaneously debated how that power should be monitored and limited.

title: Review/Theater; A Family as Symbol of Ireland's Troubles
description: Audiences arriving at Brian Friel's ''Aristocrats'' are all but enfolded within a panorama of lush Irish greenery. The setting, a heaven-sent assignment for the designer John Lee Beatty, is a Georgian mansion in provincial County Donegal. Moss and ivy crawl over every wall; a towering tree spills leaves from above; an expanse of bright lawn flows from the house's exposed parlor to the stage's edge. It is summer, the mid-1970's, and the sun is out.

title: Minorco Drive For Gold Fields
description: On the eve of the deadline for its $4.2 billion takeover bid for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of London, Minorco S.A. yesterday continued to urge Gold Fields stockholders to accept the offer.

title: Paccar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MDU Resources Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lessons
description: As Rodney Dangerfield might put it, liberal arts graduates don't get no respect.

title: 3 Newspaper Companies Report Earnings Declines
description: The Times Mirror Company reported yesterday that its net income fell by 8.5 percent, while the Washington Post Company said its net income was down by 71.3 percent. Knight-Ridder Inc. said its net income was 39.4 percent lower.

title: Jerusalem Post Stake
description: A Canadian company agreed today to buy a controlling interest in The Jerusalem Post newspaper, outbidding some of the world's leading industrialists, the owners said.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Injured
description: The United States closed out the preliminary round of the world hockey championships with a 6-1 victory over Poland yesterday, but John Vanbiesbrouck of the Rangers was taken to a hospital with a suspected broken jaw after being hit by the puck early in the second period.

title: Alleghany Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter is restated for an accounting change.

title: New York Has a Hidden Homeless Population of Broken Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $8,855,000. c-Net loss and after net from discontinued operations of $455,000. Year-ago quarter net from continuing operations included charges of about $2,200,000 for employment termination costs.

title: Jerrico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-After a gain of $5,684,000 from an accounting change. The year-ago 9 months' net from operations included a $1 million charge for litigation settlement.

title: Takeshita Undone by System That He Lived By for So Long
description: When Noboru Takeshita took office as Prime Minister 17 months ago, he brought with him a reputation as the insider's insider, a product of the clubby, arcane world of Japanese politics.

title: Saudi Women Quietly Win Some Battles
description: Elham Mansour al-Dekheil looks at her husband once in a while to seek approval, but hardly waits as she explains that the cause of women in Saudi Arabia must be fought like a guerrilla war, by stealth.

title: Tuition Sit-In Forces City College To Cancel All Classes for a Day
description: The City College of New York canceled classes yesterday as protesting students, concerned about the possibility of tuition increases, continued to occupy the main administration building.

title: First Federal Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago 9 months' results included earnings from the stock conversion date of Sept. 24, 1987.

title: In Quest for Students, Colleges Play Eager Suitors
description: These are the days in the college admissions process when the wooer becomes the wooed.

title: Great American First Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Warning Issued on 2 Heart Drugs After Deaths of Patients in a Test
description: Two drugs used to treat heart rhythm irregularities in more than 200,000 Americans increased the risk of heart attack and death in patients in a major clinical trial, Federal health officials said today.

title: Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflected $11.4 million additional nonrecurring net from the adoption of the new income tax standard, FAS 96. The company is a wholly owned consolidated subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co.

title: About Education
description: Leaders of Britain's schools and universities think they have become a target of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's ''revolution.'' Her education spokesmen say the blueprint is based largely on American models.

title: Cardinal Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain on investment sales of $77,000 and an after-tax gain on the sale of real estate acquired for investment of $54,000. c-Included after-tax gains on investment sales of $356,000. Corrected from yesterday.

title: 'Mastergate,' a Political Satire, Spins a Real-Life Web
description: Call it Satiregate.

description: LEAD: With the Supreme Court preparing to hear arguments today in the Missouri abortion case, the battle in the court of public opinion has never been more intense.

title: Take Arms Against a Sea of Trash, TV Viewers; Captives of the Antenna
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Recital; The Pleasure of Making Old Nuances New
description: Elly Ameling has been a favorite recitalist and recording artist for two decades now; most of her repertory, and her personal way with it, is a familiar pleasure to song audiences. One likes to have familiar pleasures repeated. Part of the satisfaction of Satie's ''Je te veux'' - the Dutch soprano's first encore at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening - was in re-experiencing all the timings and nuances so well known from so many earlier performances.

title: Yields Steady At Banks and On C.D.'s
description: Yields of certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were almost unchanged for the week ended yesterday, with some maturities off for the first time this year.

title: H. Bolton Seed, 66, Expert on Earthquakes
description: H. Bolton Seed, a civil engineer who was an expert in earthquake engineering, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Orinda, Calif. He was 66 years old.

title: Coca-Cola Bottling Company Conolidated reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
West Fraser Timber reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Income at Cray Research Fell 94.3% in First Quarter
description: Cray Research Inc. today reported sharply lower first-quarter earnings and revenues, compared with the comparable period a year ago. Although Cray had predicted a decline, the results were well below Wall Street analysts' estimates, and Cray shares dropped $6.125, to $49, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: Share earnings represent units.

description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing in Business Day yesterday described Adams-Russell Inc. of Waltham, Mass., incorrectly. It is independent, not affiliated with the Cablevision Systems Corporation.

description: The company said 1988 earnings are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Yankees Lose on Base Paths, 5-3
description: The Yankees apparently did not leave their miserable spring of injuries behind them. Tonight, three weeks into the season and with their offense sputtering at regular intervals, they watched another player go down.

title: Milken Trial Set for March
description: The trial of Michael R. Milken, on leave as head of the high-yield ''junk bond'' unit at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., yesterday was tentatively scheduled for March 1, 1990.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

Fuji Bank Plans Financing
description: The Fuji Bank Ltd. of Tokyo, the world's third-largest bank, yesterday announced plans for a three-pronged financing to help it reach the minimum capital levels set by banking regulators.

title: Freeport-McMoran Gold Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Indiana Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
With Karajan Departed, Who'll Lead the Berlin?
description: Herbert von Karajan's resignation on Monday as chief conductor and artistic director of the Berlin Philharmonic was an unsurprising surprise. It was unsurprising given the fragile state of the 81-year-old maestro's health and his hostile relations with the orchestra in recent years.

title: Trans Financial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Kimberly-Clark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The net income in the year-ago first quarter was reduced by a $12.3 million writedown of the company's investment in its South African affiliate.

title: Syracuse Shows Off Scoring Power
description: Rutgers has a credible lacrosse team, one that gave top-ranked Johns Hopkins a close game before losing, 10-6, and won 8 of 11 contests before taking on Syracuse in the Carrier Dome last Saturday.

title: 2 Suspects Are Assaulted in Jail
description: Two of the suspects in the rape and beating of a Central Park jogger were attacked by other inmates at Rikers Island Monday night, the Correction Department said yesterday.

title: Zenith Reports $4 Million Loss
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation today reported a $4 million loss in the first quarter, but the maker of televisions and computers said it still expects a profit this year.

title: Museum Performances
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, Park Avenue and 42d Street, will open its 1989 spring season on May 3 with Performance on 42d, five programs of music, dance and performance art. The series begins with ''Lincoln Speak,'' a dramatic poem with music by Linda Mussman, to be presented at 7:30 P.M. in the public Sculpture Court.

title: German Calls U.S. Talks Amicable
description: Despite dissatisfaction in Washington and London over Bonn's dovish new stance on disarmament, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher insisted today that his talks in Washington had been ''very amicable'' and that the Americans had recognized West Germany's ''special right'' to speak its mind.

title: Microamerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Four-Hitter By Scott Lifts Astros Over Phils
description: Mike Scott pitched a four-hitter and Glenn Davis hit a two-run homer as the Houston Astros beat the Philadelphia Phillies tonight, 4-1.

title: TW Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Post Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $115,700,000, or $8.99 a share, non-recurring gain from the sale of Cellular Telephone interests.

title: Bush and House Panel Chief Back Tough Savings Guides
description: The Bush Administration and the chairman of the House Banking Committee have joined to seek tougher capital standards for the savings industry, Administration officials said today. The Senate adopted such standards last week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Tracy-Locke Resigns Taco Bell Account
description: Tracy-Locke said yesterday that it had resigned the $60 million advertising account of Taco Bell restaurants on Monday evening, and the fast-food chain gave the business to Foote, Cone & Belding Communications. Taco Bell, a subsidiary of Pepsico, had begun reviewing the account in late February and had recently narrowed the competition to Tracy-Locke and Foote, Cone.

title: Hingham Institution for Savngs reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago per share figure not presented as the bank converted from a mutual to a stock form of ownership on Dec. 20, 1988.

description: Revenue for 1988 has been restated to reflect consolidation of previously unconsolidated subsidiaries.

title: Arrow Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $2,046,000 from discontinued operations. The company said share results also reflect payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: Toyota Gets G.M. Approval To Build Trucks in Joint Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation agreed today to expand their joint venture in Fremont, Calif., to allow Toyota to build 100,000 light trucks there starting in 1991.

title: Times Mirror Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $15.3 million from the sales of assets. The company said operating profit in the latest quarter increased 9 percent to $129.6 million.

title: Ohio Casualty reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company in the latest first quarter had investment gains of $6,258,000, compared with investment losses of $6,912,000 for year-ago period.

title: A A P.L.O. Aide Sets Out Conditions for Elections
description: A leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that Palestinian leaders had accepted Israel's proposals for elections in the occupied territories if they were part of an overall settlement.

title: Homestead Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and reflected pretax charges of $11.3 million, mainly from writedowns on its mortgage servicing portfolio.

title: Nucor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
WASHINGTON TALK: THE CAPITAL
description: Twenty years ago this month, the Republican in the White House, Richard M. Nixon, told his staff in a memorandum that he wanted ''a very effective, affirmative program covering speeches, television appearances, etc., pointing with pride with regard to what the first 100 days have really accomplished.''

title: Quaker Oats Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter net results included a $20,700,000 charge for European pet foods manufacturing consolidation.

title: Fuqua Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $4,392,000 income from discontinued operations. The company said the year-ago quarter included a gain of $68,803,000, or $2.93 fully diluted, resulting from the combination of Fuqua's photo finishing operation with the domestic photo-finishing operations of the Eastern Kodak Co.

title: Large Profit Is Reported By Texaco
description: A restructured Texaco Inc. yesterday posted a huge increase in profits for the first quarter, and analysts said that after adjustments for numerous one-time factors were made, its income from continuing operations was very promising.

title: WINE TALK
description: CHAMPAGNE POMMERY, of Reims, France, one of the best-known names in the Champagne business, has acquired a majority interest in Scharffenberger Cellars, a producer of premium sparkling wines in Philo, Calif., according to John Scharffenberger, founder and president of the winery. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

title: Banta, George reports earnings for 13wk to March 31
description: The latest sales increased included $52,349,000 from an acquisition which was accounted for as a purchase effective April 1, 1988.

title: School Board Vote
description: New Yorkers are to elect 32 local school boards next Tuesday amid investigations into corruption. The third of four reports is on page B4.

title: Texaco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter results included a restructuring gain of $1,190,000,000, or $4.87 a share. It included $1,330,000,000 from the sale of Texaco Canada Inc., reduced by charges for reserves primarily relating to environmental programs at facilities sold as part of the company's restructuring. The quarter also included a gain of $49 million on the sale of Texaco's interest in a refinery and certain marketing assets in conjunction with the formation of a joint venture in Sweden. The year-ago period included a $66 million gain on the sale of a part of the company's interest in offshore operations in Angola. Figures for the year-ago first quarter have been restated to reflect the adoption of FAS 96.

title: For Alfonsin's Party, a Hard Road to Election Day
description: In a country where things are generally expected to go wrong, the recent presentation of the economic program of Eduardo Angeloz, a presidential candidate, came off so smoothly that one newspaper compared it to a well-organized political evening in Washington.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Do Awards Greatly Help Magazines?
description: They are called the Pulitzer Prizes of periodical publishing, and today, at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan, 14 journals will discover that they have won 1989 National Magazine Awards. Many will take out ads touting their victories, to attract the attention of advertising agencies. But does winning the award contribute to a magazine's prosperity? Interviews yesterday with agency and publishing executives found a wide range of opinion. Edward P. Mansfield Advertising director, The Washingtonian (1982 award for reporting; 1985 awards for service to the individual and for public service; 1988 award for reporting)

title: Mexico Largely Unscathed by Strong Quake
description: A strong earthquake shook the Mexican capital and seven nearby states this morning, spreading confusion and alarm throughout this city of 20 million people. A man was killed, more than 350 other people were injured and more than 20 buildings were damaged.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ayer Appoints Chief Executive
description: Only five days after N. W. Ayer lost the bulk of the Burger King account, a defiant Louis T. Hagopian yesterday passed a torch he insisted was not flickering to Jerry J. Siano.

title: No More Impactings
description: Manufacturers who want to print ''I H New York'' on their goods will now have to pay the state 6 to 10 percent of the take for selling stuff so marked. The combination of three words and a red Valentine heart is state property, improvised in 1977 to promote tourism.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the seventh and eighth days of Passover and Eastern Orthodox Good Friday, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today, tomorrow and Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Wyoming Deflates the Political Experts
description: George Bush got a lot of mileage out of his Willie Horton commercial in 1988, so John Vinich, who's involved in an election in Wyoming this year, thought he'd try something similar.

title: Knick Tickets
description: A limited number of tickets for the opening-round playoff series between the Knicks and the Philadelphia 76ers will go on sale today at 10 A.M. at the Madison Square Garden box office and through Ticketmaster (212-307-7171). The tickets, which are for all three home games, are priced from $45 to $90 depending on location. There is a limit of four strips per person.

title: U.S. to Review Food-Safety Efforts
description: Concerned by a series of public scares over the safety of the nation's food supply, the Bush Administration is beginning a review of American food-safety programs.

title: Profit Scoreboard
Can You Have Fat in Your Steak and Eat It Too?
description: STEAK used to be a simple food, the kind that took no introduction, let alone apology. No more. Today, buying a steak has become an exercise in introspection.

title: Vehicle Sales Up 5.4% in Mid-April
description: Heavy discounting by the Big Three auto companies helped to raise domestic vehicle sales by 5.4 percent in mid-April. But analysts said the improvement was not enough to prevent production cutbacks larger than those announced Monday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Monday's stock market trading misstated the closing price for ITT. It closed up 3/8, to 58 1/4, after the company reported an 11 percent increase in first-quarter earnings.

title: Cone, Staying in Fine Style, Strikes Out 10 for Revived Mets
description: If you were wondering what David Cone was going to do for an encore after last season, when he sizzled to 20 victories and 3 defeats, he gave a major clue last night in Shea Stadium. He pitched powerful five-hit ball with 10 strikeouts in his fourth long start of the year and dominated the performance as the Mets edged the Atlanta Braves, 2-1.

title: Hearing Asked on Letter to Jurors
description: Lawyers for Oliver L. North yesterday requested a hearing after the verdict is delivered in his case to determine the effect of a letter delivered by NBC News last weekend to the homes of jurors.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. WHIP DEFENDS HIS ETHICS
description: In the tit for tat that is coloring partisan relations on Capitol Hill, the Republican Congressman who first accused House Speaker Jim Wright of impropriety defended himself today against Democratic charges.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: An Italian Sampler

title: First Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
USAir Orders Jets
description: USAir Group Inc. has ordered 18 Boeing 737 jets and taken options on 36 more in a transaction valued at up to $1.7 billion, the airline announced. The aircraft will be in the 737-300, 737-400 and 737-500 series. Deliveries of the 18 firm orders will be one a month in 1991 and two monthly in the first quarter of 1992. The latest transaction brings USAir's total orders for the Boeing 737 to 68 aircraft, which will be delivered between now and 1992, plus 96 options, which would be delivered between 1992 and 1995.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. the grains and oils company, said its board had approved a $150 million investment to make a wide variety of amino acids, enzymes and specialty biochemicals at a new plant in Decatur, Ill.

title: Nynex Seeks Elusive Data Market
description: New York Telephone introduced a service yesterday that permits people with a personal computer to dial a local number and be connected with a wide range of information services as diverse as USA Today and the Cabot Creamery, a small cheese shop in Burlington, Vt.

title: AMCA International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $2,817,000. c-Net loss

title: Goldome Posts Loss in Quarter
description: Goldome, one of the nation's largest savings institutions, reported a loss of $38.8 million for its first quarter ended March 31, company officials said today. Goldome lost $12 million in the corresponding period last year.

title: Canseco Faces Charges
description: Jose Canseco of the Oakland Athletics will be prosecuted in a San Francisco court on both felony and misdemeanor charges in connection with a loaded handgun the police said they found in his car last week. He was arrested Friday at the Laurel Heights campus of the University of California at San Francisco, where he had gone for an examination of his injured left wrist.

title: Goldome reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included $6.3 million of costs related to the restructuring of Goldome Realty Credit Corp.

title: BancOklahoma Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Curtice Burns Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
Wine Is Spilt; Some Tears Ensue
description: TO William Sokolin, a New York wine merchant with a penchant for publicity, the dinner at the Four Seasons Sunday night was an irresistible opportunity. In his possession was a bottle, which wine experts believe was once owned by Thomas Jefferson, that he had been trying to sell for $519,750.

title: Mitterrand Orders A Library for the Ages
description: In his latest and in some ways most ambitious effort to reshape the architectural landscape of Paris, President Francois Mitterrand is building ''a very big library'' that is supposed to be the most modern in the world.

title: Basque Strife: Harder Lines On Both Sides
description: After a three-month truce that raised hopes for peace in the long-convulsed Basque region, the Spanish Government and separatist extremists have both gone on the offensive following the collapse of the first negotiations between the two sides.

title: About New York; The Paper Trail Of a Ruckus Over Rubbish
description: New York is not generally known as a city that guards too vigilantly the cleanliness of its streets and sidewalks. But don't tell that to the seven families who live in a narrow loft building at 42 West 15th Street. They claim to be victims of an overzealous and unyielding sanitation bureaucracy - and they've got a growing paper trail to prove it.

title: Warsaw Journal; For Paper, Jungle (and Censor) Await
description: This month, the most influential source of uncensored information in Poland was laid to rest. Next month it will be reborn as the first independently published daily newspaper in the East bloc.

title: Take Arms Against a Sea of Trash, TV Viewers; An American System
description: To the Editor:

title: Cyprus Minerals Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Results Plus
description: TENNIS Seeded Players Fall in Monte Carlo: Fourth-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland and three other seeded players were eliminated yesterday at the $607,500 Monte Carlo Open. Martin Jaite of Argentina, who lost in last year's final of this tournament to Ivan Lendl, beat Hlasek by 6-4, 6-1. The two top-seeded players advanced in rainy conditions. Mats Wilander of Sweden beat a wild-card entry, Diego Nargiso of Italy, 7-6, 6-1, and Boris Becker of West Germany topped Lawson Duncan, 6-4, 6-1. Sixth-seeded Henri Leconte of France withdrew during his match against Patrick Kuhnen of West Germany. Kuhnen was leading by 6-3, 3-2, when Leconte decided to abandon the match because of a back injury. (AP) 16-Year-Old Upsets Maleeva: Carrie Cunningham, a 16-year-old amateur, won a battle of service breaks, 4-6, 7-5, 6-2, in the Virginia Slims of Houston tournament yesterday over third-seeded Katerina Maleeva, who served much of the final two sets underhanded. Maleeva, ranked No. 11 in the world, lost her serve 10 times and twice double faulted with underhand serves. Cunningham, ranked No. 121 in the world, was broken seven times. Cunningham is a high school junior from Livonia, Mich.(AP) Novotna Advances in Barcelona: Third-seeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia defeated Nathalie Guerree of France, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in the opening round of a women's tournament at the Royal Tennis Club in Barcelona, Spain. Among other first-round matches, Sylvia Hanika of West Germany beat Mercedes Paz of Argentina, 6-3, 6-7, 7-6.(AP) HORSE RACING Notation Beats Favorite: Notation charged past the favorite, Dispersal, at the top of the stretch and edged Bionic Prospect by a nose to capture the $110,250 Lexington Stakes yesterday at Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky. Notation, ridden by Pat Day, covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:44 2/5 in the Grade II race. Charlie Barley was three-quarters of a length back in third while a fading Dispersal finished another half-length back in fourth in the next-to-last prep race for the Kentucky Derby. Dispersal, once considered a strong contender for the Derby, will not run in the May 6 classic at Churchill Downs after suffering his second straight defeat. Notation returned $19.40, $8 and $4.60 for $2 across the board. Bionic Prospect paid $13.60 and $6.80 and Charlie Barley returned $6.60.(AP)

title: Signs of Slower Growth Spur Treasury Issues
description: Prices moved modestly higher yesterday in the Treasury bond and note market, helped by fresh economic reports that provide further evidence that the pace of growth may be slowing.

title: Bird's Status Is Still to Be Decided
description: Larry Bird practiced today with the Boston Celtics, but the team remains pessimistic that he will participate in the first round of the playoffs.

The year-ago first quarter revenue figure included $54,658,000 from network services and other services formerly provided or to be discontinued, which are not included in 1989 revenue.

title: Mesa Limited Net Falls
description: Citing declines in revenues from oil, natural gas and condensate production, Mesa Limited Partnership reported today that its net income declined to $14.6 million, or 15 cents a common unit, on revenues of $105 million for the first quarter of 1989. Earnings for the similar period a year earlier were $19.3 million, or 17 cents a common unit, on revenues of $95.2 million. Gas production increased for the quarter, mostly because of the addition of Tenneco Inc. properties acquired by Mesa last year, the Amarillo-based partnership said.

title: Himont Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
How to Tell the Coasts Apart
description: On my recent East Coast swing, a semiannual ritual, I had a number of pleasant encounters that all came to the same abrupt halt. I would be listening to these old friends talking about other old friends; they would be filling me in, rattling off job descriptions and house descriptions and descriptions of new babies, and invariably I'd lean forward at some point and say, ''But are they happy?''

title: So Far, Educators Give Bush No Passing Grade
description: Three months after President Bush took office vowing to make education a top priority of his Administration, the school year is approaching its close with many education experts calling his initiatives inadequate.

Entertaining in Washington's New York

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FOR several years coriander has been a voguish herb that shows up in all sorts of dishes in nearly every major cuisine. When I was a professional chef, coriander leaf and seed were rarely seen in French or American kitchens, but were more common in Indian, Chinese and Mexican food, as well as in South American and Southeast Asian cuisines.

description: WHEN the daffodils unfurl their trumpets in early spring, it's a sign for herb foragers to grab their digging and snipping paraphernalia and set off to gather the wild leeks, or ramps, as they are commonly known.

description: The Montreal Canadiens avenged last year's playoff elimination by Boston as they rode the goaltending of Patrick Roy and a strong defense to the Adams Division title with a 3-2 victory over the Bruins tonight.

title: The Jogger and the Wolf Pack
description: The news inspires horror and outrage: A pack of teen-agers rampages through Central Park, harassing and assaulting several people, ultimately brutalizing and raping an innocent young woman who had been jogging on a lonely path, leaving her for dead in the April mud. New Yorkers respond with unanimous fury: Those guilty of the atrocity deserve swift, stern punishment.

description: The chairman of New York City's Charter Revision Commission, Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., has proposed a thoughtful, provocative plan for reshaping New York City's government in response to a Supreme Court decision. The proposal would strengthen the City Council, retain a powerful mayor, provide for community involvement and try to increase minority representation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the warming of the oceans misstated the change in average temperature outside the polar region from 1982 to 1988. It rose to 68.8 degrees Fahrenheit from 67.5 (not to 36.8 degrees from 35.5).

description: An obituary and its headline yesterday about a retired surgeon and sculptor from Scarsdale, N.Y., gave his first name incorrectly. He was Dr. Kaare K. Nygaard.

Weill said yesterday that Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, a unit of the Primerica Corporation, of which he is chairman, would acquire 16 of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s 43 retail offices and about 500 of its brokers.

title: Article 029989 -- No Title
description: The Las Vegas Invitational, a five-day, 90-hole tournament, was the richest event on the PGA Tour when, in 1986, it was the first to have a $1 million purse. This year's tournament starts Wednesday with a purse of $1.25 million, but the event is now the third richest full-field tournament. Only the Doral Ryder Open at $1.3 million and The Players Championship at $1.35 million have larger purses this year for 144 or more players. The season-ending Nabisco Championships has a $5 million purse, but has a field of only 30 players.

title: Mr. Bush's Arms Control Blinders

The latest example is Monday's peremptory rejection of Bonn's proposal to start talks with Moscow on short-range nuclear forces.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE bus was heading uptown on Third Avenue. Somewhere before Bloomingdale's it stopped for a traffic light and it was then that the passengers first became aware of the pedestrian: he dashed from the sidewalk out to the middle of the street and knocked on the bus door. The bus driver ignored him. The man knocked again. ''This is not a bus stop,'' the driver shouted. The light changed and the bus took off.

title: As Long As It Isn't 'Tacky'

McColl, said, calling the withdrawal of $2.4 billion bid ''the end of the saga.'' But at a news conference at NCNB's Charlotte headquarters, Mr. McColl also promised to continue his company's aggressive expansion efforts in the Southeast into the 1990's.
