description: Americans are deeply ambivalent about abortion, with individuals torn over when it should be permitted and the nation sharply divided about whether abortion should remain legal as it is now and whether it constitutes murder, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

description: Factory orders for durable goods edged up a modest eight-tenths of a percent last month and would have fallen if not for a jump in aircraft orders, the Government said today in a report that reflected a slowing economy.

Standouts Among Bank-Run Funds
description: LEAD: STOCK mutual funds managed by bank trust departments underperformed the general stock market by a slight margin in the first quarter, according to statistics compiled by CDA Investment Technologies Inc.

title: Park Rules On Loitering Are Delayed
description: Reacting to vociferous objections by advocates for the homeless, the New York City Parks and Recreation Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, decided yesterday to delay for a month the adoption of regulations to restrict how some homeless people use the parks. Some rules will be rewritten, Mr. Stern added.

Schwarz Jr.'s vision of the future, no elected official in New York City would have final decision-making power over a development project like the Cityspire apartment complex, one of the most controversial skyscrapers to be built in Manhattan in years. Fifty years after World War II and three years before the planned completion of the European Common Market, the English are poking fun at the French Resistance, the German invaders and occupiers and their Italian henchmen in a hit show at the London Palladium.

He was 72 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Manhattan School Districts; Districts at a Glance
description: District 1: Lower East Side: Enrollment in October 1988, 11,256, the smallest decentralized district . . . Early years marked by turmoil with racial and ethnic overtones . . . In last decade conditions have stabilized . . . Bernard Mecklowitz, highly regarded district superintendent since 1977, became a deputy chancellor of city system on Feb. 1 . . . About 1,000 pupils come from shelters and hotels for homeless . . . Last year 53.6 percent of pupils were at or above grade level in reading, compared with citywide figure of 65 percent. District 2: Battery Park, Chelsea, Chinatown, Clinton, East Midtown, East Village, Governors Island, Grammercy Park, Greenwich Village, ''Little Italy,'' Liberty Island, Roosevelt Island, Stuyvesant Town, Yorkville: Enrollment, 17,911 pupils, largest district geographically and in population (more than 600,000 residents) . . . A third of pupils are Asian . . . Last year 68.2 percent of pupils read at or above grade level . . . Has had seven superintendents since 1970 . . . In July 1987, Anthony Alvarado, a former city Schools Chancellor, became superintendent . . . Since then, district has embarked on a number of educational innovations. District 3: Morningside, Manhattanville, Central Park West: Enrollment, 13,844 pupils . . . Schools historically a focus of intense interest and sometimes controversy . . . Strong parent concern . . . Past conflicts have pitted district against central authorities . . . Last year 53 percent of pupils read at or above grade level . . . Current emphasis on encouraging parents and school staffs to develop new educational approaches. District 4: East Harlem: Enrollment, 14,422 pupils . . . Recent accusations of fiscal improprieties and mismanagement . . . Gained reputation for educational innovation under a former superintendent, Anthony Alvardo, who later became Schools Chancellor . . . Last year 62.5 percent of pupils read at or above grade level . . . Current superintendent, Carlos Medina, is accused of using school funds for personal expenses and is now under suspension . . . District under investigation by Manhattan District Attorney. District 5: Central Harlem: Enrollment, 13,684 pupils . . . Has had 13 superintendents since 1970, most of any district . . . In early years central headquarters twice intervened to straighten out tangled financial affairs . . . In 1979 local board suspended for defying Chancellor's directives . . . In recent years several schools closed because of declining enrollments . . . Last year 54.2 percent of pupils read at or above grade level. District 6: Inwood, Washington Heights, Hamilton Grange: Enrollment, 22,747 pupils . . . Many pupils are recent arrivals from other countries with little or no schooling . . . Highest percentage (33 percent) of pupils with limited proficiency in English of any district . . . Reading scores among lowest in city; 51.8 percent of pupils at or above grade level last year . . . Schools also among the most crowded . . . In March 1987 local school board removed for mismanagement and for poor performance of schools . . . A new superintendent, Anthony Amato, who was selected by the trustees, is credited with bringing about improvements in district.

title: Philly Fare in New York
description: LEAD: YO! Is this really Pat's, the South Philly cheese steak shop? Home of the King of Steaks?

title: New Jersey Wresles With Sludge Dilemma
description: Six New Jersey sewage authorities, under Federal and state edicts to end their dumping of sewage sludge at sea in 1991, are rushing ahead with what they say is their least-favored alternative: multimillion-dollar incinerators to burn the sludge.

description: Anton J. Campanella, president and chief executive of New Jersey Bell, was named president of the company's parent, the Bell Atlantic Company, yesterday at the annual meeting in Baltimore.

2 Members of a Soviet Group Defect at a Bering Ceremony
description: While the leaders of their delegation stood on a narrow strip of ice in a blasting wind and called for ease of travel across the Bering Strait, two members of a Soviet group slipped away unnoticed Sunday and declared themselves defectors.

title: Cutting Gasoline-Vapor Pollution
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency last week approved a Massachusetts plan to require that the volatility of gasoline sold in the state be reduced as a means of combating air pollution. The agency has indicated that it would also approve the applications of other Northeastern states, clearing the way for a regionwide attack on gasoline vapors that is tougher than the Federal effort.

title: Article 116889 -- No Title
description: In a move that gives new impetus to an ambitious redevelopment plan for Times Square, one of the project's developers said yesterday that it would issue a $150 million letter of credit that could allow New York State to move ahead to claim property for the plan.

title: Latest Lauder Commercials Attack Giuliani as a Liberal
description: With the Republican mayoral primary five months away, Ronald S. Lauder today began airing two television commercials that criticize Rudolph W. Giuliani as a liberal, a supporter of George McGovern and a politician willing to raise taxes.

title: Seoul Dooms Plane Bomber, But a Reprieve Is Expected
description: A court here sentenced a young woman to death today for blowing up a South Korean airliner and killing all 115 aboard. However, there were strong hints that she would win a reprieve.

title: For One Hour, a Look Into Abortion's Future
description: The Supreme Court arguments in a Missouri abortion case Wednesday morning may provide an hour of great theater, trenchant repartee and abundant hints about the constitutional future of the right to abortion.

title: Maxwell Smart's Phone Is Moving Onto the Market
description: In the 1960's television series ''Get Smart,'' the secret agent Maxwell Smart had a radio telephone so small that it fit inside his shoe. Now Motorola Inc. appears to be ahead in the race for such a phone with a cellular model small enough to fit in a pocket or purse.

title: Takeshita Aide With Role in Scandal Kills Himself
description: A longtime aide to Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita committed suicide this morning at his home in Tokyo after disclosures that he had received gifts and loans from the company involved in Japan's influence-peddling and bribery scandal.

title: Amdahl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1988 earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the third quarter and the acquisition of Key Computer Laboratories Inc. for Amdahl stock in February.

description: The Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of a three-year-old system of Federal fees imposed on users of natural gas and hazardous liquid pipelines.

description: The latest quarter included results of GE Solid State acquired in November. The year-ago 9 months included a gain of $35.1 million, or 87 cents a share, from accounting changes.

title: Dig in the Ground or in Your Picket
description: IF you have never eaten ramps and want to try them, you can forage with friends. You can also visit the annual ramp celebrations in North Carolina and West Virginia, or attend one of the many fund-raising church or high-school ramp dinners held throughout the two states.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm appalled at the lack of judgment and good sense on the part of any Western publisher who would deal with any organization in Iran as long as the death threat on Salman Rushdie is in place,'' - Robert K. Massie, president of the Authors Guild, on American participation in Teheran's book fair. [ A1:1. ]

description: b-After a loss of $195,000 from discontinued operations. c-After income of $820,000 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Experts See Trade Disputes Put in Limbo as Tokyo Regroups
description: American experts on Japan, including several Bush Administration officials, expressed concern today that Japan's preoccupation with its internal political affairs would delay resolution of disputes with the United States on trade, the FSX fighter plane and other issues, for several months at least.

title: Occidental Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $9 million charge from the early extinguishment of debt. c-After a tax credit of $2 million. Included in unallocated corporate items in 1989 is a pretax charge of $36 million for a charitable contribution to the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Cultural Center. It is estimated that the full year 1989 after-tax cost to Occidental of this contribution will be about $24 million. The 1988 results included after-tax gains of $53 million primarily from the issuance and sale of a 25 percent stock interest by the oil and gas subsidiary owning Occidental's interests in Colombia. The year-ago results also included an after-tax pension gain of $16 million.

title: Rorer Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Previn Abruptly Quits Post at the Los Angeles
description: Andre Previn abruptly resigned yesterday as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic as of the end of this season, the orchestra announced.

title: Horizon Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included a loss of $3,513 from the sale of loans, compared with a gain from the sale of loans of $135,413 for year-ago period.

title: N.B.A.'s Best in Regular Season, Pistons Look Strong for Playoffs
description: The following analysis of the National Basketball Association playoffs was prepared and written by Sam Goldaper. A detailed look at the Knicks' series against the Philadelphia 76ers, will appear tomorrow.

title: Bush's Foreign Policy: Pragmatism or Indecision?
description: LEAD: The first 100 days of the Bush Administration have not produced any landmarks in foreign policy. But that's hardly cause for concern. The next 100 days will be much more important.

title: Robert S. Moss, Manufacturer, 69
description: Robert S. Moss, a manufacturing executive, died of heart disease Monday at his home in Bergenfield, N.J. He was 69 years old.

title: 2 Publishers in U.S. Are Breaking Ranks To Show at Iran Fair
description: Although American publishers are not sending representatives to the Iran Book Fair in Teheran next month, two major American publishing companies are sending books for display there.

title: 3 Prayer Vigils Held as Victom Of Attack Remains in Coma
description: Clergy, civic leaders, government officials and runners gathered yesterday in three vigils to pray and offer support for the victim of a severe beating and multiple rape in Central Park.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Sports Pages yesterday about the Giants' draft picks misstated the selection time for two players. They were taken in the seventh and eighth rounds, not the last rounds.

title: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Fills Post of Chairman
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the bankrupt steel producer, said yesterday that its board had elected William J. Scharffenberger, the company's president and chief executive, to the position of chairman. The chairman's post had been vacant since January, when Lloyd C. Lubensky, who gave no reason for his actions, resigned and sold his 34 percent stake in the company.

title: Banner Industries
description: Banner Industries said it had bid $457 million, mostly in cash, to acquire the aircraft braking systems and engineered fabrics divisions of the Loral Corporation, a company whose leading business is military electronics systems. Banner said its proposal was higher than a recently announced bid of $425 million in cash and notes by Bernard L. Schwartz, Loral's chief executive and one of its largest shareholders. Banner said its proposal consists of $432 million in cash and a $25 million face amount subordinated convertible debentures similar to the debentures offered by Mr. Schwartz. Banner said its offer was not subject to financing.

title: Whirlpool Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $3.9 million from discontinued operations. Latest first quarter results included operations of its Whirlpool International B.V. applicance joint venture, which was formed on Jan. 2 with N.V. Philips. Results included all the revenue of the joint venture but only 53 percent of the earnings, in line with the company's ownership position.

title: Blood Mixes With Dust For a Town's Industry
description: This is a town of survivors. In 1863, people here survived the siege of Yankee troops and the Battle of Bayou Bourbeaux. They survived boll weevils and watched the cotton gins disappear. They lived through the decline of sweet potato shipping. Now the town is trying to survive an assault by animal rights advocates, who want to make rooster fighting a crime in Louisiana.

title: King Has a Plan; Cayton Has a Say
description: If Bill Cayton has no objections, look for Mike Tyson to fight Carl Williams in late July and Jose Ribalta in October. That's the plan that Don King and Home Box Office are anticipating, if no hitches develop.

title: Provident Life & Accident Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its 1988 results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: First-Class Poise From a No. 1 Pick
description: Although he wore a sports jacket and a tie and didn't knock anybody down, Jeff Lageman exhibited the traits today that made him exactly the kind of player the Jets wanted on the first round.

title: Cheney Defends Budget Decisions To Cut Some Weapon Programs
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today defended his budgetary decisions to cancel weapon programs, retire Navy ships and cut the size of the Army while members of Congress complained about reductions in their favorite programs.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Kentucky Derby misstated the number of consecutive races won by Native Dancer before the Derby. It was 11 in a row.

Fieldcrest Cannon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Hong Kong Inflation
description: Hong Kong's broadest index of inflation rose 9.5 percent in March from a year earlier, the Government said today. During the first quarter of 1989, the seasonally adjusted consumer price index increased at an average rate of nine-tenths of a percent a month. The Government said it still expected overall inflation of 8.5 percent in 1989.

title: Eastern Utilities Associates reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JWP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: b-Included a 13 cents a share gain from the sale of the company's cutting edge division and a 2 cents a share charge from the early retirement of debt.

title: An American Debut for the Heralded '86 Bordeaux
description: CHATEAU MARGAUX was given top billing at the 17-wine dinner Sunday at the Four Seasons that introduced the 1986 Bordeaux vintage to the United States. But the Chateau Mouton-Rothschild stole the show.

title: Lottery at Record $100 Million
description: The pace of ticket sales has been so feverish for Wednesday's Pennsylvania lottery drawing that state officials announced today that the jackpot would exceed $100 million, a United States record.

Broadway Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Convict Freed in 1967 Child-Poisoning Case
description: A circuit judge today overturned the murder conviction of a man who spent 21 years in prison for the poisoning deaths of his seven children in 1967.

title: Group Seeks More Of Dunkin' Donuts
description: A group led by a Toronto businessman, George S. Mann, has filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to buy more than 50 percent of Dunkin' Donuts Inc. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Mann also said that he had raised his Dunkin' Donuts stake to 7.6 percent from 6.6 percent.

title: C.F.T.C. Head On Changes
description: Wendy L. Gramm, the head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, officially embraced several proposed changes for the Chicago futures markets today, but declined to take a position on other important questions.

title: Kremlin Calls Georgia Violence a Local Operation
description: Kremlin leaders did not approve the decision to send troops into a main square in the capital of Soviet Georgia and were not aware of the action until after soldiers had killed demonstrators there 10 days ago, a ranking member of the ruling Politburo said today.

title: Calmark Ends Bid To Acquire Webb
description: An investment group led by the Calmark Financial Corporation, a financial services concern in Los Angeles, said it had ended its attempt to acquire the Del E. Webb Corporation, the Phoenix real estate development concern. The Calmark group had made an unsolicited offer in December to acquire Del Webb for $17 a share, or $158 million, but took no further action.

title: Mobil Reported to Plan South African Pullout
description: A change in American tax laws may have done what shareholders and pressure groups have failed to do, according to newspapers in South Africa. They are reporting that the Mobil Corporation may be pulling out of the country for tax reasons.

title: Witco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $3,110,000, or 12 cents a shre, from the sale of a product line. c-Included a gain from an accounting change of $20,289,000.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Still a Hot Ticket With Only Dreams Guaranteed
description: Who was buying the lottery tickets? Well, there were the six high rollers who took a limousine into town and had their driver wait in an hourlong line to buy $100 of Super 7 tickets for each of them.

title: Connecticut Panels Fail To Settle Budget Crisis
description: It was business as usual at the General Assembly today, but amid the jostle of amendments and parliamentary procedure there was scarcely a mention of the issue on most minds: the failure of the Assembly's two most important committees, which govern how Connecticut taxes and how it spends, to reach a concensus about the state's budget crisis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think that some comrades, finding themselves in difficult straits, are losing confidence, giving in. And that won't do.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A14:4. ]

title: Lucille Ball, Spirited Doyenne Of TV Comedies, Dies at 77
description: Lucille Ball, the irrepressible queen of television comedy for nearly a quarter-century, died yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles a week after undergoing heart surgery there. She was 77 years old.

Derailment Forces Evacuation
description: Ten cars on a train hauling potentially toxic chemicals derailed Tuesday night, forcing the evacuation of residents up to half a mile away, officials said today. No injuries were reported and no chemicals were believed to have leaked as result of the accident, which was reported at 7:45 P.M., said Sgt. Tom Parker of the Oakland County Sheriff's office. It was not known exactly how many people were evacuated, Sergeant Parker said. Milford is about 20 miles northwest of Detroit.

Review/Television; Jesse Jackson Finds a Platform on a Sitcom
description: George Bush may be worried about how his first 100 days will be evaluated, but Jesse Jackson is already working on 1992. Tonight on ''A Different World'' - on NBC at 8:30 - Mr. Jackson is taking shrewd advantage of the sitcom as a valuable political showcase.

title: Compaq Profits Increase 77.8%
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, a leading maker of desktop, portable and laptop computers, continued its rapid growth, reporting a 77.8 percent increase in net income for the first quarter of 1988.

title: Sweden Tax Proposal
description: Sweden's Social Democratic Government Tuesday proposed a rise in indirect taxes, already among the highest in the world, to cool off the overheated economy. The plan would increase the value added tax from July 1 until the end of 1990 by two percentage points, to 25.46 percent. It calls for a rise in payroll taxes to be paid by employers of five percentage points in Stockholm and two points in the rest of the country. Also included is a 5 percent tax increase on wine, spirits and tobacco.

title: Cruising Melrose, Where Buildings Become Billboards
description: CERTAIN stretches of cities reflect certain moments in time: the visually raucous Carnaby Street of London in the 1960's; the cool minimalist SoHo galleries of New York in the 1970's. In Los Angeles in the 1980's Melrose Avenue has become an expression not only of chic retailing but also of exuberant, often cheeky, street graphics.

title: Sandstrom Signs
description: Tomas Sandstrom, the right wing from Sweden who led the Rangers in scoring last season with 32 goals, 56 assists and 88 points, has signed a multiyear contract with the team.

title: Currents; For Japan Fair, a Different Perspective
description: SINCE the YES Expo, a fair whose theme is outer space, opened March 25 in Yokohama, Japan, visitors arriving by train have found pale-gray mannequins and automobiles suspended upside down from the Yokohama railroad station ceiling. Outside, in the 10,000-square-foot plaza leading to the fair, there are more upside-down mannequins, cars and trees half-buried in the pavement, with feet, tires and roots sticking up from the concrete.

title: Citgo Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MacLean Hunter Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Exxon Tanker Adrift 7 Hours Off the Coast of Washington
description: An Exxon tanker carrying more than 22 million gallons of Alaskan crude oil lost power and drifted off the Washington coast for nearly seven hours today before it was taken in tow.

title: Yields Flat Or Up a Bit
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds ranged from unchanged to slightly higher for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about measures by some universities to restrict racially divisive expression characterized the University of Wisconsin regents incorrectly. They represent the statewide university system, not just the Madison campus.

title: NUI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $1,741,000 for the quarter and $2,182,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. The latest periods included the operations of City Gas Co. of Florida, acquired as of Aug. 1, 1988.

title: We All Love Lucy
description: If a clown's face is humanity's writ large, then Lucille Ball, who died yesterday, was born to her work. The red of her hair came out of a bottle, but who else would have chosen a shade so fiery? And who in this world ever had bigger, bluer, rounder eyes, or a mouth that slid so quickly into smiling? Hers was the mask of comedy. Remember Lucy trapped in a meat locker? Stuck in a shower stall with a plugged drain, a balky door and the water level rising? Threatened by an ever-rising loaf of bread? In those scrapes and others, she revealed her debt, and kinship, to Charlie Chaplin. He was the Little Tramp; she was the Little Woman.

title: New York State Bond Ratings Raised by 2 Credit Agencies
description: In a sign that New York State had successfully overcome a potential $2.8 billion budget deficit, two leading credit agencies today upgraded their estimates of the state's creditworthiness and awarded New York their highest ratings for short-term bonds.

title: Armco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $37.4 million for changes in accounting principles and a special charge of $35 million related to rationalizing certain Latin American operations.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter's share earnings reflects the effect on seasonal earnings of the change in federal income tax rate.

title: Norma Klein, 50, a Young-Adult Novelist
description: Norma Klein, an author of more than 30 novels for teen-agers and adults, died Tuesday after a brief illness at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 50 years old.

title: Bally Manufacturing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $5.1 million from the sale of securities.

title: Topics of The Times; Some Special Occasion
description: If Thomas Jefferson hadn't overstocked himself on Chateau Margaux '87 (that's 1787), a wine merchant named William Sokolin wouldn't have had to watch a lot of money go down the drain the other night.

title: Heroics for Lemieux Despite Sore Neck
description: Early in the playoffs, he had dubbed Mario Lemieux ''The Draped Crusader,'' alluding to his ability to play and produce despite being blanketed by defenders. Of late, he had taken to calling him ''Honest Abe,'' referring to his lanky, angular physique and recently adopted beard.

title: L.I. Youth, 16, Held In Sniper Shooting
description: A 16-year-old youth accused of shooting an anti-drug campaigner in an apparent attempt to intimidate her was ordered held without bail yesterday.

title: Torstar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $503,000. Year-ago net income figures have been restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: NEANDERTHAL MAN MAY HAVE TALKED
description: Archeologists in Israel have unearthed a 60,000-year-old Neanderthal skeleton that indicates for the first time that the primitive hominids were anatomically able to talk.

title: Will Scandal Change Face Of a System?
description: Japan's political world turned today to an uncomfortable question that was often lost in the rush to force Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita from office: Will the Recruit scandal permanently change a political system addicted to hidden money and backroom influence?

title: Ingersoll-Rand Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $8.5 million, or 17 cents a share.

title: Christie Rights Auctioned for $9.6 Million
description: Harper & Row has agreed to pay $9.6 million for reprint rights to 33 titles by Agatha Christie in a spirited auction whose bidding far exceeded industry expectations.

title: The Abortion Case: A Full Transcript
description: The oral arguments in the abortion case before the Court appear on pages B12-B14.

title: Fruit of the Loom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Goodman Fielder Rejects British Bid
description: The board of Goodman Fielder Wattie Ltd. rejected as inadequate a takeover offer worth $2.4 billion from Ranks Hovis McDougall P.L.C. of Britain. The directors said in a statement that the bid ''doesn't reflect the underlying value of the company.'' They also said a takeover by Ranks Hovis would result in the loss of effective Australasian control over ''vital elements of the local food industry.'' Goodman Fielder Wattie is the biggest food processor in Australia and New Zealand.

title: Topics of The Times; The Court, Still Off Camera
description: The throngs on the Supreme Court's steps yesterday were not all political activists and journalists. Many were just citizens interested in an important abortion case. They had a right to hear and see the arguments, a right the high court denies by keeping out cameras.

title: Battle for the Last Laugh On Minimum Wage Bill
description: In political terms, like many others, an acid test of an issue is what is made of it in the monologues of the late-night television shows. Johnny Carson is already joking about the 30 cents that divides the Bush Administration and Congress in one of their first hard- fought battles: whether to raise the minimum wage to $4.55 or $4.25 an hour by 1991.

title: Reviews/Music; Muti and the Philadelphia Offer Two American Works
description: When Riccardo Muti took over the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1980, he hadn't conducted any American music. Since then, however, his record in this respect has honorably improved, and the first two pieces on Tuesday evening's Carnegie Hall concert were American. But it was still the two Brahms scores that made the deepest impression.

title: Preservation Guide Offered
description: The Preservation League of New York State, a nonprofit organization that promotes public participation in the preservation of historic resources, recently published ''Preservation Directory: A Guide to Programs, Organizations, and Agencies in New York State.''

title: JP Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,061,000.

description: Volkswagen of America Inc. Tuesday announced an incentive program offering United States savings bonds to people who buy or lease a new Volkswagen until May 31. The program offers bonds from $1,000 to $4,000 in face value, depending on the model.

title: INSIDE
description: Chinese Editor Dismissed

title: An Antibiotic Is Given To 1,200 Poor Children
description: The New York City Department of Health began distributing an oral antibiotic yesterday to 1,200 children living in the Prince George Hotel after a 4-year-old boy there came down with meningitis.

title: Baker Hughes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,048,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $755,000 for the 6 months. c-Included extraordinary gains of $3,733,000 and $19,973,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the extraordinary items in the latest quarter and year-earlier period both included $95 million litigation settlement net of unusual charge of $64.9 million. The company also said in the latest 6 months and year-earlier period the extraordinary item represents change in income taxes arising from carryforward of prior years' operating losses.
