description: The company said the latest first quarter results included sales from Matrix Science, which it acquired last August.

title: HOUSE PANEL HEARS DEBATE ON FUSION
description: The furor over whether low-temperature nuclear fusion has been achieved in jars of water came to Capitol Hill today, with some members of Congress seeming sympathetic to calls for Federal financing of the disputed work.

title: Cincinnati Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Music; Mozart and Small Talk
description: Music and More, a series at Merkin Concert Hall that accompanies performances with spoken commentary, gave a Mozart concert on Sunday afternoon with Israela Margalit, the series director, and Martin Bookspan serving as hosts.The program included the C-major piano sonata (K. 330), the piano and wind quintet (K. 452), three well-known German songs, an aria from ''La Clemenza di Tito'' and a lovely arietta by Josef Myslivecek that was once (and, on Sunday, once again) attributed to Mozart.

title: Blackhawks Win Division
description: Bob Murray and Wayne Presley scored eight seconds apart to key a three-goal burst in the second period tonight and the Chicago Blackhawks won the Norris Division title with a 4-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Respectability Again for Orioles
description: Frank Robinson's wife and daughter did not have to tell him he was crazy when he opted to continue as manager of the hapless Baltimore Orioles this season instead of returning to the safety and sanity of the front office. ''They told me I was crazy when I took the job last year,'' Robinson related. Robinson became manager of the Orioles last year after they lost their first six games. He managed 15 more losses before the Orioles won a game, and they finished the season with a major league-high 107 losses and a margin of 34 1/2 games separating them from first place.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a political race in Wyoming misidentifed the office being sought by Craig Thomas and John Vinich. It is a seat in the House of Representatives, not the Senate.

title: Central Maine Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Allegheny Ludlum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Close to Home
description: A GRAY squirrel roams the gardens outside my apartment, much cosseted by the neighbors and nervy to a fault. This squirrel peers in windows, frustrates the cat and appears to have no relatives. I like opening my shutters in the morning and finding him perched on the fence a few feet away. I like seeing him almost as much as I like hearing the mourning dove start up around dawn.

title: Tonka Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Richard Tucker Award Goes to Texas Soprano
description: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation has named Margaret Jane Wray, a 25-year-old soprano from San Antonio, the winner of the 1989 Richard Tucker Award of $25,000. Career grants of $5,000 each will go to four other sopranos - Harolyn Blackwell, Christine Brewer, Renee Fleming and Ealynn Voss.

title: Hanover Bank Shifts Card Fees and Rates
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, which for years has promoted the low interest rates on its credit cards, is notifying more than three million holders of its cards of new fees recently authorized in New York. For some holders, it is also giving notice of a higher interest rate.

title: F.C.C. Ruling Lets Murdoch Transfer Boston TV Station
description: The Federal Communications Commission today granted Rupert Murdoch's request to transfer his Boston television station to a trust to comply with F.C.C. rules barring ownership of a broadcast station and newspaper in the same city.

title: CHANGE IS URGENT, GORBACHEV INSISTS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Communist Party leaders this week that the elections last month were a mandate for more radical change from a public embittered by the country's economic crisis, nationalist unrest, crime and mismanagement.

title: 80 Palestinians Reject Shamir's Plan
description: More than 80 local Palestinian leaders issued a statement today rejecting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's call for elections in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Murphy Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Wagner Disputes Overturning of School Law
description: The president of the New York City Board of Education said yesterday that a Federal judge who overturned a state law intended to help curb corruption on community school boards had made an error of fact and had failed to understand the problem that the law sought to remedy.

title: Filing by Regina For Bankruptcy
description: The financially troubled Regina Company, a leading vacuum cleaner maker, filed for bankruptcy protection today. The petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws was filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in New Jersey, the company said in a statement.

title: Review/Jazz; Piano and Saxophone, Unaccompanied
description: In the past two years the pianist Judy Carmichael and the saxophonist Michael Hashim have developed a relationship that is unusual in jazz. They have been playing as an unaccompanied duo - no bass, no drums - moving into rooms that normally present piano and bass or piano alone.

title: Leal F. Norton, 58, A Venture Capitalist
description: Leal F. Norton, an investor who headed Norton Venture Partners of Palo Alto, Calif., died after a heart attack in Boston last Thursday while on a business trip. He was 58 years old and lived in Hillsborough, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Aaron M. Diamond, a New York lawyer, misidentified his widow. She is the former Elinor Lewis; her stage name as a soprano is Elinor Ross.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Without question, the most resilient if not longest survivor in the field of nutritional folklore has been vitamin E. Since its discovery in 1922, megadoses of this fat-soluble vitamin have been recommended as the cure or preventive for a host of perplexing problems, from infertility and impotence to heart and muscle diseases, cancer and the most universal ''disease,'' aging.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Connors Is Beaten: Jimmy Connors, the fourth-seeded player, was eliminated quickly yesterday after an eight-year absence from the Monte Carlo Open, losing a second-round match to Paolo Cane of Italy, 7-6, 6-1. Connors, who received a bye in the first round, last played at Monte Carlo in 1981, when his final with Guillermo Vilas of Argentina was interrupted at 5-5 by rain and never finished. Kent Carlsson of Sweden, seeded third, had to withdraw with a back injury. His place in the draw was taken by Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, who won the tournament in 1986 but lost in the final round of qualifying this year. Carl Limberger routed Nystrom, 6-1, 6-1. In other second-round matches, Carl Uwe Steeb of West Germany beat 12th-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-4, 6-4, and Alberto Mancini of Argentina defeated Francesco Cancellotti of Italy, 6-4, 6-4.(AP) HORSE RACING Antley Rolls On: Chris Antley stretched his Aqueduct winning streak to 61 days yesterday when he won the fifth race aboard Eastern Lassie. Antley has won at least one race on every Aqueduct card he has ridden since Feb. 8. He was blanked in his seven other mounts yesterday, finishing second three times and third twice. In the day's featured eighth race, Antley finished third aboard Fluorescent Lou behind the entrymates Closing Bid and Hodges Bay, both trained by Mike Freeman. Closing Bid, a 4-year-old Fio Rito gelding making his first start since Nov. 13, drew off to win by 7 1/2 lengths under Eddie Maple. HOCKEY Team USA Wins: Brian Leetch of the Rangers scored one goal and had three assists as Team USA routed Poland, 11-2, last night in Stockholm to move into first place in the relegation section of the world championships.(AP)

title: 21-Year Ordeal Ends in Release
description: James Richardson tearfully thanked God, his lawyers and the Governor today on his first full day of freedom after spending 21 years behind bars in the poisoning deaths of his seven children.

title: Giants' Top Choice Is No Quitter
description: It was August 1984, and Brian Williams was a 17-year-old freshman at Minnesota, a 225-pound tight end. He had been in summer training camp for two weeks when the coaches decided (1) he would become an offensive tackle and (2) he would be redshirted that year.

title: Currents; Frames Of Cherubs And Gems
description: ''I NEVER like to design anything in perfect good taste,'' said Steven Rosen, a jewelry designer. Mr. Rosen, who is based in Manhattan, has branched into picture frames encrusted with cherubs and rhinestones, and pillboxes with fake gems.

title: Stanley Sloane Dies; A Philanthropist, 65
description: Stanley Laurie Sloane, an investor and philanthropist who held a number of leadership positions in the United Jewish Appeal, died of cancer Tuesday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 65 years old.

title: Hussein Goes on TV And Vows an Election
description: King Hussein, addressing the nation, promised quick elections today after riots over price increases forced the resignation of his Prime Minister.

title: Japan Reverses Plan to Build A Runway Over a Coral Reef
description: Giving up a long battle with environmentalists, Japan reversed itself today and canceled plans to build a new airport over the world's largest surviving blue coral reef, at the southern tip of the Japanese archipelago.

title: Plan on Arms Pressed Hard By Thatcher
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher plans a a series of moves to firm up opposition to Bonn's proposal for opening negotiations with the Soviet Union on short-range nuclear forces.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: POLITICS
description: It is not easy being Ronald H. Brown.

title: Konosuke Matsushita, Industrialist, Is Dead at 94
description: Konosuke Matsushita, who rose from poverty to found the world's largest producer of home electric appliances and to become Japan's leading postwar industrialist, died this morning in Osaka, Japan. He was 94 years old.

title: F.C.C. Waiver For GTE Unit
description: The Federal Communications Commission today gave the General Telephone Company of California permission to build a cable television system and to test a fiber-optic system that would allow customers to order movies by telephone.

title: Crystal Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its newly acquired Trifari and Palm Beach operations each contributed positively to its earnings for the quarter.

title: A Hot Line For Voters
description: To provide information about the elections and the community school boards, the New York City Board of Education is operating an election hot line from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. on weekdays through May 2. The number is (718) 935-3050.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Soaps: Plot as Mare's-Nest
description: Not long ago, confesses Jonathan Lieberson, a contributor to The New York Review of Books, he spent a day in bed watching television. In the course of this curious endeavor, he found himself tuned to the soap operas, only to discover that ''long unfamiliarity with the plot lines and actors of these dramas put me at a disadvantage, so that when I tried to follow some of them I found most of them unintelligible.''

title: Oklahoma Star Guilty
description: Charles Thompson, the former quarterback for the University of Oklahoma, pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal charge of conspiracy to distribute cocaine. By entering the guilty plea before United States District Judge Ralph Thompson in Oklahoma City, the player waived his rights to a jury trial and grand jury consideration of his case.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Calendar: All About Our First President
description: He Slept on Cherry Street, New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street; 212-873-3400.

title: Egypt Seizes 1,500 in Crackdown on Fundamentalists
description: The Egyptian Government has arrested 1,500 people it described as Muslim extremists in the latest crackdown on fundamentalist opposition to the pro-Western Government.

title: Michigan Energy Resources Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $365,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Panhandle Eastern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included a $19 million gain from the sale of a 50 percent interest in the North Antelope Coal Co., and a charge of $12.5 million related to regaining possession of two liquified natural gas tankers. Year-ago quarter included a gain of $64.3 million from a securities transaction.

title: Imasco Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Marble: Versatile but Vulnerable
description: ON a recent day, Robert King, a New York architect, was at New York Marble Works on East 104th Street choosing stone for a master bathroom. He often uses marble in bathrooms, he said, ''on floors, walls, the vanity, on cabinets, the face of the tub, everywhere.''

title: Interest Rates Being Held Steady Amid Signs of Slowing Economy
description: Ranking officials of the Federal Reserve acknowledged this week that it had stopped pushing interest rates up because of recent signs that the nation's economy might be slowing significantly.

title: Parent & Child
description: THREE years ago Henry J. Miller, the director of information technology and services at the University of Rochester, had some trouble with his home telephone. Although he was in charge of installing a new 12,500-line telephone system at the university, his friends and co-workers said they would almost always receive a busy signal when they called him at home. He quickly traced the problem to its source: his two teen-age daughters.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the resignation of Herbert von Karajan as conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra misstated the political affiliation of Anke Martiny, West Berlin's new Culture Minister. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party, not the Green Party.

title: A Bully New White House
description: If visitors to the capital grow weary of waiting in line for a White House tour, they can head for the Smithsonian Institution Museum of American History, where another grand entryway to 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue awaits them.

title: Ekco Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included a gain of $300,000 from the sale of securities.

title: How to Define a Family: Gay Tenant Fights Eviction
description: For Miguel Brashi and Leslie Blanchard, two gay men who lived together for more than a decade, the one-bedroom apartment on East 54th Street in Manhattan was the focal point of their lives. Now, two and a half years after Mr. Blanchard's death, the apartment is at the center of a legal battle as Mr. Brashi fights eviction in a case that could be precedent-setting.

title: Soviet Diplomats in South Africa After Three Decades of Hostility
description: The Soviet Union today dispatched its first public diplomatic mission to South Africa since the two countries broke off relations 33 years ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 Japan was jolted anew by a suicide. One of Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's closest aides took his life. New complications hampered the search for a new Prime Minister. Page A1

title: Major Housing Effort Is Canceled by Kemp
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development today canceled a major rehabilitation program that it found was plagued with poor management.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Comp-U-Check Inc., Southfield, Mich., a financial services subsidiary of OTF Equities Inc., appointed Martin R. Durbec president.

title: Bush's Timid 100 Days
description: No one ever said that George Bush had to end addiction, corruption and pollution in his first 100 days in office.

title: Connecticut Natural Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $1,269,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the eighth day of Passover and Eastern Orthodox Good Friday, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Ocean Drilling & Exploration Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included a gain of $2 million from the reversal of a prior year's provision for a natural gas pricing dispute.

title: Gander Mountain Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Home Improvement
description: SHEET-VINYL flooring is popular because of its appearance, its durability and its easy care.

title: WPP Group Buys Sales Promotion Firm
description: The WPP Group added another link to its growing chain yesterday, acquiring a British sales promotion firm. The London-based marketing communications conglomerate will pay up to $12.3 million for the firm, Marketing Consultancy Ltd.

title: Montblanc Inking the Check, PEN Holds Evening of Wine and Roseland
description: Established writers and old money rubbed shoulders with up-and-coming talents and fortunes last night at the thronged PEN spring dinner dance, held this year at Roseland, on West 52d Street.

title: Intel Will Cut Up to 600 Jobs
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it would eliminate up to 600 factory positions this year as part of a cost-cutting program.

title: Anheuser-Busch Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: * Colgate-Palmolive Co. agreed to acquire McKesson Corp.'s veterinary services division. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Ryland Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dynascan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Post-Postwar Europe
description: The democratically elected leader of West Germany, bowing to his public's opinion, last week decided that the threat from the Soviet Union had virtually vanished.

title: Wyoming's Election For U.S. House Seat Goes to Republican
description: A Republican state legislator was elected today to fill Wyoming's only seat in the United States House of Representatives. The seat was vacated last month when Dick Cheney became Secretary of Defense.

title: Maxus Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $70 million loss from an accounting change.

title: After Citizens Rejection, NCNB Turns to Mcorp
description: The NCNB Corporation, daunted but unbowed after the rejection of its proposed merger with the largest bank in Georgia, disclosed yesterday that it is interested in acquiring subsidiary banks of Mcorp, the largest remaining independent banking company in Texas.

title: Gainsco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jersey Bell Plans to Add 3d Area Code
description: New Jersey Bell is establishing a new telephone area code for a rapidly developing part of northern New Jersey, partly to keep pace with a brisk economy and partly to satisfy the telecommunication revolution's voracity for additional numbers.

title: Interest Withholding Means a Refund Bonanza
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold War Comfort
description: Winding down the 40-year military confrontation with the Soviet Union - ending the cold war - is an idea that fills the United States with uneasiness. That is the message coming out of Washington these days.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Federal Reserve has stopped pushing interest rates up because of recent signs that the economy might be slowing, top officials acknowledge. [ Page A1. ] The economy slowed modestly to a 3 percent rate of growth in the first quarter. [ D1. ] Moody's and Standard & Poor's upgraded New York State's creditworthiness rating and gave top ratings to the state's short-term bonds. The changes surprised state officials. [ A1. ] A Federal judge declined to reduce Ivan Boesky's prison term. Mr. Boesky settled insider-trading charges in 1986 and cooperated in the Government investgation of Wall Street. [ D1. ] The House Banking Committee approved subsidies for low- and moderate-income home buyers, while apparently weakening in its support for tough capital standards. [ D1. ] Newspaper publishers received a stark warning: reinvent the daily newspaper or risk permanent decline. [ D23. ] INTERNATIONAL Mobil may be pulling out of South Africa, newspapers there reported. Mobil declined to comment. Some people suggested that such a decision might reflect a change in American tax law. [ D1. ] Third world countries operated the hottest stock markets last year. [ D6. ] COMPANIES Minorco claimed victory in battle for Consolidated Gold Fields, but the takeover faces several legal obstacles. [ D1. ] The F.C.C. granted Rupert Murdoch's request to transfer his Boston TV station to a trust to comply with rules against owning a broadcast property and a newspaper in the same city. [ D22. ] United Airlines placed a $15.74 billion order with Boeing, the largest order ever by an airline. [ D1. ] The outside directors of the Loral agreed to sell two of the company's divisions to a management group. [ D5. ] NCNB said it was interested in Mcorp, the largest remaining independent banking company in Texas. [ D2. ] Tandy opened a plant that will assemble personal computers for Panasonic, Japan's largest consumer eletronics company. [ D8. ] The tender offer for NWA by Marvin Davis may be blocked by an order from the Minnesota Commissioner of Commerce. [ D8. ] Manufacturers Hanover is imposing new fees on its credit cards and higher interest rates on some customers. [ D5. ] Ted Turner announced a commercial-free news program for secondary schools and will pay for the show. [ D23. ] Intel will eliminate up to 600 factory positions as part of a cost-cutting program. [ D5. ] MARKETS Stock prices edged higher in listless trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.20 points, to 2,389.11. [ D12. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in moderately active trading. [ D19. ] Gasoline prices climbed to their highest level since Nov. 27, 1985, bolstered by a volatile combination of factors. [ D20. ] The dollar pushed higher against all major currencies. [ D20. ] Yields ranged from unchanged to slightly higher on money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Metropolitan Life insists that borrowers repay loans immediately if the company changed hands. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Cineplex Odeon is embroiled in a nasty fight over control of the company and its accounting. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D12. ] TBWA may establish a second network of agencies in Europe. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D24. ]

title: Norfolk Southern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Johnson & Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company's first quarter share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable May 10 to shareholders of record April 26.

title: Investcorp Gets Gucci U.S. Stake
description: Investcorp, the Bahrain investment bank, said yesterday in London that it had acquired a 50 percent interest in Gucci America Inc. in addition to the 50 percent already held in Guccio Gucci S.p.A., the principal Gucci leather goods company based in Florence. Paul Dimitruk, a member of Investcorp's management committee, said that the American investment made last week completes its acquisition plans for Gucci.

title: Such Principled Publishers!
description: Very early in the Salman Rushdie affair, Britain's Publishers Association decided not to engage in undignified ''shouting from rooftops,'' as a spokesman put it. It was true that a British writer and his British publishers were under death threat because the Ayatollah Khomeini was displeased by Mr. Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses.'' But the association was concerned ''not to aggravate unnecessarily a deeply unwelcome situation by fuelling it to no constructive purpose.''

title: Convex Profit Doubles
description: The Convex Computer Corporation, a maker of mini-supercomputers, said Tuesday that its earnings doubled in the first quarter, to $2.3 million, or 12 cents a share, from $1.1 million, or 6 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Sales for the first quarter jumped 50.7 percent, to $33.3 million from $22.1 million, because of increased demand for the company's C200 line of supercomputers.

title: MicroAge Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Chief Set At McClatchy
description: McClatchy Newspapers Inc., which is based in Sacramento, Calif., said today that Erwin Potts, its president, had been named chief executive, and that James B. McClatchy, its publisher, would become chairman. Both appointments fill positions held by C. K. McClatchy until his death ib April 16.

title: When Setting Limits, Be Realistic
description: DEVELOPMENTAL psychologists offer several suggestions to help parents handle their adolescents' increasing use of the telephone.

title: Boldness, at Least in Moscow
description: Bush Administration officials urge great caution in dealing with the Soviet Union. They fear that Mikhail Gorbachev might not last and that his successors might be less moderate in foreign affairs. Why take risks on arms control or negotiations about regional conflicts when the Soviet leader's power seems to rest on shaky ground?

title: Contract on Hold
description: Natalya Zvereva's contract with ProServ has been put on hold ''for the time being'' because it violates a team contract signed by the state sports committee, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported yesterday. Tass said lawyers for the two contract-holders would meet to work things out. Zvereva sounded somewhat contrite about her ''probably not sufficiently sound decision'' to sign independently.

title: Review/Music; Sergiu Celibidache Conducts An Unhurried Bruckner 4th
description: Sergiu Celibidache demands unheard-of amounts of orchestral rehearsal time and obviously knows what he wants to do with it. He has an extraordinary ear for orchestral detail. He has a highly developed -though, as his second concert with the Munich Philharmonic showed, not infallible - technique for maintaining spacious tempos. He understands, as Herbert von Karajan and Carlos Kleiber and a few other conductors do, that it is advantageous to play softly a lot of the time if you want a wide palette of expression and tonal beauty. He has a charismatic hold over his orchestra and his admirers.

title: A Player-Friendly Coach
description: Not long ago, Rick Pitino got a surprise. He was talking to a player who was part of the Knicks' first championship team nearly 20 years ago, a squad - Walt Frazier, Willis Reed, Dave DeBusschere, Bill Bradley and Dick Barnett - he assumed had gotten along swimmingly.

title: A Modern Detractor Of French Revolution
description: Simon Schama's hands are moving rapidly through the air as he turns thumbs down on the French Revolution.

title: Publishers Told That Papers Have to Change to Survive
description: The nation's newspaper publishers received a stark warning today: reinvent the daily newspaper or risk permanent decline.

title: Delmarva Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TBWA Is Preparing a 'Coming Out'
description: TBWA ADVERTISING, the European-and-American agency that entered the battle for control of Britain's Boase, Massimi, Pollitt Partnership last week, is considering establishing a second network of agencies in Europe, said William Tragos, TBWA's chairman and chief executive.

title: Domtar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to account for the sale of a high- pressure laminates business. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: TV Notes
description: Cronkite Speaks

title: For All Who Know a Loft From a Parlor
description: IF it's spring, it must be time for house and garden tours. This year, the range of the architecture is from 19th-century Greek Revival to modern, the interior decoration from Victorian to Art Deco, the houses from city apartments to country estates and the gardens from urban deck to English formal.

title: WMS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $2,611,000 in connection with early extinguishment of debt. c-Included a loss of $1,706,000 from discontinued telephone business.

title: Tecumseh Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter results included for the first time on a fully consolidated basis the operations of L'unite Hermetique, a new French subsidiary.

title: Currents; A Footbridge From Another Era
description: TWELVE years ago, the board of Trinity Church in Manhattan decided that its parishioners were living dangerously each time they jaywalked across Trinity Place en route from the Episcopal church to the parish house.

title: Compaq Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Soviets Renew Attack on U.S. and Pakistan
description: Aleksandr M. Belonogov, the Soviet representative to the United Nations, strongly criticized the United States and Pakistan in the Security Council today for their continued support of Afghan rebels and took Pakistan to task for ''interference'' including military involvement in Afghanistan's affairs, in violation of the Geneva accords.

title: The New Yorker Wins Top Prizes In 2 Categories
description: The New Yorker received its fifth citation for reporting and its fourth for fiction yesterday as the American Society of Magazine Editors presented the National Magazine Awards for 1989 during luncheon ceremonies at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: General Electric Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said net income included reductions related to the restructuring in various business units of $490,000 for the latest quarter and $1,847,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions
description: IN my neighborhood or in decent company generally, I would immediately be branded as a grump and maybe a subversive if I whispered even a single negative syllable against spring, now that it's here and at its peak.

title: Transamerica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting of $36,869,000. Year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Keys Shatter Bullet Fired at an Officer
description: A police officer investigating a suspicious car early yesterday was wounded when a bullet fired at him struck keys in his pocket and fragmented, the police said.

title: Reds Send Expos to Defeat in 6-5 Game
description: Chris Sabo's two-run double helped Cincinnati's Rick Mahler end a streak of tough luck with a 6-5 victory tonight over the struggling Montreal Expos.

title: Safety in the Park: In Women's Hands
description: LEAD: I'm thinking about the young woman, the investment banker, who is lying in a hospital, unconscious, after trying to relieve the day's stress by taking a run in the park, where she ran into more stress than her body, mind and heart, however healthy and strong, could withstand.

title: Chatter and Jellybeans in Presidential Reunion
description: They began with small talk about their wives. ''How's Nancy - all right?'' asked George Bush. ''Barbara's recovered, doing just fine.''

title: Guilford Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Jerome Robbins to Take 4-Month Leave From City Ballet
description: Jerome Robbins, citing the ''enormous toll'' of his work in ballet and on Broadway in recent years, will take a four-month leave of absence as co-director of the New York City Ballet.

title: Third World Markets Sizzled in '88
description: Third world countries operated the world's hottest-performing stock markets last year as exchanges in Brazil, Mexico, Taiwan and South Korea rose eight to ten times faster than the New York Stock Exchange and three times faster than Tokyo's exchange, according to data compiled by a subsidiary of the World Bank.

title: Tandy Opens Texas Plant in Link With Matsushita
description: The Tandy Corporation today opened a plant for assembling a variety of American-made personal computers, including three for Japan's largest consumer electronics company that will be sold under the Panasonic label.

title: Management Science America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Memory Inspires a Prize-Winning Quilt
description: A preschool Head Start teacher from Colorado, who is unknown in quilting circles beyond her home state, was awarded first prize yesterday in an international quilting contest sponsored by the Museum of American Folk Art.

title: Mediq Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,227,000 for the quarter and $1,506,000 for the 6 months, and extraordinary gains of $102,000 and $3,449,000 from debenture buybacks for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Martin Lawrence Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Coal Miners' Strike Hits Feelings That Go Deep
description: A strike by 1,400 members of the United Mine Workers of America against the largest coal producer in Virginia has become the contentious centerpiece of life here in the jagged southwestern tip of the state.

title: Motivation Key Factor With Athletes
description: When the National Basketball Association playoffs begin tonight, three quarters of the players -and a higher percentage of the stars - will be black. Does that mean black players have a physical edge in leaping toward the basket?

title: Lawyers Criticize Judge
description: Five law school professors criticized the judge who said baseball was engaging in a vendetta against Pete Rose and all except one said the judge should disqualify himself if the Cincinnati Reds' manager is indicted. Three of the five contacted by The Associated Press said Carl B. Rubin, the chief judge of United States District Court in Cincinnati, violated the American Bar Association's Code of Judicial Conduct in publicly commenting on Rose.

title: Revisions of Medicare Doctor Fees Are Urged
description: Congress is being urged to overhaul Medicare payments to doctors in a way intended to reflect the real costs of services, rather than their market value.

title: More Soccer Violence
description: Hundreds of rival soccer fans battled each other and attacked the police today during riots on the day of the Netherlands-West Germany World Cup qualifying match. At least 23 people were reported injured.

title: Heading for Hills? Fees Rise Slightly
description: There are some slight increases this year in the fees being charged by New York's Department of Environmental Conservation for use of the campgrounds and recreation areas it operates in the Catskills and the Adirondacks.

title: Outside the Quiet of the Court, Deeply Held Beliefs Collide Noisily
description: The passions of the abortion rights debate spilled into the streets outside the Supreme Court this morning.

title: Gooden Wins 4th In a Row
description: The Mets, mourned and even maligned this season, closed a ringing homestand last night with their fourth straight victory and their seventh in nine games, and with more of the pitching mastery that has carried them from the bottom of the National League's East to the top in a week and a half.

title: Bemis Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Faces Floodtide Of Newcomers in 90's
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lawyer Going to Tokyo For Wasserstein, Perella
description: LEAD: Wasserstein, Perella & Company Inc. announced yesterday that Toby S. Myerson, a lawyer who specializes mergers and acquisitions and corporate finance involving Japanese companies, would be its managing director in charge of its East Asian operations.

title: Gold Fields Is Claimed By Minorco
description: Minorco S.A., the overseas investment arm of the Anglo American and De Beers group of South Africa, claimed victory today in its long-running battle for control of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C., with the mining group saying it had gained control of a majority of the shares of the British company.

title: Holly Farms' Plan
description: The Holly Farms Corporation renewed its resistance to a $1.15 billion takeover bid and told shareholders an overall refinancing of the company was being considered. Holly Farms has opposed a takeover by a rival poultry processor, Tyson Foods Inc., since October. Holly shareholders voted last week to reject a management-backed move to merge their company with Conagra Inc. of Omaha. In a statement announcing a quarterly dividend of 38 cents a share, Holly managers said a ''leveraged recapitalization'' is under consideration.

title: Currents; Big Easy In the Great Outdoors
description: WHAT has been lacking in outdoor furniture design is an easy chair, and now Larry Zellner has filled that gap.

title: Market Place; Cineplex Odeon Audit Controversy
description: THE Cineplex Odeon Corporation, a Canadian company that has rapidly become one of the largest operators of movie theaters in the United States, is embroiled in a nasty fight over both control of the company and whether its accounting is fair and accurate.

title: Stocks Edge Higher as Dow Gains 2.20
description: LEAD: Stock prices edged higher in listless trading yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.20 points to close at 2,389.11.

title: SOVIETS CURB NEWS ABOUT DISASTERS
description: The Soviet Government has issued strict new curbs on press reporting of accidents at nuclear power plants, angering Soviet journalists who have enjoyed greater freedom under the current Soviet leadership.

title: Goldfield Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Helping a Spouse Cope With a Chronic Illness
description: How spouses treat their partners suffering a chronic illness like arthritis has a more profound impact than might be expected on how well the sick partners mentally adjust to the suffering, a new study indicates.

title: Kelly Is Suing His Former Agents
description: Jim Kelly, the quarterback for the Buffalo Bills, filed a lawsuit yesterday against his former agents for what he charged were improprieties in the handling of his business affairs. The suit was filed in Fort Bend County District Court in Texas, against Gregory Lustig, Kenneth Weinberger and A. J. Faigin, his agents from 1983 to 1988, who were charged in the suit as grossly negligent in their duties.

title: Fischer & Porter Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ERC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Concerns Raised on Prostate Surgery
description: The standard operation for enlarged prostates in men is less effective than the operation it replaced and, surprisingly, seems to cause more deaths in later years, a new international study has found.

title: Gasoline Highest Since '85; New Pollution Rules Cited
description: Gasoline prices climbed yesterday to their highest level since Nov. 27, 1985, bolstered by a volatile combination of factors. The chief technical factor was the expiration tomorrow of the May unleaded gasoline delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Campaign Matters; In Jersey G.O.P., Every Candidate Is Kean's Buddy
description: Show us a Republican candidate for governor, and we'll show you Gov. Thomas H. Kean's best friend.

title: New Respect for Ellington's Later Works
description: Even as the 90th anniversary of Duke Ellington's birth rolls around this Saturday, the magnitude of his contribution to American culture is still being fought over and reappraised. That is because his immense musical output resists easy categorization, because it overflows the traditional boundaries separating vernacular and high artistic expression.

title: The Central City Chorus Is to Perform Messiaen
description: Messiaen's rarely heard ''Trois Petites Liturgies de la Presence Divine'' is to be performed Sunday and Tuesday by the Central City Chorus in honor of the composer's 80th birthday. The program will also include Poulenc's ''Motets for the Season of Lent'' and Durufle's ''Messe cum jubilo.''

title: Acuson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WLR Foods reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net loss c-Included a gain of $1,112,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Shell Canada Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. Listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Official in Minnesota Plans To Block Davis's NWA Bid
description: Maintaining that NWA Inc.'s shareholders were entitled to more information before deciding whether to sell their company, the Minnesota Commissioner of Commerce said today that he planned to issue an order blocking a $90-a-share tender offer for the parent of Northwest Airlines by the industrialist Marvin Davis unless the information is provided by Thursday.

title: At Kips Bay, Chintz Eclipsed
description: THE Kips Bay Decorator Show House has come of age. The prestigious annual event - this is its 17th year - is New York decorating at the top of its form.

title: Culbro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included net of $1,424,000 from distributed consumer finance business.

title: No Glass Cage for AIDS Pupil
description: An incontinent, retarded 7-year-old girl with AIDS, who had been told that she could attend public school only if she was isolated inside a glass booth, may instead sit at a desk alongside other mentally disabled children her age, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: 2 Are Indicted In Brutal Rape In Central Park
description: Two of the eight youths accused of beating and raping a woman who was jogging in Central Park last week were indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday.

title: Pennsylvania Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Now It's Santa Fe Pacific
description: Stockholders of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation voted Tuesday to changed the name of the Chicago-based company to the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation. The change was required by the company's sale of the Southern Pacific Transportation Company to Rio Grande Industries last October.

title: America West Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credit of $3,629,000. c-Net loss

title: Rospatch Seeking Bids for Company
description: The Rospatch Corporation said the special evaluation committee of its board was actively soliciting acquisition offers for all or part of the company. All serious offers, including a possible leveraged buyout by the company's management, would be considered, said Jones Pharr, chairman of the committee.

title: For Afghans, A Major Goal Is Credibility
description: The Afghan rebels' newly formed ''interim government'' is floundering, Afghans and Western diplomats say, troubled by military stalemate, by rivalries among its seven parties and the complex legacy of more than 10 years of civil war.

title: Northern States Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Rock; Up From the Underground, Pulnoc Plays at P.S. 122
description: Ominous drumbeats and stark, droning chords carried the music of Pulnoc (Midnight), the Czechoslovak rock band that started a two-night stand Monday at P.S. 122. The lyrics are in Czech, but the dark tone and inexorable momentum of the songs made perfect sense to an American ear.

title: Tucson Electric Power reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed yesterday in moderately active trading, as market participants shrugged off a preliminary Government report that showed non-farm economic growth in the first quarter had slowed.

title: Mattel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Airline Failed to Obey Rule on Cargo Door Checks
description: United Airlines failed last year to make repeated inspections of cargo bay doors on its Boeing 747 aircraft as new rules required, an airline official told the board investigating why a door ripped off a United jet leaving Honolulu in February.

title: North Jury Still Deliberating
description: The jurors in the trial of Oliver L. North deliberated about six hours today without giving any indication that a verdict was near. The jurors have now spent five days, for a total of 27 hours, weighing the the case against Mr. North, a former aide to the National Security Council who is accused of 12 crimes stemming from his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Downey Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $10,945,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Schwarz Foresees No Sceptered Mayor in New York
description: As the Charter Revision Commission tries to put New York City's government back together again, some officials and experts are fearful that an already powerful chief executive will end up an Imperial Mayor.

title: Hazy Election Outlook Fans Fears in Argentina
description: With the presidential elections next month unlikely to produce a clear-cut winner and the economy spiraling out of control, many political and economic leaders fear that the coming months will bring growing instability to Argentina.

title: George Coulouris, 85, Is Dead; Actor Relished Villainous Roles
description: George Coulouris, an actor who portrayed a rogue's gallery of villains in dozens of plays and films, died of heart failure Tuesday in London after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Review/Dance; 'Mozartiana' Opens City Ballet's Spring Season
description: As she glided forward in ''Mozartiana'' on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, Kyra Nichols slowly raised her arms in wonder and reverence. Because ''Mozartiana'' opened the New York City Ballet's first program of the spring season, those gestures were especially appropriate. They reminded one of the wonder of this company's repertory and seemed to ask a blessing upon the performance.

title: Fire Kills 216,000 Chickens At Egg Farm in Connecticut
description: A fire at the largest egg farm in the state destroyed 216,000 chickens and caused $3 million to $4 million in damages, the authorities said today.

title: Pacific Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Walvis Bay Journal; At Namibia's Gateway, South Africa Has the Key
description: In 1487, the Portuguese navigator Bartholomeu Dias, searching for a passage to the Orient, sailed into the harbor here and discovered nothing beyond the dunes but more sand.

title: Beizbol Isn't an Old Russian Village Sport?
description: To the Editor:

title: Scana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Standex International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Margery Madden Porter, Executive, 85
description: Margery Madden Porter, one of the first women appointed as a corporate officer of a worldwide company, died of cancer Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Duriron Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split that was paid in March.

title: Shot-Putter Says Threat Effective
description: A shot-putter suspended for using banned drugs said today that he was reinstated by the Canadian Track and Field Association after he threatened to expose steroid use by the sprinter Ben Johnson and his teammates.

title: Montana Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Glossary of Court Precedents
description: In the Supreme Court abortion argument today, both the Justices and the lawyers referred frequently, usually through shorthand citations, to the Court's precedents in abortion and privacy cases. What follows are brief descriptions of the principal cases cited.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on March 31 about black talk radio described the programming of WCEV, a Chicago radio station, incompletely. The station broadcasts in several languages besides Polish.

title: Alfred G. Milotte, 84, And Elma Milotte, 81
description: Alfred G. and Elma Milotte, nature-film photographers who won six Academy Awards while working for Walt Disney, died less than a week apart. Mrs. Milotte died April 19 at the couple's home near Tacoma. She was 81 years old. Her husband, who was ill and lived in a nursing home in Gig Harbor, Wash., died Monday. He was 84.

title: CDI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Metropolitan Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
United Places Order for 370 Boeing Planes
description: United Airlines said yesterday that it had placed a $15.74 billion order for new planes in a move expected to put pressure on its weaker competitors and enable the airline to begin to catch up with American and Delta airlines in the race to dominate major markets.

title: Wynn's International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $1,375,000 from the sale of substantially all of the company's interest in Wynn-Kiki Inc., a joint venture. c-Net loss The year-ago quarter results were adversely affected by an after-tax charge of $1,011,000 relating to costs associated with management changes and the termination of the company's supplemental retirement plan.

title: Golden Valley Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Profiles of the Three Advocates in the Appeal
description: Three lawyers made their arguments for and against abortion rights today at a Supreme Court hearing on Missouri law that restricts women's right to abortion. Here are sketches of the lawyers. WILLIAM L. WEBSTER William L. Webster, Attorney General of Missouri, knows that if he is successful today, his name will become part of American legal history.

title: Drug Found to Reduce Chance of 2d Ulcer
description: A drug that reduces the amount of acid produced by the stomach can often prevent a second ulcer from appearing if the medicine is given each night, California researchers reported today.

title: Mother's Almanac, Revisited
description: MARGUERITE KELLY does not have a medical degree, but she can spot a child with a fever at five hundred paces. And she's no psychiatrist, but she has ways of quelling waves of anxiety and she knows all about the psychological value of a child's dillydallying.

title: May Transfers Official From Sibley to G. Fox
description: Matthew D. Serra, who in the mid-1980's was president of the Gimbels stores in New York and Philadelphia, has been named president and chief executive officer of G. Fox & Company of Hartford, the largest department-store chain in Connecticut.

title: Turner Plans to Give Schools An Ad-Free News Program
description: Ted Turner, chairman of Turner Broadcasting Inc., announced plans yesterday for a new commercial-free news program that would be provided to secondary schools beginning in August.

title: Bhopal Aid Rise Rejected at Carbide
description: Shareholders of the Union Carbide Corporation overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to increase the compensation the company will pay victims of the poison gas leak in Bhopal, India, in 1984 that caused the deaths of more than 3,300 people. Earlier this year, the Indian Government and the Danbury, Conn., chemical giant agreed on a $470 million settlement of claims stemming from the gas leak.

title: Talley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $45,000 in income from discontinued operations.

title: Norton Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $1.6 million for the latest first quarter and $2.2 million for the year-ago period.

title: Valvano Is Pressured
description: The faculty senate at North Carolina State unanimously endorsed a report yesterday from its Committee on Academic Integrity that recommended Jim Valvano, the head coach, should not also be the college's athletic director because of a conflict of interest when he creates policies for himself. The committee was formed to examine North Carolina State's handling of student grades in the wake of allegations of improper grade changing on the basketball team. The committee chairman, Dr. Edward P. Stahel 2d, a professor of chemical engineering, said the panel had discovered that basketball players were not encouraged to achieve beyond the minimal level to keep them eligible to play.(AP)

title: Du Pont, E I de Nemours & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter included a gain of $38 million from the sale of a partial interest in a north sea natural gas property. The year-earlier period included a gain of $30 million from the settlement of litigation and the sale of technology.

title: BCE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Q&A
description: Squeaky Floors Q. We recently moved into an old house and we are having a problem with squeaky floors. Is there anything we can do, or do the floors have to be replaced? A. I doubt very much that you would have to replace the flooring. Most squeaks result from loose floorboards that move up and down slightly when walked on. The edges rubbing together make the squeaking noise.

title: Suicide of a Takeshita Aide Adds Drama to Search for a Successor
description: Shaken and weakened by Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's decision to resign, the Government was jolted anew today by the suicide of one of Mr. Takeshita's closest aides and by complications hampering the search for a new Prime Minister.

title: Attack on Jogger Underlines Need to Deal Wtih Urban Violence; Safety Measures
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Shouldn't Abet Patients in Fraud; Inaccurate Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Hannaford Brothers Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $1,874,000 from an accounting change.

title: Repairing a Chair's Loose Framework
description: LEAD: The lasting tightness of a chair with a loose dowel or roundrail seat frame can never be achieved satisfactorily without at least partially dismantling the framework.

title: Interpublic's Profit Increases by 20%
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said its net income jumped 20 percent in the first quarter over the corresponding period last year. The parent company of McCann-Erickson, Lintas: Worldwide, and Dailey & Associates reported net income of $8 million, compared with $6.6 million in the first three months of 1988. Earnings per share increased to 36 cents, from 31 cents last year, and revenue jumped almost 14 percent, to $276.5 million from $242.7 million.

title: Court Ruling Helps Brooklyn Incumbents' School Board Bids
description: A Federal judge's ruling striking down a state law intended to reduce conflicts of interest has given a boost to a number of Brooklyn incumbents who are seeking re-election in community school board elections next Tuesday. Until the ruling was handed down Tuesday, those candidates, as well as some incumbents in other boroughs, had been campaigning for board positions that they could not hold.

title: Tokyo Contract For G.E. Turbines
description: The General Electric Company's chairman, John F. Welch Jr., announced at the company's annual meeting here that G.E. would be given a gas-turbine order by the Tokyo Electric Power Company, valued at about $750 million. ''That is the largest fossil generation order in the history of G.E.,'' Mr. Welch said.

title: Leslie Fay Cos reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Books of The Times; Alice Walker Stresses Man's Cruelty
description: The Temple of My Familiar By Alice Walker 416 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: At Least 40 Are Dead In Mauritania Attacks
description: Rioters stabbed, stoned or clubbed to death at least 40 people and injured 700 in two days of attacks against Senegalese living here in the capital of Mauritania, hospital officials said today.

title: Washington Gas Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Weighing Arctic Drilling
description: A measure that would open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration and drilling is now before Congress. So is one that would take the refuge out of play by upgrading it to wilderness status. Here is the public's view.

title: House Rejects $1 Billion Cut in Pentagon Spending
description: Rebuffing their own leadership, House Democrats today joined Republicans to defeat a bill that would have taken more than $1 billion from this year's Pentagon budget to help pay for programs to aid the homeless and fight drugs.

title: Bolt Beranek & Newman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $6,395,000. c-Net income

title: Roses, Woven in a Fragrant Tapestry
description: Now that even tulips cost $6.50 for half a dozen at the corner fruit and vegetable market and many store-bought flowers seem to wither in two days, a florist who creates arrangements of roses that look superb when they arrive and also dry beautifully is sure to be in demand.

title: HIGH COURT ASKS SHARP QUESTIONS IN ABORTION CASE
description: For an intense, tightly orchestrated hour, the Supreme Court heard arguments today in a Missouri abortion case that could be a vehicle for withdrawing or restricting the 16-year-old constitutional right to abortion.

title: Creating New Habits For the Common Good
description: Every other Monday, when Mira and Jose Alvares take out the trash at their home in Manhasset, L.I., they also leave bundled newspapers and an orange bucket full of cans and bottles to be recycled.

title: Knicks vs. Barkley: Round 1 Tonight
description: Forget that the Knicks won the Atlantic Division title for the first time since 1970-71. Forget, too, that they won 52 games, the most since 1972-73, and set a franchise record of 26 straight victories at home, posting a 36-5 mark at Madison Square Garden. That tied a club record established by the 1972-73 Knicks, who won the National Basketball Association championship.

title: Bridge
description: There is a fine line between bids that are never right and bids that are almost never right. Opening in a suit and raising a one-level response to a slam might seem to belong in the former category, but the diagramed deal demonstrates that it must be placed in the latter.

title: Atlanta, Used to Praise, Confronts Crime Ranking
description: After years of promoting itself as one of the nation's premier centers for economic growth, Atlanta now finds itself trying to refute figures indicating that it leads the nation in something less enviable: crime.

title: Betz Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Richard Bourne-Vanneck, Publisher, 75
description: Richard Bourne-Vanneck, who owned The New York Age, a black weekly newspaper that ceased publication in the 1960's, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. He was 75 years old.

title: Attack on Jogger Underlines Need to Deal With Urban Violence
description: To the Editor: Every citizen of New York City was shocked and outraged by the brutal assault on the young woman who was set upon April 19 jogging in Central Park. The crime chilled even the most hardened New Yorkers, but none more so than those of us who work with her at Salomon Brothers.

title: Yonkers 'Lone Voice' Admits Fake Threats
description: Laurie A. Recht, the Yonkers legal secretary who gained prominence as a ''lone voice'' favoring compliance with a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court to concocting death threats against herself.

title: 9th Murder Victim Identified
description: The death toll from a killer apparently stalking prostitutes and drug users rose to nine today as investigators tentatively identified another body left along a highway in southeastern Massachusetts. The authorities said an autopsy on the victim, found Monday along Interstate 195 in Marion, yielded a preliminary identification. But they declined to release the victim's name pending confirmation with dental records.

title: Irwin Overcomes Problem to Earn a Tie
description: Hale Irwin, one of golf's finest mid-iron shotmakers when he won two United States Open titles in 1974 and 1979, said today he was not comfortable playing the tour these days.

title: General Binding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.N.P. Rate Is Up by 3% For Quarter
description: The economy slowed modestly to a 3 percent rate of growth in the first quarter after a special adjustment for last summer's drought, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Union Exploration Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Great-West Lifeco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After special charges of $4,806,000. c-Included a special gain of $156,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Talking Deals; Metropolitan's Bond Covenants
description: FOR nearly four years the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has insisted that any company that wanted to borrow money from it agree to repay the loans immediately if the company changed hands.

title: Net Up 13.6% At Johnson
description: In its final quarter under James E. Burke, who stepped down yesterday after 13 years as chairman and chief executive, Johnson & Johnson posted a 13.6 percent earnings gain.

title: Baughan Resigns
description: Maxie Baughan, who last season led Cornell to its first Ivy League football title since 1971, has stepped down as head coach amid reports he was romantically involved with his top assistant's wife. Citing personal tensions in Cornell's football program, the 50-year-old Baughan resigned Tuesday from the post he has held since 1983. His resignation came six months after the Big Red tied Penn for the Ivy League championship, Cornell's first title since 1971. A rift between Baughan and his assistant head coach, Peter Noyes, surfaced two weeks ago. The Ithaca Journal reported later that the rift stemmed from a romantic relationship between Baughan and Noyes's wife, Cathy.

title: Reviews/Music; From Master of the Tango, A New, Darker Ensemble
description: To an innocent outsider, it might seem no big deal that Astor Piazzolla, the master of the tango, had changed his ensemble from a quintet to a sextet. To tango lovers, it is a very big deal indeed, Mr. Piazzolla's first new band in 27 years, and Alice Tully Hall was full Monday night to witness the ''world debut'' of his new ensemble.

title: Kentucky Says Coach's Job Was Not Offered Carlesimo
description: University of Kentucky officials met for more than an hour yesterday in Lexington with Coach P. J. Carlesimo of Seton Hall. But when the officials emerged from the meeting, they said that Carlesimo had not been offered the job as Kentucky's basketball coach.

title: New Jersey Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Eastern Promises Payments

Review/Music; Slatkin Leads the St. Louis In the Shostakovich 10th
description: Leonard Slatkin hardly confines his explorations of the 20th-century symphonic tradition to American composers; he is also a Shostakovich specialist. He led a well-received series of performances of Shostakovich's Eighth Symphony earlier this year with the New York Philharmonic, having already given the Eighth with his St. Louis Symphony here in 1982. He did the 11th and the Fifth here with St. Louis in 1985 and 1987, and the 10th with the Philharmonic also in 1987. Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, for the first of three St. Louis Symphony concerts in Manhattan, he offered the 10th yet again.

title: Correction: Transcript In Abortion Argument
description: The transcript of oral arguments in the Supreme Court in the case of Webster v. Reproductive Health Services was incomplete in some copies yesterday. Justice Stevens While you are getting ready, General Webster, I would like you to answer Justice Scalia's question whether in the funding provision, the funding officer would have a duty to promulgate regulations that would prevent a doctor, a state employee, from performing abortions and the like. title: Review/Film; Doomed Passion Of Abelard And Heloise
description: The true story of the 12th-century lovers Abelard and Heloise has everything a grand, passionate film could want - sex, religion, intellect, violence and elaborate costumes. The love affair between the philosopher and teacher Pierre Abelard and his beautiful, gifted student defied not only the convention of chastity for teachers, but also Heloise's powerful uncle's wishes for her prosperous marriage. So after the lovers had a child and secretly married, her uncle took the nastiest possible revenge and had Abelard castrated. Stricken in his conscience as well as his loins, Abelard became a monk; Heloise reluctantly entered a convent.

title: Dining Out Guide: Restaurant Row
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Joe Allen * (Aug. 19, 1988), 326 West 46th Street (581-6464) - The cast of dining spots along restaurant row (46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues) has changed dramatically in recent years. One establishment that has endured for 24 years is Joe Allen. A good starter is a salad of grilled sea scallops over arugula and red peppers in a mild vinaigrette. Reliable entrees include grilled chicken and the hefty house hamburger. Most desserts are heavy hitters: creamy cheesecake, and hot fudge pudding. At dinner, appetizers are $4 to $7, entrees $14 to $19. Noon to midnight daily except Wednesday and Saturday, when the kitchen opens at 11:30 A.M. Carolina * (Feb. 14, 1986), 355 West 46th Street (245-0058) - The main dining room is one of the more accommodating on the block, with its arching skylight, gray banquettes and wraparound mirror walls. Carolina's narrowly focused menu is based on regional American cuisine: beefy chili stoked with hot peppers, deep-fried crab cakes, and hot-smoked brisket of beef. Most desserts are winners, from the citric lime pie to dense chocolate cheesecake. At dinner, appetizers are $4 to $9, entrees $16 to $25. Lunch Monday through Friday noon to 3 P.M.; dinner Monday, 5:30 to 9 P.M.; Tuesday through Saturday, 5:30 to midnight; Sunday, 5:30 to 9 P.M. Lattanzi * (Sept. 14, 1984), 361 West 46th Street (315-0980) - This is a simply decorated room with exposed brick walls and small hanging lights. The cappellini primavera, with its impeccably cooked vegetables, is one of the finest renditions in town. Baby artichokes prepared in the style of the Jewish quarter in Rome are superb in golden-green olive oil pungent with garlic. Pasta, available in appetizer portions, is for the most part exceptional. Tomato sauce, in various guises, is common to many of the dishes: a notable rendition is the lightly spiced sauce with capers and browned nuggets of chicken in the pollo capriccioso. A rich tartuffo, almond-scented Italian chocolate gelato, is a good finale. At dinner, appetizers are $5.50 to $10.50, entrees $13.95 to $21.95. Lunch noon to 2 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner starts at 5 and continues until 10 P.M. Monday and Tuesday, 11 P.M. Wednesday and Thursday and midnight on Friday and Saturday. Closed Sundays. Orso ** (Feb. 17, 1989), 322 West 46th Street (489-7212) - This breezy restaurant is done in clean ocher tones and wood, with an open tile-and-steel kitchen in the rear that buzzes practically nonstop. The pizzas are light enough to sample without spoiling the appetite, with thin yeasty crusts and sprightly toppings. Pastas rotate daily, and among the best of the regular repertory is tagliatelle tossed with cubes of grilled eggplant, radicchio and Parmesan. Seafood is the best of the entrees. You can't go wrong with the grilled tuna steak in a clean and lively Mediterranean sauce of black olives, tomatoes and capers. Try the eye-opening espresso gelato for dessert. At dinner, appetizers are $7 to $8, entrees $16 to $19. Noon to 11:30 daily except Wednesday and Saturday, when the kitchen opens at 11:30 A.M. What the stars mean, page C22.

title: Washington's Inaugural, Afloat, Aloft and on Foot
description: ANOTHER bicentennial is upon us, and, as always, that means it's time for a no-holds-barred citywide celebration. Like the 1976 Bicentennial of American independence and the 1987 bicentennial of the Constitution, the 200th anniversary of George Washington's inauguration on April 30, 1789, will be duly and flamboyantly noted. Fireworks, a parade, a fleet of ships, the opening of a new museum and a flurry of exhibitions are planned for this weekend. But the centerpiece of this patriotic pageantry will be a dramatization of the first Inaugural at Federal Hall National Memorial in lower Manhattan that is scheduled to include President Bush, a George Washington impersonator and a troupe of politicians.

title: Review/Film; Seeking Redemption In a Beauty Pageant
description: ''Miss Firecracker'' begins and ends with the image of a little girl in a fuzzy hat that looks like a cropped yellow wig. She wears a droopy yellow dress, has some missing teeth and smiles excitedly as she waves and blows kisses at someone passing by. She seems so pathetic and so remarkably hopeful that the image is disturbing and resonant, suggesting the poignant funny-looking tale of hope and despair that might have been ''Miss Firecracker.''

title: KEMP HALTS MONEY FOR RENOVATIONS
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has canceled spending on a major rehabilitation program that it found plagued with poor management.

title: Hearst Plans Cable Sale
description: The Hearst Corporation has put its cable operations up for sale. The system, which has 60,000 subscribers and passes 110,000 homes, is in the San Francisco market.

title: Restaurants
description: You have to be in a festive mood to appreciate Oriental Pearl, a sprawling 500-seat Chinese party palace on Mott Street. I have never been there when there wasn't a wedding, birthday party, family reunion or straight-A's-in-seventh-grade party rattling the house. Major celebrations are partitioned off from other diners by a long pink curtain, which is sort of like insulating a ski chalet with a screen door. When chopsticks clink against glasses, beckoning the bride and groom to kiss, the din can create waves in your tea cup.

title: Paper Says Brawley Friend Was Told of Faked Assault
description: A friend of Tawana Brawley has said that the black Dutchess County teen-ager - in league with her mother, Glenda - concocted the account of racially motivated sexual assault by white men in 1987 to escape punishment by her mother's companion for staying out late, New York Newsday reported yesterday.

title: The Woman Behind the Fetus
description: In the case of Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, the Supreme Court this week heard arguments about protection of the fetus and its relation to the right of privacy in using contraceptives. Almost lost in the legal tangle is that the high court is making a decision about women: their health, dignity, sexuality - even their economic well-being.

description: b-Net loss Included in the consolidated results are USAir Group's principal operating subsidiaries, USAir and Piedmont Aviation, and four wholly owned commuter airlines. Piedmont was acquired by USAir Group on Nov. 5, 1987, and will be merged with USAir on Aug. 5, 1989. USAir's 1989 operations included operations conducted on routes formerly served by Pacific Southwest Airlines, which was merged into USAir on April 9, 1988.

title: Ewing Player of Month
description: Patrick Ewing, the Knicks' center, was named yesterday as the National Basketball Association's player of the month for April. Ewing, who helped lead the Knicks to their first division championship since 1971, averaged 24 points, 10.4 rebounds, 3.4 assists and 3.3 blocked shots in the April games before the playoffs started last night.

title: Review/Film; A Canine Constable and Partner, in 'K-9'
description: Jerry Lee, the drug-busting German shepherd who upstages James Belushi in the new comedy-thriller ''K-9,'' is one tough animal. When a vicious thug hurls a pool ball at his head, the dog - named after rock-and-roll's legendary ''Killer,'' Jerry Lee Lewis, and nicknamed K-9 -blithely snags the missile between his teeth and shreds it in one gleeful chomp. Jerry Lee's taste in cuisine runs to gallons of hot chili. And like any red-blooded American police dog, he has a healthy interest in the opposite sex. In the course of ''K-9,'' Jerry Lee meets his ideal mate: a fluffily tarted-up poodle, whom he ends up proudly squiring to Las Vegas.

Now, in a welcome move, it has begun to crack down on those who offer payoffs.

Despite changes, the show remains what it always was - a space-age ''Peter Pan'' of particular interest to Trekkies, star warriors and sci-fi fans of all generations.

title: Where to View Festivities
description: 1. Tomorrow, about 11:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M.: Parade of ships from New York Harbor and up the Hudson River to midtown. Visible from the Lower West Side of Manhattan, the north shore of Staten Island, the western shore of Brooklyn, and Jersey City and Hoboken. Marching bands in Battery Park at noon, and airplane flyover at 1 P.M. 2. Tomorrow, 2:30 to 5 P.M., and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.: H.M.S. Rose and other ships will be open to visitors at the South Street Seaport. 3. Tomorrow, about 8:45 P.M.: Fireworks above the East River. Visible from lower Manhattan and Brooklyn Heights. Viewers may use the Frankllin D. Roosevelt Drive, which will be closed to traffic from Houston Street to the Battery from 6 P.M. to 1 A.M. The Brooklyn Bridge will be closed to pedestrians and traffic. 4. Sunday, noon: Commemorative inaugural ceremony at Federal Hall Natinal Memorial. Limited viewing. 5. Sunday, about 1 to 3:30 P.M.: Bicentennial parade with about 100 marching bands and other units on Broadway from Wall Street to Waverly place, ending at Washington Square Park. 6. Sunday, noon to 4 P.M.: Navy ships may be visited at Piers 86, 90 and 92 (12th Avenue and 46th to 50th Streets); at Piers 6 and 7 in Brooklyn Heights, and at the Stapleton Navy Piers at Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island. Also Monday through Wednesday, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

Donald J. Trump is in the process of acquiring the Eastern shuttle.

The talks could lead to P.&W.'s acquisition by Conrail; a capital infusion from Conrail, or efforts to build more freight centers on P.&W. lines, the statement said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bozell to Show Soviets Good Side of Advertising
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev saw Times Square's neon signs on his visit to New York City last fall, the Soviet leader glimpsed American advertising at its most exuberant. Tonight the Soviet people will get a fuller - if more low key - introduction to this peculiarly capitalist phenomenon.

title: Jackson Hits 'Biggest Shot Of My Life'
description: With only three seconds on the clock and the Knicks about to win, 102-96, in their playoff opener against the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden last night, Rick Pitino enjoyed the moment that Mark Jackson had provided with his desperate 3-point basket from about 30 feet that was half shot, half shot-put. Wiping his face with a towel, the Knicks coach turned to those near the bench and smiled. ''Luck never hurt,'' Pitino said. Luck has seldom smiled on the Knicks in their playoff history as it did when Jackson's shot opened a 100-96 lead with 16 seconds remaining. If it had missed and the 76ers had grabbed the rebound, the 76ers had time to organize what might have been the winning basket. Instead, of putting on his mauve tie now, Jackson was explaining what happened.

Rothmeier, the chairman of NWA Inc., said today that the company's officers are not currently examining a possible management-led leveraged buyout of NWA, which owns Northwest Airlines. Instead, he indicated that NWA's directors favor finding an outside party, or ''white squire,'' that would inject new money into NWA in the form of debt or equity and allow the company to continue to operate independently.
