description: Federal regulators never completely reviewed whether United Airlines was complying with safety rules involving the cargo doors on its Boeing 747 jets, officials said today.

title: Excerpts From Speeches at Moscow Party Meeting: Raging at the Changes
description: Following are excerpts from speeches to the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee meeting on Tuesday, published today by Pravda and translated by The New York Times: Yuri F. Solovyev First Secretary of Leningrad region, candidate member of the Politburo

title: Treasury Issues Move Upward
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in fairly active trading yesterday, propelled by weaker-than-expected economic data and rumors that a coming report from the nation's purchasing managers will show that economic conditions worsened in April.

title: Belding Heminway Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter included a gain of 3 cents a share from sales of Cellular interests.

title: 3 More Youths Indicted in Beating And Rape of Central Park Jogger
description: Three more youths were indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday on charges of raping and attempting to murder a 28-year-old investment banker jogging in Central Park last week. Another youth was released, although he has not been cleared by the grand jury.

title: Slattery Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $160,000 and $166,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: M/A-Com Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Allied Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
National Community Banks reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TV Weekend; Is Oliver North a Hero or a Scoundrel?
description: Rushing the Oliver North story to the court of public opinion, even as a real court weighs his guilt or innocence, television has used the standard tabula-rasa approach of docudramas dealing with controversial subjects. Is Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, uniformed star of the Iran-contra hearings, a hero or a scoundrel? ''Guts and Glory: The Rise and Fall of Oliver North'' - a four-hour production being broadcast on CBS Sunday and Tuesday, at 9 each night -offers a blank slate capable of encompassing all opinions. Most aren't likely to be altered.

title: Masco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter's net included gains equal to 17 cents a share from the sale of securities. Year-ago figures were restated to reflect pooling-of-interests.

title: 150,000 March in Defiance of Beijing
description: More than 150,000 demonstrators openly defied official warnings and a concentration of troops today to march for 14 hours through the capital, repeatedly and effortlessly puncturing lines of policemen and soldiers sent to stop them, in one of the biggest displays of dissatisfaction in 40 years of Communist rule.

title: Enserch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $17,320,000 and a gain from an accounting change of $27,033,000. The company said income from discontinued operations included a $23 million gain from the cumulative effect of the change in accounting for income taxes. Year-ago first quarter is restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Flushing: Where The World Twice Met and Newcomers Dwell
description: THE No. 7 subway line through Queens turns into a time machine this weekend, carrying venturesome passengers back 25 and 50 years to the days when Flushing Meadows was the site of two New York World's Fairs. The anniversary celebration, sponsored by the Queens Museum, will recall the great expositions of 1939 and 1964 with tours of what is now known as Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, with films, lectures, collections and recollections, and with the Belgian waffles that were a hit at the fair a half-century ago.

title: Intermet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''GRIMM'S FAIRY TALES READ-IN,'' a free program from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. tomorrow, with Tom Lee, a professional storyteller, and parents, students and faculty members of St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's School who will tell a variety of tales, at the school, 619 West 114th Street. Refreshments available. Information: 666-9645. DANCES FOR CHILDREN, a program by the Kaleidoscope Dancers for Children of New York University, who will perform eight dances, with a variety of live music from instruments and synthesizers, 2 P.M. tomorrow, at N.Y.U.'s University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street. Tickets: children under 12, $2; students, $4; others, $5. Information: 998-5411. ''SOUVENIRS OF OLD NEW YORK,'' a new play directed by Amie Brockway, presented by the Open Eye: New Stagings for Youth, at 2 P.M. Sundays, through April, at the group's theater, 270 West 89th Street. Admission: children, $6; adults, $8. Information: 769-4143. ''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' a puppet show by Gooens Balloowins, at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890.

title: MCI Announces Long-Distance Discounts
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce the cost of residential long-distance telephone calls on weekdays from 7 P.M. to 8 A.M., a move expected to heat up an already intense competition between the company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Crown Books Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Cordis Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,880,000 and $8,635,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $535,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and tax credits of $605,000 for the quarter and $1,798,000 for the 9 months.

title: Review/Art; More Women and Unknowns in the Whitney Biennial
description: By now, the Whitney Museum of American Art's biennial survey seems more self-propelled than curator-generated, like a regularly appearing market index. The exhibition also adds up to the art world's Academy Awards, a ritual of collective -and public - celebration whose honors are carefully rotated among a pool of more or less deserving professionals.

title: Donnelley, R R & Sons Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
10% Withholding Tax Abolished by Germany
description: The West German Government announced today that it was abolishing a controversial four-month-old withholding tax that caused billions of marks to flow out of the country and drained confidence in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's financial policies.

title: Santa Fe Energy Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $4.9 million from the settlement of a take-or-pay contract dispute.

title: Here Lies Tawana Brawley's Lie
description: Even at the peak of her celebrity last year, Tawana Brawley didn't talk much in public. After state investigators and journalists challenged her tale of abduction, rape and abuse, her most memorable comment was, ''I am not a liar.'' But she apparently has been much more loquacious in private. New reports of her statements amount to an epitaph for a lie.

title: Alexander B. Klots Is Dead at 85; Leading Authority on Butterflies
description: Dr. Alexander Barrett Klots, a leading authority on butterflies and other insect life, died of emphysema on April 18 at the Day Kimball Hospital in Putnam, Conn. He was 85 years old and had lived in retirement in Putnam for 16 years, having previously lived in Pelham, N.Y.

title: Mets Collect Confidence, Then Take It on the Road
description: Just a week and a half after straggling home in last place, the Mets flew to Houston yesterday in first place with a four-game winning streak, seven victories in a ringing nine-game home stand and renewed confidence in their ability to foil their rivals, critics and doubters.

title: W. Ware Lynch, 75, Author and Executive
description: W. Ware Lynch, an author and retired public-relations executive, died of cancer Tuesday at the Charles W. Gerstenberg Hospice Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: UAL Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $548,935,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Roses Still Appealing Despite Easy Goer
description: The allure of running a horse in the Kentucky Derby seems to be stronger than the possibility that taking on Easy Goer may be futile. With just eight days to go before the 115th Derby, as many as 17 3-year-olds are still being considered for the race.

title: Dubcek, on TV, Says Brezhnev Deceived Prague Leadership
description: Alexander Dubcek, the former Czechoslovak leader, appeared on Hungarian television Wednesday night and accused Leonid I. Brezhnev of double-dealing just before Soviet-led forces put down the 1968 Czechoslovak movement of change known as Prague Spring.

title: Canron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: IP Timberlands Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings represent units. The company said because it has two types of units - type A (publicly traded) deriving the majority of its revenue from timber sales and type B-deriving its revenue from actual land sales - and because a greater amount of revenue in the latest first quarter came from timber sales than in the 1987 first quarter, even though there was a decline in revenue during the latest first quarter, its publicly traded type A unit was allocated a greater unit value.

title: Official Won't Tell Congress About Airline Security Alerts
description: The United States Secretary of Transportation said today that he would no longer tell Congress about airline security alerts for fear of unauthorized disclosures and that he was considering seeking legislation to make such disclosures a crime.

title: Numerica Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Provision for loan losses in the latest first quarter was $695,000, compared with $555,000 for year-ago period.

title: Harvey Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included tax credits of $58,837 and $433,837 for the quarter nad year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $176,000 for the quarter and $287,000 for the year.

title: Good Guys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nerco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a credit of $45 million related to coal contract settlements and after an extraordinary charge of $9.1 million.

title: Kinetic Concepts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
What to Do; When to Do It
description: A 1939 and 1964 World's Fair anniversary weekend will be held tomorrow and Sunday at the Queens Museum. Museum admission - $2; $1 for children - includes all events. The museum is in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, next to the Unisphere, in Flushing. Information: (718) 592-2405. Tomorrow DEALERS' BOURSE, sponsored by the World's Fair Collectors Society, with more than 20 dealers from a variety of major world expositions. Second floor. Noon to 4:30 P.M. COMMEMORATIVE POSTAGE CANCELLATION, featuring a United States Post Office station canceling letters and postcards with a cancellation commemorating the opening days of both fairs. In the first-floor lobby. Noon to 4 P.M. FILM: ''TO THE FAIR,'' commissioned by Robert Moses (30 minutes). In the first-floor theater. At 1 and 1:30 P.M. TOURS, to the Time Capsule Burial Sites and several fair locations, including the RCA Pavilion. Meet in museum lobby. At 1, 2 and 3 P.M. ANNIVERSARY PROGRAM, featuring music, slides and lectures by prominent participants in the '39 and '64 World's Fairs. In the Great Hall at the New York Hall of Science. 1:15 to 4 P.M. FILM: ''1964 WORLD'S FAIR,'' by the official photographer of the fair's Hall of Science (50 minutes). In the first-floor theater. At 2 and 3 P.M. SLIDE TALK, by Conrad Rupert. In the first-floor theater. At 2:30 P.M. NATURALIZATION CEREMONY, for 100 new citzens, with marching band music. At the Unisphere. At 3 P.M. ''REFLECTIONS OF THE FAIR,'' a television documentary on the '64 Fair. In the first-floor theater. At 3:30 P.M. FILM: ''DEMOLITION OF THE '39 AND '64 WORLD'S FAIRS'' (20 minutes). In the first-floor theater. At 4 and 4:30 P.M. ''RCA 1939 FILM,'' a montage of '39 Fair footage that served as a backdrop to the president of RCA, David Sarnoff, giving the first public announcement of the invention of television. In the first-floor theater. At 4:15 P.M. Sunday DEALERS' BOURSE, (see above). Noon to 4 P.M. TWO SLIDE TALKS, Conrad Rupert at 12:30 P.M. and Alfred Stern at 1:30. Both in the first-floor theater.

title: Lebanon Wants to Be Free of Foreign Occupiers; Syria's Machinations
description: To the Editor:

title: Kinark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MEI Diversified reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First Financial Caribbean reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $512,000 charge for spinoff expenses.

title: Reviews/Film; Of Two Gay Teen-Agers, And Dolphins in a Show
description: ''Wonderland'' is a loony romantic melodrama about two gay teen-age working-class lads in Liverpool who, like Maria in ''West Side Story,'' dream of finding that somewhere, sometime, where they can be happy.

title: 15-Year Promotional Accord Is Set by Disney and Kodak
description: The Walt Disney Company and the Eastman Kodak Company announced a 15-year promotional agreement yesterday that each company said was the largest such contract it had ever signed.

title: Changes in Top Ranks Set at Morton Thiokol
description: Morton Thiokol Inc. announced yesterday that U. Edwin Garrison, the president of its aerospace group and a corporate vice president, will become president and chief executive of Thiokol's aerospace business when it is set up as a separate company.

title: Cornell Picks Coach
description: One day after the resignation of Maxie Baughan, Cornell University named Jack Fouts, its offensive line coach, as its new football coach Wednesday night. Baughan's resignation as coach came amid published reports in The Ithaca Journal that he had been romantically involved with the estranged wife of his chief assistant, Peter Noyes.

title: Sheila D. Feick, Fund-Raiser, 55
description: Sheila D. Feick, a former president of the Women's Committee of the New York Zoological Society, died of kidney and bone cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ametek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $429,000 from spun-off operations and income of $3,633,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect Ametek's spinoff of Ketema Inc.

title: Arms Rift: Who's Afraid of a Brand New Europe?
description: Underlying the tension between the United States and West Germany over the future of NATO's short-range nuclear missiles is a subtle but crucial difference between Bonn and Washington in assessing the opportunities presented by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Castle, A M & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cincinnati Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Teen-Agers Favor Radio
description: Teen-agers are more likely to listen to the radio than to read a newspaper on an average day, says a survey presented to the American Newspaper Publishers Association today.

title: WYOMING VICTORY A RELIEF FOR G.O.P.
description: Republican leaders, who had spent much energy in the last month explaining away their loss of the first two special elections for the House of Representatives in President Bush's term, were relieved this morning to learn that they had finally won one.

title: Premark International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter results included a charge of $15,900,000 from an accounting change.

title: Control Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter included a pre-tax gain of $18.8 million for restructuring gains mainly from the sale of certain International Control Data Institutes, as well as $10.7 million of income due to a favorable legal settlement. The company also said the first quarter results were hurt by losses in computer systems, supercomputer operations, and VTS, which were partially offset by positive results in information services, Imprimis and government systems.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Charles R. Evans Jr. has joined Wells, Rich, Greene as executive vice president and account group head.

title: Merchants Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $493,000 for the latest first quarter and $388,000 for year-ago period. The latest quarter also included tax credits of $875,000.

title: First Source Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Film; The Search For a Killer Set Free By the Law
description: The day after Ben Chase (Gary Oldman), a crackerjack Boston defense lawyer, secures the acquittal of Martin Thiel (Kevin Bacon) of murder, another woman is murdered in a fashion that looks suspiciously like the crime Martin was accused of. The victim was gagged with a disposable diaper, raped and viciously battered before being killed.

title: Enron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter included a pretax gain of $36.5 million from the sale of Mobil Corp. stock, a pretax gain of $11.8 million from the settlement of litigation and an extraordinary charge of $200,000 from the early redemption of debt. Year-ago first quarter included a pretax gain of $12.2 million from the sale of Mobil Corp. stock and an extraordinary charge of $6.1 million from the early redemption of debt.

title: Albert Loewentheil, Developer, 88
description: Albert Loewentheil, a retired Westchester County real-estate developer, died Wednesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He was 88 years old and lived in Eastchester.

title: Bic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $2,800,000.

title: Saztec International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Cabot Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $816,000 charge from the refinancing of debt.

title: LaBarge Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-After tax benefits of $249,100 for the quarter and $628,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included net from discontinued operations of $432,849. c-After tax benefits of $44,200 for the quarter and $204,500 for the 9 months.

title: Jefferson National Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
North-West Telecommunicaions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Seabrook Owners File a New Plan
description: The owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant have filed papers with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that they believe clears remaining obstacles to receiving a low-power license. Seabrook, in New Hampshire near Massachusetts, has been blocked from operating by a dispute over emergency planning. The owner of the largest share of Seabrook, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, is bankrupt, and the commission said the owners must demonstrate that they could pay to clean up radiation from low-power testing.

title: Flyers Force Penguins to a Game 7
description: To a man, the Flyers left Pittsburgh Tuesday night in embarrassment. And to a man, they pledged that wouldn't be the manner in which they left the season. The Philadelphia players assured any and all who would listen that although they might lose, they surely wouldn't lose face again.

title: First Fincl Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
John Feels Some Relief As Righetti Saves Yanks
description: Even after all these years, he still gets edgy when the game is close. It was this close tonight: a one-run game, bases loaded, one out and George Brett walking toward the plate.

title: First of Michigan Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Johnston Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Interlake Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tech-Ops Sevcon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Traffic Alert
description: Because of Eastern Orthodox Good Friday, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Slices of History
description: The Wall Street Journal is celebrating its centenary with daily vignettes on business milestones of the past 100 years. Readers have learned about things like the Pullman strike of 1894, the 1929 crash and Milton Hershey's chocolate bar. They are important, of course. But all pale beside one that appeared last week: the invention of sliced bread.

title: CUNY Protests Spread to More Schools
description: Demonstrations against a proposed tuition increase at colleges of the City University spread to six new campuses yesterday, with students marching, padlocking buildings and taking over administration offices.

title:
About Real Estate;
Waterfront High-Rise Will Be Built in Astoria
description: LEAD: The Astoria section of Queens has seen little residential development in the last 20 years, but that is about to change as demand grows for new housing.

title: Space Scientists Say Soviets Will Press Program on Mars
description: Despite pressures to cut space outlays and the recent failure of two Mars missions, the Soviet Union remains committed to a robust program of Mars exploration over the next decade, Soviet scientists said here today.

title: Bill to Benefit 'Baby Bells' Is Proposed
description: A bipartisan group of House members today introduced legislation that would permit the seven regional Bell telephone companies to create and provide information services, including electronic publishing.

title: Lone Star Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,564,000 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: Louis B. Neumiller, 93; Led Caterpillar Inc.
description: Louis B. Neumiller, former chairman and chief executive officer of bi>Caterpillar Inc., died Wednesday at his home. He was 93 years old and had been ill for more than a year.

title: 'Eyeless Tears'
description: ''Eyeless Tears in a Universe of Ether,'' a dance work choreographed by Linda Rappaport, with music by Waddy Thompson, a text by Robert Epstein and sculptures by Sonia Balassanian, is to be performed at the Dia Art Foundation, 155 Mercer Street, tonight at 8 o'clock. The dancers are Randa Broughton, Michael Greer, Linden Holt and Traci Kramer. Also in the cast are Phyllis Fay Farmer, soprano; Robert Epstein, baritone; Richard Goldsmith, clarinetist; Nancy Ives, cellist, and Martha Wade, pianist. Tickets are $9. Information: 877-4577.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 7-Eleven Reaches Out With Realism
description: A NEW wave of television advertising for the Southland Corporation's 7-Eleven Stores will use the realistic style of ''thirtysomething'' to seek a broader audience for convenience-store shopping, a task often associated with working-class men loading up on six-packs and cigarettes.

title: Fitness, Esq., where the flabby can become firm - and the firm picks up a heavy tab
description: The time is 8:15 A.M., the setting a Manhattan gym crammed with space-age, calorie-consuming contraptions. The players are sweating middle-aged men. In the background is a cacophony of news programs, clanging metal and the agony of heavy lifting, the sounds of the chain gang once sung of by the late Sam Cooke: ''Uh!'' ''Ah!'' ''Uh!'' ''Ah!''

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds decreased by $435.5 million, to $303 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $921.3 million, to $74.32 billion. But the assets of the 232 general-purpose funds were down by $129.9 million, to $99.67 billion, and the 95 broker-dealer funds decreased by $1.23 billion, to $129.02 billion, the institute said.

title: A Chance for Change in Japan
description: With Noboru Takeshita's decision to resign as head of Japan's Government, the world's second-largest economy has lost another Prime Minister to scandal. Conventional wisdom is that prime ministers do not greatly matter in Japan; the Liberal Democratic Party will reshuffle faces and continue its 34-year reign, while Japan's powerful bureaucracy continues foreign and domestic policies without change. But this time, just possibly, scandal will prompt a reform of Japan's decrepit, money-greased political system.

title: Corrections
description: The transcript of arguments before the Supreme Court in the Missouri abortion case was incomplete yesterday in some copies. The omitted section, a rebuttal argument by Attorney General William L. Webster of Missouri, appears today on page B8.

title: Congress Opens Hearing on Course of Rudderless Civil Rights Panel
description: Lacking clear direction from the White House, Congress today opened hearings on the future of the embattled United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: Standard Register reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: The company said its first quarter results were reduced by 5 cents a share as a result of a charge to earnings related to recording inventory costs.

title: Control Data Net Slides; Prime Computer Has Deficit
description: The Control Data Corporation today reported a sharp drop in first-quarter earnings that it attributed to losses in its computer and supercomputer businesses. It also said it expected a second-quarter loss from the cost of a restructuring announced last week.

title: Large Park Fire Controlled as Trails Close
description: A forest fire was brought under control today after burning across thousands of acres of Harriman State Park.

title: Tyson Is Arrested On Speeding Charge
description: Mike Tyson, the world heavyweight champion, whose brushes with the law have become as familiar as his triumphs in the ring, was arrested Wednesday night for speeding, the Albany police said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Film; British Sex Scandal of the 60's Is Dramatized
description: ''It's a closed society,'' Dr. Stephen Ward (John Hurt) says to Christine Keeler (Joanne Whalley-Kilmer), a pretty nightclub dancer, as he shows her around the grounds of the great Astor estate of Cliveden. ''To get in, you have to be either beautiful or rich.''

title: Investors Title Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Japan's Opposition Struggles Despite Government Scandal
description: As Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's Government sank into political disgrace in recent weeks, leaders of Japan's normally fractious opposition parties declared that ''this golden opportunity'' might enable them to win an election for the first time in history.

title: Van Slyke Disabled
description: Andy Van Slyke, the Pirates' center fielder, who has a strained muscle in his right rib cage, was placed on the 21-day disabled list by Pittsburgh yesterday. Since the move is retroactive to April 17, the center fielder will be able to return to the Pirates' lineup May 8.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Soviet Team Edges Czechoslovakia: Vyacheslav Bykov, a center, scored with 6 minutes 24 seconds left to give the Soviet Union a 1-0 victory over Czechoslovakia yesterday in the opening game of the medal round at the world championships in Stockholm. In the second game, Team Canada defeated Sweden, the defending champion, by 5-3.(AP) TENNIS Wilander and Becker Manage to Gain: Mats Wilander and Boris Becker, the top-seeded players, played streaky tennis but still qualified for the quarterfinals of the Monte Carlo Open. Wilander, ranked second in the world, ran off four games in a row in the first and second sets to beat Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay, 6-4, 6-4. Becker, seeded second, beat 16th-seeded Jordi Arrese of Spain, 6-1, 6-3. (AP) Hungarian Upsets Garrison: Andrea Temesvari of Hungary continued her comeback from ankle and shoulder injuries by upsetting second-seeded Zina Garrison, 6-3, 6-7, 6-2, yesterday in a second-round match of the Virginia Slims of Houston tournament. Temesvari, once among the top 10 players in the world, missed 18 months on the tour while recovering from her injuries. She is now No. 111 in the world. Garrison is sixth.(AP) GOLF Two Teams Share Legends Lead: The teams of Al Geiberger and Harold Henning and Bob Charles and Bruce Devlin each shot nine-under-par 61 yesterday to share the first-round lead in the $650,000 Legends of Golf tournament in Austin, Tex. Gardner Dickinson and Dave Hill were one stroke back in the two-man, better-ball event over the 6,367-yard Onion Creek Club course. Charles scored seven of his team's nine birdies, including a 30-foot chip-in on the 367-yard third hole.(AP)

title: Germania Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KLLM Transport Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Altus Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KLM-Boeing Deal
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said it planned to order 15 aircraft from the Boeing Company for about $950 million. The Dutch carrier said it would order ten Boeing 737's and five 747-400's, to be delivered between 1990 and 1992. KLM said the planes would replace its DC-10's and DC-9's by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and its twin-jet Fokker-100 passenger planes by Fokker N.V.

title: Magna Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Clear Channel Commun reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and share earnings were less than one cent a share.

title: National-Standard Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $45,000. c-Net income and after extraordinary gains of $132,000 for the quarter and $2,977,000 for the 6 months. The first half of last year included a non-operating gain, net of taxes, of $4.3 million, or $1.08 a share, on settlement of pension liabilities associated with termination and re-establishment of the company's pension plan for domestic employees.

title: Monrovia Journal; Dunned by U.S., Liberia Dips Into Many Pockets
description: The man was old and blind and gnarled, and the woman, her legs useless from some crippling disease, sat next to him. Another man stood on crutches, one leg several inches shorter than the other.

title: MS Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Boston Edison Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WRIGHT IS OPPOSED TO TV AT HEARINGS
description: House Speaker Jim Wright is opposed to television coverage of his disciplinary hearing before the House ethics committee and the panel is not likely to allow the coverage, officials on Capitol Hill said today.

title: Pupil Starts A Revolution Of Her Own: Ban Plastics
description: A revolution began in this rural township because of the writings of the 18th-century pamphleteer Thomas Paine and the 15-year-old high school sophomore Tanja Vogt.

title: Noble Affiliates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $8,825,000 from an accounting change.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Security Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council CHILDREN'S FUND - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Suit in Connecticut Challenges Schools As Racially Divided
description: A coalition of civil rights organizations sued Connecticut today, challenging its racially imbalanced school districts as violating Connecticut's Constitution.

title: Celtics Leave Bird Behind
description: Larry Bird will not be accompanying the Boston Celtics to Detroit for the start Friday night of the team's first-round playoff series, Celtics officials said today.

title: Turbo Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $782,000. The company said the loss for the latest first quarter was after the payment of preferred share dividends of $3.2 million. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Designatronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Delta Woodside Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Market Place; Surge in Stocks Has Its Doubters
description: HAPPY days ought to be here again, at least to judge from the action of stock prices. But good times haven't returned to Wall Street, where the talk is more of possible layoffs than of stocks that are likely to double.

title: An Annenberg Art Show
description: The National Gallery of Art announced today that it would exhibit the Annenberg collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art next year, bringing to Washington one of the finest private collections in the world.

title: TOKYO SEEKS CURBS IN POLITICAL FUNDS

Huntington, the National Academy of Design under the directorship of John Dobkin has lately played a considerable role in New York life. It is many things in one -an art school, a society of artists, a center for lectures and concerts, a first-rate store for art books, a distinguished backdrop for festivity and (every Tuesday afternoon) the best tearoom in town.

Major works - some from prominent collections - include such seminal images as a Jackson Pollock drip painting, an Andy Warhol Marilyn, a Jasper Johns alphabet and David Hockney's first ''stage painting.''

title: Corrections

title: Review/Art; C.C. Wang and the Fruits of Perseverance
description: ''Mind Landscapes: The Paintings of C. C. Wang'' is one of the sleepers of the season. It arrived without fanfare in the small exhibition space of the China House Gallery. Its subject is largely unknown except to followers of Chinese art. Yet it casts a spell, and it has a message that people who believe in perseverance and painting will be glad to hear.

At least 23 people were reported killed and more than 60 wounded.

title: Tampering Suspected in Drug Doses Given to 2 Lenox Hill
description: Two patients at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan went into comas last week after they were given potentially fatal doses of a paralyzing drug that had been deliberately mixed in with intravenous fluid, the police said yesterday.

title: Study Questions Cost Of Physicians' Using Facilities They Own
description: Twelve percent of the doctors who treat Medicare patients refer them to laboratories and clinics in which the doctors have financial interests, according to a Government report released today.

title: Colombian Cocaine Dealers Tap European Market
description: Using Spain as the principal port of entry to a lucrative new market, Colombia's powerful drug cartels have set up a highly proficient trafficking network that is feeding Western Europe's rising demand for cocaine.

title: Boeing Changes

The corporate senior vice president, Dan Pinick, will become president of the new organization, called Boeing Aerospace and Electronics. The reorganization, which takes effect Monday, will involve a variety of military programs, including the Awacs system, several Boeing-built missiles, NASA space-station efforts and work on the Strategic Defense Initiative.

description: Results for the fourth quarter and full fiscal 1989 year reflect the acquisition of the car care division of Borden Inc. in mid-year.

title: Allied Stores Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Net income represents operating cash flow. The company said year operating cash flow excluded a gain of $330 million on the sale of the Brooks Brothers division. As a result of the change in the company's fiscal year-end from Dec. 31 to Jan. 31, the disposition of a significant number of operating subsidiaries and real estate properties throughout the prior fiscal year and the sale of Brooks Brothers, results of operations are generally not comparable between this year and last.

title: Escalator Dangers Called Preventable
description: Yvonne L. Little, a 56-year-old Maryland resident, caught the belt of her raincoat in an escalator step when she was leaving a subway station in suburban Washington earlier this month. Ms. Little, unaware, rode to the top of the moving stairs. The machinery reeled in the belt and yanked her to the ground, breaking her wrist, dislocating her shoulder and stripping away most of her clothing before a transit worker shut off the escalator.

title: Some Changes At Forest Hills
description: Although the Eagle Tournament of Champions will not be included on the men's tennis tour next year, officials said yesterday that the tournament would be kept alive as a special event and that members of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills were willing to consider changing the surface from synthetic clay to hard courts.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Leaking Auto Air-Conditioners
description: If you drive your air-conditioned car to the beach this summer but fear lying in the sun because of the depletion of the ozone, you may be the cause of your own problem. Environmental experts point out that automobile air-conditioners are a major source of the chemicals that are destroying Earth's ozone layer.

title: Athey Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect stock dividends.

title: Duramed Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $195,000. c-Net loss

title: Savin Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago revenue included $3,600,000 for the sale of rental copiers to a third-party financing company. Year-ago results reclassified to comply with 1989 presentation.

title: Roy L. Williams Is Dead at 74; Ex-President of Teamsters' Union
description: Roy L. Williams, a former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who served three years in prison for conspiring to commit bribery, died yesterday at the farm where he lived in Leeton, Mo. Mr. Williams, who was 74 years old, had long suffered from heart trouble and emphysema.

title: Marc Daniels, 77, Dies; Directed 'I Love Lucy'
description: Marc Daniels, who directed the first 38 episodes of the ''I Love Lucy'' television series, died Sunday of congestive heart failure at St. John's Medical Center. He was 77 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Acme Steel Co., Riverdale, Ill., said it plans to acquire Sudbury Inc.'s Alpha Tube and Beta Tube business. Terms were not disclosed.

title: France Expels Pretoria Envoys
description: France said today it was expelling three South African Embassy officials to protest what it described as an illegal effort by Pretoria to acquire a stolen British Blowpipe missile in Paris. Officials said one of those being expelled was Daniel Storm, who was found in a Paris hotel on April 21 with three Protestant extremists from Northern Ireland. The three militants have been charged with arms trafficking and conspiracy for the purpose of terrorism.

title: Campeau Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: The company said the prior year represents the 13 months ended Jan. 31, 1988.

title: Colin Carter, Banker, 55
description: Colin Carter, a former vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 55 years old.

title: Black & Decker Has 95% of Emhart
description: The Black & Decker Corporation said it had received 95 percent of the stock of the Emhart Corporation in a tender offer, enough to complete a $2.8 billion takeover of the diversified manufacturing company. Black & Decker offered Emhart shareholders $40 a share for their stock.

title: Plymouth Five Cents Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter results included a charge of $200,000 from the termination of a hotel management agreement.

title: South Jersey Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $86,000 and $18,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

description: b-Net loss

Stocker & Yarle reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush 'Environmentalists' - Who's Watt, and Why
description: If President Bush believes that all he had to do to prove himself an ''environmentalist'' was to name William K. Reilly head of the Environmental Protection Administration, he is dead wrong.

title: DSC Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $41,000.

title: Ferro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company had a gain on foreign currencies of $1.2 million in the latest first quarter, in contrast to a currency loss of $774,000 a year-earlier.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-5 Development of a U.S.-Japanese jet will proceed, President Bush announced, declaring that prolonged negotiations had yielded an agreement ''in the strategic and commercial interests of the United States.'' Page 1 A U.S. trade retaliation against Japan is planned because of Japan's failure to open its $9 billion-a-year market in telecommunications market to American companies. 33 Takeshita gets a new jet, and a budget 5 Mobil will leave South Africa, the corporation said, blaming ''very foolish laws'' enacted by the United States Congress. The largest American company still in South Africa made its decision on economic grounds. 1 Announcement jolts South Africa's business community 35 Europe's demand for cocaine is being fed by Colombia's drug cartels which have set up a highly proficient trafficking network, with Spain as the principal port of entry. 1 Widespread vote fraud in Panama is being prepared by the Government to steal the May 7 national elections, independent monitors and opposition leaders assert. 1 News analysis: The strains on NATO appears to have been born in the debate over American medium-range missiles six years ago, leading some diplomats to say that Washington's victory was a Pyrrhic one. 3 News analysis: NATO's full recovery from the possible consequences of Chancellor Kohl's speech on Thursday may be difficult, British officials say. 3 In the West German press, support for Soviet talks 3 Chinese students appeared to reject the Government's conditional proposal for dialogue, as they jubilantly planned the next moves in their campaign a day after one of the biggest Beijing protests ever. 5 National 6-9, 28 Use of genetically altered hormones is at least a year away from approval by the F.D.A., but opponents are already taking steps toward a ban in the United States, Canada and Europe. 1 In inquiry into a housing program that led developers to pay large consulting fees to prominent Republicans is expected to be opened by the Justice Department, Administration officials said. 1 A run by Jesse Jackson for Mayor of Washington is seriously being considered, according to friends and associates who say he thinks Mayor Barry's problems have gotten too serious. 1 The rigors of life at sea are easing, with some ships providing salad bars and cellular phones. But over the centuries some things about long voyages have never changed, like loneliness and the lure of alocohol. 1 Doctors who refer Medicare patients to laboratories and clinics in which they have financial interests make up 12 percent of the physicians who treat such patients, a reports says. 1 U.S. panel backs a five-year contraceptive 8 Malfunctions in the shuttle Atlantis abruptly halted its countdown 31 seconds before its launch. The problems have forced at least a three-day postponement. 8 Again, fusion claim does not hold up in tests 28 Military analysis: Old battleships have come under new criticism with the announcement that the Iowa's gun turret cannot be repaired. If such guns cannot be repaired in peacetime, what happens in war? 6 Deforestation has given Arbor Day a new meaning. In Chicago, the annual celebration of trees and tree plantings was marked by handing out 1,500 honey locust seedlings. 6 The trial of Edwin Meese's friend and former legal adviser, E. Robert Wallach, began with an opening statement describing him as the corrupted Wedtech Corporation's ''mole in the Federal Government.'' 6 The North trial's jury comprises nine women and three men who form a mural of working Washington. So far, they have spent 37 1/2 hours in deliberation. 6 The economic outlook clouded further as the Government's main gauge for forecasting growth fell in March. It was the second straight decline and the biggest since July. 33 Regional 29-32 Jogging in Central Park continues to be popular, despite the attack last week. There are several reasons for night jogging, but it's mainly a result of busy schedules. 29 Three of the youths accused of rape and attempted murder in the attack were denied bail at a raucous court hearing. 30 Dinkins leads meeting on park rape 30 New York State's financial woes have not evaporated with the recent fiscal crisis, and as officials hungrily look for new revenue, eyes are falling upon the next phase of the state's income-tax cuts. 29 Abolish the Board of Estimate? New York City's Charter Revision Commission wants to, but some members are worried that the borough presidents would be left without enough power. 29 In the race for borough president of Manhattan, Assemblyman Herman Farrell is preparing to drop out, paving the way for the virtually uncontested election of City Councilwoman Ruth Messinger. 31 Cuomo weighs action on CUNY tuition increases 31 Prosecutor to study charges against Suffolk officials 31 A desegregation lawsuit in Hartford has focused attention on racial isolation in Connecticut's schools. But the root of the problem appears to be the isolation of poverty. 29 Colt to sell firearms division 33

title: Maxxam Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter results included aluminum operations conducted through a subsidiary of Kaisertech Ltd., Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corp.

title: Pacific Aqua Foods reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company did not have any operations a year earlier.

title: Raul Sendic, 64, Founder of Uruguay Rebel Group
description: Raul Sendic, the founder of the leftist Tupamaro guerrilla movement in Uruguay, died late Thursday at a clinic in Paris after a long illness. He was 64 years old and had gone to France several weeks ago from Uruguay seeking treatment.

title: Arbor Day, 1989: A Sense of Urgency
description: While city workers passed out 1,500 honey locust seedlings today in small plastic bags, schoolchildren, politicians and officials gathered downtown in fog and drizzle for Chicago's annual celebration of trees.

title: About New York; Of Zeppelins, Hidden Treasure And a Boy's Awe
description: In a far corner of the Bronx at 6001 Riverdale Avenue, where the city merges into Yonkers, is a shop whose storefront sign, ''Jody Stamp Studio,'' provides no clue of treasures inside: artifacts, mementos, books and doo-hickeys recalling the short lapsed age of dirigibles and zeppelins, those soaring hulks that someone once called ''the technological audacities of the century.''

title: C-Tec reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Abrams Picks Prosecutor to Study Charges Against Suffolk Officials
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appointed a special prosecutor today to review charges that Suffolk County's top law-enforcement officials had engaged in unethical and possibly criminal conduct.

title: An Electronics Chain's Sharp Slide
description: Early in this decade the consumer electronics industry was riding high, with sales, spurred by videocassette recorders and microwave ovens, advancing smartly each year. But with increasing competition and a lack of new products, the industry has gone into a slump. Highland Superstores Inc., a Midwest-based chain with sales of nearly $1 billion, has become a symbol of the difficulties now eating away at the profits of these chains.

title: Envirodyne Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Builders Transport Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Midwest Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SPS Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $393,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $550,000 tax credit.

title: Colt to Sell Unit That Won the West
description: While the Colt .45 revolver has often been credited with taming the lawless West, the modern Colt Industries has been less successful at taming the problems of its firearms division. And yesterday Colt said the division was being offered for sale.

title: Pinnacle West Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the decline in earnings can be primarily attributed to Merabank's $29.2 million loss, of which about $12 million repreents additional loan-loss provisions established in March. The company also said losses at Pinnacle West's three smaller subsidiaries, Suncor Development Co., Malapai Resources Co. and El Dorado Investment Co., totaled about $3.9 million while Arizona Public Service Co. earned about $6.3 million for the quarter.

title: Dow Off, but Most Other Gauges Advance
description: The stock market was mixed yesterday, although most measures of its performance still managed to reach their highest levels since the October 1987 market crash.

title: Abha Journal; Saudi Leaders Lend an Ear to Anyone
description: Sheik Saud Abdelaziz al-Mutthami, the chief of the Rabiaa and Rufaydah tribe, was sipping his tea and taking a whiff of incense as he listened to a petitioner from his clan the other day at his afternoon majlis, or open-house audience.

title: Bridge
description: When prospects are bleak, a wily declarer will often find a way to present an opponent with a problem. A fine example of this occurred on the diagramed deal, played Sunday in the Grand National Team final at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan. It was the start of the final quarter, and the teams were virtually tied.

title: New Issue in Debate Over Old Ships
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's decision to keep four World War II battleships on active duty with the fleet does not end the debate on the utility of vintage warships. In fact, the explosion last week in a gun turret on the battleship Iowa gave critics new evidence to cite in their demands that the ships be deactivated.

title: Dynamics Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Apache Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $59,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $342,000 gain from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: George Washington - What a Guy!
description: LEAD: George Washington, the bicentennial of whose inauguration we are currently celebrating, was the indispensable man, both in the creation of the United States and in preventing the emerging nation from splitting apart. If, when he was a young man, the shot fired at him in the wilderness at point blank range by an Indian had not missed, the territory that is now the United States would probably be, like Europe, a conglomerate of separate, often hostile nations.

title: Quicker Psychology Aids Arkansas Relay Victory
description: John McDonnell, the Arkansas track coach, is a psychologist at heart. As he said, ''You use anything you can.''

title: Reviews/Music; Between Asian and Western Influences
description: In a no man's land between Asian and Western music - one populated largely by half-truths - Chou Wen-chung has moved with unusual confidence and sense of purpose. Mr. Chou is a composer of several layers. He was raised in China and has become in later life an Americanophile. He teaches at Columbia University, and on Thursday at the Asia Society, admirers and friends heard six of his pieces, one of them a premiere. This was a co-production with the Greenwich House Music School.

title: Direct Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Upper Peninsula Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Club Med Adding
description: Club Mediterranee, the French operator of vacation resorts, said it would take a 34 percent stake in the French travel company Nouvelles Frontieres. Club Med said in a statement the two groups had decided to join forces to face up to competition at home and abroad but added that each company would retain management independence and separate identities. Under the agreement the two groups will develop a common plane seat-buying strategy with an aim of forming a new charter operator.

title: Mother Suing Distiller Testifies on Drinking
description: An alcoholic woman who is suing a liquor company over her son's birth defects testified today that she drank herself into unconsciousness several times while pregnant, but was never warned that alcohol would hurt her baby.

title: Suit Is Filed In Bid for NWA
description: Lawyers for Marvin Davis, who is stalking NWA Inc. with a hostile $2.62 billion offer, said they had filed suit against the Minnesota Commerce Commissioner, Michael Hatch, contending he exceeded his legal authority when he suspended Mr. Davis's $90-a-share tender offer. The challenge was filed in Federal District Court in Minneapolis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We had been seriously affected by the very foolish laws that had been passed in the U.S.

title: Communications Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Editors' Note
description: A commentary on the Word and Image page on Tuesday about dignity versus sensationalism in television discussed news programming changes over the years. It said the CBS producer Don Hewitt once declared that a report was boring if he felt an itch near the seat of his pants, a doctrine that ''infuriated the orthodox acolytes of Edward R. Murrow.''

title: A. V. Cima Wed To Mary Curran
description: Mary Carole Curran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Joseph Curran Jr. of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Alessandro V. Cima, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Giulio Cima of Waterford, Conn. The Rev. Robert Armstrong, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of Mary Our Queen in Baltimore.

title: U.S. AND JAPANESE AGREE TO PROCEED ON FIGHTER PLANE
description: President Bush announced today that the United States intends to proceed with a $7 billion project with Japan to produce a new jet fighter, declaring that prolonged negotiations had yielded an agreement ''in the strategic and commercial interests of the United States.''

description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $25,000 and $2,069,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $3,144,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $9,041,000 for the quarter and $13,735,000 for the 9 months, and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $11,690,000 and $6,802,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said its operating results for 1987 included a pretax gain of $3,671,000 on the sale of an a operating company.

title: Trustco Desjardins reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,106,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A New Jolt to Corporate South Africa
description: The announcement today that the Mobil Corporation will sell its holdings and leave South Africa has jolted the business community here, which had looked to the American oil company as an example of corporate enlightenment in improving the lot of black South Africans.

title: Stalin's Empire Strikes Back
description: ''Repentance'' is a bold movie made in Soviet Georgia in which the corpse of a dictator very much like Stalin refuses to stay put. This is no symbolic fantasy for Mikhail Gorbachev. He faces a revolt in Stalin's native land against a colonial system that Stalin made worse.

title: Acme United reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Pinnacle Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $164,000 and $781,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Hoch and Stadler Search for the Happy Ending
description: Scott Hoch, who came within 2 feet of victory at the Masters recently, and Craig Stadler, are a couple of golfing veterans who haven't won a PGA Tour event in five years. But it's not for lack of trying. What each one needs is a more positive way to finish a round.

title: NATO Crisis: London Frets Over the Alliance . . . As Scars Reopen on the Continent
description: The debate now straining the Atlantic alliance echoes the controversy that brought millions of demonstrators into the streets of Western Europe six years ago to protest the deployment of American medium-range missiles.

title: 3 Presidents at American Express
description: The American Express Company said Thursday that it was restructuring its Travel Related Services Company, in the process naming three new presidents.

title: Patents; A Method to Determine Fertility in Women
description: Two researchers at the Yale University School of Medicine in New Haven have won patent approval for a new method of determining fertility in women.

title: Emergency is Declared After Senegal Killings
description: Senegal declared a state of emergency today and imposed a curfew here in the capital after at least 25 Mauritanians were killed, apparently in retaliation for the deaths of Senegalese in neighboring Mauritania.

title: Meese Friend Is Described as 'Mole' at Onset of a Wedtech Trial
description: E. Robert Wallach, the longtime friend and former legal adviser to Edwin Meese 3d, was described yesterday as the Wedtech Corporation's ''mole in the Federal Government'' in opening statements at his racketeering trial in Manhattan.

Oscar Panel to Review Show Assailed by Stars
description: The producers of the Academy Awards said today they had appointed a committee to review last month's Oscar show after such Hollywood stars as Julie Andrews and Paul Newman called it an embarrassment.

title: Mets Top Astros as Hernandez Returns With Homer
description: Memories? Keith Hernandez has few about the cavernous Astrodome, where home runs are simply hard to come by. But as the Mets embarked on a five-game trip tonight, Hernandez surely began to like the place.

description: Net loss

Prices Paid To Farmers Down by 2%
description: Lower costs for cattle, eggs, hogs, soybeans and lettuce pushed prices that American farmers receive for their raw goods down by 2 percent in April, the Agriculture Department reported today.

description: The latest quarter included results of GE Solid State acquired in November. The year-ago 9 months included a gain of $35.1 million, or 87 cents a share, from accounting changes. Corrected from Wednesday, April 26.

description: b-Included a gain of $629,000 from an accounting change. The results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Grady's Inc., completed in February 1989.

title: Pope, in Madagascar, Talks of South Africans
description: Starting a nine-day journey to Africa, Pope John Paul II today discussed the possibility of a future trip to South Africa but said the Pretoria Government must meet certain conditions.

title: Unilever Calls Off Deal To Buy Faberge Inc.
description: The Unilever Group said yesterday that its agreement to buy Faberge Inc. for $1.55 billion had been terminated.

title: Interstate-Johnson Lane reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Innovex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Judge Approves A Plan to Pump Hudson Water
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that New York City could begin drawing water from the Hudson River on Monday, as planned, to help ease a drought emergency, but that it could not treat the water with the chemical alum pending a hearing on its effects that same day.

title: TIE Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Five-Way Tie in Nashville: Nancy Lopez shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to move into a five-way tie for the lead after the first round of the Sara Lee Classic in Nashville. Lopez, looking for her first tour victory of the year, had three birdies and an eagle on par-5 holes at the 6,242-yard Hermitage Course. Sharing the lead were Missie Berteotti, Colleen Walker, Cindy Figg-Currier and Patty Sheehan.(AP) Geiberger-Henning Team Leads: Al Geiberger and Harold Henning fired their second consecutive 61 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead in the Legends of Golf tournament in Austin, Tex. Their 18-under 122 total tied the 36-hole record, set in 1982 by Don January and Sam Snead, for the two-man better-ball seniors event. (AP) Tennis Wilander and Becker Gain: Mats Wilander of Sweden and Boris Becker of West Germany, the top two seeded players, won their quarterfinals yesterday at the Monte Carlo Open in Monaco, the first major clay-court event of the season. Wilander topped Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-3, 7-6. Becker beat Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, 6-3, 6-3.(AP) Agassi and Noah Advance: Andre Agassi and Yannick Noah advanced yesterday to a semifinal showdown in their bracket of preliminary matches at the AT&T Challenge in Atlanta. Agassi defeated Aaron Krickstein, 6-0, 6-3. Fourth-seeded Noah defeated Andres Gomez, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2.(AP) Evert Advances: Top-seeded Chris Evert advanced to the semifinals of the Virginia Slims of Houston tournament yesterday with a 7-6, 6-3 victory over eighth-seeded Gretchen Magers.(AP)

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; A Fan for All Seasons
description: Ceiling fans are now popular in all parts of the country. In warm weather run them in the normal direction (counterclockwise) to send a gentle flow of air downward; this can allow air-conditioners to be set at higher temperatures. In cold weather reverse the fan to pull cooler air up, which forces warm air near the ceiling down. A ceiling fan is connected to an electrical outlet box on the ceiling that must be fastened to an overhead beam, not the plaster or drywall. Many homeowners remove an existing ceiling light and mount the fan in its place. If overhead light is still desired, there are lighting kits that attach to the bottom of the fan. Licensed electricians are required in some communities, so check with your local building department. $ What to look For Advantages Variable speed control Adjusts speed for maximum comfort. A fan that reverses Saves on cooling and heating costs. Five blades instead of four Moves more air. Size Fans vary from 40 to 52 inches in diameter. Choose largest ones for large spaces.

title: Campaign Trail; Borough Race May Go To Messinger by Default
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell, the Manhattan Democratic leader, is preparing to drop his bid for Manhattan borough president. That would pave the way for the virtually uncontested nomination and election of City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger as the new borough president.

title: Hextall Goes Out of Control to Help Flyers
description: Ron Hextall, a virtual madman in goalie's pads for the last three hours, was showered and dressed and calmly facing reporters late Tuesday night in Pittsburgh.

title: UNR Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,100,000.

title: Another Front in Trade War
description: The United States said it would retaliate because Japan had not opened its telecommunications market to American companies. Hearings will be held in May to decide what form the retaliation should take. Page 33.

title: Pages From the Life Of Tennessee Williams
description: On one page of notes to ''Mes Cahiers Noirs,'' an unpublished autobiographical fragment written in 1979, Tennessee Williams asked rhetorically, ''What are artists?'' He answered, ''Desperate searchers after whatever can be found of truth and beauty, even when the two may be poles apart.''

title: For a Young Violinist, Sudden Stardom
description: ''How did I get here? I'm still wondering about that myself,'' said Gil Shaham, an 18-year-old violinist from the Bronx who flew to London on Wednesday as a last-minute replacement for an ailing Itzhak Perlman in performances with the London Symphony Orchestra on Thursday evening and last night.

title: Plea in Mercy Killing of Baby
description: A father who pulled his comatose 16-month-old son from a hospital life-support system at gunpoint entered a plea of not guilty Thursday to charges of first-degree murder. The 23-year-old father, Rudy Linares, was freed on a $75,000 bond in the death of his son, Samuel. The boy, who died Wednesday, suffered severe brain damage last August after swallowing a balloon at a birthday party.

title: Review/Philharmonic; Leinsdorf's Blend of Today and Yesterday
description: Erich Leinsdorf, who is conducting this week's New York Philharmonic subscription concerts, is dividing his program between conservative contemporary works - two concertos, played by soloists from the orchestra - and a 19th-century symphony that was regarded as conservative in its own time, the Brahms Third.

title: Patents; Drive to Head Patent Office Under Way
description: The Bush Administration has not yet decided who should be the next Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, but several groups are lobbying for rival candidates and the outcome is likely to affect several important policies now in place.

title: Diversified Human Resources Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $62,355 for the latest quarter and $13,375 for the year-earlier period.

title: Yugoslav Inflation Rises
description: Yugoslavia's Bureau of Statistics reported today that prices soared by a monthly record of 92.6 percentage points, to a rate of 490.1 percent, compared with 397.5 percent in March. In April 1988, inflation was 152 percent. Yugoslav economists said inflation could rise to almost 1,000 percent by the end of the year, further depressing living standards that have already plummeted to their lowest levels since the late 1960's.

title: Durakon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included income of $78,000.

title: Blackmail Will Be Cited By Rose, Paper Says
description: Pete Rose, manager of the Cincinnati Reds, will tell investigators for the baseball commissioner's office that a former friend's attempt to blackmail him led to accusations that Rose bet on baseball games, The Cincinnati Post reported today.

title: Questar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Takeshita Gets a New Jet, and a Budget
description: Japanese officials said today that the agreement with the United States on the joint development and production of an advanced jet fighter was a reflection of Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's determination to settle several difficult issues before leaving office.

title: In West German Press, Support for Soviet Talks
description: The gathering storm in NATO over short-range missiles dominated the front pages of West German newspapers today, giving Chancellor Helmut Kohl temporary respite from the political battering of recent weeks but presaging tougher battles ahead.

title: Prenor Group Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Petrolane Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Fuel Line Malfunction Forces Delay in Shuttle Liftoff
description: The space shuttle Atlantis came within 31 seconds of being launched today, but a malfunction in an engine fuel line abruptly halted the countdown and forced at least a three-day postponement of the mission.

title: Eastern Sets 14-Jet Lease

All adjustments necessary to fairly state the results for such period have been included and are of a normal recurring nature. The share earnings for the year-ago periods included about 7 cents a share related to the reversal of taxes previously accrued on non-repatriated earnings deemed permanently reinvested.

Life on a Tanker: More Salad, Less Grog
description: Many of the rigors of life at sea are easing. This ship, for instance, has a salad bar and each night many of the sailors call their wives on cellular phones.

The Ethos of the Late-Night Jogger
description: Despite the attack last week on a jogger making a moonlight run through Central Park, the park continues to be populated after dark by clusters of men and women in shiny stretch pants and high-tech rubber-soled shoes, pursuing physical fitness along dirt paths and paved roads well into the night.

title: Oil and Gas Leases Sold
description: The Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management on Thursday sold oil and natural gas exploration leases on 64,752 acres in six Southern states for $17.2 million. Some 325,000 acres, mostly in national forests, in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Virginia were offered at the auction. A bureau spokesman, Bob Ward, said the five-year exploration leases allow holders to look for oil and gas, but other permits are needed to extract it.

title: Prime Computer Seeking Suitor
description: Prime Computer Inc., fighting a $966 million bid from a much smaller rival, is promoting its lucrative European operations to entice a friendly suitor, the company's president, Anthony Craig, said in an interview. MAI Basic Four Inc., a Tustin, Calif., company controlled by Bennett LeBow, the financier, has pursued Prime since November. Prime rejected the $20-a-share bid, announcing April 11 that it would shop for a higher offer.

title: Monroe I. Katcher, Lawyer, 80
description: Monroe I. Katcher, former associate counsel for the New York State Liquor Authority, died of a heart attack Thursday at the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Your Money; Returning Home May Be a Mistake
description: Thousands of college graduates will soon be looking for jobs and places to live, and many will end up back home with Mom and Dad, having determined that they cannot afford an apartment on the paycheck from an entry-level job. But some experts question that calculation. ''I often find 'I can't afford' translates to 'I'd rather spend my money here,' '' for an expensive car or stereo system, said Bernard E. Poduska, a psychologist who teaches family therapy and financial management at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah.

title: Thompson Says He Met Suspect in Drug Case
description: John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown, said Thursday night in a live appearance on ABC's ''Nightline'' that he had got in touch with a Washington man charged with running a cocaine ring. Thompson said he had wanted to make sure none of his players would be hurt while spending time at a Washington nightclub known for drug trafficking. None were suspected of using drugs, Thompson said.

Yanks Win With Some Help From Umpires
description: The Yankees and the Chicago White Sox, two lowly teams, seemed to drag the umpires down to their level last night. How else to explain a couple of calls they made that helped the Yankees to a 3-1 victory? The umpires, though, had an excuse for one of their controversial calls.

title: U.S. to Put Off Production Of Nuclear Arms Gas Till '90
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins has told Congress that production of tritium, a radioactive gas used in making nuclear warheads, will not resume this year.

title: KEY RATES
Reviews/Music; A Mayan Creation Legend, for Orchestra
description: Alberto Ginastera died in June 1983 before he could finish ''Popul Vuh,'' his orchestral interpretation of a Mayan legend about the world's creation that Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra had commissioned from the composer eight years earlier. Although Ginastera wrote seven of the intended eight movements, the Philadelphians decided not to go through with a performance, so the score languished among Ginastera's papers until just a few months ago, when it was brought to the attention of Leonard Slatkin, music director of the St. Louis Symphony. Mr. Slatkin liked what there was of ''Popul Vuh'' enough to lead his ensemble through its New York premiere on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: American National Insurance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bank Puts Your Money Where Your Heart Is
description: Taking another step in an emerging approach to investment, Vermont's second-largest bank has begun offering accounts that guarantee depositors their money will be lent only to ventures that meet certain social goals.

title: British Soccer Fans Convicted
description: Fourteen British soccer fans today were convicted of involuntary manslaughter in connection with the deaths of 39 Italian fans at an abortive match at Heysel Stadium here nearly four years ago. The 14 were given sentences of three years, with half of the time on probation. They were each also fined $1,500. Eleven other fans were acquitted. The riot came just before the 1985 European soccer championship final between Liverpool of England and Juventus Turin of Italy.

title: Soviets Readmit Medvedev
description: The Communist Party has readmitted Roy A. Medvedev, a historian whose chronicle of the bloody dictatorial rule of Stalin prompted his expulsion 20 years ago, the press agency Tass said today. Asked if he attributed his restoration to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies, Mr. Medvedev said: ''I didn't change my views. A turnabout occurred in the party, the Central Committee. They stopped discriminating against me.''

title: New York's Universities Need a Raise
description: Students at public universities throughout New York State face a likely $200 annual tuition increase next year if Gov. Mario Cuomo accepts the budget proposed by the State Legislature. State University students generally accept the proposal. But those on several City University campuses are demonstrating and occupying buildings in protest.

Regrettably, that essentially racist assumption may have been reinforced in a documentary this week on N

title: North, Citing 'Nut Element,' Has Hidden-Weapon Permit
