title: Brawley Denies She Fabricated Tale of Rape
description: Tawana Brawley yesterday denied published reports that she had told a boyfriend that she and her mother fabricated her story of abduction and rape. But she refused to answer questions about the reports.

title: Cynthia Keller to Wed T. P. Macdonald
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Keller of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Susan Keller, to Thomas Philip Macdonald, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James P. Macdonald of Huntington Woods, Mich. The wedding is to be next month.

title: ALL IN THE FAMILY
description: One of the highest compliments a child can pay a parent is to choose his or her profession. In the food world, the passing of the baton from parent to child is often more natural than in other fields. A child absorbs the smells, tastes and skills as an ordinary part of life at home. Growing up, though, he or she must overcome the challenge facing any child of famous parents: how to take those skills and establish an independent style.

title: Single's Fees
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Betsy Wade's ''Getting Around Fees on Singles'' (Practical Traveler, March 12). Having toured the world during a 10-year period as a single (widow), I preferred the freedom and privacy of my own quarters, when available. Being part of a tour has many advantages, but the close proximity to several dozen people every day makes time alone quite worthwhile.

title: A TASTE OF THEIR OWN MEDICINE
description: PROMISED LAND By Karel Schoeman. Translated by Marion V. Friedmann. 205 pp. New York: Summit Books. Paper, $7.95. Cloth, $18.95.

title: Prospects; Rethinking Gramm-Rudman
description: The Gramm-Rudman law to reduce the budget deficit requires a balanced budget by 1993. Under the act, next year's deficit target is $100 billion - which was met earlier this month in an agreement between Congress and the Bush Administration. Critics argue that the act is flawed and that the budget agreement was achieved through accounting tricks. Without these tricks, they say, the real deficit for next year would be $30 billion to $40 billion greater. Four experts on the budgeting process give their views on Gramm-Rudman and its future. Stanley E. Collender Director of Federal budget policy, Price Waterhouse.

title: For Soviet Athletes, A Greater Presence In American Sports
description: They are arriving in the United States in increasing numbers and participating in a wider variety of sports, amateur and professional athletes from the Soviet Union doing their part to make perestroika a success. It is a friendly invasion and one of the more visible signs of the political and economic reforms initiated by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: A Precedent?
description: To the Editor:

title:
PAPERBACKS;
FROM THE TWO-BIT BEGINNING
description: LEAD: Just 50 years ago, in June of 1939, we sailed for New York from Southampton on the Nieuw Amsterdam. Two newlyweds, aged 20 (Betty) and 23 (Ian), setting out to prove that what America needed was paperback books.

title: POSTINGS: Organize Now, Build Later; 24 Homes Sites on a Fairfield County Tract
description: The concept of shared responsibility for residential properties is spreading, with homeowners associations being created to bear the costs of landscaping and maintenance even before houses are built.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Dartmouth; Forestry Team, Flexing Muscles, Turns Back Clock
description: Using muscle power to fell a tree, pulp a log or chop a block is passe in today's highly mechanized world of commercial logging. But for students on the Dartmouth Forestry Team, it's the only way.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Plant carrots, beets and chard. If egg masses of gypsy moths are found, scrape them off into a can filled with strong laundry bleach or motor oil. Last call to have power equipment serviced. Last call to apply pre-emergent herbicides to lawns and service areas to control weed growth, especially crabgrass. New Guinea Impatiens

title: Illinois-U.S.C. Set for Moscow
description: A football game between Illinois and Southern California will take place Sept. 2 at Moscow's Dynamo Stadium, the first time a match between American football teams will be played in the Soviet Union, the Tass press agency said Friday.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The M.V.P. In the N.B.A?
description: Magic Johnson, without a doubt. He may not lead the league in scoring, assists or rebounds, but he is the glue that holds the Lakers together. Jordan will always be there setting records, and Ewing, Malone and Barkley should stick around long enough for another chance. MATTHEW QUIRK Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: Tracy A. Woodfield Marries U. Patrik Jakobson
description: Tracy Ann Woodfield, a securities analyst at the First Boston Corporation, and U. Patrik Jakobson, an associate at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Revs. David Pederson and John Dean Twiname performed the ceremony.

title: Kathleen Beck Weds a Writer
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Kingston, N.Y., Kathleen Mary Beck, a daughter of George Beck and Margaret Kelleher Beck, both of Kingston, was married yesterday to Stephen Phillip Policoff, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard D. Policoff of Berkeley, Calif. Msgr. James Keating officiated.

title: Children's Books: Inside the Baby-Sitters Club
description: The absolute best book for Nicole Zajack was the one in which Dawn moved into her new house and she and the other baby sitters became convinced there was a ghost rattling around. It turned out to be a playful mouse. ''That was great,'' said Nicole, who's 13. ''Dawn's really neat. She's just like me. She's on the quiet side, but she's definitely mature. A very neat person.'' After she read the fifth book, Nicole began to phone her local bookstore every day to see if the next one had come in yet. ''I mean, I couldn't wait,'' she said. ''Who could?''

title: Puzzles And Possibilities
description: THE steps are the sort that should take you to the front door of an older house in the city. Instead, they are in a rural area and go up a short slope to a clearing in the woods.

title:
GARDENING;
A Few Tips for Successful Spring Planting
description: LEAD: OF all the facets of plant care, soil preparation and planting in a timely manner are the most important.

title: Michelle Oaklan Weds
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York, Michelle M. Oaklan and John M. McFaul were married last evening by the Rev. Salvatore Matarazzo. Mrs. McFaul, a daughter of Norman E. Oaklan and Marie Oaklan, both of Buffalo, is the director of public relations in New York for Loews Hotels. Mr. McFaul, a son of John McFaul of Watertown, N.Y., and the late Mary McFaul, is a partner in the law firm of Hatter, Donovan & McFaul in Lynbrook, L.I.

title: PAPERBACKS: New & Noteworthy
description: THE WHITE LANTERN, by Evan S. Connell. (North Point, $9.95.) In essays on Antarctic exploration, the Vikings' discovery of America, the origins of man and other matters, Evan S. Connell muses on the oddities and incongruous facts that stand in defiance of our compulsion to theorize. ''Merely to list Mr. Connell's subjects is to describe his mind: stubbornly unsystematic, curious, enamored of unsolved puzzles,'' Paul Zweig said here in 1980. '' 'The White Lantern' is not a history of scientific discovery, or of anything else for that matter. It is an antiquarian's attic; a trove of sidelights and overlooked details.'' QUINN'S BOOK, by William Kennedy. (Penguin, $8.95.) Drawing on his now familiar ingredients - journalists, politicians and a magical city called Albany - William Kennedy tells the story of Daniel Quinn, a young newspaperman who tries to win the heart of the elusive Maud Fallon, the beautiful enigma he saved from drowning in the Hudson when she was 12 years old. ''If the history sometimes overwhelms the story, it is always fascinating,'' T. Coraghessan Boyle said here last year. ''Mr. Kennedy does indeed have the power to peer into the past, to breathe life into it and make it indispensable. . . . Alive on every page with its author's passion for his place and the events that made it, it is a novel to savor. One puts down 'Quinn's Book' with a sigh, ever envying Mr. Kennedy his roots.'' WHO KILLED CBS? The Undoing of America's Number One News Network, by Peter J. Boyer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) CBS News was once known as the aerie of such distinguished broadcast journalists as Edward R. Murrow, Charles Collingwood and Walter Cronkite. Then along came Van Gordon Sauter, who presided over its fall. ''This is a horror story and Mr. Boyer tells it well,'' Jeff Jarvis said in The Book Review in 1988. ''His writing is polished, his reporting thorough. His analysis, so far as it goes, is savvy and intelligent.'' SAILING, by Susan Kenney. (Penguin, $7.95.) Phil, who is dying of cancer, is dubious when his wife, Sara, wants to buy him a sailboat; then he finds that taking flight across the water is a way to wrest control of his life. ''Although capable and good in sketching the mine field of marital feelings, [ Susan Kenney ] has captured the exquisite pleasures and dangers of the sea marvelously,'' C. D. B. Bryan said here last year. FRIENDS IN HIGH PLACES. The Bechtel Story: The Most Secret Corporation and How It Engineered the World, by Laton McCartney. (Ballantine, $8.95.) The Bechtel engineering services company has given the world Hoover Dam, the Trans-Alaska Pipeline and the Saudi Arabian city of Jubail. It has also supplied the United States Government with a Secretary of State (George P. Shultz), a Secretary of Defense (Caspar W. Weinberger) and a Director of Central Intelligence (Richard Helms). There is nothing improper about this, the San Francisco-based corporation has insisted in a response to this book, denying that its political connections are based on anything more nefarious than networking. ''No other private corporation in modern history has had closer ties to the Federal Government than Bechtel,'' Stephen Labaton said in The Book Review last year. ''By either Mr. McCartney's or Bechtel's standards, it is corporate networking of unparalleled dimensions.'' LIFE IN THE LAND OF THE LIVING, by Daniel Vilmure. (McGraw-Hill, $6.95.) One summer's night, a disturbed boy who thinks he's another James Dean joins his younger brother on a rampage through their seedy Florida town. The novelist Daniel Vilmure's ''vivid, terse language aptly embodies the hard-driving, violent drama and makes us feel we are running through the night with these brothers driven by a painful loss of innocence and fate,'' Gardner McFall said here in 1987. DOROTHY DAY: A Radical Devotion, and SIMONE WEIL: A Modern Pilgrimage, both by Robert Coles. (Merloyd Lawrence/Addison-Wesley, $9.95 each.) The psychiatrist Robert Coles met Dorothy Day more than 35 years ago when he worked in one of her soup kitchens. He became acquainted with another reformer, Simone Weil, through her books of radical social criticism. In these biographies, ''Dr. Coles takes up certain themes and passions that preoccupied his subjects, and wrestles with them as one might do with those of any figure who has become a lifelong spiritual companion,'' Kenneth L. Woodward said here in 1987. ''It is well worth having both of the Coles books for what they tell us about the life of the spirit.'' THE DEATH OF METHUSELAH: And Other Stories, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) When Isaac Bashevis Singer's 10th collection of short stories was published last year, our reviewer, Robert Pinsky, said he catches ''the spiritual energy of that abrupt transition from the ancient to the modern'' that suffuses Yiddish literature. ''This energy seems to underlie the urbane sorcery of his work, his almost manic power to spin out abundant and immensely entertaining narrative.'' ALBANY PARK: A Story of Bohemian Adventure and Obsessive Love, by Patrice Chaplin. (Atlantic Monthly, $8.95.) A British writer reminisces about the mid-1950's, when she left her dreary London suburb at the age of 15 and embarked on a hitchhiking trip that ended in Spain, where she fell in love with a poet. ''Memories of the wartime blitz and her mother's suicidal psychotic episodes are stitched into good, hard-edged writing that about halfway through becomes a romance,'' our reviewer, Irma Kurtz, said in 1987. The story of Patrice Chaplin's further adventures, ANOTHER CITY ($9.95), is available from Atlantic Monthly as a paperback original. THE RETURN OF MR. HOLLYWOOD, by Josh Greenfeld. (Carroll & Graf, $8.95.) When his mother dies, Larry Lazar, an obnoxious Hollywood director, goes home to Brooklyn to contemplate the mess his life has been. In 1984 our reviewer, Herbert Gold, said this story by the author of ''A Child Called Noah'' is ''as vulgar as a Hollywood novel should be and usually is, as witty as a Hollywood novel should be and often is not.'' LAST WALTZ IN VIENNA: The Rise and Destruction of a Family, 1842-1942, by George Clare. (Owl/Holt, $11.95.) In this memoir, a survivor who lost his family in the Holocaust reminisces about the days in Vienna when it was still possible to believe in the virtues of assimilation. ''Along with the horror of its collapse, Mr. Clare has conveyed precisely and charmingly the world that for nearly a century Western Europe's Jews thought they were living in,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times in 1982. EYELESS IN GAZA, by Aldous Huxley. (Carroll & Graf, $10.95.) After a chance encounter with an older, enlightened man, a fashionably cynical libertine learns that world peace can be achieved only through individual acts of compassion. ''For all its structural faults 'Eyeless in Gaza' is an important and portentous book - one that no thinking man or woman of the twentieth century can read without stimulation and deep respect,'' our reviewer, J. Donald Adams, said when this novel was published in 1936. THE STALKER AFFAIR, by John Stalker. (Penguin, $7.95.) Sent by the Thatcher Government to investigate allegations that policemen had killed unarmed Irish rebels in 1982, John Stalker was removed from the case in what he says was a cover-up. His book about the affair opens ''a fine, shocking window on the more shadowy parts of the modern English-Irish agony that knowledgeable Americans cannot afford to ignore,'' Francis X. Clines said in The Book Review in 1988. MASTERS OF ATLANTIS, by Charles Portis. (McGraw-Hill, $6.95.) From his very own secret temple in a suburb of Gary, Ind., Lamar Jimmerson and his fellow illuminati protect the secret wisdom of the lost continent of Atlantis. Charles Portis, the author of ''True Grit,'' has a ''pitch-perfect ear for the solemnly ridiculous,'' The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in 1985. ''A purpose infuses the craziness, a sense that the author is after something bigger than jokes.'' HEROES OF THEIR OWN LIVES. The Politics and History of Family Violence: Boston 1880-1960, by Linda Gordon. (Penguin, $8.95.) By studying almost a century's worth of records from three Boston agencies devoted to protecting children, Linda Gordon constructed a history of society's attitudes toward child abuse, incest and wife beating. This is ''feminist scholarship at its best,'' Kenneth Keniston said in The Book Review last year. GENTLEMEN IN ENGLAND: A Vision, by A. N. Wilson. (Penguin, $6.95.) Horace Nettleship, head of a middle-class Victorian family, gives up God for geology, then discovers that his son wants to become a man of the cloth. ''Laden with literary allusions, studded with cameo appearances by Victorian luminaries, steaming with the scientific, religious and esthetic controversies of the day, lightly and fantastically comical, yet filled with moments of luminous insight, this is one of Wilson's most ambitious and successful novels,'' one reviewer said in 1986. Penguin has also reissued Mr. Wilson's first novel, THE SWEETS OF PIMLICO ($6.95), in which Evelyn Tradescant, a lonely woman who loves natural history, is pursued by a mysterious elderly man. It was published in 1977. EMBATTLED COURAGE: The Experience of Combat in the American Civil War, by Gerald F. Linderman. (Free Press, $11.95.) In his analysis of their letters, diaries and memoirs, a historian captures the frightening innocence of the men who so eagerly rushed to fight in the battles between North and South. The result is a book ''that comes a good deal closer to a true understanding of the Civil War soldier than we have had before,'' Stephen W. Sears said here in 1987. THE FIFTH ESTATE, by Ferdinando Camon. Translated by John Shepley. (Marlboro, $9.95.) When Patrizia, a girl from the city, moves in with a family of Italian peasants, she seems to them like an ambassador from another world. Ferdinando Camon's novel of Italian life in the decade after World War II ''paints a scene like a Bruegel canvas,'' Susan Zuccotti said here last year. ''These peasants have an animal sensitivity, intuition rather than intelligence.'' The publisher has also reissued Mr. Camon's LIFE EVERLASTING ($10.95), a novel about how the lives of these people were disrupted by the two world wars. In both books, John Shepley's translation is ''invariably smooth and vivid,'' the reviewer said. JOHN McGRAW, by Charles C. Alexander. (Penguin, $8.95.) As manager of the New York Giants in the early decades of the century, John J. McGraw was ''the incarnation of rowdyism, the personification of meanness and howling blatancy,'' one contemporary sportswriter said. Charles C. Alexander ''blows away the golden dust of myth and weaves his history with such restraint and precision that we recognize the game of McGraw and Cobb,'' John Hough Jr. said in The Book Review in 1988. OFFSHORE, by Penelope Fitzgerald. (Carroll & Graf, $7.95.) This novel about eccentric Britons living on barges moored in the Thames is written with ''great care and skill,'' Barbara Fisher Williamson said in The Book Review in 1987. ''Ms. Fitzgerald excels at deft touches of characterization and dialogue.'' The book won England's Booker Prize in 1979. ALL MY FRIENDS ARE GOING TO BE STRANGERS, by Larry McMurtry. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) After Danny Deck sells his first novel, he leaves Houston and the only people in his life who seem stable, Emma Horton and her husband, Flap. Then he heads for San Francisco, wondering whether it's possible for a writer to stay creative and lead a normal life. In 1972 one reviewer called the novel ''acute, elegiac, funny and dangerously tender.'' Emma, who first entered the world in Mr. McMurtry's novel ''Moving On,'' shows up again in the newly reissued TERMS OF ENDEARMENT ($8.95) as the daughter of Aurora Greenway, a widow whose many suitors include a retired general (converted into an astronaut for the movie version). ''Through three very different books . . . Emma kept growing on me,'' Mr. McMurtry says in a preface to this new edition. And Touchstone has also reissued his 1968 collection, IN A NARROW GRAVE: Essays on Texas ($7.95). ''What I didn't know then,'' he writes in the preface to this new edition of the essays, ''was that I was about to leave not merely the land itself but also the rural point of view and, in a sense, the myth.'' RIDING THE IRON ROOSTER: By Train Through China, by Paul Theroux. (Ivy, $4.95.) In another of his railway chronicles, Paul Theroux writes about a miserable year he spent touring China. Last year our reviewer, Mark Salzman, said Mr. Theroux is better at evoking the land than the people. ''He is in top form as he describes the barren deserts of Mongolia and Xinjiang, the ice forests of Manchuria and the dry hills of Tibet. He captures their otherworldly, haunting appearances perfectly. . . . [ But ] although he saw every corner of the country, ate plenty of Chinese food, visited lots of museums and met a variety of people, apparently [ he ] didn't make any Chinese friends.'' ISLAND, by Thomas Perry. (Avon, $3.95.) Working almost from scratch, a con man makes his own Caribbean island from a mostly submerged reef, promoting it as an offshore tax haven and a tourist resort. Then he tries to join the United Nations and repel covetous invaders. Thomas Perry's novel is ''wacky, imaginative, funny, serious and altogether different,'' Newgate Callendar said in The Book Review last year. ''Try not to miss it.''

title: HOMOSEXUALITY: WHO AND WHY?
description: According to the findings Melvin Konner cites, most cultures of the world accept the inevitability of homosexuality as a naturally occurring human event. Is it not time, therefore, to investigate why the need to condemn this mode of sexual expression exists to so great an extent?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Columbia, S.C.;
Seeds of Growth On the River
description: LEAD: CITY officials are working here to develop the Congaree Vista, 800 acres in a mile-and-a-half-long, mile-wide stretch along the east bank of the Congaree River. The tract is now a crazy-quilt of parks, industrial warehouses, office buildings, vacant lots, a water-treatment plant, the Governor's Mansion and the Central Correctional

title: Traditional Greek Easter Fare
description: LEAD: IN a scene that is being repeated in thousands of Greek-American homes across the state today, Dr. Christos Romas of Short Hills and his 10-year-old daughter, Maria, will crack red-dyed eggs against each other with the greeting ''Christos Anesti'' (''Christ Is Risen'') and ''Alithos Anesti'' (''Indeed He Is Risen'').

title:
THE VIEW FROM: ENFIELD;
A Town Finds Noise a Small Price to Pay for a View
description: LEAD: THERE is no accounting for taste, or, it appears, noise. While the state has a waiting list of 189 sites where people have asked for highway noise barriers, residents in Enfield have just waged what looks like a successful battle to stop the state from putting them up in one part of the town.

title: Zanzibar's Exotic Medley
description: LEAD: ZANZIBAR was known in the 19th century as the Metropolis of East Africa - the place where trading in slaves held as great an attraction as trading in ivory. Once the mainland was opened for commerce from Europe, it was also the depot and clearing port for East Africa. It is said that the Portuguese arrived by 1497, searching for a route to the

title: Brian Friel's Ireland: Both Private and Political
description: It was a rainy afternoon in New York, the day's rehearsals had ended, and the Irish dramatist Brian Friel was back in the city where he began his international career with ''Philadelphia, Here I Come!'' more than two decades ago. He was in town for the belated American premiere of his 1979 play ''Aristocrats,'' which opened Tuesday, and that meant submitting to a journalistic rite - the interview - which he is known to dislike. ''I'm never quite sure what they're for,'' he said amiably over drinks at a Chelsea restaurant, worlds away from the nature and the quiet of his Greencastle, County Donegal, home. Indeed, in 1972 he took preventive measures to forestall such occasions by interviewing himself in a BBC radio ''self-portrait'':

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; On History's Trail in Tarrytown: From Colonial Days to 19th Century
description: When Washington Irving sat down late at night to work on his biography of George Washington, he wrote by the light of a French whale-oil lamp. When he relaxed after dinner, it was in a green upholstered armchair that looked out over the Hudson River.

title: Edith A. Tarbox, A News Anchor, Weds Executive
description: Edith Ann Tarbox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Holcomb Tarbox of Lakeway, Tex., and Pequot Lakes, Minn., was married yesterday to Marc Philip Weill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford I. Weill of New York and Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Robert Widom and the Rev. Frank Erwin, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Covenant Presbyterian Church in Austin, Tex.

title: Flying Blind With Few Sources on Security Threats
description: Until the bombing of Pan American World Airways Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, last December, few American travelers were aware that the Government routinely alerts airlines to the possibility of such acts of terrorism.

title: Sick of the 60's, 3 Men Of the 80's Try to Give Nostalgia a Bad Name
description: For the fledgling American Association for the Advancement of Time, this may be the finest hour. Yet its members - all three of them - vow never to look back longingly on these early days since their purpose is to make nostalgia a thing of the past.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Two of the best-defined subsets of collectors are those who care about the backs of stamps, and those who do not. Collectors who care, check whether an older stamp has its original gum, or whether there is a piece of a hinge stuck on. Collectors who do not care, are content with a fine design or clear cancel on the face.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Look Up From the Trenches
description: The tempest over Bonn's call to negotiate with the Soviets on short-range nuclear missiles in Europe should be kept in a teacup. Chancellor Helmut Kohl is a bumbler, which can't be news to anyone, and his natural insensitivity is compounded by his panic at losing votes. His Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, is pushy, which is politically rewarding in West Germany these days.

title:
FOCUS: Low-Income Housing;
More Corporations Investing in Low-Income Housing
description: LEAD: The roster of American corporations that invest in low-income rental housing is expanding as a result of tax legislation that lets them do well by doing good.

title: Too Many Books?
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Illinois; Being Accepted: Gay Students Attend a Prom
description: It might have looked like the average fraternity formal, but to the students in tuxedoes and evening gowns at the University of Illinois it was an ''Alternative Prom'' - a dance co-sponsored by the Lesbian and Gay Illini and the Illini Union Board, which organizes university-sponsored events.

title: Vowing 'City of Law,' Mayor Of Yonkers Begins Campaign
description: Standing on the steps of City Hall with more than 100 well-wishers, Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko officially announced his bid for re-election today, asserting that ''never before has the opportunity been so right to bring about a meaningful political reform in the city of Yonkers.''

title: 1939: THE BIRTH OF THE MODERN PAPERBACK
description: ''OUT TODAY - THE NEW POCKET BOOKS THAT MAY REVOLUTIONIZE NEW YORK'S READING HABITS.'' The advertisement announced Pocket Books' intention ''to open up new frontiers of literature . . . by distributing low-priced books.'' The 4 1/2-inch-by-6 1/2-inch volumes, bound in brightly colored paper covers, cost 25 cents and were sold at drugstores and newsstands as well as bookstores and department stores.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE HORSE BUSINESS;
FOR SMALL-HORSE BREEDERS, MORE BUYERS AND BIGGER PROFITS
description: LEAD: Lynn Spicer takes his horse Jack almost everywhere. Jack accompanies him to work most mornings - and wanders around the premises of Mr. Spicer's swimming pool business in Waverly, N.Y. The horse even goes on vacations with the Spicers, traveling in the family's motor home. (Jack can signal Mr. Spicer when he needs to step outside.) Jack can be treated like any other domesticated pet because he is a miniature.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Dancing Feet

title: 'Television Is Like Having a Stranger In'
description: SINCE the early 1970's, social scientists and educators have been examining the effect of television on the cognitive, social and emotional development of children. One of the pioneer researchers in this area is Jerome L. Singer of Bethany, a professor of psychology and child study at Yale and a co-director of the Yale Family Television Research and Consultation Center.

title: What Aquino Wants
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: RENEWAL TIME. By Es'kia Mphahlele. (Readers International, Paper, $8.95; Cloth, $16.95.) As a herdboy and street urchin, the South African writer Es'kia Mphahlele knew both his country's rich pastoral pleasures and its stark urban blight. In his new book of short stories, ''Renewal Time,'' Mr. Mphahlele collects haunting scenes from that childhood, steeps them in the alienation of his lengthy exile, which lasted from 1957 to 1977, and illustrates the bitter estrangement he experienced upon his return. In his introduction, drawn from his 1984 autobiography, ''Afrika My Music,'' he describes his early literary focus as ''the drama of life as lived in the ghetto,'' a perspective that regarded '' 'white' life merely as peripheral'' to his concerns. But this new book clearly aims for a broader picture. Far from peripheral, whites have now become central to the author's acid observations and caustic view. In ''The Living and the Dead,'' for example, a black South African, a sanitation worker named Lebona, delivers a letter he has found on the street to the home of a wealthy white, only to be accused of opening it and thus receive a dressing-down. ''They're not even decent enough to suspect one's telling the truth!'' Lebona thinks of the man, and by extension all whites. ''They always lie to you when you're white,'' the white man thinks, as if in reply. In the ensuing dialogue, the more Lebona tries to impress the white man that he has performed a service, the greater is the other's mistrust and disdain. Similarly, in another story, ''A Ballad of Oyo,'' a South African exile observes an open-air market in Nigeria where the local women laugh in ridicule at the sight of a white missionary who brings her own scale to weigh meat before aggressively trying to bargain down the price. ''Ninepence is too much,'' another white woman says, as the negotiations are concluded. And so she leaves, defeated, as are so many people in these stories, by mutual suspicion and unfamiliarity.

title: A Support Group On Child Disorder
description: LEAD: ''IT whittles away at your self-esteem, at your feeling of being able to cope and function as a parent,'' Lynn Falvo of Tinton Falls said. ''It's important for you to know that there are other people who have kids like this, who are kind and generous and rational and intelligent and professionally oriented and good, and they're hanging on by their fingernails, too.

title:
THE WORLD;
The Crackdown in Soviet Georgia: An Eyewitness Account
description: LEAD: VIOLENCE in the Soviet republic of Georgia this month was a rude reminder to the Soviet leadership of the deep resentment harbored by many of the country's non-Russian nationalities.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Prospect, Me.; A Time for Planning
description: THERE is little about this sleepy little Maine town at the mouth of the Penobscot River that would indicate a building moratorium was needed.

title: Taking Time Off From the Rat Race To Shoehorn In a Little Power Fun
description: It's the first Friday night that Lisa B. Reznik has had off in a couple of 65-hour weeks. She zips into her phone booth of an apartment on the East Side, rids herself of her pin-striped suit, slips into something black and with a smear of blush and a squirt of hair spray she is transformed, ready for a relentless night of power fun.

title: Cutting Prison Barge Corners
description: New York City is acquiring another big barge to use as a jail. Does it matter that several officials misled the Board of Estimate about the selection of a consultant to plan for it?

title: Go to College To Develop
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Ms. Priest? DECIDING what to call the new priest is the first problem facing the small congregation of St. John's Episcopal Church in Oakdale. What do you call a female priest? ''I don't know,'' said Betty Voehl, whose family has attended St. John's since 1946. ''Father won't do,'' said her husband, William.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Bard; Using the Stage To Voice Feelings About Racism
description: ''Fear is like a shadow -it's always there,'' says one of the characters in ''Purgatory,'' a play written by Bard College students about racism and inspired by the death of Edmund Perry.

title: Heather Hawkins And J. B. Duncan Wed in Louisiana
description: Heather Covell Hawkins, a daughter of Walter E. Hawkins Jr. of Shreveport, La., and the late Gaynell Little Hawkins of Shreveport, was married yesterday to John Bruce Duncan, a son of J. Bruce Duncan of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Leila Hammond Duncan. The Rev. John B. Rogers performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Shreveport.

title: Nancy Boardman, Freelance Writer, Wed at Princeton
description: The Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Goddard Boardman and James Douglas Sparkman Jr. The Rev. Frank Strasburger, the university's Episcopal chaplain, officiated.

title: For Spy Addicts, The Sandbaggers Are the Real Stuff
description: Attention, addicts of British spy shows who have not been getting much of a kick from ''Game, Set & Match,'' the latest spy series to be doled out on ''Mystery'': The real stuff is at hand. Channel 21, Long Island's public station, has brought back ''The Sandbaggers'' - and scheduled it to follow the Thursday evening showing of ''Game, Set & Match,'' which seems even murkier by comparison. A repeat is available on Sundays.

title: Canada Celebrates A Mission In Film
description: On the outside, it's a grimy brick building facing a noisy expressway. On the inside, a Kafkaesque maze of corridors, stairways, offices, laboratories and screening rooms.

title: Foreign Affairs, State by State
description: More state governments have business representatives in Japan's capital than in America's, according to the National Governors Association. There are 39 in Tokyo, 38 in Washington.

title: Avery Fisher Awards
description: Avery Fisher Career Grants of $10,000 each have been awarded to Allison Eldredge, a cellist; Daniel McKelway, a clarinetist, and Paul Neubauer, a violist. Grants are presented each year to instrumentalists who are United States citizens considered ready for major careers.

title: The Letters of Dr. Karl
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The M.V.P. In the N.B.A?
description: To choose an m.v.p. you have to imagine the team without that player. The Lakers without Magic would be above .500 because they would still have Scott, Worthy, Cooper, Green, Thompson, and the still formidable Abdul-Jabbar. The Rockets without Olajuwon would be an eighth playoff team with good passing. If the Bulls did not have Jordan they would definitely be a lottery team. MOSHE SZLECHTER Brooklyn

title: Can Japan Also Change Its System This Time?
description: THE crisis leading to the downfall of Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita last week demonstrated once again the difficulties faced by Japan in establishing strong political leadership to buttress its growing economic power in the world.

title:
GARDENING;
A Few Tips for Successful Spring Planting
description: LEAD: OF all the facets of plant care, soil preparation and planting in a timely manner are the most important.

title: JOHN GOTTI: RUNNING THE MOB
description: Some readers, seeing John Gotti featured on the cover of your magazine, might assume that crime does pay - at least in the public relations sense of ''I don't care what you say about me as long as you spell my name correctly.''

title: A Brief Encounter With a Foster Child
description: THUMPAH, thumpah. My heart was beating so hard I could feel it, almost hear it. A dog barked on the other side of the door. Could it sense my fear? Somewhere behind that door was my foster daughter and in a moment or two I would see her for the first time. Would she reject me out of hand? How would I get along with her? ''Answer the door, Pam,'' said a women from within the house. The door swung open. Two young girls stood there, both wan. The darker of the two, the one with her hair in a French braid, had an expectant expression. That must be Pam.

title: Corporate Day Care: A Success Story
description: The article [ April 16 ] accurately describes corporate interest in child care. However, it gives no recognition to one of the major success stories in corporate child care on Long Island. Well over 50 businesses have been involved in providing direct financial support of a near-site center called the Children's Community since 1981.

title: Another Look at Fulbright
description: To the Editor:

title: Salem Journal; Companies 'Stand Up' to Help City's Revitalization Efforts
description: SOMETHING strange is happening here.

title: Mikes Enhance Amateur Music
description: George Bernard Shaw declared that ''Hell is full of amateur musicians.'' How, or where, this information was obtained, he doesn't say. But he was a music critic before becoming a playwright, so maybe he just knew.

title: U.S. Decision To Curb F-14 Sends a Jolt to Economy
description: THE Pentagon's decision last week to cancel new production of the Navy's F-14D fighter, made by the Grumman Corporation, has sent violent tremors throughout the Long Island economy, already reeling from earlier cuts in defense spending.

title: Vanessa Noel: Shoe Designer
description: As a child in the Main Line area, near Philadelphia, Vanessa Noel refused to go to birthday parties shod in Mary Janes. Pumps were more her style. While studying fashion in Paris one summer, she lived on hard-boiled eggs and spent her food money on 32 pairs of pumps. ''They were too beautiful for the floor,'' she recalled, ''so I hung them on the wall.''

title: Is It Funny? Read the Program
description: Wit in music is too rare to constitute a genre. It does turn up here and there - in the operas of Mozart and certain songs of Hugo Wolf, for example - but what passes for musical wit is rarely fine-tuned enough to deserve the name. Understood, all musical levity is in the ear of the beholder. Listener A slaps a thigh over the very idea of the late Dennis Brain performing a concerto for garden hose; B merely groans. X laughs heartily when superboy Siegfried torments a dwarf; Y curls a lip. Z, meanwhile, will listen to nothing but Bruckner and finds nothing at all funny about serious music unless advised otherwise by the program notes.

title: BEYOND THE QUARK
description: DRIVING SOUTH FROM THE DALLAS FORT Worth airport, you see signs for some well-known Texas landmarks - Texas Stadium (home of the Dallas Cowboys), the Six Flags Over Texas theme park.

title: The Day the Well Went Dry
description: OF all the world's munificent resources, none are as essential as water, nor perhaps as fragile.

title: In 'Fool Me Once' Show, Items Aren't What They Seem to Be
description: LEAD: MUSEUMS don't often boast about their fakes, but the current exhibit at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford turns the spotlight exclusively on objects that are not what they seem.

title: 1945: THE FIRST 'INSTANT' PAPERBACK
description: Only nine days after the sudden death of President Franklin D. Roosevelt from a cerebral hemorrhage, a new book about the man and his accomplishments went on sale. ''Franklin Delano Roosevelt: A Memorial,'' a 249-page paperback, sold for 25 cents and was published by Pocket Books. Pocket's editor in chief, Donald Porter Geddes, spent a long weekend gathering and editing the text - biography, tributes, poetry, photographs - with the cooperation of scholars and news organizations. By Monday morning, copy was sent to a printing plant in Massachusetts, which rearranged its production schedule for the occasion. Within hours of reaching stores and newsstands, the 340,000-copy printing was completely sold out; millions of copies could have been sold if the paper supply hadn't been limited by wartime restrictions. In ensuing years, scores of similar ''instant books'' were issued by paperback houses to mark significant events, including ''Report of the Warren Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy'' (1964), ''Ninety Minutes to Entebbe'' (1976), ''Sayings of Ayatollah Khomeini'' (1980) and ''The Pursuit of the Presidency'' (1980).

title: French Jews in an Uproar Over Arafat Visit
description: France's invitation to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, to come here for talks has unleashed a passionate reaction among the 600,000 to 700,000 French Jews.

title: Katherine Mason Weds
description: Katherine Kendall Mason, a daughter of Antony Mason of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Frederica Bishop of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married yesterday to William Terrell Webster 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Webster Jr. of Southern Pines, N.C. The Rev. Fred Thompson officiated at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Southern Pines. The bride is a marketing representative at Tropical Marketing of Dallas. Her husband is the president and a co-owner of the company.

title: CARRYING A TORCH FOR KURT
description: LENYA A Life. By Donald Spoto. Illustrated. 371 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: RECONSTRUCTING A BROTHER
description: FORGOTTEN LIFE By Brian Aldiss. 284 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: Jamaica Wins 3 Boys' Relays
description: For the second year in succession, the high schools from the Caribbean island of Jamaica swept all three boys relay championship events plus the triple jump today at the Penn Relays.

title:
STYLEMAKERS;
Timothy Greenfield-Sanders: Portrait Photographer
description: LEAD: Timothy Greenfield-Sanders takes portraits the old-fashioned way, with a huge 80-year-old Fulmer and Schwing view camera. Under soft lighting in his East Village studio, subjects sit several feet away from the long lens that peers down at them.

title: Proposed School Budgets Reflect Efforts to Restrain Spending
description: LEAD: VOTERS in the county will begin going to the polls this week to determine the fate of 34 non-city school district budgets and of school-board candidacies in all communities but Yonkers.

title: Lucio Fontana: Slashing His Way Toward Infinity
description: Precisely four decades have passed since Lucio Fontana decided that a canvas was not simply something to be painted on but also something to be punctured, slashed and appended with stones. By the mid 1940's Fontana had established a name for himself in his native Argentina and had become known in his adopted homeland of Italy as a sculptor of wildly diverse inclinations, having produced staid academic statues, polychromed figurines, geometric arrangements and what looked most of all like amorphous lumps of mud. But it was his decision to violate the canvas that elevated him to a stature of particular importance throughout Europe.

title: Savoring its Serenity, Village Awaits Newcomers
description: LEAD: THE 16 people who live year round in Dering Harbor, the state's smallest village, may have some company soon.

title: Jeffrey Perry Wed To Ms. Bingham
description: At the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Elizabeth A. Bingham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Bingham of New York and Argyle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey R. Perry, the son of Beverly Perry of New York and the late Jay H. Perry. The ceremony was performed by Acting New York Supreme Court Justice Anne G. Feldman.

title: Teamster Chief Names Twice-Convicted Official to Top Post
description: The teamsters' president, William J. McCarthy, who assured Congress this month that he was committed to improving the union's image, has named to its governing body a leader twice convicted of union-related offenses.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: As long ago as the 1978 Olympiad in Buenos Aires, a lesser player came up to the late Tigran Petrosian and inquired how the Russian team had done that day. To which the former world champion from the Soviet Armenian Republic replied, ''Which Russian team?''

title: 'The Figure Revisited,' Figural Energy Is Explored
description: THE last time art's magnetic field reversed itself was at the start of the 1980's, when figuration, in the form of Neo-Expressionism, officially replaced abstraction. Presaged by Pop, the shift reflected its influence and there are signs of this in ''The Figure Revisited'' at the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: After Jalalabad's Defense, Kabul Grows Confident
description: After nearly two months of fighting at the eastern city of Jalalabad, the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul is showing increasing confidence that it can hold the city against a siege by Muslim guerrillas and ultimately force the guerrillas and their backers to negotiate peace.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The M.V.P. In the N.B.A?
description: The m.v.p. is Larry Bird.

title:
PAPERBACKS: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION

I am afraid of forgetting. That is why I appeal to you: . . . 'Help me not to forget,' '' writes Elie Wiesel. In six brief meditations upon the six days of creation according to Genesis, written by Mr.

title: Esposito Unprofessional
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Acoustics Are The Treasure In Bank's Hall
description: Craig Dory and Brian Levine have opened a joint account, so to speak, at the Troy Savings Bank in upstate New York, but not at a teller's window. They are doing business as Dorian Recordings, in the acoustically celebrated concert hall atop the bank.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: It used to be true, in both North America and the rest of the world, that experts and administrators were in separate groups: The experts did not administer, and the administrators were not experts. But that trend has dwindled, with improved results in a variety of ways. It seems to be true that smart players make smart organizers when they are willing to find the time and make the effort.

title: WHERE TERROR IS A GIVEN
description: ASAD OF SYRIA The Struggle for the Middle East. By Patrick Seale with Maureen McConville. Illustrated. 552 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: George Weiler 3d And Miss Legler Exchange Vows
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Mary Ann Legler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy Legler Jr. of Longboat Key, Fla., and Crystal Lake, Mich., was married yesterday to George H. Weiler 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Weiler Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J.; Brodheadsville, Pa., and Orleans, Mass.

title:
MUSIC;
Hollybush Festival Adds Diversity
description: LEAD: NOW well established as a major festival in South Jersey, the Hollybush Festival has come up with a season of exciting and innovative works. The festival, under the supervision of its executive director, Veda Zuponcic, is now in its seventh season at Glassboro State College and will offer a more diverse and extensive program than it has in the past.

title: Self-Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Shanley on Amore and Puccini in Fairfield
description: IT is not every theater that has the grace and the nerve to perform a play as sublimely unconventional as ''Italian American Reconciliation'' by John Patrick Shanley. Give the Boston Post Road Stage Company credit for that.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Leisurely Dining in the Suburbs
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - poor, satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. C'est Si Bon

description: LEAD: THE commercial real estate market that has been pushing south from the Route 1 corridor in Princeton and the one that has been moving north from Philadelphia are converging in the rural countryside of Mansfield Township.

title: This Time, the Army Isn't Even in the Wings
description: AT first glance, the economic chaos and political uncertainty that have taken hold in Argentina might seem to make the country vulnerable to a military coup. But even though Argentines can only wonder what will happen on or after May 14, when presidential elections are scheduled, or by inauguration day at the end of the year, the risk of a coup does not appear to be on people's minds.

title: HOMOSEXUALITY: WHO AND WHY?
description: Melvin Konner writes that his friend ''changed his sexual orientation.'' However, it is far from clear that anyone can change so essential a part of his personality. Some sex therapists have advised their lesbian and gay patients to use homosexual fantasies during heterosexual behavior, which is hardly a change in sexual orientation. MARK A. KOPPEL New York, N.Y.

title: FLYERS ELIMINATE THE PENGUINS
description: The game that began with perhaps the most inauspicious news the Philadelphia Flyers could have imagined ended with the most delicious development the playoffs can provide save the Stanley Cup itself.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of events marking the bicentennial of the Washington inaugural, vehicles are banned in much of Manhattan below Chambers Street until 6 P.M. today. The parade for the bicentennial begins at 1 P.M. at Water and Wall Streets, proceeds to Broadway, up Broadway to Waverly Place and around Washington Square.

title: Test Vote on Taxes
description: IN an atmosphere of rising antagonism toward higher property taxes, residents in more than 36 Long Island school districts will vote this week on school budgets.

title: Suffolk District Attorney Race Heating Up After Rebuke
description: LEAD: ANGUISHED by a State Commission of Investigation report, which called him derelict in the performance of his duties as Suffolk County District Attorney, Patrick Henry says he is reconsidering his decision of last month not to run for a fourth term.

title: New Rose Report
description: One of the closest friends of Pete Rose said that someone in the comissioner's office had suggested that Rose ''step aside'' as the Cincinnati Reds' manager until the investigation of Rose's affairs was completed and that Rose had refused.

title: Setting Up the Reverse Trojan Horse
description: WHEN the Greeks left a wooden horse at the gates of Troy, the idea was to make a structure filled with people appear to be empty and lifeless. The suburban homeowner about to leave on vacation has quite the opposite task. He must make an empty and lifeless structure appear to be filled with people during his absence. Having recently gone through the process, I can tell you it takes a lot of doing.

title: Fresh Shipments From the Knitting Factory
description: The Knitting Factory is a room just about wide enough to swing a guitar overhead, with a window behind the stage overlooking a blank stretch of East Houston Street in lower Manhattan. The narrow, lozenge-shaped tables are comfortable unless you have knees, and the art on the walls isn't the envy of Leo Castelli or Mary Boone. But the beer list is up to date, there's a choice of herbal teas, admission prices are reasonable and usually there's a different program every night of the week - sometimes two or three different programs a night.

title: JOHN GOTTI: RUNNING THE MOB
description: If John Gotti's crime family grosses only $500 million a year, then, in this era of the $25 billion leveraged buyout, the Mafia has become small potatoes (''John Gotti: Running the Mob,'' by Selwyn Raab, April 2). Recently indicted junk-bond king, Michael R. Milken, earned $550 million in one year himself. It would probably take the whole Gotti organization a couple of weeks of loan sharking, gambling and prostituion to make as much money as Ivan F. Boesky, in his heyday, could make in a good afternoon of insider trading. If Mr. Gotti wants to make some real money, he should try his hand at white-collar crime. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D. Lexington, Conn.

title: Q and A
description: Piggyback M.C.I.

title: Comedies With a Dash of Menace
description: A self-deprecator by nature - ''I'm a tall, thin, funny-looking lady, a ridiculous person'' - Tina Howe is trying hard not to tempt the fates by getting overexcited. Her new play, ''Approaching Zanzibar,'' opens Thursday at the Second Stage Theater on Manhattan's Upper West Side, while an earlier one, ''Painting Churches,'' is scheduled to debut on London's West End this fall.

title: Young Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME
description: A fresh, crisply accented voice comes blowing out of Kansas City in HOT WIRE (Bantam, Paper, $3.50). In this breezy debut by Randy Russell, a petty car thief with the wonderful moniker of Alton Benjamin (Rooster) Franklin graduates to the big time by knocking off a bank. The heist is nice; but things go haywire when the loot is lost and Rooster's accomplice gets killed. Seeking both revenge and redemption after doing time, Rooster determines to take on the Kansas City mob with the help of the local godfather's own granddaughter.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Computerized Drafting; Architects Create 3-Dimensional Graphic Models
description: AS architects replace drafting boards with computer work stations, not only are they generating blueprints with greater speed and accuracy, but they also are creating new visual aids such as three-dimensional models that create the illusion of walking through buildings yet unbuilt.

title: School Votes Test Tax Sentiment
description: LEAD: IN an atmosphere of rising antagonism toward higher property taxes, residents of more than three dozen Long Island school districts will vote this week on school budgets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Hockey Soviet Union Clinches Title: The Soviet Union, with the high-scoring ''KLM'' line leading the way for the first time in the tournament, clinched the world championship by edging Canada, 5-3, last night in Stockholm. It was the 21st world championship for the Soviet Union since 1954. The Soviet team, winning its ninth consecutive game in the championships, has 4 points in the four-team medal round. Czechoslovakia, which earlier yesterday edged Sweden, 2-1, can also reach 4 points by beating Canada in the finale tomorrow. But the Soviets, who will play Sweden in their last game, will still win the world title because they defeated the Czechoslovaks, 1-0, in Friday's medal-round opener. The KLM line - the center Igor Larionov and the wings Vladimir Krutov and Sergei Makarov - failed to live up to its reputation in the previous games. But Larionov scored two goals in the opening period, and Krutov added another one as the Soviets took a 3-1 first-period lead. Last night, the Soviet coach, Viktor Tikhonov, said his players - including the stars on the KLM line - would be allowed to compete in the National Hockey League. Soviet authorities ''will make no problems'' for them, Tikhonov said.(AP) Tennis Mancini and Becker in Final: Alberto Mancini of Argentina and Boris Becker of West Germany gained the final of the $607,500 Monte Carlo Open tournament in Monaco yesterday by taking straight-set semifinal victories. Mancini routed top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-0, 6-3, before Becker eliminated Hans Skoff of Austria, 6-3, 6-3. It will be the first final on clay for Becker in a pro tournament, although he won a junior event at the Monte Carlo County Club in 1984. (AP) Evert Faces Teen-Ager: Top-seeded Chris Evert remained on track to win her fourth consecutive Virginia Slims of Houston tournament, defeating Susan Sloane, 7-6, 6-2, yesterday in a semifinal match. Evert will play 15-year-old Monica Seles of Bradenton, Fla., who beat Carrie Cunningham, 6-0, 6-1.(AP) Agassi Defeats Noah: Andre Agassi beat Yannick Noah, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday in a semifinal match of the A.T.&T. Challenge exhibition tournament in Atlanta. The match at the Horseshoe Bend Country Club lasted 54 minutes as Agassi took advantage of Noah's injured right Achilles' tendon. Ivan Lendl was to play Michael Chang last night in the other semifinal.(AP) Soccer Tottenham Wins, 5-0: Paul Stewart scored three goals to lead Tottenham to a 5-0 English First Division victory yesterday at Millwall on a day marked by a memorial service in Liverpool for the 95 fans killed in the Sheffield Stadium tragedy. The top two teams in the First Division, Arsenal and Liverpool, did not play. Arsenal will face third-place Norwich tomorrow, and Liverpool will play at Everton Wednesday in its first league game since the tragedy two weeks ago. (AP) Golf Langer Takes Lead: Bernhard Langer of West Germany made a 45-foot chip shot for a birdie 3 on the 18th yesterday to close with a 67 and a two-shot lead after three rounds of the Spanish Open in Valencia. Langer needed only 27 putts in recording the lowest round of the tournament and a three-round total of seven-under-par 209. Paul Carrigill of England, who had been the leader, made a 12-foot birdie putt on the 18th for a 72 and a 211 total to hold second place. (AP) Geiberger and Henning Maintain Lead: Al Geiberger and Harold Henning held onto their lead in the Legends of Golf tournament by shooting an eight-under-par 62 in the third round yesterday. The pair opened the tournament with consecutive 61's and have been on top since the first round. They posted a 54-hole total of 184, giving them a 2-shot lead over their first-round co-leaders, Bob Charles and Bruce Devlin. (AP) Postlewait a Stroke Ahead of King: Kathy Postlewait, boosted by a 40-foot birdie putt early in her round, shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Betsy King and Val Skinner after the second round of the $425,000 Sara Lee Classic in Nashville. Postlewait had a 36-hole total of 10-under-par 134 on the par-72, 6,242-yard Hermitage course. The 15-year tour veteran had four birdies on the front nine, including a snaking 40-foot putt on the seventh hole.(AP) Gymnastics Team Title for Soviet Women: The Soviet Union yesterday won the team championship in a dual women's gymnastics meet in Columbus, Ohio, with the United States, even though Brandy Johnson took all-around honors. The United States and Soviet men's teams will compete today in a similar meet at Ohio State. Johnson, whose 16th birthday is today, won the vault, the uneven bars and the floor exercise to total 39.575 points. The next two finishers in the all-around were the Soviets Elena Sazonenkova with 39.375 points and Svetlana Baitova with 39.325. The Soviet Union had 195.875 team points and the United States totaled 194.725.(AP)

title: Deborah Shapiro, A Student, Weds
description: At the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y., Deborah Ann Shapiro, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. Shapiro of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Alan Richard Plumer, the son of Robert Plumer of North Massapequa, L.I., and the late Thelma Blau Plumer. Rabbi Nathan Kapner and Cantor Bernard Dienstag officiated.

title: A LIFE IN LIMBO
description: I was moved by Peter Brandon Bayer's article ''A Life in Limbo'' (April 2). His writing is informed throughout by sensitivity, candor and a striking lack of self-pity. Although I have a passing knowledge of hemophilia, I had never really grasped the implications of the incredible toll - physically, socially and emotionally - that this disease exacts. As the mother of four children, two of whom are young boys, I wonder if I could muster the courage to allow my son the freedom to lead an active life if he were a hemophiliac. Mr. Bayer's parents are to be commended; they instilled in him early on an attitude of hope - a philosophy which clearly served him well over the years. SUSAN KERTMAN AARON Wayside, N.J.

description: AFTER THE MIRACLE The 1969 Mets Twenty Years Later. By Maury Allen. Illustrated. 260 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $17.95.

description: ABOUT FACE By David H. Hackworth and Julie Sherman. Illustrated. 875 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

description: The marriage of Cynthia Armstrong Grant, the daughter of Prof. William C. Grant Jr. of Williamstown, Mass., and the late Joan Armstrong Grant, to Robert Howard Tykot, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard B. Tykot of Westfield, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. Bryant Whitman Dennison performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown, assisted by the Rev. Peter Elvin.

title: THUS SPAKE SUPERMAN
description: THE IMPORTANCE OF NIETZSCHE Ten Essays. By Erich Heller. 199 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. Paper, $11.95. Cloth, $29.95.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: This month construction is to begin on the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, which will occupy a 1.7-acre site adjacent to the Mall, within view of the Washington Monument and looking across the Tidal Basin to the Jefferson Memorial. It is a prominent site for a museum that will mark an event that is remembered not for its glory, like most other things commemorated on the Mall, but for its horror. In this sense this museum, which was authorized by an act of Congress in 1980, bears a certain similarity to the memorial across the Mallto soldiers killed in Vietnam. For Maya Yang Lin's moving, abstract wall cut into the earth also recalls a painful moment of history, and stands as a powerful reminder that architecture has not lost all ability to evoke deep emotion.

title: Trial at Churchill Downs Captured by Houston
description: Houston, who looked so brilliant two starts back and so dismal last time out, seemed somewhere in between today when he scored a five-length victory in the $84,150 Derby Trial Stakes on opening day at Churchill Downs.

title: Q and A
description: John Muir Trail

title: Anglican Heads Try to Defuse Women's Issue
description: The heads of the world's Anglican churches, meeting last week in Cyprus, have endorsed a report aimed at preventing the question of consecrating women as bishops from creating new divisions among the 70 million Anglicans.

title: On a Treadmill Coining Anagrams
description: THE treadmill may not be the modern equivalent of the medieval rack, but it comes close. Those of us condemned to its inexorable belt suffer doubly. Not only do we have to push our fading muscles to their limit, but we're bored out of our wits doing it. Of the two, I found the boredom more difficult to bear.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about an exhibition at the Pelham Art Center misstated the closing date. The show, ''Selected Images: 150 Years of American History by American Photographers,'' continues through May 27, not May 1.

title: Dr. Burton Dickey Marries Yean Sun
description: Yean Sun, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Tsieh Sun of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Burton Fuller Dickey, a son of Gloria Dickey of Riverside, Conn., and the late William Burton Dickey. The Rev. David Shek, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Rosecliff historical mansion in Newport, R.I.
