How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 4 4 12 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 5 3 7 ONE UP ON WALL STREET, by Peter Lynch with John Rothchild. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Advice on investing in stocks from a veteran fund manager. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) ACCIDENT/A DAY'S NEWS, by Christa Wolf. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15.95.) This urgent, serious novel by an East German takes one day to happen: the narrator lives through the news of the Chernobyl disaster and her brother's brain operation, two faces of modern technology that can kill or save. METAPHOR & MEMORY: Essays, by Cynthia Ozick. (Knopf, $19.95.) Reviews and commentaries on books and writers, filled with questions and speculations that seem to arise from a lifetime's passionate meditation on language. THE PROGRESS OF THE SEASONS: Forty Years of Baseball in Our Town, by George V. Higgins. (Holt, $18.95.) Personal memories and public events blend handsomely in this memoir embracing four generations of a family's affair with the Red Sox. TIME'S WITNESS, by Michael Malone. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A generous, good-humored crime novel in which an appealing young white police chief in North Carolina investigates the case of a black man whose murder conviction seems to have holes in it. PLAYMATES, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $17.95.) Mr. Parker's very tough, very intelligent private eye, Spenser, appears in his 17th novel, which concerns a college basketball point-shaving scandal and presents a racial drama that rings true to our time. GLENN GOULD: A Life and Variations, by Otto Friedrich. (Random House, $24.95.) A seamless and plausible reading of the life of one of the odder people of our time, the reclusive and visionary pianist who retired from the stage at 31 and died at 50. SEE UNDER: LOVE, by David Grossman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) A thoroughly disturbing novel, an investigation of both the horrors of the Holocaust and the art of storytelling.

title: New Template for the Hundred Days
description: JOHN H. SUNUNU, White House chief of staff, objected a few weeks ago to the way some pundits were judging the Bush Administration. Too many of us, he felt, are accustomed to a frenetic first >hundred days.

title:
ART;
Photographs With Surprises
description: LEAD: THE Zimmerli Museum exhibition's title, ''Reflections: Woman's Self-Image in Contemporary Photography,'' is confusing. One might expect a slew of images of women in diverse roles, but instead, in the show at Rutgers University here, six female photographers examine themselves most of the time but others also.

title: Jack Cummings, 84, a Producer at M-G-M
description: Jack Cummings, who as a veteran staff producer for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer was responsible for the motion-picture musicals ''Kiss Me Kate'' and ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,'' died of a heart attack Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 84 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: THE GUIDE
description: ESTRIN ANNIVERSARY Morton Estrin, the noted concert pianist, has been teaching at Hofstra University for 30 years. But instead of letting other musicians fete him on his anniversary, he's doing the honors himself: at 3 P.M. today with a concert at Hofstra's John Cranford Adams Playhouse in Hempstead.

title: Restored Budget Aid Praised
description: THE managers of social services programs in the county praised the new state budget last week, pleased that devastating cuts had been averted for at least a year. The $47 billion plan, on which legislators reached agreement earlier this month, restores many of the social programs Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had sought to eliminate and raises state taxes and fees.

title: Arthur Kennedy: Comeback for a Curmudgeon
description: At 75, Arthur Kennedy's throaty cackle seems more orchestral, and surely more wicked, than it did when he ventured it professionally in ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' ''Elmer Gantry,'' ''Peyton Place'' and many of his 70-odd other films. There he was, at lunch in the city he now calls home, cackling his way through Laurence Olivier stories and Marlene Dietrich stories on a recent afternoon, when Pat Hogan - his favorite waitress in the Pavilion Restaurant on Liberty Street - stopped by to tease him a bit.

title: Sentences Differ
description: When a Federal grand jury in Chicago began looking into payments by sports agents to college athletes, Cris Carter and David Lueddeke both lied about a $5,000 payment Lueddeke had made to Carter when Carter, now a wide receiver with the Philadelphia Eagles, was a student at Ohio State.

title: County List of Historic Sites Grows
description: LEAD: A CHURCH with the first figured stained-glass windows in the United States, a 19th-century tavern, a stately red brick house built in 1907, a Spanish-American War monument and a Colonial home dating from 1750 are the newest additions to the Westchester County Inventory of Historic Places.

title: DATA UPDATE: April 30, 1989
'Picking Up Sand'
description: In Arcadia, Fla., in 1967, the seven children of James Richardson died after eating lunch tainted with insecticide. Although Mr. Richardson was working in a citrus grove eight miles away when a baby sitter served lunch, he was convicted and originally sentenced to death. Last week, a judge assigned to review the case ordered his release, ruling that the 1968 trial was marred by prosecutors' misconduct and perjured testimony. A special prosecutor and lawyers for Mr. Richardson presented testimony pointing to the baby sitter, Betsy Reese, as a suspect. She is in a nursing home suffering from Alzheimer's disease. Said Mr. Richardson after his release, ''It's a pleasure to walk on the beach, see the sunlight, picking up sand and dirt, kicking my feet in the water.''

title: Thomas H. Stires And Susan Craig Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Eugene Craig of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Joy Craig to Thomas Homer Stires, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer Stires of New York and Bay Head, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE HORSE BUSINESS;
HITCHING HOPES TO AMERICAN BREEDS - AT HOME AND ABROAD
description: LEAD: Riders in this year's Volvo World Cup Finals enjoyed a level of hospitality rarely shown to the horse set in the United States. Not counting Volvo, 33 companies, spent more than $1 million to sponsor activities surrounding the six-day event in Tampa, Fla., this month. In 1981, when the event was last held in this country,

title: A Ceremony for Shereskys
description: The Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York was the setting yesterday for a wedding ceremony conducted by the Rev. Orlando Fuller for Kimberly and Jeffrey Sheresky.

title: RUSSIA WITHOUT TEARS
description: OURS A Russian Family Album. By Sergei Dovlatov. Translated by Anne Frydman. 135 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title: Reviews/Music; Drawing Out Young Talent With Less Difficult Works
description: Hale Smith, a composer himself, reminded us before Wednesday evening's New Music for Young Ensembles concert at Weill Recital Hall that ''writing easy music is not easy.'' This, however, is the obstacle that the 14-year old series tries to overcome in its attempts to promote contemporary composition suitable to developing young talent.

title:
GARDENING;
A Few Tips for Successful Spring Planting
description: LEAD: OF all the facets of plant care, soil preparation and planting in a timely manner are the most important.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE DREAM LONG DEFERRED. By Frye Gaillard. (University of North Carolina, Paper $9.95; Cloth, $19.95.) In 1971, the United States Supreme Court upheld a Federal District Court decision that transformed American education. No one felt the effects sooner than the people of Charlotte, N.C., whose school board had been ordered to employ all known methods, including busing, to extinguish segregation in its schools. Frye Gaillard, who covered the crisis for The Charlotte Observer and is currently that newspaper's southern editor, has written in ''The Dream Long Deferred'' a compelling account of how the first city to use busing for school desegregation made it work. Mr. Gaillard probes the public drama of bombs, death threats and spitting mobs alongside the private agony of those who determined the city's fate. We see the attorney Julius Chambers stuttering as he rehearses his Supreme Court presentation; the school board chairman William Poe stubbornly resubmitting his limited busing plan, his attempt to prevent not just white flight but anarchy; and genteel Federal District Court Judge James McMillan enforcing his interpretation of the law with insistent authority. Charlotte's eventual success with busing, Mr. Gaillard suggests, led to higher test scores for all students, newly integrated neighborhoods and democracy in local government. Though occasionally too polite and cautious in his assessments, Mr. Gaillard offers thorough research, perceptiveness, balance and an engaging style that leaves room for one's own conclusions.

title: Jackson Says the Crowd Helped, Too
description: For a first-round game, it was the equivalent of Havlicek-steals-the-ball, or Magic-plays-center, or Willis-limps-on-the-court, those legends of the final round.

title: Jurors in North Trial Recess for Weekend Without a Verdict
description: After a half-day of deliberations today, the jurors in the Oliver L. North trial recessed for the weekend.

title: Ms. Hearst, Antiques Dealer, Is the Bride of John Gay Jr.
description: Deborah Hearst, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Randolph Hearst of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to John Gay Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gay of Southampton. The ceremony was performed by Capt. William Brantmeyer aboard the motor yacht Lady Mary off Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Wiretap Evidence in Gambino Case Links Garment Group to Mob
description: On a May evening six years ago, two men met in the dining room of a Staten Island home discussing business deals in New York City's garment industry.

title: New York Nights: Venice and Its Glass, France and Its Song
description: It was dinner at Tiffany's on Tuesday, a benefit for Save Venice Inc. About 120 people dined by candlelight at tables tucked in among counters filled with glittering treasures. All this after a cocktail reception honoring an 80-year-old Venetian glass blower, Archimede Seguso. Fifty of his most-admired works were on display, but as Mr. Seguso pointed out, ''This is only a little, as my family has been blowing glass for the past 700 years.''

title: 1966: ''THE LORD OF THE RINGS''
description: J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Lord of the Rings,'' a 1,200-page trilogy about a fantasy world in which Good is at war with Evil, made the No. 1 spot on the paperback best-seller list - a remarkable event, because the highly praised saga had originally been published in hard covers a dozen years before, but had not sold notably well. The series' second life began in 1965, when two science fiction/ fantasy fans, editors at Ballantine Books, decided to package the three volumes as a $2.85 boxed set for Christmas giving. The 50,000 copies of the set promptly sold out, but it was the word-of-mouth enthusiasm of college students across the country that turned it into one of 1966's biggest best sellers. Until this time, science fiction and fantasy books enjoyed a cult following, but the republication of Tolkien's work in paperback created a new audience for the genre.

title: Darien Student Honored For Helping Others
description: LEAD: JENNIFER BISHKO's volunteering efforts would make a formidable list for someone twice her age. Her only regret is that she is unable to work for more social causes than she does.

title: Correction
description: The Executive Computer column last week misstated the telephone number of Traveling Software Inc. It is 206 483-8088.

title: Vexing Problems Delay Shuttle Liftoff Indefinitely
description: The launching of the space shuttle Atlantis was postponed indefinitely today as engineers investigated the mystifying malfunction that prevented the liftoff Friday.

title: Diplomatic 'Walk in Woods'
description: IN its most cosmically conscious season yet, how fitting for the Whole Theater to choose ''A Walk in the Woods'' by Lee Blessing. This is the play about a Russian (who says he's a diplomat) and an American (who calls himself a negotiator), sitting around and talking about saving the world - or at least forging ''a path to sanity.''

title: Singing, From Arias to Cabaret
description: FROM a German requiem to an American cabaret, from Italian opera to French operetta, this week appears to be a grand one for singing in the county. Up first is operetta, with a production of ''La Fille de Madame Angot'' at the State University of New York at Purchase and a concert edition of ''Die Fledermaus'' by the New Rochelle Opera.

title: Patricia Gentile Weds Paul Dong
description: SS. John and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Patricia Eileen Gentile, the daughter of Dr. Ralph L. Gentile of Larchmont and the late Teresa McDonough Gentile, to Paul Dong, a son of Gin Dong and Alice Joy, both of Seattle. Msgr. Joseph J. Boyd officiated.

title: Reviews/Music; Ashkenazy in Two Roles With Cleveland Orchestra
description: In January, the Cleveland Orchestra came to New York for a series of concerts led by its music director, Christoph von Dohnanyi. Now the orchestra is back for two programs with its principal guest conductor, Vladimir Ashkenazy.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday about booming Southern cities misstated the populations and recent growth rates of several. The 1987 populations of the metropolitan areas, with the increase since 1980 in parentheses, are: Charlotte, 1,091,000 (12.3 percent); Nashville, 956,000 (12.4 percent); New Orleans, 1,321,000 (5.1 percent); Orlando, 935,000 (33.5 percent), and Tampa, 1,965,000 (21.7 percent). The figures for the United States are 243,419,000 (7.4 percent).

title: Soft-Shell Crabs, Quick and Intriguing, Are Back
description: SPRING has arrived when soft-shell crabs appear in the fish market. The traditional way to cook them is very simple - a la meuniere - lightly dusted with flour and sauteed in butter. But there are other intriguing and unusual recipes for this popular speciality.

title: Evelyn F. Restivo Is a Bride
description: Evelyn Frances Restivo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Restivo of Irving, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Elmslie Moore Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel E. Budd officiated at the Unitarian Universalist Church in Buffalo.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 30, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) The changing fortunes of a New York banking family. 2 3 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $12.95.) Continuing the horror story begun in ''The Gunslinger.'' 3 13 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 4 8 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $5.95.) A Congressman's secret dealings with terrorists. 5 3 PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Bantam, $4.95.) The rivalry of two clans in New York society and one man's role in it. 6 4 TEXAS FURY, by Fern Michaels. (Ballantine, $4.95.) From the oil fields of the Lone Star State to Tokyo and Switzerland; a family saga. 7 1 LIGHTNING, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters. 8 3 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Penguin, $8.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested. 9 4 PRELUDE TO FOUNDATION, by Isaac Asimov. (Bantam, $4.95.) An overture to the science fiction saga about the Foundation empire. 10 1 OKLAHOMA! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $4.50.) Gunplay and treachery among the territory's pioneering settlers. 11 5 SILVER TOWER, by Dale Brown. (Berkley, $4.95.) The superpowers edge toward high-tech war in the Middle East in 1992. 12 22 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 13 * 2 A GLIMPSE OF STOCKING, by Elizabeth Gage. (Pocket, $4.95.) The pleasures and ordeals of a starlet on her way to an Oscar. 14 3 DOUBLE, DOUBLE, by Michael Jan Friedman. (Pocket, $3.95.) A new ''Star Trek'' novel. 15 3 FREAKY DEAKY, by Elmore Leonard. (Warner, $5.95.) Survivors of the tumultuous 1960's embark on a crime spree. 16 * 27 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 4 BITTER BLOOD, by Jerry Bledsoe. (Onyx, $4.95.) Nine murders in three wealthy families connected by obsessive love and custodial conflicts. 2 288 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 49 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 4 8 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society. 5 46 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The ways in which mythology illuminates the stages of life. 6 19 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $8.95.) A ''new science'' that makes it possible to see order and patterns in what appears to be erratic. 7 9 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Ballantine, $14.95.) A history of the American Civil War era. 8 3 CONTRACT ON AMERICA, by David E. Scheim. (Zebra, $4.95.) Evidence suggesting that the Mafia was responsible for President John F. Kennedy's assassination. 9 * 19 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Warner, $5.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 10 11 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) Ways in which companies can survive. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 6 YUKON HO! by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) More ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 1 WILDLIFE PRESERVES, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) The 10th collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. 3 40 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 10 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Ivy, $4.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 5 16 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1989 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Crimson Top Penn To Stay Unbeaten
description: At the end no one knew which crew had won, Harvard or Penn. The oarsmen did not know, nor did their coaches in the trailing launches, and the spectators on shore were unsure.

title: 1980: ''THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED.''
description: ''The Road Less Traveled,'' by M. Scott Peck, a Connecticut psychiatrist, was published by Touchstone, the trade paperback imprint of Simon & Schuster. An inspirational work with a strong nondenominational Christian tone, it presented teachings on discipline, love, grace and growth, supported by examples drawn from the author's psychiatric practice. Its sales in hardback were a modest 18,000 copies. But its record in the nine years since shows what an author's faith and word-of-mouth recommendations can do for a book. Dr. Peck toured the South and Midwest, speaking to many church-related groups. In its first year, the paperback sold 30,000 copies; in the second, 60,000; in the third, 120,000; in the fourth, 240,000. To date, it has sold 3.2 million copies. First appearing on the New York Times paperback nonfiction best-seller list on Oct. 13, 1983, it has remained there for a total of 288 weeks, a run exceeded only by ''The Joy of Sex.''

title: Towns Shift Zoning Rules to Protect Historic Paths
description: LEAD: ON the earliest colonial map, Indian trails are called ''ancient highways,'' and before the days of Interstate highways - or even the Boston Post Road - they were the way to get around.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Salzburg
description: One of Europe's loveliest cities will also be among its most crowded during the summer festival, July 27 to Aug. 31. For each visitor who has been foresighted or fortunate enough to secure tickets for some opera performance, play, concert or recital there may be 50 others who come just to glimpse the celebrities. Quite a few people appear to enjoy the mob scenes when the city of 135,000, so staid in winter, seems to be bursting at its dirndl seams.

title: County Plans New Plant as Next Step in Recycling Effort
description: COUNTY officials are planning to build a technologically sophisticated plant that would convert solid wastes to reusable products. The plant could make recycling easier for Westchester residents and profitable for municipalities.

title: G.O.P. CHAIRMAN LEE ATWATER: PLAYING HARDBALL
description: IT'S 2 A.M. ON A SULTRY SATURDAY IN COLUMBIA, S. C. Does the Republican Party know where its chairman is? Harvey Lee Atwater, hometown boy, is on stage at Bullwinkle's, a smoky dive with two pool tables, dollar beers and the raunchy, long-haired Mojo Blues band shaking the rafters.

title: Transfer Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: AN UNPRETTY PORTRAIT
description: CARY GRANT The Lonely Heart. By Charles Higham And Roy Moseley. Illustrated. 358 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: Study Finds a Surge of Enthusiasm For the Arts
description: From modern jazz to Mozart and Macbeth, Connecticut residents are venturing out into the world of art and culture in higher numbers than ever before, fostering new growth and confidence in the state's home-grown arts community, according to a state study.

title: Samaranch Ailing
description: Running the International Olympic Committee can be a headache, which may explain why Juan Antonio Samaranch, the 68-year-old I.O.C. president, wound up in a hospital in Barcelona, Spain, last week after conducting four days of meetings preparing for the 1992 Summer Games.

title:
PAPERBACKS: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SHIFTS. By Christopher Meredith. (Seren/Dufour Editions, Paper, $12.95; Cloth, $28.) Christopher Meredith, a Welsh poet, has written a beautiful, understated first novel about the lives of a group of young steelworkers in a mill that is about to close. The time is 1977, the setting industrial south Wales, the milieu that of contemporary working-class men who have lost any expectation of inheriting their fathers' lives.

title: Baseball; Darling Gets First Victory of '89
description: Ron Darling's April of inconsistency, which had produced little more than three defeats and some hope for better things, finally turned tonight. The Mets pitcher won for the first time this season, and his victory in the Astrodome extended the team's winning streak to six games.

title: Bond Issue Stints On Private Universities
description: With the recent announcement that Fairleigh Dickinson University's dental school will close, the following is extremely timely.

title: U.N.'s Finn in Namibia Finds Ties That Bind
description: When Martti Ahtisaari, the United Nations official charged with helping Namibia to independence from South Africa, arrived in Windhoek, the Namibian capital, on April 1, his local namesakes had just turned 10.

title: Back to Basics, With Meat and Potatoes
description: IT is beginning to look as though a single organization, Entertaining Moments Inc., has revitalized the downtown dining scene of New Haven. Entertaining Moments is the company that brought the trendy and delightful Bruxelles Brasserie, Scoozzi Trattoria and Wine Bar, and Gentree Ltd. to the city. Its latest restaurant is called Three Sixty Eight, on the corner of Orange and Audubon Streets.

title: Breakthrough Seen in 'Star Wars' Weapon
description: Scientists have conducted a 20-second flight test of a prototype weapon designed to maneuver in space to destroy enemy booster rockets early in flight, Pentagon officials say.

title: When the Setting Upstages the Sound
description: THE genuine music festival is an immovable feast where site and sound are inextricable. They go together like Yin and Yang, Laurel and Hardy, heads and tails, breathing in and out. Thinking back over decades of summertime traveling in pursuit of the festival high, I find that memory is sharpest where the music and the milieu intermingle and fuse. It becomes barely possible to conceive of the one apart from the other. That is truest in the obvious places like Bayreuth, where the Festspielhaus that Wagner built to house his works sits majestically on its green hill and where he is an almost palpable presence. Or Salzburg, where Mozart's ghost walks everywhere, probably still trying to escape from the hometown that he hated while alive. Those are festivals that define the word.

title: A Fall Wedding For Miss Urstadt And Wing Biddle
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jordan Urstadt of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Catherine Cary Urstadt, and Willing Legendre Biddle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Biddle of Princeton, N.J., and St.-Barthelemy, French West Indies.

title: DONALD DESKEY, INNOVATIVE DESIGNER, DIES A 94
description: Donald Deskey, the innovative industrial designer whose prolific career spanned more than half a century, died of pneumonia yesterday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla., where he had lived since he retired in 1975. He was 94 years old.

title: A Star Steps In, Splendidly
description: SINCE each show during a regular season's repertory runs a mere three to six weeks in the state's professional theaters, it is rare to come upon a replacement in a leading role.

title: Congress Panel Urges Establishing A Federal Office for Rare Diseases
description: A Congressional commission has recommended that a permanent Federal office be established to coordinate campaigns against relatively rare diseases.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Kansas; Teacher's Fantasy Opens to Students Via Computers
description: Students who enroll in Psychology 574 at the University of Kansas are soon hunting murderers and dancing at a supernatural disco as part of their homework.

title: Education Is the Best Way to Fight Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING: Keeping Cool; Regulations Governing Equipment
description: ANY New Yorker who suffered through the prolonged heat wave of 1988 will be concerned about the adequacy of the air-conditioning system that will be serving his or her apartment this summer. In some instances, alterations and additions may have to be made.

title: G. D. Iverson 6th And Amy Wardell Married in Jersey
description: Amy Dickenson Wardell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Makin Wardell of Bay Head, N.J., and George Dudley Iverson 6th, a son of Mrs. Brevoort MacNeille of Chevy Chase, Md., and Mr. Iverson 5th of Washington, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Bay Head by the Rev. Edward B. Gammons Jr. Lee Parks was the maid of honor. Andrew P. Iverson was his brother's best man.

title: 5 Candidates for Mayor Clash Over Housing
description: Five New York City mayoral candidates sparred on housing issues yesterday at a forum on the Upper East Side, condemning the Koch administration's record on building affordable housing but differing widely on reforms.

title: 1990 Census Seems Not Too Far Away
description: LEAD: BECAUSE a complete and accurate census count can make a big difference to a community, some local governments are preparing now for the 1990 census. The goal is to be sure every housing unit is identified and everyone living in the community is counted.

title: Pope Urges Madagascar's Young to Fight Poverty
description: Pope John Paul II traveled along ramshackle city streets today and flew over lands stripped of their natural wealth as he pleaded for a struggle against the poverty that oppresses much of this island nation.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Annuals for Gardeners Who Dare to Be Different
description: LEAD: If Dr. Howard Irwin had his way, there would be far fewer zinnias offered at spring plant sales - or petunias or marigolds, for that matter.

title: Colorado's Sahara Sands
description: SHORTLY after dawn one day in October I arrived at Great Sand Dunes National Monument in south-central Colorado to watch the sun peel onto the sand. There was a glorious sunrise as I hiked toward the sweeping crescent-shaped ridges of sand that, on a knife edge, split the darkness from light.

title: U.S. Prelate Not Indicted in Italy Bank Scandal
description: To the dismay of the public prosecutor, an American Archbishop was not among 35 former employees and associates of an ill-fated bank who were indicted on charges of fraudulent bankruptcy here this month.

title:
GARDENING;
A Few Tips for Successful Spring Planting
description: LEAD: OF all the facets of plant care, soil preparation and planting in a timely manner are the most important.

title: Lisa S. Dettelbach And Paul Revson Exchange Vows
description: Lisa Scheer Dettelbach and Paul Revson were married yesterday at the Metropolitan Club in New York by Judge James Lawrence Edmondson of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit. Mrs. Revson is a daughter of Eugenia D. McClellan of Atlanta and the late Louis L. Dettelbach. The bridegroom is a son of Eleanor Revson and a stepson of Martin Revson of New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: Idled Two Years Ago, Nuclear Plant Restarts
description: The Peach Bottom nuclear power plant has resumed operation after a two-year shutdown ordered by Federal regulators who had found plant employees sleeping on the job.

title: Bowing Out
description: On his silver jubilee as chief conductor and artistic director of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra in 1980, Herbert von Karajan talked of his love for his players and their relationship ''as a family.'' As has happened in some families, Mr. Karajan, now 81, may have overstayed his welcome. More recently there was discord between an autocratic maestro and an orchestra trying to reassert its independence. Last week, Mr. Karajan resigned, ending a 34-year relationship between what some music lovers said was the greatest living conductor and the world's finest orchestra. He cited a back ailment and the lack of specified duties in the vague terms of his lifetime contract. Medical tests, he said, ''have proved to me that I am unable to carry on my duties as I would want.''

title: Jewelry
description: To the Editor: While Susan Heller Anderson's Hong Kong pearl piece (Travel, March 26) was a model of how to shop for jewelry, it obscured some points. It is nearly impossible to compare strands of pearls, or other pieces of jewelry, if they are not being evaluated side by side. Her comparison of Falconer's ''pink-hued pearls'' in Hong Kong and New York assumes there is only one shade of pink, and then overlooks the quality of the ''skin'' of the pearls. As she mentioned earlier, blemishes change the value of pearls immensely. There is no gainsaying the fact that shops on 47th Street in New York may charge more for a similar product than those in Hong Kong, but being certain one is comparing identical products is the question.

title: Instrument Makers Strive for Quality
description: EVEN as increasing numbers of mass-produced musical instruments tumble off assembly lines, three local craft shops are assiduously turning out small numbers of quality handcrafted musical instruments every year.

title:
PAPERBACKS: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A SHORT DANCE IN THE SUN. By George Benet. (Lapis, Paper, $9.95.) The longshoremen in this collection of related stories have one goal: to ''get out and get a drink.'' And it's not always an easy goal to meet. Delirium tremens makes it difficult for them to put on their pants. Or they're thwarted by the staffs at the detox centers where they must check in so they can retain their jobs.

title:
A WORLD OF MUSIC;
The Line for 1990 Starts Now
description: LEAD: EUROPE'S music festivals have grown so popular that some are sold out a year or more in advance. Among the most difficult to get tickets for are the Wagner Festival in Bayreuth, West Germany, the Salzburg Festival in Austria, the Lucerne International Music Festival in Switzerland, the Drottningholm Court Theater in Stockholm and the Glyndebourne Opera Festival in

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on April 2 misidentified a street in Beverly Hills. It is Hillcrest Road.

title: Fools Deserve a Whole Week
description: APRIL Fool's Day has come and gone, and once again we are left with thousands of fools who never got to do their thing because of the time factor imposed by the single day allotted. It is now clear that we must increase this allocation and set up a format under which all these fools can get their proper due.

title: Political Fallout From Smog Blurs Future for Los Angeles
description: As the choking summer air pollution season nears, the air over the Los Angeles basin, the worst in the country, is as thick with the politics of smog as with the smog itself.

title: YOUTHFUL PAIN IN NORMANDY
description: MY FATHER'S MOON By Elizabeth Jolley. 171 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: AFRICA UP CLOSE
description: AS THE PLANE ASCENDED, I STARED down at the ruggedly beautiful landscape of Africa for the last time as a correspondent. When the clouds finally obscured my view, I began to read the diaries I had kept during an assignment that spanned nearly four years and took me to about 20 countries.

title: BOHEMIA DIED, BUT LIFE WENT ON
description: IN THE NIGHT CAFE By Joyce Johnson. 231 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title:
The View From: Caramoor;
A Spring Renaissance Begins
description: LEAD: SPRING at Caramoor. The crabapple trees are abloom with lacy pink blossoms, the tan stucco walls of the Spanish Courtyard seem to glow in the sun and the light pours in through the stained-glass windows. The musicians are not here but one can imagine the first faint strains of a symphony wafting on the warm air.

title: Clyde Geronimi, 87, An Animator at Disney
description: Clyde (Gerry) Geronimi, an Academy Award-winning animator who worked on such classic Walt Disney films as ''Cinderella'' and ''Sleeping Beauty,'' died at his home Monday. He was 87 years old.

title: In Films, Heaven's No Paradise
description: Does heaven contain cornfields or poolside cabanas? Does it resemble a post-modern palazzo, where Degas ballerinas dance in a grand foyer and children play violins while strolling through wide halls? Or is heaven a more mundane idea entirely, a place where you can eat whatever you want and never get fat? Anyone looking to recent films for spiritual guidance will find instead this confusion of heavenly images, proof that the hereafter has a tenacious but slippery hold on film makers' imaginations.

title: When the Iron Horse Came to a Stop
description: For the first time in his long playing life with the New York Yankees - through Prohibition, the Flapper Age, the Roaring Twenties, the Great Depression and the New Deal - Lou Gehrig, baseball's Iron Horse, accepted a salary cut in the winter of 1939.

title: Hoch Edges Into the Lead
description: Just three weeks after he could have and should have won the Masters, Scott Hoch moved into position to achieve his first PGA Tour victory in five years.

title: Tucker's 3-Pointer Gives Knicks 2-0 Lead
description: Rick Pitino had two dreams Friday night, both dealing with the outcome of yesterday afternoon's playoff game against the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: No Toast For Davis
description: Baseball and beer have been strange but fairly constant bedfellows for as long as anyone can remember, but Glenn Davis, the Houston Astros' first baseman, has apparently decided to take a small but significant stand against the marriage.

title: Women Relax in Fierce Soccer Competition
description: BETSY MONTGOMERY became interested in soccer a decade ago when her 15-year-old son started playing it. Now, Mrs. Montgomery and nearly 250 other women have moved from the sidelines to the playing field.

title: Dr. Felise Milan To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Milan of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Felise Beth Milan to Dr. Mark Joseph Polisar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Polisar of New York and Mountain Lakes, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Kuwait to Remove U.S. Flag From Two of Its Oil Tankers
description: Kuwait is about to remove the American flag from 2 of the 11 oil tankers that it registered in the United States at the height of the Iran-Iraq war, diplomats said today.

title: 17 U.S. ACCIDENTS RESEMBLE BHOPAL'S
description: Over the last 25 years, 17 industrial accidents in the United States released deadly chemicals in volumes and levels of toxicity exceeding those that killed 3,000 people in Bhopal, India, in 1984, according to a draft report for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: ISMS IN COLLISION
description: LEAD: INESSENTIAL WOMAN Problems of Exclusion in Feminist Thought. By Elizabeth V. Spelman. 221 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $22.95.

title: U.S. Needs Victory In World Cup Bid
description: The basic strategy of every country involved in World Cup qualifying games is to win at home and tie on the road.

title: Maimed Girl Is Back Home
description: A 5-year-old girl maimed by the explosion of a pipe bomb at a K Mart store last week returned home from the hospital Friday, her left hand amputated and the lens of her left eye removed by surgeons. The bomb went off when the girl, Erin Bower, picked up from a shelf a pump-style container of toothpaste in which the device was concealed. The authorities continue searching for two men seen leaving the store soon after the blast.

title: 60 New Members Elected to Academy of Sciences
description: The National Academy of Sciences, the nation's most prestigious scientific honorary society, has announced the election of 60 new members.

title: A London Enclave of Whole Foods
description: VISITORS to London will never stumble into Neal's Yard; they must look for it tucked away, almost a cul-de-sac in Soho. But once there, the inclination is to mosey around, taste a little this, investigate a little that and relax in the congenial courtyard. It might be called an updated 17th-century shopping center. About 10 small, clustered shops sell handmade products like bread, cosmetics, cheese and essential oils, all appealing alternatives to mass-produced items.

title: 'We Are Doomed to Be Successful'
description: After nearly four years, perestroika has failed to produce tangible economic results in the Soviet Union. By some accounts, life for the average Soviet citizen is now worse than it was before Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power. As a result, many Soviet political leaders are desperately seeking new ideas - and Nikolai P. Shmelyov, head of the economics department at the Institute for the U.S.A. and Canada in Moscow, is one person to whom they turn. Mr. Shmelyov, who was elected to the Soviet parliament earlier this month as a representative of the Academy of Science, was in New York on April 10, to address a meeting on the progress of perestroika at the Institute for East-West Security Studies. After the meeting, Mr. Shmelyov spoke with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about perestroika and its pitfalls. Q. You have said that what the Soviet Union needs is not more economic growth, but less of it. What do you mean by less economic growth? Mr. Shmelyov: Yes, I said this, but not with respect to high tech. We need growth in the high-tech sectors of our economy, like computers. But in the rest of the economy we produce a real surplus of trash of every kind. We produce more steel than we need, more tractors of bad quality and make more shoes of poor quality than anyone else. We have huge stockpiles and inventories of these goods. For five years or so we need zero rates of growth for most of the economy because of these stockpiles. We may need minus growth in these areas. Q. How will growth in the high-tech sectors be accomplished? Mr. Shmelyov: From state investment, state credit facilities and even artificial price supports. This would be accomplished through central planning.

title: Gloria A. Roca, a Bank Officer, Weds Houston Cox Jr., a Retired Executive
description: Gloria A. Roca and Houston A. Cox Jr., both of Huntington, L.I., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's brother, Dr. Luis A. Algarra, in Coral Gables, Fla. The ceremony was performed by Luis Lucas Fernandez, a lawyer in Miami.

title: Seoul Police Seize 2,200 to Block Labor Rally
description: The police arrested about 2,200 workers and students today to block a planned labor rally, and the Government warned that it might take emergency measures to end a wave of strikes and labor unrest.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Democrazy While democracy sometimes seems to be a mixed blessing, it is usually a good subject for satire - which is what Florence King does in ''Reflections in a Jaundiced Eye'' (St. Martin's).

title: Finally, Milton Avery Has a Solo Show in Hartford
description: MILTON AVERY (1885-1965) lived in Hartford for 25 years, but only now is the artist having his first solo show in the city - at the University of Hartford.

title: KINDER, GENTLER, EARLIER
description: William Safire inquires whether the adjectives ''kinder, gentler'' were ever used together before George Bush (On Language: ''Recuse, J'accuse!'' March 12). He is able only to cite Clarence Darrow's usage of ''kindlier, gentler'' as a precursor.

title: South African Consul Flees College Protest
description: More than 300 chanting students at Temple University forced a representative of the South African Government to flee the campus Friday, shortly after he was trapped in an elevator facing an angry crowd.

title: City Charter: Test Driving A New Model
description: A MONTH after the United States Supreme Court ruled that the New York City Board of Estimate ran afoul of the Constitution, the Charter Revision Commission began considering how to rearrange local government. A plan proposed last week by the commission's chairman, Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., would weave an intricate system of checks on mayoral authority, giving a legislature - the City Council and perhaps another house - more influence, and community boards and voters more information on city policies and programs. Mr. Schwarz acknowledged that his proposal still had rough edges that are likely to be polished by the commission before being presented to the voters in November. But even as a working paper it offered an intriguing vision of how a new city government might work. Reporters on the metropolitan staff of The Times gave some examples. BUILDING A JAIL

title: HOMOSEXUALITY: WHO AND WHY?
description: Melvin Konner's article, ''Homosexuality: Who and Why?'' (Body and Mind, April 2), should go far toward stimulating informed, rational thinking on the subject. For the present, however, ''the bad old days'' have simply gotten worse.

title: In Christie Whodunit, Red Herrings Abound
description: AGATHA CHRISTIE's ''Go Back for Murder,'' which deals with family values and filial devotion, has a lot to recommend it. It is a classic whodunit filled with red herrings. It has a subplot of romantic love. And it is receiving a strong production at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, where it will remain through May 14.

title: INSIDE
description: A Rare, Wrenching Merger The issue of race is complicating consideration of a plan in which Nashville would merge its white-dominated public hospital into a historically black institution, a step no city has ever taken. Page 24. Quiet on the Soviet Frontier Tension on the far-eastern Soviet-Chinese border has given way, for now, to a bemused vigilance. Page 18.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Is The M.V.P. In the N.B.A?
description: Statistically, Jordan wins flat out. He is in the top 10 in 4 of the 10 measured categories, and for the third year in a row has led the league in scoring, a feat matched by only five other players.

title: Jesuit Priest Faces Dismissal
description: A Jesuit priest says he has been threatened with dismissal from the order for refusing to sever his ties with the Quixote Center, a Roman Catholic group that raises money for humanitarian aid to Nicaragua and opposes church policies toward women and theological dissenters.

title:
A Tale of Two Cities;
In London, Snobs and Jobs, In New York, Dreams and Screams
description: LEAD: Which city do you like better, New York or London? I was accosted with this question every night after my show for three months.

title: Sunglasses, Either Hot Or Cool
description: Sunglasses have their fashions like anything else. What looked dowdy or ridiculous a few years after it was in style begins to seem amusing and smart again 10 or 20 years later.

title: Workers' Advocate, a Front-Runner in Brazil, Shows He Thinks Like a Boss
description: With his wrestler's build, bushy beard and forceful demeanor, Luiz Inacio da Silva looks as if he would delight in flipping a Wall Street banker on his back in a 30-second pin.

title: Review/Opera; 'Jane Heir,' Italianate Bronte
description: Everybody has defects, and one of mine is that I have never managed to read any novel by Charlotte Bronte. Accordingly, I anticipated visiting ''Jane Heir,'' presented by the Mesopotamian Opera on Friday night at Performance Space 122 (First Avenue and Ninth Street), in the position of someone who attempts to appreciate Donizetti's ''Lucia'' without having read ''The Bride of Lammermoor,'' or ''Nabucco,'' ''Messiah'' and ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' without having read the Bible.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
New Life for Old Complex
description: LEAD: A 1,079-UNIT apartment complex long considered an eyesore in the Borough of Baldwin, a community of 23,400 residents about nine miles from downtown Pittsburgh, has been given new life by a Hawthorne, N.Y., developer.

title: Too Many Books?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stealing Home: Another View
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: One of photography's distinguishing characteristics is its ability to render a wealth of detail. Some sages have gone so far as to suggest that the descriptive capacity of photography is part of what defines its essence as a form of visual expression. In any case, pictures taken with cameras can be crisp and clear in a way that no other pictures can be.

title: POSTINGS: Queens Conference; Caveats On Co-ops
description: Co-op fever is gripping Queens and its Borough President, Claire Shulman, wants its residents to be aware of what might be in the fine print of any contracts they sign. So Mrs. Shulman is holding a co-op buyers' conference at 6:45 P.M. Wednesday in Queens Borough Hall, 120-55 Queens Boulevard, near the intersection of Union Turnpike in Kew Gardens.

title: The Favorite at Churchill Downs: Derby-Pie
description: DERBY WEEK is the one time of year when sin is sanctioned in Kentucky. Betting is not only condoned but actually regarded as a patriotic duty, since so much is riding on the Run for the Roses on the first Saturday in May. Overindulgence also seems socially acceptable in the whirl of energy and excess that marks the week leading up to that over-in-an-instant horse race. Fitness is left to the three-year-olds on the track at Churchill Downs in Louisville. Most everyone else is busy eating and drinking, usually in immoderation.

title: When Art Becomes a Matter of Life or Death
description: Avner Eisenberg, who is also known as Avner the Eccentric, is balancing a hat on his nose. The hat is blue, with a wide, shiny black plastic brim, and it is by the edge of its brim that it is standing, motionless, ignorant of gravity, on his fleshy slope. Mr. Eisenberg has performed this particular feat quite often, of course, but this time there is something different about it. That is because the hat in question is a facsimile of the uniform cap worn by Jewish policemen in the Nazi-run Vilna Ghetto in Lithuania during World War II.

title: New Start for Pitcher
description: For someone who began the season on top of the world as a starting pitcher for the Toronto Blue Jays, Jeff Musselman fell far fast.

title:
FOCUS: Low-Income Housing;
Tax Credits for Corporations That Invest
description: LEAD: THE roster of American corporations that invest in low-income rental housing is expanding as a result of tax legislation that lets them do well by doing good.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: An exhibition of coins and bills from German concentration camps will take place in New York, May 5 through 7, at the Greater New York Numismatic Convention, at the Omni Park Central Hotel, 7th Avenue and 56th Street.

title: Debuts; Violinist and 2 Pianists In Their First Recitals
description: Hong-Ying Ho

title: Recalling the Graphics Feast At the 1939 World's Fair
description: To the 50 million people who visited it and the many more who wish they had, the 1939 New York World's Fair was visually a graphics feast, with a dynamic icon - the Trylon and Perisphere. Stark white and streamlined, the soaring 610-foot-high triangular spire (its name coined to suggest a three-sided pylon) and massive, 180-foot-diameter globe, both sheathed in painted gypsum, dominated the fair when it opened in Flushing Meadows Park in Queens 50 years ago today.

title: The 'Look' That Makes the Yankees
description: THE streets bordering the Raleigh Athletic Equipment Company on Columbus Avenue here are narrow and deserted. There is not enough room, or enough people, to get up a stickball game. Aside from the company name, nothing about the aging structure hints of athletics.

title: VARIED VINO
description: First, they tried new bottles. That didn't work. Then they tried new wine-making rules. That didn't work. So next they decided to go all the way and make a new wine. That worked. Well, sort of.

title: Miss Powers Wed To R. A. O'Leary
description: Susan Stately Powers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Beston Powers of Weston, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Allen O'Leary, the son of Mrs. Frederick Kelly of Huntsville, Ala., and the late Thomas J. O'Leary. The Rev. George Croft performed the ceremony at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Fairfield; Hello Troll, Meet Puddles, Or Is It Flipper?
description: For college students, freshman year inevitably starts with polite introductions, handshakes, ''where are you from'' and ''what's your major.'' But it quickly becomes a time for one of the hottest competitions on campus: the nickname game.

title: Cuomo Not Likely to Veto $80 Million for Lawmakers
description: Though they have been denounced by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as pork and cited by watchdog groups as a good example of bad government, $80 million in grants sponsored by individual legislators are expected to survive this year with few casualties.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Handel: Carmelite Vespers (1707) Jill Feldman, Emma Kirkby and Emily Van Evera, sopranos; Margaret Cable and Mary Nichols, altos; Joseph Cornwell, tenro; David Thomas, bass; Tavernor Choir and Players, Andrew Parrott, conductor. AMI/Angel CDS 7497492; two CD's.

title: Ton of Drugs From Jet Seized
description: Federal agents here have seized 2,200 pounds of cocaine and arrested two South Americans in what the Customs Service describes as ''probably the largest ever'' confiscation of drugs smuggled into the country aboard a regularly scheduled passenger airliner.

title: For More Information
description: Aruba Tourism Authority, 521 Fifth Avenue, 12th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10175; 212-246-3030 or 800-862-7822.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Can I say hello? My name's Dan Quayle, and I just wanted to stop by and see what's going on.'' - The Vice President at the Lord Nelson Hotel and Brewery in Sydney, Australia. [ 20:1. ]

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Quick and Punchy Chili: Enough Taste for a Texan
description: To Texans, the Northeast is full of people who think barbecue is something you do in your backyard on a grill and chili meat is ground beef. Well, barbecue is brisket that has been cooked for hours over a low fire and unless you know of a butcher shop that is open on Sundays, you will not be able to find the tiny, pre-cut cubes of beef they use in Texas for chili.

title:
PAPERBACKS: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: K2, TRIUMPH AND TRAGEDY. By Jim Curran. (Houghton Mifflin, Paper, $8.95.) If mountains are the leviathans of the land, Pakistan's monumental K2 - second only to Everest in height - makes Moby Dick look like a great white minnow. For the whale had only one obsessed Ahab; in the summer of 1986 alone, 27 climbers reached the top of ''the world's hardest mountain.

title: POSTINGS: Union Square Theater; Curtain Going Up
description: At a time when real estate development is reducing the number of legitimate theaters in Manhattan, a new one will formally open Wednesday in the basement of a new condominium in Union Square. The 130-seat facility at 108 East 15th Street will be used by the Vineyard Theater, a nonprofit dramatic company, and named the Gertrude and Irving Dimson Theatre. Mr. Dimson, founder of the Carlyle Construction Corporation, donated $400,000 to a campaign seeking more than $2.85 million for construction and equipment of the theater. Federal, state and municipal arts groups already have made contributions.

title: At Site of Its Founding 200 Years Ago, Yonkers Church Celebrates
description: LEAD: AT 10 A.M. next Saturday, a man on horseback will arrive on the top of the rise of Underhill Street and remake history.

title: Counting Food and Water As Extraordinary Support
description: THREE weeks ago, Carrie A. Coons regained consciousness and managed to speak after four and a half months in what doctors had said was an irreversible coma. The 86-year-old New York woman's unexpected recovery further complicated one of modern medicine's most complex ethical quandaries. Only a few days before, a judge had authorized her doctor and next of kin to remove the feeding tubes that continue to keep her alive.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
A Sound Reuse Of a Roller Rink
description: LEAD: AN Art Deco-style roller rink in the Adams Morgan neighborhood here is being transformed into one of the largest sound studios on the East Coast.

title: C. H. Burdge Jr. And Miss Mark Wed in Virginia
description: The marriage of Catherine Virginia Mark and Charles Henry Burdge Jr. took place yesterday at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Forest, Va. The Rev. James Drinard Smith and the Rev. John Grace, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: AN AFFAIR OF CONVENIENCE
description: BEFORE THE BIRTH OF THE MOON By V. Y. Mudimbe. Translated by Marjolijn de Jager. 203 pp. New York: Fireside/Simon & Schuster. Paper, $7.95.

title: The Sickening Cost Of Getting Sick
description: THE cost of health care in America is out of control. And Connecticut has become a major contributor to the problem. One of the better-kept secrets is the ''All Payor'' system enacted by the state legislature.

title: Outdoors; New Limit for Striped Bass in Northeast
description: Striped bass angling has begun in some areas of the Northeast, and fishermen should remember that minimum-length limits for the species have once again inched upward.

title: Lindsay Schine Wed to M. K. Klingher
description: Lindsay Schine, who expects to receive an M.D. next month from the University of Connecticut, and Michael K. Klingher, a lawyer who is an associate in the real-estate department of Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Frank Hall, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Governor Lounsbury Mansion in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Kings Park
description: ''IF you like water recreation,'' said Smithtown Town Councilman Michael T. Sullivan of his home community of Kings Park, ''you couldn't find a better place. Long Island Sound is our backyard.''

title: FOR JAILED SAUDI FINANCIER, SWISS HOTEL FOOD AND A FAX MACHINE
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi financier who has been a central figure in billions of dollars of arms sales over the last two decades, may be in a Swiss jail for as long as 10 months before the United States request for his extradition is settled, his lawyer and an official of the Swiss Justice Department say.

title: Data and Comment About Smoking
description: Professional antismoker Karen J. Fersht made a number of misleading statements in her recent interview [ ''Westchester Q&A,'' March 19 ] . According to Ms. Fersht, the tobacco industry has made a ''target'' of minority and low-income Americans. Yet, by Ms. Fersht's own admission, 51 million American adults choose to smoke. Surely the choice to smoke must be more broadly based than she implies.

title: Bill Irwin on Safari In an Urban Wonderland
description: In ''Largely New York,'' Bill Irwin's dreamy ruminations on life, love and art in the big city and beyond, there are breakdancers wearing high tops and boom boxes and a beautiful dancer in pink obsessed with post-modern parallels and perpendiculars. There is a herd of bespectacled academicians on autopilot. Then there is ''B.I.,'' Mr. Irwin's bewildered innocent, who finds, as Mr. Irwin did when he first got to the city, that ''the things you don't know about are always menacing at first,'' but who perseveres to a loopy sort of triumph.

title: Will the Real President Please Stand Up
description: On the eve of his inauguration, George Washington, dressed in jeans and a red T-shirt, was sitting in his room at a sleek high-rise hotel in lower Manhattan, blow-drying his silvery hair and pondering the most important speech of his life.

title: U.S. ANGER RISING AGAINST GERMANS OVER NATO STAND
description: Some Bush Administration officials say they are growing increasingly upset with the West German Government for threatening NATO's unity by pressing for speedy negotiations with Moscow on short-range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: At the beginning of some vacation trips, Donna Cosulich throws her wristwatch at the bottom of her duffel bag, to be retrieved only as she prepares to return home. Her companions generally follow suit, and after the initial shock no one really cares about the time. That makes a lot of sense when you're at the bottom of the Grand Canyon.

title: Correction
description: A passage about music festivals on page 35 of the Travel section today is obscured by a printing error in some copies. The reference, to the Sintra Music Festival in Portugal from June 15 to July 15, should read, ''Portuguese and visiting pianists offer concerts on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday at the Royal Palace, Pena Palace and Quinta da Piedade in Sintra and Queluz Palace near Lisbon.''

title: HUMAN RIGHTS IN GUATEMALA
description: The human rights situation, which Stephen Kinzer describes in his article ''Guatemala: What Has Democracy Wrought?'' (March 26), is inconsistent with his claim that ''there is no indication that top army officers are involved'' in directing death squads.

title: A Different View on Dining Out
description: The article on Chengdu East said that ''$27 for half a duck and four pancakes seems a little excessive.'' The price, $27, is for a whole duck, not a half duck. Indeed, it would be too expensive for half a duck at that price. We at Chengdu East take the review seriously and sincerely and will, with our best effort, improve ourselves as fast as we can. EMERSON W>ANG General Manager Chengdu East East Hanover

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are planning a one-room addition to our vacation house. It will have a cathedral ceiling and be exposed on three sides. The house has 2-by-4 construction with fiberglass insulation, which we don't feel is adequate. Would we better off building the new walls with 2-by-6's to allow room for more insulation, or should we build with 2-by-4's and use rigid Styrofoam boards for insulation?

title: Documents That Got Away: Now, to Unravel the Mystery
description: On March 31, 1987, an F.B.I. agent wearing rubber gloves reached into a box of documents taken from Oliver L. North's office and pulled out a plum: a memorandum showing that Ronald Reagan had approved the air drop of two anti-tank weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE HORSE BUSINESS;
BIGGER PURSES, BETTER RIDERS AND A RING FULL OF SPONSORS
description: LEAD: American breeders are close to closing the trade gap. Last year, 30,000 horses were shipped into this country, only slightly more than the 26,500 horses exported, according to the Department of Agriculture. In 1984, about 24,000 more horses were imported than were exported. Because they run small enterprises - even the largest have revenues in the low millions - most horse breeders lack the resources to ship and quarantine animals overseas.

title: When Duke Sat Down At the Orchestra
description: When people say that Duke Ellington played piano but his real instrument was his orchestra, they refer to the use he made of the distinctive sounds of his instrumentalists. What is not usually mentioned is that Ellington helped to shape these distinctive qualities by the way he used them in his arrangements. Almost all of Ellington's celebrated soloists, with the possible exception of Ben Webster, were never heard to as good advantage either before or after their years with Ellington.

title: No Headline
description: On the surface it's a simple question: should Nashville merge its antiquated public hospital, a rambling brick building on a bluff near the Cumberland River, with a newer private hospital about three miles away?

title: Police Authority And Weaponry
description: R. H. Hodges' April 2 letter, on the choice of semiautomatic pistols for many police departments [ ''Police Turning to 9-mm. Guns to Fight Crime,'' March 12 ] was informative in many aspects, but did not respond to the fears voiced in the original report by Dorothy L. DiCintio, to the effect that the police trend toward more firepower would lead to the shooting of ''more innocent people.''
